Title: The use of prior knowledge to accelerate the determination of the permissible operating envelope of an internal combustion engine
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: An output from a 5-year programme of research funded by Cosworth Technology (now Mahle Powertrain), which was also supported by the Akehurst's EPSRC Advanced Research Fellowship (EP/C540883/1 and EP/C540891/1). The success of this work resulted in the techniques being applied to low CO2 engine development in the £4.2M TSB ‘Ultraboost’ project (TP BN008E 400135, with £589k to Bath ), aiming to reduce engine CO2 emissions by 35%. The project partners include Jaguar Land Rover, Lotus, and Shell.

Title: Modelling the performance of a continuously variable supercharger drive system
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study into the performance benefits of a CVT system applied to a supercharger drive as an engine downsizing enabling technology. This work originated from a 5-year programme of research funded by Intersyn Technologies & Orbital Traction (USA) and it was also supported by Akehurst’s EPSRC Advanced Research Fellowship (EP/C540883/1 and EP/C540891/1). The research has led to interest from Jaguar Land Rover and further analysis is being undertaken under a current £4.2M TSB funded programme (TP BN008E 400135, with £589k to Bath). Project partners include Jaguar Land Rover, Shell and Lotus.

Title: Systems approach to the improvement of engine warm-up behaviour
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A collaborative paper on work funded by the TSB on ’engine optimisation for reduced parasitic losses’ project (TP/9/LCV/6/1/S0052K) with Ford, BP, Mahle and academic partners. Results from a novel and complex configuration of engine and cooling oil arrangements were subject to extensive experimental and statistical evaluations. This highlighted previous unknown system interactions affecting the fuel economy of diesel engines during warm up. The work is being exploited by Ford in the implementation of hardware and lubricant technologies in the ECOnetic range of vehicles which made up half of European sales in 2012 (Mr Scarisbrick, former Ford Technical Specialist - andy@adscol.co.uk).

Title: Steady-state steering of a tilting three-wheeled vehicle
AdditionalInformation: The unique nature of tilting vehicle dynamics requires a controller that combines both active steering and body tilt control. This paper builds on experimental measurements undertaken by the authors to propose a controller that will help prevent roll-over without compromising the path following capabilities of the vehicle. This controller has subsequently been implemented on a prototype vehicle. The vehicle, originally designed as part of an EU funded project, was shown at a Royal Society Summer Science Exhibition and received publicity in Eureka Magazine (07/09) as well as international TV coverage.

Title: Prediction of the pressure-flow characteristic of a Belleville washer-based damper valve
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This extensive simulation and experimental study into the flow dynamics of vehicle damper valves identifies a new approach for the design of components that were previously selected by industry on a trial and error basis. The work was undertaken with Horstman Defence, which has adopted the analysis method in its product design process.

Title: The vibration control of speed-dependent flexible rotor/magnetic bearing systems using linear matrix inequality gain-scheduled H-∞ design
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The first implementation of magnetic bearing control under the LMI structure, which enables rigorously stable operation to be guaranteed, is derived. It has led to further collaboration with researchers (Ulbrich, Thümmel, Ginzinger and Heckmann) at the Technical University of Munich in the magnetic bearing control field. Dr Ginzinger spent 6 months in Bath over 2009-2010 in this process. The research content was a leading reason for Keogh to be nominated as Convenor of ISO/TC108/SC2/WG7 in 2009.

Title: Hydraulic actuation of multi-body structures through large-scale motions. Part 1: development and validation of system model
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: The controlled actuation of flexible structures through large motions and with high dynamic precision is originated. The fundamental results led to the concepts incorporated into the £492k EPSRC grant EP/D060478/1 ‘Integrated systems for high bandwidth ultra high precision actuation’. This paper was associated with Part 2: Controller design and performance (222, 3, p. 365-375). The combination received the 2008 PE Publishing Award by the Editorial Board of the Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science.

Title: Contact dynamic phenomena in rotating machines: active/passive considerations
AdditionalInformation: This is the first published work to express rub induced dynamic thermal bending of a rotor in terms of a Nyquist formulation, hence to enable rigorous stability assessments to be made. The research was funded by the £314k EPSRC grant EP/D031389/1 ‘Controlled escape from trapped contact modes in magnetic bearing systems’. It was originally delivered as a Keynote paper at the 8th IFToMM International Conference on Rotordynamics in Seoul, Korea in 2010. Further opportunities have arisen through the design and manufacture of a bespoke rotor/magnetic bearing facility for GE Global Research (Munich).

Title: Measured dynamic properties of flexible hoses
VolumeTitle: Journal of Vibration and Acoustics-Transactions of the Asme
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to quantify rigorously the dynamic properties of a wide range of flexible hoses, enabling the modelling of a wide range of essential hydraulic systems with confidence, such as safety-critical aircraft and submarine systems. It arose from an industrially funded project (Eaton, £154k), an EPSRC studentship and other industrial collaboration. The hose model and data are used in Bath’s Prasp and Tune software programs, used by several companies in the UK, Europe and USA including John Deere, GM, Nexteer, Tofas, Eaton and Airbus.

Title: Piezoelectrically actuated hydraulic valve design for high bandwidth and flow performance
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded the 2011 IMechE Donald Julius Groen Prize. It was the major output from EPSRC project EP/D060478/1 (£492k). The valve is based on a unique combination of piezoelectric actuation and ultra-high flow gain using multiple grooves, to give the invaluable characteristics of high bandwidth and high flow needed for modern high performance control systems. The valve has facilitated a PhD project on active control of fluid-borne noise.

Title: On the use of actively controlled auxiliary bearings in magnetic bearing systems
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from research funded by the EPSRC (EP/D031389/1, value £314k). A novel strategy was designed to control the contact modes of a magnetic bearing/rotor system through active auxiliary bearings. The reduction of contact force levels and contact durations leads to longer operational life of rotating machinery; hence the research has significant positive impact on the efficiency and cost of conventional and renewable energy/power generation plants.

Title: Experiments on the transient performance of an adaptive multi-objective controller for rotating machinery
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: The work covered in this paper received great interest from academic and industrial participants at the ASME Turbo 2010 conference. One of the journal referees commented: ‘This is a great paper, of both immediate and continuing value’. The paper was pivotal in setting up industrial links with Calnetix Inc (Larry Hawkins, Director of Technology, lhawkins@calnetix.com) and Capstone Turbine Corporation (Dan Lubell, Manager, recently moved to Calnetix dlubell@calnetix.com) in the USA, both of which have significant interest in energy generation/recovery and distributed power systems. The visit to these companies was supported by the EPSRC (EP/J003034/1, value £11k).

Title: A multiobjective adaptive controller for magnetic bearing systems
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: A key factor in smart machines is the ability to reconfigure when a fault has been diagnosed. This paper introduces a novel adaptive control technique to be used with controllable elements, such as active magnetic bearings, as a significant step towards achieving autonomous smart rotating machines. This work has led to increased capabilities and more robust operation of turbomachinery, and to collaboration with GE Global Research, Munich (Kunal Goray, kunal.goray@ge.com) through the design and commissioning of a magnetic bearing rig for oil and gas technology development.

Title: An adaptive multi-objective controller for flexible rotor and magnetic bearing systems
VolumeTitle: Journal of Dynamic Systems Measurement and Control - Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to tackle three interrelated problems associated with rotating machinery to automatically cater for changes in the system dynamics and external disturbances. This greatly improves fault tolerance capability and safety of rotating machinery with active elements. This paper led to the securing of a funded project from the British Heart Foundation (PG/12/17/29448, value £122k) to investigate the use of magnetically levitated pumps, integrated with conducting polymers, to introduce pulsatile pumping action and overcome current limitations of heart assist pumps for children.

Title: The effect of engine and transmission oil viscometrics on vehicle fuel consumption
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first explanation and insights into how modulating the properties of lubrication and transmission oils can achieve lower levels of fuel consumption in a diesel engine (ipegg@ford.com). The work undertaken by Bath gave Ford a head-start in allowing the development of a specific engine oil for the new Ford 1.0L EcoBoost engine (graham.hoare@ford.com). Funded through a 3-year dti project (TP/2/5/10036) on enhanced diesel lubrication systems with Ford, BP, Imperial College and the University of Nottingham, the results from this paper were instrumental in securing a TSB project (TP/9/LCV/6/1/S0052K, with £510k awarded to Bath) with the same partners.

Title: Analysis of cyclic variability in combustion in internal combustion engines using wavelets
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The novel use of wavelets described in this paper highlights that, contrary to commonly used approaches, cyclic variability (CV) of engine operation is not a time-invariant phenomenon. By addressing this constraint a practical application of the technique to improve engine calibrations is facilitated. This has a direct impact on engine CO2 and economy. The insights gained have contributed to our expertise in this area and have been beneficial to the Ultraboost Project, a major TSB project (TP-BN008E) in partnership with Jaguar Land Rover and Lotus aimed at radically downsizing engines for use in premium vehicles.

Title: Structural health monitoring of fixed offshore structures using the bicoherence function of ambient vibration measurements
AdditionalInformation: The first application of the bicoherence method to a structural health monitoring problem using a realistic complex structure and environmental loading. This method was investigated under the EC sixth framework programme 'AERONEWS' (AST-CT-2003-502927) for detection of damage in aero structures. The method is unique in requiring no additional forcing beyond standard environmental operating conditions, and also in being immune to parasitic effects of variable operating conditions that limit the use of most alternative methods. The work has attracted interest from the offshore wind farm operator SSE, and will be tested in early 2014 with data collected from UK windfarms.

Title: Determination of optimal parameters for a hydraulic power take-off unit of a wave energy converter in regular waves
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a comprehensive multi-physics simulation approach for hydraulic power take-off devices and is the first to consider realistic hydraulic circuits and components. This research has led to industrially funded projects to advise on power take-off design and control with Ocean Power Technology, Wavebob, Archimedes Wave Swing, GarradHassan and others (Ref: Stuart Bower, Engineering & Projects Director, sbower@oceanpowertech.com; Michael Livingston, Michael.Livingstone@gl-garradhassan.com). The research was also presented as an invited plenary address at the 8th International Fluid Power Conference, Dresden, March 2012.

Title: Multi-input multi-output control of an automotive active engine mounting system
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The work resulted from collaboration with DTM Vibration Management Systems, a major supplier to the automotive sector. The intelligent control systems have subsequently been applied to the problem of active fluid-borne noise cancellation in a new generation of efficient switched mode hydraulic systems under investigation as part of the EPSRC grant 'Efficient Fluid Power Systems' (EP/H021490/1, value £618k). The paper also led to collaboration with Stirling Dynamics UK on the cancellation of vibration in helicopter seats.

Title: A detailed dynamic model of a six-axis shaking table
AdditionalInformation: The results in this paper have been used by Instron Structural Testing Ltd. to develop a new control system for the large IWHR earthquake simulation table (Beijing), the world’s leading facility for seismic testing of dams (http://www.iwhr.com/iwhr99/laboratory/lab-en-View.asp?NewsID=1298). The modelling described in the paper was embedded in a model-based controller, and was also used to test the controller using off-line and real-time simulations (Ref: Paul Hayford, R&D Director, Instron: paul_hayford@instron.com). It also led to an invitation to advise the EC at the ‘European Facility for Advanced Seismic Testing’ Workshop, Ispra, Italy, June 2011.

Title: A general co-ordinate transformation framework for multi-axis motion control with applications in the testing industry
AdditionalInformation: This paper is unusual in that for the first time it proves that a number of existing industrially-relevant control approaches are in fact variants of a general method. Thus, rather than presenting new controllers for specific applications, examples of existing controllers are presented and unified. Following funded invitations, the work has been presented to Hitachi Heavy Plant Ltd (March 2012), Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology (March 2012), Italian Institute of Technology (Genova, June 2011), Beihang University (Beijing, April 2013) and as a keynote address at the 8th International Conference on Fluid Power Transmission and Control (Hangzhou, April 2013).

Title: Learning control strategies for high-rate materials testing machines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: High performance hydraulic testing machines for high rate materials testing are required by automotive and aerospace companies (amongst others) for crash-test research. These are specialised machines, only manufactured by three main companies worldwide. Two of these, Instron (the market leader in this field) and Zwick, have adopted the control approach described in the paper. The University has worked directly with Zwick to support its commercial implementation through £40k consultancy activity Ref: PTMCQ355/380 'Iterative error correction software for high rate machines' (Reference: Markus Tobisch, Senior Engineer - Special Machines, Markus.Tobisch@zwick.de).

Title: Cooling system improvements - assessing the effects on emissions and fuel economy
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents results from a complex experimental optimisation methodology designed to assess fuel economy benefits via thermal controls to a level of precision never previously obtained by Ford (ipegg@ford.com). The work was funded through a 3-year dti project (TP/2/5/10036) on enhanced diesel lubrication systems for reduced environmental impact with Ford, BP, Imperial College and the University of Nottingham. The results from this collaborative Bath/Ford paper were instrumental in securing a further TSB project on engine optimisation for reduced parasitic losses (TP/9/LCV/6/1/S0052K with £510k awarded to Bath) with the same partners.

Title: Development of a tilt control method for a narrow-track three-wheeled vehicle
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This combined simulation and experimentally based paper presents new findings on an unusual class of road vehicle that combines both motorcycle and car dynamics. The work was originally undertaken as part of an interdisciplinary EU funded project, which was publicised internationally (Eureka, July 2009). The prototype vehicle used for this work was shown at the 2007 Royal Society Summer Science Exhibition. This paper expands the EU funded work to generate control methods suitable for tilting vehicles. The original project consortium included BMW as a partner.

Title: Critical evaluation of on-engine fuel consumption measurement
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper assesses the accuracy of fuel consumption measurements on engine dynamometers, and was the first to consider installation effects under cold-start conditions. It proposes novel correction factors and procedures that significantly enhance current international standard practice, but are necessary to achieve adequate measurement precision. The paper resulted from a TSB funded project (No: TP/9/LCV/6/I/S0052K) on reducing engine parasitic losses. The work played a key role in prolonging knowledge transfer activities with Ford for the 'High precision evaluation of vehicle fuel consumption for reduced carbon dioxide emissions' in an EPSRC Knowledge Transfer Account project with total value £296k.

Title: The transmission line method for modelling laminar flow of liquid in pipelines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A new approach to modelling flow in pipelines is presented that gives a very high accuracy and bandwidth with a much higher computational efficiency and ease of use than previous methods. This has been used extensively in the  EPSRC project EP/H024190/1 (£618k). It has also been used by researchers in Samara State Aerospace University (Russia) and Aero Engine Controls (UK), notably for the analysis of the stability of aircraft fuel systems.

Title: An empirical model for the carbon dioxide emissions of a diesel engine
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper details a novel approach to engine model generation, by using dynamic design of experiments in order to train a neural network model of engine CO2 emissions. This technique significantly reduces experimental procedures while producing much more robust time domain responses with higher model accuracy. Uniquely, this technique allows the capturing of the effects of engine thermal transient responses during engine warm-up, as experienced in real-world driving situations. The work was supported by IAV (Germany) and Akehurst's EPSRC Advanced Research Fellowship (EP/C540883/1 and EP/C540891/1).

Title: An active auxiliary bearing control strategy to reduce the onset of asynchronous periodic contact modes in rotor/magnetic bearing systems
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: The performance of the first active touchdown bearing design for use in magnetic bearing systems is reported. The basic rotor/stator dynamic contact issues that were identified have also been included in the international standard, ISO 14839-4 ‘Mechanical vibration – Vibration of rotating machinery equipped with active magnetic bearings – Part 4: Technical guidelines’, published in 2012. The research was funded by the EPSRC grant EP/D031389/1 ‘Controlled escape from trapped contact modes in magnetic bearing systems’.

Title: A novel piezohydraulic aerospace servovalve. Part I: design and modelling
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: For the first time a piezoelectrically actuated servovalve is proposed and investigated which is appropriate for aerospace actuation. This has led to a patent (WO/2012/123691), and a £850k TSB project between the University of Bath, Moog Controls Ltd and Renishaw Plc to extend the approach towards Technology Readiness Level 6 (TSB Ref: 17413-117299). It has also led to research and knowledge transfer on ‘Piezoelectric aeroengine control systems’ supported by an EPSRC CASE award, an EPSRC Knowledge Transfer Account award, and AEC (Aero Engine Controls, a Rolls-Royce subsidiary).

Title: Development and field trial of a driver assistance system to encourage eco-driving in light commercial vehicle fleets
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the result of collaboration with Ashwoods Automotive, funded by Ashwoods and the University of Bath EPSRC Knowledge Transfer Account. The findings have been incorporated into a commercial product, the most successful retro-fit system of its type. The product has already been adopted by six major fleet operators, with 1500 installations of the system saving around £340k/year in fuel costs and has resulted in 3 jobs being created within Ashwoods. The paper was a contributory factor to the successful award of two TSB projects to further develop the technologies (TP 11177 72141 and TP 18770 135148).

Title: The control of chassis dynamometer fuel consumption testing noise factors and the use of response modelling for validation of test repeatability
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This collaboration with BP allowed, for the first time, very small changes in vehicle CO2 performance to be observed reliably using a chassis dynamometer. The paper led directly to a major collaboration with Ford to halve the variability of CO2 measurement at its Dunton Research Centre, which has justified a $50M investment by Ford in its laboratories. This impacts on the strategically critical need for precision of testing applied to all Ford of Europe vehicles by allowing improved CO2 performance through the adoption of technologies that require precise evaluation of performance metrics to demonstrate effectiveness.

Title: Development of a new method to assess fuel saving using gear shift indicators
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper details a method to reduce calibration effort whilst improving effectiveness, leading to significant commercial impact. This research was a collaboration between Ashwoods Automotive and the University, part funded by the EPSRC. The findings have been incorporated into a hybrid electric powertrain built and marketed by Ashwoods and allows a significant (average 7.2%) improvement in real world fuel economy over the unmodified vehicle. The insight has proved essential to designing the control algorithms used in the hybrid system. The success of the work has resulted in two further TSB projects with Ashwoods (TP 11177 72141 and TP 18770 135148).

Title: On the quantification of eigenvalue curve veering: A veering index
VolumeTitle: Journal of Applied Mechanics - Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper was written to satisfy a previously unfruitful search in academic circles for an objective measure of eigenvalue curve veering in structural dynamic systems. The work was supported by a CASE award in conjunction with AgustaWestland, and the methods led to key insights in the development of adaptive stress-stiffening based vibration mitigation strategies for rotorcraft. The findings have also permitted the development of novel finite element model updating techniques, which can reduce equipment costs in vibration tests by two orders of magnitude by employing inexpensive, uncalibrated accelerometers in place of their more expensive, calibrated counterparts.

Title: Modeling and testing of a semiactive hydraulic damper in periodic working regimes
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to present results from semiactive augmentations to a production helicopter lag damper. The work formed part of the Rotor Embedded Actuator Control Technology project in conjunction with AgustaWestland, sponsored by the TSB (Project No: TP/Q2035J). Estimates of 72% lateral hub load reductions have been made based on the work outlined in this paper, indicating substantial vibration alleviation capabilities. The results have informed decisions made in the follow-on Rotor Technology Validation Programme, influencing the development of smart rotor technology, which aims to produce safer, more efficient and more capable aircraft.

Title: Numerical modelling of unsteady turbulent flow in tubes, including the effects of roughness and large changes in Reynolds number
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel, powerful and efficient method for modelling unsteady turbulent flow, and has resulted from cross-disciplinary discussions with researchers in civil engineering. The paper arose from a £460k research project funded by Airbus UK and Parker Aerospace. The method has since been used by researchers in Aero Engine Controls (UK) and Samara State Aerospace University (Russia) for the analysis of the stability of aircraft fuel systems.

Title: Causal inversion of non-minimum-phase systems for hardware-in-the-loop transmission testing
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Hardware-in-the-loop transmission testing requires precise speed and torque tracking of the actuators that emulate the engine and vehicle dynamics. This paper generates a novel, yet simple and effective controller to enable preview filters to provide causal inversion within the frequency range of interest. Causality is achieved by adding manual delays to the measured response signal either in a closed loop or open-loop configuration. The effectiveness of the proposed coupled controllers is demonstrated experimentally by using the dual actuator hardware-in-the-loop transmission test facility and commercially supplied models for the engine, driver and vehicle. The project was supported by Ford.

Title: On stability of rotordynamic systems with rotor-stator contact interaction
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This work is the first in which Lyapunov’s direct method has been successfully applied to the stability analysis of general rotordynamic systems under rotor-stator contact interaction. The work was supported in part by an EPSRC platform grant (GR/S64448/01). The findings have subsequently been used for the design of active vibration control systems through follow-on research funding (Thailand Research Fund, Grant RSA 5280027).

Title: A discrete-time approach to impulse-based adaptive input shaping for motion control without residual vibration
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces a new data-based adaptive input shaping technique and shows that a new model-free adaptation of high order time-delay shaping filters can be achieved continuously during motion. The technique has significant potential for use in ‘plug-and-play’ adaptive filter modules for industrial motion control systems.

Title: A direct method of adaptive FIR input shaping for motion control with zero residual vibration
AdditionalInformation: This paper yields a new data-based optimisation algorithm for on-line adaptation of generalised multi-input multi-output input shaping filters. Experimental validation, where the approach is applied to path-tracking control of a 2-degree-of-freedom flexible-link manipulator, is also shown for the first time.

Title: An analysis and design framework for robust control of a multi-axis active vibration isolation system with unkown payload
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by a grant from the National Electronics and Computer Technology Center, Thailand (contract number NT-B-22-E5-11-49-09). The study is the first to address the problem of robust controller design for unknown payloads in multi-axis vibration isolation systems. The work led to a series of collaborative visits involving authors of the paper at Chiang Mai University, Thailand and Professor Michael Brennan at the University of Southampton, UK.

Title: Active control of pressure pulsation in a switched inertance hydraulic system
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a unique approach for the active cancellation of fluid-borne noise for a new generation of efficient switched mode hydraulic systems as part of the EPSRC grant 'Efficient Fluid Power Systems' (EP/H021490/1, value £618k). In this work, an average noise reduction of 30dB was achieved, which is very significant as it makes these new efficient systems viable. The work is of great benefit across a wide range of industries, and particularly to the collaborating companies (Parker-Hannifin, Instron, and JCB).

Title: Steady-state emulation of a diesel engine air charging system through real-time turbocharger modelling
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A novel approach for evaluating the performance of a new turbocharger system prior to the existence of prototype hardware is presented. A unique artificial boosting system to deliver controlled air pressure and temperature boundary conditions to an engine at a high bandwidth was developed. This was then controlled using a real-time turbocharger model. The method achieves considerable accuracy when compared with the real turbocharger hardware. This methodology can result in significantly lower costs and shorter time frames for the engine development process. The facility has attracted TSB funding through the 'Ultraboost' project (Project Number: 400135, Bath grant value £589k).

Title: Using Taguchi method to optimise performance and product cost at the conceptual stage of design
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Optimising the specification and cost of products at the early design stages is critical to sustain UK industry. The research led to collaboration with DePuy International (co-authors). The research was then expanded via Knowledge Transfer Activity funding from the EPSRC and DePuy International to embed the new approach into DePuy's design process. When used by DePuy to assist in making decisions on orthopaedic implant designs, a cost reduction of 65% was identified and this was used to undertake the trade-off between requirement and cost. These reductions are required to enter markets, such as China.

Title: Adiabatic shear band formation as a result of cryogenic CNC machining of elastomers
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper defines a novel approach to the cryogenic machining of soft elastomers. This was an invited paper, which was selected from the International Conference MATADOR 2010. An experimental analysis of the cryogenic machining process was achieved for two example elastomers, ethylene vinyl acetate and neoprene rubber, which showed the need to counteract adiabatic shear bands. The research was part of a £420k EPSRC research programme (GR/R67507/01) at the University of Bath entitled CRYMAN - rapid manufacture of soft flexible materials for customised shoes.

Title: Process comprehension for shopfloor manufacturing knowledge reuse
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new solution to the problem of the unidirectional information flow in the CAD/CAM/CNC chain, which has long been a major barrier against knowledge reuse in computer integrated manufacturing. This approach, which does not involve a major overhaul of the entire manufacturing resource pool, is now being used as the basis for the manufacturing knowledge interface elements of the EU FP7 STEPMAN project (Ref: 286962, €2.9M). According to InnoLab, an SME association group in the project: 'this approach finally solves the manufacturing knowledge access problem that many of our associated SMEs have long faced'.

Title: Numerical optimization approach to modelling delamination and buckling of geometrically constrained structures
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This was invited for a special issue of the Proceedings of the Royal Society A on the 'Geometry and mechanics of layered structures and materials'. It presents a novel means for modelling the bending of carton board in terms of minimising internal energy whilst allowing for the effects of delamination to be explored and processing to be matched to material properties. The work was part of EPSRC-funded research (EP/E00184X/1, £7.3M). Experimental work was undertaken in collaboration with Smithers Pira. It has been used by Smithers Pira to create specialised test equipment for characterising the properties of folding carton board (CBerry@smithers.com).

Title: A novel methodology for cross-technology interoperability in CNC machining
AdditionalInformation: This research allowed one of the long-standing barriers in CNC interoperability to be overcome. For the first time, programs can be transferred from machines using one technology (e.g. turn-mill) to machines using a different technology (e.g. 4-axis milling) without the need for human intervention. The research was the result of EPSRC funded research (within the IdMRC EP/E00184X/1, £60k) on ‘Interoperability in turn mill machining’. The implementation of the outcomes has major potential benefits to SMEs with limited resources enabling them to assign a piece of work to machines with different technologies, enhancing the utilisation of their machines and their flexibility.

Title: Uncertainty in competitive bidding : a framework for product-service systems
AdditionalInformation: Through-life support for long-life, high-value assets requires robust identification and management of uncertainty. A new framework to aid decision-making when bidding for service contracts has been created enabling the probability of winning the contract, making a profit and estimating the expected profit to be predicted. The outcome is a repeatable and auditable process identifying the consequences of a particular price bid. BAE Systems, Defence Materiel (Australia) and Rolls-Royce Submarines have been trained in using the framework. BAE Systems are using the framework and Dr Wicks (Head of Business Analysis, Rolls-Royce Submarines Tel: 01332 632173) describes the research as 'leading edge'.

Title: Designing for ‘use phase’ energy losses of domestic products
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper was one of the foundation outputs from a research project that focuses on designing energy efficiency consumer products by addressing the energy impacts associated with the user's behaviour. In particular, it is the first to introduce the concept of the 'theoretical minimum'. It importantly creates design strategies for tackling intrinsic and user-related losses of products. As a consequence, the authors were invited to submit a paper for the IEEE Symposium on Electronics and the Environment, 2008 in San Francisco.

Title: Energy efficient process planning for CNC machining
VolumeTitle: CIRP Journal of Manufacturing Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the first research for multi-criteria process planning that shows that energy consumption can be considered as an objective of process planning for CNC machining. This paper was selected for the CIRP Manufacturing Systems Technology journal from a keynote paper presented at the first International Colloquium on Energy-Efficient Product and Process Innovation in Production Engineering in Chemnitz, Germany 2010. The research described in the paper has led to new funding of €202k with the University of Bath as a partner in a EU FP7 research programme (NMP-2009-3.4-2) entitled DEMAT (Design of dematerialised machine tools).

Title: The use of creative stimuli at early stages of industrial product innovation
AdditionalInformation: This is an important publication resulting from longitudinal collaboration on creativity within the Innovation Centre at a large multinational packaging company (Crown Packaging UK plc). The work was undertaken as part of the EPSRC Innovative Design and Manufacturing Research Centre (EP/E00184X/1). The results from the work led the company to create an internal design tool called ‘Sweeper’, which uses material from previous projects as stimuli in the early stages of industrial product innovation. Ongoing research collaboration with Crown continues to help the company improve its innovation process (contact: Chris.RAMSEY@eur.crowncork.com).

Title: Methodological insights from a rigorous small scale design experiment
AdditionalInformation: This paper tackles research quality in engineering design as it takes a critical view of the methods typically used in the design research community and proposes much needed methodological improvements. Furthermore, the research advocates the open sharing of research data to promote replication by making the raw experimental data freely available (http://designresearchmethods.com/). The work was undertaken as part of the EPSRC Innovative Design and Manufacturing Research Centre (EP/E00184X/1). The paper was shortlisted for the annual Design Studies Award 2012.

Title: Understanding the rapid evaluation of innovative ideas in the early stages of design
AdditionalInformation: This work presents a rare empirical study of creative idea evaluation in the early stages of the new product development process. This paper was the result of close research collaboration with two French Universities (Nancy Université-INPL and INSA Strasbourg) and EDF Energy in France. This paper is significant in design research for three reasons: firstly the topic of ‘selecting’ ideas in under-researched in comparison to ‘generating’ ideas; secondly, the data collected are from experienced practising designers; and, finally, empirical data on creative activities in design are still rare.

Title: Understanding engineering email: the development of a taxonomy for identifying and classifying engineering work
AdditionalInformation: By analysing the contents of project emails, signatures can be identified reflecting the project performance at a point in time. The signatures can also be used to predict future events. This paper describes how these signatures may be identified and how project managers can use them. The aim is for managers to be able to identify any future problems/opportunities with a project’s performance. The findings have contributed to the award of an EPSRC High Value Manufacturing/ICT project (EP/K014196/1, £1.95M) to identify signatures based on changes in digital records for high-value complex projects.

Title: Study of the uncertainty of angle measurement for a rotary-laser automatic theodolite (R-LAT)
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports a novel procedure for the estimation and experimental verification of measurement uncertainty of the indoor-GPS (iGPS) laser transmitter, modelling it as a rotary-laser automatic theodolite. The results show how angular uncertainty is influenced by design parameters and that azimouth angle uncertainty decreases with sampling duration and is relatively constant throughout the working volume. Its key significance is the characterisation of the uncertainty of the iGPS transmitter that allows the uncertainty calculation of the factory-wide iGPS network. This was the first independent study of iGPS uncertainty, influencing research internationally and with NPL (NPL REPORT ENG 23, 2010).

Title: Operation sequencing optimization for five-axis prismatic parts using a particle swarm optimization approach
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an operation sequencing methodology for 5-axis milling using the evolutionary algorithm, particle swarm optimisation (PSO). The novelty of the paper lies in the modelling and codification of the process planning stages for 5-axis machining as elements of the PSO algorithm. Further, several new operators have been developed especially for this application, to deal with local optima, leading to a modified PSO algorithm. A comprehensive case study was used to verify performance.

Title: Large volume metrology instrument selection and measurability analysis
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The paper received the 2010 Best Paper SAGE Award from the Institution of Mechanical Engineers for Part B of the Proceedings. Large Volume Metrology (LVM) is a very new and rapidly expanding field of dimensional metrology encompassing a wide range of instruments for which there are no coherent methods for instrument selection and measurability analysis. The paper addresses the need to establish LVM as a manufacturing process and sets the foundations for measurement planning research. They can be deployed for integrated design specification and measurability evaluation, with research underway and sponsored by Airbus and Rolls-Royce.

Title: Experimental comparison of dynamic tracking performance of iGPS and laser tracker
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper outlines an experimental technique for establishing the dynamic tracking capability of indoor-GPS (iGPS) using a robotic cell and a laser tracker as the reference. The key novelty of the paper is in establishing a generic method for carrying out dynamic repeatability comparisons of dynamic, motion tracking Large Volume Metrology (LVM) instruments. LVM is increasingly seen as a core technology for developing 'measurement-enabled production' of superior accuracy and this study contributes to experimental measurement techniques that underpin such efforts. The paper influenced research internationally, and was adopted in a new, collaborative £2.47M EPSRC Grant (EP/K018124/1) led by Bath.

Title: Toward interoperable CNC manufacturing
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: A new paradigm for realising interoperability in CNC manufacturing is introduced in the form of a universal framework that not only transcends vendor barriers, but also allows heterogeneous systems from multiple application domains to be integrated. The research was informed by collaboration with other internationally leading authors (Xu and Rosso Jr.) in the field. This paper led to the EPSRC IdMRC project ‘Realisation of a universal manufacturing platform’ (EP/E00184X/1, £850k) and then the STEPMAN project (Ref: 286962, €2.9M), which aims to bring the benefits of the proposed framework to European SMEs by 2014.

Title: A unified manufacturing resource model for representation of computerized numerically controlled machine tools
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: A novel data modelling approach is proposed that allows functional capabilities of all CNC machine tools to be captured in exactly the same manner regardless of their technology, embedded processes and structure. The approach was utilised as the basis of the ISO 14649-201 international standard for modelling machine tools. The research also formed the foundation for a collaborative research project (AeroFRAME, €15k) with the Centre for Italian Aerospace Research (CIRA) to extend its application to composite cutting machines. Finally, it became the backbone for machine tool modelling within the EU FP7 Dematerialised Manufacturing Systems (DEMAT) project (Ref: 246020, €4.7M).

Title: Using constraints at the conceptual stage of the design of carton erection
AdditionalInformation: Cartons are widely used to package products. A constraint-based approach is presented for the design of mechanisms within packaging machines used to form cartons. Its novelty is in the use of a constraint-based model of the carton to understand the design problem and then expanding this to cover the design and assessment of the forming mechanisms and their interaction with the carton. The paper integrates ideas from a projects funded by DEFRA (FT1106, £328k and AFM21, £86k) and the EPSRC (EP/E00184X/1, £7.3k) relating to constraint modelling and the design improvement of packaging machinery.

Title: Using constraint satisfaction as a means for modelling parallel folding evolution
AdditionalInformation: A novel means for modelling and predicting the behaviour of folds within laminate structures is presented. The approach is constraint-based with the constraints specifying the integrity of the structure while its internal energy is minimised. This avoids the need to assume a particular solution form, which all previous approaches have done. The research led to collaboration with Kyoto University and Edmunds obtaining a two-year post-doctoral fellowship at the Toyota Technological Institute in Kyoto (2009-2011).

Title: Atlas of spherical four-bar mechanisms
AdditionalInformation: The question of mechanism synthesis is vital to many machine designers and the problem is difficult when the required path or motion is truly three-dimensional. An atlas of mechanisms and their outputs provides a starting point for new designs. The work relates to research on reconfigurable packaging equipment sponsored by DEFRA under its Advanced Food Manufacturing programme (AFM211, total value £644k, on completion it was assessed with a score of 9/10). This project was undertaken in collaboration with King's College, London and group of industrial companies (Quin Systems, Marden Edwards, Bendicks of Mayfair, Field Packaging, Marks and Spencer).

Title: Defining a framework for the evaluation of information
AdditionalInformation: This is the result of multidisciplinary collaborative work beween Civil and Mechanical Engineering research teams. It is a paper that introduces a novel network based Bayesian method for evaluating information quality. The method has also been evaluated on a lessons learned corpus from a range of collaborating companies. The work was funded by the Bath-led 11-Institution EPSRC and ESRC Grand Challenge on Through Life Information (EP/C534220/1). The idea of information evaluation is a critical dimension of the recently awarded EPSRC Bath and Bristol project - The Language of Manufacturing (£1.95M, EP/K014196/1).

Title: Investigating ontology development for engineering design support
AdditionalInformation: This is a theoretical and applied paper associated with the use of ontologies in the engineering design space. This work has been used to underpin the research into Design Information And Knowledge (DIAK), which has been one of the core themes in the Innovative design and Manufacturing Research Centre (IdMRC) (EPSRC, EP/E00184X/1) and the Immortal Information and Through Life Grand Challenge (EPSRC, EP/C5342201/1). Interestingly, it was also very important as a follow-on Knowledge Transfer Partnership project with Converteam to 'Develop sustainable strategies for organising explicit knowledge' (Ref ZK-R0037 for Converteam UK Ltd).

Title: Reuse of ideas and concepts for creative stimuli in engineering design
AdditionalInformation: It is extraordinarily difficult to undertake high validity research in the area of understanding the detailed activities associated with engineering. The input to this paper is the result of embedding a researcher within a design team in the multi-national company, Crown Packaging, simultaneously undertaking work and research. This eliminates a wide variety of detrimental effects that impact on this type of research. A novel re-use support system was implemented and tested. It is still in use. The stimulation from this work also resulted in a number of important patents for Crown Packaging.

Title: An intelligent approach for the prediction of surface roughness in ball-end machining of polypropylene
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new predictive model based on genetic algorithms for determining the optimised manufacturing parameters for ball-nose machining of sculptured surface polypropylene products. This was an invited paper to the RCIM journal selected from the international conference FAIM2007 (USA). The research provides a new means to predict surface roughness for polypropylene machined parts. This work was part of a £420k EPSRC research programme (GR/R67507/01) at the University of Bath entitled 'CRYMAN-Rapid manufacture of soft flexible materials for customised shoes'. The results have led to an industrially funded studentship with Renishaw plc to investigate machining and modelling techniques.

Title: A unified manufacturing resource model for representing CNC machining systems
AdditionalInformation: A novel universal method is described to define and model kinematic structures for any CNC manufacturing workstation. The resource information models described in this paper have been adopted and accepted by ISO Technical Committee TC184/SC1-Working Group 8 as the international standard ISO 14649 Part 200 for machine tool resource representation. This research has led to an EU research programme with funding of €550k for Bath's involvement as the leading technology partner in the EU FP7-SME-2011 project STEPMAN (no. 286962) on STEP-NC standard based integrated product lifecycle management solution to increase the competitiveness of European machine tool manufacturing SMEs.

Title: A methodology for the determination of foamed polymer contraction rates as a result of cryogenic CNC machining
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides new knowledge to CNC machine polypropylene sculptured surfaces using ball-end cutters from the generation of a predictive model for optimised machining parameters for a specific surface roughness. The research is one of the outputs from a £420k EPSRC research programme (GR/R67507/01) on the rapid manufacture of shoe soles. The paper was invited for publication from the international conference on Flexible Automation and Intelligent Manufacturing in 2009. The research has led to a follow-on EPSRC KTA EP/H500103/1 research grant of £145k with Renishaw plc to design a desktop machine tool for insole manufacture.

Title: Detecting damage in composite material using nonlinear elastic wave spectroscopy methods
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a multifaceted investigation of nonlinear ultrasound techniques to detect microcracks and contact damage in composite materials. The basis of this work originated from the EU project AERONEWS FP6-502927 (€4.8M) in collaboration with the Universities of Leuven and Lille. The success of this work was a significant input to a new EU FP7 (ACP2-GA-2012-314768- €3.3M funded project ‘A life-cycle autonomous modular system for aircraft material state evaluation and restoring system’. It is led by Dr M Meo in collaboration with nine European partners where the new techniques will be being tested on large scale aerospace structures.

Title: Time reversal DORT method applied to nonlinear elastic wave scattering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first successful investigation of an ultrasound imaging technique able to distinguish nonlinear from linear scatterers. This was achieved by combining a nonlinear elastic wave spectroscopy method based on high harmonic generation with time reversal algorithms and DORT technique. This work will result in more accurate non-destructive evaluation of materials and structures. The fundamental work has led to a UK-RCNDE funded project ‘Nonlinear FE modelling of cracks/damage precursors’. The work spawned further research included in an EU FP7 funded project ‘A life-cycle autonomous modular system for aircraft material state evaluation and restoring system’ (ACP2-GA-2012-314768- €3.3M).

Title: Optimization of composite stiffened panels subject to compression and lateral pressure using a bi-level approach
AdditionalInformation: A new approach is presented to the optimum design of stiffened aerospace panels manufactured from composite laminates. The research led to the generation of a new optimization method for the Airbus A350 wing during a secondment of Dr Liu to Airbus. The method was essential to the capture of a successful EPSRC bid for the £668k Airbus, Bristol and Bath STrategic Research Alliance in Composites (ABBSTRACT, EP/H025898/1) and has generated results used in an Airbus study for the development of new structures for future aircraft concepts.

Title: Impact detection in anisotropic materials using a time reversal approach
VolumeTitle: Structural Health Monitoring - An International Journal
AdditionalInformation: This work reports a new technique to detect impact source location in a complex aerospace composite structure (stiffened panel) using only one sensor and with no knowledge of material and geometrical properties. The proposed technique will enable early identification of structural impact events and consequent reduction in the structural performance, leading to lighter components and a reduction in the amount of CO2 emissions. The success of this work has led to a collaborative project with AgustaWestland under the ICOMP TSB funded project where the technique was applied successfully to the tail blade of the AWE 129 Helicopter.

Title: Baseline-free estimation of residual fatigue life using a third order acoustic nonlinear parameter
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: A novel method to estimate the residual fatigue life of an aircraft component is presented in this paper. The proposed method enables aircraft operators to accurately and timely changeover periods, improve aircraft safety and consequently reduce catastrophic failures. A successful demonstration was carried out on a Tornado aircraft rib by the Italian Air Force. The successful outcome of this research led to a new project funded by DSTL ‘Fatigue life estimation using a nonlinear wave modulation spectroscopy method’ (MAST Project CDE 23726-£49,842).

Title: Compressive strength of delaminated aerospace composites
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: The first set of experimentally validated results of a new model is presented. The model is more accurate than FEA for predicting the compressive strength of laminates containing an artificial delamination. The model can be used to predict the residual strength of composite structures following damage, at low computational cost. The work followed from the £668k EPSRC grant, Airbus, Bristol and Bath STrategic Research Alliance in Composites Technology (ABBSTRACT, EP/H025898/1). The model has been used to verify the damage tolerance of new robotically laminated structures, manufactured by GKN Aerospace at the National Composites Centre (Richard.Newley@gknaerospace.com).

Title: Damage tolerance of fully orthotropic laminates in compression
AdditionalInformation: A new class of unconventional high-performance laminate designs with unique elastic properties and optimized damage tolerance is presented. Results show over 20% increase in damage tolerance compared with conventional laminates, leading to opportunities for 20% structural weight saving, reduced fuel burn and lower emissions. The research led to an EPSRC CASE award from GKN Aerospace and facilitated a collaborative partnership with Prof R Haftka, Past-President, International Society for Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization, University of Florida. The new laminates are more easily manufactured than conventional designs, and underpinned a Knowledge Transfer Partnership (1000774) with GKN Aerospace at the National Composites Centre.

Title: Bending strength of delaminated aerospace composites
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes an experimentally validated nonlinear model highlighting the susceptibility of delaminated composite beams to bending-induced fatigue. When supported by experimental test results, the model can be adapted to provide a more repeatable method for determining the Mode II toughness of polymer resin than all existing methods. The work was conducted under a Great Western Research studentship with AgustaWestland/Rolls-Royce and led to two follow-on projects, also funded by AgustaWestland/Rolls-Royce, on damage tolerance and fatigue of composite laminates.

Title: Compressive static strength model for impact damaged laminates
AdditionalInformation: A newly created model combining periodic strip and energy methods to calculate the compressive strength of impact damaged composite plates is presented. Experimental results from the literature are accurately replicated. High computational efficiency makes the model suitable for early design stage optimisation for damage tolerance: a key capability for weight reduction currently lacking in the aerospace industry. This work followed from a Great Western Research (GWR) funded PhD study as part of the Airbus, Bristol and Bath STrategic Research Alliance in Composites (ABBSTRACT). The model was essential to the damage tolerance aspects of a successful £668k follow-on EPSRC grant (EP/H025898/1).

Title: Engineering design optimization using services and workflows
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper was invited for publication for the significance and impact of the work. It presents the construction of Resource Oriented Architecture for high fidelity multidisciplinary engineering optimisation for the first time. This provides an interoperable platform-independent framework for distributed and collaborative multidisciplinary optimisation. The architecture enables the combination of inputs from heterogeneous data sources, large-scale data communication and asynchronous workflow. The data of this work formed the basis for collaboration with NASA Glenn researchers on the high profile OpenMDAO project.

Title: Hysteresis in modeling of poroelastic systems: quasistatic equilibrium
AdditionalInformation: A new mechanism for hysteresis in porous materials is identified. This work represents highly interdisciplinary and creative collaboration with scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) and ETH/EMPA. This study of the permeability of rocks and earthquakes is being exploited, in collaboration with the LANL scientists, to support research in oil/gas estimation, in seabed carbon sequestration, and earthquake triggering. This work has led to funding for continuing collaboration from the Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics and LANL. Further funding of $327k from the oil and gas industry is expected from 2014.

Title: Matched excitation energy comparison of the pulse and lock-in thermography NDE techniques
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first objective comparison of the defect imaging capabilities of the pulsed and lock-in thermographic NDE techniques by introducing a means of matching excitation energies and of obtaining signal to noise ratios of defect images.  It is listed on the NDT&E International home page as the second most cited (47 times) article published in the journal since 1996.  It was a major output of the Core Research Programme of the EPSRC funded, GR/S09388/01, UK Research Centre in NDE.  This work led to a British Council UKIERI grant funding collaboration with Professor Tuli of the IIT Delhi.

Title: Crack imaging by scanning laser-line thermography and laser-spot thermography
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel thermographic means of imaging cracks using laser line heating and an original thermographic image edge enhancement technique that produces realistic crack images. The work was EPSRC funded (EP/F024096/1) as a targeted project of the UK Research Centre in NDE, it was a collaboration with researchers at Warwick University and it received support from Rolls-Royce, RWE npower and the National Nuclear Laboratory. The paper was selected for special publicity by Measurement Science and Technology on its publication and later it featured in the journal’s 2011-2012 Highlights as an 'example of high quality, well executed outstanding research'.

Title: Thermographic techniques for the detection of cracks in metallic components
VolumeTitle: Insight: Non-Destructive Testing and Condition Monitoring
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents three different thermographic techniques for imaging of cracks in metallic components. It covers the work of three targeted projects of the UK Research Centre in NDE (EP/F024096/1, EP/F022522/1, EP/E04641X/1). It involved academics at Imperial College and the Universities of Warwick and Newcastle and industrial support from Rolls-Royce, RWE npower, National Nuclear Laboratory, Alstom Power and Airbus. The paper was prepared for the British Institute of NDT journal Insight to inform NDT practitioners of the new developments. It was awarded the 2011 John Grimwade Medal for the best paper by an Institute member to appear in the journal.

Title: An analytical study of the pulsed thermography defect detection limit
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first comprehensive analytical treatment of the defect imaging capability of pulsed thermographic NDE and it shows a long used rule-of-thumb to be ill-founded and misleading. The work is a major output of the Core Research Programme of the EPSRC funded, EP/F017332/1, UK Research Centre in NDE. A further grant of £100k has been received from NDEvrR, representing the industrial members of the UK Research Centre in NDE, to develop a thermographic NDE expert system that will be based on the analytical treatment presented in the paper

Title: Optimal configurations of bistable piezo-composites for energy harvesting
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a detailed investigation that optimises bistable laminates for energy harvesting applications. In particular, a careful formulation of the optimisation problem and methodology was necessary to overcome the technical challenge of this highly nonlinear and multimodal problem. This is an international collaboration with Inman, from the University of Michigan, who is an international leader in energy harvesting. It formed the basis of a successful EPSRC grant application, EP/J014389 (£370k) in collaboration with Perpetuum and the National Physical Laboratory. The significance that it is the first study that optimises bistable energy harvesters.

Title: A new hole insertion method for level set based structural topology optimization
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces a stable and robust method based on improved numerical convergence properties for level set topology optimisation. The results formed the basis for funded research by NASA Langley ($245k) and the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research ($265k). Further funding is currently under discussion with GE Global Research. It also led to invited keynote at a European Framework meeting and seminars at MIT and the Universities of Michigan and Florida. The follow-up paper to this work has been invited to a special issue reflecting ‘past, present and future of multidisciplinary design optimisation’ in the AIAA Journal.

Title: Manipulation of particles in two dimensions using phase controllable ultrasonic standing waves
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London Series A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Ultrasound can apply appreciable forces to particles with diameters of tens of microns, an important length scale that encompasses most biological cells. Previous cell trapping techniques have used resonant devices to trap microparticles at fixed positions. The paper describes the first use of ultrasound transducers with minimised reflectivity to trap microparticles on a grid which can be translated in two dimensions. This provides a tool for life scientists to precisely pattern cells. The work is an outcome of the EPSRC Sonotweezers project (EP/G012067/1, value £4.2M over four years), a collaboration between four universities.

Title: Proof of principle study of ultrasonic particle manipulation by a circular array device
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London Series A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Ultrasound can be used to trap and manipulate microparticles (including biological cells) in fluids. This work presents the first proposal for an ultrasonic particle manipulator capable of trapping and manoeuvring multiple particles independently. These devices, which have since been demonstrated in practice (Courtney et al., Applied Physics Letters, 102, 123508, 2013), are intended to allow life scientists to dexterously manoeuvre cells, with potential application to tissue engineering. The work is an outcome of the EPSRC Sonotweezers project (EP/G012067/1, value £4.2M over four years), a collaboration between four universities.

Title: On the nucleation and growth of kink and shear bands
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper highlights a unique mathematical connection between the distinctive phemonena of kink and shear banding, which are classic failure mechanisms observed in layered and granular materials. This recent work has led to a new project (Kink band instabilities in MAX Phase Ceramics); which is investigating the formation of nano-scale kink bands in MAX Phase Ceramics, a light weight material used in novel aero-engine applications. Funding for this project is derived from a University of Bath Prize Fellowship awarded to Dodwell.

Title: Multi-layered folding with voids
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This work presents a novel interdisciplinary framework for modelling the formation of voids/delaminations, which naturally form during the folding of layered materials. The methods have significant applications to the fields of geoscience and composite materials. The work has led to an industrial collaboration with GKN Aerospace, which extends this contribution to model the formation of defects during the manufacture of carbon fibre composites (£40k, EP/J015504/1). This paper was directly relevant to the successful EPSRC bid 'Multiscale Modelling of Aerospace Composites' (£396k, EP/K031368/1).

Title: Application of a methodology to assess the performance of a full-scale diesel oxidation catalyst during cold and hot start NEDC drive cycles
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new technique to measure the spatial and temporal distribution of exhaust catalyst temperature distribution. These temperature results are related directly to exhaust gas composition before and after the catalyst during the actual test used for vehicle certification. This knowledge will contribute to more optimised catalyst designs which make more sustainable use of scarce and expensive precious metal resources used in automotive catalysts. The work was funded by an EPSRC grant (EP/E059074/1, £499k), and also supported by Ford and catalyst manufacturer Johnson Matthey.

Title: Computational extrapolation of turbine sealing effectiveness from test rig to engine conditions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy
AdditionalInformation: This is the first output from TSB KTP Project 8147 (£183k) based on computations carried out at Siemens Industrial Turbines Ltd as project industrial partner. This paper presents for the first time a method for scaling results from simplified experiments to engine conditions. Aspects of the methods have been incorporated into Siemens industrial design procedures (Dr Yan Sheng Li, yansheng.li@siemens.com). The KTP project attracted further Siemens funding of £56k in PhD studentships (J. Maltson, john.maltson@siemens.com) for projects involving experimental testing to verify the methods and the testing of other models to be incorporated into industrial design codes.

Title: Transport by an intrusion generated by boundary mixing in a lake
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first 3D tracking of fluid intrusions from turbulent patches generated at the boundaries of stratified water bodies and the first direct documentation of this process in lakes. Both the lake and ocean research communities have used and cited these novel results. The research output was used as pilot data for a research proposal to US National Science Foundation, which was funded for $482k (~£317k).

Title: Jet noise: sound generation by disc and cylinder sources
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London Series A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper helps to resolve an issue which has been important in the problem of aerodynamic noise for decades: what exactly is meant by the noise source and can it be identified? The exact analysis that is presented gives an explicit criterion for determining which parts of a jet noise source radiate and which do not. A reviewer of the paper described the analysis as 'precise and elegant', saying that the work was 'a brilliant paper whose publication will do a lot of good'.

Title: Computational fluid dynamics simulations of flow and heat transfer in a preswirl system: influence of rotating-stationary domain interface
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This is an output from international collaboration with the University of Stuttgart (jvw@itlr.uni-stuttgart.de). The paper resulted from industry-sponsored meetings between a syndicate of three universities (Bath, Stuttgart and Duisburg-Essen; syndicate meetings coordinator, Kok Mun Tham, kokmun.tham@siemens.com), each having gas turbine research funded by Siemens. The study described in the paper contributes to the validation and calibration of computational tools being used in industry to support the design of the next generation of Siemens gas-turbine engines. The Bath pre-swirl research that is the basis for this paper was associated with European Gas Turbines Ltd/EPSRC grant GR/M08868 (£122k).

Title: Analysis of optimal conditions for adsorptive hydrogen storage in microporous solids
VolumeTitle: Colloids and Surfaces, A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides a new engineering tool for assessing adsorptive hydrogen storage solutions in sustainable energy systems. It is based on an original model for the pressure and temperature dependence of hydrogen adsorption, and is a major improvement on current methods using simple, single-point uptake measurements. The paper followed an oral presentation at the 6th International Workshop on the Characterization of Porous Materials, Delray Beach, FL, USA. It also supported the award of the 2013 SET for Britain Westminster Medal (overall winner) to one of its authors, V Ting, for her presentation Engineering Nanomaterial Systems for Storage of Solid-like Hydrogen.

Title: Effect of ingestion on temperature of turbine discs
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to show the effects of ingestion on the temperature of a rotating disc. The output resulted from collaboration between the University of Bath and Siemens Industrial Turbomachinery. The research was funded by Siemens/EPSRC (£286k EP/G069107/1  + £340k Siemens). It led to the successful capture of a follow-on grant: Siemens/EPSRC (£532k EP/J014826/1 + £302k Siemens). The paper is used by Siemens to validate its CFD and 1D codes and has led to an international collaboration with Professor Tom Shih, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, USA.

Title: Solutions of Fourier's equation appropriate for experiments using thermochromic liquid crystal
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This paper explains a new method of analysis for thermochromic liquid crystals, to increase the accuracy of measuring adiabatic wall temperatures. The output resulted from collaboration between the University of Bath and Siemens Industrial Turbomachinery. The research was funded by Siemens/EPSRC (£286k EP/G069107/1 + £340k Siemens). The new method of analysis is being used in a new test facility funded by Siemens and the EPSRC (£532k EP/J014826/1 + £302k Siemens).

Title: Investigation and analysis into the impact of rapeseed methyl ester biodiesel on the diesel oxidation catalyst performance
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Most papers examining biodiesel and vehicle after treatment systems focus on the diesel particulate filter. In contrast, this paper reports on the impact of biodiesel use on oxidation catalyst performance with far-reaching implications for automotive manufacturers. This work was undertaken in collaboration with Ford and through the RCUK Fellowship (EP/E500498/1) of the primary author. This paper led to continued collaboration with Ford relating to after treatment systems, securing an additional £25k of industrial support.

Title: Swash zone sediment fluxes : field observations
AdditionalInformation: The work completed for this paper used a novel remote sensing technique to provide the first comprehensive measurements of the volume of sand transported in the swash zone at the timescale of individual waves.  The work was completed as part of a major international collaborative field study involving nine universities from Europe, USA, Australia and New Zealand.  The research was motivated by a consensus among coastal modellers that sediment transport data on short timescales were essential for the validation and further development of numerical models. The results have subsequently been used by internationally based coastal modellers.

Title: Alongshore fluid motions in the swash zone of a sandy and gravel beach
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports on a series of unique field measurements of alongshore flow velocities in the swash zone of contrasting sand and gravel beaches.  The data collection was completed as part of two externally-funded, collaborative field experiments involving universities from Europe, USA, Australia and New Zealand, which have been widely reported in the literature.  The results indicate the importance of alongshore motions in determining the rate of sediment transport on beaches, a variable which is consistently discounted in many coastal sediment transport models.

Title: The effect of relative crest submergence on wave breaking over submerged slopes
AdditionalInformation: This detailed laboratory study provides new data on the details of wave breaking on submerged reef structures.  The work is relevant to wave breaking on natural reefs as well as providing much needed design data for artificial reefs for coastal protection.  Artificial submerged reefs cause waves to break seaward of the beach, reducing the erosive power of waves at the beach, leading to an increased beach width.  These structures are becoming increasingly used to provide coastal protection, with existing reefs installed in Italy, Japan, Wales and the Caribbean. This work has extended the previously limited design guidance.

Title: Bubble size measurements in breaking waves using optical fiber phase detection probes
AdditionalInformation: The research used a novel optical fibre probe technique to measure the bubble size distribution in the highly aerated, active bubble plumes generated by breaking waves. The technique was subsequently used on a major NERC UK-SOLAS research project (Field Observations of Sea Spray, Gas Fluxes and Whitecaps: SEASAW).
