Fieldwork included one dedicated research cruise (D317 in 2007) as reported by Brooks and 48 co-authors, 2009: Physical exchanges at the air-sea interface: UK-SOLAS Field Measurements. Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society, 90(5), 629-644. The data are valuable for the estimation of gas transfer across the air-sea interface.

Title: Unsteady characteristics of inlet vortices
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to record systematic time-resolved experimental measurements of the meandering characteristic of inlet vortices. It was found for the inlet vortex that meandering occurs at dominant frequencies. The results benefit aircraft engine manufacturers in developing novel inlet vortex alleviation techniques to improve the engine efficiency. The study was supported by a Research Councils UK Academic Fellowship in Unmanned Air Vehicles (EP/C50948X/1, £125k).

Title: Flow reattachment and vortex re-formation on oscillating low-aspect-ratio wings
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first systematic study of the effects of wing oscillations on flow reattachment and vortex reformation over low aspect ratio wings. The results have significant impact on improving the gust response of Unmanned and Micro Air Vehicles. The study was supported by a Research Councils UK Academic Fellowship in Unmanned Air Vehicles and the EPSRC grant EP/C015258/1 (£71k).

Title: Bifurcating flows of plunging airfoils at high Strouhal numbers
AdditionalInformation: This paper gives significant insight into the fundamental problem of deflected jets. For the first time comprehensive force measurements are presented, the influence of competing asymmetries is considered, and bifurcation onset criteria are devised and validated with a wide range of experimental measurements. This work was supported by a grant from the US Air Force Research Laboratory (FA 8655-10-1-3093).

Title: Lift enhancement by means of small-amplitude airfoil oscillations at low Reynolds numbers
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a combined experimental and computational effort undertaken in collaboration with the Computational Sciences Branch of the US Air Force Research Laboratory. It considers performance improvement due to small amplitude airfoil oscillations at Reynolds numbers relevant to Micro Air Vehicles. For the first time it demonstrates the dependence of thrust generation on a new mode of vortex behaviour, and the link between optimal lift generation and the natural shedding frequency. It was supported by a grant from the US Air Force Research Laboratory (FA 8655-10-1-3093).

Title: Experimental measurements of ingestion through turbine rim seals. Part 1: externally induced ingress
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new approach to testing and modelling hot gas ingestion into the wheel-space of a gas turbine stage. Experimental data and a new mathematical model were used to assess, and subsequently improve, the performance of rim-seal geometries. The work was undertaken in collaboration with Siemens Fossil Power Generation (£347k) and supported by EPSRC grant EP/G069107/1 (£286k). The work was presented at the ASME Turbo Expo 2011 and received a Best Paper Award from the ASME IGTI. Following the publication, the model has been integrated into Siemens’ 1D design codes (Ref: Yan-Sheng Li, Siemens Industrial Turbomachinery, Lincoln).

Title: Conjugate forced convection flow past a circular cylinder with internal heat generation which is embedded in a porous medium
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Numerical Methods in Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: The paper won the 2009 Outstanding Paper Award in the International Journal of Numerical Methods for Heat and Fluid Flow. It involved collaboration with Professor Ioan Pop (Universitatea Babes Bolyai, Cluj, Romania). The research finds application to the dissipation by external flow of the heat generated by a buried cylinder of either radioactive or chemically reacting material.

Title: Comparison between steady and unsteady double-entry turbine performance using the quasi-steady assumption
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper was also awarded the ASME Best Paper award in 2010 at the IGTI Turbo Expo before publication in the Journal of Turbomachinery in 2011. It presents the first, full comparison for a double-entry turbine between its unsteady-flow and steady-state performance to test the quasi-steady assumption. This is of critical importance to inform new modelling approaches when the turbine is exposed to highly pulsating exhaust flows. The article was the culmination of a three-year research programme sponsored by ABB Turbo Systems and led to the renewal of the research contract for a further three years.

Title: The effect of unequal admission on the performance and loss generation in a double-entry turbocharger turbine
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper is unique in that it demonstrates that the flow in the rotor of a double-entry turbine is unable to fully establish to steady-state conditions when exposed to unequal flows. This was of importance to the sponsors of this work, ABB Turbo Systems, since it furthers the understanding of turbine design. It also led to more general research on the subject of turbine timescales with a paper at the IMechE Turbocharging 2012 conference. This paper was also awarded an ASME Best Paper award in 2011 at the IGTI Turbo Expo.

Title: High capacity hydrogen adsorption in Cu(II) tetracarboxylate framework materials: the role of pore size, ligand functionalization, and exposed metal sites
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper involved international academic-industrial research collaboration on new metal-organic framework materials for hydrogen storage. Continued interest in the work stems from its original combination of materials synthesis, characterization and end-use analysis especially for hydrogen storage in low-carbon vehicles. Most of the UK contributions to the paper were funded by the £5.9M EPSRC SUPERGEN UK Sustainable Hydrogen Energy Consortium (EP/E040071/1), of which Mays was PI. The paper, a 2009 Research Highlight in Nature (Vol. 462, p. 961), led to Mays' invitation to present at the 2011 Faraday Discussions 151 on Hydrogen Storage Materials.

Title: Improving comparability of hydrogen storage capacities of nanoporous materials
AdditionalInformation: A new, rigorous experimental and data analysis methodology is reported for collecting and reporting hydrogen storage measurements for nanoporous materials. This resolves the current lack of standardisation and consistency in this field. The paper followed an invited oral presentation at the 2010 AIChE Annual Meeting, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. It led to support from Hiden Isochema (the major UK manufacturer of gas sorption equipment) for a successful EPSRC bid by Mays and others for a five-year £4.0M SUPERGEN Hydrogen and Fuel Cells Hub (EP/J016454/1), which started in 2012.

Title: Analysis of hydrogen storage in nanoporous materials for low carbon energy applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper on new methodology to assess nanoporous materials for hydrogen storage followed Mays' invited oral presentation at the 2011 Faraday Discussions 151 on Hydrogen Storage Materials at Rutherford Appleton Laboratory. FD151 also contained original discussion contributions by Mays and led to funded applications by Mays and collaborators for £242k of neutron beam time at the ISIS facility at RAL (RB1220310, RB1210041, RB1310292, RB1310301) for extended studies of H2 storage.  The paper also led to a successful bid by Mays and co-workers to hold the 14th International Symposium on Metal-Hydride Systems in the UK in 2014.

Title: Effect of an axial jet on vortex merging
AdditionalInformation: This output is one result from a research project (FAR-Wake, €3.75M) funded by the EC 6th Framework. The University of Bath research group investigated the effect of the engine jets on aircraft vortices. Turbulence generated by the engine jets and their interaction with the tip and flap vortices were investigated. New understanding provides a means to optimise the positioning of an engine on the wing of a large transport aircraft.

Title: Effect of spanwise flexibility on flapping wing propulsion
AdditionalInformation: This is the first experimental paper on the effect of wing spanwise flexibility relevant to micro air vehicles. It is shown that, for an optimum flexibility, the propulsive force is maximised. It demonstrates a new paradigm in the area of flow control at low Reynolds numbers, and has been widely used by other researchers as a test case for numerical simulations. It is the most cited article in the Journal of Fluids and Structures since 2007 (www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-fluids-and-structures), achieving 101 total citations (Scopus, July 2013).

Title: Low Reynolds number aerodynamics of free-to-roll low aspect ratio wings
AdditionalInformation: This is an output from a project funded by the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research (FA8655-06-1-3058; $200k). It shows that self-induced roll oscillations are possible for wing shapes that are realistic for fixed-wing micro air vehicles. The means by which tip vortices cause the roll oscillations is explained for these wings for the first time. The paper arose from an invitation to contribute to a special issue of the journal and led to an ongoing PhD project (and associated publications) to create new design methods to achieve controllable MAV flight.

Title: Computational and experimental investigation of a nonslender delta wing
AdditionalInformation: This joint experimental and computational paper is based on research in collaboration with the Computational Sciences Branch of the US Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL). It is the first paper to consider the flow structure over nonslender wings at moderate Reynolds numbers. The results are being used to validate CFD code, which is in continual use by the AFRL in its design of future UAV concepts. The experimental portion of this work (University of Bath) was funded by a grant from the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research (FA8655-06-1-3058; $200k).

Title: The use of multi-variate models for the prediction of heat transfer in vehicle exhaust systems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to cover a thorough experimental characterisation of the heat transfer within individual exhaust system geometries and combine these with detailed heat transfer theory to enable accurate predictions for real-life automotive exhaust configurations. The work was funded by Mahle Powertrain and led directly to a £60k commercially funded follow-on study. The heat transfer model developed during the work described in this paper is currently being used by Mahle Powertrain in its commercial consultancy activities (James Taylor, james.taylor@gb.mahle.com).

Title: Aerothermal investigations of tip leakage flow in axial flow turbines-part III: TIP cooling
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper received the 2008 Best Paper Award from the ASME Heat Transfer Committee. It is the first to show the thermodynamic benefit of injecting coolant into the separation bubble on the tip of a turbine blade. The output was a collaboration between the Universities of Bath and Cambridge, as well as European Gas Turbines (now Siemens) and Alstom Power. The research was funded by the EPSRC (GR/N33997/01; GR/N33980/01, £178k). The paper also led to a research project in Framework 5 (AITEB) at Cambridge.

Title: Accurate heat transfer measurements using thermochromic liquid crystal. Part 1: calibration and characteristics of crystals
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This is an important paper for researchers who wish to quantify the uncertainty related to thermochromic liquid crystals; the effects of rotation, layer-thickness and ageing were quantified. The output arose from collaboration between the University of Bath and Rose-Hulman University, USA (Dr JE Mayhew, Department of Mechanical Engineering). The Bath pre-swirl research that is the basis for this paper was associated with Siemens/EPSRC grant GR/M08868 (£157k).

Title: Microscopic modeling of  the two-temperature model for conduction in heterogeneous media
AdditionalInformation: The two-temperature model is used by many as an improved model for heat transfer computations over the single-temperature model, and is used in many fields, such as geoscience, material science and groundwater modelling. This is the first paper to present correlations for heat transfer for stagnant porous media. Previously published works by other authors concentrate on moderate to high flow rates in the porous medium, but they fail to reproduce these symmetries in the zero flow limit. The correlations presented provide users with the correct formulae to use for convective instability analyses.

Title: Local thermal non-equilibrium effects arising from the injection of a hot fluid into a porous medium
AdditionalInformation: The paper involved a collaboration with Australian (Prof Andrew P Bassom, UWA, Perth) and Indian (Prof Pradeep G Siddheshwar, Bangalore University) academics. Siddheshwar was a Royal Society visitor to the University of Bath during the preparation of the paper while Bassom is a long-term collaborator. The paper shows that the presence of local thermal nonequilibrium between the two phases of a porous medium can lead to the presence of thermal shocks. This work can be applied to geothermal heat extraction and allows engineers to determine optimum flow rates for the flushing of heat.

Title: The onset and nonlinear development of vortex instabilities in a horizontal forced convection boundary layer with uniform surface suction
AdditionalInformation: This was an invited paper to commemorate the life and achievements of Robin Wooding, an eminent geoscientist from New Zealand. It is demonstrated that the vortex pattern which emerges depends very strongly on the form of the initial disturbances and may exhibit strongly nonlinear subcritical behaviour. This is the time that such behaviour has been reported for a forced convection boundary layer flow. This work finds application in the flushing of heat from geothermal reservoirs and of pollutants from groundwater flows, as it predicts greater rates of entrainment of either heat or solute.

Title: Moving least squares via orthogonal polynomials
AdditionalInformation: An analysis of moving least squares in the framework of orthogonal polynomials is presented, giving a novel theoretical underpinning to a method used in the solution of various numerical problems, including those occurring in Lagrangian vortex methods, finite element and finite difference analyses.

Title: Series expansion for the sound field of a ring source
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: An exact series expansion for the sound field radiated by ring sources is an important element in propeller and rotor noise analysis. This paper presents the first such exact expansion to appear in the literature, building on earlier work for axisymmetric sources. It has since been applied in analyses of aerodynamic noise.

Title: Aeroacoustic sources of motorcycle helmet noise
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: Superseding much previous work, this is a detailed analysis of the aerodynamic processes that give rise to noise inside motorcycle helmets, including numerical data from wind tunnel testing. The data analysis techniques developed for the study clarified the link between measured aerodynamic data and noise at a rider's ear. The work was conducted as part of a COST Action 'Accident Prevention Options with Motorcycle Helmets (PROHELM)' project and presented to industry partners, including motorcycle and helmet manufacturers, at the Milan Bike Show in 2008.

Title: Unsteady fluid-structure interactions of membrane airfoils at low Reynolds numbers
AdditionalInformation: This is an invited paper published in a special issue (Animal Locomotion - The Physics of Flying) of Experiments in Fluids. This is the first paper reporting the existence of strong coupling between membrane oscillations and the separated shear layer instabilities. The results have been applied by engineers from the US Air Force to improve the models for developing novel Micro Air Vehicles. The project was funded by grants from the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research (FA8655-09-1-3007, $30k), and a Research Councils UK Academic Fellowship in Unmanned Air Vehicles (EP/C50948X/1, £125k).

Title: Functional morphology of the nasal region of a hammerhead shark
VolumeTitle: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology A - Molecular & Integrative Physiology
AdditionalInformation: This paper arose from interdisciplinary collaboration with the Faculty of Science of the University of Bath that bridged the gap between biology and engineering. The paper is the first study to consider fluid dynamics and morphological features in the nasal region of the hammerhead shark. It was found that the complicated flow around the nasal region provides an asymmetric moment for manoeuvre without external power consumption, with application to the control of Under Water Vehicles. This study has led to a successful joint application to the Alumni Fund of the University of Bath (£12k).

Title: The impact of biodiesel blend ratio on vehicle performance and emissions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: While other papers have examined the impact of biodiesel on engine performance and emissions, this paper is the first to explain the interactions between blend ratio and varying ambient temperature, providing insight into viscosity effects. Work was undertaken in collaboration with Ford and through the RCUK Fellowship (EP/E500498/1) of the primary author, securing a further £100k in Ford funding. This paper was commended as being one of the top three most downloaded papers from the Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering in 2010.

Title: An empirical approach to predicting heat transfer within single- and twin-skin automotive exhaust systems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first study to document a systematic experimental evaluation of the impact of twin-skin exhaust pipe geometries on heat transfer within automotive exhaust systems. The work was funded by an international automotive consultancy, Mahle Powertrain, and a fully documented, configurable heat transfer model, based on work presented in this paper, was delivered to the industrial sponsor. It is currently being used as an analytical tool within the company (James Taylor, james.taylor@gb.mahle.com). This work led to the inclusion of heat transfer modelling in a £800k Ford/Jaguar/Cummins/Bath Turbocharging project from the EPSRC Knowledge Transfer Account (EP/H500103/1).

Title: Effect of radial location of nozzles on performance of preswirl systems: a computational and theoretical study
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy
AdditionalInformation: European Gas Turbines Ltd/EPSRC grant GR/M08868 (£122k) provided input to this paper in the form of experimental measurements for verification of results. Continuing industrial collaboration led to further co-funded research on the different topic of ingestion in gas turbines (Siemens/EPSRC grant EP/G096107/1, £283k). These research projects provided information on the behaviour of gas-turbine internal air systems that can lead to lower emissions, increased efficiency and reduced costs in power generation.

Title: CFD analysis of flow and heat transfer in a direct transfer preswirl system
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This is an output from collaboration with the University of Surrey (Chew, J.Chew@surrey.ac.uk). The paper describes benchmarking of commercial and industrial codes as used by engine designers against unique University of Bath experimental measurements, identifying sensitivity to modelling assumptions. The Bath computations, carried out by a visiting PhD student from Northwestern Polytechnic University, China, resulted in a further 12 month visit (Associate Professor Gaowen Liu, gwliu@nwpu.edu.cn). The experimental research resulted from European Gas Turbines Ltd/EPSRC grant GR/M08868 (£122k). This paper led to further international collaboration with University of Stuttgart (jvw@itlr.uni-stuttgart.de) on the same physical problem.

Title: Thermal modelling of modern diesel engines: proposal of a new heat transfer coefficient correlation
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This article presents a new heat transfer model for the modern generation of high speed direct injection diesel engines, and is based on new data. This is the first time that basic empirical models developed over 40 years ago have been brought up to date to reflect major changes in diesel engine design and operation. The revised model allows engine designers to predict temperatures and heat fluxes in thermally critical engine components with greater accuracy and confidence, thereby allowing designs to progress closer to the thermal limits of materials, and operational limits of the engine.

Title: A model from first principles of the radial heat flux in a cylinder bore of a modern diesel engine
VolumeTitle: Journal of Thermal Science and Engineering Applications
AdditionalInformation: An original approach is descibed to model heat transfer in a diesel engine, which takes into account conduction from the piston and piston ring friction as well as heat from combustion, and compares it with new experimental data. This provides deeper insights into the origins of the heat transfer than existing models and allows design for higher engine efficiency. The model and the experimental techniques used were expanded further in a study, which is still in progress under a TSB project with Ford (TP/9/LCV/6/I/S0052K, with £540k to Bath).

Title: Transient experiments on a full-scale DOC - methodology and techniques to support modelling
AdditionalInformation: A new experimental technique to measure the spatial variation of the operating temperature of a diesel engine oxidation catalyst, and simultaneous measurement of gas species concentration, is investigated under a variety of operating conditions. It allows progress to be made in designing more effective catalysts and/or more efficient use of scarce and expensive materials. The work involved collaboration between chemical and mechanical engineers at the University of Bath, and results from the study have been disseminated to the industrial partners, Ford and Johnson Matthey. The work was funded by the £499k EPSRC grant EP/E059074/1.

Title: Electrical characterization of hydroxyapatite-based bioceramics
AdditionalInformation: Development and refinement of new generation of biologically active bone substitutes will have profound significance clinically. The work reported in this paper underpins cell culture studies carried out on novel electrically active bioceramics. There is an outstanding need for new devices that stimulate biological response via mechanotransduction. This research resulted in invitations to write a review article in the prestigious American Journal Annals of Biomedical Engineering and to deliver lectures at the American Ceramics Society meeting in January 2010 and the Next Generation Biomaterials session at the Materials Science and Technology 2012 Conference & Exhibition in Pittsburg.

Title: Fabrication of HA/TCP scaffolds with a graded and porous structure using a camphene-based freeze-casting method
AdditionalInformation: The successful use of freeze-casting for the manufacture of functional gradient bioceramics materials is reported in this paper. This process is innovative in that it allows for the control of porosity, microstructure and thus mechanical properties. Bone, as a natural functional gradient material, lends itself readily to replacement with synthetic alternatives produced using this novel technique laying the foundation for a new range of bone substitute materials. With development and optimisation, such materials can be used for bone reconstruction, replacement and repair where there is an unmet clinical need. This paper has received over 50 citations.

Title: An in vitro study of electrically active hydroxyapatite-barium titanate ceramics using Saos-2 cells
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first report on the in vitro study of hydroxyapatite-barium titanate (HABT) composites developed as novel electrically active materials for clinical use. This project brought together an interdisciplinary team of materials scientists and chemical engineers with cell culture expertise. This is one of two publications that has generated international interest leading to the delivery of an invited lecture at the American Ceramics Society meeting in January 2010 and an invitation to lecture at the 'Next Generation Biomaterials' session at the Materials Science and Technology 2012 Conference & Exhibition in Pittsburg.

Title: Polarization of hydroxyapatite: influence on osteoblast cell proliferation
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from interdisciplinary research collaboration with a leading group of tissue engineering specialists. The paper reports the first study of osteoblast type cell response to polarised hydroxyapatite. Harnessing the electrical properties produces a new generation of electrically active bioceramics. The results highlight the potential clinical benefit of these innovative materials.

Title: Theoretical models for the quantification of lung injury using ventilation and perfusion distributions
VolumeTitle: Computational and Mathematical Methods in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper funded by EPSRC (GR/L74835/01) addresses a subject that has received little attention, namely, the modelling acute lung disease, a topic that is critical in adult intensive care. The models generated in this paper offer the unique opportunity to develop realistic simulation on the effects of lung disease and the potential for incorporating these into larger scale models of the respiratory and cardiovascular systems.

Title: Mechanical properties of three different compositions of calcium phosphate bioceramic following immersion in Ringer’s solution and distilled water
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Bath has patented fabrication techniques for producing synthetic calcium phosphate bone graft materials with mechanical properties similar to those of cortical and cancellous bone. This study, funded by a Furlong Charitable Research Foundation grant (RE-ME0420), demonstrates that there was no loss in the mechanical properties of these materials in a simulated in-vivo environment reinforcing the potential application as a structural bone graft for orthopaedic applications to address bone loss. The work was linked to a portfolio of research funded by Stryker Orthopaedics and linked to a commercial product, BoneSave.

Title: A computer model of the artificially ventilated human respiratory system in adult intensive care
AdditionalInformation: This EPSRC (GR/L74835/01) funded multidisciplinary project involving four universities (Bath, Sheffield, Nottingham and Warwick) was a novel study employing advances in 3D medical imaging to model artificially ventilated patients in adult intensive care.  A proprietary compartmental modelling software tool created at Bath (Bathfp) enabled integration of different modelling techniques with data from patients in intensive care, thereby benefitting recovery programmes.

Title: Sensing methodology for in vivo stability evaluation of total hip and knee arthroplasty
AdditionalInformation: Smart implants to monitor implant stability and performance in vivo in total joint replacement are of major current interest. This paper presents a new method of sensing both migration and micromotion of implants, previously not possible. This paper builds on significant experience at Bath in micromotion studies associated with grants from Plus Orthopaedics AG (RE-ME0387) and led more recently to funding from Nobel Biocare AG (RE-ME3791). The work led to a successful announcement of a dti grant with UCL and Smith and Nephew (York) (subsequently not pursued for budgetary considerations by Smith and Nephew, USA).

Title: Formation of a human-derived fat tissue layer in PDLLGA hollow fibre scaffolds for adipocyte tissue engineering
AdditionalInformation: Adult or mesenchymal stem cells can be differentiated to give fat tissue. Such tissue engineered fat grafts could restore the volume of soft tissue lost at surgical sites leading to cell therapies for soft tissue reconstruction and augmentation. This is the first report of the use of novel, hollow fibres of poly(lactide-co-glycolide) being used to support the bioprocesses of culture and differentiation of stem cells to fat tissue.  This is a unique interdisciplinary collaboration between cell biologists and biochemical engineers that is at the forefront of regenerative medicine.

Title: MagicWand: a single, designed peptide that assembles to stable, ordered α-helical fibers
AdditionalInformation: This paper documents a unique interdisciplinary collaboration between protein chemists, stem cell biologists and biochemical engineers. It describes, for the first time, a purpose-designed peptide that promotes cell attachment, with the end use as a functional biomaterial for tissue engineering. This biomaterial was subsequently investigated by the consortium to be used as a scaffold to support the attachment and growth of human mesenchymal stem cells in a bioreactor system.

Title: Three-dimensional culture systems for the expansion of pluripotent embryonic stem cells
AdditionalInformation: This interdisciplinary paper is the first to describe how the combination of murine embryonic stem cells and three-dimensional microcarriers can be used to efficiently screen and optimise cell culture and bioprocessing conditions for human embryonic stem cells in stirred flask bioreactors. It is also one of the first to prove that human embryonic stem cells can be cultured on commercial microcarrier systems in bioreactors. This work arose from the interdisciplinary funding from the BBSRC under the stem cell science and engineering initiative (BB/D014549, £227k).

Title: Investigation of cancellous bone architecture using structural optimisation
AdditionalInformation: Described in this output is the first application of the computational technique of evolutionary structural optimisation to predict trabecular bone formation and remodelling. This work provides important new evidence of the link between mechanical loading and the development of trabecular bone structures to support this loading. Subsequent work using the same technique (Kim et al., 13th International Conference on Biomedical Engineering; Lim & Goh (eds.), Springer Berlin Heidelberg, Vol. 23, 1636-1639, 2009) has built on this to extend the ability to predict how trabecular bone responds to both normal and abnormal loading and pathological change.

Title: Weight bearing after tibial fracture as a guide to healing
AdditionalInformation: A causal relationship had previously been assumed between healing and weight-bearing. This output describes a formal verification that measured increases in weight bearing during fracture healing are closely related to measured changes in the stiffness of the healing fracture. This suggests that increases in fracture stiffness (and therefore healing) can easily be quantified by the simple measurement of changes in weight-bearing during healing. Non-union and delayed union of fractures are significant clinical problems affecting between 5-10% of all fractures. The measurement procedures are effective in determining whether healing is progressing normally or whether further clinical intervention is necessary.

Title: A novel closed-loop electromechanical stimulator to enhance osseointegration with immediate loading of dental implant restorations
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H - Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This output describes the design and in-vitro testing of a novel stimulation system to improve the rate of osseointegration of dental implants and represents a new approach in enhancing osseointegration by using controlled early mechanical loading of the implant. This enables the time taken between implantation and full functional use of the implant to be considerably reduced. The work was funded as part of an international multi-centre collaborative EU project (‘IMLOAD: improving implant fixation by immediate loading’, QLK6-CT-2002-02442).

Title: Fabrication and characterization of poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid)/polyvinyl alcohol blended hollow fibre membranes for tissue engineering applications
AdditionalInformation: The fabrication of poly(lactide-co-glycolide) (PLGA) membranes with the addition of poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) is described for the first time. This is an enabling technology where the membranes are used to grow cells for cell therapy. PVA offers considerable advantages over ethanol for pre-wetting membranes, thus preventing distortion and reducing the time and cost of membrane start-up. Furthermore, addition of PVA improves PLGA hydrophilicity and increases the pore size to improve cell culture giving a better structure for cell culture. Its use is to grow cells for cell therapies, an enabling technology.

Title: Definition and validation of operating equations for poly(vinyl alcohol)-poly(lactide-co-glycolide) microfiltration membrane-scaffold bioreactors
AdditionalInformation: This is the first publication of an operating equation for hollow fibre membrane bioreactors for tissue engineering that incorporates the geometrical, fluid dynamics and mass transfer properties. This interdisciplinary collaboration with the Oxford Centre for Industrial and Applied Mathematics will support the design of more predictable and controllable bioreactors for tissue culture. The operating equation concept has led to three further PhD projects (two in Oxford, one in Bath) and Dr Shipley was awarded Young Researcher of the Year for the UK Tissue and Cell Engineering Society in 2011 for this work.

Title: A strategy to determine operating parameters in tissue engineering hollow fiber bioreactors
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to demonstrate a strategy for modelling oxygen transfer in a hollow fibre membrane bioreactor based on a specific tissue. This ensures that all cells are supplied with enough oxygen, which is historically problematic in tissue engineering. The work was in collaboration with the Oxford Centre for Industrial and Applied Mathematics. The output of this paper and the collaboration with Dr Shipley has led to an NC3Rs project ‘Development and mathematical modelling of zonated hollow fibre bioreactors for in vitro to in vivo extrapolation of systemic chemical toxicity’, which involves four universities and four companies.

Title: Simvastatin release from poly(lactide-co-glycolide) membrane scaffolds
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents for the first time a method to combine statins with scaffolds for bone tissue engineering, which will release statins locally and contribute to bone regeneration and vascularisation. This will be of benefit to patients with compromised bone formation such as those with osteoporosis. The work was done in collaboration with Dr Sarah Cartmell (Manchester). This work has led to continued collaboration with Dr Cartmell (grant application submission), and an MD student who is investigating ways to improve hip reconstruction in sickle cell disease patients.

Title: Ultrasound transmission loss across transverse and oblique bone fractures: an in-vitro study
AdditionalInformation: The technique presented allows inference of the presence of bone fractures by monitoring parameters such as sound pressure loss that characterise the propagation of ultrasound in solids. It is demonstrated that sound pressure loss, while being sensitive to different fracture geometries, retains its diagnostic potential. This is particularly significant as other ultrasound-based techniques, relying on simple speed of sound measurement, are not robust when the geometry of the fracture is changed. The robustness of the technique makes ultrasound a non-ionising alternative to X-ray imaging, with the added advantage of offering improved diagnostics due to its quantitative basis.

Title: Ultrasound mimics the effect of mechanical loading on bone formation in vivo on rat ulnae
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study indicating that ultrasound can stimulate bone formation in the absence of injury, and that its effects on bone deposition are comparable to those achieved with mechanical loading. This finding is of clear clinical interest as it can be exploited to counteract bone degeneration induced by metabolic diseases such as osteoporosis. The work resulted from a collaborative effort with colleagues from the Universities of Bristol and Southampton, and the Royal Veterinary College.

Title: Influence of setting liquid composition and liquid-to-powder ratio on properties of a Mg-substituted calcium phosphate cement
AdditionalInformation: This research, which fits within a wider framework aimed at understanding the clinically relevant mechanical and rheological properties of bone cements, was of direct relevance to the characterisation of Hydroset, a $32M/year product marketed by Stryker (USA). The technical file, necessary for Federal Drug Administration approval of Hydroset in screw augmentation procedures, was compiled at Bath (Stryker, T.R.1862.E503). The programme of work was funded by a Fellowship Grant from the Portuguese Foundation for Science (SFRH/BD/21761/2005) that allowed a visiting researcher, working under the supervision of Dr Gheduzzi, to benefit from the techniques generated at Bath to evaluate injectable cements.

Title: Numerical and experimental simulation of the effect of long bone fracture healing stages on ultrasound transmission across an idealized fracture
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: Ultrasound attenuation is investigated as a quantitative predictor of fracture healing, hence showing a potential diagnostic method that is superior to X-ray imaging. The work was funded by an Action Medical Research grant (AP0953), which demonstrated the feasibility of using ultrasound. This paper formed an important early part of research into the complex interaction between sound waves and bone and resulted in a collaborative project with the Universities of Bristol and Southampton, and the Royal Veterinary College.

Title: Paracrine interactions between mesenchymal stem cells affect substrate driven differentiation toward tendon and bone phenotypes
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to show that a specific growth factor secreted by tendon cells inhibits bone cell formation from adult stem cells. Tissue engineering studies focus on one cell, when in reality multiple cell types are deposited on a substrate to form tissue. This paper establishes important guiding principles for stem cell differentiation to tendon and bone, highlighting the implications of cells influencing other cells when designing biomaterials for cell therapies. The work was selected for oral presentation at the Orthopaedic Research Society, Jan 2011 (normally less than 10% selected for oral presentation from 3000 papers).

Title: Nanomaterials can dynamically steer cell responses to biological ligands
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to use differentially sized nanoparticles to enhance skin cell motility. A novelty of this system is that the nanoparticles are metabolizable by cells, which means the system can be extended to long-term studies and animal models to use the initial findings to study skin wound healing.  This paper highlights the importance of 'nano influencing micro' when designing substrates for tissue engineering applications. This work contributed towards the award of a Schering-Plough Science and Innovation Award (2006) to Sharma, and a NSF grant of $1M.

Title: Predictive model to assess the molecular structure of biodiesel fuel
AdditionalInformation: Simple-to-measure variables, such as the density or refractive index, that could potentially form a sensor array on vehicle, are used to determine the structure of any given biodiesel fuel. This work was supported by the EPSRC Platform Grant (GR/M97503) and undertaken with material support from Ford (Dr Phil Price) and BP (Dr Alisdair Brown) who supplied fuels and expertise.

Title: Biochemical and biomechanical gradients for directed bone marrow stromal cell differentiation toward tendon and bone
AdditionalInformation: This paper, endorsed by the Faculty of 1000 (http://f1000.com/prime/5687959), was the first to take into account how designer materials affect molecular pathways in stem cells to give tendon cells. It was the first paper in the stem cell engineering field to demonstrate how tendon cell differentiation can be induced using materials-based approaches rather than biochemical methods. The work was selected for oral presentation at the Orthopaedic Research Society, March 2010 (normally less than 10% of 3000 papers are selected for oral presentation).

Title: Nanoscale variation of bioadhesive substrates as a tool for engineering of cell matrix assembly
AdditionalInformation: In tissue engineering, nanoparticles can be used to make a cell-derived matrix. This is the first report of how matrix assembly can be regulated using different sized nanoparticles to produce varying amounts of matrix protein. An important finding is that matrix assembly can be induced with this system when soluble protein is not readily available, making the technique clinically relevant. This system also emphasises the importance of a dynamic rather than static system in promoting cell function. These findings were the basis of a patent application (Methods, Systems, and Compositions for Extracellular Matrix Production, 2008/1/18 2008008435).

Title: Pseudotumours associated with metal-on-metal hip resurfacings
AdditionalInformation: Here is presented the first significant series of destructive soft tissue reactions associated with metal-on-metal hip resurfacing; the term pseudotumour is now commonly used for to cover these reactions. This complication has led to a Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency alert, the withdrawal of the ASR hip resurfacing and one of the most expensive medico-legal actions of recent years. This paper is widely regarded as the key publication that reduced dramatically the usage of metal-on-metal hip resurfacing globally. It is the most cited article published in the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (Br) since 2006, with 305 citations.

Title: Correlation between inclination of the acetabular component and metal ion levels in metal-on-metal hip resurfacing replacement
AdditionalInformation: This is the first work to establish the relationship between orientation of the acetabular component and the risk of abnormally high wear of metal-on-metal hip resurfacing implants. It identifies key factors that increase the incidence of metal wear related failures in female patients. This paper originated the concept of the 'arc of cover', which has changed the understanding of the lubrication mechanism of metal-on-metal hip replacement. It involved international collaboration between UK engineering and Belgian clinical researchers and is the third most cited article published in the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (Br) since 2006, with 176 citations.

Title: The effect of bearing congruency, thickness and alignment on the stresses in unicompartmental knee replacements
AdditionalInformation: A validated finite element model of the human tibia was used with joint load data, measured in vivo, to determine the effects of bearing designs on the polyethylene components of unicompartmental knee replacements. Wear of the polyethylene component is a major reason for failure and this paper has provided an understanding of the effects of various design parameters influencing the mechanical stress conditions in the bearing, which play a role in the wear process. The reasons for higher failure rates in non-congruent designs are identified as due to high sub-surface stresses. It involved international collaboration between UK and US researchers.

Title: Fracture of mobile unicompartmental knee bearings : a parametric finite element study
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H - Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Fracture of knee replacement bearings is a highly traumatic event for the patient. This study used a sophisticated parametric finite element model (validated by experimental measurements) to understand the mechanics underlying fractures of unicompartmental knee replacement bearings. The tensile stress distribution results were predictive of the clinically observed failure patterns. The findings demonstrated the importance of minimising wear and, for the first time, of reducing stress concentrations by using radio-opaque marker balls instead of the more conventional marker wires. The findings also provided an insight into crack propagation caused by cyclic loading representative of that experienced during functional activity.

Title: A theoretical approach to zonation in a bioartificial liver
AdditionalInformation: The liver is a highly organised, structured organ that carries out many physiological functions. This paper is the only account of developing and modelling a bioartificial liver that considers the structure and oxygen gradients through the liver sinusoid compartments, i.e. the periportal, pericentral and perivenal zones. Previous reports only considered the average properties across the complete sinusoid, so this an original study that includes realistic liver physiology in the model. The paper arises from our previous work on modelling a bioartifiial liver (Davidson et al, 2011, Biotechnol Bioeng).

Title: Investigation of an acoustic-mechanical method to detect implant loosening
AdditionalInformation: This paper arose from a collaborative project between research groups at the Universities of Bath and Rostock and was part funded by the DFG (German Research Foundation). It presents a novel approach to determining implant loosening using vibration. Unlike previous work in this area, a vibration source is used within the implant and detects the vibration using an accelerometer placed externally on the limb, which has the potential to greatly increase the sensitivity of the technique.  Subsequent work is aimed at transferring this technique to an in-vivo environment bringing it one step closer to clinical application.

Title: Monolithic nanoporous alumina membranes for ultrafiltration applications : Characterization, selectivity-permeability analysis and fouling studies
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the manufacturing of tubular ultrafiltration membranes obtained via the electrochemical anodization of industrial-grade aluminium, showing that this technology can be scaled to an industrial level. This resulted in the fabrication of monolithic membranes, which have an asymmetric pore structure that mimics polymer membranes, achieving comparable selectivity. This paper is an output from work funded by an EPSRC First Grant (EP/G045798/1) and a Royal Academy of Engineering Research Fellowship; it has been presented at the 2012 the Euromembrane Conference. Results in the paper have formed the basis for a recently awarded TSB grant (16090-117132).

Title: A polymer of intrinsic microporosity as the active binder to enhance adsorption/separation properties of composite hollow fibres
AdditionalInformation: This work has arisen from collaborative interdisciplinary research, with Dstl. Its focus is the replacement of current carbon filter respirators (both military and workplace), with more efficient low pressure drop, easier to breath membrane systems. The paper gives the proof of concept for the design showing a reduced pressure drop and retention of adsorption capacity. A new funded studentship will emerge (awaiting approval from Dstl) to work on the design.

Title: Toward better understanding of the catalytic action of acidic zeolites: investigation in methane and ethane activation and transformation
AdditionalInformation: This fundamental paper presents novel data to confirm the theory of alkanation on zeolites. Its significance is that it could be used for scientific design and detailed understanding of the use of such catalysts in reactors. One of the paper’s reviewers commented: 'a clear mechanistic picture has been created based solely on the results of experiments. In my opinion, this study is a substantial contribution to the field of zeolite catalysis'.

Title: Development of a continuous flow reactor for pharmaceuticals using catalytic monoliths : Pt/C selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the culmination of 11 years of work: a major breakthrough was achieved in demonstrating how continuous flow catalytic fixed-bed reactor technology could be applied in the pharmaceutical industry at pilot-plant scale. The concept, outlined in a patent application (Kolaczkowski WO 2008/04099 A2), is shown to work. Opportunities for the application of this technology are being discussed with GSK (andrew.q.rutter@gsk.com, andrew.m.buswell@gsk.com). The translation of this concept into an engineering design is planned in collaboration with Cambridge Reactor Design Ltd (bashir@crduk.com), and also with MAST Carbon International Ltd (steve.tennison@MastCarbon.co.uk ), who supplied the carbon monoliths as catalyst supports.

Title: Thickness, stability and contact angle of liquid films on and inside nanofibres, nanotubes and nanochannels
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to derive the thermodynamic conditions for liquid plug formation in nanochannels, showing how the equilibrium contact angle value is affected by the channel curvature. The derived model can be used to control the formation of complex 3D polymer nanostructures (e.g. nanowire arrays) when using nanostructured templates. This paper is a result of collaboration with Professor Victor Starov, University of Loughborough, and has been in part funded by a Royal Academy of Engineering Research Fellowship (EP/H044256/1).

Title: Highly dispersed encapsulated AuPd nanoparticles on ordered mesoporous carbons for the direct synthesis of H2O2 from molecular oxygen and hydrogen
AdditionalInformation: This paper opens a route to use nanostructured carbon as a successful support for the encapsulation of gold–palladium nanoparticles. Modified selectivities were observed for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from O2 and H2 with almost no decomposition. Importantly, the nanoparticles were encapsulated without ligands. This is the first time this has been done without mass transfer limitations. This represents an important breakthrough towards the use of H2O2 as green oxidant to replace current oxidants in industrial applications. This work is the result of international collaboration with groups led by Tomás Garcia (CSIC) and Benjamin Solsona (University of Valencia).

Title: Hollow fibre membrane reactors for high H2 yields in the WGS reaction
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the outcome of collaborative work with Professors Chadwick and Li (Imperial College). It shows for the first time that the combination of nanostructured catalysts with hollow-fibre membrane reactors is a way of producing a COx-free H2 stream from the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, thereby increasing the overall process yield. This work was presented in the 10th International Conference on Catalysis in Membrane Reactors (ICCMR10) and was awarded the Prize for the Best Presentation.

Title: Crystallography of hydrogen-containing compounds: realizing the potential of neutron powder diffraction
AdditionalInformation: New, multi-technique experimental approaches for structural characterisation of hydrogen-containing materials are described. This represents the definitive publication resulting from two EPSRC grants (EP/E051049 and EP/E050859) and involved collaboration between researchers from Southampton, Glasgow and Grenoble. This paper was selected to feature on the cover of Chemical Communications (June 2009). The unique beamline equipment developed for this study has subsequently been used by researchers from ESS, Sweden, and has led to the award of an EPSRC grant (EP/G068038/1, £135k) and approximately £300k of STFC beamtime.

Title: Structural isotope effects in metal hydrides and deuterides
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a rigorous experimental study of the structural differences between model metal hydride and deuteride systems, through definition of the significant differences between atomic positions. This research was the result of a new collaboration between synthetic groups within the Universities of Southampton, Glasgow and Grenoble. This work spawned a host of other studies applying neutron powder diffraction techniques to related hydride systems from a range of UK-based and international research groups (e.g. Kohlmann et al., J.Solid State Chem. (2012); Jaroń and Grochala, J Nucl Mater (2012); and Alonso et al., Z. Kristall. (2010)).

Title: Copper exchanged ultrastable zeolite Y - A catalyst for NH3-SCR of NOx from stationary biogas engines
AdditionalInformation: This paper arose from an international collaboration that was initiated in 2009, with the Jagiellonian University in Krakow (Poland) where Kolaczkowski is a Visiting Professor. It is also the first paper on the theme of investigating DeNOx catalyst systems, to control NOx emissions from gas engines powered by gas from biomass/waste gasification processes. Although ammonia is used as a reducing agent, the main focus of the collaborative work is on the use of hydrogen from the gas produced.

Title: One-step production of monolith-supported long carbon nanotube arrays
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel one-step method for the synthesis of carbon nanotube arrays on cordierite monoliths for catalysis. This work is the first outcome of a £1.4M EPSRC ‘Nanotechnology for the environment’ Grand Challenge grant (EP/H046305/1). Interest in this paper has led Sasol UK to participate as a full partner in a follow-on grant submission to EPSRC on the same topic. The results of this work have spurred further research in the area of Fisher-Tropsch catalysis using iron nanoparticles/carbon nanotube supports, the results of which are currently being patented.

Title: Rhodium containing magnetic nanoparticles: effective catalysts for hydrogenation and the 1,4-addition of boronic acids
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers the topology and geometry of easily separable nanostructured catalysts with embedded magnetic function. These catalysts have a very high surface area and high efficiency; are small and very mobile during the reaction; and are magnetic so are easy to recover. This is the first report of the kinetics of such nanomagnetic catalysts. This work was initially supported by an EPSRC grant EP/C519736/1, which led to follow-up EPSRC projects: EP/D064937/1 and EP/G02703X/1 with total funds of ca. £1.44M (involving collaboration with the Universities of Liverpool and Durham).

Title: Liquid phase hydrogenation in a structured multichannel reactor
AdditionalInformation: This builds on our expertise with compact multichannel reactors for multiphase catalysis showing for the first time the kinetics and mechanisms of hydrogenation reactions in these reactors. This provided essential information for process scale-up and commercial design, and led to an interdisciplinary flow chemistry grant from EPSRC (EP/G028141/1,  £568k, GlaxoSmithKline, robert.j.watson@gsk.com).

Title: Coupling of Heck and hydrogenation reactions in a continuous compact reactor
AdditionalInformation: Building on earlier work at Bath on the use of compact multichannel reactors for multiphase catalysis, this paper describes a novel technique, in which the direction of flow in the reactor is changed in a sequential manner, limiting the extent of catalyst leaching. This is the first time a tandem reaction has been run continuously in a single reactor. This has great potential to be applied in a process for the manufacture of pharmaceutical products and intermediates. The collaboration involved the Universities of Bath and Cardiff, and MAST Carbon.

Title: Easy-separable magnetic nanoparticle-supported Pd catalysts: Kinetics, stability and catalyst re-use
AdditionalInformation: This output from international collaboration focuses on the detailed kinetics of reactions with nanomagnetic catalysts. It is the first paper to investigate the kinetics of catalyst reuse and shows that many statements on the stability of nanocatalysts, published in the literature, are incorrect. It led also to collaboration and publications with Dr Pedro Alvarez’s group from the University of Extremadura, Spain.

Title: The initial release of cisplatin from poly(lactide-co-glycolide) microspheres
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a controlled drug delivery system for the slow, sustained release of a chemotherapy drug, used in a novel treatment regime for specific ovarian cancer. The work arose from the New and Emerging Applications of Technology (NEAT) programme (£44.1k, FSC02) of the Department of Health. This joint work with the Senior Oncologist and his team at the Royal United Hospital, Bath, led to further collaborative research with the Avon & Somerset Cancer Research Centre and the award of £23k from a Bath cancer charity. Plans for clinical trials are awaiting approval and funding.

Title: Novel adsorbent hollow fibres for oxygen concentration
AdditionalInformation: Portable oxygen generators are extremely important for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients. The paper describes a novel, energy efficient hollow fibre device as a low pressure drop structure for the production of oxygen-enriched air. This work arose from Bath patents and a Royal Society Brian Mercer Innovation Award. This paper has demonstrated that the novel fibre configurations give rise to very rapid PSA cycles, which can be used to enhance process efficiency, leading to the world’s fastest PSA, compact oxygen unit. The publication also led to the award of a PhD studentship from Ultra Electronics for oxygen research.

Title: PVDF/CB composites prepared by novel solvent casting method for low voltage PTC temperature regulation applications
AdditionalInformation: This publication confirms the superiority of a novel coating technique developed to achieve the energy efficient desorption and regeneration of adsorbents. This has very wide application to many adsorption systems. This publication provided the foundation for the generation of new structured adsorbent technologies, for example, the removal of oil vapours from compressed air systems. Commercialisation has commenced via a £210k KTA project funded by EPSRC/KTA057 and Parker Domnick Hunter.

Title: Highly selective and stable alkylation of benzene with ethane into ethylbenzene over bifunctional PtH-MFI catalysts
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
AdditionalInformation: This is an original approach to the design of thermodynamically-limited reactions. It demonstrates the feasibility of the environmentally-benign production of ethylbenzene, the key intermediate in polystyrene. Resulting from an EPSRC project (EP/C532554) this work is the basis for a series of 8 publications (in J. Catalysis)  and 15 conference presentations. The approach developed here has already been used successfully by Lukyanov in studies of methane transformation that is an area of significant industrial interest (Johnson Matthey, John.Casci@matthey.com).

Title: Selective and stable benzene alkylation with methane into toluene over PtH-MFI bifunctional catalyst
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
AdditionalInformation: This work stems from the EPSRC project EP/C532554 (£250k). It demonstrates for the first time the principle of continuous methane activation with subsequent reaction with another chemical (benzene) over bifunctional catalysts. The significance of this work is the demonstration of the highly selective catalyst operation that paves the way to the design of commercial methane-based reactions, for example, toluene to xylene transformation, which is of interest to Johnson Matthey (John.Casci@matthey.com).

Title: Transformation of methane over platinum supported catalysts at moderate temperature
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
AdditionalInformation: This EPSRC funded work (EP/C532554, £250k) demonstrates for the first time that non-oxidative continuous methane transformation over platinum catalysts is possible at moderate temperatures (370°C). Thus, it opens a new direction for kinetic studies of methane activation and transformation over transition metals that are likely to lead to novel results relevant to a number of industrially important reactions (e.g. high temperature Fischer-Tropsch). This paper was published as the ‘Editors Choice’ paper - one per issue.

Title: Characterization of crude oils and their fouling deposits using a batch stirred cell system
AdditionalInformation: This is a principal joint publication on a £2.2M EPSRC grant (EP/D506131/1) to Bath, Cambridge and Imperial College. The research described in the paper facilitated a £572k EPSRC Energy Programme grant (EP/G059497/1) to Bath and Manchester to study intensified heat transfer for energy saving in the process industries; preheating of crude oil was used as a case study. The paper has also directly led Heat Transfer Research Incorporated (Texas, USA) to design an improved version of the Bath apparatus to support international oil refining companies in managing their crude oil fouling problems.

Title: Fouling thresholds in bare tubes and tubes fitted with inserts
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents, for the first time, a methodology for correlating fouling in enhanced heat transfer devices - the equivalent velocity concept. The research described arose from a £572k EPSRC Energy Programme grant (EP/G059497/1) awarded jointly to Bath and Manchester and directly facilitated the award of €1.2M (FP7-SME-2010-1-INTHEAT-262205) to an consortium (industry: Germany, UK, Ukraine; academic: Bath, Manchester, Paderborn (Germany), Pannonia (Hungary)) to study intensified heat transfer technologies for enhanced heat recovery. The equivalent velocity concept has already been adopted by SODRU (Ukraine) for plate heat exchangers.

Title: Effect of channel geometry, degree of activation, relative humidity and temperature on the performance of binderless activated carbon monoliths in the removal of dichloromethane from air
AdditionalInformation: This publication arose from a request by a Spanish academic to work alongside Bath’s expertise on adsorption using activated carbon monoliths. The paper provides, for the first time, the effects of activation level and humidity on the performance of NOVOLAK activated carbon monoliths and has helped the manufacturer, MAST Carbon Ltd, to develop such materials for a new volatile organic chemical recovery technology, which has been patented jointly with Bath (US 6964695, EP 1372917).

Title: Nonuniform channels in adsorbent monoliths
AdditionalInformation: This is the main publication from a £1.0M TSB grant (K3510G) awarded to the University of Bath, MAST Carbon International, Wellman Defence, and four other companies. The paper provides the scientific understanding required for a materials technology patented jointly by the University and MAST Carbon for the recovery of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in factories. The research led directly to a successful trial of the technology such that a customer (ConvaTec in South Wales) could now (i) meet its Environment Agency limit on discharging VOCs used for drying wound dressing natural polymers, and (ii) recover solvents for reuse.

Title: The influence of hydrophobicity, roughness and charge upon ultrafiltration membranes for black tea liquor clarification
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper reporting the relative importance of hydrophobicity, roughness and charge, alongside size exclusion effects, for the removal of haze and tea cream from black tea liquors using polymeric membrane filters. This paper represents international collaboration: co-authors were from the Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland. The paper was made possible by a BBSRC Industrial CASE project allocated by Unilever R&D Colworth (10/2004 – 10/2007). The industrial supervisor was Jacek Obuchowicz (Jacek.Obuchowicz@premierfoods.co.uk). This paper heavily influenced concurrent and subsequent PhD projects: Dan Wu (ORS 2005 – 2008) and Iain Argyle (DTA 2009 – 2013).

Title: Measurement of polyphenol-membrane interaction forces during the ultrafiltration of black tea liquor
VolumeTitle: Colloids and Surfaces, A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
AdditionalInformation: Arising from an ongoing cross-university and industrial collaboration to create world-class expertise in the quantitative use of Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) with membranes, this was the first report of a new multiple measurement (x200) AFM technique that gives more reliable results than standard techniques that rely upon a far smaller number of measurements. Collaborators were Drs Chris Wright and Dale Rogers of Swansea University. This paper arose from a BBSRC Industrial CASE project: Unilever R&D Colworth (10/2004 – 10/2008). Industrial supervisor: Jacek Obuchowicz (Jacek.Obuchowicz@premierfoods.co.uk).

Title: An experimental investigation into the pre-treatment of synthetic membranes using sodium hydroxide solutions
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel preconditioning strategy for new membranes that could lead to improved industrial performance and, consequently, greater process efficiency.  The paper resulted from industrial and international collaboration with Alfa Laval, Denmark (Frank Lipnizki, frank.lipnizki@alfalaval.com), Nordic Sugar, Denmark (John Jensen, john.p.jensen@nordicsugar.com), and involved an international co-author, Arto Pihlajamki, from the Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland.

Title: Fluid dynamic gauging of microfiltration membranes fouled with sugar beet molasses
AdditionalInformation: Fluid Dynamic Gauging (FDG) was used to simultaneously measure flux and thickness of real food deposits filtered using polymeric membranes under crossflow conditions; the first time this technique has been reported for membranes in the literature. FDG indicates foulant location, extent and morphology, representing a very useful diagnostic tool. This international, industrial collaboration resulted from a Food Processing Faraday/EPSRC CASE award with Alfa Laval, Denmark (Frank Lipnizki, frank.lipnizki@alfalaval.com) and Nordic Sugar, Denmark (John Jensen, john.p.jensen@nordicsugar.com). This paper contributed to two subsequent EPSRC DTA PhD projects (William Lewis and Oliver Peck).

Title: Production of pharmaceuticals: amines from alcohols in a continuous flow fixed bed catalytic reactor
AdditionalInformation: Building on earlier research at Bath on continuous flow pharmaceutical processes, this paper is the first to describe how a novel reaction based on ‘borrowing hydrogen’, could produce amines from alcohols with a novel catalytic packed bed reactor. Visitors from GSK (Mark Buswell) and Lilly (Matthew Yates) to Bath (2011) commented that they had not seen such advanced work anywhere else at this scale, with the catalyst supported on carbon monoliths in a multi-chamber continuous flow reactor. This work has continued and the successful viability of this approach at pilot-scale will be presented at ICOSCAR 2013, Beijing.

Title: Catalyst ‘light-off’ experiments on a diesel oxidation catalyst connected to a diesel engine - methodology and techniques
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds on Kolaczkowski’s reputation as co-author of the first text book titled: Introduction to Catalytic Combustion (1997). This is the first demonstration that bench-top experiments on powdered catalysts (or small sections of monoliths), could be applied to a commercial catalyst connected to a live engine. This is the first paper in a series of four on the theme of ‘On-line and on-engine catalyst characterisation - a diagnostic technique to design a better auto-catalyst system', a real first in the field. This work arose from an EPSRC grant (EP/E059074/1, £502k, 2007-10).

Title: Application of fluid dynamic gauging to annular test apparatuses for studying fouling and cleaning
AdditionalInformation: Fluid dynamic gauging is a novel method to measure surface fouling of porous materials in situ. Understanding fouling will reduce process downtime due to cleaning and loss of performance due to fouling. This paper presents the successful application of the device to monitor membrane performance with yeast suspensions. This follows on from work performed during a RAEng/EPSRC Fellowship (2005-2010) and is a direct outcome of an Anglo-German Research Collaboration (2010-2012) with the Technical University of Braunschweig (Wolfgang Augustin: w.augustin@tu-bs.de). The work has resulted in funding from Unilever and collaboration with Chalmers University.

Title: A scanning fluid dynamic gauging technique for probing surface layers
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel fluid dynamic gauging device that uniquely measures the thickness and strength of soft solids in liquids, in situ and in real-time. This work has resulted in two PhD studentships (2009-2012 and 2011-2014) funded by Procter and Gamble (P&G). P&G has also purchased two devices for in-house Research & Development applications (Anju Brooker, brooker.am@pg.com), as it allows P&G to screen greener cleaning formulations. This paper and subsequent PhD thesis won two prizes (European Hygienic Food Design, 2012; best dissertation at University Cambridge, Department of Chemical Engineering, 2012).

Title: Effect of increasing anode surface area on the performance of a single chamber microbial fuel cell
AdditionalInformation: This study describes fundamental analysis, both theoretical and experimental, on the effects that increasing anode surface-area-to-cell-volume-ratio has on the current and power output of an air-cathode single chamber biofuel cell. The confirmed benefits of highly porous 3D electrode structures are the basis of current research, focused on micro sized biofuel cell design (RG110344). This work was supported by a European Union for Transfer of Knowledge award for biological fuel cells (MTKD-CT-2004-517215) and Northumbrian Water. It involved collaborations between the Chemical Engineering and Advanced Materials, and the Civil and Environmental Engineering Departments at Newcastle University.

Title: Continuous feed microbial fuel cell using an air cathode and a disc anode stack for wastewater treatment
AdditionalInformation: This study focused on the practical application of microbial fuel cells in wastewater treatment. This system is one of a few operated continuously and fed with real wastewater whilst simultaneously producing energy. For the first time a coulombic efficiency as high as 60% was observed with real wastewater. The system is easy to scale-up and the cheap membrane used could substantially reduce the costs. This work was supported by an EU Marie Curie Action on biological fuel cells (MTKD-CT-2004-517215) and was in collaboration with Northumbrian Water.

Title: Sour compression process for the removal of SOx and NOx from oxyfuel-derived CO2
AdditionalInformation: The authors received the Rushlight Carbon Capture and Storage Award in 2009 for this work. It is the first paper to demonstrate how impurities can be removed from highly concentrated CO2 streams in coal-fired power stations to avoid the contamination of aquifers.  Funded by the DTI 404–UK-Oxycoal project in collaboration with Air Products, this is the first time such work has been undertaken at a pilot plant scale (Clive McGhie, cmghie@doosanbabcock.com). The work has directly led to a patent with Air Products (Dr Vince White, whitev@airproducts.com).

Title: A refined one-filtration method for aqueous based nanofiltration and ultrafiltration membrane molecular weight cut-off determination using polyethylene glycols
AdditionalInformation: This paper outlines a new, reliable, faster, more cost effective and simpler method of determining the molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) of membranes. It is the most precise ever one-filtration determination of MWCO for nanofiltration and low ultrafiltration range membranes for aqueous applications (where most industrial applications of these membranes lie) providing a new benchmark and enabling MWCO for these to be more accurately determined than ever before. The method allows the time consuming and costly multiple filtrations of pure single compounds to be replaced by a single filtration, saving membrane researchers, manufacturers and users time and money.

Title: An experimental and modelling investigation of the effect of the flow regime on the photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue on a thin film coated ultraviolet irradiated spinning disc reactor
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to comprehensively evaluate thin film photocatalysts for process intensification in a spinning disc reactor. In particular, it is the first for this type of reactor to comprehensively evaluate the effect of operating parameters and reactor characteristics on the degradation rate of pollutants and photocatalytic activity for wastewater treatment. This work demonstrated that reaction rate maxima can be achieved: two further journal papers established this to be twice the maximum reaction achievable in a conventional annular photoreactor. This work directly led to an EU Marie Curie Career Integration Grant (SMDR; FP7-333952).

Title: Photocatalysis with nanostructured zinc oxide thin films: the relationship between morphology and photocatalytic activity under oxygen limited and oxygen rich conditions and evidence for a Mars Van Krevelen mechanism
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided the first elucidation of the mechanism responsible for zinc oxide photocatalyst dissolution and the unique observation that adding sufficient oxygen made the films more stable. Since zinc photo-induced leaching is commonly cited as the limiting factor in the wider application of these films, this work has completely revolutionised the field of zinc oxide photocatalysis, initiating a pathway to eventual Industrial application by, for example, wastewater companies. This paper is also the first to comprehensively correlate zinc oxide nanostructure, photocatalytic reaction rate and reaction mechanism, providing a rational design basis for these photocatalysts.

Title: Membrane characterisation by SEM, TEM and ESEM: the implications of dry and wetted microstructure on mass transfer through integrally skinned polyimide nanofiltration membranes
AdditionalInformation: This work was the first to conclusively show that polyimide integrally skinned membranes had nano-sized pores, confirming pore-flow was a transport mechanism. It was the first to show that membranes when wetted in solvents have a different microstructure than with dry SEM imaging. Since many transport and separation mechanisms in the literature have been based on dry microstructures, this indicates they probably need to be rethought. It also provides new, robust definitions for the thickness of different membrane microstructural regions. This paper was one of the top 25 ‘hottest’ articles (14th most downloaded) in the journal when published (April-June, 2009).

Title: Explaining high flow rate of water in carbon nanotubes via solid-liquid molecular interactions
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a thermodynamically-derived model for flow enhancement in carbon nanotubes that for the first time makes explicit the contribution of solid-liquid molecular interactions on liquid flow in nanotubes. The model is capable of predicting flow enhancement for any liquid in any nanochannel validated by data from the literature.  This paper is the result of an international collaboration with Francesco Calabrò, a mathematician from the University of Cassino, Italy, and was funded by a Royal Society grant. This work was invited for presentation the Institute for Membrane Technology, Italy, 2013.

Title: Random search with k-prototypes algorithm for clustering mixed datasets
VolumeTitle: Royal Society of London. Proceedings A. Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Data clustering is a data discovery technique used in intelligent manufacturing systems. Many real problems involve data with mixed numerical and categorical values. Correctly clustering mixed-value data items can be very difficult due to the complexity of determining when they are similar to one another. The algorithm presented in this paper can efficiently cluster data with mixed numerical-categorical values. Even without using the advanced normalisation method of Output 3, by combining stochastic search and iterative refinement, the algorithm can avoid local optimum traps and quickly converge to globally optimal clustering solutions. The research was supported by EU Grant EC-FP7-ICT 247772.

Title: Unsupervised training of Bayesian networks for data clustering
VolumeTitle: Royal Society of London. Proceedings A. Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Bayesian networks are statistical tools for modelling knowledge in engineering, science, medicine and business. When the knowledge concerns how to group cognate items into classes, these networks are known as ‘Bayesian network classifiers’.  These classifiers are usually trained in a ‘supervised’ manner to perform their tasks, i.e. a data set with examples pre-classified by an expert is needed for training purposes. The novel unsupervised method of training presented does not require a human to provide a pre-classified data set.
