Its effectiveness is evident from the engineering application reported in the paper.  The research was supported by EU Grant NMP2-CT-2004-500273.

Title: The Bees Algorithm: modelling foraging behaviour to solve continuous optimization problems
VolumeTitle: Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Proceedings. Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: In manufacturing, there are many complex multimodal optimisation problems defying conventional solution.  They include job-shop scheduling, machine sequencing and assembly planning.  The Bees Algorithm (used to provide the stochastic element of the data clustering algorithm of Output 1) is a novel biologically-inspired optimisation algorithm developed by Pham et al.  It is capable of efficiently locating the global optimum in a multidimensional and multimodal landscape. Benchmarking the algorithm against existing heuristic optimisation methods, this paper provides a clear insight into its operation and the type of problems to which it is best suited. The research was supported by EU Grant NMP2-CT-2004-500273.

Title: Shape preserving data reduction for 3D surface points
AdditionalInformation: This novel approach to data reduction is of importance to the CADCAM community in general, especially to surface modellers and designers, due to the growing use of laser scanning technologies that generate huge data sets.  This new method geometrically controls data reduction and establishes the use of the point-based modeling approach, based on the Generalised Cornu Spiral, to assess whether a particular point can be discarded without loss of shape information.  Interest has been shown by Airbus UK (Carren Holden, Transverse M&T Development, email:Carren.Holden@airbus.com) and BAE Systems (Mark Wilson, Manager, email:Mark.Wilson2@baesystems.com) in the underlying point-based modelling approach.

Title: A robust efficient tracing scheme for triangulating trimmed parametric surfaces
AdditionalInformation: This fundamental work provides a more efficient, stable method of triangulating a trimmed surface held as a collection of Non-Uniform Rational B-Splines (NURBS) surfaces. It is of importance to a wide range of researchers across many fields where a computer-based model of a 3D object requires triangulation for either visualisation or analysis.    The method has been evaluated by Delcam (Steve Hobbs [smh@delcam.com]) as the basis for improving their algorithms and interest has also been shown by Siemens Product Lifecycle Management Software Inc. (Tamas Hermann, email:tamas.hermann@siemens.com).

Title: Smooth polynomial approximation of spiral arcs
VolumeTitle: Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics
AdditionalInformation: The significance of this work is in establishing the viability of approximating a high quality non-polynomial based curve, originated in the pioneering point-based approach [EPSRC GR/R35735], with a low order Bézier curve suitable for use with existing CADCAM systems. The work is of importance to the entire CADCAM community, especially curve and surface modellers, and to the wider scientific community where approximation is of interest.  The work has led to funding for further research from Delcam (Steve Hobbs, Development Director, email:smh@delcam.com) to consider improved approximations that are more robust and better suited to interactive CADCAM systems.

Title: Point-based approach to enhance the quality of geometric data for CAE
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the results of the Alpha-rated research project: Point-based Plug-ins to Enhance the Quality of Geometric Data for Computer Aided Engineering [EPSRC GR/K31268]. Of importance to the CADCAM community, especially to manufacturers of high quality precision components (e.g. aerodynamic wing surfaces and fan blades in the aircraft industry), this fundamental novel research has led to a new EPSRC funded project (EP/L010321) in collaboration with Delcam and Renishaw.

Title: Hole quality assessment following drilling of metallic-composite stacks
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper details research into one-shot drilling through 3-layer metallic-composite stack materials (Ti-6Al-4V/CFRP/Al-7075) typically used in modern aircraft structures. The quality of holes produced using previously established optimal operating strategies and cutting conditions was assessed to determine process feasibility for production. Cutting environment and drill geometry were highlighted as critical factors in ensuring acceptable hole tolerance and integrity. The work has led to the development of specific tool designs for next-generation drills using ultrahard PCD material by one of the industrial collaborators (Element Six Ltd., Dr. Wayne Leahy, Product Applications Manager, email:wayne.leahy@e6.com) . The new products were launched commercially in 2013.

Title: 3D FE modelling of high-speed ball nose end milling
VolumeTitle: The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides a comprehensive description of a 3D FE model of high-speed machining together with associated experimentally validated predicted output measures. The work was part-supported by EPSRC (GR/L88986) with industrial collaborators including Rolls-Royce. The research provides a benchmark for the modelling of machining processes, which is a key activity, with OEMs such as Rolls-Royce currently focussing resources on predictive modelling capability within their manufacturing operations. A follow-on project with Rolls-Royce (Dr. Stan Nikov, Manufacturing Engineering Specialist, email:stan.nikov@rolls-royce.com)  relating to workpiece surface integrity prediction after machining was initiated based on this work to decrease production costs and increase component reliability/safety.

Title: Drill geometry and operating effects when cutting small diameter holes in CFRP
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This work involved drilling small diameter holes (1.5mm) in advanced carbon fibre reinforced plastic (CFRP) laminates. This was carried out in collaboration with an industrial consortium led by GKN Aerospace in order to improve their current manufacturing process on a new all-composite acoustic liner. Preferred operating regimes, drill configuration/type and coating material to achieve greater productivity and reduce workpiece damage (delamination etc.) were identified and communicated to the company. Outcomes from the research were also reported to the wider industry via an invited lecture at a seminar (December 2010) on ‘The Art of Composite Machining’ organised by Seco Tools UK.

Title: Deformation analysis of large aerospace components during assembly
VolumeTitle: The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes the first tool of its kind for systematically predicting geometrical deformation of large aerospace components during assembly. The focus is on the assembly of ribs to skin panels which gives the greatest source of geometrical variations in wing assembly. This work forms the basis of longer-term research to (a) provide process improvements for the existing wing production method, and (b) develop the basis for future automated systems. Airbus supported the research through an industrial grant (RUBX07404).  The results were used to conduct further related research to develop complex multiple wing joint analysis for cumulative geometrical variations.

Title: Cavity Air Flow Behavior During Filling in Microinjection Molding
VolumeTitle: Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Air evacuation in micro injection moulding is investigated for the first time in order to understand how it affects the process dynamics and also the filling behaviour of micro cavities. The paper provides empirical evidence regarding the effects of process parameters on cavity air evacuation, and its influence on the part flow length. The findings of this paper underpinned the development of a flexible compression injection moulding platform for replicating multi-scale surface structures as part of a FP7 Factory of the Future project, IMPRESS (Mael.MOGUEDET@poleplasturgie.com).

Title: Development of a novel process chain based on Atomic Force Microscopy scratching for small and medium series production of polymer nano structure components
VolumeTitle: Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The paper proposes and validates a novel method for producing nano-structured replication masters as a cost effective route for low and medium volume production of nanostructured devices in thermoplastic materials. The method was developed to address the specific requirements of users in two major infrastructure projects, in particular the EPSRC project Nanoaccess@Cardiff and the FP7 project EuminaFab. The initial research reported in this paper was used as a starting point for an EPSRC-funded project to investigate systematically Atomic Force Microscope scratching as a manufacturing technology for producing nano-structured surfaces on metal substrates that are widely used in tool making.

Title: Investigation of amorphous and crystalline Ni alloys response to machining with micro-second and pico-second lasers
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, it was reported that by subjecting bulk metallic glass (BMG) materials to micro-second and pico-second laser processing, it is possible to retain their short-range atomic ordering. Thus, it was experimentally proven that laser machining/structuring can be applied as a cost-effective manufacturing route for producing both replication masters and parts in BMG materials without triggering any crystallisation and thus retaining their very attractive mechanical and physical properties. The paper was selected as a research highlight in Nature Photonics “Technology Focus” May 2009.

Title: An EM/E-MRF algorithm for adaptive model based tracking in extremely poor visibility
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an algorithm for visual segmentation and tracking of moving objects in image sequences. The work is unusual, in that it tackles the problem of vision in extremely poor visibility conditions – in contrast the vast majority of machine vision is done in comparatively clear visibility conditions. Poor visibility is tackled by a novel machine learning approach, where models of both the tracked object and the background are continuously relearned online during tracking. Additionally, poor visibility is tackled by presenting a novel extension of Markov Random Field theory which combines observations with predictions within a principled probabilistic framework.

Title: Twist drilling of Haynes 282 superalloy
AdditionalInformation: Aerospace industry-wide research has shown compromised fatigue performance to relate directly to manufacturing anomalies produced in drilled holes in critical gas turbine components, as holes amplify any in-service stresses.  This paper, which has significance in relation to possible future condition monitoring strategies, stemmed from a Rolls-Royce funded research programme (Colin Sage, Specialist Engineer, email:colin.sage@rolls-royce.com) associated with the evaluation of Haynes 282 as material for a high-thrust variant of the Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 aero engine. It details the machinability/surface integrity following twist drilling, (including burr formation, surface and subsurface microstructural alterations and associated microhardness changes.)

Title: Machinability and surface integrity of RR1000 nickel based superalloy
AdditionalInformation: Funded by Rolls-Royce (Colin Sage, Specialist Engineer, email:colin.sage@rolls-royce.com), the research detailed in the paper focuses on the drilling and radius end milling of RR1000, an advanced powder metallurgy superalloy with a novel microstructure suitable for the future low-cost net shape development of aeroengine casings.  The work reported was the first fundamental study of machinability performance with reference to workpiece surface/subsurface damage.

Title: High speed ball nose end milling of γ-TiAl alloys
AdditionalInformation: Gamma titanium aluminide intermetallic (γ-TiAl) alloys are undergoing worldwide assessment for the replacement of nickel based superalloys for blades in new gas turbine aeroengines. The main driver is weight saving as γ-TiAl alloys have a density typically half that of nickel based superalloys.  However, the low room-temperature ductility (<2%) of γ-TiAl alloys means producing surfaces of acceptable integrity is extremely difficult. This paper presents new insight into ball nose end milling of fifth-generation thermo-mechanically processed γ-TiAl. The research was funded by EPSRC case award and Rolls-Royce, Colin Sage, Specialist Engineer, email: colin.sage@rolls-royce.com.

Title: Radius end milling of Haynes 282 nickel based superalloy
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Nickel-based superalloys are used extensively in aeroengines due to their high strength at temperatures above 700ºC. Haynes 282 is an advanced superalloy with improved thermal stability and weldability compared with materials such as Waspaloy. Sponsored by Rolls-Royce (Colin Sage, Specialist Engineer, email:colin.sage@rolls-royce.com), with technical and product support from Seco Tools (David Pearson, Development Manager, email:david.pearson@secotools.com, this research was the first published study on the machinability of this alloy when radius end milling critical surface features. In addition to extensive tool life and cutting force data, the paper contains comprehensive workpiece surface integrity information necessary for process selection and ratification.

Title: Statistical approach to normalization of feature vectors and clustering of mixed datasets
VolumeTitle: Royal Society of London. Proceedings A. Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Data clustering has many applications in intelligent manufacturing. During the training of a clustering algorithm, feature vectors representing items to be clustered are automatically grouped together without requiring pre-classification. This is normally achieved using a distance metric to measure feature vector similarity. To prevent features with large numerical values from dominating the metric, feature vectors are sometimes normalised. However, where feature vectors involve a mixture of numerical and categorical attributes, normalisation becomes difficult.  Founded upon statistics theory, the unified normalisation approach presented can effectively handle mixed-attribute data.  The research was performed collaboratively with Moscow State University and Moscow Technical University.

Title: Heavy tools manipulation by low powered direct-drive five-bar parallel robot
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes and validates a novel Suspended Tool System (STS) for manipulating heavy tools.  Comprising a low-powered direct-drive parallel linkage, the STS provides many advantages over direct payload systems including reduced joint friction.  The effectiveness of the STS was demonstrated in applications where the tool moved vertically, e.g. drilling/boring by compensating gravitational force effects. Other applications include implementations as jigs and fixtures, where accurate manipulation of large components is required, as in aerospace assembly. This research was in collaboration with Deakin University, Australia, and was partly supported by the Royal Academy of Engineering (Industrial Secondment Award – 10465/161).

Title: Agent-Based Interaction Protocols and Topologies for Manufacturing Task Allocation
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics, Part A: Systems & Humans
AdditionalInformation: This original research advances agent interaction protocols and topologies in multi-agent systems within the broader concept of distributed artificial intelligence. The research offers new high-performance alternatives to widely-used market-based topologies. Industrial verification on complex task allocation problems in a large gas turbine manufacturing company has demonstrated improvement of key performance criteria including machine utilisation, manufacturing lead time and cost. The model has been validated for industrial take-up and is being implemented in phases by the sponsoring company (Ref. Dr. M. Owliya, Vice President – Engineering, Mapna-TUGA Co. - under Siemens licence; Email: Owliya.mohammad@mapnaturbine.com).

Title: Dynamic modelling of servo pneumatic actuators with cushioning
VolumeTitle: The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: An original analytical model of a double-acting servo pneumatic cylinder is proposed and validated. The novelty of this work lies in the complete and accurate modelling of the entire stroke length including cushioning sections at both ends of the piston stroke.  The main output is a precision nonlinear model that provides accurate control in industrial applications requiring highly precise positioning of pneumatic cylinders.  Using this nonlinear model instead of existing models where effects of cushioning are ignored can be expected to result in superior actuation performance.

Title: Creep Feed grinding of burn resistant titanium (BuRTi) using superabrasive wheels
VolumeTitle: The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper relates to the machining of a next-generation burn resistant titanium alloy (BuRTi) designed to replace heavier nickel based alloys in the hot section of gas turbine engines. The work was performed in collaboration with Rolls-Royce to evaluate the feasibility of harder superabrasives replacing the conventional abrasives currently employed in production. Operating windows leading to significant improvement in wheel life/productivity and workpiece surface integrity were identified. These results were provided to Rolls-Royce for potential implementation in production. (Dr Donka Novovic, Global Process Owner for Grinding and Manufacturing Engineering Specialist for Machining Technologies: email donka.novovic@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Process Factors Influence on Cavity Pressure Behavior in Microinjection Moulding
VolumeTitle: Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports a novel experimental setup for monitoring the microinjection moulding process and acquiring information about the process dynamics and filling behaviour.  This new approach makes it easier to assess the replication quality and the process performance. The research has led to the development and implementation of an advanced micro injection moulding platform by Battenfeld as part of the FP7 large scale project COTECH (Dr Helmut Loibl, loibl@fotec.at).

Title: Upsetting of bi-metallic ring billets
AdditionalInformation: Financed by the Serbian government (Prof Plancak, email:Plancak@uns.ac.rs), this study was the first to examine the behaviour of bi-metallic components during cold upsetting. Through finite-element analysis and experimentation, the work has revealed the influence of relative geometry and material properties of the two components in the process, the ring and the cylinder. The results provide a clear understanding of process conditions under which bi-metallic components with excellent interfacial contact can be produced. This establishes the process as both a viable new route for manufacturing finished bi-metallic components and a pre-forming operation prior to further processing.

Title: A novel selection evolutionary strategy for constrained optimization
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel evolutionary algorithm strategy for constrained optimisation problems (COPs). Typically COPs are solved with algorithms that, firstly, search for a “feasible” solution (one which satisfies the constraints), and secondly perform optimisation within the feasible region of the problem space. The novelty of this work lies in showing that infeasible solutions may still provide useful information to speed up optimisation within the feasible region. Evolutionary algorithms allow us to maintain a population containing both feasible and infeasible solutions, and combine both of these kinds of information to significantly outperform other state of the art methods.

Title: Probability of Detection and Optimal Sensor Placement for Threshold Based Detection Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents fundamental concepts in the basic theory of detecting events or objects by a distributed set of sensors. We show how to calculate the probability of detection, and a function for how this drops off with range, for a very broad/general set of sensor-based detection systems. We also show how to use this function to optimise the placement of a field of sensors, maximise the detection probability for a fixed number of sensors, or predict the minimum number of sensors required to give a desired reliability of coverage. These findings have fundamental and very broad applications.

Title: Carbon Nanotube Based High Resolution Holograms
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the novel use of carbon nanotubes to produce visible holograms. After publication, this research was featured in a News & Views article by Nature (“Optics: Nanotube holograms”, Nature 491, 47 (2012)). The work was highlighted by several science news websites, magazines, and by Cambridge University Research News. Dr Butt gave several media interviews on this research, the most recent being published by “Business Weekly” (April 2013). The work also led to invited talks at 3 major events in 2013 (ChinaNANO, NCEM-2 Cambridge, Houses of Parliament).  Dr Butt also received the Philip Leverhulme Prize and ABTA award 2013 for this investigation.

Title: Plasmonic Band Gaps and Waveguide Effects in Carbon Nanotube Arrays Based Metamaterials
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel and fundamental study into fabricating metamaterials based waveguides using carbon nanotubes. This work was partly funded by Cambridge Commonwealth Trust (Research bursary), a Hughes Hall College Scholarship and the Nokia-Cambridge Strategic Partnership in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology (Prof G.A.J. Amaratunga e-mail: gaja1@cam.ac.uk). This article is the journal version of a prize-winning conference presentation by Dr Butt at the IEEE International Electronics, Communications & Photonics Conference, Riyadh (April 2011), where it received the Best conference paper award. Butt also received the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) Ambitious Research Award 2010 for this metamaterials research. http://www.theiet.org/students/studying-engineering/meet-students/haider-butt.cfm

Title: Continuous diffraction patterns from circular arrays of carbon nanotubes
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology (Prof. T.D. Wilkinson e-mail: tdw13@cam.ac.uk) and the Nokia-Cambridge Strategic Partnership in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology (Energy Programme) (Prof. G.A.J. Amaratunga e-mail: gaja1@cam.ac.uk). This paper was the first to report the idea of using nanostructures to produce continuous diffraction patterns (holograms). It laid the foundations for the successful work later published in the Advanced Materials journal (Butt’s Paper 1). This article was also featured as the front cover image of "Applied Physics Letters" (101, 25, 2012). http://apl.aip.org/resource/1/applab/v101/i25

Title: Metamaterial filter for the near-visible spectrum
AdditionalInformation: This research was supported by an EPSRC grant (Ref: EP/G060649, Prof. J.J. Baumberg, e-mail: jjb12@cam.ac.uk).  Dr Butt demonstrated the novel use of metal-coated silicon nanopillars to produce metamaterials operating near the visible spectrum. Metamaterials are artificial materials engineered to have properties possibly not found in nature.  For this research on metamaterials, Dr Butt received a Henslow Research Fellowship at Wolfson College, University of Cambridge (October 2012-September 2013). The fellowship was funded by the Cambridge Philosophical Society.  Butt gave an invited seminar on the work at the Advanced Technology Institute, University of Surrey in 2012.

Title: Response of titanium aluminide alloy to abrasive waterjet cutting: geometrical accuracy and surface integrity issues versus process parameters
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This work received the Best Paper Award for 2009 in the Journal of Engineering Manufacture from the Institution of Mechanical Engineers for reporting the first use of abrasive waterjet cutting of titanium aluminide alloys and being a thorough parametric study.  The research was sponsored by Rolls-Royce Plc., which is are continuing work on waterjet development.  Contact person: Dr Jamie McGourlay, Partnership Manager, Rolls-Royce Plc. (e-mail: jamie.mcgourlay@rolls-royce.com).

Title: An innovative method to perform maskless plain waterjet milling for pocket generation: a case study in Ti-based superalloys
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an innovative method allowing plain waterjets to generate pockets of good dimensional/geometrical definition (with minimal under/over-erosion).  The proposed method leads to the avoidance of grit embedment on the target workpiece and the elimination of the extra cost and time associated with the use of masks. The innovation described in the paper has resulted in patent applications (assignee: Rolls-Royce Plc.) in the United States and Canada, with a European Patent granted (EP 2 113 348 B1, A method of fluid jet machining). Contact person: Ms. Ruth Barcock, Patents Manager, Rolls-Royce Plc. (e-mail: ruth.barcock@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Mathematical modelling of abrasive waterjet footprints for arbitrarily moving jets: Part I—single straight paths
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation:
This work breaks new ground in the geometrical modelling of abrasive water jet milling by reducing the number of variables required for predicting the footprints obtained under real industrial conditions.
The model is being used to support the development of a new ISO standard (ISO/TC 44N1770) for high-energy fluid-jet milling in collaboration with industrial partners in the ConforM-Jet project (FP7-NMP-THEME 4, contract 229155) - BAE Systems, ELLA-CS s.r.o, Finecut AB and Waterjet AG.  The work has also underpinned the award of a new EC-funded project, STEEP (FP7-PEOPLE-ITN, contract 316560) and a patent application (filed on 18th Sep 2012, GB1216625.2).

Title: Evolutionary generation of neural network classifiers—An empirical comparison
AdditionalInformation: Classifiers are needed for different automated pattern classification tasks in manufacturing. How to generate accurate classifiers has been a long-standing research issue. This work is an in-depth study into the evolutionary generation of multi-layer perceptron classifiers. Two generation methods were investigated, the so-called ‘wrapper’ and ‘embedded’ methods. These were compared with manual and automatic neural network generation techniques on several benchmark problems. The embedded method produced the best results, whilst the intrinsic computational costs limited the performance of the wrapper algorithm. The work definitively showed the importance of feature selection to the accuracy and compactness of the classification results.

Title: Benchmarking and comparison of nature-inspired population-based continuous optimisation algorithms
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes an investigation into four nature-inspired continuous optimisation methods: the authors’ Bees Algorithm and Evolutionary Algorithms, Particle Swarm Optimisation, and Artificial Bee Colony. The aim was to understand and compare the specific capabilities of the algorithms using twenty-five new minimisation benchmarks designed by the authors. The results highlight the strengths and weaknesses of the algorithms. The existence and extent of origin and alignment biases related to the use of different recombination operators were uncovered for the first time. The work reveals interesting regularities that will help to guide the choice and configuration of optimisation algorithms for practical applications.

Title: Dynamic optimisation by a modified bees algorithm
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part I Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The Bees Algorithm is a novel, versatile and effective nature-inspired tool created by the authors and their team for difficult optimisation tasks.  A new version was developed and applied to dynamic optimisation problems in chemical engineering. A statistical factorial experiment was used to tune the settings of the population parameters. Tested on eight benchmark problems, the tuned algorithm outperformed the standard Bees Algorithm and other well-known state-of-the-art optimisation methods.  The results demonstrate the efficacy of the enhanced Bees Algorithm and the effectiveness of the statistical parameter tuning method devised and used for the first time in this work.

Title: Evolutionary feature selection applied to artificial neural networks for wood-veneer classification
AdditionalInformation: FeaSANNT, an evolutionary algorithm for optimisation of neural networks developed by Dr Castellani, was used to train a multi-layer neural network to identify wood veneer defects. Given a fixed network structure, FeaSANNT concurrently evolved the input feature vector and the network weights. The novelty of the method lay in the implementation of the embedded approach in an evolutionary feature selection paradigm. Tests showed that FeaSANNT produced high-performing solutions with robust learning results. Compared with two standard wrapper and filter methods, FeaSANNT gave solutions with equal or higher accuracy using fewer features. This will facilitate industrial use of pattern classification.

Title: On the relationship between the dynamics of the power density and workpiece surface texture in pulsed laser ablation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a validated universal model of the texture obtained during pulsed laser ablation, based on the dynamic superposition of individual footprints. Validation trials performed on Ti6Al4V showed a maximum error in predicting surface texture of only 9%, proving the accuracy of the model. The work underpins a new EC-funded project, STEEP (FP7-PEOPLE-ITN, contract no. 316560) and is the basis of a new collaboration with Rolls-Royce.  Contact person: Dr James Kell, ELT-16. (email: James.Kell@Rolls-Royce.com).

Title: An Evolutionary Multi-objective Approach to Sparse Reconstruction
AdditionalInformation: This is a new method for finding sparse solutions to linear systems problems – a fundamental task with very wide application. These problems are difficult because they involve two competing cost function terms (measurement error and sparseness). We show: that knee regions exist on the Pareto Front (PF) yielding optimal solutions; how evolutionary algorithm techniques can be used to rapidly and robustly estimate the PF; how to find optimal solutions at knee regions. Experiments show that our method significantly outperforms five other well known techniques. Practical applications are demonstrated to fundamental problems of recovering signals and images from noisy data.

Title: Fabrication and quality factor control of a microelectromechanical system resonator with linear differential drive
AdditionalInformation: The vibration properties of microscale mass-spring resonators are degraded in air by viscous damping, which reduces the quality factor (Q) of the resonance.  High Q-factor is important when using the resonators as sensors. This paper presents a microresonator designed to be used with a force feedback technique “Q-factor control” that can overcome the damping force, improving sensor resolution. Specifically a force feedback circuit is designed and the resonator fabricated with a differential drive to allow linear feedback control signals to be used in the circuit. The findings are important for researchers developing resonant chemical/biological sensors to work in air.

Title: Effect of focused ion beam milling on microcantilever loss
AdditionalInformation: Focused ion beam (FIB) milling has been developed as a rapid prototyping/device modification tool for micro/nanoscale devices. However the heavy ions that cause sputtering also create surface damage, affecting the capability of vibrating MEMS devices to act as sensors by increasing damping. This paper reports an investigation of the effect of this damage on Atomic Force Microscope cantilevers FIB milled to reduce their stiffness for improving the sensitivity of Casimir Force measurements. The research reveals a significant 40-50% reduction in quality factor. The finding is of important reference-value for researchers considering using FIB in the fabrication of micro/nano resonator sensors.

Title: Development of a bioinspired MEMS based capacitive tactile sensor for a robotic finger
AdditionalInformation: Microscale tactile sensors that sense the force of touch can be used to create artificial finger pads for robotic hands, to improve sensitivity and delicateness of their touch. This paper presents the development of a novel microscale tactile sensor using a cost efficient microfabrication approach with much reduced processing steps. The results of this work carried out on the FP6 Nanobiotact project (Ref:EU-FP6-NMP-033287) have led into a FP7 project including Unilever (NanoBioTouch, Ref:228844) to improve understanding of the human mechano-transduction system and to establish tissue engineered tactile sensors capable of emotional touch through integrated thermal sensing capability.

Title: Viscoelastic properties of bovine articular cartilage attached to subchondral bone at high frequencies
AdditionalInformation: This research arises from funding from Arthritis Research UK (grants H0671 and 17901).  The paper describes original research on the viscoelastic properties of articular cartilage determined under high frequency loading.  The results can be expected to have implications for mechanical damage to articular cartilage and the onset of osteoarthritis, which is a disease that affects millions of people world-wide.  The results of this study have helped to enable a researcher (Dr Daniel Espino, d.m.espino@bham.ac.uk) to obtain a Marie Curie Intra-European Fellowship within the 7th European Community Framework Programme (Programme number: FP7/2007-2013; under grant agreement n°252278) to develop the research further.

Title: Toughening of zirconia/alumina composites by the addition of graphene platelets
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: Graphene possesses a tensile strength 100 times that of steel. This paper reports research in utilising this excellent property by producing graphene-zirconia-alumina ceramic composite for the first time. To achieve the graphene ceramic composite, we have overcome the challenges in the dispersion of graphene platelets, in anti-oxidation and in avoiding graphene decomposition when going through a 1550o C sintering process. The resultant composite demonstrates a 40% increase in fracture toughness and improves the brittleness property of ceramics considerably. It is light, hard, strong, and low in thermal expansion, which is ideal for important engineering applications, such as hot turbine blades.

Title: Net shape fabrication of stainless steel–alumina composite micro parts
AdditionalInformation: General MEMS fabrication techniques are suitable for making high precision components in Si and resists, but such materials cannot withstand high stress and temperature. This paper presents a novel process for fabricating stainless-alumina composite microcomponents in high precision. The microcomponents produced in the new metallic materials combine low costs of MEMS fabrication with greatly improved strength, high temperature sustainability, and bio-compatibility in comparison with Si components, enabling them to be used in a wider range of applications. This is one of the most representative papers in an area where the group is in the leading position.

Title: Characterisation of metal organic frameworks for adsorption cooling
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates metal organic frameworks (MOFs) as a new class of micro-porous materials for water adsorbent cooling applications. MOFs possess high porosity and with large surface areas (up to 5500m2/g).  This research was used as a foundation for the creation of the only UK research group at the University of Birmingham aiming at developing, characterising and using MOFs in heat powered adsorption applications including refrigeration, air conditioning and energy storage.  It has enabled funding to be secured from the Department of Energy and Climate Change for a study into using MOFs in domestic energy storage systems (Grant No. HS28).

Title: Characterization of coupled micro/nanoresonators using inverse eigenvalue analysis
AdditionalInformation: Resonators mechanically coupled using springs create a resonating system with a multi modal frequency response, which changes when the resonator masses change. This paper presents a method of determining the individual system masses of a coupled resonator system from the modal response using only a single input and output resonator. Two perturbed Eigenvalue sets are found and then Inverse Eigenvalue analysis used to find the mass elements of the coupled system. The finding is important   to researchers developing artificial-nose and other gas sensors as it greatly simplifies the fabrication and operation of coupled resonators by eliminating most of the electrical connections.

Title: Articular cartilage surface rupture during compression: Investigating the effects of tissue hydration in relation to matrix health
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
AdditionalInformation: Pilot data supporting a new concept for paradoxical protection of articular cartilage against failure through excess fluid uptake is reported; i.e. swelling during initial onset of osteoarthritis protects against cartilage failure. The study includes an international co-author from Auckland University.  Developed from a Maurice & Phyllis Paykel Trust Post-Doctoral Fellowship, and combined with knee mechanics research (Öhman et al., 2011) it led to a Marie Curie Intra-European Personal Fellowship (FP7; grant agreement no.252278). Ensuing findings have been presented at six national and international conferences, including the 3rd International Conference on Medical Physiology (Greece, 2012).

Title: Development of a transient large strain contact method for biological heart valve simulations.
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, a transient contact analysis technique has been established for mitral heart valves compatible with simultaneous fluid-structure interaction. This method has applications in fluid-solid modelling of such valves, as well as other biological heart valves. The initial stages of this study were funded through a British Heart Foundation Junior Fellowship (FS/05/32). This study opens up new potential for existing research into Fluid-Structure Interaction modelling of heart valves (e.g. Comp Meth Biomech Biomed Eng DOI: 10.1080/10255842.2012.688818, and international conference presentations in New Zealand, Germany, Italy and within the UK) by enabling hydrodynamic systolic simulation of the mitral valve.

Title: Subject-specific knee joint model : Design of an experiment to validate a multi-body finite element model
AdditionalInformation: This study defines an experimental methodology and associated criteria to validate novel patient-specific knee joint models. Validated models offer surgeons reliable patient-specific insight when planning interventions. This paper includes international co-authors from Italy, France and Germany, as part of a wider collaboration with researchers from Belgium, Denmark, Switzerland, and the UK. Invitations followed from the study to give a lecture at the World Congress on Engineering (London, 2009) and a demonstration at the 2nd Workshop on 3D Physiological Human  in Switzerland (2009). Further presentations were made at international conferences in Greece, Portugal and within the UK.

Title: MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF CHORDAE TENDINEAE OF THE MITRAL HEART VALVE: YOUNG'S MODULUS, STRUCTURAL STIFFNESS, AND EFFECTS OF AGING
VolumeTitle: Journal of Mechanics in Medicine and Biology
AdditionalInformation: Arising from a clinical collaboration (Mr KG Buchan, Consultant Cardio-thoracic Surgeon, Aberdeen), this is the first report of mitral heart valve chordae having age-dependent stiffness which is constant across chordal categories. The results are of importance to clinical practice as surgical replacement of chordae, and future biomaterials development, should account for age following heart valve failure. Surgical implications have been presented at the 22nd World Congress, World Society of Cardio-Thoracic Surgeons (Canada, 2012), the 2nd International conference on Surgery (Prague, 2011).

Title: The effect of screw insertion angle and thread type on the pullout strength of bone screws in normal and osteoporotic cancellous bone models
AdditionalInformation: This research arises from collaboration with Surgicraft Limited, Redditch, UK (Mr Tony Fennell, International Sales Director, tony.fennell@surgicraft.co.uk).  This paper describes, for the first time, the strength of angled screws in models of bone corresponding to varying degrees of osteoporosis.  As the population lives for longer, surgeons are looking to use screws for greater surgical indications.  The results of this study are important in understanding the performance of devices in diseased bone and helping to develop improved designs and methods of pre-clinical mechanical testing.

Title: Investigating the potential advantages of a new design metacarpophalangeal joint
AdditionalInformation: The outcomes of finger joint replacement are typically poor, with most designs suffering from early failure.  This paper describes collaborative research between academia, industry and surgeons to develop a novel implant design for replacement of the finger joints.  The initial research was undertaken while Shepherd held a Leverhulme Trust Special Research Fellowship.  The design concept has been patented (US2006167559) and an exclusive license agreement is being discussed with a major medical device company (Professor Alan Johnstone, Consultant Orthopaedic Surgeon, a.johnstone@nhs.net).  This research has the potential to improve the lives of patients affected by arthritis of the finger joints.

Title: Friction in metal-on-metal total disc arthroplasty: Effect of ball radius
AdditionalInformation: This research arises from EPSRC research grant EP/F014562 which funded a new type of spine simulator.  Close collaboration with the manufacturer (Bose Limited, ElectroForce Systems Group, MN, USA) was required to develop a simulator capable of complex spinal movements (Dr Darren Burke, Technical Marketing Manager, darren_b@bose.com).  The research presents, for the first time, the friction and lubrication in metal-on-metal disc replacements.  This research is vital in understanding the performance of these devices before they are implanted into patients.  The results have helped to secure a European Commission grant to develop a European Industrial Doctorate in Spinal Implant Design (FP7-PEOPLE-2013-ITN-Proposal-604935).

Title: Experimental and theoretical investigation of small-scale cooling system equipped with helically coiled evaporator and condenser
VolumeTitle: Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Proceedings. Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a theoretical and experimental investigation into the development of a small scale cooling system for a wide range of applications including electronic devices and personal cooling. The innovative use of small diameter helical coils and the development of a new method to predict the characteristics of boiling heat transfer of refrigerants within these coils were recognised by the Institute of Refrigeration with a Ted Perry award (given to researchers undertaking work of a practical nature in a field related to air conditioning or refrigeration).

Title: Solar powered vapor absorption system using propane and alkylated benzene AB300 oil
AdditionalInformation: This paper, describing work supported by the Jamaican Petroleum Company, discusses the development of a new working fluid for absorption refrigeration systems. The novelty of this research is that the systems utilise low temperature waste heat sources and solar energy. Outputs from this have been used directly in the development of innovative Jamaican air-conditioning systems by the Caribbean ESCo Ltd (Mr. Eaton Haughton, Managing Director, eaton@caribbeanesco.com). The application of the technology has resulted in annual energy savings of 350,000kWhr, equating to a reduction of 291,865 tonnes CO2e which has contributed directly to the Jamaican Government’s Environmental commitments.

Title: Physical and operating conditions effect on silica gel-water adsorption chiller performance
AdditionalInformation: This research employs a new form of genetic algorithm, developed by the investigators, to study the effect of various operating parameters within a novel thermal model describing silica gel-water adsorption chillers.  The work was supported by an EPSRC Industrial Case award (No.08001389) and the Weatherite group (Mr John Whitehouse, managing director, jwhitehouse@weatheritegroup.com).  The outputs included the identification of new adsorbents that outperform silica gel leading to more energy efficient adsorption chillers. The research has strengthened links with Weatherite, including a KTP project (KTP008922) to develop the technology.

Title: Macroscopic invisibility cloaking of visible light
AdditionalInformation: Invisibility cloaks for visible light used to be confined to the imagination. This paper presents a breakthrough in this field by demonstrating the first realisation of a macroscopic volumetric invisibility cloak constructed from natural birefringent crystals. The cloak operates at visible frequencies and is capable of hiding three-dimensional objects of the scale of centimetres and millimetres. The achievement has been ranked as 4th of the top 10 breakthroughs in 2010 by Physics World http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/44618. A reviewer commented: “This is an excellent paper which deserves publication in Nature. The cloaking experiment is beautiful in its simplicity”.

Title: The fabrication of high-aspect-ratio, size-tunable nanopore arrays by modified nanosphere lithography
AdditionalInformation: Nanopatterns can generate plasmons, a property that can be used for applications ranging from biochemical sensors to future communications systems. Producing nanopatterns for a large area economically is a challenge that must be addressed before this technology can be deployed in practice. The proposed nanofabrication process is a breakthrough in producing high-aspect ratio and ordered nanopores on large areas in an economic way. The tunable property of the process enables fabrication of the various nanopatterns to suit many applications.

Title: Vapour-phase and particulate-bound PAHs profile generated by a (SI/HCCI) engine from a winter grade commercial gasoline fuel
AdditionalInformation: Polyaromatic Hydrocarbons (PAH) are dangerous components of emissions.  In this research, for the first time, the concentrations were measured of 16 individual PAHs in semi-volatile gas phase and in particulate matter exhaust from a SI/HCCI engine fuelled with gasoline. Studies of the effect of fuel composition and engine operating conditions on the formation of individual PAHs are of paramount importance to fuels and catalysts manufacturers.   PAHs were quantified to find generation and/or depletion processes at different modes and operation conditions. Probable mechanisms for the production of some of the pyrosynthetic PAH were also discussed for the first time.

Title: Biogas upgrade to syn-gas (H-2-CO) via dry and oxidative reforming
AdditionalInformation: Biogas manufacturing installations are growing exponentially.  Biogas (2/3rd CH4, 1/3rd CO2) is a difficult fuel to use in engines, although it offers low emissions of nitrogen oxides. This paper addresses for the first time in detail a reforming process that utilises CO2 and CH4 to produce cleaner and higher energy content fuels in the form of hydrogen-rich gases. Our reforming process  improves the combustion of widely available biogas. This research has been conducted in collaboration with Johnson Matthey (Andy York, Principal Scientist; ayork@matthey.com).

Title: Materials Testing for Finite Element Tire Model
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Materials Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: A novel procedure has been developed for generating tyre materials data, for finite element analysis, using test specimens extracted from tyre products. This overcomes a major challenge for tyre modellers and researchers due to the complex nature of tyre materials and associated proprietary protections of constituent material properties by tyre manufacturers. Techniques developed include the use of image processing to identify reinforcement layup and material modelling to determine hyperelastic and viscoelastic properties. The paper was judged one of the most outstanding SAE papers of 2010 (Letter from Dr El-Sayed, Editor SAE International).

Title: Bus Structure Behaviour under Driving Manoeuvring and Evaluation of the Effect of an Active Roll System
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Vehicle Structures & Systems
AdditionalInformation: Inadequate torsional rigidity of a bus structure lowers its rollover threshold under cornering manoeuvres. The rollover threshold can be raised by increasing the roll stiffness of the suspension but this is usually at the expense of ride quality. As a result of collaboration between Birmingham University and Carlos III University Madrid, an active roll system, developed using a fuzzy logic controller to provide additional roll stiffness during vehicle manoeuvring, has been implemented on a passenger bus by a Spanish bus manufacturer. Further collaboration is directed at improving torsional rigidity of bus structures (JAE Vol 225 (2) 2011).

Title: Prediction of vehicle reliability performance using artificial neural networks
AdditionalInformation: In order to remain competitive, manufacturers must seek to shorten significantly the product development phase, from design concept to complete product release, while maintaining product quality and reliability.  An expert system has been developed for predicting reliability performance at the later stages of a vehicle’s life by using only information from a first inspection after the vehicle’s prototype production. This has been developed as one of the tools for a Reliability Improvement Expert System in collaboration with Jaguar LandRover (Julian Buckingham, Manager, email:Jbuckin2@jaguarlandrover.com) to identify potential reliability problems in new products at an early stage of production prototype evaluation.

Title: Finite element analysis of aircraft tyre - effect of model complexity on tyre performance characteristics
AdditionalInformation: In an Aerospace Technology Exploitation project sponsored by Advantage West Midlands, with partners Dunlop Aircraft Tyres (DATL) and Airbus, the effect of FE tyre model complexity on accurate prediction of real tyre behaviour has been investigated. A novel tyre design system has been realised for virtual prototyping of aircraft tyres at DATL, based on optimised FE models, enabling a reduction in prototype development cycles from 5 to 2 (see Process Modelling Impact Case) and providing reduced models for Airbus for aircraft and landing gear simulation. This work has led to the development of a novel low-rolling resistance tyre (TSB grant:112000-73308).

Title: Effect of injection timing on gasoline HCCI particulate emissions
AdditionalInformation: Except for one document from Ford, most publications have stated that HCCI (a generic combustion mode for next-generation engines) is ‘smoke-free’, but our own work at Birmingham was the first to report on particulate matter (PM) emissions from HCCI. This paper provides evidence to show that HCCI is not ‘smoke-free’ and in fact requires careful control of injection timing in order to limit PM emissions.

Title: Cylinder-to-Cylinder Variations in a V6 Gasoline Direct Injection HCCI Engine
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
AdditionalInformation: Although over 1000 papers have been published so far on HCCI technology, only very few have investigated combustion in multi-cylinder engines. This paper reports the author’s work on the world‘s first prototype V6 HCCI engine produced by industry. It examines challenging issues arising when the technology is applied to a V-type engine. These are associated with bank-to-bank and cylinder-to-cylinder variations in combustion and emissions due to the sensitivity of HCCI to the in-cylinder charge temperature. The research has answered many questions from industry about the practicality of HCCI engine production (JLR/Ford, Steve Richardson, Manager, email:srichar5@jaguarlandrover.com ).

Title: Raising the fuel heating value and recovering exhaust heat by on-board oxidative reforming of bioethanol
AdditionalInformation: This paper for first time demonstrates that the exhaust gas fuel reforming technique pioneered at Birmingham simultaneously improves engine fuel economy and reduces CO2 and other emissions. The work was in collaboration with Cardiff University and subsequently supported by an £8M TSB (400176/149) project in collaboration with Ford, Jaguar LandRover, Johnson Matthey and Cambustion.  As part of this project we have demonstrated significant improvements in engine efficiency (higher than 4%) and achieved CO2 emissions reduction (Paul Millington, Principal Scientist, Johnson Matthey; millipj@matthey.com). This work led to an invention, which is the subject of a GB patent application (No:AA1888GB).

Title: Enhancing the NO2/NOx ratio in compression ignition engines by hydrogen and reformate combustion, for improved aftertreatment performance
AdditionalInformation: NO oxidation to NO2 is an important intermediate step involved in all current after-treatment systems designed for NOx and Soot removal. This is the first study of how hydrogen and reformate additions enhance NO2 production (without raising total NOx) during diesel combustion and improve the performance of several catalytic after-treatment systems in reducing emissions. The work was supported by EPSRC (EP/G03139) in collaboration with Brunel and Cardiff Universities, Johnson Matthey, Shell and the Environmental Sciences group at Birmingham. This work formed a work package in the £8M TSB (400176/149) project in collaboration with Ford, Jaguar LandRover and Johnson Matthey.

Title: Acoustic noise from polymer gears - A tribological investigation
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper published that compares noise generated by plastic gears made from a variety of engineering polymers.  The study was supported by EPSRC (EP/P50541) in collaboration with the School of Metallurgy and Materials (University of Birmingham).  The study revealed the importance of tribological interactions in the design of low noise accurate all-plastic transmissions.  The results are being used by Hewlett Packard (Vancouver) in the development of drive systems for desktop printers (Michael Rode, Hardware Engineer; michael.rode@hp.com).

Title: A kinematic analysis of meshing polymer gear teeth
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part L-Journal of Materials Design and Applications
AdditionalInformation: This was the first dynamic investigation presented on the kinematics of meshing polymer gear teeth and contained a new approach to wear and failure analysis for plastic gears. The research was supported by EPSRC DTA funding (EP/P504813) and Romax Technology Ltd (Barry James – Technical Director Simulation, b.james@romaxtech.com) and was completed in collaboration with Imperial College London (M Karimpour - Research Fellow - morad.karimpour08@imperial.ac.uk).  The results were used as a basis for further research on performance improvements of polymer gear trains (see Dearn Output 2).

Title: On the fundamental lubricity of 2,5-dimethylfuran as a synthetic engine fuel
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to report on the lubricating properties of 2,5-Dimethlyfuran (DMF) a potentially disruptive, fructose based bio-fuel.  It shows significant improvements in lubricity over both Gasoline and Ethanol.  The project was funded by EPSRC’s Collaborative Research with China call (EP/F061692/1) and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (50875071).  Project partners were Shell, JLR and Hefei University of Technology (HUT), China.  Research collaboration with HUT has continued with funding from the Chinese 863 National High Technology R&D programme (2012AA051803) and the RAEng (Roy_Acad 27612) investigating alternative fuel tribology (Prof Xianguo Hu, Institute of Tribology, xghu@hfut.edu.cn).

Title: Controlling Soot Formation with Filtered EGR for Diesel and Biodiesel Fuelled Engines
AdditionalInformation: One of the most researched pollutants from internal combustion engines is the Particulate Matter (PM)/Soot, with all the published studies focusing on their formation during combustion, reduction in the exhaust through catalysis, and the effect on humans and environment. This is the first worldwide study to report the influence of PM/Soot recycled in the engine combustion chamber (as part of the EGR technology that is commonly used in today’s diesel vehicles), on the vehicle out PM/soot emissions. This work was in collaboration with Johnson Matthey (Andy York, Principal Scientist; ayork@matthey.com) and supported by EPSRC (EP/G038139/1).

Title: Finding synergies in fuels properties for the design of renewable fuels -hydroxylated biodiesel effects on butanol-diesel blends
AdditionalInformation: Global research conducted on next-generation alternative fuels focuses on engine adaptation to account for the diverse range of fuel properties. These differences in characteristics render large-scale implementation impractical. This paper details research making a breakthrough in the use of multi-component renewable fuel blends in diesel engines, crucially, without the need for any engine modifications. The work formed part of a range of ongoing collaborative projects (e.g. BAUHAUS with 5 sponsored PhDs and 1 ESPRC DTA scholarship) with Johnson Matthey (Andy York, Principal Scientist; ayork@matthey.com, Shell (Roger Cracknell, Technology Manager; roger.cracknell@shell.com) and the University of Castilla La-Mancha (Professor Magin Lapuerta; Magin.Lapuerta@uclm.es).

Title: Neat tallow combustion in a large diesel engine for electricity generation from waste
AdditionalInformation: 1 million tonnes of waste animal fat could be used annually as biofuel in the UK. This world-first paper explores the use of neat tallow for electricity generation in a large diesel engine (2000 h testing/800 kW). Sponsors included TSB, Pointons (largest UK animal renderer) and EU (Science City). The vital new methods for compliance with the Waste Incineration Directive included cooled and humidified exhaust gas recirculation for NOx abatement. The requirement that exhaust be subjected to high temperatures could be satisfied by the upgrading of waste tallow to syngas in a tallow reformer looped with the engine.

Title: Corrosion effects of RME in blends with ULSD on aluminium and copper
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to study the corrosion of aluminium and copper exposed to biodiesel. Effects on metal surfaces and changes in fuel composition through prolonged high-temperature exposure to metals were quantified. Increasing the biodiesel content made the fuel more corrosive, causing damage on metal surfaces and pronounced change in fuel properties. The work has major implications for the development of more resilient fuel injection equipment for modern diesel vehicles. This work now forms  part of a (£750k) research project into fuel deposits  funded by Jaguar LandRover (Adam Weall, Project Engineering, email:aweall@jaguarlandrover.com) and Shell (Roger Cracknell, Technology Manager; email:roger.cracknell@shell.com).

Title: Speciation of Hydrocarbon and Carbonyl Emissions of 2,5-Dimethylfuran Combustion in a DISI Engine
AdditionalInformation: A complete understanding of 2,5-Dimethylfuran (DMF) is important to engine manufacturers and vehicle OEMs to confirm it as a new-generation alternative fuel (Jaguar Land Rover letter). This paper describes the world-first detailed investigation into hydrocarbon emissions for DMF combustion. Three reviewers (refer to Professor Simone Hochgreb, Cambridge University) all rated the paper ‘high quality’. The research has provided the only data available so far in response to concerns about the impact of the new biofuel on the environment, also allowing our School of Biosciences to study the impact of DMF use on human health (MSc thesis, “Toxicity of 2,5-Dimethylfuran” 2011).

Title: Effect of spark timing and load on a DISI engine fuelled with 2,5-dimethylfuran
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports progress in the world-first research on the combustion performance of 2,5-dimethylfuran in engines. Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) commented: “Their published findings are very informative for engine design providing answers related to the new bio-fuel and valuable knowledge on the development of combustion systems for modern gasoline direct injection engines” (JLR letter). The research was conducted in collaboration with Tsinghua University and Xi’an Jiaotong University (China). For this work (reported by Green Car Congress), the author was invited by the ENI Committee as candidate for the ENI Award (“Nobel prize of energy research”) endorsed by JLR and Shell.

Title: Applications of dry film lubricants for polymer gears
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the frictional characteristics of engineering polymers in roll/slide applications, when coated with a variety of dry-film lubricants.  This is the first time that DFL lubricants have been used in this application.  It shows that in some cases the frictional losses (manifest as temperatures and noise) are reduced when compared with uncoated and internally lubricated gears.  The work was supported by Indestructible Paints Ltd (Mr Brian Norton, Managing Director, brian@indestructible.co.uk) and was an international collaboration with the Technical University of Sofia (Prof. Eng. D G Petrov, Head of Department, dimgog@abv.bg) supported by the Bulgarian Government

Title: Modelling crystallization and melting kinetics of cocoa butter in chocolate and application to confectionery manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the results of PhD work supported by Magna confectionary (contact Ian Smart) who make chocolate eggs for all of the major manufacturers. They wished to understand how one of their processes, 'frozen-cone' actually worked. The paper reports the first successful computational model for the phase behaviour of chocolate during cooling and solidification; this model can be used to predict phase composition and temperature distribution, and was validated using Xray crystallography to determine the crystal type. The model is now being used for process design at both Magna and Mondelez (formerly Cadbury).

Title: Emulsification mechanism and storage instabilities of hydrocarbon-in-water sub-micron emulsions stabilised with Tweens (20 and 80), Brij 96v and sucrose monoesters
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: Nanoemulsions offer many benefits for the food and personal care industries - but they have to be stable and capable of being moved from manufacturer to consumer. This paper reports part of an EngD programme with Unilever (Frith) on how nanoemulsions can be stabilised using different chemicals. This work has been taken forward in a number of projects in Prof. Norton's lab and as part of the EPSRC CIM in Food Manufacture.

Title: C-botulinum Inactivation Kinetics Implemented in a Computational Model of a High-Pressure Sterilization Process
AdditionalInformation: High-pressure sterilisation is a candidate process to replace conventional thermal processing - but to do this it is necessary to understand how organisms are killed. This paper results from a sabbatical visit by Peter Fryer to CSIRO Food Science in Melbourne, during which a computational model of high-pressure processing was developed. Here the model is used to test a variety of models for how C. botulinum (the critical poisoning organisms) will behave during processing - and shows that different models give answers that are sufficiently different to cause concern for practical operation of the device.

Title: The influence of hydrocolloid hydrodynamics on lubrication
AdditionalInformation: There is major interest in lowering the fat content of foods while maintaining the quality of in mouth properties. Our work pioneered the idea of studying tribology in relationship to the mouth as a machine. This paper reports ground breaking findings on how different biopolymer structures at the tertiary level cause different lubrication performance. The work has led to food formulations for low fat and more widely for non-petroleum lubricants.  The work was funded by industry and an 1851 Fellowship and has led to a number of new projects with companies, with a research income of approximately £500k over 3-years.

Title: Food grade duplex emulsions designed and stabilised with different osmotic pressures
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a comprehensive study on how duplex emulsions might be formed and the microstructure controlled. It continues to investigate how such complex structures might be used to control release of actives including control of salt perception. This science understanding has the potential to allow the salt content of a range of foods to be reduced by up to 80%.  This was funded under the EngD scheme with Unilever as the host company.  The work has resulted in a number of new directly funded projects with companies with a current income of £1.5M over a 4-year period.

Title: Modelling the Rapid Cooling and Casting of Chocolate to predict Phase Behaviour
AdditionalInformation: First paper to report a model which links crystallization kinetics to heat transfer in chocolate molding processes.  Model enables a priori process design to obtain correct chocolate microstructure rather than by previous trial and error methods. Model has been validated at different scales (lab to production) and is used in manufacture of new products by the sponsoring company - Magna (contact and co-author Mr Ian Smart), a major confectionery supplier under multiple major brand names (e.g. Cadbury, Nestle).

Title: Bioinformatics predicts diverse Aspergillus hydrophobins with novel properties
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the first use of bioinformatics in the food sector to look for previously unidentified industrially relevant hydrophobins.  Work has identified 75 new proteins for exploitation (for example as biosurfactants) and a new class of hydrophobin.  This work represents probably the first exposure of this technology to academics and industrialists active in food research. Work funded through BBSRC studentship and collaboration between Universities of Birmingham and Wolverhampton.

Title: Development and characterisation of tempered cocoa butter emulsions containing up to 60% water
AdditionalInformation: Paper describes the first practical approach to produce chocolate matrices with up to 60% water content.  This is extremely challenging because due to the hydrophobicity of the matrix, any attempt to reduce the fat content adversely affects the attractive physical properties of the product (e.g. snap, gloss, taste, texture).  Work was carried out by BBSRC funded student and has had considerable industrial impact - filed patent (UK reference 0910358.1) and ongoing funded research by a significant European company.

Title: Hydrophobins stabilised air-filled emulsions for the food industry
AdditionalInformation: This paper opens a brand new area of use of air-filled emulsions for use in low fat foods.  The work describes creation of novel air –filled structures which could accurately mimic lipid droplets but without any oil being present. Novel proteins covered air-cells had a size, interfacial rheology and flow characteristics that accurately matched the lipid droplets, thus a 50% reduction in lipid for traditionally high fat foods was possible.  Work funded by BBSRC (BB/G005478/1) and has most recently to EU patent (EP2365758) and collaboration with a significant US based multinational food company.

Title: A conceptual model for fluid gel lubrication
AdditionalInformation: First report on potential of fluid gels for novel fat replacement/reduction approaches in foods - fluid gels can be used to control both the bulk and thin-film rheological behaviour of reduced-fat ‘soft foods’ (texture and mouthfeel). Funding by Unilever (£153,358) enabled translation of the work into other research/product categories such as cosmetics. Work led to BBSRC DRINC grant (£330,637) on the gelation of fluid gels under ‘stomach-like’ conditions to impact on satiety (BB/G005478/1). An additional short project funded by Wellcome Trust ISSF Grant (£30,000), on potential of fluid gel particles to act as cell-carrying matrices led to patent filing (P340605GB).

Title: O/W emulsions stabilised by both low molecular weight surfactants and colloidal particles: The effect of surfactant type and concentration
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: Leading-edge study presents novel evidence on interfacial interactions between Pickering particles and surfactants, leading to either synergistic (facilitating particle adsorption) or antagonistic (promoting particle displacement) behaviour. At a fundamental level, this work revealed that chemical modification of colloidal particles is not necessary to ‘provoke’ Pickering behaviour. Instead, study demonstrates that colloidal particles’ wettability can be ‘fine-tuned’ by addition of moderate amounts of surfactants. Approach was the focus of the “edible Pickering Emulsion Technology” (ePET) project (TS/J003697/1) funded by TSB/EPSRC (£301,610), as the top-ranking proposal from the “Nutrition for Life” competition. ePET is led by Cargill who are contributing additional £371,030.

Title: Development of an in-vitro mouth model to quantify salt release from gels
AdditionalInformation: This paper details the development of an in-vitro mouth model, and uses it to measure salt release kinetics from gel systems.  It provides a repeatable system to quantify release and breakdown of model food structures under phenomena relevant to oral processing. The system has been adopted by Dr Souchon's group, INRA, France, providing one joint publication and has formed the basis of a subsequent internal study in collaboration with the department of sport and exercise science  (currently EPSRC pump priming grant EP/J501414/1).  The work was EPSRC funded in collaboration with industry (DT/E010474/1).

Title: Quantification of Microcapsules Deposited in Cotton Fabrics before and after Abrasion Using Fluorescence Microscopy
AdditionalInformation: Research co-funded by EPSRC (EP/H035540/1) and Procter and Gamble (contact Dr Carlos Amador); paper outlines a new method based on fluorescent microscopy to investigate the interaction of particles with flexible porous fabrics under friction. Previous models assumed hard fabric surface which is incorrect physics. Work has revealed different mechanisms of attachment and removal of particulates giving understanding of the effect of mechanical forces.  Approach being validated and applied by Procter and Gamble to design environmentally friendly products.  Work has led to two new EngD projects with the sponsor.

Title: Drying of agar gels using supercritical carbon dioxide
AdditionalInformation: Many food supply chains involve transport of substantial amounts of water; if it were possible to produce dehydration methods that leave structures that can be reformed rapidly and effectively on contact with water, more efficient supply chains would result since water reduction saves weight and thus energy. The work in this paper is the first attempt to see how hydrogels dry using supercritical CO2 - this work is now being developed as part of the EPSRC Centre for Sustainable Energy use in Food Chains.

Title: SPG rotating membrane technique for production of food grade emulsions
AdditionalInformation: This is the first report of the use of rotating membranes to produce edible emulsions in which a fundamental science approach was taken to tease apart the mechanism of droplet behaviour in such devices. The original work was funded directly by the food industry who continue to invest in the research. TSB/EPSRC have funded a project to translate the findings to agrochemicals and to scale up the process to pilot scale.

Title: Comparing droplet breakup for a high-pressure valve homogeniser and a Microfluidizer for the potential production of food-grade nanoemulsions
AdditionalInformation: There is a commercial interest in reducing droplet sizes below 100 nm. However, the mechanism of droplet formation is not well understood when small droplets are produced. This paper is a detailed study of two devices: a high pressure homogeniser and a microfluidizer. Droplet size has been shown to be independent of viscosity ratio (0.1–80) for both homogenisers indicating that breakup is occurring in turbulent flow.  This was funded by a major food industry.

Title: Experimental and theoretical studies of thermal conductivity, viscosity and heat transfer coefficient of titania and alumina nanofluids
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This paper strongly questions recent works on heat transfer in nano-fluids claiming strong enhancement of thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient.   It confirms that thermal conductivity follows well established Maxwell (19th century) model and shows that heat transfer coefficients can be accurately predicted from correlations developed for simple fluids.  This research demonstrates that ideas still popular in terms of heat transfer enhancement nanofluids cannot be theoretically or experimentally proven.  Work carried out as part of recently completed EU FP7 NanoHEX project and findings carried forward by Universities KTH Stockholm (Prof B Palm) and Twente.

Title: Exploring the effects of high shear blending on lactose and drug using fluidised bed elutriation
AdditionalInformation: Inhalation as a means of drug delivery is very useful for respiratory ailments (e.g. asthma).  The correct particle size distribution is key in allowing correct delivery of active drug to the correct areas of the lungs.  Blending of the non-active components with the active drug is essential, but causes changes in the fine particle size which needs to be better understood.  Being able to test for changes in powder behaviour is essential in developing process understanding, and fluid bed elutriation is a potential tool for such investigation.  Work funded by the EPSRC and GSK who also collaborated on the project.

Title: Lubricating properties of human whole saliva as affected by beta-lactoglobulin
AdditionalInformation: Paper demonstrates that is possible to control the astringent response during eating.  Astringency is caused by phenolic compounds in food (e.g. tea) which requires careful control to avoid a negative oral sensation.  This work used tribology to assess the effect of astringency upon the lubricating properties of saliva.   Since new foods must appeal to the consumer during eating, this approach enables astringency to be controlled in their design.  Work is collaboration between Birmingham and internationally-leading food engineering group of Foegeding in North Carolina (USA).  Thus, novel methods for in mouth relevant measurement have been applied to a difficult physiochemical effect.

Title: Application of external lubrication during the roller compaction of adhesive pharmaceutical formulations
AdditionalInformation: Magnesium Stearate (Mg St) is used as a lubricant in tablet formulations to help get material through the process.  However Mg St has a significant detrimental effect on tablet performance in-vivo and so minimising Mg St content is desirable.  By spraying the Mg St only onto the surface that required lubrication, a significant reduction (100 fold) can be achieved while maintaining throughput levels. The work was funded in part by EPSRC (through EngD scheme) and Bristol Myers Squib who collaborated on the project. Further work is ongoing in optimisation of the spray system and full process chain.

Title: Characterising the cleaning mechanisms of yeast and the implications for Cleaning In Place (CIP)
VolumeTitle: Transactions of the Institution of Chemical Engineers, Part C - Food and Bioproducts Processing
AdditionalInformation: Food production plant needs to be cleaned regularly to maintain efficient production.  Better understanding of the cleaning process can reduce loss of production time, reduce energy use (e.g. through lower temperatures) and reduce environmental burden (e.g. less chemical to effluent treatment).  Removal of yeast deposits is of importance in brewing and work here was able to show that initial rinsing at low temperature (30°C) followed by chemical clean at high temperature (70°C) was the most cost effective and environmentally beneficial.  The work was funded by EPSRC, DTI link scheme (ZEAL) and Heineken who also collaborated on the project

Title: A method for characterising solids translational and rotational motions using Multiple-Positron Emission Particle Tracking (Multiple-PEPT)
AdditionalInformation: EPSRC funded research (EP/C509080/1) allowing simultaneous tracking of multiple tracers in Positron Emission Particle Tracking (PEPT) by developing new algorithms to track particles with different activities.
