Represents a step change in PEPT capability enabling for the first time the translational and rotational motion of particles to be recorded in unit operations relevant to food (canning, Campden BRI) and minerals processing (milling, IMERYS), as well as detergent tablet dissolution (Procter & Gamble). Work has delivered underlying capability that is now commonly used within the Centre for Positron Imaging.

Title: Dynamics of textile motion in a front-loading domestic washing machine
AdditionalInformation: First reported chemical engineering analysis of transport phenomena occurring in a domestic washing machine.  Positron Emission Particle Tracking (PEPT) was used to determine flow dynamics and mechanical (shear/friction) forces acting on fabrics.  Work carried out by Procter & Gamble (contact and co-author Dr Carlos Amador) sponsored EngD student; P&G are using this approach to design scale-down cleaning tests for fabrics and to design improve new products that will allow significant reduction on energy (reduced temperature) and water usage in washing machines (300 bn washes/annum in Western hemisphere, approx 10 litres per wash)  without compromising performance.

Title: The effect of amorphous pyrophosphate on calcium phosphate cement resorption and bone generation
AdditionalInformation: Describes a bone replacement which interacts with the bone formation pathway. First report of a material that can degrade in response to and simultaneously stimulate bone formation. It represents a change in the way bone graft replacements are designed – considering the biological milieu as opposed to mimicking tissue properties. The work was funded by EPSRC CASE studentships (Smith and Nephew – Farrar) (CASE/CNA/06/66), and a fellowship. Further work was funded by the NSFC (51150110156).  Two patents were filed to cover the invention (US 61/016212, WO2004028576).  An EPSRC project will explore this composition in producing living bone in vitro (EP/H028277/1).

Title: A novel phosphonate for the repair of critical size bone defects : A novel phosphonate for the repair of critical size bone defects
VolumeTitle: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Paper describes BBSRC and NIHR funded research on development of novel bone scaffold which has been proven to enhance bone formation as well as inhibit bone resorption using an ex vivo model, leading to faster healing.  Conventional approaches focus only on the former.  There is potential for the material to be used instead of BMP (bone morphogenic protein) replacement therapy, the current ‘gold standard’ in medical treatment; this is very expensive whilst the material proposed here is much more cost effective. An injectable and moldable version of the material is being developed currently for hip injuries, funded by BBSRC.

Title: In situ modification of chromatography adsorbents using cold atmospheric pressure plasmas
AdditionalInformation: This Bioprocessing Research Industry Club (BRIC) output performed in collaboration with J.L. Walsh (U. Liverpool) builds on a previous BRIC output (Arpanaei et al., 2010) and represents one of the first successful demonstrations of cold atmospheric plasma processing of materials directly in liquid suspension. It is envisaged that the gentle underwater plasma techniques applied herein will significantly extend the range of materials that can be surface engineered using plasmas. This work is being continued in an EPSRC CDT funded PhD project (EP/K502984/1), and a follow-up EPSRC – Industry funded collaboration with J.L. Walsh and Micropore Technologies Ltd is being planned.

Title: Integrated system for temperature-controlled fast protein liquid chromatography comprising improved copolymer modified beaded agarose adsorbents and a travelling cooling zone reactor arrangement
AdditionalInformation: This is the first in a series of outputs concerning the advance of a radical integrated approach to chromatography exploiting ‘smart’ materials and new column hardware for the recovery and purification of macromolecular targets. The work is funded by a European Framework 7 Large-Scale Collaborative Integrating Project (CP-IP 229335-2: ‘Advanced Magnetic Nanoparticles Deliver Smart Processes And Products For Life’, MagPro2Life) aimed at delivering leaner, greener and more sustainable manufacturing technology for valuable bio-commodities.

Title: Multi-cycle recovery of lactoferrin and lactoperoxidase from crude whey using fimbriated high-capacity magnetic cation exchangers and a novel ‘rotor-stator’ high-gradient magnetic separator
AdditionalInformation: The output, which was funded by a European Framework 6 Strategic Targeted Research Project (STREP 013469, NanoBioMag) shows how far the technique of High-Gradient Magnetic Fishing has come since its invention a decade ago, i.e. to the brink of commercialization and on-site testing within the bioprocess industry sector. Its findings played an important role in securing a follow-up 17 partner strong European Framework 7 Large-Scale Collaborative Integrating Project (CP-IP 229335-2, MagPro2Life). The rotor-stator magnetic separator described in this work is currently available as a commercial prototype through PerkinElmer chemagen Technologie GmbH & ABBIS bio process automation (Vulkan Technic Maschinen-Konstruktions GmbH).

Title: Engineering an In Vitro Model of a Functional Ligament from Bone to Bone
AdditionalInformation: Describes the first robust in vitro model of a ligament.  Previous models didn’t contain a component that enabled the simulation of bone/soft tissue interface.  The ceramic component meant the sinew could be clamped in a bioreactor for long-term evaluation of extrinsic conditions on matrix deposition and mechanical properties.  This facilitated the design of a more effective rehabilitation regime following injury.  The paper also resulted in further funded work into the production of a direct ligament replacement (two grants from £160k project numbers 472 and 497, one from the BBSRC - £377k, BBG0223561), further papers and presentations at multiple conferences..

Title: Exposure of Salmonella enterica Serovar Typhimurium to High Level Biocide Challenge Can Select Multidrug Resistant Mutants in a Single Step
AdditionalInformation: This study was the first to investigate the effects of biocides on bacteria using flow cytometry. This allowed not only detection of viable cells upon exposure to biocides that were undetectable by other methods, but also characterisation of resistant mutants which have previously been impossible to isolate. This enables future research into safe biocide use, critical for human and veterinary health. Work was in collaboration with Dr Mark Webber from Infection & Immunity at Birmingham, and used BBSRC-funded equipment (BB/F011237/1, TWO CoI). This has strengthened links with the Webber/Piddock research group, which continue in the form of collaborative research.

Title: Engineering Biofilms for Biocatalysis
AdditionalInformation: This work developed an entirely novel methodology for preparing immobilised bacterial catalysts with highly advantageous properties for biotransformation reactions generating pharmaceutical precursors. The study was an interdisciplinary collaboration with Dr Rebecca Goss (University of St Andrews). The project has led to three further journal papers, several conference presentations and two successful linked BBSRC grants with the same consortium (BB/I006834/1; BB/I008713/2 total £891k) which aims to further develop the methodology into a scalable bioreactor system, potentially to pilot scale, that could be industrially applied in the future.

Title: Exploitation of GFP fusion proteins and stress avoidance as a generic strategy for the production of high-quality recombinant proteins
AdditionalInformation: This study, funded by a BBSRC/EPSRC BRIC grant (BB/E005934/1) and in collaboration with Jeff Cole (Biosciences at Birmingham) and GlaxoSmithKline (contact: Dr Richard Hall – co-author) codeveloped novel methods for optimising the production of recombinant proteins in bacterial hosts, an essential step in biopharmaceutical drug development and manufacture. This allows shortening of drug discovery and production development times and synthesis of proteins that were previously difficult to manufacture. The work has been advanced by a BBSRC-funded PhD student and has led to a successful TSB / BBSRC-funded KTP grant with Cobra Biologics (contact: Tony Hitchcock)

Title: Characterisation of spin coated engineered Escherichia coli biofilms using atomic force microscopy
AdditionalInformation: This study developed novel analytical methodologies (including atomic force microscopy and interferometry) to characterise the structure-function relationships of novel engineered bacterial biofilms employed in biotransformation reactions. This paper, on the interface of microbiological and physical analysis methods, was a collaboration with Dr Rebecca Goss (University of St Andrews). Via BBSRC grant funding with the same consortium (BB/I006834/1; BB/I008713/2 total £891k), the methodology described in this paper will be used to further characterise and optimise immobilised biocatalyst systems in a variety of laboratory and pilot-scale conditions.

Title: Determining the mechanical properties of yeast cell walls
AdditionalInformation: Compression testing by micromanipulation with associated mathematical modelling can be used to find mechanical properties of biological cell walls. This paper describes an important innovation in this technique, made by a student on a BBSRC studentship. Using very high compression speeds, time dependent effects such as water loss could be neglected. This allowed much more information to be extracted from compression data, specifically for yeast cells. Such information should be useful in designing yeast disruption equipment and in studying yeast cell wall physiology. The new technique will lead to improved research on the biomechanics of other microorganisms.

Title: Biomechanical properties of single chondrocytes and chondrons determined by micromanipulation and finite-element modelling
VolumeTitle: Journal of The Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: Chondrocyte and chondron biomechanics are important in diseases of articular cartilage but before this study (EPSRC Grant EP/C511735/1) there was a paucity of information about the mechanical behaviour and properties of such cells under large and direct deformations. Using micromanipulation it was found that chondrons were generally stiffer and showed less viscoelastic behaviour than chondrocytes and that the pericellular matrix (PCM) of the chondrons influenced their mechanical properties significantly. Knowing how the PCM influences responses to biomechanical compression is important for understanding chondron behaviour in cartilage.

Title: Molecular profiling of single cells in response to mechanical force: Comparison of chondrocytes, chondrons and encapsulated chondrocytes
AdditionalInformation: Tissue engineering of chondrocytes requires artificial matrices that mimic the mechanical strength and signalling behaviour of the chondron pericellular matrix (PCM). This paper describes investigations into the mechanical performance and mechanoresponsiveness of chondrocytes with and without PCM, and when the cells were encapsulated by chitosan and hyaluronan (EPSRC Grant EP/C511735/1). Some key genes showed significantly increased expression in both encapsulated chondrocytes and chondrons compared to chondrocytes. However, the expression in encapsulated chondrocytes did not reach the levels observed with chondrons. This paper shows that further work is needed if encapsulated chondrocytes are to replace chondrons in tissue engineering applications.

Title: Modelling the mechanical properties of yeast cell walls
AdditionalInformation: This paper from a BBSRC research student describes a new mathematical model for the compression of a single yeast cell between parallel flat surfaces. Yeast compression to failure results in large wall deformations with high strains and associated rotations, not taken into account in earlier models. The new model equations were based on more appropriate work-conjugate Kirchhoff stresses and Hencky strains. Fitting the wrong model equations to experimental data leads to erroneous values of wall material properties such as the elastic modulus so the new equations are an important step forward in understanding yeast biomechanics.

Title: Surface modification of chromatography adsorbents by low temperature low pressure plasma
AdditionalInformation: The output has led to an on-going academic collaboration with Dr James Walsh from the Department of Electrical Engineering and Electronics, University of Liverpool. Two more papers on the use of cold atmospheric plasmas to modify chromatography supports are in preparation and will be submitted to ‘Applied Physics Letters’ and the ‘Journal of Chromatography A’. Further, this output has led to a collaborative PhD project between the University of Birmingham and University College London funded by the Centre for Doctoral Training in the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Emergent Macromolecular Therapies.

Title: Serum Protein Controlled Nanoparticle Synthesis
AdditionalInformation: This is of great significance since it demonstrates that a multitude of minerals can exist in an amorphous – and hence almost undetectable state in biological fluids.   This suggests a mechanism for the formation of pathological mineralisations in vivo.  The paper also demonstrates the feasibility of using simple protein solutions to fabricate structures that otherwise would require high temperatures, aggressive solvents or expensive catalysts.  This concept has allowed us to secure funding from industry (Akzo Nobel/EPSRC funded studentship), form a spin-out company (NanuNanu Ltd.) and resulted in two filed patents (US 20120232164, US 2011/0117149 A1) and one granted (EP2076241A2).

Title: Reversible mitotic and metabolic inhibition following the encapsulation of fibroblasts in alginate hydrogels
AdditionalInformation: First report of how encapsulation in an alginate hydrogel inhibits cell proliferation, demonstrating that it is possible to isolate cells and release them so that they retain normal function.  This has formed the basis of a patch that may be used following heart attack (Hunt et al., Tissue Engineering 2013, 19, 905) and for skin regeneration (Hunt et al., Biotechnology Journal 2009, 4, 730).  We are currently investigating whether this approach can be used to prevent the proliferation of cancer cells.  The work was funded by the EU (NanoBioTact NMP4-CT-200403287) and was important in securing onward funding (NanoBioTouch - NMP4-SL-2009-228844).

Title: Shannon entropy for local and global description of mixing by Lagrangian particle tracking
AdditionalInformation: A new methodology based on the concept of Shannon entropy is developed for studying the local and global mixing performance in a batch stirred vessel, using Lagrangian particle tracking data.  Contrary to traditional ways of describing mixedness using global criteria, new local entropy mixing times enable rapid identification of the regions producing the fastest flow dispersion or reaching the fastest flow diversification, and the regions where both effects are fast.  Thus, for example, minimum mixing time locations for feed and withdrawal of material can be identified.  The work was supported by EPSRC (GR/S70517/01) and industry (P&G USA, Rhodia, Syngenta, ANSYS).

Title: Mixing of Dense Binary Suspensions: Multi-component Hydrodynamics and Spatial Phase Distribution by PEPT
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, it has been possible to accurately track by PEPT the different components of a binary solid-liquid mixture in a stirred vessel, making it possible to determine ‘non-invasively’ the full 3D velocity field and spatial distribution of the liquid phase and both solid components.  This is a radical approach to resolving the complex motion of different phase components in a polydisperse multiphase flow.  The work was supported by EPSRC (GR/S70517/01) and industry (P&G USA, Rhodia, Syngenta, ANSYS) and has led to a new EPSRC application to develop a new generation, more sensitive and accurate PEPT technique.

Title: Enhancing radial temperature uniformity and boundary layer development in viscous Newtonian and non-Newtonian flow by transverse oscillations: A CFD study
AdditionalInformation: Radial heat transfer in laminar pipe flow produces radially a non-uniform temperature distribution.  We use a validated CFD model to show for the first time that the superimposition of a transverse oscillatory motion on the steady laminar flow of a viscous Newtonian or non-Newtonian fluid, generates sufficient chaotic fluid motion which leads to considerable radial mixing and, thus, much better temperature uniformity. This also causes rapid development of the temperature profile axially, thus, reducing the thermal entrance length by a large factor.  A new PhD project is now looking at exploiting this idea in continuous food processing.

Title: Lagrangian Tools for the Analysis of Mixing in Single-Phase and Multiphase Flow Systems
AdditionalInformation: A set of novel theoretical and computational tools are developed for the analysis of single- and multi-phase Lagrangian flow data obtained from tracer trajectories in stirred vessels.  The power of these tools is demonstrated by analysing a wide range of measurements acquired using the technique of positron emission particle tracking during mixing of Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluids, as well as mixing of solid-liquid suspensions.  The work was supported by EPSRC (GR/S70517/01) and industry (P&G USA, Rhodia, Syngenta, ANSYS) and has led to a new EPSRC grant application for studying particle transport in fluids of complex rheology.

Title: Modelling of pore structure evolution during catalyst deactivation and comparison with experiment
AdditionalInformation: This work focuses on the mode and extent of deactivation of catalyst, used for heavy oil upgrading, in the presence and absence of supercritical fluid conditions which can alleviate coking by minimising the formation of coking precursors. Modelling such system gives rise to better understanding of catalysis chemistry and deactivation, which are vital factors in catalyst synthesis and process design. Through model verification, this paper provides pivotal information; an EPSRC Platform Grant is in preparation between Birmingham, Nottingham Universities, with international academic and industrial Collaborators in USA, Japan, and Korea entitled "Supercritical fluid technology from laboratory space to society benefit".

Title: Prolonging catalyst lifetime in supercritical isomerization of 1-hexene over a platinum/alumina catalyst
AdditionalInformation: This work addresses the urgent need for increased efficiency in utilising fossil energy sources and is concerned with upgrade of heavy crude oil. Having a prolonged catalytic life is a key aspect; with the double benefit of reducing the cost of catalytic replacement, and improving the reaction chemistry by reducing formation of ‘coking’ precursors.  This work is part of on-going collaborative programme between Chemical Engineering at Birmingham and Bath Universities (the Bath team is now at Nottingham).  We have engaged in talks with Saudi Aramco during the 2012 TechQuest R&D Symposium, 19-20 November, 2012, Paris with regards to exploitation.

Title: Diaryl ether synthesis in supercritical carbon dioxide in batch and continuous flow modes
AdditionalInformation: The key breakthrough of this work has been the successful translation from a reaction using volatile organic solvents to the use of supercritical carbon dioxide under continuous flow conditions in the presence of a solid phase reagent. The fact that such inherently nucleophilic processes can be carried out in CO2 is a remarkable. Paper involves collaboration with AstraZeneca and the Universities of Melbourne, Cambridge, Cornell and CSIRO, Australia. Work was funded by EPSRC (GR/R41927/01) and continues in the form of new research, papers and exchange visits with the institutions in Australia. The work also led to further EPSRC funding EP/H007784/1.

Title: Development of a hydrodynamic model for the UV-C inactivation of milk in a novel 'SurePure turbulator TM, swirl-tube reactor
AdditionalInformation: First use of Positron Emission Particle Tracking (PEPT) to determine average flow behaviour and RTD in a UV steriliser for the purpose of safe UV processing of food fluids.  Data used to develop a sterilisation model based on identified surface refreshment mechanisms, essential to ensure all fluid elements receive necessary UV-C dosage at lamp surface.   Model validated subsequently by sponsor (Surepure: contact Stephen Robinson – co-author) against microbiological data.  Work used to develop case for US FDA approval of use of device for sterilisation of high opacity food fluids by sponsor and has led to further consultancy work with Simmons.

Title: Preparation and CO2 adsorption of amine modified Mg-AI LDH via exfoliation route
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the novel preparation of a CO2 adsorbent based on amine grafted layered double hydroxides.  Adsorption could present a lower energy route to carbon dioxide capture from point sources such as power plants.  The current work describes the development, characterisation and testing of a new adsorbent for this application.  The work was supported by EPSRC (EP/G061785/1 ) and E.ON Power.  Birmingham developed and tested the adsorbents, further thermogravimetric studies were carried out by Drage and Stevens (University of Nottingham).  The work has led to several collaborative programmes between Birmingham and Nottingham in carbon capture and energy (EP/I010955/1, EP/J000361/1).

Title: Hydrogenation of 2-pentyne over Pd/Al2O3 catalysts: Effect of operating variables and solvent selection
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports the effect of engineering parameters stirring speed, hydrogen pressure, substrate concentration, catalyst preparation method and solvent upon the selectivity during 2-pentyne hydrogenation in a stirred vessel.  It demonstrates that selection of suitable conditions and catalyst formulation can have a substantial influence upon the product distribution, in addition to the surface chemistry.  The work was sponsored by EPSRC (GR/R544583/01), Johnson Matthey and involves authors from industry (Prof. Hugh Stitt) and University of Glasgow (R. Spence, Prof. S.D. Jackson).  The work has been exploited by Johnson Matthey to advise their customers how to design and operate reactors.

Title: Coke Formation and Characterization During 1-Hexene Isomerization and Oligomerization over H-ZSM-5 Catalyst under Supercritical Conditions
AdditionalInformation: The  ability of supercritical fluids to prolong catalyst lifetime by delaying coking is reported.  The more detailed characterization of the pore structure of the coked catalyst using specially developed nitrogen sorption and percolation analysis is the novel aspect.  This illustrates the detailed changes that occur to pore accessibility and connectivity as a function of aging under supercritical conditions and informs how the lifetime of industrial catalysts could be extended.  The work was sponsored by EPSRC (EP/D503892/1) and includes Dr Sean Rigby from the University of Nottingham as co-author.  A further EPSRC grant with Dr Rigby has been recently submitted (EP/K03524X/1).

Title: Modified zeolite catalyst for selective dialkylation of naphthalene
AdditionalInformation:
Dialkylated naphthalenes are of great commercial interest in the manufacture of polyethylenenaphthalate (PEN) polymers and copolymers which have uses as ﬁbers, ﬁlms, resins,
and engineering plastics. This work has demonstrated an environmentally and economically viable method for efficient selective alkylation of naphthalene over modiﬁed zeolites. The work was presented at the 22nd International Symposium on Chemical Reaction Engineering has since led to a joint venture with Prof Behbahani from the Petroleum University of Technology, Ahwaz, Iran in the application of methanol to hydrocarbon technology.

Title: Isothermal and temperature gradient supercritical fluid extraction and fractionation of squalene from palm fatty acid distillate using compressed carbon dioxide
AdditionalInformation: This work concerns recovery of high value nutraceuticals at 100% purity using fractionation technology with a benign solvent (CO2). The novelty of this work lies in independent temperature control along the sections of the fractionation column; controlling it in this manner provides full control over the product quality.  This principle is now being applied to CO2 reaction systems for Carbon Capture: this paper provides the foundation for an upcoming collaboration as part of the Geo-Engineering Programme with Earth Sciences at Oxford (Dr Tim Kruger), Cambridge Carbon Capture and Southampton University; for the carbonisation of Olivine for CO2 sequestration.

Title: Effect of pH on deagglomeration and rheology/morphology of aqueous suspensions of goethite nanopowder
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, we were able to demonstrate that the viscosity of very dilute Newtonian suspensions of goethite nanoparticles increases by five/six orders of magnitude and they become strongly shear thinning in response to change of pH.  Results obtained on novel design of rheometer enabling visualisation of morphology under shear developed in conjunction with Malvern Instruments (patent filed in USA) enabled explanation of such behaviour.  A BBSRC research project was funded on behaviour of stem cells in two phase gelling aqueous –aqueous systems as a result of this work (BB/K010999/1).

Title: Manufacturing of agarose-based chromatographic adsorbents - Effect of ionic strength and cooling conditions on particle structure and mechanical strength.
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: The pore size distributions are key property determining the quality of any type of adsorbent. In close collaboration with Millipore UK Ltd, the effect of processing conditions on pore size in sub-millimetre adsorbent particles was investigated by direct measurements using ATM and indirectly using micromanipulation technique. This is the first paper in open literature examining the effect of ionic strength and cooling conditions on the microstructure of micron-sized agarose beads and the results were utilised by Millipore.  This paper led to funded BBSRC grant application (BB/KO11111/1).

Title: Generation of Hydrogen Gas during the Catalytic Oxidation of Sodium Lignosulfonate to Vanillin: Initial Results
AdditionalInformation: For the first time since 1936 when the vanillin manufacture from lignosulphonate was developed, the composition of the gas phase in the scale down version of commercial reactor  (pH =14, P=11 bar, T=180C) was investigated. It was found that whenever vanillin was produced, hydrogen was produced, considering the high process pH this is very unusual.  These results have guided the largest vanillin manufacturing company in the world in operation of their process (Borregaard: Oysten Loe – co-author) as the industrial oxidation is carried out under the same conditions but in a larger reactor.

Title: Study on sub-critical water mediated hydrolysis of Miscanthus a lignocellulosic biomass
AdditionalInformation: Lignocellulosic biomass is a key source for second generation biofuels. A sub-critical water mediated process designed to delignify Miscanthus (lignocellulose biomass) was used, generating a cellulose fraction free of potential fermentation inhibitors.  This is a vital step to production of bioethanol and sulphur free lignin. The project was sponsored by EPSRC Industrial CASE studentship with Phytatec Ltd and was a featured Case-Study in the Chemistry Innovation KTN. The results have led to a grant application via FAPESP in Brazil and BBSRC where sugar cane baggase will be used as the feed stock.

Title: Solubility Measurements and Analysis of Binary, Ternary and Quaternary Systems of Palm Olein, Squalene and Oleic Acid in Supercritical Carbon Dioxide
AdditionalInformation: The chemical and pharmaceutical industries rely on vegetable oils and their distillates from oil refining as one of the main sources of valuable components such as squalene, vitamins, sterols and fatty acids. The work evaluated the solubility of lipid components typically found in palm oil including Palm fatty acid distillate (PFAD) and successfully demonstrated that the Supercritical-CO2 extraction of squalene from PFAD is feasible especially when the feedstock material has a low free fatty acids concentration. The work was sponsored by IoI Loders Croklaan in the Netherlands, one of the world’s leading suppliers of sustainable palm oil.

Title: Modelling the extraction of soil contaminants with supercritical carbon dioxide.
AdditionalInformation: The development of a novel process for non-invasive in situ sampling and analysis of contaminants in soil was achieved. The excellent correlation between sCO2 extraction and pollutant availability allowed sCO2 to become the basis for a risk based assessment system in real environments. This technology is showing considerable promise as a tool for the long term monitoring of CO2 reservoir stability in relation to long term carbon capture and storage programmes. Two patents have been granted GB2429059 and US767733. The work was sponsored by TSB (TP/5/CON/6/I/H0570D) in partnership with PJH Partnerships, Pera Innovations, Crowcon, Dando Drilling and Lankelma.

Title: The effect of stator geometry on the flow pattern and energy dissipation rate in a rotor–stator mixer
AdditionalInformation: For the first time it has been shown by full 3D numerical simulations verified by experimental data (LDA) that in certain designs of stators used in Silverson mixers, the liquid in the bulk flows in the opposite direction to the rotor rotation.  Those results were used by Silverson to optimise the shape and size of the openings in the stators and to improve inherently difficult bulk mixing in batch systems.  Work carried out by Unilever sponsored EngD student [contact Mike Baker: co-author].

Title: A novel approach to understanding and modelling performance evolution of catalysts during their initial operation under reaction conditions – Case study of vanadium phosphorus oxides for n-butane selective oxidation
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis: B Enzymatic
AdditionalInformation: Novel methodology presented for development of validated models for conditioning and activation steps for industrial catalysts using combined parallel difference testing and kinetic modelling.  First attempt at general methodology which can be used to explain fundamental chemical and morphological changes in catalyst activity following start-up and these approaches have been used for a model (VPO) catalyst system; changes in selectivity and activity as the catalyst approaches steady-state operation explained by new two site kinetic model.  Work carried out by Johnson Matthey sponsored EngD student (Wilkinson) and methodologies being extended to other systems by the industrial sponsor (contact Hugh Stitt  co-author).

Title: Improving Selectivity in 2-Butyne-1,4-diol Hydrogenation using Biogenic Pt Catalysts
AdditionalInformation: The paper brings together several novel areas of study including the preparation of platinum nanoparticles using bacterial support, chemical cleaning and characterisation of the particles by cyclic voltammetry.  It reports for the first time the use of redisual bacterial biomass to improve selectivity in a hydrogenation reaction.  It highlights the potential to replace lead containing Lindlar catalysts with “greener” alternatives.  Birmingham tested catalysts in collaboration with Cardiff carrying out spectroscopy (Prof. Gary Attard, EPSRC grant EP/I007806/1).  A further EPSRC grant is in preparation and a patent has been filed on related work Biologically Derived PdAu Catalyst (PB140008GB).

Title: A Laplacian-based algorithm for non-isothermal atomistic-continuum hybrid simulation of micro and nano-flows
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: In recent years, a large number of new models have been proposed in the area of atomistic-continuum hybrid modelling for nano/microfluidics. The majority of these studies only consider momentum transport or, in a few cases, heat transport. None of them can handle multi-component system. The Laplacian Method is introduced in this paper: a framework for all transport phenomena. This is the only available hybrid method of this type with this capability. The formal extension to multicomponent systems is going to be published in another paper, but the foundation of the method was discussed, for the first time, in this article.

Title: Liquid–gas flow patterns in a narrow electrochemical channel
AdditionalInformation: This article deals with the hydrodynamics of narrow electrochemical chlorate cells with gas evolution. Chlorates production is a multibillion industry with several hundred million tons of chlorates produced yearly. The work shows that, contrary to the popular belief, the flow in these cells is usually not turbulent and this can make a lot of difference in the industrial design of these reactors. Dr. Wanngård (co-author), research leader of Akzo Nobel – Sweden, a renowned authority in the field who has worked for more than 35 years in this industry, has judged these results as revolutionary.

Title: Molecular dynamic simulations of carbon nanotubes in CO2 atmosphere
AdditionalInformation: Today the idea of carbon dioxide removal using carbon nanotube is widespread. The main interest is related to carbon capture as a potential means of mitigating the contribution of fossil fuel emissions to global warming. This publication is the first modelling work at the molecular dynamics level in this field. It opened the way for many other studies in the field such as, to cite one example from the UK, the work of Prof. Drikakis’ group at Cranfield University.

Title: Comparison between CFD calculations of the flow in a rotating disk cell and the Cochran/Levich equations
AdditionalInformation: The Levich Equation models diffusion and flow conditions around a Rotating disk electrode; it was proposed in 1954 and since then uncritically used in countless electrochemical studies. This work questions the general validity of some assumptions underlying the Levich equation. This paper shows that, despite its widespread use, it must be employed with caution and its misuse can bring to significant errors. After sixty years the Levich equation was originally proposed, the precise limits of its validity have been determined for the first time.

Title: Improved biodiesel manufacture at low temperature and short reaction time
AdditionalInformation: Biodiesel is produced from plant or vegetable oils and fats by transesterification with an alcohol.  In this work, the sunflower oil transesterification reaction with alcohol was successfully carried out in a Downflow Liquid Contactor Reactor (DLCR). High yields of 96.5 wt% (ester content) were obtained in a very short period of time 2.5 min at 40 °C when compared to other processes. Also it does not require washing with water unlike in other biodiesel processes as the separation of the biodiesel from glycerol was carried by gravity. The work was sponsored by WRK Ltd and the Kuwait government.

Title: Use of angle resolved PIV to estimate local specific energy dissipation rates for up- and down-pumping pitched blade agitators in a stirred tank
AdditionalInformation: First attempt to integrate total power dissipated in a stirred tank via PIV using various calculation methodologies for energy dissipation.  Results are favourable with sub-grid-scale models with appropriate changes in constants, compared with the measured power input to the fluid calculated from the impeller power number.  Interest in paper led to three studentships by Johnson Matthey for complementary mixing studies.  The approach to calculate energy dissipation developed in this paper will be used to determine turbulence modulation in separated and dispersed two phase flows carried out as part of a new EPSRC Programme Grant in multiphase flows (MEMPHIS).

Title: The flow of liquid foods in an agitated vessel using PEPT: Implications for the use of TTI to assess thermal treatment
AdditionalInformation: Time Temperature Integrators (TTI) have been used extensively in solid foods but extension to thermal processed fluid foods requires assurance that their flow path is representative of the fluid.  For the first time, PEPT is used to determine the relative differences between the flow paths of the fluid and TTI for fluids of varying rheology in a scaled-down model of an industrial thermal food process vessel.  Validity of the TTIs is demonstrated over a rheology range representative of starch based food fluids.  The work was sponsored by Briggs of Burton giving improved knowledge of the operation of their vessels.

Title: Supercritical water oxidation of nitrogen compounds with multi-injection of oxygen
AdditionalInformation: This work shows for the first time that multi-injection of oxygen into N-containing hydrocarbons in supercritical waste treatment units improves the destruction of these compounds by at least 20%.  This ground-breaking technology for a complex class of carcinogenic wastes has led to a patent application in 2012 (GB123031472-ZSR811). Moreover, the work was conducted in collaboration with Prof. Portela (co-author, University of Cadiz, Spain), a world leader in supercritical water pilot plant technology, and has led to a visiting 10-month PDRA and internal University funding to initiate collaboration with the group Prof Phil Savage (UMich, USA).

Title: PEPT and discrete particle simulation study of spout-fluid bed regimes
AdditionalInformation: International collaborative research with Hans Kuipers' group at Twente (co-author, now at Eindhoven) sponsored by industry (Yara Sluiskil BV).  Data obtained using PEPT has been used to validate CFD models for the coupling between the discrete (particles) and continuous phases (gas) in a spouted bed.  PEPT is uniquely able to provide validation data in this way – providing information on particle-particle and particle-wall collision phenomena.  Work led to British Council NWO funding for Wood (co-author) to visit Twente to build further collaborations.

Title: Granular flow fields in vertical high shear mixer granulators
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration with the Particles Group at University of Leeds (Ghadiri, co-author) on EPSRC (GR/S25029) and multiple industry sponsored (P and G, Hosokawa Micron, Pfizer and Borax Europe) project to investigate the particle motion and mixing time in a conical high-shear granulator using PEPT.  Data provides critical information of scale-up of such devices, demonstrating constant tip speed as a relevant scale-up criterion which can be used by industry.

Title: An Electrically Reversible Switchable Surface to Control and Study Early Bacterial Adhesion Dynamics in Real-Time
AdditionalInformation: We have developed the first real-time based assay for monitoring and analysing the passage between reversible and non-reversible bacterial cell adhesion. The work funded by the European Community Framework Programme 7 opens new opportunities to advance our understanding of cell adhesion processes. The partnership initiated during this work between the School of Chemical Engineering, University of Birmingham and the National ESCA and Surface Analysis Center for Biomedical Problems, a National Institutes of Health (NIH) Supported Resource Center, University of Washington, US has been recognised by an UK-US Development Award in 2012.

Title: Microscopic interpretation of granule strength in liquid media
AdditionalInformation: The novelty of this collaborative work with the University of Sheffield was to develop a theoretical basis for understanding some of the key factors that are important in the dispersion, and hence dissolution, of granules in liquid media. The focus was to delineate the role of wetting on the mechanical properties of model granules with well-defined interparticle autodhesive bonding. Measurements of the Young’s modulus and strength were carried out in aqueous propanol solutions since the attenuation of the van der Waals interactions is a function of the concentration.  The results were interpreted using theoretical micromechanical models.

Title: Spin-on carbon based on fullerene derivatives as hardmask materials for high-aspect-ratio etching
VolumeTitle: Journal of Micro/Nanolithography, MEMS, and MOEMS
AdditionalInformation: As lithographic features have shrunk it has become necessary to use thinner photoresist, constraining etch aspect ratio. We have developed and patented an ultra-low-hydrogen content fullerene-based underlayer that successfully addresses problems in trilayer etching, one of the fastest growing areas of the semiconductor industry. Our material demonstrates internationally leading etch performance. The work was supported by EPSRC and Industrial funding. The patent licensee (Irresistible Materials) has developed a product and three semiconductor companies (Commercially Confidential; Names held by University and Irresistible Materials) have begun evaluations. A university (Commercially Confidential) has also entered an agreement to collaborate on development of variants.

Title: Hierarchical electrohydrodynamic structures for surface-enhanced raman scattering
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the first use of hierarchical electrohydrodynamic (HEHD) patterning to fabricate reliable, low-cost, surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS)-based devices.  This is a straightforward method to generate well-defined multi-scale devices in a tuneable manner.  Formed structures are effectively tailored as SERS platforms with enhanced sensitivity and specificity while offering distinct advantages for sensing applications.  Each of the individual HEHD structures on the SERS-based device can be used to detect a different molecular species.  Such devices herald the realization of point-of-care diagnostics vital for environmental monitoring and security.  Paper was highlighted via cover story article in Advanced Optical Materials.

Title: Thermal Convection and Temperature Inhomogeneity in a Vibrofluidized Granular Bed: The Influence of Sidewall Dissipation
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration with multi-scale mechanics group at Twente (Rivas, co-author) to elucidate sidewall interactions with particles in a vibrating fluidized bed.  Work has shown, for the first time, that sidewall dissipation influences various properties of the bed and critically that these effects are non-local and influence bulk flow behaviour away from the walls.

Title: Numerical and experimental study on multiple-spout fluidized beds
AdditionalInformation: International collaborative research with Hans Kuipers' group at Twente (co-author, now at Eindhoven).  Paper focuses on modelling of an industrially-important (sponsor Yara Sluiskil BV) multiple spouted fluidised bed, using PEPT data to validate CFD models for the coupling between the discrete (particles) and continuous phases (gas) – the Discrete Phase Model –DPM.  The PEPT data on the particle motion revealed for the first time a new type of flow regime which may be critical for understanding aspects of granulation.

Title: Predicting the pressure distribution during roll compaction from uniaxial compaction measurements
VolumeTitle: 9th International Symposium on Agglomeration/4th International Granulation Workshop, Jun 24-26, 2009.  Sheffield, England
AdditionalInformation: Pfizer funded this research since they required a simple method to compare the expected pressure distributions of different feed-powder formulations for roll compaction; this process is used to produce ribbons that are milled to form granules for tableting presses. This was achieved by the use of confined uniaxial compaction and incorporating a different pressure-volume relationship in the Johanson model of roll compaction. In addition, the critical limitations of the Johanson model were identified, which is being used as a basis for developing a more advanced model of roll compaction for a AstraZeneca funded postdoc project.

Title: Supercritical carbon dioxide as a solvent for deposition of a tailored dye in dye sensitized solar cells
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a new technique whereby dyes can be deposited onto metal oxide surfaces using supercritical carbon dioxide for use in solar cell applications. This eliminates the need for hazardous organic solvents and waste solvents and has reduced time and energy in the process. This paper is a result of an on-going collaboration with the University of Melbourne and CSIRO, Melbourne, Australia (Prof Andy Holmes FRS, co author). The work forms part of the Victorian Organic Solar Cells Consortium funded by Australian Solar Institute and the Victorian State Government Departments of Business and Innovation.

Title: Co-extrusion of multilayered ceramic micro-tubes for use as solid oxide fuel cells
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a methodology for the manufacture of self-supporting solid oxide fuel cell elements by continuous co-extrusion.  It discusses the calculation of the pressure drop through a manifold die to produce a functionally graded material of five layers from a nickel-zirconia cermet to pure zirconia electrolyte.  Of particular note is the equation for double convergent flow.  This allowed in combination with knowledge presented in a separate paper the manufacture of integral multi-layer tubes with 250 micron wall thickness.  The technology is being used for the development of other functional material systems (beta-alumina, cutting tools and carbons).

Title: Effect of incorporation of zirconia layer upon physical and mechanical properties of investment casting ceramic shell
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel method for control of investment casting shell strength particularly addressing the weakening of the shell after casting to prevent defect formation during solidification; this project was in collaboration with Rolls Royce (co-author Paul Withey).   Zirconia undergoes a phase transition which results in a contraction on heating and an expansion on cooling. As damage by contraction is repaired during sintering the shell is strong enough to cast but on cooling the expansion at the phase change causes the shell to fail.  This work led to an EngD project and several commercially evaluated formulations.

Title: Mechanical properties of single alginate microspheres determined by microcompression and finite element modelling
AdditionalInformation: Paper presents novel experimental data obtained using a powerful micromanipulation technique combined with finite element analysis to determine intrinsic viscoelastic properties of biocompatible materials, which were independently validated by experiments. It sets a standard approach to characterize viscoelastic materials with a porous structure. Work funded by an EPSRC grant (EP/C511735/1) and has led to collaboration with Dr Pawel Sikorski’s group, Department of Physics, Norwegian University of Science and Technology. Two journal papers and one conference paper have been jointly published with Dr Pawel Sikorski’s group, and a grant for further collaboration has been awarded by the Research Council of Norway.

Title: Determination of the Elastic Properties of Compressed Microcapsules Using Finite Element Modelling
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel approach to determine shell thickness and Young’s modulus of single microcapsules with a core-shell structure from micromanipulation measurements and finite element modelling (FEM), which have been independently validated by experiments. The work was funded by an EPSRC grant (EP/F068395/1), and the approach has been taken to analyse micromanipulation data generated from compression of various single microcapsules provided by Procter & Gamble, which has revealed how formulation and processing conditions can affect the thickness and stiffness of microcapsule shells. The results have been used to optimize formulation and processing of new P&G products containing microcapsules.

Title: Compression of elastic-perfectly plastic microcapsules using micromanipulation and finite element modelling: Determination of the yield stress
AdditionalInformation: Paper presents detailed analysis of small to medium deformations of single microcapsules under compression to determine the yield stress of their shell material. The work demonstrates that the shell of dry melamine formaldehyde microcapsules behaved as an elastic–perfectly plastic material, which is crucial to fully determination of their stress-strain relationship until failure. The work was funded by an EPSRC grant (EP/F068395/1), and resulted from collaboration between Birmingham and Procter & Gamble, USA and Encapsys, USA. The results can be used to interpret the behaviour of the microcapsules in various processing equipment and during the end-use applications.

Title: Failure of elastic-plastic core-shell microcapsules under compression
AdditionalInformation: Paper presents a systematic approach for the first time to fully model force versus displacement data from compression of single microcapsules to rupture and to determine intrinsic mechanical property parameters including elastic limit, yield stress, plastic modulus, strain and stress at rupture and where the rupture in the shell occurs. It describes the stress and strain distributions within the shell of microcapsules under compression using an elastic-perfectly plastic model with strain hardening.The work was funded by an EPSRC grant (EP/F068395/1), and the approach can be exploited to formulation microcapsules with better controlled release of their core materials by mechanical forces.

Title: Twin screw wet granulation: The study of a continuous twin screw granulator using Positron Emission Particle Tracking (PEPT) technique.
VolumeTitle: European Journal of Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
AdditionalInformation: Continuous twin screw granulation is a relatively new technique that is gaining rapid ground in the pharmaceutical industry and is considered one of the underpinning technologies for implementation of Quality-by-Design.  This work used a specially modified granulator to enable PEPT to be used for the first time to observe particle motion in continuous twin screw granulation. The paper presented a unique and insightful analysis of the flow that improves understanding of the mixing and transport processes.  The work has led to a CASE award studentship with Astra Zeneca.  The work was funded by the Overseas Research Student Awards Scheme.

Title: Tailoring 3D Single-Walled Carbon Nanotubes Anchored to Indium Tin Oxide for Natural Cellular Uptake and Intracellular Sensing
AdditionalInformation: We have presented the first intracellular electrochemical sensor based on carbon nanotubes, providing an unprecedented opportunity to monitor intracellular events in real-time. Its importance in advancing fundamental biological and clinical science has been recognised by being selected to feature as a cover article in the prestigious Nano Letters journal. The work was funded by Leverhulme Trust and performed in collaboration with Prof Simon Jackson, Centre for Research in Translational Biomedicine, University of Plymouth.

Title: Rheological studies of polycaprolactone in supercritical CO2
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the first reptation studies to be conducted on polymers in the presence of scCO2. There have been numerous papers on the thermal and physical effects of CO2 on polymers but nothing at the molecular level. This is a new collaboration with Howdle (Chemistry) and Shakesheff (Pharmacy) at the University of Nottingham. The work was funded by the European Commission (FP7-PLA-FOAM project number 232145) and has led to a follow-on project funded by the European Commission (ISA-PACK, project number 289521, replacement of clingfilm with a biodegradable alternative).

Title: Model Organic Surfaces to Probe Marine Bacterial Adhesion Kinetics by Surface Plasmon Resonance
AdditionalInformation: Understanding how bacteria adhere to a surface is a critical step in the development of novel materials and coatings to prevent bacteria forming biofilms. Surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy (SPR), in combination with self-assembled monolayers that have different backbone structures and/or functional groups, was used for the first time to study in real-time the initial stages of bacterial adhesion to surfaces. Apart from giving insights into the bacterial adhesion kinetics, this study provided crucial detail on the effect of extracellular polymeric substances-EPS on bacterial adhesion in a single assay. The work was funded by the European Community Framework Programme 7.

Title: Tuning Specific Biomelecular Interactions Using Electro-Switchable Oligopeptiede Surfaces
AdditionalInformation: Under a Leverhulme Trust grant, we have pioneered the use of molecular mechanical motion of surface-bound electro-switchable molecules at the nanometre scale to induce ON-OFF switching of biomolecular activity. Such surface technology is of great theoretical interest and practical impact in the biomedical and biotechnology fields. As a result of this work, a collaborative research program, funded by Wellcome Trust, has been established with Birmingham Women’s Hospital, where critical cellular mechanisms, that when defective cause significant and diverse diseases such as infertility, are being uniquely investigated.

Title: Positron emission particle tracking as a method to map the movement of particles in the pulp and froth phases
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, positron emission particle tracking (PEPT) has enabled the motion of fine particles in the pulp and froth phases of flotation cells to be determined in a non-invasive manner; this enables maximisation of recovery of lower grade ores which are nowadays being processed.   Work has formed basis of collaboration with McGill University (RAEng exchange for Prof Finch, world flotation expert) and use of PEPT to examine other minerals unit operations including milling (4 further papers submitted). Work has led to a £100k TSB grant with IMERYS on the development of a pilot scale vertically stirred media mill.

Title: Adsorption of heavy metals from acid mine drainage by natural zeolite
AdditionalInformation: This paper pioneers use of natural zeolite, a low cost, high functionality material, to adsorb heavy metals from acid mine drainage (AMD).  Work has resulted in further PhD support from EPSRC and industry (Harsco/Tata Steel). Pilot scale-up studies are planned and commercial development of the technology is being discussed with NERC and industry (Harsco/Tarmac/Rocktron). Paper has been widely read across the minerals processing and environmental engineering sectors and has provoked international interest from Zambian Government leading to a further Commonwealth sponsored PhD project (seconded lecturer from University of Zambia, Department of Metallurgy)

Title: Modification of ilmenite surface chemistry for enhancing surfactants adsorption and bubble attachment
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation:
Modification of ilmenite surface chemistry for enhancing surfactants adsorption and bubble attachment - Rowson, Neil
Paper has been of interest to flotation reagent industry and has resulted in further froth flotation studies being funded at the University.- for example TSB project on the recovery of Kish graphite from steel waste via froth flotation techniques which started  October 2012. The work has also been developed into techniques to recover Lithium Micas from kaolin waste funded by EPSRC and IMERYS.

Title: Fullerene Resist Materials for the 32 nm Node and Beyond
AdditionalInformation: Introduces a novel non-polymeric fullerene based molecular photoresist capable of recording patterns at feature sizes of 25nm with industrial speed. Molecular resists are of increasing interest to the lithography community as the small molecular size over traditional polymeric resists offers advantages for nanopatterning, whilst the high carbon content of fullerene give excellent etching characteristics. The work was supported by EPSRC, EU and Industrial funding. It led to a patent (GB0420702.3) and to the formation of a spin out company (Irresistible Materials Ltd), which has subsequently licensed the patent, raised venture capital and is now commercializing the product.

Title: Direct Electron-Beam Writing of Highly Conductive Wires in Functionalized Fullerene Films
AdditionalInformation: It has previously been shown that the conductivity of pure C60 can be manipulated using incident radiation. Here we demonstrate that films of fullerene derivatives, which give significant processing advantages over C60 can be converted in a controlled manner from highly insulating to highly conductive, and simultaneously topographically patterned allowing the creation of conductive microstructures. The work was supported by the EPSRC and EU. It led to a patent (GB0913919.7), which has subsequently been licensed.

Title: Fabrication of co-axial field emitter tips for scanning probe energy loss spectroscopy
AdditionalInformation: This work combined a number of microfabrication techniques in an innovative manner to create a coaxially screened high aspect-ratio microfabricated tip. The tip showed exceptionally stable field emission compared to a standard tungsten tip, and was used successfully to significantly improve signal level in scanning probe electron loss spectroscopy (SPELS). The tip was also used in subsequent scanning tunneling microscopy and SPELS work published in Physical Review B. This paper was the Cover Image. It was supported by EPSRC and AWM. The SPELS equipment/technique has been licensed to a company (Interface Spectra) and is now subject of further commercial development.

Title: Developing mechanistic understanding of granular behaviour in complex moving geometry using the Discrete Element Method Part B: Investigation of flow and mixing in the Turbula (R) mixer
AdditionalInformation: This paper concerns application of a modelling technique (DEM) to a solids mixing process (the Turbula) wherein a mixing vessel undergoes a complex 3D motion subjecting the vessel contents to thorough and rapid mixing.  This is the first time that such a complex movement has been incorporated in a DEM model.  Novelty also lies in the analysis of the output from the model, and the development of mixing criteria that are unique to the DEM technique but translatable to what could be measured experimentally.  The work was supported by an EU Marie Curie fellowship and Johnson Matthey  (co-author, Stitt).

Title: Effect of packing fraction on granular jetting from solid sphere entry into aerated and fluidized beds
AdditionalInformation: Granular jetting occurs when a solid sphere impacts the surface of a granular bed – the collapse of the cavity following penetration gives rise to a high speed vertical jet.  Under certain circumstances this is followed by a thicker, slower jet.  In exploring the factors that affect jet formation and attempting to explain the observations, the paper gives useful insight into the complex rheology of granular systems and for the first time, how this is affected by packing fraction and aeration.  The student (Marston) has continued on this topic via a collaboration with KAUST (Saudi Arabia).

Title: Investigation of the effect of impeller rotation rate, powder flow rate, and cohesion on powder flow behavior in a continuous blender using PEPT
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the output from a transatlantic collaboration between the University of Birmingham and Rutgers University, New Jersey, funded by the NSF and supported by the EPSRC Platform Grant.  The novelty of the work is the application of PEPT to a continuous powder process and the unique data generated that can be used to characterise powder mixing processes – in particular those parameters such as dispersion coefficients necessary for developing and validating models.  The work has led to further application of PEPT in continuous pharmaceutical processing, seen as an enabling tool for the implementation of process analytical technology.

Title: Maldistribution of fluids in extrudates
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper discusses the phenomena of phase migration during paste extrusion.  A model system comprising micro ballotini and a highly viscous Newtonian fluid was used to map the mass balance and pressure drop with time.  The simplicity of the paste system was deliberate to allow verification of soil mechanics models – a rapid re-meshing algorithm was an offshoot of this work.  The knowledge gained here has been used to develop robust formulations for industry and further studies on the influence of polymer chain length on phase migration are part of an EngD project on carbon extrusion funded by Mast Carbon.

Title: The role of zircon particle size distribution, surface area and contamination on the properties of silica-zircon ceramic materials
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: Zircon is a natural refractory used extensively in the manufacturing of ceramics used in the investment casting of turbine components. It has long been speculated that zircon acts as a grain growth inhibitor but also that it is a nucleation site for the development of cristobalite.  In this paper we shown that it is the contaminants that influence the behaviour to a greater extent and that zircon does not influence the crystallisation of silica during sintering.  The work has led to two EngD studentships with Rolls-Royce on developing understanding in model zircon systems and turning the knowledge gained into practice.

Title: Application of Colloid Probe Atomic Force Microscopy to the Adhesion of Thin Films of Viscous and Viscoelastic Silicone Fluids
AdditionalInformation: The work was fully funded by Unilever R&D to understand the influence on adhesion of the physical properties, and hence the molecular architecture, of silicone fluids; such fluids are widely used in their hair products. This required the development of a novel analytical nonlinear viscoelastic model to rationalise the data; the existing analytical models were limited to viscous fluids or using numerical techniques such as finite element analysis, which limit their use in industry. The work has led to further funding by Unilever on the influence of silicone fluids on the behaviour of inter-hair fibre contacts.

Title: Principles of a micro squeeze flow rheometer for the analysis of extremely small volumes of liquid
AdditionalInformation: The novelty of this work was to develop a method for measuring the storage and loss moduli of very small samples (1 – 10 nL) up to a maximum frequency that is an order of magnitude greater than is possible using a conventional cone and plate rheometer. It was funded by Unilever R&D in order to provide a method that is capable of measuring small volumes of expensive research materials. The work formed the basis of further Unilever funded project on analysing the adhesion of silicone fluids using atomic force microscopy.

Title: The electrochemical detection and characterization of silver nanoparticles in aqueous solution
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented a novel method of identifying and characterizing any oxidisable metal nanoparticle in suspended solution, funded by The Leverhulme Trust for a project to develop means to monitor environmental nanoparticle pollution and patented under (PCT/GB2012/050371). The key result was that metal nanoparticles could be exhaustively oxidised during an impact with an electrode and yield information on the metal identity, and nanoparticle size. Following on from this paper, more than 20 papers have been produced by the authors exploiting this phenomenon, and additional funding secured in excess of £2M.

Title: Microcracking in electron beam deposited scandia-stabilised zirconia electrolyte
AdditionalInformation: The paper was prepared within a cooperation with the Institute for Problems in Materials Sciences (IPMS), Kyiv (Ukraine), in which we applied functional layers of an anode supported SOFC cells (ASC) by Electron Beam Physical Vapour Deposition (EB-PVD).  Part of the Kyiv work concerned modelling the cracking behaviour of layers. Our contribution was the transfer of the expertise necessary in producing the PVD layers, testing their gas tightness and finally validating the results in SOFC cell tests in Juelich.   The activity has fed into a continued cooperation on novel type SOFC cells with high performance between UoB and IPMS.

Title: Responsive Core−Shell Latex Particles as Colloidosome Microcapsule Membranes
AdditionalInformation: A new method for creating colloidosome structures is discovered and evaluated. It offers a robust and scalable manufacturing route for assembling ‘smart’ microcapsules, whose payloads can be released through temperature control. The novelty of the method is described, most significantly enabled by use of an internal cross-linking method to create a coherent dense and single-layered stimulus-responsive membrane on an emulsion droplet templates. The paper reveals the elegance and functionality of the colloidosome cages that can be created. The research reported here has also resulted in a granted patent, that has found industrial and biomedical application.

Title: Production of solid-stabilised emulsions through rotational membrane emulsification: influence of particle adsorption kinetics
AdditionalInformation: Continuing pioneering work on production of coarse emulsions using a rotating membrane manufacturing method, this paper quantifies the rate of addition of nanoscale particle-stabilisers on emulsion droplet size and  stability.  Such systems are relevant to product formulation in the personal products and food sectors. The paper demonstrates that coarse emulsion can be produced using particulates as surfactants, and how these can be optimised to yield monodisperse systems. The paper elucidates the mechanisms of the control process.

Title: Predictions of porosity and fluid distribution through nonspherical-packed columns
AdditionalInformation: A digital packing algorithm developed by the authors is used to gain fundamental understanding of the packing characteristics of industrial (asymmetric) packing. The subsequent fluid flow characteristics within the packing in then computed directly using a lattice Boltzman model using the same digital framework. This also enables the pressure drop through the bed to be directly computed for design purposes hence providing a direct link, through simulation, of particle packing shape and packing method on process operation. The methodology developed and demonstrated has generic application in the chemical process industry for process design and creation of new packing.

Title: On line analysis of structure of dispersions in an oscillatory baffled reactor using electrical impedance tomography
AdditionalInformation: The first application of electrical impedance tomography to elucidate fluid flow dynamics in an oscillatory baffled reactor demonstrates how three-dimensional cross-correlation of pixel data can be used to capture velocity information of the dispersed liquid phase. The paper brings together advanced instrumentation that is customised for insertion in a process-scale continuous reactor and used to analyse a complex process system to enable optimisation of process operation, in this case relating to the use of baffled reactors to formulate emulsions.

Title: An integrated system for thermal power generation, electrical energy storage and CO2 capture
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a highly innovative peak-shaving technology based on the integration of power generation, cryogenic energy storage and CO2 capture. The work demonstrates the potential of the novel technology with power-generation efficiency as high as 70% including energy consumption for carbon capture. This is approximately 50% higher than other carbon capture technologies proposed so far. The work is as a result of an international collaboration with Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), which has led to a patent and contributed to the establishment of a joint research institute with CAS.

Title: Mechanistic investigation into antibacterial behaviour of suspensions of ZnO nanoparticles against E. coli
AdditionalInformation: A combination of chemical probes and pH sensitive fluorescent probe pyranine was used for the first time to investigate the antibacterial behaviour of ZnO particles against E.coli. The results demonstrate in a convincing way that the dominant mechanisms of the antibacterial activity are associated with interactions between chemical species generated due to the presence of ZnO particles and membrane proteins, and that with the lipid bilayer. The outputs of the work form the basis for our subsequent work on risk reduction strategy for engineered nanomaterials as part of a large scale EU project (MARINA, contact: Terry Wilkins, t.a.wilkins@leeds.ac.uk).

Title: Rheological behaviour of nanofluids containing tube / rod-like nanoparticles
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates experimentally that ethylene glycol based nanofluids (dilute suspensions of nanoparticles) containing titanate nanotubes are non-Newtonian across a range of temperatures and particle concentrations particularly at an elevated temperature, clarifying the controversy in the field of nanofluids. The work provides experimental evidence and theoretical basis that the thermal conductivity of nanofluids can be related to the structures of nanoparticles. The work has led to over 20 invited presentations / keynotes on the topic at international conferences / Universities / research institutes.

Title: On the relative importance of the kinetic and frictional contributions to granular motion in an annular Couette flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates for the first time that the commonly used kinetic-theory-based model with equal weight of collisional and frictional contributions gives a large deviation from experiments. The results provide direct evidence that a heavier weight (up to 25-50%) towards the frictional contribution is needed for real dense phase granular flows. The work was done by a PhD student (Ng) who has been applied the outputs to his current work as an employee of Procter & Gamble Company (ng.b.4@pg.com).

Title: The Design of a Resistively Loaded Bowtie Antenna for Applications in Breast Cancer Detection Systems
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
AdditionalInformation: Near field imaging using microwaves in medical applications has been found by numerous researchers to perform well in comparison to more established screening tools such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), digital mammography and ultrasound. This work documents the development of a resistively-loaded Bowtie antenna for microwave imaging applications such as breast cancer detection. The application has similarities to Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) but operates at higher frequencies with minimal late-ringing and internal reflections.  Genetic algorithms were used to optimize the antenna design and give very promising outcomes. This research will be taken forward with the submission of a breast cancer campaign grant application.

Title: Bandwidth Limitations on Linearly Polarized Microstrip Antennas
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
AdditionalInformation: This work is a part of a KTP between the University of Bradford and Pace Plc (no.7277) and the international collaboration with Tehran PolyTechnic. It proposes a new way of calculating the limiting Bandwidth-Reflection coefficient product for uni-planar conducting sensors/antennas and showing the advantages of higher order impedance-matching circuit. This shows for the first time the range and limits of the applications where such sensors can be effectively deployed and is one of the very few, in any context, to apply these calculations to second order networks. This work surmounts considerable mathematical difficulty in finding a new design approach for small, broadband antennas, which are problematic but also much in demand.

Title: Wideband Printed MIMO/Diversity Monopole Antenna for WiFi/WiMAX Applications
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes our pioneering decoupling network for 2x2 MIMO antennas in ultra-wideband applications. Offering significantly improved mutual coupling and return loss compared to other published work, the design enables better communication performance in dense multi-path environments. The work originated in a KTP project (number 8734) with Datong plc, developing enhancements for their commercial tracking systems (Simon.Marker@datong.co.uk). The data have underpinned a subsequent EPSRC grant proposal.

Title: On Bézier surfaces in three-dimensional Minkowski space
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a new theoretical framework to understand geometric surfaces in higher dimensions, particularly in three-dimensional Minkowski space. The properties of various well known surfaces in geometric design are analysed within the Minkowski space providing further insight into how these surface behave. These findings can be used by geometric designers and industry in order to gain further insight into these special surfaces commonly used in geometric design.

Title: Explicit polynomial solutions of fourth order linear elliptic Partial Differential Equations for boundary based smooth surface generation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a method for computer generation of geometric surfaces. These are one of the fundamental components for representing real life object in a digital form. In particular, the paper demonstrates how to compute polynomial solutions for such surfaces allowing the development and implementation of fast algorithms for computer design of complex surfaces. This work is highly relevant to the geometric design industry where data rich geometry are created and transmitted over networks.

Title: Method of modelling the compaction behaviour of cylindrical pharmaceutical tablets
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a technique for designing the shape of pharmaceutical tablets which can be easy to use within the relevant industry. The model and algorithms presented allows the design and calculation of important properties such as compression, volume and area of pharmaceuticals which are cylindrical in nature. This is highly relevant to industry as it provides an easy to use and accurate method for understanding compression behaviour and other relevant properties of cylindrical tablets.

Title: Elastic–plastic contact law for simulation of tablet crushing using the biharmonic equation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a mathematical model for computer based analysis of the compression behaviour of pharmaceutical tablets. The method shows how the physical properties of compression behaviour of pharmaceutical tablets can be estimated using simple mathematical functions based on a solution to partial differential equation. The work has led to the development of a simulation tool which the pharmaceutical industry can use for understanding tablet compression behaviour before the actual tablets are manufactured in large quantities.

Title: Cine cerebrospinal fluid imaging in multiple sclerosis
AdditionalInformation: With >100 subjects, this is the largest clinical trial to investigate cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics in MS. It demonstrated that MS is associated with increased CSF pulsatility and showed (for the first time) that this is correlated with MS-lesion formation. Beggs used a systems engineering approach to interpret the results. Follow-on work by Beggs (BMC Medicine 2013, 11:142 and Journal of Magnetic Resonance Imaging – in press) has shown that increased CSF pulsatility is probably due to constricted venous outflow altering intracranial compliance. Collectively, this work represents a major leap forward in understanding the CSF dynamics associated with MS.

Title: Sustainable acoustic and thermal insulation materials from elastomeric waste residues
AdditionalInformation: This presents a novel technological route to transform waste from the shredding of tyres, car bumpers and carpets into acoustic and thermal insulation materials that match or even outperform commercial products.   The approach is to bind the waste particulates with a foaming polymer, the chemistry of which is manipulated to control structure stiffness and evolution of the foaming gas into open cells (for acoustic insulation) or closed cells (for thermal insulation). This research was funded by the DTI Technology Priority Initiative on Design & Manufacture of Sustainable Products Landfill. Anglo Felt Industries has now taken up the technology.

Title: Dissolution and growth of entrained bubbles when dip coating in a gas under reduced pressure
AdditionalInformation: This paper forms part of a fundamental study conducted uniquely at Bradford, using a vacuum chamber, on the critical role of the gas phase viscosity on dynamic wetting and the onset of gas entrainment in coating operations hitherto not considered.  The study examines the details of the mechanism of gas entrainment in dip coating under reduced pressures and compares these with gas entrainment at atmospheric pressure.  The data from this study are now being taken by theoreticians to develop new models on dynamic wetting which take into consideration the important role of the gas phase viscosity.

Title: When Is Visual Information Used to Control Locomotion When Descending a Kerb?
AdditionalInformation: Although it is widely known that lower visual field (lvf) information is an important source of feedback used in the control of adaptive locomotion involving negotiation of obstacles in the environment, this study is the first to demonstrate exactly when such information is used; in particular in this study, to control locomotion when stepping from a kerb. A sister study (Timmis and Buckley, Gait & Posture 36: 160-162) determined exactly when lvf information is used to control locomotion when crossing floor based obstacles. Collectively, this work advances our understanding of how vision is used to control locomotion.

Title: Changes to Control of Adaptive Gait in Individuals with Long-standing Reduced Stereoacuity
