AdditionalInformation: The impact of the relatively prevalent visual impairment conditions of amblyopia and strabismus, on the lives of individuals who exhibit these conditions, has previously been examined by assessing how such individuals perform prehension tasks and other hand-eye coordination tasks. This study is the first to examine the impact of these conditions on everyday locomotion involving negotiation of floor based obstacles. Findings provide evidence that such individuals may be at greater risk of tripping or falling during everyday locomotion compared to visually normal individuals, which is an important advancement of knowledge in this area

Title: Use of Single-Vision Distance Spectacles Improves Landing Control during Step Descent in Well-Adapted Multifocal Lens-Wearers
AdditionalInformation: Our previous work (Johnson et al., 2008 J Am Geriatr Soc; 56: 178-180 and 2007 Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci, 48: 1466-71) has shown that wearing multifocal spectacles can reduce safety on steps and stairs. This study showed that switching to using single-vision distance spectacles improved stairs safety. Collectively our work indicates that use of single-vision distance lenses for everyday locomotion may be advantageous for elderly individuals particularly those who have a high risk of falling. Based on this work we are currently assessing (support from lens manufacturer; Essilor International) the efficacy of using intermediate multifocal lenses for everyday locomotion

Title: Does My Step Look Big In This? A Visual Illusion Leads To Safer Stepping Behaviour
AdditionalInformation: Tripping on stairs is a common factor in falls. The present study found that a visual illusion superimposed onto a block increased the perceived height of the block and consequently that when participants stepped on to the block foot clearance (and thus safety) was increased. We believe this application has  functional value in making the most dangerous steps on stairs, the first and last ones that the elderly often trip on, appear taller to thus improve safety; and we are currently investigating the efficacy of such an application in elderly individuals (NIHR grant, Public Health Research Programme, 10/3009/06).

Title: Tough Bio-Based Elastomer Nanocomposites with High Performance for Engineering Applications
AdditionalInformation: Coates and Zhang (Beijing) are the corresponding authors for this groundbreaking research on the manufacture of novel polyester elastomers from biomass, whose properties exceed those of other natural or synthetic elastomers.    It springs from the RCUK Bradford Science Bridges China collaborations and researcher exchanges, with a US industry partner, and is a foundational study for polymers synthesised from biomass, with nanofillers, exhibiting key engineering properties.  The most cited paper in the journal for 2012, and its issue cover feature.  A 100 tonnes p.a. pilot plant is now being built in Beijing to exploit the research.

Title: Imaging and analysis of wave type interfacial instability in the coextrusion of low-density polyethylene melts
AdditionalInformation: This collaboration with University of Zlin provides the first ever characterisation of instability generation at the confluence of two melt streams, at different entry angles, in multi-layer extrusion, a widely used process for polymer multilayer film production.   Leading edge rheo-optical experimentation (Bradford) in a unique windowed coextrusion die demonstrated instabilities, including measurement of oscillating stress fields (stress birefringence) and disturbances to velocity fields (laser lit particle tracking velocimetry).  This was combined with leading computational analysis (Zlin) to show clearly the cause of instabilities; such understanding can assist process control and die design, and feeds into commercial Compuplast software development.

Title: Chain Deformation in Entangled Polymer Melts at Re-entrant Corners
AdditionalInformation: Reporting results from complex experimentation and theory on mapping molecular conformation under high temperature flow using small angle neutron scattering (SANS). The necessity of using molecular modelling rather than standard fluid dynamical formulations for complex non-Newtonian flow predictions was proven in the paper, of interest to both academia and industry. Gough was instrumental in design of the flow rig and performed all SANS measurements. He is the only co-author on all papers using this equipment including the novel instrumentation development (Review of Scientific Instruments 74(9), p.4052) and a highlight Science paper (Science 301, p.1691).

Title: Simultaneous birefringence, small- and wide-angle X-ray scattering to detect precursors and characterize morphology development during flow-induced crystallization of polymers
AdditionalInformation: Presentation of a new combined measurement system allowing, for the first time, simultaneous measurements of stress birefringence and crystallisation kinetics using synchrotron radiation to elucidate flow enhanced structuring in polymers under flow. Gough was instrumental in the design of experiments, flow cell developments as well as performing all complex measurements presented as part of an international team from 5 countries.

Title: Cocrystalization and Simultaneous Agglomeration Using Hot Melt Extrusion
AdditionalInformation: Cocrystals are highly attractive to the pharmaceutical industry but limitations in production techniques have limited their uptake.  A new continuous process based upon twin screw extrusion was developed at Bradford by an interdisciplinary research group formed by Dr Kelly (process engineering) and Professor Paradkar (pharmaceutical science).  The initial research was supported through a Yorkshire Innovation fund, which employed a PDRA (Dr Dhumal). This project led to a patent application surrounding the technology being filed by the inventors (GB0813709.3), the award of a 3 year £495k EPSRC project (EP/J003360/1) and a recent synchrotron ESRF beam line award in Grenoble.

Title: Shear and extensional rheology of hydroxypropyl cellulose melt using capillary rheometry
VolumeTitle: Journal of Pharmaceutical and Biomedical Analysis
AdditionalInformation: Polymers are increasingly being used in pharmaceutical applications. This paper describes collaboration between Bradford and the Poona College of Pharmacy in India in which the flow behaviour of one such polymer (HPMC) was studied using capillary rheometry. This study was the first reported attempt to characterise the rheology of pharmaceutical polymers under conditions representative of manufacturing processes. Understanding these flow characteristics is a vital pre-formulation tool for development of new pharmaceutical processes such as melt extrusion.  This work demonstrated the application of Dr Kelly’s expertise in rheology in a field outside that of the conventional plastics industry.

Title: AFM relative stiffness measurement of the plasticising effect of a non-ionic surfactant on plant leaf wax
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: This study uses atomic force microscopy to directly measure, for the first time, changes in mechanical properties of plant leaf waxes with the application of surfactants.  This is important for agriculture as the uptake of sprayed chemicals such as pesticides is known to be dependent on  leaf wax plasticization.  Since this study the commercial partner, Syngenta Ltd., has gone on to develop agrichemicals such as fungicides that rely on changing the mechanical properties of the leaf wax for their efficacy (e.g. Seguris).  The technique presented here has allowed quantification of these effects.

Title: High resolution imaging of bio-molecular binding studies using a widefield surface plasmon microscope
AdditionalInformation: This is an original work that presents 'proof of principle' in results. Its significance is that the widefield surface plasmon resonance (WSPR) microscope used here enabled interfacial binding images with significantly higher lateral resolutions than prism based systems. We demonstrated the functionality of the WSPR by imaging a sequence of binding events between micro-patterned ECM proteins and their specific antibodies. Using the WSPR system a change in contrast was observed with each binding event. This work has provided better understanding of protein-surface interactions at the interface.

Title: Mechanical Investigations on Agar Gels Using Atomic Force Microscopy: Effect of Deuteration
AdditionalInformation: This study investigates the effect of deuteration on gel structure and stiffness.  In tissue engineering, gels such as agar are commonly used as the scaffold material to support the cells.  The gel has mechanical, structural, biological and chemical roles to fulfil in this application and the performance of candidate materials is a compromise between these roles.  This study introduces a novel mechanism for controlling gel structure and stiffness that interacts with gelling agent composition and concentration, but is an independent parameter.  This mechanism offers a new approach to tissue engineering scaffold optimisation, with advantages for soft tissue applications.

Title: Pseudostatic and Dynamic Nanomechanics of the Tunica Adventitia in Elastic Arteries Using Atomic Force Microscopy
AdditionalInformation: The tunica adventitia, a seldom studied fibrous collagenous structure found on all blood vessels (arteries and veins), is characterised for the first time using advanced atomic force microscopy (AFM) nanoindentation techniques. Here, we determine the mechanical and visco-elastic properties of the tunica adventitia (aorta and pulmonary artery); relate these to the structural components of the tissue; further linking this to their anatomical role with a view for tissue engineering applications. The details of this paper on the nano-mechanics of arterial tunica adventitia were accepted and presented at the national annual SPM conference series run by the Royal Microscopy Society.

Title: Decreased brain venous vasculature visibility on susceptibility-weighted imaging venography in patients with multiple sclerosis is related to chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency
AdditionalInformation: The work presents a major new finding relating to MS. With >90 subjects, this study was the first clinical trial to demonstrate that MS is associated with physical loss of cerebral veins - subsequently confirmed by Sinnecker et al (Multiple Sclerosis 2013, 19(3):316-325) and Zeng et al (European Radiology 2013, 23(3):869-878). Beggs used a systems engineering approach to interpret the data and demonstrated (for the first time) that vein loss is strongly associated with constricted venous outflow. Subsequently, Beggs (Neurological Research 2012 34(8):793-801) developed a venous diagnostic metric to distinguish between MS patients and healthy controls with 100% accuracy.

Title: Thinnest Uniform Liquid Films Formed at the Highest Speeds with Reverse Roll Coating
AdditionalInformation: This is the first ever study on the fluid mechanics of deformable reverse roll coating.  It presents data, which are effectively the design and operation information, to assess how thin, uniform and fast a liquid film can be made.  The data are particularly important in that they show that roll to roll manufacture of high-tech films (photovoltaics, flexible electronics, etc.) can be achieved using this simple process.	The results of this work are now being taken up by Toyobo (Japan), the sponsor of this work, to develop these valuable thin films in a wide range of new technological applications.

Title: The effect of continuous pore stratification on the acoustic absorption in open cell foams
AdditionalInformation: Simple physical principles tell us that thermal insulation is enhanced in foams that have closed cells and acoustic insulation is enhanced in foams that have open cells.  In this study, we made foams that have layers of open cells and layers of closed cells thus performing well for both thermal and acoustic insulation.  The merit of the paper resides in the technique employed to achieve this stratification and the fit between performance measured and the predictions made by the model developed. This work is now taken up further in collaboration with Armacell UK to develop these important materials.

Title: Three dimensional finite element analysis of the flow of polymer melts
AdditionalInformation: Work presented from EPSRC funded Microscale Polymer Processing: Applying the Tools grant in association with 6 UK universities and many industrial partners. Gough performed all complex three-dimensional experimental work at Bradford feeding into code developments at Leeds. Experimental results form a data set being used internationally for non-Newtonian code developments.

Title: High-Stress Shear-Induced Crystallization in Isotactic Polypropylene and Propylene/Ethylene Random Copolymers
AdditionalInformation: A detailed study into flow enhanced crystallisation of polypropylene and propylene/ethylene copolymers using novel injection moulding apparatus developed at CalTech to provide extreme shear rates in conjunction with time resolved measurements under a synchrotron x-ray source. A collaboration between Eindhoven, ESRF and Bradford – the author was instrumental in performing all measurements, developing control software and experimental protocols for this complex study

Title: Assessment of cerebral venous return by a novel plethysmography method
AdditionalInformation: With >80 subjects, this study was the first clinical trial to conclusively demonstrate that MS patients diagnosed with chronic cerebrospinal venous insufficiency (CCSVI) have profoundly altered cerebral venous drainage characteristics compared with healthy controls. Novel cervical plethysmography, together with a systems engineering approach, was employed to characterize (for the first time) the dynamics of the cerebral venous drainage system – something that would be impossible using Doppler ultrasound. As such, the study represented a major leap forward; clarifying the controversy associated with CCSVI and demonstrating that CCSVI is a real physiological phenomenon, which is associated with MS.

Title: Monitoring ibuprofen–nicotinamide cocrystal formation during solvent free continuous cocrystallization (SFCC) using near infrared spectroscopy as a PAT tool
AdditionalInformation: The process of continuous cocrystallisation by twin screw extrusion was developed at Bradford by the authors and this work led to a patent application surrounding the technology being filed by the inventors (GB0813709.3) and the award of a 3 year £495k EPSRC project (EP/J003360/1).  This paper describes the application of in-process monitoring to quantify levels of cocrystallisation.  Process analytical technology (PAT) is being promoted by the US Food and Drug Administration as a key technology to improve the quality of pharmaceutical products and processes. Here, near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy has been applied to the continuous cocrystallisation process for the first time.

Title: Absence of nonlinear responses in cells and tissues exposed to RF energy at mobile phone frequencies using a doubly resonant cavity
AdditionalInformation: This work is funded by the UK government's ‘Mobile Telecommunications and Health Research’ programme (£255k), involving simulation and undertaking of a crucial experiment to determine whether radiation from mobile phones has a non-thermal interaction with human tissue. The project brought together a national and international research team including the University of Maryland (USA) (Prof Q. Balzano) and Public Health England (Dr Simon Bouffler). The outcomes led to the award of an EPSRC grant (EP/E022936/1, £160k), aiming to design low SAR-balanced antennas for mobile handsets.

Title: An aerobiological model of aerosol survival of different strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa isolated from people with cystic fibrosis
AdditionalInformation: Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a major cystic fibrosis (CF) pathogen, is not thought to be spread by the airborne route. However, previous work (BMC Microbiology 2008, 8:105) showed that airborne transmission of P. aeruginosa is possible. The present study builds on this earlier work and is the most rigorous investigation of the subject undertaken to date. It confirms that airborne cross-infection is likely to occur in CF treatment rooms. As such, it has been influential in changing CF treatment/management policy (Cohen-Cymberknoh et al American Journal of Respiratory Critical Care Medicine 2011, 183:1463–1471). Beggs developed the engineering models used in the study.

Title: Estimating the Mechanical Properties of Retinal Tissue Using Contact Angle Measurements of a Spreading Droplet
AdditionalInformation: This study presents a novel method for the measurement of the mechanical properties of very soft materials and was developed to investigate retinal tissue.  Macular hole formation is a major cause of sight loss and is the result of a tear in the retina.  The formation and expansion of these flaws are mechanical processes, as is the repair procedure.  Without good data on the mechanical properties of the tissue, our understanding of these processes is limited.  The method presented here is the first to provide a measure of shear modulus at a scale and location relevant to macular hole formation.

Title: Development of a novel liquid crystal based cell traction force transducer system
AdditionalInformation: A novel cholesteryl ester liquid crystal (CELC) based cell traction force transducer system with improved sensitivity, flexibility and linear responses was developed. The LC had Young’s modulus close to that of the epidermis. CELC promoted expressions of punctuated vinculin and short circumferential actin filaments at the perimeter of the cells. The linear viscoelastic surface of the LCs is very sensitive to traction forces of adherent cells and can detect a wide range of cell traction forces (10–120nN) with spatial resolution of ~1mm. The systems presented here have significant potentials for development of novel single cell based pharmacological assays.

Title: Imaging of the cell surface interface using objective coupled widefield surface plasmon microscopy
AdditionalInformation: High resolution interfacial studies for biological applications is reported for the first time in this work. The same widefield surface plasmon resonance (WSPR) microscope was used (as in previous study) for cell-surface interfacial investigation at submicron lateral resolutions. The interface between HaCaT cells and the gold layer for both fixed and live cells were imaged. Imaging in air enabled the visualisation of high resolution submicron features as component of focal contacts/adhesions. Imaging in fluid enabled cell surface interfacial interactions to be tracked by time-lapse video WSPR microscopy. The cell surface interface was therefore interrogated without the use of labelling/immunostaining techniques

Title: Interfacial study of cell adhesion to liquid crystals using widefield surface plasmon resonance microscopy
AdditionalInformation: WSPR microscope was also found to be an effective tool for interrogating cell-soft surface interactions. The focal adhesions and location of the nucleus found by immunofluorescence staining matched WSPR images and revealed cell body mass could contribute to different topographic features at cell-surface interface depending on the absence and presence of a soft substrate such as a thin liquid crystal (LC) film. Cell growth on LC resulted in reduced cell adhesion area associated with remodelling of focal adhesions. Theoretical simulation suggested LCs could shift the excitation angle to higher order yet provide sufficient reflectivity for surface plasmon resonance imaging

Title: Employing a novel bioelastomer to toughen polylactide
AdditionalInformation: This output from the RCUK supported Science Bridges China collaborations, again with leading researchers from Beijing University of Chemical Technology (led by Prof Liqun Zhang), plus Australia, results from our co-operations in two strategic areas: (i) resource efficiency of materials, via the first reported use of a novel biocompatible elastomer from biomass (see Adv Eng Mat paper), to toughen biodegradable, biocompatible polylactides, and (ii) advanced materials for healthcare – where PLAs are of great interest for implants including tissue fixations.  Polylactides, are brittle, hence the novel, significant, controllable toughening achieved will extend their biomedical- and other potential engineering - applications.

Title: Tensile Deformation of Oriented Poly(ε-caprolactone) and Its Miscible Blends with Poly(vinyl methyl ether)
AdditionalInformation: Leading edge combination of elegant beam-line characterisation for precision controlled micromoulding of polymer blends, reflecting a strong, deepening international collaboration between Bradford and Changchun Chinese Academy of Sciences groups; based on research undertaken during researcher exchanges under our RCUK Science Bridges China/ EPSRC Global Innovations programmes.  This is the first detailed structural characterisation of micromoulded samples.  Micromolding is a thermally dominated very high speed process for production of precise geometry, controlled structure products for healthcare, telecommunications, etc, driven by increasing miniaturisation and provides a prime example of the tension between material kinetics and process dynamics leading to structural changes

Title: Nano-scale temperature dependent visco-elastic properties of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) using atomic force microscope (AFM)
AdditionalInformation: This study is one of the first investigations of visco-elastic temperature effects at nanometer spatial resolutions.  The development of these techniques is important for understanding the behaviour of polymer nanocomposites, both during processing and application.  While this study concerns an unfilled polymer, this provides the mechanical profile necessary to explore the effect of nano-particulate additions, which is a current area of investigation.  The combination of AFM with differential scanning calorimetry allows mechanical changes due to crystallisation to be understood.  Again, the properties of the crystalline phase at processing and application temperatures is an area of current research

Title: Polymorphic transformation of artemisinin by high temperature extrusion
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new technique to produce an improved, stable form of artemisinin, a globally important drug used in the treatment of malaria.  This work reported continuous polymorphic transformation of artemisinin for the first time, using a solvent-free extrusion based process. Solvent based processes are unable to create a stable form of the desired polymorph.  A patent application, with Kelly as co-inventor, on this technology (PCT/GB2013/051248) demonstrates the commercial potential of this technique, which has also been proven with other drugs.

Title: Oxidative coupling of methane in a fluidized bed reactor: Influence of feeding policy, hydrodynamics, and reactor geometry
AdditionalInformation: The relevance of hydrodynamics, reactor geometry, and feeding policy on the performance of a ﬂuidized bed reactor (FBR) for the Oxidative Coupling of Methane is shown. Several case studies of FBRs were simulated in full 3D geometry with different reactor geometries and feeding policy. These studies show the signiﬁcance of hydrodynamic parameters, and moreover, how FBR performance can be improved by a study of coupled momentum-mass transport-reaction phenomena. Furthermore, it could be demonstrated that a suitable distributed feeding policy of oxygen provides an improved yield while a traditional FBR design results in an inferior performance among all investigated cases

Title: Strength and structure of granules produced in continuous granulators
AdditionalInformation: This work is an extension of research conducted in 2009 from batch to continuous process to make the operation more economical. Three different types of continuous granulators were evaluated. These are Extrudomix, Modulomix (manufactured by Hosokawa Micron, UK and The Netherlands, respectively) and the Nica M6 Turbine continuous granulator (GEA, UK). The crushing strength, internal structure and morphology of produced granules were evaluated. Among the continuous granulators only the Modulomix granulator produced some seeded granules. The impact of this work is very beneficial to the industrial collaborators of this project. It is planned to continue this work with EPSRC and industrial collaborators to control the process to produce the desired granules.

Title: Characterisation of granule structure and strength made in a high shear granulator
AdditionalInformation: In this work, for the first time, the structure characterisation of particles and granules was conducted with the highest resolution of less than 1 μm per pixel using X-ray micro tomography equipment, Nanotom. The work was followed to quantify the granule structure using our developed computer code as the current available software packages were not able to analyse the structure of particles and granules. Structure descriptors such as phase volume fraction (as representative of porosity), chord length distribution and auto-correlation function (as indices of homogeneity of structure) were used to quantify the internal structure of granules in 3D, which in turn affects the granule strength.

Title: Seeded granulation
AdditionalInformation: One of the greatest challenges in granulation technology is to produce consistent granules. As a result of an EPSRC project (Grant no. GR/S25029/01), a novel method of granulation by seeding has been developed where granules are produced containing a seed by operating in a special way so that each seed produces a granule. This can overcome the challenges of producing uniform granulated product in both chemical and pharmaceutical industry.  A regime map has been identified for production of consistent granule structure and properties. The impact of this work is on chemical and pharmaceutical companies such as P&G and Pfizer. This work is not patented yet due to non-technical reasons.

Title: Effects of process parameters on granule properties produced in a high shear granulator
AdditionalInformation: It is so far impossible to fully predict the rheological behaviour of granulated fluids due to complex and non-Newtonian nature of the process. This is a comprehensive study to analyse effects of process parameters and formulation on the properties of produced granules. The work was supported by the EPSRC and four industrial collaborators, i.e. Borax Europe Ltd, Hosokawa Micron B.V., Pfizer (UK), and P&G (UK). We found the optimum conditions to produce granules with the desired properties. This work is beneficial both for the industrial sponsors and other local pharmaceutical and equipment manufacturers such as GEA Pharma (UK), Hosokawa Micron (UK).

Title: Brake Judder - An Investigation of the Thermo-elastic and Thermo-plastic Effects during Braking
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Vehicle Structures & Systems
AdditionalInformation: This output is based is the result of industrial and EPSRC funded (CASE Award) projects which resulted in the publication of a PhD thesis.  The work has significantly impacted on the understanding of the brake judder phenomenon and was the first to show the dynamic nature of brake disc deformation, which is a result of both thermo-elastic and thermo-plastic effects, and its impact on brake judder.  It was also the first to show that in-service stress relieving could occur on a brake disc.

Title: The Influence of Pad Abutment on the Generation of Brake Noise
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Vehicle Structures & Systems
AdditionalInformation: This output gives a comprehensive overview of the brake noise research carried out by the authors on a wide variety of braking system designs.  The research is amassed from knowledge gained over the course of numerous industrially funded research projects on noise investigation and resolution for OEMs and tier 1 suppliers across the globe.  The knowledge from the output has been applied to many brake systems in order to suppress squeal noises and led therefore to  reductions in customer complaints and provision for vehicles to be signed off for production.

Title: Optimal determination of steric mass action model parameters for β-lactoglobulin using static batch experiments
AdditionalInformation: Parameters of the steric mass-formalism SMA were optimally ascertained for a reliable determination of the adsorption isotherms of β-lactoglobulin A and B under non-isocratic conditions. Here, static batch experiments were used in contrast to the protocols based on different experimental steps, which use a chromatographic column. It is shown that parameters can already be determined for a small number of experiments by using a systematic procedure based on optimal model-based experimental design and an efﬁcient NLP-solver. Moreover, anti-Langmuir shape of the isotherm for small concentrations of β-lactoglobulin A and indications for a porosity variation with changing protein concentrations were corroborated.

Title: Generation of discrete first- and second-order sensitivities for single shooting
AdditionalInformation: An approach to the forward generation of discrete first- and second-order sensitivities is proposed. Here, an algorithm has been developed, which can basically be applied to general implicit differential-algebraic equation (DAE) systems. Moreover, the approach has been tailored to both the generation of directional derivatives and sensitivities with respect to discontinuous control trajectories. The implementation of the method is based on the orthogonal collocation method based on Legendre–Gauss–Radau points and considering the linear implicit DAE type, which arises typically in problems related to chemical engineering. Lastly, the approach has been applied to three case studies of different complexities.

Title: An efficient sparse approach to sensitivity generation for large-scale dynamic optimization
AdditionalInformation: An efficient approach is proposed for the combined step-wise state and sensitivity integration tailored to the orthogonal collocation in finite elements integration method. The developed algorithm can be adapted to any one step integration method where gradients are available from the solution of the discretized system. Moreover, it is completely based on sparse matrix calculus, which makes it especially suitable for large-scale equation systems with a relative small number of independent variables. The relative computational effort in comparison to a state integration is small with a linear increase w.r.t. the number of independent variables.

Title: Metamodel-based collaborative optimization framework
AdditionalInformation: Work has been successfully refined and applied to a complex engine calibration optimisation problem in a subsequent funded project sequence with a major car manufacturer, yielding significant improvements in fuel economy and emissions (in relation to standard drive cycle data) with respect to current calibration methodologies, and subsequent invitation to present to an industry-led forum in Berlin (2009).

Title: Improving fuel quality by whole crude oil hydrotreating: A kinetic model for hydrodeasphaltenization in a trickle bed reactor
AdditionalInformation: Whole crude oil hydrotreating is a new technology that has not been reported by anyone else except us. This output is one of four papers on the topic submitted to REF2014 by Wood (and Mujtaba). This paper develops kinetic models for hydrodeasphaltanisation using kinetic parameters previously non-existent in the literature until the work of Mujtaba3. An accurate kinetic model is essential for model-based activity such as scale up, economic feasibility calculations, and so on. At recent PARTC (Cape Town) and MEPEC (Bahrain) conferences, the work attracted the attention of a number of industries (Invensys, Johnson Matthey, DuPont, Sasol, Haldor Topsoe).

Title: Improvement of the Middle Distillate Yields during Crude Oil Hydrotreatment in a Trickle-Bed Reactor
AdditionalInformation: Whole crude oil hydrotreating is a new technology that has not been reported by anyone else except us. This output is one of four papers submitted to REF2014 by Wood (and Mujtaba) and is linked to Wood2 through the improved kinetic model developed therein. It is expected that significant economic benefit will result from the changes in flow and fouling (in heat exchangers) characteristics of the new RCR fuel (due to different thermo-physical properties). At recent PARTC (Cape Town) and MEPEC (Bahrain) conferences, the work attracted the attention of a number of industries (Invensys, Johnson Matthey, DuPont, Sasol, Haldor-Topsoe).

Title: Kinetic model development and simulation of simultaneous hydrodenitrogenation and hydrodemetallization of crude oil in trickle bed reactor
AdditionalInformation: Whole crude oil hydrotreating is a new technology that has not been reported by anyone else except us. This output is one of four papers submitted to REF2014 by Wood (and Mujtaba). This paper develops kinetic models for the removal of nitrogen and heavy metals with kinetic parameters previously non-existent in the literature. An accurate kinetic model is essential for any model based activity such as scale up, economic feasibility calculations, etc. At recent PARTC (Cape Town) and MEPEC (Bahrain) conferences, the work attracted the attention of a number of industries (Invensys, Johnson Matthey, DuPont, Sasol, Haldor Topsoe).

Title: An assessment of steering drift during braking: a comparison between finite-element and rigid body analyses
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an industrial project work which is related to a serious vehicle condition which compromised the safety of a vehicle on the road and its stability during braking. Our research identified a deficiency in the current company component design procedure. We determined the cause and effects of drift during straight-line braking and our research enabled the manufacturer to modify their design process and enabled them to produce stable and safer vehicle behaviour during braking. The research showed the importance of using flexible (compliant) components in vehicle handling design. The project proposed fixes to already manufactured cars by changing the suspension bushings which eliminated the drift behaviour

Title: Design concepts and analysis of a semi-active steering system for a passenger car
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted in an innovative technology for an automotive steering system called ‘Semi-Active Steering System’. The advantage of this system is similar to a conventional electrical power assisted steering with the replacement of the rigid steering shaft with a low stiffness resilient shaft, the presence of which allows ‘active control’ to be performed on vehicles similar to the concept of full steer-by-wire (SBW). But, unlike SBW, the advantage of the proposed system is that it is an integral part of the system characteristics. Using this system the vehicle stability and drivability is ensured in the event of the failure of the active system.

Title: Analysis of the properties of a steering shaft used as a back-up for a steer-by-wire system during system failure
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The aim of the research was to determine the best selection criteria for the properties of a steering shaft to be used as a back-up component for steer-by-wire (SBW) during system failure. Both steering shaft stiffness and damping were tested and monitored. It is concluded this research that a suggested stiffness and damping coefficient values increased the steering ratio, and the results of further investigations are presented which confirm that the vehicle is safe to be driven in the event of SBW system failure if the recommended shaft properties are used. This research showed that a car with steer-by-wire may be safely fitted with the proposed low stiffness emergency backup system.

Title: Effect of component stiffness and deformation on vehicle lateral drift during braking
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This research investigates the effects of compliant vehicle sub-frame and suspension arm components on the characteristics of a vehicle experiencing steering drift during straight-line braking. The research confirms that variation of component stiffness and interactions within components give rise to side-to-side deflections which resulted in braking instability. It was shown that components whose stiffness varies from side to side can cause different side to side deflections that can induce and influence the variation of suspension characteristics. The most significant influence of component deflections were noted for the front wheel toe steer angles, which were influenced by the lateral deflections of the steering carrier, gear and tie rods.

Title: Simulation and optimization of MSF desalination process for fixed freshwater demand: Impact of brine heater fouling
AdditionalInformation: Fouling affects external energy consumption (and thus carbon footprint) significantly in MSF desalination processes. For the first time, a dynamic fouling model has been developed and incorporated in model based simulation and optimisation of the MSF process with an ultimate goal of minimising the total operating cost (steam & power consumption representing energy cost). A number of recent papers on desalination including this one led to the keynote presentations at the Computer Aided Process Engineering Forum 2008 (Greece) and International Symposium on Process Systems Engineering 2012 (Singapore).

Title: Significant thermal energy reduction in lactic acid production process
AdditionalInformation: Beyond a certain threshold quality, energy consumption (carbon footprint) can increase nonlinearly with quality. This paper, for the first time, demonstrated (using model based techniques) that flexible operation (reflux ratio) not only enhances the quality of product but also reduces the energy consumption significantly. This work led to further research on energy savings in nonconventional batch distillation columns by Mujtaba and collaborators from Libya.

Title: Optimal design and operation of reverse osmosis desalination process with membrane fouling
AdditionalInformation: Fouling affects external energy consumption (and thus carbon footprint) significantly in RO processes. For the first time, sensitivity of fouling distribution in different RO stages has been analysed and incorporated in model based optimisation of RO process with an ultimate goal of minimising the total capital and operating cost (pumping cost representing energy cost) while optimising the RO network. A number of recent papers on desalination including this one led to the keynote presentations at the CAPE Forum 2008 (Greece) and International Symposium on PSE2012 (Singapore).

Title: Kinetic parameter estimation and simulation of trickle-bed reactor for hydrodesulfurization of crude oil
AdditionalInformation: Whole crude oil hydrotreating is a new technology that has not been reported by any other research groups. Since the publication of this paper Saudi Aramco have launched a research funding call on whole crude oil desulphurisation. Mujtaba was invited to give a keynote presentations on the topic at the ToG2012 conference in Libya. At recent PARTC (Cape Town) and MEPEC (Bahrain) conferences, the work attracted the attention of a number of industries (Invensys, Johnson Matthey, DuPont, Sasol, Haldor Topsoe).

Title: A generalised vortex ring model
AdditionalInformation:
This study in conjunction with Tallinn Technical University, Estonia was funded by both EPSRC and Ricardo UK Ltd (EP/E047912/1) and demonstrated the first relevant automotive engineering application of a new generalised theoretical model of vortex rings to fuel sprays. Results have advanced the technical knowledge of Ricardo UK Ltd contributing to development programmes for low CO2 production engines for multi-national, automotive OEM clients. As a result Ricardo supported a larger EPSRC grant EP/K005758/1 that extends the collaborations to include Moscow State University.  
(Professor Neville Jackson , CTO, Neville.Jackson@ricardo.com)

Title: Dynamics of vortex rings and spray induced vortex ring-like structures
AdditionalInformation:
This feasibility study was funded by both EPSRC and Ricardo UK Ltd (EP/E047912/1) and conducted in conjunction with Tallinn Technical University, Estonia. The work led to a new solution for the normalised vorticity distribution for a viscous vortex ring that was applicable to a DI gasoline fuel injector used in the development of new gasoline combustion systems. Results have advanced the technical knowledge of Ricardo UK Ltd contributing to development programmes for fuel efficient production engines for multi-national, automotive OEM clients. As a result Ricardo supported a larger EPSRC grant EP/K005758/1 that extends the collaborations to include Moscow State University. 
(Professor Neville Jackson , CTO, Neville.Jackson@ricardo.com)

Title: Vortex ring-like structures in gasoline fuel sprays under cold-start conditions
AdditionalInformation:
This EPSRC funded feasibility study, in conjunction with Tallinn Technical University, Estonia and Ricardo UK Ltd (EP/E047912/1) demonstrated for the first time the application of vortex ring models to automotive engineering, in both low pressure (PFI) and high pressure (DI) fuel sprays. Results have advanced the technical knowledge of Ricardo UK Ltd contributing to development programmes for spray-guided direct injection production engines for multi-national, automotive OEM clients. As a result Ricardo supported a larger EPSRC grant EP/K005758/1 that extends the collaborations to include Moscow State University. 
(Professor Neville Jackson , CTO, Neville.Jackson@ricardo.com)

Title: Low intake valve lift in a port fuel-injected engine
AdditionalInformation:
The paper reports for the first time, in-cylinder air and fuel spray measurements at conditions representative of a CVVL gasoline PFI engine at idle conditions, for peak valve lifts as low as 0.37 mm. The results have advanced the technical knowledge of Ricardo UK Ltd., contributing to multi-national OEM engine development programmes, such as the twin mechanical variable lift engine (TMVL) and controlled auto-ignition (CAI/HCCI) concepts and led to the replacement of PFI with DI in these systems for reduced emissions. The study was supported by an EPSRC CASE studentship award with Ricardo UK Ltd. 
(Professor Neville Jackson , CTO, Neville.Jackson@ricardo.com)

Title: Through life capability vetronics systems integration testbed
AdditionalInformation: Publication only available for UK MOD research funded programmes. Rigorous selection process with only advanced high impact contributions reviewed and selected by DSTL/MOD Scientists. The unique testbed presented here was funded under RT/COM/4/5008 umbrella grant.  It is used as a concept systems integration laboratory and has revolutionised military vehicle electronic architecture development contributing towards Standards and Guidelines, in particular DefStan 23-09 (GVA - Generic Vehicle Architecture) influencing major procurement programmes and DefStan transition to a NATO STANAG.  60% of programmes under the follow-up DSTLX-1000077466 umbrella research grant are using this testbed.  (Scientist, Systems Engineering Integration Team, Security Sciences Department, DSTL)

Title: Windage sources in smooth-walled rotating disc systems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of The Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part C - Journal of Me
AdditionalInformation:
This experimental research work was carried out at the Thermo Fluid Mechanics Research Centre, University of Sussex, as part of EU ICAS-GT2 (Internal Cooling Air Systems) programme, funded by the 5th Framework of the GROWTH programme of the European Union.
Since the new data was obtained at rotational speeds and pressures not previously measured, results could be used to improve the validation of the windage friction correlations used by the industrial research partners as part of their gas turbine engine design practices. The work led to further funding from Rolls-Royce plc directly for additional experimental research work and further publications.
Professor Peter Childs < p.childs@imperial.ac.uk>

Title: A breakup model for transient Diesel fuel sprays
AdditionalInformation:
This collaborative work (Universities of Brighton, Keele, and Lyon) funded by EPSRC (EP/F058276/1) and Ricardo UK Ltd, significantly improved the classic WAVE model to better predict transient sprays, such as those found in Diesel engines. Ricardo benefitted from an increased knowledge of the processes that influence the breakup processes in transient Diesel fuel sprays.
(Professor Neville Jackson , CTO, Neville.Jackson@ricardo.com)

Title: Diesel fuel spray penetration, heating, evaporation and ignition: modelling vs. experimentation
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Engineering Systems Modelling and Simulation
AdditionalInformation:
This paper was a deliverable for a collaborative research programme (CORIA, Universities of Brighton and Rouen) funded by the EU (INTERREG III Project 162/025/247) and Ricardo UK Ltd. Ricardo benefitted from an increased knowledge of the key processes involved in the evaporation of Diesel fuel sprays.
(Professor Neville Jackson , CTO, Neville.Jackson@ricardo.com)

Title: Grouping and trapping of evaporating droplets in an oscillating gas flow
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative work (University of Brighton and Ben-Gurion, University of the Negev) funded by EPSRC (EP/D002044/1) and Ricardo UK Ltd, demonstrated for the first time a novel approach which considers fuel sprays as clusters of droplets, and the consequences of that effect on the formation and evaporation of Diesel droplets.

Title: High-speed microscopic imaging of the initial stage of diesel spray formation and primary breakup
AdditionalInformation: This publication underwent full peer review and was a key deliverable from an EPSRC CASE project awarded by BP. It demonstrated for the first time that both high-resolution microscopy and ultra-high speed microscopic imaging can be applied successfully at realistic engine conditions (citation evidence: Manin et al. (2012) THIESEL 2012). This work forms the basis of a £0.75m collaborative EPSRC grant with City University and BP (EP/K020528/1; EP/K020846/1).

Title: Transient heating of an evaporating droplet
VolumeTitle: International Journal Of Heat And Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation:
In this paper, the work on which was supported by the European Regional Development
Fund Franco-British INTERREG IVA (Project C5, Reference 4005) and the Royal Society (joint project with Russia, Reference JP 071790), two new solutions to the heat conduction equation, describing transient heating of an evaporating droplet, and taking into account the effect of the reduction of the droplet radius due to evaporation, assuming that this radius is a linear function of time, are suggested. It is recommended that this effect of on droplet heating is taken into account in modelling droplet heating and evaporation in CFD codes.

Title: Transient heating of an evaporating droplet with presumed time evolution of its radius
VolumeTitle: International Journal Of Heat And Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation:
In this paper, the work on which was supported by the European Regional Development
Fund Franco-British INTERREG IVA (Project C5, Reference 4005) and the Royal Society (joint project with Russia, Reference JP 071790), new solutions to the heat conduction equation, describing transient heating of an evaporating droplet, are suggested, assuming that the time evolution of droplet radius Rd(t) is known. It is shown that in the case of constant droplet initial temperature, models both taking and not taking into account the changes in the initial droplet temperature with the distance from the droplet centre predict the same results.

Title: Multi-component droplet heating and evaporation: numerical simulation versus experimental data
AdditionalInformation:
In this paper, the work on which was supported by the European Regional Development
Fund Franco-British INTERREG IVA (Project C5, Reference 4005) and the Royal Society (joint project with Russia, Reference JP 071790), a model for multi-component droplet heating and evaporation, taking into account the coupling between droplets and the ambient gas, is suggested. The model is recommended for the implementation into Computational Fluid Dynamics codes and used for engineering applications, including internal combustion engines. This paper led to successful application for the new EPSERC grant EP/K020528/1, the work on which is ongoing.

Title: A kinetic model of droplet heating and evaporation: effects of inelastic collisions and a non-unity evaporation coefficient
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the work on which was supported by EPSRC grant EP/H001603/1, the previously developed kinetic model for droplet heating and evaporation into a high pressure air is generalised to take into account the combined effects of inelastic collisions between molecules in the kinetic region, a non-unity evaporation coefficient and temperature gradient inside droplets. It is shown that the effects of inelastic collisions lead to strong increase in the predicted droplet evaporation time in Diesel engine-like conditions. This paper led to successful application for the new EPSRC grant EP/J006793/1, the work on which is ongoing.

Title: A simplified model for bi-component droplet heating and evaporation
VolumeTitle: International Journal Of Heat And Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: A new analytical solution of the partial differential equation (PDE) for transient species diffusion inside droplets is derived and incorporated into numerical code alongside analytical solution of the transient heat conduction PDE.  Effects of recirculation and non-unity activity coefficient are taken into account. The numerical code agrees with the direct measurement of average droplet temperatures for acetone-ethanol droplets. This work has contributed to a major EU INTERREG project E3C3 in collaboration with Ricardo, Imperial College London, University of Cambridge and French partners CNRS, University of Rouen, INSA Rouen, University of Caen, and into securing a major EPSRC grant EP/K020846/1.

Title: A quasi-discrete model for heating and evaporation of complex multicomponent hydrocarbon fuel droplets
VolumeTitle: International Journal Of Heat And Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: A new, CPU-efficient method for numerical modelling of multicomponent droplets is suggested, based on the introduction of quasi-components for representing chemical composition of fuel. The method takes into account thermal gradients and species’ diffusion inside the droplets, and it lends itself for the case when a large number of components is present in the liquid fuel. This work led to a major EU grant (INTERREG project E3C3) in collaboration with Ricardo, Imperial College London, University of Cambridge and French partners CNRS, University of Rouen, INSA Rouen, University of Caen, and into securing a further EPSRC grant EP/K020846/1.

Title: Monodisperse monocomponent fuel droplet heating and evaporation
AdditionalInformation: Heating and evaporation of monocomponent droplets is modelled based on the analytical solution to the transient heat conduction partial differential equation (PDE) inside droplets. This eliminates the need for discretisation of the PDE when implementing the model into CFD codes.  The interaction between droplets is taken into account based on the experimentally determined corrections to Nusselt and Sherwood numbers. Recirculation inside droplets is accounted for by the effective thermal conductivity model. The results are compared with the monodisperse spray experiment in an ambient air of ﬁxed temperature and atmospheric pressure for acetone, ethanol, 3-pentanone, n-heptane, n-decane and n-dodecane droplets.

Title: Robust mobility adaptive clustering scheme with support for geographic routing for vehicular ad hoc networks
AdditionalInformation: The material presented provided the basis of a part of an £11m Vehicle Technology Integrated Demonstrator programme led by QinetiQ (RT/COM/4/048). The task was to answer how ad-hoc networks might be implemented as an element of the overall Network Enabled Capability (NEC) system, and how such an NEC system could deliver enhanced situational awareness to military vehicles as an element of overall integrated survivability.  Subsequently, along with video processing research, another research programme looking at wired and wireless LSA integration strategy for military vehicles was funded by the UK MOD under the RT/COM/4/5008 umbrella grant. (Principal Engineer, Survivability Team, QinetiQ)

Title: A network-centric approach to space-restricted distributed processing
AdditionalInformation: The work presented here offers the first inspiration of logical/functional abstraction and physical integration of embedded distributed systems electronic architecture.  This approach investigates some fundamental concepts in terms of processing capabilities, scalability, openness, space restriction, and all these in combinations to providing through life capability management.  These concepts triggered further research in collaboration with QinetiQ under the UK MOD RT/COM/4/5008 umbrella grant and have influenced positively the UK MOD Vehicle Systems Integration (VSI) Standards and Guidelines. (Principal Engineer, Survivability Team, QinetiQ)

Title: Object-based video coding with dynamic quality control
AdditionalInformation: The paper identifies a novel approach to video processing algorithms through MPEG-4 objects, offering distinct and advanced capabilities on object tracking.  This work in collaboration with QinetiQ has given an insight on further work building a Video Distribution Framework for Local Situation Awareness (LSA) for military vehicles that also contributed towards DefStan 00-82 and NATO STANAG 4697.  It was funded by the UK MOD under the RT/COM/4/5008 umbrella grant and was also used as a basis a subsequent programme looking at wired and wireless LSA integration strategy for military vehicles. (Principal Engineer, Survivability Team, QinetiQ)

Title: Working fluid selection for a subcritical bottoming cycle applied to a high exhaust gas recirculation engine
AdditionalInformation: A fundamental study of the matching of working fluid and thermodynamic cycle to the heat sources available in a heavy duty engine was undertaken.    The motivation was to identify alternative working fluids through thermodynamic modelling and consideration of the impact of chemical structure on performance and other metrics such as toxicity, ozone depletion and flammability.  This work resulted on invitations to collaborate through joint grant applications with Ricardo and Libertine that along other earlier published findings have contributed to securing three commissioned research projects and TSB funding (TP101566). (Engine Research, Ricardo UK and Libertine)

Title: Molecular dynamics study on evaporation and condensation of n-dodecane at liquid-vapor phase equilibria
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the work on which was supported by EPSRC grant EP/H001603/1, a new molecular dynamics model to the dynamics of n-dodecane molecules has been suggested and validated. This model is based on the observation that methyl (CH3) and methylene (CH2) groups in n-dodecane molecules can be regarded as united atoms (hydrogen atoms are not modelled separately as distinct atoms, which led to substantial reduction of computer time without sacrificing the accuracy of calculations). This paper led to successful application for the new EPSRC grant EP/J006793/1, the work on which is ongoing.

Title: A solution of the Boltzmann equation in the presence of inelastic collisions
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the work on which was supported by EPSRC grant EP/H001603/1, a new  computer efficient model to take into account the effect of inelastic collisions between two molecules in the solution of the Boltzmann equation in the vicinity of Diesel fuel droplet surfaces has been suggested, validated and implemented into the numerical code, designed for simulation of the processes of heating and evaporation of Diesel fuel droplet. This paper led to successful application for the new EPSRC grant EP/J006793/1, the work on which is ongoing. Wider engineering, medical and environmental applications of this model are anticipated.

Title: Non-modal stability of round viscous jets
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the work on which was supported by EPSRC grants EP/F069855/1 and EP/G000034/1, hydrodynamic stability of round viscous fluid jets is considered for the first time within the framework of the non-modal approach. Linear combinations of modes (optimal disturbances) leading to the maximum kinetic energy at a specified set of governing parameters are found. For the velocity profiles under consideration, it is found that the non-modal instability mechanism is significant for non-axisymmetric disturbances, and needs to be taken into account when developing quantitative models of Diesel fuel jet primary break-up.

Title: A quantum chemical study of the processes during the evaporation of real-life Diesel fuel droplets
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the work on which was supported by EPSRC grant EP/J006793/1, the process evaporation of Diesel fuel droplets has been considered taking into account the quantum chemical effects at the droplet surfaces. This approach is fundamentally novel and allows us to achieve an in-depth understanding of the processes which take place at these surfaces. The methods developed in this paper are expected to lead us to quantities estimate of the evaporation coefficient to be used in kinetic modelling of Diesel fuel droplet heating and evaporation processes. Wider applications of this model in engineering and medicine are anticipated.

Title: Fmoc-Diphenylalanine Self Assembles to a Hydrogel via a Novel Architecture Based on π–π Interlocked β-Sheets
AdditionalInformation: The work is a collaboration between several groups at the University of Manchester. It reveals how FMOC-diphenylamine self assemble into complex architectures to give rise to hydrogels. A range of techniques is used to investigate the self assembly.  Coppo investigated the optical properties of such gels, revealing how  interactions of the FMOC units play a key role in the assembly, resulting in white emission from the excimers upon gelification. The article has been enthusiastically received and cited over 100 times to date.

Title: Copper(I) Trinuclear Phosphorescent Complexes with Tuneable Optical and Photophysical Properties
AdditionalInformation: The work was entirely carried out at the Wolfson Centre, Brunel University. It aims to investigate Cu 1+ trinuclear alkynyl coordination complexes with a rational approach to the tuning of the light emission. In this work we have prepared a number of new complexes, tailored to prove how the aromatic groups attached to the alkynyl unit influence the emission energy (colour) and the lifetime of the emission. We have found a pathway to obtaining the desired properties by altering the environment around the ligand. The article was granted the issue cover by the editorial team.

Title: A large eddy simulation of an airfoil turbulent wake subjected to streamwise curvature
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a numerical simulation and experimental study for turbulent flow in the wake of an airfoil. There has been a limited number of experimental and numerical studies on wakes subjected to streamwise flow curvature. The importance of this paper is therefore in providing experimental data for possible future numerical simulations.  The present numerical simulation provides the first application of large eddy simulation to the geometrical configuration adopted in this study.

Title: A new method for finding the first- and second-order eigenderivatives of asymmetric non-conservative systems with application to an FGM plate actively controlled by piezoelectric sensor/actuators
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports on part of the output of project funded by EPSRC and the aerospace industry on inverse optimisation of structures vibratory behaviour.  The paper, which was published in IJNME, the leading journal in engineering numerical simulation, represents a fundamental new formulation  for computing eigenvalue and eigenvector derivatives of asymmetric non-conservative systems. The formulations and algorithm proposed in this paper have significant impact in the wider finite element community as the approach is now being adopted by a number of major commercial simulation software and used by the aerospace and car industries.

Title: Assessment of technical and environmental performances of wheat-based foams in thermal packaging applications
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of a TSB and EPSRC co-funded project “Biobased lightweight sandwich structures for packaging applications” (DT/F006101/1).  The project was conducted in collaboration with 10 industrial partners. It provided comprehensive characterisation of cell structure, mechanical and thermal properties of starch foams and composites, design of thermal packaging solutions, modelling and experimental assessment of thermal insulation performance.  It demonstrated that biofoam can outerperform plastic foams as thermal barriers and led to a further investigation “Design of reusable biomaterial packaging systems for the chilled meat and fish industry”, funded by TSB (Grant 131380).

Title: Multi-lognormal soot particle size distribution for time-resolved laser induced incandescence in diesel engines
AdditionalInformation: In-cylinder and exhaust soot particle size distribution measurements were carried out using the time resolved laser induced incandescence (TR-LII) and electrical mobility spectrometer in a single cylinder high speed optical diesel engine and in a multi-cylinder high speed diesel engine respectively. For the first time using the TR-LII technique we have shown that the in-cylinder and the exhaust soot particle size distributions are better represented by a multi-lognormal size distribution compared to the most normally used single lognormal size distribution. This publication resulted from an EPSRC sponsored project.

Title: Experimental investigation into wing span and angle-of-attack effects on sub-scale race car wing/wheel interaction aerodynamics
AdditionalInformation: This work was undertaken in conjunction with Toyota F1 with the main aim to achieve a better understanding of the primary flow physics resulting from modifying several fundamental variables related to inverted wing/wheel aerodynamics. These include the effects of changing wing span, angle of attack(AOA), wheel track, and width on the interaction aerodynamics of an inverted wing/wheel combination (subjected to a moving ground). Research within this area was conducted using both experimental methods and CFD.

Title: Solidification Behavior and Microstructural Evolution of Near-Eutectic Zn-Al Alloys under Intensive Shear
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to describe the effect of intensive shear on solidification behaviour and microstructural evolution of binary Zn-Al alloys at hypoeutectic, eutectic, and hypereutectic compositions. This work is important because during eutectic solidification under intensive shear, nucleation occurs at temperatures very close to the equilibrium condition and the intensive shear can significantly alter the microstructure from the conventional lamellar morphology of the Zn-rich and Al-rich phases to separately distributed fine and spherical particles. The project was supported by EPSRC. This paper was reviewed as 'revolutionary discovery for eutectic solidification' and nominated best paper in 2009 by MMTS.

Title: Processing of Ultrafine-Size Particulate Metal Matrix Composites by Advanced Shear Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel route for processing metal matrix composites involving dispersion of ultra-fine ceramic particles in an Al-matrix by intensive melt shearing. This processing route has provided a solution to a long-standing engineering problem: producing uniform dispersion of fine ceramic particles in a metal matrix.

Title: Solidification of Al-Sn-Cu Based Immiscible Alloys under Intense Shearing
AdditionalInformation: Thermodynamic assessment has confirmed that a miscibility gap exists in the ternary Al-Sn-Cu system. Intensive shearing was used to produce a well dispersed 3-phase mixture, alpha-Al and two immiscible liquids, prior to high pressure die casting (HPDC). It was demonstrated that this is an very effective route to process immiscible liquids for creating a fine and uniform microstructure, which is impossible by the conventional casting process.

Title: Solidification Behavior of Intensively Sheared Hypoeutectic Al-Si Alloy Liquid
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel route, melt conditioned high pressure die casting (MC-HPDC), for processing hypoeutectic Al-Si based alloys for improved microstructural uniformity and reduced cast defects. This process will provide a easy to implement route for producing high quality Al castings, and is particularly relevant to the automotive industry.

Title: Study of Heterogeneous Nucleation of Eutectic Si in High-Purity Al-Si Alloys with Sr Addition
AdditionalInformation: Sr is used in industry to modify eutectic Si. This paper uses a novel entrained droplet technique to investigate the role of Sr and P in the nucleation of Al-Si eutectic. Key results demonstrate that unlike P which has small undercoolings indicating a potent nucleation site, Sr was found to depress the eutectic nucleation temperature i.e. increase undercooling, which indicates that the potency of the nucleant is decreasing. This was attributed to the formation of a Sr phase observed in TEM investigations which could detrimentally affect/consume the potent AlP nucleation sites.

Title: Influence of intensive melt shearing on the microstructure and mechanical properties of an Al-Mg alloy with high added impurity content
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we have demonstrated for the first time that the melt conditioned twin roll casting (MC-TRC) process is capable of producign high quality Al-alloy strip with increased Fe contents. This provides firm evidence that the MC-TRC process is an effective technique for recycling Al-scrap. This work is highly relevant to the automotive industry for reducing CO2 emissions.

Title: Processing of Aluminum-Graphite Particulate Metal Matrix Composites by Advanced Shear Technology
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel route for processing graphite reinforced metal matrix composites through forced wetting between graphite and molten aluminium by intensive melt shearing. This processing route has provided a solution to a long-standing engineering problem: producing uniform dispersion of usually non-wetting graphite particles in a metal matrix.

Title: Enhanced heterogeneous nucleation in AZ91D alloy by intensive melt shearing
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we have revealed experimentally that oxide films in Mg-alloys are liquid films consisting of densely populated MgO particles with 100-200 nm size, and that such nano-scale MgO particles can be effectively dispersed by intensive melt shearing. More importantly, we have discovered experimentally that such dispersed MgO particles can act as nucleating substrates leading to significant grain refinement. This has opened a new approach to grain refinement: physical grain refinement, and paved the way for processing Mg-alloys for improved mechanical performance.

Title: Effects of solute content on grain refinement in an isothermal melt
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we demonstrated for the first time that a well accepted linear relationship between the reciprocal of growth restriction factor (Q) and the grain size is incorrect. We suggest changing this linear relationship to a 1/3 power law. In addition, we revealed that the effect of solute is to retard the growth rate, which allows further nucleation before recalescence. Overall, this paper has made a solid contribution to the understanding of microstructural refinement through solidification processing.

Title: Design and performance of an open jet wind tunnel for aero-acoustic measurement
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of a DTI MSTTAR DARP project “Numerical and experimental investigation of trailing edge broadband noise”, partnered with Rolls-Royce Plc. I led the design and performance characterisation of a low-noise open jet wind tunnel, situated in a large anechoic chamber at the Institute of Sound and Vibration Research, University of Southampton.

Title: Simulation of multi-deck medium temperature display cabinets with the integration of CFD and cooling coil models
AdditionalInformation: As part of outcomes from DEFRA funded project R25150, in this paper, the model for the multi-deck medium temperature display cabinets is developed with the integration of CFD and cooling coil sub-models. The distributed method is used to develop the cooling coil model with the airside inputs from the outputs of the CFD model. Inversely, the airside outputs from the cooling coil model are used to update the boundary conditions of the CFD model. The cabinet model has been validated and used to explore and analyze the cabinet performance and control strategies at various operating and design conditions.

Title: Vacuum Insulation Panels (VIPs) for building construction industry – A review of the contemporary developments and future directions
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented state-of-the-art and future directions for Vacuum Insulation Panels (VIPs) for use in buildings. A comprehensive economic analysis of VIPs and a review of important contemporary developments towards producing VIPs using various materials such as glass fibre, foams, perlite and fibre/powder composites was presented. This paper resulted from an on-going PhD study and has led to another peer reviewed journal publication (Energy and Buildings journal) since then. The knowledge created has been successfully exploited in an on-going industry funded project (funder: EVONIK Industries Germany) and another industry funded project (funder: Microtherm Belgium) scheduled to begin in October 2013.

Title: Trigeneration in food retail: An energetic, economic and environmental evaluation for a supermarket application
AdditionalInformation: Trigeneration for the food industry (combined heating, power and refrigeration) has been an extensive research activity at Brunel funded by DEFRA, AFM 177, AFM196, AFM251, and several industrial partners. The paper provides a methodology for sizing trigeneration systems in supermarket applications and has been used by industry to evaluate potential applications. The work won the Institute of Energy Exxon Mobil award for innovation in 2005, and the paper ‘Trigeneration – a solution to efficient use of energy in the food industry’ was awarded the Kenneth Lightfood Medal for the best paper presented to the Institute of Refrigeration in 2007-08.

Title: A review of natural convective heat transfer correlations in rectangular cross-section cavities and their potential applications to compound parabolic concentrating (CPC) solar collector cavities
AdditionalInformation: A comprehensive review of the natural convection phenomena inside a rectangular concentrating compound parabolic collector cavity was presented. It was established that natural convective heat transfer in CPC collector cavities is a complex function of cavity shape, aspect ratio, boundary conditions at the walls and properties of the fluid within the enclosure. From analysis of the correlations developed for regularly shaped enclosures, it was concluded that the employment of these correlations to describe natural convection in CPC solar collector cavities was misleading. The results led to a full experimental study and the results were published in the Solar Energy journal.

Title: Modelling the interaction of haemodynamics and the artery wall: Current status and future prospects
AdditionalInformation: The future role of multi-scale computer models in haemodynamics is mapped out in terms of how modelling techniques of different temporal and spatial scales will interact with each other. The importance to clinical practice is highlighted.

Title: Diesel exhaust-gas reforming for H2 addition to an aftertreatment unit
AdditionalInformation: This work was the result of a research programme on the development of novel diesel engine aftertreatment technologies utilising on-board generated hydrogen. The integration of a NOx aftertreatment unit with a fuel reformer was studied experimentally and guidelines for the development as well as optimised operation of the system are presented. The work was supported by Johnson Matthey (co-author S.E. Golunski) and led to follow-up EPSRC funded research in collaboration with the University of Birmingham, Johnson Matthey and Shell Global Solutions (G038007,‘Novel Compact Aftertreatment Systems for Simultaneous Reduction of Diesel Engine NOx, PM, CO and HC Emissions’, 2009-13).

Title: Processing of advanced Al/SiC particulate metal matrix composites under intensive shearing – A novel Rheo-process
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrates dispersion of nano-scale reinforcement in light metal matrices, allowing the ductility of an alloy to be retained whilst increasing the strength. The €19m research project “EXOMET” (NMP-2011-LARGE-5; NMP.2011.4.0-1) is currently looking at prototyping nanocomposites and the assessment of industrial applications in four selected commercial sectors: (i) automotive powertrain and chassis, (ii) aircraft and aero-engine structures, (iii) space satellite and rockets, and (iv) high-strength high-conductivity Al electrical cabling. To evaluate the ballistic performance of these nanocomposites and their use in other defence applications, an additional 4 year research programme is ongoing with support from DSTL (DSTLX-1000084334).

Title: Interventions for large-scale carbon emission reductions in future UK offices
AdditionalInformation: A comprehensive set of technological interventions that are able to reduce CO2 emissions from existing UK office buildings by 80% were presented. Calculations employed realistic office geometries for four office types, climatic conditions (TRY 2030 data) and state of the art and futuristic technologies. Different intervention and climatic scenarios were created. The paper formed one of the major research outputs of the TARBASE project funded by the Carbon Trust UK and EPSRC.

Title: Development of room temperature and relative humidity linear parametric models for an open office using BMS data
AdditionalInformation: Optimal temperature control for office buildings can reduce energy consumption. An accurate thermal behaviour prediction model is required to achieve adaptive optimal control when there is any change in the building thermal behaviour (e.g. new equipment added or office equipment re-arranged). This paper reported the study of developing linear parametric models using data from existing building management systems. The experience and knowledge gained from this study are not restricted to office building temperature prediction and control problems, but can be extended to other types of buildings such as hospitals, supermarkets, airports and schools.

Title: Cool roof technology in London: An experimental and modelling study
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of an EU IEE programme ‘Cool Roofs in the EU’ – Contract N°: EIE/07/475/SI2.499428. In the UK, the project was conducted in collaboration with the Greater London Authority (GLA). In 2010, the Greater London Authority (GLA) first published the ‘Climate Change Adaptation Strategy for London’ which was updated in 2011.  The strategy commits in Action 5.10 that ‘the Mayor will work with partners to assess and promote “cool roof technology” in London to reduce demand for mechanical cooling.

Title: Application of exhaust gas fuel reforming in diesel and homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) engines fuelled with biofuels
AdditionalInformation: This paper documents the application of exhaust gas fuel reforming of biodiesel and bioethanol in CI (compression ignition) and HCCI (homogeneous charge compression ignition) engines. The research was supported by Shell Global Solutions and built on two previous EPSRC projects on the application of fuel reforming (R12688 ‘Fuel Reforming of Biodiesel Mixtures for Reduced Environmental Impact’ and R58338 ‘Controlled Homogeneous Autoignition Reformed Gas Engine’). The effects of addition of reformate on CI and HCCI combustion, fuel economy and emissions have been studied experimentally and the work makes significant contributions to the design of practical efficient engine-reformer systems that utilise biofuels.

Title: Comparison of flow and dispersion properties of free and wall turbulent jets for source dynamics characterisation
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of the ‘ALAQS’ project (Airport Local Air Quality Studies), funded by EUROCONTROL. The ALAQS consortium was composed of European universities, consultancies and airport operators, and aimed at promoting best practice methods, raising awareness about local air quality issues, and providing a test bed toolset for airport operators. The PhD student who co-authored the paper was fully funded by EUROCONTROL. For verification, please contact: Mr Ian Fuller, EUROCONTROL Experimental Centre, E-mail: ian.fuller@eurocontrol.int

Title: An experimental study of the turbulence quantities in the boundary layer and near-wake of an airfoil placed at upstream of a 90° bend
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an experimental study of turbulent wake of an airfoil, with the aim of producing data to support validation of numerical modelling.
