Examples of practical situations where this kind of flow occurs are in multi-element airfoils, guide vanes in ducts and turbomachines. The importance of the paper is in contributing to a limited database of experimental data for turbulence quantities in situations where the wake is subjected to downstream flow curvature. The data can be used by numerical modellers to set up a number of test cases to assess the performance of various turbulence modelling techniques.

Title: Effect of inlet valve timing and water blending on bioethanol HCCI combustion using forced induction and residual gas trapping
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents research that combines HCCI (homogeneous charge compression ignition) engine combustion with bioethanol, one of the most widely used biofuels. The research followed an EPSRC project on boosted HCCI (S81964 ‘Controlled Homogeneous Autoignition Supercharged Engine’) and it was supported by Shell. The work provides a theoretical insight as well as ways to extend the HCCI engine operating range in order to develop practical bioethanol fuelled HCCI engine systems. The documented approach explores systematically inlet valve timing and water blending as two ways that, when optimised, can lead to lower cylinder pressure rise rates and reduced NOx emissions.

Title: Performance, combustion and emissions of a diesel engine operated with reformed EGR. Comparison of diesel and GTL fuelling
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a comprehensive comparative study of the effect of two liquid fuels, ultra-low sulphur diesel and GTL (gas-to-liquid fuel), combined with three types of exhaust gas recirculation (standard EGR and two different ‘reformed EGR’ compositions) on the performance, combustion process and emissions of a CI (compression ignition) engine. The work provides an insight to practical ways of combining GTL with reformed EGR to achieve significant reductions of diesel smoke and NOx emissions compared to standard diesel fuelling. The research was carried out in collaboration with industry (co-authors R.F. Cracknell and R.H. Clark are Shell Global Solution Technology managers).

Title: The near wall effect of synthetic jets in a boundary layer
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: The scope of this EPSRC-funded research (Grant No. AF566NEZ) was to provide a comprehensive experimental study of the interaction mechanism of a synthetic jet actuator (SJA) and a boundary layer. The research was conducted with the combination of two qualitative visualisation techniques, novel to SJA application – temperature-sensitive liquid crystals (surface visualisation) and stereoscopic dye technique (off-surface visualisation). This study was the first of its kind to establish a parameter space for the formation of different types of SJA vortical structures, including those known to delay flow separation for drag reduction.

Title: Numerical investigation of a perturbed swirling annular two-phase jet
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates swirling annular gas–liquid two-phase jet flow systems by solving the compressible, time-dependent, non-dimensional Navier–Stokes equations using highly accurate numerical methods. The very intensive simulations made use of the facilities of HPCx, the UK’s national high-performance computing service. Computing resources were provided by the UK Turbulence Consortium under EPSRC Grant No. EP/D044073/1. The continuation of this work led to the award of EPSRC Grant No. EP/G062714/1.

Title: Heat transfer from the stagnation area of a heated cylinder at Re(D)=140,000 affected by free-stream turbulence
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports on a simulation of laminar heat transfer enhancement by free-stream turbulence impinging on the stagnation region of a circular cylinder at a relatively high Reynolds number. The physical mechanism, identified earlier to promote stagnation heat transfer at low Reynolds numbers, was found to be also responsible for heat transfer augmentation at high Reynolds numbers. Again, benchmark data are generated with which industrial models for heat transfer augmentation can be verified and improve. For verification contact Prof. Dr. Vittorio Michelassi, Chief Engineer - Aero-Thermal technologies, ATMS, GE Global Research - Munich: vittorio.michelassi@ge.com.

Title: Numerical derivation of constitutive models for unbonded flexible risers
AdditionalInformation: This output is a result of a project funded by EPSRC  (Grant EP/C510232/1) involving a consortium led by Brunel and involving Imperial College, Oxford University, BP, Shell, Lloyds Register, Subsea 7 and Zentech. Dr Bahtui, PhD student in the project, was immediately employed by and is still working for Lloyds Register. The numerical model presented in this output provides the foundation of the computational multi-scale method used in the EPSRC CASE project (CASE/CAN/07/01), which will be further developed in a new project funded by EPSRC (EP/K034243/1) led by Brunel in collaboration with Imperial College, Southampton University, BP and Shell.

Title: Effective elastic properties of randomly distributed void models for porous materials
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an extension to a previously funded EPSRC project (GR/R03426) on the strength of porous materials to expand the numerical modelling capacity, allowing for statistic characters of the porous morphology to be simulated for the design and optimisation of porous materials in specific engineering applications.

Title: Performance evaluation and optimal design of supermarket refrigeration systems with supermarket model “SuperSim”. Part II: Model applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper is Part II following Part I published in the same Journal.  In this part, the developed software ‘SuperSim’ was used to evaluate and compare the performance of a CO2 booster refrigeration system with that of a conventional R404A multiplex system in a supermarket application. Floating head pressure control was implemented for both systems when they are in subcritical cycles. For the CO2 system, the supercritical head pressure was optimized as a function of ambient air temperature. As a result, the system performance will benefit from a lower ambient temperature and a sizeable heat recovery for the CO2 system.

Title: Performance evaluation and optimal design of supermarket refrigeration systems with supermarket model “SuperSim”, Part I: Model description and validation
AdditionalInformation: The research on supermarket modelling was originated with an EPSRC project on ‘Modelling of the Energy and Environmental Impact of Supermarket Environmental Control Systems’, Grant No: GR/L32088. After several years’ improvement, a complete supermarket model ‘SuperSim’ has been development. This paper provides a detailed description of the modelling procedure of ‘SuperSim’ for the simulation of the performance of centralised vapour compression refrigeration systems and their interaction with the building envelope and HVAC systems. The model which has been validated against data from a supermarket is then used for the performance comparison of different refrigeration systems.

Title: The effect of Al8Mn5 intermetallic particles on grain size of as-cast Mg–Al–Zn AZ91D alloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides substantial experimental evidence that Al8Mn5 intermetallic particles in AZ Mg-alloys are not potent substrates for heterogeneous nucleation of alpha-Mg. This paper has settled a decades-long debate on whether Al8Mn5 intermetallic particles are responsible for grain refinement of AZ Mg-alloys.

Title: Effect of activated alloys on hydrogen discharge kinetics of MgH2 nanocrystals
AdditionalInformation: This research was sponsored by Natural Resources Canada, ICPET-ENERGY MATERIALS, Hydrogen Research Institute and Laval University within the Climate Change Initiative and Technology and Innovation Program for the development of Nanomaterials for Hydrogen Energy Storage. The research project assessed new emerging nanotechnologies in conjunction with advanced hydrogen storage for fuel cell distributed energy applications. Novel activated alloys synthesized by arc-melting were examined as catalysts for improving the hydrogen sorption characteristics of nanostructured magnesium hydride. Hydrogen unloading results demonstrate that doping nanostructured Mg-hydride with activated alloys yield increased desorption kinetics and provided substantial reduction of discharge temperature of MgH2 nanocrystals.

Title: Experimental study on a metal hydride based hydrogen compressor
AdditionalInformation: This research was sponsored by Natural Resources Canada, Natural Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada and Stuart Energy Systems, and resulted in the development of a thermal hydrogen compressor based on metal hydrides for sustainable energy storage applications. A three-stage metal hydride based hydrogen compressor prototype was designed and built, and the thermal integration to a low-pressure electrolyser has been demonstrated. The developed compressor has shown very reliable operation and reached project’s expectations in terms of efficiency and compression flow performance. Moreover, innovative concepts of sorption vessels for efficient thermal management and hydrogen compression performance have been developed.

Title: Beyond the Virtual Intracranial Stenting Challenge 2007: Non-Newtonian and flow pulsatility effects
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposed that the role of non-Newtonian models and pulsatile flow in the well-known VISC07 stent study could be more important than assumed by the research community. Results showed that the best stent under average flow conditions may not perform best at all points of the cardiac cycle, with short-term more harmful levels of flow rates or shear stresses being demonstrated.

Title: Pulse wave propagation in a model human arterial network: Assessment of 1-D visco-elastic simulations against in vitro measurements
AdditionalInformation: This work belongs to the field of physiological flow modelling.  Pulse wave propagation analysis is a current topic of investigation in arterial mechanics, but is also of clinical relevance to gain a greater understanding of vascular disease, such as e.g. hypertension. The novelty lies in the incorporation of visco-elastic wall properties for the human artery model, as opposed to the more widely used, but simplified elastic wall model. Strong correlation with in-vitro measurements was achieved. This is a follow up study with Imperial College collaborators that builds on earlier work done for Haemodel, a €1M EU funded 5th Framework Programme.

Title: Bond graph based sensitivity and uncertainty analysis modelling for micro-scale multiphysics robust engineering design
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated how bond graph modelling could be applied to complex networks of components in small devices in order to extract the system equations for sensitivity analysis. The method provides an efficient approach to uncertainty analysis that applies to multiphysics domains. This research on Micro-scale Robust Engineering Design, including paper 1, was funded by EPSRC (GR/S63496/01 and 02) and was given a very high rating (‘Tending to Outstanding’).

Title: Microstructural refinement of Al–10.2%Si alloy by intensive shearing
AdditionalInformation: This work clearly demonstrated that intensive shearing of Al-Si liquid metal in conjunction with liquidus casting can be successfully employed to produce a refined microstructure. In addition, well distributed finer intermetallic particles can be also obtained through intensive shearing, which otherwise, is not achievable through a conventional casting method.

Title: Cold cracking in DC-cast high strength aluminum alloy ingots: An intrinsic problem intensified by casting process parameters
AdditionalInformation: This paper published in a high-ranking journal (I.F. 2.108) is based on the presentation at TMS (Metals, Minerals and Materials Society) Annual Meeting in 2011, USA (major forum for metallurgists and materials scientists), of which the paper won the Warren Peterson Cast Shop for Aluminum Production Award of TMS. The paper describes the first modern criterion of cold cracking that can be used to prevent this disastrous casting defect and improve the productivity and safety at cast houses around the world. Based on this paper a keynote lecture will be given at 13th Aluminium Cast House Technology Conference, Australia, 2014.

Title: Characterisation of Gd2O2S:Pr phosphor screens for water window X-ray detection
VolumeTitle: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a fruitful collaboration between the Wolfson Centre at Brunel University and the Physics department at Kings College London. The phosphors produced by the Wolfson group were superior to any currently available from industry. This paper led to six successful bids for time on the Diamond light source and on Bessy II with total beam times being worth around £82K. All six bids were phosphor based. Two of these were within the collaboration and the other four came out of new international collaborations (with Indian and Italian universities) that grew from this publication.

Title: Macrosegregation in direct-chill casting of aluminium alloys
AdditionalInformation: Published in the most prestigious materials science journal (I.F. 23.194), this paper presents the first comprehensive and analytical review on the subject. It equips industrial researchers with tools for understanding the interaction between process parameters, alloy composition and acting mechanisms of macrosegregation. Resulted in invited lectures at the 12th Int. Conf. on Aluminium Alloys (Japan, 2010), Nippon Light Metals (2010), keynote lecture at TMS Annual Meeting (USA, 2014).

Title: Direct numerical simulation of diluted combustion by evaporating droplets
AdditionalInformation: This is one of the earliest publications of a series of computational studies on complex interactions among combustion, turbulence and evaporating droplets. Interactions of this kind occur in a multiplicity of combustion-related engineering applications, e.g. flame suppression and diluted combustion. A hybrid numerical methodology was developed, where the continuum Eulerian approach and the point-source-based Lagrangian approach are used for the turbulent reacting gas phase and the dispersed evaporating droplets, respectively. The numerical accuracy of the code was demonstrated by excellent consistence of the results on different grids using the Eulerian-Lagrangian approach, which is a well-known difficult aim to achieve.

Title: Thermal stability of a binary non-faceted/non-faceted peritectic organic alloy at elevated temperatures
AdditionalInformation: Transparent organic substances are used in solidification studies to investigate solidification events in real time. To date the substances have been used to study eutectic solidification. This paper is significant in that it examines a potential peritectic non-facetted non-facetted organic model alloy, NPG (neopentylglycol)–TRIS (tris(hydroxy-menthyl)aminomethane) system. By comparing Bridgman experimentation results with DSC results a window was found that would enable the directional solidification of peritectic systems, under stable conditions, to be studied.

Title: Urban heat island intensity in London: An investigation of the impact of physical characteristics on changes in outdoor air temperature during summer
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as part of the EPSRC funded project LUCID – grant no EP/Eo16308/1 and the EU IEE programme ‘Cool Roofs in the EU’ – Contract N°: EIE/07/475/SI2.499428.  Results from this paper will make a contribution to the new International Energy Agency (IEA), Energy in Buildings and Communities (EBC) programme, Annex 62: Ventilative Cooling which has been approved by the EBC executive committee and will start in January 2014 for 4 years with the collaborative contribution from 15 countries from Europe, USA, China and Japan.

Title: A validated methodology for the prediction of heating and cooling energy demand for buildings within the Urban Heat Island: Case-study of London
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of the EPSRC funded project LUCID – grant no EP/E016308/1.  The results of this paper contributed to the revision of CIBSE Guide A, chapter 2: External design data, section on Climate Change and Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect.

Title: Correlations for natural convective heat exchange in CPC solar collector cavities determined from experimental measurements
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents a comprehensive experimental study of the natural convective heat  flow that plays a major role in the heat loss from the selectively coated receiver of a solar concentrating compound parabolic collector.  For the first time, experimentally measured characteristics and correlations were presented that are able to take into account collector geometry and operational parameters to predict and natural convective heat transfer coefficient inside the collector cavity. It is expected that results will be employed in a research proposal for Horizon2020 currently under preparation.

Title: Mode-shape recognition and finite element model updating using the Zernike moment descriptor
AdditionalInformation: A new technique using image processing and pattern recognition concepts is developed for the problem of  mode-shape recognition for plate structures. The method uses the Zernike moment descriptor which is a region-based shape descriptor having outstanding mathematical properties, computing efficiency, ease of reconstruction and robustness to noise. The descriptor is showing considerable advantages over the traditional industrial methods of correlation when identifying the cyclically symmetric mode shapes  that occur in axisymmetric structures at identical frequencies. The concept used previously in other areas of science and engineering such as medicine and forensics, is for the first time applied in this field.

Title: Direct numerical simulations of transition in a compressor cascade: The influence of free-stream turbulence
AdditionalInformation: Physical mechanisms involved in free-stream-turbulence induced laminar-to-turbulent boundary layer transition around compressor blades are identified and analysed. The results provide benchmark data that are relevant for the improvement and verification of models used in industry for the calculation of turbomachinery flows. For verification contact Prof. Dr. Vittorio Michelassi, Chief Engineer - Aero-Thermal technologies, ATMS, GE Global Research - Munich: vittorio.michelassi@ge.com.

Title: Direct numerical simulation of heat transfer from the stagnation region of a heated cylinder affected by an impinging wake
AdditionalInformation: Highly accurate numerical simulations were performed to identify and understand the physical mechanisms that play a role in the enhancement of heat transfer by a wake impinging on the stagnation region of gas turbine blades. Also, benchmark data is produced with which models employed in numerical codes used to calculate turbomachinery flows by turbo machinery manufacturers can be verified and improved. For verification contact Prof. Dr. Vittorio Michelassi, Chief Engineer - Aero-Thermal technologies, ATMS, GE Global Research - Munich: vittorio.michelassi@ge.com.

Title: Articular human joint modelling
AdditionalInformation: Our muculoskeletal joint modelling is one of the most advanced in the field, modelling joints with anatomical surfaces rather than standard engineering joint types, capable of performing forced contact driven articulation.   The modeller is unique and attracted a great deal of attention. The authors were invited by Prof. Edmund Chao (a leading authority in musculoskeletal joint modelling) to give a keynote lecture in his VIM conference in Taiwan.  The software also attracted industrial interest and was used by Unilever to investigate joint stiffness and muscle tremor in the settings of inverse and forward motion analysis  (Dr Guoping Lian, Unilever).

Title: Synthesis of YBa2Cu3O7−δand Y2BaCuO5 Nanocrystalline Powders for YBCO Superconductors Using Carbon Nanotube Templates
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates a method to synthesise ~30 nm nano-sized high temperature superconducting ternary oxide powders using carbon nanotubes as templates. These nano-particles have been successfully introduced in a single grain superconductors and the processing method is identified to be an effective source of pinning centres. This work led to further research development and is currently being applied in producing batch process superconductors for storing solar energy for the use in desalination of sea-water in the Saudi Kingdom. An international collaborative research programme with Professor Ibrahim S. Al-Mssallem at King Abdulaziz City for Science and Technology has been established.

Title: Copper(I) complexes with bipyridyl and phosphine ligands: a systematic study
AdditionalInformation: The work is a collaboration between Brunel, Durham University and the University of Bari. A new range of mononuclear Cu 1+ bipyridine coordination complexes are prepared, characterised and the emission thoroughly investigated. The complexes have been prepared with the aim to prove how the energy and intensity of the emission can be manipulated by the chemistry of the ligands, in order to obtain emitting species with a wide range of optical properties. These complexes are aimed to be applied to the emerging OLED technology and a deep investigation of their stability has also been carried out in this work.

Title: Direct numerical simulation of the near-field dynamics of annular gas-liquid two-phase jets
AdditionalInformation: This paper developed an advanced direct numerical simulation technique to examine the near-field dynamics of annular gas-liquid two-phase jets. The simulations were very intensive and time consuming, and the work made use of the facilities of HPCx, the UK’s national high-performance computing service. Computing resources were provided by the UK Turbulence Consortium under EPSRC Grant No. EP/D044073/1.

Title: Particle image velocimetry measurements of the interaction of synthetic jets with a zero-pressure gradient laminar boundary layer
AdditionalInformation: The scope of this EPSRC-funded research (Grant No. AF566NEZ) was to quantify the interaction between the different vortical structures formed from a synthetic jet actuator (SJA) and a boundary layer, using particle image velocimetry. The study was the first of its kind to demonstrate which type of vortical structure is most suitable for potentially delaying flow separation for drag reduction. This is particularly relevant for optimising SJA operating conditions in an application setting for separation control, e.g. deflected aircraft control surfaces such as slats and flaps.

Title: Analysis of Controlled Auto-Ignition/HCCI Combustion in a Direct Injection Gasoline Engine with Single and Split Fuel Injections
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper clarified the role of the physical and chemical effects of fuel reforming process associated with the direct fuel injection into hot residual gases and their effect on the combustion timing in a CAI/HCCI engine. The finding identified a means to controlling the autoignition combustion phasing during the CAI/HCCI operation. This work was sponsored by EPSRC and Ford Motor Company.

Title: Dynamic Large-Eddy Simulation of Droplet Effects on a Reacting Plume in Countercurrent Configuration
AdditionalInformation: Different from the previous 3 outputs in which direct numerical simulation (DNS) was used, this paper presents the large-eddy simulation (LES) results of interactions between water droplets and a reacting plume. While DNS is ideal for exploring physics and developing models, LES can save computational costs and meanwhile reveal instantaneous flow phenomena. The developed LES methodology features dynamic subgrid flow models, which do not require predetermined model constants, thereby significantly decreasing model uncertainty. It is worth mentioning that this paper presents the first LES study of an idealised water-based fire suppression system.

Title: Characterisation of magnesium oxide and its interface with α-Mg in Mg–Al-based alloys
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time that the interface between MgO and alpha-Mg is semi-coherent in solidified Mg-Al alloys, providing the ultimate evidence that MgO can be a potent substrate for heterogeneous nucleation of alpha-Mg during solidification processing. This paper makes a solid contribution the understanding of heterogeneous nucleation on potent substrate.

Title: Conditional statistics of inert droplet effects on turbulent combustion in reacting mixing layers
AdditionalInformation: The Conditional Moment Closure (CMC) is a modelling approach that has found its successful application in a variety of cases and is currently under active development. This paper presents the inert-droplet effects on conditionally averaged statistics, thereby investigating the feasibility of the application of the CMC in turbulent multiphase combustion and related topics such as if a singly conditioned CMC can properly model such a case. A revised “mixture fraction’’ was proposed for the first time for a diluted combustion case, where a gaseous diffusion flame interacts with inert evaporating droplets. This definition underpins the development of mixture-fraction-based models.

Title: Quantitative measurements of in-cylinder gas composition in a controlled auto-ignition combustion engine
AdditionalInformation: In-cylinder mixture composition has significant impact on the combustion process, efficiency and pollutant formation in an IC engine. This paper demonstrates that Spontaneous Raman Scattering (SRS) can be used to measure multiple species simultaneously with excellent accuracy by incorporating the newly developed calibration method and data processing techniques. This work was conducted by a PhD student and supported by EPSRC.

Title: Light-emitting nanocasts formed from bio-templates: FESEM and cathodoluminescent imaging studies of butterfly scale replicas
AdditionalInformation: An image from this paper was chosen for the front cover of the issue. The paper was the first to present both cathodoluminescent and SEM images (collected in the same scanning electron microscope) of a nanocast of a bio-template (e.g. butterfly wing scale replicas. Extraordinary details were observed. The paper/technique has pioneered/opened a new field of research for biologists, physicists and material scientists. This work led to the University buying a new a new STEM with a cathodoluminescent attachment that allows us to study single nanoparticles of phosphors and obtain cathodoluminescence (CL) spectra from individual crystals.

Title: A finite-element-based formulation for sensitivity studies of piezoelectric systems
AdditionalInformation: Brunel developed new computer models that led to improved design rules, which in turn allowed Redux/HiWave/NXT (the company has adopted new business names since project end) to produce better piezoelectric actuators used for audio devices incorporated into products of Microsoft, Toshiba, HTC, Nissha printing, Yota and Hybra Corp. Over 280,000 units have been sold to date with another 24 million plus units expected to ship from 2014. James East, Engineering Manager at Redux Labs, can verify these facts. This paper describes a finite-element-based sensitivity method developed to identify the key parameters affecting device performance.

Title: Surface plasmon resonance imaging detection of silver nanoparticle-tagged immunoglobulin
VolumeTitle: Journal of The Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: This paper was part of an on-going programme on surface plasmon resonance studies on tagged biological materials. The paper reports that the detection limit of this SPR imaging instrument is 6.66 nM of gIgG achieved through signal enhancement by a factor of larger than 4, arising from nanoparticle tagging with the antibody. The work reported in this paper led to the award of a grant to Dr Fern (and others) from St George’s Hospital innovation fund for studies entitled “Viral Surface Plasmon Resonance: A Novel Approach to Bio-sensing”.

Title: An overview of recent applications of computational modelling in neonatology
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an invited contribution to a special issue on ‘The virtual physiological human (VPH): computer simulation for integrative biomedicine’. The VPH is ‘a methodological and technological framework to enable collaborative investigation of the human body as a single complex system’. The original abstract was selected from a pool of several hundred contributions, and the full paper went through a thorough peer review process. The paper highlights the utility of the VPH approach in exploring the functioning of complex medical devices in a more integrative manner.

Title: Biodegradable and compostable alternatives to conventional plastics
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This is an invited contribution to a special edition of the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society. It is accompanied with original research in home compostability of a wide range of bio-materials and life cycle assessment. It has been well cited since its publication.

Title: Focused Ion Beam NanoSQUIDs as Novel NEMS Resonator Readouts
AdditionalInformation: Nano-scale electromechanical system (NEMS) resonators are expected to have a variety of applications, ranging from ultra-sensors for physical parameters (mass, force, charge, spin, chemical specificity) to single molecule bio-sensing, information storage and processing technologies, and even to nanoscale refrigerators. This paper presented novel methods for exciting cantilever-style NEMS resonators and reading out information for sensing purposes. The theoretical and experimental studies reveal that sub-picometer amplitude sensitivity is potentially achievable.

Title: A parametric study of passive flow control for a short, high area ratio 90 deg curved diffuser
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper is related to the development of a technique to control the highly unstable flow in a curved diffuser. The results show that flow separation was inhibited and a maximum pressure recovery at the diffuser exit was achieved. The technique is then successfully applied to a large scale aeroacoustic wind tunnel in the University of Southampton (see my other nominated paper on the “Design and performance...”). Similarly, the flow control technique developed in this study can easily be applied to other engineering applications such as the combat aircraft engine intake and racing car diffuser inlet.

Title: Modeling sound propagation in acoustic waveguides using a hybrid numerical method
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: This article presents fundamental modelling techniques that underpin articles N01-N03.

Title: A hybrid finite element approach to modeling sound radiation from circular and rectangular ducts
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by EPSRC grant numbers EP/H015280/1 and EP/H015469.  The article presents an entirely new and computationally efficient way of studying sound radiation problems.  This enabled the integration of the work into three dimensional models of sound propagation in sewer systems, which include all elements of the sewer system including the manhole.  The results are being applied in the development of the commercial product Sewerbatt  (http://www.acousticsensing.co.uk/).

Title: Design and Assessment of a Multiple Sensor Fault Tolerant Robust Control System
VolumeTitle: Journal of Control Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Fault-tolerant control is an emerging technology to improve reliability, availability and survivability for safety critical systems such as aircraft and high speed trains. This paper proposed a fault-tolerant control framework for systems with potential multiple sensor faults. This research was influenced by discussions within the framework of the European Flight Mechanics Action Group on Fault Tolerant Control, comprising collaborators from the European industry, universities and research establishments as part of the Group for Aeronautical Research and Technology in Europe (GARTEUR) programme.

Title: Thermal behaviour model identification for an office space using BMS data
VolumeTitle: Building Services Engineering Research and Technology
AdditionalInformation: Due to nonlinear and complex nature in relationships between thermal behaviour and the factors affecting it, nonlinear models are best suited to predict room temperature in office buildings. This paper studies both linear and nonlinear models in order to develop good prediction models for building environment management and energy efficient improvement.

Title: Theoretical and experimental studies of air-hybrid engine operation with fully variable valve actuation
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper was conducted as a PhD project in collaboration with Lotus Engineering. The results demonstrated the potential of air hybrid engines for improved fuel economy and identified the need for further development of production feasible mild air hybrid powertrain technologies, which were the subject of two subsequent EPSRC projects and led to a commercial licence agreement with Guangxi Yuchai Machinery Ltd.

Title: Transition of amorphous to crystalline oxide film in initial oxide overgrowth on liquid metals
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we have for the first time demonstrated theoretically that formation of a thin layer of amorphous oxide at the early stages of oxidation of liquid metals is thermodynamically favourable for pure aluminium, but not for pure Mg. This paper makes a solid contribution to the understanding of oxidation of liquid metals and alloys and provides a theoretical basis for melt protection during casting processes.

Title: Improvement in silicon morphology and mechanical properties of Al–17Si alloy by melt conditioning shear technology
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Cast Metals Research
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates for the first time that intensive melt shearing can be used to refine the primary Si phase in hypereutectic Al-Si alloys without involving any chemical inoculation. In addition this paper provides the theoretical basis for grain refining primary Si in such alloys. This could have a significant impact on the automotive applications of such alloys and a positive effect on environmental protection.

Title: Effect of intensive shearing on morphology of primary silicon and properties of hypereutectic Al–Si alloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates clearly that intensive melt shearing can be used to enhance mechanical performance of hypereutectic Al-Si alloys through significant refinement of primary Si. This could have a significant impact on the automotive applications of such alloys and a positive effect on environmental protection.

Title: Effect of differential compression on in-plane permeability tensor of heterogeneous multilayer carbon fibre preforms
AdditionalInformation: This paper contributes to a long-standing problem in composites manufacturing. For the last decade, the measurement of permeability for fibre reinforcements has been under investigation and there is no consensus on the correct manner to establish a true value. One of the problems is the changing of permeability during manufacturing. This paper has experimentally tested and numerically clarified further the impact of mould compression on in-plane permeability values of a specific composite multi layer stack of unidirectional and 5-harness satin weave carbon fibre fabric, which is a common lay-up and therefore of great relevance to the aerospace and defence industries.

Title: Enhanced self-field critical current density of nano-composite YBa2Cu3O7 thin films grown by pulsed-laser deposition
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrates that chemically stable artificial nano-scale flux pinning centres can be introduced into high temperature rare earth cuprate superconducting materials. The research led to filing patents in the UK, USA, Japan and Europe. The patent is licensed to Boeing Phantom Work Ltd (Contact name: Dr Mike Strasik). The technology is further developed to “mass produce” bulk superconductors for flywheel energy storage applications. Over 12 research papers were published in collaboration with research groups from Germany, Austria, USA, Slovakia and Japan. Numerous invited lectures were delivered (e.g, Centennial Superconductivity conference EUCAS 2011, ICSM 2010 Turkey, PAREG 2012 Taiwan).

Title: Finite element analysis of intramedullary devices: the effect of the gap between the implant and the bone
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of a PhD project, carried out in conjunction with both a biomedical manufacturing company (Stryker) and a practising consultant orthopaedic surgeon, as part of an ongoing programme to investigate the importance of modelling criteria in the design of intramedullary devices. The programme involved both modelling and in-vitro experimental work, and was funded through work carried out for the biomedical company.

Title: Numerical simulation of ram extrusion in short-fiber-reinforced fresh cementitious composites
VolumeTitle: Journal of Mechanics of Materials and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper developed an elasto-viscoplastic constitutive model for short discrete fibre-reinforced semi-solid fresh cementitious composites. The model was utilized for design and optimisation of industry-scale extrusion system for manufacturing cement-based building products such as roof tiles, down pipes, wall panels, etc. The outputs of this research have been transferred into industry with two factories established in China using this technique. For verification, please contact Dr Zongjin Li, Professor in Civil Engineering Materials, Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (zongjin@ust.hk).

Title: Application of a Pendulum Support Test Rig for Aircraft Stability Derivative Estimation
AdditionalInformation: This work was undertaken as part of Contract No. CU004-26949 for the Aerodynamics Integration Division, Future System Technologies, Qinetiq Farnborough, and involved the investigation a Pendulum Support Rig (PSR) as a viable platform for the accurate determination of both static and dynamic aircraft stability parameters. The work involved the measurement of a wind tunnel model dynamic response in up to five degrees of freedom (pitch, roll, yaw, heave and sway). From analyzing these motions and comparing them to the known control surface inputs, dynamic stability data was then estimated and compared to other testing techniques with good correlation.

Title: Experimental Investigation of Bistable Winglets to Enhance Aircraft Wing Lift Takeoff Capability
AdditionalInformation: This work was undertaken through a Marie-Curie Excellence grant MEXT-CT-2003-002690 funded by the European Commission and involved the investigation and experimental validation of a new and novel bi-stable winglet design that would allow two discrete winglet configurations depending on the aircraft flight configuration. This involved a planar winglet configuration that would enhance wing lift under low speed condition (i.e. at take-off) and a secondary, more traditional winglet configuration, for cruise flight. The design and performance of the winglet was proven through experimental analysis and wind tunnel testing.

Title: Characterization and properties of NiTi(W) and CuAlNi shape memory alloys
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Materials Research (formerly Zeitschrift fuer Metallkunde)
AdditionalInformation: Shape memory alloys (SMAs) have an important role in advanced applications, as a predetermined response from the alloys can be obtained from a thermal or electrical signal. This paper determines the effect of processing and training of three different alloy systems (NiTi, NiTiW and CuAlNi) under a constant stress, on the microstructure and mechanical response.  Two-way shape memory effects (TWSMEs) were successfully introduced in these alloys by training. Results found that the higher strength materials were more difficult to train, exhibit smaller TWSMEs, but are more stable against fatigue.

Title: Effects of lattice mismatch on interfacial structures of liquid and solidified Al in contact with hetero-phase substrates: MD simulations
VolumeTitle: IOP Conference Series: Materials Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper revealed for the first time the existence of atomic ordering at the liquid/substrate interface at temperatures above the melting point and the effect of lattice misfit on such atomic ordering. The academic significance of this finding comes from that such atomic ordering becomes a pre-nucleation event, which in turn has a strong effect on the heterogeneous nucleation process. This paper has paved the way to molecular dynamic simulation of the heterogeneous nucleation process.

Title: On the emission of bis-arylacetylide trinuclear Cu(I) complexes
AdditionalInformation: The work is a collaboration between Brunel University and the Polytechnic in Milan. Following our empirical findings, as described in output NO. 2, we have carried out a range of DFT calculations in an attempt to clearly explain the correlation between the electronic environment of the ligand and the geometry of the excited state in trinuclear Cu 1+ coordination complexes.  The findings born out of the calculations confirm the existence of a strong correlation between the electronic nature of the ligand and the energetic level of the excited state, resulting in tuning of the emission colour.

Title: Incorporation of wheat starch and coupling agents into poly(lactic acid) to develop biodegradable composite
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of Silva’s PhD studies, under my supervision, on “Incorporation of wheat starch and coupling agents into poly lactic acid to develop a biodegradable composite”. PLA is still biodegradable but not home compostable and, with the incorporation of wheat starch, we were able to demonstrate compostability without significant reduction in mechanical properties. For this project, the student won second price in a poster competition on Renewable Materials for Biodegradable Packaging at Loughborough University in April 2009, on the topic “Bioplastics Processing and Properties”.

Title: A modal coupling procedure to improve residual modal effects based on experimentally generated data
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with dynamic analyses of structures using the component mode synthesis method. In this method, the original structure is decomposed into simpler and smaller substructures, and the modal properties of the resulting substructures are first evaluated independently.  In order to avoid inaccuracies normally associated with the modal coupling results, we proposed a modified method to assess the effect of neglecting the higher frequency modes during the regenerating process. The proposed modified method offers a more accurate way of analysing structures using data from the substructures, and has a considerable impact on the accuracy of dynamic design of structures.

Title: London's urban heat island: Impact on current and future energy consumption in office buildings
AdditionalInformation: Similarly to output no 2, this output was disseminated as a result of the EPSRC funded project LUCID – grant no EP/E016308/1.  The results of this paper contributed to the revision of CIBSE Guide A, chapter 2: External design data, section on Climate Change and Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect.

Title: On the scattering of torsional elastic waves from axisymmetric defects in coated pipes
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a companion paper to N01.  These are the first articles to measure the acoustic properties of a viscoelastic coating in the frequency range of interest for long range ultrasonic testing.  The findings of these articles permit the accurate modelling of coated oil and gas pipelines and will provide a clear advantage when it comes to developing new ultrasonic diagnostic techniques.

Title: Evolution of manufacturing processes for fiber-reinforced thermoset tanks, vessels, and silos: a review
AdditionalInformation: This publication is a review on the evolution of composite manufacturing methods and best practice in industry, specifically for the application of tanks and pressure vessels, in a journal (IIE Transactions) that is recognized and read by the composites manufacturing industry sector. Due to its relevance, Spanish company Poltank, internationally active in the fabrication of Glass Reinforced Plastic (GRP) pressure vessels and large filtration systems, gave access to its production facilities in order to gain hands-on industry experience for some of the production techniques addressed in the review.

Title: Numerical implementation and experimental validation of a through-the-thickness temperature model for non-isothermal vacuum bagging infusion
VolumeTitle: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses a problem in composites manufacturing. Non-isothermal injection processes can suffer from inhomogeneous cure, causing residual stresses or deformations. With aerospace and automotive industry making ever bigger and thicker parts via vacuum bagging injection, this is a significant and costly problem that is currently addressed by trial and error because heat transfer simulation models are not well explored for vacuum bagging techniques. In this work, an analytical temperature gradient model is derived specifically for the vacuum bagging process. Results demonstrate that the model can reproduce the through-the-thickness temperature gradient with reasonable accuracy and be relevant for industrial practice.

Title: Predicted and in situ performance of a solar air collector incorporating a translucent granular aerogel cover
AdditionalInformation: This research work was part of an EngD programme sponsored by EPSRC and Buro Happold Ltd and titled ‘Novel Retrofit Technologies Incorporating Silica Aerogel for Lower Energy Buildings’, which resulted in the development of an innovative solar-air heater incorporating aerogel, successfully integrated into the façade of a newly refurbished 1960s end-of-terrace house in South East London. The product was the winner of the “Passive Product of the Year” at the 2013 CIBSE Building Performance Awards.

Title: Tests of prototype PCM ‘sails’ for office cooling
AdditionalInformation: This research was part of an EngD programme sponsored by EPSRC and Buro Happold Ltd and titled ‘The Application of Phase Change Materials to Cool Buildings’, which resulted in the development of a new low energy cooling system, known as NewMass. A prototype system has been tested in a custom built thermal chamber. Results revealed excellent temperature control potential and beneficial convection cycle in the air. Modelling, based on empirical operation parameters, suggests around 35% energy savings. The NewMass PCM cooling system is currently the subject of a patent application and component parts for mass manufacture have been identified.

Title: Performing co-ordinated turns with articulated wing-tips as multi-axis control effectors
AdditionalInformation: This work was undertaken through a Marie-Curie Excellence grant MEXT-CT-2003-002690 funded by the European Commission and involved the investigation and experimental validation of a novel aircraft flight control method using articulated winglets. Included in this work was the prediction of flight control forces and aerodynamics together with the experimental validation using a purposely designed and built active wind tunnel test model. This work has led to various subsequent investigations undertaken both by the original authors as well as other external investigators.

Title: Numerical simulation and comparison with experiment of natural convection between two floors of a building model via a stairwell
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This paper aims to further investigate previously published experimental data by the present author, which was proposed as a possible test case for numerical simulations of a highly three-dimensional natural convection flow. The paper relates specifically to a rather narrow and less studied case of flow between floors of a building via the connecting stairwell. The importance of the paper is in providing a numerical study with direct comparison with experimental data. The results showed a good level of consistency between different simulation results and the experimental data, which validated both the experimental and numerical data for this purpose.

Title: Numerical study and comparison with experiment of dispersion of a heavier-than-air gas in a simulated neutral atmospheric boundary layer
VolumeTitle: Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a comparison study of numerical prediction and experimental data for the dispersion of a plume of heavier-than-air gas in an atmospheric boundary layer. The paper uses a published wind tunnel experimental data to set up a numerical model for further investigation. The importance of the paper is in the assessment of the degree to which the experimental conditions and plume parameters can be reproduced theoretically. A method based on the use of an existing empirical correlation was suggested to facilitate the choice of the turbulent Schmidt number.

Title: Wavelet approach to vibratory analysis of surface due to a load moving in the layer
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper results from collaborative work with a number of European universities for the last twelve years.  We developed a multi-body version of the model and implemented in our MBDS (multi-body dynamics simulator) software which is widely used in industry, particularly by Trelleborg in rail related applications.  The improved model not only has the ability to consider random foundations, but also non-linear mounts.  Trelleborg has now made a decision to base all their future modelling on MBDS  (Prof. Piotr Koziol, University of Koszalin; Bill Mortel, Trelleborg).

Title: A novel method to obtain a real-time control force strategy using genetic algorithms for dynamic systems subjected to external arbitrary excitations
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel algorithm applicable to the optimal control of any dynamical system under arbitrary excitations.  This is based on the Ponyagin principle to determine reversals in the control strategy, which determines the chromosome length with which evolution optimal control can be obtained.   This research has been the foundation of a large number of PhD research projects in our group.  Furthermore, our optimal control work resulted in developing a KTP project with Trelleborg which has  now led into developing a fully functioning  engine vibration cancellation device to be commercialised by Trelleborg (Contact: Bill Mortel, Trelleborg).

Title: Non-destructive evaluation of cement-based materials from pressure-stimulated electrical emission – Preliminary results
AdditionalInformation: The determination of the residual strength of in-situ concrete structures remains a major challenge.  This PhD project examined the measurement of very small electrical emissions, stimulated by loading, to assess the stress levels in reinforced concrete.  The project was the result of international university collaborations, based on work carried out by the Greek partners.

Title: Measurement of in-cylinder soot particles and their distribution in an optical HSDI diesel engine using time resolved laser induced incandescence (TR-LII)
AdditionalInformation: Nano particles are detrimental for human health and environment, in this work the formation of nano-soot particles from a single cylinder optical diesel engine was explored. Time-resolved laser induced incandescence technique (TR-LII) was used to measure crank angle resolved soot particle size and soot volume fraction during the combustion and expansion process. Particle sizes are dependent on the engine load and no sized dependence was observed for fuel injection timings. The average sizes of particles measured were larger at higher engine loads compared to lower engine loads. This work was published together with Shell - industrial collaborators on this project.

Title: Effects of injection parameters and EGR on combustion and emission characteristics of rapeseed oil and its blends in diesel engines
AdditionalInformation: The combustion and emission characteristics of rapeseed oil and the blends of 50%, 30%, 20% and 10% of rapeseed oil in diesel for different fuel injection pressures, fuel injection timing and for different percentages of EGR were explored. Increasing the EGR and retarding the fuel injection timing reduced the NOx emissions for rapeseed oil blends in diesel engines. By simultaneously retarding the fuel injection timing and increasing the injection pressure, the soot emissions were effectively reduced by maintaining low NOx emissions, particularly for blends up to 30% rapeseed oil with diesel.

Title: Bond-slip analysis via a thermodynamically consistent interface model combining interlocking, damage and friction
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This output is the result of a collaboration with the University of Sannio in Italy in the framework of a line of research on the development of interface models for the analysis of crack propagation which account for friction but also other dissipating phenomena. The results presented in this article have also been presented by Dr Alfano in invited seminars at the Universities of Glasgow, Durham and Eindhoven.

Title: Flow boiling in a 1.1 mm tube with R134a: Experimental results and comparison with model
AdditionalInformation: The paper contributes to the further understanding of the prevailing mechanisms in flow boiling in micro passages and the possibilities for modelling. Thome and co-workers in EPFL (Lausanne) produced a novel mechanistic model to predict heat transfer in these geometries (Thome et a. IJHMT, 2004). The Brunel team (in frequent communication with Lausanne) produced accurate local heat transfer results to compare with the model. They concluded that the model results are sensitive to three parameters that need to be optimized. They noted that the predictive capability will improve if these are independently determined, improving also modelling of the partial dryout.

Title: A study of discrepancies in flow boiling results in small to microdiameter metallic tubes
AdditionalInformation: The discrepancies in the published data on flow boiling heat transfer and its dependence on parameters such as mass and heat flux, pressure and vapour quality limited the ability of researchers to agree and converge to models/correlations that can be used in the design of micro-evaporators for thermal management applications. The paper made a unique/novel contribution documenting the reasons for the disagreement, namely the effect of the heated length and surface characteristics, also noting that instability is the third reason. Inclusion of the effect of these parameters was considered essential in comparisons among results from different laboratories and modelling/correlation work.

Title: Light-weight wood–magnesium oxychloride cement composite building products made by extrusion
AdditionalInformation: This paper developed attractive wood-like door frame and door panels made from low carbon magnesium oxychloride cement using a continuous energy- and water-saving processing technology, i.e., extrusion. The building products developed possess wood colour and are nailable but with acceptable strength ready for replacing real natural wood. The raw materials for producing magnesium oxychloride cement require much less energy and release much less carbon during the manufacturing process compared with those for producing clinker for manufacturing Portland cement. Therefore, this study presented a true sustainable solution of materials for the building products industry.

Title: Mechanisms of enhanced heterogeneous nucleation during solidification in binary Al–Mg alloys
AdditionalInformation: For the first time we discovered that the oxide films in Al-Mg binary alloys are liquid films containing discrete MgAl2O4 particles, which are effective substrates for heterogeneous nucleation of alpha-Al. In addition, we found that such heterogeneous nucleation can be enhanced by intensive melt shearing, which disperses the oxide films into individual particles. Academically, this discovery demonstrates a new approach to grain refinement using in situ formed oxide particles. Technically, this discovery has led to a patent application for a new grain refiner alloy based on MgAl2O4 particles (Patent Application No: 1107060.4. Priority date: 27/04/2011).

Title: Discovery of two new phases of zirconium tetrakis(8-hydroxyquinolinolate): synthesis, crystal structure and their electron transporting characteristics in organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs)
AdditionalInformation: This paper, published in a high-ranking journal, describes the discovery of two new phases of a zirconium compound (zirconium tetrakis 8-hydroxyquinolinolate) which remain undetected for over 50 years. We have named these two new forms α (monoclinic) and β (orthorhombic). In organic light emitting devices, the α form was found to reduce the operating voltage by 21% and enhance the life-time by 6 fold compared to the industry “workhorse” aluminium tris (8-hydroxyquinolinolate) (Alq3). It also leaves no residues on heating at 300 0C in a vacuum OLED production plant for over 6 weeks, making it environmentally friendly.

Title: Novel lithium Schiff-base cluster complexes as electron injectors: synthesis, crystal structure, thin film characterisation and their performance in OLEDs
AdditionalInformation: Organic electron injectors permit the use of low cost, air stable metal cathodes such as aluminium as opposed to highly reactive low work function metals such as Ca, Mg or its alloys in organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs). Further, organic electron injectors are also admixed with electron transporters to provide balanced charge injection, which is critical for long life-time of OLEDs. The paper describes the synthesis of a low cost and non-toxic alternative (Lithium-Schiff Base Complex) to the toxic lithium quinolinolate (LiQ) currently used in the industry.  This work was supported by Merck Chemicals GmbH.

Title: Arylvinylene phenanthroline derivatives for electron transport in blue organic light emitting diodes
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes an investigation into the possibility of increasing the stability of an electron transporting /hole blocking layer in an organic lighting emitting device stack by molecular engineering. We succeeded in delivering a highly thermally and electronically stable material which improves the efficiency of typical blue emitting OLED devices by 83% and their life-time by 6 fold compared to the industry standards.

Title: Novel phenanthroline derivatives for electron transport in organic light-emitting diodes
AdditionalInformation: Organic light emitting Diodes (OLEDs) have now become accepted as a major flat panel display technology. OLED displays revenue for AMOLED phones (Samsung Galaxy series) in 2012 is over US$10 billion. There is still a continuing demand for voltage reduction and enhancement of the device life-time dictated by the environmental concern. The paper describes the synthesis of a new class of compounds which reduce the operating voltage by 36% and increase the life time by up to 1000 fold. The work was supported by Merck Chemicals, Germany.

Title: A study of gasoline-alcohol blended fuels in an advanced turbocharged DISI engine
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Fuels and Lubricants
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as the result of a two-year full-time collaboration between BP Fuels and the powertrain consultancy business MAHLE Powertrain Ltd (where the author was formerly employed as the Principal Investigator). The work therefore has direct relevance to the global automotive industry. The fuels evaluated are either now available in key global markets or remain under development at BP.

Title: Effects of injection timing on CAI operation in a 2/4-stroke switchable GDI engine
AdditionalInformation: This project was disseminated as the result of an EPSRC funded project (Grant EP/F058942/1) looking at future high efficiency modes of automotive powertrain operation. The method showed significant promise and has since resulted in subsequent follow-on work with direct support from industry (via SAIC Motor UK). Alasdair Cairns joined Brunel during the project but provided support as co-investigator.

Title: Nanoquasicrystalline Al–Fe–Cr-based alloys. Part I: Phase transformations
AdditionalInformation: This paper was published in the top journal for metallurgical research.  It reports the development of new nanoquasicrystal containing alloys with Tantalum or Niobium which show for the first time microstructures with thermal stability to sufficiently high temperatures for bulk processing and thus the potential for real application.  Elements of this work led to the award of the Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining (IOM3) Student Niobium Award.  The research in this paper was the basis of one of the authors (Galano) being awarded an RAEng/EPSRC Research Fellowship (2009-2014).

Title: Nanoquasicrystalline Al–Fe–Cr-based alloys. Part II. Mechanical properties
AdditionalInformation: This paper was published in the top journal for metallurgical research.  It reports the development of new nanoquasicrystal containing alloys which have elevated temperature strengths significantly exceeding existing commercial high temperature aluminium alloys.  Elements of this work led to the award of the Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining (IOM3) Student Niobium Award.  The research in this paper was the basis of one of the authors (Galano) being awarded an RAEng/EPSRC Research Fellowship (2009-2014).

Title: Microstructural evolution in semi-solid AA7034
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds upon previous highly cited work on experiments and modelling of isothermal grain coarsening in the semi-solid state (E.D. Manson-Whitton, I.C. Stone, J.R. Jones, P.S. Grant, B. Cantor, Acta Materialia, 50, 2517-2535, 2002). It extends the original work into a solid fraction regime in which the alloys are unable to support their own weight, and develops a brand new model of coarsening by flow enhanced liquid film migration under this regime. This and related work formed the basis of an invited lecture “Mushy Metals: The Behaviour of Alloys in the Semi-solid State”, West Surrey Materials Society, January 2012.

Title: Direct numerical simulation study of evaporation effects in combustion suppression by inert droplets
AdditionalInformation: In this output, computational studies supported by the EPSRC on the interactions among turbulence, combustion and evaporating droplets continue, and the focus was on evaporation effects on turbulent mixing and combustion. Due to the invalidity of the conventional mixture fraction for the diluted combustion case, the local equivalence ratio was used to measure the mixture status and serve as the conditioning variable. The effects of thermal cooling and mixture dilution by vapour on the six scalar dissipation rates due to three correlated but independent scalars, i.e. fuel, oxidiser and vapour, were investigated.

Title: Criteria of Grain Refinement Induced by Ultrasonic Melt Treatment of Aluminum Alloys Containing Zr and Ti
AdditionalInformation: Published in a high-ranking journal (I.F. 1.627) this paper for the first time explains the mechanisms of grain refinement in commercial alloys by ultrasonic processing and opens a way to its industrial application. The results of the paper were the foundation of an invited lecture at the 12th Int. Conf. on Aluminium Alloys (Japan, 2010).

Title: Microstructure and performance of a biodegradable Mg–1Ca–2Zn–1TCP composite fabricated by combined solidification and deformation processing
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development of a biodegradable Mg-1Ca-2Zn-1TCP composite fabricated by combining high shear solidification and equal channel angular extrusion, which is a novel approach for producing nanoparticle reinforced composites.  The research offers a technological breakthrough in fabricating magnesium based biomaterials with both controlled mechanical properties and biological performances. The research was supported by EPSRC.

Title: The Impact of Melt-Conditioned Twin-Roll Casting on the Downstream Processing of an AZ31 Magnesium Alloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an investigation into the impact of intensive shear melt conditioning on the solidification behaviour and microstructural development during twin roll casting of an AZ31 magnesium alloy and on the material performance during the downstream processing including homogenization, hot rolling and annealing. The paper is selected as a “free access” article by the Chief Editor of the journal due to its comprehensive nature and overall excellence. The research is supported by EPSRC.

Title: The formation of nanograin structures and accelerated room-temperature theta precipitation in a severely deformed Al-4wt.% Cu alloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses the effect of lowering deformation temperature on the minimum grain size achievable for grain refinement by severe plastic deformation and reports for the first time the accelerated room temperature theta precipitation in severely deformed Al-4wt%Cu alloy. The research was supported by EPSRC.

Title: Development of a super ductile diecast Al–Mg–Si alloy
AdditionalInformation: This is the first systematic study of the effect of alloying elements on the mechanical properties of aluminium casting alloys with high ductility. This work is important because it demonstrates that as-cast aluminium alloys can provide mechanical properties to satisfy the industrial requirement for car body application.

Title: An embedded FE model for modelling reinforced concrete slabs in fire
AdditionalInformation: A non-linear layered procedure is developed to quantitatively model the progressive tensile failure of reinforced concrete slabs subjected to large deflections in fire. The model inherits the advantage of the smeared approach, and introduces the opening crack width explicitly by taking advantage of the better description of the kinematic characteristics of the EFEM approach. For the first time this procedure enables designers to assess fire resistance of a building directly on the basis of both structural stability and integrity criteria. This would dramatically change structural fire engineering design practice, in which arbitrary limiting deflections are currently used by consulting engineers.

Title: Three-Dimensional Analysis of Reinforced Concrete Beam-Column Structures in Fire
AdditionalInformation: A robust non-linear finite-element procedure is developed for three-dimensional modelling of reinforced concrete beam-column structures under fire conditions. The cross section of the beam column is divided into a matrix of segments, and each segment may have different material, temperature, and mechanical properties.  A void segment is developed to effectively model the effect of concrete spalling on the fire resistance of concrete beam-column members. This model enables structural engineers to quantify the residual strength of spalled reinforced concrete beam-column structures in fire.

Title: Modelling the bond between concrete and reinforcing steel in a fire
AdditionalInformation: A non-linear procedure is presented for modelling the bond characteristics between concrete and reinforcing steel for reinforced concrete structures in a fire. The model is clearly capable of predicting the response of reinforced concrete members and structures under fire conditions with acceptable accuracy. It is the first time that the bond condition between the concrete and reinforcing steel bar is shown to have an important influence on the fire resistance of reinforced concrete structures. Hence, the current assumption of a perfect bond condition for analysis of reinforced concrete structures under fire conditions is unconservative.

Title: Progressive collapse analysis of steel structures under fire conditions
AdditionalInformation: A robust static-dynamic procedure has been developed, which can be used to perform a structural analysis to continue beyond the temporary instabilities which would cause singularities in full static analyses. The development enables structural engineers to very effectively model the dynamic and static behaviour of steel buildings during both local and global progressive collapse of the structures under fire conditions. A series of comprehensive studies on the collapse mechanism of steel frame due to columns’ failure under fire conditions has been presented. It is concluded that the bracing system is a key player to prevent the frame from progressive collapse.

Title: A comparative study of ternary Al–Sn–Cu immiscible alloys prepared by conventional casting and casting under high-intensity ultrasonic irradiation
AdditionalInformation: In this paper high intensity ultrasonic irradiation was used to disperse Sn-rich liquid droplets in an Al-rich liquid hoping to produce a finely and uniformly distributed Sn-rich phase in an Al-matrix after solidification. Although we have demonstrated that ultrasonic treatment is much better for this purpose than the conventional casting process, we only achieved partial distribution of the Sn-rich phase.

Title: Novel, flexible AC electroluminescent lamps for innovative display applications
VolumeTitle: SID Symposium Digest of Technical Papers
AdditionalInformation: This paper was given as an invited lecture at the International Symposium of the Society-for-Information-Display (SID 2008), in Los Angeles. SID Meetings are vast, with up to 7,000 delegates attending. Over 400 people turned up for the lecture. The work was an output of two TSB programmes PLACES and SHAPEL. The work reported in this paper led to a follow up TSB programme “Addressable Conductive Tracks in Vehicles for Electroluminescent Displays” (ACTIVEL). The paper reported lamps containing a single emissive layer comprising the ACEL phosphor, a binder, ferroelectric nanoparticles and an optional dye between transparent electrodes.

Title: Inertia effect in squeeze film air contact
AdditionalInformation: This paper contains results of a fundamental nature which provided a scientific foundation for the paper N02 and subsequently contributed to the award of EPSRC grant No. EP/F04979X/1. The findings of this article provide an insight into the mechanism of acoustic bearing operation and the role of inertia in creating acoustic pressure separating contacting element.

Title: Surface damage of brittle polymer resulting from static cyclic contact loading
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper developed an original method for assessing surface damage of brittle materials in static contact under cyclic loading. This type of contact conditions is quite often encountered in industrial applications. This fundamental research with a clear application outcome was supported and adopted by the Thailand Institute of Scientific and Technological Research (TISTR): http://www.tistr.or.th. Dr Pratip Vongbandit, from the Laboratory of Materials Performance Analysis (TISTR) based in Khlong Luang, Thailand, is co-author of the paper.

Title: Numerical modeling and experimental verification of compressible squeeze film pressure
AdditionalInformation: The use of acoustic pressure to separate contacting elements is an exciting idea to be utilised in specialist applications such as lithography, medical equipment, drag and fund industries where absolute cleanliness is the norm. The paper shows, through numerical models and limited experimental verification, that the acoustic pressure developed by a standing sound wave is a practically feasible idea. Continuation of the research in this area led to the award of EPSRC grant No. EP/F04979X/1.

Title: Alternation on rolling contact properties of steel due to magnetic field
AdditionalInformation: The presence of a magnetic field is a frequently encountered feature of operation of many modern electro-mechanical devices. This paper addresses important practical implications for rolling contacts (commonly used in practice) resulting from the presence of a magnetic field. The research was carried out as a joint project with Professor Kenichi Sato (ksato@chiba-u.ac.jp), Chiba University, Japan and its findings were disseminated among leading Japanese high-tech companies.

Title: Grain refinement in a AlZnMgCuTi alloy by intensive melt shearing: A multi-step nucleation mechanism
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we have demonstrated experimentally that significant grain refinement of a complex Al-Zn-Mg-Cu-Ti alloy can be achieved by intensive melt shearing prior to conventional casting processes. The mechanisms for high shear induced grain refinement have been identified as: intensive melt shearing leads to well dispersed oxide particles, which enhances heterogeneous nucleation of Al3Ti particles, which in turn result in refinement of alpha-Al.

Title: A study of mechanical variable valve operation with gasoline–alcohol fuels in a spark ignition engine
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as the result of a one-year full-time direct funded project at the powertrain consultancy business MAHLE Powertrain Ltd (where the author was formerly employed, again acting as the Principal Investigator). The type of engine operation studied is currently being widely considered across the European and US automotive markets.

Title: Wavelet approach for vibration analysis of fast moving load on a viscoelastic medium
AdditionalInformation: Fast moving trains in tunnels and on surface and their interactions with the environment represent an important topic for the EU research today. A mathematical model developed using wavelet formulation allows to characterize the complex soil-track dynamics in the range of relatively high and low load frequencies with increased efficiency for parametric analysis of realistic cases. This work, in a sequence of published models, allows the understanding of ground boom vibration phenomenon and train vibrations generated for velocities close to the Rayleigh wave velocity in the soil.

Title: Experimental investigation into the response of elastohydrodynamic films to harmonic vibrations
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Mechatronics and Manufacturing Systems
AdditionalInformation: Many practical machine components work in the lubrication regime known elastohydrodynamic (EHD) lubrication, where the complex effects of surface motion  and deformation are coupled with high local pressures and shear stresses in contact,  continuous loads variation and vibrations affecting the performance. In the present research, high-speed optical interferometry is used to study the behaviour of EHD films subjected to harmonic vibrations. Results from this work presented at the International  Conference for Engineering and Technological Innovation (IMETI 2008), Orlando USA received a best paper award in the topic section.

Title: Using non-parametric statistics to identify the best pathway for supplying hydrogen as a road transport fuel
AdditionalInformation: The author list is in order of the level of input. This paper is paired with the Fuel (2012) paper and represents a substantial body of work on the implications of resource availability for future fuels for road vehicles. This paper presented the detailed statistical methodology using the well-to-tank analyses of hydrogen as the principal example.

Title: A robust, data-driven methodology for real-world driving cycle development
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Part D: Transport and Environment
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates a way of using on-road data directly for drive-cycle analysis. All current methods grossly over-estimate the efficiency of new vehicles. Our method gives a realistic assessment of what a ‘normal’ driver could achieve. It will take many years for this to become an ‘industry standard’ method.

Title: Identifying the fuels and energy conversion technologies necessary to meet European passenger car emissions legislation to 2020
AdditionalInformation: The author list is in order of the level of input. This paper is paired with the IJHE (2011) paper and represents a substantial body of work on the implications of resource availability for future fuels. This paper exploits the novel methods set out in IJHE (2011) to present the well-to-tank analyses of all other current and projected fuels for road vehicles, It also presents the implications for international legislation for vehicle CO2 emissions standards.

Title: Deflection and frequency monitoring of the Forth Road Bridge, Scotland, by GPS
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the ICE - Bridge Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Structural integrity monitoring using GPS for the measurement of deflections and frequencies in large-span structures is a major challenge.  This paper describes the progress made in a project to test the development and interpretation of technology that enables the long-term assessment of structural performance.  The project was funded for both partner universities - The University of Nottingham and Brunel University - by industry (in this case the Forth Estuary Transit Authority- verification available from Bridgemaster Mr. B. Colford).

Title: Diamond-like carbon/epoxy low-friction coatings to replace electroplated chromium
AdditionalInformation: Since publication hexavalent chromium (CrVI) compounds have been classed as Substances of Very High Concern due to their toxicity to humans and wildlife under EU chemicals regulations. Dr Troisi sits on European Chemicals Agency - Risk Assessment Committee which working on a EU ban of these compounds.
