This will have serious implications for industries reliant on hard chrome plating including aircraft and automotive sector. The findings of this article are have been used by collaborators at Lufthansa Technik to identify suitable replacement materials for the overhaul of their aircraft landing gear.

Title: Structure and morphology of ACEL ZnS:Cu,Cl phosphor powder etched by hydrochloric acid
AdditionalInformation: Despite many researches over the last half century, the mechanism of ac powder electroluminescence remains to be fully elucidated and, to this end, a better understanding of the relatively complex structure of alternate current electroluminescence ACEL phosphors is required. This paper came out of an ongoing research programme on ACEL that in the last eight years has been funded by the EPSRC, the DTI, the TSB and ten UK companies (total grants £2.877M; Brunel share £1.136M). This paper led to a further TSB programme (BEDS) with six more UK companies (total grant £0.906M; Brunel share £0.250M).

Title: Vulnerability of existing buildings: empirical evaluation and experimental measurements
AdditionalInformation: Collaborative work focusing on material characterisation using genetic algorithms, which resulted in a number of publications.  This paper is a continuation of the identification work applied to measuring the vulnerability of existing buildings in Algeria to earthquakes.  This collaboration led to Prof Esat helping setting up a new Vibro-Acoustics lab at the University of Science and Technology Houari Boumediene of Bab Ezzour in Algeria.  The research also led to the development of an earthquake module for our VIBRATIO software, which was used by Silvertown Ldt for an oil pipeline project in Eastern Turkey (Contact: Mick Huckerby, SilverTown Ltd.).

Title: Issues in the integration of active control turbochargers with internal combustion engines
AdditionalInformation: This work was the result of research disseminated during EPSRC project EP/H050183/1, building on from a previous EPSRC project (EPSRC GR/S04338/01). In addition, because of the potential of the original intellectual property which resulted (WO2006/061588) the technology transfer company Imperial Innovations was also involved to further help secure funding through Carbon Trust (Project ICN 2453). The work presented in the paper disseminated the experience gained from communication with turbocharger and engine OEMs as well as prior art in the field in order to propose ways to better integrate ACT with the internal combustion engine.

Title: Experimental and analytical assessment of ductility in lightly reinforced concrete members
AdditionalInformation: A conceptually novel approach for predicting the capacity of reinforced concrete members based on rational failure criteria is presented. The research includes large-scale experiments, detailed numerical modelling and a new analytical approach. This method departs from previous proposals which typically do not consider the failure criteria, thus leading to overly-conservative designs. The content of this paper was presented at a number of conferences and the work was supported by a £241,000 EPSRC grant (No. EP/C511204). The study enabled the development of a similar model for full slabs which greatly improves the understanding and design philosophy for these members in fire.

Title: Low-diffusivity scalar transport using a WENO scheme and dual meshing
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces and verifies a numerical code that was especially developed to accurately describe the transport of dissolved scalars that have a diffusivity that is several orders of magnitude smaller than the molecular diffusivity of the carrier fluid. The code is currently used to numerically investigate gas transfer across the air-water interface affected by turbulence diffusing from below or buoyant convection.

Title: Vibration mode shape recognition using image processing
AdditionalInformation: Advanced  full-field optical measurement techniques such as scanning laser Doppler vibrometer and digital image correlation make accurate dynamic characteristics available for large complicated structures.  A new method using the mathematical concept of ‘shape feature descriptor’ is developed for correlation between experimental and analytical data in model updating in the presence of uncertainty. The correlation is transformed into a statistical pattern recognition problem and hierarchical clustering, principal component analysis and Bayesian decision theory are examined to compare and classify the shape vectors assembled from different shape descriptors, offering a more complete understanding of modes shapes to complement the conventional MAC correlation.

Title: An approximate model for cancellous bone screw fixation
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This output was also disseminated as part of the ongoing programme to investigate the importance of modelling criteria in the design of biomedical devices, and in this case focused on contact modelling between bone and device.  This programme of work has been entirely funded by industry (Stryker Osteosynthesis - contact Prof P. Procter for verification), and represents a small part of the programme to improve the scientific basis for device design sponsored by Stryker.  The programme has gone on to develop methods for full 3-d modelling, and the prediction of the performance of different device designs.

Title: Wheat straw and wheat flour biocomposites prepared by extrusion process
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biobased Materials and Bioenergy
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of a DEFRA and HGCA co-funded project “Novel Bio-Composites Based on Whole Utilisation of Wheat Straw” under DEFRA Renewable Materials LINK Program, grant No CAS 7531-LK0830 (DEFRA) and RD-2007-3351(HGCA). The project was conducted in collaboration with 13 research and industrial partners and developed a portfolio of low-cost and high performance bio-composites. This has led to commercial exploitations of the biocomposites in horticulture, construction and furniture applications.

Title: Novel method to improve engine exhaust energy extraction with active control turbocharger
AdditionalInformation: This work was the result of EPSRC-funded research on “Exhaust Energy Recovery in Low Carbon Vehicles by Intelligent Turbocharging” (Project iTurbo: EPSRC EP/H050183/1) in collaboration with the Universiti Teknologi Malaysia.The outcome of this project involved the collaboration with a major European automotive manufacturer through which the potential of the integration of the ACT technology was quantified at the simulation level for a specific commercial diesel engine application before being tested on an engine. In addition, a patent has arisen as a result of this research (WO2008/129274, 2008).

Title: The impact on human health of car-related air pollution in the UK, 1995–2005
AdditionalInformation:
The use of UK data is for illustrative purposes only, the novel method is internationally applicable for determining the health effects of emissions from passenger and light goods vehicles. It is a much more straightforward method than any previously devised. This paper is the first in a projected series on measuring the sustainability of the UK car fleet. 

As a result of this work R Darton was invited to Veszprem (Hungary) and to participate in an Elsevier book edited by Prof Jiri Klemes on Measuring Sustainability (klemes@cpi.uni-pannon.hu).

Title: Fabrication of nanocelluloses from hemp fibers and their application for the reinforcement of hemp fibers
AdditionalInformation: The ‘natural’ for ‘natural’ is the principle of this research. This output demonstrates that the inherent defects of the natural fibres can optimally be repaired by using their own substances which are the most compatible material. The outcomes of this discovery have led to the successful development of a FP7 Eco-Innovation project called CELLUWOOD (Laminated strong eco-materials for building construction made of cellulose-strengthened wood, Project no. CIP-EIP-Eco-Innovation 277331) and the technologies are firstly applied in the InWood Development company in UK and Tecnifusta company in Spain. Two PARK funds have also been obtained for its patenting.

Title: On the scattering of longitudinal elastic waves from axisymmetric defects in coated pipes
AdditionalInformation: Viscoelastic coatings limit the effectiveness of ultrasonic techniques for locating defects in oil and gas pipelines.  This article addresses developmental work that underpins a current project aimed at integrating new measurement techniques into the commercial product Teletest (http://www.plantintegrity.com/teletest/mini-tools.jsp).  This aims to deliver a commercial advantage for the Teletest product and, because coated pipes are very common, the potential future commercial impact of this work is significant.

Title: Investigation of the dislocation of natural fibres by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of the TSB funded project NATCOM (Project No. TP/5/CON/6/I/H0565L). The project was conducted in collaboration with industrial partners across the whole supply chain, from farmers to fibre developers to composite developers and manufacturers. This was probably the first project in Europe to develop a new processing technology (pultrusion) for high strength natural fibre composites for structural application in construction. Exel Composites, a world leading technology company, is the NATCOM manufacturer. This paper identifies the key parameters affecting the formulation of production and performance of the final products.

Title: Green modification of natural fibres with nanocellulose
AdditionalInformation: This output represents the principle of a ‘green’ technology for the modification of natural fibres for tailored products for various industrial sectors. This important outcome has led to two further successes in the field: one is called ‘Grow2Build’ - Local cultivated hemp and flax as resource for biobased building materials (NWE Interreg Project) and the other is called ‘ICECLAY’ - Highly effective production of ultra-lightweight aerogel materials and their integrated composites for building insulation (EU FP7-SME-315548). The outcomes of both projects will have significant impacts to the building material and construction industries across Europe.

Title: Characterization and Performance of Elementary Hemp Fibres: Factors Influencing Tensile Strength
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a comprehensive experimental study of hemp fibres and understanding of their performance and failure mechanisms, which established the principle of natural fibre materials and serve as guidelines for the value added development of natural fibre based composite materials.  The outcomes led to the successful development of the TSB project ‘Highly efficient production of high strength natural fibre composites’, for which the author was the Technical Leader.

Title: A computational model for the cooling phase of injection moulding
AdditionalInformation:
This paper discusses the techniques used to build a realistic numerical model to analyse the cooling phase of the injection moulding process. The final model is validated using direct comparisons with experimental results generated in an earlier study. The model is shown to be a useful tool for further studies aimed at optimising the cooling phase of the injection moulding process. Using the numerical model provides additional information relating to changes in conditions throughout the process, which otherwise could not be deduced or assessed experimentally. 
The research work was funded by an EPSRC grant with the support of John Guest.

Title: Studies of Adsorption and Viscoelastic Properties of Proteins onto Liquid Crystal Phthalocyanine Surface Using Quartz Crystal Microbalance with Dissipation Technique
AdditionalInformation: Extensive research has been undertaken over the last three decades to develop organic nanoelectronics for health care. Whilst electronic paper exploits organic thin films through their electronic addressability and rapid reversibility,  the biosensing strategy proposed here will exploit a chemical reactivity, but one which translates directly into electronic mode. Emphasis was  given on easy manufacturability and integration of mechanically flexible sensors over  large areas, which are suitable for multiple  applications in  health care. Protein adsorption on  organic semiconductors  has created huge interest in the scientific community and attracted European funding.

Title: Achieving structured colour in inorganic systems: Learning from the natural world
AdditionalInformation: An overview of the work reported in this invited paper was given at a conference entitled “Colour and Design-Colour in Plants and Animals-Inspiration for Design” organised jointly by the Linnean Society and the Institute of Mechanical Engineers in London. This paper brought together a body of work on the understanding of the origins of structural colour, which was relevant and complementary to the group’s work on phosphors. Some of the materials described are also phosphors. The work was funded by EPSRC and TSB programmes and the papers findings were used to successfully apply for other TSB programmes.

Title: Mechanisms of grain refinement by intensive shearing of AZ91 alloy melt
AdditionalInformation: This paper revealed for the first time the mechanism of grain refinement by intensive melt shearing: enhancing heterogeneous nucleation on dispersed MgO particles through increasing the potential substrate number density by three orders of magnitude. This paper provides the theoretical basis for the development of physical approaches to grain refinement and direct recycling of Mg-alloy scrap without chemical treatment.

Title: A novel approach for the preparation of discrete phosphor nanoparticles
AdditionalInformation: The work in this paper was a spinout of an EPSRC and two TSB programmes. The work describes a method of pre-coating precursor phosphor nanoparticles with silica then firing the resulting coated particles. The resulting particles of coated phosphor can then be partially back etched thinning the silica coating and thereby freeing any agglomerated particles. This work was a very useful step in the control of methodology to avoid nanoparticle agglomeration and was a major aid in the group obtaining an EPSERC/TSB challenge grant entitled” Enhanced solar energy harvesting in dye sensitized solar cells using nanophosphors and nano-structured optics (CONVERTED).

Title: Contact effects in compact models of organic thin film transistors: Application to zinc phthalocyanine-based transistors
AdditionalInformation: Emphasis of this multidisciplinary cross-Atlantic research collaboration is on design of novel organic thin film transistors for wearable electronics. With industrial needs for low manufacturing cost in mind, this project has exploited thin film organic transistors with the ability to harness electronic functionality by optimising device parameters at circuit level.  This research will, therefore, have not only an impact on silicon technology but it represents a big leap in nascent plastic electronics in the long run. The results have already attracted the interest of the European Office of Aerospace Research and Development, who are continuing their financial support.

Title: Cathodoluminescence of small particle Gd2O2S:Pr X-ray phosphor
VolumeTitle: IDW '09 - Proceedings of the 16th International Display Workshops
AdditionalInformation: This work originated from a BBSRC grant on making nanoparticle phosphors as tags for protein identification and imaging in electron microscopy using cathodoluminescence. The work was the first to demonstrate that reasonable luminous efficacies could be achieved via cathodoluminescence using sub-micrometre sized phosphor particles.  It further demonstrated that 1 mol% Pr was the dopant concentration that exhibited the highest luminance. Furthermore, the green colour point achieved expanded the colour space of the HDTV CCIR 709 triad significantly.  The ratio of green to red emission lines was shown to be dependent on Pr concentration and firing temperature.

Title: Experimental and theoretical luminous efficacies of phosphors used in combination with blue-emitting LEDs for lighting and backlighting
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Society for Information Display
AdditionalInformation: This paper was given as an invited lecture at Latin Display in Brazil 2008. The paper was fully refereed and gives an overview of the then state of the art in LED phosphors. Much of the findings were from two TSB funded programmes where eight UK companies worked with Brunel (total program costs £4.25M; Brunel share £0.43M). The paper led to two  further TSB program CONVERT and a joint EPSRC/TSB program CONVERTED  (in these, the LED phosphors are/were used for improving photovoltaic cell performance with three UK industries (total programme costs. £1,625M; Brunel share £0.63M).

Title: Configurations and dynamics of single air/alcohol gas–liquid compound drops in vegetable oil
AdditionalInformation: Our EPSRC/TSB/BP-supported research on crystallization in thin aqueous liquid films and diesel emitted particles led naturally to our consideration of two-phase transesterification reactions to give FAME biodiesel more effectively. This output reports on chemistry/chemical engineering real-time in-situ experimental analysis of reactions in low-energy air/alcohol compound drops as they pass through sunflower oil at constant temperature. We then considered the feasibility of compounds drop formation with passage of N2/sunflower oil drops through CH3OH induced by a bubble train. This was extended by studies at 0.02<Re<13.43 and 298-323K, leading to more recent work on low energy biodiesel with support from Biofuel Refineries.

Title: Nanoengineering X/AlOOH-Al(2)O(3) Sols by Sequential Adsorption to Produce Xerogel Ceramic Catalytic Films for Environmental Pollution Control and Nanoparticles for BaSO(4) Scale Control in Water
VolumeTitle: JOURNAL OF THE AUSTRALIAN CERAMIC SOCIETY
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports on research with Ian Collins (BP Exploration, Sunbury) on the potential for nanoengineering oil recovery with implications for the better use of UK and worldwide oil-gas reserves. This involved BP-TSB-EPSRC support through DT/F006845/1. The research has resulted in a 2007 patent application [I.R.Collins and P.A.Sermon US2007284100] on control and inhibition of scale formation using injectable BaSO4 nanoparticles smaller than 50nm. In the paper, we describe sequential adsorption routes to and properties of nanoengineered 90-100nm X/AlOOH-Al2O3 sols for environmental pollution control catalysts and BaSO4 scale-control in oil-reservoir waters. BP and a spinoff company NewCatCo will exploit these results.

Title: In situ chemichromic studies of interactions between a lutetium bis-octaalkyl-substituted phthalocyanine and selected biological cofactors
VolumeTitle: Journal of The Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the result of a very successful collaborative research, at the interface of physical and biological sciences, between two UK universities and two international institutions. The findings of this work are very significant in the early stage diagnosis of many age-related diseases such as Alzheimer.  Professor Ray has been invited, with financial support from the Shenzhen Government, China, to the Annual International Conference of Emerging Industry where he will meet representatives of the Chinese industry for discussions on the development of point of care, portable, user friendly medical instruments.

Title: Novel, bright, inorganic electroluminescent flexible displays comprising ink jet printed silver back electrodes
VolumeTitle: SID Symposium Digest of Technical Papers
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an invited talk at the Society for Information Display 2010 International Symposium in Seattle, USA. It reported work from three TSB projects FAB-3D, SHAPEL and ACTIVEL which had/have a total of 11 industrial partners. The paper attracted an audience of over 250 people. It led to a number of inquiries from international and national industry and three of the original industrial partners, along with three new industrial partners, applied with us for another TSB programme entitled “Biopolymer-based Electronic Circuits and Displays” (BEDs) (TP No. 5754_44879) (Total value  £906,055; Brunel  £249,994), which is still running.

Title: Sound transmission testing of polymer compounds
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a technique developed in the Wolfson Centre for the sound transmission testing of polymers and polymer compounds. The importance of sample preparation and mounting in the sound testing apparatus was demonstrated.  Examples of the performance of a range of polymer and polymer composite samples were presented to support the reported testing method. This paper resulted from the work carried out in the TSB SOUNDPROOF project. The expertise gained from the project was a very important feature in the application for the TSB LANDS project currently running in the Wolfson Centre.

Title: Tuning X/(TiO 2) x-(SiO 2) 100 - x (0 < x < 40) xerogel photocatalysts
AdditionalInformation: Brunel has long researched xerogels and alkyl phenol ethoxylates and their properties/toxicity, supported by AWE, British Gas and Mobil North Sea. This output describes the nanoengineering of PEG-PPG templated microporous X/(TiO2)x-(SiO2)100-x (0<x<40) xerogel photocatalysts by sol-gel methods, either by partial-prehydrolysis or reflux of alkoxides, and their characterisation by several complementary techniques (29Si-NMR, XRD, Ti-K-edge EXAFS, XPS, TPR, FTIR, N2 BET, TEM, DLS, UV-vis and AFM), along with their activity in removal of TX100 from water. Sermon chaired a symposium and spoke on biomimetic TiO2 photocatalysts at the 15th International Congress on Catalysis, and submitted a patent application on biomimetic TiO2.

Title: Deterring gun crime materially using forensic coatings
AdditionalInformation: This output reports research by a multidisciplinary Brunel-Surrey-Cranfield-York-Brighton-FSS-BAeSystems consortium formed to formulate, investigate and develop relevant forensic nanomaterials (EPSRC grant EP/E003826/1). The research concentrated on the nanoengineering of coatings that were atomically rough and therefore harvested more DNA in skin cells, while donating unique tags with nm thick sol-gel overcoats. The RCUK website reported that this ‘bullett tagging technology developed in the UK could help tackle gun crime’ and cites it as being an example of excellence with impact [http://www.rcuk.ac.uk/research/xrcprogrammes/prevprogs/nano/Impact/Pages/Pollen.aspx]. As a spin-off, a 2013 patent application relates to the potential of nanoengineered coatings in fighting against malaria.

Title: Effect of intensive melt shearing on the formation of Fe-containing intermetallics in LM24 Al-alloy
VolumeTitle:
The 3rd International Conference on Advances in Solidification Processes
7–10 June 2011 / IOP Conference Series: Materials Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we have demonstrated that intensive melt shearing is effective for refining the Fe-containing intermetallic compound in the high pressure die cast Al-alloys. This paper provides the experimental evidence for increased scrap contents in Al-alloy castings without compromising the mechanical properties. This is highly relevant to recycling of Al-alloys in the automotive industry.

Title: Contrasting behaviour of the co-activators in the luminescence spectra of Y2O2S:Tb3+,Er3+ nanometre sized particles under UV and red light excitation
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports the preparation and luminescent properties of nanoparticles of yttrium oxysulfide co-activated with terbium and erbium cations.  Both cations were seen to affect the downconversion emission of the phosphors, but only erbium emission was observed in the upconverted emission. As these two kinds of emission were seen in the same material one application of these phosphor materials is in the field of security (e.g. for currency) and the nanoparticulate form is an added advantage for this purpose.  The downconversion could be a monitored verification foe vending, the upconversion a covert safeguard.

Title: Iron doped lithium aluminate embedded in polypropylene as a potential infra-red emitter for stimulating plant growth
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the International Display Workshops
AdditionalInformation: This paper came from a successful TSB/EPSRC programme entitled “Plastic UV Radiation Protection Operating by Stokes Emission”(PURPOSE)  (Total grant £1.35M, £464K from EPSRC), with Brunel and eight industrial partners. The paper reported the first demonstrations of the proof of principle of the grant. It led to three of the partners continuing work on nanoparticle phosphors by winning another TSB programme “Biopolymer-based Electronic Circuits and Displays”(BEDs) (Total £906K,  Brunel £250K). The paper  also led to group members giving invited lectures to present further findings of this work at international meetings in India, Japan and Hong Kong in 2012.

Title: The potential for solid biomass wastes as fillers in polymer compounds
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes an evaluation of the potential for using two solid waste streams as fillers for thermoplastic components.  One of the waste streams was produced from a sustainable biomass source and the other was a waste product from the processing of a biomass product.  Both materials showed very good potential for this application.  The work was carried out as part of the TSB Novel Blending and Processing of Biomass Waste (REFERTILIZER) project .  The results of this paper were used in a successful grant application for the TSB LANDS project currently running in the Wolfson Centre.

Title: Acoustic transmission properties of plastics compounds
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes an acoustic sound testing apparatus, which was shown to be an effective bench-top method for the evaluation of polymer-based compounds intended for applications requiring the knowledge of acoustic properties.  It was proposed that the method could be used in the automotive, aerospace and construction industries to assess materials before the expensive testing of prototype components was carried out. The method has now been adopted in the TSB LANDS project currently running in the Wolfson Centre.

Title: High flexibility powder ACEL displays
VolumeTitle: IDW '09 - Proceedings of the 16th International Display Workshops
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported a successful low cost production route for producing simple highly flexible AC electroluminescent displays that had a novel geometry. The powder ACEL lamp is suitable for applications where repeated flexibility of the device or tight bending is required. The work was an output of a TSB programme where we were teamed up with a UK SME industry called Elumin8 Ltd. The work reported in this paper led directly to a follow up TSB programme “Shape Formable, Thin, ACEL Devices” (SHAPEL) and to work for another TSB programme “Addressable Conductive Tracks in Vehicles for Electroluminescent Displays” (ACTIVEL).

Title: AC powder electroluminescent displays
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Society for Information Display
AdditionalInformation: This paper was presented as an invited talk at Latin display 2010 in Brazil, it was then an invited contribution to Journal of SID Special Section on LatinDisplay/IDRC 2010 (Eds. D. den Engelsen and V. Mammana) . The current status of AC powder electroluminescent (ACPEL) displays was reviewed with particular emphasis given to colour and lifetime. The review covered all aspects of ACPEL displays, and arose from the group’s on-going programme in this area that has been funded by both the EPSRC and the TSB on many joint programs with UK industries, and has led to industrial partners business success.

Title: Selecting a white point using (Y1-aGda)3Al5O12:Ce3+ (where a is in the range 0.3 to 0.6) phosphors on screens and two blue LEDs
VolumeTitle: IDW/AD '12 - The 19th International Display Workshops in conjunction with Asia Display
AdditionalInformation: This work was accepted as a late news paper at The International Display Workshops in Kyoto Japan (IDW 2012). It describes work from a TSB project entitled “Addressable Conductive Tracks in Vehicles for Electroluminescent Displays” (ACTIVEL). The work was based on developing particular light products for a UK-based large car manufacturer. The successful research has led the company to patent aspects of the work and to continue working with the Wolfson Centre at Brunel in a second TSB programme. The company now wants to start further work on white light with us and is currently deciding how to proceed.

Title: Selecting a red point using CaS:Eu2+ and SrS: Eu2+ phosphors on screens and one blue LED
VolumeTitle: IDW/AD '12 - The 19th International Display Workshops in conjunction with Asia Display
AdditionalInformation: This work was presented at the International Display Workshops in Kyoto Japan (IDW 2012). It describes work from a TSB project entitled “Addressable Conductive Tracks in Vehicles for Electroluminescent Displays” (ACTIVEL). The work was aimed at developing particular light products for a UK-based large car manufacturer. The successful research has led the company to patent aspects of the work on red phosphors and to continue working with the Wolfson Centre at Brunel in a second TSB programme. The company now wants to start further work in this area with us and is currently deciding how to proceed.

Title: Refining grain structure and porosity of an aluminium alloy with intensive melt shearing
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we demonstrate that intensive melt shearing is not only effective for a significant grain-refining effect, but also a effective approach for degassing of Al-melt, resulting in a reduction of both the volume fraction and the size of porosity.

Title: Extrusion fractionation of wheat straw for biocomposites utilising the entire straw constituents
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Materials and Product Technology
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of a DEFRA and HGCA co-funded project “Whole utilisation of straw for industrial applications” under DEFRA Renewable Materials LINK Program, grant No CAS 7531-LK0830 (DEFRA) and RD-2007-3351(HGCA). The project was conducted in collaboration with 13 research and industrial partners and developed a portfolio of low-cost and high performance bio-composites. This has led to commercial exploitations of the biocomposites in horticulture, construction and furniture applications.

Title: Control optimisation of CO2 cycles for medium temperature retail food refrigeration systems
AdditionalInformation: As part of outputs from DEFRA funded project LINK AFM 251, this paper describes a detailed procedure of optimised control strategies for CO2 cycles in medium temperature retail food refrigeration systems. To achieve this objective, an integrated model was developed which composed of a detailed condenser/gas cooler model, a simplified compressor model, an isenthalpic expansion process and constant evaporating temperature and superheating. The control strategy assumes variable compressor speed and adjustable air flow to meet the constant cooling load requirement at different ambient conditions. As a result, the system performance can be controlled and optimised at various ambient conditions.

Title: A novel method for the preparation of non-agglomerated nanometre sized particles of lanthanum phosphate phosphors utilising a high surface area support in the firing process
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports a novel method (applicable to many inorganic materials) of preparing nanoparticle-sized phosphors utilising glass wool as a surface to spread out and support the phosphor precursors. This paper resulted from a BBSRC/EPSRC grant (total £810K; Brunel £412.6K) with biologists from York University, the MRC and JEOL UK, entitled “NanoProbes: Development of Novel Probes for Biological Submicroscopic Multicolour Imaging”.  As a follow up to this grant, Brunel University invested in a new STEM Microscope fitted with a cathodoluminescence attachment (investing £1.7M in the microscope alone) and we are currently applying for funding to continue the collaboration.

Title: Compound effect of EHD and surface roughness in pool boiling and CHF with R-123
AdditionalInformation: The paper refers to work carried out with Kassel University – expertise in surface characterisation for boiling. It is the first part of the work subsequently carried out in collaboration with Thermacore Europe and TWI (r.j.mcglen@thermacore.com) to identify optimised surface structures that enhance pool boiling heat transfer rates and lead to smaller thermal equipment designed by the company for meeting given loads (see Ferhati et al. UKHTC2013). Additional work on the use of electric fields (EHD) leads to further understanding of the fundamentals of EHD-boiling and the assessment of compound enhancement -passive (surface) and active (EHD) – in systems.

Title: Application of texture analysis and Kohonen map for region segmentation of pavement images for crack detection
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Record: Journal of the Transportation Research Board
AdditionalInformation: Distinguishing cracks from patch boundaries have significant consequence as 90% of the roads are highly patched and/or trenched. Since pavement management decisions are based on crack evaluation results, the overestimation of cracks caused by the detection of surface irregularities can cause erroneous prioritization and inefficient utilization of rehabilitation funds. An intelligence-based method, using textural and colour properties of different image regions with an un-supervised learning procedure, was developed to differentiate the edge of a patch repair and cracks from digital images. The simplicity and high accuracy (> 97%) is expected to attract interest from researchers and road authorities.

Title: Fundamental properties of rubber modified self-compacting concrete (RMSCC)
AdditionalInformation: This paper gave fundamental understanding on how addition of recycled tyre rubber in self-compacting concrete affect the performance of RMSCC at the mixing stage as well as in their early life. Key issues such as workability, resistance to segregation (viscosity), and the flow ability of the fresh mixture are reported. The research was then extended to determine fundamental dynamic mechanical properties such as dynamic modulus of elasticity, Poisson’s ratio and dynamic shear modulus on the cured specimens by a novel non-destructive testing method.

Title: Moisture susceptibility of high and low compaction dry process crumb rubber-modified asphalt mixtures
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Record: Journal of the Transportation Research Board
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as part of the EPSRC grant “Characterisation of Dry Process Crumb Rubber Modified (CRM) Asphalt Mixtures” (Project: GR/N08209/01). The research was aimed at improving the understanding of chemical and mechanical interactions that occur between crumb rubber particles produced from scrap truck tyre and bitumen within CRM mixtures during the production stage, and their effect on the compaction and in the long-term durability. This research was the first of its kind in the UK and therefore, the results presented in this paper provided vital engineering data for developing a design guideline for bitumen manufacturer and practicing engineers.

Title: A charge structure for trenching in the highway
Publisher: Transport for London and County Surveyors' Society
AdditionalInformation: Utility trenching can have a detrimental effect on both the surface condition and the underlying structure of highways, thereby shortening their service lives. This project was sponsored by Transport for London and the country surveyors’ society, to which I contributed to develop a mathematical model to estimate the service life reduction caused by road trenching. In this publication, a charge structure has been reported that enables charges to be levied against those trenching the highway in order to recover the additional maintenance cost. This publication is now widely used by local authorities and other highway authorities as a reference document.

Title: Effects of the host lattice and doping concentration on the colour of Tb3+ cation emission in Y2O2S:Tb3+ and Gd2O2S:Tb3+ nanometer sized phosphor particles
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first unified explanation of the luminescence phenomena for both Y2O2S:Tb3+ and Gd2O2S:Tb3+ phosphors. It explains the colour changes from blue to green with terbium concentration increase in the former phosphor and shows the mechanism is present in the latter phosphor but is masked by a second mechanism that is responsible for transferring excited electrons to the conduction band and then preferably to states giving green emission. The second mechanism is dominant in the Gd phosphor.  Additionally the results vindicate the method of synthesising the phosphor nanoparticles with total control of the Tb3+ concentration.

Title: An experimental study of airfoil instability tonal noise with trailing edge serrations
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents a comprehensive experimental study of the physical mechanisms that play a role in the aerofoil trailing edge tonal noise generation in some fan-based applications that operate at moderate Reynolds numbers. An improved understanding of the noise mechanisms enabled the author to successfully achieve a 20dB tonal noise reduction by the trailing edge serrations (a nature-inspired technology). The author was invited to present the results at the LG Electronics Seoul’s research laboratory in 2012. The simplicity of the noise control technique developed in this study is expected to attract interests from other fan companies.

Title: Nonlinear multi-scale homogenization with different structural models at different scales
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This output is a result of a CASE Project co-funded by EPSRC (CASE/CAN/07/01) and Lloyds Register, conducted in close collaboration with the industrial sponsor. Dr Edmans, PhD student in the project, is now working for Lloyds Register in a new Global Technology Centre (GTC) set up by the company in Singapore to focus on topics including “Deepwater / floating offshore installation” (http://www.lr.org/about_us/research/singapore_gtc/research-topics/index.aspx ). This output reports some of key results building on which a new large grant has been funded by EPSRC (EP/K034243/1) to the other two authors, who lead a consortium including Imperial College, Southampton University, BP and Shell.

Title: A novel rate-dependent cohesive-zone model combining damage and visco-elasticity
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of an Industrial CASE Project co-funded by EPSRC (V.N. 09002167) and Dunlop Oil & Marine, titled , “New computational models to predict the delamination failure load in elastomeric composites with application to marine hoses”. The project was conducted in close collaboration with the industrial sponsor, as a result of their great interest for the industrial application of the method presented. Furthermore, the co-author Marco Musto, PhD student on the project, had already been working with Dunlop Oil & Marine and is currently still employed by them.

Title: Heat transfer correlation for flow boiling in small to micro tubes
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This 2013 paper describes work at Brunel to develop design correlations for predicting flow boiling heat transfer rates in small to micro passages. The correlation presented is based on the fundamental premise that both nucleate and convective boiling occur in such passages. It is based on a large data bank collected by the team over a period of more than 10 years. The first version developed earlier was already used by the international community with excellent results (Anwar et al. UKHTC2013). This new version is able to capture the experimental trend more closely and hence offers an improved predicting ability.

Title: An Epitaxial Model for Heterogeneous Nucleation on Potent Substrates
AdditionalInformation: This is the first model describing heterogeneous nucleation on a potent substrate at the atomic level. Academically, it revealed theoretically that lattice misfit is the key parameter governing heterogeneous nucleation and demonstrated mathematically the effect of elastic strain energy on heterogeneous nucleation. In addition, it also revealed the mechanism of how adsorbed solute atoms at the liquid/substrate interface affect heterogeneous nucleation. Practically, this paper provides a guideline for developing effective grain refiners: selecting nucleating particles with minimum lattice misfit followed by selecting a solute element to further reduce the lattice misfit by adsorption at the liquid/substrate interface.

Title: The effect of solutes on grain boundary mobility during recrystallization and grain growth in some single-phase aluminium alloys
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports for the first time experimental results of the effect of solute elements on grain boundary migration during recrystallization and grain growth using a novel combined SEM in-situ annealing and high resolution EBSD technique, presenting a series of quantitative plots of grain boundary mobility as a function of boundary misorientation and rotation axes for a wide range of single-phase aluminium alloys. This work is of great importance as it offers the essential material data for practical control and theoretical modelling of thermomechanical processing. The research was supported by EPSRC.

Title: Effect of iron on the microstructure and mechanical property of Al–Mg–Si–Mn and Al–Mg–Si diecast alloys
AdditionalInformation: This is the first systematic investigation of the effect of iron in ductile aluminium alloys for car body application. The results are important to the use of recycled materials. Research was supported by EPSRC. This paper forms the foundation of subsequent work on material recycling studies.

Title: Microstructural Evolution and Solidification Behavior of Al-Mg-Si Alloy in High-Pressure Die Casting
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to describe the solidification behaviour and microstructural evolution of Al-Mg-Si alloys cast using the HPDC process. The experimental results are assessed with an MS model, which explains the fundamentals in HPDC process. This work is supported by EPSRC and TSB.

Title: Novel Grain Refiner for Hypo- and Hyper-Eutectic Al-Si Alloys
AdditionalInformation: This research identified a chemical composition that can refine the grain structures of light alloys, enabling the processing of thin walled cast structures and leading to filing a patent (PCT/GB2012/050300).  It is one central part of the activities in the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Liquid Metal Engineering. The composition has been further developed into a “practical product” through EPSRC follow-on-funding (EP/J013749/1) and a 2nd patent (GB1214650.2) has been filed. This product is being applied to produce larger automotive structures in a TSB project (TSB/101177); and large automotive structures have been produced in UK, German, Italian and Japanese industries.

Title: Stress Corrosion Cracking in Al-Zn-Mg-Cu Aluminum Alloys in Saline Environments
AdditionalInformation: This is the first major discussion of stress corrosion cracking (SCC) of this important class of alloys which are the backbone of the world’s aerospace industry. These alloys are of increasing importance to the world’s aircraft manufacturer’s and as alloy strengths are increased and alloying levels are increased it is critical that a high resistance to SCC is maintained and lessons are learnt from past experience as analysed in the paper.

Title: Influence of Grain-Refiner Addition on the Morphology of Fe-Bearing Intermetallics in a Semi-Solid Processed Al-Mg-Si Alloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first attempt to understand the influence of Al-Ti-B grain refiners on the type and morphology of Fe-bearing intermetallic phases independent of primary grain size. These intermetallics are crucial to the productivity of downstream processing. The paper is a collaboration between partners of the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Liquid Metal Engineering (LiME) which is a National Centre for fundamental and user-led research, and a hub for the UK solidification and casting community. Ongoing work is being carried out by an Industrial Research Fellow sponsored by Sapa, a major aluminium supplier and key partner of LiME.

Title: Shear enhanced heterogeneous nucleation in some Mg- and Al-alloys
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Cast Metals Research
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates that intensive melt shearing is an effective approach to the grain refinement of both Mg- and Al-alloys. This melt conditioning technique can be used for microstructural refinement, enhancing mechanical properties of as cast components and increasing recycled scrap content during casting processes. This technique will make a solid contribution to environmental protection and natural resource preservation.

Title: Refinement of primary Si in hypereutectic Al-Si alloys by intensive melt shearing
VolumeTitle: IOP Conference Series: Materials Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes for the first time a physical solution to the problem of refining primary Si in hypereutectic Al-Si alloys, which is crucial for commercial implementation of such alloys, by applying high shear to the melt prior to casting.  The physical solution is more effective than the existing inefficient commercial chemical practice.

Title: Melt conditioning by advanced shear technology (MCAST) for refining solidification microstructures
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Cast Metals Research
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we describe MCAST (melt conditioning by advanced shear technology) as a novel processing technology developed recently for conditioning liquid metal prior to solidification processing. We have successfully demonstrated that the microstructural refinement is achievable through an enhanced heterogeneous nucleation during subsequent solidification processing.

Title: Experimental testing of an active control turbocharger turbine inlet equipped with a sliding sleeve nozzle
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This project involved the development of a novel variable geometry turbine nozzle of the sleeve type to effect active control of the pulsating exhaust flow at the inlet of the turbocharger turbine. This work was EPSRC-funded (EPSRC GR/S04338/01).The outcome of this project involved the specification, design manufacturing and experimental testing of the novel nozzle design. The nozzle design was tested on a standalone turbocharger facility and demonstrated the ability to increase the power output of the turbocharger turbine by up to 7.5%.  In addition, a patent has arisen as a result of this research (WO2006/061588, 2006).

Title: The application of active control for turbocharger turbines
AdditionalInformation: This project funded by EPSRC (EPSRC GR/S04338/01) involved the development of a novel variable geometry turbine nozzle of the sleeve type to effect active control of the pulsating exhaust flow at the inlet of the turbocharger turbine. The outcome of this project involved the theoretical grounding of the concept of active control as an extension of the current state-of-the art in mechanical turbocharging which until today is the Variable Geometry Turbocharger. In thus doing, the paper defined a new type of turbocharger termed, the Active Control Turbocharger (IP protected by WO2006/061588).

Title: An inelastic Timoshenko beam element with axial–shear–flexural interaction
AdditionalInformation: In this work, a novel numerical procedure for the nonlinear dynamic analysis of skeletal structures is presented. The elastic Timoshenko beam element formulation is extended by introducing a set of smoothly evolving hysteretic degrees of freedom. The theoretical framework provided sets a cross-connection between nonlinear dynamics and classical plasticity. The solution procedure is based on the derivation of two state matrices, the elastic stiffness and the hysteretic matrix. These are evaluated once at the beginning of the analysis and remain constant thereafter. Thus, the derived methodology bears significant computational advantages when compared to classical iterative Newton-Raphson procedures.

Title: A macro-element based practical model for seismic analysis of steel–concrete composite high-rise buildings
AdditionalInformation: This paper was disseminated as an output of grant no 2012BAJ13B02 of the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology through the 12th Five-Year Plan National Key Technology R&D Program. A structural model was established for deformation checking of high-rise composite buildings under earthquakes with huge computational cost saving compared with micro-element based models, but without losing accuracy. The outcome of this research has been included into seismic design codes for Chinese buildings. For verification, please contact Dr GQ Li, Professor in Structural Engineering, Tongji University (gqli@tongji.edu.cn).

Title: Rheology of semi-solid fresh cement pastes and mortars in orifice extrusion
AdditionalInformation: This output made the base for the successful bid for the EU FP7 ‘FIBCEM’ project (Nanotechnology Enhanced Extruded Fiber Reinforced Foam Cement Based Environmental Friendly Sandwich Material for Building Applications), grant No 262954, for which I am the Scientific Manager (www.fibcem.com). An analytical model was verified for characterizing rheology of semi-solid fresh cement-based materials tailored for extrusion which is the key to achieve successful and successive extrusion for manufacturing building products from these materials. It only requires simple experimental set-up to apply the model for characterizing relative complex coupled elasto-viscoplastic constitutive behaviour of semi-solid fresh cement-based materials tailored for extrusion.

Title: The advantage of using extrusion processing for increasing dietary fibre level in gluten-free products
AdditionalInformation: This research evaluated the use of extrusion technology and a range of different fruit and vegetable powders to improve the nutritional profile of gluten free snacks. The results indicated that production of gluten-free expanded products with high dietary fibre levels can be achieved with control of extrusion conditions and selection of suitable raw ingredients. It has received favourable citations, interest from industry and inspired new studies on the development of low Glycaemic index’s products that was carried out in collaboration with Zaragoza University, Spain, which resulted in two peer-reviewed papers.

Title: The effect of extrusion cooking using different water feed rates on the quality of ready-to-eat snacks made from food by-products
AdditionalInformation: This paper continues the work on the incorporation of food by-products into ready-to-eat snacks, and deals with the effect of different feed moisture levels during extrusion cooking on the nutritional and textural quality of expanded products. The results showed that extrusion could have a marked effect in improving some nutritional and textural characteristics of extruded products. This work was carried out in collaboration with the University of Gazientap, Turkey.

Title: The effect of different enzymes on the quality of high-fibre enriched brewer’s spent grain breads
AdditionalInformation: This paper is part of the development of high-value added products using different technologies. A number of different enzymes, as advised by Novozymes, Switzerland, including Max-Life 85, Lipopan Xtra BG, Pentopan Mono BG and Celluclast L were incorporated into bread-making technology in order to improve the textural characteristics of high-fibre breads. The results revealed that the combination of these enzymes could improve the texture, loaf volume and shelf life of the breads. This work was extended with developing wholemeal breads and forming a sourdough with the addition of a range of enzymes and a book chapter was published.

Title: Cauliflower by-products as a new source of dietary fibre, antioxidants and proteins in cereal based ready-to-eat expanded snacks
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by the EU, Framework 6, project REPRO, involving 12 partners from 9 different countries. It concerns the development of high-value added products by using extrusion technology. It has received favourable citations, interest from industry and was elected among the 25 top hottest articles by Science Direct. This work inspired a new study that was conducted in collaboration with the Faculty of Medical Sciences University in Kragujevac, Serbia, who sponsored a project on the use of Jerusalem artichoke in development snacks with high level of inulin. As a result, a journal paper is currently under review.

Title: Structural modelling and testing of failed high energy pipe runs: 2D and 3D pipe whip
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: This work is an expansion to the R3 documentation of UK nuclear industry for the impact assessment on the design safety of nuclear power plants. The continuing development of this research contributes to the new built programme.

Title: Gradient design of metal hollow sphere (MHS) foams with density gradients
AdditionalInformation: Like paper No. 1, this work is related to an earlier EPSRC funded project (GR/R03426) on the mechanical strength of porous solids, but on a new generation of porous solids comprising of patterned hollow metal spheres in manipulated/optimised density gradients for specific energy absorption applications.

Title: Relative motion of tendon limbs in a loop tendon graft
VolumeTitle: Biomedical Engineering: Applications, Basis and Communications
AdditionalInformation: This work was an extension of an award winning research (2011 PraxisUnico’s Collaborative Impact Award) on the development and commercialisation of a new knee implant for ruptured anterior cruciate ligament. The IP rights are owned by the NHS and product based on the licensed design took over 20% of the US market within a year’s sale. The research helps to improve the quality of bonding of the graft to the bone, speed up healing and improves patients’ rehabilitation, leading to fewer hospital readmissions for ACL reconstruction failures.

Title: Analysis of a novel mild air hybrid engine technology, RegenEBD, for buses and commercial vehicles
AdditionalInformation: The research in this paper describes Regenerative Engine Braking (RegenEBD), a mild air hybrid engine technology, which is the subject of a commercial licence agreement with Guangxi Yuchai Machinery Ltd in China. The technique has been adopted for buses and showed a 5-15% reduction in fuel consumption. This work was sponsored by the EPSRC.

Title: A physical approach to the direct recycling of Mg-alloy scrap by the rheo-diecasting process
AdditionalInformation: Currently, Mg-alloys cannot be directly recycled in house due to the existence of a significant amount of oxide films and other inclusions. In this paper we have demonstrated a physical approach to direct recycling of Mg-alloys without the involvement of any chemical treatment. We found that intensive melt shearing can disperse the oxide films into nano-scale particles, which are not only no longer harmful to mechanical performance but also provide effective substrates for grain refinement. This discovery has led to a new patent for melt treatment: UK patent Application No. 1015498.7. Priority date: 15/09/2010.

Title: Impurities in Al–5Ti–1B grain refiner rod
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Cast Metals Research
AdditionalInformation: This study employed 3D tomography to examine as-received grain refiner rods. Results showed that the rods, without a carefully controlled manufacturing process, contained impurities in the form of residual and spent salts. The tomography enabled an unprecedented insight into non deformed impurity structures within the rod which were related to optical and electron microscopy microstructural findings. Not only could these impurities block filters but they could also affect the uniformity of the final as-cast properties of the casting. Grain refiner tests also revealed that these rods had poorer refining capabilities.

Title: Premixed Burn Fraction: Its Relation to the Variation in NOxEmissions between Petro- and Biodiesel
AdditionalInformation: It is commonly reported that biodiesel-operated diesel engines produce higher NOx emissions than petro-diesel, while there are also widely published literature claiming the opposite. In this work the engine operating conditions were carefully scrutinised to yield both increasing and decreasing NOx emissions while using biodiesel. The analysis of engine combustion parameters from the measured cylinder pressure data revealed that the NOx emissions from the biodiesel operated engine are linked to premixed burn fraction (PMBF). Any change caused to PMBF may explain the dilemma of NOx variations. This study was published together with Hatherill - industrial collaborator on this project.

Title: Modelling and control approaches for energy reduction in continuous frying systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an EPSRC funded project ‘OPTITHERM-Optimisation of Thermal Energy Recovery Utilisation and Management in the Process Industries’ EP/GO59799/1. The project was led by Brunel and involved the Universities of Newcastle and Northumbria and industrial partners including United Biscuits. The work reported in the paper utilised data from a United Biscuits food frying facility to investigate energy consumption and develop simulation models and controls to improve the performance of food frying systems. Implementation of the findings is now under discussion together with extension of the methodology to superheated steam drying through an EU funded project, 605228-STEAMDRY.

Title: Effectiveness of CFD simulation for the performance prediction of phase change building boards in the thermal environment control of indoor spaces
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a result of an EPSRC funded project on the ‘Integration of active and passive indoor thermal environment control systems to minimise the carbon footprint of airport buildings’, Grant No.  EP/H004181/1  led by Brunel and involving the universities of Loughborough, Reading, Kent and City, a number of airport authorities and equipment manufacturers. The research at Brunel led to four high quality journal publications and has contributed to the development of methodologies for  modelling the behavior of Phase Change Materials in buildings and their optimum integration within the building fabric and HVAC systems to reduce energy consumption.

Title: Integration of CO2 refrigeration and trigeneration systems for energy and GHG emission savings in supermarkets
AdditionalInformation: The paper is a result of Defra funded project AFM280 that involved 14 industrial partners including retailers such as Tesco and refrigeration equipment manufacturers, on the development of an innovative supermarket refrigeration and environmental control system involving CO2 refrigeration and trigeneration http://www.r744.com/news/view/1279/. Results from the research on trigeneration have been used in the design of Tesco environmental stores and optimisation of CO2 refrigeration equipment working with GEA Bock (compressors), GEA Searle (gas coolers) and Bond retail Services (refrigerated display equipment).

Title: On the multi-scale computation of un-bonded flexible risers
AdditionalInformation: This output resulted from a major project which was jointly funded by the EPSRC and offshore industry.  A novel modelling approach was proposed to simulate the dynamic behaviour of deep water flexible risers.  A constitutive law for un-bonded flexible risers was formulated and a procedure for the identification of the related input parameters was developed using a multi-scaling finite element approach.  The work reported in this paper subsequently became the benchmark for non-linear flexible riser simulation by other researchers working in the area.  The method is now also used by major oil companies for designing their deep water risers.

Title: An updated Lagrangian finite element formulation for large displacement dynamic analysis of three-dimensional flexible riser structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper was disseminated as one of the outputs of a major project jointly funded by the EPSRC and offshore industry.  It presents a new formulation for a class of non-linear finite elements based on continuum theory.  The element was carefully designed to simulate the very complex behaviour of deep water marine flexible pipes.  The use of this new element offers significantly improved accuracy and computational efficiency and has a wide ranging impact beyond the riser application.

Title: Self-noise produced by an airfoil with nonflat plate trailing-edge serrations
AdditionalInformation: There is a recent surge in interest on the application of trailing edge serration for the reduction of industrial fan broadband noise. In nearly all cases, however, the serration has been cut into flat plates and then inserted into the trailing edge of the main aerofoil body. This configuration suffers serious implementation, structural and health and safety issues. The research presented in this paper, which covers a wide range of Reynolds numbers, is expected to improve the industrial worthiness and increase the technology readiness level of the flow control technique by employing a non-flat plate type serration.

Title: Active Flow Control Systems Architectures for Civil Transport Aircraft
AdditionalInformation:
This output was disseminated as a result of the EU FP6 ‘AVERT’ project (Aerodynamic Validation of Emission Reducing Technologies), Contract No AST5-CT-2006-030914, led by Airbus UK: http://www.avert-aero.eu/. The flow control systems modelling tools developed and disseminated in this output by the lead author have industry significance, with the application of these tools and/or modified versions thereof utilised by Airbus UK within and outside of AVERT (Dr Norman Wood, Expert: Aerodynamics and Flow Control,
 Norman.Wood@airbus.com) and for Advanced Fluidics LLC (Dr Surya Raghu, Managing Director, sraghu@advancedfluidics.com).

Title: The Effect of Chain Extender on Poly(3-hydroxybutyrate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate): Thermal Degradation, Crystallization, and Rheological Behaviours
VolumeTitle: Journal of Polymers and the Environment
AdditionalInformation: This output was disseminated as a result of a TSB and EPSRC co-funded project in the area of Biomaterials and Advanced Materials. The project was titled Renewable Microcellular Foams, and involved eight partners including Sainsbury’s as an end user. The companies involved represent different links in the supply chain. PHA properties were extensively improved using surface treatment techniques and chain extenders to control crystallization.

Title: A plasticity model for powder compaction processes incorporating particle deformation and rearrangement
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: In this collaborative work between the Universities of Brunel, Aberdeen and Manchester, a mechanistic model is developed for dealing with compaction of granular materials that can be used with a commercial finite element package. The model draws on the ideas of critical state soil mechanics and theory of envelopes to develop an elasto-plastic model with a non-associated flow rule. The model incorporates both local deformation of the granule contacts and rearrangement of the granules so that, jointly, they account for any bulk deformation.

Title: Microwave foaming of starch-based materials (I) dielectric performance
AdditionalInformation: This work was disseminated as a result of the TSB project “Lightweight eco-composites based on renewable raw materials” (TP/2/MS/6/I/10118). Extruded pellets from starch-based materials were heated and foamed under microwave radiation. The foaming mechanisms and effects of some additives on the dielectric properties of the materials were investigated using a microwave calorimeter. The effects of starch destructurisation and additives are correlated to dielectric loss, glass transition, onset of peak energy absorption and foaming, and provided key information for control of material processing and microwave-assisted foaming.

Title: Magnetic properties of randomly oriented BaM, SrM, Co2Y, Co2Z and Co2W hexagonal ferrite fibres
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper is part of a series on Magnetic Inorganic Fibres that we have developed. The aim of developing these fibres is to produce components with fibre-reinforced composites of lightweight metals that can easily be processed and shaped. These fibres will impart strength to the lightweight metals, as well as imparting magnetic characteristics. By designing the magnetic properties of these fibres, one can develop composites with desired magnetic qualities of the metal. The application of these fibres is to impart stealth properties to lightweight aircraft components, among others.

Title: Effect of microstructural evolution on magnetic properties of Ni thin films
AdditionalInformation:
Nanocrystalline materials show structure-dependent optical magnetic and catalytic behaviour. 
This paper on thin films is part of a series of papers aimed at producing films with different crystalline sizes, either by starting with a nanocrystalline material, by producing nanostructures during the processing stage or by producing nanowires to improve packaging of integrated circuits.

Title: Excimer Laser Induced Nanostructuring of Silicon Surfaces
AdditionalInformation: This paper forms part of the series discussed for output N02, aimed at producing films with different crystalline sizes.

Title: Electric-field-induced nanostructuring of metallic thin films
AdditionalInformation: This paper forms part of the series discussed for output N02, aimed at producing films with different crystalline sizes.

Title: Late-News Paper: How to Fabricate Much Brighter AC Electroluminescent Lamps: Optimizing the Alignment of the Emitting ZnS:Cu Phosphor Particles to the AC Field
VolumeTitle: SID Symposium Digest of Technical Papers
AdditionalInformation: This was a prestigious late News Paper at the Society of Information Display meeting (Vancouver, May 2013). It was an output of TSB BEDS and ACTIVEL projects; it presented the culmination of many years of work with UK industries (supported by EPSRC and TSB; over £1.5M to Brunel) on ACEL. We showed that the microstructure of the phosphor was important and therefore, for optimum brightness, the crystals needed to align with the AC field. The audience was over 200 people; question time was busy, and since then we have had two further industrial enquiries that may lead to further collaborations.

Title: Eco-friendly AC electroluminescent lamps
VolumeTitle: IDW/AD '12 - The 19th International Display Workshops in conjunction with Asia Display
AdditionalInformation: This paper was chosen for oral presentation at International Displays Workshop in Kyoto in 2012, and is the culmination of the group’s many years of work in the ACEL field. It arose from an on-going TSB project entitled “Biopolymer-based Electronic Circuits and Displays” (BEDs) (TP No. 5754_44879)  with six industrial partners  (Total value  £906,055,  Brunel  £249,994).  The concept offers opportunities for biodegradable BEDs with recycling of components and is raising much interest from industry; as a result, we and three  companies have recently applied for another TSB programe to follow up an aspect of this work.

Title: A liquid crystalline copper phthalocyanine derivative for high performance organic thin film transistors
AdditionalInformation: This paper can be regarded as being an exciting step jump in the materials research in plastic electronics. So far, chemical compounds which exhibit high mobility are not environmentally robust. However, the custom designed molecules used in this research are highly thermally and chemically stable. These light molecules are soluble in common organic solvents and, therefore, amenable to the roll-on-roll processing on flexible substrates. These molecules show ambipolar charge transport. The impact of the research is that the University is now actively engaged in exploiting the novel observation in monolithic integration for the development of organic electronic circuits.

Title: Towards the enantioselective synthesis of (−)-euonyminol – preparation of a fully functionalised lower-rim model
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported the vanguard core scaffold structure of a large family of natural product polyesters found exclusively in herbaceous perennials of the Celastraceae family which possess interesting biological activities (e.g. anti-HIV activity). For the development of the enantioselective synthetic pathway the absolute stereochemistry for a number of light atom chiral synthetic intermediates was determined allowing the overall direction of the synthetic pathway to be designed. The impact of the paper will pave the way for future grants to investigate more of this family of compounds  and lead to a new area of drug research/development over the next few years.

Title: Engineering robust polar chiral clathrate crystals
AdditionalInformation: This paper contributes to understanding crystal engineering (a major theme of current chemical research). Its area is in the design and understanding of clathrates important for the supramolecular assembly of new systems (applications include: drug delivery, isomer separation, optical resolutions, storage of toxic and reactive materials and second harmonic generation).  Specifically it relates to Dianin’s compound and is the first chromatographic resolution of parent yielding enantiomerically pure samples of R-(+)-Dianin’s compound,  S-(+)-thiaDianin’s compound, and  their optically pure antipodes.  It teaches how these enantiomers yield the first quasiracemic polar host lattice structurally elucidated in the absence of a stabilizing guest molecule.

Title: (1S)-1-Phenylethanaminium 4-{[(1S,2S)-1-hydroxy-2,3-dihydro-1H,1′H-[2,2′-biinden]-2-yl]methyl}-benzoate
VolumeTitle: Acta Crystallographica Section C Crystal Structure Communications
AdditionalInformation: This work was undertaken for an industrial company. The indane pharmacophore occurs in many different bioactive molecules, including the nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory indane sulindac (Clinoril, Merck) and the protease inhibitor indinavir (Crixivan, Merck), used as a component of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Synthesized and characterized a series of dimeric indanes that demonstrate potent anti-inflammatory activity.  One such compound (PH46), is the title compound of this paper. To enable the PH46 to proceed further down the development pipeline it was necessary to determination of the absolute configuration of PH46 as part of the regulatory process.

Title: Synthesis of anti and syn hydroxy-iso-evoninic acids
AdditionalInformation: The work reports the first synthesis of hydroxy-iso-evoninic acid, a pyridyl diacid found as a macrodilactone bridging ligand in bioactive Celastraceae sesquiterpenoid-based natural products. These compounds are prized because their extracts exhibit an astonishingly wide range of medicinal properties and have been widely used in both traditional medicine (e.g. anti-HIV activity) and agriculture. The synthesis utilized a benzilic ester rearrangement and a late stage benzylic oxidation to give access to all four stereoisomers whose absolute stereochemistry was assigned following anomalous dispersion X-ray crystallography. The work has formed the foundation of new joint research programs on the discovery of new pharmaceuticals

Title: Photophysics and Electrochemistry of some Thione Far-Red/Near-IR Triplet Emitters
AdditionalInformation: Three indan-thiones, whose photophysics and redox properties had not previously been characterized, were examined. Two were novel; all three were shown to exhibit room temperature phosphorescence in the far red/near IR regions. Earlier speculation that phosphorescence might occur at much shorter wavelengths was laid to rest. 2,2-dimethylindan-1-thione emits at 640-750nm with a phosphorescent quantum yield of 0.15, whilst the novel structures, 2,2-dimethyl-indan-1-one-3-thione and 2,2-dimethyl-indan-1,3-dithione emit at 700-850nm with smaller yields. These structures are devoid of undesirable heavy metal atoms, and exhibit reversible redox characteristics which make them important for OLED, PV and biological sensor applications.

Title: Mechanical modeling of flexible OLED devices
AdditionalInformation: This study addresses the mechanical stability of thin multilayer electronic devices, where the different material layers have very different moduli of elasticity. For example, ITO as a ceramic transparent conductor (160Gpa) on PET supports (4GPa) is easily overstressed by the bending required in roll-to-roll manufacturing, resulting in poor device yields. The mechanical analysis and modeling software developed leads to the practical means of reducing such stresses and has huge impact for the printed electronics industry, in particular flexible OLED manufacture. An important patent (US Patent No. 20110241063A1) has resulted from this work.

Title: A nano-indentation study of the reduced elastic modulus of Alq3 and NPB thin-film used in OLED devices
AdditionalInformation: This study continues the work on mechanical stability of thin multilayer structures. Whilst the important moduli of elasticity are known for conventional metal, ceramic and polymer materials, they are completely unknown for the classes of new single-molecule organic/organometallic materials. Nano-indentation studies are performed on thin films of two common OLED materials to show how these quantities can be obtained. The report teaches that for such materials, a knowledge of these quantities for the already-established mechanical modelling/analysis is mandatory for assessing the minimum bending radii in a manufacturing process, or end use in a flexible device.

Title: Critical Role of Triplet Exciton Interface Trap States in Bilayer Films of NPB and Ir(piq)3
AdditionalInformation: This study uses state-of-the-art time-resolved spectroscopic techniques on organic/organometallic thin film bilayer structures, where the thickness of one layer is varied. Triplet excitons are created in this layer, allowed to percolate and cross the interface into layer 2, where they are detected as phosphorescence. A kinetic model is described which agrees quantitatively with experiment over more than 3 orders of magnitude in intensity and time. This fundamental experiment goes to the heart of understanding of triplet exciton transport through layers, and across boundaries, and offers a practical approach to optimizing critical aspects of OLED design.

Title: Study of a micro chamber quadrupole mass spectrometer
VolumeTitle: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the design and testing of a bakeable, small-volume quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS) intended for determining residual gas analysis (RGA) in devices that have extremely small volumes. The QMS, basically constructed of alumina, was successfully tested in small field emission displays, which have small evacuated volumes. The short electrodes reduce the resolution of the mass spectrometer somewhat; however, that is not a problem for measuring RGAs with this device.

Title: Method to obtain nonuniformity information from field emission behavior
VolumeTitle: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures
AdditionalInformation: This work was part of an on-going programme on the development of cold emitters for field emission displays. The paper describes a novel and simple technique to determine the effect of spatial non-uniformity of field emitters on the emission by using a spherical anode. For field emission displays emission uniformity is a very important property. This paper has had the highest citation rate of the actual JVST B issue. This is because the uniform emission of electrons has many uses in the aerospace industries.

Title: Field Enhancement of Full-3D Carbon Nanotube Arrays Evaluated in an Axisymmetric 2D Model
AdditionalInformation: The work described in this paper was carried out at the Centro de Tecnologia da Informação Renate Archer in Campinas (Brazil). It is part of an ongoing study on the field emission of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene sheets. We found that the field emission from 3D-arrays of CNTs can be accurately evaluated in a 2D model, enabling even the evaluation of the emission from arrays of open-ended (i.e. not closed with a hemisphere) CNTs.  The evaluation of field emission from arrays of the latter type of CNTs is virtually impossible in a 3D-geometry because of the meshing requirements.

Title: Cathodoluminescence of Powder Layers of Nanometer-Sized Y2O3:Eu and Micrometer-Sized ZnO:Zn Phosphor Particles
VolumeTitle: ECS Journal of Solid State Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper is the first in an on-going investigation at the Wolfson Centre for Materials Processing of Brunel University on how the cathodoluminescence (CL) of phosphor powder layers can be maximized. One of the ideas is making double layers of a low voltage and high voltage phosphor, as was done in the past for penetration CRTs (penetrons). The paper describes a new method to measure the CL of charging, non-conducting powder layers and a way to increase the accuracy by measuring the CL in reflection and transmission mode.It has set the standard for such measurements in the future.

Title: Effect of different grain structures on centerline macrosegregation during direct-chill casting
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with the practically important problem of centreline macrosegregation in direct-chill casting and the role of floating crystals in the formation of this phenomenon. The paper presents the very first experimental study on the contribution of coarse-cell and fine-cell grains to macrosegregation based on direct measurements of their composition.
