It is shown that the coarse-cell, floating grains are depleted of solute and the areas of their accumulation contribute to the negative macrosegregation. The areas of fine-cell grains can be either enriched in solute or be close to the nominal composition. It is suggested that that their composition results from the interplay between thermo-solutal and shrinkage-induced flows. The roles of casting parameters and grain refining are also under scrutiny in this paper.

Title: Numerical Analysis of Alternating Current Voltammetry: Identifiability, Parameter Selection and Experimental Design
AdditionalInformation: This work has led to Industrial collaborations with Johnson Matthey plc UK, (contact available on request).  Ongoing projects are exploring the application of high sensitivity voltammetric analysis approaches and their application to fuel cell systems. Exploitation of the identifiability strategy developed within the paper allows the statistical relevance of small and large amplitude ac measurements to be applied to current and next generation fuel cell systems. These methods are currently being exploited for the first time in combination with in-situ imaging techniques such as confocal microscopy, to study the current/concentration characteristics of fuel cell systems.

Title: Channel-Flow Cell for X-ray Absorption Spectroelectrochemistry
AdditionalInformation: This work has led to industrial collaboration with Schlumberger research, Cambridge, (contact available on request).  The approach uses a combination of in-situ imaging with microfabricated reactors for the analysis of electrochemical systems. The concepts have been developed further in collaboration with Schlumberger to explore the application of downwell microfluidic devices for the sensing of gases.

Title: The electrochemical detection of droplets in microfluidic devices.
AdditionalInformation: This study has led to new industrial collaborations with The Welding Institute (TWI), Cambridge, (contact available on request). This article looks at novel approaches to the analysis of electrochemical systems and in collaboration with TWI these will be adapted to analyse localised corrosion with the marine environment. The article also explores the potential for further identification of microdroplet properties and we hope these can also be used within a corrosive system.

Title: A Method for the Positioning and Tracking of Small Moving Particles
AdditionalInformation: This work has led to new collaborations with Schlumberger Research, Cambridge (contact available on request). The new approaches to the analysis of complex electrochemical systems will be exploited for the electrolytic generation and investigation of chemicals in downwell applications. The article notes the potential for further identification of particle properties and we are interested to explore the use of this novel approach to investigate particle properties downwell.

Title: Effect of water on overbased sulfonate engine oil additives
AdditionalInformation: Use of Small Angle Neutron Scattering for observation of a single molecule layer of water around 5 nm calcium carbonate particles dispersed in organic media. This is the smallest layer ever observed. This work has led to three further studentships with Infineum. The findings from the initial study, shown in this paper, has led to a research program at Infineum of 7 PhD and 12 BSc FTE's. The output from one of the subsequent student's work is currently going through the patenting process and this may lead to a manufacturing redesign. (contact Dr Dowding, email available on request).

Title: Plasticity and Fracture in Drying Colloidal Films
AdditionalInformation: This article demonstrates that cracks forming in a drying suspension experience extensive plasticity and therefore a way to minimise such cracking occurrences is by maximising plastic losses.This work has lead to numerous invited talks (IPCG, Shanghai June 2013 http://ipcg-conference2013.com/index.html; COSI Noordwijk June 2012 http://www.coatings-science.com/history/2012/asc12.html) and to an invited review article (Reports on Progress in Physics 76 046603 2013).

Title: Encapsulation of lactic acid bacteria in colloidosomes.
AdditionalInformation: This process will hopefully find use with probiotic bacteria, where protection through the harsh environment of the stomach, allows delivery of biologically active material to the gut. We have previously shown encapsualtion of yeast cells (Langmuir, 28(2):1169-1174 2012 ). We are currently seeking patent protection (contact Amanda Wooding, Cambridge Enterprise, email available on request).

Title: Bespoke periodic topography in hard polymer films by infrared radiation-assisted evaporative lithography
AdditionalInformation: We are manufacturing materials, from colloidal base particles, without the need for a 3D printer.The work is an output from a longstanding collaboration with Surrey University (contact Joe Keddie, email available on request). Other outputs include a textbook (Joseph L. Keddie and Alexander F. Routh, Fundamentals of Latex Film Formation: Processes and Properties, Springer 2010), two EU grants (Framework 6 Napoleon; Marie Curie ITN TRANSCEND) and an EPSRC grant (EP/H035397/1).

Title: Catalytic and chaperone-like functions in an intrinsically disordered protein associated with desiccation tolerance.
VolumeTitle: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
AdditionalInformation: This paper, resulting from interdepartmental and international collaborations, has been described by an independent expert in the field of intrinsically disordered proteins as 'of special interest': Tompa (2011) Curr Op Str Biol 21:419. It led to (a) an invitation to contribute to an invitation-only special edition of Molecular Biosystems, published as Chakrabortee et al. (2012) Mol. Biosyst. 8:210-219; and (b) invitations to present at international meetings in 2012, e.g. the Gordon Research Conference on Intrinsically Disordered Proteins, in Vermont, USA, and a conference on water stress proteins in Tsukuba, Japan, 2012.

Title: Inhibition of polyglutamine-mediated proteotoxicity by Astragalus membranaceus polysaccharide through the DAF-16/FOXO transcription factor in Caenorhabditis elegans.
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of several outputs resulting from ongoing collaborations with Chinese colleagues from several leading research centres in China (Shanghai, Wuhan, Shenzhen, Guangzhou). Three patent applications have been filed and a spin-out company, Shize Biotech Ltd., has been established in Wuhan to exploit aspects of this work. Further grant funding to support the academic research, both in China and Cambridge, is being sought. A collaboration with Infinitus (China) Co. Ltd., part of the Lee Kum Kee Group of Hong Kong, has been initiated to explore product development.

Title: Biochemical diversification through foreign gene expression in bdelloid rotifers.
AdditionalInformation: This work highlights the bizarre genetics of the bdelloid rotifer and prompted a new collaboration with colleagues from the Max-Planck Institute in Cologne and TGAC in Norwich to sequence the genome of Adineta ricciae. The first phase of this collaboration is nearing completion and high impact publications are expected. Invitations to speak at an international conference in Zurich (September 2013), and to give a seminar at the Free University of Brussels, were received as a result of this and related work.

Title: Bioinformatics and protein expression analyses implicate LEA proteins in the drought response of Collembola.
AdditionalInformation: This international collaboration led to a broader understanding of the significance of intrinsically disordered proteins in drought stress tolerance, and extended the phylogenetic relevance to insects. This was acknowledged in an influential review journal: Hand et al. (2011) Annu Rev Physiol 73:115.

Title: Exploring the Origins of Turbulence in Multiphase Flow Using Compressed Sensing MRI
AdditionalInformation: The referees described this as beautiful work which represents a leap forward in the temporal resolution achievable with MR velocimetry (PRL Jane Throwe contact available) and which will broaden the applicability of MRI. This paper was chosen by the journal editors as part of their 'editor’s selection' and was subsequently highlighted by the American Physical Society in their 'spotlighting exceptional research' program. The work formed the basis of a future invited review article in Journal of Magnetic Resonance. Alex Tayler was awarded the Sir Paul Callaghan Young Investigator Prize at the International Conference on Magnetic Resonance Microscopy for this work.

Title: Time resolved velocity measurements of unsteady systems using spiral imaging
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an MRI method of measuring structural images and velocity images in 5 milliseconds and at 200 images per second. Described as 'truly innovative and novel' by a reviewer (CES Anton Middelberg, contact available) it represents a breakthrough for the type of applications that can be investigated with MRI. The work led to a new entry in the Encyclopedia of Magnetic Resonance and to invited talks at the International Conference of Magnetic Resonance Microscopy 11 and Interpore 4. The new techniques shown in this paper led to an industrial project with Nestle Research (Lausanne, Marco Ramaioli, contact available).

Title: MRI technique for the snapshot imaging of quantitative velocity maps using RARE.
AdditionalInformation: This paper enables us to continue to lead in the application of MRI to pharmaceutical drug delivery systems and other transient engineering applications. The fast velocity imaging sequence developed here has been used in other projects including fluidisation (EPSRC Grant EP/F041772/1) and Biofilm growth (EPSRC Grant EP/E012205/1) and in several subsequent pharmaceutical projects including Dorothy Hodgkin/MerckSharpDohme PhD fellowship 'NMR and MRI studies of controlled release drug delivery systems' and current PhD project 'MRI of drug delivery systems'.

Title: Applications of ultra-fast MRI to high voidage bubbly flow: Measurement of bubble size distributions, interfacial area and hydrodynamics
AdditionalInformation: This work is based on  the techniques developed previously in dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jmr.2011.03.017 but are the application of the MRI technique to relevant engineering applications and bubbly flows in particular. This work shows that is is possible to apply ultra-fast MRI to Chemical engineering relevant two-phase systems. This has now been extended to liquid-liquid flows and being used in EPSRC Grant EP/H025405/1.

Title: The in-flow capture of superparamagnetic nanoparticles for targeting therapeutics.
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates multi-disciplinary research at the interface between engineering and biotechnology by making key observations on the dynamics of capturing magnetic nanoparticles that were suspended in a flowing carrier fluid by means of a permanent magnet. The observations in this paper led to a further four years of research projects, four journal papers (DOIs 10.1007/s11051-010-9885-6; 10.1016/j.jmmm.2009.02.088; 10.1007/s11051-009-9615-0; 10.1016/j.ces.2008.04.057), a conference proceedings (DOI 10.1063/1.2956814) and the invitation to write a book chapter, currently in press, on the subject of modelling magnetic nanoparticle capture (Monograph editor: Dr Adrian Ionescu, contact available on request).

Title: Multiple Microcapillary Reactor for Organic Synthesis
AdditionalInformation: This paper successfully proves the concept of a novel chemical microreactor system based on plastic components. This work lead to an external company, Lamina Dielectrics, developing prototype reactor units and their supporting systems with the intention of developing new business within this field. More broadly, work related to this paper undertaken by other investigators has resulted in development of immunoassays (filed by Reis et al. as WO2011117579) which, in turn, has led to the founding of a spin-out company, Capillary Film Technology Ltd. Contact details for Lamina's MD, Mr Patrick Hester, are available on request.

Title: In situ measurements of the formation and morphology of intracellular β-amyloid fibrils by super-resolution fluorescence imaging.
AdditionalInformation: We developed the first ‘direct Stochastic Optical Reconstruction microscope’ in the UK for this work, which initiated collaborations with NPL (Dr Alex Knight) and Würzburg (Prof. Markus Sauer). The basis for capabilities funded under the next generation light microscopy initiative by the MRC (MR/K015850/1) in the Cambridge Advanced Imaging Centre of which Kaminski is cofounder and board member (contact Prof. William Harris). Led to awards (as PI) from EPSRC (EP/H018301/1), Alzheimer Research UK (ARUK-EG2012A-1), and participation in the £5M Wellcome Trust/MRC funded Neurodegeneration Initiative (contact Prof. Peter St.G. Hyslop). Led to invited talks at MacromolecularDynamics 2011 and Spetsai2013 (www.spetsai.org)

Title: A quantitative protocol for dynamic measurements of protein interactions by Forster resonance energy transfer-sensitized fluorescence emission
AdditionalInformation: This work was presented as part of the Förster International Lecture Series, which I organised in Cambridge in 2008 to commerate the 100th anniversary of Theodor Förster.  As a result I was invited by the Royal Society to edit a special anniversary issue on Förster Resonance Energy Transfer in Royal Society Interface Focus (http://tinyurl.com/pbmz42m) and subsequently became a member of its permanent editorial board (contact Dr. Tim Holt).  It led to an invitation also to organise a topical issue on FRET in ChemPhysChem (http://tinyurl.com/aq7p7r5).

Title: Solitary Pulse Generation by Backward Raman Scattering in H-2-Filled Photonic Crystal Fibers
AdditionalInformation: Collaborative work and basis of Kaminski’s international SAOT optics award and award of SAOT guest professorship at Erlangen (contact Prof. A Leipertz). Led to invitations to speak at FLAIR 2011 (Murnau), CLEO 2011 (San Jose), Gordon Research Conference in Laser Diagnostics 2011 (Waterville Valley). Resulting further papers include theoretical research on supercontinuum light generation in PCF (e.g. Liu et al Optics Letters 35(24):2010 & Optics Express 20(6):2012), applications of PCF in gas phase sensing (Langridge et al Optics Express 16(14): 2008)) and liquid phase sensing (Kiwanuka et al Anal. Chem., 82(17)2010).

Title: A FRET sensor for non-invasive imaging of amyloid formation in vivo.
AdditionalInformation: The sensor concept is enabled by our fundamental discovery that protein amyloids develop size specific energy states on aggregation (Chan et al., Analyst 138 (7),(2013). It enabled applied research in disease (e.g. Murakami Hum. Mol. Genet., 21(1),(2012), Chakrabortee et al., PNAS,107(37),(2010)). It led to grant support (as PI) from Elan Pharmaceuticals (RG63781 – contact Dr. Matthams), the MRC (G0902243 & MR/K02292X/1), the BBSRC (BB/H023917/1), and AlzheimerResearchUK (ESG2012-1 & PG2013-14). The method is widely used by members of the WT/MRC funded neurodegenerative disease consortium in projects on Tau (Alzheimer’s) and alpha-synuclein (Parkinson’s) (contact Prof. StGeorge Hyslop).

Title: Platform for Techno-economic Analysis of Fouling Mitigation Options in Refinery Preheat Trains
AdditionalInformation: Preheat train fouling is the major source of energy inefficiency in oil refining. This paper demonstrates how cleaning schedules can be optimised for the large and complex networks of heat exchangers on oil refineries, in real time, using fouling models derived from the plant’s own data.  Author Wilson delivered a Distinguished Speaker Series lecture at UBC, Vancouver, on this work in September 2009. The IPR generated in this project has been commercialised in the IHS-ESDU software tool SmartPM [contact Simon Pugh, email available on request] which has been purchased by Phillips66 and is being trialled by other oil majors.

Title: A scanning fluid dynamic gauging technique for probing surface layers
AdditionalInformation: The scanning FDG mode revolutionises this unique technique and allows several locations to be studied concurrently, greatly increasing the amount of data which can be collected. This CASE project was sponsored by P&G [contact Dr Anju Brooker, email available], who subsequently purchased a unit and supported a follow-on PhD project. Royal Society funding for a zero flow FDG was awarded in 2012. Dr Gordon won a 2009 Schladming international fouling conference prize and the 2012 EHEDG Prize for the best dissertation in the field of hygienic engineering. The facility has attracted visiting researchers from Germany, Spain, Sweden and India.

Title: Extrusion-spheronisation of microcrystalline cellulose pastes using a non-aqueous liquid binder.
AdditionalInformation: Extrusion-spheronisation is a popular pharmaceutical granulation technique but encounters problems when the active ingredient is incompatible with water. This study demonstrated that non-aqueous liquid binder selection can be guided by biopolymer chemistry. The group’s leading work on the mechanics of extrusion-spheronisation resulted in a plenary lecture on the topic at the European PharmSci Fair in Prague, 2011. The work was supported by MSD (contact Dr Christian Seiler, email available) and the company funded a follow-on Dorothy Hodgkin PhD studentship in this area.  Author Mascia moved on to the  MIT/Novartis institute to a key role in developing continuous pharmaceutical granulation.

Title: Phenomenological study and modelling of wick debinding
AdditionalInformation: Ross Ceramics (contact Dr Alex Cendrowicz, ACendrowicz@rossceramics.co.uk) manufacture precision technical ceramic parts by injection moulding and reduce the time and energy required to remove the liquid phase from the part by wick debinding. This paper established, for the first time, the phenomenology involved as well as presenting a rigorous quantitative model. Author Somasundram won the oral presentation prize at the International Drying Symposium in Hyderabad, India, in 2009 for this work. Ross Ceramics supported a subsequent Collaborative Training project to transfer the modelling technology and techniques into their manufacturing science base and to investigate defect formation during debinding.

Title: Reducing data acquisition times in phase-encoded velocity imaging using compressed sensing.
AdditionalInformation: This technique led to a further publication in Physical Review Letters (PRL 108, 264505, 2012) and collaborations within Cambridge (Dr Anders Hansen, Dr Carola-Bibiane Schönlieb, Prof. Nick Kingsbury, Dr Daniel Nietlispach), at Oxford (Dr Sean Smart) and in Canada (Dr Steven Beyea) with associated high profile articles (Nanoletters 11, 4666, 2011; J. Colloid Interface Sci. 392, 7, 2013; Ultramicroscopy 131, 70-91, 2013; Nature 502 80-84 2013; Angewandte Chemie 50, 6548, 2011; J. Biomol NMR 54, 15, 2012; Mag Res Med in press 2013) and EPSRC (EP/K008218/1) and KTP projects (contact: Wes Maru, OGSL, +44 1353 666640 ) (KTP009424).

Title: Axial transport within bidisperse granular media in horizontal rotating cylinders
VolumeTitle: Physical Review E - Statistical, Nonlinear, and Soft Matter Physics
AdditionalInformation: A referee for Physical Review E (contact Editor in Chief Gene Sprouse, email available on request) stated that the new results help to clarify the topic and provide data that should clear up the confusion and/or lead to additional studies that will do so.  Such additional studies are underway.  A recent paper by Christov and Stone (PNAS, www.pnas.org/cgi/doi/10.1073/pnas.1211110109) cites the work as contributing to a paradox between experiment and computation. The work is being extended by Dr Third (email available on request) and collaborators in the Institute of Energy Technology, Dept of Mechanical and Process Engineering, ETH Zurich.

Title: Axial dispersion of granular material in horizontal rotating cylinders
AdditionalInformation: Third's work was part of the research he did for his PhD. He subsequently gained a postdoc position at the Institute of Energy Technology, Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, ETH Zurich.  This work led to further developments by Third (contact available on request), myself and collaborators (Granular Matter 12, 587-595, 2010 DOI 10.1007/s10035-010-0199-2, Granular Matter 13, 75-78, 2011, DOI 10.1007/s10035-010-0224-5) and by Third and collaborators in Zurich, including Physical Review E, 86, 061314, 2012 doi:10.1103/PhysRevE.86.061314, and conference papers.

Title: Flow of granular material through an inclined, rotating cylinder fitted with a dam
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to report results on flow through rotating cylinders with internal dams. The results have been reported in a review (Gao et al., Powder Technology doi: 10.1016/j.powtec.2012.05.060) to be useful for industrial kilns where conical brickwork dams at different locations are common.  The results have been used to assess the accuracy of an analytic solution for bed depth (Danish et al., Powder Technology, doi: 10.1016/j.powtec.2012.06.042).

Title: Modelling laminar pulsed flow in rectangular microchannels
AdditionalInformation: The paper has been cited in a paper reporting experimental and theoretical work on pressure in elastic microfluidic devices (Wunderlich et al, Lab on a Chip doi: 10.1039/B920221H), and in a paper on further developments on particle removal from surfaces by Kumar and Narayanan (Chemical Engineering Science doi: 10.1016/j.ces.2010.08.005).

Title: Functional consequences of amino acid substitutions to GerVB, a component of the Bacillus megaterium spore germinant receptor.
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript is considered to represent an important milestone in the field of bacterial spore germination research, and was described as a "landmark publication" in an independent peer review submitted by Professor Stanley Brul (University of Amsterdam) to the Faculty-of-1000 Biology website (http://www.f1000biology.com/article/id/1102044).

Title: Identification of New Proteins That Modulate the Germination of Spores of Bacillus Species
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative publication identified a new class of membrane protein that participates in the function of bacterial spore germinant receptors, challenging the decades long belief that the receptors comprise only three distinct protein subunits (Moir A. 2006. How do spores germinate? Journal of applied microbiology 101:526-530). The manuscript has consolidated the partnership between the Setlow and Christie labs, who are now working collaboratively on structural elucidation of various components of the spore germination apparatus.

Title: Characterization of the germination of Bacillus megaterium spores lacking enzymes that degrade the spore cortex
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript represents the first joint publication between the Christie and Setlow groups, leading directly to on-going collaborative research that has resulted in further higher-impact publications.  These include work that attempted to characterise functional relationships between different proteins involved in peptidoglycan hydrolysis during spore germination (Journal of Bacteriology 195(11): 2530-2540), and research that revealed a novel protein component of the Bacillus spore germinant receptor (Journal of Bacteriology 195(13): 3009-3021).

Title: Identification of a receptor subunit and putative ligand-binding residues involved in the Bacillus megaterium QM B1551 spore germination response to glucose.
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript represents the first study of its kind.  The paper was followed soon after by similar studies conducted by the Moir group on Bacillus subtilis germinant receptors (J Bacteriol. 2011. 193(9):2261-7) and led also to an invite from Prof. Ernesto Abel-Santos (University of Nevada) to contribute a chapter entitled “Initiation of Germination in Bacillus and Clostridium Spores” to the book “Bacterial Spores: Current Research and Applications”. Caister Academic Press (2012).

Title: Prediction of the mutual diffusivity in binary non-ideal liquid mixtures from the tracer diffusion coefficients
AdditionalInformation: This paper identifies the resolution of a controversy active since the 1920s (see for example Schreiner, 1922; Darken, 1946) about how to relate inter- and intra- diffusion coefficients. As well as representing a significant breakthrough in the understanding of diffusion in non-ideal liquids (Prof Ed Cussler at Minnesota, email available on request), it has industrial importance in liquid catalysis. Here reaction rates are often controlled by the diffusion of reactants or products in porous materials. The liquid mixtures are often highly non-ideal (e.g. alcohol-water) and conventional diffusion measurements impossible (Andy York at JM, email available on request).

Title: Chemical Product Design
AdditionalInformation: This second edition, double the length of the first, represents the culmination of a decade of research (e.g. DOI:10.1515/revce-2012-0002, DOI:10.1002/aic.10880, DOI:10.1205/026387600527022), focusing chemical engineering on higher value products. Submissions NO3/NO4 are examples of this approach in my research. Invited lectures at ECCE 2011 (Berlin) and the 2013 Sino-US Chemical Engineering Congress (Beijing) and a request to produce an e-learning course for the AIChE have followed. Almost 5000 copies of the two editions have sold. New material throughout: chapters 6-10 are entirely new, describing a division of product classes and novel approaches to their design. Contacts to verify impact on request.

Title: Effect of Stretching on the Structure of Cylinder- and Sphere-Forming Styrene-Isoprene-Styrene Block Copolymers
AdditionalInformation: There are a wide range of potential applications from this work. One we have pursued is the design and manufacture of an improved prosthetic heart valve, highlighted by the British Heart Foundation in an Observer feature (The New Review 13/11/11 p4) . £20k EPSRC Pathways to Impact Award. In collaboration with Papworth Hospital we have constructed a prototype valve which we are now testing and improving under a £250k BHF grant - implantation into pigs is scheduled for March 2014. Mr Nair (Papworth NHS Trust) for detail of clinical importance; Leah Pippard (BHF) for grant details, emails available on request.

Title: Zebra mussel filtration and its potential uses in industrial water treatment.
AdditionalInformation: The paper is one of several underpinning the Impact Case study on the control of invasive zebra mussels. It has contributed to the the development of patented technology by BioBullets Ltd. (co-founded by GDM). The BioBullet has been used successfully in five UK water treatment works. Biobullets has a manufacturing plant capable of producing 3000 tonnes per year, in partnership with Tastech Ltd. www.biobullets.com, Peter Sargent (TasteTech), Dr Piers Clark, Commercial Director of Thames Water, states 'We believe BioBullets will tackle [the zebra mussel] problem, saving hundreds of thousands of pounds in operational costs.'

Title: Applications of terahertz pulsed imaging to sustained-release tablet film coating quality assessment and dissolution performance
AdditionalInformation: This study established non-destructive, rapid terahertz imaging as an alternative to dissolution tests for coating quality control. Bayer funded a studentship following up from this work resulting in patent (EP12167035.0-1219) and five  papers. In 2012 Advantest Corporation developed its own THz tablet coating imaging instruments to compete with TeraView Ltd. They have hired >10 scientists in their new facility in Princeton, USA to develop work in this field. The work has stimulated research initiatives in the US (Lisa Zurk, Portland State, NSF 1231783) and Germany (Applied Competence Cluster Terahertz, Ruhr University Bochum, 2013) looking into pharmaceutical THz applications. Contacts available.

Title: Terahertz and far infrared Spectroscopy of alanine-rich peptides having variable ellipticity
AdditionalInformation: THz spectroscopy can be used to quantify how peptide molecules interact in aqueous solution. Following from this work MedImmune (Shahid Uddin) funded a one year PDRA together with Robert Falconer at University of Sheffield (7/2012-7/2013, £110k), who developed a THz assay to test the stability of antibody formulations. MedImmune has renewed PDRA position for a further 8 months in Aug 2013 (£70k) and together with TeraView Ltd (Paddy O'Kelly)  we have since won a TSB grant (09/13, TS/L005573/1, £68k) to test the feasibility of technology transfer of this method from our lab to MedImmune using commercial THz equipment. Contacts available.

Title: Terahertz in-line sensor for direct coating thickness measurement of individual tablets during film coating in real-time.
AdditionalInformation: We demonstrated THz imaging can be used in production scale tablet coating in real-time, a world first of a THz sensor for quantitative measurements of moving objects. Following from this work the EPSRC/Newton Trust funded a 1yr PDRA to further refine the concept in our lab as well as a 2yr PDRA as part of a EPSRC/TSB grant (EP/K503721/1, £244k) together with Aston Martin and TeraView Ltd. where we aim to advance this technique for applications during painting of cars. EPSRC grant application pending (EP/L019922/1, together with Yaochun Shen at University of Liverpool and James Elliott at Materials Science, Cambridge).

Title: Glassy dynamics of sorbitol solutions at terahertz frequencies
AdditionalInformation: We believe the dielectric beta relaxation, measured here, is directly related to the stability of the glass to crystallisation. This had led to further work and we have just filed a patent on this through Cambridge Enterprise (Christine.Martin@enterprise.cam.ac.uk). We have since used B22 at Diamond synchrotron (contact available) to expand our spectral range which confirmed our initial analysis. This work was presented at Faraday Discussion 167 and Austen Angell from Arizon State University commended us for the work. Publication submitted to PRL. Presentation at IRMMW-THz 2013 lead to new collaboration with free electron laser facility at Radboud University, Netherlands.

Title: The rate and extent of uptake of CO2 by a synthetic, CaO-containing sorbent
AdditionalInformation: A result is new research collaborations with ETH and NTU-Singapore under CREATE, including in-situ interrogation with synchotron radiation. The theory led to EU RFCS project ReCaL: "Novel Calcium Looping CO2 capture process incorporating sorbent reactivation by Re-carbonation" which is testing laboratory findings on improving the utilisation of calcium-based sorbents for CO2 removal at the 2 MW scale at La Pereda power-plant, Spain.

Title: Development and performance of Cu-based oxygen carriers for chemical-looping combustion
AdditionalInformation: The first suitable technique to be published for chemical-looping (CL) with solid fuels. The copper-based carriers are commercially-exploited by Gas-Recovery and Recycle Ltd (Cambridge Enterprise portfolio). for the clean-up of noble gases. Multi-institutional, UK-China collaborations, elucidating the materials-science of looping-materials, have emanated from this research to relate process-performance to structure, leading to funding by e.g. EP/I010912/1, EP/F027435/1 and Singapore CREATE.

Title: Life-Cycle Assessment of Potential Algal Biodiesel Production in the United Kingdom: A Comparison of Raceways and Air-Lift Tubular Bioreactors
AdditionalInformation: This research contributed to the establishment of the process engineering elements in the  University's Algal Biotechnology Consortium (http://www.bioenergy.cam.ac.uk/abc-directory), which, in turn, was funded ~£3.0M by Shell in recognition of work spanning from basic bioscience to process scale-up (Shell contact: David Parker, email available on request). The paper has raised much discussion, including enquiries from ExxonMobil Corporate Research (Venkatesh Vasudevan, email availabe on request).

Title: Production of Very Pure Hydrogen with Simultaneous Capture of Carbon Dioxide using the Redox Reactions of Iron Oxides in Packed Beds
AdditionalInformation: This paper  has major implications for moves towards the 'hydrogen economy'. The research is also relevant to a scheme being developed in CEB to convert woody biomass to liquid hydrocarbon fuels via gasification and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, obviating slow and uncertain processes for converting woody biomass to ethanol by biological means. This research underpinned the award of EP/I010912/1.

Title: In vitro quantitative H-1 and F-19 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and imaging studies of fluvastatin (TM) in Lescol (R) XL tablets in a USP-IV dissolution cell
AdditionalInformation: This publication led to the author being invited to give a talk at the Eastern Analytical Symposium in 2013 by conference chair Xujin Lu, from Bristol-Myers Squibb. It has also recently also led the author being invited to write a comprehensive review for the prestigious Journal Current Opinions in Collid and Interface Science (DOI: 10.1016/j.cocis.2013.03.006).

Title: Rapid distinction of intracellular and extracellular proteins using NMR diffusion measurements.
AdditionalInformation: This publication describes the first use of high magnetic field strength (12 T/m) PFG- NMR to study the Brownian dynamics of proteins in biological media. The impact of these developments show it is now possible to distinguish between inter- and intracellular proteins and thus represents a significant breakthrough for the unambiguous identification of intracellular dynamics. This paper has recently been selected by the editorial board of JACS to be highlighted in a JACS Select issue highlighting some of the currently most active areas in magnetic resonance, and the most trans-formative recent developments in the field. (Contact available on request).

Title: Quantitative ultra-fast MRI of HPMC swelling and dissolution.
AdditionalInformation: This work lead to the author being invited to write a comprehensive review in the area for a special issue of International Journal of Pharmaceutics 417(1-2):173-195 2011. This work also led to further funding of a EPSRC/Dorothy Hodgkin Ph.D. fellowship with Merck Sharp and Dohme (MSD Contact Dr Paolo Avalle: email available on request).

Title: Pulsed-Field Gradient NMR Spectroscopic Studies of Alcohols in Supported Gold Catalyststs
AdditionalInformation: This article presents new and exciting results concerning the mass transport of small organic molecules that are frequently encountered in industrial heterogeneous catalysis process. This work was funded under the EPSRC Green Oxidation Catalysis grant (GR/S41906/01) which led to further funding from the Technology Strategy Board for "The Glycerol Challenge"; grant refefence TP/7/ZEE/6/I/N0262B.

Title: Analysis of temperature programmed desorption (TPD) data for the characterisation of catalysts containing a distribution of adsorption sites.
AdditionalInformation: This work is part of a wider strategy to obtain physically meaningful parameters on catalysts from experimental data. These parameters can then be used to model catalytic processes and predict performance under a full range of operating conditions. The methods developed are now being used by other groups to analyse their results – for instance, the groups of Prof. G. Vidali (Syracuse University, USA), Prof. T. Orlando (Georgia Institute of Technology, USA) and Prof. H. Brune (EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland).

Title: The mathematical origins of the kinetic compensation effect: 1. The effect of random experimental errors.
AdditionalInformation: Many research groups observe compensation effects when studying the kinetics of chemical processes. As a consequence of the new results in this work, researchers are now testing whether random errors are inducing the effect (e.g. Prof. I. Kozhevnikov, University of Liverpool). This is important because predictions of the rates of chemical processes using observed kinetic compensation effects will otherwise be flawed.

Title: The mathematical origins of the kinetic compensation effect: 2. The effect of systematic errors.
AdditionalInformation: This paper explores for the first time the situations in which systematic errors cause apparent compensation effects. As a consequence, researchers are now aware of the link between systematic errors and apparent kinetic compensation effects (e.g. Prof. I. Kozhevnikov, University of Liverpool; Prof I. Metcalfe, Newcastle University). The paper identifies situations in which predictions of the rates of chemical processes using the compensation effect will be reliable and when they will be flawed.

Title: Interactions and Binding Energies of Dimethyl Methylphosphonate and Dimethyl Chlorophosphate with Amorphous Silica
AdditionalInformation: This work is part of a project investigating the adsorption properties of molecules that mimic chemical warfare agents (without being so toxic). Measurement and prediction of binding energies has implications in the design of sorbents and decontamination strategies. The project is in collaboration with Prof. J. Morris (Virginia Tech, USA).

Title: Identification of a biological signature for schizophrenia in serum
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study which proved that these conditions can be detected by changes in the levels of molecules in the blood. This work led to the development of blood-based biomarker test for schizophrenia in a clinical setting (www.veripsych.com/ contact available on request). The follow up has involved extensive collaboration with clinical psychiatrists in Germany, The Netherlands and the USA, and with the Myriad-RBM biomarker facility in Austin, Texas, USA (contact available on request) in efforts to identify biomarker tests for schizophrenia, depression and bipolar disease.

Title: Validation of a blood-based laboratory test to aid in the confirmation of a diagnosis of schizophrenia.
AdditionalInformation: The results from this work have led to a diagnostic test for distinguishing schizophrenia patients from controls (www.veripsych.com/), marketed by Myriad-RBM (Christopher E. Martin, Communications Director, Myriad RBM, Inc., contact details available on request). This paper was the first publication which has also led to 20 patent applications and 2 granted patents (PCT2006GB50035 and PCT2008GB04186). Also, it has led to continued development of further projects with Myriad-RBM and this work is on going.

Title: Increased levels of circulating insulin-related peptides in first-onset, antipsychotic naive schizophrenia patients
AdditionalInformation: This work led to finding changes in many other hormones of the diffuse neuroendocrine system (Guest et al. Psychoneuroendocrinology. 2011 Aug;36(7):1092-6). This work is being followed up by testing the possibility that antidiabetic medications, or drugs which target other hormone signalling pathways, can be used as effective supplemental or alternative treatment strategies for symptom improvement in schizophrenia patients. This has been established through collaborations with clinicians in The Netherlands.

Title: Transcriptional neoteny in the human brain
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows that the brain transcriptome is dramatically remodeled during postnatal development and that developmental changes in the human brain are delayed relative to other primates such as apes. This work has received a high number of citations indicating its importance in ongoing research with the world famous Svante Pääbo (contact available on request) who carried out highly publicised work on Neanderthal Man and evolution of apes, which has been covered in international newspapers such as the US News (http://www.usnews.com/usnews/culture/articles/030120/20paabo.htm).

Title: Turbulent plumes with heterogeneous chemical reaction on the surface of small buoyant droplets
AdditionalInformation: The model has a wider contribution towards understanding and developing safe carbon storage strategies. The model also describes flows such as the BP oil plume in the Gulf of Mexico (2010) and the volcanic plume in Iceland (2010). Impact: Invited talks at University of Paris (Prof. S. Vergniolle), Applied Mathematics(Cambridge, Prof. H. Huppert FRS), BP Institute (Cambridge, Prof. A. Woods), Imperial College (ChemEng Day UK, Prof. O. Matar )(contact details available on request).

Title: Turbulent entrainment into inert and reacting multiphase plumes
AdditionalInformation: The work quantifies the mixing between plume and environmental fluids in flows such as the BP oil plume in the Gulf of Mexico (2010) and the volcanic plume in Iceland (2010). It also applies to the dynamics of a hypothetical accidental release of carbon dioxide from a storage reservoir into the ocean. Impact: Invited talks at University of Paris (Prof. S. Vergniolle), Applied Mathematics(Cambridge, Prof. H. Huppert FRS), BP Institute (Cambridge, Prof. A. Woods), Imperial College (ChemEng Day UK, Prof. O. Matar )(contact details available on request).

Title: Effects of natural convection on thermal explosion in a closed vessel
AdditionalInformation:
Distinguished as ‘hot article’ by the journal. Referees' comments include ‘This is one of those papers that when you have read a few sentences you say “Why didn’t I think of that?”’ and '...this is a remarkably and superbly presented paper ... full of novel and interesting information ...highly relevant to the deeper understanding of how physics play a part in explosion phenomena.'
Editor:  Dr Madelaine Chapman (email of 12/6/2008, Article ref B808222G)

Title: Onset of convection in a porous medium in the presence of chemical reaction
AdditionalInformation: The work has wider implications for the engineered storage of carbon-dioxide in geologic reservoirs. Impact: Invited talks at Applied Mathematics (Cambridge, Prof. H. Huppert FRS), BP Institute (Cambridge, Prof. A. Woods), Imperial College (ChemEng Day UK, Prof. O. Matar) and Universite Libre Bruxelles (Prof. A. De Wit)(contact details available on request).

Title: Identifying optimal cleaning cycles for heat exchangers subject to fouling and ageing
AdditionalInformation: The findings of this work, based on rigorous optimisation approaches for timing and type of cleaning actions, are essential for optimal operation of heat exchanger networks, particularly in energy-intensive processes (e.g. crude oil refineries) where fouling leads to significant energy losses. They were a key part of a successful TSB project application by co-author Ian Wilson, “Closing the Fouling Loop”, and attracted a PhD student from Oman on a funded scholarship.

Title: Scheduling the cleaning actions for a fouled heat exchanger subject to ageing: MINLP formulation
AdditionalInformation: This work is the among the first to consider a dual fouling formation mechanism which allows more than one method for cleaning, and hence lead to more effective and cost-efficient maintenance policies.  This via the waste of energy and resources leads to negative environmental impact and unnecessary increase of CO2 emissions.  The work in this paper built upon earlier research presented at the Sustainable Thermal Energy Management Conference, (SusTEM2010), Newcastle, November 3rd, 2010.

Title: Towards the real-time monitoring of glucose in tear fluid: Holographic glucose sensors with reduced interference from lactate and pH
AdditionalInformation: This work built on earlier studies on the assessment of the performance of holographic sensors in contact lenses for minimally-invasive glucose measurements in tear fluid (Domschke et al. (2006) Proc IEEE 3, 1320-1323) and the initial clinical testing of the sensor (Domschke et al. (2006) Diabetes Technology & Therapeutics 8, 89-93). Understanding the nature of the interaction between glucose, lactate and pH and selected phenylboronates was important to greatly reduce the lactate and pH dependence of the glucose-responsive holographic sensor and bring it a step closer to being used in contact lenses to monitor glucose in real-time in tear fluid.

Title: Encoded and multiplexed surface plasmon resonance sensor platform.
AdditionalInformation: Follow up work on this highly flexible new optical sensor system has demonstrated its value in simultaneously assaying proteomic and oligonucleotide markers (Kastl et al. (2010) Biosens. Bioelectron. 26, 1719-1722).The technique has been further validated to detect a multiplexable assay for simulated spores, bacteria, viruses and toxins in environmental samples in a proof-of-concept funding project from DSTL (contact Dr Elaine Perkins) via Magna Parva Ltd (contact Dr Devaki Bhatta). This technique will be combined with a sample preparation module and exploited via the establishment of a new company LabXero Ltd (contact Dr Devaki Bhatta).

Title: Complexation of L-lactate with boronic acids: A solution and holographic analysis
AdditionalInformation: This 11B-NMR and holographic study established the nature of the interaction between L-lactate and phenylboronic acids in order to improve the selectivity for glucose. It was important to understand the mechanism of this interaction since there are high concentrations of lactate in tear fluid. Furthermore, it has led to a similar approach being used to create a potentially-implantable real-time acoustic sensor for glucose (Hu et al. (2012) Biosens.Bioelectron. 35, 425-428) which has been licensed to Quantz Medical (Suzhou) Ltd and to create metabolite-sensitive holograms readable by a camera-enabled Smartphone and thereby be of value to diagnostic physicians in resource-poor environments.

Title: Holographic enzyme inhibition assays for drug discovery.
AdditionalInformation: Linking chemically-responsive reflection holograms to enzyme catalysed reactions configured in a multi-layer construction has since been used to extend the range of selectivity of holograms to other analytes. One of our main objectives currently is to fabricate a holographic pregnancy test based on the principle of enzyme-linked immunoassay in a project funded by Swiss Precision Diagnostics (contact Dr Stewart Wilson) and involving enzymes which generate apolar products from polar substrates using our newly developed and patented laser ablation technology for fabricating holograms in apolar materials such as poly-dimethylsiloxane (PDMS) (Martinez-Hurtado et al. (2010) Langmuir, 26, 15694-15699).

Title: Azamacrocycle Activated Quantum Dot for Zinc Ion Detection
AdditionalInformation: This emerged from collaborative projects (EPSRC GR/T17007/01 and /BBSRC E19751) generating scorpion azamacrocycles as biorecognition ligands.  It is highly cited  demonstrating biorecognition ligand/semi-conducting nanoparticle interaction with photo generated electron-hole pairs and measurement of  intracellular Zn2+ accumulation in the patients with Alzheimer’s. It links with our clinical study on drug-active contrast agents at Addenbrookes Hospital (Wellcome Trust ISSF internship), whereas particular interest for our Sydney collaborators (http://groups.chem.usyd.edu.au/todd/research-azamacrocycles.html) stems from their candidature as drugs for HIV and cancer. They are interested in the influence of azomacrocyle Zn2+ binding linked to apoptosis and we are interested in their potential as sensitive imaging agents.

Title: Breaking the barrier to fast electron transfer
AdditionalInformation: This research area, first presented, pre-publication at the Gordon Conference on Chemical Sensors & Interfacial Design  has attracted invitations to give >dozen plenary and keynote presentations, including opening plenaries (Asianalysis, 2009 and RSC Tokyo International Conference, 2013). It was selected for the Bioanalytical Sensors Gordon Conference (2012) and its theme nominated as a session lead for 2014; it has resulted in the author  nomination as Gordon Chair(2016). This work  won the RSC Belcher award (2009), providing the break-through via synthetic biology to design directly connected mutant-GOx, which others are only just beginning to pick up.

Title: Ultrabubble: A Laminated Ultrasound Contrast Agent with Narrow Size Range
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows how we transferred our research on sensors to the development of contrast agents. It resulted in the filing of a patent application (GB0908827.9, May 2009). It also marked a turning point in our research. Collaborations were forged with Oxford (Stride) and London (Eckersley) as well as Addenbrookes Hospital (Wellcome Trust ISSF clinical internship), where clinical application in cells is under investigation. The capsule  geometry has been used in optrode development to produce fast responding (due to the thin shell diffusion path) analytical capsules (DOI: 10.1039/C1AN15336F) and to develop a highly novel contactless acoustic microsensor (IEEE Sensors, 2013).

Title: Multiplexed energy transfer mechanisms in a dual-function quantum dot for zinc and manganese
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided the incentive to propose a multichannel, multianalyte assay using quantum dot labels.  It was the inspiration behind an EU project on paper diagnostics (Biognostix, 5 countries, 6 partners) that is entering pre-prototype testing in 3 SME biological testing laboratories in Spain (Proteomika), Italy (PTP) and Switzerland (Prionics). The work and subsequent developments has initiated invitation to present at Pittcon 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 in an invited session on Ionophore sensors as well as keynote lectures at EUChemS 2012 and Euroanalysis 2012.

Title: Use of expanded bed adsorption to purify flavonoids from Ginkgo biloba L.
AdditionalInformation: This demonstrates that our expanded bed technologies, which have been developed for the production of therapeutic proteins, can be applied to the isolation of pharmacologically active ingredients from plants. This has lead to an approach for industrial collaboration from Sustein Ltd (contact available on request) who are seeking vegetal proteins for the Indian market at the scale and price suitable for mass consumption and are interested in the possibility of using EBA technology for this purpose.  Part of portfolio of research that lead to award of IChemE's Donald Medal for "outstanding services to the field of biochemical engineering".

Title: Single and two-component cation-exchange adsorption of the two pure major whey proteins.
AdditionalInformation: This paper has lead to an approach from Arla Foods Ingredients Group P/S, Denmark (contact available on request) to discuss the possibility of collaboration on the fixed bed separations of  food ingredients (including milk proteins) signifying industrial interest in this work.  Part of portfolio of research that lead to the award to Prof Chase of IChemE's Donald Medal for "outstanding services to the field of biochemical engineering".

Title: Adsorptive detagging of poly-histidine tagged protein using hexa-histidine tagged exopeptidase.
AdditionalInformation: Part of portfolio of research that lead to the award to Prof Chase of IChemE's Donald Medal for "outstanding services to the field of biochemical engineering".  The award certificate specifically refers to his work in "Industrially related research in the field of bioseparations technology" - the development of a new technique to simplify industrial bioseparations is the specific topic of this paper.

Title: Microwave-heated pyrolysis of waste automotive engine oil: Influence of operation parameters on the yield, composition, and fuel properties of pyrolysis oil
AdditionalInformation: This research was the subject of an ACS Press Release following presentation during the 241st American Chemical Society National Meeting & Exposition in Anaheim, California, March 27-31, 2011.  It has lead to multiple enquiries about the possibility of industrial exploitation (Starlight Energy Inc., Oakwood Fuels, U.K., Enval Ltd (contact emails available on request)).  Enval Limited is the subject of one of the impact case studies that constitute this REF submission.

Title: Rationalising MRI, conductance and pressure drop measurements of the trickle-to-pulse transition in trickle beds
AdditionalInformation: This and related work on hydrodynamic transitions and flow in trickle beds has led to long-term continued funding with Johnson Matthey through EPSRC grants GR/S43179/01; EP/G011397/1, and and a collaboration with ExxonMobil EMRE in the USA (since 2008 to date); the latter being worth >£0.5M (contact available on request). This work contributes to the practical and theoretical understanding of hydrodynamic transitions in trickle beds, and how to monitor them using cheap, robust probes that can be used on plant.

Title: Bubble size measurement using Bayesian magnetic resonance
AdditionalInformation: Leading from this work, Dr Tayler (the PhD student on the project) has been employed by Schlumberger Gould Research from October 2013 to work on implementing low field measurements of multi-phase flows. Schlumberger have funded an MR spectrometer and sponsored/seconded  a researcher at the MRRC for over 10 years; a proposal to extend this research partnership is currently under review by SGR (contact available on request). The bubble size measurements reported (for high gas voidage)  in this paper cannot be made using any other technique.

Title: Grain Sizing in Porous Media using Bayesian Magnetic Resonance
AdditionalInformation: Having exploited the Bayesian methodology for sizing spherical objects using magnetic resonance in characterising bubble sizes, the method was translated to the characterisation of grain size in rock cores. Dr Mitchell is fully funded by Schlumberger Gould research and works 50:50 in our lab and Schlumberger Gould Research. The success of this work means that it may be possible to implement this measurement on commercial logging tools - such as those developed by SGR. A patent application (61616280) arising from this work is held jointly by Gladden, Holland and Mitchell.

Title: Operando magnetic resonance: monitoring the evolution of conversion and product distribution during the heterogeneous catalytic ethene oligomerisation reaction.
AdditionalInformation: This is a significant development in advancing the application of magnetic resonance spectroscopy and imaging in realistic process environments. A fixed bed typical of those used in industrial scale-up studies was used. The reactor was designed by us in collaboration with Zeton BV, and now allows us to study vapour-liquid equilibria, catalytic reactions and separations at process conditions. Johnson Matthey plc (Dr Barry Murrer), ExxonMobil (Dr Doug Kushnerick) (contacts available on request) have both contributed funding for the development of this reactor and for future projects on industrially-relevant conversions.

Title: Modelling the internal structure of nascent soot particles
AdditionalInformation: The first time a cluster of 50 coronene molecules has been geometrically optimised using computational chemistry techniques. This work and other work on soot particles have led to an invitation to contribute a chapter together with David Kittelson to the Encyclopedia of Automotive Engineering. (contact: Lucy Wheeler, Publishing Assistant, John Wiley & Sons, Ltd). It has also sparked a debate on the fundamental nature of young carbon nanoparticles in the review paper:  H. Wang, "Formation of nascent soot and other condensed-phase materials in flames," (doi:10.1016/j.proci.2010.09.009).

Title: A detailed kinetic model for combustion synthesis of titania from TiCl4
AdditionalInformation: The data from this paper has been used by Huntsman Tioxide and Kronos, both substantial titania nanoparticle producers. Contacts are: Stephen Sutcliffe (Huntsman) and Andreas Kowalik (Kronos). This paper contains the first detailed chemical model for the decomposition of TiCl4  and forms the basis of a fundamental understanding of the gas-phase synthesis of titania nanoparticles under industrial conditions. Our work on titania has been featured on the cover of Combustion and Flame, no 158.

Title: Towards a detailed soot model for internal combustion engines
AdditionalInformation: The work has been carried out with the leading OEM Toyota and is now available commercially. Many OEM (Caterpillar, MAN, Navistar, Jaguar, Toyota, Mazda, Ford, GE. GM Europe) are now using the SRM 7.2 software from my spin-out company CMCL innovations to simulate emissions in engines. The software has been awarded by SAE with the AEI 2010 tech award. Contact Dr K-O Kim (email available on request) and http://www.cmclinnovations.com/

Title: Modelling soot formation in a premixed flame using an aromatic-site soot model and an improved oxidation-rate
AdditionalInformation: This modelling work develops the first soot model which accounts for particle morphology and composition. As it is the most detailed model which is currently is available I have received many requests to speak at conferences (http://como.cheng.cam.ac.uk/).  This model has also been implemented into the research group’s engine model and is now commercially available in the SRM 7.2 software used by OEMs. Contact: http://www.cmclinnovations.com/

Title: Protection of live bacteria from bile acid toxicity using bile acid adsorbing resins
AdditionalInformation: Emerging from TSB and BBSRC Pathfinder grants (DT/F002343/1 & BB/FOF/PF/19/09), patent protection was filed (European Patent Application No. 10700756.9.) and the University licensed the live bacterial vaccine formulation technology to Prokarium Ltd, which will conduct a Phase 1 human clinical trial of an ETEC/Typhoid vaccine (contact available on request). The technology featured in BBC News (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-22838635), The Telegraph (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/10108110/Vaccine-to-end-curse-of-Delhi-belly.html), The Times of India (http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-09/science/39848947_1_delhi-belly-bacteria-escherichia) and other international media.

Title: Surface Patterning of Carbon Nanotubes Can Enhance Their Penetration through a Phospholipid Bilayer
AdditionalInformation: Derives from a Royal Society International Joint Project (JP080816) with Dr Baulin (Universitat Rovira i Virgili, Catalonia) that showed that adornment of nanovectors with surface active moities lowers the free energy of cell membrane penetration, enabling cell entry. Laid the foundation for surface patterned nanovectors in drug delivery leading to an EU Marie Curie ITN grant (FP7-PEOPLE-2013-ITN, 608184) with a consortium of European academics and companies. Part of the portfolio of work that led to the award of the IChemE Donald Medal (2009) for "outstanding services to Biochemical Engineering".

Title: Biopolymer mediated trehalose uptake for enhanced erythrocyte cryosurvival
AdditionalInformation: This study, funded by a contract with Pfizer Inc (now Zoetis Inc, cf. Dr Paul Domionowski,  contact available on request) employed a synthetic biopolymer to increase membrane permeability to the preservative trehalose and so impart cellular osmoprotection and resistance to freezing. The results were filed for IP protection (UK Patent Application No. 1000999.1) and underpin a BBSRC BRIC award (BB/I016961/1).  A research collaboration with GSK is being concluded (cf. Dr Christina Basford: contact available on request) to test the preservation technology with their cell line.

Title: Generation and manipulation of magnetic multicellular spheroids.
AdditionalInformation: The final paper in a sequence of publications that arose from a programme of BBSRC BRIC funded work (BB/E005853/1 & BB/D007933/1) on cell surface biotinylation for facile cell and virus capture (with Prof Farzin Farzaneh, Kings College London, contact available on request), from which emerged UK Patent Application No. 0920775.4. This work was conducted by an A-Star (Singapore) funded researcher (Dr Vincent Ho) and shows that the approach can be used to assemble tissue constructs.

Title: Opening the gate: framework flexibility in ZIF-8 explored by experiments and simulations.
AdditionalInformation: This paper was highlighted in the Diamond Light Source -synchrotron newsletter (http://www.diamond.ac.uk/Home/About/Corporate-Literature/newsletter/Summer11/mofs.html) and has been cited widely (+70 since 2011) in journals such as Chem.Reviews, J.Am.Chem.Soc., Chem.Commun, etc. It led to a further publication in Dalton Transactions 41(35):10752-10762, where this study was extended to different gases with a clear industrial application focus. These results have been presented in international conferences such as MOF2012, Edinburgh, and Characterisation of Porous Solids 2011, Dresden. This publication was key to create new research initiatives (working with Prof. Snurr and Prof. Hupp at Northwestern University, USA) and to obtain a University Research Fellowship (Royal Society).

Title: Unusual adsorption behavior on metal-organic frameworks.
AdditionalInformation: The novelty of the research in this paper (presented in international Fundamentals of Adsorption10, Japan conference), exploring the new adsorption behaviour of a novel family of materials (metal-organic frameworks), led to two international collaborations. Dr. Andrea Rossin from Dr. Maurizio Peruzzini's group at CNR - Institute of Chemistry of Organometallic Compounds ICCOM, Firenze, Italy sought collaboration to explore their experimental results (Langmuir 27(16):10124-10131 2011). Second, Prof. Antonio Rodríguez-Diéguez, from the University of Granada, Spain, asked for modelling and experimental support, leading to two publications (CrystEngComm 14(20):6390-6393 2012 and Inorganic Chemistry 52(2):546-548 2013) plus one in preparation. These collaborations continue today.

Title: Incorporation of an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene into a metal-organic framework.
AdditionalInformation: This work started as a collaboration with Prof. Stoddart's group (Northwestern University, USA) to provide assistance in resolving a crystalline structure. I was able to apply and develop the ideas presented in my previous work at ChemCommun 48(85):10496-10498. The present paper was published in 2012 and is receiving an increasing number of citations in Journals such as J.Am.Chem.Soc. and ChemCommun. Moreover, this paper allowed me to start a collaboration that continues today with Prof. Hupp's group (NU) to apply this approach on the materials they prepare. The new results have been published at Chem.Materials 25(5):739-744 and J.Am.Chem.Soc 135(28):10294-10297 2013.

Title: Understanding excess uptake maxima for hydrogen adsorption isotherms in frameworks with rht topology.
AdditionalInformation: The methodology developed in the paper to build new crystalline structures allowed me to start a collaboration with Prof. Stoddart, Northwestern University, USA (results: J Am Chem Soc 134(42):17436-17439 2012) and to develop my existing collaboration with Prof. Hupp's group (results: Chem.Materials 25(5):739-744 2013 and J.Am.Chem.Soc 135(28):10294–10297 2013). More recently, it allowed me to start a collaboration with Prof. Janusz Lewinski (Warsaw University of Technology, with a paper recently published in Angewandte Chemie) and Prof. Anthony Cheetham (University of Cambridge) combining molecular simulations and experiments to use metal-organic frameworks in a new field: drug delivery.

Title: Wasting cash - the decline of the British biotech sector
AdditionalInformation: The study contributed to two student dissertations, and was the basis for further analysis of biotech financing including European and US companies, two further papers in preparation and submitted, and two further student dissertations. The paper’s conclusions have now been provided as input into Government planning for the biotech industry, through links forged with Government advisors on the life sciences, specifically to Dr. Mark Treherne (Chief Exec of the Life Science Investment Organisation), and informally with George Freeman MP, Governor Advisor on Life Sciences.

Title: A combinatorial approach to biochemical space: description and application to the redox distribution of metabolism.
AdditionalInformation: Led to talks at conferences (5th British Astrobiology Conference, April 2013 - see http://www.astrobiology.ac.uk/files/2013/03/ASB5-science-programme.pdf  , 17th Evolutionary Biology Meeting, Marseilles, Sept 2013 - see http://sites.univ-provence.fr/evol-cgr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=22&Itemid=42), further research presented at a Synthetic Biology Gordon conference in 2013 (June 9th thru 14th 2013, Chair Vitor V. Martins Dos Santos), a sponsored visit to give a seminar at Harvard in 2014  (Harvard Dept of Astronomy Chalk Talk 2014, invited by Dimitar Saselov), and a major international collaboration between myself and researchers at ETH Zurich (Janusz Petkowski)and MIT (Sara Seager) (contacts available). A follow-up paper on this research was submitted in autumn 2013.

Title: A biomass-based model to estimate the plausibility of exoplanet biosignature gases
AdditionalInformation: The methods described have already been applied to predicting whether we can detect life on hydrogen-rich super-Earths, planets like none in our Solar System, which is in press (doi:10.1088/0004-637X/776/1/1, pre-print at http://arxiv.org/abs/1309.6016). This highly interdiscplinary collaboration between astronomy, atmospheric photochemistry, chemical thermodynamics and microbiology is now being expanded in a collaboration between JPL (CA, USA - Renyu Hu), MIT (MA, USA - Sara Seager) and Cambridge (contacts available on request). The paper received a full page of news coverage in New Scientist on 12th October 2013 [New Scientist 12th Oct 2013 p14 - http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22029382.800-how-to-sniff-aliens-gas-in-exoplanet-atmospheres.html ], illustrating its wider impact.

Title: Solvent effect and reactivity trend in the aerobic oxidation of 1,3-propanediols over gold supported on titania: Nmr diffusion and relaxation studies
AdditionalInformation: Presents a new methodology to study liquid-phase catalytic reactions and extends the initial work on a similar system (doi: 10.1002/chem.201201922). The referee (contact available on request) claimed “this work may underpin the use of NMR techniques to understand, and hence optimize, the selection of catalytic system and reaction medium” and “is of interest for a broad, heterogeneous readership of Chemistry” .This work was recognized with the “Young Scientist Award” at the ICC 2012, Munich. It sparked industrial interest in companies (Dr Andy York, Johnson Matthey, contact available) which think that the approach can be very beneficial for catalyst development.

Title: Screening of new solvents for artemisinin extraction process using ab initio methodology
AdditionalInformation: This paper includes international collaboration with two groups at RWTH-Aachen.  Industry provided new green solvent samples for this study (Huntsman's carbonate solvents). This paper has led to two projects in collaboration with industry (Case award with Sensapharm Ltd: Industrial supervisor Dr Neil Sullivan and TSB project with BIOME Ltd, contacts available on request), two invited lectures (Green Extraction, Avignon, France, 2013; Artemisinin conference, Hanoi, 2011) and invitation to write a book chapter on extraction for a new book "Green Extraction of Natural Products", Wiley.

Title: High temperature sequestration of CO2 using lithium zirconates
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a close industrial collaboration with two companies (MEL Chemicals and UOP). It provided a very fundamental look at a carbon sequestration material of significant interest. MEL Chemicals have used results of this study to formulate new commercial products MELSORB1596/1597 (http://www.zrchem.com/products/melsorb_lithium_zirconates.asp). This study also led to a new industrially co-sponsored project (Case with MEL Chemicals, industrial supervisor Dr Emiliana Dvininov, contact available on request).

Title: Simulation of catalytic reduction of nitrates based on a mechanistic model
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from the work done within a European project "Monacat" (FP7). It was the first published mechanistic model for nitrates reduction and it was already followed and further developed by research community, e.g., Appl.Catal.A: 445 (2012) 26-34. This work has led to a new FP7 project FREECATS (www.freecats.eu) in which we are continuing modeling of processes based on nanostructured carbon. This work also led to a new collaboration with Warwick Manufacturing Group and Warwick Engineering (Dr Petr Denissenko). This paper also contributed to UK Catalysis Hub project on remediation of nitrates (Prof. Graham Hutchings). Contacts available on request.

Title: Synthesis of high aspect ratio titanate nanotubes
AdditionalInformation: Our group published extensively on titanate nanotubes. This paper addressed a little explored area in hydrothermal synthesis, namely the impact of mass transfer on the morphology of the material obtained. Our findings were well received by the community and we notice the methodology being applied to different materials now, which shows impact across materials engineering field, e.g.: Langmuir 27 (2011) 5644-5649, Chemistry A European Journal, 19 (2013) 10235-10243.

Title: Optimal protection of stabilised dry live bacteria from bile toxicity in oral dosage forms by bile acid adsorbent resins
AdditionalInformation:
Emerging from TSB and BBSRC Pathfinder grants (DT/F002343/1 & BB/FOF/PF/19/09), patent protection was filed (European Patent Application No. 10700756.9.) and the University licensed the live bacterial vaccine formulation technology to Prokarium Ltd, which will conduct a Phase 1 human clinical trial of an ETEC/Typhoid vaccine (contact available on request). 

The technology featured in: 

BBC News (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-22838635), 

The Telegraph (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/10108110/Vaccine-to-end-curse-of-Delhi-belly.html), 

The Times of India (http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-06-09/science/39848947_1_delhi-belly-bacteria-escherichia) 

and other international media.

Title: Blind assessment of localisation microscope image resolution
AdditionalInformation:
We developed a mathematical theory for an advanced microscopy technique used in biomedical research.

Based on this work we published Open Source microscopy software, praised by a Journal of Optics editorial as being "invaluable for anyone implementing localization algorithms” [doi:10.1088/2040-8978/15/9/090201]. Several groups worldwide employ this software to support their applied microscopy research and technology development projects [R. Henriques, UCL; R. Roy, IIT Bangalore, +6 more]. Our expertise in this technique supported a successful bid for a grant (Leverhulme, RPG-2012-793) to apply the technique to Virology; and to further published advances in microscopy software (doi:10.1364/OE.21.010978), also Open Source.

Title: Influence of visco-elastic binder properties on ram extrusion of a hardmetal paste
AdditionalInformation: This work was sponsored by and performed in collaboration with the industrial engineering company CERATIZIT, a world market leader in hard material products. The results and recommendations from the study are currently being implemented by CERATIZIT Austria in order to improve their hard metal paste processing line via modifications of extrusion equipment in terms of operation and design (contact available). The success of the research work led to continued collaboration and ultimately a new line of research; a jointly-sponsored PhD research project has thus been developed, which now involves collaboration with CERATIZIT and their main industrial competitor, Sandvik (contact available).

Title: A comparison of ram extrusion by single-holed and multi-holed dies for extrusion-spheronisation of microcrystalline-based pastes
AdditionalInformation: The work reported in this publication was sponsored by and performed in collaboration with the global healthcare leader MSD (contact available on request). The study succeeded in developing a test in which only small charges of pharmaceutical paste are required, which is an important concept for industrial pharmaceutical companies in terms of quality control and economics. Using the initial results published here as a basis, the continuation and development of the study is providing scope for a number of journal papers, e.g. Int. J. Pharm., 456, 489-98 (2013).

Title: A novel lab-scale screen extruder for studying extrusion-spheronisation
AdditionalInformation: The research work published here forms part of a continued collaboration with the world-leading pharmaceutical company MSD (contact available). The processing of healthcare pharmaceutical products involves a number of carefully controlled unit operations, and the novel results from this study are currently being assessed by MSD in terms of implementing them into their research and development programme. The research augments the current understanding of industrial screen extrusion mechanisms. As a direct result of this study, a new collaboration with the Pharmacy Department at the University of Xian, China, is on the verge of being realised (contact available on request).

Title: Extrusion-spheronisation of highly loaded 5-ASA multiparticulate dosage forms.
AdditionalInformation: This research, which was in collaboration with the University of Milan (contact available on request), lays a pathway for revolutionising the development of tablets containing a relatively high dose of active pharmaceutical ingredient, with the intention of decreasing the number of tablets consumed daily by patients. The study is the first to provide a solution to the processing problems associated with these high dosage formulations. The success of the work led to further collaboration with the University of Milan, and another publication on the optimisation and scale-up of high dosage forms (Eur. J. Pharm. Sci., 45, 158-168, 2012).

Title: Development of an improved heating system for industrial tunnel baking ovens
AdditionalInformation: The work reported here is part of an ongoing research initiative by Fylde Thermal Engineering Ltd., a UK-based company with 25 years experience developing and implementing innovative engineering solutions for the food industry. It is expected that this research will result in a commercial viable and patentable burner system for better control of radiation received by the food during baking, as well as a novel and potentially patentable sensor for the measurement of water vapour concentration in baking ovens. The Kellogg Company (Battle Creek MI., USA) participated in this research, including the construction of a US$2m pilot plant. (contact available)

Title: Nuclear magnetic resonance relaxation and diffusion in the presence of internal gradients: the effect of magnetic field strength.
VolumeTitle: Phys Rev E Stat Nonlin Soft Matter Phys
AdditionalInformation: This work was part of a collaboration with Schlumberger (contact Edmund Fordham, email available on request) and preceded two further publications in J Chem Phys (vol 132, pp 244705, 2010) (vol 139, pp 074205, 2013). On the basis of this work the author was awarded the Giulio Cesare Borgia Prize, 2012 presented at the Magnetic Resonance in Porous Media conference by the Groupement AMPERE (http://ocs.som.surrey.ac.uk/index.php/mrpm11/mrpm11/schedConf/overview/), and the BRSG-NMRDG Annual Prize, 2013 presented by the Institute of Physics (http://www.iop.org/activity/groups/subject/brsg/prize/brsgnmrdg/page_40729.html).

Title: Emulation of petroleum well-logging D-T2 correlations on a standard benchtop spectrometer.
AdditionalInformation: This work represents part of an on-going collaboration with Schlumberger (contact Edmund Fordham, email available on request) and lead to the Schlumberger patent: "System And Method For Emulating Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Well Logging Tool Diffusion Editing Measurements On A Bench-Top Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer For Laboratory-Scale Rock Core Analysis" US patent 8,427,145 B2, granted: 23 April 2013. This work has also been incorporated in a new business venture: Schlumberger Reservoir Laboratories, Houston, TX, USA.

Title: Compressive strength of delaminated aerospace composites
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This research ensures damage tolerance of composite structures in aerospace applications. It formed part of a programme that developed an efficient design method for composite wing structures satisfying manufacturing constraints and design rules. The outputs have been further developed by Airbus, including the first layout design method for entire composite wings, patented by Airbus (US 20100223029) and adopted in the manufacture of the A350 aircraft (Optimisation Manager, Airbus Lars.Krog@airbus.com). Further outputs include follow-on collaboration with GKN to analyse composite manufacture and defects (richard.newley@gknaerospace.com) and the award of the Royal Academy of Engineering / GKN Aerospace Chair in Composites Analysis (Butler).

Title: Transient and time-averaged characteristics of a compressible ground vortex flow
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Research supported by EPSRC grant no. GR/N02504; part of Cranfield University’s long-standing research programme on jet aerodynamics applied to vertical or short take-off and landing (V/STOL) aircraft. This was the first presentation of unsteady measurements of a ground vortex using non-intrusive techniques. The data have helped inform hot-gas ingestion safe operating boundaries The contact to verify the impact of the V/STOL work is Peter Curtis of Bae Systems (pcurtis@ara.co.uk) This data have also been included in a series of continuing professional development courses delivered in the UK (Shrivenham) and in the USA (Fort Worth, Texas and Patuxent River Naval Air Station, Maryland) to aerospace engineers from around the world (richard.l.mange@lmco.com)

Title: Explicit Finite Volume Modeling of Aircraft Anti-Icing and De-Icing
AdditionalInformation:
This research follows on from a collaboration with DTI, AIRBUS UK, Rolls-Royce, GKN and QinetiQ to develop industrial design tools for modelling ice build-up on aircraft compnents in flight.

The output is a new, more inclusive mathematical treatement of the icing process, expanded to include to the case of surfaces which are heated, continuously or intermittenty, to provide efficiency improvements in aircraft systems.  Contact roger.gent@aerotex.co.uk.

Title: Uncertainty in gas turbine thermo-fluid modelling and its impact on performance calculations and emissions predictions at aircraft system level
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
