AdditionalInformation: This research won the ASME Cycle Innovations Committee Best paper Award at the AMSE Turboexpo Conference 2009 (GT60101). It was instrumental in the conception, development and verification of the PROOSIS software tool (Dr Marc Doussinault marc.doussinault@snecma.fr). This led to the commercialisation of PROOSIS by EA Internacional, Madrid (Pedro Cobas, Head of EcosimPro and PROOSIS Software Development, pce@ecosimpro.com), now used to model turbomachinery by companies including Airbus (DAX.AU@airbus.com) and Snecma (Safran Group) (marc.doussinault@snecma.fr). Techniques have subsequently been adopted for aero-engine technoeconomic environmental risk analyses in EU FP7 projects NEWAC (Cranfield value €412k), DREAM (€353k) and LEMCOTEC (€200k).

Title: The damage cost of carbon dioxide emissions produced by passengers on airport surface access: the case of Manchester Airport
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by an EPSRC project (EP/H003398/1), conducted with Loughborough and Leeds universities.  The work has been used by Manchester Airports Group to assess incentives for employees to use alternative surface access methods, and to re-examine surface access strategies at their airports to reduce their carbon footprint (Head of Environment, Manchester Airport Group, Tim Warmsley, Tim.Walmsley@manairport.co.uk).

Title: Co-operative path planning of multiple UAVs using Dubins paths with clothoid arcs
AdditionalInformation: The paper is an outcome of an EPSRC funded research project (EP/E048587/1). The research has resulted in an efficient algorithm which is capable of producing real-time flyable paths for simultaneous arrival on target of a group of UAVs http://www.epsrc.ac.uk/newsevents/news/2010/Pages/aerialsurveillance.aspx. Of 150 papers presented at IFAC (International Federation of Automatic Control) Symposium on Automatic Control in Aerospace (2007), this was one of only four selected for inclusion in this special section of the journal (ACA 2007). A further outcome was authorship of a book (Tsourdos, White & Shanmugavel) "Cooperative Path Planning of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles"   (Wiley 2010, ISBN: 978-0-470-74129-0).

Title: Contaminant Cloud Boundary Monitoring Using Network of UAV Sensors
AdditionalInformation: The paper is an outcome of a research project funded by the Data and Information Fusion Defence Technology Centre ("Mapping of urban environments subject to airborne contamination using sensor swarms", DIF-DTC-PROJ3.1, £1.2M) in collaboration with QinetiQ and University of Bristol. The output was a novel system to detect, model, and track the shape of a contaminant cloud boundary using airborne sensor swarms. Contact Nicholas Jenner, njenner@qinetiq.com.

Title: Robust Covariance Estimation for Data Fusion From Multiple Sensors
VolumeTitle: Ieee Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
AdditionalInformation: This article is the result of an Anglo-Portuguese Joint Research Programme funded by the  British Council, (Treaty of Windsor Programme). It resulted in a new technique for cooperative sensing of robot swarms, making intelligent use of additional statistical data from sensors and navigation systems. It solves an important data fusion problem in robotics with application to the emerging area of "autonomous and intelligent systems". Contact Prof Sequeira Institute for Systems and Robotics, Lisbon, joao.silva.sequeira@ist.utl.pt.

Title: Relative position and attitude coupling control of Sun-Earth L2 point formation flying by QLTV polynomial eigenstructure assignment
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by the European Space Agency and EADS Astrium. It presents a new control technique that solves problems in the control of position and attitude of flying vehicles, with application in situations where independent control of these factors can produce coupling effects that otherwise cause errors. Contact Finn Ankersen, Finn.Ankersen@esa.int.

Title: Modelling and Analysis of Turbofan Engines Under Windmilling Conditions
AdditionalInformation: This research was conducted in collaboration with Rolls-Royce via the University Technology Centre in Gas Turbine Performance Engineering. The output is a methodology for the prediction of altitude relight engine performance of an aero engine which is a matter of safety in aviation. This research provides Rolls-Royce with robust predictive capability from the very early stages of the engine design and reduces the risk associated with the relight certification of the engine. It led to follow-on funding from Rolls Royce for one PhD and three MSc projects to build on this capabilty (Contact: richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com)

Title: Considerations on the numerical modeling and performance of axial swirlers under relight conditions
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This research was conducted in collaboration with Rolls-Royce via the University Technology Centre in Gas Turbine Performance Engineering. The output is a methodology for the prediction of altitude relight engine performance of an aero engine which is a matter of safety in aviation. This research provides Rolls-Royce with robust predictive capability from the very early stages of the engine design and reduces the risk associated with the relight certification of the engine. It led to follow-on funding from Rolls Royce for one PhD and three MSc projects to build on this capabilty (Contact: richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com)

Title: A Sub-idle Compressor Characteristic Generation Method With Enhanced Physical Background
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by Rolls-Royce (through its University Technology Centre in Gas Turbine Performance Engineering, £2.1M). The research outcome improves the predictive capability in terms of the altitude relight performance of aero engines. The results were first presented at the ASME Turbo Expo 2010 conference, winning the “ASME Cycles Innovations Committee Best Paper Award” of the same year. The results have been adopted in follow-on projects funded by Rolls-Royce (2010-2013) to build on and improve the methodology.  (Contact: richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com)

Title: Analysis of turbine performance degradation effects due to geometry variations between actual components and design Intent
AdditionalInformation: This paper was produced in collaboration with the Laboratory of Fluid Mechanics and Turbomachinery, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece. It quantifies the effect of manufacturing errors on the performance of an axial two-stage steam turbine, allowing manufacturers to optimise designs for real rather than idealised component geometry. This paper adds to a body of work that has been adopted by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) to be embedded onto the design processes of the company (Contact: hiroharu_ooyama@mhi.co.jp )

Title: Design, integration, and preliminary assessment of a takeoff monitor display
AdditionalInformation: This research has arisen from previous work that is the subject of UK and US granted patents (GB2375748 and US7,158,052 respectively), awarded to the authors. The current work presents a novel concept for displaying take-off performance in the cockpit, that is unambiguous, quick and easy to read. This and other publications by the author have led to an invitation to be part of EUROCAE (European body responsible for the publication of new EU standards) WG-94, tasked with preparing an international standard on take-off monitoring.  Contact: anna.vongroote@eurocae.net,  http://www.eurocae.net/working-groups/wg-list/96-wg-94.html.

Title: Air Transport in Africa: toward sustainable business for African airlines
AdditionalInformation: There has been very little research into the commercial side of airlines domiciled in Africa, and this is one of very few academic papers published in the area. The authors have a recent article in Airline Business (monthly magazine: international circulation 20,000) on the use of partnerships, and removal of government interference, to help grow Africa's airlines. O’Connell conducted a training course for Arik Air in Lagos, Nigeria in 2013 based on the research findings, which are also being incorporated into Arik Air’s long term planning strategy. Contact: Kencho Omojafor, kencho.omojafor@arikair.com.

Title: The rise of the Arabian Gulf carriers: An insight into the business model of Emirates Airline
AdditionalInformation: This research, on the core competencies of the Gulf based carriers, has been used by Singapore Airlines' strategic planning department. Cranfield conducts corporate training for middle and senior executives biannually at the airline's headquarters in conjunction with Linda Snin, linda_snin@singaporeair.com.sg.  The research from this paper has also been used by Etihad Airways in formulating strategies to compete against Emirates, in conjunction with Mohammed Yeahiya, MYeahiya@etihad.ae.

Title: The impact of air policy on incoming tourist traffic: the contrasting cases of the Caribbean Community and the Middle-East
AdditionalInformation: Research outcomes suggest that open skies policies within the Caribbean region would stimulate the tourism industry. The authors presented these findings to the Caribbean Tourism Organization  in St Kitts, 11-12 October 2012, a meeting attended by several hundred delegates involved with economic harmonisation and integration of the Caribbean islands, in which air transport plays a major role.

Title: An investigation into traveler preferences and acceptance levels of airline ancillary levels
AdditionalInformation: Ancillary revenue generated $27 billion for the global airline industry in 2012 but there has been little academic research generated in this area to date. This research on ancillary revenue was carried out for SITA, a leading specialist in the commercial side of air transport communications and IT. Contact: Andrew Sleath, Andrew.Sleath@sita.aero. The work was highlighted in a summation in the China Daily (http://epaper.chinadailyasia.com/pools/2-20110520-015.pdf), the significance being that new revenue streams for financially distressed airlines could yield sustained profitability.

Title: An Integrated Approach for the Multidisciplinary Design of Optimum Rotorcraft Operations
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports research undertaken within the EU FP7 Clean Sky Joint Technology Initiative (http://www.cleansky.eu/). The methodology described allows for the simultaneous multi-objective optimisation of rotorcraft performance in the context of environmental impact. This is now being applied within the Green Rotorcraft (GRC) Integrated Technology Demonstrator (contact GRC7 Technical Lead - Chrissy Smith, Chrissy.Smith@agustawestland.com, (http://www.agustawestland.com/content/green-rotorcraft)). This led to 6 journal publications and further research with NLR, AW and Turbomeca, on the calculation of gas turbine emissions (contact GRC7 Technical Lead – Chrissy Smith,  Chrissy.Smith@agustawestland.com) and a research contract (£70k) with NOESIS Solutions Intl. on multi-disciplinary optimisation (contact Mr Roberto d'Ippolito, roberto.dippolito@noesissolutions.com).

Title: Time accurate modelling of the secondary air system response to rapid transients
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted in a software tool (now used within Rolls-Royce) that enhances considerably industry’s capability to model rapid transients within the secondary air system of a gas turbine. The tool can have a significant role in new engine design and certification, through a more robust engine performance prediction at extreme off-design and critical conditions. This led to Rolls-Royce agreeing to fund three further projects (£210k) to capitalise on the offerings of the new capability (contact at RR -  Richard Tunstall, Richard.Tunstall@Rolls-Royce.com).

Title: The effect of upstream duct boundary layer growth and compressor blade lean angle variation on an axial compressor performance
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: In contrast to CFD-based techniques, this work allows the detailed analysis of turbomachinery flow fields providing at the same time a flexible and cost-effective solution to the high computational demand and resource usually required (contact Prof. P. Kotsiopoulos, kotsiopoulos@hafa.gr, Hellenic Air Force Academy, HAFA). The software tool developed is now used by HAFA (contact Dr. I. Templalexis, templalexis@hafa.gr) in the investigation of the effects of intake flow distortion on compressor design and performance. This work inspired further collaboration at an international level with the Hellenic Air Force and Cranfield both contributing towards the further development of the software.

Title: A dynamic convergence control scheme for the solution of the radial equilibrium equation in through-flow analyses
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research addressed convergence issues in turbomachinery through-flow analysis codes, resulting in software that gives robust solutions over wider range of boundary conditions than previously. The robust methodologies developed were incorporated in the software tool SOCRATES, now routinely used by Cranfield and the Hellenic Air Force Academy (HAFA) in the design and performance analysis of modern axial-flow compressors (contact HAFA Dean - Prof. P. Kotsiopoulos, kotsiopoulos@hafa.gr). At Cranfield SOCRATES is also being used within the Rolls-Royce University Technology Centre in various turbomachinery design and performance improvement studies (contact at RR - Richard Tunstall, Richard.Tunstall@Rolls-Royce.com).

Title: Multiple-Point Adaptive Performance Simulation Tuned to Aeroengine Test-Bed Data
AdditionalInformation: Aeroengine overhauls can cost between hundreds of thousands to millions of pounds. This paper describes a new performance based technique, adaptation, to identify faulty components to enable a better focus of the repair effort. This is in use at Honeywell (an engine manufacturer/overhaul provider) where it has reduced post-overhaul engine failures and returns to the overhaul shop for further costly repairs.This work was a contributing factor to an improvement in the test pass-off rate from 55% to 90% at Honeywell. Contact Christos.Isseris@vectoraerospace.com (formerly at Honeywell)

Title: GA-based design-point performance adaptation and its comparison with ICM-based approach
AdditionalInformation: This research was conducted as part of a 6 year collaboration with the Manx Electricity Authority (MEA, Isle of Man), where it yielded an improved understanding of factors affecting plant performance and the effects of maintenance on operations. The outputs are computer based models for power plants that optimise performance and reduce maintenance costs. These are now in use at the MEA, to help operators refine maintenance management and improve their ability to bid their powerplant to the grid. The results also led to further collaboration between Cranfield and MEA over an additional 4-year period (and ongoing).  Contact Mike Newby Plant Engineering Manager Generation Division mike.newby@mea.gov.im.

Title: Applying heat pipes to a novel concept aero engine Part 1-Design of a heat-pipe heat exchanger for an intercooled aero engine
AdditionalInformation: This research (inspired by our  participation in the multinational EU projects VITAL (AIP4-CT-2004-012271, £550k) and NEWAC (AIP5-CT-2006-030876, £400k) evaluated technoeconomic aspects and risks of related changes in engine anatomy and the associated performance benefits that could contribute to a reduction in carbon emissions by up to 10%  compared to contemporary (2005-10) power plants.  It supported the research of partners to compare different engines and heat exchanger options for the future enabling even more environment friendly civil aviation.  This paper focuses on one type of power plant while that above focuses on another. Agreed contact andrew.rolt@rolls-royce.com.

Title: Applying heat pipes to a novel concept aero engine Part 2-Design of a heat-pipe heat exchanger for an intercooled-recuperated aero engine
AdditionalInformation: This research also evaluated technoeconomic aspects and risks of related changes in engine anatomy and the associated performance benefits that could contribute to a reduction in carbon emissions by up to 10%  compared to contemporary (2005-10) power plants.  It supported the research of partners to compare different engines and heat exchanger options for the future enabling even more environment friendly civil aviation.  This paper focuses on one type of power plant while that above focuses on another. Agreed contact andrew.rolt@rolls-royce.com

Title: Flow measurements in a Short Takeoff, Vertical Landing fountain : parallel jets
AdditionalInformation: The data has been made available to aid ground effect studies on the F-35 JSF (Contact Peter Curtis, BAE Systems, pcurtis@ara.co.uk). The research findings have also been incorporated into an internationally-delivered CPD course (Fundamentals of V/STOL Aircraft Design) delivered at Fort Worth, TX in 2009 and Patuxent River, MD in 2010 (Contact Richard Mange, Lockheed Martin, richard.l.mange@lmco.com).

Title: Flow measurements in a short takeoff, vertical landing fountain : splayed jets
AdditionalInformation: The data has been made available to aid ground effect studies on the F-35 JSF (Contact Peter Curtis, BAE Systems, pcurtis@ara.co.uk). The research findings have also been incorporated into an internationally-delivered CPD course (Fundamentals of V/STOL Aircraft Design) delivered at Fort Worth, TX in 2009 and Patuxent River, MD in 2010 (Contact Richard Mange, Lockheed Martin, richard.l.mange@lmco.com).

Title: Computational study of flowfield characteristics in cavities with stores
AdditionalInformation: The work has led to collaboration with the Aircraft Research Association (BIS20400) (apeace@ara.co.uk) and ongoing collaboration with BAE Systems (tjbirch@dstl.gov.uk) transferring knowledge (through sponsored research and CPD courses) on non-intrusive measurement of cavity flows.

Title: Computational investigation of cavity flow control using a passive device
AdditionalInformation: The work has led to collaboration with the Aircraft Research Association (BIS20400) (apeace@ara.co.uk) and ongoing collaboration with BAE Systems (tjbirch@dstl.gov.uk) transferring knowledge (through sponsored research and CPD courses) on non-intrusive measurement of cavity flows.

Title: The geography of the Spanish airport system: Spatial concentration and deconcentration patterns in seat capacity distribution, 2001-2008
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by the Spanish Ministry of Science and Innovation (Grant SEJ2006- 04023) and the Catalan Agency for Management of University and Research Grants (Grant 2009SGR0106). The analysis of network restructuring impact in Iberia, and identification of new hub-bypassing strategies by US airlines in the Spanish market, led to a collaboration with SEO Economic Research, spin-off company of the University of Amsterdam (Dr. Burghouwt, G.Burghouwt@seo.nl).

Title: Incorporating annoyance in airport environmental policy: Noise, societal response and community participation
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by the Spanish Ministry of Science (Grant SEJ2006- 04023), and performed in collaboration with the University of Santiago de Compostela (Dr. Paul, v.paul.carril@usc.es) and the ANNA (Aircraft Noise-Non-auditory Aspects) Group, coordinated by the Spanish Observatory of Sustainability in Aviation (Mr. Velarde, cvelarde@senasa.es). Its results have important applications for airports' public relations policies. Results were applied by the Spanish airport manager (Aena) for internal debate and training (Mr. Hesse, Aena Environment Director, jmhesse@aena.es).

Title: Connectivity levels and the competitive position of Spanish airports and Iberia's network rationalization strategy, 2001-2007
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by the Spanish Ministry of Science (Grant SEJ2006- 04023) and the Catalan Agency for Management of University and Research Grants (Grant 2009SGR0106). The research was a collaboration with SEO Economic Research, (Dr. Burghouwt, G.Burghouwt@seo.nl). Preliminary results from this programme were featured in a full-page opinion article in the Sunday business supplement of La Vanguardia, the leading newspaper in Catalonia and the third in Spain (5 December 2010).(http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/2011/10/02/pagina-25/85077754/pdf.html).

Title: An appraisal of the CORINE land cover database in airport catchment area analysis using a GIS approach.
AdditionalInformation: This research was a collaboration with SEO Economic Research,(Dr. Burghouwt, G.Burghouwt@seo.nl), and the Autonomous University of Barcelona (Dr. Pallares-Barbera, montserrat.pallares@uab.cat). The methodology developed in the paper mitigates biases caused by pre-defined census district boundaries in airport catchment area analysis, and was used as the basis for an OECD paper on Airport Capacity Expansion Strategies, discussing the capacity of hub airports for growing beyond their local market.(http://www.internationaltransportforum.org/jtrc/DiscussionPapers/DP201305.pdf).

Title: Helicopter maintenance error analysis: Beyond the third order of the HFACS-ME
AdditionalInformation: Novel application of the Human Factors Analysis and Classification System (HFACS) tool was cited as a research example in the University's successful bid for a 2011 Queen's Anniversary Prize, awarded for our contribution to aviation safety. It enables a systemic analysis of the human factor causes of accidents, and provides a predictive capability for assessing vulnerabilities in the maintenance process. Its application to maintenance aspects of helicopter operations was innovative, previous applications having been focused towards the flight deck of commercial fixed-wing aircraft. A prototype model was tested by Eurocopter, and is under continuing evaluation (contact Andy Bloxham, andy.bloxham@a2baero.co.uk)

Title: Perceptions of safety and offshore helicopter travel
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Energy Sector Management
AdditionalInformation: This work resulted in invited presentations to the International Helicopter Safety Team, CHC Safety & Quality Summit and Shell Aircraft Safety Seminar. North Sea Helicopter operations involve a high degree of risk, highlighted through the loss of 5 aircraft since 2009. The cost of these accidents is large and greatly affects the ability of the customer (oil / gas producers) to operate offshore facilities. The effect of lost confidence in flying following accidents, predicted by this paper was confirmed following recent incidents. (Contacts: Mark Stevens,  M.Stevens@shell.com and Duncan Trapp, Duncan.Trapp@chc.ca)

Title: Investigating the investigations: a retrospective study in the aviation maintenance error causation
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigated the impact of human reliability on aviation maintenance safety and developed a new model. Helicopters were taken as a focal case study, although results are generalisable to a wider audience. Interest has been expressed by Eurocopter (contact Patrick Pezzatini, Patrick.Pezzatini@eurocopter.com) and the tool is under evaluation by easyJet, with discussions underway for a new joint research project (contact Tony Garforth, Tony.Garforth@easyJet.com)

Title: Eradicating root causes of aviation maintenance errors: introducing the AMMP
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an approach to proactive safety applicable to an aviation Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul organisation (MRO). It introduces the Aviation Maintenance Monitoring Process (AMMP),  enabling industry to monitor the existence of human error causal factors which can, as a result, be gradually eliminated. The process has been validated within industry and a commercialised product is under development for use by airlines and maintainers. (contact Tony Garforth, tony.garforth@easyjet.com)

Title: Application of aerodynamic model structure determination to UAV data
AdditionalInformation: Outcome of a research collaboration with BAE Systems. The work resulted in a series of tools suitable for parameter-estimation of unmanned aerial vehicles. The tools have been used by BAE Systems to validate their in-house methodologies (Stephen.Carnduff@baesystems.com) and led to a follow-on study (promoted by Clyde.Warsop@baesystems.con and Chris.Fielding@baesystems.com).

Title: Pilot-model-in-the-loop simulation environment to study large aircraft dynamics
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The simulation environment discussed in the paper was developed under a previous project, as underpinning for a range of research projects supported by Airbus. This follow-on study, fully funded by Airbus UK ltd, enhanced the model and applied it to a potentially hazardous situation that has been encountered in flight.  (Thomas.Wilson@Airbus.com).

Title: Simulation of wake vortex effects for UAVs in close formation flight
AdditionalInformation: Outcome from collaboration with Cobham plc working as part of the ASTRAEA I (Autonomous Systems Technology Related Airborne Evaluation & Assessment http://www.astraea.aero) consortium (DTI project: TP/3/DSM/6/I/15769), to develop a simulation environment for wake interaction studies: recognised by the consortium as a necessary precursor to the development of autonomous refuelling systems. The work formed the basis of further studies to refine and apply the model at Cranfield (overseen by Harvey.Wilson@cobham.com) and Bristol Universities within ASTREA II.

Title: Positioning Algorithm for Autonomous Thermal Soaring
AdditionalInformation: This work resulted from a study sponsored by the FLAVIIR project (a £6.2M research programme funded jointly by BAE Systems and EPSRC, looking at unmanned aerial vehicle technology).

Title: Power and energy management system for fuel cell unmanned aerial vehicle
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research led to funding from CONACYT (Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnología - the Mexican national council for science and technology) (CONACYT REFERENCE No: 178809) total value of £73,730.

Title: Adaptive neuro fuzzy inference system-based intelligent power management strategies for fuel cell/battery driven unmanned electric aerial vehicle
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The significance of this research has resulted in exploring together wtih Euro Energy Solutions the potential of  Fuel cells for a robotic propulsion application (Dr Paul Scott, Paul.scott@euro-energy-solutions.com). This research  resulted in Dr Economou being appointed by the IMECHE part G Journal of Aerospace Engineering  to be the Guest Editor for a Special Issue Journal in “ELECTRIFICATION OF AIRCRAFT SYSTEMS–POWER AND CONTROL” .

Title: Fault diagnosis with matrix analysis for electrically actuated unmanned aerial vehicles
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research provides an optimum flight path for UAVs with the minimum energy or (fuel) requirements with significant savings. It led to funding from the Systems Engineering for Autonomous Systems Defence Technology Centre (SEAS DTC, contract C/WPE/N03751, £100k) on Intelligent Power Management (IPM) for Autonomous UAV Systems, in collaboration with Rolls Royce, BAE Systems, Roke Manor Research and QinetiQ. IPM is considered a key capability to allow vehicles, whether manned or unmanned, to meet the rising trend in systems power and the demands of system attributes such as endurance, mission flexibility and life cycle cost. Contact: David Morgan (dave.a.morgan@rolls-royce.com)

Title: Energy conservation based fuzzy tracking for unmanned aerial vehicle missions under a priori known wind information
AdditionalInformation:
This  Paper was the research outcome of  a collaboration with the University of Valenciennes in France, supported via an ERASMUS grant. 
The Graph Theory based energy management output of this work has been adopted  to solve the optimum path for a robotic manipulator in a collaboration with Allen Vanguard Ltd.  Contact Martin Lawrance (Technical Director Allen Vanguard Ltd), Martin Lawrance Martin.Lawrance@allenvanguard.com. Impact: "The current research is expected to contribute significantly to providing improved means of generating precise path control algorithms for remote manipulators, particularly suited to implementation on mobile robotic systems with limited on board processing capabilities" - Martin.Lawrance@allenvanguard.com

Title: Density Measurements for Rectangular Free Jets Using Background Oriented Schlieren
AdditionalInformation: Invited paper of the Aeronautical Journal of the Royal Aeonautical Society (contact aerojournal@aerosociety.com) presents the first application of a novel (tomographic background-oriented schlieren) technique to rectangular jet flows, relevant to V/STOL jet aircraft applications. This paper shows, for the first time, the potential of this technique to give rapid assessment of complex three-dimensional jet spreading, potentially saving considerable test time and costs for applications needing this information.

Title: Force and Moment Measurements for a Generic Car Model in Proximity to a Side-Wall
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part D-Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research has resulted in an invitation to collaborate with the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Ljubljana, Slovenia on aerodynamic issues of motorway safety barriers.

Title: Effects of different needles and substrates on CuInS2 deposited by electrostatic spray deposition
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents results from a multi-disciplinary collaborative programme involving Cranfield University, University of Bath, Northumbria University and University of Luxembourg, aimed at developing improved photovoltaic devices. The work was supported by EPSRC under grant GR/S74171/01.

Title: Aerodynamic and performance characteristics of a passive leading edge Kruger flap at low Reynolds numbers
AdditionalInformation: Experimental test techniques, arising from research under an EU Framework Programme, were developed, with the aim of manipulating pre-separation boundary layers and wakes in order to increase lift and reduce drag.  These techniques were subsequently used in wind tunnel programmes, to reduce automotive vehicle aerodynamic drag and fuel consumption, for other organisations including TATA Motors (jeff.howell@tatamotors.com) .

Title: Hypersonic interference heating in the vicinity of surface protuberances
AdditionalInformation: This work is linked to experimental techniques involving thin film gauges, explored under a research programme funded by the Government of India, Defence Research and Development Laboratory, contract DRDL/33/96P/05/0750/31824.  The programme investigated aero-thermal effects on launch vehicles to improve prediction methods, particularly in relation to localised heating effects (and as a result structural integrity) caused by surface excrescences, at the free stream Mach numbers experienced during a typical trajectory to earth orbit. Contact Dr Panneerselvam Subramanian (hyd2_panneers@yahoo.co.in)

Title: The impact of inlet flow conditions on the aerodynamic performance of a NACA submerged intake for ground vehicle applications.
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part D-Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper arose from a TSB Funded Collaborative Project (Number S0059B/400030) on commercial vehicle aerodynamic drag reduction using active devices. Prior to this work, little was known about the aerodynamic performance of submerged intakes in the flow conditions typically experienced in automotive applications.  The semi-empirical prediction methods developed have been utilised in aerodynamic development programmes of passenger vehicles, contact Dr G M LeGood (geoff.legood@gl-aerodynamics.co.uk)

Title: Measurement of shock wave unsteadiness using a high-speed schlieren system and digital image processing
AdditionalInformation: The techniques outlined in this paper were adapted to support wind tunnel tests on an EPSRC funded collaborative project with Southampton, Cambridge and Manchester Metropolitan Universities: 'A Study of Practical Abatement Techniques for Exhaust Jets from Commercial Aircraft'. (EP/H002987/1).  This has led to a novel technique for vortex wake simulation, to more accurately simulate vortex dynamics and hence pollutant dispersion.

Title: Novel Uncertainty Propagation Method for Robust Aerodynamic Design
AdditionalInformation: Initial research results from an EC 6th FP, Integrated Project, enabling robust design, were carried forward into the €50M CRESCENDO Integrated Project, under EC FP7, grant agreement number 234344 (www.crescendo-fp7.eu, Philippe.Homsi@airbus.com). The method, which allows a more efficient computation of uncertainty, also led to a NASA-funded research project (http://nasa.orau.org/postdoc/about-fellows/fellows-2011.htm) on a probabilistic approach to the design and optimisation of Boundary Layer Ingesting Inlets for novel aircraft configurations.

Title: Worst-case robust design optimization under distributional assumptions
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This publication reports an output from research begun under an EC 6th FP Integrated Project and carried forward into the €50M CRESCENDO Integrated Project, under EC FP7, grant agreement number 234344 (www.crescendo-fp7.eu, Philippe.Homsi@airbus.com). The method, which expands the scope of robust optimization, also led to a NASA-funded research project (http://nasa.orau.org/postdoc/about-fellows/fellows-2011.htm), and has been integrated in a prototype tool, AirCADia, enabling model-based and set-based design. AirCADia is now employed in a TSB project, CONGA (Configuration Optimisation of Next Generation Aircraft, Ref: 101373, martin.aston@airbus.com; michael.moss@rolls-royce.com) and EC FP7-AAT-2013-RTD-1 TOICA (Sanjiv.Sharma@Airbus.com)

Title: Computational Workflow Management for Conceptual Design of Complex Systems
AdditionalInformation: This publication is an output of research initiated under an EC 6th FP Integrated Project. Insights gained into computational workflow management led to an evaluation and validation project, funded entirely by Airbus (€200,000, Ref: CREON, ME0523715, Yannick.Caillabet@airbus.com), and extended into the €50M CRESCENDO Integrated Project, under EC FP7 (grant No: 234344, www.crescendo-fp7.eu). As a result, the computational workflow method has been evolved and integrated into a prototype set-based design tool, AIRCADIA, now employed in a TSB project, CONGA (Configuration Optimisation of Next Generation Aircraft, Ref: 101373, martin.aston@airbus.com; michael.moss@rolls-royce.com) and EC FP7-AAT-2013-RTD-1 TOICA (PIERRE.ARBEZ@airbus.com).

Title: A method for generating a well-distributed Pareto set in nonlinear multiobjective optimization
VolumeTitle: Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics
AdditionalInformation: This research was first funded by an EC 6th FP, Integrated Project. The results were carried forward into a validation and evaluation project funded entirely by Airbus (€200,000, Ref: CREON, ME0523715, Yannick.Caillabet@airbus.com), and extended into the €50M CRESCENDO Integrated Project, under EC FP7 (grant No: 234344, www.crescendo-fp7.eu). Guenov was invited to present the results to KATnet II Multi Disciplinary Design and Configuration Optimisation Workshop 2008, DLR Braunschweig, Germany. [KATnet-II was the Thematic Network on Key Aerodynamic Technologies for Aircraft Performance Improvement and was funded by the European Commission, jlfulker@QinetiQ.com]

Title: Experimental Setup for the Study of Runback Ice at Full Scale
AdditionalInformation: The research provides data on imperfect ice protection on lifting surfaces, and represents a considerable expansion of the data available for this aspect (contact Nick Dart; Nicholas.Dart@aribus.com). The outputs have been used by Airbus to support engineering decision making to establish more accurate aerodynamic allowances for imperfect ice protection, which in turn provides greater consideration for energy saving operational modes. Contact Nick Dart; Nicholas.Dart@aribus.com.

Title: Heat and Mass Transfer for Ice Particle Ingestion Inside Aero-Engine
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This research has resulted in a newly reported analysis of ice particle ingestion into gas turbine engines. It forms part of a topical discussion into testing and acceptance criteria for ice crystal icing and mixed phas icien for aircraft engines and probes at a time when regulatory changes are being developed. Contact ldcang@ustc.edu.

Title: Multiple liquid impacts on polymeric matrix composites reinforced with carbon nanotubes
AdditionalInformation:
Collaboration under EC Framework 7 funding with subcontracting relationship with Cambridge University.

The research provides a preliminary assessment of the influence of nano particulate reinforcement in a range of industrial resins of potental application to aerospace. The specific area of wing leading edges makes the focus of this work unusual. The outputs include unique errosion damage threshold data and observations on wettability and ice adhesion essential to successful further development of such materials for wing leading edges Contact: cristina.elizetxea@tecnalia.com.

Title: Disposal orbits for GEO spacecraft: A method for evaluating the orbit height distributions resulting from implementing IADC guidelines
AdditionalInformation: This research assists International Standards Organisation Technical Committee 20, Sub-Committee 14 (contact John Davey, j.r.davey@btopenworld.com), which drafts standards for space debris mitigation.  (Dr Hobbs was project lead for ISO 22108, made significant inputs to ISO 23339 (fuel measurement), and contributed to four other standards) The research and standards preparation inform each other and develop in tandem.  The paper’s contribution is to make explicit uncertainties in disposal orbit prediction due to fuel measurement uncertainties.  The research is needed to quantify, and thus inform the management of, collision risks due to space debris in the geosynchronous region. Contact J Davey, as above.

Title: Research on compensation of motion, Earth curvature and tropospheric delay in GEOSAR
AdditionalInformation: This paper results from a continuing collaboration with Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics. Latest results presented at the IET International Radar Conference in Xi’an, China, April 2013, received the prize for best paper. This follow-on research, funded by the UK Centre for Earth Observation Instrumentation, improves our ability to measure the atmosphere and enhances geosynchronous radar (GEOSAR) feasibility (contact: Dr Sheng, shengwei@buaa.edu.cn).  Cranfield is starting work on a follow-on project with ESA funding (RFQ3-13800/13/NL/CT, €400k).

Title: Radar imaging from geosynchronous orbit:temporal decorrelation aspects
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
AdditionalInformation: This paper details the importance of atmospheric phase corrections in geosynchronous radar imaging and was the first recognition that solid Earth tides may need to be compensated / become observable.  It underpinned a Centre for Earth Observation Instrumentation Seedcorn study (£49.9k) and international collaborations (e.g. Politecnico di Milano - Prof. Rocca, rocca@elet.polimi.it, Beijing Institute of Technology - Prof Cheng Hu, cchchb@gmail.com). Studies are continuing in collaboration with ESA (Earth Explorer 8 follow-on) and China (Dr Hobbs participates in a 111 Projects Program for leading international scholars, with the Chinese Academy of Science and Technology, Prof  Zhang Qingjun, ztzhangqj@163.com).

Title: Database of individual wheat plant motion in wind: Application to radar imaging of vegetation
AdditionalInformation: This study typifies the Cranfield Space Engineering approach of using system engineering to identify mission drivers, and then studying specific topics to resolve mission risks. Radar clutter is one focus of current GEOSAR research for ESA (Prof Monti-Guarnieri, monti@elet.polimi.it).  The field videogrammetry developed has other applications including patient gait monitoring (LIRMM, CNRS, Montpellier, Dr Guiraud, david.guiraud@lirmm.fr).

Title: Space radiation analysis: Radiation effects and particle interaction outside the Earths magnetosphere using GRAS and GEANT4
AdditionalInformation: Methodologies related to the application of thin-walled/inflatable structures in high-radiation environments, developed under this Cranfield research project, informed subsequent work on the design for an inflatable, high-speed Lunar rover. Contacts: Jeffrey Hendrickse Jeffrey.Hendrikse@astrium.eads.net, Pedro Rodrigues pedro.rodrigues@tekever.com.

Title: 6U CubeSat commercial applications
AdditionalInformation: This research into cubesat technologies, system design, and applications has contributed to further small satellite work, including the European Commission-funded QB50  programme (a mission of 50 cubesats), to which Cranfield is contributing a cubesat. It also led to the organisation of an international 6U cubesat workshop in July 2012 at the Australian Centre for Space Engineering Research (http://www.acser.unsw.edu.au/events/cubesat.html). The concept has also received interest from a Russian start-up company founded by a former director of SSTL UK Dr. Wei Sun w.sun@dauria.ru

Title: 6U CubeSat design for Earth observation with 6.5m GSD, five spectral bands and 14Mbps downlink
AdditionalInformation:
This research contributed to the European Commission-funded QB50 programme (a mission of 50 cubesats), to which Cranfield is contributing a cubesat, and to the organisation of an international 6U cubesat workshop at the Australian Centre for Space Engineering Research (http://www.acser.unsw.edu.au/events/cubesat.html). The Earth observation application of small satellites also has significance for other current collaborative research. Together with Surrey Satellite Technology Ltd, (Stuart Eves s.eves@sstl.co.uk) we are investigating flying payloads at lower altitudes to increase imagery resolution.
This links to the payload being flown on Cranfield's QB50 cubesat, which will help characterise drag in low orbits.

Title: Challenges in transforming manufacturing organisations into product-service providers
AdditionalInformation: This paper was one of 4 chosen at the Emerald Group Awards for Excellence, across all papers submitted to this journal in 2011.  The research formed part of an EPSRC IMRC-funded, interdisciplinary project on Servitization. It examined ways for traditional product manufacturing companies to change their business model to sell the more profitable services; this informed related collaborative work with EADS Astrium. Astrium funded a research project on Servitization and Product-Service Systems in the space sector, and contributed to a further project investigating the design of Product-Service Systems. Nick Chesher Nicholas.CHESHER@astrium.eads.net

Title: Experimental investigation of some aspects of insect-like flapping flight aerodynamics for application to micro air vehicles
Insectlike Flapping Wings in the Hover Part 2: Effect of Wing Geometry
AdditionalInformation: Output from research supported by EPSRC Grant GR/M78472, providing the first published parametric assessment of flapping-wing design features. The research provided input to flapping-wing mechanism design under EPSRC grant EP/C535278 (£270k), allowing flight-weight mechanisms to be designed with accurate knowledge of wing loadings.

Title: The leading-edge vortex and aerodynamics of insect-based flapping-wing micro air vehicles
AdditionalInformation: The original findings in this paper on vortex stability and wing aspect ratio effects informed test cases subsequently adopted by the NATO working group AVT202 investigating fundamentals of flapping-wing aerodynamics (michael.ol@us.af.mil), and led to follow-on research on wing mechanism design (Phillips) and flight control (Stabler, Phillips – “Study into Flight Controller Development for Flapping Wing MAVS”, DSTL (via CDE), £120,000, 01.03.2011 – 04.08.2012, DSTLX-1000053780).

Title: Effect of flapping kinematics on the mean lift of an insect-like flapping wing
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation:
The research described in this paper won the following awards:
1. IMechE Western Aerospace Centre prize, April 2011 (Phillips, http://nearyou.imeche.org/near-you/UK/Western/Western-Aerospace-Centre/prize-history)
2. IMechE Kenneth Harris James Prize 2011
3. IMechE George Stephenson Gold Medal 2011. 
Results were obtained using a first-of-its-kind flapping-wing mechanism developed and patented by the authors (GB Patent 2464147).

Title: Effects of offtakes for aircraft secondary-power systems on jet engine efficiency
AdditionalInformation: The research describes how the extraction of secondary power affects the design and performance of propulsion systems. It allows manufacturers such as Boeing to model this effect especially in the case of future aircraft and engines. Contact Dr Peng Ho from The Boeing Company, Seattle, USA, peng.y.ho@boeing.com.

Title: Thermal cycle analysis of turboelectric distributed propulsion system with boundary layer ingestion
AdditionalInformation: The models developed, along with the findings reported in the paper show how the the performance of a distributed propulsion system can be modelled and confirms a reduction in fuel and noise (ruben.delrosario@nasa.gov).  They led to a NASA funded project (NNX13AI78G, $297k) to continue and expand research on Distributed Propulsion integrated with Blended Wing Body Aircraft configurations. Specifically, the models have been adopted in the decision-making process for further development by including a Techno-economic, environment and risk analysis (TERA). NASA Contact: Dr. Rubén Del Rosario , Manager, Fixed Wing Project Fundamental Aeronautics Program ruben.delrosario@nasa.gov

Title: Severity estimation and effect of operational parameters for civil aircraft jet engines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The method and findings of this research provide an  understanding of the estimation of engine severity (contact  Dr Peng Ho, peng.y.ho@boeing.com). Further interest in this paper from Lufthansa Technik has led to an invitation (Laskaridis and Singh) to their headquarters to present and discuss the findings and to a Lufthansa-funded research program investigating the prediction of engine severity (Lufthansa contact, Dr Christian Werner Spatz christian.werner-spatz@lht.dlh.de).

Title: A calculation tool of a turbine cooling air schedule for general gas turbine simulation algorithms
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: The research allows for the calculation of variable turbine cooling flow and the effect it can have on the life of the engine. The paper was highlighted by the ASME Journal of Turbomachinery as being within its 10 most downloaded articles for 9 months, (9/11 - 04/12, http://asmedl.org/journals/doc/ASMEDL-home/most_downloaded.jsp?KEY=JOTUEI&Year=2012&Month=4&agg=md). The findings led to a 4 year follow-on research programme sponsored by Boeing ($150k). Contact Dr Peng Ho from The Boeing Company, Seattle, USA, peng.y.ho@boeing.com.

Title: The evolving landscape of Chinese aviation policies and impact of a deregulating environment on Chinese carriers
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the recent developments of China's aviation polices and their impacts on the industry structure and the performance of major airlines.  Given the policy relevance of this research, it is used as teaching material in a biannual training workshop for the prestigious CAAC (Civil Aviation Administration of China) Senior Executive Development programme organised by Rolls Royce (2011 – present) (Contact: Tony Atherton - anthony.atherton@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Measuring the effect of low-cost carriers on regional airports' commercial revenue
AdditionalInformation: Core data used in this research was provided by the UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).  This paper was first presented as an invited lecture at the CAA's internal research seminar.  The research finds that although low-cost carriers have significant impact on airports' commerical revenue, their contribution is much smaller compared to other carriers.  The findings have important policy implications for aviation strategy at the regional level and beyond.  (contact: Dr Charles Ng - charles.ng@caa.co.uk)

Title: The impact of airline differentiation on marginal cost pricing at UK airports
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Part A-Policy and Practice
AdditionalInformation: The results of this research were presented to the UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in April 2012.  The study provides empirical evidence in support of increased differentiation in airport charges on the basis of marginal passenger costs being sensitive to the type of airline, i.e. full-service, low-cost, and charter.  This research was well received by policymakers in the UK CAA and it provides a useful guide for optimal pricing of aeronautical infrastructure under either single- or dual-till regulations.  (contact: Dr Charles Ng - charles.ng@caa.co.uk)

Title: Will China's airline industry survive the entry of high-speed rail?
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the result of a joint international collaborative project funded by the Hong Kong Research Grant Council (RGC) (PolyU 5419/08E).  The study examined the relative competitive advantages of high speed rail, as opposed to air services, with policy implications for market competition.  Dr Zheng Lei was invited to present research results to senior managers at Hainan Airlines (May 2012). The research findings inspired Hainan Airlines to set up a low-cost subsidiary to compete with China’s high speed rail in the domestic market (contact: Mr Liu Peng - liupeng@hnair.com)

Title: Nonlinear Multiple Points Gas Turbine Off-Design Performance Adaptation Using a Genetic Algorithm
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: The research described in this paper was initially presented at the ASME Turbo Expo 2010 conference, where it won Best Paper Award in the Cycle Innovations Committee for that year. The developed new method was part of the delivery of the collaboration with China Powerplant Research Institute (CAPI) of Aviation Corporation Industry of China (AVIC) and is used by CAPI as part of their helicopter engine diagnostic system. CAPI Contact Mr Weimin Liu, 608.capi@163.com.

Title: Measurement Selections for Multicomponent Gas Path Diagnostics Using Analytical Approach and Measurement Subset Concept
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This research contributed to one of the key technical issues in gas turbine diagnostics in industrial applications (Mike.Newby@mea.gov.im). Combined with other contributions of the same authors, it led to continous collaboration with Manx Electricity Authority (MEA) on a diagnostics and lifing project from 2013-2016. MEA Contact: Mike Newby, Mike.Newby@mea.gov.im

Title: Improved Multiple Point Non-Linear Genetic Algorithm Based Performance Adaptation Using Least Square Method
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: The research a collaboration with China Powerplant Research Institute (CAPI) and was used by CAPI in their diagnostic systems for helicopter engines (CAPI Contact Mr Weimin Liu, 608.capi@163.com). The developed method was also applied to gas turbine diagnostics by the Manx Electricity Authority and used by MEA for their gas turbine diagnostic analysis (MEA Contact: Mike Newby, Mike.Newby@mea.gov.im).

Title: Gas Turbine Performance and Health Status Estimation Using Adaptive Gas Path Analysis
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: The method was adopted in follow-on projects sponsored by the Manx Electricity Authority with total value of £28k to apply gas turbine diagnostics to gas turbines run by MEA (“Gas turbine health monitoring”, “Gas turbine simulation work in support of hot section life extension” and “Site application of gas turbine gas path diagnostics in MEA”). The new diagnostic system has been used by MEA for their gas turbine diagnostic analysis. MEA Contact: Mike Newby, Mike.Newby@mea.gov.im

Title: Experimental investigation of intake ground vortices during takeoff
AdditionalInformation: This is the first of two complementary outputs arising from collaborative research funded by Rolls Royce and an EPSRC Industrial CASE award (Voucher 05000203). The research provides the first quantitative flowfield measurements and assessment of the effect of take-off conditions on intake ground vortices (Richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com). Its outcomes have directly informed engine development programmes, helped solve engine issues, reduced the risk on current and future engines and informed commercial negotiating positions [Richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com]. The research has led to further co-operation with the Rolls Royce Installations Group which has culminated in the UK Centre for Aerodynamics NADIT Programme (TSB101368 Cranfield value £224k).

Title: Ground vortex aerodynamics under crosswind conditions
AdditionalInformation: This is the second of two complementary outputs arising from collaborative research funded by Rolls Royce and an EPSRC Industrial Case award (Voucher 05000203). The research provides the first quantitative measurement of the three component velocity field and associated key characteristics of intake ground vortices [Richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com]. Its outcomes have directly informed engine development programmes, helped solve engine issues, reduced the risk on current and future engines and informed commercial negotiating positions [Richard.tunstall@rolls-royce.com]. The research has led to further co-operation with the Rolls Royce Installations Group which has culminated in the UK Centre for Aerodynamics NADIT Programme (TSB101368 Cranfield value £224k).

Title: Computational and experimental investigation into aerodynamic interference between slender bodies in supersonic flow
AdditionalInformation: This is the first of two complementary outputs for research in collaboration with the UK MoD (Defence Science and Technology Laboratory) and the Franco-German Institute St. Louis, France, funded by DSTL and EPSRC (GR/T18424). The research quantified the ability of computational methods to calculate the effects of supersonic aerodynamic interference for multi-body configurations. The results nurtured research activities in high-speed aerodynamics which has led to subsequent funding from the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research (EOARD/FA8655-11-1-3025 $63,600) along with invited access and use of a key facility in the US (Contact: Principal Scientist, DSTL, email available on request).

Title: Experimental investigation into the interference aerodynamics of two slender bodies in close proximity
AdditionalInformation: This is the second of two complementary outputs for research in collaboration with the UK MoD (Defence Science and Technology Laboratory) and the Franco-German Institute St. Louis, France, funded by DSTL and EPSRC (GR/T18424). The research revealed the detailed aerodynamics and possible trajectory changes due to supersonic aerodynamic interference on multi-body configurations. The results have nurtured research activities in high-speed aerodynamics which has led to subsequent funding from the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research (EOARD/FA8655-11-1-3025 $63,600) along with invited access and use of a key facility in the US (Contact: Principal Scientist, DSTL, email available on request).

Title: Towards a means of consistently comparing airline business models and an application to the Low Cost Airline sector
AdditionalInformation: An output from a collaboration with Wilfred Laurier University and University of British Columbia Contact: Prof David Gillen David.Gillen@suader.ubc.ca.  The capability of this work to predict which parts of a business model lead to increased profitability has attracted follow-on funding from Embraer (dany.oliveira@embraer.com.br), and GDS company Amadeus (bfiedler@amadeus.com).

Title: The impact of emigrants' homeland relations on air travel demand in a security volatile market: a case study on Lebanon
AdditionalInformation: This is an output from one of two research projects at Cranfield funded by the ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organisation), who are interested in the results as an illustration of how governance structures and national regulatory frameworks impact the success of the aviation markets. (contact at IACO, Assad Kotiate, icaohq@icao.int).

Title: Mergers and Acquisitions in the EU low cost carrier market. A Product and Organisation Architecture (POA) approach to identify potential merger partners.
AdditionalInformation: This paper applies the model developed in Mason output 1, to assess the similarity of business models between airlines, as merger success depends on business model similarity. The Chief Economist of the International Air Transport Association, Dr Brian Pearce (PearceB@iata.org), has examined the work and considers it potentially useful for systematically evaluating future mergers. (Contact Dr Brian Pearce, PearceB@iata.org).

Title: Similarity measures for mid-surface quality evaluation
AdditionalInformation: Research to develop a novel CAD feature recognition approach for thin walled parts.  The research led to a collaboration with Transcendata, a UK company that develops CAD/ CAE interoperability software, to investigate feature recognition capabilities for their interoperability software CADFix and allow automatic recognition of geometric features on imported CAD models, facilitating de-featuring for finite element analysis. (Dr Geoff Butlin, CEO TranscenData Europe Ltd.  gab@transcendata.com)

Title: Fabrication of geometrical features using wire and arc additive manufacture
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B-Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: An EPSRC/ Cranfield IMRC funded project (EP/E001874/1), investigating design requirements for Wire and Arc Additive Manufactured parts. A demonstrated need to redesign parts, to realise the benefits of this novel process, led to industrially-funded design studies for the Aircraft Research Association and Bombardier Aerospace, and to Cranfield participation in the £1.5 Million industry-funded WAAMMat (Technology Maturation of Wire + Arc Additive Manufacture ) research programme. Industrial partners include BAE SYSTEMS, Lockheed Martin and Air Products.  Contacts: R Porter, ARA, rporter@ara.co.uk; Ken Poston, Bombardier Aerospace (ken.poston@aero.bombardier.com) and Jonathan Meyer at EADS Innovation works (Jonathan.Meyer@eads.com).

Title: Product service systems and supply network relationships: An exploratory case study
AdditionalInformation: This research was the first stage of a suite of inter-disciplinary EPSRC/ Cranfield IMRC funded research projects in Product Service Systems (EPSRC Grant EP/E001874/1, project 130) and was a collaboration between three Cranfield’s Schools: School of Engineering, School of Applied Sciences and School of Management.  The methodology developed following this research was undertaken in partnership with Rockwell Automation, and has subsequently been applied by Rockwell with their customers to steer their growth and performance strategy for maintenance services.  (Contact:  Mr Mark Crawford (Manager UK & Ireland Customer Support and Maintenance, mcrawford@ra.rockwell.com)

Title: Stabilisability and detectability in networked control
AdditionalInformation: This work was carried out under a project funded by Jaguar Land Rover (Dr Phil Barber: pbarber2@jaguarlandrover.com).  This is the first time that least- restrictive sufficient conditions, for the stabilisability of a process under certain communication sequences, has been mathematically proven, allowing determination, a priori, of whether certain communication policies can destabilize a system. The results appear in the book "Optimal and robust scheduling for networked control systems" by Longo, Su, Herrmann and Barber published by Taylor & Francis in 2013.

Title: The effects of hydrogen substitution on turbulent premixed methane-air kernels using direct numerical simulation
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents results of Direct Numerical Simulations using the code SENGA 2, developed by  Dr K Jenkins (Cranfield) and Prof Cant (Cambridge) (stewart.cant@eng.cam.ac.uk). The work was carried out with a large collaborative consortium formed from 6 Universities (Cambridge, Cranfield, Imperial, Leeds, Southampton and Manchester) under EPSRC grant number EP/D076773/1.  The code is widely used at Cranfield, and by Prof Cant (Cambridge), Dr Prosser (Manchester, robert.prosser@manchester.ac.uk)) Prof Chakraborty (Newcastle, nilanjan.chakraborty@ncl.ac.uk) and Prof Emerson (Daresbury labs, david.emerson@stfc.ac.uk), and is part of a new 5 year UK reacting turbulent flow consortium  (EPSRC grant number EP/K025104/1).

Title: Flame surface density distribution in turbulent flame kernels during the early stages of growth
AdditionalInformation: The work used a numerical code developed at Cranfield in collaboration with Cambridge University (Prof Cant, stewart.cant@eng.cam.ac.uk) and Daresbury Laboratories (Prof D Emerson, david.emerson@stfc.ac.uk). The code SENGA is now used in Australia (Prof E Hawkes, evatt.hawkes@unsw.edu.au), USA (Prof J Chen, jhchen@sandia.gov) and Canada (prof S Tullis, stullis@mcmaster.ca), and provides one of 3 UK codes nationally recognised by Daresbury laboratories for work in chemically reacting flows. It has been selected to bench mark the new national supercomputer ARCHER (Prof D Emerson, david.emerson@stfc.ac.uk)

Title: Modelling of instabilities in turbulent swirling flames
AdditionalInformation:
This paper results from a collaboration between Cranfield and Leeds universities under EPSRC grant EP/E036945/1. 
The computational code for LES, which will offer industrial and academic users of LES an improved sub-grid scale modelling technique, was initially developed in the framework of an international collaboration with Prof  Kirkpatrick at the University of Sydney (michael.kirkpatrick@sydney.edu.au) and Dr Ranga Dinesh (dinesh.kahanda-koralage@soton.ac.uk) at Southampton University.

Title: Investigation of the influence of swirl on a confined coannular swirl jet
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the result of an international collaboration between Cranfield University and Melbourne University.  The work and computational developments led to further collaborative publications, and will be progressed under a 5-year EPSRC fellowship awarded to Dr Ranga Dinesh, to be held at Southampton University.

Title: An automated timeline reconstruction approach for digital forensic investigations
AdditionalInformation: This research presents a new technique for generating summaries of activity on hard disks obtained during criminal or civil investigation. This timeline reconstruction was co-funded by EPSRC  (EP/H023135, total £2.2M) in collaboration with 8 other partners. Outputs have been adopted in our MSc in Forensic Computing and enabled additional publications, including Hargreaves (2013): Visualisation of unallocated blocks in block based files. A further output is a prototype tool to demonstrate the technique (PyDFT) which has been transferred to several law enforcement agencies around the world, and is scheduled for  release as an open source project in 2014.

Title: Using a software exploit to image RAM on an embedded system
AdditionalInformation: This research developed forensic computing techniques to establish the amount of copyright material in the memory of an Xbox. The results demonstrated that material from the game is indeed recoverable from the memory of the games console. The techniques have been applied to a legal case that was featured in New Scientist (issue 2749) as “Legal team hack Xbox memory for defence evidence” -  http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20527495.500-legal-team-hack-xbox-memory-for-defence-evidence.html

Title: Forensic data recovery from the Windows Search Database
AdditionalInformation: This work allows the potential recovery of deleted data from the Windows Search database stored on hard disks obtained during digital investigations. The broad international impact of this work is evident from the resulting requests for information, help or tooling and tooling, which include law enforcement and commercial forensic analysts (confidential details available on request), and also forensic educators (e.g. Canadian Police College, Research Council of Italy).

Title: Windows Vista and digital investigations
AdditionalInformation: This research provided the first analysis of the forensically significant changes to the Microsoft Windows operating system when Vista was introduced. The significant aspects of this work included identifying deficiencies in mainstream digital forensic tools at the time, including techniques that offer significant opportunity for recovery of evidence that suspects believe is deleted, and techniques that can be used to gain access to data encrypted via Bitlocker.

Title: A neural network model to minimise the connected dominating set for self-configuration of wireless sensor networks
AdditionalInformation: This was an international collaboration with the University of Tampere, Finland (Prof. Erkki  Mäkinen, School of Information Sciences, erkki.makinen@uta.fi),  in artificial intelligence (AI) applications for wireless sensor networks.

Title: Linguistic Decision Making for Robot Route Learning
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transaction on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
AdditionalInformation: Supported by a Leverhulme Trust grant F00430F, this work demonstrated the Linguistic Decision Tree (LDT) method for a Robot Route Learning Problem.

Title: Energy Awareness Workflow Model for Wireless Sensor Nodes
AdditionalInformation: A collaboration with the University Of Manchester (Dr S Olutunde Oyadiji, s.o.oyadiji@manchester.ac.uk) investigating a comprehensive model to describe the workflow of a wireless sensor node.

Title: Robot control code generation by task demonstration in a dynamic environment
AdditionalInformation: Supported by a Leverhulme Trust grant F00430F, this work investigated automatic control code generation of dynamic tasks in specific environments in order to overcome the challenge of the complex interaction between a robot and the environment.

Title: Large eddy simulation using high-resolution and high-order methods
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A-Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation:
This research was funded via EPSRC (EP/C515153, EP/D053994), MoD and AWE (JGS no. 971) and EPSRC, BAE SYSTEMS and MoD through the Defence Aerospace Research Partnership consortium ‘Modelling and Simulation of Turbulence and Transition for Aerospace’.
 The research allows large eddy simulations to be accurately applied to complex turbulent flows. This resulted in an invited talk (Drikakis) at the Royal Society (Applied Large Eddy Simulation Symposium, http://royalsociety.org/Applied-Large-Eddy-Simulation). It has been used by AWE in validating computational methods used in compressible turbulent mixing simulation (Prof David Youngs: david.youngs@awe.co.uk)

Title: Richtmyer-Meshkov turbulent mixing arising from an inclined material interface with realistic surface perturbations and reshocked flow
AdditionalInformation: This research was supported by AWE Plc in the framework of Professor Drikakis's William Penney Fellow Award. It yielded quantification of the effects of initial conditions on compressible turbulent mixing of multi-component flows featuring Richtmyer-Meshkov instability. The results are in use at AWE to further validate their models for compressible turbulent mixing associated with inertial confinement fusion devices, where advanced and accurate modelling is required under the comprehensive test ban treaty (Prof David Youngs: david.youngs@awe.co.uk, Dr Robin JR Williams, Robin.Williams@awe.co.uk)

Title: On entropy generation and dissipation of kinetic energy in high-resolution shock-capturing schemes
AdditionalInformation: Algorithms developed here are now employed in CFD codes in the German Aerospace Agency DLR (heinrich.luedeke@dlr.de), Pennsylvania State University (houim@lcp.nrl.navy.mil), the French Commissariat a l’Energie Atomique (jerome.griffond@cea.fr) and AWE (Toby.Harris@awe.co.uk) for flows ranging from nuclear hydraulics through to scramjets. This work was funded by the EPSRC, MoD and AWE (EP/C515153-JGS no. 971, EP/D053994) (david.youngs@awe.co.uk) as well as two AWE Industrial PhD Case awards with Prof Drikakis as PI. Ongoing research projects using this new algorithm include an industrial DTA with AWE (Robin.Williams@awe.co.uk), TSB projects 130772 and 10173-53479 with Reaction Engines Ltd (Helen.Webber@reactionengines.co.uk) and TSB project 10173-53479 with AMPAC Ltd (ICoxhill@ampacisp.eu).

Title: The influence of initial conditions on turbulent mixing due to Richtmyer-Meshkov instability
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by the EPSRC, MoD (EP/C515153-JGS no. 971 and EP/D053994) and AWE (Prof David Youngs: david.youngs@awe.co.uk). It led to an invited presentation at a special session on compressible turbulent mixing at the AIAA Theoretical Fluid Mechanics in 2011 (Session organiser Dr. Ye Zhou: zhou3@llnl.gov). This work gained recognition with Thornber being awarded the ERCOFTAC Osborne Reynolds Research Student Prize (ERCOFTAC Co-ordinator Dr David Standingford: david.standingford@zenotech.com). It has also led to further industrial contracts from AWE Plc (Prof David Youngs: david.youngs@awe.co.uk, Dr. Robin Williams: Robin.Williams@awe.co.uk).

Title: The new frequency response functions for structural health monitoring
AdditionalInformation: Output from collaboration funded by Shell. Novel frequency response functions led to an improvement of damage diagnosis in structures and turbines. Implementation of the techniques for Shell gas turbine blades has enabled Shell to maintain its world-leading edge in turbine maintenance, through decreased costs and improved reliability (market share of 10% envisaged, with annual sales of 2500 monitoring systems) (Mr. Innes, Shell, ken.innes@shell.com). This technology, providing in-service early differential diagnosis of turbine fatigue damage, will be further developed  under a European project PileInspect: grant agreement number 605676.

Title: Optimal filtering of gear signals for early damage detection based on the spectral kurtosis
AdditionalInformation:
Output from a collaboration with ERIKS (UK), Severn Trent Water and Compact Orbital Gears, within a DTI (UK) project Sustain: grant STI 6-037. The proposed technology, with early in-service automatic differential damage diagnosis capability, was further funded by SKF (UK) and experimentally validated for bearings:  Project reference 023925, (Dr. Murray, brian.murray@skf.com). Implementation of this technology has enabled Sustain partners and SKF to maintain a world-leading edge in maintenance (market share of 8% envisaged with annual sale of 2000 monitoring systems).  (Contact: Mr. Ohren, David.Manning-Ohren@eriks.co.uk)
Further development will be funded by European project IndGear: grant agreement number 605834.

Title: Novel detection of local tooth damage in gears by the wavelet bicoherence
AdditionalInformation:
Output from a collaboration with ERIKS (UK), Severn Trent Water and Compact Orbital Gears, within a DTI (UK) project Sustain: grant code STI 6-037. The technology offers early in-service automatic differential damage diagnosis. Further development and experimental validatation for bearings took place under SKF project 023925, (Dr. Murray, brian.murray@skf.com). Implementation has enabled Sustain partners and SKF to maintain a world leading edge in maintenance (market share of 8% envisaged with annual sales of 2000 monitoring systems). (Mr. Ohren, David.Manning-Ohren@eriks.co.uk). 
Development continues under European projects IndGear: EC grant agreement number 605834 and PileInspect: EC grant agreement number 605676.

Title: Novel adaptation of the demodulation technology for gear damage detection to variable amplitudes of mesh harmonics
AdditionalInformation:
This technology won the “William Smith Prize 2009”,  Aerospace Industries Division of IMechE. It is an output from a DTI (UK) project Sustain: grant code STI 6-037, with ERIKS (UK), Severn Trent Water and Compact Orbital Gears. The technology offers early in-service automatic differential damage diagnosis. It was further developed and experimentally validated within a Rolls-Royce project: reference 5000393909. Implementation for Sustain partners and Rolls-Royce has enabled these companies to maintain a world-leading edge in gearbox maintenance (market share of 12% envisaged with annual sales of 3000 monitoring systems).  (Mr. Ohren, David.Manning-Ohren@eriks.co.uk, Mr. Slater, robert.slater@rolls-royce.com)
.

Title: CFD modelling of the fast pyrolysis of biomass in fluidised bed reactors. Part B. Heat, momentum and mass transport in bubbling fluidised beds
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by EPSRC in collaboration with Biffa Group Ltd. The CFD modelling results and methodology contributed to development of better thermal conversion processes for production of high value fuel and chemical products from industrial waste streams (Contact Chris.Parry@biffa.co.uk). The first author received the UK Scopus Young Researcher Engineering Award (2011). Furthermore, the computational models led to an EPSRC grant (EP/G034281 £426,844): Scale-up modelling to address the"Pyrolysis Challenge". South Africa has the largest production of coal to transport fuel facilities in the world, with potential to be the major biofuel producer. Contact at University of Stellenbosch: jgorgens@sun.ac.za.

Title: Effects of limestone calcination on the gasification processes in a BFB coal gasifier
AdditionalInformation: This paper received The Felix Weinberg Prize, Institute of Physics, 2011 for its novel contributions to the numerical implementation of  chemical reactions in complex multiphase flows. The results have been adopted to develop carbon capture methods in a follow-on EPSRC project: Computational Modelling and Optimisation of Carbon Capture Reactors (EP/J020184) in collaboration with E.ON. (Contact Dr Robin Irons.  Robin.Irons@eon.com).

Title: Modelling of impingement phenomena for molten metallic droplets with low to high velocities
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation:
A series of models was developed and used for developing new coating products in partnership with Monitor Coating Ltd. This project has increased the technical capacity of the company and allowed them to develop new products more efficiently by reducing time-consuming experiments.  Contact: Dr Bryan Allcock, b.allcock@monitor.
Further outputs include an EU FP7 project, SIMUSPRAY: Computational Simulation to Enhance Technology Development of Thermal Spray Coating (230715) in collaboration with Pyrogenesis SA (Dr Michalis Vardavoulias mvardavoulias@pyrogenesis-sa.gr). The results of this project further led to EU FP7 project, IPACTS: International Partnership for Advanced Coatings by Thermal Spraying (268696, €700k, Coordinator – Gu).

Title: Study of wall-to-bed heat transfer in a bubbling fluidised bed using the kinetic theory of granular flow
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation:
We have developed advanced CFD models for fluidised bed reactors. The models were trialled by E.ON, who were able to evaluate pilot plants at the design stage for different feedstock and optimize size of reactors required (Contact Dr Robin Irons.  Robin.Irons@eon.com). 
The results also led to the EU FP7 project, iComFluid: International Collaboration on Computational Modelling of Fluidised Bed Systems for Clean Energy Technologies (312261).

Title: Local self-optimizing control with average loss minimization
AdditionalInformation: A new criterion, average loss (instead of the traditional use of worst case loss) is proposed and solved for self-optimizing control, showing that design based on the new criterion is super-optimal. The theory and design approach led to a TSB research project (TP/5/OIL/6/I/H0366E) including Chevron (Joe.Shen@ com), E&H (wolfgang.drahm@flowtec.endress.com) and DeFlow (David.Whittingham@Neftemer.com). Outputs also include a patent on Inferential Slug Control (US8489244, granted). The method has been widely adopted by the process control community (e.g. Prof S Skogestad, skoge@ntnu.no, Dr ACB Araujo, antonio@dep.ufcg.edu.br, 6 papers in the session on Plantwide Control, UKACC Control Conference 2012).

Title: Nonlinear system identification for predictive control using continuous time recurrent neural networks and automatic differentiation.
AdditionalInformation: This research formulated a new algorithm to develop Differential Recurrent Neural Networks as a general modelling tool. This ensures that models are independent of sampling time, unlike traditional approaches. The results led to an international collaboration with National University of Singapore (Prof. GP Rangaiah gprangaiah@nus.edu.sg) and Curtin University of Technology, Australia (Moses Tade M.O.Tade@curtin.edu.au) to apply this approach to an industrial evaporation process.
