The work was published in Control Engineering Practice, 18(12) 1418—1428. A second output was a collaboration with the Royal Veterinary College (BBSRC grant BBC5189221) (contact Theo Demmers, tdemmers@rvc.ac.uk)

Title: Bidirectional branch and bound for controlled variable selection: Part I. Principles and minimum singular value criterion.
AdditionalInformation: The software tool developed in this research has been made publicly accessible through Mathworks File Exchange  and gained a 5* rating from users (see http://www.mathworks.co.uk/matlabcentral/fileexchange/25870). It led to a patented innovation (GB2468973 - granted in 2011) for Inferential Slug Control (ISC). The technique was adopted by Dong Energy in a real field trial of the ISC conducted in a North Sea oil field. The trial successfully demonstrated that the ISC increased oil production by 9.6% (Martin Olldag Bay MAOBA@dongenergy.dk). The ISC solution was awarded the East England Energy Group (EEEgr) Innovation Award in 2010.

Title: State-space independent component analysis for nonlinear dynamic process monitoring
AdditionalInformation: The work proposed a novel approach that allows both dynamic and nonlinear behaviour of process operations to be efficiently monitored. This work led to a collaboration with Nayan Technological University, Singapore (Vinay Kumar Kariwala Vinay@ntu.edu.sg and Tao Chen, tc.tao.chen@gmail.com) published in Journal of Process Control, 20(10) 1198—1206, 2010, supported by the Royal Society (grant IV0871568). It also led to an EU FP7 project (ref 264940, Total €3.3M) on energy savings from smart operation of electrical, process and mechanical equipment  including Imperial College London (n.thornhill@imperial.ac.uk), ABB Germany (guido.sand@de.abb.com), BASF (matteo.cicciotti@basf.com), ETH Zurich (mariethoz@control.ee.ethz.ch), and Politechnika Krakowska (pesulowi@cyf-kr.edu.pl).

Title: A CFD parametric study of geometrical variations on the pressure pulsations and performance characteristics of a centrifugal pump.
AdditionalInformation: The relationship between the  generation of pressure pulsations in centrifugal pumps and a limited range of design parameters has been, until now, typically investigated through testing. This research enabled the extension of the number of parameters varied to a number of combinations that is too costly to investigate through experimental means. The output of this work enables engineers at Clyde Union, a large British pump manufacturer, to make use of parametric design combinations that have been demonstrated by this study to contribute to minimise damaging pressure pulsations while maintaining high hydraulic efficiencies. (Contact b.millward@clydeunion.com)

Title: Investigation into pressure pulsations in a centrifugal pump using numerical methods supported by industrial tests
AdditionalInformation: This research provided the engineers of Weir Pumps, now Clyde Union, an improved insight into the design parameters and associated flow physics that lead to the occurrence of large pressure pulsations in pumps leading to impeller blade fatigue failures (a.bhatia@clydeunion.com). The understanding of the way pressure pulsations develop in complex hydraulic systems which include bulk and leakage path flows is important in terms of helping reduce very costly fatigue failure events. Specific outputs of the research included detailed pump design guidelines as well as guidance for conducting test campaigns. (Contact a.bhatia@clydeunion.com)

Title: Mechanical seal failure analysis
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the first reported application of the Weibayes method to the statistical treatment of a limited data set of failures in mechanical face seals. This new methodology is now employed by AESSEAL, a UK seal manufacturer, in their product design process, leading to reduced seal failures of the products in use. (Contact Joel.Ojile@aesseal.co.uk).

Title: Parametric study of injection angle effects on stability of transonic axial compressors
AdditionalInformation: This research provided  insight into mechanisms of transonic axial compressor stability enhancement through case injection and examined the potential for performance improvement at off-design operation regimes. This research has led to the demonstration of cost-effective methodologies that help to reduce the performance degradation under near-stall conditions in transonic compressors. The case injection concept has attracted interest in the high speed turbomachinery sector being adopted in research papers of leading aerospace companies, GE Global Research and GE Aviation, United States.

Title: Robust cooperative visual localization with experimental validation for unmanned aerial vehicles
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first development of Cooperative Visual Simultaneous Localisation and Mapping for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles in the UK. The research was completed under the FP7 Marie Curie International Research Staff Exchange Scheme (Ref:FP7-PEOPLE-IRSES-2008-230797) with collaborators Polytechnic University Polytechnic Madrid and The Australian Research Centre for Aerospace Automation (ARCAA). The results were adopted in a follow-on collaboration via International Cooperation Program for Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Research and Development. They led to further publications using real airborne platform data collected by our collaborators. Contact Prof Pascual Campoy, Universidad Politécnica Madrid, pascual.campoy@upm.es.

Title: Experimental airborne NH infinity vision-based simultaneous localization and mapping in unknown environments
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper results from an international research collaboration with University Polytechnic Madrid, Spain. It presented the first real scenario solution of 3D Visual Simultaneous Localisation and Mapping for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles. This led to further development via an International Cooperation Program for Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Research and Development  including a European FP7 Marie Curie project (Ref:FP7-PEOPLE-IRSES-2008-230797) with partners Polytechnic University Polytechnic Madrid and The Australian Research Centre for Aerospace Automation (ARCAA). Contact Prof Pascual Campoy, Universidad Politécnica Madrid, pascual.campoy@upm.es.

Title: Recursive estimation of three-dimensional unmanned aerial vehicle motion and structure based on the L-infinity-norm
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper solves the problem of motion and structure of moving Unmanned Aerial Vehicle platforms in three dimensions without recourse to the most common tool of aircraft navigation, Inertial Navigation Systems. This advance led to the article being highlighted in a list of most read and most cited articles (online) of the Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering, (list published 27th January 2012, sagenews@updates.sagepub.co.uk).

Title: Particle swarm optimization inspired probability algorithm for optimal camera network placement
AdditionalInformation: International Collaboration between Cranfield University and Ministry of Defence (MOD) Algeria, this research solves the problem of automatic deployment of camera networks in dedicated infrastructures to give better coverage, detection and tracking. The solution has been used by General Dynamics, UK to validate the efficiency of the solution in the typical scenario of an international project requiring networked camera placement. Contact: Mr Philip Tudor, formerly SEM - Technology, philip.tudor@multispectral.co.uk.

Title: Turbulence-flame interactions in lean premixed hydrogen: Transition to the distributed burning regime
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents a body of research (including Aspden et al, Astrophys. J. 689, 2008; Astrophys. J. 710, 2010; Proc. Combust. Inst. 33 2011b) to develop understanding of the response of premixed flames to the intense turbulence expected, for example, in gas turbines used for transport and power generation. This research provides evidence contradicting convention wisdom that suggests such flames extinguish under certain conditons (Peters 2000, Cambridge University Press). A conclusion of the paper is that operating in this regime has potential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by reducing the peak operating temperature.

Title: Boundary slip dependency on surface stiffness
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output of the EU FP6 DINAMICS collaborative research project (NMP4-CT-2007-026804) co-ordinated by Lambda GmbH (Dr. Christian Mittermayr (Mittermayr@lambda.at), which concerned the development of DNA-based sensors for bioagent detection in water supply.The results of this paper enabled the development and manufacturing of the nanofluidic chamber as a sensor for detecting bio-hazards. Lambda GmbH have now adopted this and developed it through to the manufactured prototyope stage (Dr. Christian Mittermayr (Mittermayr@lambda.at).

Title: Wall-mass effects on hydrodynamic boundary slip
AdditionalInformation: As above, this paper is an output of the EU FP6 DINAMICS project (NMP4-CT-2007-026804) co-ordinated by Lambda GmbH (Dr. Christian Mittermayr (Mittermayr@lambda.at), which concerned the development of DNA-based sensors for bioagent detection in water supply. The results of this work led to an understanding of the effects of hydrodynamic slip inside the microfluidic-based sensor device in order to improve its flow properties. As mentioned above, the device has been adopted by Lambda GmbH who have developed it through to the manufactured prototyope stage (Dr. Christian Mittermayr (Mittermayr@lambda.at).

Title: Enhanced carbon dioxide adsorption through carbon nanoscrolls
AdditionalInformation: This research concerned a novel carbon nanostructure, the nanoscroll. The results showed that the nanoscroll can be used as a new baseline material for carbon dioxide filters with improved efficiency and 10 times higher flux rates compared to the current state of the art (contact Dr Alessio Alexiadis, a.alexiadis@bham.ac.uk). This led to a patent “Gas filter with chamber comprising carbon nanotubes for filtering CO2” (UK Patent 2479257 published 12-6-2013) with application in the automotive industry.

Title: Filtering carbon dioxide through carbon nanotubes
AdditionalInformation: The paper demonstrates the applicability of carbon nanotubes for carbon capture. The research described here also underpinned the a patent  “Gas filter with chamber comprising carbon nanotubes for filtering CO2” (UK Patent 2479257 published 12-6-2013).

Title: Adaptive mesh refinement for two-phase slug flows with an a priori indicator
AdditionalInformation: Shows adaptive methods to accurately predict slug flow, even when partially ill-conditioned. Has led to expert reviewer invitations for the PETROMAKS2 project (Norwegian Research Council); a nomination to the Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE) Distinguished Lecturer programme (30 experts appointed annually, worldwide), and industrial grant income of over £1M (Dr Lloyd Brown, recently ConocoPhillips, Lbrown@scideep.com). A study is being supported by SPT Group, who develop and sell the industry standard pipeline tool, to incorporate the technology  (gunnar.staff@sptgroup.com).   This technology is allowing further investigation of multi-phase flow instability, which is of great engineering importance. (hjsubramani@chevron.com).

Title: Non-Newtonian multi-phase flows: On drag reduction, pressure drop and liquid wall friction factor
AdditionalInformation: This publication presents numerical results on gas/shear-thinning fluid, for different flow regimes. It has led to invitations to act as expert reviewer for the PETROMAKS2 project (Norwegian Research Council); a nomination to the Society of Petroleum Engineers Distinguished Lecturer programme (30 experts appointed annually, worldwide), and industrial grant income of over £1M in 2012/13. (LBrown@scideep.com, recently of ConocoPhillips). Further research is looking at turbulence modelling, droplet break-up and coalescence in liquid-liquid dispersions. This is critical to the petro-chemical industry (and others) to support the design of processes and equipment (e.g. separators,mixers, reactors). (Contact: lee.rhyne@chevron.com)

Title: Adaptive diagnosis of the bilinear mechanical systems, Mechanical Systems and Signal Processing.
AdditionalInformation:
Collaboration between Cranfield University and Dresser Rand (UK), a manufacturer of steam turbines. Funded under DTI/EEDA  grant, EEDA ref. PMS 4591.
The radically-novel  generalized higher order spectra developed in this work led to improved effectiveness of damage detection in turbines. Technology transfer of this technique has enabled Dresser Rand to maintain its world leading scientific and commercial edge in development of bespoke steam turbines, to decrease maintenance costs and improve turbine safety and reliability.
Design Engineer Nathan Abbott, NAbbott@Dresser-Rand.com.

Title: Biobjective design optimization for axial compressors using tabu search
AdditionalInformation:
This work extended previous optimisation of current Rolls-Royce compressor blades in collaboration with Cambridge University Engineering Design Centre. It led onto one of one of the first true multi-objective optimisations for all four unconstrained design parameters, explaining earlier, experimental- findings. (contact Geoff Parks gtp10@cam.ac.uk)
The methods have now been adopted across a wide range of multi-disciplinary aerodynamic applications including projects (total value £350k) funded by Airbus (Murray.Cross@airbus.com) and also within the EPSRC UK Applied Aerodynamics HPC Consortium (GR/F005954, £2.76M).
 (see Special Issue of Progress in Aerospace Sciences Volume 52 (2012))

Title: LES of intermittency in a turbulent round jet with different inlet conditions
AdditionalInformation: First output from collaborative EPSRC project work with Leeds University (GR/E036945, £276k) using numerical simulation to predict turbulence effects in high Reynolds number jet flows. The output has been applied to both scalar mixing in jet burners with bluff bodies introduced to stabilise subsequent combustion flames (eg at Sydney University, contact: Michael Kirkpatrick michael.kirkpatrick@sydney.edu.au), and jet engine exhaust emissions mixing processes with important implications for pdf modelling (Mike Fairweather m.fairweather@leeds.ac.uk) . The research also contributed to the EPSRC UK Turbulence HPC Consortium (GR/D044073) (Workpackage 2 Simulation of Canonical Flows: PI Richard Sandberg R.D.Sandberg@soton.ac.uk).

Title: Swirl effects on external intermittency in turbulent jets
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper uses Large Eddy Simulation (LES) to model practically important swirl effects for burner flows. It builds on collaboration with the University of Sydney, and for jet exhaust plumes with Leeds University (EPSRC GR/E036945, £276k) and experimental colleagues at Cranfield (HEIF3 OMEGA project, £125k, www.cate.mmu.ac.uk/omega-overview/). The results demonstrated stronger effects for burners than for engine exhausts, but in both cases identified for the first time the need to account specifically for intermittency effects in LES modelling to improve accuracy of mixing predictions. (contact Mike Fairweather m.fairweather@leeds.ac.uk) and led onto Helicopter LES studies that won a Best Poster Award from the Royal Society of Chemistry: Energy Group, 2012.

Title: External Intermittency Simulation in Turbulent Round Jets
AdditionalInformation: Output from a collaborative project with Leeds University, (EPSRC grant GR/E036945, £276k) and UK Turbulence HPC Consortium (EPSRC GR/D044073 & GR/G069581, £2.62M). Both Direct Numerical and Large Eddy Simulations were performed to reveal the importance of turbulence intermittency effects in jet flows. The results identified a clear need to model these effects separately for both velocity and scalar fields, and proposed three novel approaches to account for such intermittency. The results can be used to better design combustor and exhaust mixing processes, and hence reduce environmental emissions. (contact Mike Fairweather m.fairweather@leeds.ac.uk). The methodology has been applied in further research into plane jet flows (contact Ranga Dinesh Dinesh.Kahanda-Koralage@soton.ac.uk).

Title: A mechanistic model of turbulent drag reduction by additives
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports basic research into the Tom’s Phenomenon (discovered in 1948). It offers a first physical explanation of that phenomenon, and therefore gives insight into how drag reduction is influenced by different characteristics of additives (contact Prof Gad Hetsroni, hetsroni@technion.ac.il).

Title: Miniaturization limitations of HCCI internal combustion engines
AdditionalInformation: This research has predicted the constraints and limits of miniaturization of internal combustion engines which have not been broken yet by any working engine (contact Prof Eran Sher, sher@bgu.ac.il).

Title: Modified coupled-mode model for thermally chirped polymer Bragg gratings
AdditionalInformation: This study was conducted in a collaboration between the Thermal Management of Photonic and Electronic Systems Laboratory and the Laboratory for Optomechanics and Micro/Nano Semiconductor/Photonics Systems, at the University of Maryland (USA). It is one of the first studies into thermal management aspects of Bragg gratings This has significance for optical fibre strain sensing, where unwanted cross-response to temperature changes is an important factor (contact Prof Avram Bar-Cohen, abc@umd.edu).

Title: Theoretical limits of scaling-down internal combustion engines
AdditionalInformation: This was a continuation of the research described in paper 2. This research has resulted in simple relations predicting miniaturization limits for any practical internal combustion engine (contact Prof Eran Sher, sher@bgu.ac.il).

Title: Weakly compressible Poiseuille flows of a Herschel-Bulkley fluid
AdditionalInformation: This research was supported by EU Structural Funds and the Research Promotion Foundation of Cyprus (grant DIDAKTOR/DISEK/0308/32). It led to new software that can provide operational ocean forecasts in near real time for the Eastern Mediterranean sea, to assist marine activities, such as search and rescue operations, response to hazard pollution, and offshore construction. The methods were adopted in a follow-on project (EU Structural Funds / Research Promotion Foundation of Cyprus grant Parallel-CyCOFOS: SUSTAINABLE/NATURE/0609(BIE)/15 and FSI-GPGPUs: ICT/COMPUTE/0609(BE)/11), to develop software, accelerated by general purpose graphics processing units (GPUs), to solve fluid-structure interaction problemson problems (contact Dr. Hari Radhakrishnan, hari@exahpc.com).

Title: Dispersed-phase structural anisotropy in homogeneous magnetohydrodynamic turbulence at low magnetic Reynolds number
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted from collaboration between the University of Cyprus, the US Naval Research Laboratory and the University of Maryland College Park, with support from a Marie Curie Transfer of Knowledge grant (ToK-DEV Contract MTKD-CT-2004-014199). In addition to investigating new turbulence physics, the simulations  provide the first published validation of a novel set of software modules. This led to the article being highlighted by the Journal as being among its top 20 most downloaded articles (http://pof.aip.org/features/most_downloaded?month=2&year=2008)

Title: Combined effects of compressibility and slip in flows of a Herschel-Bulkley fluid
AdditionalInformation: The work was partly supported by the EU Structural Funds and the Research Promotion Foundation of Cyprus through grant agreements Parallel-CyCOFOS: SUSTAINABLE/NATURE/0609(BIE)/15 and FSI-GPGPUs: ICT/COMPUTE/0609(BE)/11. This work helped attracted additional research funds through MEDESS-4MS, a Mediterranean Decision Support System for Marine Safety; dedicated to maritime risk prevention and strengthening of maritime safety related to oil spill pollution in the Mediterranean Mediterranean (http://www.medess4ms.eu/, contact Dr Efstratios Georgoudis, project lead, Dept of Merchant Shipping, Cyprus, email available on request).

Title: Aerodynamic lift forces on multihulled marine vehicles
AdditionalInformation: The paper won the Calder Prize of the Royal Institution of Naval Architects 2011 (best paper by a member under the age of 30 on the subject of small or high-speed craft). The research led to Renaissance Design UK Ltd developing the AAMV (Aerodynamically Alleviated Marine Vehicle) concept to a higher TRL. An AAMV is a vehicle that can bridge the gap between marine and air transportation in terms of speed and payload. As a direct consequence Renaissance Design have funded a follow-on project (£115k) into the preliminary design of an AAMV configuration. Contact Tony Ryan, Managing Director, Renaissance Design: tony.ryan@renaissance-design.co.uk)

Title: Preliminary design of a floating support structure for a 5 MW offshore wind turbine
AdditionalInformation:
This paper describes a case study that brings together the results of the 2.8 M£ ETI (Energy Technology Institute) funded project NOVA (http://www.eti.co.uk/technology_programmes/offshore_wind).
This paper has been one of the first to give a complete yet simple overview of a design methodology for floating wind turbines: as a result it has been highlighted by the journal Ocean Engineering for being the most downloaded article for the whole 2012 period (http://top25.sciencedirect.com/subject/engineering/12/journal/ocean-engineering/00298018/archive/42/).
This article led to Cranfield University being chosen as work package leader in the FP7-OCEAN-2011 collaborative project H2Ocean (No 288145), coordinator Armando J. Palomar (ajpalomar@awstruepower.com)

Title: Three-dimensional numerical simulation of blood flow in two coronary stents
AdditionalInformation: This work was a collaboration between the University of Rome and the University of Southampton and analysed the performance of two types of commercial stent.

Title: A new adaptive fast cellular automaton neighborhood detection and rule identification algorithm
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics, Part B: Cybernetics
AdditionalInformation: Supported by EPSRC Platform Grant (EP/H00453X/1  £1.2M 2010-2015), this paper introduces a novel algorithm that significantly reduces computational complexity for Cellular Automaton modelling meanwhile prevents ill conditioning and over fitting. This algorithm has been applied to Irritable Bowel Syndrome data analysis in collaboration with Dr BM Corfe (Department of Surgical Oncology, University of Sheffield, email: b.m.corfe@shef.ac.uk), based on which a research grant proposal has been submitted to Yorkshire Cancer Research (£80,278). It has also facilitated the research of the EPSRC grant titled “Spatio-Temporal Systems Estimation, Modelling and Analysis” (EP/G042209/1, £480K 01/2010-06/2013).

Title: Lattice dynamical wavelet neural networks implemented using particle swarm optimization for spatio-temporal system identification
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces a totally novel algorithm for wavelet networks to model spatio-temporal systems. This paper resulted in the award of an EPSRC grant EP/G042209/1 £480K 01/2010-06/2013. Based on this method, collaboration with Dr R.I.Ristic (Department of Chemical & Biological Engineering, University of Sheffield, email: r.i.ristic@sheffield.ac.uk) was then established to model the relationship between morphological growth of crystal and controllable variables, which can help medicine  manufactory design the drug easy to be absorbed by human body. This paper also led to an academics spending study leave (06/2012-06/2013, Dr Y Ding, Beijing Institute of Technology, China, email: dingyan@bit.edu.cn).

Title: Tracking time-varying causality and directionality of information flow using an error reduction ratio test with applications to electroencephalography data
AdditionalInformation: This is an important paper to introduce a novel method to fast track the directionality of information flow with corresponding strength without fitting a full model. This paper resulted in the award of a Ryder Briggs Trust funding (£16,278 04/2013-04/2014) in collaboration with Dr PG Sarrigiannis (Clinical Neurophysiology, Royal Hallamshire Hospital, Sheffield, email: Ptolemaios.Sarrigiannis@sth.nhs.uk). This paper also led to collaborations in climatic changing field with Prof GR Bigg (Department of Geography, University of Sheffield, email: grant.bigg@shef.ac.uk), and in spherical actuators control with Prof Liang Yan (Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China, email: yanliang@buaa.edu.cn).

Title: Multistep Results in ICECREMO2
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of a series of articles about aircraft icing codes (known as ICECREMO), written to allow predictions for aircraft under icing conditions, and aid design of ice protection systems. The software is now used by Airbus as part of the certification of every new aircraft. It has played an essential role in several programmes which have values of millions of pounds (nicholas.dart@airbus.com). It is also used by BAeSystems for icing projects including the refurbishment of NIMROD  (andrew.press@baesystems.com), and in all current large civil aircraft projects by Rolls Royce. (ed.brook@rolls-royce.com)

Title: WENO schemes on arbitrary mixed-element unstructured meshes in three space dimensions
AdditionalInformation: The algorithms developed are applicable to fluid problems such as aeronautical and automotive applications, acoustics, climate and weather forecast modelling, where high computational efficiency and accuracy is required.

Title: Resource Allocation Algorithms for Virtualized Service Hosting Platforms
VolumeTitle: Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration between the University of Hawaii at Manoa, USA (where the author was working at the time), the Institut National de Recherche en Informatique et en Automatique (INRIA, France), and the LIP Laboratory of the Ecole Normale Superieure de Lyon (ENS Lyon, France), partially supported by a U.S. National Science Foundation award #0546688 and a European Commission Marie Curie Fellowship IOF #221002. The algorithms  developed in this work were later extended under a competitively-won INRIA-funded research fellowship, held at Lyon.

Title: Multi-Stepping Ice Prediction on Cylinders and Other Relevant Geometries
AdditionalInformation: An output from a study on the development of the ice prediction code ICECREMO2. This project (RA/6/31/05) was partially funded by the Department of Trade and Industry and involved a collaboration between Cranfield University and the main aircraft companies in the United Kingdom. ICECREMO2 is now used for design and certification of all Airbus aircraft (DART, Nicholas: nicholas.dart@airbus.com) and is also heavily used by UK organisations including Rolls-Royce, AgustaWestland and BAE Systems (PRESS, Andrew: andrew.press@baesystems.com).

Title: CaO-Based Pellets with Oxygen Carriers and Catalysts
AdditionalInformation:
This work is directed to making composite sorbent pellets and has led to a follow on projects at the University of Ottawa and 3 year R&D program under funding from Carbon Management Canada (Project ID number: A3-046), with partners in CanmetENERGY, Ecole Polytechnique, the University of Ottawa (Professor Arturo Macchi: Arturo Macchi, Arturo.Macchi@uottawa.ca)
and the University of Calgary. This work has also led to a joint collaboration with ETH in Switzerland (Dr. Christoph Müller: Müller  Christoph muelchri@ethz.ch).

Title: Comparison of UV/TiO2 and UV/H2O2 processes in an annular photoreactor for removal of micropollutants: Influence of water parameters on metaldehyde removal, quantum yields and energy consumption
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in the paper was the first time the use of advanced oxidation had been demonstrated to be viable for the removal of Metaldehyde in real applications. The outcomes have directly influenced Severn Trent’s strategy for managing pesticide compliance and resulted in the technology being taken forward as part of there plans for the next AMP period (Kieron.Maher@severntrent.co.uk)

Title: Characterization of organic and inorganic chemicals formed by batch-cooling crystallization: Shape and size
AdditionalInformation: This research was conducted as part of 'Chemicals Behaving Badly', funded by the EPSRC (Grant No:GR/R93353/01) and in collaboration with key pharmaceuticals companies in UK. It is currently being used in pharmaceutical drug development.(Astrazeneca Contact: Gerald.Steele@astrazeneca.com).

Title: Impact on reactor configuration on the performance of anaerobic MBRs: Treatment of settled sewage in temperate climates
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this paper was pivotal in the decision by Yorkshire Water to develop a novel anaerobic flowsheet for sewage treatment, which now forms part of the company's long term strategic plan and is currently in the planning and design phase for a large scale demonstration project planned for operation during next assest management plan period (james.n.robinson@yorkshirewater.co.uk).

Title: Chemical solutions for greywater recycling
AdditionalInformation: This work was the first to report the potential of chemical solutions for grey water treatment resulting in the invention of a new technology, the membrane chemical reactor (patent: KR20070112456) and has been subsequently commercialised by Water Innovate Ltd (http://www.waterinnovate.co.uk/product-datacentre/mc-r).

Title: Temporal and spatial changes in the microbial bioaerosol communities in green-waste composting.
AdditionalInformation: This research was supported by NERC (NE/E008534), EU (ERASMUS), EPSRC and Sita UK Ltd. It demonstrates how culture-independent methodologies can be used to monitor bioaerosol emissions from commercial composting facilities, and for source apportionment. The results are part of a body of research including DEFRA project WR1121 (lynn.raw@defra.gsi.gov.uk) leading to a report to DEFRA (http://randd.defra.gov.uk/Document.aspx?Document=11581_WR1121Bioaerosols-FINALREPORT.pdf ). The Environment Agency is preparing new guidance - M9: Monitoring of Bioaerosols in Ambient Air - incorporating these results (contact Dr Kerry Walsh kerry.walsh@environment-agency.gov.uk).

Title: Spatial variations in airborne microorganism and endotoxin concentrations at green waste composting facilities.
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Hygiene and Environmental Health
AdditionalInformation: The insights developed in this NERC-funded (NE/E008534) research led to the commissioning of a collaborative research project (DEFRA project WR1121, £490k) involving Cranfield, Imperial College, Open University, NPL and the Environment Agency (lynn.raw@defra.gsi.gov.uk).  Critical new knowledge from this research on the spatial dispersion characteristics of bioaerosols and on culture dependent / independent analytical methods is informing updates of (i) the Environment Agency’s Position Statement on composting and potential health effects from bioaerosols; and (ii) the revision of the Environment Agency’s standard protocol for the monitoring of open window composting facilities (Dr Rob Kinnersley rob.kinnersley@environment-agency.gov.uk).

Title: Bioremediation of leachate from a green waste composting facility using waste-derived filter media
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded through the Government’s Landfill Tax Credit Scheme and commissioned by SITA Environmental Trust. The results mitigate the environmental consequences of runoff from open composting arising from the expansion of the composting industry as a result of the EU Landfill Directive (Stephen.wise@neales-waste.co.uk). The research findings have been instrumental in generating a portfolio of spin-off research on passive / low energy wastewater treatment ranging from demonstration projects (e.g. EU-LIFE LIFE04 ENV/UK/809  €697k), strategic industrial research (david.knaggs@albionwater.co.uk) and fundamental research on the microbial ecology of biofiltration and its implications for engineering resilience (EPSRC EP/G005788).

Title: The effect of organic loading rate on foam initiation during mesophilic anaerobic digestion of municipal wastewater sludge
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded Anglian Water, Northumbrian Water, Severn Trent Water, Thames Water, United Utilities and Yorkshire Water. Results from this paper (and the associated research portfolio on foaming) have been used by environmental consultancy MWH Global Inc to assess remedial strategies for managing foaming events (Isabelle Lewin Isabelle.lewin@mwhglbal.com). It also led to an invitation in 2012 to provide advice to a US research programme (approx total budget $1M, co-funded by Iowa Pork Producers Association) on the causes and remediation of foaming in swine manure management systems (Professor Steven J Hoff hoffer@istate.edu).

Title: Microbial community analysis of fouled reverse osmosis membranes used in water recycling
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrated the limitation in evaluating biofouling potential in reverse osmosis membranes based on feed water characterisation and its use as a strategy for water recycling site selection. This study broadened the knowledge of membrane biofilm composition which directly informed the development of sustainable biofouling control measures (Yvan Poussade, Veolia Water Australia, yvan.poussade@veoliawater.com.au).

Title: A forward modeling approach for interpreting impeller flow logs
AdditionalInformation: The research was funded by the Environment Agency (NER/S/A/2005/13328). The method has subsequently been used to analyse data from Sweden by SRK Consulting (rpedder@srk.co.uk), and from a hazardous landfill site in Ireland to identify the location of an aquitard (low-permeability bed overlying aquifer) by Arup (Lee-A.Chambers@arup.com) and the University of Leeds (l.j.west@leeds.ac.uk).

Title: Climate change, population trends and groundwater in Africa
VolumeTitle: Hydrological Sciences Journal-Journal des Sciences Hydrologiques
AdditionalInformation: This work formed an invited key note presentation for the “Groundwater and Climate in Africa” conference held in Uganda, June 2008, a conference supported and attended by international development organisations, including BGR, GTZ, DFID, Ministry of Water and Environment , IAH, UNESCO-IHP, DANIDA, NSF, African Development Bank and World Bank. The overall conclusion, that population growth will have a more significant impact on water resources in Africa than climate change, is informing the work of Cranfield Visiting Professor Richard Carter (richard@richard-carter.org) in developing a Department For International Development project on water resource management and adaptation to climate change.

Title: Testing a rapid climate change adaptation assessment for water and sanitation providers in informal settlements in three cities in sub-Saharan Africa
AdditionalInformation: Water and Sanitation for the Urban Poor (WSUP) funded an application of this methodology in Maputo, Mozambique in 2011. The conclusion, that good water management is usually climate resilient, was presented at the  WSUP Project Implementation Workshop and disseminated at other international meetings on water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), attended by SIDA, NGOs and academics. It is now being reviewed by the Overseas Develpment Institute (j.doczi@odi.org.uk) as part of their Climate Adaptation and Risk Screening for WASH work in Ethiopia.

Title: Tank costs for domestic rainwater harvesting in East Africa
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers-Water Management
AdditionalInformation: The results are being used by the Uganda Rainwater Harvesting Association (urwa@infocom.co.ug) in their database of rainwater harvesting tanks. They are also being used in national guidance produced by the Ministry of Water and Environment (Iphraim.Kamuntu@mwe.go.ug) on rainwater harvesting  in Uganda.

Title: Hydrodynamic characteristics of a pilot-scale cold model of a CO2 capture fluidised bed reactor
AdditionalInformation: Insights into reduction of carbon emissions, developed in this work (EPSRC Grant No:EP/G06279X/1) has led to a further collaboration with Imperial and Cambridge on development of novel low cost oxygen production, and a further grant funded by UKCCSRC (led by Edinburgh) Phase 1 call (~75K). UKCCSRC contact:David Fitch (Dave.Fitch@ed.ac.uk). The research was also used in the development of a 50 kW chemical looping pilot scale facility at Cranfield, the largest of its kind in the UK. (Contact:m.pourkashanian@leeds.ac.uk).

Title: Novel Optimized Process for Utilization of CaO-Based Sorbent for Capturing CO2 and SO2 Sequentially
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an outcome of research work carried out under the UK/China H2-Network programme (Grant No: EP/G06279X/1), (China contact:hdchw66@126.com), investigating novel options for low temperature sulphur capture. This approach is now under consideration in the UK utilities sector for waste ash utilisation, to improve efficiency and lower costs in energy production (E.ON Contact:Sarah.stiff@eon.com).

Title: Minor and Trace Element Emissions from Post-Combustion CO2 Capture from Coal: Experimental and Equilibrium Calculations
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the trace elemental emissions from a post combustion pilot scale Ca looping facility (25 kW). This facility has been used extensively to explore the performance of Ca based sorbent for CO2 capture. The research is part of EPSRC Grant No: EP/G06279X/1.

Title: Solid Recovered Fuel: Influence of Waste Stream Composition and Processing on Chlorine Content and Fuel Quality.
AdditionalInformation: Funded by the Landfill Tax Credit Scheme, data reported in this paper support the business case for employing domestically-produced Solid Recovered Fuel (SRF) in the UK and inform European debate on the quality of SRF achievable in Member States. Data from this and a companion paper (Environ. Sci. Technol. 47, 2957-2965) were instrumental to initiation of an industry-led, Energy Technologies Institute study (www.uk-cpi.com/case-studies/energy-technologies-institute/) of high-efficiency technologies for clean energy, led by Caterpillar, with EDF Energy, Cranfield University and Shanks Waste Management (£1.2m; keith.sinfield@shanks.co.uk).

Title: Exposure assessment of carcass disposal options in the event of a notifiable exotic animal disease: Application to avian influenza virus
AdditionalInformation: In the aftermath of the BSE crises, this study established a revised UK disposal hierarchy for culled animals, and formed the basis for a subsequent analysis of environmental exposures from waste carcases (Environ. Sci. Technol. 44, 4416-4425). The revised hierarchy was validated in the major contingency exercise, ‘Silver Birch’ (2010), where Defra, the Scottish Government, the Welsh Assembly and key operational partners simulated a foot and mouth outbreak on a national scale to test plans and policies for disease control and eradication (gordon.hickman@defra.gsi.gov.uk).

Title: Intervention strategies for carcass disposal: pareto analysis of exposures for exotic disease outbreaks
AdditionalInformation: This extended our previous research on carcase disposal, in support of Defra’s strategic commitment to keeping this issue under review. Informed by a multi-stakeholder, multi-agency workshop, this is the first sensitivity analysis of the exposure from multiple hazards across the full waste carcase process chain. It directly informed disposal arrangements and policy within Defra’s contingency plan for exotic notifiable diseases of animals (2012) (gordon.hickman@defra.gsi.gov.uk).

Title: Character of environmental harms: overcoming implementation challenges with policy makers and regulators.
AdditionalInformation: This method allowed the first comparison of policy-level risks across Defra’s remit and was reported to Defra's Science Advisory Council in 2012 (www.defra.gov.uk/sac/files/sac-12-04-jan-risk-paper.pdf) . Championed by Defra’s Chief Scientific Advisor, this comparative analysis supported Board-level decision-making by comparing strategic environmental risks for the first time. The work is now used to build a longer-term view of policy risk; critical now Government funding is under pressure. Follow-on funding from Defra on environmental futures (Contract SD0339 £1.8m) is allowing further development for policy risks emerging over longer time frames (Edgar.Black@defra.gsi.gov.uk).

Title: Electrohydrodynamic atomization deposition of PZT sol-gel slurry and sol infiltration on the films
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: First application of deposition technique for functional devices, funded by EPSRC (GR/84156/01) and EC (MIND [Multifunctional & Integrated Piezoelectric Device] FP6-NMP 515757). Applications have led to scale-up research (including funding from National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 50905027) and Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education of China (No. 20090041120041) and development of novel coatings for faecal matter (http://nanomembranetoilet.org/index.php) funded by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, providing sanitation in developing countries (Carl Hensman; carl.hensman@gatesfoundation.org). Tillman and Dorey have shown consequent property enhancements for acoustic emission structural health monitoring systems which is being commercially explored (DOI 10.1007/s10853-012-6810-7).

Title: Micromoulding of PZT film structures using electrohydrodynamic atomization mould filling
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: The output of this new patterning technique research was used, by the National Physical Laboratory, to help develop a micro-coordinate measurement probe (markys.cain@npl.co.uk), which is now being developed as a commercial product. Applications have led to scale-up research (including funding from National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 50905027) and Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education of China (No. 20090041120041). The work was funded by EPSRC (GR/84156/01) and European Commission (MIND [Multifunctional & Integrated Piezoelectric Device] FP6-NMP 515757).

Title: Evidence and belief in regulatory decisions - Incorporating expected utility into decision modelling
AdditionalInformation: This research established the basis for integrating evidence support logic and utility for regulatory decisions on risk. The model of influence within decision-making was used to justify and evidence a portfolio of research into organisational behaviour and regulatory decision making within government (EPSRC/ESRC/NERC/Defra Risk Centre EP/G022682/1) and secure additional funding for a Defra/EPSRC project investigating effective and efficient regulatory decision making – contact Edgar Black (Edgar.Black@defra.gsi.gov.uk). The work was funded by EPSRC (EP/E017975/1) in collaboration with Nottingham and LSE.

Title: Selective detection of live bacteria combining propidium monoazide sample treatment with microarray technology
AdditionalInformation: This research was part of the validation process for novel technology patented by the first author. Selective detection of live microorganisms, together with rapid diagnostic methods, will be commercialized by QIAGEN in 2013 (contact: Dr. Holger Engel - Holger.Engel@qiagen.com). QIAGEN, the world's leading provider of sample and assay technologies, has acquired the worldwide licence. US Patent No.: US 20100035250 A1. International PCT Patent Application Serial No.: PCT/US2007/004922 (in progress). A sublicense was granted to Spanish SME GenIUL which has designed a light exposure device for this method (contact: Francesc Codony: fcodony@geniul.com)

Title: Effect of PCR amplicon length on suppressing signals from membrane-compromised cells by propidium monoazide treatment
AdditionalInformation: This research aimed at optimizing technology patented by the first author (US Patent No.: US 20100035250 A1, licensed by QIAGEN; contact: Dr. Holger Engel - Holger.Engel@qiagen.com). The technology modification suggested in this paper implies a fundamental improvement of the method and has become an important part of the amplification strategy suggested by licensees of the technology (QIAGEN or GenIUL S.L., contact: Francesc Codony: fcodony@geniul.com) for researchers applying ‘viability PCR’.

Title: Use of propidium monoazide and increased amplicon length reduce false-positive signals in quantitative PCR for bioburden analysis.
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted from an international collaboration with Baxter Healthcare, USA and was part of an industry-funded project. The technological approach is focused on Baxter's core business: parenteral drugs, QA/QC of which is critical for patient safety. The method is expected to overcome the greatest obstacle which has so far prevented the application of PCR to bioburden analysis: the elimination of false-positive results. Baxter contact: Dr. Mark Pasmore, mark_pasmore@baxter.com.

Title: Multiparameter Viability Assay for Stress Profiling Applied to the Food Pathogen Listeria monocytogenes F2365.
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by the Netherlands Organization for Applied Scientific Research (TNO), to implement new technology to assess microbial viability in microbiological samples. The resulting 'viability toolbox' is currently offered by TNO to industrial clients (e.g. dairy industry, brewing and wine making, recombinant production of drugs) for product optimization. TNO contact: Dr. Frank Schuren, frank.schuren@tno.nl.

Title: Integration and evaluation of a power plant with a CaO-based CO<sub>2</sub> capture system
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: Solid sorbent use for CO2 capture from power stations and industrial sources is increasing, due to the potential for high temperature integration and low environmental impact. Our approach, developed in this paper and in collaboration with EU industries (e.g. Alstom Power, Endesa, etc.) and research groups (e.g. CSIC, University of Stuttgart) led to a CSIC/Cranfield joint granted patent, CA 2479886 C.  The technology reduces efficiency penalties associated with other CO2 capture methods, thereby improving affordability of the electricity produced. An EU demonstration project is currently running at La Pereda in Spain. Contact - Dr Juan Carlos Abanades (CSIC), abanades@incar.csic.es.

Title: A comparison between Miscanthus and bioethanol waste pellets and their performance in a downdraft gasifier
AdditionalInformation: The gasification of biomass-derived fuels provides a route to higher efficiency electricity generation at small-to-medium scale with minimal climate change impact. While reliable production of a fuel gas of stable composition is the primary aim, the residues also provide a valuable soil conditioner/fertiliser. These studies highlight the importance of fuel pellet parameters in the biomass supply chain. Contact: Prof Jim Swithenbank (Sheffield University), j.swithenbank@sheffield.ac.uk.

Title: Study on multi-objective optimization of load dispatch including renewable energy and CCS technologies
AdditionalInformation: In electricity supply markets, there is a need to ensure that the installed capacity has the capability to  meet customer demand. The model described in the paper provides a new approach to achieve optimisation of the dispatchability of combinations of technologies, while taking full account of their environmental impact. Contact: Prof Nilay Shah (Imperial College), n.shah@imperial.ac.uk.

Title: Integration and evaluation of a power plant with a monoethanolamine-based CO2-capture process
AdditionalInformation: This work addresses minimisation of the energy penalty (and thus higher electricity cost) associated with amine scrubbing for CO2 capture, while achieving 90% capture. The paper identifies preferred plant integration options, using biomass co-firing, to minimise efficiency impacts. Contact: Dr Sjoerd van Rijen (DNVKema), Sjoerd.vanRijen@dnvkema.com.

Title: Influence of pH on gas-phase controlled mass transfer in a membrane contactor for hydrogen sulphide absorption
AdditionalInformation: This work, originally funded by EPSRC (GR/R52589), presented the development of a new technology for high rate odour removal which has since been taken up for commercialisation (Odour Extraction Membrane Reactor, OEM-R) through a university spinout company (Water Innovate Limited: A Bluewater Bio Company, richard.harnett@bluewaterbio.com). Further funding was received by Anglian Water, Severn Trent Water, Northumbrian Water and Yorkshire Water, to explore the technology's viability for CO2 separation from biogas, and has offered new strategies for biogas upgrading to the water industry (Peter.Vale@severntrent.co.uk).

Title: Comparison of dead-end and continuous filtration conditions in a denitrification membrane bioreactor
AdditionalInformation: The findings of this research formed the basis of a successful EPSRC First Grant (EP/K010360/1), ’Membrane fouling for low energy advanced wastewater treatment’, which seeks to establish the underpinning science for translation into wider applications.

Title: Impact of membrane configuration on fouling in anaerobic membrane bioreactors
AdditionalInformation: This research, sponsored by the European Commission (Marie Curie MBR-TRAIN programme), has been instrumental, with other evidence, in encouraging several water utilities to consider fullflow anaerobic treatment as part of their long term strategy (elizabeth.wood@yorkshirewater.co.uk).

Title: Optimisation of dead-end filtration conditions for an immersed anoxic membrane bioreactor
AdditionalInformation: The research, funded by Anglian Water, Severn Trent Water, Northumbrian Water and Yorkshire Water, was used to suggest sustainable, lower cost alternatives to current practice. The work resulted in a granted process patent (WIPO, WO/2010/041041) and investigation of commercial exploitation opportunities through a university spinout company (Water Innovate: A Bluewater Bio Company, richard.harnett@bluewaterbio.com).

Title: The role of map-based environmental information in supporting integration between river basin planning and spatial planning
AdditionalInformation: The work, supported by the James Hutton Institute, generated a policy brief for the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Scottish Government (http://www.knowledgescotland.org/briefings.php?id=254. Contact: Jenny Davies, SEPA, jenny.davies@sepa.org.uk). The work also resulted in Smith being invited to contribute the findings to a UK-wide policy brief on emerging challenges in water policy, prepared by the Royal Geographical Society (http://www.rgs.org/OurWork/Advocacy+and+Policy/Policy+briefings.htm).

Title: An internal carbon source for improving biological nutrient removal
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by Thames Water and Severn Trent Water. Results suggested mechanical and ultrasound disintegration technologies  that could find application at wastewater treatment sites. (Peter.Vale@severntrent.co.uk; Pete.Pearce@thameswater.co.uk)

Title: Comparison between disintegrated and fermented sewage sludge for production of a carbon source suitable for biological nutrient removal
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by Yorkshire Water, looking at internal carbon sources for biological nutrient removal. The outputs of the project were incorporated into modelling tool that helped Yorkshire Water to make a pre-selection of the most suitable technologies for phosphorus removal at defined sites, potentially resulting in capital and operational savings (Elizabeth.wood@yorkshirewater.co.uk).

Title: Preliminary evaluation of new polymer matrix for solid-phase extraction of nonylphenol from water samples
AdditionalInformation: This research investigated the suitability of molecularly imprinted polymers to extract and concentrate the hazardous pollutant nonylphenol from water samples. This research reinforced the concept of utilizing synthesized materials as affinity-based separation media for sample pre-concentration and separation, via molecularly imprinted solid-phase extraction.

Title: Fate of Alkylphenolic Compounds during Activated Sludge Treatment: Impact of Loading and Organic Composition.
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by Anglian Water, Severn Trent Water, Thames Water Utilities, United Utilities, and Yorkshire Water. Correlating operational conditions of the activated sludge process with nonyphenol ethoxylates removal rates (Elizabeth.Wood@yorkshirewater.co.uk) led to a collaboration with UK Water Industry Research (UKWIR) and the Environment Agency, to investigate the fate of hazardous pollutants in the environment, through the Chemical Investigations Programme (CIP) (http://www.ukwir.org/site/web/news/news-items/ukwir-chemicals-investigation-programme). This project identified cost effective measures to meet the requirements of the Water Framework Directive. (michael.gardner@atkinsglobal.com).

Title: Nitrous oxide emissions for early warning of biological nitrification failure in activated sludge.
AdditionalInformation: This research contributed to an international patent on early warning of wastewater treatment works failure to prevent ammonia pollution of watercourses (PCT/GB2005/001963, granted).  The patented process, N-TOX®, was assigned to a Cranfield University spinout company, Water Innovate, prior to raising >£500k of investment (www.waterinnovate.com).  It was one of 9 out of 265 entrants to win a Shell Springboard Award in 2006 for ideas with potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions (www.shellspringboard.org).  Water Innovate was bought by Bluewaterbio in 2010.  N-TOX® has been deployed in Australia, Europe and the USA (justin.heath@bluewaterbio.com, Marketing Director, Bluewaterbio).

Title: Growth and nutrient removal in free and immobilized green algae in batch and semi-continuous cultures treating real wastewater
AdditionalInformation: This research was a collaboration with the Autonomous University of Baja California, Mexico. The results were adopted in follow-on projects build pilot plants for the extraction of biofuels from algae: on the use of urban wastewater for the production of algal biomass and biodiesel (grant Fomix-Campeche-2010-01) and on production of biodiesel from algal biomass (grant CONACYT 2011).  Further collaboration contracts with the Universidad of Yucatán and the Universidad Catόlica de Honduras have been awarded to the Autonomous University of Baja California (lmendoza@uabc.edu.mx).

Title: Effect of influent nutrient ratios and hydraulic retention time (HRT) on simultaneous phosphorus and nitrogen removal in a two-sludge sequencing batch reactor process
AdditionalInformation: This research was conducted in collaboration with the China State Key Laboratory of Pollution Control and Resources Reuse, Shanghai, co-funded by a China National Natural Science Foundation Scholarship (no. 50608064).  The research led to a Chinese patent (201110376927.1, granted) on control of a two sludge denitrifying phosphorus removal process. The energy efficient operating sequences developed in this research were subsequently applied to sequencing batch reactors in package wastewater treatment plants by a UK SME, Enso International (ddaude@enso-international.com, Managing Director).

Title: Fouling control of a membrane coupled photocatalytic process treating greywater
AdditionalInformation: This research led to an international patent for a chemical reactor for the removal of chemicals from contaminated water that are otherwise difficult to remove (PCT/WO2006/079837A1, granted).  The patent was assigned to a Cranfield University spinout company, Water Innovate, prior to raising >£500k of investment (www.waterinnovate.com).  Further development by Water Innovate was funded through DTI (‘Membox’, £517K) and EU (‘Innowatech’, €2.75M) consortia. Water Innovate was bought by the UK water technology company Bluewaterbio in 2010 (www.bluewaterbio.com). Follow-on research has been supported by Severn-Trent Water (contact R&D Manager, markR.jones@severntrent.co.uk).

Title: Effects of steam on the sulfation of limestone and NOx formation in an air- and oxy-fired pilot-scale circulating fluidized bed combustor
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first study to look at the effect of moisture on SO2 and NOx in an oxyfuel CFB pilot plant, and showed that H2O has a strong effect on both in an oxyfuel environment, and on sulfation in an air environment. The results have been used by the University of British Columbia (Professor John Grace, jgrace@chbe.ubc.ca), the University of Stuttgart (Professor  Guenter Scheffknecht, guenter.scheffknecht@ifk.uni-stuttgart.de) and Imperial College (Dr. Paul Fennell, p.fennell@imperial.ac.uk).

Title: Modified lime-based pellet sorbents for high-temperature CO<sub>2</sub> capture: Reactivity and attrition behavior
AdditionalInformation: This study looks at the performance of lime based pellets prepared with calcium aluminate cement in a small bench-scale FBC reactor, and shows that they have both superior capture and attrition performance over natural sorbents.

Title: Experiences and results on a 0.8MWth oxy-fuel operation pilot-scale circulating fluidized bed
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first of a series on an 0.8 MWth oxyfuel Circulating Fluidized Bed Combustor (CFBC). It confirms good performance seen with other units of this type previously used in a $1.2 million study on oxy-fuel FBC, which supported a 30 MWth project 'CUIDEN' . Previous results were the property of Endesa and the Spanish government, who funded this work, so this is the first paper to present similar results to a public audience. (Andres Sanchez-biezma,  andres.sanchez@endesa.es; Dr. Lufei Jia, CanmetENERGY, Lufei.Jia@NRCan-RNCan.gc.ca)

Title: Influence of Operating Parameters on the Biodegradation of Steroid Estrogens and Nonylphenolic Compounds during Biological Wastewater Treatment Processes
AdditionalInformation: Research results identified optimisation options for the removal of hazardous chemicals in biological wastewater treatment and were used to select sites for and shape the development of the National AMP5 (Asset Management Plan 2010-2015) Chemicals Investigation Programme (CIP) with UKWIR (UK Water Industry Research) on hazardous chemicals under the Water Framework Directive. Programme value £25million. As a result of this paper and others, Prof Cartmell was invited to sit on the CIP steering group board. Contact Brian Ellor (brian.ellor@sky.com) and Arthur Thornton (arthur.thornton@atkinsglobal.com).

Title: The significance of sample mass in the analysis of steroid estrogens in sewage sludges and the derivation of partition coefficients in wastewaters
AdditionalInformation: Research results optimised the analytical method for determination of steroid estrogens in solid/high organic matrix samples and improved recoveries and limits of detection. The methods developed were utilised by the National Laboratory Service, which was one of the laboratories undertaking the Chemicals Investigation Programme national analysis for solid phase estrogen analysis. Reference Dave Simmons (dave.simons@natlabs.co.uk). In addition, a  follow on invited review article for a special edition in Trends in Analytical Chemistry was accepted in 2013.

Title: The significance of hazardous chemicals in wastewater treatment works effluents
AdditionalInformation: This is the first in a series of papers from the National Chemicals Investigation Programme (CIP) funded by the Water Utilities with the UK Water Industry Research (UKWIR) and regulators (Environment Agency, Defra, SEPA and OFWAT). This first phase of research identified the hazardous chemicals requiring programmes of measures to ensure compliance with the Water Framework Directive for the Environment Agency and DEFRA. Reference Tony Heaney (tony.heaney@environment-agency.gov.uk). A second paper has now also been published and the combined work is currently being utilised to scope the National AMP6 (Asset Management Plan 2015 – 2020) CIP programme.

Title: The effectiveness of anaerobic digestion in removing estrogens and nonylphenol ethoxylates
AdditionalInformation: This research examined hazardous chemical removal in anaerobic digestion. Work established digestion performance baselines and led to Cranfield involvement with WRAP (Waste Resources Action Programme) in two programmes: 'Anaerobic Digestion Technical Support’ and 'Driving Innovation in Anaerobic Digestion – Optimisation programme, 2012'. Reference Dr Nina Sweet OBE (nina.sweet@wrap.org.uk).

Title: Regulating water services for all in developing economies
AdditionalInformation: Based on a Department for International Development (DFID) funded multi-country research project, this work, examined the role of economic regulation as a driver for improved water and sanitation for the billion people in low-income settlements in lower-income countries. It led to on-going work with economic regulators, most recently in Albania with German Development Agency GIZ (andrea.goertler@giz.de)

Title: Regulating Water Services for The Poor: The Case of Amman
AdditionalInformation: Investigation of water services in Amman, Jordan, as part of a Department for International Development funded research programme has led to involvement in the 'New water for Taiz – conflict prevention and economic revitalisation' project in Yemen to assist 'the most water-stressed city in the world', with consultants JFA (James Firebrace Associates -jf@firebrace.com). If fully successful, this will transform the water supply to a city of 800,000 people from the present once-in-100 days supply to continuous supply, through commercially sustainable desalination.

Title: Water services regulation for the urban poor: Zambia
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers-Water Management
AdditionalInformation: The research into improved services for the urban poor in Lusaka is part of a wider programme supporting improved services in slums. The work led to Cranfield representation on the Governing Board of WSUP (Water and Sanitation for the Urban Poor), and to additional direct WSUP contracts with Cranfield for specific tasks (samparker@wsup.com).

Title: A comparison of disinfection by-products found in chlorinated and chloraminated drinking waters in Scotland
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an outcome of Cranfield-led research, funded by the Scottish Government (Project Code: UCR/003/07) in collaboration with Scottish Water, who experience problems in achieving 100% compliance with disinfection by-product regulations.The project informed both parties that that disinfecting drinking water with chloramines rather than chlorine would not put the health of the Scottish public at risk (Matthew Bower Matthew.Bower@scotland.gsi.gov.uk). The work also helped Scottish Water’s understanding of the disinfection by-products associated with chloramination (Richard Allan richard.allan@scottishwater.co.uk).

Title: Biodegradation of Haloacetic Acids by Bacterial Isolates and Enrichment Cultures from Drinking Water Systems
AdditionalInformation: The outcome of research sponsored by the Water Research Foundation, USA (project #3122), in collaboration with the University of Minnesota, Cranfield University, Montana State University and Penn State University.  The project has led to further research at Cranfield, sponsored by Scottish Water, to elucidate the chemistry of Haloacetic acids in the distribution system (Simon Gillespie simon.gillespie@scottishwater.co.uk).

Title: Chemical and biological oxidation of NOM surrogates and effect on HAA formation
AdditionalInformation: The work was fully industrially funded, by Anglian Water, Northumbrian Water, Severn Trent Water, United Utilities and Yorkshire Water, and performed in collaboration with the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, Australia (Contact: L Fan, linhua.fan@rmit.edu.au). Follow-on projects are now developing innovative solutions based on chemical oxidation (with Severn Trent Water) and biological treatment (with Anglian Water).

Title: Occurrence and toxicity of disinfection byproducts in european drinking waters in relation with the HIWATE epidemiology study
AdditionalInformation: This was the first study integrating quantitative in vitro toxicological data with analytical chemistry and human epidemiologic outcomes to further understand the impact of disinfection by-products (DBPs) on human health. Cell cytotoxicity results confirmed that the current UK strategy of minimising all DBPs is appropriate. The paper was an outcome of a collaboration between Cranfield University, HIWATE project partners (www.hiwate.org, funded under EU contract no. Food-CT-2006-036224), the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, USA, Portland State University, USA and CanSyn Chem. Corp., Canada.

Title: Nitrous oxide emissions and dissolved oxygen profiling in a full-scale nitrifying activated sludge treatment plant
AdditionalInformation: Research established for the first time the impact of variable aeration delivery, in full scale wastewater treatment plants, on the overall carbon footprint associated with energy use and fugitive emissions. The research has been applied to inform investment decisions on treatment plant upgrades including aeration system design and aeration control strategies in Severn Trent for the next Asset Management Plan (AMP6) submission to the regulator (Ofwat). Contact: Peter Vale, Senior Strategist (peter.vale@severntrent.co.uk).

Title: Performance of pilot-scale constructed wetlands for secondary treatment of chromium-bearing tannery wastewaters
AdditionalInformation: The work pioneers wetland technology for treatment of chromium tanning effluents. Findings have been used to size wetlands for treatment of industrial effluents in small tanneries and other industries in Argentina. In the developing world, wetland technology can help alleviate pollution input to rivers. The work was a collaboration between the Universidad Nacional del Litoral (UNL), two American universities, and a local Argentinian tannery. Continuing work, based on the findings, is being led by UNL in Argentina. Contact: Dr Alejandra Maine (amaine@fiqus.unl.edu.ar).

Title: Evaluating the quality of bioaerosol risk assessments for composting facilities in England and Wales
AdditionalInformation: This first evaluation of the quality of composting risk assessments was submitted to the Environment Agency, leading to to the development of new guidance on the evaluation of new Environment Agency risk assessments (Dr Kerry Walsh, kerry.walsh@environment-agency.gov.uk, EA Science Project P1-514).

Title: Evaluation of inflammatory effects of airborne endotoxin emitted from composting sources
AdditionalInformation: The research is part of a growing evidence base on effects of endotoxin from composting facilities (funded by NERC, NE/E008534/1). This research has contributed to endotoxins being considered for routine monitoring as part of the revision of the Association for Organics Recycling standardised protocol for bioaerosol monitoring, supported by the Environment Agency (Dr Kerry Walsh, kerry.walsh@environment-agency.gov.uk)

Title: Central role of dynamic tidal biofilms dominated by aerobic hydrocarbonoclastic bacteria and diatoms in the biodegradation of hydrocarbons in coastal mudflats
AdditionalInformation:
This work developed advanced biological methods that led to new strategies to accelerate the ecological repair process in marine and costal ecosystems. It further provided pivotal information to regulation agencies such as the Centre of Documentation, Research 
and Experimentation on Accidental Water Pollution (CEDRE), involved in responding to major oil spill incidents, which need decision tools for an integral risk assessment (Ronan Jezequel, ronan.jezequel@cedre.fr)

Title: Development of an analytical procedure for weathered hydrocarbon contaminated soils within a UK risk-based framework
AdditionalInformation: An outcome of the BBSRC/BERR/EA BIOREM_35 Link project: PROMISE (Grant BB/B512432/1).  The work addressed key requirements for  contaminated land risk assessment, and was pivotal for the Environmental Scientifics Group, formerly TES Bretby (contact: Graeme Risdon, MD: graemerisdon@eurofins.co.uk). TES Bretby have focussed specifically on enabling the technique to have a high throughput and a commercial edge (4-fold faster than conventional methods and over £200k savings on hydrocarbon analysis per year). The analytical methodology was applied during site remediation for the London 2012 Olympic games (contact G Risdon as above).

Title: Multimedia fate of petroleum hydrocarbons in the soil: Oil matrix of constructed biopiles
AdditionalInformation: As part also of the BBSRC/BERR/EA BIOREM_35 Link project: PROMISE (Grant BB/B512432/1, 2006-08), the work provides ‘fit for purpose’ assessment of the fate of hydrocarbon complex mixtures and risk-critical compounds in soils, allowing realistic remediation objectives to be set and supporting swifter, risk-based remediation. In doing so, it ensures environmental protection and allows the recovery of soil quality for reuse. (ref: Prof Emeritus Don Mackay, DMackay@Trentu.ca)

Title: When is a soil remediated? Comparison of biopiled and windrowed soils contaminated with bunker-fuel in a full-scale trial
AdditionalInformation: The research enabled Remedios Ltd, an environmental technology company, to gain a greater understanding of remediation process dynamics and their optimisation with reference to weathered hydrocarbons.  By promoting a greater understanding of the technology, both internally and externally, it has enabled strategic decisions on the company’s future direction and position in the European remediation marketplace.  It enhanced its R & D capability allowing the company to expand its services and secure access to the international market. (Contact Ken Killham, ken.killham@remedios.uk.com)

Title: An aeration energy model for an immersed membrane bioreactor
AdditionalInformation: One of few papers providing a semi-empirical model for total aeration within an Membrane Bioreactor (MBR). The practical work on which the paper was based helped inform the design and successful implementation of the MBR used at the Olympic Park during the 2012 Summer Games in London (rupert.kruger@thameswater.co.uk).

Title: Chemical cleaning of potable water membranes: The cost benefit of optimisation
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated the cost benefit of effective chemical cleaning of hollow fibre membranes for potable water treatment, based on data taken from UK-wide installations. Supplementary work using this method was conducted for two UK water utilities (United Utilities and Yorkshire Water) to help optimise operation of two full-scale installations (Peter.Hillis@aecom.com), one case study being published separately in Environmental Technology, 2009.

Title: Optimising operation of an integrated membrane system (IMS) - A Box-Behnken approach
AdditionalInformation: Along with related work published separately, this output was critically important in informing part of the 25-year Water Resources Management Plan of the research programme sponsor Thames Water. At least one Indirect Potable Reuse (IPR) plant, equating to up to £300 million in capital expenditure, is projected within the Plan, with the plant design and operation being based on the research programme outputs (rupert.kruger@thameswater.co.uk)

Title: Efficacy of relaxation, backflushing, chemical cleaning and clogging removal for an immersed hollow fibre membrane bioreactor.
AdditionalInformation: This paper is possibly the only example of direct comparison of relative efficacies of the various membrane cleaning methods on a full-scale membrane bioreactor (MBR) module challenged with real municipal wastewater. The work was pivotal in informing the strategic decision of the company to withdraw from MBR process development and focus on the core activity of membrane module provision as a commodity (Contact: Peter Aerts paerts@dow.com).

Title: Regulators as agents: modelling personality and power as evidence is brokered to support decisions on environmental risk
AdditionalInformation: Complex regulatory decisions about risk rely on the brokering of evidence between providers and recipients. This EPSRC funded (EP/E017975/1; EP/G022682/1) research develops an agent-based model, with implications for improved efficiency and quality of regulatory decision making, by understanding the role of personality and power. In particular, agent-based models may reveal the influences at work when evidence to support decisions is provided to regulators, which is not practical using traditional ethnographic approaches. Contact: Edgar Black, Defra.Risk Coordinator. Edgar.Black@defra.gsi.gov.uk

Title: Reducing gain-loss asymmetry: A virtual reality choice experiment valuing land use change
VolumeTitle: Journal of Environmental Economics and Management
AdditionalInformation: This research, funded by the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research, developed and tested a new form of virtual reality choice experiment to value future landscape change and associated non-market goods.  Significant benefits over traditional presentation techniques include improved evaluability, reducing respondent judgement error and providing more robust economic valuations.  Such techniques may prove important when valuing landscape change and ecosystem services, particularly those associated with large-scale adaptation to climate change, (e.g. managed realignment of coastal defences). Contact: Professor Andrew Watkinson, Former Director Tyndall Centre. A.watkinson@uea.ac.uk

Title: Making it real: What risk managers should know about community engagement
VolumeTitle: Journal of Environmental Assessment Policy and Management
AdditionalInformation:
This research funded by the Cooperative Research Centre for Contamination Assessment and Remediation (CRC CARE) Australia describes the communication principles that can be used in community consultation.  It resulted in the publication of a framework and handbook for community consultation, in the context of contaminated site projects, published by CRC CARE, http://www.crccare.com/working_with_industry/contaminated_sites_handbook.html
Contact: Professor Ravi Naidu Managing Director CRC CARE ravi.naidu@crc.com

Title: Comparison of coagulation performance and floc properties using a novel zirconium coagulant against traditional ferric and alum coagulants
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration with Water Innovate Ltd and Yorkshire Water. The first published work to demonstrate the effectiveness of a new zirconium based coagulant for improved removal of natural organic matter compared with conventional chemicals. (Jenny Banks, Senior Project Manager, Yorkshire Water, jenny.banks@yorkshirewater.co.uk).  Part of the work was disseminated at one of the largest drinking water conferences in the world (Water Quality and Technology Conference of the American Water Works Association, ISBN: 978-160560993-5).  The coagulant is commercially available for solid-liquid separation in, e.g. drinking water production and municipal and industrial wastewater treatment (Jeremy Biddle, Technical Director, Bluewater Bio: Jeremy.biddle@bluewaterbio.com).

Title: Pilot scale comparison of enhanced coagulation and magnetic ion exchange plus coagulation systems
AdditionalInformation: This research was influential in the decision to implement three novel ion-exchange treatment processes in Yorkshire Water, the first of their kind in the UK, at a cost of over £50m (Jenny Banks, Senior Project Manager, Yorkshire Water, jenny.banks@yorkshirewater.co.uk).

Title: The role of polymer in improving floc strength for filtration
AdditionalInformation: Funded by Yorkshire Water, this project applied novel techniques to characterise particles. The outputs helped to secure an EPSRC grant 'Controlling Problem Particles in Water Treatment' (EP/H018506). In addition, further Yorkshire Water funding was obtained to investigate greatly reducing polymer concentrations at water treatment plants (Andrew Wetherill, Asset Strategy Manager, Yorkshire Water, andrew.wetherill@yorkshirewater.co.uk). This project was carried out in collaboration with the Ecole Nationale Superiore de Chimie de Rennes.

Title: Magnetic ion-exchange resin treatment: Impact of water type and resin use
AdditionalInformation: This work showed that the application of an ion-exchange process for the production of high quality drinking water was water specific. As a result, Yorkshire Water have built three new treatment plants at a cost of over £50m, which have improved water quality for consumers. In addition Yorkshire Water have funded further research into ion-exchange treatment of high organic content water sources, which has explored how alternative ion exchange processes can be implemented at full-scale. (Jenny Banks, Senior Project Manager, Yorkshire Water, jenny.banks@yorkshirewater.co.uk).

Title: Surfactants as bubble surface modifiers in the flotation of algae: Dissolved air flotation that utilizes a chemically modified bubble surface
AdditionalInformation: The work led to the development of a new flotation technology which has been commercialized by Water Innovate Ltd (http://www.waterinnovate.co.uk/product-datacentre/posidaf)  and is currently being trialed in Australia as part of a collaborative project (ARC Linkage LP0990189 - Gayle.Newcombe@sawater.com.au).  The innovative development presented in the paper was acknowledged through the winning of an award at the 2008 International Water Asscoiation leading edge technology conference (keith.robertson@iwahq.org).

Title: The impact of contactor scale on a ferric nanoparticle adsorbent process for the removal of phosphorus from municipal wastewater
AdditionalInformation: This work was pivotal in the technology being included as one of the key options for meeting future tight phosphorus standards, in a large-scale demonstration scheme under development by Severn Trent Water (P.Vale@severntrent.co.uk). The innovation described in the paper won awards at the Water and wastewater IWEX university challenge 2011  and the IWA leading edge technology conference in 2010 (Contact for both: Keith Robinson, Keith.robinson@iwahq.org).

Title: Disinfection byproduct formation and fractionation behavior of natural organic matter surrogates
