AdditionalInformation: The understanding derived in this work directly responded to a UK water company need to enhance the link between characterization and treatment of organic matter. As a consequence of the work the technique is now being routinely used as part of water resource and treatment appraisals within UK water companies (Jenny.banks@yorkshirewater.co.uk) and has now been set up as a standard measurement tool within the Scottish Water laboratories (simon.gillespie@scottishwater.co.uk)

Title: Water distribution system vulnerability analysis using weighted and directed network models
AdditionalInformation: Funded through a Leverhulme Grant (Ref: F/0 0509/E) this work develops a novel water utility specific metric of distribution network robustness. It has led to invitations from UK water utilities to conduct robustness assessments using the developed technique (Northumbrian Water. Contact Mr. Chris Jones – chris.jones@nwl.co.uk). The work is also being pursued further as part of the EC funded TRUST project (EC grant: 265122) and by the Shell Center for Sustainability (http://shellcenter.rice.edu/).

Title: Maturing the new water management paradigm: progressing from aspiration to practice
AdditionalInformation: Emerging from an EC funded project on new approaches to water management (NEWATER – EC Grant GOCE-S11179), this contribution has influenced debate and policy development across a wide range of disciplines  and problem sets (e.g. Climate Adaptation and Water Governance). Contact: Prof. Claudia Pahl-Wostl, University of Osnabrück, pahl@usf.uni-osnabrueck.de. It also led to Jeffrey being invited to author a  chapter in a leading textbook (Grafton & Hussey (Eds) Water Resources Planning and Management. Cambridge University Press. Cambridge. Pp 292-310.)

Title: Time to Talk? How the Structure of Dialog Processes Shapes Stakeholder Learning in Participatory Water Resources Management
AdditionalInformation: The work underpinning this paper was funded by an EC grant: 511231-2, and challenged existing assumptions about the value of social learning processes in stakeholder consultation. It led directly to Jeffrey being invited to talk at events organised by the Royal Academy of Engineering (ref: Joint meeting of RAEng, ICE and IMechE ‘Engineering the Future: Local Water Recycling’. London, 13th September 2011) and Cambridge University (ref: One day conference on Post-positivist Social Sciences and the Engineering of Sustainable Urban Environments. Cambridge University, 27th September 2010.)

Title: Resilience enhancing expansion strategies for water distribution systems: A network theory approach
AdditionalInformation: Applying the theoretical work developed through an award from the Leverhulme Trust  to a practical challenge in the developing world, this paper was pivotal to one of the authors being awarded the ‘African Geospatial Excellence Award’ in 2011 (Contact Richard Appiah Otoo - richieotoo@gmail.com).

Title: Solid Recovered Fuel: Materials Flow Analysis and Fuel Property Development during the Mechanical Processing of Biodried Waste.
AdditionalInformation: Experimental results and analysis reported in this study led directly to evidence for a joint consortium between Cranfield, and energy technology and waste companies CAT, EDF, EIFER, Shanks, and CPI, to demonstrate the potential for UK waste to contribute to UK low carbon energy for the Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). This has led onto a wider Energy from Waste gasification programme. Matthew Barton matthew.barton@eti.co.uk

Title: The biogenic content of process streams from mechanical-biological treatment plants producing solid recovered fuel. Do the manual sorting and selective dissolution determination methods correlate?
AdditionalInformation: Experimental results provided evidence for a successful £60k development sequence with the National Physical Laboratory, funded by the TSB & Defra through 2x collaborative Small Business Research Initiative projects. Results demonstrated show the capability to rapidly assess calorific value of energy from waste fuel using imaging methods. Richard Dudley richard.dudley@npl.co.uk

Title: Receptivity to the production of product service systems in the UK construction and manufacturing sectors: A comparative analysis
AdditionalInformation: Results from this collaborative experiment with the construction industry have been used by the Defra waste evidence team for evaluating the use of product service systems in waste policy as part development of the UK Waste Strategy. Dr Nick Blakey nick.blakey@defra.gsi.gov.uk

Title: A systems approach to the policy-level risk assessment of exotic animal diseases: network model and application to classical swine fever.
AdditionalInformation: Developed directly from Defra’s prioritised list of priorities for risk management development (RPV21), this work has been used by Defra's Risk Co-ordinator and presented to the government’s Chief Veterinary advisor to inform disease prevention and control methods. Edgar Black Edgar.Black@defra.gsi.gov.uk

Title: Photocatalytic oxidation of natural organic matter surrogates and the impact on trihalomethane formation potential
AdditionalInformation: The results from this paper were central to the decision by Severn Trent Water to invest long term in the development of novel advanced oxidation processes for treatment of lowland water sources. As a consequence, Severn Trent Water are funding a project (Advanced Oxidation Processes: Implementation and Business Case Development; http://www.stream-idc.net/cohort5projects.php)  with the objective to trial a pilot of an advanced oxidation treatment plant, aiming to build a full scale plant in AMP 7 (Asset Management Plan); Severn Trent contact: Julie Hart, Senior Process Engineer (Julie.hart@severntrent.co.uk).

Title: Comparison of UV/H2O2and UV/TiO2for the degradation of metaldehyde: Kinetics and the impact of background organics
AdditionalInformation: The insights described in this paper have shaped the future direction of development for recalcitrant pesticide removal in real applications, and have informed the design of a novel reactor under development for Severn Trent Water. Severn Trent Water are funding a project (Advanced Oxidation Processess: Implementation and Business Case Development; http://www.stream-idc.net/cohort5projects.php) with the objective to trial a pilot of an advanced oxidation treatment plant, aiming to build a full scale plant in the AMP 7 (Asset Management Plan); Severn Trent contact: Julie Hart, Senior Process Engineer (Julie.hart@severntrent.co.uk).

Title: The impact of background organic matter and alkalinity on the degradation of the pesticide metaldehyde by two advanced oxidation processes: UV/H2O2 and UV/TiO2
AdditionalInformation: Findings enabled the practical design of advanced oxidation processes (AOP) for Metaldehyde removal and led to the decision by Severn Trent Water to develop an AOP solution as part of their pesticide management strategy. Severn Trent Water are funding a project (Advanced Oxidation Processess: Implementation and Business Case Development; http://www.stream-idc.net/cohort5projects.php) with the objective to trial a pilot of an advanced oxidation treatment plant, aiming to build a full scale plant in the AMP 7 (Asset Management Plan); Severn Trent contact: Julie Hart, Senior Process Engineer (Julie.hart@severntrent.co.uk).

Title: The use of contact angle measurements to estimate the adhesion propensity of calcium carbonate to solid substrates in water
AdditionalInformation: Applying the diagnostic approach developed under an EPSRC Platform Grant (GR/S64533/01) led directly to an innovative solution to engineer biofilm activity in rotating biological contactors, which is the focus of a currently active trial within Severn Trent Water (MarkR.Jones@severntrent.co.uk)

Title: High-purity hydrogen via the sorption-enhanced steam methane reforming reaction over a synthetic CaO-based sorbent and a Ni catalyst
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by the Canadian Office of Energy Research and Development (OERD) (Grant CCSI020, $1.8M). The paper is a result of collaborative research between CanmetENERGY and ETH Zurich, and presents a novel method of hydrogen production by employing lime-based sorbents developed at CanmetENERGY and nickel-based catalysts developed by ETH. It is demonstrated that a stream of high-purity hydrogen (99 vol%) can be produced in a SE-SMR process usng these materials. In this way natural gas can be can be efficiently converted into hydrogen, and a high purity CO2 stream (>95 vol%) ready for final sequestration. (Contact jgrace@chbe.ubc.ca).

Title: Spray water reactivation/pelletization of spent CaO-based sorbent from calcium looping cycles
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by the OERD [in full] under a $2.2 M project (grant G30.003). The partners were University of British Columbia, University of Ottawa, EU FP7 CaOling Consortium (http://www.caoling.eu/), Endesa Generacion S.A, Imperial College, Spanish Research Council. The main breakthrough is a unique technique for reactivation of lime-based sorbents for CO2 capture, improving process efficiency by >10% (contact edgardo.coda@fwfin.fwc.com). The method is the subject of a patent application (PCT/CA2013/000656). The technique can be also employed for reactivation and pelletization of sorbents from fluidized bed combustion (FBC) reactors with in situ SO2 capture (contact edgardo.coda@fwfin.fwc.com).

Title: Integration of calcium and chemical looping combustion using composite CaO/CuO-based materials
AdditionalInformation: This paper arises from a $300 k project performed in collaboration with University of Ottawa. The research proposes a new method for CO2 capture by calcium-copper based composite materials with sorbent regeneration by natural gas or syngas. Outputs include a patent application (PCT/CA2012/000647). The method has been adopted and further developed at institutions such as ETH (muelchri@ethz.ch), Queensland University (b.feng@uq.edu.au), University of Cambridge (sas37@cam.ac.uk) and the Spanish Research Council (abanades@incar.csic.es). Grants totalling >$1 M from Canadian Research Councils were won by University of Ottawa and University of Calgary in collaboration with CanmetENERGY to develop the technique to the next stage (jhill@ucalgary.ca).

Title: Thermal activation of CaO-based sorbent and self-reactivation during CO2 capture looping cycles
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by the OERD under a $730 K project, and as a member of an EU FP7 consortium ($6 M total value) which includes Endesa Generacion S.A., Hullaras del Norte S.A., Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas, Foster Wheeeler S.A., Lappeenrannan Teknillinen Yliopisto, Imperial College, University of Stuttgart (http://www.caoling.eu/). The main finding presented is that the activity of calcium-based sorbents can be enhanced in long series of CO2 capture cycles after  pre-treatment at high temperature to give up to 50% higher sorbent CO2 capture activity, which was confirmed at several R&D institutions, e.g. at UBC (jgrace@chbe.ubc.ca).

Title: Investigation of diachronic dietary patterns on the islands of Ibiza and Formentera, Spain: evidence from sulphur stable isotope ratio analysis.
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the first application of sulphur isotopes to understanding the diet and provenance of past populations in Spain. The investigation of sulphur, following a previous study on carbon and nitrogen, was aimed at investigating dietary patterns through time and identifying individuals who had not been born on the island. This study has had an impact to historians and archaeologists researching not only Ibiza but also the Western Mediterranean and it demonstrates the value of using sulphur isotopes to assess immigration in archaeological populations. (contact: Dr Gundula Muldner - University of Reading: g.h.mueldner@reading.ac.uk).

Title: Accurate measurement of the piezoelectric coefficient of thin films by eliminating the substrate bending effect using spatial scanning laser vibrometry
AdditionalInformation: This work developed a new measurement technique with increased throughput via reduced setup time and simplicity of measurement. The technique outlined in the paper has been used by Prof. M Cain (markys.cain@npl.co.uk) and Dr M Stewart (mark.stewart@npl.co.uk), of the functional materials group, NPL, Teddington, to develop this measurement technique as a standard for measuring the piezoelectric coefficient of new thin film materials.

Title: Dynamic operational stress measurement of MEMS using time-resolved Raman spectroscopy
AdditionalInformation: Investigation of induced stress both from a passive and active film has enabled us to develop new techniques to minimize/utilize this stress in the development of novel MEMS devices. The techniques developed are being used in a confidential industrial project with Matthews international, an American multinational, and ImTech technologies LLC (contact bill.buskirk@imtech-or.com) which has been running over 4 years at Cranfield University.

Title: Dimensional reduction study of piezoelectric ceramics constitutive equations from 3-D to 2-D and 1-D
VolumeTitle: IEEE transactions on ultrasonics, ferroelectrics and frequency control
AdditionalInformation: This work highlighted erroneous assumptions in the modeling of piezoelectric materials enabling us to better understand why we see differences between modelling and actual devices. The work has benefited the wider functional material community by highlighting the issues we found in formulae that had been taken as undisputed for half a century.

Title: Impedance measurements for determination of elastic and piezoelectric coefficients of films
AdditionalInformation: This work developed a new technique to measure the piezoelectric properties of thin film materials. Using the values derived from this measurement technique allowed the modelling of MEMS devices to an accuracy previously not achievable without making assumptions based on less than rigorous science.

Title: Transfer of Functional Ceramic Thin Films Using a Thermal Release Process
AdditionalInformation: This joint publication with Imperial College resulted from EPSRC grant EP/D064805/1. The techniques developed allow small footprint capacitors and varactors, that incorporate high dielectric constant materials, to be directly integrated into microwave circuits. This is of interest to companies involved in mobile communications such as Filtronic Comtek who were a project partner in this research. (wolfgang.bosch@filtronic.com and Chris.clifton@eu.sony.com).

Title: Growth and high frequency characterisation of Mn doped sol-gel Pb<sub>x</sub>Sr<sub>1-x</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub> for frequency applications
AdditionalInformation: The research was part of a portfolio of EPSRC grants (EP/D064805/1, EP/D506638/1), researching the application of functional materials for high frequency applications. The finding that tuneable and switchable duplexer filters can be made using an easy-to-prepare material system is of interest to the mobile phone electronics research community. Sony UK and Filtronic Comtek were industrial partners. (wolfgang.bosch@filtronic.com and Chris.clifton@eu.sony.com).

Title: Development of high concentrated aqueous silver dispersion for inkjet printing on ceramic substrates
AdditionalInformation: This research was conducted as part of the “Rolled Multi Material Layered 3D Shaping Technology” FP7 Project: NMP2-LA-2008- 214122 involving ~30 European partners. High Ag content inks were developed enabling thick Ag tracks to be printed with reduced time and increased line resolution. The inks are currently being exploited by project partners, CEA and LeGrand, for the interconnects on a thermoelectric energy harvester luc.federzoni@cea.fr, and Omnisys Instruments developing conductive waveguide tracks for mm-wave Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuits (MMICs) (tp@omnisys.se).

Title: Optimization design of multi-material micropump using finite element method
AdditionalInformation: This research underpinned the design of a piezoelectric micropump having state-of the art specification. Initial design took place through involvement in an FP7 Network of Excellence (http://www.4m-net.org ) in collaboration with the German Fraunhofer EMFT. Based on the design analysis a high-pressure micropump for demanding applications has been developed and is commercially available (http://www.mikroelektronik.fraunhofer.de/en/press-media/microelectronics-news/article/high-pressure-micropump-for-demanding-applications.html ) including application as a micro-dosage system. (Martin.richter@emft.fraunhofer).

Title: Interpreting the formation of bloodstains on selected apparel fabrics
AdditionalInformation: Forensic analysis of blood stains relies on precedent and not scientific theory, potentially causing miscarriages of justice.    The output of this research is a  basis for scientific study of the effect of blood stains on materials.  It forms part of a body of work that resulted in a fully funded invitation by the US government (Federal Bureau of Investigation Laboratory, US, organised by David Baldwin, chair@swgstain.org)  to present an overview of the work to the American blood stain analysis community (SWGSTAIN 2010).

Title: Blast waves from cylindrical charges
AdditionalInformation: TNT equivalency underpins all explosive safety legislation but assumes a spherical charge, despite military charges being cylindrically shaped. This research developed for the first time a simple method of predicting the blast from cylindrical charges.  This and associated work has resulted in sponsorship for follow-on research projects projects from AWE (Ruth.Cheesman@awe.co.uk), MOD-DOSG (Phil Pitcher, MOD -  DESNAG-Exp4@mod.uk) and Wallop Defence Systems Ltd (Les.Gibbons@wallopdefence.com) and a separate contract from AWE to determine the TNT equivalency of non-spherical charges of High Explosives, propellants and pyrotechnics. The results are used to assess the risks of storage and transport of explosives (Ruth.Cheesman@awe.co.uk).

Title: Development of a computer model to predict risks from an electrical bushing failure
AdditionalInformation: Sponsored by National Grid, this research is the first time that the risks from electrical bushing failures have been quantified.  For the first time techniques for modelling civilian explosions in metallic containers were applied to pressurized porcelain vessels. The results now form part of National Grid’s safety case for electrical sub-stations (Gordon Wilson gordon.wilson@uk.ngrid.com). Follow-on research has been funded by National Grid to develop safety netting for use at electrical substations to prevent injury to personnel (contact as above).

Title: Effect of core size and ground surface on debris fields of failed electric bushings
AdditionalInformation: A previous assessment of the risks from electrical bushing failures by Cranfield University demonstrated to National Grid that there were risks in personnel working too close to electrical bushings.  The work in this paper gave National Grid, for the first time, a quantified analysis of the mitigation techniques they could use.  The results have helped National Grid determine the best ground surface to use at their substations.  The results are now incorporated into National Grid’s safety case analysis for electrical substations (Gordon Wilson gordon.wilson@uk.ngrid.com).

Title: Potential energy savings by application of the novel CRIMSON aluminium casting process
AdditionalInformation: Development of novel casting process to save energy; collaboration between Aeromet International plc, C-Tech Innovation Ltd., Ford Motor Co. Ltd, Global TCT Ltd, Grainger & Worral Ltd, N-Tech Ltd., TSC Ltd., Cast Metals Federation, funded by EPSRC grant (EP/G060096). (johnparker@cmfed.co.uk), Martin Wood, Grainger&Worrall). Led to application of energy saving techniques by Aeromet in real components, doubling casting yield (Bill Stott, Aeromet). Invited papers including the World Foundry Congress, Monterrey, Mexico, 2012 (“Energy Saving in the Foundry Industry by using the CRIMSON Single Shot up-Casting Process”, MR Jolly, X Dai and B Zeng) and paper in International Foundry Trade Journal.

Title: A multiple-gate runner system for gravity casting
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new technique to make more reliable castings by reducing oxide film defects. The method is currently being used in production plants in Taiwan (Auspicium Co. Ltd, auspicium@msa.hinet.net ). The work forms the foundation for current research on reducing defects by changing geometry. (Dr F-Y Hsu, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National United University, Taiwan).

Title: The modelling of oxide film entrainment in casting systems using computational modelling
AdditionalInformation: Results from a project partially supported by the Torr Lodge & Applecross Trust for the UK foundry industry. Defects in cast metals are a major cost in manufacturing and methodologies for tracking stuck defects are widely sought by the CFD community. Software companies MAGMAsoft (Jorg.Sturm@magmasoft.de) and Flow3D (Tom Jensen, tsj@flow3d.com) supported the work by providing licences. Both are now incorporating results of this research into their products.

Title: Surface oxide film entrainment mechanisms in shape casting running systems
VolumeTitle: Metallurgical and Materials Transactions B-Process Metallurgy and Materials
AdditionalInformation: Algorithms devised are now being used in research by a group at the University of British Columbia (Steve Cockcroft, Steve. Cockcroft@ubc.ca), and at DePuy Johnson and Johnson, Cork (Alan Kavanagh akavanag@ITS.JNJ.COM) to investigate oxide defects in Cast CoCrMo knee implants, leading to further publications including “Advancing current materials and methods used in the Investment Casting of COBALT prosthesis”, M Jolly, G Dooley, A Kavanagh, 13th World Conference on Investment Casting,  Kyoto, Japan April 2012, and 3 US Investment Casting Institute publications. (http://www.investmentcasting.org/paper_detail.asp?PaperID=960).

Title: Microstructure simulation and ballistic behaviour of weld zones in friction stir welds in high strength aluminium 7xxx plate
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation:
This paper formed part of the output of the Cranfield University Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre under the project FUSEA3.  The other members of the project consortium were ALCOA, BAE Systems, and Manchester University.  The project  was sponsored by an MOD-EPSRC collaborative  scheme which was performed in collaboration with LATEST; (Light Alloys Towards Environmentally Sustainable Transport EP/D029201/1) EP/G022402/1). 
The work outlined in this paper provides insight into the mechanical and ballistic properties of weld metal between thick aluminium sections.  This knowledge is vital in the design of military vehicles to ensure crew safety when subject to ballistic or blast loading.

Title: Causes of scatter in high rate fracture testing of polymers
AdditionalInformation: This research forms part of a work activity of Technical Committee 4 of the European Structural Integrity Society, which is drafting a potential ISO standard for high rate impact testing of polymers [Prof J G Williams g.williams@imperial.ac.uk]. This activity within the committee is being is led by Cranfield University in collaboration with Università degli Studi di Brescia, Montanuniversität Leoben, Ploitechnico di Milano and Imperial College London.  The paper deals with issues raised from the second international round robin to trial a draft standard. The results are being adopted in a future round robin development on the roadmap towards an ISO standard submission (g.williams@imperial.ac.uk).

Title: Face, neck, and eye protection: adapting body armour to counter the changing patterns of injuries on the battlefield
VolumeTitle: British Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an early part of the work in a larger DSTL programme to improve the neck protection of troops in current operations.   This has resulted in a new design of ballistic collar which is undergoing user trials within MOD DE&S (contact email available on request).  The research was performed in collaboration between Cranfield University and the Royal Centre for Defence Medicine.

Title: Protecting the extremities of military personnel: fragment protective performance of one- and two-layer ensembles
AdditionalInformation: The key finding of this work is that very lightweight armour can provide significant levels of protection to the body’s extremities even though its performance is less than traditional heavier  armour.  This research has led to two further research projects at Cranfield sponsored by DSTL ('Optimisation of Fragment Protective Properties of Body Armour' and  'Environmental Degradation of Body Armour' total £125K). The results have been adopted in military procurement efforts for improved combat clothing.

Title: Characterization and application of anion exchange polymer membranes with non-platinum group metals for fuel cells
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part A: Journal of Power and Energy
AdditionalInformation: This research was an EPSRC funded collaboration between Cranfield University, Newcastle University, Surrey University and Imperial College (grants refs EP/FO26633(CU), EP/FO2658X, EP/FO27524 & EP/FO35764) and included partners DSTL, the University of Science and Technology at Hefei, China (UST) and Sun Yat-Sen University, China. Prior to this, solid polymer fuel cells were based around proton exchange membranes whose cost is a major inhibitor to commercialisation. This project investigated the possibility of developing an alkaline equivalent, offering a number of significant advantages, including faster cell reactions, cheaper catalysts, non-fluorinated ionomers and more favourable water transport. Contact Dr Robert Reeve: RWREEVE@mail.dstl.gov.uk

Title: Radiation grafted membranes for superior anion exchange polymer membrane fuel cells performance
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a further output of an EPSRC funded collaboration between Cranfield University, Newcastle University, Surrey University and Imperial College (grant refs EP/FO26633(CU), EP/FO2658X, EP/FO27524 & EP/FO35764) and included partners DSTL, the University of Science and Technology at Hefei, China (UST) and Sun Yat-Sen University, China (SYS). Prior to this, solid polymer fuel cells were based around proton exchange membranes whose cost is a major inhibitor to commercialisation. This project investigated the possibility of developing an alkaline equivalent, offering a number of significant advantages, including faster cell reactions, cheaper catalysts, non-fluorinated ionomers and more favourable water transport. Contact: Dr Robert Reeve: RWREEVE@mail.dstl.gov.uk

Title: Substantial pyroelectric effect enhancement in laminated composites
AdditionalInformation: This research, partially funded by the EPSRC (EP/D506638/1), demonstrated a substantial enhancement of the pyroelectric effect, achievable via a secondary contribution by materials engineering, in contrast to a widely held belief that the secondary contribution is limited. This result led to further research funding from EPSRC (EP/G013934/1), and benefits the research community working on basic (r.whatmore@imperial.ac.uk) and applied (reinhard.lerch@lse.eei.uni-elangen.de )  research in pyroelectric materials.

Title: High intensity electron emission from ferroelectric cathode induced by a pyroelectric crystal
AdditionalInformation: Funded by the EPSRC (EP/G013934/1), this work reports a novel mechanism to produce high intensity and high energy electron beams, which has led to ongoing collaborations with Imperial Innovations Ltd (l.mcgregor@imperial.co.uk) and  Oxford Instruments (andy.ellis@oxinst.com ), to develop new portable, ultra-compact and high energy X-Ray devices based on this mechanism.

Title: Strong electron and ion emissions induced by a pyroelectric crystal
AdditionalInformation: Funded by the EPSRC (EP/G013934/1), this work looked at optimisation of device configuration for the production of high energy and high intensity electron beams by changing the temperature of pyroelectric crystals. This work has led to ongoing collaborative efforts with Imperial Innovations Ltd (l.mcgregor@imperial.co.uk) and  Oxford Instruments (andy.ellis@oxinst.com ) to develop portable, ultra-compact and high energy X-Ray devices.

Title: Pyroelectric coefficient difference under open and short circuit conditions and their enhancements in laminate composites
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by EPSRC grants (EP/D506638/1 and EP/G013934/1), in collaboration with Meggit Ferroperm Piezoceramics A/S (Dr. Karsten Hansen, Karsten.Hansen@meggit.com),  with supports from Provibtech (DL@provibtech.com).

Title: Molten salt synthesis of PZT powder for direct write inks
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This work has been used in the synthesis of ceramic materials, including lead free piezoelectrics, (Arthur  Barlow: Arthur.Barlow@excelitas.com), and has increased understanding of stable ink formulations for particle-based manufacturing techniques. The work underpins our continuing TSB/technology transfer funded research with European Thermodynamics (Screen Printed BiTe Thermoelectric Devices, project number: 131088). Inks using our techniques for printing thermoelectric devices have recently been shown by European Thermodynamics to offer performance similar to hand assembled commercial bulk devices. European thermodynamics Ltd - kevin@etdyn.com

Title: Formation of PZT crack-free thick films by electrohydrodynamic atomization deposition
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: Outputs from this work, and recent advances on heat treatment also developed in our group, are being applied to the creation of acoustic emission structural health monitoring (AE-SHM) systems and thermoelectric energy harvesting structures, both having properties comparable with commercially available bulk devices. Contact: European Thermodynamics Ltd (ETD) - kevin@etdyn.com. Crack-free thick films are key to thermoelectric device printing for companies such as ETD. This work led to invited talks at HyperNano 2012 (IET, London, Savoy Place), and MACH 2012 (Manufacturing Technologies seminar, Birmingham, UK) on Sensors for harsh environments.

Title: Formation of PZT micro-scale structures using electrohydrodynamic atomization filling of metallic moulds
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation:
The work led to a new patterning technique, and novel design and processing for the creation of metal-ceramic hybrid microdevices, enabling significant simplification of the electrical interconnections of complex sensors. A micro-coordinate measurement probe, developed in collaboration with the National Physical Laboratory (UK), is now being developed as a commercial product (Richard Leach, richard.leach@npl.co.uk). 
The work led to invited talks at HyperNano 2012 (IET, London, Savoy Place) on Integrated structural health monitoring, and MACH 2012 (Manufacturing Technologies seminar, Birmingham, UK) on Sensors for harsh environments.

Title: Molten hydroxide synthesis as an alternative to molten salt sythesis for producing K<sub>0.5</sub>Na<sub>0.5</sub>NbO<sub>3</sub> lead free ceramics
AdditionalInformation:
This technique is being exploited to create fine, lead free ceramic powders for use in piezoelectric micro devices, both at Cranfield and at the Laboratory for High Performance Ceramics, EMPA, Switzerland. 
Francesca.Bortolani@empa.ch
Recent developments allow a greatly reduced sintering temperature, with levels of volatile elements maintained to retain functional properties. This has been applied to piezoelectric and thermoelectric materials for solar energy technology (Multipurpose Applications by Thermodynamic Solar
http://www.mats.enea.it/index.htm)
and also shows promise in controlling film composition. (fabrizio.fabrizi@enea.it)

Title: Problems in using a comb sample as a stress-free reference for the determination of welding residual stress by diffraction
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: An outcome from WELDES research programme, [EPSRC grant no. GR/N14293/01], investigating the durability of welded aircraft assemblies. The research was also applied in the Keeping Nuclear Option Open (KNOO) project [EPSRC grant no. EP/C549465/1]; The paper benefits the stress measurement community, who use neutron and synchrotron X-rays for experimental determination of residual stress state (contact Dr Joe Kelleher, Instrument scientist at ENGIN-X, joe.kelleher@stfc.ac.uk).

Title: Analysis of residual stress in metal-inert-gas-welded Al-2024 using neutron and synchrotron X-ray diffraction
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: This work was performed within the WELDES (Durability of welded aircraft assemblies) programme [EPSRC grant no. GR/N14293/01].The data were used to supplement modelling results on fatigue crack growth. Such data are vital for aerospace industries in order to create damage tolerant structures. Contact Dr Robert Maziarz of Airbus, UK (Robert.maziarz@airbus.com)

Title: Comparison of joining efficiency and residual stresses in laser and laser hybrid welding
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation:
This work was supported by an EPSRC platform grant  EP/E001874/1. The laser-arc hybrid process can achieve an order of magnitude improvement in productivity, without compromise in quality, by utilising the complementary characteristics of arc and laser technologies. The outputs from this paper were used in:
‘Laser – Hybrid Welding of Pipeline Steels’, sponsored by the Materials Innovation Institute, Netherlands, [project no. – M31.8.12461], with TU Delft as academic and Heerema Marine Corp. as industrial partners (contact Dr Bagus Yudidobroto byudodibroto@hmc-heerema.com).

Title: Characterisation of residual stress state in laser welded low carbon mild steel plates produced in keyhole and conduction mode
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation: The paper investigated the residual stress magnitude from two modes of welding. The work was supported by an EPSRC platform grant, EP/E001874/1. The research has the potential to benefit the industrial laser processing community  by improving their understanding of process selection for critical structural welding applications, contact Dr John Powell JPowell@laserexp.co.uk.

Title: RFID Opportunity Analysis Toolset for Leaner Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation:
This work was funded under EU FP6 framework (Grant number 33546, EUR 7,500,000).  The work was carried out in collaboration with Nestle UK, and achieved major quantifiable improvements in reducing the time, material and transport waste generated by untraceable operations in coffee and confectionery production (up to 30% reduction in waste), (Paul Roberts, paul.roberts@uk.nestle.com).

Invited for interview with Cambridge Radio, Euronews and Portugese national TV.

http://www.commentvisions.com/Print.aspx?id=41, 

http://www.rfidjournal.com/articles/view?5183, 

http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Business/Business-News/Curing-ham-gets-more-lean.htm

Title: Behaviour adaptation in the multi-agent, multi-objective and multi role supply chain
AdditionalInformation:
This work was funded under EU FP6 framework (Grant number 33546, EUR 7,500,000), to investigate the need for integrated optimization algorithms, allowing mid-tier suppliers to effectively navigate the complexity of the supply networks in which they are embedded. 
The results of this work were incorporated in the Supply Chain Management module given to MSc students at Cranfield University, which has up to 90% of students entering industry after graduation.

Title: Designing automated auction mechanisms for service procurement
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Computational Intelligence and AI in Games
AdditionalInformation: The project was carried out in collaboration with the Boeing Company, and analysed how the supplier – buyer matchmaking process could be made traceable and optimal in the aerospace maintenance sector, enabling the inclusion of multiple supplier and buyer selection criteria to be brought together in one algorithm. (Mr. Kenneth Owens, Boeing R&D Seattle). The work led to a patent application: Double auctions using Analytical Hierarchy Process for supplier selection EFS 10532379.

Title: Microstructure and residual stress improvement in wire and arc additively manufactured parts through high-pressure rolling
AdditionalInformation: This work resulted in a patent (GB1209562.6).  The technique has subsequently been applied to titanium additively manufactured parts through a project sponsored by EADS Innovation Works (c. £120,000).  This has drastically refined the microstructure resulting in a 15% improvement in static properties and a reduction in anisotropy from over 40% to less than 1% for elongation, potentially enabling mechanical property performance parity with existing products, which has not been previously possible with additive manufacture processes.  Contact Mr. Jonathan Meyer of EADS (jonathan.meyer@eads.com).

Title: High pressure rolling of low carbon steel weld seams: Part 2 - Roller geometry and residual stress
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation:
This work was funded from EPSRC grant EP/G014132/1, and Tata Steel.  Understanding how rolling affects the residual stress and distortion of a welded joint led to further research fro industry including:



•	Application to aerospace panels, where distortion was eliminated and the rolling load minimised. Contact Gary Moore at Bombardier Aerospace (gary.moore@aero.bombardier.com).



•	Application to a laser clad security panel which enabled distortion to be minimised. Contact Paul Goodwin at Laser Cladding Technologies (p.goodwin@lasercladding.co.uk).

Title: Liquation and post-weld heat treatment cracking in Rene 80 laser repair welds
AdditionalInformation: This work was sponsored by Doncasters and resolved conflicting findings in the literature on laser welding. The work led to the demonstration of a new repair method combining a laser treatment with subsequent hot isostatic pressing (HIP) process. Contact: Dr. Zhu Zhang of Doncasters (zzhang@doncasters.com).

Title: Energy and force analysis of linear friction welds in medium carbon steel
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to accurately determine the energy input from linear friction weld machine data, enabling the minimisation of energy input and environmental impact of the process.  The work led to a follow-on project at Cranfield, jointly sponsored by The Welding Institute, Boeing and the EPSRC, which has extended the work to titanium alloys, using numerical modelling to optimise the process and identify the conditions for defect free welds. Contact: Dr. Mike Russell of TWI (mike.russell@twi.co.uk) and David Bolser (david.r.bolser@boeing.com).

Title: A3 thinking approach to support knowledge-driven design
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted in a new problem-solving approach that the collaborating company (Visteon) used to solve numerous Electromagnetic Compatibility design problems. The company adopted part of the work to enhance their current practices of design problem solving. The research was part of the EU-PF7 project called LeanPPD (contract No. NMP-2008-214090). Industrial contacts: Amin Kassam akassam@visteon.com and Paul Ewers pewers1@visteon.com.

Title: Towards lean product and process development
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This is a result of European and industrial collaborations within the LeanPPD project funded by the FP7 grant NMP-2008-214090. The research developed a novel engineering process model in a knowledge-based environment that enhances product development productivity and innovation. This led to further collaboration with Rolls-Royce Jon Parsons (Jonathan.Parsons@Rolls-Royce.com), Visteon Engineering Service Paul Ewers (pewers1@visteon.com), Airbus Mark SUMMERS <Mark.Summers@airbus.com>, GETRAG-Germany Matthias  Hess (mhess19@getrag-ford.com) and Sitech-Poland Robert Sulowski <robert.sulowski.SITECH@volkswagen.de>. The work has also been the foundation for winning new TSB funding (CONGA project) of 3.5 million where the share to Cranfield is £421k.

Title: Knowledge based environment to support product design validation
AdditionalInformation: This is a result of a collaboration with Visteon Engineering Service in a real industrial environment. The practical approach, addressing current issues in the company and using the company's own IT-Platform, led to further collaboration with Visteon supporting EMC design (Electromagnetic Compatibility) and new A4 thinking for solving EMC design problems. Contact in Visteon related to KBE is Mr. Martin Molyneaux, (M.D.) mmolyne1@visteon.com and related to EMC are Aminmohamed Kassam akassam@visteon.com and Mark Stubberfield  mstubber@visteon.com.

Title: An analogy based estimation framework for design rework efforts
AdditionalInformation: This work offers time and cost savings in design, through the ability to predicate potential design re-work without the need for additional testing. This industry-based work has helped us to formulate our work related to Set-Based Concurrent Engineering as part of the LeanPPD European project (PF7).  Contact in Sitech-Poland is Mr. Robert Sulowski, robert.sulowski.SITECH@volkswagen.de.

Title: Zero carbon manufacturing facility - towards integrating material, energy, and waste process flows
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B-Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The research combined energy and resource process flows for the first time, for the Airbus next generation composite wing programme, and resulted in simulation software developed under a £623k TSB THERM (THrough-life Energy & Resource Modelling) (TS/H001565/1) collaboration between Airbus, Cranfield, De Montfort, Integrated Engineering Services Ltd. and Toyota.The software was deployed at both Airbus and Toyota (Project manager peter.lunt@airbus, Industrial Performance, Airbus), and was commended in the Energy Efficiency category Rushlight Awards (http://www.rushlightevents.com/rushlight-awards/background/roll-of-honour/).

Title: Industrial ecology at factory level: a conceptual model
AdditionalInformation: First application of industrial ecology at factory level. The work was the foundation for modelling buildings and production systems in the same simulation software tool. Implemented in IES Ltd’s Virtual Environment (VE) modelling product (craig.wheatley@iesve.com, Director, IES Ltd) in 2012 resulting in a beta product with global launch expected 2014.

Title: Steps towards sustainable manufacturing through modelling material, energy and waste flows
AdditionalInformation: A sustainable manufacturing improvement methodology to identify resource efficiency opportunities in factories. Applicable at factory shopfloor level without the need for specialist software. Demonstrated in Edwards Ltd to identify cost and energy reduction opportunities (e.g. €115k/yr saving in coolant projected in case company)  (leigh.smith@edwardsvacuum.com, Section Head, MED NPI - Scientific Pumps, Edwards).

Title: Sustainable manufacturing tactics and cross-functional factory modelling
AdditionalInformation: This is the first time an improvement methodology for reducing factory resource consumption has been embedded in software, under TSB project (THrough-life Energy & Resource Modelling) (TS/H001565/1), £623k. The work supported industrial energy reduction of 5.5GWh per year (or the avoidance of producing over 2,000 tCO2), and a reduction in operating cost of around €400k. Contact steve.hope@toyota-europe.com General Manager, Environmental Affairs and Corporate Citizenship; peter.lunt@airbus.com, Project Leader - Industrial Performance.

Title: Inter-species variation in bone mineral behavior upon heating
AdditionalInformation: As a result of this research, a 2008 Ludo Frevel Crystallography Scholarship (Beckett) was awarded by the International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD). The results led to authorship (Beckett) of book-section (7.3 Other Analytical Techniques, in Marquez-Grant, Roberts (eds) Forensic Ecology Handbook: from Crime Scene to Court, Developments in Forensic Science, 2012). A second output was an international collaboration between Cranfield University and the University of Melbourne to further develop the application of X-ray diffraction to osteoporosis research (EPSRC EP/K020196 Point of Care high accuracy fracture risk prediction, £766k).

Title: Bone mineral crystallisation kinetics
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science-Materials in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This work is the first time biological apatite kinetics have been measured along different crystallographic directions. Invite (Greenwood) to join team using beam-time at Diamond Light Source (SM7385). Collaboration with the Natural History Museum, London, for the development of anorganic bone analogues. (Dr Kyriaki Skartsila, k.skartsila@nhm.ac.uk). Research led to follow-on collaboration with Leeds University in the application of a novel approach of XRD analysis during dynamic heating (Dr Tim Comyn, t.p.comyn@leeds.ac.uk). Another output was collaboration with the Science and Technology Facilities Council to investigate material properties of bone types with differing collagen-mineral ratios (Kevin Buckley, kevin.buckley@stfc.ac.uk).

Title: Contrasting the crystallinity indicators of heated and diagenetically altered bone mineral
AdditionalInformation: Research lead to the oral presentation of results at the 2010 Denver X-ray Conference, USA (Beckett). A new collaboration has been established with the Oxford University Research Laboratory for Archaeology & the History of Art through a project adopting these techniques for investigation of mammoth and cow bone (Dr Fiona Brock, Fiona.brock@rlaha.ox.ac.uk).

Title: Composition of uroliths in small domestic animals in the United Kingdom
AdditionalInformation: This research results from establishment of the largest archive of domestic animal urinary stones in Europe. It led to an analysis service for urinary stones in domestic and non-domestic animals (otters, shark, and penguin) treated by UK veterinary surgeons. The methods have been adopted in a collaboration established with Sedgeford Historical and Archaeological Research Project for analysis of Anglo-Saxon urinary stone (earliest known in the UK). Results published in journal (Beckett, 2008) and a presentation at British Association for Advancement of Science, Festival of Science (Liverpool 2008) where it was awarded the Presentation of Heritage Research Prize.

Title: Thermal modeling of the material removal rate and surface roughness for die-sinking EDM
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: The model of the Electrical Discharge Machining process developed in this paper, has attracted industrial interest (e.g. Bazigos SA - k.bazigos@bazigosmolds.com - a mould and die machining SME) for predicting surface finish and process duration.

Title: Grinding wheel effect in the grind-hardening process
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: An output from an international collaboration between Cranfield, several European universities, and industrial partners (FIAT, DANOBAT, TYROLIT, Saitn Gobain) funded by the EU and European Social Fund Operational Program for Educational and Vocational Training II. The research insights (energy efficient grinding processes, allowing the reduction of carbon footprint of manufactured products) developed in this work led to several industrial projects with DANOBAT (a machine tool manufacturer) on control of the grind-hardening process (IDEKO research director: Joseba Perez Bilbatua jperez@ideko.es. IDEKO being the R&D department for the DANOBAT group).

Title: Theoretical and experimental investigation of pulsed laser grooving process
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: The outcome of this research (modeling methods for estimating the depth of groove in laser grooving process) contributed to the establishment of co-operative links with Prima Industries and Centro Riserche Fiat (CRF). A successful joint research proposal was funded by the EC under a 'Factories of the Future' (FOF) call. ENEPLAN contract no: 285461. (Contact: paolo.calefati@primapower.com).

Title: Optical emissions for monitoring of the percussion laser drilling process
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: The research was funded by Greek National and EU Community Funds (project no 03ED757). The outcome of this research (laser drilling process technologies and algorithms, allowing more accurate control of the process), contributed to the establishment of co-operative links with Prima Industries and Centro Riserche Fiat (CRF). A successful joint research proposal was funded by the EC under a 'Factories of the Future' (FOF) call. ENEPLAN contract no: 285461. (Contact: paolo.calefati@primapower.com).

Title: Optimal burn-in and preventive maintenance warranty strategies with time-dependent maintenance costs
AdditionalInformation: This research investigated optimal maintenance strategies to prolong the useful lifetime of complex systems while reducing their failure rates. The research was joint work with Prof. Maxim Finkelstein (finkelM@ufs.ac.za, Free State University, South Africa) and Prof. Ming Zuo (mzuo@ualberta.ca, University of Alberta, Canada) and was partially supported by Chalmers University of Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden, during (Prof. Michael Patriksson, mipat@chalmers.se).

Title: On the investment in a reliability improvement program for warranted second-hand items
AdditionalInformation: This study supports dealers’ decision making on whether and how much to invest in reliability improvement programs. The research was partially supported by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC). The paper was nominated as the best paper in reliability, and acknowledged by Editor-in Chief (Prof. Susan Albin, salbin@rci.rutgers.edu, Rutgers University, USA), in American IE Magazine, June 2011.

Title: On optimal upgrade level for used products under given cost structures
AdditionalInformation: This research was partially supported by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC).

Title: Modeling and analysis of effective ways for improving the reliability of second-hand products sold with warranty
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: In this research, we introduced two effective ways to improve the reliability of second-hand systems. The research was joint work with Prof. Mohammad Saidi-Mehrabad (mehrabad@iust.ac.ir) and Prof. Rassoul Noorossana (rassoul@iust.ac.ir) at Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran, and was partially supported by Makita electric company.

Title: An innovative cost modelling system to support lean productand process development
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: An output from an EU-FP7 project: contract number NMP-2008–214090. Total funding € 7,658,978. The major industrial partners are Rolls-Royce, Volkswagen, SITECH, Visteon and Indesit. The system developed under the project is being employed by the design team of SITECH, Poland to provide cost-based decisions during the early design stage. (Contact: Mr. Robert Sulowski, robert.sulowski.SITECH@volkswagen.de).

Title: Towards an operations strategy for product-centric servitization
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Operations and Production Management
AdditionalInformation: This study, which captures the key characteristics of operations for product-centric servitized manufacture, led to an invited key note lecture at the Digital Enterprise Technology (DET) 2009 conference, University of Hong Kong (contact:George Huang,gqhuang@hku.hk). It was an EPSRC/ Cranfield IMRC project in Product-Service Systems (PSS). (Total funding £368,213), carried out with industrial collaborators Lockheed Martin UK, Rolls-Royce, MAN (Truck & Bus), Caterpillar, Alstom (Train Life services) and XEROX.

Title: Enhancement of the Product Information Collaboration and Access in the Aerospace Industry
AdditionalInformation: This research project was fully funded by Airbus (Project code: WK2/WK32228V). The company has implemented the research results, to enhance integration and collaboration of its suppliers, reducing the product development cycle and ensuring improved quality of manufactured components. (Contact: Dr. Chris Fowler, chris.fowler@airbus.com). The research has led to a further collaboration with Airbus in the area of ICT extended enterprise (contact as above).

Title: A prediction system for assessing customer affordability of whole life cycle cost in defence industry
AdditionalInformation: This was a first study in the area of affordability engineering in the defence industry, forming part of an EPSRC/IMRC project: EP/E001874/1, total funding: £565,595. Collaborators were BAE Systems, Smiths Aerospace, Lockheed Martin UK, MoD, Rolls-Royce, Galorath, Cognition, the Association of Proposal Management Professonals, and the Society of British Aerospace Companies. The outcome of the study is being validated in BAE Systems, MOD and Rolls-Royce (Contact: Mr. Phil Wardle Ex BAE Systems: philip.284wardle@btinternet.com).

Title: Electrolytic in-process dressing superfinishing of spherical bearings using metal-resin bond ultra-fine CBN wheels
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B-Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Reports how a research technology, originally investigated for optics fabrication, was revised to assist fabrication of ultra-smooth bearing components. Surface roughness improvements from a typical 20 nm down to 1-4 nm were obtained, proving operational applicability of this electro-chemo-mechanical process for fabrication of advanced bearing performance.  The work was funded by UK bearing manufacturer; NMB - Minebea. Subsequent development and production demonstrated that reduced roughness led directly to improved lifetime of bearings produced. Steve Essam Head of Production, NMB - Minebea, steve.essam@nmb-minebea.com.

Title: Grinding metre scale mirror segments for the E-ELT ground based telescope
AdditionalInformation: An output from long-term research to create a rapid, free-form optics grinding technology: designed, developed and operated at Cranfield. The programme was funded by the RCUK (GR/S85337/01, £2.1m) and EPSRC (EP/F031416/1 £0.67m). The first mirror segments of the ESO Extremely Large Telescope were produced at Cranfield, and ESO’s ELT submission proposal to the EU, to create the world’s largest telescope, identifies the Cranfield BoX® (large optics grinding machine) as capable of delivering the 700+ mirrors for the ELT.  Contact: Marc Cayrel Head of Optomechanics ESO, mcayrel@eso.org. BoX® patents and trademark are exploited by Loxham Precision Limited, contact Chris.Price@loxhamprecision.com.

Title: Rapid optical surface figuring using reactive atom plasma
VolumeTitle: Precision Engineering-Journal of the International Societies for Precision
AdditionalInformation: Reports the proving of a rapid plasma figuring technology for large scale ultra-precise freeform optics, funded by RCUK GR/S85337/01, £2.1m and EPSRC grants EP/F031416/1, EP/E001874/1, EP/H003258/1 totalling £2.47m. Proving of the system led to commercial involvement with SSTL, Astrium, Boostec and G&H. Applications include: earth space observer/telescope optics, high power laser lenses and lithography optics. Additionally a space systems collaboration project with the French Space Agency has been secured, contact Michel Bourgoin, Business Space Manager, michel.bougoin@mersen.com, and a Reactive Atom Plasma (RAP)  technology advancement for industrial film processing secured: EPSRC funding EP/I033491/1, £5.8m.

Title: Reactive Atom Plasma (RAP) Figuring Machine for Meter Class Optical Surfaces
VolumeTitle: Production engineering : research and development in Germany
AdditionalInformation: Reports the creation of a unique ultra-precision large freeform optics energy beam production machine, funded by RCUK GR/S85337/01, £2.1m, EPSRC EP/F031416/1 £0.67m and EP/E001874/1 £0.6m. The machine employs a novel process stemming from a Cranfield partnership with the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. It operates at atmospheric pressure, hugely reducing operational costs, and produces < 30nm form optics with processing times <1/10 that for ion beam or polishing systems. This system equipped Cranfield to compete within international fusion, space and astronomy science programmes. Gooch and Housego are investigating Reactive Atom Plasma (RAP) applications with high technology optics. Contact p.mackay@goochand housego.com

Title: Radiocarbon-based chronology for dynastic Egypt
AdditionalInformation: This paper contained the first scientific verification for the ancient Egyptian Dynastic chronology, until now based on ancient texts and archaeology. Since the Egyptian chronology forms the backbone for all Near Eastern chronology, the impact stretches across the whole of the Near East. The results were disseminated at a specially convened international conference in the Ashmolean Museum (March 2010), sponsored by the British Academy (Grant CSG55318). They were widely reported in scientific magazines (eg http://www.nature.com/news/2010/100617/full/news.2010.304.html, http://news.discovery.com/history/ancient-egypt-radiocarbon-dating.htm) national and international broadsheets (Independent 18.06.10, New York Times 21.06.10). The project led to a Leverhulme Research Grant (F/08 622/B, £170,550)

Title: An absolute chronology for early Egypt using radiocarbon dating and Bayesian statistical modelling
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A-Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sc
AdditionalInformation: This research pinpointed the start of Ancient Egyptian civilisation, giving a scientific absolute date for the first time. It has important implications for the timing of state formation throughout the ancient world (contact details: Michael.dee@rlaha.ox.ac.uk). The work was widely reported in  Nature (http://www.natureworldnews.com/articles/3834/20130905/researchers-develop-new-timeline-egypts-first-dynasty.htm - 05.09.13), New Scientist (http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn24145-carbon-dating-shows-ancient-egypts-rapid-expansion.html#.UlUaxxZeIQ0 - 04.09.13), the Independent (http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/new-date-established-for-the-origin-of-ancient-egypt-8798483.html - 04.09.13),  other national and international newspapers and the Today Programme (e.g. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-23947820). It led  to the successful application for a further Leverhulme grant for work in this area (Leverhulme Fellowship £87,000)

Title: Characterization of 18th Century Meissen porcelain using SEM-EDS
AdditionalInformation: The paper resulted from a research collaboration with Bonhams auction house, London. It enables ancient artefacts to be properly attributed and led to an increase in the use of scientific analysis in the auction process, which is now routine for the first time (Sebastian.Kuhn@bonhams.com). This greatly assists Bonhams and increasingly other auction houses (Sothebys and Christies). The results were widely reported in the art press, http://www.antiquestradegazette.com/news/2011/may/23/bonhams-announce-partnership-with-cranfield-university-to-help-identify-fakes/, http://international.exibart.com/news/articolo.php?id_cat=42&id_news=667). The research resulted in a further research collaboration with Bonhams, adopting the principles for analysis of Chinese porcelain. The work won a major International Award from the Giacometti Foundation for combating art crimes (http://www.antiquestradegazette.com/news/2012/may/08/international-recognition-for-cranfield-fakes-project/)

Title: The provenancing of ochres from the Neolithic Temple Period in Malta
AdditionalInformation: This research  was the first to investigate the use of ochre in Maltese Neolithic Temples, where it is an  important ritual feature. These temples are world heritage sites, and unusually allowed access to their stores and the temples themselves, indicating the significance of the research. The results showing that the ochre was of local origin changed the accepted paradigm for ochre sources and has had an impact on the interpretation of ritual use of the temples.

Title: Fireside corrosion of superheaters: Effects of air and oxy-firing of coal and biomass
AdditionalInformation: This paper was one of several produced during the second phase of EPSRC project SUPERGEN 2 - Conventional Power Plant Lifetime Extension Consortium (EP/F029748/1). Results have been used in a TSB project (TP/5/MAT/6/I/H0639C, with E.ON, RWE, Doosan Power and NPL) to develop improved models for corrosion of superheaters/reheaters in conventional power plants using new fuel mixes (Colin Davis, Colin.Davis@eon.com; Tony Fry, tony.fry@npl.co.uk). The methods developed will also support research under a new EPSRC project (FLEX-E-PLANT, EP/K021095/1) co-funded by 16 industrial partners (Colin Davis, Colin.Davis@eon.com;  Jeff Hulance, JEFF.HULANCE@RWEnpower.com; Gordon McColvin, gordon.mccolvin@power.alstom.com).

Title: Deposit formation and emissions from co-firing miscanthus with daw mill coal: Pilot plant experiments
AdditionalInformation: A paper generated under the second phase of the EPSRC SUPERGEN 'Biomass Biofuels and Energy Crops Consortium' (EP/E039995/1), and building on research developments from the first phase (GR/S28204/01). Results have supported a TSB project (TP/5/MAT/6/I/H0639C, Modelling Fireside Corrosion of Heat Exchanger Materials in Advanced Energy Systems) in validating theoretical models of new fuel mixes in conventional power plants (Colin Davis, Colin.Davis@eon.com; Toby Lant, TobyP.Lant@centrica.com). Further developments will form part of a new EPSRC project (FLEX-E-PLANT, EP/K021095/1) co-funded by 16 industrial partners (e.g., Colin Davis, Colin.Davis@eon.com; Toby Lant, TobyP.Lant@centrica.com; Tony Fry, tony.fry@npl.co.uk).

Title: Passage of trace metal contaminants through hot gas paths of gas turbines burning biomass and waste-fuels
AdditionalInformation: Produced from a project investigating the development of new coatings for gas turbines fired on waste/biomass derived gases. The method of assessing trace metal contaminants was developed at Cranfield as part of an European Coal and Steel Community funded project (ECSC 7220-PR-053). A variation is being applied in a Biomass and Fossil Fuel Research Alliance (BF2RA) funded project on coatings for biomass combustion systems, in collaboration with E.ON (Colin Davis, Colin.Davis@eon.com; Peter Sage, technical@bf2ra.org) and a TSB funded project (TP101167, ASPIRE, with E.ON, RWE, Doosan Power and NPL (Jeff Hulance, JEFF.HULANCE@RWEnpower.com; Tony Fry, tony.fry@npl.co.uk; Paul Kilgallon, paul.kilgallon@doosan.com).

Title: The development of new bond coat compositions for thermal barrier coating systems operating under industrial gas turbine conditions
AdditionalInformation: An output from the second phase of the EPSRC SUPERGEN 2 - Conventional Power Plant Lifetime Extension Consortium (EP/F029748/1). The coating development methods are currently being used in research projects supported by the Biomass and Fossil Fuel Research Alliance (e.g., http://bf2ra.org/index.html; Peter Sage, technical@bf2ra.org) and EPSRC, to generate new coatings to protect heat exchangers in biomass-fired power stations. The methods developed will also find application in a new EPSRC project (FLEX-E-PLANT, EP/K021095/1) co-funded by 16 industrial partners (e.g., Gordon McColvin, gordon.mccolvin@alstom.com; Jon Wells, jonathan.wells@siemens.com; Geoff Marchant, geoff.marchant@siemens.com).

Title: The use of an electric field in the preparation of glass fibre/epoxy composites containing carbon nanotubes
AdditionalInformation: This work was part of an FP7 collaborative European project on the development of a composite tail cone (project reference: 234290 - http://www.advitac.eu/).  The addition of nanoparticles in this work aimed at offering electrical functionality to aerospace composite components. The processing methodology developed was implemented using commercial aerospace materials and subsequently evaluated in terms of lightning strike performance, resulting in a 40-60% reduction in lightning strike damage area (contact: Michael Hugon, DAHER-SOCATA, m.hugon@daher.com).

Title: Modelling flow and filtration in liquid composite moulding of nanoparticle loaded thermosets
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by BAE Systems (contact: Amir Rezai, Rezai, Amir.Rezai@baesystems.com) and the EPSRC (Cranfield IMRC- EP/E001874/1). The models developed allow tailoring of nanoparticle spatial distribution and enable localised modification of composite components to be made. Elements of this work received the Best Contribution award at the 10th International Conference on Flow Processes in Composite Materials (Ascona, Switzerland, July 2010).

Title: Monitoring dispersion of carbon nanotubes in a thermosetting polyester resin
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by Scott Bader Ltd., an international polymer and composites company. The modification of polyesters accomplished in this work offers electrical functionality at levels appropriate for commercial applications (electroplating, electromagnetic shielding) and led to successful collaboration between the sponsoring company and a global end user of industrial performance coatings (contact: Gavin Creech, gavin_creech@scottbader.com).

Title: Stochastic simulation of woven composites forming
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by EPSRC (GR/S67098/01). Process design based on this methodology results in reduction of wrinkles generated during manufacturing; this result led to a collaboration with ESI, a market leader in process simulation for composites (contact: Patrick de Luca, ESI Group, Patrick.de.Luca@esi-group.com) and also to a large project on the topic of Robustness-performance optimisation for automated composites manufacture (EPSRC - EP/K031430/1) led by Skordos and involving experts from composite manufacturing and mathematics (Daniel Lesnic, amt5ld@amsta.leeds.ac.uk, Leeds University; Andrew Long, Andrew.Long@nottingham.ac.uk, University of Nottingham; Kevin Potter, k.potter@bristol.ac.uk, University of Bristol).

Title: Preference-based Pareto optimization in certain and noisy environments
AdditionalInformation: The statistical method described in this paper provides a simple to apply solution to optimisation of multi-objective problems with noise, given a-priori user preference. The technique has been used in an industry application for steel rolling optimisation at Tata Steel UK (Steve.Thornton@corusgroup.com). The technique was also used for parameter optimisation in Wire and Arc Additive Manufacturing in the EPSRC and industry sponsored project RUAM (Airbus: Gaelle Vanard, gaelle.vanard@eads.com).

Title: Thermo-mechanical analysis of Wire and Arc Additive Layer Manufacturing process on large multi-layer parts
AdditionalInformation: The method provides a deeper understanding of the distortion and distribution of thermally induced stresses in Wire and Arc Additive Manufactured (WAAM) parts. The proposed model is 80% faster than existing alternative methods, opening the opportunity for fast parameter optimisation of large parts with wide walls. The paper helped improve rapid prototyping technology (Prof. Weidong Li, (weidong.li@coventry.ac.uk) and FEM modelling (Laurent Van Belle, (alaurent.van-belle@insa-lyon.fr). The results also found industrial applications in EPSRC-funded projects [EP/E001874/1] including partnerships with e.g. EADS (gaelle.vanard@eads.com) and others.

Title: Knowledge modelling for laser beam welding in the aircraft industry
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides a strategic framework  for advanced laser beam welding. Contact: Liu Hongbing (liuhongbing@coamc.cc). The rule base found practical application in COMAC, a major Chinese aerospace company. This research was the basis for further research projects, led by Hongbing, founded in the same company [No.SAMC12-JS-13-049], and the Shanghai Science and Technology Committee [No. 12QB1401900]. The paper also led to two draft standards now being used in Chinese aerospace companies.

Title: Movement associated reduction of spatial capacity of the equine cervical vertebral canal
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a method that helps increase the precision of radiographs of equine spinal cords. The results also help in reducing the number of false positive results of myelography (contrast radiography) carried out through extreme flexion and extension of the neck of the horses under general anaesthesia. The new method is used in veterinary surgeries (praxis@hundkatzpferd.at) and included in the internationally recognised handbook of “Issues in Veterinary Research and Medicine”, ScholarlyEditions, Atlanta, USA, 2013.

Title: A low-uncertainty measurement of the Boltzmann constant
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration between NPL and Cranfield, funded by EPSRC GR/R68139/01 and NPL. Final results of determination of Boltzmann constant – most accurate temperature measurement ever made. The kelvin/Boltzmann constant will be redefined by these measurements. (Michael de Podesta, NPL, michael.depodesta@npl.co.uk).  Attracted immediate global attention from public scientific media: Physics World cover. 2013 August: 28-32. IOP News, 2013 July, “UK leads the way in race for new temperature definition” New Scientist. 2013; 2925: 10. Scientific American. 2013 July. Acoustic Result Could Change Definition of Temperature. Precision: the measure of all things. BBC Four. du Sautoy 2013.

Title: Pyknometric volume measurement of a quasispherical resonator
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration between NPL and Cranfield, funded by EPSRC GR/R68139/01 and NPL. 5 separate techniques were devised to characterise the resonator. Critically, this one gives a low uncertainty measurement of the volume independent of the shape. The kelvin and Boltzmann constant will be redefined based on these measurement results, which have improved Boltzmann measurement uncertainty by an order of magnitude. (Michael de Podesta, NPL, michael.depodesta@npl.co.uk). Global media reports: du Sautoy M. Precision: the measure of all things. BBC Four. 2013 Billings L. Uncommon Measure: Acoustic Result Could Change Definition of Temperature. Scientific American. 2013 July.

Title: Dimensional characterization of a quasispherical resonator by microwave and coordinate measurement techniques
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration between NPL and Cranfield, funded by EPSRC GR/R68139/01 and NPL. Dimensional characterisation is the most critical aspect of apparatus design so that the contribution to measurement uncertainty is minimised. The kelvin and Boltzmann constant will be redefined based on these measurement results, which have improved Boltzmann measurement uncertainty by an order of magnitude. (Michael de Podesta, NPL, michael.depodesta@npl.co.uk).

Title: Assessment of uncertainty in the determination of the Boltzmann constant by an acoustic technique
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration between NPL and Cranfield, funded by EPSRC GR/R68139/01 (sub-project £464,000) and NPL. This work established the fundamental science required for measurement uncertainty low enough to redefine the kelvin. The kelvin and Boltzmann constant will be redefined based on these measurement results having improved Boltzmann measurement uncertainty by an order of magnitude. (Michael de Podesta, NPL, michael.depodesta@npl.co.uk). Global media reports: du Sautoy M. Precision: the measure of all things. BBC Four. 2013 Billings L. Uncommon Measure: Acoustic Result Could Change Definition of Temperature. Scientific American. 2013 July.

Title: A cost estimating framework for electronic, electrical and electromechanical (EEE) components obsolescence within the use-oriented product-service systems contracts
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B-Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation:
The research reported in the paper has become an industry benchmark to predict non recurring cost of obsolescence resolution. (Ian Blackman 
Secretariat - Component Obsolescence Group, UK, iblackman@cog.org.uk).
The UK MoD has signed a support contract worth £240K over 2 years with Cranfield, to make a tool based on the research (and another obsolescence management tool), available to industry to reduce the cost impact of obsolescence  in the defence sector (Contact: Paul Crimmins - DESJSCSCM-EngTLS-OM@mod.uk).

Title: Operations strategy for the effective delivery of integrated industrial product-service offerings: Two exploratory defence industry case studies
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Operations and Production Management
AdditionalInformation: This research led to an investigation of different incentive mechanisms within product-service systems, providing a strong foundation to win the £11.1m EPSRC Centre in Through-life Engineering Services (contact: "Leinster-Evans, Stewart (UK)" <Stewart.Leinster@baesystems.com>) and a subsequent obsolescence management research contract with the MoD.

Title: Developing a Service Knowledge Reuse Framework for Engineering Design
AdditionalInformation: This is one of the studies that attracted a 'Strategic Investment in Low-carbon Engine Technology' (SILOET) contract worth £220K over 3 years with Rolls-Royce, and a project on component degradation in-service feedback for design and manufacturing (worth £400K over 3 years) within the EPSRC Centre in Through-life Engineering Services (contact: Andy Harrison <Andrew.Harrison@rolls-royce.com>)

Title: Function-based cost estimating
AdditionalInformation: This is one of the key papers that has contributed to Cranfield's leadership in cost engineering research (Mr. Alan Barltrop, ACostE President, alanbarltrop@btinternet.com). The research has contributed to subsequent EPSRC/IMRC cost engineering research funding at Cranfield (EP/E001874/1, EP/I033246/1), and Professor Roy was elected as the President of the Association of Cost Engineers for a two year term.

Title: Effect of microstructure and temperature on the erosion rates and mechanisms of modified EB PVD TBCs
AdditionalInformation: Much previous work on thermal barrier coatings (TBC) focuses on thermal performance alone; the significance of this work is identification of the conflict between optimising thermal performance and the impact on erosion resistance, in a thermal barrier coating system for gas turbines. In follow-on work, erosion is assessed along with cyclic oxidation, thermal properties and microstructural degradation, under a new TSB/EPSRC contract aimed at improved TBC performance [EP/G035369/1;TSB ref TS/G002541/1 with Rolls-Royce plc, £1.066M], . (david.rickerby@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Effects of cyclic stress and temperature on oxidation damage of a nickel-based superalloy
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: Oxidation damage combined with fatigue is a concern for alloys used as disc rotors in aero-engines. Current alloys safely operate up to 600C, but forecasts suggest this temperature will rise, thus oxidation induced damage will become critical in disc lifing. This work, on oxidation induced sub-surface damage in the 700-800C range, has resulted in new contracts to assess oxidation and corrosion effects on the fatigue life of disc materials. Funding is provided by the TSB [TP11/CAT/6/I/BP009G] and directly by industry (contact mark.hardy@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Sensor Thermal Barrier Coatings: Remote In Situ Condition Monitoring of EB-PVD Coatings at Elevated Temperatures
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper won the best technical paper award of ASME, 2008.  Incorporation of Lanthenide luminescent materials into thermal barrier coatings provided a temperature measuring capability, enabling, for the first time, simultaneous measurement of surface temperature, bondcoat/ceramic interface temperature and heat flux through a thermal barrier coating. The methodology has been patented (WO 2007023293, owned by Southside Thermal Sciences (STS) Ltd), and provides the underpinning technology to a new company spun out of STS in 2012, focused on sensor thermal barrier coatings (contact Dr Joerg Fiest, < j.feist@stscience.com>, Managing Director, Sensor Coating Systems Ltd.).

Title: Evolution of stress and morphology in thermal barrier coatings
AdditionalInformation: The lifetime of a thermal barrier coating (TBC) is determined by microstructural evolution during service. This paper discusses the mapping of local strain fields as a function of the thermal cycling lifetime. This has allowed the role of surface finish and microstructure in minimising stress/strain fields to be investigated, thus improving component lifetime. As a result of this work, a new project was supported, funded by EPSRC (EP/G035369/1) and Rolls Royce to investigate the manufacture of new bondcoat systems for TBCs (contact: david.rickerby@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Automated inspection using database technology within the aerospace industry
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B-Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE) Thatcher Bros Prize 2008/09 for the best journal paper in manufacturing. The research reported here has been further developed into a 'snag-manager' tool that is being used within the wing manufacturing facility of Airbus UK to automate the inspection process and generate fault reports. This tool has led to an order of magnitude reduction in the inspection lead-time of wing sets (Simon Astwood, simon.astwood@eads.com).
