Title: Objective reduction in many-objective optimization: Linear and nonlinear algorithms
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents for the first time algorithms for reducing the complexity of optimisation problems with four or more conflicting objectives (funded via a Hewlett Packard Research Grant, contact Prof Keshav Dahal, k.p.dahal@bradford.ac.uk). The research reported in this paper has been highlighted by the NAFEMS (International Association of the Engineering Modelling, Analysis and Simulation Community) Optimisation Working Group as one of the key enablers for solving engineering design optimisation problems in aerospace, automotive and power sectors (Dr Gan Xiao-Peng, xiao-peng.gan@power.alstom.com).

Title: Ergonomic chair design by fusing qualitative and quantitative criteria using interactive genetic algorithms
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an original interactive optimisation algorithm to bring qualitative and quantitative design criteria together (funded via Japanese Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), Prof Hideyuki Takagi, takagi@design.kyushu-u.ac.jp). The results have led to a Technology Strategy Board (TSB) project that applies new interactive gaming technologies to digitise complex manufacturing process knowledge (Grant TSB120193, £430k, EADS UK and AERTEC). The outputs are being field tested in EADS UK (Pablo Bermell-Garcia, pablo.bermell-garcia@eads.com).

Title: Rolling System Design Using Evolutionary Sequential Process Optimization
AdditionalInformation: This is the first multi-objective optimisation approach capable of handling dependencies between multiple stages in a rolling system design problem. This research was carried out in collaboration with Corus Group plc (now Tata Steel Europe). The results have led to a new EPSRC project (Grant EP/K026348, £1.4M) that models and optimises manufacturing processes for cross-sector reuse of scrap composite materials (Simon Astwood, simon.astwood@eads.com).

Title: Influence of annealing on the photochemical deposition of silver onto PZT thin films under UV irradiation
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: The work has application in chemical sensing, based on functional nanomaterials deposited on the surface of optical fibre. This research is being progressed as part of a Daphne Jackson Fellowship (Principal Investigator Dr Divya Tiwari) for the development of optical fibre sensors to measure carbon dioxide concentration at carbon capture and storage sites (contact: rosemary.lawrence@surrey.ac.uk).

Title: Simulation study for investment decisions on the EcoBoost camshaft machining line
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B-Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The techniques described in this paper have been adopted in a decision making tool that assists manufacturers (in this case Ford) in making critical investment decisions in production facilities, e.g. new machines, redesign of material handling mechanisms etc. The novelty lies in the automatic generation of both simulated models of production facilities and financial implications of each decision. This has allowed Ford to prioritise the investment on their Valencia Engine plant to give cost savings of approx €750K pa. Contact: John Ladbrook (jladbroo@ford.com)

Title: A novel framework to link prognostics and health management and product-service systems using online simulation
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a collaborative research project between Cranfield and University of Brasilia (UnB) funded by the Brazilian CNPQ. The output was an online simulation framework that links the condition of an asset with operational decisions. This has led to a follow-on grant from the Brazilian government’s CAPES (grant 8964-12-2; 2 years). Contact: Prof Sadek Absi Alvaro, UnB (sadek@unb.br).

Title: Towards product-service systems modelling: a quest for dynamic behaviour and model parameters
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted in a simulation modelling method and construct that help manufacturers to become product-service systems (PSS) providers. Using the new simulation, companies such as AeroGulf have been able to assess risks and rewards gained from adopting the PSS business model (Contact: Ravi Raja Mohan, AeroGulf, raja@aerogulf.aero). The method has been further co-developed and validated by companies who have adopted or are currently considering PSS, including Hindustan Aerospace Ltd. Contact: Prikshat Sharma, Hindustan Aerospace Ltd (prikshatsharma@gmail.com).

Title: Analysis and optimisation of a network of closed-loop automobile assembly line using simulation
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This research used the simulation techniques employed in output 1, to develop a model that has been applied to the Volkswagen car plant located in Navarra S.A, Pamplona, Spain. The model contributed to the optimal decision of the location and sizes of in-process buffers, which ultimately reduced the overall work-in-progress of the line, speeding up the process and reducing inventory. Total saving was estimated at €500K pa. Contact: Luis Pinto Ferreira (luispintoferreira@eu.ipp.pt).

Title: A framework for computer-aided conceptual design and its application to system architecting of mechatronics products
AdditionalInformation: This research was performed as part of the Octopus project (www.esi.nl/octopus/, €7.4M) funded by the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs through Agentschap NL Innovatie. It paved a new path towards rational systems architecting instead of traditional reliance on individual experience and tacit knowledge (contact Frans Beenker, Director Industrial Programs, Embedded Systems Institute (Eindhoven, The Netherlands, frans.beenker@esi.nl). The research outputs have been used experimentally by Océ N.V. (part of Canon Group) to scientifically codify and capture knowledge for systems architecting in a computer-based tool (contact Paul Hilkens, VP Research, Océ, The Netherlands, paul.hilkens@oce.com).

Title: Integration of a service CAD and a life cycle simulator
AdditionalInformation: This paper specifically reported the connection of a service Computer Aided Design and a life cycle simulator which allows users to verify results of service design (contact  Professor Brezet, Delft University of  Technology, j.c.brezet@tudelft.nl). The developed software tools were used by DAF Trucks (contact Jack.Martens@DAFTRUCKS.com) in a project to compare  future exhaust gas processing systems, such as soot filters, urea addition, and exhaust gas recirculation, in terms of economic and environmental impacts through life cycle simulation, to achieve compliance with "Euro 5" regulations on reduced exhaust emissions.

Title: Reliability of wind turbine technology through time
VolumeTitle: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper analysed actual operational reliability data of wind turbines including operational data (SCADA data, failure modes, failure causes, repair records, etc). The results have been taken up by the Fraunhofer-Institute for Wind Energy and Energy System Technology (IWES) public database, accessible under restricted conditions (Dr. Berthold Hahn, bhahn@iset.uni-kassel.de). This paper is one of a few papers that analysed the reality of operational failures, which was useful for researchers to quantitatively understand the reality. In particular, the paper pointed out that so-called "standard turbine design" (i.e., three blades, upwind, pitch or stall control, etc.) had demonstrated sufficiently reliable performance.

Title: An architecture model to support cooperative design for mechatronic products: A control design case
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a system description language and its modelling method for systems engineering created during a research collaboration with partners Philips, Océ, Vanderlande Industries and ASML. Compared with existing languages, this has the advantage of combining high-level functional descriptions with low-level structural and behavioural information in a unified manner. The results improve communication between stakeholders, reducing errors and mistakes in architecting complex multi-disciplinary products (Frans Beenker, Director Industrial Programs, Embedded Systems Institute, Eindhoven, The Netherlands, frans.beenker@esi.nl). Currently the language is extended for professional use and being tested by ASML and Océ (Paul Hilkens, VP Research, Océ, The Netherlands, paul.hilkens@oce.com).

Title: A variable neighborhood search with an effective local search for uncapacitated multilevel lot-sizing problems
AdditionalInformation: This research improved the variable neighbourhood search (VNS) algorithm for solving uncapacitated multilevel lot-sizing (MLLS) problems in transport route palning and optimisation. The results showed that the improved VNS algorithm outperforms the existing algorithms in solving the same problems. This work was under the support from National Natural Science Foundation, China (Project No. 71071007).

Title: A framework for design knowledge management and reuse for Product-Service Systems in construction machinery industry
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from research collaboration with Shanghai Institute of Technology, China, sponsored by Shanghai Leading Academic Discipline Project (Project No. J51501). The results and methodology are being adopted to develop a design approach for achieving design knowledge management and reuse for Product-Service Systems in collaboration with Shanghai Xugong Construction Machinery Co., LTD. (contact zhanghong@xcmg.com).

Title: Development of a Fuel Consumption Optimization Model for the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem
AdditionalInformation: This paper is resulted from research collaboration with School of Reliability and System Engineering in Beihang University, China, supported by the National Natural Science Foundation, China (Project No. 71071007). This paper developed the first optimisation model to solve the evolved classical capacitated vehicle routing problem (CVRP). 5% fuel savings have been found in general in experiments based on industrial scenarios by using the developed optimisation model.

Title: Human Resources Allocation for Aircraft Maintenance with Predefined Sequence
VolumeTitle: Journal of Systems Engineering and Electronics
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted in new algorithms for minimising aircraft maintenance time and cost.  Numerical experiments based on industrial scenario showed the effectiveness of developed algorithm, with better optimised solutions in 75% of typical problems. This research led to Dr Xu being invited to organise an Academic Forum on Cost Engineering and a review article (Xu et al, International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing 25, 300-314, 2012) that helped to set the research agenda in the field and led to an EPSRC / Rolls Royce funded project (stephen.tuppen@rolls-royce.com).

Title: A gravitational deflection compensation strategy for HPKMs
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by EPSRC (GR/L90149) in collaboration with Airbus, BAE Systems and Bombardier Aerospace. The technique achieved significant improvements in accuracy for Tricept type Parallel Kinematic Machines.  (Michael Gribben, michael.gribben@aero.bombardier.com). It contributed to a further EPSRC project (EP/E001904) to further develop the area  as part of the Nottingham Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre (including further collaboration with Bombardier Aerospace).

Title: Metrology-assisted robotic processing of aerospace applications
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation:
Collaboration with Bombardier Aerospace funded by the EPSRC through the University of Nottingham Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre (EP/E001904).

The research insights, technology and algorithms developed in this work have been fundamental to the development of a significant research stream in metrology-assisted assembly in aerospace assembly applications. (Michael Gribben michael.gribben@aero.bombardier.com). Further work in this area has been directly funded by Airbus and within the FP7 project VITAL (AIP4-CT-2004-012271, €90M total) working closely with Rolls-Royce (Contact Craig Johnson, craig.a.johnson@rolls-royce.com) and Volvo Aero (Anders Sjunnesson, tel: +46 (0)70 577 5946).

Title: An improved kinematic model for calibration of serial robots having closed-chain mechanisms
AdditionalInformation:
Collaboration with Airbus funded by the EPSRC through the University of Nottingham Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre (EP/E001904/1) and later with direct funding from Airbus.

The research was developed as a test scenario for a new distributed control system for metrology intensive robotic applications. (Contact Mark Summers mark.summers@airbus.com). The underlying system led to participation in the FP7 Project FLEXA (GA 213734, Contact per.nylen@hv.se) and is being further developed within the EPSRC Centre in Intelligent Automation (EP/I033467, contact m.r.jackson@loughborough.ac.uk).

Title: A Hybrid Fuzzy Knowledge-Based Expert System and Genetic Algorithm for efficient selection and assignment of Material Handling Equipment
AdditionalInformation: This research provided a novel method for automatically selecting optimal industrial handling systems.

Title: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Wire and Arc Additive Manufactured Ti-6Al-4V
VolumeTitle: Metallurgical and Materials Transactions A: Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel additive manufacturing process that for the first time provides parts with guaranteed microstructure and mechanical properties for aerospace  (jonathan.meyer@eads.com). The results led to a rolling technology maturation programme, sponsored by Lockheed Martin (£185k plus their own £300k industrial scale facility, steve.t.burnage@lmco.com ), BAE Systems (£100k, Jagjit.sidhu@baesystems.com ), Air Products (£120k, WIKTORR@airproducts.com ), ARA (£80k, pcurtis@ara.co.uk), Bomardier Aerospace (£48k, gary.moore@aero.bombardier.com). Further funding has been awarded to extend the concepts to more complex structures (EPSRC grant EP/K029010, £489k) and to other materials (EU Contract 313781, total €18.8M, CU €250k).

Title: Investigation of the effects of basic laser material interaction parameters in laser welding
AdditionalInformation: Based on this research, a new approach to process specification and control has been developed. This enables direct transfer of specific laser welding processes between different laser systems (contact Nicholas.Longfield@the-mtc.org). This approach is being directly applied in industrial applications. Laser titanium welding has been developed under contract from Rolls Royce (clive.grafton-reed@rollsroyce.com) and then transferred to the Manufacturing Technology Centre for application to real parts (Nicholas.Longfield@the-mtc.org). The principles are also being applied to laser hybrid welding of pipelines through a contract from the M2i organisation in the Netherlands on behalf of Heerama Marine Contractors (£214k, contact byudodibroto@hmc-heerema.com  £214,364).

Title: Control of weld composition when arc welding high strength aluminium alloys using multiple filler wires
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation: This research has now enabled corrosion resistant aluminium alloys to be considered for future armoured vehicle manufacture and other defence applications (contact Mathew Lunt, DSTL – mjlunt@dstl.gov.uk). The technique is now being applied to the development of high strength aluminium in a  research programme on wire plus arc additive manufacture for large scale engineering structure. The aluminium development in this programme is principally supported Lockheed Martin (steve.t.burnage@lmco.com) and Bomardier Aerospace (gary.moore@aero.bombardier.com) and an EU project  (Contract 313781, total €18.8M, CU €250k).

Title: Dissimilar laser welding of NiTi to stainless steel
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a new technique to laser weld structural materials with different stiffness and elasticity, with importance to in-vivo medical devices such as stents (jim.fife@ATTICA.com). The concepts have led to further research lasers joining of a wide range of dissimilar materials. This includes EPSRC funding (EP/J017086, £100k), projects co-funded by AWE (Jay.Vaja@awe.co.uk) and BAE Systems (norrie.mcpherson@baesystems.com) and an EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacture in Laser Based Production Processes with Heriot Watt University (£5.6M, EP/K030884, contact d.p.hand@hwu.ac.uk ). The concepts are also being adopted for application to medical devices (Attica Components, contact jim.fife@attica.com).

Title: Forensic evidence in apparel fabrics due to stab events
AdditionalInformation: This research was commissioned by Dr M. Taylor of ESR (ESR are the major provider of forensic science support to NZ Police). Fabric age, as represented by laundering, was considered with respect to sharp weapon damage to clothing. Fabric age affected the force required to penetrate the fabric, and macroscopic and microscopic features of the severance damage. This is the first time these effects have been reported. Forensic practitioners in Australia and NZ now consider garment age during recreation studies. Contact: michael.taylor@esr.cri.nz.

Title: Effect of laundering on blunt force impact damage in fabrics
AdditionalInformation: This work was commissioned by Dr M. Taylor of ESR (ESR are the major provider of forensic science support to NZ Police). This work paved the way towards the use of apparel damage as forensic evidence in blunt force impact events. Further, the effect of laundering after impact was investigated to determine whether such evidence could still be detected. This work is of interest with respect to historical crime; such evidence had not previously been considered. Contact: michael.taylor@esr.cri.nz

Title: Physical and mechanical degradation of shirting fabrics in burial conditions
AdditionalInformation: This work,  in collaboration with ESR (ESR are the major provider of forensic science support to NZ Police) describes the first consideration in the forensic science literature of the effect of the burial environment on the degradation of modern clothing. Previous work within archaeological science has considered historical fabrics, however modern synthetic fabrics have not be considered. The work provides guidance on the effects of two burial environments on men’s shirting fabrics.

Title: Does quilting improve the fragment protective performance of body armour?
AdditionalInformation: This research presented in this paper led to the award of a follow-on research project funded by DSTL to further investigate the effect of heirarchical structure of body armour - contact Professor B. James ‎(BJJAMES@dstl.gov.uk)

Title: A giant electrocaloric effect in nanoscale antiferroelectric and ferroelectric phases coexisting in a relaxor Pb0.8Ba0.2ZrO3 thin film at room temperature
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported for the first time the formation of a thin film, by a new chemical solution deposition process, with an electrocaloric effect (ECE) large enough for use as solid-state cooling medium (temperature change 45°C compared to 1-2°C for traditional materials) (pengbl8@162.com). The results led to three invited / plenary talks (Zhang) in international conferences: Materials & Technologies For Sustainable Growth 2013 (contact eco,matech@ung.si), Materials Science & Technology 2012 (contact SKo@bridgesemi.com), 7th International conference on Advanced Materials Processing 2012 (contact jryang@ntu.edu.tw).

Title: Investigation of electrocaloric effect in PMN-PT relaxor thin films
AdditionalInformation: This research was supported by EPSRC (EP/E035043) and conducted in collaboration with Cambridge University. The results led to paper 1, demonstration for the first time of a giant electrocaloric effect (ECE) on relaxor inorganic ferroelectric thin films at room temperature. This has significance for all-solid-state cooling devices that would be simpler and easier to handle than vapour compressed cooling systems or magnetic solid state cooling devices (N. D. Mathur, ndm12@hermes.cam.ac.uk).

Title: Nanosecond-range imprint and retention characterized from polarization-voltage hysteresis loops in insulating or leaky ferroelectric thin films
AdditionalInformation: The research was a collaboration with Fudan University, China under the Shanghai Key Program (1052nm07600). This research developed a technique that allows quicker and more accurate electrical characterisation of ferroelectric materials, particularly ferroelectric thin films. This new technique is superior to traditional Sawyer-Tower measurements as it can separate current signals coming from different sources (domain switch or leakage). The technique has been used to measure the electrical properties of other ferroelectric thin films such as BiFeO3 (pxyang@ee.ecnu.edu.cn).

Title: Enhanced pyroelectric coefficient of antiferroelectric-ferroelectric bilayer thin films
AdditionalInformation: This work displayed that pyroelectric coefficient of materials can be enhanced through material design. The combination of antiferroelectric and ferroelectric thin films shows an increase of an magnitute of order in pyroelectric coefficient compared with pure ferroelectric thin film. This work was supported by EP/E035043/1).

Title: Effects of 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin exposure on bone material properties
AdditionalInformation: Dioxins are toxic environmental contaminants that accumulate in the food chain, leading to acute bone problems especially in countries bordering the Baltic Sea. This research was part of an EU funded project (BONETOX, QLK4-CT-2002-02528, 2.8M Euro, http://www.imm.ki.se/bonetox/) that investigated dioxin effects on the biomechanical properties of bone tissue. Contact Helen Håkansson, coordinator, helen.hakansson@imm.ki.se  The work underpinned the creation of the Cranfield Forensic Institute Analytical Laboratory in Shrivenham, an investment of £1M. The techniques are used in legal case work for the benefit of regulatory bodies to tackle crime, terrorism, security threats and environmental pollution problems (http://www.cranfield.ac.uk/cds/cfi/analytical.html).

Title: Microcracking damage and the fracture process in relation to strain rate in human cortical bone tensile failure
AdditionalInformation: This article was one element of a wider research programme commissioned by the Transport Research Laboratory (TRL) to derive the mechanical properties of human bone at high strain rates. The research has highlighted, for the first time, that bone at high stain rates is in fact more ‘brittle’ than expected. This result has fed into simulations in the automotive industry with  implications for the design of the in-car restraint systems and in litigation or accident cases, where forensic examiners are trying to piece together the evidence, to apportion blame either for criminal action or negligence in practice or design. Contact Dr David Hynd, TRL (investigations@trl.co.uk).

Title: Some basic relationships between density values in cancellous and cortical bone
AdditionalInformation: This research was a key element of the measurement of ultrasound speed in bone tissue as a surrogate variable for strength, allowing prediction of the biomechanical response of bones in car crash scenarios (Contact R.Hardy, NISSAN R&D, Roger.Hardy@hardy2573.freeserve.co.uk). The research resulted from BOSCOS, a DfT funded consortium (£780k), partners: NISSAN, AYTOLIV, Johnson & Johnson controls, TRW, Cranfield Impact Centre, VRSC Loughborough University, McCue plc (a bone scanner manufacturer). The result is a new bone scanner prototype to intelligently control in-car restraints to better protect car occupants. Contact R.Hardy, NISSAN R&D, Roger.Hardy@hardy2573.freeserve.co.uk. The results also informed and shaped government policy (www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200405/ldselect/ldsctech/999/4110903.htm)

Title: The fracture toughness of cancellous bone
AdditionalInformation: This research measured, for the first time, how the fracture toughness of human cancellous bone changes with density. The results allowed automotive engineers to predict the load conditions under which bones will break, especially for vulnerable young and elderly occupants (Contact R.Hardy, NISSAN R&D, Roger.Hardy@hardy2573.freeserve.co.uk). The research resulted from BOSCOS, a DfT funded consortium (for details see paper 3) which used these results to system-engineer a bone scanner prototype and intelligent control of in-car restraints so as to better protect car occupants. Contact R.Hardy, NISSAN R&D, Roger.Hardy@hardy2573.freeserve.co.uk. The results have also informed and shaped government policy (www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200405/ldselect/ldsctech/999/4110903.htm)

Title: Microfluidic electrochemical assay for rapid detection and quantification of Escherichia coli
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this publication led to a patent (US No. 13/987,392) and won a ‘best presentation’ award at the Lab-on-a-Chip World Congress 2011. One of the workers engaged on the original project is currently establishing a spin off to commercialize the sensor device. Dr Mohamedali Safavieh babaksafavieh@gmail.com.

Title: Label-free bacteria detection using evanescent mode of a suspended core terahertz fiber
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a multi-disciplinary research collaboration, funded by NanoQuebec (Hub for Nanotech development in Quebec), project No. R08BIO03, between INRS University, Quebec, Canada, and the Ecole Polytech de Montreal (Prof. Skorobogatiy: e-mail: maksim.skorobogatiy@polymtl.ca). The first author won a Quebecois Research Fund (FQRNT) ‘Early-career research star’ award (http://www.frq.gouv.qc.ca/etudiants-chercheurs-etoiles/laureats), through which the funding council recognises early-career researchers for outstanding work in Natural Sciences and Engineering.

Title: Fe3O4/Au nanoparticles/lignin modified microspheres as effectual surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) substrates for highly selective and sensitive detection of 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT)
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a multi-disciplinary, collaborative research project with Qatar Environment and Energy Research Institute, Doha, QATAR (Dr. Khaled Mahmoud, e-mail: kmahmoud@qf.org.qa), and has attracted follow-on funding from the UK Defence Science and Technology Laboratory.

Title: Detection of bacteria using bacteriophages as recognition elements immobilized on long-period fiber gratings
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a multi-disciplinary, collaborative research project with the Universite de Quebec, Outaouais (Prof. Bock; e-mail: wojetk.bock@uqo.ca), funded via NanoQuebec (Hub for Nanotechnology in Quebec), Canada (R4-RD05-B) and NSERC, Canada. This project led to follow-on NanoQuebec grant R08BIO03.

Title: X-ray diffraction with novel geometry
VolumeTitle: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment
AdditionalInformation:
This paper carries the first report of a generalised geometry for application of X-ray focal construct technology to non-idealised samples, enabling samples of any orientation to be characterised. It has enabled research groups (e.g. the Imaging Science Group at Nottingham Trent University, paul.evans@ntu.ac.uk) to adopt the technology for examination of complex objects. The work has already been recognised by Halo X-ray Technologies, who are developing a technology demonstrator through a TSB grant (131257) for future commercialisation (Dr Simon Godber, sxg@haloxray.com).
It also formed an important component of a successful bid for research monies ($3.5M) from the US Department of Homeland Security (awarded August 2013).

Title: Analyses of Power Output of Piezoelectric Energy-Harvesting Devices Directly Connected to a Load Resistor Using a Coupled Piezoelectric-Circuit Finite Element Method
VolumeTitle: IEEE transactions on ultrasonics, ferroelectrics and frequency control
AdditionalInformation: The research was part of a portfolio of funded work (EP/E001874/1: EPSRC/IMRC-137) on energy harvesting. This paper is the first published work to solve a key problem on modelling the power output of vibration-based piezoelectric energy harvesting devices (PEHD) connected to a load circuit, using a finite element method. The results contributed to the development of a portfolio of further funded work (EPSRC EP/K020331, £630k) on energy harvesting applications and the method has been adopted in the BAE Systems ‘Persistent Green Air Vehicle Technology Challenge’ programme where it will be used to contribute to the overall lean energy (Ian Harrington, ian.harrington@baesystems.com).

Title: Design study of piezoelectric energy-harvesting devices for generation of higher electrical power using a coupled piezoelectric-circuit finite element method
VolumeTitle: IEEE transactions on ultrasonics, ferroelectrics and frequency control
AdditionalInformation: This research led to a world leading performance in energy density for a cantilever energy harvester (improved by 100%). The results  and methodology have led to a number of further developments of energy harvesting technology for battery-free wireless sensing in various applications through grants: (1) EP/E001874/1 grant via IMRC grant IMRC-162 for aerospace (£149k), (2) DSTL grant via MAST STC-CDE23681 for MoD (£50k), and (3) FP7 chist-era grant via EPSRC (EP/K017950, £465k) for Green ICT.

Title: Plucked piezoelectric bimorphs for knee-joint energy harvesting: modelling and experimental validation
AdditionalInformation: The research was part of a portfolio of funded work (EPSRC  EP/H020764, £630k) on a mobile energy harvesting system which provided the first design mechanism of “pizzicato excitation” for the generation of electricity from human walking, allowing piezo-harvesters efficiently to work at lower frequency than previously possible (1-10Hz) and wider bandwidth (non-resonant). This paper was selected for the “Highlights of 2011” collection in the Journal.

Title: The pizzicato knee-joint energy harvester: characterization with biomechanical data and the effect of backpack load
AdditionalInformation: This research applied the designed mechanism mentioned in output 3 to a practical challenge in energy harvesting, demonstrating that soldiers' equipment can be powered by their walking action. This paper was selected for inclusion in the “Highlights of 2012” collection in the Journal.

Title: Airborne Vehicle Mapping of Curvilinear Objects Using 2-D Splinegon
VolumeTitle: Ieee Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents part of the outcome of a cluster project from the MoD-funded Data and Information Fusion Defence Technology Centre Tracking and Multi-Dimensional Fusion, R&D/DTC/5/1/1 - £350,000).

Title: Insectlike Flapping Wings in the Hover Part 1: Effect of Wing Kinematics
AdditionalInformation:
This paper led to two MoD-funded projects obtained competitively through the Centre for Defence Enterprise: "Autoresonant drive for insect-like flapping wing micro air

vehicles" and "Mechanism and flight controller development for flapping wing MAVs via a robotic arm based flight simulator." (CDE12748 - £95k; CDE18510 - £120k)

Title: Co-operative unmanned aerial vehicle searching and mapping of complex obstacles using two-dimensional splinegon
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel technique that enables networks of UAVs to map complex environments. The research was an important element of the SATURN system used by Cranfield's winning entry to the MoD Grand Challenge 2008 (to solve specific military challenges faced in a hostile urban environment), and awarded the RJ Mitchell Trophy. (see http://www.science.mod.uk/engagement/grand_challenge/11_3_latest_news.aspx.

Title: Unmanned aerial vehicle navigation and mapping
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation:
This paper led to two MoD-funded projects obtained competitively through the Centre for Defence Enterprise: "Autoresonant drive for insect-like flapping wing micro air
 vehicles" and "Mechanism and flight controller development for flapping wing MAVs via a robotic arm based flight simulator." (CDE12748 - £96k)

Title: Detection of Salmonella typhimurium using an electrochemical immunosensor.
AdditionalInformation: This work led to a Plenary lecture (Tothill) at AsiaSense 2013 (Dr. Jaafar Abdullah, jaafar@science.upm.edu.my), and a best paper prize at the Genomics and Proteomics of Human Pathogens Conference, June 2009, Health Protection Agency (Now Public Health England) (Prof. Haroun Shah, Centre for Infections, London, Haroun.shah@phe.gov.uk). Developments of the sensor for virus detection led to a collaboration with CINVESTAV National Polytechnical Institute, Mexico (Dr Munoz, lmunoz@cinvestav.mx), and a Key Note lecture invitation at Nanomechanical Sensing (2011, Dublin). Tothill was also invited, by the European Food Standard Agency, to act as an international expert in evaluating nanomaterial use in foods (Brazil, 2011).

Title: A Membrane-Based ELISA Assay and Electrochemical Immunosensor for Microcystin-LR in Water Samples
AdditionalInformation: This work was expanded from that conducted under EU project “Algaetox” ENV4-CT98-0784, in collaboration with European partners. A collaboration with DuPont Microcircuit Materials, on inks and transducer development, resulted from the research (Vince Arancio, Vince.Arancio@gbr.dupont.com), and also a further research project to evaluate nano inks produced by the company for the commercial biosensor market (Novel surface chemistry: http://www2.dupont.com /MCM/en_US/index.html).

Title: An electrochemical sensor based on carboxymethylated dextran modified gold surface for ochratoxin A analysis
AdditionalInformation: The research led to Tothill being invited onto the scientific committees for the 4th International Symposium, Mycotoxins: Challenges and Perspectives, (May 2011, Belgium) and the 35th Mycotoxin Workshop (May 2013, Ghent), (Prof. Dr. Apr. Sarah De Saeger, Sarah.DeSaeger@UGent.be). Further invitations followed to give a plenary lecture and lead a discussion group at the International Aflatoxin-in-Maize Working Group, USDA-ARS (May 2013, New Orleans), (Prof. Deepak Bhatnagar,  Deepak.Bhatnagar@ARS.USDA.GOV).

Title: Cancer biomarker detection in serum samples using surface plasmon resonance and quartz crystal microbalance sensors with nanoparticle signal amplification
AdditionalInformation: The work was part-funded by Sierra Sensors GMbH, and resulted in novel surface chemistries incorporated into diagnostic devices including the Quartz Crystal Microbalance sensors (QCMA-1) and Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR-2) sensor chips marketed by the company (Christopher Whalen,  chris.whalen@sierrasensors.com), which are  widely used by research laboratories to develop future sensor technologies.Tothill was awarded a Federation of European Microbiology Society (FEMS) research fellowship with the University of Valencia, Spain (2010).

Title: High throughput X-ray diffraction analysis of combinatorial polycrystalline thin film libraries
AdditionalInformation: This research formed the central structural characterisation for the EPSRC’s Supergen (PV) programme (PV21 EP/F029624 £6.2M).  It describes a novel approach developed for rapid materials discovery that has been exploited by Photovoltaic research groups at Southampton (dmb@ecs.soton.ac.uk), Bath (k.c.malloy@bath.ac.uk), Northumbria (ian.forbes@northumbria.ac.uk) and others. It was the basis of several further publications and a keynote talk invitation (Richard Jones Memorial Lecture Annual Research Conference, Nottingham, 2011).  It was the foundation of a Leverhulme project (RPG-2012-436)  where the approach was to be applied to examine methods for the rapid survey of artworks in collaboration with the Getty Museums (m.walton@getty.edu).

Title: Combined X-ray diffraction and kinetic depth effect imaging
AdditionalInformation: The research was funded through an EPSRC grant (EP/F017804/1) in collaboration with Nottingham Trent University and the Department of Homeland Security. It developed a new concept to enable materials discrimination simultaneously with depth resolved imaging. This was adopted in a follow-on research project funded by DSTL  (DSTLX-1000077679) and applied to X-ray backscatter, in collaboration with AI Ltd and Radius Diagnostics Inc. The work was initially presented at the 2010 Denver X-ray Conference where it won Best Poster prize and resulted in a New Scientist report (Aug 16th, 2010).

Title: High intensity x-ray diffraction in transmission mode employing an analog of Poisson's spot
AdditionalInformation: The paper introduced a new concept in X-ray diffraction data acquisition that had previously been shortlisted in the Times Higher Awards.  It has been subsequently used as foundation for a successful EPSRC proposal (EPSRC EP/K020196/1 £766k) and applications to the TSB. The technology is now being exploited through a new University spin-out company (Halo X-ray Technologies Ltd)  and has led to new industrial (e.g.  Radius Health, gil.travish@radius-health.com) and academic (Bristol (Prof Richard Martin, r.martin@bristol.ac.uk)); (Exeter (Prof Nick Stone, n.stone@exeter.ac.uk); Melbourne (Prof John Clement, johngc@unimeb.edu.au) collaborations focussed upon developing new medical diagnostic probes.

Title: Towards a safe non-invasive method for evaluating the carbonate substitution levels of hydroxyapatite (HAP) in micro-calcifications found in breast tissue
AdditionalInformation: The research concerns a scientific enigma associated with breast cancer genesis and this paper established the UK lead in this field.   It has been further investigated through several successful Diamond Light Source applications and has generated a new collaboration with the Royal College of Surgeons, Ireland.  It stimulated an invited keynote talk (the John Mallard lecture) at the 2009 UK Radiological Congress.

Title: Countermeasure effectiveness against a man-portable air-defence system containing a two-color spinscan infrared seeker
AdditionalInformation: Chemring Plc are world leading producers of pyrotechnics and countermeasures. To validate and sell these products they need to be able to demonstrate their efficacy. This research was part of a collaboration that looked at the interaction of multi-spectral countermeasures and counter-countermeasures. The results enabled Chemring to enact a programme of change requests and a product improvement plan for CounterSim, Chemring's principle engagement modelling software, which simulates engagements of RF and IR homing missiles against ships, aircraft and land vehicles. This was used to enhance overseas business activities in particular. Contact: Brian Butters, brian.butters@meontechnology.com (formerly at Chemring Countermeasures Ltd).

Title: Aero-optical effects of a directional infrared countermeasure pod in the transonic regime
AdditionalInformation: This research was part of a multi-national government sponsored Technical Agreement (TA108.019).  The UK was represented by DSTL, Sweden by FOI, France by ONERA, Holland by TNO and Germany by FGAN-FOM.  It yielded insights for use in precision laser-beam steering through severe environments for aircraft countermeasure systems. Verifiable via UK lead participant at DSTL: David Titterton DHTITTERTON@mail.dstl.gov.uk

Title: Countermeasure effectiveness against an intelligent imaging infrared anti-ship missile
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded Chemring Plc. Chemring are world leaders in the production of pyrotechnics and countermeasures with just over 50% of the world market.This research on advanced missile modelling has been adopted to provide insights into a particular launcher product, the Centurion® trainable naval decoy launcher, and the algorithms it uses for protection against infrared guided missiles. It has helped confirm the need for low launch angles and the control of a wide range of azimuth angles. Verifiable by: Brian Butters, brian.butters@meontechnology.com (formerly at Chemring Countermeasures Ltd).

Title: Simulating pre-emptive countermeasures of varying performance against a Man-Portable Air-Defence (MANPAD) system with a track angle bias counter-countermeasure (CCM)
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded Chemring Plc, world leaders in the production of pyrotechnics and countermeasures.This work on advanced missile modelling has helped the company in its delivery of training to overseas customers and resulted in a product improvement plan for the CounterSim model, which is Chemring's principle engagement modelling software. It was able to demonstrate advanced features of reticle seekers and was adopted by Chemring engineers when developing improved models for the licensing of the CounterSim model to overseas markets. Verifiable by: Brian Butters, brian.butters@meontechnology.com  (formerly at Chemring Countermeasures Ltd).

Title: Using DInSAR to separate surface and sub-surface features
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
AdditionalInformation: SAR is the main imaging tool for airborne and spaceborne radar platforms, but there is a gap in our ability to map, or even determine, sub-surface features in SAR imagery, from geological scales down to individual pixels. (Contact: Dr Matt Nolan, Univ. Alaska Fairbanks, matt@drmattnolan.org.) Current schemes rely on close-proximity ground penetrating radar, which severely restricts the size of area that can be investigated. The paper reports a new technique that provides, for the first time, sub-surface mapping at large stand-off distances applicable to space platforms, and at sub-wavelength vertical resolutions. (Contact: Bernhard Rabus, MacDonald Dettwiler Assoc. Ltd (Canada), brabus@mdacorporation.com).

Title: Laboratory measurement of the DInSAR response to spatiotemporal variations in soil moisture
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
AdditionalInformation: The paper was the result of an international collaboration between US and European academic and industrial partners under US DoD’s “DEPSCOR” (Defense Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research). It provides the first definitive confirmation of a relationship between soil moisture and phase signature in SAR radar imagery. Previously, only backscatter has been used to estimate this important environmental parameter. The research showed how a complex, but smoothly varying, pattern developed across a soil surface as the moisture content changed. Contacts for corroboration: Andreas Wiesmann, GAMMA Remote Sensing (Switzerland), wiesmann@gamma-rs.ch, and Alessandro Ferretti, Telerilevamento Europa T.R.E. (Italy), Alessandro.ferretti@treuropa.com).

Title: Tomographic profiling - a technique for multi-incidence-angle retrieval of the vertical SAR backscattering profiles of biogeophysical targets
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
AdditionalInformation: The new radar imaging technique of SAR Tomographic Profiling was reported, with application to forest canopies, snowpacks, and ice sheets. Advantages include greatly reduced data collection requirements compared with conventional methods, and simultaneous capture of vertical profiles over a range of incidence angles with a single measurement (see contact below). The technique has been adopted in a new collaboration between Cranfield University and the Norwegian Forest and Landscape Institute, for the study of Norwegian spruce. Contact: Professor Svein Solberg, Norwegian Forest and Landscape Institute, post@skogoglandskap.no.

Title: Ground-based C-Band tomographic profiling (TP) of a conifer forest stand
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides the first outdoor application of the new Tomographic Profiling technique to forestry. A field campaign used an outdoor radar system to provide imagery through a forest canopy at unprecedented detail down to decimetre resolution. Only indoor laboratory measurements have previously provided imagery with similar resolution, so demonstration of a comparable capability with outdoor targets is important for seeing in detail how a radar wave interacts with a real forestry canopy. This is necessary for a fuller and more timely exploitation of airborne and satellite radar imagery. Contact Professor Svein Solberg, Norwegian Forest and Landscape Institute, post@skogoglandskap.no.

Title: Refractive index sensitivity of fibre-optic long period gratings coated with SiO2 nanoparticle mesoporous thin films
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from an on-going multi-disciplinary, collaborative research project with Kitakyushu University, Japan, building on work on functionally coated fibre optic long period gratings that was pioneered at Cranfield (awarded 1st prize in the Frontier Science and Measurement Category of the National Measurements awards, 2004). The research is significant in that it shows enhanced sensitivity to materials surrounding the fibre over a wider range of refractive indices.  The collaboration was facilitated by an EPSRC Challenging Engineering project (EP/D506654/1) and EPSRC Platform grant (GR/T09149).

Title: Surface strain measurement of rotating objects using pulsed laser shearography with coherent fibre-optic imaging bundles
AdditionalInformation: An output from research initiated during a program supported by the EPSRC (GR/N11872/01), the Civil Aviation Authority and Augusta Westland, ‘Damage Detection and Damage Tolerance in Rotating Mechanical Systems’. The research shows how to measure quantitatively, without physical contact, the full surface strain over an extended area on a rotating object. This paper led to an invited review paper with an international co-author, Shearography technology and applications: a review, Measurement Science and Technology, 21, 102001 (29pp), 2010.

Title: Speckle velocimetry for high accuracy odometry for a Mars exploration rover
AdditionalInformation:
This research was completed under a PPARC CREST programme (PP/D006775) led by EADS Astrium and an EPSRC Platform grant (GR/T09149/01). The research demonstrated location and navigation accuracy to levels suitable for fully autonomous manoeuvres for the Mars rover. This led to on-going industrial collaboration with EADS Astrium, a follow on grant (EPSRC EP/H019839/1, £282k) to further develop the technique. 
Contact lester.waugh@astrium.eads.net

Title: Using integrating spheres with wavelength modulation spectroscopy: effect of pathlength distribution on 2nd harmonic signals
AdditionalInformation: Integrating spheres offer the potential for gas detection in environments subject to high levels of vibration and g-loading. This paper shows that it is possible to predict and therefore remove nonlinearities in the measurement. It forms part of a research programme on integrating spheres in Tuneable Diode Laser Absorption Spectroscopy (TDLAS) that has led to follow-on projects funded by NERC (NE/K008307) and the Royal Society Paul Instrument Fund (PI120057) to study feasibility of their use in environmental monitoring in challenging locations.

Title: Energy optimal waypoint guidance synthesis for anti-ship missiles
VolumeTitle: Ieee Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an outcome of collaborative research with the Korean ADD (Agency of Defence Development). The developed method can significantly imporve guidance performance not only of anti-ship missiles, but also of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) (contact Dr Jin-Ik Lee through 'jinjjanggu@gmail.com).

Title: Rendezvous and standoff target tracking guidance using differential geometry
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by DSTL funded research project under the Competetion of Idea programme. The proposed approach enables the fundamentals for operation of multiple UAVs (contact Alasdair Hunter, DSTL, AHUNTER@mail.dstl.gov.uk). It led to a follow-on research project funded by CDE (Centre of Defence Enterprise).

Title: Classification of personnel targets by acoustic micro-doppler signatures
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by the EPSRC and the UK MoD through a University Defence Research Centre (UDRC) grant (EP/H011625, £95k). It resulted in the collection of micro-Doppler signatures of personnel targets at 80 kHz for the first time and led to a collaboration with the European Commission Joint Research Centre to investigate its extension to detect underwater asymmetric threats (Contact franco.oliveri@jrc.ec.europa.eu). The output forms part of two NATO reports (RTO-EN-SET-172, 2011 and RTO-EN-SET-172-2012, 2012) and led to an invitation to present the results at a workshop (W20: MicroDoppler Analysis - Signatures & Applications) at the European Microwave Week conference (EuRAD) 2011.

Title: Three-component planar velocity measurements using Mach-Zehnder interferometric filter-based planar Doppler velocimetry (MZI-PDV)
AdditionalInformation: Significance of research indicated by inclusion in IOP Select, a collection of articles over 12 months nominated by journal editors for their novelty, importance and potential future impact (http://iopscience.iop.org/collections?collection_type=SELECT). This resulted in an invited review paper on optical fibre velocimetry for the journal Measurement Science and Technology (Charrett, James and Tatam, 23, 032001 (32pp), 2012).                                       Additional measurement channels reduce errors in measured velocity, and have been successfully applied in other imaging instrumentation (e.g. Charrett, Francis and Tatam, Applied Optics, 50 (2) 134-146, 2011) and led to a further EPSRC grant (EP/G033900) in the area of flow measurement.

Title: Frequency-division multiplexing for multicomponent shearography
AdditionalInformation: This work arose as an output of EPSRC grant EP/G033900 on the application of novel modulation techniques for imaging flow measurement instrumentation. Modulation techniques investigated under the grant were also applied, for the first time, to shearography measurement of surface strain fields, allowing simultaneous acquisition of both components of in-plane strain.

Title: Quantitative shearography: error reduction by using more than three measurement channels
AdditionalInformation: This research was completed under an EPSRC platform grant (EP/H02252X) and applies techniques developed for optical flow measurement to the related strain measurement technique of shearography Specifically, an additional measurement channel was shown to reduce errors in the strain components by up to 33%, offering a simple means to improve the performance of shearography in industrial environments.

Title: Objective speckle velocimetry for autonomous vehicle odometry
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an output of an on-going industrial collaboration with EADS Astrium under an EPSRC responsive mode grant (EP/H019839). It forms part of a programme of research on odometry instrumentation developed for space exploration rovers and other autonomous vehicles with improved accuracy compared to current methods (Lester.WAUGH@astrium.eads.net).

Title: Multi-component strain development in superconducting magnet coils monitored using fibre Bragg grating sensors fabricated in highly linearly birefringent fibre
AdditionalInformation: Research undertaken in collaboration with Oxford Instruments (OIS), making measurements of loads induced in energised superconducting magnets, providing insights not possible using other technologies. Transfer of this technology to OIS has enabled OIS to maintain its world leading position  in ultra-high field magnets  for state-of-the-art NMR technology. The sensors are now used routinely in measuring the dynamic strain performance of flagship 950MHz magnet coils, currently the highest strength commerically available NMR magnets, enabling their successful and safe operation. (Dr Andrew Twin, Oxford Instruments (a.twin@oxinst.co.uk))

Title: A simple and wavelength-flexible procedure for fabricating phase-shifted fibre Bragg gratings
AdditionalInformation: An output from research undertaken during a joint ESPRC-Airbus funded project, Optical fibre sensors for skin friction measurement 2 (EP/F005121). This research led to an invitation to bbe a partner in the EU FP 7 project entitled Advanced In-Flight Measurement Techniques (AIM2), a 4M Euro programme, 670k Euro to Cranfield, to further develop the technology. Dr Fritz Boden, DLR, Göttingen, Germany. (fritz.boden@dlr.de) EU Project reference 266107.

Title: Enhanced sensitivity fibre Bragg grating (FBG) load sensor
AdditionalInformation: An output from an EPSRC 'Challenging Engineering' project (EP/D506654), developing  optical fiber sensors for geotechnical applications.The principle demonstrated here was used to develop a pore-water pressure sensor that is being assessed for use in civil engineering applications by UCL. Contact Dr Raul Fuentes <r.fuentes@ucl.ac.uk>

Title: Multiplexing a serial array of tapered optical fibre sensors using coherent optical frequency domain reflectometry
AdditionalInformation: An output from EU Framework 7 project, Advanced Integrated Composite Tail Cone, ADVITAC (EU project reference 234290), a consortium including Daher Aerospace, Embraer (Brazil) and the Dutch National Aerospace Laboratory (NLR), investigating, for the first time, novel resin carbon-fibre composite construction of an aircraft tailcone assembly. Also new was the integration of fibre optic tapers within the lay-up structure for resin-flow monitoring during manufacture.( Stephanie PORTET, s.portet@daher.com, Fabiano Lobato, lobato@embraer.com.br, Chris Groenendijk, groenendijk@nlr.nl.) Selected for inclusion in Measurement Science and Technology’s Highlights (2013), ‘A compilation of outstanding papers from the last year and special 90th anniversary content’.

Title: Tunable circularly polarized lasing emission in distributed feedback dye lasers
AdditionalInformation:
The research describes a  laser tuning mechanism using the interaction of light with chiral molecules for the first time. The outcome has driven Prof. Nunzi's research field on the fabrication of chiral structures using light matter interactions and the success of achieving Tier 1 Canada Research Chair in Chiral Photonics (Queen's University, Canada, $1.4M)
The research contributed to the initialization of the Queens University CREATE Graduate school and research programme on Chiral materials 
(http://www.chem.queensu.ca/create/index.html) 
(Contact Prof. Nunzi: nunzijm@queensu.ca)

Title: Electrochemical sensor for catechol and dopamine based on a catalytic molecularly imprinted polymer-conducting polymer hybrid recognition element
AdditionalInformation: Research sponsored by the Royal Society (FI071114). The development of novel conductive and polymerisable monomers useful for a variety of applications from enhanced electrochemical sensors to invisible inks for security has led to other outputs: A patent, Lakshmi et al., EP2269194 (granted); 5 other papers including Berti et al., Biosensors & Bioelectronics, 2010; authorship of 2 book chapters (Lakshmi et al., 2010, in Polymers in Defence and Aerospace; Chianella et al., in Molecularly Imprinted Sensors), and international collaborations with Prof. Marrazza (Italy, giovanna.marrazza@unifi.it), Dr Faglia (Italy, guido.faglia@ing.unibs.it) and Prof. Güven (Turkey, guven@hacettepe.edu.tr).

Title: Quasi-monodimensional polyaniline nanostructures for enhanced molecularly imprinted polymer-based sensing
AdditionalInformation: The research shows how integration of nanowires of conductive polymer in electrochemical sensors can improve performance as compared with the same sensors without nanofeatures (Lakshmi et al., 2009, Analytical Chemistry). The results have led to the publication of a book chapter (Berti et al., 2011 in Sensors and Microsystems, Springer Science + Business Media). The novel approach has been adopted by CNR-INFM Sensor Laboratory for the development of gas sensors (contact Dr Faglia, guido.faglia@ing.unibs.it).

Title: Selection of imprinted nanoparticles by affinity chromatography
AdditionalInformation: Research to develop a pioneering method to synthesise molecularly imprinted polymer nanoparticles, which resulted in a fabrication method suitable for industrial manufacturing. Work has led to several other outputs: 2 patents (US8192762, GB2495376, both granted), 4 papers (Poma et al., Advanced Functional Materials, 2013; Moczko et al., Nanoscale, 2013; Moczko et al., Langmuir, 2013, Chianella et al., Analytical Chemistry, 2013), a grant from Wellcome Trust (09771/Z/11/Z/) and a EU project (Chebana, FP7-PEOPLE-2010-ITN-264772); Negotiations to create a spin-out company based on the technology are also in progress (Dr Simon Turner, simon@canopus-manangement.co.uk and Dr Anthony Walker, awalker@alacritaconsulting.com).

Title: New reactive polymer for protein immobilisation on sensor surfaces
AdditionalInformation: Manuscript describes the first application of a novel polymer based on a well-known chemistry for biosensors development. The polymer allows a straightforward and versatile immobilisation of any biomolecule on sensor surfaces. Work sponsored by the EU in the frame of the project BIOGNOSIS, FP6-2004-IST-NMP2, coordinated by Siemens AG (matthias.schreiter@siemens.com). The research reported here has led to 2 following publications: Kyprianou et al. Biosensors and Bioelectronics, 2010 and Kyprianou et al. Talanta, 2013, plus discussions with sensor companies on exploitation are currently on going (e.g. Siemens Technology Accelerator GmbH, Stephan.buchholz@siemens.com).

Title: Characterization of optical fiber imaging bundles for swept-source optical coherence tomography
AdditionalInformation:
Featured in an internationally-distributed list of ‘Top Downloads’, covering the two years prior to November 2012, from three highly-ranked publications published by the Optical Society of America (osa@osacommunications.org). Selected for inclusion in the Virtual Journal for Biomedical Optics 6 (3), 2011.
Led to an industrial research project with Procter and Gamble, with our OCT work allowing them to validate their finite element models of detergent packaging capsules. Contact: Dr Miguel Brandt  brandt.m.2@pg.com.

Title: Spatially-resolved volume monitoring of adhesive cure using correlated-image optical coherence tomography
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Adhesion and Adhesives
AdditionalInformation: First application of OCT to adhesive cure monitoring in situ, providing spatially-resolved information not previously obtainable by other methods. Selected as ‘Feature of the Week’ (w.c. 05/02/13) in ‘OCT News’, the primary web-based archive for the OCT community that collates details of over 2000 articles per annum on OCT research (Contact: OCT News editor Eric Swanson, eric@hivefire.com). Also featured in 'Advances in Engineering', which alerts the scientific community to breaking journal articles considered important to progress in Engineering technologies (advanceseng.com).

Title: Passive OCT probe head for 3D duct inspecton
AdditionalInformation:
This research was supported by an EPSRC responsive-mode grant EP/F034679/1, and a Platform Grant EP/H02252X/1.
The potential of this technique for small-diameter pipeline inspection, and precision measurements of departure from cylindrical symmetry, e.g. in pistons, has led directly to the award of a follow-on grant (PI120020), from the Royal Society Paul Instrument Fund (Francois.Meullenet@royalsociety.org)

Title: Hierachically Structured Hollow Silica Spheres for High Efficiency Immobilization of Enzymes
AdditionalInformation:
The work was funded by the Research Directorate-General of
European Commission under
the FP7 framework, Marie Curie Action (Ge). The significance of the paper led to it being selected and published as a Front Inside Cover by the journal.

Title: A Catalytic and Positively Thermosensitive Molecularly Imprinted Polymer
AdditionalInformation:
The work was funded by the European Commission under
the FP7 framework, Marie Curie Action (Ge). The research was recognised by the Organisation Committee of the 20th World Congress on Biosensors with the invitation to present a keynote oral presentation (Conference Chair - Prof. Anthony P. F. Turner: anthony.turner@liu.se).

Title: A zipper-like on/off-switchable molecularly imprinted polymer
AdditionalInformation:
The work was funded by the European Commission under
the FP7 framework, Marie Curie Action (Ge). The original research proposal was assessed and graded as a top one with a score of 99.1 out of 100. The results of the research led to an invitation for a plenary oral presentation at the 1st International Congress on Advanced Materials (Conference Chair - Pro.  Xin Cheng: chengxin@ujn.edu.cn).

Title: A Temperature-Responsive Nanoreactor
AdditionalInformation:
The work was funded by the Research Directorate-General of
European Commission under
the FP7 framework, Marie Curie Action (Ge). The original research proposal was assessed and graded as a top one with a score of 99.1 out of 100. The research outcome has generated and then catalysed  further collaborations with Jiangsu University, China (Contact Prof. S.J.Li: Lsjchem@ujs.edu.cn). A joint laboratory is under development.

Title: Development status of the life marker chip instrument for ExoMars
AdditionalInformation: Research performed by the international LMC (Life Marker Chip) consortium led by Sims (Leicester – Consortium PI) (mrs@leicester.ac.uk) and Cullen (Cranfield - Consortium Deputy PI) has resulted in national funding for European and UK partners - Cranfield funding includes STFC grants ST/H003606 (£452,043), ST/I000399 (£83,000), ST/I002197 (£2,213,896), ST/G00885X (£56,458) and ST/H001255 (£250,122). Has raised the international profile of, and de-risked the concept of, immunoassay-based instruments as a viable approach to use in planetary exploration (contact to corroborate: Andrew Steele, Geophysical Laboratory, Carnegie Insitute of Washington, USAasteele@ciw.edu)

Title: Immunological detection of small organic molecules in the presence of perchlorates: relevance to the life marker chip and life detection on Mars.
AdditionalInformation: A key observation demonstrating the Life Marker Chip (LMC) approach does not suffer from recently discovered presence of perchlorate in Martian samples, which strengthened the case for future use of LMC technology to find evidence of life on Mars. Funded via STFC grant ST/I002197/1 (£2,213,896). Contact to corroborate - Prof Charles Cockell, University of Edinburgh - c.s.cockell@ed.ac.uk

Title: Effects of simulated space radiation on immunoassay components for life-detection experiments in planetary exploration missions.
AdditionalInformation: Output of Cranfield-led task within the pan-European Life Marker Chip (LMC) Consortium that strengthens / de-risks the evolving case for the development of LMC, and LMC-like instrumentation, for in situ use on Mars in the search for evidence of life. Contact to corroborate - Andrew Steele, Geophysical Laboratory, Carnegie Insitute of Washington, USA - asteele@ciw.edu. Funded via STFC grant ST/I002197/1 (£2,213,896).

Title: Survivability of immunoassay reagents exposed to the space radiation environment on board the ESA BIOPAN-6 platform as a prelude to performing immunoassays on Mars
AdditionalInformation: Output of international consortium that contributed the only space flight validation to date, demonstrating for the first time that it is viable to send immunoassay reagents to Mars without mass penalty of added radiation shielding. (Contact to corroborate - Prof Charles Cockell, University of Edinburgh - c.s.cockell@ed.ac.uk).  It therefore created the context for further funding to develop such instrumentation for Mars exploration – specifically the subsequent pan-European national funding of the Life Marker Chip (LMC) consortium including Cranfield funding via STFC grants ST/H003606/1 (£452,043), ST/I000399/1 (£83,000), ST/I002197/1 (£2,213,896), ST/G00885X/1 (£56,458) and ST/H001255/1 (£250,122).

Title: Labeless Immunosensor Assay for Prostate Specific Antigen with Picogram per Milliliter Limits of Detection Based upon an ac Impedance Protocol
AdditionalInformation: The results from this work are modified electrochemical microelectrode arrays for use in sensors or biosensors, allowing greatly lowered limits of detection than would otherwise be possible. This contributed to the commercial development of Microarray Ltd www.microarray.co.uk (stuart.collyer@microarray.co.uk) with this technology forming a key part of the company’s IPR. In turn this technology has led to the development of a number of highly sensitive and selective electrochemical sensors for analytes of physiological significance, including, for example, marker proteins for cancer or stroke.

Title: Label-less Immunosensor Assay for Myelin Basic Protein Based upon an ac Impedance Protocol
AdditionalInformation: This work was an output of an EC contract ‘ELISHA’ [FP6-2002-NMP-1] and contributed to the formation of a start-up company, ELISHA systems Ltd http://www.immunosensor.com   (P.A.Millner@leeds.ac.uk).  The methods used for the immobilisation of biological receptors at electrode surfaces modified with conducting polymers forms a core part of ELISHA systems Ltd technology. The technology also contributed to the sponsorship of a further project by Unilever plc www.unilever.co.uk (Robert.Treloar@unilever.com).

Title: Characterization of Langmuir-Blodgett films of a calix[8]arene and sensing properties towards volatile organic vapors
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the formation and characterisation of thin films that display sensing properties for volatile organic compounds. As a result of this, Leksing Ltd (www.leksing.co.uk) funded a research programme which sought to combine the macrocyclic hosts with fibre optic grating technology to develop optical sensors capable of quantifying levels of aromatic compounds / solvents in air. Contact: Michael Collins mike@leksing.co.uk.

Title: Calix[4]resorcinarene-surfactant complexes: formulation, structure and potential sensor applications
AdditionalInformation: The development of a new series of liquid crystalline materials, based on macrocyclic compounds and surfactants described in this paper, resulted in a series of sensor materials that gave optical responses on binding environmental pollutants. An output of this work and other work led Leksing Ltd  (www.leksing.co.uk) to fund a project to investigate these and other materials immobilised on optical fibre gratings to allow quantification of waterborne or airborne pollutants. Contact: Michael Collins mike@leksing.co.uk.

Title: Labeless AC impedimetric antibody-based sensors with pg ml-1 sensitivities for point-of-care biomedical applications.
AdditionalInformation: A novel fabrication approach for microelectrode arrays, developed within this research, allows for lower limits of detection for electrochemical sensors or biosensors than would otherwise be possible. This work contributed to the commercial development of Microarray Ltd, www.microarray.co.uk (stuart.collyer@microarray.co.uk). The fabrication approach for microelectrode arrays forms a key part of the company’s IPR and has to date been used to develop a number of highly sensitive and selective electrochemical sensors for analytes of physiological significance, including marker proteins for, for example, psoriasin, myelin basic protein and neuron specific enolase.

Title: Investigations into the Use of Screen Printed Carbon Electrodes as Templates for Electrochemical Sensors and Sonochemically Fabricated Microelectrode Arrays
AdditionalInformation: This work is of crucial importance to Microarray Ltd, www.microarray.co.uk, for the reproducible manufacture of electrochemical sensors and biosensors using screen printed substrates (stuart.collyer@microarray.co.uk). Screen printed electrode-based sensor technology forms the core of the business for Microarray. The technology developed here also formed an integral part of a successful application to the TSB for funding of a project Intelliheal: project number TPAC057G,  the outputs of which (smart wound dressings incorporating embedded sensors) are currently undergoing clinical trial at the University Hospital of Wales, Cardiff. HardingKG@cardiff.ac.uk.

Title: Detection of Fluoroquinolone Antibiotics in Milk via a Labeless Immunoassay Based upon an Alternating Current Impedance Protocol
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrated a method whereby an analyte of biological significance (in this case an antibiotic) could be measured in a complex biological matrix such as milk. This work directly led to us to secure sponsorship from Unilever, www.unilever.co.uk,  towards a research programme consisting of two further related projects (Robert.Treloar@unilever.com).

Title: Sol-gel based sensor for selective formaldehyde determination
AdditionalInformation: This paper discusses development of a synthetic protocol for an inexpensive colourimetric sensor for formaldehyde, using a sol-gel based method. This initial study led to additional sponsorship by Leksing Ltd, www.leksing.co.uk,  (Contact: Michael Collins, mike@leksing.co.uk), and demonstrated that these sensors could be used to determine indoor air quality and to assess the levels of formaldehyde given off by materials such as MDF, used in many indoor furnishings.

Title: Using integrating spheres as absorption cells: path-length distribution and application of Beer's law
AdditionalInformation: Integrating spheres are sold as spectrometer accessories. This research was completed under Hodgkinson's EPSRC Advanced Research Fellowship (GR/T04595) and First Grant (GR/T04601). It allows accurate calibration and use at higher signal to noise ratios than previously possible. The work has been cited in the Applied Photometry textbook (Springer Series in Optical Sciences, vol 163, 2012). It also led to an invited review article (Optical Gas Sensing: A Review, Hodgkinson and Tatam, Measurement Science and Technology 24, 012004 (59pp), doi:10.1088/0957-0233/24/1/0120042013) – on the journal’s top ten downloads since publication (no. 1 at time of writing).

Title: Gas cells for tunable diode laser absorption spectroscopy employing optical diffusers. Part 1: single and dual pass cells
AdditionalInformation:
This research pioneered the use of optical diffusers to make easily aligned gas absorption cells. Funded via an EPSRC Advanced Fellowship (GR/T04595) and First Grant (GR/T04601). 

Impact: 

• Technique used by Siemens for in situ measurement of oxygen in industrial boilers (Chen et al, Appl Phys B 100: 417–425, 2010), contact Rainer.Strzoda@siemens.com.

• TSB funded Knowledge Transfer Project (KTP 0006825) with Geotechnical Instruments Ltd, supplier of landfill gas monitors with 65% of the global market. Contact Dr A Kannath, a.kannath@geotech.co.uk

Title: Methane-specific gas detectors: the effect of natural gas composition
AdditionalInformation:
Relates to gas leak detection by utility-operated gas emergency services, which in the UK, for example, involves ~5,000 frontline staff, responding to >1M public reported gas escapes pa. 



Impact:



•	A revision to the National Grid technical specification for hand-portable gas leak detectors. Previous version was adopted as a default standard by the gas distribution industry worldwide. (Mr G Murray, goldie.murray@nationalgrid.com).

•	Two granted patents outlining sensing methods that maintain accuracy in safety-critical leak detection (WO0157499, WO0194916).

•	Collaboration with Siemens UK and Siemens München to develop a new instrument for gas leak detection. (Dr R Strzoda, Rainer.Strzoda@siemens.com).

Title: Non-dispersive infra-red (NDIR) measurement of carbon dioxide at 4.2 μm in a compact and optically efficient sensor
AdditionalInformation:
Resulted from collaboration with Alphasense Ltd, a UK manufacturer of OEM gas sensor modules. 
Impact:

•	Novel optical design patented (EP1972923, 2008, worldwide filing, granted in US) and brought to market

• Marketed as having “best in class” signal to noise ratio
, for use in demand-activated heating and ventilation control of buildings, industrial safey and others
•	Extension to company’s UK manufacturing capability with their first optical sensor

•	Ongoing collaboration with Alphasense (£130k) resulting in two further worldwide patent applications
Contact Dr John Saffell, Technical Director, jrs@alphasense.com.

Title: Fiber optic long period grating sensors with a nanoassembled mesoporous film of SiO2 nanoparticles
AdditionalInformation: An output from an on-going multi-disciplinary research collaboration with Kitakyushu University, Japan, building on work on functionally coated fibre optic long period gratings that was pioneered at Cranfield (awarded 1st prize in the Frontier Science and Measurement Category of the National Measurements awards, 2004). The research enables more reliable fabrication and better signal to noise ratios than previously. The collaboration was facilitated by an EPSRC Challenging Engineering project (EP/D506654)

Title: Optical fibre long period grating based selective vapour sensing of volatile organic compounds
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a multi-disciplinary, collaborative research project, funded via EPSRC Platform grant GR/T12408/01, building on work on functionally coated fibre optic long period gratings that was pioneered at Cranfield (awarded 1st prize in the Frontier Science and Measurement Category of the National Measurements awards, 2004).

Title: Optical fibre long period grating with a nanoporous coating formed from silica nanoparticles for ammonia sensing in water
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from an on-going multi-disciplinary research collaboration with Kitakyushu University, Japan, building on work on functionally coated fibre optic long period gratings that was pioneered at Cranfield (awarded 1st prize in the Frontier Science and Measurement Category of the National Measurements awards, 2004). Further development of the work in this paper to develop a point of care diagnostic instrument, in collaboration with the Open University, Addenbrookes Hospital and Kitakyushu University, is to be funded under an EPSRC grant, EP/L010437/1, awarded October 2013.

Title: Response of fibre optic long period gratings operating near the phase matching turning point to the deposition of nanostructured coatings.
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Optical Society of America B-Optical Physics
AdditionalInformation: Further development of research pioneered at Cranfield (awarded 1st prize in the Frontier Science and Measurement Category of the National Measurements awards, 2004). The experimental results confirm previously reported theoretical predictions.

Title: Experimental and Computational Investigation of an "Open" Transonic Cavity Flow
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This project was funded by the EPSRC and MBDA Missile Systems to measure flow data from transonic cavities using particle image velocimetry (PIV). The data obtained was input into missile flight physics simulation validation at MBDA Missile Systems. (Contact Mr Alan Roberts formerly MBDA Missile Systems, contact details available on request).

Title: Coupled piezoelectric fans with two degree of freedom motion for the application of flapping wing micro aerial vehicles
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded through EPSRC Grant EP/C511190 in collaboration with Servocell Ltd to investigate the application of piezoelectric based flapping systems as a solid state electronics cooling fan  (Contact Dr Paul M. Weaver, Servocell PBT Ltd, Harlow, Essex, U.K.).  A similar flapping device was also studied as a potential propulsion system for a micro air vehicle.

Title: Development of piezoelectric fans for flapping wing application
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded through EPSRC Grant EP/C511190 in collaboration with Servocell Ltd to investigate the application of piezoelectric based flapping systems as a solid state electronics cooling fan  (Contact Dr Paul M. Weaver, Servocell PBT Ltd, Harlow, Essex, UK).  A similar flapping device was also studied as a potential propulsion system for a micro air vehicle.

Title: Experimental study of unsteadiness in supersonic shock-wave/turbulent boundary-layer interactions with separation
AdditionalInformation: This work was sponsored by the Indian Government through the Indian Defence Research and Development Laboratory under contract DRDL/33/96P/05/0750/31824 (value £70k). The programme was designed to improve understanding of aero-thermal effects on launch vehicles and to improve semi-empirical prediction methods particularly in relation to localised effects (and as a result structural integrity) caused by surface excressecences at the freestream Mach numbers experienced during a typical trajectory to earth orbit, contact Dr Panneerselvam Subramanian (hyd2_panneers@yahoo.co.in)

Title: X-ray imaging and spectroscopy using low cost COTS CMOS sensors
VolumeTitle: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces new opportunities for inexpensive X-ray instruments using commercial off-the-shelf technology for simultaneous imaging and spectroscopy. The research resulted in an invitation from David Taylor (organising committee member, djt35@btinternet.com) to present at the Spring Meeting of the British Crystallographic Association (University of Keele, 13th April 2011). It formed part of the background to a review of X-ray backscatter imaging funded by DSTL which they have used to target their future research into new military X-ray imaging technologies (DSTLX100007769) (contact: Dr Robert Moss, RMMOSS@mail.dstl.gov.uk).

Title: Combinatorial optimization of Al-doped ZnO films for thin-film photovoltaics
AdditionalInformation: This research was a collaboration between Cranfield University, Liverpool University, Glyndwr University and part of the EPSRC SUPERGEN consortium PV21 (EP/F029624), with six  academic and five industrial collaborators including Pilkington Technology, now NSG Group, one of the world's largest manufacturers of transparent conducting oxide coated glass. The outputs included the optimum conditions to grow aluminium doped zinc oxide for thin film solar cells  (neil.mcsporran@pilkington.com).
