Title: In situ analysis of cadmium sulphide chemical bath deposition by an optical fibre monitor
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded as part of the EPSRC SUPERGEN consortium PV21 (EP/F029624) that had eight other academic members and five industrial collaborators. This paper was the first report of an optical fibre monitor of chemical bath deposition. Its use results in production of less toxic cadmium waste. The technique can also be used for other semiconductor deposition processes such as MOCVD (Prof Stuart Irvine, stuart.irvine@optictechnium.com.).

Title: An approach to high-throughput X-ray diffraction analysis of combinatorial polycrystalline thin film libraries
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded as part of the EPSRC PV21 consortium (EP/F029624). It removes an analysis bottleneck in combinatorial screening for materials investigation (gregoire@caltech.edu). The new technique has been applied to thin film catalysts for fuel cells and materials for solar cells in a further collaborative study with Cornell University (John M. Gregoire now at Caltech, gregoire@caltech.edu), the University of Bath and the Diamond Light Source (Roncallo S. et al, Analytical Chemistry, 82 (11) (2010) 4564-4569).

Title: Torque ripple reduction of a direct-drive permanent-magnet synchronous machine by material-efficient axial pole pairing
AdditionalInformation: This research resulted in a motor design which  reduces use of rare-earth metals by over 10% without compromising  performance, thus providing a greener and more sustainable solution for the uptake of electric vehicle and wind generator markets (contact msatur@ArnoldMagnetics.com). This paper was instrumental in securing an EPSRC grant of £340k within a £3.5m consortium on Vehicle Electrical System Integration (EP/I038543), to further develop the technology, including industrial partners Arnold Magnetic Technologies Ltd (msatur@ArnoldMagnetics.com)

Title: A new technique of cogging torque suppression in direct-drive permanent-magnet brushless machines
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted in a new technique to enhance the performance of an electrical machine for electric vehicle applications. The research findings from this paper  led to a £1M grant from TSB (Grant Ref: 1110_CRD_ENS_SCI) to implement the technique in real-world scenarios and develop a low cost electric vehicle technology demonstrator by the end of 2014. Partners are   Liberty Electric Cars Ltd and Agility Global Ltd (contact colin.smith@liberty-ecars.com)

Title: Torque Analysis of Permanent-Magnet Flux Switching Machines With Rotor Step Skewing
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a research collaboration between Zhejiang University and Cranfield University.  The research findings were crucial in securing a joint EPSRC funding of £855K (EP/L001063) with Queens University Belfast, on developing a motor-traction-charging system for Grid Interfaced Vehicles. The project is matched funded by China’s funding council NSFC to support Harbin Institute of Technology, China Electric Power Research Institute, and Shanghai Electric Company, resulting in an £1.2M International Consortium. Contact Dr Jeremy Colandairaj, Northern Ireland Electricity (email available on request)

Title: Tuning Class E Inverters Applied In Inductive Links Using Saturable Reactors
AdditionalInformation: This paper pioneers the use of a saturable reactor to control the Class E converter in wireless power transfer applications, allowing maximum efficiency with variations of loading conditions.  Built on from the considerable work undertaken by the TSB-funded High Frequency Power And Data Distribution (HIFPADD) project (Ref: TP/5/POW/6/I/H0049D), this paper exploits the developed converter technology and is the first of four recently accepted high impact factor journal publications on Class E converters in wireless power transfer.  The technology is being commercialized by industry partners Juice Technology  (contact Ian Turner, CEO, iturner@juicetechnology.co.uk) and Isotera Ltd (www.isotera.com).

Title: Cyclostationarity of Acoustic Emissions (AE) for monitoring bearing defects
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration between University of Mons—UMONS, Belgium, Université de Reims Champagne-Ardenne, France and Cranfield University. This research showed that Acoustic Emissions (AE) associated with defective rolling element bearings exhibited cyclostationarity properties. This discovery advances the use of the AE technology as a diagnostic tool for assessing mechanical integrity of rotating machinery. (Contact: Xavier CHIEMENTIN xavier.chiementin@univ-reims.fr)

Title: Accelerated natural fault diagnosis in slow speed bearings with Acoustic Emission
AdditionalInformation: This research demonstrated the ability of the Acoustic Emission technology to identify, in-situ, the geometric location of a sub-surface defect on a bearing race under conditions that encouraged the natural degradation process of a rolling element bearing. The outcome of this paper led to Lloyds Register sponsoring a follow-on research project (£50k) to further develop the applicability of the technology in industry. Contact: Siva Koppal (siva.koppal@lr.org)

Title: A finite element-based algorithm for rubbing induced vibration prediction in rotors
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration between the Department of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran, the Mechanical Department, Shoushtar Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shoushtar, Iran, and Cranfield University. Under the scope of machine rotor dynamics and diagnosis this research led to development of a novel numerical method for predicting rotor response due to induced stator-rotor rubbing phenomena. This has the advantage of modelling the stator as a deformable body thereby enhancing model predictions. (Contact: Professor Behzad, Sharif University, m_behzad@sharif.edu)

Title: Acoustic emission and gas-phase measurements in two-phase flow
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper explores the application of a new technique for multi-phase flow measurements particularly for conditions that hitherto commercially available systems cannot cope with. The paper received two awards; the Ludwig Mond prize from the Institute of Mechanical Engineering (IMechE) in 2010 – in recognition of the best contribution to the progress of Mechanical engineering of interest to the chemical industry (UK), and, the SAGE award for the best paper published in 2010 in the Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering (IMechE).

Title: Multi-criteria assessment of offshore wind turbine support structures
AdditionalInformation: This research provided detailed results concerning the performance of fixed and floating foundations for offhsore wind turbines. This research has also been extended to two further publications (“Application and extension of the TOPSIS method for the assessment of floating offshore wind turbine support structures” Ships and Offshore Structures and “A Multi-Criteria Decision Making Method to Compare Support Structures for Offshore Wind Turbines” EWEC 2010 Conference). A follow on study is funded by ALSTOM POWER to further perform selection of support structure concepts for specific installations (cost ~£35k, contact: arturo.rodriguez-tsouroukdissian@power.alstom.com)

Title: Time domain prediction of power absorption from ocean waves with latching control
AdditionalInformation: The outcome of this research led to a collaboration with Pelamis Wave Power (http://www.pelamiswave.com/).

Title: Time domain prediction of added resistance of ships
AdditionalInformation: This research is funded by an EU FP7 VIRTUE project (www.virtual-basin.org).

Title: Effect of Thickness variation on collapse pressure of seamless pipes
AdditionalInformation: This research is a collaboration work with INTECSEA (http://www.intecsea.com/).

Title: Subsea processing - a holistic approach to marginal field developments
AdditionalInformation: This research is funded by NDDC (Niger Delta Development Commission) of Nigerian government (http://www.nddc.gov.ng/).

Title: Numerical analysis and experiment of composite sandwich T-joints subjected to pulling load
AdditionalInformation: The outcome of a research project funded by BAE Systems, leading to a method for repairing a failed joint bonded by a new manufacture technique, and simplifying manufacture with improved structural strength. The research has allowed BAE Systems to evaluate and improve the manufacture process of composite joints for a UAV airframe product, with potential for reduced manufacture costs and improved productivity of a sandwich airframe. Contact: Jim Cushing, Tech manager in composite structures; email address: jim.cushing@baesystems.com.

Title: Aeroelastic dynamic response and control of an airfoil section with control surface nonlinearities
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an EC funded FP7 research project “Smart high lift devices for next generation wings (SADE)”, which involved 13 partners including EADS, Airbus, DLR, FOI and TsAGI. The morphing mechanism and modelling developed provide a practical and effective design to improve the aerodynamic performance of the whole wing, especially in take-off and landing. The research has led to evaluation at EADS/Airbus/DLR, assisting further development of morphing wing technology in the next EC framework CleanSky-2. Contact: Hans Peter Monner, Head of Adaptronics Dept, DLR, Germany, email: hans.monner@dlr.de.

Title: Cutout shape and reinforcement design for composite C-section beams under shear load
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the key results of a research project funded by EPSRC/Airbus. A method was demonstrated to improve the design and manufacture of the cutout reinforcement of composite panels. The outcome of the project has been evaluated by Airbus and will feed in to further development of the technique. Contact: Benjamin John Phillip, A350 Program manager, Airbus, email address:  BENJAMIN.PHILLIPS@airbus.com.

Title: Optimum buckling design of composite stiffened panels using ant colony algorithm
AdditionalInformation: An output from research project funded by EPSRC/Airbus. A new optimization method was proposed and applied to a composite stiffened panel for maximum buckling capability. The optimization was subject to practical design rules employed in the aircraft A400M, based on real experience working within Airbus. The research has been evaluated by Airbus and will feed in to further development of the wing design optimization method. Contact: Benjamin John Phillip, A350 Program manager, Airbus, email address:  BENJAMIN.PHILLIPS@airbus.com.

Title: Application of the finite element method to predict the crashworthy response of a metallic helicopter under floor structure onto water.
AdditionalInformation: This work was recognised through the 2009 Derek Astridge Award in Aerospace Safety (IMechE), for widening professional and public awareness in the use of technology for aerospace safety. It arose from an EU FP6 project on development of simulation tools / design guidelines for safe helicopter structures, focussing on crashworthiness onto water and solid surfaces. The coupled Finite Element-Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (FE-SPH) approach and full-scale numerical prediction of helicopter impact onto water led to Cranfield coordinating EU project SMAES – Smart Aircraft in Emergency Situations (FP7-266172) on the development of improved simulation tools for emergency landing (ditching) of aircraft onto water.

Title: From Aerospace to Offshore: Bridging the Numerical Simulation Gaps - Simulation Advancements for Fluid Structure Interaction Problems
AdditionalInformation: Development of numerical methods for fluid-structure interaction problems was initially through a Cranfield led EU FP6 project. Our research on behaviour of structures under extreme water loading was recognised by two awards in 2009 – the Derek Astridge Award (IMechE) for widening professional and public awareness in the use of technology for aerospace safety, and the Medal of Distinction from the Royal Institution of Naval Architects. Development of the coupled Finite Element-Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (FE-SPH) capability, and numerical approaches to modelling water phenomena, including cavitation, led to Cranfield's further participation in FP7 project SMAES – Smart Aircraft in Emergency Situations (FP7-266172) related to aircraft ditching.

Title: Explicit Dynamic Formulation to Demonstrate Compliance against Quasi-Static Aircraft Seat Certification Loads (CS25.561) - Part I : Influence of Time and Mass Scaling
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This research was applied to prototype seat design for a UK based SME (BlueSky Designers Ltd, Dominic Robinson, djr@blueskydesignersltd.com) who secured SEEDA (South East England Development Agency) product development grants in 2009 and 2010, supported by this collaboration. The demonstrated capability led to an automotive seat research project with Jaguar Landrover (Dr Tayeb Zegeur, tzeguer@jaguarlandrover.com).

Title: Explicit dynamic formulation to demonstrate compliance against Quasi-static aircraft seat certification loads (CS25.561) - Part II: Influence of Body Blocks
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part G-Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a project addressing static certification compliance of a next generation civil aircraft seat.  Linking analysis-led-design, numerical simulation and experimental testing, technical outputs resulted in an automotive seat research project with Jaguar Landrover (Dr Tayeb Zegeur, tzeguer@jaguarlandrover.com). Also, sponsored by UK based SME Bluesky Designers Ltd (Dominic Robinson, djr@blueskydesignersltd.com), additional projects followed, as the company secured SEEDA (South East England Development Agency) product development grants in 2009 and 2010 for this collaboration.

Title: Effect of laser shock peening on residual stress and fatigue life of clad 2024 aluminium sheet containing scribe defects
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: An international collaboration between Cranfield, the Open University, Airbus Germany and Metal Improvements (UK) into laser peening treatments to repair mechanical damage in aircraft and control growth of fatigue cracks. This is quicker and less intrusive than cutting out the damaged area and riveting a repair patch. (Domenico Furfari, domenico.furfari@airbus.com) Research results achieved the desired performance, leading to two further industry-funded projects with Airbus. Collaborations also emerged with Metal Improvements and Toshiba, suppliers of laser peen treatments. Airbus now have high Technology-Readiness level internal programmes to further develop other peening treatments to enhance performance of metallic aircraft structures (contact as above).

Title: The response of aluminium/GLARE hybrid materials to impact and to in-plane fatigue
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an outcome of a Cranfield EPSRC/IMRC project (EP/E001874/1) with Airbus UK, Alcoa, Cytec and the Open University as partners. The final report rated it as being “ breakthrough research” and “of major value to partners” (Contact: david.steer@airbus). The research demonstrated the capability of the novel bonded retarder concept to slow down fatigue cracks in aircraft and hence prolong service life, reduce maintenance costs or construct lighter aircraft. Airbus and Alcoa have continued to sponsor this research with Cranfield and the Open University under a current TSB funded programme of aircraft wing development: “Airstream”.

Title: Size effects on residual stress and fatigue crack growth in friction stir welded 2195-T8 aluminium - Part I: Experiments
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative paper was a published output of  Framework 7 STREP “COINS” (COst effective INtegral metallic Structures contract  AST5-CT 2006-030825) investigating the manufacture, design, fatigue performance of friction stir welded aluminium. The wide range of sample geometries, residual stresses and fatigue cracks  measured allowed  direct validation of models for prediction of weld residual stress effects on fatigue cack growth across a wide range of conditions.  It has significantly added to knowledge of the relations between component size, weld residual stresses and fatigue performance.

Title: A Novel Permanent Magnet Flux Switching Machine with an Outer-Rotor Configuration for In-Wheel Light Traction Applications
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration between Cranfield University and Zhejiang University,  funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant NSFC50677061) and Qiangjiang Professionals Program of Zhejiang Province (Grant 2006R10014). It proposes a novel method of electric bicycle propulsion that can offer high efficiency over wide operational range and excellent flux weakening capability. Furthermore, effective thermal management system can be easily implemented in the novel structure. (Weizhong Fang, General Manager of Hangzhou Easitech Co., LTD, email:fangwy@easi-tech.com) Research insights led to a new collaborative project from The National Basic Research Program of China Program (China 973) in Zhejiang University under Grant 2011CB707204 (~£1M).

Title: Permanent-magnet flux-switching integrated starter generator with different rotor configurations for cogging torque and torque ripple mitigations
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration between Cranfield University and Zhejiang University. It proposes and compares techniques to reduce torque ripple in permanent magnet flux switching machines. The methods can also be employed for other conventional permanent magnet machines especially in automotive applications (Leon Rosario, Executive Engineer of Lotus Cars, email:lrosario@lotuscars.com). Research insights led to a new collaborative project from The National Basic Research Program of China Program (China 973) (Grant 2011CB707204, ~£1M). The results led to an invited keynote speech “Permanent magnet flux switching machines – topologies, analysis and optimization” in 4th International Conference on Power Engineering, Energy and Electrical Drives 13-17 May 2013.

Title: A High-Performance Line-Start Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Amended From a Small Industrial Three-Phase Induction Motor
AdditionalInformation:
International collaboration between Cranfield University, Zhejiang University and industrial partners Wujiang Nanyuan Electric Appartus Co. LTD. It developed a line-start permanent magnet synchronous machine with around 10% higher efficiency than the commercial industrial induction machine. 
The machine developed in this paper now is in mass production (100,000 units per year) for industrial ventilation application in Wujiang Nanyuan Electric Appartus Co. Ltd (contact manager Cheng Yuan, email:ychen2596@sina.com).

Title: Comparison of Cogging Torque Reduction in Permanent Magnet Brushless Machines by Conventional and Herringbone Skewing Techniques
AdditionalInformation: The paper investigates and compares two rotor step skewing techniques for cogging torque mitigation. The research was carried out under Sheffield-Siemens Wind Power Rearch Center and sponsored by Siemens Energy. The main purpose of the research is to investigate the impacts of  rotor step skewing techniques on the vibration and acoustic noise of large offshore direct-drive permannent magnet wind power generator. The findings of this paper are applied in the newly developed 3MW and 6MW permanent magnet generator to minimize both axial and circumferential force ripples. (Zhanyuan Wu, Senior Engineer of Siemens Wind Power, email:zhan-yuan.wu@siemens.com)

Title: Probabilistic sensitivity analysis of system availability using Gaussian processes
AdditionalInformation: An output of EPSRC research project (EP/E018084/1, £338,591), with applications in reliability analysis of highly complex industrial systems e.g. Aerospace engineering. It efficiently identifies the most significant parameters, allowing reduction of the number being considered. This paper has been applied by Strathclyde University, addressing robustness of optimal maintenance decisions of complex systems (contact Dr Athena Zitrou, Strathclyde University athena.zitrou@strath.ac.uk).

Title: Work-related road safety: An analysis based on U.K. bus driver performance
AdditionalInformation: This research arose from an ESRC and  Technology Strategy Board funded Knowledge Transfer Partnership between Arriva Passenger Services Ltd, one of Europe’s largest providers of passenger services, and Cranfield University. The output from this publication was to identify which drivers were at greatest risk of a collision. It led to a new simulator and classroom-based training programme being implemented by Arriva throughout the UK, and continued projects within the KTP collaborative programme between Arriva and Cranfield, giving a total 9 years collaboration (2001-2007 value = £624K). Contact Lynne Beale, Group Risk Manager, Arriva Bus UK, (bealel@arrivanw.co.uk).

Title: Development and validation of a self-report measure of bus driver behaviour
AdditionalInformation: In 2001, the ESRC and the Technology Strategy Board co-sponsored a nine year Knowledge Transfer Partnership (KTP) between Arriva Passenger Services Limited, one of Europe’s largest providers of passenger services and Cranfield University. This paper describes the development of a psychometric instrument to measure driver attitudes that underpin decision making behaviour. The output has been a spin-out company, DriverMetrics, marketing the trademarked Driver Risk Index. Since its launch in 2005, over 125,000 drivers have been risk assessed in 30 countries. Some of the multinational key clients include Unilever (contact: andy.griffin@unilever.com) and Shell (contact: mike.watson@shell.com). See www.DriverMetrics.com

Title: The effect of social desirability on self reported and recorded road traffic accidents
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Part F-Traffic Psychology and Behaviour
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration with Upsalla University, Sweden and University of Calgary, Canada led to an investigation of the validity of self-report measures of road traffic accidents. This work has highlighted methodological limitations in traffic research (Contact: anders.af_wahlberg@psyk.uu.se), which led to a symposium being accepted at a major international conference on driver behaviour hosted at Helsinki University in 2013 (www.icdbt.com) Contact Professor of Transport Psychology: heikki.summala@helsinki.fi

Title: Impatience and time pressure: Subjective reactions of drivers in situations forcing them to stop their car in the road
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Part F-Traffic Psychology and Behaviour
AdditionalInformation: This research was an outcome of an international collaboration between Universities of Lille, Rennes and Valenciennes, the Research Institute of Communications and Cybernetics in France and Cranfield University. This research was conducted with the support of the Ergonomic Psychology and Cognitive Ergonomics think tank orchestrated by the French National Centre for Research (GDR CNRS 3169 Psycho Ergo) to investigate how time pressure determines traffic rule violation and risky behaviour. Contact: Janick.Naveteur@univ-valenciennes.fr The results led to changes to travel policies for major organisations to reduce the risk of crash involvement. Contact: PClark@gategroup.com

Title: Simulating structural response to water impact
AdditionalInformation: In the top 25 most downloaded articles for the journal in 2012. The capability demonstrated through work presented in this paper led to Cranfield coordinating the EU Framework Programme 7 project 'Smart Aircraft in Emergency Situations' (SMAES, grant agreement number FP7-266172, EU contribution of 3.8M€), to develop improved simulation tools for the emergency landing of aircraft on water. The key industrial partners of the SMAES project are Airbus Miltary, Dassault, Alenia and Airbus; research partners include DLR, ONERA, University of Patras and University of East Anglia.

Title: Non-linear idealisation error analysis of a metallic stiffened panel loaded in compression
AdditionalInformation: The SAFESA (SAFE Structural Analysis) work presented in this paper was carried out under the EU Framework Programme 6 project MUSCA (Project Reference 516115) 'Non-linear static multiscale analysis of large aero-structures'.  Extending SAFESA to non-linear analysis supported the development of a virtual structural testing methodology for aerospace structures. It is a fundamental part of finite element training provided to students, the majority of whom go on to work in relevant industries, on several Cranfield courses.

Title: Simulation of Water Loading On Deformable Structures Using SPH
AdditionalInformation: The coupled fluid-structure simulation capability demonstrated in this paper is applicable to engineering areas including aerospace, automotive and offshore.  Demonstrating transient response modelling of floating deformable structures extended its range of applicability, and contributed to Cranfield coordinating the EU Framework Programme 7 project Smart Aircraft in Emergency Situations (SMAES, grant agreement number FP7-266172) on emergency landing of aircraft on water. A further paper containing final project results was awarded the Royal Institution of Naval Architects Medal of Distinction in 2011 (Trevor Blakely, tblakeley@rina.org.uk).

Title: Structural analysis of a commercial vehicle disc brake caliper
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part D-Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This project was supported by Meritor Heavy Vehicle Braking Systems and the EPSRC (grant no. GR/T18424/01). The  research programme has facilitated significant improvements in understanding and analysis of disc brake performance, which have been adopted by Meritor Heavy Vehicle Braking.  (Mr Paul Roberts, Chief Engineer, Meritor HVBS. Paul.Roberts@Meritor.com).

Title: The effect of residual stresses arising from laser shock peening on fatigue crack growth
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an EPSRC project (EP/D030307) with support from the UK Health & Safety Executive and Atkins Energy (Dr P May, philip.may@atkinsglobal.com). The work identified a means to directly measure Stress Concentration and has been further developed by TSC Inspection Systems (Dr RF Karé Raymond, Kare.Ray@tscinspectionsystems.com). It has led to successful applications for ISIS Neutron Beam-Time in the UK and Germany.

Title: A novel weight function for RMS stress intensity factor determination in surface cracks
AdditionalInformation: This paper formed the basis of a major component in the project EP/G061955, Materials for Next Generation CO2 Transport Systems (MATTRAN, £1.55m), with Newcastle, Imperial College, UCL, Nottingham and Edinburgh Universities, co-funded by E.ON (Dr Gary Masters Gary.Masters@eon-engineering.com). The outputs have impacted on development of the international standards for CO2 Transportation via BSI ISE/101/06, Fatigue Testing of Metals and Metal Matrix Composites (contact Fathy Kandil, fathy.kandil@eurotest-solutions.co.uk).

Title: Weld toe stress concentrations in multi-planar stiffened tubular KK joints
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an Exxon Mobil funded research project (Variable Amplitude Corrosion Fatigue of Jack-Up Structures) (£325k) leading to new parametric design equations for Offshore Jack-Up structures. These equations are now used for the optimisation of structural designs by Exxon Mobil (charles.o.woghiren@exxonmobil.com), DnV, Lloyds Register (Alan Smith Alan.Smith@dnv.com) and Atkins (Dr P May philip.may@atkinsglobal.com).

Title: Fatigue crack shape control under bending by cold working
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by Petronas (m.saifuldin@unimap.edu.my), and involved international Offshore Oil & Gas developer and operator, Petrofac. The technique allows the use of small-scale specimens to develop fatigue – life curves for large-scale components and structures  (Dr Shi-Song Ngiam, Shi-Song.Ngiam@petrofac.com).  The paper led to the use of the technique in a new Offshore Wind Structures project (SLIC – Sub-structure fatigue Life & Internal Corrosion assessment) sponsored by Centrica Energy, Dong Energy, RWE, Vattenfall, DECC and The Crown Estates. (Mr Isaac Tavares: Isaac.Tavares@centrica.com)

Title: Modelling of electromechanically actuated active differential wet-clutch dynamics
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part D-Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation:
A collaboration with Jaguar Land Rover and University of Zagreb in Croatia, funded by JLR. (Dr. Matthew Hancock, mhancoc1@jaguarlandrover.com, Dr. Mike Richardson, mrichar6@jaguarlandrover.com).
Outputs were utilised to develop a control algorithm to optimise yaw stability and traction in this type of active differential. This research has resulted in the production  of this differential on Jaguar XKR and XFR vehicles (Paul Darnell. pdarnell@jaguarlandrover.com).
The upcoming Automotive Encyclopaedia will include a chapter about this subject, (Lucy Wheeler, automotive@wiley.com).

Title: The Novel Application of Optimization and Charge Blended Energy Management Control for Component Downsizing within a Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle.
AdditionalInformation:
A collaboration between Cranfield University and Morgan Motor Company, funded through a KTP grant. Contact: Steve Morris (Operations Director). steve.morris@morgan-motor.co.uk.

The research illustrated that control strategies have significant impact on downsizing powertrain, hence, in reducing the cost of the future powertrains.  Furthermore, a new energy management concept is proposed in this work which 
Morgan is planning to adopt on their future production vehicles.

Title: A novel method for the parameterisation of a Li-ion cell model for EV/HEV control applications
AdditionalInformation:
This research was a part of a £25 million Low Carbon Vehicle consortium with twenty-five academic and industrial partners, addressing energy storage modelling and testing. Contact: Mr. John O'Connor, J.O-Connor@warwick.ac.uk. JLR, Ricardo, MIRA, TATA and Zytek were the main industrial partners.
The parameterized battery models in this research are being utilised by another EPSRC consortium ‘FUTURE’, EP/I038586/1, Professor Rob Thring, R.H.Thring@lboro.ac.uk, to design new ways of estimating battery State Of Charge and State Of Health, and develop new methodologies for revealing the limit of performance of batteries.

Title: Design and Development of Multivariable Robust Control for Energy Management of Hybrid Electric Vehicles
AdditionalInformation:
A collaboration between Cranfield University and Jaguar Land Rover, funded by the EPSRC, EP/H050337/1, £250,000. 

The drivability aspects of parallel electric hybrid vehicles were examined. The advanced control strategies are used to reduce the calibration overhead of hybrid supervisory controllers. Results from the paper are currently being examined by Jaguar Land Rover for their first production Range Rover Electric Hybrid Vehicle.  (Paul Darnell. pdarnell@jaguarlandrover.com)

Title: On the response of two commercially-important CFRP structures to multiple ice impacts
AdditionalInformation: This paper has built on previous work within the group (e.g. Composite Structures 91 (2009) 103–109), providing information to organisations such as Thales UK (Pradip.Sinha@uk.thalesgroup.com) on the effects of impact on composites.

Title: A study on the strength of an armour-grade aluminum under high strain-rate loading
AdditionalInformation: This research was produced under the Institute of Shock Physics (http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/shockphysics/research), a collaboration between Cranfield and Imperial College (c.thompson@imperial.ac.uk), supported by AWE (Stewart.Stirk@awe.co.uk).  It forms part of a wider remit to help re-establish UK hydrodynamics capability.

Title: Interface topography and residual stress distributions in W coatings for fusion armour applications
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: This research has recently been presented as an invited talk at a conference (MAT-ODSFS and MAT - HHFM monitoring meeting, Feb. 2013), contibuting to an international collaborative project (EU Euratom WP12-MAT-HHFM, http://www.ipp.cas.cz/Staff/generic_gr.php?IDG=00156) and as part of early collaborations contributing to new research programmes incvolving both Oxford University and the Euratom programme (http://mffp.materials.ox.ac.uk/ - patrick.grant@materials.ox.ac.uk).

Title: In-fiber shock propagation in Dyneema
AdditionalInformation: This research was produced under the Institute of Shock Physics (http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/shockphysics/research), a collaboration between Cranfield and Imperial College (c.thompson@imperial.ac.uk), supported by AWE (Stewart.Stirk@awe.co.uk).  It forms part of a wider re-mit to help regenerate UK-wide hydrodynamics capability.

Title: Perspectives on the commercial development of landing gear health monitoring systems
AdditionalInformation: This was the first application of a new condition monitoring system for electric actuators on aircraft undercarriage. The outputs helped Messier-Dowty to demonstrate reliability and robustness similar to hydraulic actuation. The project worked with international academic and industry partners in EU FP6 502909 TATEM (http://cordis.europa.eu/search/index.cfm?fuseaction=result.document&RS_LANG=DE&RS_RCN=12472888&q=) and ELGEAR. Messier-Dowty contact: Satish.Pandya@messier-dowty.com

Title: Suitability of MEMS accelerometers for condition monitoring: An experimental study
AdditionalInformation: This was the first evaluation of a MEMS vibration sensor for practical industrial condition monitoring. The work was trialled in field tests with partners VTT in Helsinki, Volvo in Gothenburg (bertil.stenbom@volvo.com) and CR Fiat in Milan. The project was funded €6.1m through EU FP6 IP017498 DYNAMITE ; partner Prisma in Greece commercialised the sensor platform “PrismaSense”  http://www.prismaelectronics.eu/site/ (contact Serafeim Katsikas, Director of R&D, sekat@prisma.gr). The work is also published in a book: Mekid S, Starr A, Pietruszkiewicz R, 2010, Intelligent Wireless Sensors, chapter 5 in E-maintenance, ed. Holmberg, K. et al, pub. Springer ISBN: 978-1-84996-204-9 http://www.springer.com/engineering/production+engineering/book/978-1-84996-204-9.

Title: BS-ISO helical gear fatigue life estimation and wear quantitative feature analysis
AdditionalInformation: This work has established a repeatable approach to fatigue life estimation related to surface damage on gears, validated by experimental indications of material removal and characterisation. It was an output of research funded by the Pakistan Government. Other researchers have already started to use this method, e.g. Prof Shao at Changsha University of Science and Technology ymshao@cqu.edu.cn.

Title: Normalised Root Mean Square and Amplitude of Sidebands of Vibration Response as Tools for Gearbox Diagnosis
AdditionalInformation: This work produced a new technique to tackle shortcomings in helicopter condition monitoring. It provided an integrated approach to the modelling and experimental validation of cause and effect in gear cracking. It came from a partnership funded by the MoD, QinetiQ and EPSRC, total ca £420k. A related conference publication won the award for the best paper published in the Proceedings of the British Institute of Non-Destructive Testing (BINDT) Condition Monitoring Conference (CM2011/MFPT2011). The work was performed jointly between Warwick University (FE simulation k.mao@warwick.ac.uk), Manchester University (signal processing j.sinha@manchester.ac.uk), and Cranfield (experimental work). Qinetiq contact ballen2@qinetiq.com

Title: Convective heat dissipation from a wheel-hub-mounted railway brake disc
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part F-Journal of rail and rapid transit
AdditionalInformation: The paper was awarded The William Alexander Agnew Meritorious Award / Clarence Noel Goodall 2008 Award, by the IMechE Railway Division. The research was conducted in collaboration with a world leading railway brake manufacturer, Faiveley Transport (approx. 30% of market share).  The methodology for designing brakes with effective heat dissipation is now routinely being applied for the design process in the supply chain, and the collaboration with the company has continued through follow-up projects, with funding awarded for a 'High performance low wear brake discs' project . Contact: John Watson, R&D Manager, Faiveley Transport UK, john.watson@faiveleytransport.com.

Title: Understanding and improving the convective cooling of brake discs with radial vanes
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part D-Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This is an invited paper for a journal Special Edition on braking.  The methodology was developed in collaboration with Meritor HVBS, a leading commercial vehicle brake manufacturer, and is used by them for generating new, lighter-weight disc designs with enhanced heat dissipation, and savings in both time and costs over previous methods. Collaboration with the company continued, on thermal aspects of Electric Parking Brakes, through EPSRC project (GR/T18424/01). Contact: Paul Roberts, Chief Engineer, Meritor HVBS, paul.roberts@meritor.com.

Title: Energy thrift and improved performance achieved through novel railway brake discs
AdditionalInformation: A new approach was developed for assessing energy efficiency of railway brake discs, through collaboration with a leading railway brake manufacturer, Faiveley Transport. Contact: John Watson, R&D Manager, Faiveley Transport UK, john.watson@faiveleytransport.com. This is a continuation of research ideas for simultaneously improving cooling and reducing pumping losses, initiated within a previous EPSRC grant (GR/M43562/01) to Cranfield.  The procedure is now used for selecting the most effective design for a specific train operating duty (route).

Title: Development of a lightweight wheel carrier for commercial vehicles
AdditionalInformation: The research builds on the results of a previous EPSRC grant GR/M43562/01. Together with Meritor HVBS, a credible working prototype has been developed, having only half the mass of the original design and doubling the brake cooling rate. Production applications are now being sought with commercial vehicle manufacturers. Contact: Paul Roberts, Chief Engineer, Meritor HVBS, paul.roberts@meritor.com.

Title: Numerical classification of curvilinear structures for the identification of pistol barrels
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration between Cranfield University, University of Nottingham and Edith Cowan University (Australia). The paper details an overlooked area that may be able to provide useful data for firearms identification.

Title: A method to quantify the degree of uniformity of thickness of thin films
AdditionalInformation: This work was completed under EPSRC funded First Grant (GR/S74171). The paper details a quick and cheap method for monitoring the uniformity of semi-transparent films.

Title: Inelastic deformation and failure of tungsten carbide under ballistic-loading conditions
VolumeTitle: Materials Science and Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration between Cranfield University and TNO (Netherlands). The research was partly funded by the Dutch Ministry of Defence, through the Research Program “V518 – Munitions and Weapons Effects”. The paper provides evidence that means the simulation of tungsten carbide armour peircing rounds can be somehwat simplified.

Title: Formation of CuSbS2 and CuSbSe2 thin films via chalcogenisation of Sb-Cu metal precursors
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration between Cranfield University and University of Bath funded by the EPSRC (EP/F029624/1). The paper details research into potential new materials, for which there is very little published data, that could be useful in photovoltaic devices.(contact: Prof L M Peter, University of Bath, L.M.Peter@bath.ac.uk).

Title: An SPH Technique for Evaluating the Behaviour of Ships in Extreme Ocean Waves
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded the Medal of Distinction of The Royal Institution of Naval Architects in 2010.  The research was supported by EPSRC grant GR/S95435 (£160k).  The technique developed during the work has been incorporated in a software tool, called Wave-X, providing a service to naval architects to predict the response of ships and offshore structures in extreme ocean waves. (See http://www.cranfield.ac.uk/soe/wave-x).

Title: Gyroscopic effects on a large vertical axis wind turbine mounted on a floating structure
AdditionalInformation: This research arose from a £2.8M project funded by the Energy Technology Institute in 2009 (called NOVA – Novel Vertical Axis Wind Turbine, contract ref OW1001) with partners OTM Consulting, University of Strathclyde, Sheffield University, James Ingram & Associates, CEFAS and QinetiQ.  The research established the feasibility of very large ocean borne vertical axis wind turbines by demonstrating the significance of gyroscopic forces on key design parameters. As a result, a feasible 10MW prototype wind turbine design has been developed with an estimated CO2 saving of 11kTonne pa (see http://www.4coffshore.com/windfarms/nova-(novel-offshore-vertical-axis)-project-demonstrator-united-kingdom-uk71.html).

Title: The longitudinal static stability of an aerodynamically alleviated marine vehicle, a mathematical model
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A-Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sc
AdditionalInformation: Aspects of the research presented in this paper have led to a Patent: “Trim control mechanism for high speed planing vessels” (GB2472266, granted). The research outcomes of higher vessel speed capability and novel (patented) control mechanism led to company interest from Renaissance Design UK Ltd (Managing Director Mr Tony Ryan guy.montgomery@renaissance-design.co.uk), in the AAMV (Aerodynamically Alleviated Marine Vehicle) concept and a follow-on contract to carry out the conceptual and preliminary design of an AAMV configuration.

Title: Minimum-time travel for a vehicle with acceleration limits: Theoretical analysis and receding-horizon implementation
VolumeTitle: Journal of Optimization Theory and Applications
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides a semi-analytic solution to the minimum time travel problem of a vehicle across a specified path. It led to a collaboration between Brunel University, Delft University of Technology (Dr Riender Happee, R.Happee@tudelft.nl), Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Prof. Emilio Frazzoli, frazzoli&mit.edu) and Georgia Institute of Technology (Prof. Panagiotis Tsiotras, tsiotras@gatech.edu), to investigate the optimality properties of driving techniques used by expert race drivers, and implications for the design of active safety systems.

Title: Steady-state drifting stabilization of RWD vehicles
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides a characterisation of a vehicle’s behaviour near its acceleration limits. It resulted from a collaboration between Brunel University, Delft University of Technology (Dr Riender Happee, R.Happee@tudelft.nl), MIT (Prof. Emilio Frazzoli, frazzoli&mit.edu) and GeorgiaTech (Prof. Panagiotis Tsiotras, tsiotras@gatech.edu). Results led to new research on novel active safety functions of modern passenger vehicles equipped with drive-by-wire controls, under an EPSRC grant (EP/I037792/1), and a collaboration with MIRA Ltd (Anthony Baxendale, anthony.baxendale@mira.co.uk) and the University of Padova (Dr Roberto Lot, roberto.lot@unipd.it).

Title: Race-car instrumentation for driving behavior studies
VolumeTitle: Ieee Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a low-cost solution for the instrumentation of a vehicle to study limit handling control. The work was a collaboration between Brunel University and Delft University of Technology (Dr Riender Happee, R.Happee@tudelft.nl) . Mechanical drawings, electronic diagrams and open-source-based software of the sensor suite are freely available online for general public use. (http://students.ceid.upatras.gr/~katzourd/rally/index.htm).

Title: Minimum time cornering: the effect of road surface and car transmission layout
AdditionalInformation: The paper was a result of collaboration between the University of Padova (Dr Roberto Lot, roberto.lot@unipd.it ), Cranfield University and Volvo Cars Research and Development (Dr Diomidis Katzourakis, diomidis.katzourakis@volvocars.com), funded by the EPSRC (EP/I037792/1). The understanding of vehicle behaviour near the limit of handling has significance for the development of novel active chassis systems.

Title: Modelling of Dynamic Behaviour of Orthotropic Metals Including Damage and Failure
AdditionalInformation: The work was funded by AWE, and resulted in the development of a new material model, integrated into AWE in-house codes, allowing them to model the response of orthotropic (anisotropic) metals including damage and failure under extreme loading, typical in AWE applications and important in many other automotive, aerospace and manufacturing processes. (Dr Graham Ball Graham.J.Ball@awe.co.uk).  The process simulation ability of the model has led to additional funding from AWE (Simon Case - Simon.Case@awe.co.uk) (£150,000) for further improvement as a part of Prof Vignjevic’s AWE-sponsored William Penny Fellowship (recognition of excellence).

Title: Modelling of dynamic damage and failure in aluminium alloys
AdditionalInformation: The dependency of the behaviour of aluminium alloy, of interest to aerospace applications under dynamic loading, was experimentally investigated and a material model developed, validated and implemented into the commercial non-linear finite element program DYNA3D. The development allows for more accurate analyses of bird strike and aircraft crashworthiness. The work was initially sponsored by AIRBUS (£100,000) (Dr Richard.Rigbey@airbus.com) and the European Commission (£210,000) project MUSCA, contract No. 516155. The model has also been successfully applied to automotive crashworthiness with Jaguar Land Rover. (Dr. Tayeb Zeguer - tzeguer@jaguarlandrover.com)

Title: Derivation of SPH equations in a moving referential coordinate system
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper led to a new form of the discrete smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) balance equations and improved accuracy of the method, providing a basis for further improvement of Cranfield’s SPH solver which enables staff to accurately model and solve real industrial engineering problems for a number of companies, e.g. bird strike on fan blades and open rotor blade-to-blade impacts with Rolls Royce (Dr Julian.Reed@rolls-royce.com), aircraft ditching with AIRBUS (Dieter.Hachenberg@airbus.com), bomb fragmentation (Raytheon - Terence.Marsden@raytheon.co.uk). Further development of the SPH method is a key area of a current collaboration between Cranfield and Laurence Livermore National Laboratory (Dr Jerry Lin, lin5@llnl.gov).

Title: Modeling shock waves in orthotropic elastic materials
AdditionalInformation: This paper addressed the dependency of shock and stress wave propagation on material orientation. A vector shock equation of state (EOS), applicable to modelling of orthotropic metals and composites, was developed, validated and implemented into the commercial non-linear finite element program DYNA3D. The EOS has been successfully applied to modelling of debris impact on aircraft aluminium alloy and composite structures, for example with Rolls Royce modelling of blade off impacts on open rotor composite blades (Dr James.Fynlayson@Rolls-Royce.com) and aircraft dithcing with AIRBUS, Dieter.Hachenberg@airbus.com.

Title: Dynamic modelling and analysis of post-combustion CO2 chemical absorption process for coal-fired power plants
AdditionalInformation: This research developed new models that describe how to successfully integrate  gas power plant and post combustion CO2 capture. The outputs have been adopted in a multi-university project (EP/J020184, £581k) with partners E-ON, on CO2 capture from gas power plants, which are currently the most challenging case (Robin.Irons@eon-engineering.com). Models developed are being used and reconfigured to explore different CO2 capture options including solvent selection, operation performance optimisation and techno economic evaluation of CO2 capture. (Contact Robin.Irons@eon-engineering.com)

Title: Dynamic modelling of CO2 absorption for post combustion capture in coal-fired power plants
AdditionalInformation: This is one the first papers to model the dynamic behaviour of carbon capture plants, validated using data from the largest available pilot plant at the time (University of Texas, Austin). It laid the foundation of ongoing research on CO2 capture and sequestration, (NERC NE/H01392X, £691k, ERPSRC EP/J020184, £581k) including collaboration with E-ON (Robin.Irons@eon-engineering.com). The model has been also adopted in the CCS System Modelling Tool Kit development by PSE Enterprise (Alfredo Ramos A.Ramos@pseenterprise.com) in collaboration with EDF Energy, E-ON, Rolls-Royce and others, funded by the Energy Technology Institute (£3M, contact andrew.green@eti.co.uk).

Title: Numerical simulation of low specific speed American petroleum institute pumps in part-load operation and comparison with test rig results
VolumeTitle: Journal of Fluids Engineering : Transactions of ASME
AdditionalInformation: Design of pumps to cope with cavitation has traditionally been based on results from test rigs. This research in collaboration with Graz University of Technology and Amarith Ltd (www.amarith.com), a UK pump company, was one of the first to use CFD  (computational fluid dynamics) to predict cavitation and part load performance. It shows that ‘design to specification’ is possible, ensuring the installed machines operate at the highest possible efficiency (Oliver.Brigginshaw@amarith.com).

Title: A new flow conditioner for mitigating severe slugging in pipeline/riser system
AdditionalInformation: Severe slugging is one factor leading to early abandonment of wells, typically leaving 60% of reserves in the reservoir (Dr. Paul Oram, Chief Engineer, BP, Paul.Oram@uk.bp.com). This research developed a new technology that enables energy companies to extend the lifetime of a well and extract more from the reservoir (joe.shen@chevron.com). Outputs of this research include a US patent, US 7857059B2 (granted) and a follow-on project supported by Chevron Energy Technology Company to complete a further stage of evaluation, demonstrating that the key device can be used in a pipeline (joe.shen@chevron.com)

Title: On the dynamic behavior of three readily available soft tissue simulants
AdditionalInformation: Dynamic tissue simulants are used to investigate blast and ballistic related events. This research, for the first time, compared three simulants to understand how their behaviour in the shock regime relates to tissues within the body. This work led to greater accuracy in the use of diagnostic methods at Cranfield (see Appleby-Thomas et al., J. Mech. Behav. Biomed. 2013) and the important strain regimes needed to replicate blast and ballistic event (see Nguyen et al. Methods of Controlled Shock Wave Generation in A Shock Tube for Biological Applications APS Shock compression of condensed matter 2013 in print) [James Wilgeroth, j.wilgeroth@imperial.ac.uk].

Title: On the interpretation of lateral manganin gauge stress measurements in polymers
AdditionalInformation: This research investigated, for the first time, the method of insertion of lateral stess gauges in polymeric materials testing under shock.  It was found that good contact between the gauge and specimen can compensate for use of different  methods of insertion.  This result has been used  to improve the hydrocode models used by AWE as demonstrated by Elliot et al. (Experimental and computational investigation of lateral gauge response in polycarbonate, APS conference proceeding, Shock Compression of Condensed Matter 2011, page 458 Published 2012).

Title: Shock behaviour of a phenolic resin
AdditionalInformation: Before this paper there was a paucity of data on phenolic resin while under shock loading. This research, which was conducted in collaboration with AWE, provided a greater understanding of the shock loading of composites for use within computation models. The results enabled AWE's computational models to be improved to match experimental data. (Nick Barnes at Nick.Barnes@awe.co.uk).  The results and methodology have also been adopted in a follow-on project (AWE, £250k) to investigate more complex phenolic based composites.

Title: Shock propagation in a tape wrapped carbon fibre composite
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A-Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: A composite of importance to AWE has been investigated under shock loading. The output has been used to improve their computational hydrocodes, due to the inclusion of strength measurements, which for the first time, were obtained using lateral gauges, where it was found the matrix material is extremely important for strength of the composite as a whole. (Nick Barnes at Nick.Barnes@awe.co.uk). The work conducted here has now been expanded into a follow-on research project (£200k) looking at a variety of other more complex composite based materials for AWE.

Title: Road vehicle state estimation using low-cost GPS/INS
AdditionalInformation: One outcome of a Cranfield collaboration with Jaguar Land Rover. The algorithms developed have potential for low-cost applications. Further investigation into implementation of the proposed systems is being conducted by Jaguar Land Rover  (Dr Naseem Akhtar, Jaguar Land Rover, nakhtar@jaguarlandrover.com).

Title: Linear feedback control of transient energy growth and control performance limitations in subcritical plane Poiseuille flow
AdditionalInformation: This work results from a collaboration with Maurizio Quadrio, Politecnico di Milano (maurizio.quadrio@polimi.it) that used theory developed by Whidborne and McKernan  to demonstrate the limits of performance using feedback for flow control. This demonstration of the practicality of the results contributed to the award of a collaborative EPSRC grant with Imperial College London and Sheffield University (EP/I016090/1 & EP/I016015/1).

Title: Attitude control system for directional drilling bottom hole assemblies
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an outcome from a collaboration with Schlumberger Oilfields UK. The proposed control methods improve performance over existing methods for directional drills (Dr Martin Bayliss, Schlumberger Oilfields UK, mbayliss@slb.com). This publication has led to additional industrial grant income of over £150k in 2013 (Chris Bogarth, Schlumberger, bogathc1@slb.com). Patents have been filed for the work (US Patent 20130126239, UK Patent 12/208/419).

Title: Linear and non-linear simulations of feedback control in plane Poiseuille flow
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a project on feedback for flow control. Results from this study contributed to a successful EPSRC grant application, for further development of flow control research, (EP/I016090/1 & EP/I016015/1) in collaboration with Papadakis from Imperial College London and Pierre Ricco from Sheffield University. .

Title: Fail-Safe Design of Integral Metallic Aircraft Structures Reinforced by Bonded Crack Retarders
AdditionalInformation: Work reported in this paper is part of a large project “Bonded Crack Retarders” funded by the EPSRC through Cranfield's IMRC (GR/R 68139) and industrial sponsors Airbus, Cytec and Alcoa Inc. USA, collaborating with the Open University. The project identified the most promising material for making crack growth retarders; a result which has led to a follow-on project “Airstream WP4” (2010-13), total value £200k for the academic partners, funded by the TSB and industrial partners as above, for application of the developed method to airframe structures aiming at higher Technology Readiness Levels. Contact: Robert Maziarz, Airbus, ESIRWU, email: robert.maziarz@airbus.com

Title: A modelling technique for calculating stress intensity factors for structures reinforced by bonded straps. Part I: Mechanisms and formulation
AdditionalInformation: Work reported in this paper is also part of the project “Bonded Crack Retarders” (2006-09) funded by the EPSRC through Cranfield 's IMRC (GR/R 68139) and industrial sponsors Airbus, Cytec and Alcoa Inc. USA, collaborating with the Open University. This paper reports the theoretical framework and computer model developed during the project, now being explored by Airbus via a follow-on project “Airstream WP4” (2010-13), funded by the TSB and industrial partners as above, for application of the developed method to realistic airframe structures aiming at higher Technology Readiness Levels. Contact: Robert Maziarz, Airbus, ESIRWU, email: robert.maziarz@airbus.com.

Title: A cohesive zone model for predicting delamination suppression in z-pin reinforced laminates
AdditionalInformation: Work reported in this paper is part of a large project “Bridging the Divide” funded by the EPSRC (EP/E001874/1) and industrial partners Airbus and BAE Systems, collaborating with two research organisations (EADS-IW, Helmholtz-Zentrum Geesthacht in Germany). The project is significant for joints between composites and metallic structures in future generation aircraft. The methodology and computer models developed in this paper enable predictions of the strength and fracture of a novel joint, to guide the design process and validation tests performed by collaboration partners. Contact: Dr D Furfari, Airbus, email: domenico.furfari@airbus.com

Title: Predicting mode II delamination suppression in z-pinned laminates
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an output from a project  “Bridging the Divide”, funded by EPSRC (EP/E001874/1), Airbus and BAE Systems, in collaboration with EADS-IW UK and Helmholtz-Zentrum Geesthacht. It focuses on the failure of a novel joint. Research outputs gained recognition by a leading academic in Australia (Prof AP Mouritz, RMIT University, Melbourne, adrian.mouritz@rmit.edu.au) leading to collaborative research on a part that was designed and tested at the RMIT and modelled by us, and a joint publication (Compos Sci & Tech. 73 (2012) 48-56). Airbus is also interested, and has approached us to suggest a follow-on project). Contact: Dr D Furfari, Airbus, email: domenico.furfari@airbus.com

Title: Simulating a building as a people movement system
AdditionalInformation: This is the first assessment of evacuation model use in egress analysis and the limitations given model capabilities and user expertise - bridging the gap between typical model descriptions and engineering practice. It led to a workshop at the conference on Pedestrian and Evacuation Dynamics, 2010 (peter.thompson@iesve.com, Dr. Thompson, Technical Director, IES), informed the ISO committee TC92/SC4/WG11 on developing egress scenarios (contact daniel.nilsson@brand.lth.se, Dr. Nilsson, Associate Professor, Lund University). It is part of an ongoing collaboration with authors from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (US) and Lund University (EU), as evidenced by several companion articles.

Title: Understanding the effectiveness of notification technologies in assisting vulnerable populations
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided a metric to understand population vulnerabilities when responding to incident notification and procedural measures to address them. It was part of an NFPA-funded project (contact rfahy@nfpa.org, Dr. Fahy, Manager of Fire Data Bases, NFPA). This was to assist NFPA to develop guidance for procedural/technology design and to inform NFPA code development. The work has influenced NFPA committee discussions regarding code modifications, related work (e.g. US government projects on notification system design), is included in SFPE Engineering Handbook and in professional courses by the SFPE and the ICC (contact erica.kuligowski@nist.gov, Dr. Kuligowski, Group Leader, Engineering Laboratory, NIST).

Title: Questioning the linear relationship between doorway width and achievable flow rate
AdditionalInformation: This was suggested by Dr Harold Nelson, an innovator in the field (formerly of NIST and Hughes Associates,Inc., now deceased). It involves using material provided by Dr. J.J.Fruin (retired, New York Transport Authority) regarding movement data from several locations (including the World Trade Centre) to quantify a previously undocumented impediment upon pedestrian flow (door-leaf configuration), which might lead to optimistic egress assumptions. This effort is described in the SFPE Handbook chapter on egress and has influenced the recent development of the New Zealand design regulations (charles.fleischmann@canterbury.ac.nz, Dr.C.Fleischmann, Associate Professor, Civil and Natural Resources Engineering, University of Cantebury, New Zealand).

Title: Representing evacuation behavior in engineering terms
AdditionalInformation: This paper covered material produced from discussions at ISO TC92/SC4/WG1 regarding the development of occupant scenarios (rfahy@nfpa.org, Dr. Fahy, Manager of Fire Data Bases, NFPA). This provided a framework for developing evacuation scenarios during engineering analysis. The authors originally contributed concepts to committee meetings and then developed them further here. This work has been embedded within broader guidance produced by National Institute of Standards and Technology (Robbins, A et al,  Proposed General Approach to Fire-Safety Scenarios, Technical Report, NIST, G2012-0371, 2012), with the effort continuing at BRANZ (Amanda.Robbins@branz.co.nz, Dr.A.Robbins, Senior Fire Research Engineer, Building Research Association of New Zealand).

Title: Levitated liquid dynamics in reduced gravity and gravity-compensating magnetic fields
VolumeTitle: JOM (The Journal of The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society)
AdditionalInformation:
Output of the ELIPS materials project SOL-EML (ESA and NASA funded international topical interest group of aerospace organisations), where Greenwich contributes as the modelling partner, using techniques develop in the FP7 IMPRESS project and EPSRC GR/L97483/01
Contacts: Douglas.Matson@tufts.edu, Prof. Dr. Dieter Herlach, DLR +49 2203 601-2332.
The analysis gives insights to the internal mechanisms of fluid levitation that cannot be observed directly, including classical levitation experiments for property measurements, Marangoni convection in microgravity, turbulence damping in combined AC and DC fields. Modelling was used to assist stabilisation of ISS levitation device designed by ASTRIUM (contact: achim.seidel@astrium.eads.net)

Title:
Review of the flowability measuring techniques for powder
metallurgy industry
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Not a review paper, but the culmination of an in-depth research programme (EPSRC project “Engineering the Green State of Powder Materials”, GR/S70937/01 collaborative with 5 other research groups and 17 industrial sponsors).  It tested all established and some novel methods (introduced by Kulkarni and Bradley) for measuring powder behaviour in the powder metallurgy industries, the relationship between them and the meaning of the measurements to the real manufacturing processes.   It gave recommendations for use of measurement techniques for this industry sector.  The most downloaded paper of the year in the Journal, and one of the ten most downloaded of all IMechE proceedings.  Researcher was PI.

Title: Modelling methodology for thermal analysis of hot solder dip process
AdditionalInformation: Funded through a US Government Grant (H94003-04-D-003-0056/10178928), this is the first time a detailed modelling approach has been developed and validated to identify optimal process conditions for a robotic controlled hot solder dip process that will ensure leaded electronic components are reliable in safety critical applications. Provides our industrial partners with a novel qualification process for these components with potential costs savings of £100,000 per component (Paul Stewart, Lead Engineer, Selex-ES, paul.stewart2@selex-es.com). Work has led onto further grant (H94003-04-D-003-0056/ 10198575) to investigate unleaded components such as ball grid arrays.

Title: Application of Kriging and radial basis function in power electronic module wire bond structure reliability under various amplitude loading
AdditionalInformation: Output funded under the EU Clean Skies project PEMREL (Grant No. 271788). Reports a first in using numerical techniques to allow fast predictions of lifetime and robustness of wirebonds used in power electronic modules. Techniques have been implemented in the university developed design tool - PowerLife - which is now used by our industrial partners SEMELAB (Liam Mills, R&D Manager, Liam.Mills@semelab-tt.com) and Dynex Semiconductors (Steve Jones, R&D Manager, Steve_Jones@dynexsemi.com). Output contributed to the group being awarded £500,000 in the new EPSRC funded project  - Underpinning Power Electronics (EP/K034804/1) - where Greenwich is leading the modelling activities.

Title: Design for reliability of power electronics modules
AdditionalInformation: A first in presenting a physics-of-failure approach to predicting lifetime/reliability of wirebonds, solder joints and bussbars for power electronics modules. Output contributed to award of two new grants -  Robustness design & health management in power electronics using damage mechanics based models (RODENT, Funded by EPSRC/IeMRC , SP/03/02/11), and the FP7 Clean Skies project PEMREL (Grant No. 271788). The output is significant as the developed models are providing our industrial partners with design rules and reliability predictions for new power electronics module designs (Liam Mills, R&D Manager, Liam.Mills@semelab-tt.com), (Steve Jones, R&D Manager, Steve_Jones@dynexsemi.com).

Title: A novel sensing technique for measurement of magnitude and polarity of electrostatic charge distribution across individual particles
AdditionalInformation: Research into a new method for measuring the distribution of bi-polar electrostatic charges on particles, which are important to particle behaviour in pharmaceutical processing (eg particle sieving, coating, segregation, mixing) but not previously measurable by customary methods.  The work is likely to have significant impact on industry as it will enable these bipolar charges to be studied so that processes involving charge (both intentionally and unintentionally) can be optimized. 2 Follow on projects have so far been funded by industry (GSK) to use the novel technique to research the properties of their materials, discussions in progress re: commercialisation. Researcher: PI

Title: A multi-disciplinary study of vibration based reliability of lead-free electronic interconnects
AdditionalInformation: The modelling work, undertaken by Greenwich, optimised the design of novel test equipment,  developed at the National Physical Laboratory, to predict reliability of micro-solder joints under vibration loading. The ability to assess the reliability of lead-free solders is important to enable industry to address EU Legislation such as Reduction of Hazrdous Substance (RoHS) which bans lead-solders in consumer electronic products. Equipment is now available and work was widely disseminated to international companies through the National Physical Laboratory Industrial Advisory Board (Chris Hunt, Head of Interconnection Team, National Physical Laboratory, Chris.Hunt@npl.co.uk).

Title: Prognostic reliability analysis of power electronics modules
AdditionalInformation: Originality is in the development of fast predictions for temperature and stress within a prognostics and health monitoring framework.  Output contributed to the award of two new grants -  Robustness design & health management in power electronics using damage mechanics based models (RODENT, Funded by EPSRC/IeMRC , SP/03/02/11), and EU project NextFactory (Grant Number 608995).  Output led to the group being invited to join the working group formulating the new IEEE standard (IEEE Std. P1856) for Prognostics and Health Management of Electronic Systems (Professor Michael Pecht, University of Maryland, Chair of working group, pecht@calce.umd.edu).

Title: The Brookfield Powder Flowability Tester, a novel instrument making the scientific measurement of powder flow properties much more widespread in industry than ever before, for QA and Formulation Development.
Place: University of Greenwich at Medway, Chatham Maritime, Kent ME4 4TB
Publisher: Brookfield Engineering Laboratories, Inc.  11 Commerce Boulevard  Middleboro, Massachusetts, USA, 02346  Phone: 800-628-8139, 508-946-6200  Fax: 508-946-6262  Email: web.sales@brookfieldengineering.com  Web-site: http://www.brookfieldengineering.com
AdditionalInformation:
Output of DEFRA project AFM 206 “Development of an Economical Powder Flowability Tester”: http://randd.defra.gov.uk/Default.aspx?Menu=Menu&Module=More&Location=None&Completed=0&ProjectID=12508
Previous instruments for measuring powder flow behaviour scientifically were expensive (£50k+), needing great expertise to use and interpret the data.  Cheaper instruments lacked scientific link between measurement results and powder behaviour in-plant.  The authors and the manufacturers perceived need for an instrument that is: 
•	economical, 
•	automated,
•	quick to use, 
•	could be used, and results interpreted, by non-powder-experts, 
•	with sound scientific foundation and objective link to how the powder will flow in a given plant,
for QA on powder raw materials and products, and formulation development.  
Bradley and Berry provided intellectual (scientific and design) input.  Brookfield provided manufacturing and software input.  Cadbury, Kerry Ingredients, United Biscuits and GlaxoSmithKline provided case studies and prototype testing.
Significant scientific research was required to determine (i) the best measurement method to predict powder behaviour in the diverse processes in the operating plants, (ii) optimum test method (annular shear cell, principle known from previous practice), (iii) novel test protocols for most selective, robust, automated data generation and analysis across many powders with multiple dimensions of behaviours, and (iv) develop mechanical arrangements giving necessary accuracy and sensitivity, value engineered for low cost.  Supporting evidence on USB.
The instrument fulfuls the technical goals, selling for £12k; highly successful - 200 in use by 140 companies in 24 countries (user list on USB) in 3 years.  Most users never used powder flowability measurements previously.  Annual sales $2M, but the value of the production protected by use of the instruments is several orders of magnitude higher.
Accolades: IMechE Innovation in Bulk Materials Handling Prize 2012, US R&D magazine top 100 Award 2011, 10/10 rating by DEFRA, Shortlisted for IChemE Innovation Awards 2010 and Times Higher Education Awards 2010 (evidence on USB)

Title: Numerical algorithms for modelling electrodeposition: Tracking the deposition front under forced convection from megasonic agitation
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids
AdditionalInformation: The originality is the development of multi-physics models to support process design, optimisation of process variables, and design rules. The work is significant as for the first time this allowed the feasibility of using transducers in the electroplating bath to promote electro-deposition and better quality design of printed circuit boards for high performance applications. This has led to our industrial partner - Merlin Circuits - to implement this technology (Dennis Price, Quality Director, Merlin Circuits, dennis.price@merlincircuit.couk).  Output led onto the award of the DTA Aspect Project (Funded under EP/C534212/1) which led to award of PhD for N Strusevich.

Title: Finite-element simulation of stress intensity factors in solder joint intermetallic compounds
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
AdditionalInformation: Originality is the use of a fracture mechanics approach to predict crack behaviour of intermetallic compounds (IMC’s) found in solder joints. This is the first time such a numerical study has been undertaken in comparing behaviour of IMC’s in both Tin-Lead and Lead-Free Solders. This is significant as tin-lead solders are now banned under ROHS EU Legislation. Led onto a new project funded US Government (H94003-04-D-003-0056)  worth US$350,000, to develop physics-of-failure models for electronic components in aerospace environments for companies such as Cassidian and Selex Galileo (Prof John Roulston, Ex CTO Selex-Galileo, jfroulston@yahoo.co.uk)

Title: Smeared shell modelling approach for structural analysis of heritage composite structures - An application to the Cutty Sark conservation
AdditionalInformation: New validated finite element formulation for predicting structural behaviour of composite materials in heritage ships is presented for the first time. This was used to inform the Cutty Sark Trust on how to best disassemble and reassembly this national maritime treasure which was opened by the Queen in 2012 (CEO, Cutty Sark trust, Richard Doughty, richard.doughty@cuttysark.org.uk).  Greenwich work was awarded best Knowledge Transfer Partnership for London in 2008, and the Times Higher Education Award for Outstanding Research Team of the year (2009). Output led onto a further project to support restoration of Medway Queen (Wyn Davies, Naval Architect, wynbdavies@sky.com)

Title: Modelling of electromagnetic levitation - consequences on non-contact physical properties measurements
AdditionalInformation: A research collaboration with the MADYLAM laboratory in Grenoble and the Institute of Physics in Riga, resulted in an extensive study of the flow parameters affecting the accuracy of property measurements by EM levitation, especially under terrestrial conditions. In particular the role of turbulence was highlighted as a cause of error in viscosity measurements, but also in measurements of thermal conductivity. Bojarevics supervised the Grenoble PhD student Benoit Bardet, who was seconded to Greenwich for this task.

Title: Dynamic model for metal cleanness evaluation by melting in a cold crucible
AdditionalInformation: Sampling molten metal to assess the level of impurities without interrupting the manufacturing process is important for industry. Collaboration with the National Physical Laboratory [contact: R.Brooks@NPL], evaluated this new sampling technique: metal is collected in a small crucible surrounded by an induction coil; electromagnetic Kolin-Leenov forces separate impurities to the surface where they can be counted. Our spectral code SPHINX was used to verify this concept and the process was presented to an industrial club by NPL. This beginning led to EU FP7 projects EXOMET (€19M/€400k) for MMNC production and SIKELOR (€4M/€309k) for silicon recycling from kerf.

Title: Effect of magnetic forces on bubble transport and MHD stability of aluminium electrolysis cells
AdditionalInformation: Linked to our spectral shallow-layer MHD-VALDIS software for Hall-Herault aluminium electrolysis cells, this study looks at the interaction of gas bubbles with anode current. This is not a well-understood phenomenon, which nevertheless influences cell efficiency. The software is essential for cell stability calculations and found worldwide use for the design of energy-efficient new cells: Russia, contact  Radionov Evgeniy Evgeniy.Radionov@rusal.com; Dubai, contact L. K. MISHRA lalit@dubal.ae; China, contact ruanshaoyong82@qq.com; USA, contact J. W. Evans (Prof Emeritus, Berkeley) jim.w.evans@gmail.com.

Title: Scale-up and design of a continuous microwave treatment system for the processing of oil-contaminated drill cuttings
AdditionalInformation: The result of DEFRA and industry funded work to develop a novel method of treating cuttings from drilling of oil exploration wells, to prevent discharge of oil pollution to sea.  It described the new technique and how it can be applied in practice including the key practical considerations for making it work safely on an oil drilling platform.  The design has been the subject of patents GB2007/004344, EP20070824569, US 12/514,983 and is approaching commercialisation.  Several stages of prototype have been built and final system is expected operational Q1 2014 (NOV Brandt, contact via sam.kingman@nottingham.ac.uk).  Contribution of researcher: PI for Greenwich (collaborative with Nottingham University).

Title: Integrating personnel movement simulation into preliminary ship design
VolumeTitle: Transactions of The Royal Institution of Naval Architects Part A: International Journal of Maritime Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Paper resulted from EPSRC project EGO (GR/T22100/01), a collaboration with UCL (GR/T22117/01) and UK MoD.  It contributed to PhD’s for Deere (2011), Casarosa (2011) and Pawling (2007) and also won the 2008 RINA Samuel Baxter Prize for best IJME paper on safety.  The work contributed to two EU FP7 projects, SAFEGUARD (SCP7-GA-2009-218493) and FIREPROOF (contract 218761) concerning evacuation from large passenger ships.  It introduces for the first time a capability to incorporate human factors into early ship design. FSEG are in discussion with the Australian DSTO to adapt the approach for use by the RAN (Zenka.Mathys@dsto.defence.gov.au, Head Naval Platforms Division).

Title: Fire and evacuation analysis in BWB aircraft configurations: Computer simulations and large-scale evacuation experiment
AdditionalInformation: This paper won the 2011 bronze award for best paper to appear in the RAeJ.  The work was widely publicised in the technical press (Flight International, The Engineer).
