The paper was the culmination of two projects EU FP 5 project VELA (GRD1-2001-40140) and EU FP6 IP NACRE (AIP4-CT-2005-516068) and lead to a new EU FP7 project AIRCRAFTFIRE (contract  265612) concerned with fire/evacuation analysis in new composite aircraft.  The work has been applied to three aviation design projects associated with evacuation, a B747 VIP aircraft (Gulfsteam Aerospace, s_locatelli@hotmail.com), the new C-Series regional-jet (Bombardier antonio.damore@aero.bombardier.com) and a new concept jet (Bombardier ben.pownall@aero.bombardier.com).

Title: Investigating evacuation lift dispatch strategies using computer modelling
AdditionalInformation: This work explored the use of lifts for highrise building evacuation through computer simulation.  It was funded by an EPSRC studentship resulting in a PhD for Kinsey (2011).  The work also resulted in the development of a general lift modelling component for use in the commercial software buildingEXODUS increasing the scope of application of the software. The work also demonstrated that mixed stair-elevator evacuation strategy can result in optimal evacuation times informing the use of lift evacuation strategies proposed for use in modern highrise buildings and informed the development of lift evacuation standards (jason.averill@nist.gov, Leader Engineered Fire Safety Group, NIST).

Title: The UK 9/11 evacuation study: Analysis of survivors' recognition and response phase in WTC1
AdditionalInformation: Paper resulted from EPSRC project HEED (GR/S74201/01, EP/D507790), a collaboration between Greenwich, Ulster, Liverpool Universities into 911.  The project resulted in the development of the High-rise Evacuation Evaluation Database, a unique on-line database identifying human behaviour in high-rise evacuation. HEED is freely available to international researchers/engineers/legislators to explore and utilise in building design/research projects.  The database was used by Dr Erica Kuligowski (erica.kuligowski@nist.gov) of NIST as the basis of her PhD.  The techniques developed in HEED led to a new EU FP7 project BeSeCu (contract 218324, http://www.besecu.de/) concerned with evacuation behaviour in buildings and a new KTP (KTP009153, worth £180,000).

Title: Approximating the evacuation of the World Trade Center North Tower using computer simulation
AdditionalInformation: Paper resulted from EPSRC funded HEED project (GR/S74201/01, EP/D507790), a collaboration between Greenwich, Ulster, Liverpool Universities.  Paper presents simulation analysis of the 9/11 evacuation. It successfully reproduced the evacuation, providing important insight into the complex evolving evacuation dynamics of the North Tower, provided further validation evidence for the internationally used buildingEXODUS evacuation simulation software and demonstrated the practical limitations of full building evacuation of high-rise buildings by stairs alone identifying the need for evacuation lifts (jason.averill@nist.gov, Leader Engineered Fire Safety Group, NIST). This led to further research on modelling lift evacuation with an EPSRC PhD studentship for Michael Kinsey (2011).

Title: Investigating the representation of merging behavior at the floor-stair interface in computer simulations of multi-floor building evacuations
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from the EPSRC funded project HEED (GR/S74201/01, EP/D507790) which was a collaboration between Greenwich, Ulster, Liverpool Universities.  The paper demonstrated for the first time the importance of merging behaviours and deference behaviours on stairs in highrise buildings during evacuation.  It has contributed to the validation of the commercial software buildingEXODUS increasing its appeal for building design analysis.  Questions raised by this work has led to several research projects concerning human factors associated with movement on stairs (USA: NIST, jason.averill@nist.gov; UK, University of Ulster KE.Boyce@ulster.ac.uk; Korea, Kyungpook National University, hongwh@knu.ac.kr).

Title: A systematic methodology to assess the impact of human factors in ship design
AdditionalInformation: Paper resulted from EPSRC project EGO (GR/T22100/01) a collaboration with UCL (GR/T22117/01) and UK MoD resulting in a PhD for Deere (2011).  It represents the first example of extending ship based evacuation simulation to generalised personnel movement in normal operations. It provided the basis of two EU FP7 funded projects, SAFEGUARD (SCP7-GA-2009-218493) and FIREPROOF (218761) concerning evacuation from large passenger ships.  The approach described in this paper has been implemented in the commercial software maritimeEXODUS and FSEG are in discussion with the Australian DSTO to adapt the approach for use by the RAN (Zenka.Mathys@dsto.defence.gov.au, Head Naval Platforms Division).

Title: Experimental analysis of the effectiveness of emergency signage and its implementation in evacuation simulation
AdditionalInformation: This work explored how people interact with signage during evacuation and for the first time quantified the likelihood that signs are detected. The work has implications for both building regulations and evacuation model development/applications.  The work was selected as one of the best papers in the 4th HBIF conference for inclusion in the journal special edition (editor s.grayson@dial.pipex.com) and contributed to the award of a PhD for Xie (2011).  The work also assisted in the development of an innovative signage system by EVACLITE (Director bmcdonagh@evaclite.com) and a new EU FP7 funded three year project (GETAWAY 265717) to test the concept.

Title: Numerical investigation of tube furnace toxicity measurement method (ISO 19700)
AdditionalInformation: For the first time CFD tools were used to predict the fire environment within the tube furnace setup (ISO 19700) and demonstrate its impact on the accuracy of toxicity measurements for low and well ventilated conditions. The impact of the work lies in better understanding the ISO test method and its applicability (developer of the test method is david-purser@ntlworld.com, former senior scientist at BRE). The secondary quenching effect identified was instrumental in ensuring that the operating conditions need to be controlled to ensure “real condition” toxicity values of fire products. The work lead to a PhD for A. Mahalingam (2008).

Title: A method for the micro-encapsulation of dielectric fluids in joined polymer shells
AdditionalInformation: The significant impact of this work has led to the better understanding of a novel one-step (as opposed to multi-step) electrostatic-induced lithography process to enhance reliability, integrity, cost and time required to fabricate high-aspect ratio, hollow self-encapsulated microstructures. Outcomes of the research have fed into experimental work at the Chinese Academy of Science (contact: W. Yu (yuwx@ciomp.ac.cn) to demonstrate how process failures can be overcome and how these can be migrated to an industrial manufacturing process. Aspects of the research have lead to potential patenting applications which are currently being considered. Funded:-EPSRC-DTA award (EP/P504945/1) in collaboration with Heriot-Watt University.

Title: Predicting toxic gas concentrations at locations remote from the fire source
AdditionalInformation: The key impact of this research is the improvement in prediction accuracy of toxicity and hence life safety remote from the fire.  The newly developed methodology is implemented within the SMARTFIRE CFD software enhancing its usability as an engineering tool. The ability to predict toxic species remote from the fire source enabled the authors to win the EU FP7 project AIRCRAFTFIRE (265612), in which SMARTFIRE is used to investigate the impact of fire on evacuation in aircraft. The technique is being enhanced to accommodate new composite materials found in the next generation of aircraft (contact Graham.greene@caa.co.uk at UK CAA).

Title: Progress towards the design and numerical analysis of a 3D microchannel biochip separator
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The impact of this research has fed into a number of prototype designs and subsequent testing of 2- and 3-dimensional microfluidic biochip plasma blood separators at Cambridge University (Prof Bill O’Neil wo207@eng.cam.ac.uk) in relation to micro-flow behaviour due to geometrical changes. The work has contributed to two PhD projects (M.Kersaudy-Kerhoas (m.kersaudy-kerhoas@hw.ac.uk) and David Topham (dt@artsience.co.uk) and subsequently a DTA funded PhD student. Work supported by:-EPSRC Grand Challenge Project: 3D-Mintegration (EP/C534212/1). Funds:-(Total:£4.5M-UoG:£405k). Partners: University (Heriot-Watt, Cambridge, Nottingham, Loughborough) and 28 commercial organisations

Title: Modelling the dynamics of the tilt-casting process and the effect of the mould design on the casting quality
AdditionalInformation: An important output of the EU FP6 IMPRESS intermetallic materials project (€41M, UG €600k), [David.John.Jarvis@esa.int ESA head advanced materials] shows synergy of experiments (Birmingham) and modelling (UG), to develop a unique casting technique for gamma-TiAl blades, destined for future RR aeroengines, replacing heavy nickel superalloys [ask Wayne.Voice@esa.int, ex. RR currently at ESA]. TiAl is notoriously difficult to cast, highly reactive and it has to be defect-free for aerospace application. UG software (from EPSRC GR/N14316/01 ) simulate this multi-physics process (fluid flow, electromagnetic induction, free surface behaviour, solidification).  Follow on projects: TSB ‘COLDMELT’ (UG £141k) and FP7 EXOMET (€19M, UG €400k)

Title: A multiscale 3D model of the vacuum arc remelting process
AdditionalInformation: High quality steel and titanium ingots for aerospace and power generation are produced by Vacuum Arc Remelting (VAR) using a DC arc to melt electrode feed material. The melt pool is stirred by buoyancy and electromagnetic fields. Complex interactions with the solidifying front lead to defects, as in cases where the arc wanders altering flow and temperature. World first 3D coupled macro (UG) plus micro models (IC) through a shared PhD student (Yuan) and EM field measurements (Birmingham) identify causes of common defects (white spot, freckles). EPSRC  EP/D505011/1  (UG £169k), industrial partners Rolls-Royce, Corus, Wiggins Special Metals [contact: R.Siddall@wiggins.co.uk]

Title: Toward a full simulation of the basic oxygen furnace: Deformation of the bath free surface and coupled transfer processes associated with the post-combustion in the gas region
AdditionalInformation: The Basic Oxygen Furnace (BOF) represents a significant energy user in steelmaking, where optimisation can be achieved by better process understanding. This article stems from a joint UG/Nancy PhD study (Yannick Doh) funded by ArcelorMittal and the French government (ADEME). Greenwich  developed a coupled model of the compressible reacting top space containing a supersonic oxygen jet, with bath chemistry, removing carbon to a required tolerance. The model identified the crucial influence of intermediate reactions in the process and the role of fragmented bath material thrown in the top space (Contacts: pascal.gardin@arcelormittal.com, alain.jardy@ijl.nancy-universite.fr)

Title: The effect of secondary arm growth on thermoelectric magnetohydrodynamics
AdditionalInformation: This article examines the influence of external magnetic fields on the microstructure of alloys, in a fully coupled, 3D, flow, EM field and crystal growth simulation. In particular, the unexplored phenomenon of thermoelectric current interaction with the field to induce solute micro-convections at the scale of secondary and tertiary arms, offers a deterministic control for altering microstructure, producing materials with specific properties. This research led to EPSRC EP/K011413/1, (Disruptive Solidification Microstructures via Thermoelectric Control, £279k) in collaboration with the Diamond UK Synchrotron facility and Manchester University (Contact: peter.lee@manchester.ac.uk), which aims to observe this effect in situ, in real time.

Title: A Habitable Fluvio-Lacustrine Environment at Yellowknife Bay, Gale Crater, Mars.
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the first discovery of an ancient habitable river and lake environment on Mars, ie., one that is suited to support a possible Martian biosphere. The paper highlights the biological viability of sedimentary rocks on Mars. The report is one of the major results of NASA's Mars Science Laboratory Curiosity rover mission on which Gupta is a Science Team member. Gupta analysed and interpreted the palaeoenvironmental contexts, participated in rover operations, and provided strategic leadership in his role as a mission Long Term Science Planner. Led to invited plenary at International Association of Sedimentologists Conference (Manchester, UK 09/2013).

Title: A semi-analytical model for the combined aeroelastic behaviour and gust response of a flexible aerofoil
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel and efficient means of analysing the gust response of a flexible aerofoil. It is a key component of the multi-fidelity approach developed by the authors for the aeroelastic optimisation of wings and aerofoils (presented at AIAA, ASMO-UK and ISSMO conferences). It was also extended and applied by Berci while employed as a research contractor for Airbus DE after completing his PhD, to provide a comparison with high fidelity FSI results (Computers and Structures 122 (2013) 202–216). This work is also an important aspect of the EU Initial Training Network AMEDEO (Ref: 316394, Euro3.6M).

Title: A model for film-forming with Newtonian and shear-thinning fluids
Tri-Helical Gravure Roll Coating
A two-scale model for discrete cell gravure roll coating
Improved processing of carbon nanotube/magnesium alloy composites
CNT reinforced light metal composites produced by melt stirring and by high pressure die casting
Corrosion behaviour of multiwall carbon nanotube/magnesium composites in 3.5% NaCl
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to systematically study the corrosion of CNT/pure Mg composites. It shows a possibility to tune corrosion behaviour for biomedical applications besides the improved mechanical properties of such composites. This research led to a follow up publication and invited cover page (DOI: 10.1002/maco.201006023, Materials and Corrosion, 2012). Partly based on this work, I was accepted as member of the Cluster of Excellence “Engineering of Advanced Materials"), University of Erlangen, Germany in which I was the only non-professorial member (Monika.Schenk@eam.uni-erlangen.de). My research was included in the successful phase-two proposal of the Cluster (DFG, 28 Mio. €, robert.singer@ww.uni-erlangen.de).

Title: Influence of MWCNT dispersion on corrosion behaviour of their Mg composites
AdditionalInformation: This paper for the first time studied on the dispersion influence on CNT/magesium alloy composites and indicated that the dispersion is not only important for mechanical properties of the composites, but also to the corrosion behaviour. This paper was invited to be the cover page of the journal issue (Materials and Corrosion, 63 (5), May 2012). Based on the promising results from this work, Prof. Zaiser (Materials Simulation, University of Erlangen, Germany, michael.zaiser@ww.uni-erlangen.de) is working on the simulation of the interaction between CNT and Mg matrix now.

Title: Steerable miniature jumping robot
AdditionalInformation: The jumping performance of the robot presented in this paper is ten times better compared to similar other systems. This makes it an outstanding robotic platform for mobile sensing in rough terrain. The work has been awarded the best paper award at IEEE IROS (http://tinyurl.com/bc4hr48) and IEEE ROBIO (http://tinyurl.com/abcdgh4), the Fondation Marguerite prize (http://tinyurl.com/bt6efhv), the cover page of Autonomous Robots (http://tinyurl.com/a72hpf7) which is a top 3 journal in robotics (http://tinyurl.com/co2v7hu) and a nomination for the EPFL best PhD thesis award (http://tinyurl.com/cu3wgq4). Furthermore, it has received wide international media attention (http://tinyurl.com/KovacMediaCoverage) ncluding coverage from New Scientist, BBC and New York Times.

Title: IMPULSE RESPONSE APPROXIMATIONS OF DISCRETE SHAPE HESSIANS WITH APPLICATION IN CFD
VolumeTitle: SIAM Journal on Control and Optimization

Title: New forcing scheme to sustain particle-laden homogeneous and isotropic turbulence
AdditionalInformation:
This paper is the first to demonstrate that  particles can modify turbulent energy transfer, 
This study resolved a long-standing controversy about whether particles can be studied in 
forced turbulence and showed clearly that the problem was not the forcing per se,
but the manner in which the forcing had been previously implemented. The
implications for turbulence-particle studies are quite significant,
since forced turbulence is much easier to implement and the results
easier to understand than the alternatives.

Title: Two-point correlations in high Reynolds number flat plate turbulent boundary layers
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes part of an experiment sponsored by the EU 7th Framework STREP as WALLTURB.   WKG was one of 15 principals, which included Airbus and Dassault.  This particular experiment involved researchers from three universities and ONERA/Toulouse, and utilized the 20m long test section of the unique high-Reynolds number boundary layer facility of Laboratoire de Mécanique de Lille.  The research identified unambiguously for the first time streamwise flow structures of many boundary layer thicknesses in length.  This has important implications for both future experiments and numerical simulations.  The WALLTURB database is being used to improve industrial turbulence models (contact: Bertrand.Aupoix@onera.fr).

Title: Experimental Study of the Far Field of Incompressible Swirling Jets
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses a long-standing argument about the effects of swirl on entrainment and jet behaviour.  It resolved a controversy over whether upstream conditions can persist far-downstream, and whether similarity theory can be applied to such flows. Moreover the experiments confirm the prediction of equilibrium similarity theory for rotating jets.  The results were included in the major review paper by WKG written as a part of his 2008 ASME Freeman Award (George, W.K. 2012 “Asymptotic effect of initial and upstream conditions on turbulence,” J. Fluids Engr., 134, 061203, 1 -26.), and were in part responsible for his receiving the award.

Title: The exponential decay of homogeneous turbulence
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided a theoretical basis for experiments at Imperial by Vasillicos and co-workers using fractal grids.  It predicted the existence of a state of turbulence that had not previously been observed.  It also led directly to lead author's Marie Curie Professorship, and joining the faculty at Imperial College.  Both theory and experiments provide a significant challenge to our present understanding of turbulent flows with profound implications for the future of turbulence theory and modelling (c.f. George, W.K. (2012) “Asymptotic effect of initial and upstream conditions on turbulence,” J. Fluids Engr., 134, 061203, 1 -26.)

Title: Corner effect and separation in transonic channel flows
Unsteady shock wave dynamics
AdditionalInformation:
This paper sheds new light on a topic (unsteady shock waves) that is widely reported as being poorly understood, despite its importance in the prediciton of parameters such as peak heat transfer rate in high speed applications (Dolling, 2001, AIAA JOURNAL Vol.39).

This paper's material was presented at the 46th AIAA conference (AIAA Paper 2008-0721), where it was awarded "Best paper in session", raising the first author's profile within AIAA and resulting in him becoming coordinator of the AIAA Fluid Dynamics SWBLI discussion group (Jan 2012-present).

Follow-on work includes: EPSRC "Support fund" grant (£45k, 2011), EPSRC funded PhD student (2012-15).

Title: Experimental and Numerical Study of Oscillating Transonic Shock Waves in Ducts
AdditionalInformation:
This paper represents a significant output from the EU FP6 project UFAST: http://www.ufast.gda.pl.
The presented results were obtained from collaborative research with industry (NUMECA Intl.).
The use of advanced experimental techniques and data processing algorithms highlighted a number of (previously-unidentified) weaknesses in state-of-the-art turbulence models and URANS codes in modelling unsteady shock-wave/boundary-layer interactions.
This paper was used in the application for the awarded 3.8M Euro EU FP7 Marie Curie IDP MULTISOLVE to demonstrate expertise in advanced experimental techniques which was key to securing this grant.
The material was presented at an invited seminar at the University of Southampton (23/11/2011).

Title: Experimental Study into the Flow Physics of Three-Dimensional Shock Control Bumps
AdditionalInformation:
The results presented in this paper set a benchmark for experimental research into a promising new flow control technology using state-of-the-art experimental techniques.

Results from this work were presented as paper AIAA-2011-0855 at the 2011 AIAA conference, where it received the "AIAA Applied Aerodynamics Best Paper" award.

Work paved the way for a transonic flow control workshop hosted by P.Bruce at Imperial (13/06/2012) with 21 participants.

Research resulting from this work includes an EPSRC funded studentship at Imperial (2012-2015) and elements of the EU FP7 project NEXTWING (2011-2014): http://cordis.europa.eu/projects/rcn/100013_en.html.

The paper was presented at an invited seminar at TUDelft (12/4/2012).

Title: Motion of a spherical solid particle in thermal counterflow turbulence
AdditionalInformation: This was the first computation of particle-superfluid vortex collisions in a self-consistent way, a phenomenon that had previously only been studied experimentally. The results expounded the effect of superfluid-vortex stratification, and the formation of a vortex tail behind the particle when stratification was strong. Never before has it been possible (in superfluids) to compare directly velocity measurement data with theoretical predictions from first principles. It was achieved here, and the excellent agreement with experiment [Zhang and Van Sciver, J. Low Temp. Phys. 138, 865 (2005)] was instrumental in the justification of the employed PIV methods [Phys. Fluids 23, 107102 (2011)].

Title: Collisions of solid particles with vortex rings in superfluid helium
AdditionalInformation:
This first first-principles computation of particle-superfluid vortex collisions in superfluids provides templates
for the detection of superfluid vortex rings via their effects on particles upon collision at both ultra low and higher temperatures.  In the former case, particle-vortex ring collisions lead to sudden, spiralling trajectories in a previously rectilinear particle motion; in the latter, the resulting particle oscillations are normal to its direction of motion.
The results (reviewed by Sergeev and Barenghi in J Low Temp Phys (2009) 157: 429–475) suggest that available experimental techniques (J Low Temp Phys (2009) 156: 84–94) could detect vortex rings and verify theoretical predictions.

Title: Normal-fluid velocity measurement and superfluid vortex detection in thermal counterflow turbulence
AdditionalInformation: This work aimed to guide and explain results from particle tracking and PIV experiments in superfluids. it showed that, contrary to standard beliefs at the time, particles are not trapped by superfluid vortices and provided, for the first time, a template for the identification of particle-vortex collision patterns in experiment. The work resolved an apparent inconsistency between results by two different groups at Florida State and Maryland Universities by showing that, unknowingly, the two groups were studying different flow regimes as pointed out by Prof. Sergeev of Newcastle University (Yuri.Sergeev@ncl.ac.uk) and appeared in the review paper JLTP (2009) 157: 429–475.

Title: Spreading of superfluid vorticity clouds in normal-fluid turbulence
AdditionalInformation: The analysis was the first ever direct numerical simulation of superfluid turbulence at finite temperatures. It revealed that the coupling effect of mutual friction force is weak (comparable with viscous dissipation in the normal-fluid) and that, contrary to prevailing ideas at the time, superfluid vorticity is not organised in bundles, but is characterised by a mild polarization. Following this publication, I was invited to present my findings (http://www.kitpc.ac.cn/?p=ProgDetail&id=PN20120312&i=schedule) to the Institute of Theoretical Physics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences as a long term participant to their "New Directions in Turbulence" program (http://www.kitpc.ac.cn/?p=ProgDetail&id=PN20120312&i=participants).

Title: Buckling of thick cylindrical shells under external pressure: A new analytical expression for the critical load and comparison with elasticity solutions
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: A new analytic expression for the loss of stability (buckling) of thick cylindrical shells under hydrostatic pressure is proposed. It is based on a higher order theory that accounts more rigorously for the shell thickness compared to the standard theory. The new expression can predict with greater accuracy the critical load. This work on structural stability complements parallel work in the area of flow stability and has resulted in the award (in 2010) of the EPSRC grant EP/I016015/1 (grant value £374,395) on the control of instabilities that develop within boundary layers.

Title: A novel pressure-velocity formulation and solution method for fluid-structure interaction problems
AdditionalInformation: The paper proposes a unified method for fluid-structure-interaction problems in which the same variables (velocities and pressure), discretisation method (finite volume) and segregated, pressure correction algorithms are used for the solution of the equations that describe both media (fluid and solid). The method eliminates the need for a separate interface between different codes that solve the fluid and solid equations using different techniques and algorithms. The numerical methodology was implemented in an in-house solver, which was critical in securing (in 2012) a 3.8 million euro EU award MULTISOLVE for the simulation of multi-scale flows (grant agreement number 317269).

Title: Investigation of the effect of external periodic flow pulsation on a cylinder wake using linear stability analysis
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides for the first time a theoretical explanation for the symmetric vortex shedding pattern observed experimentally in the wake of a circular cylinder when periodic pulsation is superimposed to the free-stream velocity. Preliminary results were presented on the ASME-PVP conference on July 2010 and won the Outstanding Technical paper award (date of award July 2011) from the fluid-structure-interaction committee of ASME (PVP Division Newsletter, Spring 2012, page 10, http://files.asme.org/Divisions/PVP/31931.pdf).  This work also led to collaboration with the National University of Singapore (joint PhD studentship awarded in 2012) for airfoil drag reduction using periodic wall actuation.

Title: New analytic solutions for wave propagation in flexible, tapered vessels with reference to mammalian arteries
AdditionalInformation: A theory is proposed that solves a long standing problem in wave propagation in tapering arteries. Analytic solutions for tapering vessels first appeared in the mid 60’s and are based on asymptotic expansion (WKB theory) but the results are not applicable to mammalian arteries. The theory provides general analytic solutions, directly applicable to the cardiovascular systems of mammals. The paper is the culminaton of theoretical work in biofluids that has resulted in collaboration with the School of Medicine of King's College London and the award (in 2009) of £1.2 million grant from the Biomedical Research Centre (acknowledged in  http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jbiomech.2010.05.031).

Title: An Energy-Preserving Description of Nonlinear Beam Vibrations in Modal Coordinates
AdditionalInformation: The quality and nature of finite dimensional approximating systems for the dynamics of nonlinear beams are investigated. Approximations are constructed which are energy-preserving and, surprisingly, this property is independent of the dimension of the approximating system, which is useful in control system design. Important potential applications include new-generation lightweight, flexible aircraft, such as the tailless Lockheed Martin X56a, which possess nontrivial nonlinear dynamics and therefore require advanced control systems to maintain flight. Understanding and simply representing this nonlinear behaviour, for example using the methods developed in this paper, is therefore essential to the successful design of such controllers.

Title: Optimal Mode Decomposition For Unsteady Flows
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel algorithmic method, Optimal Mode Decomposition, for extracting coherent information from experimental fluid flow data. The algorithm creates flow profiles which are dynamically important, allowing users to easily and visually determine flow features of interest. The method is significant since it generalizes and improves Dynamic Mode Decomposition, a technique which has recently gained wide popularity in the fluids community.  This work led to an EPSRC-funded travel grant to visit the University of Michigan in March 2013, and results from the paper were presented during this visit at an Applied and Interdisciplinary Mathematics seminar.

Title: alpha-admissibility of the right-shift semigroup on L-2(R+)
AdditionalInformation:
A method is developed for translating the control-theoretic property of admissibility between discrete and continuous time systems. It is used to show that transport equations whose solutions are described by a shift-semigroup do not satisfy the weighted Weiss conjecture. 

This work has led to fully-funded invitations to speak at three international conferences: EU-FP6-funded ‘TODEQ’ (Gdansk, March 2010) the EU-FP7-supported ‘Asymptotics of Semigroups’ (Oxford, September 2009) and the ‘Conference on Control of Distributed Parameter Systems,’ Wuppertal, Germany in July 2011. The final visit led to ongoing collaborative research with Professor Jacob (jacob@math.uni-wuppertal.de).

Title: COUNTEREXAMPLES TO THE DISCRETE AND CONTINUOUS WEIGHTED WEISS CONJECTURES
VolumeTitle: SIAM Journal on Control and Optimization
AdditionalInformation:
The weighted Weiss conjecture states that the fundamental property of admissibility – whether an actuation input to a control system produces a desirable response – has a frequency domain characterisation. This work shows that such a characterization is not always possible for two separate system classes. These results are surprising since they are in contrast to the behaviour of the conjecture in its original, unweighted, setting. 

This work led to a successful application for an EPSRC-Phd-Plus grant at Oxford University (April–July 2009). Research extending these results is currently undertaken by Professors Jacob (jacob@math.uni-wuppertal.de), Partington (J.R.Partington@leeds.ac.uk) and Pott (sandra@maths.lth.se).

Title: Pseudo-bistable self-actuated domes for morphing applications
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the first demonstration of the presence of pseudo-bistability in structures with zero Gaussian curvature and was written in collaboration with the ACCIS DTC at the University of Bristol. Adaptive surface aspects were used to initiate a research collaboration with Prof. Pedro Reis (preis@mit.edu), Department of Mechanical Engineering, MIT, to investigate variable roughness surfaces exploiting thin membrane stability. An invited paper on this work was also presented in a special session at the 2012 European Solid Mechanics Conference.

Title: Self-actuated snap back of viscoelastic pulsing structures
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time the mechanics of a new class of structure that has a response between monostable and bistable. The paper led to a collaboration with the ACCIS DTC at the University of Bristol (paul.weaver@bristol.ac.uk) with a joint PhD student. Further to the collaboration with Bristol, a joint project with the Space Structures Laboratory at Caltech (sergiop@caltech.edu) has commenced to investigate similar time-dependent effects in composite boom structures.

Title: Topological Optimization of Compliant Adaptive Wing Structure
Compliant multistable structural elements
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The first generalisation of a successful methodology to connect bistable tapespring-based structures to form multistable systems. The tapespring work – in particular their integration into complex compliant systems – led to a collaboration with the Space and Atmospheric Physics group in the Department of Physics, Imperial College London, and formed the basis of two funded projects with the US Air Force Research Laboratory (Award No. FA8655-10-1-3065, £27,000) and the European Space Agency (Award No. 4000106430, £94,000).

Title: Estimating wall-shear-stress fluctuations given an outer region input
AdditionalInformation: The recent discovery of the influence of super-large structures on near-wall turbulence proved non- universality of near-wall turbulence and thus threatened the entire ideology linking fundamental research in turbulence and important practical applications. This problem was resolved by the theory (first described in an arxiv manuscript (http://arxiv.org/abs/1203.3714) and presented at the Joint ERCOFTAC/PLASMAERO Workshop, Toulouse, 2012). The paper is the first official publication involving that theory. Being too recent for formal indications of impact, it does signify a start of collaboration with Prof. Marusic (University of Melbourne).

Title: Modelling turbulent skin-friction control using linearized Navier-Stokes equations
AdditionalInformation:
Contribution of aviation to CO2 emissions is set to rise to 15% by 2030. Therefore, reducing turbulent drag on aircraft is of high importance. This paper gives the first evidence that the magnitude of the turbulent drag reduction by in-plane wall oscillations can be estimated using linearized Navier-Stokes equations. This result is profound, since turbulence is nonlinear. It opens a possibility of developing new methods of turbulent drag reduction. This result is one of the products of a long term effort which was recognized by an invitation to the Newton Institute Programme (the talk:  
http://www.newton.ac.uk/programmes/HRT/seminars/2008090814001.html) and a keynote presentation (http://www.southampton.ac.uk/engineering/research/groups/afm/ipc_65.page).

Title: Turbulent flow and heat transfer in eccentric annulus
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the results of direct numerical simulation of a flow with a laminar-turbulent interface in as simple geometry as possible for such a problem, namely, that of the flow in an eccentric annulus. The properties of a laminar-turbulent interface are among the most complicated and least studied fundamental questions concerning turbulence. This paper formed a milestone in the continuing long-term collaboration with Dr.N.Nikitin (Moscow State University), which led to EPSRC grant EP/D050871/2, and to other joint papers including one in 2013 which demonstrates that  two known turbulent drag-reducing methods, riblets and in-plane wall oscillations, can be combined beneficially.

Title: Global stability analysis of fluid flows using sum-of-squares
AdditionalInformation: In most cases steady flows are better, ensuring smaller fuel consumption, less fatigue, and less noise. For more than a century finding a Lyapunov function proving stability of a nonlinear system depended on ingenuity of the researcher. A recent breakthrough (Parrilo, 2000) provided a constructive method for systems with polynomial dynamics. Our paper extended this approach to fluid flows. This resulted in an EPSRC grant EP/J011126/1, led by ICL and involving teams from Oxford,  Southampton, and ETH Zurich, collaborations with internationally acknowledged experts Prof. B. Bamieh (University of California Santa Barbara), Prof. C.R. Doering (University of Michigan), and Airbus support.

Title: Experimental estimation of fluctuating velocity and scalar gradients in turbulence
AdditionalInformation: It is shown that high-order gradient computation schemes can be implemented on experimentally acquired data, in the same way that they can for numerical simulations. This will bring the precision of gradient quantities, such as dissipation which is a crucial aspect of all turbulence models, from experimental studies more into line with those from numerical studies. This can thus lead to a better validation of new and existing codes against comparable experiments, as well as improving the ongoing efforts to measure dissipation experimentally, including in the new generation of very large Reynolds number experiments.

Title: The effects of resolution and noise on kinematic features of fine-scale turbulence
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the effects of noise and limited spatial resolution, inherent to all experimental data, on the observation of the strain-rotation interaction in turbulent flows. The analysis presented in this paper has been subsequently incorporated into a variety of tomographic PIV studies as a means to illustrate the limitations of the data presented. This is a nascent technique that is rapidly developing into the most powerful tool in experimental turbulence as it can provide fully three-dimensional velocity data at Reynolds numbers that are beyond the reach of numerical simulations.

Title: Amplification of enstrophy in the far field of an axisymmetric turbulent jet
AdditionalInformation: Fine-scale turbulence has long been considered to be "universal". The arbitrary alignment between the vorticity vector and the extensive strain-rate eigenvector is considered to be a "universal" phenomenon. This paper, in fact, shows that the alignment is strongly dependent upon whether the local fluid is enstrophy amplifying or enstrophy attenuating. This has serious implications for LES turbulence modelling, which employs a variety of models that rely on this "universality". It has also led to greater scrutiny amongst the community on the alignment tendencies of the vorticity vector in a variety of flows, including turbulent combustion.

Title: The interaction between strain-rate and rotation in shear flow turbulence from inertial range to dissipative length scales
AdditionalInformation: This paper further shows that the alignment tendencies of the vorticity vector and the extensive strain-rate eigenvector is heavily scale dependent, showing much stronger tendencies at larger, inertial range scales. This is of great significance to turbulence LES modelling as this behaviour must be taken into account when deciding on the turbulence model for a given grid size. The scale dependence has been further observed both experimentally and numerically and acknowledged to be " a crucial ingredient in any effort to properly understand the dynamics of the velocity gradient tensor".

Title: The response of a multi-directional composite laminate to through-thickness loading
AdditionalInformation: Quantifies experimentally the stochastic nature of the mechanical response of composite laminates to through-thickness loading and reports for the first time direct measurements of a strong size effect in tensile through-thickness failure stress of thick laminated composites. The paper demonstrates that stochastic variation in material properties must be taken in account when designing thick composites laminates. Output of a small (10k£) exploratory project funded by Rolls-Royce at Oxford.

Title: Prediction of the dynamic response of composite sandwich beams under shock loading
A new weight-function enrichment in meshless methods for multiple cracks in linear elasticity
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering

Title: The response of rigid plates to blast in deep water: fluid-structure interaction experiments
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical & Engineering Sciences

Title: Identification of impact force for smart composite stiffened panels
AdditionalInformation: A novel method has been proposed to reconstruct the force history of foreign object impacts on aircraft fuselage, by using strain waves recorded with Piezoelectric sensors. The proposed method is being applied to aircraft wings in a large EU project on smart intelligent aircraft structures (www.saristu.eu), involving AIRBUS. This work formed part of   successful EU grant application, Cleansky project SCOPE 335948, which secured 400k Euros.

Title: Influence of the body on the response of the helmeted head during impact
Determination of impact location on composite stiffened panels
AdditionalInformation:
For the first time, nonlinear impact models of aircraft composite panels have been developed through training Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) with a large number of impact data, recorded by Piezoceramic sensors. The ANNs were subsequently used to accurately determine locations of foreign object impacts. This work formed part of a subsequent successful EU grant
application, Cleansky project SCOPE 335948 (400k Euros), to develop algorithms for accurate identification of impact and damage in aircraft structures.

Title: Effects of the presence of the body in helmet oblique impacts
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a novel method for assessing the protective capability of safety helmets during oblique impacts. This work led to collaborations with IIT India within a UKEIRI project (ref. no. UKUTP201100304). Moreover, it contributed to a successful fellowship application, which brought Dr Ghajari an Imperial College’s Junior Research Fellowship (jane.williams@imperial.ac.uk) to continue his research on biomechanics of brain trauma and head protection.

Title: An investigation into the stresses in double-lap adhesive joints with laminated composite adherends
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures

Title: Feedback control of flow resonances using balanced reduced-order models
AdditionalInformation: This paper derives balanced reduced order models of resonant fluid systems and uses these to design stabilising feedback controllers. Specifically, the Eigensystem Realisation Algorithm is used, which captures input-output dynamics accurately ("balanced modelling") without requiring adjoint simulations, making it applicable experimentally. This paper is the first to use the ERA for model reduction and feedback control in fluids, and includes application to experimental data (verification contact: Prof. Cattafesta, cattafesta@eng.fsu.edu). It was the fruit of collaboration with Prof. Clancy Rowley's Princeton University Group  (contact: cwrowley@Princeton.EDU), during which strategies from the combustion instability and flow modelling communities were merged (see also http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2012.330).

Title: Tuned passive control of combustion instabilities using multiple Helmholtz resonators
AdditionalInformation:
This paper describes how passive controllers for suppressing combustion instability can be tuned when operating conditions vary, by slowly varying the geometry of the controller (here a Helmholtz resonator). Algorithms are presented to achieve robust tuning. This work was presented as an invited paper at a structured session on Thermoacoustics at the 2010 International Congress on Sound and Vibration (contact: Prof Jim Kok, J.B.W.Kok@utwente.nl). The paper instigated significant follow-up work on tuned passive control of combustion instability in Asia, including groups in South Korea, Singapore and China (e.g. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jsv.2010.06.027, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jsv.2010.02.018, http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00102202.2012.660224,
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ast.2010.12.004, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1000-9361(09)60263-6).

Title: Phase prediction of the response of choked nozzles to entropy and acoustic disturbances
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops and validates mathematical models for the noise generated by the acceleration of temperature variations at the exit of a gas turbine combustor. The conference version of this paper was awarded 1st Prize in the Young Scientist Competition at the 6th European Aeronautics Days 2011 conference in Madrid. The findings of the paper contributed directly to the award of a prestigious ERC Starting Grant proposal (ACOULOMODE, PI: Morgans, 2013-2018) to further investigate entropy/acoustic interactions and their importance to both combustion instability and aero-engine noise.

Title: Feedback control for form-drag reduction on a bluff body with a blunt trailing edge
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, a new active control strategy for reducing the aerodynamic drag of a bluff body was developed and demonstrated in low and moderate Reynolds number flow simulations. These findings, first published in an internal report in 2010, led directly to a successful HECToR supercomputer proposal (PI: Morgans, 10 million APUs, 2012) to extend the strategy to higher Reynolds numbers and more realistic geometries, and a successful EPSRC proposal (EP/I005684/1), to extend the strategy to experiments and to enhance understanding of why it is effective.

Title: Computational Aeroelasticity Framework for Analyzing Flapping Wing Micro Air Vehicles
AdditionalInformation: Efficient flapping flight of engineered vehicles is one of the frontiers in aeronautics and this work advanced the computational tools by directly tackling the 3D coupled simulations on a fully-flexible flapping wing, as part of an international collaboration researchers at the University of Michigan. The computational framework developed in this work is the basis for two successful UK research grants sponsored by the EPSRC (EP/J002070/1) and the European Office for Aerospace Research and Development of the US Air Force Office of Scientific Research, to develop actuated membrane wings for application in micro-air vehicles.

Title: Camber effects in the dynamic aeroelasticity of compliant airfoils
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces the simplest possible model (3 degrees of freedom) to study aeroelastic instabilities on a deforming airfoil. This simplicity is drawing a very substantial attention to it as a tool to investigate the main trade-offs in the dynamics of "morphing wings", as it provides an intuitive understanding of the linear physical mechanisms in fluid-structure interactions driven by aerofoil compliance aerofoil: In early 2012 it was the "hottest paper" at the journal (top25.sciencedirect.com/journal/08899746), it has six citations so far, and since 2011 is a top three download at Spiral (Imperial College open-access repository, www.imperial.ac.uk/library/subjectsandsupport/spiral/toptwenty), with 200+ downloads each month.

Title: A moderate deflection composite helicopter rotor blade model with an improved cross-sectional analysis
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures

Title: Nonlinear normal modes in an intrinsic theory of anisotropic beams
Numerical analysis of size effects on open-hole tensile composite laminates
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A - Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper in which the thickness-dependence of translaminar fracture toughness is accounted for in the numerical modelling of composites. The methodology accurately predicts for the first time (by a deterministic model) the thickness size effect in the strength of open-hole composite laminates failing by pull-out. The work was invited to national and international conferences such as ACME-UK (http://www.acmeuk.org/), ICCM (http://www.iccm18.org/) and WCCM (http://www.wccm2012.com/). The work has led to on-going collaborations with the National University of Singapore (fully-funded joint PhD student) and a TSB funded project with Rolls Royce (SILOET, http://www.rolls-royce.com/about/technology/research_programmes/gas_turbine_programmes/siloet.jsp).

Title: Partition of unity and drilling rotations in the boundary element method (BEM)
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to introduce drilling rotations into the Boundary Element Method (BEM), addressing a long-standing problem in the simulation of complex 3D thin-walled structures (plates/shells) by BEM. It also introduces a novel way to incorporate partition of unity enrichment in BEM. The paper was invited for a keynote lecture at the International XFEM 2011 conference (http://www.xfem2011.com/index.html). The work has led to collaborations with Brazilian researchers (Dr. Albuquerque and Prof. Sollero at Brasilia and Campinas Universities) who are now expanding the areas of applications with the support from two fully funded PhD students (which Dr. Baiz co-supervises).

Title: A locking-free meshfree method for the simulation of shear-deformable plates based on a mixed variational formulation
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This is the first work in the meshfree community to address locking in thin walled structures by a mixed variational formulation. The proposed approach is the most general to-date as all previous techniques are limited to specific basis functions or only alleviate, rather than solve, the locking problem. Its most important aspect is that it lays the foundation for a general way of optimally enriching meshfree formulations. This work won PhD prizes at the International XFEM 2011 Conference (http://www.xfem2011.com/index.html) and the ACME-UK conference (http://www.acmeuk.org/).

Title: Post buckling analysis of shear deformable shallow shells by the boundary element method
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The first paper to introduce a Boundary Element Formulation for the simulation of post-buckling in shell structures under a variety of boundary conditions, this work addresses the application of “in-plane loading” and the “effect of imperfections” (never attempted previously within BEM). Thanks to this work, Dr. Baiz was invited for a two weeks research visit to the Instituto Politecnico Nacional in Mexico. The work has also led to collaborations with a researcher in Colombia (Dr. Useche at Universidad Tecnológica de Bolivar). This work was funded by a 2.8M€ EU Grant on Damage Tolerance for New Structural Concepts (DaToN, http://ec.europa.eu/research/transport/projects/items/daton_en.htm).

Title: A BEM sensitivity formulation for three-dimensional active noise control
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The first computational method capable of determining both optimum position of the control volume and the optimum location/orientation of the secondary source in Active Noise Control (ANC). The method which is based on BEM and sensitivity analysis was applied to the complex environment of an aircraft cabin. The new ANC strategy was implemented and validated inside a mock up cabin at Thales in Toulouse during an industrial workshop. The research was key in securing an EU project SEAT coordinated by ICL. An invited presentation at Aerodays Conference in Madrid. Article in the CORDIS magazine: http://cordis.europa.eu/result/brief/rcn/7351_en.html

Title: A fast 3D dual boundary element. method based on hierarchical matrices
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The new boundary element formulation developed in this paper has speeded up the solution by factor of 10 and reduced the storage requirements by 50%. The method is based on hierarchical matrices and has enabled the application of the BEM to large scale problems. The success of the method led to a proposal and award of a Marie Currie Fellowship for the co-author Benedetti to work at Imperial (grant number 274161) and extend the method to multiscale analysis of polycrystalline materials which would not have been possible with previous formulations. A keynote paper was presented at the BeTeq2012, Prague.

Title: Dual boundary method for assembled plate structures undergoing large deflection
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports on a significant development in DBEM, as for the first time it presents a formulation for the analysis of large deformations of cracked thin-walled structures. Previous DEBEM formulations (originally developed by Aliabadi and co and widely implemented into commercial codes (e.g. http://www.beasy.com/)), are limited to modelling small deformations. Therefore, the new development opens up an entirely new and important field of application for BEM. The work led to an invitation to join Airbus UK in a TSB project (SABCAD TP/5/MAT/6/S/H0644G) and a Keynote lecture at 12th International Conference on Engineering Structural Integrity Assessment - ESIA12 Manchester.

Title: Meshfree modeling and homogenization of 3D orthogonal woven composites
Constitutive modelling of fibre-reinforced composites with unidirectional plies using a plasticity-based approach
Modelling the R-curve effect and its specimen-dependence
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures

Title: Measurement of the in situ ply fracture toughness associated with mode I fibre tensile failure in FRP. Part II: Size and lay-up effects
A micromechanical model for kink-band formation: Part II-Analytical modelling
Insights from von Neumann analysis of high-order flux reconstruction schemes
AdditionalInformation:
• For first time provided comprehensive guidelines for selecting optimal Flux Reconstruction (FR) schemes (in terms of stability and accuracy).
• For first time obtained dispersion and dissipation relations for FR schemes.
• For first time demonstrated experimentally the super-accuracy of FR schemes.
• Results used by Y. Lu (yl443@eng.cam.ac.uk) and W. Dawes (wnd@eng.cam.ac.uk) at Cambridge University to increase efficiency of FR schemes on industrially relevant meshes with high-aspect ratio boundary layer elements.
• Authors invited to present results of the paper at Peking University, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Tsinghua University, Barcelona Supercomputing Centre, BAE Systems, Numeca International.

Title: A New Class of High-Order Energy Stable Flux Reconstruction Schemes for Triangular Elements
A New Class of High-Order Energy Stable Flux Reconstruction Schemes
Blood flow in the rabbit aortic arch and descending thoracic aorta
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation:
• For first time demonstrated how large-scale flow features in aortic arch can influence shear stress patterns (and thus potentially arterial disease patterns) at entrances to downstream aortic branches.
• Featured on journal front cover.
• Featured on front page of Imperial College website.
• Won multiple British Heart Foundation (BHF) ‘Reflections of Research Awards’ (http://www.bhf.org.uk/research/our-science-image-competition.aspx).
• Featured on BHF website (http://www.bhf.org.uk/research/our-science-image-competition.aspx).
• Led to collaborations with Stanford University, Barcelona Supercomputing Centre, and Kings College London.
• Formed basis for large cross-disciplinary Aeronautics/Bioengineering research programme at Imperial College (including award of a £1.3M BHF Programme Grant).

Title: Large-eddy simulation of turbulent boundary layer separation from a rounded step
AdditionalInformation:
- EU-funded research focusing on important subject of separation from curved surfaces (wings and curved ducts), with thin, elongated separated zone.  Particular emphasis on the fundamental physics of turbulence around the separated region. 

- One of very few studies providing a wide range of statistical and structural data, including second-moment budgets, and related analysis, and demonstrating intense generation of turbulence, and extreme anisotropy downstream of separation. Of major interest for RANS validation. 

- Invited inclusion of data and analysis into public NASA and ERCOFTAC databases for general world-wide turbulence-model development and validation. http://qnet-ercoftac.cfms.org.uk/w/index.php/SilverP:UFR_3-31_Test_Case ; http://turbmodels.larc.nasa.gov/Other_LES_Data/curvedstep.html

Title: The interaction of round synthetic jets with a turbulent boundary layer separating from a rounded ramp
AdditionalInformation:
- Major EPSRC/Airbus-funded study investigating the fundamental processes associated with pulsed injection of turbulent round jets into a separating boundary layer, to inhibit separation in high-lift devices in Aeronautics.

- Provides insight into the physics and the effectiveness of alternative actuation scenarios over broad range of statistical and structural properties during the cyclic injection.  

- Three invited/keynote papers or presentations in the UK, Europe and Japan, including  Advances in Computational Mechanics, Japan Society of Computational Engineering and Science, Yokohama, 2010 and Royal Society Theme Issue. http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/369/1940/1495.short.

Title: Large-eddy simulation of separated flow over a three-dimensional axisymmetric hill
AdditionalInformation:
- EPSRC-funded work on a key 3D generic laboratory flows investigated experimentally for a decade. The definitive computational study of the fundamental turbulence mechanics involved, culminating a decade of efforts to characterise key processes (the only JFM paper on this subject). 

- Data and insight derived supported the development of hybrid RANS-LES strategies for computing industrially relevant complex flows at high Reynolds numbers. Underpinning follow-up EPSRC grant EP/H01070X/1 on RANS-LES modelling. 

- Four invited/keynote presentations in Europe and Japan., including 5th. European Congress on Computational Methods, ECCOMAS2008 and  Royal Society Theme Issue http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/367/1899/2885.short

Title: Near-wall streak modification by spanwise oscillatory wall motion and drag-reduction mechanisms
AdditionalInformation:
- EPSRC/EADS/Airbus-funded research on a central ambition in external aerodynamics: turbulent-drag reduction on wings.  Of major interest to sponsoring civil aviation.  Identifying the fundamental mechanisms that drive drag reduction due to oscillatory surface motion. 

- First study to extend simulations to high Reynolds numbers, allowing estimation of Reynolds-number dependence.

- Three invited/keynote lectures and presentations in the UK, Europe and Japan, including  Japan Society of Mechanical Engineering,  Int. Computational Mechanics Symposium, Kobe, Japan, 2010.

Title: Mixed finite elements for numerical weather prediction
A mixed discontinuous/continuous finite element pair for shallow-water ocean modelling
AdditionalInformation: This work introduced a discretisation scheme for unstructured mesh ocean modelling, providing stable representation of both gravity waves and slow balanced dynamics, crucial for large scale modelling. This scheme is used in the Imperial College Ocean Model (external users included British Antarctic Survey (p.holland@bas.ac.uk)), allowing the first unstructured mesh basin-scale simulations that make predicting large scale ocean circulation possible, and led to a successful NERC proposal (NE/I02013X/1, £165k FEC). Comblen et al (2010, Int J. Num. Meth. Fluids) showed it outperforms many other schemes; it has also been adopted by the Hamburg Max Planck Institute (Dueben et al (2011, JCP)).

Title: Solving the Poisson equation on small aspect ratio domains using unstructured meshes
AdditionalInformation: This paper solved a key problem with vertically unstructured meshes for large scale nonhydrostatic ocean modelling: the ill-conditioning of the pressure Poisson equation. The described multigrid preconditioner reduces the computational cost of the pressure Poisson solve by several orders of magnitude so that it is now competitive with vertically aligned meshes. This approach has been incorporated into the Imperial College Ocean Model (which forms part of the NERC Earth System Modelling Strategy (http://www.nerc.ac.uk/research/programmes/esm/background.asp), allowing the first basin scale vertically unstructured simulations. Cotter gave an invited talk on this work at SIAM Geosciences 2009 (http://meetings.siam.org/sess/dsp_programsess.cfm?SESSIONCODE=8362).

Title: A FRAMEWORK FOR MIMETIC DISCRETIZATION OF THE ROTATING SHALLOW-WATER EQUATIONS ON ARBITRARY POLYGONAL GRIDS
Fractal space-scale unfolding mechanism for energy-efficient turbulent mixing
AdditionalInformation:
Demonstrated that fractal grids can be used to enhance heat/scalar transfers by an order of magnitude and at the same time reduce pressure drop by half. Led to 3.8M Euro 
48-month Marie Curie Grant (Innovative Doctoral Programme Number 317269; Conceptually new, multi-scale solutions to industrial flow problems) starting 01/04/2013 and to one plenary invited lecture plus one of two plenary pre-seminars at The 4th International Conference 
on Jets, Wakes and Separated Flows (ICJWSF-2013) Nagoya, Japan Sept.16-20, 2013. Important
element of CISM course on fractal flow design (September 2013; http://www.cism.it/courses/C1310/), the first course ever on this new field started by JCV.

Title: Turbulence without Richardson-Kolmogorov cascade
AdditionalInformation:
One of JCV's papers in a series since 2007 which created a new field
of fluid mechanics research, turbulent flows generated/designed in
fractal/multiscale ways, for which ERCOFTAC inaugurated a new EU-wide
Special Interest Group in 2011 and the Japan Society for the Promotion
of Science held two UK-Japan workshops in March 2011 and 2012. Led to 
EPSRC grant EP/H030875/1 (615K pounds, 2010-2014). A
special issue of Fluid Dynamics Research to appear in 2013 is devoted to this
new area which includes many industrial applications as demonstrated
by the three patents of JCV's filed by Imperial Innovations (two granted: 
EP2004314, EP2274523).

Title: Universal Dissipation Scaling for Nonequilibrium Turbulence
AdditionalInformation:
Culmination of substantial, detailed and rigorous experimental
research reported by JCV since 2007 including in Valente & Vassilicos
(J. Fluid Mech. vol. 687, 300-340, 2011) which led to 2.3M Euro 5-year
ERC Advanced Grant (Multiturbulence) starting 2013. Demonstrated existence 
of a new turbulent dissipation law for non-equilibrium turbulence. Importance 
lies in the fact that the turbulence dissipation law is the most sensitive 
cornerstone of all turbulence modelling over past fifty years. Led to lectures at 
8th Spring School on Transition and Turbulence, Escola Politecnica of the 
University of Sao Paulo, 24-28 September 2012.

Title: Sweep-stick mechanism of heavy particle clustering in fluid turbulence
AdditionalInformation:
Culmination of substantial, detailed, rigorous computational and
theoretical research by JCV reported since 2006 including in Coleman &
Vassilicos (Phys. Fluids 21, 113301, 2009). Discovered new mechanism 
which explains where/why particles cluster in fully turbulent flow of 
lighter fluid (e.g. water droplets in air) and thereby solved this 
long-standing problem as the clustering phenomenon was known for decades. 
Led to invited lecture at COST International Conference on Fundamentals, Experiments,
Numerics and Applications: Particles in Turbulence. University of
Potsdam, 16-18 March 2011. Currently applied to subgrid particle flux models by chamecki@meteo.psu.edu 
for large-eddy simulations of particle dispersion in atmospheric boundary layer.

Title: A homogenised continuum constitutive model for visco-plastic deformation of uni-directional composites
AdditionalInformation: This research was targeted at developing understanding and predictive models for high rate blast loading.  The work aimed to develop a constitutive model which captures full orthotropic behaviour of a laminated composite by employing nine material parameters and accounting for strain-rate sensitivity to loading. The formulation is an extension of the work by Ogihara and Reifsnider. The model developed accounts for strain-rate dependence and can be used for various composite architectures, including woven and uni-directional. The model is being studied by Dstl (Dr Dan Pope) for its potential to predict realistic blast loading in real life scenarios.

Title: Improving the prediction of tensile failure in unidirectional fibre composites by introducing matrix shear yielding
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops a model I developed to predict the tensile strength of unidirectional composite materials. The student Behzadi extended the Monte-Carlo model to include the effects of matrix shear yielding at high strain regions around fibre breaks. This greatly improved the predictions of failure stress/strain. The model now permits the strength of these materials to be predicted from the basic fibre/resin properties alone and accurately represents the observed failure mechanisms, including the sequence of fibre failures. Further work is using CT inspection to confirm the predictions. The model is aiding the more effective use of composite materials.

Title: A study of early-time response in dynamically loaded visco-elastic composites
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by ESPRC and Dstl and forms part of the output aimed at developing understanding/tools to predict ballistic and blast effects on novel polymeric armour materials. This paper describes work leading to the development of a model for blast. The output is being incorporated into tools at Dstl (Dr Dan Pope) for modelling blast effects on military equipment using lightweight polymer-based armour materials fielded by MoD. In the wider programme it is helping the design of more effective armour materials. Work is continuing to study new material concepts and to extend the model to include an optimiser.

Title: Structural composite supercapacitors
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A - Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This sets out the concept of structural power materials, and is the cornerstone publication of our body of work. The work reported here led to leadership of a €3.3M FP7 (STORAGE;#234236), £1M+ of MoD funding and patent (WO/2007/125282). It has led to articles in Materials World, New York Times, New Scientist, The Economist and Professional Engineer Magazines, and a Youtube video with over 73,000 hits (www.youtube.com/watch?v=jZ7A51h6cwU). The work has led to invited FCO tours of Singapore (2011) and Montreal (2011), a keynote at ECCM19 (2012), invited talks in the US (ARL, NASA, DOE), as well as numerous international seminars.

Title: Parametric analysis of runway stone lofting mechanisms
Fractographic Observations on Delamination Growth and the Subsequent Migration Mechanisms Through the Laminate
Hierarchical composites reinforced with carbon nanotube grafted fibers: The potential assessed at the single fiber level
AdditionalInformation:
This is from the development of a novel route to synthesise carbon nanotube reinforced polymer composites. A
micrograph from this study was used as the Journal front cover and this paper was one of the first to
describe the now the highly active field of nanoreinforced hierarchical composites. It led to two subsequent
follow-on programmes being funded (£600K) by the MoD (dstl), and the capability developed has been utilised
in other programmes, such as a 3.3M Euro FP7 (STORAGE) and £1.4M EPSRC (Crashcomps). 
Finally, it led invitations to present at a TTCP 2010 workshop on nanoreinforcement in the US (Annopolis).

Title: Modelling of strain rate effects on matrix dominated elastic and failure properties of unidirectional fibre-reinforced polymer-matrix composites
Decohesion finite element with enriched basis functions for delamination
A progressive failure model for mesh-size-independent FE analysis of composite laminates subject to low-velocity impact damage
A progressive failure model for composite laminates subjected to low velocity impact damage
Effect of aortic taper on patterns of blood flow and wall shear stress in rabbits: Association with age.
AdditionalInformation: This research challenges a 40 year hypothesis about the association of atherosclerosis disease with low wall shear stress in arteries and how the disease changes pattern with age. The article is the culmination of research funded under an £838k EPSRC Fellowship (EP/C539834/1,EP/C539842/1)  and was instrumental in the award of £9M BHF research excellence award. It received the best oral presentation prize at BHF Centre of Research Symposium 2012 and third prize in PhD student competition at ASME bioengineering conference (2012). Keynote lectures were presented at Newton workshop “Cardiac Physiome” (2009), Computational Haemodynamics, Switzerland (2010) and Patient Specific Modelling, Cardiff (2013).

Title: Convective instability and transient growth in flow over a backward-facing step
AdditionalInformation: This was the first application of transient instability analysis of unsteady base flows in non-trivial geometries. The study led to the £374K EPSRC grants Advanced Instability Methods (EP/H050507/1) and  £353K Bypass Transition (EP/F045093/1). This line of research was instrumental in establishing a Royal of Academy of Engineering Research Chair (2012) with McLaren of £600K. Invited keynote lectures were presented at ERCOFTAC workshop in Toledo 2011 (http://www2.mech.kth.se/sig33/events/9th/index.html) and the 17th UK National workshop on computational mechanics, 2009 as well as seminars at Bristol, Cardiff and Cambridge.

Title: Streamwise vortices in shear flows: harbingers of transition and the skeleton of coherent structures
AdditionalInformation: This collaboration between applied mathematics and computational analysis has provided the link between asymptotic theory from 1991 by Hall & Smith called Vortex Wave Interaction with a concept from dynamics systems called self sustaining processes. These concepts are related to the underpinning structures of high Reynolds number turbulent flows. The research interaction was an important component in establishing the £4.2M EPSRC Laminar Flow Control Centre (EP/I037946/1) supported by Airbus/EADS and McLaren Racing. Invited keynote lectures were made at the ERCOFTAC Special Interest Group on Transition Mechanisms, Prediction and Control in Toledo, 2011 (http://www2.mech.kth.se/sig33/events/9th/index.html) and Nice, 2010 (http://www2.mech.kth.se/sig33/events/8th/index.html)

Title: From h to p efficiently: Implementing finite and spectral/hp element methods to achieve optimal performance for low- and high-order discretisations
AdditionalInformation: This research provides a fundamental insight into the implementation barriers to making finite element codes run efficiently at both high and low orders. The research was an output from the £838K EPSRC Advanced Research Award (EP/C539834/1 & EP/C539842/1) and the basis for the for £1.2M EPSRC grant “LibHPC: Intelligent component-based development of HPC applications” (EP/I037946/1 & EP/K038788/1 ) involving new collaboration with Computer Scientists. There have been three subsequent papers based on the research and the research was presented at invited plenary/semi-plenary at Finite Element in Fluids (Munich) 2011 and ICCFD (Hawaii) 2012, HONOM (Trento) 2011.

Title: Turbulent friction drag reduction using electroactive polymer and electromagnetically driven surfaces
AdditionalInformation: Paper is the first to report, by the application of pulsed-jet blowing immediately beneath the point of separation, the increase in base pressure on a bluff body by as much as 35%, leading to drag reductions of about 15%.  The approach – “virtual streamlining” – of a wake has led to: further support from EPSRC/I005684 for development of feedback control; Imperial Innovations, the Climate-KIC programme and EPSRC “Pathways to Impact” to develop efficient actuators. Invited talks: Institute of Aeronautical and Space (IAE/DCTA), São José Dos Campos, October 25, 2011 and Embraer, Unidade São José Dos Campos, Brazil, October 26, 2011.

Title: Electro-active polymer (EAP) "dimple" actuators for flow control: Design and characterisation
AdditionalInformation: One of a series of papers reporting development of electro-active polymers (EAPS) for novel application of time-dependent surface deformations for boundary-layer control.  EAPs are used as the basis of a ‘smart’ controllable surface for the reduction of turbulent skin-friction or the delay of separation.  The novelty of the paper lies in its combination of results from an investigation of the mechanical properties of EAP as well as its use in wind-tunnel tests.  Patent publication WO2006040532, 2006.  Work led to contract EADS IW202838.  Invited talk: Summary of Meeting, Minnowbrook VI – Triennial Flow Control Workshop, Syracuse University, Aug 23-36, 2009.

Title: Relaminarisation of Re-tau=100 channel flow with globally stabilising linear feedback control
AdditionalInformation: Linear control theory is used to control the nonlinear system of turbulent channel flow, resulting in relaminarisation.  Interpretation using linear ideas in turbulence theory shows that the wall-normal velocity provides a unique means for control, involving: a linear synthesis problem providing a global, nonlinear, stability result; the “passivity” concept wherein nonlinearity is identified to have a conservative property which has a direct elegant, analogue in fluid mechanics.  Work led to new contract from EADS-IW203591 and Programme grant, LFC-UK, EPSRC/I037946.   Invited talks at Dept. Ingenieria Mecanica, Universidad De Malaga, February 13, 2012 and Escola Politécnica da USP, Brazil, October 24, 2011.

Title: Similarity of the streamwise velocity component in very-rough-wall channel flow
AdditionalInformation: The results focus on the effects of turbulent channel flow with large relative roughness.  It is first to report: previous guidelines on values of relative roughness at which similarity breaks down are conservative and depend on the form of roughness; outer similarity is robust, even when self-similarity of the mean profile breaks down; large coherent structure persists on such surfaces. Work led to a new research grant EPSRC/I037938.  Invited talks at KTH Stockholm, Workshop & Spring School, April 6-30, 2010, and Centro Andaluz De Medio Ambiente, University of Granada Feb 15, 2012.

Title: Assessment of added mass effects on flutter boundaries using the Leishman-Beddoes dynamic stall model
AdditionalInformation:
It is customary to neglect inertial effects in aeroelastic
analysis of rotor blades. This simplifies the analysis
but it is very difficult to find evidence that it is acceptable. 
This paper addresses this issue. Using typical aerofoil section 
with linear springs in pitch and plunge and aerodynamic loads represented 
by a well-established dynamic stall model, we show that inertial effects lead 
to errors that depend on mass ratio. This simplified aeroelastic model is 
commonly used in industry for the analysis of helicopter and wind turbine
blades. Current work is concentrating in extending this
analysis to aeroelastic models.

Title: Modelling pulse wave propagation in the rabbit systemic circulation to assess the effects of altered nitric oxide synthesis.
AdditionalInformation:
This is the first time that in vivo data has been collected (in the
rabbit) for validating numerical simulations using a reduced model of the 
circulation. Alterations of blood viscosity, peripheral resistance and compliance,
and wall elasticity of conduit arteries were identified as plausible mechanisms
responsible for observed changes in peripheral pulse waveforms after
administering drugs that alter nitric oxide synthesis. Long-term
aim is to establish a protocol for calibrating such models using limited 
and uncertain patient data. Ultimate goal is to devise, with the help of medics, 
a clinical protocol based on such
models.

Title: Automatic reconstruction of a patient-specific high-order surface representation and its application to mesh generation for CFD calculations.
AdditionalInformation: This invited article summarizes work that spans fifteen years of my research on patient-specific shape reconstruction from medical images, mesh generation of unstructured high-order meshes and the simulation of flows in these meshes using a high-order hp-spectral solver. This describes one of the very few available tools for high-order patient-specific simulation. My research expertise in high-order mesh generation and flow simulation, and this sumarizing paper in particular, has led to invitations to participate in two european projects: IDIHOM on “Industrialisation of high-order methods – A top-down approach” and ANADE on “Advances in numerical and analytical tools for detached flow prediction”.

Title: A free-surface and blockage correction for tidal turbines
AdditionalInformation: This article develops a theoretical analysis of effects of free surface and seabed on the flow field around tidal stream turbines modelled using actuator disc theory. We advocate the incorporation a blockage correction for axial induction to model these effects that can be incorporated in state-of-the-art blade element momentum codes for wind turbines. The predictions agree very well with experimental results for low tip-speed ratios. This has resulted in a grant from the Environmental Services Association Education Trust for support a PhD student to undertake research on the experimental and computational design and analysis of self-starting vertical axis wind turbines.

Title: High performance composites with active stiffness control.
AdditionalInformation: The ability to control the flexural stiffness of a fibre reinforced composite material could revolutionise the use of composites in structural applications. Active control of the stiffness will have applications in morphing structures, collapsible and deployable structures and to introduce load redistribution on demand in statically indeterminate structures. This is the first paper in which the concept of a controllable stiffness composite has been achieved by the use of temperature sensitive coating on the reinforcing fibre. The initial research described in this paper lead to a successful CASE award proposal to the EPSRC industrial pool and a patent application (PCT/GB2013/050826).
