Title: A detailed finite element investigation of composite bolted joints with countersunk fasteners
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A - Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: Joining of composite components with countersunk bolts is used extensively in aerospace structures yet the behaviour of these joints cannot be fully predicted and so optimisation of joint designs is restricted. A very detailed FE model was presented of a single lap shear composite joint which included bolt preload and a complete contact definition. Parametric studies clearly demonstrated the effects of coefficient of friction, clamping force and clearance, and good agreement was achieved with experiments. The work led to a patent application for an improved bolt design (GB1301772.8) and participation in the Airbus-led EU Level 2 project SARISTU.

Title: Translaminar fracture toughness: The critical notch tip radius of 0 degrees plies in CFRP
AdditionalInformation: Translaminar toughness of composite laminates is an important input property in the prediction of failure development in composite components. This paper was the first to demonstrate the sensitivity of the measured Mode I toughness to the initial crack tip radius. This was part of a body of work that lead to a successful grant application to EPSRC to explore the translaminar toughness of composites in other fracture modes (Grant ref: EP/I030034/1)

Title: Effect of variation in fibre volume fraction on modes I and II delamination behaviour of 5HS woven composites manufactured by RTM
AdditionalInformation: Resin infusion is a flexible, cost-effective manufacturing route for composite components but can exhibit significant variability in fibre volume fraction (Vf). This paper was the first to show that Vf in a resin infused woven composite has a marked influence on Mode I toughness.  The paper also explored the roles of transverse yarns in Mode I toughness, and friction and mechanical interlocking in Mode II toughness. Understanding the interplay between toughening mechanisms and the ability to model the resulting behaviour were key features in the successful EPSRC Programme Grant bid HiPerDuCT (EP/I02946X/1) which is developing composites with significantly improved ductility.

Title: Computational and experimental study of supersonic flow over axisymmetric cavities
AdditionalInformation: Despite extensive study of supersonic cavity flows, most published experiments consider only planar geometries. These are inevitably contaminated by side wall effects, as are any flows involving flow separation. We eliminate such problems by using the obvious, but rarely employed, approach of testing bodies of revolution. This approach has led to past grants (e.g.  EP/H020853/1) and also underpins the combined CFD/experimental work of the present paper. A particular finding is that whereas most papers identify, without explanation, that cavity unsteadiness often corresponds to a high order mode of the standard Rossiter model, the actual excitation mechanism is a Kelvin-Helmhotz instability.

Title: DETERMINATION OF PROMINENCE PLASMA beta FROM THE DYNAMICS OF RISING PLUMES
AdditionalInformation: Solar magnetic storms are an important component of space weather and are a serious threat to communications and electronics on Earth. An accurate prediction is important and requires knowledge of the magnetic field strength of the associated solar prominence. Direct measurement of this is almost impossible and must be inferred by other means. This paper derives a solution from compressible Magnetohydrodynamic flow for the ratio of gas pressure to magnetic pressure (Beta) at the head of prominence plumes created by the magnetic Rayleigh-Taylor instability. From experimental determination of prominence compression, the magnetic field strength can then be estimated.

Title: Experimental investigation of axisymmetric hypersonic shock-wave/turbulent-boundary-layer interactions
Wake dynamics past a curved body of circular cross-section under forced cross-flow vibration
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports comparisons of the predictions of sectional methods applied to the study of vortex-induced-vibration of flexible riser pipes with very accurate but computationally expensive fully three-dimensional studies. The limits of sectional analysis, which is the more practical approach used by the industry to assess riser performance, are demonstrated for the important cases where the riser is significantly curved. The work was conducted in a collaborative program involving the offshore industry, specifically BP Offshore, Halliburton, Lloyds Register.

Title: Flow-induced forces arising during the impact of two circular cylinders
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides formal inviscid analysis of two-dimensional impact of circular cylinders moving independently due to (water) flow induced vibration (FIV). Impact loads are predicted forming a basis for the study of flexible riser pipe clashing which is a significant FIV problem for the offshore oil and gas industry. The paper corrects  earlier results in the literature and through numerical simulation demonstrates the relationship to impact loads in a real fluid. The flexible riser FIV research is continuing collaboratively with Brunel University (project under application to EPSRC with industry support, Shell, BP).

Title: Wall shear stress and near-wall convective transport: Comparisons with vascular remodelling in a peripheral graft anastomosis
AdditionalInformation: The paper details new computational techniques to characterize changes in artery geometry (remodelling) and haemodynamics following bypass graft surgery. This work involved  collaboration with Japan's leading expert in computational haemodynamics (Yamaguchi), with whom PhD student Gambaruto spent a few months on exchange, building on previous successes of Doorly in computational and experimental haemodynamic studies on arterial geometry and flow. Results presented in part at plenary lecture to 9th International Symposium on Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering, Valencia 2010.

Title: Computational modeling of flow and gas exchange in models of the human maxillary sinus.
AdditionalInformation:
The paper revealed the dramatic effect on maxillary sinus ventilation of an
accessory ostium (i.e. an additional opening), overturning the prevailing
view of sinunasal exchange and offering a rationale for the current surgical
practice. The results attracted the attention of the surgical community,
with first prize award at British Rhinological Society (Edinburgh 2011) to
Dr. Rennie's group who validated the results in their Krypton imaging
studies. It sparked investigation of new sinunasal imaging techniques and
effects of decongestants, as reported at invited and plenary lectures (1st
International CFD Medicine & Biology, Israel 2012, 1st PSM & Translational
Research, Swansea 2013).

Title: Inflow boundary profile prescription for numerical simulation of nasal airflow.
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: This paper revealed the influence of the external geometry on the patterns of inspiratory flow and inhaled particle transport. The research initiated a collaboration with the Health Protection Agency at Harwell (Dr. Jenny Smith) to explore predictive models of aerosol transport and deposition. It also has spawned a collaboration with the Barcelona Supercomputer Group to create whole large airway flow simulations, with this project being awarded one of the largest allocations (20 million CPU hours) on the 2PFlop FERMI machine in August 2012.

Title: Nasal architecture: form and flow
VolumeTitle: Royal Society of London. Philosophical Transactions A. Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: The paper presented the first ever continuous PIV measurements and direct numerical simulations of nasal inspiratory airflow. The research altered the community’s understanding  of the mechanics of flow-mediated transport and exchange, leading to invitations to participate in Japanese Global Centres of Excellence Programme, (Prof. Wada, Osaka) and chairmanship of World Congress of Biomechanics Respiratory Track (2010). It has led to collaboration with Tel Aviv, via British Council BIRAX award (2010), and a Marie Curie Fellowship (for former PhD student Gambaruto). In the UK, NHS-funded surgical MD researchers were attracted to join the group, (Drs. Rennie and Cetto).

Title: The role of wake stiffness on the wake-induced vibration of the downstream cylinder of a tandem pair
AdditionalInformation: The paper explains how the downstream circular cylinder of a pair of cylinders in tandem responds to vortex-induced forces. Previous researchers had thought that the response was due to a kind of galloping mechanism but this publication shows for the first time that it is a type of vortex-induced vibration. It is shown that wake stiffness exists and explains how this influences the oscillation frequency, including in the absence of any structural stiffness. The understanding gained from this study led to further research, funded by BP to a value of £103k, on the suppression of this type of vortex-induced vibration.

Title: On the wake-induced vibration of tandem circular cylinders: the vortex interaction excitation mechanism
AdditionalInformation: First paper to explain the mechanism for wake-induced vibration (WIV) of the downstream cylinder of a pair in tandem, and how a time-mean transverse force is generated on the downstream cylinder. These were long standing problems related to predicting wind-induced response of overhead cables. The research also has application to predicting the response of riser arrays used by the offshore industry and led to collaboration with BP, a research contract on suppressing WIV funded by BP and a paper with BP engineer Neil.Kitney@uk.bp.com. It formed the basis for opening keynote lecture at IUTAM symposium BBVIV6 (ISSN:0889-9746).

Title: Computer Model of Nucleotide Transport in a Realistic Porcine Aortic Trifurcation
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated that unsteady blood flow influences blood borne nucleotides differently to steady state, which was against the established assumption. The work has been instrumental in building an international collaboration with researchers at the Tohoku University, which subsequently resulted in a further publication in the same journal. More recently, the research provided an integral component in obtaining a Marie Curie Career Integration Fellowship (EU-FP7). In particular, it demonstrated the ability to carry out research into arterial mass transport.

Title: Synovial fluid lubrication of artificial joints: protein film formation and composition
Lubricating film thickness measurements with bovine serum
AdditionalInformation: The paper was the first to report film thickness measurements and the role of synovial fluid proteins in the lubrication of artificial hips. The research paper contributed to new EPSRC funding (£380K EP/H020837/1“In contact analysis of synovial fluid lubricating film properties”).  The work was presented in an Invited lecture at the Leeds-Lyon Symposium 2010.  In 2011 Taiho Tribology Research Fund grant (£10K) was awarded for further research into synovial fluid lubrication mechanisms. The research reported in the paper also initiated the first International Conference on Biotribology organised by Dr Cann in London 2011.

Title: Lubrication of metal-on-metal hip joints: the effect of protein content and load on film formation and wear.

On the blast resistance of laminated glass

Dynamic response of full-scale sandwich composite structures subject to air-blast loading

Title: Experimental and numerical investigation of rotating bladed disk forced response using underplatform friction dampers
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power - Transactions of the ASME

Title: Management of the variability of vibration response levels in mistuned bladed discs using robust design concepts. Part 1 Parameter design
AdditionalInformation: Revisits an unsolved problem of 50 years standing in which small variations between nominally identical turbine blades adversely affect the reliability of most gas and steam turbines. Paper describes a new method to manage the blade mistuning problem (i.e. keep under control) rather than trying to solve it.  This is achieved by developing a much more realistic approach to the extreme case statistics problem. The basis of a Keynote Lecture at the 12th International Symposium of Unsteady Aerodynamics, Aeroacoustics and Aeroelasticity of Turbomachines (ISUAAAT 12 London, 2010) and the Opening Presentation at ASME TurboExpo Session on Blade Mistuning (Canada, 2011).

Title: Applications of continuous tracking SLDV measurement methods to axially symmetric rotating structures using different excitation methods
Numerical evaluation of equivalence ratio measurement using OH* and CH* chemiluminescence in premixed and non-premixed methane-air flames

Title: Uniaxial tensile properties underlying plane-stress rapid fracture resistance in polyethylene
A maximum stress at a distance criterion for the prediction of crack propagation in adhesively-bonded joints
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new approach to failure prediction and challenges the validity of using cohesive-zone models when embedded into a finite-element analysis (FEA) program. The research resulted from Kinloch being invited to be a PhD co-supervisor at the University of Louvain, Belgium. It has led to a new collaborative research programme between the Imperial College London, University of Louvain, University College Dublin and Trinity College Dublin, with an EPSRC funded studentship at Imperial. The paper has led to Invited Plenary Papers at the ‘US Adhesion Society Meeting 2014’ and at ‘The European Adhesion Conference 2014’ in Spain.

Title: The fracture behaviour of adhesively-bonded composite joints: Effects of rate of test and mode of loading
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures

Title: Modelling the fracture behaviour of adhesively-bonded joints as a function of test rate

Large Eddy Simulation of an industrial gas-turbine combustion chamber using the sub-grid PDF method
Large eddy simulation of spray atomization with stochastic modeling of breakup
Large-eddy simulation of particle-laden turbulent flows
AdditionalInformation: Research described in paper represents amongst the first successful applications of Large Eddy Simulation to particle laden flows and subsequently formed basis of method for simulating liquid spray fuelled turbulent combustion.  Subsequently used to complete the first successful LES computation of ignition in a kerosene fuelled gas-turbine combustor, Jones, WP; Tyliszczak, A., Flow Turbulence Combust 85:711 (2010).  Led to invitation to join EU project TIMECOP-AE (Contract N° AST5-CT-2006-030828, value to MED £260K), which funded 3 PhD students and a Postdoctoral assistant.  Results also presented in keynote lecture at Workshop on LES and DNS of ignition Processes, Czestochowa, Poland, (2008).

Title: Large Eddy Simulation of the Sandia Flame Series (D-F) using the Eulerian stochastic field method

VolumeTitle: Journal of Tribology - Transactions of the ASME

Title: The Effect of a Friction Modifier Additive on Micropitting
Phenomenological modeling of critical heat flux: The GRAMP code and its validation
AdditionalInformation: Improved ability to predict critical heat flux is vital to understand nuclear reactor performance during accidents, and phenomenological analysis provides this. This work arises from the Imperial-BARC (Babah Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai) collaboration, and has led to Walker leading a £0.8M expansion of the Imperial-BARC collaborative work (EP/K007777/1).

Title: Comparison of measured and modelled droplet-hot wall interactions
AdditionalInformation: Novel transient infrared microscopy has allowed the heat extracted by a sub-mm droplet bouncing from a hot surface in O(1/100 s) (without wetting it; ‘spitting on a hot iron’) to be measured, to validate associated three-dimensional level-set two phase computations. This led to an improved understanding of this contributory mechanism to cooling in the vital “reflood” phase of a PWR loss of coolant accident. It led to MoD support for an EngD in the area, and to Walker leading an EPSRC Imperial-BARC (Babah Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai) collaboration £196K, on droplet and related heat transfer modeling and measurement (EP/I012427/1).

Title: Multi-pin modelling of PWR fuel pin ballooning during post-LOCA reflood
Modelling heat transfer and dissolved species concentrations within PWR crud
Some advantages and challenges of running a Euro IV, V6 diesel engine on a gasoline fuel
Particle capture by turbulent recirculation zones measured using long-time Lagrangian particle tracking
AdditionalInformation: This paper established, for the first time, the mechanism of particle capture by a turbulent recirculation zone. The mechanism for engulfment is overwhelmingly by a single eddy of the size of the flow geometry acting at the end of the mean recirculation zone, resulting in large radial acceleration. These Lagrangian measurements permit evaluation of CFD models in this flow type typical of almost all combustors flame stabilizing zones. This paper has led to an invitation to deliver a plenary paper at CFTL 2012 which brings together more than 120 scientists in the field of laser technique for fluid mechanics.

Title: Spatial resolution of a chemiluminescence sensor for local heat-release rate and equivalence ratio measurements in a model gas turbine combustor
Local curvature measurements of a lean, partially premixed swirl-stabilised flame
Predicting damage and failure under low cycle fatigue in a 9Cr steel

Influence of the inorganic phase concentration and geometry on the viscoelastic properties of latex coatings through the glass-transition

Conforming Hierarchical Basis Functions
A p-MUS preconditioner for the EFIE

Title: The effective thermal conductivity of crud and heat transfer from crud-coated PWR fuel
Adsorption kinetics, capacity and mechanism of arsenate and phosphate on a bifunctional TiO2-Fe2O3 bi-composite.
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: Removal of arsenic from groundwater is an important problem. Paper presents a novel method for the synthesis of mixed oxides and a thorough analysis of the underlying processes which result in precipitation. A broadly similar process arises in the precipitation of corrosion product deposits (CRUD) in nuclear reactors (where the process is undesirable) and these aspects have developed into a shared interdisciplinary interest with Dr Dominik Weiss (Earth Science and Engineering Dept). Development of such mathematical models find application in both areas and this has led to an EPSRC/NNL grant proposal for the study of CRUD precipitation in nuclear reactors.

Title: The application of Fermat's principle for imaging anisotropic and inhomogeneous media with application to austenitic steel weld inspection

Title: Advances in the development of a virtual car driver
Car driving at the limit by adaptive linear optimal preview control
Characterisation of a soft elastomer poly(glycerol sebacate) designed to match the mechanical properties of myocardial tissue.
AdditionalInformation: Patients at risk of heart failure are often treated using scarce donor transplants. An exploratory approach instead “repairs” the weak section of the heart with a mechanically reinforcing patch that delivers regenerative cells. This paper demonstrates that tailored processing of a particular polymer (PGS) provides a promising solution for “repairing” hearts at risk of failure. This paper was part of the body of work that led to Imperial College €0.388M share of €6.31M for project on elastomeric polymers for cardiac tissue engineering (EU FP-7 214539; 15 partners from 8 EU countries).

Title: Finite element modelling of primary hip stem stability: the effect of interference fit.
AdditionalInformation: This paper established the optimum level of pressfit to ensure the fixation and survival of the implant without risking fracture of the bone. This paper was part of body of work that led to £1.20M (Mechanical Engineering) share of £10.9M grant awarded to Imperial College to establish Centre for Medical Engineering Solutions in Osteoarthritis (Wellcome Trust/EPSRC 088844/Z/09/Z)

VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

Title: Toward a Miniaturized Needle Steering System With Path Planning for Obstacle Avoidance
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes my first integrated surgical system for percutaneous intervention along curved paths within soft tissue (www.stingproject.eu). As the culmination of a six-year effort, it describes a functional prototype which fulfils clinical requirements. Follow-on work which beats the state of the art in the field of three-dimensional needle steering has since been published (IEEE ICCAS 2013), alongside a novel 3D controller (IEEE ICRA 2013), plenary talks at URAI 2012 (Daejeon, Korea) and Living Machines 2013 (London, UK). The 2013 Leverhulme Prize for Engineering (£70,000) was awarded to me in recognition of this work.

Title: Four-State Rotary Joint Control: Results With a Novel Programmable Brake
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a solution to the open challenge of faithful reproduction of realistic tactile sensations. The solution is based on a “programmable” brake which can be used to reproduce predefined stiff collisions in space, for example those between a rigid tool and bone, without posing any danger to the user. The research behind this mechanism, which has been patented (WO2011030112, pending), is part of a body of work on haptics and cooperative control, which has culminated in a €5.6M FP7 grant on Active constraint Control in Ill-defined and Volatile Environments (EU FP7-ICT-2009-6-270460-ACTIVE), which started in April 2010.

Title: Closed-Loop Planar Motion Control of a Steerable Probe With a "Programmable Bevel" Inspired by Nature
Measured and estimated friction interface parameters in a nonlinear dynamic analysis
Turbulent mixing in three-dimensional droplet arrays
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow

Title: Flame Stabilization Mechanisms in Lifted Flames
Numerical investigation of swirling kerosene spray flames using Large Eddy Simulation
On shear sheltering and the structure of vortical modes in single- and two-fluid boundary layers
AdditionalInformation: Paper has explained, for the first time, the phenomenon of Shear Sheltering originally proposed by Lord Julian Hunt.  Work was recognized by Lord Hunt himself in his recent paper in Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society (vol 369, pp811-832, 2011), where he noted the importance of our analysis in detailing the interaction of vortical disturbances with shear. Methodology was applied to single- and two-fluid flows. The impact spans engineering flows (receptivity in aerodynamics), environmental flows (wind-ocean interactions) and flow control. Findings led to funding to model wind-ocean interactions (Grantham Institute, £50K) and transition delay (EPSRC contract EP/F034997/1, £255k).

Title: Direct numerical simulations of transition in a compressor cascade: the influence of free-stream turbulence
AdditionalInformation: This publication is the first fully-resolved, direct numerical simulation of flow in a compressor passage. It has, for the first time, shown the effect of turbulence on the separated compressor flow and how this should be used in compressor design.  This work was the subject of a plenary talk at the Engineering Turbulence Modelling and Measurements (ETMM9) conference (2012), and an invitation to be part of the scientific committee for the next meeting.  The research led to new EPSRC contract (EP/H050507/1, £374k) on Advanced Instability Methods (AIM for Industry).

Title: Stability of zero-pressure-gradient boundary layer distorted by unsteady Klebanoff streaks
The continuous spectrum of time-harmonic shear layers
AdditionalInformation: The paper explains, for the first time, how unsteady forcing can delay transition to turbulence and hence be used to reduce drag significantly in engineering flows.  The paper has been the most downloaded paper in Physics of Fluids (March 2011), and the work has been presented at invited talks at Princeton (USA) and at the International Specialist Workshop on Open-Loop versus Closed-Loop Control of Wall Turbulence (Japan).  It has also been the foundation for a prestigious fellowship by the Japanese Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS—JAPAN) to be held by the researcher during 2013.

Lubricant Flow in an Elastohydrodynamic Contact Using Fluorescence
Characterization of EB-PVD yttrium-stabilised zirconia by nanoindentation
AdditionalInformation: This work focused on a long standing problem relevant to industrial gas turbines, namely characterisation of the elastic properties of the columnar thermal barrier layer on turbine blades. This led to further collaborations with the EMPA laboratory in Switzerland, on nanoindentation of EB-PVD zirconia and ceramic multilayer coatings for tool wear applications, and acting as PI of a grant application to the G8 Research Councils Initiative with US and Japanese collaborators (G8MUREFU2-FP-377-015, MEProCoat, 3 partners, Total: 1.16M €, IC: 0.44M €) on the Room-temperature Processing as an Energy-Efficient Method of Fabricating Environmental Barrier Coatings.

Title: Discrete dislocation plasticity analysis of the grain size dependence of the flow strength of polycrystals
AdditionalInformation: This is fundamental research and one of the first discrete dislocation studies of grain size strengthening, showing the effects of slip blocking/transmission and source density on the Hall-Petch effect. This work was presented at invited seminars at Oxford, Cambridge, Harvard, Glasgow and Northwestern Universities. This work resulted in new insights into a long standing problem in materials science on the mechanism of grain size strengthening, and led to a FP7 project (NMP3-SL-2008-213600, M3-2S, 12 partners, Total: 3.45M €, IC: 0.7M €).

Title: Anisotropic TGO rumpling in EB-PVD thermal barrier coatings under in-phase thermomechanical loading
An integrated scheme for crystal plasticity analysis: Virtual grain structure generation
The Influence of Surface Topography on Energy Dissipation and Compliance in Tangentially Loaded Elastic Contacts

Experimental and numerical investigation of localized thinning in hydroforming of micro-tubes
VolumeTitle: European Journal of Mechanics A - Solids
AdditionalInformation: Following the theoretical work  (Journal of Multiscale Modelling 2009, Vol. 1, pp107-124), develops the first Crystal Plasticity FE system for micro-forming process modelling and prediction of grain size effects on localised failure in hydro-forming of micro-tubes. Led to  invited plenary lecture at the 14th International Conference of Metalforming 2012. The theory and the software system were developed within EC project, FP6 MASMICRO, (38 partners, Total: €21.5m; Imperial: €0.4m) and led to other two funded FP7 projects, NMP3-SL-2008-213600 M3-2S (Total: €3.47m; Imperial: €0.7m ) and CP-TP 229266-2 POLYTUBES (Total €3.8m; Imperial: €0.33m).

Identification of a friction model for the bearing channel of hot aluminium extrusion dies by using ball-on-disc tests
Through-Thickness Velocity Profile Measurements in an Elastohydrodynamic Contact
Using light to study boundary lubrication: spectroscopic study of confined fluids
VolumeTitle: Royal Society of London. Philosophical Transactions A. Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This work shows the effectiveness of fluorescence techniques in understanding the structure and dynamics of confined fluids. It has led to two invited talks, one for the Institute of Physics Workshop, University of Leeds (Nov 2011) and the other for Department of Physics and Materials Science, City University of Hong Kong (Sept 2009). It has attracted £10k from SKF (world’s largest bearing manufacturer) and further funding from EPSRC (EP/J015385/1; £408k) which focuses on the effects of friction modifiers. Croda (a major additives company) is interested in this work and has donated relevant chemicals for a project on corrosion detection/inhibition.

Title: Fluorescence Recovery after Photobleaching Measurements of Polymers in a Surface Forces Apparatus
VolumeTitle: Journal of Polymer Science Part B - Polymer Physics
AdditionalInformation: Paper presents, for the first time, a direct measurement of the translational dynamics in a 1.8 nm thick polymer by in-situ fluorescence spectroscopy. It shows dynamics heterogeneities in thin polymer films where surface layers behave differently from the rest of the materials. This can impact on using polymers for coatings and nano-pattern formation. Results obtained on pressure dependent dynamics are relevant to tribology as the pressure experienced by the lubricant is position-dependent in a tribological contact. Hence a concept derived from this work was implemented to tribological systems and has also led to a subsequent paper submitted to REF.

Title: Polymer Surface Diffusion in the Dilute Limit
AdditionalInformation: This work was the first to show the theoretical Rouse-like diffusion regime for polymer at a solid-liquid interface. It also shows, for the first time, that 3 polymer surface diffusion regimes, instead of 2, exist, with a new kinetic regime discovered for polymer of high molecular weight.  The scaling laws obtained can predict how molecular weight affects polymer surface dynamic, hence is important for polymer adhesion and coatings.  It was presented as an invited talk at the Department of Physics, University of Surrey (Jan 2012) and has led to EPSRC grant EP/J008141/1 (£96K) which focuses on the dynamics of nanoadditives.

Title: High-resolution imaging without iteration: a fast and robust method for breast ultrasound tomography.
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

Title: Direct evaluation of the subgrid scale scalar flux in turbulent premixed flames with conditioned dual-plane stereo PIV
Acetone laser-induced fluorescence behavior for the simultaneous quantification of temperature and residual gas distribution in fired spark-ignition engines
Simultaneous temperature, mixture fraction and velocity imaging in turbulent flows using thermographic phosphor tracer particles.
Validation experiments for spatially resolved one-dimensional emission spectroscopy temperature measurements by dual-pump CARS in a sooting flame
AdditionalInformation: We demonstrate and validate an approach for the tomographic reconstruction of emission spectra for thermometry in particle laden flows. This approach  greatly reduces measurement time which is important for applications where fast measurements are essential.  The work led to invited talks in the framework of the VDI seminar series in Siegen, Germany (2011) and at the 2012 meeting of the British section of the Combustion Institute. The technique was later used e.g. by Will et al (Microgravity Sci. Technol. (2010) pp499) during a parabolic flight campaign and for drop tower experiments for the investigation of soot formation under zero-G conditions.

Title: Mechanical analysis and toughening mechanisms of a multiphase recycled CFRP
Characterising the information requests of aerospace engineering designers
Understanding how the information requests of aerospace engineering designers influence information-seeking behaviour
Towards automatic causality boundary identification from root cause analysis reports
How to evaluate reading and interpretation of differently structured engineering design rationales
VolumeTitle: Artificial Intelligence for Engineering Design Analysis and Manufacturing

Title: Producing Hydrogen and Power Using Chemical Looping Combustion and Water-Gas Shift
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power - Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: Development of fundamental cycle for high efficiency power generation with inherent carbon capture. Separation of oxidation and reduction reactions using a fluid phase oxidation carrier yielded a cycle efficiency of 75% with inherent carbon capture at engineering compatible pressures and temperatures. Won the Americal Society of Mechanical Engineers Turbo Expo Cycle Innovations Committee Best Paper award, 2009. Led to keynote lectures at the European Turbomachinery Network International Gas Turbine Conference, 2010, and the International Symposium on Jet Propulsion and Power Engineering, China, 2010, where applications examples also presented.

Title: An Advanced Multiconfiguration Stator Well Cooling Test Facility
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery - Transactions of the ASME

Title: Experimental Investigation of Turbine Stator Well Rim Seal, Re-Ingestion and Interstage Seal Flows Using Gas Concentration Techniques and Displacement Measurements
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power - Transactions of the ASME

Title: Windage sources in smooth-walled rotating disc systems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part C - Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

Title: A heterogeneous framework for real-time decoding of bioacoustic signals: Applications to assistive interfaces and prosthesis control
A dynamic channel selection strategy for dense-array ERP classification.
A biologically inspired micro-vehicle capable of aerial and terrestrial locomotion
A Feature Ranking Strategy to Facilitate Multivariate Signal Classification
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Systems Man and Cybernetics Part C-Applications and Reviews

Title: Large Eddy Simulation of a Turbulent Lifted Flame using Conditional Moment Closure and Rate-Controlled Constrained Equilibrium
A LOI-RCCE methodology for reducing chemical kinetics, with application to laminar premixed flames
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, a novel approach to the integration of complex chemistry in turbulent flame simulations, an outstanding problem in turbulent combustion modelling, is proposed. This approach, incorporating the RCCE and LOI methods, results in a complete methodology for deriving reduced mechanisms. Work on this approach has led to EPSRC funding (EP/G057311/2, £140,300). It is the latest outcome of the author’s series of papers on the RCCE method, for which he has been awarded the Hinshelwood Prize of the Combustion Institute, British Section.

Title: Modeling of aerosol formation in a turbulent jet with the transported population balance equation-probability density function approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel approach to the study of polydispersed aerosol formation in a gaseous flow, which allows us to study the effect of turbulence on the particle size distribution (PSD) of the aerosol. This paper belongs to a line of research supported by the author's Royal Society University Research Fellowship (£354,000, extension awarded in 2010) and has led to the publication of an invited review paper in the prestigious journal Progress in Energy and Combustion Science.

Title: Modeling of Turbulent Precipitation: A Transported Population Balance-PDF Method
Performance of the resurfaced hip. Part 2: the influence of prosthesis stem design on remodelling and fracture of the femoral neck
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part H - Journal of Engineering in Medicine

Title: Pre-clinical evaluation of ceramic femoral head resurfacing prostheses using computational models and mechanical testing
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part H - Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This work presents key development and evauation of the world’s only ceramic on ceramic (CoC) hip resurfacing which received regulatory approval for clinical use in 2010. Patent describing the implant design was granted in 2013 (EP2442754).  Work contributed to £1,006,102 Wellcome Trust translational grant (098269/Z/12/Z) to design similar kind of implant for the shoulder. Also led to a keynote invitation lecture on ceramic implant design at the 25th International Society for Technology in Arthroplasty, Sydney 2012. Based on this work I was also elected one of the youngest ever fellows of the IMechE aged 30 years.

Title: An experimental study on the relation between surface texture and tactile friction
A contact model for orthotropic-viscoelastic materials
Relating Friction on the Human Skin to the Hydration and Temperature of the Skin
Investigating the influence of sand particle properties on abrasive wear behaviour
Travelling fires for structural design-Part II: Design methodology
Carbon emissions from smouldering peat in shallow and strong fronts
Baseline intrinsic flammability of Earth's ecosystems estimated from paleoatmospheric oxygen over the past 350 million years
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
AdditionalInformation: Multidisciplinary research across thermodynamics and geoscience. We combined combustion experiments with cellular automata modelling and paleoatmospheric data to study Earth’s past fire phenomena. It is a leading example of mechanical engineers (led by Rein) contributing to understand palaeoecology and biogeochemistry topics. In recognition of this work, Rein was awarded a Fellowship by RAEng-Leverhulme Trust (#ERI014659, £52k), and won co-funding from PRTLI Ireland (#ENS23, £115k) with UCD. Rein has been invited to write the review chapter for a Wiley book, to a solicited presentation at European Geoscience Union (Vienna 2011) and to seminars at 14 international institutions (incl. Berkeley, Oxford, Texas).

Title: Forecasting fire dynamics using inverse computational fluid dynamics and tangent linearisation
Sub-threshold sampling in a correlation-based ultrasonic spectrometer
A comparison of stochastic and effective medium approaches to the backscattered signal from a porous layer in a solid matrix.
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America

Title: Bulk shear wave propagation in an epoxy: attenuation and phase velocity over five decades of frequency.
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Ultrasonics Ferroelectrics and Frequency Control

Title: Models of ultrasonic wave propagation in epoxy materials.
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Ultrasonics Ferroelectrics and Frequency Control

Title: The tungsten isotopic composition of the Earth's mantle before the terminal bombardment.
AdditionalInformation: This study contains the first geochemical evidence for a cataclysmic meteorite bombardment that struck planet Earth more than 3.9 billion years ago and replenished all of the precious metals accessible today. The publication attracted considerable news coverage (e.g. BBC Radio; France 5; BBC News, CNN International, National Geographic, Daily Mail, Fox News; The Times, Le Parisien, Daily Mirror, Sun). Willbold received invitations to talk at major scientific conferences, universities and societies (American Geophysical Union, University of Cambridge, Geologists’ Association London, Bath Geological Society). The work led to follow up funding from NERC (~£857,000; grants NE/J018031/1; NE/J009024/1).

Title: Melting during late-stage rifting in Afar is hot and deep
AdditionalInformation: This work emerged from the £2.5M NERC Afar consortium project (NE/E007414/1) in the Horn of Africa and it was the first study to simultaneously constrain plate thickness and mantle temperature during the final stages of continental breakup. It this has important implications for the understanding of hydrocarbon-rich rifted margins worldwide.

Title: Upper mantle seismic structure beneath the Ethiopian hot spot: Rifting at the edge of the African low-velocity anomaly
AdditionalInformation: Upon publication, this was the most detailed seismic tomographic model of the upper mantle beneath Earth's youngest continental flood basalt province: the Ethiopian traps. It was also the most detailed upper mantle image of the final stages of transition from continental rifting to incipient ocean spreading in Ethiopia. Bastow was invited to present details of this work at several Earth Science departments, including Cambridge. This work, and that of others from the NERC-funded Ethiopia-Afar Geoscientific Lithospheric Experiment, contributed to successful bid for new £2.5M NERC funded Afar consortium (NE/E007414/1).

Title: The stable vanadium isotope composition of the mantle and mafic lavas
AdditionalInformation: Paper reports first ever vanadium isotope measurements of igneous rocks. Work defines the bulk silicate Earth vanadium isotope composition and assesses robustness to alteration processes. Publication led to invitations for Prytulak to speak AGU (2011) and at seven departmental seminars in four countries (Canada, UK, Australia, Germany) during 2010-2012. Prytulak presented data as Keynote speaker at the Australian SGGMP meeting (2013). Preliminary work led to NERC Fellowship (NE/H010319/1: 2010-2013; £288,000) for Prytulak and when published led to an ARC Discovery Grant (2013-2016; ~$330,000 AUD) including an international collaboration award for a 3 month visit to Australia National University.

Title: Determination of Precise and Accurate V-51/V-50 Isotope Ratios by Multi-Collector ICP-MS, Part 2: Isotopic Composition of Six Reference Materials plus the Allende Chondrite and Verification Tests
AdditionalInformation: The first and only method for precise and accurate vanadium isotope data on geologic materials including rigorous data control protocols. Vanadium tracks oxidation-reduction and is of interest to oil companies (the work was funded by a Petrobras grant to Halliday). Inorganic applications range from ocean anoxia to core formation. Provides the first documentation of a large isotopic difference between terrestrial and extraterrestrial materials. The groundbreaking work led to NERC fellowship (NE/H010319/1: 2010-2013; ~£288,000 GBP) for Prytulak which applies V isotopes to the oxidation state of subduction zones.

Title: Supercritical CO(2) core flooding and imbibition in Tako sandstone-Influence of sub-core scale heterogeneity
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents one of the first X-ray/CT-scanner core flood numerical modelling results demonstrating that the correlation between CO2 saturation and resulting porosity profiles can be accounted for by a Leverett J-function type scaling factor, reflecting the effect of porosity/permeability heterogeneity on capillary pressure. These findings are essential for the interpretation of CO2 storage field monitoring data. Long-standing collaboration with RITE (Research Institute of Innovative Technology for the Earth) [http://www.rite.or.jp/en/] and the publication led to further €0.81M funding in the current €5.2M European project [http://www.co2care.org/Default.aspx?section=376] which utilises the post-closure monitoring data from the Nagaoka CO2 storage pilot.

Title: Relative permeability and trapping of CO2 and water in sandstone rocks at reservoir conditions
Clay assemblage and oxygen isotopic constraints on the weathering response to the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum, east coast of North America
North American continental margin records of the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum: Implications for global carbon and hydrological cycling
Eustatic variations during the Paleocene-Eocene greenhouse world
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents novel organic biomarkers and demonstrates the existence of a sea-level rise at the Paleocene-Eocene boundary 55 million years ago. The demonstration that global warming during the Paleocene-Eocene resulted in sea-level rise is a critical one to help mitigate the effects of future global warming. This work was presented by John in an invited keynote lecture at the British Sedimentological Research Group’s  annual meeting (http://www.bsrg.org.uk/meetings_agms_reviews/agm_review_2011.html) and a series of invited departmental seminars (e.g. Royal Holloway University, 12/09, UTEP El Paso, 04/11). This work led to Sluijs becoming assistant professor at University of Utrecht.

Title: Timing and magnitude of Miocene eustasy derived from the mixed siliciclastic-carbonate stratigraphic record of the northeastern Australian margin
Dynamic behaviour of the East Antarctic ice sheet during Pliocene warmth
AdditionalInformation: Knowledge about potential collapse of the large polar ice sheets under warmer than modern global temperatures is a topic of major societal concern. This paper presents a novel approach to the problem, and established a long-lasting collaboration with the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University (USA). The work led to follow up funding from the Royal Society, NSF, NERC, Grantham Institute for Climate Change, and the European Commission (~£420k), an invitation for van de Flierdt  to participate in Integrated Ocean Drilling Expedition 318 (2010), and to present an evening talk in the Shell University lecture series (2009).

Title: Persistent near-tropical warmth on the Antarctic continent during the early Eocene epoch.
AdditionalInformation: This paper marks the first significant output from IODP Expedition 318, and answers the long-standing debate on polar temperatures under warm global climates ~50 million years ago (‘Greenhouse world’). It yielded NERC funding (£50,942; NE/I006257/1), a keynote invitation for van de Flierdt to the 2012 Goldschmidt conference, and new international collaborations (Frankfurt, MARUM – Germany; Utrecht and NIOZ, Netherlands; Granada – Spain; Scripps, USGS, Montclair – USA; NOCS - UK). Youtube videos from the expedition were watched >10,000 times within two months of release (http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8AC7E48053CB639C) and a blog by van de Flierdt was accessed >250,000 times since 2010 (https://wwwf.imperial.ac.uk/blog/wilkeslandiodpexpedition/).

Title: GEOTRACES intercalibration of neodymium isotopes and rare earth element concentrations in seawater and suspended particles. Part 1: reproducibility of results for the international intercomparison
AdditionalInformation: This paper summarises four years of effort in realising the first international calibration for neodymium isotopes and concentrations in seawater. It represents the enabling stage of the international GEOTRACES program, for which van de Flierdt served as a US and UK steering group member (www.ukgeotraces.com). Work was vital in attracting a NERC consortium grant (Imperial part: £259,027; NE/H005390/1) and a NERC standard grant (£365,606; NE/J021636/1). It resulted in invitations for van de Flierdt to participate in two international cruises and for plenary presentations at ‘Frontiers of Marine Science UK-Australia meeting’ (2010), and International Union for Quaternary Research workshop (2013).

Title: Deep-sea coral aragonite as a recorder for the neodymium isotopic composition of seawater
AdditionalInformation:
Deep-sea corals are probably the single most promising archive to unravel mechanisms of past abrupt climate change. Neodymium isotopes in seawater are the single most promising tracer for past water mass movement. 
van de Flierdt was first to combine the coral archive and neodymium isotope tracer records, which resulted in three invitations on coral collection cruises, and financial support from the NSF, NERC, Leverhulme Trust, Grantham Institute for Climate Change, and the European Commission (~£630k). It established an international collaboration with Caltech and resulted in the prestigious invitation to deliver a plenary talk at the International Conference on Paleoceanography (2013).

Title: Transformation of tectonic and climatic signals from source to sedimentary archive
AdditionalInformation: This study provided major insights into when and how tectonic and climate signals are chronicled in the geological record. Based on this work, the Geological Societies of London and America sponsored Whittaker to convene the flagship “Teleconnections in Sedimentary Systems” sessions at EGU in 2011 and 2013. The paper led to invited keynotes at the “Frontiers in Science” meeting, Burlington House (2011), the "Strata and Time" William Smith meeting (2012), and an invited editorship of a special issue on  “Tectonics, Sedimentation and Surface Processes” in the key geomorphology journal "Earth Surface Processes and Landforms".

Title: Decoding temporal and spatial patterns of fault uplift using transient river long profiles
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides a new way of estimating fault slip rates from the landscape, which directly relates to seismic hazard. The approach has been used to quantify earthquake hazard in developing countries such as Turkey, and has led to new hazard mapping for the city of Antioch (population of 1.5 million). (adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2009Geomo.107.299B). The study is part of a series of papers that led to Whittaker receiving the Chorley Medal from the British Society for Geomorphology in 2008, and the prestigious President’s Award from the Geological Society in 2009 in recognition of 'an outstanding research contribution by a young academic'.

Title: New constraints on sediment-flux-dependent river incision: Implications for extracting tectonic signals from river profiles
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates how landscapes record tectonic forces over million-year timescales. The work directly led to a £200K PTDF (Nigerian oil company) grant to apply these ideas to sub-marine channels (PTDF/E/OSS/PHD/BAJ/263/10). Whittaker was invited to present plenary keynotes at GSA in Denver 2008 and AGU San Francisco 2009 and to convene the flagship ‘Tectonics, Climate and Landscape’ session at EGU Vienna 2009. Following publication Whittaker was asked to serve on the steering committee of the tectonics group of the European Geosciences Union.

Title: Volcanism in the Afar Rift sustained by decompression melting with minimal plume influence
Shock synthesis of amino acids from impacting cometary and icy planet surface analogues
AdditionalInformation: First experiments that prove amino acids are generated by impacts of comet ice mixtures. Results have implications for producing life's raw materials on icy moons and planets in the solar system. Led to Martins invitation to be a Co-Investigator of the Close Up Camera for the MarcoPolo-R asteroid sample return mission (PI Prof Josset, jeanluc.  josset@space-x.ch) and to Co-chair session at Goldschmidt 2014 conference (8-13 June, USA, coordinator Dr Bouvier, abouvier@umn.edu). Research had worldwide media coverage (Time magazine, SkyNews, NBC News, Brazilian TV) and will be broadcast November 2013 on the BBC1 show Horizon (BBC Producer Josh Green, josh.green1@bbc.co.uk).

Title: Extraterrestrial nucleobases in the Murchison meteorite
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows that nucleobases detected in meteorites are extra-terrestrial, ending a more than 40 years debate.  As result Martins was awarded a 5 years Royal Society University Research Fellowship (UF080820, £0.53M). This paper had wide international media attention (e.g. BBC One, Channel 4 News, Russian TV, Euronews). It has been the 24th most downloaded article in the field of Planetary Science and the most downloaded article of the EPSL journal for several months (according to Science Direct), the most viewed story of 2008  on the Imperial College website, and was on the Discover magazine Top 100 Stories of 2008.

Title: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and amino acids in meteorites and ice samples from LaPaz Icefield, Antarctica
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to analyse the organic content of meteorites from the LaPaz region of Antarctica and ice samples collected directly underneath those meteorites. Martins presented the results in an invited talk at the international COSPAR Conference. Martins was invited to be a Committee Member of the Astrobiology Society of Britain (ASB), and a Co-Investigator (Co-I) on two ESA-ELIPS space missions (OREOCUBE and MUE), which will be on-board the International Space Station (PI of OREOCUBE Prof. Pascale Ehrenfreund p.ehrenfreund@chem.leidenuniv.nl; PI of MUE Dr Louis d'Hendecourt ldh@ias.u-psud.fr).

Title: Meteorite ablation products and their contribution to the atmospheres of terrestrial planets: An experimental study using pyrolysis-FTIR
AdditionalInformation: New quantitative technique for generation and recognition of carbon dioxide and water from small samples. Application to meteorites revealed that bombardments could have helped to make the early Earth’s atmosphere more habitable for life. Meteorite work led to UK Space Agency Aurora Fellowship (2013). The work attracted substantial media interest and was covered by the Canadian National Radio (CBC), BBC, Telegraph and Wall Street Journal (e.g. http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8079796.stm). The research was made one of Discovery Magazine’s top 100 stories of 2009 (http://discovermagazine.com/2010/jan-feb/077#.UT2tFRw66So).

Title: Giant magnetofossils and hyperthermal events
AdditionalInformation: Paper demonstrates that giant magnetofossils were globally distributed, and are temporally not constrained to just the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), as was previously thought. Work also discovered a new type of giant bullet-shaped magnetofossil in sediments from the equatorial Indian Ocean during the Mid-Eocene Climatic Optimum. Finite-element numerical modelling indicates that these magnetofossils were unlikely to be used exclusively for navigation, indicating multiple functionality.

Title: Critical superparamagnetic/single-domain grain sizes in interacting magnetite particles: implications for magnetosome crystals.
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: Using extensive finite-element numerical modelling this paper reported the optimal magnetite crystal (magnetosome) size range for efficient navigation of magnetotactic bacteria. This key paper reconciled community-wide disagreements as to the functionality of unusual magnetosomes, giving rigorous physical foundations to the biological systems. This paper was picked up by press organisations around the world, e.g., The Times of India, and led to Muxworthy writing an article for The Times’s Eureka! magazine (11/2011). Following this Muxworthy was invited to be the British Geophysical Association (BGA) Bullerwell Lecturer 2011, which involved keynote presentations at the European Geoscience Union and the BGA graduate-school conferences.

Title: A Preisach method for estimating absolute paleofield intensity under the constraint of using only isothermal measurements: 2. Experimental testing
AdditionalInformation: This paper details the Preisach palaeointensity protocol and successfully tested the new method against a suite of synthetic samples and historical rocks (< 120 years old). The empirical testing is the largest ever palaeointensity study undertaken on historical samples (> 300 samples from Mexico, Italy, Iceland, Chile and the USA).  This work has led to a successful NERC standard grant proposal (NE/J020508/1, £595k of which £286k to Imperial).

Title: A Preisach method for estimating absolute paleofield intensity under the constraint of using only isothermal measurements: 1. Theoretical framework
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new non-heating method of determining absolute ancient magnetic field intensities (palaeointensities) from rocks and minerals: the Preisach palaeointensity protocol. This technique has been applied in a number of independent studies (e.g., Ferk et al., 2012, doi:10.1016/j.pepi.2012.06.004; Lappe et al., 2013, doi:10.1002/ggge.20141) . Muxworthy was asked to present a keynote presentation detailing this work at the Magnetic Exchanges meeting in Oxford 2011. The publication led to a STFC grant to apply this technique (ST/J001260/1, consolidated grant total £1,374k). The technique has been recently added to Dr. Richard Harrison’s FORCinel analysis software (http://www.esc.cam.ac.uk/research/research-groups/forcinel).

Title: Measurements of Interactions between Particles and Charged Microbubbles Using a Combined Micro- and Macroscopic Strategy
Cratonic basins and the long-term subsidence history of continental interiors
AdditionalInformation: Explains cratonic basins with new quantitative model of prolonged, low strain rate stretching, with strong implications for heat flow history. Armitage received ‘best paper by young scientist’ from Geological Society. Led to invitation for Allen to contribute chapter on cratonic basins to ‘Tectonics of Sedimentary Basins: Recent Advances’ (http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1405194650.html) and first chapter of forthcoming Geological Society Special Publication on ‘Precambrian Basins’. Led to Allen joining Australian Research Council Discovery Grant ‘The link between the deep Earth and its dynamic surface’ as international collaborator and Norwegian Science Foundation Centre of Excellence on ‘Integrated Earth System Dynamics’ as external member.

Title: From grain size to tectonics
AdditionalInformation: Full-length documentation of theory for regional grain-size trends resulting from selective deposition from surface sediment fluxes. Develops new theory and tests model with large field datasets collected during campaigns in the Spanish Pyrenees. New method helps discrimination of tectonic and climatic forcing on sedimentary systems. Core piece of work funded (£1.073m) by Statoil, with implications for porosity and permeability of aquifers and hydrocarbon reservoirs. Led to Allen convening of a session on ‘Teleconnections: far-field links in sedimentary source-to-sink systems’ at the European Geosciences Union 2011 meeting (2-8 April 2011) jointly sponsored by Geological Society London and Geological Society of America.

Title: From landscapes into geological history
AdditionalInformation: Peer reviewed contribution for International Year of Planet Earth Supplement following Allen’s William Smith keynote lecture at the Geological Society of London. Opened a new research front on the selective preservation of erosional and depositional landscapes in the rock record. Provided background for 2011 William Smith international meeting on ‘Landscapes into Rock’ (21-23 November 2011) and Royal Society Kavli International research seminar on ‘Earth surface dynamics: building a UK and European Research network’ (18-19 October 2010), both convened by Allen who gave keynotes at each event. Publication led to invitations to give talks at UCL (2011), Southampton (2012) Cambridge (2012).

Title: Sedimentary challenge to Snowball Earth
AdditionalInformation: Analysis of new, powerful sedimentary evidence negating the Snowball Earth hypothesis by demonstrating action of a strong hydrological cycle during glaciations in deep time, based on Allen’s fieldwork in Oman. Results established Oman sections as internationally important (e.g. doi: 10.1144/M36.19; doi:10.1144/M36.20). Led to invitations to give talks at Universities of Melbourne (November 2009) and Adelaide (November 2009), as well as UK universities (Liverpool, UCL, Royal Holloway), and to write 2 chapters for Geological Society of London Memoir 36 on ‘The Geologic Record of Neoproterozoic Glaciations’ (2011). Research funded by grants from Swiss NSF and ETH Zürich Research Committee (CHF 587k).

Title: A Silurian myodocope with preserved soft-parts: cautioning the interpretation of the shell-based ostracod record.
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new soft-bodied fossil Ostracod which throws traditional interpretations of the entire Palaeozoic record of these crustaceans into doubt. Paper uses newly developed 3D techniques, software and data formats that have been adopted by biologists (e.g. doi:10.1038/ncomms2036), as well as other palaeontologists (e.g. doi:10.1098/rspb.2011.0777). As a result of this work Sutton has presented invited lectures at conferences (2012 Lyell Meeting, DigitalFossil 2012 Berlin), organised a workshop at the International Organisation of Palaeobotany Meeting London 2010 and has been awarded a book contract (http://www.amazon.co.uk/Techniques-for-Virtual-Paleontology-POD/dp/1118591135).

Title: Anatomically modern Carboniferous harvestmen demonstrate early cladogenesis and stasis in Opiliones.
AdditionalInformation: Paper applies virtual palaeontology techniques to fossils of harvestmen, a major arachnid group whose origins were hitherto poorly documented. Provides first well-preserved anatomical data from Palaeozoic harvestmen and the first reliable placement of these organisms on an evolutionary tree. The work impacts recent hypotheses of relationships and timings of arachnid origins. In particular, the paper harmonizes fossil and genetic data. Publication had a high public impact (e.g. http://www.nhm.ac.uk/about-us/news/2011/august/ancient-harvestmen-in-3d-reveals-early-evolution102725.html). Work was awarded the Tenth International Award in Palaeontological Research by the Spanish body FCPTD, worth €4,500 (http://www.fundaciondinopolis.org/index.php/component/content/article/62-uncategorised/242-paleonturology-2013.html).

Title: Silurian horseshoe crab illuminates the evolution of arthropod limbs
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
AdditionalInformation: Horseshoe crabs have existed for more than 450 million years and evolution has mainly affected their legs. This paper provides new data from an exceptionally-preserved fossil horseshoe-crab that possessed an unexpected profusion of legs; the nature of these informs a high-profile debate on the origins of arthropod ‘exopods’ (outer appendages), which in turn informs the still higher-profile debate on the interrelationships of major arthropod groups. It is one of many outputs from a Sutton NERC-funded (grant NE/F01693X/1) international team. Publication generated substantial media attention (e.g. see http://phys.org/news/2012-09-fossil-discovery-clues-evolutionary-horseshoe.html; wired.com, scitechdaily.com, etc.).

Title: A Silurian armoured aplacophoran and implications for molluscan phylogeny.
AdditionalInformation: This Nature paper provides palaeontological evidence that unambiguously links, for the first time, two groups of molluscs (the Polyplacophora and Aplacophora) whose evolutionary relationships have long been contentious. It was funded from a multi-institute NERC grant (~£400K, ~40K to Imperial), and is one of a series of high-impact papers on the three-dimensional soft-bodied fossils of the Herefordshire Lagerstätte (e.g. doi: 10.1098/rspb.2009.2122 and doi: 10.1098/rsbl.2010.0540). Publication generated significant media interest (magazine, newspaper and online articles; e.g. http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/10/121003132324.htm). The work led to the Palaeontographical Society inviting Sutton to give its Annual Address in 2012.

Title: Seismic anisotropy estimated from P-wave arrival times in crosshole measurements
Multichannel matching pursuit for seismic trace decomposition
Reflection seismic waveform tomography
AdditionalInformation: This paper extended an important seismic technique that is used for petroleum exploration so that it can now be applied to a much wider range of problems and data sets than hitherto.  The work described was instrumental in launching the FULLWAVE research consortium which is supported by 15 oil and gas companies, with a budget since 2009 of over £3 million.  The methodology has been widely adopted across the petroleum industry, and forms part of the software package developed by Imperial College for full-waveform inversion that has been licensed to 18 companies worldwide (c.sanderson@itfenergy.com).

Title: Crustal structure across Longmenshan fault belt from passive source seismic profiling
AdditionalInformation: This research was motivated by the large magnitude-8 earthquake that occurred on the eastern margin of Tibet in 2008.   The results showed an unusually high crustal Vp/Vs ratio and a negative-polarity PS conversion at the top of the lower crust, and confirmed the existence of a low-viscosity channel beneath eastern Tibet.  The results have significantly modified the model used by the Chinese Academy of Science for the assessment of seismic hazard in central Asia (zhangzj@mail.iggcas.ac.cn).

Title: Synthetic images of dynamically predicted plumes and comparison with a global tomographic model
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an outcome of an international collaboration funded by NSF (EAR-0855487) that covered the existence of plumes and their responsibility for volcanism, continental break-up and climate change. The work furthered research started with a Science paper in 1999 (http://www.sciencemag.org/content/286/5446/1928). Follow-up paper from this project (http://gji.oxfordjournals.org/content/187/1/273) shows that spotty lower-mantle seismic images cannot be used as evidence against deeply sourced mantle plumes. Results presented in at least 5 invited talks and most recently by Goes at UK SEDI 2011.

Title: Small-scale convection during continental rifting: Evidence from the Rio Grande rift
AdditionalInformation: Controls on stability and destruction of continental lithosphere are long debated. We show that seismic features found under the western US have the dynamically predicted characteristics of destabilizing continental roots.  Follow-up paper appeared in Geology 2010 (http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/38/7/611.full). Led to Invited presentations including ICCFD meeting in Beijing (2011). This and related work led to a number of UK and international collaborations and motivated a community effort to improve thermodynamic data bases that are essential for seismic interpretation of mantle structure (ThermoDynaMix II and III workshops in 2008 and 2011 -  www.dias.ie/ThermoDynaMixIII/index.html).

Title: India-Asia convergence driven by the subduction of the Greater Indian continent
AdditionalInformation: This paper uses a novel subduction modeling approach to provide new insights into India-Asia convergence, and in particular the transition from subduction to collision. It was featured in a Nature Geoscience News & Views article (http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v4/n8/full/ngeo1228.html), and was reported in the Indian Deccan Herald newspaper (Jan-2010). This work led to a £105,070 NERC grant (NE/J007854/1) and two Australian Research Council grants (DP110101697, DE130100604). Capitanio was awarded an Outstanding Young Researcher Award by the American Geophysical Union (2012) for this and associated work.

Title: Evidence of lower-mantle slab penetration phases in plate motions
AdditionalInformation: Using subduction models, we show that young and light rather than old and dense plates are more prone to lower-mantle penetration. Findings help explain observed episodes of fast plate motions. Paper was featured by Nature in a News and Views article (http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v451/n7181/full/451899a.html). Work led to three follow-up NERC projects (NE/G004749/1, NE/I024488/1, NE/J007854/1, total £785k). Goes subsequently received 11 invitations to present data (including 2013 Gordon Conference and Royal Society Geological Association) and request to write Nature News & Views article on related subject in 2013 (http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v496/n7443/full/496035a.html). Research was featured on BBC Radio 4 Material World on 6 March 2008 (http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b0092j12/Material_World_Animal_Robots_Plate_Tectonics/).

Title: The Rhynie Chert, Scotland, and the search for life on Mars.
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated the preservation of organics within silica sinters (geyser deposits) over 400 Ma using infrared spectroscopy suggesting such deposits on Mars could contain evidence for past microbial life. The paper led to a keynote lecture at the Mineralogical Society of Poland meeting on meteorites and astrobiology in Poznan in 2012.

Title: A multidisciplinary study of silica sinter deposits with applications to silica identification and detection of fossil life on Mars
AdditionalInformation: Research identified key spectral signatures of silica sinters (geyser deposits) by which these could be recognised on Mars as potential locales for microbial life. The paper was cited by the NASA Mars Exploration Rover team in their discovery of sinters on Mars (e.g. Skok et al., 2010, Nature Geoscience, doi:10.1038/ngeo990) and thus influenced exploration targets for the subsequent $287 million NASA Mars Odyssey mission. The paper was product of a PhD project supervised by Genge and resulted in a CPSX Fellowship at Western University, Canada for the lead author and Genge being appointed to the ESA Mars Aurora grants panel.

Title: The classification of micrometeorites
AdditionalInformation: This work standardized the classification of micrometeorites through consensus of the leading researchers in the field led by Genge based on textural, chemical and isotopic analyses of thousands of particles. The classification system has had international recognition being widely adopted in 90% of all subsequent papers on micrometeorites. As the first paper to formalize a rigorous classification it is a landmark work in this international field. It has led to collaborations on new discoveries of micrometeorites (e.g. Voldman et al, 2012, doi:10.1002/gj.2418), a successful STFC grant (ST/G002924/1, £35k) and a continued position on NASA's cosmic dust committee for Genge.

Title: Koronis asteroid dust within Antarctic ice
AdditionalInformation: Paper reports the first discovery of micrometeorites in Antarctic Ice from a known asteroid family. Work laid a cornerstone for subsequent studies, because it showed, contrary to long standing consensus, that population analysis can allow the source of micrometeorites to be determined. Subsequent papers followed our conceptual analysis to identify sources for other groups of cosmic dust (e.g. Cordier et al., 2010, doi; 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2011.01218.x). Publication led to successful grant application (Genge and Bland, STFC, Project B, ST/J001260/1, £1374K) proposing the use of micrometeorites to investigate the early Solar System.

Title: High precision isotope measurements reveal poor control of copper metabolism in Parkinsonism
AdditionalInformation: First study to demonstrate potential offered by high precision isotope analyses of trace metals in health sciences. Discovery of link between deficiencies in human copper metabolism and Parkinsonism. Disease affects 7 million people globally. Led to new research collaborations with Cancer Research UK Centre (Prof. RC Coombes, Faculty of Medicine, Imperial College London; c.coombes@imperial.ac.uk) where method is being investigated for diagnosis of other Metallomic medical conditions such as breast and liver cancer. Rehkamper presented work as Plenary at 2011 Winter Plasma Conference. Larner won conference prize for student first author at 2011 International Society For Trace Element Research in Humans.

Title: Tracing Bioavailability of ZnO Nanoparticles Using Stable Isotope Labeling
AdditionalInformation: First demonstration of stable isotope labelling with high-precision mass spectrometry for tracing nanoparticles in complex exposure experiments. Highest ever sensitivity enables improved understanding of bioavailability and fate of nanomaterials in environment at realistic concentrations. Prompted use by nanoparticles industry (Dr. Steffi Friedrichs, Director General, Nanotechnology Industries Association; steffi.friedrichs@nanotechia.org) and water industry (Dr. Ailbhe Macken, Norwegian Institute for Water Research, Ecotoxicology and Risk Assessment, NO-0349 OSLO; Ailbhe.Lisette.Macken@niva.no). Led to follow on funding (£93k from NERC-FENAC, EPSRC and DEFRA; FENAC/2012/11/005, FENAC/2011/05/004; ICL EPSRC Kick Start; DEFRA PROSPECT LINK LK0852). Rehkamper Presented as Keynote talk at 2013 Goldschmidt Conference.

Title: Cadmium stable isotope cosmochemistry
AdditionalInformation: Manuscript presents and interprets novel cadmium isotope data. Cadmium in meteorites reveals planet formation processes. First use of ‘non-traditional’ stable isotope system as valuable research tool in cosmochemistry. Method immediately adopted by other leading laboratories (Estrade et al. 2009, GCA, 73, 2693-2711; Armytage et al. 2011, GCA, 75, 3662-3676). Led to £265k funding from STFC Consolidated Grant for further isotopic studies of meteorites (ST/F002157/1). Rehkamper presented work as Plenary at 2009 Paneth Conference on meteoritics. Resulted in three invitations to prepare review articles (including Rehkämper et al. 2012, http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9783527650484.ch10/summary and Rehkämper et al. 2012, http://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-642-10637-8_8).

Title: The thallium isotope composition of carbonaceous chondrites - New evidence for live (205)Pb in the early solar system
AdditionalInformation: This paper is first to conclusively demonstrate that variations in thallium isotopes result from radioactive decay of short-lived 205Pb. These radionuclides reveal the chemistry and timing of early solar system processes. Work part of early solar system research programme that has achieved results of broad significance, including models of element production in stars and Earth accretion. Led to £300k funding as part of consolidated STFC grant ST/J001260/1. Rehkamper presented as Plenary at 2009 ICP-MS conference in Ghent.

Title: Predicting air recovery in flotation cells
An investigation of the stable orientations of orthorhombic particles in a thin film and their effect on its critical failure pressure.
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science

Title: Characterisation, modification and mathematical modelling of sudsing
VolumeTitle: Colloids and Surfaces A - Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects

Title: Hysteresis in unsaturated flow in packed beds and heaps
The entrainment factor in froth flotation: Model for particle size and other operating parameter effects
PEPT combined with high speed digital imaging for particle tracking in dynamic foams
Macroscopic scattering of cracks initiated at single impurity atoms.
AdditionalInformation: Rock fragmentation is an essential part of mining and mineral separation but consumes vast amounts of energy. Quantum-mechanical simulations and high-resolution STM (scanning tunnelling microscopy) show, for the first time, the relationship between rate of fracture propagation, molecular impurities and the roughness of the fracture surface. This understanding is essential for improving the energy efficiency of particle size reduction. This paper is the culmination of five years of fracture research in the Rio Tinto Centre for Advanced Mineral Recovery at Imperial College. Results of this fundamental work on fracture resulted in the £5.5m Centre renewal to the end of 2018.

Title: A model for the stability of films stabilized by randomly packed spherical particles.
da Vinci fluids, catch-up dynamics and dense granular flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel flow model of dense granular matter, using solid friction as the drag mechanism between streamlines. It is the first model combining regular flow with plug flow (flow of finite regions as rigid bodies) and it quantifies plug formation and growth dynamics. The flow equations developed in this paper are essential to model correctly numerical flow codes for granular materials. The paper led to an invited talk at the prestigious Gordon Conference on Granular and Granular Flow , Waterville, ME, USA (http://www.grc.org/programs.aspx?year=2010&program=granular).

Title: On granular stress statistics: compactivity, angoricity, and some open issues.
AdditionalInformation: A first-principles derivation of the diffusion constant of grains in dense granular systems, relating it to the compactivity, allowing  experimental evaluation of  the latter. This solves the long-standing problem of determining the effects of mixing of granular materials. The lead author (RB) gave a plenary talk on this work at a Workshop in Leiden (http://www.lorentzcenter.nl/lc/web/2009/340/program.php3?wsid=340) and an invited talk at the prestigious Gordon Conference (http://www.grc.org/programs.aspx?year=2010&program=flow). It led to a £271,432 grant (EPSRC EP/H051716/1), to two Alan Howard PhD Scholarships of £229,858 (2009-2013) and of £230k (2013-2016) (https://workspace.imperial.ac.uk/energyfutureslab/Public/Alan%20Howard%20Scholarships%20brief_2011.pdf).

Title: Stress chain solutions in two-dimensional isostatic granular systems: Fabric-dependent paths, leakage, and branching
AdditionalInformation: The first derivation from first-principles of the stress field in nonuniform isostatic granular matter. It reveals novel phenomena: force-chain branching, 'leaking' and force attenuation, previously not associated with force chains. It makes it possible to better assess stability of soils. The paper led directly to 4 invited talks at: (i) the IOP Meeting on Condensed Matter and Materials Physics 2008, London; (ii) Granular Gases: Beyond the Dilute Limit, Thurnau, Germany (http://www.granulargas.uni-bayreuth.de); (iii) IUTAM-ISIMM: Mathematical Modeling and Physical Instances of Granular Flows, Italy (http://mat521.unime.it/granular09); (iv) Workshop on Particulate Matter: Does Dimensionality Matter?, Dresden, Germany (http://www.mpipks-dresden.mpg.de/~pardim10/PARDIM10_NEU.pdf).

Title: Interdependence of the Volume and Stress Ensembles and Equipartition in Statistical Mechanics of Granular Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows that the long-held assumption of independence of volume and stress partition functions in statistical mechanics of granular matter is incorrect. It corrects the theory and uses it to derive macroscopic measurable properties and an equipartition relation, previously believed not to exist in granular systems.  This work was presented as an invited talk at: (i) Workshop on Complexity in the Oil Industry, Inst. Physics, Brazil (https://www.imperial.ac.uk/ref/webarchive/ctf). This paper is a culmination of a £271,432 grant (EPSRC EP/H051716/1) and has proved seminal: (i) Puckett and Daniels, Phys.Rev.Lett. (2013) (doi: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.110.058001);  (ii) Bi et al., Europhys.Lett.  (2013) (doi: 10.1209/0295-5075/102/34002).

Title: Normal fault growth and fault-related folding in a salt-influenced rift basin: South Viking Graben, offshore Norway
Three-dimensional seismic analysis of megaclast deformation within a mass transport deposit; implications for debris flow kinematics
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides the first ever example of the application of 3D seismic reflection data to documenting the detailed internal structure of large clast (‘megaclasts’) contained in a deep-water mass transport deposit, and challenges the long-held notion that such flows are only weakly-turbulent.
