Novel coupling of geological and geophysical methods presented in this and other sedimentology-focused papers resulted in the award of the Roland Goldring Prize by the British Sedimentological Research Group (BSRG) in 2011 for ‘noteworthy published research in the field of sedimentology’.

Title: Source-to-sink analysis of ancient sedimentary systems using a subsurface case study from the Møre-Trøndelag area of southern Norway: Part 2 – sediment dispersal and forcing mechanisms
The influence of normal fault geometry on igneous sill emplacement and morphology
The Chicxulub asteroid impact and mass extinction at the Cretaceous-Paleogene boundary.
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows that the Cretaceous-Tertiary mass extinction event, which wiped out more than half of all species on the planet, occurred on a much faster timescale than contemporaneous flood volcanism and that the timing of the extinction coincides precisely with a large impact in the Gulf of Mexico. The paper received extensive international media coverage, including interviews on BBC 10 o'clock News and Radio 4's Today programme. The Imperial contribution combined geophysical data interpretation and numerical modelling to constrain the crater dimensions and structure, the energy of the impact and the immediate environmental consequences of the impact.

Title: Plant spore walls as a record of long-term changes in ultraviolet-B radiation
AdditionalInformation: First ever use of a new plant-based proxy for ambient UV light to uncover variations through time.  Present day records can now be placed in a historical and geological context. Technique is product of a successful partnership with Thermo aimed at finding new science markets for their FTIR microscopes (david.james@thermofisher.com). The initiative was successful and method was subsequently applied to understand UV variations because of present day forest canopy cover (doi: 10.3402/polar.v30i0.8312) and altitude change during mountain building (doi: 10.1016/j.epsl.2012.07.039,). Recently led to multi-institutional £543,000 NERC award to reconstruct cloud cover reflecting climate change over last 500,000 years (NE/K005294/1).

Title: Aromatic units from the macromolecular material in meteorites: Molecular probes of cosmic environments
AdditionalInformation: First use of small-sample hydrogenation of meteorites. Data finally explained observations of unusual organic structures in meteorites that have puzzled scientists since 1960s. Revelations provided elegant means of discriminating between organic matter in meteorites and life. Paper used by NASA Mars 2020 Science Definition Team (biosignature subpanel) to plan for the next NASA Mars mission. Impressive preliminary data led to a £192,025 urgency grant award by the Science and Technology Facilities Council (ST/K000551/1). Supported appointment as Chair of UK Space Agency Space Exploration Advisory Committee in 2013. http://www.bis.gov.uk/ukspaceagency/news-and-events/2013/Mar/new-chairs-for-two-uk-space-agency-advisory-committees. Paper prompted convenorship of biosignatures session at AGU 2013, San Francisco.

Title: Investigating the contribution of methane produced by ablating micrometeorites to the atmosphere of Mars
AdditionalInformation: Paper constrained sources of atmospheric methane on Mars and revealed meteorites contribute only minor amounts. Results represent boost for search for life on Mars and led to appointment on several high level NASA/ESA international committees, including Co-Chairmanship of Mars Sample Return End-2-End International Science Analysis Group (2010) (doi:10.1089/ast.2011.0805) and membership of Mars2020 Science Definition Team (2012) (http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/mars2020/). Data presented as Keynote, Observing the Earth Meeting, University Leicester (2011). Methane work led to BP shale gas grant (£220,556) in 2012. Wide media coverage (BBC, Scientific American, Telegraph, e.g. http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8402741.stm). Mars work led to design and presentation roles on BBC documentary (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-23349496).

Title: Chemical constitution of a Permian-Triassic disaster species
AdditionalInformation: Abundant microfossils appear at close of Permian but controversy surrounded origin of these entities. Paper represents first comprehensive geochemical investigation of these fossil organisms. The microfossils’ origin as fungal species was experimentally supported and community now more confidently uses these "disaster species" as markers of global terrestrial ecosystem collapse. Data first presented during prestigious invited lecture at Bicentenary for World’s Oldest Earth Science organisation - The Geological Society. Humanity's most widely read magazine, The National Geographic, photographed and reported on author during sample collection (http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0009/feature4/fulltext.html) and publication of findings (http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/10/091006-mass-extinction-fungi-forests.html). Also covered by Telegraph, Financial Times, Discovery Channel and ABC.

Title: Asymmetric Distribution of Lunar Impact Basins Caused by Variations in Target Properties
AdditionalInformation: Published to support NASA's $500 million GRAIL mission to accurately measure the Moon's gravity field, this paper explains why the giant impact craters on the Moon's nearside are larger than those on the farside and not representative of the earliest inner solar system impact bombardment. It is the culmination of an Imperial-led program of numerical simulations of large lunar impact basins that led to three other journal publications (Potter et al., 2012, Icarus, doi:10.1029/2012GL052981; Potter et al., 2012, GRL, doi:10.1016/j.icarus.2012.05.032; Potter et al., 2013, JGR Planets, doi:10.1002/jgre.20080) and an invited talk at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting in 2012.

Title: The size-frequency distribution of elliptical impact craters
Dynamic modeling suggests terrace zone asymmetry in the Chicxulub crater is caused by target heterogeneity
AdditionalInformation: Paper demonstrates that target heterogeneity, rather than the direction of impact, is the primary cause of Chicxulub crater asymmetry and that the absence of a topographic crater rim in the NE would have led to large tsunami waves propagating over the Gulf of Mexico. The model proposed will be tested by a £14M Integrated Oceanic Drilling Program borehole in 2015; two of the paper's co-authors form the principal scientists on this internationally funded project. This work led to an invited talk at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting (2009) and a 5-year, £435K Advanced Natural Environment Research Council Fellowship (NE/E013589/1).

Title: TIDAL MODELING OF AN ANCIENT TIDE-DOMINATED SEAWAY, PART 1: MODEL VALIDATION AND APPLICATION TO GLOBAL EARLY CRETACEOUS (APTIAN) TIDES
Conservative interpolation between unstructured meshes via supermesh construction
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering

Title: A new computational framework for multi-scale ocean modelling based on adapting unstructured meshes
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids

Title: Synthetic-Eddy Method for Urban Atmospheric Flow Modelling
Evidence for the mechanisms of zinc uptake by rice using isotope fractionation.
AdditionalInformation: First in situ evidence that key mechanism for Zn uptake efficiency in rice is release of phytosidorphores. This represents breakthrough for determining rice breeding strategies and solving micronutrient deficiency. Work led directly to BBSRC funding (BB/J011584/1, 2011-2014, £1.1m) for further research into Zn uptake mechanisms in rice in collaboration with International Rice Research Institute. Pioneering work on metal isotopes in plants was recognized by Weiss receiving Cox Visiting Professorship at Stanford University, invitations to talk at Hebrew University (2008), Stanford (2013), ENS-Lyon (2010), Oxford (2010) and keynote talk at an expert European Science Foundation workshop (France, 2011).

Title: Accurate and Precise Zinc Isotope Ratio Measurements in Urban Aerosols
AdditionalInformation: Paper demonstrates that isotopic composition of atmospheric Zn reveals its source. Assigning Zn provenance is a fundamental challenge to urban planners. Work required development of an analytical method to measure precise isotope ratios in aerosols. Weiss recieved invitations for invited and keynote talks at main mass spectrometry conferences (Plasma Spectrometry, 2008, USA; Geoanalysis, 2012, Brazil) and feature articles in respected journals (Environmental Science and Technology, 2008; Elements, 2009). Work led to appointment as Visiting Professor at Xiamen University (China). Follow on grant (£3m, FP7-CLIM-AMAZON-project, www.clim-amazon.eu; 2012-2015) is testing this technique to reveal trace element fluxes in Amazon Basin.

Title: Stable Lead Isotope Compositions In Selected Coals From Around The World And Implications For Present Day Aerosol Source Tracing
AdditionalInformation: Paper demonstrated that emissions from China affect air quality in USA and showed that coal is major contaminant source in Asian atmosphere. Work also proved that recycled Pb from leaded gasoline remains important pollutant in UK environment. Findings prompted invitation for Weiss to present keynote talk at Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (London, 2010), and invitation to editorial board of Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta. Work led to consortium funding (£2.8m; NERC; 2NE/H005390/1; 2010-2014) to study metal fluxes in Southern Atlantic and the award from University of Hamburg for a fellowship as scientist in residence.

Title: The effect of crude oil on arsenate adsorption on goethite
AdditionalInformation: Oil spills during petroleum exploration endanger marine ecosystems and understanding the environmental impact has become a global research question following the accident in the Gulf of Mexico. Effective investigation is challenging owing to the difficulty of producing representative laboratory systems. This paper developed a model of metal-oil-mineral interactions demonstrating that the filtering capacity of sediments is reduced after oil spills.  This process has been overlooked so far and findings attracted worldwide media attention (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-02/oil-spills-raise-ocean-s-arsenic-level-in-toxic-time-bomb-study-shows.html). Led to funding to test molecular structure of sorption complexes (Leverhulme; RPG-213, £170,000; 2011-2013).

Title: A wetting and drying algorithm with a combined pressure/free-surface formulation for non-hydrostatic models
Accurate representation of geostrophic and hydrostatic balance in unstructured mesh finite element ocean modelling
AdditionalInformation: Multi-scale numerical methods offer significant advantages for ocean modelling, but major issues with the representation of large-scale force balances have significantly hindered progress for more than a decade. Through detailed analysis and simulation compared to laboratory data, this paper thoroughly examines the representaion problem and proposes and assesses a novel approach to solve it. The resulting multi-scale ocean modelling capability has led to significant NERC (NE/G018391/1, £350K, 2010-13, Piggott PI;  NE/F004184/1, 2008-12, £308k, Piggott PI;  NE/F012594/1, £311k, 2009-12, Pain PI; NE/J015938/1, £232k, 2012-14, Piggott Co-I) and EPSRC (EP/I00405X/1, £790k, 2010-2013, Pain PI) funding.

Title: Developing the next-generation climate system models: challenges and achievements
VolumeTitle: Royal Society of London. Philosophical Transactions A. Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper highlights issues related to the multi-scale nature of simulating climate and the Earth system, and numerical codes that can make full use of future computer architectures. It argues for the use of novel adaptive mesh algorithms and a direct outcome of this was the award of a four month Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences programme in this area (http://www.newton.ac.uk/programmes/AMM/index.html, Piggott co-organiser). The ideas presented in this work led to NERC grants on multi-scale atmospheric (NE/H002847/1, £190k, 2010-12, Piggott PI) and ice shelf (NE/G018391/1, £350k, 2010-13, Piggott PI) modelling.

Title: Eastern Mediterranean tectonics and tsunami hazard inferred from the AD 365 earthquake
Pore-to-field simulation of single-phase transport using continuous time random walks
Signature of Non-Fickian Solute Transport in Complex Heterogeneous Porous Media
AdditionalInformation: A major achievement that helped secure the second phase of $70 million 10-year funding by the Qatar Foundation, Qatar Petroleum and Shell. This distinctive signature of transport in highly heterogeneous media has also been observed in a range of carbonate samples, including reservoir rocks (BB etal Water Resources Research, 2013,49,2714-2728; BB etal Advances in Water Resources, 2013,51,197). The work was presented by BB at invited talks at:  3rd International Conference on Porous Media-INTERPORE, Bordeaux,  France, 2011 (http://interpore2011.u-bordeaux.fr); Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics Geoscience Conference, Long Beach,  USA, 2011 (http://meetings.siam.org/sess/dsp_talk.cfm?p=40139); 2nd “Complexity in Oil Industry” Meeting, Natal,  Brazil, 2011 (http://www.iip.ufrn.br/?pg==oFWaxmYuJleYJjUsR2RGBnYB1TP&lang=en&inf===QTUVUP).

Title: Modelling two-phase flow in porous media at the pore scale using the volume-of-fluid method
Predictions of non-Fickian solute transport in different classes of porous media using direct simulation on pore-scale images.
AdditionalInformation: This paper explains the origin of anomalous solute transport in different classes of porous media by the novel analysis of velocity distribution and structure on micro-CT images. The predictive pore-scale simulator is validated against previously published experiments. It is the culmination of transport studies using digital rock technology that helped secure the second phase of the $70 million project funded by Shell, Qatar Petroleum and the Qatar Foundation (2013-2018) and an EPSRC grant (EP/L012227/1, £394,000). BB presented this work at invited talks at the Synchrotron Users Meeting, Diamond Light Source, Didcot, 2012 (http://www.diamond.ac.uk/Home/Events/Past_events/SR-User-Meeting-2012/Energy-and-Storage-Materials-Workshop.html) and the EGU, Vienna, 2013 (http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/egu2013/meetingprogramme).

Title: A Modified Nested-Gridding for Upscaling-Downscaling in Reservoir Simulation
Structural characterization and statistical properties of two-dimensional granular systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to make direct measurements of the characteristics that are required to validate the modern formulation of the statistical mechanics of granular media. This empirical validation was a vital step to using and extending this theoretical approach. This work led to an EPSRC grant of £240k to Imperial (EP/H051716/1), awarded in conjunction with Prof D Frenkel, Chemistry Department, Cambridge, as well as an invitation to one of the co-authors to visit Prof Matsushima at Tsukuba University in Japan. An Alan Howard PhD Scholarship from the British Council (£230k) was recently awarded to continue this work (2013-2016).

Title: Effect of anisotropy on the scaling of connectivity and conductivity in continuum percolation theory
Hierarchical coarse-graining transform
Numerical study of the effects of particle shape and polydispersity on permeability
AdditionalInformation: First discrete body mechanical simulation of packs of sand grains with realistic i.e. non-idealised shapes and polydisperse sizes. Made possible by a new efficient sphere clustering algorithm for irregular/angular-shaped grains, (Garcia doi:10.1680/geot.8.T.037). This work formed one of five talks given on the theme ‘VGW -Virtual Geoscience Workbench for discontinuous systems’ presented at the International Symposium/RCUK-China Summer School on Discrete Element Methods and Numerical Modelling of Discontinuum Mechanics, Beijing, 24-30 Sept 2008. Two further invited papers on VGW (£470K, 2004-2009 EPSRC, GR/S42699/01), were presented by Latham at this symposium. VGW, now publicised through VGeST.net, illuminates several particulate packing simulation technologies.

Title: Modelling stress-dependent permeability in fractured rock including effects of propagating and bending fractures
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Rock Mechanics and Mining Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Presents advanced geomechanical models of stressed fractured domains and enhanced realism for flows. Simulations described support the critically stressed crust hypothesis of Zobach (2006). The work described in this paper was a key to Universities Montan, Heriot-Watt and Imperial winning Phase 3 (April 2010 - April 2013) of the fractured reservoirs consortium “Gravity Assisted Recovery Processes” with €620K funded by Total, Conoco Phillips, Exxon-Mobil, OMV, Statoil and Saudi Aramco, see http://www.pet.hw.ac.uk/research/itf-ISF/.

Title: Modelling of fluid-solid interactions using an adaptive mesh fluid model coupled with a combined finite-discrete element model
Finite strain, finite rotation quadratic tetrahedral element for the combined finite-discrete element method
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering

Title: Insights into non-Fickian solute transport in carbonates
AdditionalInformation: In this study under a $70 million project with Shell, Qatar Petroleum and the Qatar Foundation (www.imperial.ac.uk/qccsrc), the nature of transport for carbonates with different degrees of pore-scale heterogeneity is predicted with application to the understanding of transport and reaction in the context of carbon dioxide storage and enhanced oil recovery. The work has led to further funding (EPSRC EP/L012227/1, £394,000), and invited talks in 2013 at the Interpore Meeting in Prague and MIT (MJB, contact juanes@mit.edu). MJB received the 2012 Darcy Award from the Society of Core Analysts (www.scaweb.org) for lifetime achievement based on this and related research.

Title: Residual CO(2) imaged with X-ray micro-tomography
AdditionalInformation: The culmination of the £3 million Shell-Imperial Grand Challenge on Clean Fossil Fuels (2006-2011) extended under a $70 million project with Shell, Qatar Petroleum and the Qatar Foundation. This is the first reservoir-condition pore-scale imaging of multiple fluids showing that capillary trapping does indeed surround supercritical carbon dioxide in immobile droplets in the pore space, ensuring safe carbon storage. This work inspired the construction of a new £2 million laboratory at Imperial opened in September 2012 (www.imperial.ac.uk/qccsrc).  Presented at an invited lecture to the ENI Petroleum Engineering Conference, Milan 2012 (Alberto Cominelli, acominelli@eni.com‎).

Title: Pore-network extraction from micro-computerized-tomography images
AdditionalInformation: The paper solves the problem of extracting a topologically representative network structure from micron-resolution images of porous rock allowing predictive modelling of flow and transport properties with application to improved hydrocarbon recovery. Funded by an industrial consortium (£120,000 per year from BG, Statoil, JOGMEC and Shell), it is the intellectual basis of a spin-out company founded by the authors in 2011 (www.iRocktech.com) and is also used commercially by Lithicon (www.lithicon.com; peoe@numericalrocks.com).  MJB received the 2012 Darcy Award from the Society of Core Analysts (www.scaweb.org) for lifetime achievement based on this and related research on pore-scale modelling.

Title: Design of carbon dioxide storage in aquifers
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a novel injection design involving brine recirculation to ensure safe carbon dioxide storage. It was an early success under the £3 million Shell-Imperial Grand Challenge on Clean Fossil Fuels (2006-2011) and helped secure $70 million from Shell, Qatar Petroleum and the Qatar Foundation for a 10-year programme (2008-2018). The work uses streamline-based simulation, a technology pioneered by MJB, who is CTO of a commercial spin-off Streamsim Technologies, www.streamsim.com.  This technology was cited in his Uren Award from the Society of Petroleum Engineers (www.spe.org) for achievements in petroleum technology made before the age of 45.

Title: Mapping benthic habitat in regions of gradational substrata: An automated approach utilising geophysical, geological, and biological relationships
AdditionalInformation: Paper demonstrates utility of the emerging field of marine resource evaluation and management, in particular the ability of acoustic backscatter to predict benthic habitat. Represents a cross-disciplinary (geophysics-biology) collaboration funded by NERC Connect B (NER/D/S/2000/01307, £232k) and HEFCE JREI (JR00IMCOEQ, £524k) equipment grants. Findings led directly to a £156k research grant from DEFRA (Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs) through the Marine Aggregate Levy Sustainability Fund (MALSF) in 09/09 (09/P80). This follow on work was presented in 07/10 at a Royal Society conference, London.

Title: Age of Seychelles-India break-up
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided the first accurate determination of the timing of continental break-up of the Seychelles micro-continent from India. Field area is one of the key locations for determining whether deep mantle plumes are responsible for continental breakup. The advance in knowledge came from the interpretation of new samples and data collected during three NERC-sponsored oceanographic cruises, each led by Collier (CD134b, CD144, CD149). Significance of the findings has been recognised by two invited keynote lectures at the leading international conferences that cover the subject – at EGU, Vienna in 04/09 and at AGU, San Francisco in 10/12.

Title: Factors influencing magmatism during continental breakup: New insights from a wide-angle seismic experiment across the conjugate Seychelles-Indian margins
AdditionalInformation: Paper documents a NERC-and EU- funded seismic experiment led by Collier, which is largest to-date in the Indian Ocean. Work stimulated the collection of commercial data   to increase the understanding of the region’s hydrocarbon potential (http://www.iongeo.com/Data_Library/Africa/East_AfricaSPAN/). Findings presented at an invited lecture at the University of Oslo in 03/10. Summary of the study was commissioned as a popular science article in 09/10 (NERC, Planet Earth Magazine, http://planetearth.nerc.ac.uk/features/story.aspx?id=884) and as a Backstory in Nature Geoscience in 07/08 (http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v1/n7/full/ngeo245.html). Hammond was awarded a NERC Research Fellowship and Collier was awarded NERC Large grant NE/K010824/1 (£3.7 million total) to continue the work.

Title: The importance of rift history for volcanic margin formation
AdditionalInformation: Paper represents culmination of a 10-year programme studying continental breakup funded by NERC (NER/A/S/2000/01332) and EU (HPRI-CT-1999-00037). Findings challenged prevailing theory that volume of magma erupted when two continents spilt is controlled by mantle temperature. The work was publicised in Science Daily (http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/06/100616133321.htm) and presented as departmental seminars at both UK and European institutes (09/11 University of Oxford; 02/12 University of Bristol, 12/12 ETH, Zurich). Collier presented findings as a keynote lecture at AGU Fall meeting (12/10). Armitage was awarded a Marie Curie Fellowship and Collier was awarded NERC grant NE/K010824/1 (£3.7 million total) to continue the work.

Title: The Development and Application of a Novel Optimisation Strategy for Solid Oxide Fuel Cell-Gas Turbine Hybrid Cycles
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel methodology to optimise the performance of Solid Oxide Fuel Cell-Gas Turbine hybrid systems, and to inform the operation of these emerging high efficiency power generation systems.  The work was in collaboration with Zhao, a visiting researcher from China, being part of the body of work by Brandon which resulted in the award of the OBE for services to UK-China science in 2011. The work also contributed to the appointment of Brandon as Director of the £4.1M EPSRC SUPERGEN Hub (EP/J016454/1) in Hydrogen and Fuel Cells in 2012, leading this area for the UK.

Title: Multi Length Scale Microstructural Investigations of a Commercially Available Li-Ion Battery Electrode
Investigation of lithium-ion polymer battery cell failure using X-ray computed tomography
3D reconstruction of SOFC anodes using a focused ion beam lift-out technique
AdditionalInformation: Presents a novel method for three dimensional characterisation of solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) electrodes by Focussed Ion Beam/Scanning Electron Microscopy tomography. The Journal lists this paper as one the top most cited since 2008. The work underpins nine subsequent papers on understanding SOFC electrode structures by Brandon et al (e.g. Solid Sate Ionics 2012, Journal Power Sources 2010). Brandon has delivered 3 plenary (e.g. MODVAL10, Germany, 2013) and 4 keynote lectures (e.g.  International Society Electrochemistry, Japan, 2011) on this work at international conferences. Led to a £1.657M grant (EP/I02249X/1- 2011-2016) on materials imaging  (Brandon as CoI).

Title: Martian Fluvial Conglomerates at Gale Crater
AdditionalInformation: First in situ documentation of water-transported sedimentary gravels on the surface of Mars from NASA's Mars Science Laboratory Curiosity rover mission on which Gupta is a Science Team member and Long Term Science Planner. Provides direct evidence of sustained surface water flow on ancient Mars. Research led to a plenary talk at International Association of Sedimentologists Conference (Manchester, UK 09/2013), and invited public talks at Cheltenham Science Festival (6/2013), UK National Astronomy Meeting (St. Andrews 7/2013), and Geological Society of London Shell London Lecture series (9/8/2013). Featured on BBC1, 6 and 10 o'clock TV news (8/2013).

Title: Hesperian equatorial thermokarst lakes in Ares Vallis as evidence for transient warm conditions on Mars
AdditionalInformation: This paper identified the first evidence for episodes of climate warming on Mars during the Hesperian epoch, a time previously considered to be extremely cold and hyper-arid, from the presence of ancient lakes formed by melting of permafrost. The research was funded by a STFC Astronomy standard grant (grant ST/F003099/1) and a Royal Society-Leverhulme Trust Senior Research Fellowship to Gupta. Gupta gave invited talks at Royal Astronomy Society (12/12/08); Glasgow Univ. (2/10/09); ENS, Lyon, France (1/06/10). The paper attracted significant media interest (half-page feature in the Daily Telegraph (5/01/10); live interview on BBC News 24 TV (5/01/10)).

Title: A refined chronology of catastrophic outflow events in Ares Vallis, Mars
AdditionalInformation: This paper used high-resolution impact crater statistics to show that the martian outflow channels, formed by the largest known movements of surface water on Mars, were carved by multiple flow episodes, an important result for martian hydrology. Funded by a STFC Astronomy standard grant (grant ST/F003099/1) and a Royal Society-Leverhulme Trust Senior Research Fellowship to Gupta. Led to invited talks at British Association of Science Festival (09/09) and at the 2014 Binghampton Geomorphology Symposium on Planetary Geomorphology (09/14, Knoxville, TN, USA). The research featured in BBC Radio 4 documentary "A Trip around Mars with Kevin Fong"  (27/03/13).

Title: Three-dimensional simulation and inversion of borehole temperatures for reconstructing past climate in complex settings
AdditionalInformation: Describes a method for relating down-hole temperatures to past climates using a computationally efficient reduced order approach that eliminates localized borehole affects.  The methods were further developed for broader application to ocean modeling and fluid flows  and contributed to winning several EPSRC grants (EP/I00405X/1-£789k, EP/L000407/1-£1,287k, EP/K003976/1-£4,986k). Fang invited to present work at Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (Boston, USA, 2013) and Fang and Pain presented results at several Chinese Universities (e.g. Tsinghua University, Beijing, 2013; East China Normal University, Shanghai, 2012; TongJi University, Shanghai, 2012; Wuhan University, 2011; ZheJiang University, Hangzhou, 2013).

Title: A sub-grid scale finite element agglomeration multigrid method with application to the Boltzmann transport equation
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering

Title: Non-linear Petrov-Galerkin methods for reduced order modelling of the Navier-Stokes equations using a mixed finite element pair
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A new non-linear Petrov–Galerkin approach has been developed for reduced order modelling (ROM) of the Navier–Stokes equations. It provides the first rigorous solution to the stability problem plaguing reduced order models at high Reynolds number flows, facilitating the application of these techniques to numerous industrial and environmental problems. Work funded by a £789k EPSRC grant (EP/I00405X/1) to develop reduced order models for the Imperial College Ocean Model (ICOM). Prior to publication, led to co-author Du at the CAS Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP) being awarded a fellowship at IAP in Beijing and a NERC international collaboration grant (NERC-NE/J015938/1, £230k).

Title: A POD reduced order unstructured mesh ocean modelling method for moderate Reynolds number flows
AdditionalInformation: Data-assimilation is essential for ocean modelling but is computationally expensive because of the large dimensionality of the problems. This paper presents a reduced order model, developed for an unstructured mesh ocean model. This method represents the dynamics of the system with a smaller number of degrees of freedom. This work led to 1) a £789k EPSRC grant being awarded to Imperial (EP/I00405X, 2010-2013) on multi-scale free surface regional ocean modelling, 2) a NERC international collaboration grant (NE/J015938/1-£230k), 3) Invited seminars at the following Chinese institutions:- CAS Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Universities of Wuhan, Tsinghua and Zhejiang.

Title: Facies model of a fine-grained, tide-dominated delta: Lower Dir Abu Lifa Member (Eocene), Western Desert, Egypt
Sedimentology, stratigraphic occurrence and origin of linked debrites in the West Crocker Formation (Oligo-Miocene), Sabah, NW Borneo
Sustained turbidity currents and their interaction with debrite-related topography; Labuan Island, offshore NW Borneo, Malaysia
Facies architecture of a net transgressive sandstone reservoir analog: The Cretaceous Hosta Tongue, New Mexico
TIDAL MODELING OF AN ANCIENT TIDE-DOMINATED SEAWAY, PART 2: THE APTIAN LOWER GREENSAND SEAWAY OF NORTHWEST EUROPE
The impact of mesh adaptivity on the gravity current front speed in a two-dimensional lock-exchange
Modelling tidal current-induced bed shear stress and palaeocirculation in an epicontinental seaway: the Bohemian Cretaceous Basin, Central Europe
Characterization of stratigraphic architecture and its impact on fluid flow in a fluvial-dominated deltaic reservoir analog: Upper Cretaceous Ferron Sandstone Member, Utah
Controls on large-scale patterns of fluvial sandbody distribution in alluvial to coastal plain strata: Upper Cretaceous Blackhawk Formation, Wasatch Plateau, Central Utah, USA
Trajectory analysis: concepts and applications
Sediment dispersal and quantitative stratigraphic architecture across an ancient shelf
Tidal circulation in an ancient epicontinental sea: The Early Jurassic Laurasian Seaway
Generating High Mg-numbers and Chemical Diversity in Tonalite-Trondhjemite-Granodiorite (TTG) Magmas during Melting and Melt Segregation in the Continental Crust
AdditionalInformation: Combines novel melting experiments and numerical modelling to demonstrate that batch and fractional melting models and experiments, used ubiquitously in geochemical studies, may be in error due to their omission of key physical processes that occur during separation of melt from mush. This has profound implications for our understanding of igneous processes. The work led to Jackson’s keynote presentation at the 2009 Annual Meeting of the Volcanic and Magmatic Studies Group, an invited presentation at the 2012 American Geophysical Union meeting, and collaboration with Bristol University (Sparks and Blundy) on a related £0.4M Leverhulme-funded project (Grant ref: F/00 182/AY).

Title: Three-dimensional modeling of a shoreface-shelf parasequence reservoir analog: Part 1. Surface-based modeling to capture high-resolution facies architecture
Impact of wettability on laboratory measurements of streaming potential in carbonates
VolumeTitle: Colloids and Surfaces A - Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects

Title: Fluid flow monitoring in oil fields using downhole measurements of electrokinetic potential
Screening and selection of sites for CO2 sequestration based on pressure buildup
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control

Title: Numerical simulation of multiple 3D fracture propagation using arbitrary meshes
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering

Title: Compressibility and shear compliance of spheroidal pores: Exact derivation via the Eshelby tensor, and asymptotic expressions in limiting cases
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents first derivation of bulk and shear compliances of spheroidal pores starting directly from Eshelby tensor by making use of rigorous asymptotic expressions for cracks and needle-shaped pores having finite aspect ratios. The expressions provide crucial input to schemes for calculating effective elastic moduli of porous materials (rocks, ceramics). Led to contract for RWZ from Cambridge University Press for new edition of Compressibility of Sandstones. Results were presented in the invited Warren Lecture, University of Minnesota, 2011, as part of RWZ's MTS Visiting Professorship and at an invited talk at the Conference on Poromechanics, Vienna, 2013 (http://biot2013.conf.tuwien.ac.at/)

Title: Shear compliance of two-dimensional pores possessing N-fold axis of rotational symmetry
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical & Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: A new method for deriving closed-form expressions for complex stress potentials in a 2D elastic body containing a cavity under remote shear loading has been developed and validated against boundary element calculations. The exact analytical solutions were used to develop an approximate expression for the shear compliance of an arbitrarily shaped pore in terms of its area and perimeter, providing a route to modelling materials with realistic, irregularly shaped pores. This and related papers led to RWZ receiving the 2010 Maurice Biot Medal for poromechanics from the American Society of Civil Engineers. http://www.asce.org/leadership-and-management/awards/biot-award-past-winners/

Title: Using time-lapse seismic monitoring to identify trapping mechanisms during CO2 sequestration
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control

Title: Appraisal of reservoir compartmentalization using fluid mixing time-scales: Horn Mountain Field, Gulf of Mexico
Quantifying the Impact of Permeability Heterogeneity on Secondary-Recovery Performance
Experimental and Numerical Investigations Into Oil-Drainage Rates During Vapor Extraction of Heavy Oils
Full waveform tomographic images of the peak ring at the Chicxulub impact crater
AdditionalInformation: Paper represents state of the art development for peak-ring formation in large impact craters of which Morgan was co-proposer. Research led to proposal for scientific drilling of the Chicxulub impact crater in Mexico to test model of peak ring formation and investigate the role of asteroid impact in the mass extinction event 65 Ma. Consequently, in 2011, the Integrated Oceanic Drilling Program elected Morgan as a co-chief scientist, and scheduled drilling for 2015 at a cost of ~£14 million (http://www.ecord.org/pub/Chicxulub-IODP-NL19.pdf).  The work led to invitation for Morgan to contribute to Distinguished Lecturer Program, University of Wyoming, November 2010.

Title: Shallow oceanic crust: Full waveform tomographic images of the seismic layer 2A/2B boundary
Structural uplift beneath the Chicxulub impact structure
AdditionalInformation: Paper presents model of three-dimensional structure of the Chicxulub impact crater, derived by joint inversion of multiple geophysical datasets. Data were acquired during two international NERC/NSF seismic experiments in 1996 and 2005, that were co-led by Morgan, and cost ~£1 million each. Structural model in this paper was adopted by modellers to constrain dynamic simulations of large crater formation, including research groups at Harvard (doi: 10.1016/j.epsl.2009.08.033), Russian Academy of Science (doi: 10.1007/s11208-005-0051-0) and Imperial College London (doi:10.1016/j.epsl.2008.03.032; doi: 10.1016/j.epsl.2008.03.032). Work led to invitation for Morgan to give a Plenary lecture at the Large Meteorite Impacts IV, Vredefort, South Africa, 2008.

Title: Modeling the formation of the K-Pg boundary layer
AdditionalInformation: First numerical simulation of ejecta from the Chicxulub impact site that replicated observational data from the global K-Pg boundary layer.  Work led to Morgan being awarded a Leverhulme Trust Research Fellowship in 2010 on:  “How did the era of the dinosaurs end?” (RF/4/RFG/2010/0159). Paper also led to Morgan being profiled in 2010 by the Science Museum in London as part of their exhibition “Atmosphere: Exploring Climate Science” (http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/visitmuseum/galleries/atmosphere.aspx) as a scientist working in the field of palaeoclimate and mass extinctions. Paper provided a fundamental contribution to subsequent paper in Science (Schulte et al., 2010; doi: 10.1126/science.1177265).

Title: Seafloor glacial features reveal the extent and decay of the last British Ice Sheet, east of Scotland
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the result of the novel application of oil industry seismic data to reconstruct the evolution of the last British Ice Sheet, a topic of importance to understanding ice sheet behaviour in response to global warming. Collaborative PhD project with British Geological Survey (BGS funding of £23.95k). The research led to an invited keynote talk by LL at the International Quaternary Conference (INQUA) in Bern, Switzerland, 2011 (http://www.inqua2011.ch) and invitation to write a chapter in Ehlers, J., et al. 2011, Quaternary Glaciations - Extent and Chronology - A Closer Look. Developments in Quaternary Science 15, Elsevier.

Title: The response of turbidite slope channels to growth-induced seabed topography
Seven glacial cycles in the middle-late Pleistocene of northwest Europe: Geomorphic evidence from buried tunnel valleys
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the culmination of a major research effort that uses oil industry seismic data to reconstruct the extent and limits of NW European ice-sheets during the late Quaternary. The results will inform modelling of ice-sheet extents prior to the Last Glacial Maximum, in response to climate forcing. Commercial seismic data were provided by Petroleum Geo-Services and Hess Ltd. The research led to an invited keynote talk by LL at the International Quaternary Conference (INQUA) in Bern, Switzerland, 2011 (http://www.inqua2011.ch) and invited talk at Cambridge University (2008) on the research that led to this paper.

Title: Calculation of the transport properties of a dilute gas consisting of Lennard-Jones chains
Ab initio intermolecular potential energy surface and thermophysical properties of hydrogen sulfide
AdditionalInformation: This work has generated accurate and reliable values of viscosity, thermal conductivity and self-diffusion coefficient that are invaluable to chemical and petroleum engineers, especially as properties of hydrogen sulfide play an increasingly important role in processes that involve sour natural gas. Furthermore, the work has provided chemical physics community with an accurate ab-initio, state-of-the-art intermolecular potential surface. Co-author R. Hellmann received the European Conferences on Thermophysical Properties (ECTP) Netzsch Young Scientist Award in 2011 for his contribution.

Title: Calculation of the transport and relaxation properties of dilute water vapor
AdditionalInformation: This is the most complicated molecule for which transport properties have ever been calculated directly from the intermolecular potential. As a result of this work, the International Association for the Properties of Water and Steam (IAPWS) re-evaluated all the experimental data on thermal conductivity of steam at high temperature and published a new recommended correlation (M. Huber et al., J.Phys.Chem.Ref.Data  41, 033102, 2012)). V. Vesovic has given two invited international conference talks (ECTP 2011 (http://19ectp.cheng.auth.gr/index.php/en/program/27-invited),  ATPC 2013 (http://www.atpc2013.org/) and one plenary lecture (XXV Interamerican Congress of Chemical Engineering 2011 (www.ciiq2011.cl) on this work.

Title: A kinetic theory description of the viscosity of dense fluids consisting of chain molecules.
Anisotropic 3D full-waveform inversion
A finite element multifrontal method for 3D CSEM modeling in the frequency domain
INVERSION OF FULL ACOUSTIC WAVEFIELD IN LOCAL HELIOSEISMOLOGY: A STUDY WITH SYNTHETIC DATA
Importance of pre-impact crustal structure for the asymmetry of the Chicxulub impact crater
AdditionalInformation: Asymmetries in impact craters have been conventionally ascribed to impact direction; in this paper we demonstrated, in an exceptionally well-preserved large terrestrial impact, that asymmetry is instead a function of pre-impact target heterogeneity.  The model proposed will be tested by a £14million Integrated Oceanic Drilling Program offshore borehole scheduled for drilling in March 2015. Two of the paper's authors are the Principal Scientists for this internationally funded project.

Title: How metalliferous brines line Mexican epithermal veins with silver.
AdditionalInformation: Presents the first analysis of silver-ore forming fluids from the world’s second largest silver deposit (currently producing £370M of silver annually). The work shows that such deposits form rapidly in rare and unusual hydrothermal fluid flow events. This unique dataset informs current thinking on the the fundamental nature of mineralizing hydrothermal systems, exemplified by Simmons and Brown (2006, Science, v. 314, p. 288-291) and Heinrich (2006, Science, v. 314, p. 263-264). Prior to publication the work was presented at the Gordon Research Conference on Inorganic Geochemistry of Ore Deposits (2008).

Title: Multistage Intrusion, Brecciation, and Veining at El Teniente, Evolution of a Nested Porphyry System
AdditionalInformation: This study tests competing models for the formation of one of the world’s largest copper deposits and explains why the deposit is of such remarkable size and high grade. The work has been incorporated in the mine geology model at El Teniente (Chile) and led to funding of further porphyry-copper studies in Peru (NERC-Gold Fields Open CASE project “Geological Optimisation for Sustainable Copper-Gold Mining”; contact: Dr A. Wurst, Chief Geologist, Gold Fields Inc. Andy.Wurst@gfexpl.com), Arizona, Utah and Mongolia (Rio Tinto) and Australia (collaboration with AMIRA International/University of Tasmania) with total funding of £2.5M.

Title: Chemical mass transfer during hydrothermal alteration of carbonates: Controls of seafloor subsidence, sedimentation and Zn-Pb mineralization in the Irish Carboniferous
AdditionalInformation: Presents a quantitative model for fluid-rock interaction that elucidates the role of hydrothermal fluids reacting with carbonates in an ore-forming system. The novel interpretation of syn-sedimentary hydrothermal subsidence is proposed. The study forms part of a body of work that has produced 3 PhD graduates, 15 journal papers and 16 conference presentations including invited talks at Prospector's and Developer's Association of Canada 2008 (Toronto), Zinc 2010 (Cork), and International Association on the Genesis of Ore Deposits 2010 (Adelaide), plus a chapter in Elsevier’s benchmark Treatise on Geochemistry (Wilkinson, in press, publication October 2013). Mineral exploration thinking has been influenced (gearls1@btinternet.com).

Title: Anomalously Metal-Rich Fluids Form Hydrothermal Ore Deposits
AdditionalInformation: Laser ablation ICP-MS analyses of single fluid inclusions in ore minerals are presented for the first time. Results challenge the paradigm that ore deposits form from “typical” crustal fluids subjected to efficient metal deposition. Paper reviewed in Science (v. 323, p. 724) and Nature Geoscience (v. 2, p. 161) and stimulated research that confirmed the wider validity of the findings (Econ. Geol. 106, 55-78; Am. Jour. Sci. 312, 22-80). Work also cited in major review articles (Econ. Geol. 105, 593-625; Econ. Geol. 107, 559-584) and presented in a plenary address to 600 delegates at the 2009 SGA Conference, Townsville.

Title: Super-resolution reconstruction based on incoherent optical aperture synthesis
AdditionalInformation: This work showcases a new method of super resolution reconstruction (SRR) based on incoherent optical aperture synthesis and sub-pixel superposition. It provides significantly enhanced image clarity.  Potential applications include improvement of spatial resolution in surveillance CCTV footages and satellite images. The research builds on Liu’s MoD project on SRR (£205k) and PCIAS sub-pixel technology, and results from collaboration between Imperial and Wuhan University, China. The collaboration enabled co-author Tao Sun to win a scholarship from the China Scholarship Council and NSFC Grant 4117145 which will support future development of the methodology.

Title: GIS modelling of earthquake damage zones using satellite remote sensing and DEM data
Phase correlation pixel-to-pixel image co-registration based on optical flow and median shift propagation
Precise Subpixel Disparity Measurement From Very Narrow Baseline Stereo
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing

Title: A geostatistical and probabilistic spectral image processing methodology for monitoring potential CO2 leakages on the surface
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: Methodology for detecting CO2 leakages at terrestrial surfaces developed in a €5M EU Project in collaboration with BGS-UK, OGS-Italy and BGR-Germany. Uses airborne spectral data and was extended to spaceborne spectral data assessment [ENERGY PROCEDIA, 2011, Vol.4,3421-3427]. The geostatistical image filtering methodology combined with Independent Component Analysis and parametric Reed-Xiaoli anomaly detection indicates seepage points at the Latera and Laacher See natural analogue sites [ENERGY PROCEDIA, 2013, 37, 4057-4064]. Exploiting both spatial and spectral domain correlations improves accuracy significantly and provides for a robust CO2 leakage monitoring methodology. It led to new collaboration with JGI Inc. Japan on InSAR research.

Title: Carbon dioxide storage risk assessment: Analysis of caprock fracture network connectivity
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: The first probabilistic fracture network percolation model for CO2 storage risk assessment, developed during a €0.46M EU project, enables the appraisal of fracture connectivity prior to and post-injection. The model was used to investigate fracture connectivity and potential for CO2 migration through the reservoir and caprock at the In Salah and Otway sites in collaboration with BP [ENERGY PROCEDIA, 2011, Vol.4, 5299-5305] and CO2CRC, Australia. Research led to two new EU projects worth €1.06M in collaboration with Vattenfall, Statoil, Sintef, GEUS and GfZ, assessing caprock integrity and leakage risk at potential CO2 storage sites in the UK, Denmark and Norway.

Title: Life cycle modelling of fossil fuel power generation with post-combustion CO2 capture
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: Presents a novel engineering-based Life Cycle Assessment model, the only tool covering the full fossil fuel power generation value-chain at unit process level. The model was developed with funding from Vattenfall [ENERGY PROCEDIA, 2009, Vol.1,3771-3778; and 2011, Vol.4,2510-2517] and the BG Group [ENERGY PROCEDIA, 2013, 37, 2840-2847]. It is used to inform UK government policy [POSTnote 268,2006; and 383,2011]. BG group uses the model to guide their resource exploitation strategy and formulate their strategic position on climate change. Current research is funded by £1.4M RCUK Energy Programme, £0.48M Scottish Power and a new €4M EU project led by the authors.

Title: Application of factorial kriging analysis to the FOREGS European topsoil geochemistry database.
AdditionalInformation: Builds on an award winning publication [Trans. IMM B, 2006]. Uses factorial geostatistical analysis for the first time, to evaluate geochemical variation in topsoils at continental scale. Quantification of natural and anthropogenic sources in modern topsoils at regional scale (namely geology, tectonics, glacial history, landuse and contamination), enables setting appropriate environmental quality standards. Work funded by a consortium of metals industry associations through a £120,000 project reporting to EU regulators. Led to £230,000 worth further research funded by the EU [ENVIRON GEOCHEM HLTH, 2009; Vol.31; 133-145], CODELCO Chile and the UK HPA [SCI TOTAL ENVIRON, 2009; Vol.407; 4231-4237].

Title: An experimental and numerical investigation into the impact of dissolution/precipitation mechanisms on CO2 injectivity in the wellbore and far field regions
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: This paper details the effects of pressure and temperature changes on dissolution/precipitation mechanisms and their impact on CO2 injectivity. Research established the only known relationship defining porosity and permeability changes experienced due to near wellbore salt precipitation during supercritical CO2 injection. Research findings were presented at the 11th Greenhouse Gas Technologies Conference attended by 1,400 delegates in 2012 [http://www.ghgt.info/index.php/Content-GHGT11/session-2-mon-19th.html#1]. This work resulted in further £1.22M of EPSRC funding in a consortium project led by Imperial, investigating wellbore behaviour in collaboration with industry and academia [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewGrant.aspx?GrantRef=EP/K035967/1].

Title: Assessment of carbon dioxide plume behaviour within the storage reservoir and the lower caprock around the KB-502 injection well at In Salah
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the findings of research collaboration with the In Salah Gas JIP on a large-scale industrial CO2 storage field pilot [http://www.co2remove.eu/]. Coupled flow and geomechanical modelling of fracture/fault behaviour integrated with time-lapse InSAR surface uplift analysis have shown that 24% of the injected CO2 has migrated into the lower caprock within the storage complex at In Salah. These findings and analysis of the seismic and geomechanical data led to the decision to temporarily suspend CO2 injection in June 2011 [http://www.globalccsinstitute.com/projects/12361; http://sequestration.mit.edu/tools/projects/in_salah.html] Research led to a new €4M EU grant [FP7-ENERGY-2012-1 Grant No:608517] coordinated by Imperial.

Title: Improving the CO(2) well injectivity and enhanced coalbed methane production performance in coal seams
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the results of a first field-based comparative study on Enhanced Coalbed Methane (ECBM) production and CO2 storage performance of horizontal and vertical wells using pure CO2, flue gas and/or CO2 enriched flue gas injection. The methodology developed was implemented successfully in assessing the effective CO2 storage capacity of a Scottish coalfield [david.jones@bg-group.com; ENERGY PROCEDIA, 2011, Vol.4,2150-2156]. Research on horizontal well applications for CO2-ECBM led to two new EU funded projects [RFCR-CT-2010-00002; FP7- ENERGY.2010.5&6.2-1/268194] involving coalfields in Slovenia, Spain, Slovakia, China and India with a total value of €6.1M led by the authors.

Title: Phase Behavior of Off-Critical A/B/A-C Blends
AdditionalInformation: Publication demonstrates engineering of nanostructured polyolefin block-copolymer composites, introduces novel analysis for architecture and thermodynamics, and develops an accurate predictive model for nanostructure. Data treatment has been incorporated into the open access tool NIST analysis package and the modeling technique has been adopted by others doi:10.1021/jp3020172,,10.1016/j.polymer.2011.10.039 Chinese Academy of Sciences). Stable nanostructures were produced over 80% of all possible feedstock compositions, directly leading Dow Chemicals to dedicate a commercialisation research project (contact Tom Kalantar, THKalantar@dow.com) and continuing research. Follow-up funding by Royal Society research grant (RG110374/£14860).

Title: The cost of offshore wind: Understanding the past and projecting the future
AdditionalInformation: This paper explains why the cost of offshore wind rose when expected to fall. It models and disaggregates drivers of costs. The paper was pre-published as UKERC policy report (http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/support/tiki-index.php?page=Great+Expectations:+The+cost+of+offshore+wind+in+UK+waters), cited by Committee on Climate Change ‘4th Carbon Budget’ 2010. The paper was used by Dr Gross when Specialist Advisor to the Energy and Climate Change Select Committee’s pre-legislative scrutiny of draft Energy Bill, a key part of the legislative process (http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmselect/cmenergy/275/27502.htm).  Gross helped write this report. The paper informs the Committee’s discussion of strike prices for renewables. Laura Sandys MP can verify Gross’s role for the Committee. laura@sandys.org.

Title: Estimating bio-energy resource potentials to 2050: learning from experience
AdditionalInformation: Research requested by DECC and the Committee on Climate Change led to this paper and 3 linked UKERC reports (http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/support/tiki-index.php?page_ref_id=3026). The paper is ground breaking in breadth and substantially improves understanding of the global role of bio-energy, providing a meta-analysis of why estimates of bio-energy differ. The work was pre-published as UKERC reports cited by the 2010 CCC Bioenergy Review, 2012 UK Bioenergy Strategy, and Parliamentary Office on Science and Technology POSTNOTE, 410, 2013. The paper informed evidence to the Energy and Climate Change Select Committee. Adrian Gault, Chief Economist, (Adrian.gault@theccc.gov.uk.), can verify the importance of the work.

Title: Intermittent renewable generation and maintaining power system reliability
AdditionalInformation: This paper won the IET Premium award 2009 (http://conferences.theiet.org/achievement/-documents/brochure-2009.cfm). It provides a conceptual framework for accounting for the contribution of intermittent wind to capacity margin, providing a simple engineering/economic model of the cost of maintaining system margin. The paper resolves confusion surrounding accounting for the systems cost of intermittency, advancing the intellectual/policy debate. It describes a method that was developed for use in an earlier report (http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/support/Intermittency). The report was cited in 3 Government reports and a House of Lords enquiry. Adrian Gault, Chief Economist, Committee on Climate Change, can verify the importance of the work to policy. Adrian.gault@theccc.gov.uk.

Title: Risks, revenues and investment in electricity generation: Why policy needs to look beyond costs
AdditionalInformation: This paper contributed to a major shift in energy policy. It explains why wholesale market risk undermines investment in such plant, hence why fixed price contracts (key to the Energy Bill) may be more economically efficient. Gross interacted extensively with policymakers whilst undertaking the UKERC research for the paper and presented his analysis to officials in government and Committee on Climate Change (CCC). A conference paper was also presented at a high level policymaker/academic conference in Oxford in 2008. Subsequent policy changes closely mirror the arguments in this paper. Adrian Gault, Chief Economist-CCC, (Adrian.gault@theccc.gov.uk.), can verify Gross’s influence on policymaking.

Title: Synthesis of high aspect ratio titanate nanotubes
AdditionalInformation: The use of nanostructured oxides as catalyst supports for metal nanoparticle is a rapid growth area. This paper demonstrates control of the aspect ratio of titanate nanotubes through improved hydrothermal processing. It is the first publication from on-going research into the application of nanostructured oxides to catalytic processes for oxidation of hydrocarbons and bio-derived alcohols. This has produced a patent application (WO/2011/051643A1), presentation at EuropacatIX (Salamanca, Spain 2009), further publications (Applied Catalysis B 132(2013)116-122; J. Memb. Sci., 405-406(2012)30-37), and a new project (value £200,000) in the KACST-Oxford Petrochemicals Research Centre (contact: Prof. Peter Edwards, FRS; peter.edwards@chem.ox.ac.uk).

Title: Kinetics of Heterogeneous Catalytic Epoxidation of Propene with Hydrogen Peroxide over Titanium Silicalite (TS-1)
AdditionalInformation: Development of “green” selective oxidation processes using air or hydrogen peroxide is essential for the future chemicals industry. The paper reports a rigorous study of the reaction kinetics of propene epoxidation which discovered an inhibition effect of the solvent under mild conditions. This was exploited to discriminate between mechanistically based rate equations. Presentations were made on propylene oxide production in narrow channel reactors at WCCE8 (Montreal, Canada, August 2009, ISCRE21 (Philadelphia, USA, June 2010), ECCE7 (Prague, Czech Republic, August 2010), and selective oxidation research continued under the Glycerol Challenge (TP N0062B, Technology Strategy Board).

Title: Single-stage oxychlorination of ethanol to ethylene dichloride using a dual-catalyst bed
AdditionalInformation: The use of bio-derived ethanol as a replacement in current ethylene based chemical processes requires efficient dehydration. The paper reports a new catalytic process which couples dehydration and oxychlorination in an unexpected reaction pathway to produce ethylene dichloride, one of the largest scale petrochemical intermediates, used to make PVC. This is the first academic work in the area. A process flowsheet was developed showing the viability in collaboration with Ineos under a TSB programme (TP/16307). Further work showed how a balanced process from ethanol could also be developed (contact: Graham N. Rice, graham.rice@ineos.com).

Title: One-step dehydration and isomerisation of n-butanol to iso-butene over zeolite catalysts.
AdditionalInformation: Development of sustainable chemical processes is a 21st century challenge. This paper introduces original new processes for production of large-scale petrochemical intermediates from bio-derived feedstocks. In collaboration with BP (contact: M. Atkins, martin.atkins@uk.bp.com), the shape selectivity offered by the channel structure of zeolites was exploited to achieve one-step conversion to isobutene, a major intermediate in polyolefin manufacture. Three patent applications (WO2009/074798; WO2009/074801; WO2009/074804) and a follow up paper (Applied Catalysis A 403(2011)1-11) were produced. The work led directly to research on conversion of glycerol to chemicals (Applied Catalysis A 400(2011)148-155) in the Glycerol Challenge (TP N0062B, Technology Strategy Board).

Title: The online use of first-principles models in process operations: Review, current status and future needs
AdditionalInformation: Despite its theoretical advantages, current use of first-principles models (FPMs) in online process operations is limited. This paper argues that complex online applications need to be based not on a single FPM (as has been attempted unsuccessfully in the past) but on a range of models differing in scope and degree of detail, all being derived automatically and in real-time from the same “master” FPM via formal model transformations. These concepts underpinned patent applications UK 1200547.6 (2012) and PCT/GB2013/050038 (2013). The paper formed the basis of an invited plenary presentation at the prestigious 2012 Chemical Process Control conference (Savannah, GA).

Title: Efficient Handling of Molecular Flexibility in Lattice Energy Minimization of Organic Crystals
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation
AdditionalInformation: This is a breakthrough in ab initio prediction of the structures of crystals formed by the large, flexible molecules that occur in the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries, which were too complex for earlier methods. The paper led to invitations to present plenary lectures in the Pharmaceutical Division of the AIChE annual meeting (2012) and at the inaugural Future Innovations in Process Systems Engineering conference (Olympia, Greece, 2012). The codes described in the paper are now used at UCL (s.l.price@ucl.ac.uk) and the University of Innsbruck (doris.braun@uibk.ac.at), and played an important role in the award of EPSRC platform grant EP/J014958/1 (£1.53m).

Title: Successful prediction of a model pharmaceutical in the fifth blind test of crystal structure prediction.
AdditionalInformation: This striking demonstration of the results of our recent research on the prediction of structures of crystals formed by organic molecules was achieved in the context of the independently organised and verified 2010 Blind Test on Crystal Structure Prediction (Acta Crystallographica, B67, 535 2011). Our techniques achieved a completely ab initio accurate prediction for "Molecule XX", the largest molecule ever considered under blind test conditions. This was one of only two correct predictions out of the 14 submissions from the world's top groups in this area; the other one (U. Cambridge) was obtained also partly using our algorithms.

Title: Effect of Deuterium Substitution on the Physical Properties of Polymer Melts and Blends
AdditionalInformation: Part of an on-going collaboration, successfully applying a new, simple equation of state to interpret experimental data from polymer blends thus increasing fundamental understanding of equilibrium and  phase separation.  Neutron scattering provides key information, but hydrogen-deuterium substitution in one component affects phase behaviour in some extensively-studied blends. New understanding from the equation of state allows this to be quantified and potentially predicted for new blends. The work was reported in 2011 in Brisbane, Sydney, Perth and Melbourne by Higgins as the Selby Lecturer of the Australian Academy of Sciences, and prompted a consultancy with Merck in 2012. (E-mail contact Gareth_pearce@merck.com)

Title: The measurement of heat transfer from hot surfaces to non-wetting droplets
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: In a postulated accident sequence in a water-cooled nuclear reactor, water is injected to cool the fuel which becomes hot after a Loss-Of-Coolant Accident. When droplets of water impinge on a very hot surface, the drops do not wet the surface but tend to rebound. In this paper unique infra-red techniques were developed to measure the amount of heat extracted in these crucial drop-hot wall interactions. The success of this work has contributed to extensive support for nuclear projects at Imperial College, including from Rolls Royce under one of their University Technical Centres (contact Jon.Downing@Rolls-Royce.com).

Title: Modelling and explicit model predictive control for PEM fuel cell systems
AdditionalInformation: Our patented model based advanced control technology is detailed here in the design of novel multi-parametric programming controllers for integrated fuel cell energy systems, where their superiority is shown especially under varying conditions. The research is part of international collaborations with experimental validation in Seville [Professor Carlos Bordons bordons@esi.us.es], CERTH [Dr. Voutetakis paris@cperi.certh.gr] and recently our own laboratory at Imperial. The research has been presented at plenary lectures and was pivotal for the main author to be elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in July 2013 [http://www.raeng.org.uk/about/fellowship/new_fellows_biogs/2013/Professor_Stratos_PISTIKOPOULOS.htm]

Title: A Multi-Objective Optimization Approach to Polygeneration Energy Systems Design
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel complete systems methodology for the holistic design optimization of poly-generation energy systems, based on which  future energy scenarios can be systematically analyzed in terms of energy efficiency, cost, and environmental impact under uncertain conditions and risk. The research is part of our energy systems engineering research vision and programme, presented at plenary lectures [PSE Asia 2013 [http://www.cheme.utm.my/pseasia2013/, ECCE-6], featured in review articles [I&ECR] and special issues [Energy & CACE journals] and led to new funding [EPSRC EP/GO59071/1 and EU PIRSES-GA-2011-294987].

Title: Multi-objective blood glucose control for type 1 diabetes.
AdditionalInformation: This paper establishes for the first time the closed loop implementation of our developed explicit/multi-parametric controllers as a preferred choice for optimal drug delivery of insulin within the artificial pancreas concept. The research led to a prestigious European Research Council [ERC] Advanced Investigator’s Award [Grant No226462 – MOBILE, http://sites.google.com/site/imperialercmobile/], exploited in two other biomedical systems [anaesthesia and leukaemia] and presented in plenary lectures [Benelux 2011, ICCAS 2012 http://2012.iccas.org/program/plenary.asp and PSE Asia 2013 http://www.cheme.utm.my/pseasia2013/].

Title: Explicit/multi-parametric model predictive control (MPC) of linear discrete-time systems by dynamic and multi-parametric programming
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents novel theory and algorithms for deriving explicit solutions of Model Predictive Control (MPC) problems by multi-parametric programming, that avoids the repetitive solution of an on-line optimization problem and enables for the first time the delivery of MPC on a cheap chip [patents - EP1399784, US733743]. This research has led to new funding by EPSRC [EP/IO1460/1], to plenary lectures including FOCAPO 2012 [http://focapo.cheme.cmu.edu/2012/index.html], the 2009 Bayer Lecture in Process Systems Engineering at CMU and the 2012 Computing Award in Chemical Engineering of the Computing and Systems Technology (CAST) Division of the AIChE [http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/newsandeventspggrp/imperialcollege/engineering/chemicalengineering/newssummary/news_21-6-2012-11-59-28]

Title: High flux membranes for organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN)-Interfacial polymerization with solvent activation
AdditionalInformation: The discovery of solvent activation which dramatically enhances permeance of thin film composite (TFC) membranes formed by interfacial polymerisation is reported in this paper. Aggressive solvents are used to remove partially reacted material, which is possible because the thin film is formed on a solvent stable support. The discovery was filed as PCT/GB2011/051364, subsequently licensed to Evonik MET Ltd (yuri.bouwhuis@evonik.com). The expertise in TFC membranes deriving from this work was key in securing a £2.553M project into the fundamental performance of TFC membranes from the BP International Centre for Advanced Materials (PI AGL, start 1 Oct 2012; robert.sorrell@uk.bp.com).

Title: Controlling molecular weight cut-off curves for highly solvent stable organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN) membranes
AdditionalInformation: For the first time a single polymer is used to produce a range of organic solvent nanofiltration membranes, with varying nanometre-scale permeation pathways. The innovations are covered in UK Patent No GB2437519 and related international family (PCT/GB2007/050218). The now commercially available DuramemTM range of organic solvent nanofiltration membranes (http://duramem.evonik.com/; contact: andrew.boam@evonik.com) is based on the fundamental discoveries outlined in the paper. This work was presented in a keynote lecture at Euromembrane 2009 (Montpelier, FR, Sept 2009), and the translation of the research into the DuramemTM series was recognised when Livingston won the Royal Academy of Engineering Silver Medal in 2009.

Title: The effect of membrane formation parameters on performance of polyimide membranes for organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN): Part A. Effect of polymer/solvent/non-solvent system choice
AdditionalInformation: What controls the permeation of molecules through integrally skinned asymmetric membranes? This paper is one of a series of three papers (including Parts A-C) which seek an answer. The findings have been presented as a Plenary Lecture at the North American Membrane Society (NAMS) (New Orleans, June 2012), and as an invited talk at the Gordon Conference on Membranes (Manchester, NH, USA, July 2012). The work has established the team at Imperial at the forefront of research in membrane fabrications and has been key in winning a platform grant renewal (EP/J014974/£1.289M; PI:AGL).

Title: Organic solvent nanofiltration and adsorbents; A hybrid approach to achieve ultra low palladium contamination of post coupling reaction products
AdditionalInformation: Removal of residual palladium from post-reaction mixtures is a key purification challenge for homogeneous catalysis, addressed in this paper. The unique insight is that the hybrid system is highly effective because the two different techniques remove different ends of the Pd nanoparticle size distribution. Led to EPSRC/EPG070172/£617k..Presentation as invited lecture at ACS Prospectives conference (2009, Rayliegh NC) led to a collaboration with the Department of Chemical Engineering at MIT, and to Imperial joining the Novartis-MIT Centre for Continuous Manufacturing project as a funded (sub-award for USD1.5M over five years) partner (MIT - Klavs F Jensen kfjensen@MIT.EDU; Novartis:  berthold.schenkel@novartis.com ).

Title: Protein Crystallization by Forced Flow through Glass Capillaries: Enhanced Lysozyme Crystal Growth
AdditionalInformation: Crystallising proteins is a potentially cost effective route for the manufacture of commercial biopharmaceuticals. Proteins crystallised within a capillary under variable protein solution flow conditions resulted in a 75-fold concentration of crystal mass increase relative to a sealed batch crystallisation.   This method offers promise for growing large protein crystals for use in structure determinations or for the manufacture of protein therapeutics. The work led to a BBSRC Pathfinder Award BB/FOF/PF/13/08(£30k),an invited presentation at 18th International Symposium on Industrial Crystallization in Zurich in 2011, and formed the basis of a pending European patent application 10718256.0

Title: Role of Surface Chemistry and Energetics in High Shear Wet Granulation
AdditionalInformation: Many fundamental aspects of the high shear wet granulation of powders are not understood. This paper established the importance of powder hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity on the final granule properties. This work was presented by invitation to the 14th International Workshop on Solid-State Characterization of Pharmaceutical Solids (Barcelona, June 2012), IChem.E PTSG Workshop (Newcastle, September 2013) and the 2013 UK-China Particle Technology Forum IV in Shanghai.  The paper also led to a new BBSRC CASE Studentship (BB/J012319/1/£155k) with P&G (Dr. Zayeed Alam alam.z@pg.com) on bioadhesion/cleaning of complex bio-solids and a successful invitation to request research funds ($108k over 3 years) from IFPRI(www.ifpri.net/).

Title: Crystallization of Proteins at Ultralow Supersaturations Using Novel Three-Dimensional Nanotemplates
AdditionalInformation: Nano-templates with specifically engineered pores sizes for known proteins resulted in crystallisation occurring at concentrations 3-10 times lower than previously reported. The successful approach demonstrated here runs counter to current practise of using nucleants with polydispersed pore size distributions.  Currently in confidential commercial discussions with 3 UK biopharmaceutical companies (Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies john.liddell@fujifilmdb.com; UCB; Novozyme) where these nucleants could be used for direct industrial crystallisation from bio-reactor broths.  EPSRC Centre at UCL is funding a feasibility study (£25k) in Imperial Chem Eng using monoclonal anti-body worth £50k being provided by Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies.

Title: Inverse gas chromatographic method for measuring the dispersive surface energy distribution for particulates.
AdditionalInformation: Surface energy information is critical to many particle processing operations eg powder flow, agglomeration. This paper demonstrates a new statistically based experimental approach to surface energy measurement.  The methodology is now adopted in current commercial inverse gas chromatography instruments (www.thesorptionsolution.com/Products_IGC.php) and is used by 50 industrial/academic research groups worldwide. This paper resulted in invited contributions to the 8th International Symposium on Contact Angle, Wetting, Adhesion (2012) and the TAC 2013 Conference, “Modern Thermal Methods from an Industrial and Academic Perspective". It also resulted in 2 studentships being supported in the Department by Surface Measurement Systems Ltd  including an EPSRC/CASE Studentship.

Title: Interfacial Tension of (Brines+CO2): CaCl2(aq), MgCl2(aq), and Na2SO4(aq) at Temperatures between (343 and 423) K, Pressures between (2 and 50) MPa, and Molalities of (0.5 to 5) mol.kg-1
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data
AdditionalInformation: This is the first comprehensive study of interfacial tension between CO2 and concentrated brines under reservoir conditions. The experimental data, gathered using bespoke apparatus developed in JPMT’s laboratory, are being exploited by Shell in reservoir simulation work related to CO2 injection into saline aquifers (contact: Dr Claus Otto, Shell Global Solutions, Email: claus.otto.@shell.com). This study helped secure a further £1.0M funding from Qatar Petroleum and Shell (project CENRE PS7864) and led to an invitation to present a keynote lecture at the 5th International Symposium on New Frontiers of Thermal Studies of Materials, Yokohama, Japan (2013).

Title: Measurement and modeling of the phase behavior of the (carbon dioxide plus water) mixture at temperatures from 298.15 K to 448.15 K
AdditionalInformation: Knowledge of the phase behaviour of CO2 with water/brines is critical in predicting the long-term fate of CO2 sequestered in deep saline aquifers. This paper reports a fundamental experimental and modelling study of the subject, covering for the first time the entire temperature-pressure space of interest. The work is being exploited by Shell as part of the evidence base to support proposed CO2 sequestration in middle-eastern aquifers (contact: Dr Claus Otto, Shell Global Solutions, Email: claus.otto.@shell.com). The study has helped secure £1.1M funding from Qatar Petroleum and Shell for further research in this area (project CENRE PS7863).

Title: Thermodynamic properties and equation of state of liquid di-isodecyl phthalate at temperature between (273 and 423) K and at pressures up to 140 MPa
AdditionalInformation: Di-isodecyl phthalate has been proposed as a reference fluid for the calibration of industrial viscometers. This paper reports a comprehensive study of the thermodynamic properties of this liquid, unique in terms of the number of properties and the wide ranges of temperature and pressure investigated. Additionally, a novel fundamental equation of state is reported. The results were essential input for a subsequent experimental and modelling study of the viscosity of the liquid over similar ranges of pressure and temperature (see doi:10.1021/je101256z). For industrial context and impact consult Dr Anthony Goodwin (Schlumberger Technology Corporation, Email:agoodwin@slb.com).

Title: Viscosity and Density of Five Hydrocarbon Liquids at Pressures up to 200 MPa and Temperatures up to 473 K
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data
AdditionalInformation: This article describes a state-of-the-art experimental facility for measuring the viscosity and density of fluids under extreme conditions of temperature and pressure. Experimental results are presented for five hydrocarbon liquids of various molecular architectures and the viscosity data were modelled with a theoretically-based approach. These results have since been used by other researchers (e.g. the US DOE National Energy Technology Laboratory doi:10.1021/ie301727k) to help develop predictive models for thermophysical properties. This paper resulted in an invitation to present a keynote lecture on viscosity measurement and modelling at the 24th European Seminar on Applied Thermodynamics, Santiago de Compostela, Spain (2009).

Title: Integrated model of the production of soluble microbial products (SMP) and extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) in anaerobic chemostats during transient conditions
AdditionalInformation: A seminal contribution to our work on the production, characterisation and removal of SMPs in anaerobic systems. This complex dynamic model for the production and removal of SMPs in anaerobic systems crucially treated SMPs and ECPs as separate components. Mennetti and Morgenroth (Wat. Res., 2010, 44, 5240) showed our model to be significantly more accurate than previous models. This major body of work was recently (2012) awarded the “Sustainable Water” Prize by the Royal Society of Chemistry, with invited lectures in Hull, Newcastle and Bristol.

Title: Flux and performance improvement in a submerged anaerobic membrane bioreactor (SAMBR) using powdered activated carbon (PAC)
AdditionalInformation: This examined two areas never combined before; anaerobic membrane bioreactors, and powdered activated carbon (PAC).
