The work in this paper led to Keynote invitations to speak at the IWA Leading Edge Technology conference in Brisbane (June 2012), an RSC organised seminar at GE-China in Shanghai (April 2012), and at the International conference on “Recovery of Value-added Products” (Waterloo, August 2012). Recently, this work led indirectly to a BBSRC LoLa award (with 3 other UK Universities-BB/K003240/1 Engineering Synthetic Microbial Communities for Biomethane Production-Total £4mil, IC-£450K) on improving methane yields using bioaugmentation in anaerobic membrane reactors.

Title: Continuous treatment of the organic fraction of municipal solid waste in an anaerobic two-stage membrane process with liquid recycle
AdditionalInformation: This paper developed the new idea of continuous recycle of leachate from municipal solid waste (MSW) digestion through sequential anaerobic membrane bioreactors, and contributes to the UK renewable energy thrust to generate energy from residues. This technology was awarded the Royal Society Brian Mercer Innovation Award (2008-£250K) to build a anaerobic membrane pilot plant in collaboration with Black and Veatch (B&V) and Anglian Water (Head of Innovations, S. Kaye- skaye@anglianwater.co.uk). This work also led to an appointment at Nanyang Environment and Water Research Institute at NTU in Singapore as a Visiting Professor to further develop this technology

Title: Are compatible solutes compatible with biological treatment of saline wastewater? Batch and continuous studies using submerged anaerobic membrane bioreactors (SAMBRs).
AdditionalInformation: This paper published with international collaboration (NMR measurements by Prof Santos, U. Nova Lisboa, Portugal), investigated the new concept of adapting cultures to treating high salinity wastewaters by adding an osmoprotectant (compatible solute). This work led to invitations to Keynote speeches at the 11th Latin American AD meeting (October, 2011, Ouro Preto, Brazil), and recently to a Keynote at the 2nd International conference on “Recovery of Value-added Products” (Seoul, June 2013), and the 7th “Distinguished Speaker” at the “Anaerobic treatment short course” in Marquette University, Milwaukee which invites International leaders in this field to teach a short course (September, 2013).

Title: Novel anticorrelation criteria for model-based experiment design: Theory and formulations
AdditionalInformation:
Design-of-Experiments (DOE) based on black-box sampling is 50 years old and includes Macchietto’s pioneering use of deterministic, dynamic models. However all this previous work used “classic” objective functions. This paper presents new understanding of design objectives and constraints, enables the versatile tailoring of problem formulations to problems, and results in more robust solutions with applications in Engineering (DOI=10.1021/ie400133m), Process Control (DOI= 10.1016/j.jprocont.2011.12.004)  and Biology (DOI=10.1016/j.ces.2012.05.002) .  It resulted in prestigious keynotes including the opening lecture at the Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences, Cambridge (http://www.newton.ac.uk/programmes/DAE/index.html 
http://www.newton.ac.uk/programmes/DAE/seminars/2011071811301.html  ) and closing lecture at the 1st Aachen Conference on Computational Engineering Science (http://www.acces11.rwth-aachen.de/MainContents/KeynoteLect.php).

Title: Refinery Pre-Heat Train Network Simulation Undergoing Fouling: Assessment of Energy Efficiency and Carbon Emissions
AdditionalInformation: Refining energy losses represent 6% of worldwide oil production, and 2.5% man-made CO2 emission. This work uses a novel thermo-hydraulic heat-exchanger model to simulate in unprecedented detail technical, energy, emissions and economic performance of complex energy recovery networks. It  indicated that 15% savings could be achieved, leading to the establishment of a UK-Russian Applied Research Centre (http://www.uniheat-project.com )  with £9.3m funding (SkolkovoFoundation-BP (http://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/press/press-releases/bp-skolkovo-foundation-boreskov-institute-and-imperial-college-london-to-work-together-on-energy-efficiency-research-programme.html ). Launched with UKTI at the IOD (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gYzx1Q2Mv4Y ) by David Peatty, then BP-Russia CEO and Charles Cameron, BP Head-Research&Technology it generated worldwide business attention(http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-21/bp-to-set-up-energy-efficiency-research-with-russia-s-skolkovo.html http://www.globalenergyworld.com/news/3075/BP_Russia_and_partners_to_Work_on_GBP_93_M_Energy_Efficiency_Research_Programme.htm   and technology transfer workshops with leading industry groups  https://www.gov.uk/government/world-location-news/global-leaders-in-russia-meet-on-energy-efficiency-sustainable-environment, http://www.uniheat-project.com/news/annual-conference-12th-september-2013-moscow

Title: Optimal Design of Clinical Tests for the Identification of Physiological Models of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a model-based method for personalised medical treatment for Type-1 Diabetes, improving identification of individual subject’s characteristics, their response to glucose and insulin treatment, and the design of optimal identification protocols. Initiated at Imperial, the last author utilised and transferred to Padova methods pioneered by Macchietto, gaining an Assistant Professorship. The first author, based on the work at Imperial, has been offered a position at UCL (v.dua@ucl.ac.uk). The approach’s potential for providing safer, faster, more effective protocols for tailoring diabetes treatment to individual subjects has been highlighted in an authoritative systems-biology review series (DOI=10.1002/wsbm.1204) and biomedical research (DOI=10.1109/tbme.2011.2176939).

Title: A Dynamic, Distributed Model of Shell-and-Tube Heat Exchangers Undergoing Crude Oil Fouling
AdditionalInformation: Refining energy losses represent 6% of worldwide oil energy with fouling responsible for 50% and 2.5% of global CO2 emissions. This fundamental model provides a significant advantage in predictive ability above previous methods and enables reduction of energy losses/emissions through better equipment design/retrofit, energy integration and operations planning. Validated with Exxon and Shell (http://heatexchanger-fouling.com/papers/papers2009/9_Coletti_Macchietto_F.pdf ), developed with industry collaborators representing 70% of world refining capacity(http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01457632.2010.495579 ) this technology and related patent WO2012131281-A1 (http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/newsandeventspggrp/imperialcollege/newssummary/news_21-2-2013-15-59-9 ) were licenced to Hexxcell Ltd (www.hexxcell.com ), a new spinoff launched 2011, operational 2013.

Title: Limitations of size-exclusion chromatography in analyzing petroleum asphaltenes: A proof by atomic force Microscopy
AdditionalInformation: The unique challenge addressed in this paper was how to take Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), established in physics and chemistry, and apply it to oil field problems.  A consequence of this work was an extended study of oilfield related AFM publications through collaboration with Dr Aziz Al-Hashmi in Oman, azizra@squ.edu.om. Additionally the work led to a plenary presentation at 20th  CSCST-SCI, London September 2013 http://conference2013.cscst.org/, a keynote lecture at the “Characterisation Instrumentation for Formulation” seminar June 2011 http://www.connectyorkshire.org/?page=Event&itemid=291908, and a  keynote lecture at the meeting “New Frontiers in Colloid Science” London 2008 http://www.certh.gr/dat/019BBD7B/file.pdf.

Title: Towards rationalising collapse times for the delayed sedimentation of weakly-aggregated colloidal gels
Development of lysolipid-based thermosensitive liposomes for delivery of high molecular weight proteins.
AdditionalInformation:
This paper is the first reported paper where proteins have been released from thermo-sensitive liposomes. It is likely that technology based on this paper will be used for the controlled release of bio-pharmaceutics. 
Based on the work presented in this paper we have received a Grant of £50,000 from National Institute for Health Research Imperial College's Therapeutic Primer fund (http://imperialbrc.org/node/866) which recognises potentially patentable and commercially exploitable technology in the medical field, specifically to study the encapsulation and release of thrombolytic proteins. This work has gone well and publications and a patent will be forthcoming.

Title: Surface tension-induced gel fracture. Part 1. Fracture of agar gels.
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the intriguing phenomenon of gel fracture by the addition of dilute surfactant solutions, a very recently discovered effect. It involved international collaboration with the Aristotle University in Thessaloniki in Greece, Dr Goudoulas.  Based on this work PFL was asked to give a keynote lecture at the Joseph Kitchener memorial symposium in London July 2010. Work has led to discussion with Prof Karen Daniels NCSU kdaniel@ncsu.edu who has developed a theory to explain the growth of these films http://meeting.aps.org/Meeting/DFD12/Session/G19.2.  Extension of this work to gelatine films has also been published LANGMUIR (2012)  28  8017-8025   DOI: 10.1021/la205165q

Title: Interfacial Tension of (Brines + CO2): (0.864 NaCl+0.136 KCl) at Temperatures between (298 and 448) K, Pressures between (2 and 50) MPa, and Total Molalities of (1 to 5) mol.kg(-1)
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data
AdditionalInformation: This research, within the Qatar CCS Research Centre,  provided some of the first high temperature/pressure interfacial tension data on supercritical CO2 interacting with brines typical of deep saline aquifers, the most widespread of sites suitable for future underground storage of CO2.  The models developed from these data can be applied to field brines as an essential part of the design and optimisation of such processes - CO2 injection, fluid plume development and dissolution.  Equipment, models and people have been transferred to Qatar Petroleum's new Doha research laboratory for investigation of Qatari reservoir fluids and design of field demonstration projects (saad@qp.com.qa).

Title: Viscosity and Density of Carbon Dioxide+2,6,10,15,19,23-Hexamethyltetracosane (Squalane)
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data
AdditionalInformation: This was one of the first studies of the effect of (supercritical) CO2 on the viscosity and density of a relatively viscous hydrocarbon, squalane (acting as an analogue of a heavy crude oil) under high temperature/pressure reservoir conditions.  The major changes observed have significant implications for the design of enhanced oil recovery and CO2 underground storage processes.  This and related work led to major long-term sponsorship by Shell and Qatar Petroleum ($75M, 10 years) of a research centre (Director: GCM) studying the underpinning science/engineering of such processes, including the measurement and modelling of CO2-real reservoir fluids thermophysical properties (sabeur.mansar@shell.com).

Title: Interfacial tension measurements and modelling of (carbon dioxide plus n-alkane) and (carbon dioxide plus water) binary mixtures at elevated pressures and temperatures
AdditionalInformation: One of four papers to emerge from the Shell Grand Challenge Programme on Clean Fossil Fuels (£3M, 2006-11), addressing the dearth of interfacial tension (IFT) and other thermophysical property data for supercritical CO2 with hydrocarbons/water/brines under high temperature/pressure reservoir conditions, essential for the design of CO2 EOR and CCS processes. Molecular equations of state, calibrated only on VLE data, were capable of predicting IFT to within experimental error.  The data, experimental techniques and predictive models have been adopted and exploited by our sponsors Shell for optimising these processes in sandstone reservoirs (claus.otto@shell.com)

Title: Rheology modification in mixed shape colloidal dispersions. Part II: mixtures
AdditionalInformation: Part of a trilogy of papers explaining for the first time the major changes in the gelation and flow properties of clay dispersions by the addition of ~10% of a smaller colloid of different shape, providing design rules for fluid manipulation. Has major implications for new/improved industrial gels such as drilling fluids and personal products using low-cost, widely available raw materials.  Schlumberger M-I Drilling Fluids (atehrani@miswaco.slb.com) are actively pursuing this approach for enhanced oilfield fluids.  This and related drilling work contributed to GCM receiving the 2010 IChemE ChemEnvoy and 2012 SCI/RSC Rideal Awards.

Title: Pressure-driven miscible two-fluid channel flow with density gradients
AdditionalInformation: This is a direct numerical simulation of the effect of buoyancy on pressure-driven flow of two miscible fluids in inclined channels at moderate to large Reynolds numbers. The results elucidate the mechanisms underlying mixing as a function of the density and viscosity ratios, and channel inclinations. This paper led to industrial funding of over £500k since 2012 from multi-national companies (P&G [alam.z@pg.com], BP, Chevron [lee.rhyne@chevron.com], Petrobras, Statoil, Total, FMC, MSi Kenny, Intecsea). It also led to an invitation to present a keynote at the Multiphase Flow and Transport Phenomena international conference in Agadir 2012.

Title: Linear stability analysis and numerical simulation of miscible two-layer channel flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a generalised stability analysis and full numerical simulations of fast two-fluid, miscible channel flows, with applications to foulant removal for fast-moving consumer goods. The costs of cleaning in the UK household care, cosmetics and toiletries, and food and drink industries were estimated to be between £0.7-0.8 billion per annum (DTI, 2006). This paper led to OKM being awarded a £5M EPSRC Programme Grant (EP/K003976/1) to develop the next-generation predictive tools for multiphase flows. Seven articles resulted from this paper between 2009-12, published in journals such as Phys. Fluids, Chem. Eng. Sci., and Int. J. Multiphase Flow.

Title: Pinning, Retraction, and Terracing of Evaporating Droplets Containing Nanoparticles
AdditionalInformation: Here, we present the first rigorous model coupling the appropriate nanoparticulate physics with wetting, heat transfer, moving contact lines, and phase change. The results and associated understanding of the fundamental physical mechanisms can be used for the development of reliable numerical codes that simulate boiling heat transfer with nanofluids, of central importance to the nuclear industry (rewetting of rods to prevent melt-down). This paper was published in Langmuir and has led to three keynote presentations (UK Heat Transfer conference, 2009; 9th and 10th international conferences on nanochannels, microchannels, and minichannels, 2011 [Edmonton], and 2012 [Puerto Rico]).

Title: On surfactant-enhanced spreading and superspreading of liquid drops on solid surfaces
AdditionalInformation: 'Superspreading' has fascinated researchers since the 80s; its resolution is of importance to coating flow technology. It was unclear what led certain surfactants to drive extraordinarily rapid spreading of liquids in non-wetting situations to perfect wetting. We identified the mechanism underlying the superspreading process in this paper published in the Journal of Fluid mechanics, and highlighted in its "Focus on Fluids" feature. It has led to 8 invited talks (including keynotes at the Fields Institute, Toronto, 2012; MMT2012, Israel, 2012; ECCOMAS2012, Vienna, 2012), and funded  EPSRC grant ([EP/J010502/£700K] with OKM as PI).

Title: Discrete element simulation of particle flow in arbitrarily complex geometries
AdditionalInformation: A novel algorithm for detecting particle-surface interactions in complex geometries is presented in this paper. Based on this algorithm (RIGID), a new discrete element method (DEM) solver has been developed and implemented into an open source code. It has attracted many enquiries so far, driving us to prepare for the release of an updated version (RIGID-II).  The code is expected to significantly increase the use of DEM for industrial problems. An example of such application is to predict the mixing of biomass suspensions in bioreactors as part of a BBSRC funded project on the production of fuels from lignocelluloses (BB/I00534X/£675K).

Title: High levels of 18F-FDG uptake in aortic aneurysm wall are associated with high wall stress.
VolumeTitle: European Journal of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the first observations pointing to a potential link between high wall stress and accelerated metabolism in aortic aneurysm wall. It’s the outcome of an interdisciplinary collaboration between XYX group and a clinical team in Liege, Belgium. The computational model employed in this study was presented in an invited lecture at Artery 9 (Cambridge, UK, Sept 2009). The method has been further developed to evaluate the performance of endovascular stent graft in abdominal aortic aneurysms of different anatomical features (David Stevenson, Head of Design – Endovascular, Vascutek Ltd).

Title: Nitric oxide transport in an axisymmetric stenosis
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a mathematical model for the transport of nitric oxide (NO) in an arterial stenosis model. The novel contribution is that it provides theoretical evidence for hindered NO transport in regions of disturbed flow. This study was designed and completed under XYX’s guidance when the first author (PhD student at Beihang University) visited Imperial in 2011. This work has led to new collaborations with Beihang (sponsored by the Chinese Natural Science Funding Council, 11228205). It has also provided a platform for modelling drug transport in solid tumours as part of an EPSRC Healthcare Partnership grant (EP/I001700/£1.26M).

Title: Effects of elastic compression stockings on wall shear stress in deep and superficial veins of the calf.
VolumeTitle: American Journal of Physiology - Heart and Circulatory Physiology
AdditionalInformation: Lower-limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a major health hazard for hospitalised patients, but it can also affect healthy individuals after periods of inactivity. This paper is the seminal contribution leading to a series of further papers (e.g. Medical Engineering & Physics, 2012, 34:17-27) which seek to understand the effect of compression stockings on lower limb venous haemodynamics. It reports the first quantitative data on the effectiveness of compression stockings in raising wall shear stress in deep veins in the calf, which is essential for the explanation as to why compression stockings provide clinical benefits for the prevention of DVT.

Title: Computer-aided molecular design of solvents for accelerated reaction kinetics
AdditionalInformation: The significance of this recent publication, which reports a computational approach to solvent design for reactions and provides experimental verification, was highlighted in a two-page commentary by Truhlar, a world-leading physical chemist, in Nature Chemistry News & Views (doi:10.1038/nchem.1774). Following online publication, the article was reported by Chemical & Engineering News (http://cen.acs.org/articles/91/i38/Computer-Aided-Solvent-Screening.html) and The Chemical Engineer (http://www.tcetoday.com/latest%20news/2013/september/computing%20a%20method%20for%20selecting%20solvents.aspx). The paper has already led to an invitation to discuss the work at Accelrys (Victor Milman), a leading provider of molecular modelling software. Based on the results in this paper, Syngenta (Patrick Piccione) is funding a new PhD student in this research area.

Title: A duality-based optimisation approach for the reliable solution of (P, T) phase equilibrium in volume-composition space
AdditionalInformation: This general framework for the solution of phase equilibrium combines novel theoretical results and extensive algorithmic studies. One of two guaranteed approaches to solve multicomponent multiphase equilibria for SAFT-type equations, the solution strategy is fundamentally different to the original work (Xu et al, IECR, 2002). We have since shown that our rigorous approach can be turned into a reliable and practical algorithm (Pereira et al, Comp Chem Eng, 2012, doi:10.1016/j.compchemeng.2011.07.009). CSA's EPSRC Leadership Fellowship (EP/J003840/£1,278,003), a large Pfizer grant (Senior Research Fellow) and a collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory (Sven Leyffer) build on this track record in algorithm development.

Title: Fluid phase stability and equilibrium calculations in binary mixtures Part I: Theoretical development for non-azeotropic mixtures
AdditionalInformation: How can advances in molecular thermodynamics, such as the SAFT equation of state, benefit the work of process engineers, despite their numerical complexity? This work tackles this question by combining thermodynamic insight with rigorous mathematical analysis. A reliable and fast solution for binary mixture phase equilibrium is proposed, overcoming a key issue in developing new thermodynamic models from experimental data. This fundamental work at the interface of thermodynamics and applied mathematics contributed to the award of the prestigious Leverhulme Prize for Engineering (2009, www.leverhulme.ac.uk/files/seealsodocs/339/2009.pdf) to CSA, and facilitated the transfer of the SAFT technology to PSE (Mark Matzopoulos).

Title: Integrated solvent and process design using a SAFT-VR thermodynamic description: High-pressure separation of carbon dioxide and methane
AdditionalInformation: High pressure separations have important industrial applications, but had hitherto been beyond the reach of computer-aided solvent design techniques because of the limitations of the thermodynamic models used. This paper presents a systematic approach for integrated process and solvent design at high pressure. It is the first time the powerful SAFT-VR equation of state is used for solvent design. This work has led to funding in molecular design (EPSRC Platform EP/J014958/£1,529,576; TSB/Novartis/DynamicExtraction/EP/K504099/£136,354), plenary talks at prestigious conferences (Thermodynamics 2011 (Greece), FOMMS 2012 (USA), Equifase (Chile, 2012) and participation in international research evaluation panels (e.g., Max Planck Partner Group).

Title: Prediction of binary intermolecular potential parameters for use in modelling fluid mixtures
AdditionalInformation:
The statistical associating ﬂuid theory (SAFT) represents one of the most sophisticated and successful equations of state for molecules with realistic interactions (hydrogen bonding, polarity, chain flexibility) for use in industrial applications: http://www.psenterprise.com/gproms/options/physprops/saft/data/tce_saft_feb10.pdf
One limitation of SAFT is the need for molecular parameters. In our paper we provide a reliable prediction of binary parameters in mixtures of polar molecules, augmenting the capability of SAFT. The predictive nature of SAFT is at the core of the work of our Molecular Systems Engineering activity (EPSRC EP/E016340, £3M, and Platform Grant EP/J014958, £1.5). Associated plenaries given at SciMeeting2012(Paris, 2012) and DECHEMA/ProcessNet(Würzburg, 2013).

Title: Communications: Evidence for the role of fluctuations in the thermodynamics of nanoscale drops and the implications in computations of the surface tension.
AdditionalInformation: The relationship between the pressure difference of a liquid drop and the interfacial tension was recognised by Young and Laplace in 1805. We show that this type of mechanical treatment is not appropriate for nanoscopic drops; instead large entropic contributions to the energy are found. This has important implications to classical nucleation theories where a large inaccuracy in the rate is commonly found. This work was elaborated as a perspective article [J. Phys.: Condens. Matter, 24, 464121, 2012] linked to a keynote presentation, CODEFIII Conference (Bonn, 2012), and plenary lecture, Max Planck Soft Matter Conference (Schloss Ringberg, 2013).

Title: Generalized van der Waals theory for the twist elastic modulus and helical pitch of cholesterics.
AdditionalInformation: We derive the first algebraic expressions for the density/temperature dependence of the twist elastic modulus and cholesteric pitch of liquid crystals in terms of the molecular characteristics. Chirality is ubiquitous in systems ranging from optoelectronic displays to biomolecules. The link between the microscopic features and bulk chirality is poorly understood. Our predictions help explain the recent apparently contradictory experimental findings for solutions of chiral viruses [Grelet and Fraden, Phys. Rev. Lett. 90, 198302, (2003)]. The work described in our paper was presented as keynote presentations at the British Liquid Crystal Conference (Hull, 2009), and Statistical Physics XVI Conference (Zaragoza, 2009).

Title: Classical density functional theory for the prediction of the surface tension and interfacial properties of fluids mixtures of chain molecules based on the statistical associating fluid theory for potentials of variable range.
AdditionalInformation: We develop one of the first quantitative density functional theories (DFT) for the interfacial tension, density profiles and adsorption of associating mixtures. The  SAFT-VR DFT formalism has been used subsequently to describe the interfacial properties of aqueous mixtures of carbon dioxide, amines and hydrocarbons of key relevance in oil recovery and carbon capture [Rodriguez et al., Mol. Phys. 111, 1325, 2012] providing a unified platform for thermophysical properties for post combustion carbon capture processes in amine solvents. This DFT approach is finding direct application in collaborative projects with BP (Dan.Coy@bp.com), Shell (Rick.Wentinck@shell.com), Qatar Petroleum (saad@qp.com.qa), and Scottish Power (Rhona.Peat@ScottishPower.com).

Title: Finding a needle in a chemical haystack: tip-enhanced Raman scattering for studying carbon nanotubes mixtures.
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new imaging approach that combines the high resolution of AFM and chemical information of Raman spectroscopy, thus breaking the diffraction limit of light, which is necessary for imaging nanoscale materials. It was used to differentiate carbon nanotubes of different diameters within a mixture for the first time. This research led to the award of an ERC Advanced Grant (227950, EUR 1,430, 607). The paper has been featured on http://nanotechweb.org/cws/article/lab/44149, resulted in invited lectures at European MRS Congress, France (2012), ICORS-23, India (2012) and ICAVS-7, Japan (2013) and led to further developments in this powerful methodology http://nanotechweb.org/cws/article/lab/45614

Title: FT-IR Spectroscopic Imaging of Reactions in Multiphase Flow in Microfluidic Channels.
AdditionalInformation: ATR-FTIR imaging was combined with newly designed microfluidic devices to chemically image fast segmented flows. Image acquisition times of 50 ms were achieved, a rate similar to visible video, while retaining quantitative chemical information. “Chemical movies” of evolving reactions in the moving droplets were thus demonstrated. This breakthrough offers the possibility of imaging many different reactions and processes in real time through microfluidic devices, particularly for the development of spatial distribution and separations in multiphase flows. This potential impact led to the ERC Advanced Grant and to a BRIC grant (BB/K011030/1,£226,387) and dedicated international conference hosted at Imperial College http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/vibrationalspectroscopyandchemicalimaging/news/ftirimagingconference

Title: Simultaneous FTIR spectroscopic imaging and visible photography to monitor tablet dissolution and drug release.
AdditionalInformation: Here we developed novel spectroscopic imaging to study and optimise tablet dissolution. It resulted in a series of papers where the results from the imaging datasets were incorporated into mathematical models for better prediction of tablet dissolution/drug release. This work led to industrial consultancies (BMS, BASF, AbbVie) and two Pathways to Impact fellowships. Importantly, AbbVie has been implementing this technology in their industrial practices since 2011 (gerd.woehrle@abbvie.com). This work was also presented in a plenary lecture at ICAVS-5, Melbourne (2009), an invited lecture at IUPAC Analytical Congress, Japan (2011) and by invitation at the Royal Society Science Exhibition (2010) www.ps.ic.ac.uk/vsci/arsvideo.html

Title: Chemical imaging of live cancer cells in the natural aqueous environment.
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we pioneered chemical imaging of live cancer cells in the natural aqueous environment by two novel ATR-FTIR imaging approaches, without recourse to expensive synchrotron sources. This represents a major advance since it allowed us to monitor fine chemical changes in situ with fast acquisition times, high spatial resolution and high molecular specificity provided by spectroscopic imaging. This provides a powerful method for optimisation of chemotherapy approaches. This work was presented in a plenary lecture (ICAVS-5, 2009,Australia http://monash.edu/science/about/schools/chemistry/biospec/icavs/program-thu.html), led to invited article in Analyst (http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlehtml/2013/an/c3an36865c) and at the Moscow Science Festival by invitation of the British Embassy (2011).

Title: Performance enhancement of fullerene-based solar cells by light processing.
AdditionalInformation: Interdisciplinary article involving chemists, physicists and chemical engineers, demonstrating a novel processing strategy to address a major bottleneck in organic photovoltaics: the limited lifetime of solar cells. By harnessing the photosensitivity of fullerenes, the morphology is stabilised and a 10-fold increase in lifetime achieved a benchmark system: ongoing research extends it by another order of magnitude. The work's industrial and academic impact in photovoltaics attracted Solvay (marie-beatrice.madec@solvay.com) to discuss follow-up patent applications and project funding, resulted in Institut Laue Langevin PhD studentship (2013), and invited talks at Heriot Watt and Stuttgart Universities, and APS March meeting Denver USA (2014).

Title: Patterning Polymer-Fullerene Nanocomposite Thin Films with Light
AdditionalInformation: Cover article demonstrating light-induced spatial patterning of nanocomposites, leading to enhanced film stability and directed assembly of nanoparticles into functional circuits. This attracted media coverage (Energy harvesting Journal, IDTechEx, http://www.energyharvestingjournal.com/articles/a-new-low-cost-tool-for-3d-circuit-printing-00005371.asp, ILL Grenoble, www.ill.eu/?id=14299) and led to an invited talk at Banff International Research Station Canada (2012), a plenary talk and a PhD student prize at UK Neutron and Muon meeting (2013).

Title: Spinodal Clustering in Thin Films of Nanoparticle-Polymer Mixtures
AdditionalInformation: Reports the coordinated nucleation of fulleneres in polymer films, with applications in functional nanocomposites. As a result of this work, JC delivered Keynote talk at the European Conference on Neutron Scattering (ECNS 2011). The project student (Wong) received an EPSRC doctoral award. JC was invited to chair the soft matter committee at the Institut Laue Langevin, the world's leading neutron source, and was invited to be a course lecturer at the Oxford Neutron Summer School (2011,2013).

Title: Complex micropatterning of periodic structures on elastomeric surfaces
AdditionalInformation: This cover article reports the facile and inexpensive manufacture of controlled 2D buckling on soft surfaces, with applications in wetting, coatings and photonics. The work in the paper resulted in invited talks at EU-Softcomp annual meeting (Heraklion, Crete 2011), Banff International Research Station (BIRS, Canada, 2010), and at Microfluidics and Nanofluidics 2013 (USA); Resulted in a Royal Society Research grant (2008/R1, £14.7k), and an award of a PhD studentship from the Centre for Plastic Electronics DTC at Imperial, and in two CASE PhD studentships with Unilever on complex fluids and surface science (project leader Dr Peter Graham, Peter.Graham@unilever.com).

Title: Experimental strategies for increasing the catalyst turnover number in a continuous Heck coupling reaction
AdditionalInformation: A continuous process for a catalytic Heck coupling reaction (for the production of substituted alkenes) combined with in-situ, elevated temperature separation of the homogenous catalyst using a polyetheretherketone (PEEK) nanofiltration membrane, is described. Remarkably, the membrane remains stable in a solution of dimethylformamide and organic base at 90oC for extended periods. This successful research, and specifically creation of the PEEK membrane, was crucial in renewing a $1.5M USD, 5 year project funded by the Novartis-MIT Center for Continuous Manufacturing – USA (http://engineering.mit.edu/labs/novartis) carried out in collaboration with MIT Department of Chemical Engineering (MIT - Klavs F Jensen kfjensen@MIT.EDU; Novartis: berthold.schenkel@novartis.com).

Title: Membranes for Organic Solvent Nanofiltration Based on Preassembled Nanoparticles
AdditionalInformation: The fabrication of membranes with finely tuned molecular separation properties is reported in this paper. Pre-formed nanoparticles of narrow size distribution are used for fabrication of solvent stable nanofiltration membranes forming discrete interstitial spaces (“pores”) which determine the separation performance of the membrane. Membrane separation properties can be varied by simply altering the size of the nanoparticles. The approach was first reported in a keynote lecture at ICOM2011 (Amsterdam July 2011), and the fabrication principal introduced in this paper has led to contracts of £372K over 4 years) with Lanxess Deutschland GmbH (martin.mechelhoff@lanxess.com), who manufacture polymer nanoparticles

Title: Organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN) with spiral-wound membrane elements-Highly rejected solute system
AdditionalInformation: Performance data and design rules for scale up of organic solvent nanofiltration using spiral wound membrane modules are reported in this paper. These design considerations provided underpinning engineering design for the fluid processing and application of organic solvent nanofiltration (i) to the recycle and recovery of processing solvents; and (ii) the application of spiral wound modules in pharmaceutical purification (http://duramem.evonik.com/product/duramem-puramem/en/Pages/default.aspx; contact: andrew.boam@evonik.com). This work also led to Imperial (Peeva) coordinating European Project IMETI PIAP-GA-2008-218068 (1.8M Euro)) centred on technology transfer to industry, and specifically on the development and performance of spiral wound elements.

Title: Membrane enhanced peptide synthesis.
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports Membrane Enhanced Peptide Synthesis (MEPS), a technology platform invented and developed at Imperial and covered by international patent applications (PCT/GB2009/050,990; PCT/GB2009/051,525). Both patent applications have been licensed by Evonik Membrane Extraction Technology Ltd (yuri.bouwhuis@evonik.com). The MEPS process advantageously combines organic solvent membrane separation with peptide synthesis, and can be extended to further synthetic processes such as oligonucleotide synthesis, the subject of an on-going collaboration with GSK (£190K to date) in oligonucleotide process technology (Mark Buswell, andrew.m.buswell@gsk.com). MEPS has recently been highlighted for its potential as a new manufacturing technology in Speciality Chemicals Magazine, May 2013 (www.cpcscientific.com/pdfs/spe-chemicals-magazine-article.pdf).

Title: A generalisation of the SAFT-gamma group contribution method for groups comprising multiple spherical segments
AdditionalInformation: A general group contribution method is presented which is applicable in a predictive way and accurate for the entire thermodynamic range and type of fluid phase behavior. The generality and accuracy of the approach have attracted interest from industry, leading to funding from the pharma industry especially (eg., Pfizer ~ $1M; Senior Research Fellow), as group contribution methods are highly relevant for solubility prediction or solvent screening. This work was presented as the opening plenary lecture at the ESAT 2012 meeting in St Petersburg, a key conference in the area of Applied Thermodynamics.

Title: Thermotropic Biaxial Liquid Crystalline Phases in a Mixture of Attractive Uniaxial Rod and Disk Particles
AdditionalInformation: Biaxial nematic phases which lead to faster switching, and displays with lower energy requirements, have been sought for over 40 years. A first example of the stabilization of such a phase in a mixture of uniaxial particles is presented. This work impacts those aiming to design and fabricate these materials experimentally (Phys. Rev. Lett. (2011), 106, 017801) and the fields of nanotechnology (Liq. Crys., (2011), 38, 729) and applied mathematics; AG was invited to the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences (March 2013) to discuss this research with key experts in the mathematics of liquid crystals.

Title: Modeling the Fluid Phase Behavior of Carbon Dioxide in Aqueous Solutions of Monoethanolamine Using Transferable Parameters with the SAFT-VR Approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates how physical models, which treat implicitly the key reaction equilibria involved in CO2-capture processes, can be used with amine solvents. Results are shown to be highly reliable in comparisons with experimental data over wide ranges of temperature, pressure and composition, and for different solvents. This provides a distinct advantage for process design and development and has attracted significant industrial interest, including funding for a PhD (E.On) and the recent acquisition of the rights to the underlying technology by Process Systems Enterprise Ltd (http://www.psenterprise.com/gproms/options/physprops/saft/) where it is already finding extensive industrial application (m.matzopoulos@psenterprise.com).

Title: Application of a renormalization-group treatment to the statistical associating fluid theory for potentials of variable range (SAFT-VR).
AdditionalInformation: Rigorous inclusion of molecular correlations leads to the prediction of critical exponent values in agreement with universal scaling laws in the SAFT-VR equation; the first time this has been shown for this family of equations. The method yields accurate derivative thermodynamic properties (such as heat capacities) (Fluid Phase Equil. (2013), 337, 274) useful for process design. The work contributed to further funding in project EP/J020788/1(£2.4M) where the SAFT-VR methodology is used in conditions close to critical involving CO2 and where derivative properties are needed. This work formed the basis of an invited lecture at the Boulder Thermophysical Properties meeting 2013.

Title: The use of murine embryonic stem cells, alginate encapsulation, and rotary microgravity bioreactor in bone tissue engineering.
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted in the development of a novel bioreactor that has been deployed internationally in Japan (Prof Furukawa; furukawa@mech.t.u-tokyo.ac.jp) and Singapore (Dr Lim; MayasariLim@ntu.edu.sg). Translated technology in an animal study confirming safety and efficacy of the technology. In talks with a company to manufacture the bioreactor (jc@jcbio.co.kr; www.jcbio.co.kr). This technology resulted in an EU project funded “AmbuLung” (FP7-Health-57614//€1.4M). Patent application filed (WO2006079854-A1; GB2437689-A). Keynote lecture at 3rd Asian Biomaterials Congress, Korea, September 2011; plenary at Belgian Symposium on Tissue Engineering, September 2012 and 8th International Meeting of the Portuguese Society for Stem Cells and Cell Therapies, April 2013.

Title: Global Sensitivity Analysis Challenges in Biological Systems Modeling
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses the issue of model analysis in biological models. It elucidates the aspects of sensitivity analysis and identifies, with reasoning, the most suitable group of sensitivity analysis methods for application to highly non-linear dynamic models in the context of biological systems. This paper has resulted in 2 invited publications: a) MICROBIAL BIOTECHNOLOGY, Volume: 4 Issue: 2 Special Issue: SI, 2011; and b) Computational and Structural Biotechnology Journal, Volume 3, Issue 4, 2012. Also, this paper led to the award of an EU project “Multimod” (FP7-People-46667//€0.8M).

Title: Linking genes to microbial growth kinetics: an integrated biochemical systems engineering approach.
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates how to utilise the powerful molecular biology tools to produce a “step change” for modelling microbial growth kinetics by linking biomass growth and substrate consumption rates to gene regulatory networks that control these processes. In essence, it replaces the traditional Monod-type models by combining a genetic circuit with growth kinetic models and decouples biomass growth and substrate consumption rates, which are expressed as independent functions of the rate-limiting enzymes produced by the genes. The paper was a plenary lecture at the biennial 13th International Conference on Pseudomonas, Sydney, Australia, in September 2011.

Title: Long-term cytokine-free expansion of cord blood mononuclear cells in three-dimensional scaffolds
AdditionalInformation: This paper was identified by “Global Medical Discovery” as being of “special interest to the drug development sector” (Dr Rob Smith, Rob.smith@globalmedicaldiscovery.com), and  was elected by the Journal of Visualised Experiments to create a film (J Vis Exp, 10(62), 2012). The research described let to a Patent application (GB1019932.1), and establishment of a collaboration with the National Blood Service (Dr. Ash Toye; ash.m.toye@bristol.ac.uk).. The research was featured by Research Councils UK as one of the “Big Ideas UK” revolutionary projects (http://www.rcuk.ac.uk/Publications/reports/Pages/BigIdeas.aspx) and led directly to an ERC Advanced Investigator Award on “BioBlood” (ERC-2013-Adv-340719/€2.5M).

Title: Quantification of valve leakage rates
AdditionalInformation: The paper was a collaboration between Imperial, Statoil and the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU). Acoustic and other measurements of valve leakage from NTNU were combined with advanced signal analysis from Imperial for rigorous determination of through-leakage rates of shut-off valves. The methods of the paper have the potential to reduce the amount of field inspection by oil and gas companies such as Statoil. Erling Lunde can be contacted for comment (elunde@statoil.com). The ideas also led to Task 3.2 of a €3.4M FP7 project PITN-GA-2010-264960 coordinated by Imperial with Statoil as a partner.

Title: Cause-and-effect analysis in chemical processes utilizing XML, plant connectivity and quantitative process history
AdditionalInformation: We extract process connectivity information from a piping and instrumentation diagram and use it for analysis of root causes of process upsets. The paper links the engineering and operational phases of the plant lifecycle automatically for the first time. Other authors have only ever been able to do this manually before. BP fully funded a PhD student and purchased a license for our codes in 2010 (Imperial ref: CERES_P13563). They had a large-scale trial in Whiting refinery (Chicago) where Dr L. Natarajan be contacted (Lakshman.Natarajan@bp.com). The work continues in a 3.4M EUR FP7 project PITN-GA-2010-264940 which is coordinated by Imperial.

Title: A practical method for identifying the propagation path of plant-wide disturbances
AdditionalInformation: The algorithms developed in this paper and codes written by the authors are incorporated directly in Loop Performance Monitor (Plant Disturbance Analyser extension), a commercial product from ABB (a.horch@de.abb.com). An article in ABB Review gave an independent evaluation of the impact of this and other algorithms in a study with Eastman Chemical Company (Alexander Horch, John W. Cox, and  Nunzio Bonavita, Peak Performance, ABB Review 2007(1), 24-29). Dr Jim Downs of Eastman Chemical Company (jjdowns@eastman.com) may be contacted for a statement of the impact of the method in solving several difficult industrial problems and its significance for the process industries.

Title: Comparison of Three Electromechanical Oscillation Damping Estimation Methods
AdditionalInformation: Aalto University, Imperial, ABB, National Grid and Fingrid, studied the assessment of damping factor of wide-area electrical power transmission grids. While it is easy to determine damping after a major transient event, we devised and evaluated three new methods for determining damping factor from ambient operation.  The significance of Imperial's interdisciplinary contribution was to show that methods of multivariate signal analysis devised for monitoring of refineries can cross over into power transmission. Alex Carter (National Grid, Alex.Carter@nationalgrid.com) will verify the importance for future operation of the UK transmission grid. The collaboration led to 1.1M EUR of FP7 funding REAL-SMART PIAP-GA-2009-251304.

Title: Interfacial properties of selected binary mixtures containing n-alkanes
AdditionalInformation: This work showcases a three-way experimental, theoretical and simulation account of the fluid phase behaviour and interfacial properties of highly asymmetric mixtures. The results are of direct interest in the oil and gas, process and formulation industry, where the theories and correlations available for determination of interfacial properties are limited and of poor predictive ability. This work was initially seed funded by the Royal Society and has been followed up by the approval of two consecutive international grants (CONICYT 1120228/Chile). It has attracted funding by BP (T. Totton; Tim.Totton@uk.bp.com) and COP (J. Torres; Jose.A.TorresRivero@conocophillips.com)

Title: Determination of the surface area and porosity of carbon nanotube bundles from a Langmuirian analysis of sub- and supercritical adsorption data
AdditionalInformation: Adsorption and transport of gases through nanoporous carbons (i.e. nanotubes, graphene sheets) is a key promising technique for the development of state-of-the art energy storage and membrane separations. In this joint experimental and simulation paper, product of EPSRC-funded research, (grant EP/D035171; £125k) we elucidate the problem of how to obtain reliable information on the porosity and surface area of single-walled carbon nanotube bundles from adsorption data. The impact of this work has spawned invitations to present it in plenary ( IBA1/EBA9, Brazil, 2012; FOA11, USA, 2013) and topical ( AIChE Annual meeting, USA, 2013) sessions.

Title: SAFT-γ force field for the simulation of molecular fluids. 1. A single-site coarse grained model of carbon dioxide.
VolumeTitle: The Journal of Physical Chemistry. B
AdditionalInformation: This is the first of a series of three published papers that describe a unique modelling methodology which is a major change in paradigm in the field of molecular modelling. Within this paper EAM has put forward the concept of employing physically-based equations of state to obtain parameters for intermolecular potentials that can be used for the molecular simulation of macroscopic thermophysical data. The research described in this paper has attracted considerable support and funding both from industries (P&G; B. Murch; murch.bp@pg.com, Pfizer, R. M. Shanker, ravi.m.shanker@pfizer.com) and research councils EPSRC (EP/E016340; £3M; EP/J014958; £1.5M).

Title: Molecular dynamics simulation of the mesophase behaviour of a model bolaamphiphilic liquid crystal with a lateral flexible chain
AdditionalInformation: This contribution presents a novel methodology that allows the efficient computer simulation of the self-assembly of complex polyphilic molecules with direct application to liquid crystals, surfactants, polymers, etc. This paper had immediate impact, opening collaborations with experimentalists (e.g. EPSRC grant EP/I018212 £168k ; EP/J010502; £336k), companies (P&G Case studentship, Z. Alam; alam.z@pg.com) and warranted an invitation to a Faraday Discussion (FD144). A further four follow-up papers have expanded these results, three of them appearing on the cover of their respective issues and one of them branded as a “hot article” by the journal editor (http://blogs.rsc.org/sm/category/hot-article/ ; search "self-organisation" )

Title: Hierarchical composites reinforced with robust short sisal fibre preforms utilising bacterial cellulose as binder
AdditionalInformation: Reinforcing fibres are valuable and off-cuts are currently disposed of. This paper demonstrates that nanocellulose can be used as efficient binder to create fibre mats, shown exemplarily for natural fibres, that can be used as reinforcement for thermosetting matrices. Such composites can be produced using conventional manufacturing processes. The invention is covered in patent application WO2012049198-A1. Utilizing (especially carbon and high performance polymer) fibre waste in composites upgraded by nanocellulose offers significant economic potential (tom.james@formax.co.uk) and a large volume application for nanocellulose. First author Lee, a former PhD, was awarded the Student Achievement Award by BEPS (www.beps.org) for this innovation.

Title: High Internal Phase Emulsions Stabilized Solely by Functionalized Silica Particles
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates that particle stabilised very concentrated emulsions are suitable templates to produce high porosity macroporous polymers. The innovations are protected in Patent WO2009013500-A1. First author V.O. Ikem, a former PhD, was awarded the Imperial College Faculty of Engineering Armstrong Medal and Prize 2012 for “…outstanding research for application of scientific methods to industrial problems…” and AB won the International Materials Science Prize at the PolyChar-18 (Rouen, Fr, 2009) for the work in this paper, which was also presented in a keynote lecture at ACS Porous Polymer Section (Denver, USA, 2011).

Title: Surface modification of natural fibers using bacteria: Depositing bacterial cellulose onto natural fibers to create hierarchical fiber reinforced nanocomposites
AdditionalInformation: It is shown that bacteria can be used to deposit nanosized cellulose onto fibres and that combining renewable micro- and nanoscale reinforcements within a renewable matrix produces composites with much better mechanical properties. The innovations are covered in Patent application WO2008020187-A1. This work led to EPSRC grant EP/F032005/1 (£442,090) and then to Follow-On Grant EP/J013390/1 (£132,336) (see http://www.formax.co.uk/composite_article.php?s=29&np=1). This work was presented in keynote lectures at PPS-24 (Salerno, It, 2008), and APTS-1 (Linz, A, 2009). The development of renewable hierarchical composites described in this paper was recognised when AB was awarded the BEPS Outstanding Young Researcher Award 2010 (see: http://www.beps.org/awards.html).

Title: Highly permeable macroporous polymers synthesized from pickering medium and high internal phase emulsion templates.
AdditionalInformation: Macroporous polymers made by emulsion templating were first described in 1962 but remained largely of academic interest. The work in this paper shows that it is possible to increase the permeability of conventional poly(merised)High Internal Phase Emulsions (HIPE) (see: DOI: 10.1039/B900426B) by orders of magnitude through using particle stabilised HIPE templates to which surfactant is added. Mechanical properties of these very permeable polyHIPEs are addressed in (DOI: 10.1039/C1SM05272A). The innovations are covered in patents US2011034583-A1 and US2011034583-A1. The materials are currently under evaluation by Halliburton (lewis.norman@halliburton.com) as replacements for packed sand bed filters (http://dx.doi.org/10.2118/141256-PA).

Title: A mathematical modelling framework for understanding chemorepulsive signal transduction in Dictyostelium.
AdditionalInformation: This is the first modelling paper (Pubmed) on chemorepulsion (migration away from chemicals), a process involved in tumour cell spreading, angiogenesis (blood-network formation), immune transplant rejection. It employs a multi-model approach to elucidate chemorepulsion in a model organism. This resulted in the development of a new cell-type-independent systems-design methodology to understand how cells are wired to exhibit both chemorepulsion and chemoattraction (JTB:273:80-99:2011) for controlling migration in a variety of cell types, keynote lectures (ActinCellPolarity, Warwick, 2008, Angionet2009, Dundee), invited lectures (Oxford 2011), systems biology talks (ICSB2013, Copenhagen), emerging collaborations (Prof.Eickholt:Britta.Eikholt@charite.de) applying results to neurons, and conference prizes (ChemEngDayUK, 2013).

Title: Investigating the effects of ABC transporter-based acquired drug resistance mechanisms at the cellular and tissue scale
AdditionalInformation: Going beyond the current paradigm of investigating/understanding acquired drug resistance mechanisms at the single cell level, we investigate tissue-level (group) effects, revealing striking tissue-level differences. This has important implications for tissue-level functioning of both examined (a widespread, and standard multi-drug resistance mechanism) and other resistance mechanisms, and broad significance for understanding cell behaviour individually and collectively. This led to lecture invitation at the international “Individuals and Groups” workshop, 2012, Almora, seminar invitations (Michigan: ninalin@umich.edu), international cancer modelling talks (MathwaysintoCancer 2013, Carmona, Indian Institute of Science(invited) 2013) emerging industrial collaboration (Cellworks Inc:santanu.datta@gmail.com), emerging medical collaborations studying breast cancer endocrine-therapy resistance (Prof.Stebbing/Xu:j.stebbing@imperial.ac.uk).

Title: An investigation of spatial signal transduction in cellular networks
AdditionalInformation: Spatial regulation of biochemical networks is crucial to many vital cellular processes of basic and applied (biomedical/biotechnological) importance and a frontier area in cell signalling. We initiate a network-based framework enabling tools and methodologies of network analysis to be systematically combined with spatial aspects to efficiently elucidate cellular regulation in multiple contexts. This led to Keynote Industrial Workshop talks (Syngenta:2012 Anita.Rea@syngenta.com), international talks spanning biology (EMBO Spatial2013 conference, Israel), applied mathematics (TIFR:2013(invited)) international collaboration/invitation to co-supervise PhDs (Prof.Venkatasubramanian, Columbia, venkat@columbia.edu), new developments (BiophysicalJournal:105,7,1720-31,2013), seminar invitations (Harvard:Jeremy@hms.harvard.edu). This paper received a permanent designation of “Highly accessed” by BMC Systems Biology (6:1752-0509:2012)

Title: Regulation of release factor expression using a translational negative feedback loop: A systems analysis
AdditionalInformation: Using experiments (Prof.Stansfield:Aberdeen) and modelling, we provide the first experimentally-validated substantive model (Pubmed) to unravel an in-built feedback mechanism regulating the basic cellular process of translation, transcending the unidirectional process paradigm of translation. Premature termination is widespread (causing diseases like cystic fibrosis, muscular dystrophy) and the demonstrated counteracting effect of naturally-occurring feedback has applications for synthetically engineering feedback control (with additional biotechnological relevance). The modelling was presented in international cell biology conferences (Cold Spring Harbor 2009 Hinxton) resulted in international talks/invitations (NCBS:2013, Univ. Pennsylvania), and a £744000 BBSRC grant (BB/I020454/1) to develop a comprehensive systems toolkit for translation feedback control.

Title: Isolation of Size Exclusion Chromatography Elution-Fractions of Coal and Petroleum-Derived Samples and Analysis by Laser Desorption Mass Spectrometry
AdditionalInformation: Chemical characterisation of heavy hydrocarbons (asphaltenes, coal/biomass tars) is challenging due to a large number of species in these samples. Lighter fractions have masking effects on high Molecular Weight fractions (HMWF), which are less abundant but operationally problematic (precipitation, fouling, catalyst deactivation). The paper combines Size Exclusion Chromatography and Laser-Desorption Mass Spectrometry to enhance detection of HMWF. This work secured funding from (Petronas [£75k, Dr Shahidah, shahims@petronas.com.my], BP [£44k, Dr Eccleston, Alison.Eccleston@uk.bp.com]), joint European Union-funded projects with industry  (RFCR-CT-2009-00004 [£110k], RFSR-CT-2009-00004 [£127k]), Skolkovo Foundation/BP [~£250k subproject], and collaboration with Mexican Petroleum Institute (Fuel Processing Technology, 2013, 734).

Title: Tar Formation and Destruction in a Fixed-Bed Reactor Simulating Downdraft Gasification: Equipment Development and Characterization of Tar-Cracking Products
AdditionalInformation: Tar formation in coal/biomass gasification is an obstacle to further development and overall economic performance of syngas utilisation and gasification-based power generation. This paper shows that tar content in the gases can be greatly reduced through cracking in the gasifier by optimising operating conditions without the need for external tar removal, and presents a thorough inventory of the cracking products. This research led to invited talks at Huazhong [Prof Sun sunlushi@mail.hust.edu.cn] and Enna Kore [Dr Roberto Volpe roberto.volpe@unikore.it] Universities and was the basis of research contracts funded by Sasol, which led to joint conference presentations [Dr Van Niekerk daniel.vanniekerk@sasol.com].

Title: Investigation of the Oxy-fuel Gasification of Coal in a Laboratory-Scale Spouted-Bed Reactor: Reactor Modifications and Initial Results
AdditionalInformation: Fluidised bed (FB) gasification enables the production of power from low quality coals, but it must be made compatible with CO2 capture to be sustainable. FB Gasifiers are typically air-blown, which makes them unsuitable due to costly N2/CO2 separation. This study introduced a new concept: the gasifier fluidised in an O2/CO2 mixture to overcome these limitations and improve gas heating values. This work led to a joint European Union-funded project with industry  (RFCR-CT-2010-0009, £230k), invited talks at International Energy Agency’s Fluidised Bed Conversion Group (IEA-FBC) and 2012 Gasification Summer School (CIEMAT, Madrid), and nomination as UK representative to IEA-FBC Committee.

Title: Impact of Steam on the Interaction between Biomass Gasification Tars and Nickel-Based Solid Oxide Fuel Cell Anode Materials
AdditionalInformation: Utilising biomass-derived syngas in Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC) would lead to higher efficiencies in Combined Heat and Power generation. However, tars in syngas produce cell degradation. This article sets the scene for a series elucidating the effect of operating conditions on carbon formation on Ni-based anodes. This novel in-depth study of the tar/anode interaction led to determination of conditions under which SOFCs can operate free from significant degradation. It gave rise to Johnson Matthey-EPSRC Case Award (10001851), collaboration with Delft University (Journal Electrochemical Society, 2011, B1310-B1318) and an invited talk (“SOFC for Next Generation Power Plants” 2013 Symposium).

Title: Contact lines over random topographical substrates. Part 2. Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: Wetting phenomena occur in a wide variety of natural-technological settings, from the repellency of rain water by plant leaves to microfluidic devices. To date, no attempt has been made to quantify the effects of substrate randomness on wetting. Here we reported the first mathematically rigorous study of the effects of random heterogeneities on wetting. The main result was to prove that the classical “Wenzel law”, according to which substrate roughness enhances wetting, is in incorrect. This study was crucial in winning ERC Advanced Grant/247031/€1,300,000.

Title: General Dynamical Density Functional Theory for Classical Fluids
AdditionalInformation: This paper formulated, using statistical mechanics approaches, a new mean-field framework for the modelling of the motion of soft matter, e.g. colloidal fluids. The formulation results a Navier-Stokes-like equation but with a novel diffusion tensor which depends non-locally on density and is time-dependent. The paper led to several keynote-plenary lectures, notably at the session ``Non-Newtonian and Complex Fluids" of the XXIII International Congress of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics, Beijing, 2012.

Title: Unification of dynamic density functional theory for colloidal fluids to include inertia and hydrodynamic interactions: derivation and numerical experiments.
AdditionalInformation: Following from SK's paper in Phys. Rev. Lett. 109, 120603 (2012), the validity of the new model was confirmed using stochastic dynamics simulations. The study also unified in a generic framework all previous models and showed how they can be recovered in certain limits. It was selected as a journal news item/``labtalk" [http://iopscience.iop.org/0953-8984/labtalk-article/51831] and for inclusion in ``IOP Select" (``Chosen based on: Significant breakthroughs; High degree of novelty; Significant impact on future research") [http://iopscience.iop.org/0953-8984/25/3/035101? fromSearchPage=true].

Title: Liquid Film Coating a Fiber as a Model System for the Formation of Bound States in Active Dispersive-Dissipative Nonlinear Media
AdditionalInformation: Bound states, i.e. composites of building blocks behaving as single objects, appear in many areas. We demonstrated experimentally for the first time the formation of bound states in interfacial hydrodynamics. This was corroborated by a theory using a prototype that retains the fundamental elements of any nonlinear evolution process. As such the findings are of interest for the study of generic features in other nonlinear systems. The paper was crucial in obtaining EPSRC grants EP/H034587/£390K, EP/K008595/£610K, led to several keynote-plenary lectures, notably Centre Paul Langevin, 2011, Conference on Multiscale Complex Fluid Flows, Brussels, 2010.

Title: Catalysis in flow: the practical and selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes and ketones
AdditionalInformation: A joint effort between Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, the paper demonstrates a green/atom efficient, continuous partial oxidation process to convert pharma-relevant alcohols with high selectivity to aldehydes using oxygen as terminal oxidant. This resulted in award of a Pathway to Impact grant (£50k - RSRO_P43480) to develop a prototype system. Our results were crucial in securing a £1Million grant from EPSRC under its Dial-a-Molecule scheme (with UCL and Leeds - EP/L003279/1/). The publication also resulted in the award of a grant from Shell Global Solutions (£560k – PT25442) to pursue liquid-phase oxidation reactions for the activation of small hydrocarbons (andrew.horton@shell.com).

Title: Parameters affecting the growth and hydrogen production of the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii
AdditionalInformation: The seminal contribution of this paper lies in the identification and quantification of various parameters (light intensity, nutrient concentration etc.) that affect the growth and hydrogen productivity of a model green alga. This work has been reported in plenary/keynote lectures [2nd Bioplant Workshop, Braga, 2011; International Hydrogen Research Showcase, Birmingham 2011], and attracted media attention and broadcasted interviews [Fully Charged Show with Robert Llewellyn (April 2012)- web page: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMOxrDxq_do to be screened on Discovery Channel (2013); UKTI promotional video for Clean Energy Ministerial event, presented to Prime Minister (April 2012); interview by Dong-a Ilbo (East Asia Daily - March 2012).

Title: Catalysis in flow: Au-catalysed alkylation of amines by alcohols
AdditionalInformation: This seminal paper in our ‘flow’ series (collaborative effort between Chemistry and Chemical Engineering), describes application of gold nano-particles in the amination of alcohols under flow conditions without base. We demonstrate for the first time effective translation of the homogeneous H-borrowing concept to a heterogeneous continuous flow system. We identify the scope and elucidate key reaction mechanisms, delivering a complete catalytic model accounting for all products. The work has attracted the attention of companies (invited seminars Firmenich, 2011 and Astra Zeneca, 2012) and resulted in funding of an industrial CASE award 11220222 (Johnson-Matthey-ellispr@matthey.com) and a DTA studentship plus £30k, (Syngenta-colin.brennan@syngenta.com).

Title: Design of a novel flat-plate photobioreactor system for green algal hydrogen production
AdditionalInformation: The key initial paper, followed by 4 in the same journal, describes the design of a novel photobioreactor, which allows the detailed analysis of the growth and hydrogen evolution kinetics of algal and cyanobacterial systems capable of bio-photolysis. Of major significance is the continuous in situ measurement of hydrogen production rates. This work has led to the publication of a book chapter (Advanced Applied Microbiology) with colleagues from Biochemistry, plenary/keynote lectures [CHEMRAWN XIX, 2011; Global Artificial Photosynthesis, 2011], televised interviews (Channel 4, 2009; BBC Arabia 2009, a New Moon production for UKTI, 2009) and a Science Museum exhibition (Antenna, 2010).

Title: Optimisation based design of a district energy system for an eco-town in the United Kingdom
AdditionalInformation: This paper couples multiscale equipment and infrastructure models with spatial energy models to develop alternative optimised urban energy system (UES) designs. It arises out of our interdisciplinary programme on energy systems for sustainable cities and demonstrates the power of new algorithms to deal with such problems.  . Two large new projects (EP/I038837/1 - £5.9m, FP7-CELSIUS, €14m, €600k at Imperial) have ensued, as has a software tool (UrbEn) that is undergoing commercialisation with Imperial Innovations and BP (rosemary.albinson@castrol.com). As a result of this work, NS was invited to be a lead author of the prestigious Global Energy Assessment Report (http://www.iiasa.ac.at/web/home/research/Flagship-Projects/Global-Energy-Assessment/Home-GEA.en.html)

Title: Multiscale modelling of hydrothermal biomass pretreatment for chip size optimization.
AdditionalInformation: This paper applies multiscale modelling process modelling to the pretreatment of biomass (pretreating/fractionating biomass is a major bottleneck in its conversion). Most of the literature arises out of life science/biochemistry departments and misses key phenomena associated with mass transfer limitations. The approach here combines chemical engineering science with multiscale modelling to identify the main rate-based processes and optimise the key degrees of freedom. This is to our knowledge the first paper where the effect of particle size is taken into consideration explicitly and optimised. Three follow-on grants (EP/K014749/1, EP/K014676/1, EP/K014897/1, £7m, £3.5m at Imperial) have resulted from this work.

Title: Spatially Explicit Static Model for the Strategic Design of Future Bioethanol Production Systems. 1. Cost Minimization
AdditionalInformation: This is Part 1 of a two-part paper which combines the modelling and optimisation of spatially-explicit energy systems and bioenergy supply chains and develops a holistic model for the strategic design of a bioethanol system. It is also the culmination of a successful international collaboration with Dr Bezzo at Padova University (fabrizio.bezzo@unipd.it). An EPSRC grant (EP/K036734/1, £1.5m; Imperial £600k) on whole systems modelling of bioenergy has been awarded as a result of this work. Participation in FP-7 grants ensuing from it include BIOCORE (€14m, €400k at Imperial) and RENESENG (€4m, €450k at Imperial), as did a plenary lecture at ESCAPE-19.

Title: Design and operation of a future hydrogen supply chain: Multi-period model
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes our conceptual representation of spatially- and temporally-explicit models of complex process systems such as energy systems. This has resulted in a platform for the analysis and design of energy systems. Many UK-relevant projects have been undertaken using this representation, including: Bioenergy (NE/C516279/1, £750k); Urban Energy (BP, £4.5m), Carbon Capture and Storage (NE/H01392X/1, £700k)]. The methodology was used to develop a bioenergy value chain modelling tool for the Energy Technologies Institute (Geraldine.Newton-Cross@eti.co.uk), to help prioritise bioenergy acceleration investments. Two new EPSRC grants (hydrogen systems: EP/J016454/1 £4.1m, £2m at Imperial, energy systems: EP/K039326/1, £4.6m, £1.2m at Imperial) have ensued.

Title: Crystal Habits and the Variation in Surface Energy Heterogeneity
AdditionalInformation: The effect of powder processing (crystal habit change due to crystallisation) is related to anisotropic wetting behaviour for organic crystalline solids. The work led to JH being accepted by GlaxoSmithKline (L. Freitas dos Santos - Luisa.M.Freitas.Dos.Santos@gsk.com) on a Royal Academy of Engineering Secondment in 2011 (1 year 50% FTE), funding from Bristol-Myers Squibb (£175k) and an EPSRC Industrial CASE with Pfizer (T. Lukas – tim.lukas@pfizer.com) in 2013. This work on surface energy heterogeneity has been presented at invited talks at the Physical Chemistry Collouqia, University of Cambridge (2008) and the British Pharmaceutical Conference Annual Meeting (2009).

Title: Influence of fines on the surface energy heterogeneity of lactose for pulmonary drug delivery.
AdditionalInformation: The paper reveals the development of a methodology to determine powder surface energy heterogeneity, which succeeds in understanding role of fines in formulation for pulmonary drug delivery. Two industrial CASE PhD projects supported by the EPSRC (industrial with SMS – D. Burnett - burnett@smsna.com) and BBSRC (BB/G017506/1) are related to this study. This work led to JH being awarded the New Investigator Award ($25,000) in Pharmaceutics and Pharmaceutical Technologies by the American Association of Pharmaceutical Scientists in 2010. JH was invited to present this work at the Academy of Pharmaceutical Sciences Annual Meeting (2010).

Title: Effects of Oscillatory Flow on the Nucleation and Crystallization of Insulin
AdditionalInformation: A crystallisation flow methodology resulting in enhanced protein growth and yields of insulin crystal is reported, providing a new downstream separation processes for biopharmaceuticals, resulting in a patent application (WO.2010/125360). JH was invited to deliver a Keynote at the 4th UK-China Particle Technology Forum, Shanghai in 2013; a Chemistry Departmental Seminar at Tsinghua University, China (Z. Yang - zyang@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn) in 2013 and seminars at GlaxoSmithKline (M. Lee - mei.2.lee@gsk.com) and Novartis (T. Galvao - tomasr.galvao@novartis.com) in 2012.

Title: Selective Crystallization of Proteins Using Engineered Nanonucleants
AdditionalInformation: An approach using 3D-nanotemplates as substrates for heterogeneous nucleation is reported, for the first time correlating the protein hydrodynamic radius to pore size, and we have successfully crystallised >10 proteins including therapeutically relevant antibodies using this methodology. This work has led to a BBSRC Industrial Case Award (BB/J012327/1) with GlaxoSmithKline (F. Ricard - Francois.X.Ricard@gsk.com) in 2012. JH was invited to present the work at the 16th International Conference for Crystal Growth (ICCG-16), Beijing (2010) and Invited Speaker Seminar at the EPSRC Continuous Manufacturing and Crystallisation Centre, Strathclyde (2013).

Title: An optimised method for extraction and quantification of nucleotides and nucleotide sugars from mammalian cells.
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an optimised method for extracting and quantifying the metabolic precursors of protein glycosylation. The latter is a key quality indicator for therapeutic proteins. The method is 50% faster than previous ion exchange chromatography protocols and can resolve more nucleotide and nucleotide sugar species. It is already being used in collaborative projects with MedImmune plc., subsidiary of AstraZeneca specialising in biologics (Chris Sellick, Team Leader In-Process Analytics) and with Danish biotechnology company Symphogen (Dietmar Weilguny, Principal Scientist).

Title: Genome-based kinetic modeling of cytosolic glucose metabolism in industrially relevant cell lines: Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Chinese hamster ovary cells
AdditionalInformation: The central significance of this manuscript is a strategy to derive kinetic information about cell metabolism using flux balance analysis. Significantly, this information is then employed to make predictions of dynamic behaviour, including the effects of genetic modification. The strategy was applied to two industrially-relevant systems, Chinese hamster ovary and Saccharomyces serevisiae cells, demonstrating unique expertise in dynamic analysis of metabolic pathways.  The work led to EPSRC EP/K014897/1 (Co-PI: Kontoravdi; £1.923M), which involves the design of metabolic pathways for the biological conversion of biomass into high-value pharmaceutical intermediates.

Title: Systematic development of predictive mathematical models for animal cell cultures
AdditionalInformation: A robust framework for the development and validation of dynamic models of bioprocesses is applied for the first time to construct a mathematical model of antibody-producing hybridoma cell culture. Validation by experimental data shows the potential of using this approach to make predictions for cell growth and protein productivity under different culture conditions. This seminal work led to optimisation applications presented in AUTOMATICA Special Issue on Systems Biology 47(6):1147-1155 (2011). Additionally, the results were key in securing funding (EP/H03126X/1, £688K) to extend the methodology to amino acid metabolism in collaboration with Lonza Biologics (Richard Alldread, Head of Technology Development).

Title: In Situ Monitoring of Intracellular Glucose and Glutamine in CHO Cell Culture
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript describes the development and calibration of protein-based biosensors for in vivo non-destructive metabolite profiling in Chinese hamster ovary cells. It is the first publication on online, real-time monitoring of intracellular metabolites concentrations in animal cells. The system allows users to make quantitative measurements in situ. Initially developed as a BBSRC Targeted Priority Studentship project, the work described in the paper led to a BBSRC grant BB/I017011/1 (over £0.9M), which includes 10% funding from BRIC industrial members (Richard Alldread, Head of Technology Development, Lonza Biologics; Ray Field, Director of Cell Sciences, MedImmune) who can comment on the significance.

Title: Influence of high-temperature steam on the reactivity of CaO sorbent for CO₂ capture.
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to demonstrate in a bench-scale (rather than TGA) reactor the effects of steam (of course, always present in power station flue-gases) on Carbonate looping for CCS.  The work informed a patent application (UK 1114105.8), where the addition of steam helped to raise the overall reactivity of the material patented.  The work was also important for scale-up activity in the the EU Caoling project (www.caoling.eu), the largest demonstration of post-combustion carbonate looping in the EU (1.7 MWth), and where effects of steam were not known previous to the project

Title: Morphological Changes of Limestone Sorbent Particles during Carbonation/Calcination Looping Cycles in a Thermogravimetric Analyzer (TGA) and Reactivation with Steam
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time that shrinkage of particles of CaO during repeated cycles of calcination and carbonation invalidated simple attrition models relying on laser scattering and allows proper closure of mass balances relying on particle diameter. Such research fostered an invite to join the EU Caoling project (www.caoling.eu) the largest industrial/academic pilot-scale demonstration of carbonate looping in the EU (1.7 MWth), (~£7,000,000), including (amongst others) Foster Wheeler and Endesa. The plant has been built and successfully operated; Foster Wheeler now consider the technology ready for scaleup to 30 MW. Contact Javier Alvarez: Francisco.Alvarez@fwes.fwc.com

Title: The zero emission carbon concept (ZECA): Extents of reaction with different coals in steam/hydrogen, tar formation and residual char reactivity
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time the potential for hydrogasification of coals using pressures of 70 bar and temperatures of up to 900°C and realistic but challenging to achieve heating rates of >1000K/s, supporting a new highly efficient (~ 70 % electrical efficiency) potential pathway for coal or biomass utilisation. This led to further collaborative work with China and in the UK under the UK-China collaboration on clean coal (EP/G06265X/1, £272,455; EP/I010912/1, £578,218). EP/G06265X/1 builds directly upon this work, moving from the mg (wire mesh reactor) to g (fluidized bed) scale.

Title: Investigation into potential synergy between power generation, cement manufacture and CO2 abatement using the calcium looping cycle
AdditionalInformation: Joint work with cement manufacturer, Cemex, firstly demonstrated (publishing 2 years before competitors) that exhausted by-product from the calcium looping cycle for CCS can be used to manufacture viable cement, engendering further funded work with Cemex and the Grantham Institute. Owing to the  portfolio of industrial CCS research developed following this paper, including £300k for further cement research (EP/K021710/1), PSF was nominated as Co-I  (research champion – Industrial CCS) for the £10 million UK CCS research centre (EP/K000446/1), jointly leading the UK industrial CCS prioritisation process for DECC and BIS. Contact Philip Sharman, Chairman Advanced Power Generation Technologies Forum, philip.sharman@evenlodeassociates.co.uk.
