Title: Modelling of a two-phase thermofluidic oscillator for low-grade heat utilisation: Accounting for irreversible thermal losses
AdditionalInformation: Application of the heat transfer framework in http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijheatmasstransfer.2012.08.023 to account for losses in a thermofluidic-oscillator engine, whose consequent extension to reciprocating machines led to: (1) "Best Paper in Thermodynamics" award, International Conference HEFAT2012 (7/2012, Malta); (2) £1M EPSRC project [EP/J0060411] and $10Mn UNIHEAT-project [MMikhailov@corp.i-gorod.com] with BP [Dan.Coy@bp.com]. Basis of collaboration with: (1) UK industry – directly relevant to company Isentropic with which close co-operation was facilitated [James.Macnaghten@isentropic.co.uk]; (2) global industry – initiating a relationship with Honeywell (e.g. on DECC Advanced Heat-Storage Competition); presented at Foster-Wheeler (FW) Technology Forum (2/2012) as part of industrial outreach and CNM's FW-Fellow role [Michael_Stockle@fwuk.fwc.com].

Title: Heat transfer augmentation in unsteady conjugate thermal systems - Part II: Applications
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: A cornerstone theoretical-modelling-experimental contribution wherein a new framework is defined that allows for the characterisation of augmentation in unsteady convective flows. The first paper (of two-parts) develops the approach, while this second paper employs the framework to predict the magnitude of augmentation in two canonical flows, in excellent agreement with state-of-the-art measurements. Notable global visibility is attained via the collaboration with the Japanese Defence Academy (see co-authorship). Contributed to lead/corresponding author's (CNM) invitation to co-Chair the 13th UK Heat Transfer Conference (9/2013, London), and was the springboard for the securing of the directly-related £840k EPSRC heated films project [EP/K008595].

Title: A dynamic model for the efficiency optimization of an oscillatory low grade heat engine
AdditionalInformation: First presentation of a complete dynamic model, including inertial effects, of two-phase thermofluidic oscillators for low-grade heat (waste/solar) conversion, which spawned 5 follow-up papers in high-impact journals (e.g. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2012.11.056, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2012.12.069). This work’s significance is evidenced by CNM’s invitation to give a Keynote on waste heat utilisation systems at International Conference SusTEM2011 (10/2011, Newcastle). Further significance arises through a collaboration with UK SME-company Thermofluidics (see co-authorship) [Tom.Smith@thermofluidics.com]. The work was an essential contributor towards the €1Mn (Imperial=€230k) EU-FP7 Up-THERM project [#605826], and catalysed DECC/DCLG relationships, with inroads into UK government energy-policy shaping (e.g. presentation at DECC on solar/thermal-powered technologies, 1/2013) [Robert.Edwards@decc.com].

Title: Shear layers in the turbulent pipe flow of drag reducing polymer solutions
AdditionalInformation: World-first reported identification of the effects of drag reducers on turbulence, documenting "shear layers" for the first time in the literature, enabling the proposal of a new drag reduction mechanism. Industrial partner Halliburton are using the results and insight from this work to develop new high-efficiency/low-degradation drag reducers [NormanConsultingService@gmail.com]. Led to Halliburton-funded Research Associate position to continue this work, and was the foundation of a Sulzer-funded project; details being finalised [Moncef.Tanfour@sulzer.com]. This approach to drag reduction is also under evaluation by members of the Transient Multiphase Flow consortium [Lee.Rhyne@chevron.com], e.g. leading to £150k ENI-funded PhD project being finalised.

Title: A quantitative atlas of histone modification signatures from human cancer cells
AdditionalInformation: This article presents a holistic and proteomic characterisation of histone post-translational modifications (PTMs) across 24 cancer cell lines, which was referenced by Biome as ‘a helpful resource for the community to further analyse and classify cancer cells’ (http://www.biomedcentral.com/biome/cancer-mapped-an-atlas-of-histone-modifications-across-cancer-cell-lines/). The LC-MS/MS workflow utilised in this article for quantitatively profiling histone PTMs is being translated to identify therapeutic targets with Pfizer-Neusentis (Dr. Rachel Grimley; Epigenetics Exploratory Lead) and has resulted in a joint Pfizer-Neusentis and Institute for Chemical Biology (ICB)-funded PhD studentship award (http://www.icb-cdt.co.uk/research/projects/profiling-the-methylome-targets-of-histone-lysine-methyltransferases).

Title: Novel phosphorylation sites in the S. cerevisiae Cdc13 protein reveal new targets for telomere length regulation.
AdditionalInformation: In this work LC-MS/MS and sophisticated bioinformatics were combined to identify 16 novel sites of phosphorylation on Cdc13 and quantify their changes across the cell cycle to identify targets affecting telomere length, a chromosomal feature that has strong links to aging.  The bioinformatics algorithm first described here was further developed into software that was licensed through Princeton University (http://puotl.technologypublisher.com/technology/8306) to Novartis and Constellation Pharmaceuticals, Inc.  (Bill Amsbaugh, Director) to assist in their search for epigenetic therapeutic targets.  This subsequently led to a consulting appointment with Constellation Pharmaceuticals under the activities of data analysis and experimental method development.

Title: Biclustering via optimal re-ordering of data matrices in systems biology: rigorous methods and comparative studies
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an optimization-based approach for the biclustering of large-scale datasets in systems biology.  In contrast to other clustering methodologies, this method mathematically guarantees optimal re-ordering.  The optimal biclustering algorithm (publically available as a webtool: http://helios.princeton.edu/OREO/) subsequently became an integral subroutine for several algorithmic frameworks for protein design (as referenced in Bellows M. et al., Biophys. J., 99(10), 2010) and protein structure prediction (http://helios.princeton.edu/ICON/), and led to a successful collaboration with the US Environmental Protection Agency (Dr. Richard Judson; EPA NCCT) on the prediction of in vivo toxicities from in vitro assays (DiMaggio et al., Toxicol. Sci., 118(1), 2010).

Title: A Mixed Integer Linear Optimization Framework for the Identification and Quantification of Targeted Post-translational Modifications of Highly Modified Proteins Using Multiplexed Electron Transfer Dissociation Tandem Mass Spectrometry
AdditionalInformation: In liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS), when peptides of the same elemental composition elute at similar times, they co-fragment and produce ‘mixed’ tandem MS.  This problem is unusually prevalent for hypermodified proteins, and this article presents the first approach for the interpretation of mixed tandem MS.  The algorithm combined with a novel LC-MS/MS approach (Young N. et al., Mol. Cell. Proteom., 8(10), 2009) resulted in the high-throughput analysis of combinatorial histone codes, which was described by Michael Washburn as ‘an impressive development of an enabling technology’  (http://f1000.com/prime/1164285) and led to an NIH Research Service Award (Award Number F32GM093490; $69,687).

Title: Global Optimization of Mixed-Integer Quadratically Constrained Quadratic Programs (MIQCQP) through Piecewise-Linear and Edge-Concave Relaxations
AdditionalInformation: The manuscript proposes a novel deterministic global optimisation approach for solving Mixed-Integer Quadratically-Constrained Quadratic Programs and lays the theoretical foundation for the commercial software GloMIQO (http://helios.princeton.edu/GloMIQO). Using the software implementation integrating: edge-concave relaxations; piecewise-linear underestimators; eigenvector projections; the reformulation linearisation technique, the authors subsequently collaborated with Dr. Michael Bussieck towards releasing GloMIQO publicly (mbussieck@gams.com; GAMS Software GmbH; http://gams.com/solvers/solvers.htm#GLOMIQO). The paper was further validated when researchers from: Carnegie Mellon University; ExxonMobil; LNEG (Portugal) successfully used GloMIQO for their research (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0098135413000458; http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0098135413000306). The paper contributed to the Royal Academy of Engineering awarding a five-year Research Fellowship to Dr. Misener (£540k, 2012-17).

Title: Forced desorption of nanoparticles from an oil-water interface.
AdditionalInformation: Self-assembly of nanoparticles at fluid interfaces is central to the stabilization of emulsions and foams in oil recovery and in biomass conversion. The reverse process – disassembly – enables the recycle and reuse of nanoparticles in more sustainable processes, but has received less attention. We demonstrated the possibility of recovering the nanoparticles by mechanical compression of the interface, without the aid of chemicals. Being the first compelling demonstration of this phenomenon, it was featured on the cover of the journal (http://pubs.acs.org/toc/langd5/28/3) and resulted in an invited Feature Article (Garbin, Crocker, Stebe, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science 387, 1-11, 2012).

Title: Revisiting the chemistry of graphite oxides and its effect on ammonia adsorption
AdditionalInformation: What does sulfur have to do with graphite oxide (GO)? While GO is thought to be composed of C, O and H, this paper evidences that sulfur, in the form of the sulfonic group, is incorporated in the structure of GO synthesized via Hummers method. As a result, the chemistry of GO is significantly modified as for instance during ammonia adsorption. This work was presented in an invited lecture at the 4th International Symposium on Carbon for Catalysis (Dalian, China, Nov 2010) and was pivotal in securing funding from the US Army Research Office (PI: Teresa J. Bandosz; 2010-2013; $370,000).

Title: Reactive Adsorption of Ammonia on Cu-Based MOF/Graphene Composites
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the synthesis of a new adsorbent composed of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and graphene, for the removal of toxic gases such as ammonia. New reactions between ammonia and MOFs as well as the creation of a new pore structure are described. This work was patented in 2011 (US 2011/0217217 A1). It was also presented as a plenary lecture at the 2010 Brazilian Meeting of Chemical Engineers and Brazilian Adsorption Society (Iguazu Falls, Brazil). The development of these new adsorbents initiated an industrial collaboration with Avon Protection (pete.swearengen@avon-rubber.com).

Title: MOF−Graphite Oxide Composites: Combining the Uniqueness of Graphene Layers and Metal−Organic Frameworks
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the solvothermal synthesis and characterization of a new class of porous composites of metal-organic frameworks and graphene, using spectroscopic and imaging techniques. The significance of this research was acknowledged at the 2011 International Carbon Conference as Dr. Petit received the French Carbon Group Award (http://www.gfec.net/) and gave an invited talk (Shanghai, China, Jul. 2011). This work encouraged new research by other groups on the application of these materials in CO2 capture (Chem. Commun. 2013, 49, 4947) and sensing (J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 14487).

Title: The role of hydrophobic amino acid grafts in the enhancement of membrane-disruptive activity of pH-responsive pseudo-peptides
AdditionalInformation: Electrostatic repulsion from cell membranes is a key challenge in using anionic polymers for cytoplasmic delivery, and is addressed in this paper. This paper enables us to develop two novel platform technologies: (i) drug-delivery platform for siRNA (Adv. Funct. Mater. 2013, 23:565-574), protein (Adv. Mater. 2009, 21:3910-3914) and small-molecule model drugs (Biomaterials 2011, 32:2953-2958); (ii) cell preservation methods as covered in Patent No WO/2011/089391 and papers including Biomaterials 2010, 31:6096-6103 (Pfizer co-authors; paul.j.dominowski@pfizer.com) and Biomaterials 2011, 32:4443-4449. These two platform technologies were crucial to Imperial becoming a partner (€571K; PI: RC) in a large European project (SNAL 608184 FP7-PEOPLE-2013-ITN; €3.65M).

Title: Synthetic pH-Responsive Polymers for Protein Transduction.
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes successful cytoplasmic delivery of tumor-specific apoptotic protein, MBP-Apoptin, using a novel synthetic-polymer drug-delivery system. It represents a promising step in implementation of Apoptin as a viable antitumor therapeutic and also enables development of a novel protein-delivery system. The work was presented as a Keynote Lecture at the 18th Joint Annual Conference of CSCST-SCI (Cambridge, UK, September 2011, http://www.cscst.org/2011/speakers.htm). It has been key in winning a BBSRC Industrial CASE PhD Studentship (BB/I016058/1; PI: RC), which is supported by additional funding from MedImmune (Ralph Minter, MinterR@medimmune.com), on further developments for cytoplasmic delivery of MedImmune’s novel biological payloads.

Title: pH-responsive endosomolytic pseudo-peptides for drug delivery to multicellular spheroids tumour models.
AdditionalInformation: The transport of drugs through extracellular barriers to enter all cells in a tumour is a key drug-delivery challenge, and is addressed in this paper. The work establishes a new method for simple three-dimensional drug-delivery evaluation using magnetic multicellular spheroids tumor models. This method allows for facile magnetic separation of spheroids and avoids conventional centrifugation. The paper also led to a collaboration with NIH (John Park, parkjk@ninds.nih.gov) on in-vivo applications of cytoplasmic delivery of siRNA for malignant glioma treatment (Adv. Funct. Mater. 2013, 23:565-574) and to two CamBridgeSens Innovation Awards (http://www.ceb.cam.ac.uk/news.php/58/cambridgesens-innovation-competition-winners, http://www.ceb.cam.ac.uk/news.php/100/cambridgesens-awards).

Title: MCCORMICK-BASED RELAXATIONS OF ALGORITHMS
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative work with the Department of Chemical Engineering at MIT (Paul I. Barton, pib@mit.edu) laid out the theoretical foundations for constructing convex relaxations for the outputs of algorithms (as opposed to conventional, explicit functions). It has led to multiple applications in the fields of global optimization, e.g. for relaxing implicit and dynamic systems, and robust optimization, e.g. for enforcing worst-case constraints. It also initiated the development of the MC++ library (http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/environmentenergyoptimisation/software), which is maintained at Imperial College and freely available for academic users

Title: Adaptation strategies for real-time optimization
AdditionalInformation: In the context of an increasingly demand-driven and competitive economy, how can one make the most of a set of real-time measurements and a mathematical model in order to certify optimality of an existing process? This paper seeks an answer to this key question, and sets the basis for a new real-time optimization paradigm called modifier adaptation. It is the outcome of a long-standing collaboration with the EPFL (Automatic Control Laboratory), Switzerland, and the Ecole Polytechnique Montreal (Chemical Engineering), Canada. This work was presented in a plenary lecture at the 2008 European Symposium on Computer-Aided Chemical Engineering (ESCAPE).

Title: Convex/concave relaxations of parametric ODEs using Taylor models
AdditionalInformation: Constructing tight bounds on the trajectories over time of uncertain dynamic systems is a key computational challenge in robust and global dynamic optimization. This fundamental work considered the combination of nonconvex-set propagation techniques with polyhedral relaxation procedures, and it led to the global solution of dynamic systems comprising up to 10 decision variables for the first time, while the previous state-of-the-art methods were limited to 4-5 variables only. These developments are implemented in the freely available library MC++ (http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/environmentenergyoptimisation/software) and continued as EPSRC Grant EP/J006572/1 (PI: Chachuat, First Grant Scheme, £125k).

Title: Three-reaction model for the anaerobic digestion of microalgae.
AdditionalInformation: Anaerobic digestion of microalgae is a promising technology for biogas production and nitrogen/phosphorus recovery from biomass residues in microalgae biorefineries. For the first time, a mathematical model specifically describing the coupling between microbial growth and inhibition by ammonia is developed and experimentally validated. This paper is the result of a long-standing collaboration between the Chachuat research group and two French laboratories (LBE-INRA in Narbonne and BIOCORE-INRIA in Sophia-Antipolis). The society Naskeo Environment (contact: bruno.sialve@naskeo.com), which specialises in biogas plants, has taken up this research for development of advanced monitoring and control strategies

Title: Spontaneous imbibition in nanopores of different roughness and wettability.
AdditionalInformation: We developed Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations to predict quantitatively how the oil-water contact line dynamics in capillary flow depends on pore wettability and roughness. We upscaled the rate of imbibition from nano-pore to oil reservoir level given average roughness and wettability at pore level. These results can be used to better predict recovery rates from oil reservoirs, leading to invited publication in industry journal Saudi_Arabia_Oil_and_Gas 18, 22-27 (2011): http://saudiarabiaoilandgas.com/magazines/SAOG_ISSUE_18/saog18.pdf#page=2. Plenary presentation at international Pore2Field conference, Paris, 2011. This research has led to new PhD project, CASE-funded by Shell-Thornton (R.Cracknell, roger.cracknell@shell.com) on transport of hydrocarbons in porous media.

Title: Lattice-Boltzmann studies of fluid flow in porous media with realistic rock geometries
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we directly calculate hydrodynamic dispersion and molecular displacement in 2D micro-models, in absence of experiments. We develop combined particle-tracking and Lattice-Boltzmann (LB) simulations, using viscous-drag lubrication approximation; calculate sample-size dependence of permeability in 3D X-ray-tomography pore space images; and predict relative permeabilities. This is valuable in petrophysical analysis as experiments are difficult. Keynote presentation at Intl.-Symposium-Application-Of-Nanogeosciences-in-Petroleum-Engineering, Kyoto, Japan (2012). This research led to funding for combined multi-scale imaging/simulation lab (value £6M) with 5 new research contracts sponsored by Qatar Petroleum (QP), Shell, and BG-Group. Method is now evaluated for internal use by QP (Naji Saad, saad@qp.com.qa).

Title: Deposition of colloidal asphaltene in capillary flow: Experiments and mesoscopic simulations
AdditionalInformation: We directly compare microfluidic experiments and multi-scale particulate computer simulations to investigate colloidal asphaltene deposition vs. flow rate in capillary flow. Plenary presentation at Petrophase Conference, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 2009. It resulted in a recent industry paper (E.S.Boek et al., SPE 147539 (2011)) presented at the SPE-ATCE conference, Denver (USA), 2011, where the capillary flow results are upscaled to continuum scale Deep Bed Filtration (DBF) model. Schlumberger has implemented the upscaled DBF asphaltene model in their ECLIPSE reservoir simulator, see http://www.software.slb.com/store/_layouts/SLB/Pages/ProductDetailPage.aspx?pid=ACE3-P1. This work led to a new PhD project funded by Schlumberger (Ziauddin@slb.com) and an EU research grant FP7/608621/£170K.

Title: Quantitative Molecular Representation of Asphaltenes and Molecular Dynamics Simulation of Their Aggregation
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, we have created a generic 3D algorithm to systematically generate and optimise Quantitative Molecular Representations (QMRs) for crude oil asphaltenes based on experimental data. We have pioneered the use of these structures directly in Molecular Dynamics calculations to predict aggregation behaviour in different precipitants. The method enables identification of problematic crude oil asphaltenes and systematic development of aggregation inhibitors. Plenary presentation at Petrophase Conference, Florida(USA), 2012. The paper has resulted in new research contract with Shell (PhD project, £200K, Rajappan.Vetrivel@shell.com) to determine QMRs for their asphaltenes and Shell in-house R&D project to calculate solubility parameters.

Title: The “Djedi” Robot Exploration of the Southern Shaft of the Queen's Chamber in the Great Pyramid of Giza, Egypt
AdditionalInformation: Prestigious, world leading design and deployment of unique robot within the Great Pyramid, Egypt, published in leading applied robotics journal. Richardson developed the concept, led the design/construction team, piloted the robot. Discovered writing hidden for 4500 years and discovered mysterious copper pins were decorative, answering questions that had troubled archaeologists for decades. Featured in New Scientist Magazine (May 2011) and ranked in top 10 stories 2011 (http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn21309-2011-review-the-year-in-life-science.html). News articles in every continent. Resulted in funding to solve new problems [Scoutek ltd (Phd funding £45K)(creationeer@btinternet.com)]. Work featured prominently in successful EPSRC National Robotics Facility £4.3M (including industry)[Richardson PI].

Title: Estimating the mechanical properties of retinal tissue using contact angle measurements of a spreading droplet
AdditionalInformation: Recently published in arguably the premier journal in the field of interfaces, colloids and physical chemistry, this Medical Research Council funded (Project G0802583) multidisciplinary collaboration of physicists, engineers and a consultant vitreo-retinal surgeon establishes a new technique for determining the mechanical properties of soft biological materials such as retinas. Characterising such tissue is vital for research into developing less invasive treatments for retinal problems, but is extremely difficult using e.g. atomic force microscopy. The work led to further funding from the Yorkshire branch of the National Eye Research Centre as pump-priming for a larger MRC application.

Title: Regional cartilage properties of three quadruped tibiofemoral joints used in musculoskeletal research studies
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This study was with a clinical collaborator (Conaghan, Consultant Rheumatologist, Leeds Teaching Hospital Trust p.conaghan@leeds.ac.uk ) and undertaken in the Leeds Musculoskeletal Bioengineering Research Unit, a NIHR funded unit (http://lmbru.ac.uk/) supporting collaboration between the University and Leeds Teaching Hospital Trust. This study led to novel work demonstrating a link between the location of knee bone marrow lesions and areas of cartilage denudation in patients with knee osteoarthritis (presented at the British Orthopaedic Research Society, JBoneJointSurg Br 2012 94-B:suppXXXVI 19). These combined studies support the development of an in vitro whole joint model to use in translational research.

Title: Effect of tribological factors on wet adhesion of a microstructured surface to peritoneal tissue
AdditionalInformation: The first work describing adhesion properties of intra-abdominal tissue. Provides significant data for the design of a miniature mobile surgical device based on novel biomimetics approach. Supported by New and Emerging Applications of Technology (NEAT) grant (£363k, ref. FSD009). Interdisciplinary work achieved from collaboration between Mechanical and Electrical Departments at Leeds University and St. James’s University Hospital. Based on invited talk (Viennano International Conference on Nano Technology, Vienna, March 2009). Led to follow-on research and ongoing collaboration with St. James’s Hospital (validation contact, David Jayne, D.G.Jayne@leeds.ac.uk). Initiated new research direction on using magnetic fluids in surgery.

Title: Adaptive Undulatory Locomotion of a C. elegans Inspired Robot
AdditionalInformation: This paper, published in the highest impact mechatronics journal, demonstrates that a distributed control system inspired by the Caenorhabditis elegans nervous system solves the significant problem of autonomous adaptation to external constraints in serpentine robot locomotion. The novel control strategy achieves world-leading performance in obstacle negotiation and path-finding, with unprecedented computational efficiency. The research received significant media attention nationally and internationally, featuring on Channel 5’s Gadget Show (Season 16, Episode 4) and BBC Radio Leeds (12/09/2011) and being the subject of articles in The Engineer, Financial Times, New Scientist, Times Higher Education, Futurity (USA) and Scoop (Netherlands).

Title: The importance of fluid-structure interaction in spinal trauma models
AdditionalInformation: Based on prize winning paper at the Australasian Biomechanics Conference 2009 and built on previous international collaborations (with UBC, Canada (cripton@mech.ubc.ca)) culminating in the work of a Marie Curie Fellow (ESTER – 20599). Step change in modelling spinal cord trauma - first published account of a fluid-structure interaction model in which the cerebrospinal fluid was taken into consideration. Revealed that previous assumptions on the effect of trauma on the cord to be erroneous. Led to an invited book chapter (Neural Tissue Biomechanics 2011). Follow-on research currently being undertaken through two EPSRC funded DTC/CDT PhD students in collaboration with the Open University.

Title: Orientation of polyoxymethylene by rolling with side constraints
AdditionalInformation: International collaboration supported by British Council grant (WAR/342/22) to enable PDRA on EPSRC research grant (GR/R80087/01) to spend time at Galeski’s world leading centre for polymer engineering at Lodz. Novelty arises from application of compressive stress field during processing of highly oriented polymer by rolling with side constraints. It is demonstrated that the tensile voiding that causes premature fracture in die-drawn orientation processing is suppressed. This understanding has led to optimisation of the die-drawing processing conditions to make this an economically viable production route, now being exploited by industry (Contact: Johannes Verwaayen, Technical Director, Bridon – verwaayenj@bridon.com).

Title: Damage in large scale solid state deformation of thermoplastic polymers at elevated temperatures and varying strain rates
AdditionalInformation: Reports results of large collaborative EPSRC project GR/R80087/01 to investigate commercially viable means of producing highly oriented polyoxymethylene for wire rope applications. Understanding and optimisation of process parameters that control damage in die-drawn material has enabled order of magnitude increase in production speed. Results sufficiently encouraging for major collaborating company (Bridon) to set up prototype facility to produce nearly 70km of polyoxymethylene wire for deep sea mooring trials (Contact: Johannes Verwaayen, Technical Director, Bridon – verwaayenj@bridon.com). Has led to invited presentations at the Universities of Oxford (15/2/10), Cambridge (3/6/10) and IISc, Bangalore (4/8/11).

Title: Influence of autoignition delay time characteristics of different fuels on pressure waves and knock in reciprocating engines
AdditionalInformation: Spatial distributions of temperature and pressure in fuel-air mixtures create gradients of auto-ignition delay times and associated auto-ignitive propagation velocities. Acoustic theory is used to find amplitudes of the pressure waves, generated by the rate of change of heat release rate. If large, this leads to damaging engine knock, if small it benefits controlled auto-ignition. This innovative approach is confirmed by a variety of experimental studies by different workers. The paper demonstrates the influence of fuel properties on different modes of auto-ignition. It won the prestigious Sugden Prize of the Combustion Institute for the best British combustion paper in 2009.

Title: Electrochemical instrumentation of a hip simulator: a new tool for assessing the role of corrosion in metal-on-metal hip joints
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: These first in-situ electrochemical measurements on an instrumented hip joint simulator enabled estimates to be made of the contribution of corrosion to total material degradation in metal-on-metal hip replacements. Ion release was considerably less than in simple laboratory machines, suggesting that lubricating films were partially protecting the bearing surfaces throughout much of the cycle.  Milder conditions at the interacting bearing surfaces encouraged the formation of protective tribofilms consisting of organo-metallic species.  Evidence of ennoblement after about 100,000 cycles, reflected gradual running-in.  This significant study opened the way to quantify separate contributions to bearing degradation of mechanical wear and corrosion.

Title: Biotribocorrosion of metal-on-metal hip replacements: How surface degradation can influence metal ion formation
AdditionalInformation: Degradation was; 1% corrosion; 13% wear-enhanced corrosion and 86% wear. Corrosion represented (5-40%) in all tests. Enhanced elastohydrodynamic analysis revealed film thickness minima late in the swing phase, with current peaks and de-passivation later in the cycle at greater film thicknesses. This research underpins international debate on ‘metal ions’ and pseudo-tumours’; major reductions in metal-on-metal hip replacements and product withdrawals by major companies – (Cohen, (2012); BMJ 344; e 1410). Plenary invitations and awards; Dowson;- Bio-Tribology, Roy. Soc. Chem. (2012) Faraday Discussion 156, 9-30;   Neville;- Leeds-Lyon Symposium on Tribology, France (2013); Dowson;-   highest German Tribology Society Award (Georg-Vogelpohl Medal) October (2013).

Title: 2009 Knee Society Presidential Guest Lecture: Polyethylene wear in total knees
AdditionalInformation: A journal publication associated with a prestigious invited lecture at American Association of Orthopaedic Surgeons, Knee Society in 2009. New fundamental wear relationships for polyethylene in knee replacements are defined, which describe the effect of cross shear and contact area on wear. The research has led to the definition of distinctive low wear design solutions in mobile, fixed and partial knee replacements, which are now sold globally. Research was supported by EPSRC Platform grant EPF04387201 and subsequently applied in collaborative studies with DePuy (contact chardake@its.jnj.com).

Title: A new formulation for the prediction of polyethylene wear in artificial hip joints
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds from the fundamental understanding of the wear mechanism in UHMWPE artificial joints and presents a new paradigm shift using contact area rather than load in computational wear modelling for the first time. This extends the capacity of computational wear modelling and provides a complimentary tool to pre-clinical experimental testing of artificial hip joints. Research was carried out through EPSRC GR/T01013/01 and Portfolio grant GR/S63892/01 and subsequently applied in collaboration with DePuy through EPSRC/TSB IKC in regenerative therapies and devices EP/G032483/1 to support a global project in design and development of new hip prostheses (industry contact Isaac, gisaac@its.jnj.com).

Title: The effect of aspherical geometry and surface texturing on the elastohydrodynamic lubrication of metal-on-metal hip prostheses under physiological loading and motions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This is an invited paper published in a special issue “Elastohydrodynamic Lubrication” and contains the latest research findings in the computational lubrication modeling of metal-on-metal bearings for artificial hip joints. Research has been supported from ORSAS, EPSRC project GR/S62307/02 and Portfolio grants GR/S63892/01 and in collaboration with industry (DePuy, Isaac, gisaac@its.jnj.com and Zimmer, Rieker, claude.rieker@zimmer.com) over a period of ten years. The unique computational modelling methodology provides an important part of the pre-clinical testing portfolios for metal-on-metal artificial hip joints as well as the design and optimization of the next generation devices to minimize the wear under adverse edge-loading conditions.

Title: Turbulent flame speeds in ducts and the deflagration/detonation transition
AdditionalInformation: A highly original analysis, based on acceleration of burning rate by self-induced turbulence, was proposed for determining whether a deflagration to detonation transition, DDT, might occur for flame propagation along a duct. Presented in the premier journal on combustion (high IP). It links flame velocities to shock wave equations in a numerical analysis. Co-financed by EPSRC gr/s70203/01, Siemens Industrial Turbomachinery (£16 000) and Shell Global Solutions (roger.cracknell@shell.com) (£11 500). Lotus Engineering and Jaguar Cars (jturner1@jaguarlandrover.com) also contributed to technical discussions. The Research Fellow, Dr Liu, is now employed at Siemens, ensuring transfer of knowledge and expertise.

Title: Friction Characteristics and Topography of Tribofilms from Anti-Wear Additives Applied to Metal V-Belt Type CVT Fluids
AdditionalInformation: This collaboration led to an invited plenary paper for Priest at the World Tribology Congress in Kyoto 2009 and 4 journal papers. The scientific outcome was increased efficiency of CVTs by increasing traction through lubricant formulation and reducing the clamping force and oil pressure demands.  Narita (keiichi.narita@idemitsu.com) is from the oil company Idemitsu Kosan of Japan, seconded to Leeds for PhD study as part of the internationalisation agenda of the company.  As a result he is now senior in the R&D division of the company and an Associate Editor of Tribology Online, the journal of the Japanese Society of Tribologists.

Title: Technique of simultaneous synchronized evaluation of the tribological components of an engine under realistic conditions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Improving fuel economy through lubricant formulation is a key automotive industry and legislative driver and this novel mapping technique allows the detailed sources of friction in an engine to be revealed with confidence and simultaneously. Major output from an EPSRC project with Federal Mogul, Ford, Jaguar and Shell (EPSRC GR/M56326, £173k, robert.i.taylor@shell.com) and placed us alongside MIT (USA) and Musashi Institute of Technology (Japan) as global research leaders in this field. The developed techniques used in subsequent research in Leeds funded by the EPSRC, Ricardo and Shell; in total yielded 8 journal papers and 1 SAE technical paper to date.

Title: Topology optimization of truss-like continua with different material properties in tension and compression
AdditionalInformation: First publication of method to successfully optimize structure with different material behaviour in tensile and compressive regions. Published in the prestigious journal of the International Society for Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization (ISSMO). Follow on work has led to design of steel reinforcement for concrete structures. Continued international collaboration with leading Spanish optimization group at Cartagena University.  Instrumental to new EPSRC project (EP/K020463/1) on A Biomimetic, Self-Tuning, Fully Adaptable Smart Lower Limb Prosthetics with Energy Recover (£618,676) as it allows to determine the position of the artificial ligaments, tendons, muscles and supporting structure when topologically designing the prosthesis.

Title: A control Strategy for Upper Limb Robotic Rehabilitation With a Dual robot System
AdditionalInformation: A unique and world leading approach to upper-limb rehabilitation that supports the shoulder, preventing damage likely with all other devices.    Results demonstrate controller reliability to deliver safe and coordinated upper-limb movements in stroke patients.  Published in the highest impact Mechatronics journal. The work won a 2008 innovation award from NHS (http://www.medipex.co.uk/events/nhs-innovation-awards-past-winners-finalists/nhs-innovation-awards-2008-winners/), and an international graphical system design award 2009 from National Instruments (www.ni.com/pdf/citizenship/en/report2009.pdf).  Successful in obtaining £684K follow on funds to for initial clinical trials (NIHR HTD 475).  Dr Peter Culmer obtained prestigious Senior Translational Research Fellow post at University of Leeds, 2011 as result of this work.  .

Title: Influence of acetabular cup rim design on the contact stress during edge loading in ceramic-on-ceramic hip prostheses
AdditionalInformation: The paper highlights for the first time the need for implant designers to consider acetabular cup rim geometry to reduce stress levels and corresponding accelerated wear in hip arthroplasty during edge loading / micro-separation. Micro-separation was defined at Leeds as contact between the spherical femoral head and the sharp edge of the acetabular cup. The work contributed to the successful £6.6M refunding of the Leeds Musculoskeletal Biomedical Research Unit (lmbru.ac.uk) by the NIHR. Computational models developed are currently being applied in collaborative research with DePuy/Johnson and Johnson (Graham Isaac, gisaac@dpygb.jnj.com) to support a new global product development programme [088908/Z/09/Z Wellcome/EPSRC].

Title: Thin film flow on surfaces containing arbitrary occlusions
AdditionalInformation: Presents collaborative research with the University of Canterbury, New Zealand. It develops the first model for thin film flow past arbitrary occlusions and extends lubrication methods to more practically-important flows (e.g. pesticides on foliage) where the occlusions are much taller than the characteristic film thickness. A spatially- and temporally-adaptive multigrid approach is developed which is capable of providing the required local grid resolution near occlusions without rendering the flow problems computational infeasible. This is the first study to provide the efficiency needed to obtain grid-independent solutions for thin film flows over the highly heterogeneous substrates encountered throughout science and engineering.

Title: Tribology and wear of metal-on-metal hip prostheses: Influence of cup angle and head position
VolumeTitle: The Journal of bone and joint surgery. American volume
AdditionalInformation: Focuses on the cause of high wear, ion release and failure in metal-on-metal hips.  Findings support clinical concerns raised in an MHRA warning (http://www.mhra.gov.uk/home/groups/dts-bs/documents/medicaldevicealert/con079162.pdf, April 2010) relating to clinical consequences of high wear.  Co-authored by industry. Study forms one of the first comprehensive systematic assessments of the effects of rotational and translation misalignment of the head and cup on wear of metal-on-metal hips.  Findings have been presented at clinical meetings worldwide by two authors (SW/JF) invited to speak as consultants to DePuy International (Isaac, gisaac@its.jnj.com).  Laboratory techniques developed have been used to more rigorously test other new bearing materials.

Title: The dynamics of the impact and coalescence of droplets on a solid surface
AdditionalInformation: Multidisciplinary work from a new collaboration between Leeds Mechanical Engineering and Cambridge University under ESPRC Programme Grant EP/H018913/1, grant EP/F065019/1 and industry (FFEI Ltd, peter.walsh@ffei.co.uk).  Describes a novel experimental rig allowing flow visualisation within droplets previously not possible. Presentation at the international 63rd Annual Meeting of American Physical Society's Division of Fluid Dynamics confirmed the leading nature of the system, which formed the basis for later experimental and computational work. The paper also describes and validates a new predictive lattice Boltzmann model including contact angle hysteresis. The work led to an industrial research position at Domino Ltd for Betton (Eleanor.Betton@domino-uk.com).

Title: Competing geometric and inertial effects on local flow structure in thick gravity-driven fluid films
AdditionalInformation: Published in one of the two premier international fluid mechanics journals, this was an international collaboration with Bayreuth University, Germany sponsored by EPRSC visiting fellowship grant (EP/E029183/1) to Leeds authors. This is the first paper in the field of thin film flow to devise a means of characterising surface topography effects on recirculating flow development in terms of a local Reynolds number. The work has been presented at three international meetings (EUROMECH Colloquium 497, 8th European Coating Symposium, XXII International Congress of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics) and led to several follow-up papers in leading journals plus further funding to Bayreuth.

Title: The Coordination of Upper and Lower Arm Rotation
AdditionalInformation: Written in collaboration with internationally recognised clinicians and neuroscientists, the measurement techniques developed overcame the fundamental problem of reliably measuring dynamic position of the upper-limb using markers attached to soft tissue, enabling robust evidence of recovery post stroke and functional coupling between upper and lower arm segments to be gathered. This fundamental neuroscience insight highlights the need for upper-limb physiotherapy robots to provide coordinated movement patterns, setting the standard for robot controller algorithms. Both the measurement system developed and controller algorithms designed to promote coordinated movement, have subsequently been used in high-quality UKCRN portfolio clinical studies (UKCRN-ID:2142, 7951 and 11531).

Title: Electrochemical investigation of corrosion and wear interactions under fretting conditions
AdditionalInformation: The first paper to map tribo-chemical behaviour of materials tested under fretting conditions. The results are significant for the design and increased safety in exploitation of steam generator components in nuclear plants (verification contact: Helmi Attia, Helmi.Attia@nrc-cnrc.gc.ca). Fundamental work providing novel experimental method for prediction of wear accelerated due to corrosion under fretting by analysing passive film removal kinetics. Led directly to follow on research in bearings where the method is being used to measure resistance to fretting of selected ceramic materials as a part of Marie-Curie ITN Twin Site project between Leeds and SKF Netherlands (FP7, ref. 317334, €1.5m).

Title: Comparison of ceramic-on-metal and metal-on-metal hip prostheses under adverse conditions
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: This study formed support of FDA submission that was unanimously supported by the panel (http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm259061.htm ), prior to clinical launch of ceramic-on-metal hip replacements, and was funded by industry (DePuy International Ltd, a Johnson and Johnson company, contact Isaac gisaac@its.jnj.com also co-author) through a technology partnership. The paper demonstrates that ceramic-on-metal hip replacements are more resistant to wear under clinically relevant hip simulator conditions compared to metal-on-metal hip replacements.  Invited to present at Chinese (Xiamen, China 21/11/2009), Korean (Daegu, Korea 14/05/2010) and Dutch (Utrecht, Netherlands 14/11/2011) Hip Society on topic.

Title: A new tool for assessing human movement: the Kinematic Assessment Tool
AdditionalInformation: This paper details a portable system for the measurement of human movement in fundamental neurological research which has been translated to clinical and educational applications for assessment of movement disorder. The research has led to a patent (PCT/GB2007/001931). It has driven ongoing multidisciplinary collaboration (j.williams@aberdeen.ac.uk, Aberdeen; CHLi@mednet.ucla.edu, UCLA) with citations in high-impact publications (Current Opinion in Neurology, Neuropsychologia). It is being used in the NHS ‘Born in Bradford’ study to help assess over 10000 children and will thus help inform UK health policy. The research has led to a commercial version, developed with Mulraney Group (Gerry.Mulraney@mulraney.com) and Scottish Enterprise.

Title: Influence of the meniscus on friction and degradation of cartilage in the natural knee joint
AdditionalInformation: A tribological simulation of the medial compartment natural knee and the first definition of relationships between contact stress, frictional shear stress and wear. Presented as part of a keynote plenary lecture at World Tribology Congress in  Kyoto 2009 “Tribology for Life”. Research has led to the award of EPSRC programme grant in Tribology of Cartilage and Cartilage Substitution £5M 2009-14 EPSRC  EPG 01121721.  The simulation method has now been  developed  for the full natural knee and new simulation equipment developed and commercialised in partnership with Simulation Solutions (contact nick.eldred@simsol.co.uk).

Title: Development and characterization of an acellular porcine medial meniscus for use in tissue engineering
AdditionalInformation: An output from major collaborative research programme with Ingham in Biological Sciences which has led to development of novel tissue specific acellular biological scaffolds, with properties matched to those of the native tissue. Research supported by EPSRC EPG 01121721 and through the Wellcome Trust/ EPSRC Centre of Excellence in Medical Engineering. The international patent WO 2008/1059244, has been licensed to university spin out Tissue Regenix PLC (Fisher & Ingham 2006). The dCELL® partial meniscus biological scaffold is being commercialised by university spin out Tissue Regenix PLC.

Title: The biomechanical effectiveness of prophylactic vertebroplasty: A dynamic cadaveric study: Laboratory investigation
AdditionalInformation: Delivered through an Action Medical Research Grant (AP 1028) with DePuy Spine as partners Led to two major international collaborations through a prestigious EU Marie Curie ITN (SpineFX – 238690, €3M, 2009-13 - RMH Coordinator/PI – www.spinefx.eu, 3 leading EU Universities (including ETH Zurich) and 3 SMEs) and an EPSRC investigation of vertebroplasty for treating multiple myeloma with Dr Whyne (cari.whyne@sunnybrook.ca), University Toronto (EPSRC - EP/H013385/1 £596K – RMH PI, Industrial partner, Arthrocare SE). Formed the basis for several consultancies with DePuy Spine, Inion SE, Arthrocare SE and Apatech Ltd, total value>£120K . Led to invited presentations (GRIBOI, Uppsala 2012, ABC7, Brisbane 2009).

Title: Cross-linked glenoid prosthesis: A wear comparison to conventional glenoid prosthesis with wear particulate analysis
VolumeTitle: Journal of Shoulder and Elbow Surgery
AdditionalInformation: Arising from a multidisciplinary industrial research contract held jointly by Faculty of Biological Sciences and School of Mechanical Engineering (CKlotz2@DPYUS.JNJ.com). Published with an international clinical co-author (Wirth) and international industry co-authors (Klotz, McNulty DePuy Synthes USA). Nanometre-sized wear particles contribute to the failure mechanism of implants and in this study were identified in shoulder simulator lubricants for the first time. The paper had a major surgical influence and international reach. This research has led to further industrial research contracts with DePuy to isolate particulates from new polymer bearing materials from simulator lubricants (Anti-oxidant polyethylene, polyether ether ketone (PEEK)).

Title: Identification of nanometre-sized ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene wear particles in samples retrieved in vivo
VolumeTitle: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery - Series B
AdditionalInformation: Nanometre-sized particles identified in tissues from failed hip joints for the first time. International reach via an invited presentation (UHMWPE Congress, Turin, 2009), and Tipper joining the organising committee, chairing sessions and presenting at the 5th and 6th UHMWPE Congress in Philadelphia (2011) and Turin (2013). Led to two industrial contracts to isolate wear particles from different UHMWPEs (DePuy Synthes, USA, gisaac@its.jnj.com), collaboration with Kurtz  (skurtz@exponent.com, Philadelphia), two journal publications (Wirth et al, 2009; Bladen et al, 2013), two Case studentships (DePuy/EPSRC), transfer of the methodology to the spine and award of a NIH programme Grant (5R01AR052653-04, $2 million).

Title: The influence of tibial tray design on the wear of fixed-bearing total knee replacements
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Investigation of wear of a new commercial tibial tray design from DePuy International, which demonstrated a wear reduction compared to previously used titanium tray under high kinematic demand. An example of simulation beyond ISO14243-3 standard conditions to differentiate performance in high demand patients using methods developed in Leeds.  This work was presented at the 2008 World Biomaterials Congress (Netherlands) and was carried out through our ongoing technology partnership collaboration with DePuy in knees (>£1m) (contact Cath Hardaker, chardake@its.jnj.com).  Research has also supported our collaboration and commercialisation of knee simulation systems by Simulation Solutions (contact Nick Eldred, nick.eldred@simsol.co.uk).

Title: Three-Component Multi-phase Velocimetry measurements on a GDI spray using optically efficient fluorescent tracers
AdditionalInformation: Invited for a special issue of Experiments in Fluids from the best papers at the 15th International Symposium on Applications of Laser Techniques to Fluid Mechanics, Lisbon, 2010.  The paper presents the first simultaneous two-phase velocimetry measurements from high pressure petrol sprays introducing an optical absorber to overcome multiple scattering and using a novel colour recording approach.  The work was funded through a multi-disciplinary project, Engineering/Chemistry (EPSRC GR/S69108).  The outcomes contributed to the award of an industrial contract from Parker Hannifin with funding from Yorkshire Forward through the Grant for R&D scheme, £345k to Leeds (pcore@parker.com).

Title: Deformation of Si(100) in spherical contacts - Comparison of nano-fretting and nano-scratch tests with nano-indentation
AdditionalInformation: Fundamental work providing increased understanding of mechanical behavior of silicon under complex loading geometries. Results are significant for the design of thin films on silicon for MEMS technology and simulations of ductile-regime machining of silicon. Led to follow-on research and ongoing collaboration with MicroMaterials – leading international manufacturer of innovative nanomechanical equipment. Led to development of a new product offered commercially by the company – currently used by research groups at MIT and nCAST (Southampton). Validation contact Ben Beake, ben@micromaterials.co.uk. Work resulted in follow-on funding from the Welsh Assembly Government Fund for the company (£342,421 in total, ref. A-ID009-13-qA767591 and A-ID009-13-qA870489).

Title: Dynamic surface microstructural changes during tribological contact that determine the wear behaviour of hip prostheses: Metals and ceramics
AdditionalInformation: This fundamental work in collaboration with Sheffield University (Rainforth M.Rainforth@sheffield.ac.uk) analysed the microstructure of explanted prostheses, characterizing the evolution of abnormal stripe wear patterns observed clinically. The work was presented at the Orthopaedic Research Society(San Diego, 2010) and has led to further publications (doi: 10.1002/jbm.b.3192, doi:10.1016/j.actamat.2012.01.009). The research was part of the Leeds Musculoskeletal Biomedical Research Unit (lmbru.ac.uk) and contributed to the successful £6.6M refunding of this BRU by the NiHR. The results have provided important evidence for users moving from Biolox Forte alumina to Biolox Delta composites clinically (http://www.ceramtec.com/ceramic alumina ceramic -materials/biolox/delta/ , (Robert Streicher, R.Streicher@ceramtec.de).

Title: Contact surface motion paths associated with leg length inequality following unilateral total hip replacement
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study to investigate the clinical potential for adverse hip replacement wear caused by leg length inequality following total hip replacement surgery.  The paper supports a clinical study by the authors indicating that leg length inequality is a top 5 cause of litigation in the UK/USA (doi:10.1302/0301-620X.95B1.30908). The work was supported by the Leeds Musculoskeletal Biomedical Research Unit.  Methodologies developed will be used to support the recent EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Medical Devices [EP/K029592/1].  19 patients have undergone new clinical assessment  by Martin Stone at Chapel Allerton Orthopaedic Hospital (Martin.Stone@leedsth.nhs.uk).

Title: Algorithms for the automated analysis of cellular dynamics within living fungal colonies
AdditionalInformation: This work provides a novel and robust methodology for long time series analysis of organelle dynamics in live cell systems.  The exemplary data from fungal cell colonies provided supporting evidence for a new understanding of the role of cell fusion in colony growth and phenotyping of individual organelles.  The work was the result of a new collaboration funded through a BioPhotonics platform grant (EPSRC GR/S96555) and directly led to a new project to study mosquito behaviour as a vector for malaria (FP7 AFRICA-HEALTH-F3-2011-265660, £325k to Leeds), the latter generating a patent application for new bed net designs.

Title: Computational fluid dynamic analysis and design optimization of jet pumps
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a computational fluid dynamics study of a jetpump within a formal optimization framework with validation through experiment  (Yorkshire Forward funded £375k). This has provided optimised jetpump geometries. Parker Hannifin, a major supplier of filtration systems, has adopted the methodology and designs and as a result developed a highly efficient droplet separation filter that was awarded the British Engineering Excellence Award in 2012 and has allowed engine manufacturers to reduce emissions in line with EURO6 requirements. Parker Hannifin have won contracts totalling £3M between Jan 2012 and Dec 2013, and £1.5M per annum between 2014-2017. Corroboration:  pcore@parker.com

Title: Investigation of the interactions between a novel, organic anti-wear additive, ZDDP and overbased calcium sulphonate
AdditionalInformation: Harmful environmental impact is limiting the use of conventional lubricant additives for anti-wear performance. For the first time, this paper introduced the mechanisms how an environmentally-friendly lubricant additive provides superior anti-wear performance to conventional additives. It provided novel/non-conventional approach for wear protection of engines, major impact on development of novel lubricants for markets in USA/Europe (Lubrizol/Mike.Sutton@lubrizol.com). - Led to a follow-on PhD project (Lubrizol/EPSRC CASE, £96k/Mike.Sutton@lubrizol.com), - Internationally recognised (Morina invited to examine a PhD viva of a candidate in Ecole Centrale de Lyon in France/Clotilde.Minfray@ec-lyon.fr)). The PhD candidate (Greenall/Andrew.Greenall@shell.com) successfully graduated and is now employed in Shell, Germany.

Title: Measurement of turbulent burning velocities in implosions at high pressures
AdditionalInformation: Awarded the Gaydon Prize for “most significant UK contribution to the 33rd International Symposium on Combustion”, Beijing, China, 2010. Presented at the premier event in combustion which has high IP. For the first time, a highly original twin kernel technique allowed detailed optical combustion studies at high pressures relevant to engines.  Detailed measurements, including observations of turbulent flame structure, have previously been unavailable at such conditions due to the associated technical challenges, which were resolved herein. The work contributed to the PhD of Mansour, (Markous.Abdo@kaust.edu.sa).  Subsequent research contracts of about £60000 have resulted from Shell Global Solutions (roger.cracknell@shell.com).

Title: Burning rates of turbulent iso-octane aerosol mixtures in spherical flame explosions
AdditionalInformation: A significantly more accurately quantified and fundamental study of enhanced burning rates due to aerosols than has been reported previously. Directly relevant to engines and hazards such as the Buncefield explosion. Presented at the premier event in combustion,  proceedings of which have high IP. First presented by Saat, amins@fkm.utm.my, at the Early Career Researchers Meeting, Combustion Physics Group, IOP, 22 September 2009, Loughborough University and was awarded 1st prize for ‘Best industrially-relevant research poster’ and 2nd prize for ‘best poster presentation’. It attracted a fully funded visiting Chinese academic, Dr liao shiyong, shyliao@gmail.com for a period of one year.

Title: Role of friction modifiers on the tribological performance of hypereutectic Al-Si alloy lubricated in boundary conditions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: Study of lubricant tribofilms’ formation kinetics will significantly increase the understanding of lubricant additive/surface interaction and their effect on friction/wear. Novel tribofilm characterisation approach in this paper provides the basis for developing the technique for tribofilm analysis in non-vacuum conditions, using Raman spectroscopy and X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy techniques. Results obtained have significantly improved lubricant development technologies for low density materials (BP Castrol/Jonathan.Green@uk.bp.com). This research led to follow-on funding: Morina/EPSRC/EP/I008519/£125k, a PhD project (Lubrizol/£80k/Mike.Sutton@Lubrizol.com) and contributed towards a EU Marie Curie Initial Training Network project (ENTICE/290077/€3,2 million). It also led to two synchrotron sessions in Diamond Light Source (SP6209 and SP6926/fred.mosselmans@diamond.ac.uk).

Title: The Effect of Anterior-Posterior Shear on the Wear of CHARITÉ Total Disc Replacement
AdditionalInformation: Delivered through a prestigious Wellcome/EPSRC medical Engineering Centre utilising a novel wear simulator for assessing wear in spinal disc replacements (SDR); exceeds ISO/ASTM standards. Based on an invited presentation at Spine Arthroplasty Society (2009). Research led to RMH accepting an invitation to Chair the BSI CH150 subcommittee – Spinal Devices and Osteosyntheses with a view to leading the UK’s contribution to the development of ISO standards in this area. Contributed to a Invited book Chapter (Comprehensive Biomaterials: Article 00212, 2011).

Title: De novo designed positively charged tape-forming peptides: self-assembly and gelation in physiological solutions and their evaluation as 3D matrices for cell growth
AdditionalInformation: Paper presents outcome of collaboration between Engineering (Wilcox), Chemistry (Aggeli) and Biology (Ingham) including work of PhD student Miles funded through EP/F010575/1 (Wilcox). Study focuses on fundamental characterisation and biocompatibility testing of novel self-assembling peptides developed at Leeds and demonstrates that they can be optimised for biomedical applications. Miles awarded PhD student of the Year from 2000 students across university for her research. Outcomes recognised at international conferences (podiums European Biomaterials Madrid 2013, TERMIS World Congress Vienna 2012), led to patent application (GB1306338.3) and follow-on funding (£1M ERC306615 and £3M Oxford collaboration EP/K020757/K021729/1; Wilcox) to develop peptides for spinal treatments.

Title: The use of preserved tissue in finite element modelling of fresh ovine vertebral behaviour
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Computational models offer potential to improve medical device testing by simulating patient variance, but large image datasets are necessary to build them. Here a novel approach to generate models using preserved tissue is presented, enabling larger datasets to be used for future simulations. Study recognised internationally (invited presentation World Biomechanics Singapore 2010), led to follow-on commercialisation funding (£50k through EP/G032483/1) with Simpleware Ltd (Philippe.Young@simpleware.com) and EPSRC Doctoral Prize (Garner). Study funded through £1M EPSRC Challenging Engineering (Wilcox, EP/F010575/1), successful outcomes of which led to £3M follow-on funding with Oxford (EP/K020757/1) and invitation to join RAEng Biomedical Engineering Panel (www.raeng.org.uk/societygov/policy/current_issues/biomedical_engineering).

Title: Comparison of Periprosthetic Tissue Digestion Methods for Ultra-High Molecular Weight Polyethylene Wear Debris Extraction
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: Contributed to the advancement of understanding of polyethylene wear particles associated with osteolysis in hip replacements. Applied novel particle isolation methodology, developed by Baxter (rmb29@drexel.edu, Drexel University, Philadelphia, USA) in collaboration with Tipper at the University of Leeds to improve reproducibility and speed of particle characterisation. International reach via presentation at the Orthopaedic Research Society (San Francisco 2008) and led to further collaborations between Tipper and Kurtz (skurtz@exponent.com, Philadelphia) on spinal disc replacements and an opportunity to join the Scientific Organising Committee for the 5th and 6th UHMWPE International Congress meetings in Philadelphia in 2011 and Turin in 2013.

Title: Wear and creep of highly crosslinked polyethylene against cobalt chrome and ceramic femoral heads
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Industry funded research in collaboration with Ceramtec AG (Germany) of a ceramic hip replacement prosthesis used clinically. The research demonstrated lower wear rate of highly cross linked polyethylene against the ceramic product compared to conventional cobalt chrome head. The Leeds simulation method is able to quantify low wear rates and therefore differentiate the effect of femoral head material on cross linked polyethylene for first time. Awarded the ‘International Collaboration’ prize in the Yorkshire Forward Centre of Industrial Collaboration Awards (2007). Presented at Ceramtec’s BIOLOX Symposium (Italy, 2006), Orthopaedic Research Society (USA, 2007), British Hip Society and IMechE Conferences (UK, 2007).

Title: Computational wear prediction of artificial knee joints based on a new wear law and formulation
AdditionalInformation: The new wear law developed recently with support through EPSRC Portfolio grant GR/S63892/01 has been applied for the first time for computational wear prediction in artificial knee joints in collaboration with DePuy and published in the top journal in Bioengineering. The computational prediction has confirmed importance of optimizing contact area and provided design guidance for future developments of artificial knee joints. The model is currently used extensively in collaboration with DePuy to underpin an industry funded experimental simulation programme on lower wearing prostheses (industry Hardaker, chardake@its.jnj.com), and to underpin collaborative work with Simulation Solutions on advanced knee simulators (Eldred, nick.eldred@simsol.co.uk).

Title: Robust and General Method for Determining Surface Fluid Flow Boundary Conditions in Articular Cartilage Contact Mechanics Modeling
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a generic algorithm that allows the computational modeling of a full anatomical joint model based on biphasic properties with the support from ORSAS and EPSRC EP/F043872/1. It complements the experimental part of EPSRC programme grant “Tribology of Cartilage and Cartilage Substitution” EP/G012172/1 > £5m 2009-2014. Research method is now being applied in collaborative industry research in partnership with Tissue Regenix (http://www.tissueregenix.com/) and supported by collaborative award through EPSRC/TSB IKC in Regenerative Therapies and Devices EP/G032483/1 to characterize decellularised meniscus as a biphasic material and to develop novel manufacturing metrology methods for quality assurance of partial meniscus product.

Title: The effect of contact stress on cartilage friction, deformation and wear
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Significant study in terms of the threshold damage levels in cartilage reported to underpin functional tribological experimental and computational simulations of the hip.  Supported by a CASE studentship (DePuy; with industry co-author; Burton aburton1@its.jnj.com ).  Paper details the effects of stress on cartilage in a pin-on-plate model simulating the in vivo effects.  Follow on work has developed a hip hemiarthroplasty simulation supporting the findings of the simple geometry model (Lizhang et al., JEngMed, In press) and underpins future work developing a novel whole joint in vitro simulation of the hip undertaken in the EPSRC Programme grant in Cartilage Biotribology (EP/G012172/1).

Title: Development of specimen-specific finite element models of human vertebrae for the analysis of vertebroplasty
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Presents the first comparison of specimen-specific computer models of human vertebrae against cadaveric data, for both intact specimens and those augmented with bone cement. Discoveries about cement-in-bone modelling made possible extension of application to further clinical cases. Methods were applied to a larger vertebral cohort through EPSRC Challenging Engineering grant (EP/F010575/1), and now to proof of concept funding with Simpleware (p.young@simpleware.com). The work led to considerable media interest including EPSRC YouTube video (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DM84qVXYjTY) and BBC coverage (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-12606144), plus Jones awarded prestigious British Science Association Media Fellowship (2010, http://www.britishscienceassociation.org/science-society/media-fellowships).

Title: Engaging children in healthcare technology design: Developing rehabilitation technology for children with cerebral palsy
AdditionalInformation: Winning the journal’s award for best paper 2010 and bringing together engineers, clinicians and paediatric physiotherapists, this paper describes how the novel techniques developed, elicited robust data from children with disabilities to inform the design of rehabilitation technology. Working in this challenging area, 37 non-disabled children and 15 children with cerebral palsy from 6 schools were involved in this study. The innovative process developed, generated important guidance for designing for children, subsequently used to design an award winning robot (GSDA finalist 2011 http://uk.ni.com/casestudies/winners) in an NIHR project (NIHR/NEAT-K005;£360k) and used in high-quality UKCRN portfolio clinical studies (UKCRN-ID:6303, 9600 and 11789).

Title: Effect of Engine Operating Conditions and Lubricant Rheology on the Distribution of Losses in an Internal Combustion Engine
AdditionalInformation: The mechanism of friction reduction with advanced engine lubricants of low viscosity and with friction reducing additives in an actual engine is demonstrated for the first time in this paper, published in the top US tribology journal.  The Lubrication Science Leader at Ford Research in the US, Dr Arup Gangapodhay (agangopa@ford.com), reported by email that it uniquely explains important anomalies seen in large scale vehicle fuel economy tests.  In the top 10 most downloaded articles for this journal from October to December 2009.  Led to an invited keynote paper for Priest at the 18th International Tribology Colloquium, Esslingen, Germany, 2012.

Title: Subscale tribofilm tribological modelling in boundary lubrication using multivariate analysis
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: Funded by BP (chris.warrens@uk.bp.com) and utilised extensive statistically designed laboratory experiments to significantly enhance a physical model through multivariate analysis, leading to equations that empirically capture surface chemistry in a way not yet possible through ab initio chemical modelling.  This approach is novel and very effective and this was a keynote presentation at the international conference Leeds-Lyon Symposium on Tribology, Lyon, 2009.  The Technical Specialist for tribology at Ricardo UK, Dr Phil Carden (phil.carden@ricardo.com), commented by email “I congratulate you and your colleagues on really taking forward the practical modelling of friction and wear in this kind of system”.

Title: Topology design of two-dimensional continuum structures using isolines
AdditionalInformation: First publication of new topology optimization method using design criterion contours to generate structural boundary, allowing multiphysics optimization. Published in highly regarded optimization journal, led to publications on method’s extensions to: 3D continuum, multiple load cases and stiffener designs of thin shell structures. Continued international collaboration with leading Spanish optimization group at Cartagena University. Has led to:  KTP with EADS UK (£138K) on topology optimization of aircraft components (Reference number: 8074) and new collaboration with another Spanish leading optimization group at the University of the Basque Country in Bilbao: (javier.canales@ehu.es, ruben.ansola@ehu.es)

Title: Dynamic capture of free-moving objects
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A unique approach to capturing delicate free moving objects that is based around jerk minimisation and self-tuning for robustness to mass/velocity measurement errors.  The paper validates theoretical controller design through experimental results.  The work is a new, fundamentally different approach that has broad applications in areas such as landing UAV’s and docking space vehicles.  In 2013 work at University of Central Florida is building on this work to develop robot hardware based on harmonic drive actuators towards capture of dynamic objects ($25K of internal funding, arjun@cs.ucf.edu).

Title: Three-dimensional modeling of in vitro hip kinematics under micro-separation regime for ceramic on ceramic total hip prosthesis: An analysis of vibration and noise
AdditionalInformation: This core research involved international collaboration with a French Orthopaedic Surgeon (El-hadi Sariali, hedisari@yahoo.fr) and presents for the first time, following fundamental in-vitro friction studies, a computational model of vibration and noise that may occur under edge loading conditions in Ceramic on Ceramic hip prostheses, a clinical concern worldwide. The study led to further work (doi:10.1016/j.jbiomech.2011.10.033, DOI: 10.1002/jor.21510, DOI: 10.1002/jor.21100) and was presented at the prestigious American Academy for Orthopaedic Surgeons (Las Vegas, 2009). These new findings are important to manufacturers (Ceramtec (http://www.ceramtec.com/biolox/), Mathys (http://www.mathysmedical.com/) and suppliers of ceramic on ceramic hip prostheses whom ensure product safety (Robert Streicher, R.Streicher@ceramtec.de).

Title: High cup angle and microseparation increase the wear of hip surface replacements
AdditionalInformation: An invited presentation at meeting of International Hip Society describing the mechanisms of edge loading and high wear in metal on metal hips, due to rotational and translational mal-position. This evidence of the causes of high wear in metal on metal surface replacement hips contributed to the subsequent recall from further clincial use. Subsequently  described in an invited clincial review paper, Fisher JBJS 2011, and in an  invited lecture to IMECHE Joined at the Hip meeting in 2011. These methods have been applied in industry research funded by DePuy (contact Gisaac@its.jnj.com).

Title: Effect of conformity and contact stress on wear in fixed-bearing total knee prostheses
AdditionalInformation: Supported by EPSRC portfolio award (GR/S63892/01) and WELMEC (Centre of Excellence in Medical Engineering funded by Wellcome Trust and EPSRC, WT088908/Z/09/Z) first description and experimental demonstration of the reduction in surface wear of polyethylene in  knee prostheses as a result of reduced conformity and contact surface area. Supported by fundamental pin on plate studies and definition of new wear law.  Findings have been applied  to describe low wear design solutions in low conforming total knee replacements, and in partial knee replacement, collaboration with DePuy (>£1m) (contact Cath Hardaker, chardake@its.jnj.com) both of which are now commercial products in global markets.

Title: Effect of cup inclination angle during microseparation and rim loading on the wear of BIOLOX® delta ceramic-on-ceramic total hip replacement
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: Fundamental wear study of a commercially available product (Ceramtec’s BIOLOX® Delta) using a stratified approach of clinically relevant adverse conditions. It was shown that the current commercially available ceramic matrix composite products are more wear resistant compared to previous generations of alumina ceramics under adverse conditions. This work was presented at the British Hip Society (UK, 2009), British Orthopaedic Research Society (UK, 2009), Orthopaedic Research Society (USA, 2010), and was an invited presentation at the Ceramtec BIOLOX Symposium (UK, 2009). The stratified approach to studying hip wear under adverse conditions has been adopted in current industry-funded research (contact sabine.begand@mathysmedical.com).

Title: An integrated methodology for predicting material wear rates due to erosion
AdditionalInformation: Funded by Syncrude (Canada) and the focus of 2 PhD researchers, this paper describes a new framework to minimize the requirements for experimental testing through the use of computational fluid dynamics in interpreting laboratory data. This led to an 18 month knowledge transfer fellowship (EPSRC/ University of Leeds /Cameron, Ireland) and played a major role in Cameron’s >£500k test program to gain thorough knowledge of the degradation mechanism within a choke under service conditions and used to design next generation chokes for the oil and gas industry in a reduced time-frame, thus demonstrating the industrial impact - corroboration: Eddie.McHugh@c-a-m.com.

Title: Bend Propagation in the Flagella of Migrating Human Sperm, and Its Modulation by Viscosity
AdditionalInformation: Paper is a result of an international and multidisciplinary collaboration across UK (NHS and Universities) and Brazil. This paper is the first to examine the waveform of the flagellum of human sperm in controlled physiological conditions. The demonstration of this informs basic research, the studies of chemotaxis and novel diagnostics and has been very well cited across observational and theoretical papers including broader work developing the theoretical understanding of swimming organisms in complex fluids.

Title: Wettability versus roughness of engineering surfaces
VolumeTitle: Wear/ The 12th International Conference on Metrology and Properties of Engineering Surfaces
AdditionalInformation: International and industrial collaboration with Ecole Centrale de Lyon, France and ALTIMET SAS, France, invited for peer-reviewed publication in Wear, a premier journal in the field, following presentation at 12th International Conference on Metrology & Properties of Engineering Surfaces, 2009, Poland. It describes the first wetting model directly linked with measurable real surface roughness parameters, hence allowing wettability to be predicted. Article is in SciVerse ScienceDirect "Top 25 Hottest Articles" (most downloaded) in 2011 for journal Wear and led to an invited 2-month research visit by Kubiak to the lab of Maxence Bigerelle, University of Valenciennes, France in 2012.

Title: Correlation of turbulent burning velocities of ethanol-air, measured in a fan-stirred bomb up to 1.2 MPa
AdditionalInformation: Presented in the premier journal on combustion (high IP). For the first time, world leading measurement and analysis techniques are presented/employed to yield detailed experimental data and prediction tools simultaneously at high pressure and high turbulence. Data for several fundamental burning rate parameters  is presented for this important bio-fuel.  The work clarifies several definitions of burning to reconcile ambiguities found in previous works.  Such data and interpretations are essential for improved engine model validation and will find application in the automotive and aircraft industries. The PhD student, Mansour, Markous.Abdo@kaust.edu.sa, has graduated and is applying the techniques developed at Leeds.

Title: Die drawn wood polymer composites. I. Mechanical properties
AdditionalInformation: First paper to report the incorporation of waste wood particles in a thermoplastic matrix prior to molecular orientation to give much enhanced properties compared with conventional wood particle composites.
