This paper describes the processing and mechanical properties whilst subsequent papers deal with the micro-mechanical modelling and hydro/thermal stability of the product. This approach was taken up commercially by Dow Chemicals (to whom rights were assigned) and similar products are now being marketed by Eovations (contact: kevin.nichols@eotek.com). Research directly led to Royal Society funded workshop at IISc, Bangalore attended by UK and Indian experts on biocomposites (27-28 March 2012).

Title: In vitro simulation and quantification of wear within the patellofemoral joint replacement
AdditionalInformation: First successful in-vitro measurement of polyethylene wear of patellofemoral joint replacement in multi-axis joint simulator.  Multi-body dynamics simulation has enabled rig to be designed to replicate accurately kinematics of actual joint for first time and to produce wear patterns of similar form to explanted prostheses. Follow on work in collaboration with Simulation Solutions has led to development of unique six station patellofemoral  knee simulator (contact: nick.eldred@simsol.co.uk). This has been applied in research studies supported by DePuy to determine the effect of different input kinematics and design on the wear of the patellar (contact: Dr G Isaac at gisaac@its.jnj.com).

Title: Effect of oil additives on the durability of hydrogenated DLC coating under boundary lubrication conditions
AdditionalInformation: This paper developed the missing knowledge link between fundamental mechanisms and engineering application. It is the first study which discusses the impact of lubricant additives on Diamond-Like Carbon (DLC) coatings durability, by testing them in conditions relevant to real engine systems. Methods developed are now adopted by other authors (DOI:10.1016/j.tsf.2009.09.110; DOI:10.1016/j.surfcoat.2011.11.031;DOI:10.1016/j.surfcoat.2010.07.012). - Internationally recognised (this work led to Morina being invited 2009 STLE/expert panel and keynote presentation/2009 World Tribology Congress).  This research led to follow-on funding: EC/NMP/2020Interface and two PhD projects (Infineum/£81k/Emmanuel.Laine@Infineum.com; Afton/£85k/Alisdair.Brown@AftonChemical.com). The PhD candidate (Haque/tabassumul.haque@exxonmobil.com) successfully graduated and is now employed in ExxonMobil, USA.

Title: A study of the effect of model geometry and lubricant rheology upon the elastohydrodynamic lubrication performance of metal-on-metal hip joints
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: Metal-on-Metal (MOM) hip joints potentially offer extended implant life to many patients.  However, generation of millions of (20-80) nm wear particles and release of large numbers of metal ions into the body have limited their use.  This early elastohydrodynamic (EHL) analysis of (MOM) implants for average loads and speeds considered conjunction modelling and shear thinning features of synovial fluid.  Minimum film thicknesses predictions for (MOM) hip joints of (30-50) nm were similar to the mean wear debris size, encouraging further development of the numerical procedures for combined squeeze and entraining motions.  Dominant roles of component diameters and clearances were recognised.

Title: A neuro-fuzzy approach to the weight estimation of aircraft structural components
AdditionalInformation: First publication of use of neuro-fuzzy logic techniques for weight estimation of aircraft structures at the preliminary design stage. Allows adaptability and inclusion of new materials and manufacturing to prediction method rather than using existing aircraft regression data. First advancement in the field in over 20 years. Work carried out in collaboration with the Airbus mass properties team (Evangelos.Vekris@Airbus.com), who funded student secondment, and with QinetiQ’s structures and aerodynamics groups (JCHarris@qinetiq.com). Led to further PhD work and Airbus secondment on weight estimation of aircraft hydraulic and electrical systems. Student has since obtained research position at Manufacturing Technology Centre, Coventry (Christine.Hannon@the-mtc.org).

Title: Bilevel optimization of blended composite wing panels
AdditionalInformation: First paper to optimize composite wing panes using lamination parameters with angle of composite plies as design variables; buckling, strain, and ply percentage as constraints. Allows very fast structural evaluation, so problem can now efficiently be optimized using global optimization method like Genetic Algorithms. Led to:  EC-FP7 funding for Advanced Lattice Structures for Composite Airframes project (€ 194K) (Reference: 265881) and follow-on EU project on the Production and Analysis Evolution for Lattice Related Barrel Elements Under Operations with Advanced Robustness; collaboration with TU Delft’s Aerospace Structures and Computational Mechanics Research Group (Z.Gurdal@tudelft.nl) and German Aerospace Centre (DLR) (Steffen.Niemann@dlr.de, Heike.Lohse-Busch@dlr.de).

Title: Erosion-corrosion of engineering steels-Can it be managed by use of chemicals?
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first paper in a long series of future papers and was the first to show that chemical inhibitors could be used to prevent erosion in oil and gas systems, Wang received PhD in 2007.  It stimulated contracts with Baker Hughes, s.ramachandran@bakerhughes.com (Ismail PhD, 2012), BP, alan.crossland@uk.bp.com (£300K over 3 years), Shell, steve.paterson@shell.com (PhD Barker, 2012).  Keynote talks by Neville at ABRACO corrosion conference Brazil, May 2012, NACE Corrosion US in 2010 and many invited talks by Neville at oilfield meetings in Aberdeen (2009/2010), Abu Dhabi (2009) and Houston (2010).

Title: Assessment of barium sulphate formation and inhibition at surfaces with synchrotron X-ray diffraction (SXRD)
AdditionalInformation: This paper was one of a series which used the Brookhaven National Laboratory Synchrotron Light Source in New York to make in-situ x-ray diffraction measurements on real scaling (surface crystallisation) systems.  The reviewers described this research as “pioneering”.  Mavredaki was awarded her PhD in 2009 and is employed by oil plus.  The work is sponsored by a 20-partner Joint Industry Programme (with Heriot Watt University) in which Neville is the Leeds PI.  The confirmation of this work is through the new FASTV Program 2013-2017.

Title: The influence of clearance on friction, lubrication and squeaking in large diameter metal-on-metal hip replacements
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: Novel experimental study using ultrasonic techniques to evaluate lubrication of metal-on-metal resurfacing replacements, in collaboration with University of Sheffield and Tribosonics Ltd (p.harper@tribosonics.com).  Study demonstrated correlation between friction, lubrication and incidence of squeaking in hip replacements.  First study to experimentally investigate squeaking of metal-metal resurfacing implants, and demonstrated it to be a tribological phenomenon. Ultrasonic methodology has been commercialised by Tribosonics Ltd for research applications. The approaches and understanding developed in this study are being applied to industry funded research to support new product developments and evaluate new products, such as DePuy Delta-motion hip replacement (GIsaac@its.jnj.com).

Title: Ceramic-on-metal bearings in total hip replacement: whole blood metal ion levels and analysis of retrieved components
VolumeTitle: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery - Series B
AdditionalInformation: This study examined clinical performance of ceramic-on-metal hip replacements, invented and developed at the University of Leeds in collaboration with DePuy International (GIsaac@its.jnj.com).  This study was conducted in collaboration with clinicians from South Africa and industry co-authors. The clinical data continued to show reduced metal ion levels compared to metal-on-metal at 2 years. To date approximately 15000 of these bearings have been implanted worldwide, 1600 in UK and has demonstrated 97% survivorship at 3 years, (National Joint Registry Report 2012), which is substantially better than metal-on-metal. This study is important in supporting its continued clinical use worldwide.

Title: The wear of fixed and mobile bearing unicompartmental knee replacements
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: First published wear study contrasting performance of fixed and mobile bearing unicompartmental knee replacements, investigating effect of design and reduced conformity on wear.  Industrially-funded study investigating novel low conformity bearing compared against the clinical market-leading implant.  This study has led to further collaboration with industry (DePuy International, CHardake@its.jnj.com) and clinicians to establish a more stratified approach to investigation of wear under clinically relevant conditions.  Presented as invited presentations at World Tribology Congress, Kyoto, Japan (2009), and European and Asia Surgeon professional education meetings (Kuala Lumpur, Vienna, Barcelona, Annecy 2009-2011).

Title: Wear of ceramic-on-carbon fiber-reinforced poly-ether ether ketone hip replacements
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research Part B:  Applied Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: This paper, conducted in collaboration with industry (DePuy International, GIsaac@its.jnj.com), investigates novel material for total hip replacement (THR). Carbon-fibre-reinforced-PEEK was examined in a flexible-design cup by University of Durham, but this study demonstrated its suitability as a low-wear option for THR. Follow-up research, through the EPSRC/Wellcome Trust WELMEC Centre of Excellence in Medical Engineering (grant code WT088908/Z/09/Z.), has caused us to examine material suitability for other joints and under more demanding conditions. This has led to major industry funded project with Invibio Inc. (abriscoe@invibio.com) to study carbon-fibre-reinforced-PEEK in knee. Keynote presentation at World Biomaterials Congress, Chengdu, China 2012.

Title: Comparison of nano-f`retting and nano-scratch tests on biomedical materials
AdditionalInformation: The first paper to report use of novel accelerated nanomechanical testing methods for tribological characterisation of biomaterials. The approach used simulates the repetitive and complex contact occurring in the body during abrasion by third-body wear. It addresses a key mechanism that governs roughening of metallic surface and damage nucleation at the bearing surface of artificial joints. It proved that nano-fretting method extends significantly the capability of nanomechanical testing in the optimisation of biomaterials. It has led to follow on research and ongoing collaboration with MicroMaterials – leading international manufacturer of innovative nanomechanical measurement equipment. Industrial co-author, validation contact: Ben Beake ben@micromaterials.co.uk.

Title: Autoignitions and detonations in engines and ducts
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: A turbulent flame accelerating along a duct generates a shock wave ahead of it. Analyses identify conditions for attainment of a sufficient turbulent burning velocity for the shock to trigger detonation in different mixtures. A commonality also is revealed between such a detonation and one arising from compression in an engine. An important new dimensionless criterion emerges for both the stability of the detonation front in the duct and the generation of strong “super-knock” in engines, possibly more useful than the existing one based on detonative cell size. This Issue of Transactions was dedicated by the Editors to the author.

Title: Large vapour cloud explosions, with particular reference to that at Buncefield
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper arises from the authors’ studies on the Buncefield Inquiry Explosion Mechanism Group, investigating this huge explosion. The severity of the explosion had not been identified in previous hazard assessments and it was imperative to develop an understanding of the underlying mechanisms. The paper covers pioneering analyses of self-acceleration of turbulent flames along lines of hedgerows, generating damaging pressure waves, with possible full, or partial, transitions to detonations. The generation of high-rising fireballs and firestorms is shown to be less likely, due to insufficient localised spillage, as was the role of strong radiation in significantly enhancing flame propagation.

Title: Analysis of wear, wear particles, and reduced inflammatory potential of vitamin E ultrahigh-molecular-weight polyethylene for use in total joint replacement
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: Invited paper selected as a research highlight of the 2010 Orthopaedic Research Society, USA. Collaboration with internationally leading group in Japan headed by Tomita (ntomita@chachan.mbox.media.kyoto-u.ac.jp). Research revealed novel biological benefits of adding Vitamin E to UHMWPE, indicating this material could outperform gold standard materials, leading to improved implant longevity. Led to Tipper being invited to deliver 5 international presentations in Turin and  Philadelphia (UHMWPE Congress 2009, 2011, 2013), San Antonio (ORS 2013) and Venice (CORS 2013), an invited journal paper (Bone & Joint Research, in preparation) and invited to join the scientific committee for two conferences in Philadelphia and Turin.

Title: Cross-shear implementation in sliding-distance-coupled finite element analysis of wear in metal-on-polyethylene total joint arthroplasty: Intervertebral total disc replacement as an illustrative application
AdditionalInformation: Delivered through a prestigious NIH Bioengineering Research Partnership (R01 AR052653-01 Uni/Iowa, USA, Leeds and Orthzentrum, Munich, £2.5M, 2006-11, RMH local PI). Describes, for the first time, the effect of input kinetics on the wear in total disc replacement within a unique design of simulator developed at Leeds. Concepts within this paper led to the successful bid for an EU FP7 NMP grant (LifeLongJoints – 238690, €13.32M, 20013-18 - RMH Coordinator/PI – 5 leading EU Universities (including ETH Zurich, Uppsala) and 7 commercial/healthcare organisations) to investigate novel coatings in total joint replacement with an emphasis on population based assessment of implants

Title: Biomechanical characterisation of ovine spinal facet joint cartilage
AdditionalInformation: First study to characterise biphasic properties of facet joint cartilage using combined experimental and computational approach, published in leading biomechanics journal. New data presented is needed to develop successful therapies for facet degeneration and for computational models of spine where properties have previously been approximated. Pilot study for this work formed basis of Spine Theme of successful £5M EPSRC Programme Grant proposal (EP/G012172/1). Methods now adopted by other researchers to characterise human cartilage and fed into ERC grant (ERC306615, £1M, Wilcox). Research recognised through international conferences (podiums European Biomechanics Edinburgh 2010, World Biomechanics Singapore 2010).

Title: Trabecular level analysis of bone cement augmentation: a comparative experimental and finite element study
AdditionalInformation: This study, in collaboration with the University of Bristol, is first to use a novel rig to image cement-augmented specimens during loading under high resolution x-ray tomography. Cement is widely used in orthopaedics and our earlier validation studies showed current modelling methods vastly overestimate the cement-bone stiffness. This paper provides a novel means to examine the microstructural behaviour and enables a direct comparison with micro finite element models, leading to improved model accuracy. Research led to invited talks (World Biomechanics Singapore 2010, Injectable Biomaterials Research Society (GRIBOI) Boston 2011), and contributed to successful major follow-on funding (ERC306615, Wilcox, £1M).

Title: Reduced motor asymmetry in older adults when manually tracing paths
AdditionalInformation: This paper, in a leading neuroscience journal, reports our human-kinematic measurement system used to assess the impact of age on human motor control. It uniquely enables high-quality, objective kinematic analyses in non-laboratory settings. It shows degraded performance in dexterous tasks with age that will inform fundamental neuroscience and healthcare research in conditions like Stroke. It led to an invitation to present the work at the keynote talk of the National Instruments 'NI Week' conference (Aug 2013, Austin, USA), highlighting the research to over 3500 international delegates.

Title: Design and Evaluation of a Buckled Strip Compliant Actuator
AdditionalInformation: Published in a premier international journal, this paper describes a highly novel reconfigurable actuator used as the fundamental building block of a full real-time hardware-in-the-loop cardiovascular simulation including a physical beating heart. Supported by Heart Research UK (RG2567;£378k), research overcame significant challenges to develop a system of sufficient fidelity to replace animal testing of heart assist devices. Capable of simulating various disease models, requiring variable size, shape and compliance, it won numerous international industrially sponsored awards including a humanitarian award, life science award and the prestigious National Instruments “application of the year”, (http://www.ni.com/gsdawards/explore_2012.htm), beating over 120 applications from 20 countries.

Title: Development of anti-icing materials by chemical tailoring of hydrophobic textured metallic surfaces
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: First study on functionalised metallic surfaces for delaying ice formation on the surface, published in leading interface science journal. It introduces a novel approach for preventing ice accretion on surfaces, potentially replacing the current approach harmful for the environment. Hydrophobic surfaces functionalised with anionic polyelectrolytes were designed, developed and tested with an in-house build freezing rig showing statistically significant lowering of freezing temperatures. This study was recognised in podium presentation in an international conference (Developments in Materials/Processes/Applications of Emerging Technologies(MPA)/Portugal/2012). The PhD candidate (Charpentier/T.Charpentier@leeds.ac.uk) successfully graduated and is now appointed as a research fellow in the University of Leeds.

Title: Evaluating an eye tracking interface for a two-dimensional sketch editor
AdditionalInformation: Computer support for creative design requires systems that demand less cognitive load from users so minimising interruptions to their creative flows.  This paper reports experiments using gaze data from an eye tracker to support shape exploration in a two-dimensional vector-based sketch editor. Results indicate that gaze can be used as an indicator of designers’ attention and intention, and that eye tracking has significant potential as an interface which responds to designers’ visual interactions. This is a novel application of eye tracking technology and the research could change how designers interact with future generations of computational design systems.

Title: Turbulent flame and mass burning rate in a spark ignition engine
AdditionalInformation: We provide expert advice, often based on simulations performed with bespoke software to engine OEM's, (£4.5M UltraBoost Project – TSB BN008E: scott.bredda@geprecision-engineering.co.uk, dricha69@jaguarlandrover.com). The burning rate models employed in this software were put to a comprehensive test using ported optical engines, LUPOE2, and it was found that flame propagation exhibits three distinct stages: strong flame acceleration followed by more or less constant propagation speed and a decelerating stage near walls. Existing models apply only to the second stage while largest energy release happens within the wall-affected period; for which a simple model for the burning rate has been formulated.

Title: Average vaporisation rate in turbulent subcritical two-phase flow
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a development of a novel, entirely Eulerian, approach to the description of turbulent two-phase flows with vaporisation; this approach is currently the only one allowing a description of liquid atomisation from the first principles. This paper’s significance is that it proves that the small-scale turbulence, often neglected in theory, is the rate-limiting process and without it it is impossible to predict pressure effects on vaporisation. As a follow-up work, a CASE studentship (0900250X, co-funded by Siemens Ind. Turbomachinery, jonathan.may@siemens.com ) was awarded in 2010 for incorporation of this model into the design process for their combustion chambers.

Title: Computational fluid dynamic investigation of liquid rack cooling in data centres
AdditionalInformation: Highlights energy efficiency gains in cooling of data centres using active rear door heat exchangers. Introduces a novel way of modelling server racks within data centres to capture both small and large scales. Published in a high impact journal, with an industrial co-author from Airedale, has leveraged an industrial contribution of £30000 active rear door heat exchangers in the Leeds HPC facility for model validation (contact g.r.hannah@airedale.com). Research led directly to the launch of the professional industry association, the Data Centre Alliance (simoncw@datacentrealliance.org) and attracted research funding from Iceotope and 3M to the value of £112000 (Peter.Hopton@icetope.com).

Title: Modelling of electrokinetically driven mixing flow in microchannels with patterned blocks
AdditionalInformation: Moving fluids in very small channels usually requires driving the flow by electro-osmosis. This paper combines, for the first time, the lattice Boltzmann method for the hydrodynamics with the traditional solution procedures for the calculation of the electric double layer and ion concentration. The solution procedure is more complex than may be first perceived as there is a two way coupling between the electrokinetics and the hydrodynamics. The flow dictates the advection of ions, whilst the charge density modifies the body forces that appear in the hydrodynamics.

Title: An analytical solution for the radial and tangential displacements on a thin hemispherical layer of articular cartilage
AdditionalInformation: This work develops for the first time an analytical model of the radial and tangential deformations of a hemispherical cartilage using asymptotics and Laplace transforms, which has been validated via biphasic numerical simulations. This approach offers an advantageous unique multiphysics coupling capability with an elasto-hydrodynamic lubrication solver to predict the behaviour of the bio-lubricant mechanics of a hip joint. Exposure of this work in a high impact journal has led to the industrial employment of Dr Felix-Quinonez as a researcher at the SKF Research Laboratories in the Netherlands (Armando.Felix@skf.com).

Title: Shape detection with vision: implementing shape grammars in conceptual design
AdditionalInformation: The problem of sub-shape detection prevents application of shape grammars to design synthesis problems involving arbitrary shapes in visual objects. The international shape grammar community has spent over 30 years searching for analytical solutions without success. This paper reports a novel application of object recognition from computer vision to shape grammar implementation.  Hausdorff distance is used as a similarity measure of arbitrary shapes, resulting in the world's first computational design synthesis system that works with arbitrary emergent shapes in designers’ 2D sketches. The research led to a further project (Leverhulme Ref: F/00269/Z) and an EU proposal with 8 partners.

Title: Shape exploration in design: formalising and supporting a transformational process
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops a taxonomy of shape rules used by professional designers that bridges the divide between theories of design computation and design practice. Results of experiments exploring how designers use sketches in creative design tasks are reported. Close alignments between the transformations identified in shape grammar theory and those made by the designers were identified. The use of shape grammars as an analytical framework to understand designers’ behaviours is the key novelty in this paper; insights gained provide a theoretical basis for emerging computational design systems and design education.

Title: A case study and critical assessment in calculating power usage effectiveness for a data centre
AdditionalInformation: Develops a new robust methodology for calculation and critical assessment of the industry-standard Power Usage Effectiveness Metric and identifies limitations of current methods for quantifying data centre energy efficiency. Applying the analysis to Facebook’s open compute project indicates the possibility of using opensource data to verify industrial claims about data centre energy efficiency. Research led directly to the Uptime Institute Green Enterprise IT Award 2013 for Facility Product Development with Iceotope (Peter.Hopton@icetope.com) and several academic and industrial collaborations in energy efficient cooling  who, with authors as co-investigators, secured a  €1.7 million Regions of Knowledge EU grant (ref. 320013).

Title: Life cycle greenhouse gas assessment of a coal-fired power station with calcium looping CO2 capture and offshore geological storage
AdditionalInformation: The key output from work optimising the life cycle GHG emissions of new CCS technologies. Presents a new engineering systems model of Calcium-Looping CCS plant, to produce the first published LCA of the technology. Identifies previously unrecognised potential for negative lifecycle GHG emissions, by exploring the importance of plant operating conditions and CaCO3 disposal mechanisms. The model is unique in the community and is fundamental to the system optimisation work of recent EPSRC award EP/J020745/1, developing novel solid sorbent technologies for natural gas CCS which will bring step performance and environmental improvements over amine based approaches.

Title: The role of large scale storage in a GB low carbon energy future: Issues and policy challenges
AdditionalInformation: Demonstrates that high temporal resolution models are necessary to understand the role of electricity storage in future energy systems with large renewables penetrations. In consequence, most current studies underestimate the value of storage in future networks. Presents a new high level systems approach to quantifying the commercial viability of storage, drawing on high time resolution resource data. Findings justified further UKERC support in 2011 for a workshop to refine the ideas developed (see http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/support/tiki-index.php?page_ref_id=2889). As a result Gruenewald joined the advisory board for an influential Carbon Trust study (see http://www.carbontrust.com/media/129310/energy-storage-systems-role-value-strategic-assessment.pdf). Gruenewald was supported by UKERC (http://www.ukerc.ac.uk/support/0907Studentships) with Cockerill as supervisor.

Title: Life cycle GHG assessment of fossil fuel power plants with carbon capture and storage
AdditionalInformation: Output from work supported by the NERC UK Carbon Capture and Storage Consortium (NE/C516528/1), with Cockerill as Institutional lead Investigator supervising PDRA Odeh. The paper demonstrates the importance of lifecycle assessment of CCS, gaining broad attention, including citation in POST note 383 (http://goo.gl/6OGKw) and Hansard (http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmhansrd/cm110620/text/110620w0005.htm)  with a supporting paper cited in ICE report “Building a Sustainable Future”(http://www.ice.org.uk/getattachment/75ab26c8-fc21-40ef-a0d8-548dae834144/ICE-low-carbon-infrastructure-trajectory---2050.aspx, p30). In consequence, Cockerill was invited to address MEPs on the need for LCA in devising energy policy, at a EURACOAL meeting in 2011 (http://www.euracoal.org/pages/medien.php?idpage=938). As of 2013, listed as one of the most cited papers in Energy Policy since 2008.

Title: Optimisation of the energy efficiency of bread-baking ovens using a combined experimental and computational approach
AdditionalInformation: Funded by EPSRC Grant EP/G5058504/1 (part of the PRO-TEM Process Industry Thermal Energy Management Network) and reported in a high impact journal, develops a new framework for optimising efficiency of bread-baking ovens. Combines experimental measurements of heat flux on a commercial pilot baking oven within accurate CFD simulations yielding oven temperature uniformity and heat transfer analysis yielding bake time, two important objectives in energy-efficient baking. Resuts used in new optimisation framework, accounting for key energy losses, that achieves energy savings of at least 5%. Methodology used by UK’s largest baker, Warburtons, to assess efficiency of their baking plants (colin.kelly@warburtons.co.uk).

Title: Electrified thin film flow at finite Reynolds number on planar substrates featuring topography
AdditionalInformation: Collaborative research with Heilbronn University, Germany, Veremieiev supported by EU Marie Curie Initial Training Network grant ESTER: MEST-CT-2005-020599. Develops a novel analytical approach for modelling influence of electric field on hydrodynamics, enabling existing two-dimensional analyses of electrified thin film free-surface flows to be extended to more practically-relevant three-dimensional cases, for the first time. Paper demonstrates limitations of popular approaches to modelling inertia in thin film free-surface flows and shows that depth averaged form (DAF) approach used here is more accurate for finite Reynolds numbers. Results show that electric fields can be used to planarise free-surface disturbances initiated in practical applications.

Title: Inertial thin film flow on planar surfaces featuring topography
AdditionalInformation: Research funded by EU Marie Curie Initial Training Network grant ESTER: MEST-CT-2005-020599. Develops a new model for 3-D free-surface flows which can account for the important effects of inertia, which can amplify free surface disturbances and initiate flow instability. Comprehensive validation against experimental and computational data shows this model is more accurate and of wider range of applicability than existing models. Work has subsequently been used on EPSRC Knowledge Transfer Secondment project with Food and Environmental Research Agency, York, to develop accurate models of pesticide flows on foliage (Richard.Glass@fera.gsi.gov.uk).

Title: Pre-ignition and 'super-knock' in turbocharged spark-ignition engines
AdditionalInformation: Pre-ignition of reactants becomes prevalent as engine pressures increase due to turbo-charging. Critical hot spot sizes for the observed gas phase pre-ignitions are calculated to assess this probability over ranges of fuel/air mixtures and engine conditions. Although spasmodic, it is sometimes followed by end gas auto-ignition at “hot-spots” followed by engine-damaging “super-knock.” Computations for these conditions suggest the observed “super-knocks” are not commensurate with the fuel and observed engine conditions. This is an important area of uncertainty and it is suggested that the auto-ignition might arise from small droplets of long-chain lubricants. Awarded the SAGE Best Paper Prize 2012.

Title: The influence of swing phase load on the electrochemical response, friction, and ion release of metal-on-metal hip prostheses in a friction simulator
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: The use of Metal-on-Metal hip replacements in younger, active patients focussed attention on metal ions in the body.  Wear is traditionally measured as mass or volumetric changes.  This first simultaneous study of ‘wear’ and ‘electrochemical corrosion’ in a simple friction simulator revealed significant tribocorrosion.  Major findings were that joints operated in a ‘mixed’ lubrication regime; that friction increased markedly with higher swing phase loads (coefficients of friction 0.054 to 0.089) and that tribo-corrosion represented a much greater proportion of material loss than previously reported.  The roles of tribo-film formation and lubricant composition revealed powerful synergistic effects between ‘wear’ and ‘corrosion’.

Title: Compensating lateral chromatic aberration of a colour fringe projection system for shape metrology
AdditionalInformation: This paper was invited for the journal’s special issue on fringe projection techniques based on our group’s international lead on phase metrology with colour sensors.  Importantly, compensation of chromatic aberration enables parallel acquisition in the RGB planes of colour cameras and absolute phase based shape metrology from a single colour image (reported as Applied Optics 49 (31) 5847-5953, 2010).  Follow-on-funds were received to develop sensors for pulmonary function assessment of infantile scoliosis patients which is an unmet clinical need and where temporal and spatial resolution are critical (British Scoliosis Research Foundation £37k grant COB-WISUP, Action Medical Research, £135k grant GN2087).

Title: An Instrumented Walking-Aid to Assess and Retrain Gait
AdditionalInformation: Developed by a multidisciplinary team of engineers, therapists and clinicians, with strong engagement from an NHS patient user group throughout, the instrumented Walking Aid (iWA) readily gained user acceptance in clinical trials. This paper in a leading international journal, showed for the first time how the iWA precisely quantified key usage metrics required by therapists to improve rehabilitation and monitor adherence to prescription. This enabled trials with a range of patient groups and clinical teams (including amputees) which underpinned our group’s success in attracting funds for smart orthoses (EPSRC-EP/K020463/1) and ultimately the EPSRC National Facility for Innovative Robotic Systems (http://www.epsrc.ac.uk/newsevents/news/2013/Pages/85million.aspx).

Title: The sweep-extend mechanism: A 10-bar mechanism to perform biologically inspired burrowing motions
AdditionalInformation: The first time manipulators were applied to search and rescue robots for moving debris. A unique, energy efficient mechanism based around continuously rotating motors. The work theoretically analysed a new mechanism, created and tested a physical prototype. Work received worldwide recognition including: 5 minutes on Canadian discovery channel (Sept 2007) 2M viewers, featured in New Scientist website (http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn12657-mechanical-mole-could-seek-out-disaster-survivors.html Sept 2007). The work resulted in prestigious invitation (Scoutek UK creationeer@btinternet.com) to develop robots to explore the last wonder of the ancient world, the Great Pyramid of Giza, Egypt– a world leading expedition and £88K funding from Dassault Systems, France (Richard.BREITNER@3ds.com).

Title: Empirical Prediction of Carbon-Steel Degradation Rates on an Offshore Oil and Gas Facility: Predicting CO2 Erosion-Corrosion Pipeline Failures Before They Occur
AdditionalInformation: Development of a new complementary experimental and theoretical approach to erosion-corrosion modelling and prediction which is correlated with oilfield inspection data, presenting a unique approach to model validation in oil and gas research. The model is developed specifically for and funded by industry (Shell U.K.) with an industrial co-supervisor (S.Cushnaghan@leeds.ac.uk). On the basis of the results, Shell implemented a change to their corrosion management strategy on the Brent fields, as well as taking the decision to increase production rates on the wells. Incidents have reduced on the facility from 1-2 every year to 0 since the change was implemented.

Title: Getting ready for carbon capture and storage through a 'CCS (Carbon Capture and Storage) Ready Hub': A case study of Shenzhen city in Guangdong province, China
AdditionalInformation: Output from DECC and China Ministry of Science and Technology CAPPCCO project (see https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/chinese-advanced-power-plant-carbon-capture-options-cappcco-final-summary-report-2012). Presents a new tool combining spatial techno-economic CCS systems models with Li and Liang’s local knowledge to devise novel approaches to Chinese CCS deployment. Contributed to CAPPCCO’s identification of how CCS can be rolled out in China to support rapid development but avoid long-term carbon lock-in, thereby informing DECC Science and Innovation Strategy (e.g. https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/48335/5107-decc-science-innovation-strategy-2012.pdf, p17). Initiated a new group theme modelling economically efficient technology-driven emissions reduction approaches (entraining 3 funded PhDs) that contributed to a recent high profile commissioned report’s methodology (see: http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/climatechange/publications/collaborative/halving-global-co2-by-2050 & http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/environment/article3871902.ece)

Title: Spatial grammar implementation: from theory to useable software
VolumeTitle: Artificial Intelligence for Engineering Design, Analysis and Manufacturing: AIEDAM
AdditionalInformation: Seven spatial design grammar systems presented at a workshop on shape grammar implementation at Design Computing & Cognition 2010 (http://www2.mech-eng.leeds.ac.uk/users/men6am/DCC-10-SG-Implementation-Workshop-Agenda.htm) are evaluated against a comprehensive list of properties for computational design synthesis systems.   The analysis covers a range of topics including mechanics of shape algebras for linear and nonlinear elements of up to two dimensions manipulated in two and three dimensional spaces; standard and parametric grammars including rule schemas; shape analysis and segmentation for fabrication and assembly; design evaluation; and user interfaces.  The paper provides a roadmap for future developments of such systems and the authors include two international partners.

Title: Effects of large-scale turbulence on cyclic variability in spark-ignition engine
AdditionalInformation: Cyclic variability in engines is well-known, however, its previous studies were undertaken in engines where several conflicting factors act together and  their relative influence is still hotly debated. This work systematically isolates individual effects using a new generation of Ported Optical Engines. The work shows the strong correlation between the turbulence field at the moment of spark discharge and later flame propagation. It signifies that turbulence in engines has much longer memory than is currently believed; there is currently a project underway with Mahle Powertrain UK (paul.freeland@gb.mahle.com) as to how to exploit this finding in the applied engine design software.

Title: Predicting the Behavior of Screen Printing
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: Screen printing finds wide application in manufacture of goods such as organic solar cells, printed electronics, medical diagnostic devices, yet this is the first paper to offer prediction of the film transfer and subsequent experimental validation. Additional to the numerical model, the underpinning physics of the process is elucidated. This has allowed McDermid Autotype, a major supplier to the screen printing industry to exploit the findings of the PhD programme of work on which this was based. Elisabeth Dolden now senior design engineer Sharp Displays, Europe. The resulting products led to sales at a value of ~£2.2M. Corroboration: dparker@macdermidautotype.com.

Title: Laminar burning velocities of three C3H6O isomers at atmospheric pressure
AdditionalInformation: While there exist chemical kinetic mechanisms for ethanol, there are scarce, if any, data for other oxygenates, especially aldehydes, one of the main pollutants associated with biofuels. This article presents a comprehensive study of the laminar flame speeds, major benchmarking criterion for chemical kinetics, for isomers representative of modern gasolines. These isomers have strikingly different flame speeds and for an explanation we initiated an international collaboration with Prof. A. Konnov, the world leading expert in detailed kinetics mechanisms. As a follow-up  there is currently a joint research project sponsored by Siemens, both its UK (jonathan.may@siemens.com)  and Swedish divisions (daniel.lorstad@siemens.com).

Title: The effect of MoDTC-type friction modifier on the wear performance of a hydrogenated DLC coating
AdditionalInformation: This paper results from the 3rd sponsored PhD project in a series by Infineum, Emmanuel.laine@infineum.com (Voong 2003, Haque 2008, Kosarieh 2013). The study showed for the first time the standard changes in Diamond-Like-Carbon coatings that make them susceptible to high wear in Mo-contacting lubricants.  The results were key to us being awarded the ENTICE Marie Curie programme on Tribochemistry (started 6/3/12, €3.3M, Grant agreement 290077) and the subsequent FUTURE-BET Marie Curie Programme.  Keynote talk was delivered by Neville at the Gordon Conference in 2011 and at Leeds-Lyon Conference, Lyon in 2013.  Neville awarded 2012 Donald Julius Groen prize for Tribology.

Title: Crevice corrosion of biomedical alloys: A novel method of assessing the effects of bone cement and its chemistry
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a KTP project with DePuy (KTP007712).  The associate (Bryant) completed a PhD in 34 months.  He investigated a particular series of failures in Norwich and Norfolk and found the cause backed up by underlying science where others failed.  The results for this paper led to a MHRA device alert in 2012.  The work is the first to link specific antibiotics in bone cement to initiation and propagation of crevice corrosion.  The study is followed on in a large FPVII Project (Life Long Joints (LLJ, Grant Agreement No. NMP-310477)) €13.3M, Neville as scientific coordinator.

Title: The Effect of Fracture Stability on the Performance of Locking Plate Fixation in Periprosthetic Femoral Fractures
AdditionalInformation: Latest study from the prestigious Latta fellowship (British Orthopaedic Association, Joint Action Fund, GRA/01/10/01, sole shortlisted application awarded £400k). A combined experimental and computational approach provides strong mechanical evidence for the fixation of periprosthetic femoral fractures, using metal plates. Evidence on importance of initial partial weight bearing is influencing surgical practice through the clinical leadership of this project. The international, interdisciplinary project team includes consultant orthopaedic and trauma surgeon Prof. Eleftherios Tsiridis (Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece), Secretary General of the European Hip Society.  Research has led to collaborations with Stryker UK (Tosin.Umukoro@stryker.com) and Legacy Biomechanics Laboratory, Portland, Oregon (mbottlang@biomechresearch.org).

Title: Measurement of ventilation and airborne infection risk in large naturally ventilated hospital wards
AdditionalInformation: Collaborative research with Bradford Royal Infirmary and supported by an EPSRC Challenging Engineering grant (EP/G029768/1). A new pulse-injection tracer method is developed to carry out one of only a very small number of studies that have measured and evaluated ventilation in a naturally ventilated hospital environment. Reported in a high quality journal, results have supported ongoing collaboration with Architects at Cambridge (EPSRC EP/G061327) to redesign ward layouts. Publication has led to discussions with leading international researchers and an invitation for Noakes to contribute a talk on natural ventilation for healthcare in a workshop at the ASHRAE 2013 conference in Vancouver.

Title: A novel robotic system for quantifying arm kinematics and kinetics: description and evaluation in therapist-assisted passive arm movements post-stroke
AdditionalInformation: This paper, for the first time, defines requirements of any potential physiotherapy robots designed for use with the upper limb. Supported by the NIHR (NIHR/HTD475;£684k) and involving 16 adults with stroke, the work described was crucial in the development of a new robotic system iPAM Mk2 which has now been approved by the MHRA for use in clinical trials in three NHS hospitals, the largest trial of robots in an acute setting within the UK (http://www.controlled-trials.com/ISRCTN16472838). This paper sets performance standards for future upper limb robots based on actual movements prescribed by a clinical team undertaking robotic physiotherapy.

Title: Wavefront sensing for three-component three-dimensional flow velocimetry in microfluidics
AdditionalInformation: This paper was invited for a special issue of Experiments in Fluids selecting the best papers from the 14th International Symposium on Applications of Laser Techniques to Fluid Mechanics, Lisbon, 2008.  The paper reports a new direction for volumetric velocimetry in microfluidics where sensor performance can be optimized over a wide range to suit the flow field of interest.  The work was exploited by research groups internationally, e.g. Prof Tropea (ctropea@sla.tu-darmstadt.de) for the study of flow in injector nozzles.  We have recently received follow-on support to extend the approach funded via the MRC super-resolution microscopy call (£1.49M MR/K015613/1).

Title: A seafarer's reliability assessment incorporating subjective judgements
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: This work “presents a really well thought out model for the assessment of the reliability of seafarers’ performance” and “can be used to model the effects of a number of factors over extended time period” (Reviewer reports from Assistant Editor, em.jeme.0.272269.5e881c0f@editorialmanager.com). This work was supported by a joint EPSRC grant (EP/F024436, Wang & Jenkinson, £247k and EP/ F024606; Yang, Manchester University, £315k, 2008-2012) in collaboration with five industrial partners. The work was tested and used in a pilot study of improving seafarers’ reliability at Islamic Republic of Iran Shipping Lines (IRISL) in 2012 (General Manager of Group 5, IRISL).

Title: A proposed decision-making model for evaluating a container's security score
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: This work represents a major research outcome from a joint EPSRC grant (EP/F024436, Wang & Jenkinson, £247k; EP/ F024606, Yang, Manchester University, £315k, 2008-2012). It was used as a key reference at International Maritime Organization (IMO)’s prioritisation of security measure for access control in port facilities and in the IMO’s workshops in Panama, Trinidad and Tobago, Turkey, Peru and Thailand with more than 200 delegates attending in 2013 (Maritime Security Specialist, IMO). It has directly led to an award of a highly competitive research grant ($54k, Riahi, 2013-2015) from the Nippon Foundation (General Secretary, International Association of Maritime Universities).

Title: Marine and Offshore Safety Assessment by Incorporative Risk Modeling in a Fuzzy-Bayesian Network of an Induced Mass Assignment Paradigm
AdditionalInformation: The preliminary part of this work was awarded a prestigious IMarEST Denny Medal received in 2008 (Chairman, IMarEST). It pioneered research in the area; “The work is particularly intriguing and a novel design with potential for application” (Editor-in-Chief, Risk Analysis, 2011). It has been widely referenced by other researchers and “among the top 5% most frequently cited papers published in this journal since 2008” (Managing Editor, Risk Analysis, November 2013). It has been used by Risktec Solutions Ltd in their consulting businesses relating to accident analysis (Managing Director, Risktec Solutions Ltd).

Title: Risk-based verification of large offshore systems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: The chief editor invited the authors to write a paper in this area having noticed the work conducted at LOOM (Chief Editor, Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment). The framework proposed has been used to effectively evaluate the risk associated with safety critical elements (Senior Surveyor, Lloyds Register). This work was generated through an RAEng fellowship of 6 months at ABS Consulting Ltd (General Manager). It was invited for presentation in the 2012 International Applied Reliability Symposium, Warsaw, 30 March 2012. It has directly led to a new PhD project (2012-2015) funded by Lloyds Register (Manager, Lloyds Register EMEA).

Title: A subjective approach for ballast water risk estimation
AdditionalInformation: “The work presented in the paper is important to ocean engineering since the factors inherent in ballast water risk estimation are often uncertain for which traditional quantitative risk assessment approaches do not give adequate answers/solutions in many cases” (Reviewer reports from Editor-in-Chief, Ocean Engineering). The work reported represents a major output from a Leverhulme Trust Fellowship (RF/7/RFG/2010/0019, Wang, £42,281, 2011-2013) and a Royal Society Kan Tong Po Fellowship (Wang, £6k, 2011-2012) in collaboration with Hong Kong Polytechnic University and Chung-Ang University, Korea (Professor of Maritime Safety, Hong Kong Polytechnic University and Chung-Ang University).

Title: Incorporation of formal safety assessment and Bayesian network in navigational risk estimation of the Yangtze River
AdditionalInformation: “This paper reports a novel approach capable of predicting the navigational risk level of commercial vessels in dynamic operational environments in inland waterways” (Managing Editor, Reliability Engineering & System Safety). The research findings have been highly commended by Changjiang Maritime Safety Administration (CMSA), China and used in its routine safety management (Section Chief, CMSA). The work was supported by CMSA and China National Science Foundation (GR/51209165, Zhang, Wuhan University of Technology, £26k, 2012-2015). It was also supported by a FP7 Marie Curie project in collaboration with Wuhan University of Technology (Reference-314836, Wang & Yang, €383k, 2012-2016).

Title: Incorporating uncertainty and multiple criteria in vessel selection
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: The Chief Editor invited the authors to produce the paper after recognising the significance of the research work in this area conducted by LOOM (Chief Editor, Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment). The paper was used as the showcase for the journal; it was one of the 2 papers highly recommended to readers (one of the 3 papers shortlisted for a Professional Engineering Publishing Best Paper Award) in 2009 (journal_of_engineering_for_the_m@mail.vresp.com). The publisher has made the paper free to view on-line (Chief Editor). The results of this paper were used by ABS Nautical Systems (Technical Manager, ABS Nautical Systems).

Title: Fuzzy Rule-Based Bayesian Reasoning Approach for Prioritization of Failures in FMEA
AdditionalInformation: This paper “presented a novel and efficient approach useful in FMEA and has had significant impact in reliability engineering and research” (Associate Editor, IEEE Transactions on Reliability, 2012). “It is the most frequently cited paper in this journal from 2008 to 2013” (Associate Editor, IEEE Transactions on Reliability, November 2013). This work was a pre-cursor to the award of an EPSRC grant in fire and rescue management (EP/S041993, Wang as PI, £135k, 2009-2012). A Research Leadership Award to J. Wang by the Society for Reliability Engineering, Quality and Operations Management (SREQOM) in 2008 stemmed from this work (Chairman, SREQOM).

Title: Fuzzy risk assessment of oil and gas offshore wells
AdditionalInformation: “The paper presents a novel method to support risk management, is of interest and makes contribution to process safety and environmental protection community” (Reviewer reports from Chief Editor, Process Safety and Environmental Protection). “This paper addresses a topic area associated with offshore oil and gas wells whose importance was demonstrated by the Deep Water Horizon tragedy. Full details on how to validate the model and perform sensitivity analysis were given” (Chief Editor, Process Safety and Environmental Protection). The principle of this work has been successfully used by the SAFF-ROSEMOND Group for producing cost-effective offshore designs (Managing Director, SAFF-ROSEMOND Group).

Title: A proposed System of Hierarchical Scorecards to assess the implementation of maritime regulations
AdditionalInformation: This work is the first of its kind in investigating the performance of maritime safety regulations. “It is a paper addressing an important area” (Associate Editor, Safety Science). This work led to an award of a highly competitive Leverhulme Research Fellowship (RF/7/RFG/2010/0019, Wang, £42k, 2011-2013). The work has been well received by the international research community in marine engineering system design and operations. It has led to an invited collaboration in research of maritime safety regulations with Hong Kong Polytechnic University (Head of Department), funded by a Royal Society Kan Tong Po Visiting Professorship (Wang, £6k, 2011-2012).

Title: Use of hybrid multiple uncertain attribute decision making techniques in safety management
AdditionalInformation: This paper was “well-commended for application and published in a journal ranked 3rd worldwide in operational research/management science” (Editor-in-Chief, Expert Systems with Applications, 2011). It has been widely used by researchers; “it is among the top 5% most frequently cited papers published in this journal since 2009” (Editor-in-Chief, Expert Systems with Applications, October 2013). It provided a fundamental basis for the award of an EPSRC grant (EP/F024436, Wang as PI, £247k, 2008-2012) which was ranked 1st in EPSRC’s prioritisation panel (www.epsrc.ac.uk). It directly led to an invited keynote address in 2012 International Port Forum, Korea (Forum Organiser, Incheon University, Korea).

Title: Use of Fuzzy Evidential Reasoning in Maritime Security Assessment
AdditionalInformation: This work resulted from collaborative research with Shanghai Maritime University (SMU) with financial support from the China Scholarship Council (Vice President, SMU). “It is among the top 5% most frequently cited papers published in this journal since 2009” (Managing Editor, Risk Analysis, November 2013). It provided a solid basis for an award of an EU grant of €3.5m in Intelligent Transportation for Dynamic Environment (allocation of €542k to LOOM). This work led to an invited book chapter “Ship formal safety assessment”, in Maritime Safety, Security and Piracy, Informa, pp.31-58, ISBN978-1-84311-767-4 (Book Editor and Professor, Old Dominion University, USA).

Title: A new fuzzy evidential reasoning method for risk analysis and control of a liquefied natural gas carrier system
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: This work “has been highly commended by the Editor and Editorial Board of Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment and appeared on the shortlist when allocating the SAGE Best Paper Award” (one of the three nominated papers) (Assistant Managing Editor of Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment, SAGE Publications Ltd, jeme@sagepub.co.uk; 2012). The paper has been ”highlighted on the Journal’s website and Facebook page” (Assistant Managing Editor, jeme@sagepub.co.uk). It has been “made available free of charge in recognition of the high quality of the work” (Assistant Managing Editor, jeme@sagepub.co.uk).

Title: A modified CREAM to human reliability quantification in marine engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper, published in a leading journal of maritime engineering, proposes a novel approach to facilitate human failure probability quantification development. Independent reviewer feedback: “This is a well written paper” (from all the reviewers), “… the capability of evaluating human failure probabilities more sensitively… detailed discussions provide a vivid picture from general to specific to identify the problems of CREAM methods” (Editor-in-Chief, Ocean Engineering). This work has led to a PhD project of three years (2014-2017, Principal supervisor: Z. Yang) supported by Lloyds Register (Manager, Lloyds Register EMEA).

Title: A methodology to model causal relationships on offshore safety assessment focusing on human and organizational factors
AdditionalInformation: This work was produced from a joint EPSRC project (GR/S85504, £113k, Wang & Jenkinson; GR/S85498, £114k, Yang, Manchester University, 2004-2007) with its final report rated "outstanding" in Communication of Research Output by the EPSRC. The preliminary part of this work was among the five best papers out of 110 (http://ieeexplore.ieee.org) in an IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE, Shanghai, China, October 8-10, 2006). It has been widely used by other researchers and “is among top 5% most frequently cited papers published in Journal of Safety Research since 2008” (Editor, Journal of Safety Research, October 2013).

Title: An Offshore Risk Analysis Method Using Fuzzy Bayesian Network
VolumeTitle: Journal of Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering
AdditionalInformation: “This work pioneered the research in fuzzy-Bayesian network modelling applied to offshore system operations” (Associate Editor, Journal of Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering). This work was a result of a joint EPSRC project (GR/S85504, £113k, Wang & Jenkinson; GR/S85498, £114k, Yang, Manchester University, 2004-2007) which was ranked 1st in an EPSRC’s prioritization panel in 2004 (source: www.epsrc.ac.uk). The research was conducted in collaboration with Health & Safety Executive and Shell Global Solutions. The work outcome was used in the feasibility study of offshore safety-based decision making in Shell Global Solutions (Senior Consultant, Shell Global Solutions).

Title: Decision support framework for risk management on sea ports and terminals using fuzzy set theory and evidential reasoning approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel risk management methodology for seaport terminals which has been used by ABS Nautical Systems in its business (Director, ABS Nautical Systems). The work was partially supported by an EU project named Weastflows (Wang, Ren, et al., €350k of €4.5m to LJMU, 2011-2015). The research was conducted in collaboration with three Iranian ports of Bushehr, Shahid Rajaie and Chabahar (board member of Shahid Rajaei Port, Iran). The research findings were used in the feasibility study of selecting a new seaport in Iran (Pro-Vice Chancellor, Chabahar Maritime University, Iran).

Title: A decision-support framework for agile enterprise partnering
VolumeTitle: The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by an EPSRC project “Links with China on Global Logistics” (EP/D039444/2, Yusuf as PI, University of Central Lancashire, £20k, 2006-2007). It reports a novel decision-making framework for agile enterprise design. It was conducted in collaboration with NetGen Inc. (Manager, NetGen Inc.) and NW Automotive Alliance (CEO, NW Automotive Alliance). This work has been used in the design of the global supply chain (CEO, NW Automotive Alliance). The work was developed into a new PhD research project (at LJMU in 2010-2014) in logistics industry benchmarking funded by the Arab Academy (Professor of Supply Chain Management, Arab Academy).

Title: Methodology of using delay-time analysis for a manufacturing industry
AdditionalInformation: “This paper reports a novel methodology of using delay-time analysis for reducing downtime, costs and also environmental risks of process systems” (Editor-in-Chief, Reliability Engineering & System Safety). “The work is one of the top 2% most frequently cited papers published in Reliability Engineering & System Safety since 2009” (Editor-in-Chief, Reliability Engineering & System Safety, October 2013). The research was conducted in collaboration with Cabot-Carbon, UK. The research result was successfully used to improve the company’s inspection scheme (Technical Manager, Cabot-Carbon).

Title: An integrated product–process design methodology for cost-effective product realisation
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This work was produced from an EPSRC-funded project “CALEBRE” involving 6 university partners (EP/G000387/1, Loveday, Loughborough University, £2.05m, 2008-2013). It reports a design and manufacturing methodology developed to support the realisation of a new gas heat pump which was prototyped as part of the project by Warwick University (Professor & Head of SEED, Warwick University). It was deployed in the development of heat pump and vacuum glazing prototypes, with test results to EN14511 standard being highly promising (coefficient of performance was over 10 times better than a gas boiler)  (Professor of Energy & Director of the Centre for Sustainable Technologies, Ulster University).

Title: A study of human reaction during the initial stages of a dwelling fire using a Bayesian network model
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability
AdditionalInformation: A new model for human reaction during the initial stages of a dwelling fire “is clearly presented and thoroughly validated” (Reviewer reports from Assistant Managing Editor). The work was supported by a responsive EPSRC grant (EP/F041993/1, Wang, Wall & Jenkinson, £135k, 2009-2012) in collaboration with Merseyside Fire and Rescue Authority (MFRA) (Director, MFRA) and Manchester University (Director of the Decision and Cognitive Sciences Research Centre, Manchester University). The research work has been used as a key reference by the MFRA in fire fighter training, fire alarm installation planning and accident investigation (Strategic Planning Manager, MFRA).

Title: The use of fuzzy set modelling for maintenance planning in a manufacturing industry
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: “The paper presents a promising methodology for the standardization of information for application of delay-time analysis to maintenance and inspection department, along with the application of the methodology to a case study of a factory producing carbon black which demonstrates the practicality of the proposed technique” (Reviewer reports from Assistant Managing Editor, Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering). The research was conducted in collaboration with Cabot-Carbon (Technical Manager, Cabot-Carbon). “This is one of a few fuzzy set modelling-based maintenance assessments whose applicability has been practically demonstrated in process system maintenance/inspection planning” (Technical Manager, Cabot-Carbon).

Title: Selection of techniques for reducing shipping NOx and SOx emissions
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Part D: Transport and Environment
AdditionalInformation: This paper for the very first time provides ship owners with a transparent decision tool and a practical guide for choosing cost effective emission control technologies. It was supported by the China Scholarship Council (GR/2010695021, Yan, Wuhan University of Technology (China), 2010-2011, £20k, http://en.csc.edu.cn/). The result was used in the feasibility study of emission reduction measures selection by Changjiang Maritime Safety Administration (CMSA) leading to an estimated emission reduction of 5% for 10 large vessels (Technical Manager, CMSA). This collaborative research has directly led to the award of a FP7 Marie Curie project (Enrich-612546, Yang, Wang & Riahi, €590k, 2013-2017).

Title: Modelling dwelling fire development and occupancy escape using Bayesian network
AdditionalInformation: Independent reviewer comments: “…very happy to see this take place…In many ways this paper distinguishes itself through the thoroughness of the work presented. …very much enjoy the carefulness with which the model is built and presented. …an important evaluation…is something we don't see often. ….a very adequate tool for improving the decision making regarding efficient measures to avoid fire-related human disaster. …really good and easy to follow” (Editor-in-Chief, Reliability Engineering & System Safety). The publication was a major outcome from an EPSRC project (EP/F041993/1, Wang as PI, £135k, 2009-2012) in collaboration with Merseyside Fire and Rescue Authority (MFRA) (Director, MFRA).

Title: Continuous Dynamic Constrained Optimization—The Challenges
AdditionalInformation: This paper was a major output from an EPSRC project (EP/E058884/1, Yao, Birmingham University, £264k, 2007-2011) with BT and Honda. Reviewer feedback: “…could form a fundamental guideline for future research…an excellent paper even by high standards of IEEE TEC” ; “…may close a research gap …. has all the conditions to be a strong reference for future …”; “…a very important issue … a significant contribution” (Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation). A preliminary part (in CEC2009) won an IEEE Travel Grant (Grant Chair, Texas A&M University). Selected as one of IEEE Computational Intelligence Society’s Publication Spotlights, May 2013, http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6496198.

Title: Propagation of Slepyan's crack in a non-uniform elastic lattice
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the analysis of the propagation of a Mode I semi-infinite crack through an anisotropic elastic lattice that describes the microstructure of an elastic material. The paper “provides useful insight on the stability of crack propagation for different crack speeds and different elastic parameters” (Reviewer reports distributed by Editor, Journal of the Mechanics of Physics and Solids). This work was carried out by the PDRA researcher under EPSRC “linked” grants (EP/H018239/1, Jones, £249k; EP/H018514/1, Movchan of Liverpool University, £111k, 2010-2013) in collaboration with an EU research project (FP7-PEOPLE-IAPP, PIAPP-GA-284544-PARM-2, Mishuris of Aberystwyth University, €1,775k, 2012-1016).

Title: Waves in lattices with imperfect junctions and localized defect modes
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This work was carried out as part of an EPSRC grant (EP/D035082/1, Movchan and Jones, £144k, 2006-2009) in collaboration with Liverpool University. Fundamental important results giving effective boundary conditions for thin-walled structures with defects in the vicinity of junctions were derived and these results were applied to wave filtering properties of periodic structures. This led to a successful collaboration with Serco Assurance Ltd (Senior Scientist, Serco Assurance Ltd) on the modelling of wave propagation in non-destructive testing. "This work published in a foremost journal in physical science was considered to be of much fundamental importance…" (Senior Scientist, Serco Assurance Ltd).

Title: A thermoelastic junction problem in a thin-walled structure: asymptotic analysis
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This work was carried out as part of an EPSRC grant (EP/D035082/1, Movchan and Jones, £144k, 2006-2009) involving Zalipaev as PDRA in collaboration with Liverpool University. This was coupled with asymptotic techniques to model the potential growth of surface defects subjected to oscillatory thermal loading in the middle part of thin-walled bridges, leading to a successful industrial collaboration with Serco Assurance Ltd on the modelling of weld structures (Senior Scientist, Serco Assurance Ltd).

Title: Dispersion and localization of elastic waves in materials with microstructure
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This was completed under EPSRC “linked” grants (EP/H018239/1, Jones, £249k; EP/H018514/1, Movchan of Liverpool University, £111k, 2010-2013). The proposal was ranked 3rd out of 37 responsive-mode proposals in the Materials, Mechanical, Medical Engineering Panel (http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/) with the work being published in a leading journal in science and engineering. Reviewer comments: “An interesting new point is the consideration of a so-called ‘elastic lens’”, “It is quite rich” (Editor, Proceedings of the Royal Society A). The flat “elastic lens” in a micro-polar lattice was first conceived in this paper (Editor, Proceedings of the Royal Society A).

Title: Waves and damage in structured solids with multi-scale resonators
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This work represents a major result of internationally collaborative research funded under three grants (EP/H018239/1, Jones, £249k, 2010-2013; EP/H018514/1, Movchan of Liverpool University, £111k, 2010-2013; 2007YZ3B24, Corigliano of Politecnico di Milano, €322k from the Ministry of Education, Universities and Research (Italy), 2008-2010). “This manuscript is of high quality” (Editorial Board Member, Proceedings of the Royal Society A). Our international authority in this area is highlighted by one reviewer’s comment “Several papers laying out the ground work on the subject have been published in the Proceedings by the authors” (Editorial Board Member, Proceedings of the Royal Society A).

Title: Numerical study of strengths of spot-welded joints of steel
AdditionalInformation: This work was a pre-cursor to an EPSRC Industrial CASE award in modelling the micro spot welding process (No. 09001706, Ren, £60k, 2010-2013). It has contributed to the development of a Royal Academy of Engineering grant (Ren, £18k, 2010-2011) with Serco Technical Services (Team Leader, Serco Technical Services). The work has also led to a new PhD research project funded by the Indonesian government in developing new optimisation strategies for material parameter identification based on indentation tests (Professor of Materials Engineering, University of Udayana, Indonesia, 2009-2013).

Title: Numerical modelling of low-density cellular materials
AdditionalInformation: This work was carried out as part of a HEFCE Promising Research Fellowship in collaboration with Loughborough University. It has contributed to the development of an EPSRC CASE project (CASE/CAN/05/74) with Clatterbridge Centre for Oncology (Cancer Research UK Fellow, CCO). This work has led to a successful industrially sponsored research project (Ren, £41K, 2010-2013) in predicting the behaviour of polymer foams in sports footwear and in modelling the damage of metatarsals bones (Product Development Manager, Anta, China), leading to an industrial patent granted to the industrial user (CN102488352A, 27/12/2011-26/12/2031, Product Development Manager, Anta).

Title: Fe–24wt.%Cr–4.1wt.%C hardfacing alloy: Microstructure and carbide refinement mechanisms with ceria additive
AdditionalInformation: This is a key output of a joint project with a world leading research centre at Yanshan University, China through One-Hundred-Excellent-Talents-Programme (09215106D, Yang of Yanshan University, £30k, 2008-2011). It is a key paper leading to a patent (ZL-2010-1-0236826, 23/07/2010-22/07/2030). The work has led to the development of crack resistant welding materials worth an annual market of £5m in an industrial company since 2011 (Managing Director, Special Welding Industry Ltd, China). The reported characterisation program was used in another publication (Welding Journal) on new hardfacings development, receiving American Welding Society’s A.F. Davis Silver Medal Award in 2013 (Senior Manager, AWS).

Title: MRI image-based FE modelling of the pelvis system and bladder filling
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper was a key output of an EPSRC CASE project in improving the planning accuracy in prostate cancer radiotherapy treatment at Clatterbridge Centre for Oncology (CCO) (Case/CNA/05/74, Ren, £60K from EPSRC, £20K from CCO, 2006-2010, Project Manager). “It reports a realistic model to simulate the bladder deformation, which is important for understanding the clinical practice in managing water taking protocol for CT and MRI scanning” (Cancer Research Specialist, CCO). This work has led to another joint PhD project with CCO in characterising the properties of bladder tissues and other thin membranes (Cancer Research UK Fellow, CCO, 2010-2013).

Title: Adaptive RBF network for parameter estimation and stable air–fuel ratio control
AdditionalInformation: This paper published in the flagship journal of the area presents the research findings from a collaborative research project “Fault detection and fault tolerant control for automotive engines” with the BMW E30 in Munich (Senior Specialist, BMW E30, 2004-2007). “The research findings reported are novel and can, with further tests, be effectively used for improving engine performance” (Senior Specialist, BMW E30). The paper “described a new methodological development for stable sliding mode control with adaptive neural model compensation for internal combustion engines” as commented by one of the reviewers (Co-Editor-in-Chief, Neural Networks).

Title: Radial-basis-function-based feedforward–feedback control for air–fuel ratio of spark ignition engines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a collaborative research project “Fault detection and fault tolerant control for automotive engines” with the BMW E30 in Munich (Automobile Control Specialist, BMW E30, 2004-2007). A senior specialist at BMW E30 commented that “due to the simplicity and reliability, the developed method is very likely to be considered in the on-board fault diagnosis and fault tolerant management research in BMW. This work has made significant contribution to air-fuel ration control of spark ignition engines” (Senior Specialist, BMW E30).

Title: Mission management and control of BSA-AUV for ocean survey
AdditionalInformation: This paper was from the research collaboration with Harbin Engineering University (HRBEU) and China Ship Scientific Research Center (CSSRC) (Research Professor, CSSRC). “The major contribution of this paper is the introduction of the novel multi-agent based distributed control architecture into Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) system. The hierarchical Petri nets based mission management and control method makes the AUV handle various discrete events smoothly. The paper contributes to the future development of AUV systems” (Reviewer reports from Editor-in-Chief, Ocean Engineering). The developed work continues through another PhD research project at HRBEU, funded by CSSRC (2013-2017) (Research Professor, CSSRC).

Title: Dynamic Fault Detection and Isolation For Automotive Engine Air Path By Independent Neural Network Model
AdditionalInformation: This paper was produced from the collaborative research with Cummins Inc., a leading engine manufacturer (Vibration Specialist, Cummins Inc.). It reports a new fault detection and isolation scheme for automotive engines. One reviewer commented: “this paper made an innovative contribution to dynamic fault diagnosis of IC engines” (Editor, International Journal of Engine Research). “The core technique in this work will be used in our on-line product quality monitoring for engine fuel injection systems” (Vibration Specialist, Cummins Inc.). A PDRA project (2013-2015) funded by the Libyan government continues this work for real-data experiment (Professor of Control Engineering, Omar Almukhtar University, Libya).

Title: Un-throttling a direct injection gasoline homogeneous mixture engine with variable valve actuation
AdditionalInformation: This paper, which was invited by the journal editor, reports the outcomes of a major EPSRC funded collaborative project (GR/S91734/01) with Lotus Engineering Ltd, Continental Automotive and Loughborough University. The project researched various schemes which could reduce parasitic throttling losses in gasoline engines, a major source of fuel inefficiency. Based on the outcomes of the project, Lotus Engineering and Continental Automotive developed a three cylinder gasoline engine with improved fuel efficiency and installed it in a vehicle technology-demonstrator which was showcased in the UK and Europe. The project won the 2008 UK Engineer Technology & Innovation Award (Automotive) (http://www.theengineerawards.co.uk/pastwinners.aspx).

Title: Diffusion- and Homogeneous-Charge Combustion of Volatile Ethers in a Compression Ignition Engine
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with di-methyl ether (DME), a volatile fuel which is attracting increasing interest in the Far-East because it can be manufactured from coal, natural gas and renewable biomass sources by adapting known process technologies. DME offers new opportunities, as it can be manufactured from a wide variety of primary energy sources and has good ignition qualities, but it also offers challenges in terms of lack of lubricity and fuel system compatibility in vehicle applications. The project was carried out in collaboration with the Korean Advanced Institute of Science and Technology where the third author  (Prof.Bae, csbae@kaist.edu) is based.

Title: The influence of molecular structure of fatty acid monoalkyl esters on diesel combustion
