AdditionalInformation: This paper was published in the leading journal for fundamental combustion studies and it introduces a novel technique for removing the effects of ignition delay on diesel fuel combustion. The paper elucidates little known influences on combustion of biofuels which were previously masked by ignition delay effects. The project is part of a 10-year strategic collaboration with BP Fuels Technology and it was wholly funded by BP (Dr Robert Allan, robert.allan@uk.bp.com). It has led to a patent (EP20070254964-20071219) being filed by BP based on the IPR generated during this project.

Title: Ignition control of homogeneous-charge compression ignition (HCCI) combustion through adaptation of the fuel molecular structure by reaction with ozone
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the experimental investigation of a highly innovative concept where the ignition quality of diesel fuel can be altered by reacting part of the fuel or a fuel additive with ozone. This approach allows control of the time of ignition of the fuel in real time and can be applied on board vehicles operating in Homogeneous Charge Compression Ignition (HCCI) mode, with a promise of high fuel efficiency and low pollutant emissions. The research was supported by BP fuel technologies (Dr. John Williams, john.williams2@uk.bp.com).

Title: Numerical prediction of wind turbine noise
AdditionalInformation: A model was developed for predicting aeroacoustics of wind turbines based on permeable Ffowcs-Willliams Hawkins model. The model was validated using available experimental data and then used to predict the influence of wind speed and rpm on noise levels from the well documented National Renewable Energy Laboratory NREL-VI wind turbine. The developed model has been used for 3D automatic optimization of wind turbine blade profiles for maximum power and low noise.

Title: Parametric Design of a Waterjet Pump by Means of Inverse Design, CFD Calculations and Experimental Analyses
AdditionalInformation: This paper arises from a collaboration with Rolls Royce Marine. The results of this work led to the development of new generation of marine waterjets at RR marine with significantly higher propulsive efficiency. Greater efficiency was achieved by improving both the hydrodynamic performance and the cavitation behaviour of the waterjet pump. The efficiency and cavitation performance of the new stage was measured at the cavitation tunnel facilities of RR Marine to confirm the computational results. The design has been commercialised by the company and is implemented in their current product lines.

Title: On the Coupling of Inverse Design and Optimization Techniques for the Multiobjective, Multipoint Design of Turbomachinery Blades
VolumeTitle: JOURNAL OF TURBOMACHINERY-TRANSACTIONS OF THE ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a methodology for multi-objective/multi-point design of turbomachinery. It resulted in an industrial consortium [needs name] IDOE in Asia to apply this methodology to practical designs with a number of major companies joining the consortium, e.g. Aisin AW (torque converters), Ebara Corporation (Pumps). It has also led to a strategic partnership between Advanced Design Technology Ltd (UCL spin out company) and Dessault Systems Simulia. A computational code based on the methodology described has been commercialized by the UCL spin out Advanced Design Technology Ltd ( www.adtechnology.co.uk).

Title: On multi-objective optimization of geometry of staggered herringbone micromixer
AdditionalInformation: This paper covers the application of multi-objective optimization to design of micromixers in order to improve mixing and reduce pressure loss. The paper represents the first systematic attempt to optimize the geometry of micromixers for both mixing and pressure drop by using a multi-objective automatic optimization strategy. The paper outlines a methodology that can also be applied to other microfluidic devices.

Title: On the Conceptual Design and Performance of a Matrix Converter for Marine Electric Propulsion
AdditionalInformation: This paper, published in a leading international journal, reports on experimental and theoretical investigations for the design of electrical power conversion in the next generation of electric propulsion drive systems. The work, jointly funded by an EPSRC studentship, QinetiQ and UK-MoD, contributes to on-going developments in All-Electric-Ship technologies (contact: Barry Saunders DESShipsMPS-FSE-CMEL@mod.uk). A reviewer commented ‘…original analysis and contribution to all-electric ship studies…’. The work, presented to a meeting of All-Electric Ship Group (UK/USA) sponsored by US Office of Naval Research (ONR) in December 2010, is on-going within a UCL led multi-university EPSRC project on low carbon shipping (EP/H020012/1).

Title: Harmonic Calculations of Proximity Effect on Impedance Characteristics in Subsea Power Transmission Cables
AdditionalInformation: The research, sponsored by a Joint Industry Project involving BP, British Gas International and Shell (UK), developed fundamental theory of complex multi-layered subsea power transmission cables in which harmonic currents are regularly encountered e.g. in offshore oil, gas wind generation applications. This paper develops for the first time an account for harmonic impedance and proximity effects. Commercial electrical computer simulation packages do not account for such effects but this paper demonstrated the importance of needing to do so in certain cable arrangements. The results have subsequently been used by JIP partners (contact: Bob Fallaize at fallaizer@bp.com).

Title: Collision risk assessment for ships
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: Current unmanned surface vessels (USVs) are semi-autonomous or remotely controlled. This paper concentrates on the design of navigation systems to allow USVs to navigate autonomously. The area is new with very few universities worldwide working in this field. The work reported was funded by the Office of Naval Research USA (contact: Paul Rispin paul.rispin@navy.mil‎) and has been extended recently with a follow-on project. The research is collaborative with Florida Atlantic University, Virginia Tech., Stevens Institute of Technology (NY), and US Navy. The aim is to have a demonstrator fully autonomous vehicle by 2014 (contact: Professor M. Dhanak at FAU dhanak@fau.edu).

Title: Path-planning algorithm for ships in close-range encounters
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: Efficient maritime navigation in the presence of moving close-range obstructions is an increasingly serious challenge faced by mariners. This paper assesses collision risks for surface ships in close-range encounter in compliance with international collision regulations (COLREGs). The paper reports on research funded by the Office of Naval Research (ONR, USA) as part of a multi-university investigation including Florida Atlantic University and US Navy Post-graduate School. The work reported in the paper has led to further investigations sponsored by ONR (contact: Kelly Cooper at kelly.cooper1@navy.mil) with the objective of merging path planning, collision avoidance and energy management into prototype autonomous vessels.

Title: An EM/E-MRF algorithm for adaptive model based tracking in extremely poor visibility
AdditionalInformation: This work is the culmination of a 12 year research programme by Greig into vision in poor visibility. Most image processing work assumes good visibility but this paper is distinctive and original because the tracking algorithm was designed to operate in degraded visibility.  The algorithm was successfully validated using a robot mounted camera to track an object obscured by mist.  The work was funded by the EPSRC and Sira Ltd (EPSRC Grant Ref. 99313004) and has potential application for underwater vision where degraded visibility is a real problem and many existing image processing algorithms cannot accommodate this.

Title: Continuous flushing of contaminants from ballast water tanks
AdditionalInformation: The transportation of Non Indigenous Species (NIS) via ship ballast water discharge has a major impact on the local marine eco-system. The paper demonstrates that the current rules aimed at avoidance of NIS transport are overly simplified. These rules are set by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO), the UN agency that governs global maritime legislation. The paper was tabled as an information document at the 59th Marine Environmental Protection Meeting (MEPC59/INF.25.); MPEC is the forum where maritime environmental legislation is decided.

Title: Turbulent acidic plumes injected into an alkaline environment
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with the environmental impact of acidic waste water discharged from ship diesel engine exhaust gas scrubbers. Acidic waste water dispersion and its chemical interaction with seawater are of international concern and not well understood. The paper combines experimentally-validated models of chemistry and fluid flow to assess the acidic plume dispersion and its reaction in seawater. It was sponsored by the Exhaust Gas Cleaning Systems Association (donald.gregory@egcsa.com) and will be presented to the International Maritime Organisation's (IMO) Marine Environment Protection Committee 66/67 to advise on the formulation of IMO pollution regulations for ship-board scrubber systems.

Title: Comparing Trimaran Small Waterplane Area Center Hull (TriSWACH), Monohull, and Trimaran Hullforms: Some Initial Results
VolumeTitle: Journal of Ship Production and Design
AdditionalInformation: The Tri-SWACH is a novel ship hull form combining features of a SWATH and a Trimaran, and is attracting keen interest from the US navy because of improved sea-keeping. The paper presents results from initial design studies from naval architecture and marine engineering perspectives. This work was funded by the US Office of Naval Research, as part of the ACCeSS project grant (Ref N00014-07-1-0652). The authors were invited to submit this paper by the American Society of Naval Engineers a result of their presentation at the FAST 2011 conference, the world's leading technical conference addressing fast sea transportation issues.

Title: Similarity solution of oblique impact of wedge-shaped water column on wedged coastal structures
AdditionalInformation: The paper considers violent wave impact on coastal defences/offshore platforms/ships and employs an extension of the boundary element method in a joint project with the National University of Singapore supported by the Office of Naval Research (USA) focused on superfast boats (one to two hundred knots). The numerical model is being validated by collaborative experimental work carried out at Harbin Engineering University (HEU) as part of the joint research centre on Deep Water Engineering set up by UCL in 2010 jointly with Shanghai Jiao Tong University and HEU and supported by a £1.25 million grant by Lloyds Register Educational Trust.

Title: Coupled hydrodynamic and structural analysis of compressible jet impact onto elastic panels
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports joint research between UCL and Lavrentyev Institute of Hydrodynamics, Russia for over 15 years involving several projects. This particular project is jointly supported by the Royal Society (2005/R2) and Russian Academy of Sciences (Prof. A. Korobkin) and focuses on the very short period during a fluid/structure impact, involving extreme loading. Included are the effects of both the fluid compressibility and structure elasticity and their coupling. The results shed new light on fluid flow and structural deformation and the fluid-structure coupling during violent collisions.

Title: Simulation of water entry of a wedge through free fall in three degrees of freedom
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A - Mathematical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: Various novel methodologies are reported dealing with the rapid deformation of free water surface, the development of thin jets and the stability of body motion. Computational results are compared with experimental data collected at Shanghai Jiaotong University (SJTU) in a joint UCL/SJTU project supported by the Royal Society. This is a major research publication by the Joint Research Centre on Deep Water Engineering set up by UCL in 2010 with SJU and Harbin Engineering University (HEU) and supported by a £1.25 million grant by Lloyds Register Educational Trust. The collaboration includes movement of staff between SJTU/HEU and UCL.

Title: Fully nonlinear simulation of resonant motion of liquid confined between floating structures
AdditionalInformation: The paper includes significant improvements in numerical simulations which overcome difficulties with mesh distortion at the wave surface. Supported by the National Science Foundation of Qatar, this paper is a result of the joint project involving Qatar University, UCL, and National University of Singapore. Advanced numerical method to follow the variation of the computational domain due to variation of the wave surface and the body motion was developed. This successful overcome the difficulty of mesh distortion due to the variation. Extensive results are obtained for the second order resonance for the analysis for the motion of the LNG ship.

Title: Comparison of electrical and laser spark emission spectroscopy for fuel concentration measurements
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new novel method of measuring fuel concentration using electrical sparks. This research compares the radical and species dynamics generated from both electrical and laser sparks. This approach, based on electrical sparks, has potential to be used under extreme temperature and pressure conditions encountered in internal combustion engines. The method has potential to be incorporated in commercial engines, using the standard spark plug, for real-time combustion quality diagnostic and control. This work was a joint effort between UCL, University of Cambridge (Prof E Mastorakos, em257@cam.ac.uk) and University of Patras - Greece (Prof Stelios Couris, ‎scouris@physics.upatras.gr).

Title: Non-linear response of turbulent premixed flames to imposed inlet velocity oscillations of two frequencies
AdditionalInformation: The paper investigates combustion driven oscillations in gas turbine combustors. This work provides fundamental understanding related to the use of external forcing to control combustion oscillations. For the first time, the effectiveness of flame control was presented, based on forcing at frequencies other than the natural frequency of the system. This could potentially lead to development of new combustion instabilities mitigating strategies. This was  collaborative research with Profs Epaminondas Mastorakos (em257@cam.ac.uk) and Ann P Dowling (apd1@cam.ac.uk) of University of Cambridge and supported by Rolls Royce Plc (Mark Jefferies, Mark.j.jefferies@rolls-royce.com) and led to follow-on funding from the EPSRC (EP/G063788/1).

Title: Heat release rate correlation and combustion noise in premixed flames
AdditionalInformation: Lean burning is a common approach in many practical combustion devices to reduce emissions and improve fuel efficiency, but susceptible to combustion noise and combustion instabilities. This paper established a new heat release rate correlation based on flame thickness to predict direct noise generation from combustor turbulent flames. For this paper, the authors received the Sudgen Award 2011 from the Combustion Institute (British Section) for the most significant UK contribution to combustion research. The project was collaborative with University of Cambridge (Dr N Swaminathan, ns341@cam.ac.uk and Prof AP Dowling, apd1@cam.ac.uk) and Chinese Academy of Sciences (Mr G Xu  xug@iet.cn).

Title: Experimental investigation of dynamics of premixed acetylene-air flames in a micro-combustor
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the dynamics of travelling flames inside micro-combustors. The project covers an emerging energy conversion technology that is related to micro-power generation for Micro Electrical Mechanical Systems (MEMS). This work resulted in Royal Society funding (RG090832) for further research and has also resulted in collaborative work with Imperial College London (Dr C.N Markides, markides@imperial.ac.uk). This paper further the detailed understanding of combustion in micro-channel and resulted in the development of a new generation of micro-combustor that is able to operate in a periodically stable oscillating mode.

Title: On the dynamic mechanical properties of open-cell metal foams - A re-assessment of the 'simple-shock theory'
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the authors’ previous ‘simple shock theory’, published in J. Mech. Phys. Solids (2005) V53 pp.2206, is critically re-assessed and a new multiscale approach is proposed to eliminate the shortcomings of a homogenised idealisation. This work was supported by the EPSRC (GR/R26542/01) and carried out in collaboration with Aberdeen University. The results were presented by the first author as invited speaker at the IUTAM Symposium in Austin, Texas (8-13th May 2011) and at the Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (18-Aug-2011). A multiscale model is being developed by the first author with support from a follow on EPSRC grant (EP/I028811/1).

Title: Dynamic crushing of honeycombs and features of shock fronts
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates how nodal connectivity at the cell-scale affects the macro-deformation mode in 2D and 3D lattices. The aim is to examine ways of engineering cell micro-architectures to improve the energy absorption capacity of 3D lattices. The results also provides a critical re-assessment of the authors’ previous ‘1D shock model’ (J. Mech. Phys. Solids, 2005, V53, pp. 2174). It is used to guide the development of a multi-scale damage theory for 3D lattices in a follow-on EPSRC grant (EP/I028811/1).  This work was supported by the EPSRC (GR/R26542/01) and carried out in collaboration with the Universities of Manchester and Aberdeen.

Title: Crack initiation and fracture toughness of random Voronoi honeycombs
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates how random variations in cell architecture affects the fracture toughness of cellular solids, previously believed to be influenced only by their relative density. The conclusions are relevant to our understanding of osteoporotic fracture risks in trabecular bones; leading to follow-on collaborations with Sam Oussedik (sam.oussedik@gmail.com) at UCLH. The work was funded by the EPSRC (EP/I028811/1) and presented at the IMA conference (Mathematics of Medical Devices and Surgical Procedures, 17-19th Sept. 2012) where it won the Best Poster Prize. PJT was invited to present this work at an Applied Mechanics Colloquia at the National University of Singapore (16-Aug-2012).

Title: Viscoplastic constitutive theory for brittle to ductile damage in polycrystalline materials under dynamic loading
AdditionalInformation: A multi-scale constitutive theory is presented within a continuum damage mechanics framework, capable of capturing low to high strain rates and ductile to brittle damage response in a single unified model, never before possible for polycrystalline materials. It is funded by the EPSRC (EP/I028811/1) and is part of an ongoing collaborative research programme into the synergistic effects of combined blast and impact loading with the MOD (David Manley, DESNAG-VR@mod.uk) and Lloyd’s Register (Fai.Cheng@lr.org), who are currently co-sponsoring two PhD students. PJT has been invited to present this research at Oxford University (25-Feb-2013) and at the National University of Singapore (15-Aug-2013).

Title: On the reflection of coupled Rayleigh-like waves at surface defects in plates
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: The research was supported by a grant from the Swiss National Science Foundation (SNF grant PBEZ2-114186) and has led to follow on funding (HES SO Applied Sciences Western Switzerland SAGE-X: 27116) for an international collaboration with Prof. B. Masserey at EIA-FR Fribourg, Switzerland (Bernard.Masserey@hefr.ch) and Prof. J. Reymondin at HEIG-VD Yverdon, Switzerland (jean-pascal.reymondin@heig-vd.ch). The paper was published in a leading journal in the field and received outstanding reviewer comments ”This paper makes a significant contribution in both understanding the phenomenon of coupled Rayleigh-like waves and exploring their potential use for detecting damage. Overall it is an excellent paper” (jasa@aip.org).

Title: Feature-guided waves for monitoring adhesive shear modulus in bonded stiffeners
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes results for a proposed novel methodology for the inspection and monitoring of adhesive joints in aircraft. It is the outcome of an international collaboration between UCL,University of Bordeaux (CNRS, Prof. M.Castaings, m.castaings@i2m.u-bordeaux1.fr) and Imperial College London (Prof. M.Lowe, m.lowe@imperial.ac.uk). The paper was published in the leading journal in nondestructive testing and received excellent editorial comments “clearly both reviewers liked the work a great deal - these are some of the best reviews I've seen!” (NDT&E Int., Editor: B.Drinkwater@bristol.ac.uk).

Title: Surface defect detection in stiffened plate structures using Rayleigh-like waves
AdditionalInformation: The research was supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation (PBEZ2-114186) and has led to follow-on funding (Applied Sciences Western Switzerland SAGE-X:27116) for an international collaboration with Prof. B.Masserey at EIA-FR Fribourg, Switzerland (Bernard.Masserey@hefr.ch) and Prof. J.Reymondin at HEIG-VD Yverdon, Switzerland (jean-pascal.reymondin@heig-vd.ch). The paper was published in the leading journal in nondestructive testing and received outstanding reviewer comments: ” The paper … contains much original material … adds to the on-going and interesting debate about how to best perform long-range testing of complex structures and so will be of significant interest to readers of NDT&E Int.” (Editor: B.Drinkwater@bristol.ac.uk).

Title: Effect of amputation level on the stress transferred to the femur by an artificial limb directly attached to the bone
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports a new attachment method for artificial limbs developed through interdisciplinary collaboration between the John Scales Centre for Biomedical Engineering, UCL Division of Surgery & Interventional Science and Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital (Contact: g.blunn@ucl.ac.uk). A world patent (WO-2005/087145) was awarded for the fail-safe device to protect the bone. The innovation is currently undergoing clinical trials and has been licensed to Stanmore Implants Worldwide, a former spinout company of UCL. The work won the BLESMA Prize 2008 at the UK Annual Scientific Meeting of the International Society for Prosthetics and Orthotics.

Title: Movement of airborne contaminants in a hospital isolation room
AdditionalInformation: This work describes a study, using analogue laboratory experiments, of the movement of airborne contaminant in a hospital isolation room. The results were reported in a themed volume of the Royal Society J. Interfaces (Lead Editor: Eames, December 6, 2009; 6). Extension of this work was reported in 3 other papers (J. Hospital Infection vol 77, RSJ Interfaces Vol 6, New Approaches in Modeling Multiphase Flows and Dispersion in Turbulence  2012) and led to major collaboration with National University of Singapore. The was funded by the Department of Health (Dr Wilson, UCLH, 2008-2011) and supported a Senior Leverhulme Fellowship (2010-2011).

Title: Effect of turbulence on the downstream velocity deficit of a rigid sphere
AdditionalInformation: This paper relates to a common engineering problem involving a rigid body or lifting surface (e.g. offshore structure, aircraft, submarine) moving through ambient flow which is often turbulent. The paper describes the first mathematical model explaining the role of external turbulence on wake spreading which could not previously be explained by published computational and experimental results. This is an outcome from industrial funding by EGCSA (UCL Consultants, donald.gregory@egcsa.com) on entrainment from acidic jets in the ocean.

Title: Numerical study of flow through and around a circular array of cylinders
AdditionalInformation: A major outcome from this work was the development of a general fluid mechanics code (ACEsim, www.acesim.co.uk), made available as open-source, for large-scale calculations using over 1000 processors. The code has also been taken up by the National University of Singapore who have built a 700 core machine to run the code and who have appointed two post-docs for further code development over 3 years. The code is being used by other UK groups, eg University of Leeds (Civil Engineering) and BP Ltd as part of commercial funding through UCLC.

Title: A Theoretical Model for Predicting Interfacial Relationships of Retinal Tamponades
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative work with Moorfields Eye Hospital consultants (Mr Angunawela, Mr Alyward) relates to the tamponade which keeps the retina fixed in position following surgery. Together with a companion paper (IRVOS, 2011, V52, 7046-7051) on tamponade dynamics, this paper demonstrates that post-operative patient posturing is unnecessary in cases of retinal breaks treated with tamponades. This has provided support for modifying clinical practice by Mr Alyward. This work has led to 2 PhD studentships, supported by Moorfields Charity funds, in collaboration with Prof Luthert (Director of IOOP on retinal blood flow, p.luthert@ucl.ac.uk) and Prof Khaw (p.khaw@ucl.ac.uk) on glaucoma.

Title: Imaging and heat flux measurements of wall impinging sprays of hydrocarbons and alcohols in a direct-injection spark-ignition engine
AdditionalInformation: This study quantified spray wall impingement in a direct-injection spark-ignition engine with alternative fuels. Paper published in Fuel, the leading international journal in fuel research; it is an extension of work in two papers presented at SAE’s International Conferences (Papers 2007-01-2712, 2008-01-1591; first paper received a best-paper award and the second selected for SAE’s Transactions). Research funded by Jaguar and EPSRC (GR/S58850/01). Technical collaboration with Shell also enabled use of purpose-built fuel evaporation models (Roger Cracknell, roger.cracknell@shell.com, Harold Walmsley, harold.walmsley@shell.com). Work led to long-term strategic research-centre partnership between UCL and Jaguar, commencing in 2012, for new low CO2 engines.

Title: Mechanisms of spray formation and combustion from a multi-hole injector with E85 and gasoline
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the physics of atomization and combustion of a high ethanol content fuel (E85) in comparison to gasoline in a direct-injection spark-ignition optical engine. The analysis involved quantitative data obtained from experiments and linked with current theories. It was ‘3rd hottest paper’ of Combustion & Flame in 2010 and it appears consistently in the most downloaded papers (First, July-2012 to September-2012). This is the leading international journal on the fundamentals of combustion systems. Work supported financially and technically by Ford UK and Germany (Jon Caine, jcaine1@ford.com; Martin Wirth, mwirth1@ford.com); the results were incorporated in Ford’s engine operation strategies.

Title: Effect of fuel temperature on in-nozzle cavitation and spray formation of liquid hydrocarbons and alcohols from a real-size optical injector for direct-injection spark-ignition engines
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This publication demonstrates coupling of microfluidics, cavitation and flash boiling with spray formation phenomena inside injection system nozzles, of traditional and bio-derived fuels. A novel design of a real-size optical injector was devised which provided unique fuel atomisation insights. The International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer is a leading journal on the fundamentals of heat and fluid flow. The work was supported financially and technically by Jaguar and Shell (contact names respectively: Dave Richardson, dricha69@jaguarlandrover.com; Roger Cracknell, roger.cracknell@shell.com) and led to further funding by the EPSRC as one of 40 industrial CASE PhD studentships awarded nationwide in 2009.

Title: Flame chemiluminescence and OH LIF imaging in a hydrogen-fuelled spark-ignition engine
AdditionalInformation: This paper analysed hydrogen combustion in an optical spark-ignition engine supported by EPSRC (EP/C520211/1). The International Journal of Hydrogen Energy is the leading journal on hydrogen research. Related work also presented at SAE’s International Fuels Conference (Paper 2009-01-1921 selected for SAE’s Transactions) and established links with key hydrogen labs (e.g. Argonne National Labs USA; Thomas Wallner, twallner@anl.gov). Extension of the work to controlled autoignition of hydrogen accepted by Combustion and Flame, the leading international journal on combustion. Technical support by MAHLE Powertrain (Hugh Blaxill, hugh.blaxill@gb.mahle.com) is being exploited for designing a new engine for very low CO2 emissions.

Title: Art and science in the design of physically large and complex systems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A - Mathemtical Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This article follows on from two earlier Royal Society Proceedings papers on design of complex systems (see references) and brings together the author’s philosophical investigations as the international leading authority in marine design methodology. One of the article’s referees commented: “ an interesting and insightful analysis. The paper offers an internationally important and useful contribution to the growing body of scientific knowledge about the most technically-difficult design contexts.” (Joanna.Harries@royalsociety.org). The investigations outlined in the paper were drawn on for the invited Keynote Address “Is Marine Design now a Mature Discipline?” given to the International Marine Design Conference in June 2012.

Title: Integrating personnel movement simulation into preliminary ship design
VolumeTitle: RINA International Journal of Maritime Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented the outcome of an EPSRC project (GR/T22100/01 & GR/T22117/01). It showed that complex personnel movement simulation could be applied early in ship design, enabling human factors (HF) to be addressed at the same time as “classical” naval architectural analysis in early stage ship design. This world leading expertise in integrating HF in initial ship design resulted in the first author’s research team leading the design package in a major 2012 FP7 project (FAROS [r.puisa@strath.ac.uk]) incorporating HF in passenger ship design as part of Risk Based Design. This paper was awarded the RINA Samuel Baxter Prize for 2008.

Title: A demonstration of an advanced library based approach to the initial design exploration of different hullform configurations
AdditionalInformation: This research supported by the UK MoD (DESSMCES-DCE@mod.uk) addresses how, hull types, such as multi-hulls, can be considered in initially evolving a design requirement. This research was used directly in justifying a major ($1.5M) research programme funded in 2011 by the US Office of Naval Research (kelly.cooper1@navy.mil), where the second author is in partnership with Professor Singer (University of Michigan) and Professor Hopman, Professor of Ship Design, TU Delft. In this four year project these three, internationally leading, ship design research centres will advance the knowledge and practice of architecturally based ship design, pioneered by the second author (Reference 13).

Title: Marine Requirements Elucidation and the Nature of Preliminary Ship Design
VolumeTitle: Transactions of the Royal Institution of Naval Architects Part A: International Journal of Maritime Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The author, as former Head of Naval Concept Design in the UK MoD, has challenged the prevailing paradigm of Requirement Engineering in defence procurement and this substantial paper argues for a more appropriate strategy for the design of major engineering projects. It led to an extensive debate amongst ship designers and leading systems engineers in UK and USA, captured in the 2012 discussion and author’s reply, indicating the significance of the paper and this topic in influencing UK Defence Acquisition (still the largest customer for British Industry) in an era of stringent cost constraint and the ongoing search for cost-effectiveness.

Title: Decomposition of flow structures in stirred reactors and implications for mixing enhancement
AdditionalInformation: The paper was invited by the journal editor and the research was funded by EPSRC (EP/D032539) with technical support from project partners, Syngenta (alan.hall@syngenta.com) and Dantec-Dynamics (graham.hassall@dantecdynamics.com). The paper provides new insights on the physical mechanisms underlying macro-instability structures in stirred tank reactors. This study is part of long term research (AIChE J. 53 (2)) into power reduction in chemical and pharmaceutical processes. The implications of this work are well reflected in the comments from one of the reviewers “this paper is of interest for practical application and the authors best describes how their results can be utilized in practice”.

Title: On the Manifestation and Nature of Macroinstabilities in Stirred Vessels
AdditionalInformation: This paper is published in the leading international journal for chemical engineering research and it was funded by EPSRC (EP/D032539) with technical support from project partners Syngenta (Alan Hall - alan.hall@syngenta.com) and Dantec Dynamics (Graham Hassall- graham.hassall@dantecdynamics.com). The study builds on previous published research (AIChE J. 53 (2); IECR, 57 (11)). The paper demonstrates that different periodic phenomena obtained with different impeller types  can be linked to the precession of a vortex around the impeller axis. The results presented in this paper attracted Kühner AG into a new collaboration and the sponsorship of an EngD studentship (EPSRC-IDTC) on bioreactor design/scaling.

Title: Three-Dimensional Deformation Dynamics of Trailing Vortex Structures in a Stirred Vessel
AdditionalInformation: This study uses a novel approach to gain new understanding into the highly three dimensional deformation dynamics caused by impeller trailing vortices in stirred tank reactors. The research was funded by EPSRC (EP/D032539) with technical support from industrial partners Syngenta (alan.hall@syngenta.com) and Dantec Dynamics (graham.hassall@dantecdynamics.com). The methodology developed has general applicability in scaling problems of chemical and biochemical processes: it is directly linked to an EPSRC Advanced Research Fellowship (EP/E055958/1) awarded to Ducci to study the strain and mixing dynamics in shaken bio-reactors. Part of this work was also presented at the 8th World Congress of Chemical Engineers (1458, MIX5).

Title: On the fluid dynamics of shaken bioreactors-flow characterization and transition
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel experimental study on the flow dynamics in an orbitally shaken cylinder and offers improved methodologies for scaling of shaken bio-reactors. The research was funded by the EPSRC Advanced research fellowship (Ducci, EP/E055958/1), with technical support from industrial partners Syngenta (Hall, alan.hall@syngenta.com) and BHR group (Ozcan, GOzcan@bhrgroup.co.uk).  The laminar to turbulent flow transition and flow scaling law identified in this work have already been successfully applied to assess the mixing time in shaken bio-reactors (ChERD, DOI: 10.1016/j.cherd.2013.1003.1005). The outcomes of this research have strengthened the collaboration with our industrial partner Kühner AG (T. Anderlei, tanderlei@kuhner.com).

Title: Shear-Induced Unfolding of Lysozyme Monitored In Situ
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports on a novel study of shear induced protein unfolding in collaboration with the University of Manchester; it was supported by the EPSRC Chemistry –Chemical Engineering Interface Initiative EPSRC (EP/D500818/1, EP/F007736/1) and described as ‘a challenging interdisciplinary venture’ by reviewers. It represents the first successful attempt in UK to monitor flow induced conformational changes of proteins in real time. The work is of significant importance to therapeutic protein production and has lead to further collaborations and funding from the Technology Strategy Board (TP 4783-44 269, Technology Inspired Collaborative R&D).

Title: On the quasiperiodic state in a moderate aspect ratio Taylor-Couette flow
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes flow transitions in a Taylor-Couette bioreactor studied with time–resolved particle image velocimetry. Novel post processing based on orthogonal decomposition allowed study of flow instabilities, revealing a different route to turbulence than previously reported. It was demonstrated that Taylor-Couette geometry is important to fundamental studies and practical applications in reaction and separation. It leads to consultancy (Protein Technologies Ltd, UK, paul.goddard@potein-technologies.com), and further collaborative research with industry (Plymouth Marine Laboratories, Plymouth PL1 3DH, UK, mija@pml.ac.uk; EDTE, UK and Protein Technologies Ltd, UK) in the field of algal biofuel production supported by TSB (TP 4783-44 269).

Title: Coupled human erythrocyte velocity field and aggregation measurements at physiological haematocrit levels
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study in which red blood cell aggregation and flow velocity field are measured simultaneously using human blood at physiological haematocrit levels (45%). Optical shearing and microPIV techniques were employed to quantify both cell aggregation and velocities of sheared blood and demonstrated the strong coupling between the two, not considered hitherto in published hemodynamics studies. The work, performed in collaboration with a blood rheologist, was subsequently expanded via a PhD studentship (funded by KCL graduate school) in experimental micro-haemodynamics and resulted in collaboration with modellers both nationally and internationally as well as with cardiovascular biologists.

Title: Detecting the Early Onset of Shear-Induced Fibril Formation of Insulin in situ
AdditionalInformation: This interdisciplinary research was funded by the EPSRC Chemistry/Chemical Engineering Interface Initiative (EP/F007736/1) and highlights the significant effect of flow in accelerating fibril formation and its implications for biotechnology, health and pharmaceutical processing. Insulin is of both physiological and pharmaceutical interest and is known to be susceptible to aggregation. This paper reports a novel method for in situ monitoring of fibrilogenesis in the presence of shear using Raman spectroscopy in conjunction with Principal Component Analysis. It shows that insulin fibrils are formed much earlier than previously reported in the presence of shear.

Title: The pyrolytic degradation of wood-derived lignin from pulping process
AdditionalInformation: This widely cited paper was funded by a major EPSRC Grant (EP/G034281/1) as well as a research exchange grant from the Ministry of Science and Technology of China. The collaboration enabled the combination of advanced modelling expertise in the UK with state of the art experimental facility in Zhejiang University, China (Prof. M.X. Fang; mxfang@zju.edu.cn). The results reported in this paper improved fundamental understanding of the fast pyrolysis and chemical pathways in bio-fuel production. An EU FP7 follow-on project “ECOFUEL” (Grant No. 246772) involve academic and industrial partners in China, Finland and the UK.

Title: Inert-droplet and combustion effects on turbulence in a diluted diffusion flame
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a major study of a reactive turbulent flow using direct numerical simulation and involves the largest ever number of evaporating droplets attempted (17 millions). The study revealed intricate phenomena and mechanisms of multiphase turbulent combustion not hitherto captured. The findings will help underpin the design of  ultra low NOx gas turbine combustors (Contact: stefan.wysocki@alstom.com). This major study was supported by a series of EPSRC grants (EP/E011640/1, EP/I000801/1 and EP/D080223/1). The results will also be presented in a keynote speech by Kai Luo (22nd International Congress of Mechanical Engineering, Brazil, 3-7th November, 2013).

Title: Lattice Boltzmann method for relativistic hydrodynamics: Issues on conservation law of particle number and discontinuities
AdditionalInformation: This paper, supported by EPSRC (EP/I012605/1), presents the development of a relativistic lattice Boltzmann (RLB) method to hydrodynamics. It was cited by an international team including Prof Sauro Succi (succi@iac.cnr.it), Prof Ilya Karlin (karlin@lav.mavt.ethz.ch) and Prof Hans Herrmann (hjherrmann@ethz.ch) as having discovered “spurious diffusive effects” in previous theories and developed “an improved version of RLB” which they term a new “MRT RLB” model. The method developed also have applications from complex fluids to astrophysics and high-energy physics. It has led to the recent formation of a “UK Consortium on Mesoscale Engineering” supported by EPSRC (EP/L00030X/1), led by the corresponding author.

Title: Modeling the thermochemical degradation of biomass inside a fast pyrolysis fluidized bed reactor
AdditionalInformation: This publication is the outcome of a multi-institutional collaboration (Dr. van Wachem in the UK, b.van-wachem@imperial.ac.uk ; Prof. Brown in the USA, rcbrown3@iastate.edu) which conducted rigorous comparisons between advanced multi-physics simulations and purposely designed experiments. The substantial financial support required for this project was provided by the EPSRC (EP/G034281/1 and EP/I000801/1) and EU FP7 (ECOFUEL project No. 246772). The paper won the first author an EPSRC Doctoral Prize and nomination for a European Federation of Chemical Engineering Excellence Award. There was further exploitation of the research findings through industrial consultancy for K+K Wissenstransfer e.K., Germany (Joern_Bruchmueller@gmx.de).

Title: Hypoxic culture of human pluripotent stem cell lines is permissible using mouse embryonic fibroblasts
AdditionalInformation: This article describes bioprocess environment modifications for the robust, scalable expansion of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs). Hypoxia is favourable for production of neurons from pluripotent cells but there is significant worry that supportive fibroblast feeders become unstable in these conditions. Feeders are desirable for cell expansion, as feeder-free methods cause genetic instability in hESCs and, potentially, cancer. This work underpins a subsequent collaborative BBSRC BRIC project grant with ReNeuron (Dr John Sinden CSO ReNeuron, John-Sinden@reneuron.com) for scalable production of a genetically stable regenerative cell line for neurologic injury that is clinically safe, overcoming limitations of hESCs.

Title: TiO2-doped phosphate glass microcarriers: A stable bioactive substrate for expansion of adherent mammalian cells.
AdditionalInformation: Cell therapy for bone requires scalable tissue engineering approaches that can be personalised to the individual patient requirements such as size and shape of defect. This paper assessed the potential of TiO2-doped phosphate glass microcarriers as a stable substrate for cell expansion. TiO2-doped phosphate glass is already regarded as an excellent substrate for bone cell growth and the work in this paper demonstrating that adherent mammalian cells can adhere and grow on microcarriers provides the proof of principle for a scalable platform technology for manufacturing tissue engineered micro-units in a scalable fashion.

Title: Effect of capillary shear stress on recovery and osteogenic differentiation of muscle-derived precursor cell populations
AdditionalInformation: Bones are exposed to shear stress in vivo, as tissue fluid flows through channels within bone, leading to stem cell recruitment and differentiation as a direct result of the mechanical shear stress signal the cells experience. In this study, adult stem cells from a distinct tissue, muscle, were placed in suspension and passed through an ultra scale down capillary device to induce shear stress. The combination of capillary flow with defined differentiation medium resulted in significantly increased calcified matrix production compared with differentiation medium alone. A capillary-based device has potential for enhancing production of bone cell material for therapy.

Title: Biochemical changes caused by decellularization may compromise mechanical integrity of tracheal scaffolds
AdditionalInformation: This paper described the limitations of the current gold standard decellularisation method used to manufacture bioengineered trachea for clinical transplantation. In particular, the loss of structural proteins critical for a functional airway were reported and previously unreported biomechanical compromise in the engineered construct was found. The work underpinned the subsequent cGMP manufacture of a tissue-engineered trachea actually used for human transplantation at Great Ormond Street Hospital (Prof Martin Birchall, m.birchall@ucl.ac.uk) and featured on a BBC documentary about life-saving experimental surgery. The work underpinned development of a new bioreactor-based method of decellularisation that is faster and yields a mechanically stronger scaffold.

Title: Ultra Scale-Down Stress Analysis of the Bioprocessing of Whole Human Cells as a Basis for Cancer Vaccines
AdditionalInformation: This rigorous definition of process-stress impact on human cell survival is central to future predictive design of cell therapy manufacturing routes. An original combination of fluid/particle dynamics, ultra scale-down methodologies (created in the EPSRC Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre (IMRC) in Bioprocessing) and cell biology insight is used within a Design of Experiments framework for early process studies. Differences in cells’ susceptibility to process damage are successfully predicted as is the design of low-stress systems to prevent cell damage. The technology supports a TSB project on new cell lines for therapy and their manufacture at scale (Dr Stephen Ward, COO, Stephen.ward@ct.catapult.org.uk)

Title: Rapid Whole Monoclonal Antibody Analysis by Mass Spectrometry: An Ultra Scale-Down Study of the Effect of Harvesting by Centrifugation on the Post-Translational Modification Profile
AdditionalInformation: This use of ultra scale-down methods  (see USD Technologies impact case study) provided a first rigorous insight of cell culture interaction with recovery and purification of a monoclonal antibody, the impact on its molecular heterogeneity and hence clinical efficacy and safety. A key discovery was of intracellular near-neighbour variants and how their presence in the recovery chain may be prevented by use of low-stress engineering designs. This research  led to an industrial collaboration with ImmunoBiology on  recovery of antibody-based fusion vaccine candidates where  greater extents of molecular heterogeneity make low stress engineering of high significance (Dr Graham Clarke, CEO,graham.clarke@immbio.com).

Title: Ultra Scale-Down Prediction Using Microwell Technology of the Industrial Scale Clarification Characteristics by Centrifugation of Mammalian Cell Broths
AdditionalInformation: Use of microwell technologies operating at the sub-millilitre scale to study high-speed, continuous-flow industrial-scale centrifugation over a full range of operating conditions allows the rigorous characterisation of the interaction between cell culture and cell recovery. The fuller understanding gained in this work of the relationship between cell culture age, process stress susceptibility and recovery chain performance has opened the route to whole bioprocess design and optimization and use of IMRC ultra scale-down technologies for real-time monitoring of bioreactor operation. This, and related research, has led to creation of a £1.1m GSK-UCL Centre of Excellence in Bioprocessing (Dr Mark Uden, mark.x.uden@gsk.com).

Title: An ultra scale-down characterization of low shear stress primary recovery stages to enhance selectivity of fusion protein recovery from its molecular variants
AdditionalInformation: This is a first characterisation of the challenges of recovery of a next generation biopharmaceutical product; an engineered fusion protein used to promote a selective immune response. Ultra scale-down methods (see USD Technologies impact case study) were used to create a new understanding of how process stress affects the presence of near-neighbour contaminating molecules as well as a range of non-protein contaminants. This paper has provided a first USD demonstration of the value of a low stress cell culture and recovery sequence involving centrifugation or depth filtration and shown how successful early predictions of full scale operations may be achieved.

Title: Strategic biopharmaceutical portfolio development: An analysis of constraint-induced implications
AdditionalInformation: This research established a software optimisation tool to facilitate the necessary linkage between drug portfolio selection and 'build-versus-buy' capacity sourcing decisions during biopharmaceutical drug development. This extended drug development evaluation models established within the Decisional Tools impact case study(Rajapakse et al, 2005 & 2006). A novel approach that harnessed the benefits of Bayesian networks combined with evolutionary algorithms was established to search efficiently a much larger decision space of over 10^21 permutations without having to enumerate all possibilities or use rigid mathematical formulations. This research provided the basis for an EngD collaboration with Bayer Technology Services (Dr Thomas Daszkowski, thomas.daszkowski@bayer.com).

Title: Decisional tool to assess current and future process robustness in an antibody purification facility
AdditionalInformation: With increases in cell culture productivity, it has become critical to identify robust strategies that alleviate downstream bottlenecks. This paper describes creation of a novel database-driven simulation tool to identify optimal purification strategies and visualise their robustness. We demonstrated how to integrate effectively dynamic simulation, optimisation, process economics, uncertainty analysis and relational databases, thus building upon the Decisional Tools impact case study. Novel visualisation plots enabled rapid identification of purification configurations that were robust to upstream fluctuations, and the purification facility limit. This led to new EngDs with Pfizer (Dr Sa Ho, sa.v.ho@pfizer.com) and Lonza Biologics (Dr Dave Pain, dave.pain@lonza.com).

Title: Fed-batch and perfusion culture processes: economic, environmental, and operational feasibility under uncertainty.
AdditionalInformation: This paper explored the potential of emerging continuous cell culture and cell separation technologies. Batch simulation models, created in the Decisional Tools impact case study, were extended to capture the dynamics of continuous manufacture. Algorithms were created to optimise continuous processes and to model the complex consequences of failures in continuous systems. Environmental indices relevant to the bioprocessing industry were devised, allowing the operational, economic, and environmental feasibility of these processes to be assessed simultaneously using multi-attribute decision-making.  This research provided the basis for further collaboration with Bayer Technology Services (Dr Thomas Daszkowski, thomas.daszkowski @bayer.com).

Title: Integration of stochastic simulation with multivariate analysis: short-term facility fit prediction.
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds on Stonier et al. (2012) and the Decisional Tools impact case study linking stochastic simulation with advanced multivariate analysis to help pinpoint the root causes of unwanted events in boprocesses.  The multidimensional nature of the stochastic datasets was analysed using principal component analysis, clustering algorithms and stacked parallel co-ordinate plots.  This provided a rigorous approach to facility fit assessment that captures the impact of batch-to-batch variability, predicts the likelihood of product loss, identifies risk hotspots, and visualises the robustness of the process allowing for rapid identification of the combination of batch characteristics that result in product losses.

Title: An automated microscale platform for evaluation and optimization of oxidative bioconversion processes.
AdditionalInformation: The uptake of oxidative biocatalysts in pharmaceutical manufacture has been hindered by long development times. We demonstrate how, using automated microscale technologies, oxidative bioconversions can be designed with a reduced cost and timeframe compared to conventional experimentation. Substrate specificity and product selectivity were demonstrated with previously untested substrates and two novel products synthesized. Successful 90,000-fold scale-up provides confidence in the approach and extends the BiCE impact case study findings to oxidative bioconversions. This work led to new EngD project with Synthace (Dr Markus Gershater, CSO, m.gershater@synthace.com) and to a €10.5M EU-wide collaborations as part of the FP7 BIONEXGEN Project.

Title: A generic hierarchical screening method for the analysis of microscale refolds using an automated robotic platform.
AdditionalInformation: The refolding of protein derived from inclusion bodies is a key process step where optimisation traditionally demands significant resources and time. The paper represents the first example of the application of automated microscale technology to the study of refolding of inclusion body proteins and demonstrates how quantitative process information can be more rapidly obtained using sub-millilitre quantities of often precious material. A generic and novel sequence of analytical assays is proposed that enables the identification of favourable conditions to be detected early in process development. The approach has since been taken up by Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies (Dr John Liddell, john.liddell@fujifilmdb.com).

Title: A Multidisciplinary Approach Toward the Rapid and Preparative-Scale Biocatalytic Synthesis of Chiral Amino Alcohols: A Concise Transketolase-/omega-Transaminase-Mediated Synthesis of (2S,3S)-2-Aminopentane-1,3-diol
AdditionalInformation: This work was the first to describe the integration of enzyme engineering, bioinformatics-led strategies, automated microscale bioprocessing, modelling and scale-up expertise with the aim to develop a concise and efficient two-step biocatalytic preparative synthesis of a chiral pharmaceutical intermediate from inexpensive substrates. The use of automated microscale technology facilitated rapid optimisation at the early stages of process development, when intermediates and information on reaction kinetics is often scarce, allowing successful process design and scale-up. The research has led to our IChemE Innovation and Excellence award in Bioprocessing in 2010 and helped underpin the BiCE impact case study.

Title: Use of microwells to investigate the effect of quorum sensing on growth and antigen production in Bacillus anthracis Sterne 34F2.
AdditionalInformation: This work describes a first investigation of the anthrax bacteria culture environment using microwell technologies. It reveals that anthrax uses a complex, population density dependent, cell signalling mechanism that is key for growth and vaccine production. The study attributed the long lag phase seen in the commercial vaccine manufacturing process to cultures not reaching a sufficient population density and proposed modifications to make vaccine manufacturing more productive and reproducible. The impact of this work is being evaluated by the Health Protection Agency for adaptation of the UK licensed Anthrax vaccine production process (Dr Nigel Allison, nigel.allison@hpa.org.uk).

Title: Evaluation of anthrax vaccine production by Bacillus anthracis Sterne 34F(2) in stirred suspension culture using a miniature bioreactor: A useful scale-down tool for studies on fermentations at high containment
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates the use of scale-down tools for the development of challenging, high-containment vaccines, such as anthrax. In this case, a scaled-down miniature bioreactor provided insight into culture kinetics by mimicking and characterising the process environment. These results were successfully exploited to propose a new method for vaccine manufacture that halved production time and increased yields by 20%. The impact of this work is such that the Health Protection Agency is evaluating the results for adaptation of the licensed UK Anthrax vaccine production process (Dr Nigel Allison, nigel.allison@hpa.org.uk). It also illustrates use of USD Technologies impact case study outputs.

Title: Characterization of lentiviral vector production using microwell suspension cultures of HEK293T-derived producer cells.
AdditionalInformation: This work examined the production of lentiviruses as a therapeutic vaccine for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. A key challenge is to ensure that the virus suitably 'packages' the corrective gene and is biologically active for delivery. This paper combined statistical Design of Experiments with micro-scale cell cultures to identify key parameters for the production of lentivirus vectors.  An optimal harvest window was identified based on an interaction between fluid hydrodynamics and virus half-life calculations. These findings currently underpin the development of a manufacturing-scale process for Phase 3 clinical trials by Oxford Biomedica (Dr Kiri Mitrophanous, k.mitrophanous@oxfordbiomedica.co.uk).

Title: High throughput quantification of capsular polysaccharides for multivalent vaccines using precipitation with a cationic surfactant
AdditionalInformation: Development of purification processes for polysaccharide vaccines are constrained by a lack of analytical tools. Current technologies for the measurement of polysaccharide recovery at various stages of purification are variable and not amenable to high throughput process development. This paper details advances in improving assay speed and throughput based on electrostatic precipitation. The new assay is characterised by a two log dynamic range, high accuracy and precision and takes just 30 minutes to perform. Pfizer will utilise this methodology to support rapid process optimisation for a number of polysaccharide vaccines currently in development (Dr Khurram Sunasara, khurram.sunasara@pfizer.com).

Title: Modular microfluidic reactor and inline filtration system for the biocatalytic synthesis of chiral metabolites
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis B - Enzymatic
AdditionalInformation: This work describe a novel microfluidic combination of upstream and downstream bioprocess steps, yielding the first demonstration of biocatalytic synthesis of a pure pharmaceutical intermediate in a continuous flow setting. For rapid process development, the microreactor provides a quick and easy route towards testing different bioconversions; in particular, the tangential-flow filtration device reversibly seals any membrane type for facile investigation of membrane-based enzyme recovery, and other membrane-based separation steps. Data from the microfluidic reactor was found to scale robustly. Based on this unique research, Nicolas Szita subsequently won an ERA-net grant (£1.4M) to establish further designs and extend their application.

Title: Microfluidic approaches for systems and synthetic biology.
AdditionalInformation: This work describes how microfluidics can improve biological analysis and biocatalyst design. Consideration is given to biomolecule analyses which exploit high-throughput methods such as droplets travelling in channels, yet critically depend on channel coating methods, and coupling strategies with traditional analytical equipment (such as MS); to cell phenotype analyses with more complex (micro-)reactor design, necessitating in-situ instrumentation to demonstrate linkage with larger reactors. A first illustration is given as to the suitability of these different devices and fabrication methods to create a cellular assembly train, which could lead to de novo constructed cells (synthetic biology), e.g. for novel biocatalyst engineering.

Title: Microfabricated Modular Scale-Down Device for Regenerative Medicine Process Development
AdditionalInformation: This publication details how microfluidics can achieve a step change with the same impact in stem cell process development as microbioreactors delivered for traditional biotechnology. Feeder-attached human stem cell culture at a microfluidic scale was successfully demonstrated. The microfabricated device contains all the elements required to scout process conditions: cell growth substrates, extra-cellular matrices, seeding densities, culture medium exchange and perfusion rates can. An image-processing algorithm was developed which permits online quantification of colony sizes against the background of feeder cells. Based on this patented technology, an EPSRC Impact Acceleration Account (£100k) was won with Camtech Innovations Ltd.

Title: Microfluidic multi-input reactor for biocatalytic synthesis using transketolase
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis B: Enzymatic
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, ‘fed- batch’ like substrate feeding strategies are applied to continuous-flow biocatalytic microreactors. With our novel multi-input design, different feeding strategies are easily tested. We successfully demonstrate a 5-fold increase in output concentration and throughput compared with a conventional single input reactor. This represents a significant step towards the process intensification capability that has thus far only been associated with chemical microreactors, and will dramatically accelerate the development of multi-step synthetic processes for complex molecular products now being investigated with Sigma Aldrich (Dr Roland Wohlgemuth, Roland.Wohlgemuth@sial.com).

Title: Hypoxia enhances the generation of retinal progenitor cells from human induced pluripotent and embryonic stem cells.
AdditionalInformation: Developing efficient processes for the production of retinal cells from pluripotent stem cells will underpin the development of new therapies for the treatment of blindness. In this paper we demonstrate for the first time that the early retinal differentiation of both human embryonic and human induced pluripotent stem cells can be improved at 2% O2 when compared with ambient (21% O2). This approach could be used for both allogeneic and autologous treatments. This paper also represents the successful translation of our early results using mouse cells (Mondragon-Teran et al, 2009,  DOI: 10.1002/btpr.248) into clinically relevant human cells.

Title: The release of single cells from embryoid bodies in a capillary flow device
AdditionalInformation: The recovery of cells from cellular aggregates known as embryoid bodies (EBs) is an essential production step in many cell-based therapies. We developed a novel technique for breaking apart EBs based on controlled exposure to shear forces in a capillary device. The break-up process was described using a first-order relationship with both the rate and final yield being a function of the flow rate and the total time of exposure to shear stress. This paper details both the fundamentals kinetics governing EB breakage and provides an alternative shear-based process which avoids the use of animal-derived enzymes in the manufacturing process.

Title: The impact of manual processing on the expansion and directed differentiation of embryonic stem cells
AdditionalInformation: Exploiting the clinical promise of Embryonic Stem Cells (ESC) will be dependent on the development of production processes which consistently meet stringent quality control and release criteria. This work demonstrated, for the first time, the importance of controlled manual handling during ESC processing. Operator control over cell density, shear forces, exposure to ambient conditions and centrifugal forces were all shown to be critical variables. This work underpins related studies on stem cell process automation and provided the basis for a TSB collaborative grant with Lonza on production of cells for clinical application (Dr Behzad Mahdavi, behzad.mahdavi@lonza.com).

Title: Oxygen-controlled automated neural differentiation of mouse embryonic stem cells.
AdditionalInformation: Current protocols for the directed differentiation of embryonic stem cells (ESC) tend to be inefficient and irreproducible.  This innovative paper combines efficient oxygen controlled differentiation described in previous publications (Mondragon-Teran et al., 2009 and 2011 DOIs:10.1002/btpr.248 and 10.1002/btpr.675) with reproducible automation technology.  We present a novel technology which controls the gaseous environment (O2, CO2 and temperature) during both the liquid handling and incubation stages of differentiation, meaning that cells are not repeatedly exposed to deleterious ambient conditions during lengthy cell culture protocols.  The result is a significant step towards standardised and efficient processing of cells for human therapy.

Title: A multi-level metaheuristic algorithm to optimise antibody purification processes at the bioprocess-business interface.
AdditionalInformation: This was an output of a TSB/EPSRC project with Simaria as lead reseracher and Farid as PI. The research focused on identifying more cost-effective purification processes for next generation biopharmaceuticals. Simaria devised advanced combinatorial optimisation techniques and linked them to process models from the Decisional Tools impact case study to effectively search large decision spaces whilst rationalising multiple conflicting targets. This has led to the collaborators, Medimmune, sponsoring a joint £0.7M Centre of Excellence (Dr Richard Turner, TurnerRi@medimmune.com). This work also underpinned the award of a new £4.9M EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Emergent Macromolecular Therapies.

Title: Prediction and verification of centrifugal dewatering of P. pastoris fermentation cultures using an ultra scale-down approach.
AdditionalInformation: Yeast cells like Pichia are favoured in the bioprocessing industry for their ability to produce and release soluble therapeutic proteins of high quality. A challenge with Pichia are the very high cell densities achieved. This creates a bottleneck in the dewatering of the cells during separation where operating conditions at large scale need to be evaluated and optimised. This paper provides the first ultra scale-down predictive laboratory tool to assess the dewatering characteristics of cells during centrifugation. The work was sponsored by an IMRC partner, Merck, and verified at pilot scale in collaboration with Fujifilm Biotechnologies (Dr John Liddell,  john.liddell@fujifilmdb.com).

Title: Study of robustness of filamentous bacteriophages for industrial applications.
AdditionalInformation: Bacterial viruses, phages, are at the forefront of research into new therapies such as vaccines and alternative antibiotics. Filamentous phage have the added advantage that they can be used for a much wider application including semiconductor nanowires in diagnostic devices. Despite their potential diversity of application, bioprocess development for phages is still in its infancy. This paper reports the first assessment of their robustness under high shear processing conditions at industrial concentrations. The findings are now helping define the sequence of operations for efficient and robust phage manufacturing processes currently being developed by Cobra Biologics (Dr Tony Hitchcock,  tony.hitchcock@cobrabio.com).

Title: Characterisation of mechanical properties of transgenic tobacco roots expressing a recombinant monocylonal antibody against tooth decay
AdditionalInformation: Together with a companion publication (Hassan et al, 2008, DOI: 10.1111/j.1467-7652.2008.00354.x) this paper is “proof of principle” of the use of tobacco roots as a future means of large scale protein production. The minimum force required to release the product from roots was established, minimising debris formation and reducing downstream processing cost. This is important in light of the global need for replacing usage of tobacco crops in sustainable economies and is a demonstration of the use of USD Technologies impact case study outputs in new areas. The work was in collaboration with St George’s Hospital (Prof Julian Ma, jma@sgul.ac.uk).

Title: Precipitation of filamentous bacteriophages for their selective recovery in primary purification.
AdditionalInformation: The bottleneck in the efficient industrial application of filamentous phages is in the downstream processing of these viruses. This paper reports a novel approach to precipitation as an effective method for separating and purifying phages (with high yield and purity) from the main process contaminants including cell proteins and potentially cellular toxins. This work together with its companion paper (Branston et al, 2011, DOI 10.1002/bit.23066) has put UCL at the forefront of phage bioprocessing in the world. The work has led to a new collaboration with a US company Neurophage Pharmaceuticals (Dr Jason Wright, jwright@neurophage.com).

Title: Study of a novel tube forming method for preparing engineered blood vessels
AdditionalInformation: This multidisciplinary paper represents the first mathematical modelling of a novel approach to tissue-engineering blood vessels in a robust and reproducible manner. Coronary artery bypass surgery requires the replacement of blocked arteries by vein harvested from the leg in a second operation. Thus there is a requirement for the scalable bioprocessing of de novo arteries of different lengths and wall thicknesses depending upon patient requirements. The model facilitates extrusion by a novel process (invented by Mason and Town) that enables bespoke living vessels to be produced in an automated bioreactor. This technology received a NESTA Medical Futures Innovation Award.

Title: Feeder-free culture of human embryonic stem cells for scalable expansion in a reproducible manner.
AdditionalInformation: Animal cells (“feeders”) are often required to grow human cells in vitro (co-culture). If the human cells are intended for clinical implantation this is highly undesirable e.g. potential to transmit animal viruses to man. Through a TSB collaboration with Plasticell and NIBSC, we were the first to demonstrate a robust scalable methodology to successfully grow human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) without feeders and without compromising quality. This enabled us to secure further TSB collaborative funding with Lonza to explore novel uses of hESC cell surface markers for bioprocess monitoring and control (Dr Kim Warren, kim.warren@lonza.com).

Title: Scale-up of human embryonic stem cell culture using a hollow fibre bioreactor
AdditionalInformation: Cell therapies require the manufacturing of cells in sufficient quantity for routine clinical practice. The current method of growing cells on the surface of a flat-sided bottle is pragmatically acceptable for clinical proof of concept but not for scaled Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) production. Collaborating with Beckman Coulter (now acquired by Terumo) we were the first to demonstrate that even highly delicate human embryonic stem cells can be successfully grown in a closed system of parallel hollow fibres. Terumo is currently using our data to support development of their next generation GMP hollow fibre bioreactors (Dr Stefano Baila, stefano.baila@terumobct.com).

Title: Effect of Sub-Atmospheric Oxygen on the Culture of Rabbit Limbal Epithelial Cells
AdditionalInformation: Corneal (limbal) epithelial cells are cultured in vitro for the restoration of human eyesight following a chemical burn and the subsequent scarring of the cornea.  The process is, however, not yet robust.  One specific challenge is the sensitivity of limbal cells to oxygen tension.  Since human limbal cells are only available in limited quantity, we studied the rabbit equivalent.  A sub-atmospheric oxygen tension of 14% was found to promote the maintenance and expansion of the cells.  This approach has now been incorporated into the routine Good Manufacturing Practice of limbal cell therapies at Moorfield's Eye Hospital (Prof Julie Daniels, j.daniels@ucl.ac.uk).

Title: The Simplex Algorithm for the Rapid Identification of Operating Conditions During Early Bioprocess Development: Case Studies in FAb' Precipitation and Multimodal Chromatography
AdditionalInformation: We describe a data-driven approach for locating the optimal sub-set of experiments needed to characterise complex bioprocess operations. This Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre (IMRC) method is a significant advance over traditional Design of Experiments techniques by harnessing knowledge from previous experiments when determining, in real-time, the next conditions to investigate for focusing the search. The approach is demonstrated  showing at least a 50% reduction in the number of experiments needed to achieve comparable levels of knowledge when compared to existing state-of-the-art methods. The work is now being followed up in an industry partnership with Merck (Dr Peter DePhillips, peter.dephillips@merck.com).

Title: A methodology for the comparative evaluation of alternative bioseparation technologies.
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows how Mixed Attribute Decision Making can guide decision making during the development of high resolution purification techniques for biologics. The novelty of this Decisional Tools approach (see impact case study) is in the assignment of qualitative and quantitative measures describing the viability of operations upon scale-up and defining the potential of each using probabilistically-based scores showing the sensitivity to a range of input variables. This allows for the rapid identification of process alternatives. Such insights enable industry to target improvements of each method and supports on-going process development research with GE Healthcare (Dr Karol Lacki, karol.lacki@ge.com).

Title: Principal Component Score Modelling for the Rapid Description of Chromatographic Separations.
AdditionalInformation: This IMRC output provides a novel approach for the modelling of complex chromatographic separations that form the heart of biologics manufacture. Conventional mass-transfer models only accommodate a few components and require extensive experimental parameterisation. Using statistical models (Principal Component Analysis) we have shown, for the first time, how highly accurate correlations for complex separations can be made, accommodating critical scale-up parameters of direct industrial significance including bed dimensions and operating conditions. The generic technique, proven in industry with Fujifilm Diosynth, provides a rapid means for accurate scale up and process transfer with minimal consumption of resources (Dr John Liddell, j.liddell@fuijifilmdb.com).

Title: Strategic assay deployment as a method for countering analytical bottlenecks in high throughput process development: Case studies in ion exchange chromatography
AdditionalInformation: Analysis of process samples is a bottleneck in rapid process characterisation and development; a key IMRC goal. We describe the construction and deployment of a novel mathematical routine for ranking of analytical methods to determine the optimal selection to be used for a given development problem. The method evaluates, iteratively, measurement techniques for selected analytes based upon user-specified criterion e.g. sample consumption. The direct benefit is that analysis is no longer rate-limiting. The method was tested in industry, with GE Healthcare, for a set of realistic chromatographic separations demonstrating significant reductions in assay time (~40%) (Dr Eva Heldin, eva.heldin@ge.com).

Title: Directed evolution of transketolase substrate specificity towards an aliphatic aldehyde.
AdditionalInformation: This work was central to a series of directed evolution papers which led to improved enzymes, and where novel experimental methods achieved this with greater efficiency than previously possible. A combination of enzyme structure analysis and bioinformatics identified just 20 key residues (from 680) for mutagenesis. Screening only 400 variants generated mutants with new substrate specificity now used by company partners (see BICE impact case study). This previously required thousands of variants to be screened, thus enzymes can now be engineered more rapidly to access new chemical transformations within the typically short timelines available for development of new synthetic routes.

Title: Rapid Optimization of Protein Freeze-Drying Formulations Using Ultra Scale-Down and Factorial Design of Experiment in Microplates
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses the challenge of identifying chemical formulations that improve the shelf-life of freeze-dried biological medicines using only minimal quantities of material. It demonstrated protein freeze-drying in microplates for the first time, and that the outcome was equivalent to a standard vial-scale process. The method enabled the impact of multiple chemical factors to be explored in parallel using a 'factorial design' approach, and to optimise the formulation to retain 100% of the biological activity. Such research provides a landmark technique for the freeze-dried formulation of therapeutic proteins, and is now used at NIBSC by Dr Paul Matejtschuk (Paul.Matejtschuk@nibsc.org).

Title: Distributions of enzyme residues yielding mutants with improved substrate specificities from two different directed evolution strategies
AdditionalInformation: This paper mapped the efficiency of two leading directed evolution techniques for protein engineering. It was the first to show that the most widely-used method, error-prone PCR (epPCR), is 100x less efficient than saturation mutagenesis. It also showed that the most effective protein residue targets for saturation mutagenesis form two groups: those with high conservation; and those with intermediate conservation, where in both cases they are in direct contact with protein ligands. It was also demonstrated that epPCR could only rarely target these important residues. This work will enable more efficient protein engineering of enzymes and therapeutic proteins for industry.
