Title: Thermodynamic parameters for salt-induced reversible protein precipitation from automated microscale experiments.
AdditionalInformation: The characterisation of protein precipitation profiles in a high-throughput manner will have significant impact on the ability of engineers to establish rapidly chromatographic and protein refolding processes that avoid unwanted protein precipitation. It will also enable the design and rapid optimisation of protein precipitation processes when used for early stage protein purification. This paper describes the first application of salt-induced protein precipitation in microtitre plates from which thermodynamic parameters could be measured with high accuracy. Such parameters will enable future modelling of chromatographic separations and prediction of precipitation profiles (for separation by fractional precipitation) using protein structure information.

Title: Chromatography modelling to describe protein adsorption at bead level.
AdditionalInformation: Mechanistic modelling can be used to understand the fundamental behaviour of biological species during their chromatographic separation and purification.  This paper describes the first example of modelling these separations at bead level.  The model takes into account the heterogeneity in bead sizes and the spatial variations in the packed bed, thus offering a detailed description of the flow field and mass transfer phenomena.  It provides the basis for in silico experiments to evaluate the design of new resins prior to lengthy experimental programmes to fabricate and test such materials. The work underpins ongoing studies with Pfizer (Dr Ranga Godavarti, Ranga.Godavarti@pfizer.com).

Title: Integration of scale-down experimentation and general rate modelling to predict manufacturing scale chromatographic separations.
AdditionalInformation: We describe an integrated experimental and modelling approach to the design of chromatographic separations for biopharmaceuticals. Ultra scale-down data from a 1mL packed bed column enables parameter estimation for a mechanistic rate based model. The model is then shown to predict accurately scale-up of up to 105 fold. The approach has significant advantages over traditional empirical methods as the model provides a basis for process understanding throughout the unit’s lifecycle, especially important considering the desire to move to a Quality by Design (QbD) paradigm for biopharmaceutical manufacture. The approach is currently being advanced with Pfizer (Dr Ranga Godavarti, Ranga.Godavarti@pfizer.com).

Title: Factors Influencing Antibody Stability at Solid-Liquid Interfaces in a High Shear Environment
AdditionalInformation: The labile nature of therapeutic proteins creates unique processing challenges. Product molecules are subject to many different stresses during manufacture. One such mechanism, damage at solid-liquid interfaces, is an outstanding challenge in our ability to control the molecular environment during manufacture. Using a novel ultra scale-down device designed in-house the effect of solid-liquid interfacial shear on the aggregation of monoclonal antibodies is shown. Study of solid interface variables, such as material of construction and surface roughness, together with liquid interface variables shows a mass transfer controlled mechanism at the interface.  This work helps underpin the USD Technologies impact case study.

Title: Nanofiber adsorbents for high productivity downstream processing.
AdditionalInformation: New adsorbent materials for novel bioseparations are of immediate relevance to the challenges of biopharmaceutical manufacture. They will be critical in delivering next generation molecules (which are frequently more complex and less robust) and for reducing costs. This work describes the design and fabrication of a new cellulosic nanofibre material and its characterisation for bioseparations relative to existing adsorbent materials. The intellectual property arising from the work led to a patent which is the basis for our spin-out company, Puridify (see USD Technologies impact case study). Puridify are now translating this work into a commercial  technology platform.

Title: Characterization and feasibility of a miniaturized stirred tank bioreactor to perform E. coli high cell density fed-batch fermentations.
AdditionalInformation: The need to accelerate fermentation process development has focused much attention onto the design and application of miniaturised bioreactors (MBR). This work demonstrates the feasibility of scaling down industrial high cell density fermentations on the basis of specific power input and indicates the potential of direct scale-up from miniaturised to large scale bioreactors thereby shortening process development times. Furthermore, we show that the combined use of the MBR with ultra scale-down centrifugation provides an efficient way to design and develop bioprocesses with good upstream performance and downstream manufacturability. This work helped to underpin the USD Technologies impact case study.

Title: Whole-cell bio-oxidation of n-dodecane using the alkane hydroxylase system of P-putida GPo1 expressed in E-coil
AdditionalInformation: This is the first demonstration of the in-vivo synthesis of 1-dodecanol in a recombinant microrganism. There is a large market for this fatty alcohol for use in detergents and personal care products. The topic is of great interest since selective oxidation of unactivated C-H groups remains very difficult using conventional chemistry. The study of oxygenase enzymes is thus of high potential impact in the next generation of biocatalytic processes. As part of this research an alkane specific transporter protein has been identified and this discovery contributed to a new TSB project with Synthace Ltd. (Dr Markus Gershater, CSO, m.gershater@synthace.com).

Title: Design and Characterization of a Prototype Enzyme Microreactor: Quantification of Immobilized Transketolase Kinetics
AdditionalInformation: This work developed an immobilised enzyme microreactor and applied it for detailed quantification of enzyme-catalysed reactions useful in pharmaceutical synthesis. Using Michaelis-Menten kinetics we showed that reaction rates and substrate affinity constants were comparable to those in free solution. The ability to determine kinetic parameters at this scale has potential for rapid and parallel evaluation of enzymes and for generation of kinetic models to aid bioconversion process design and reactor selection. This research led to an EngD collaboration with Sigma-Aldrich on synthesis of fine chemicals in a microfluidic reactor and underpins the BiCE impact case study (Dr Roland Wohlgemuth, Roland.Wohlgemuth@sial.com).

Title: Tools for characterizing the whole-cell bio-oxidation of alkanes at microscale
AdditionalInformation: This work reports the first ultra scale-down evaluation of a two-liquid phase bioconversion. It is shown that similar productivities can be obtained in parallel microwell devices to those in a stirred tank reactor. This system was then employed firstly to identify the major bottlenecks and interactions of an alkane bio-oxidation and then to optimize this bioconversion using a statistical experimental design approach. This research provides a generic framework for rapid characterisation and optimisation of multiphase bioconversions supporting the BiCE impact case study. It led to a new EngD collaboration and an EU project with Evonik Industries (Dr Philip Engel, philip.engel@evonik.com).

Title: Mimic of a Large-Scale Diafiltration Process by Using Ultra Scale-Down Rotating Disc Filter
AdditionalInformation: An experimental and modelling ultra scale-down approach to mimic flux and transmission performance during diafiltration operations was established. This is based on a novel rotating disc filter device requiring only 1.5 ml of feed material. The method uses simple dead-end operation to mimic more complex crossflow operations used at larger scales and so overcomes the difficulty of accurately controlling pressure at such small scale. The work, which contributes to the USD Technologies impact case study, has led to further collaboration with Pfizer (Dr Sa Ho, sa.v.ho@pfizer.com).

Title: A logic-reasoning based system to harness bioprocess experimental data and knowledge for design
AdditionalInformation: This multidisciplinary work (Biochemical Engineering and Computer Science) presents a new computational method that uses artificial intelligence to harness bioprocess data and knowledge to assist decision making. Experimental data including terms, e.g. strains, have been standardised and the relationships among the terms have been modelled. Three data mining and analysis functionalities have been created. This enables the method to handle data heterogeneity, incompleteness and inconsistency which are often found in industrial data sets.  Bioprocess development is experimentally intensive and costly. This tool has the potential to utilise the data systematically and to more effectively manage the data and knowledge generated.

Title: Global Sensitivity Analysis for the determination of parameter importance in bio-manufacturing processes
AdditionalInformation: The most important attributes that influence the performance in multi-step biomanufacturing processes and the interactions within and between unit operations have been identified using Global Sensitivity Analysis techniques. The synthetic ligand adsorbent step was consistently the key factor in determining both yield and throughput for the commercial-scale production of a rattlesnake antivenom. The sensitivity indexes for each variable can be quantified and so allow development studies to be concentrated on the relevant design space. Process optimisation can thus be achieved more efficiently. This technique has the potential to significantly reduce experimental efforts

Title: Step change in the efficiency of centrifugation through cell engineering: co-expression of Staphylococcal nuclease to reduce the viscosity of the bioprocess feedstock.
AdditionalInformation: Physical extraction of biopharmaceuticals from microbial cells is challenging due to the presence of large DNA polymers that cause high viscosity when released. Typically this material is removed by addition of costly DNA-digesting enzymes (nucleases). We demonstrated how re-engineered microbial cells, producing a recombinant nuclease to digest large DNA molecules in feedstocks in situ, gave a 75% reduction in viscosity and a 4-fold reduction in the predicted settling area needed during disc stack centrifugation. This work lead to an EPSRC-sponsored Knowledge Transfer Scheme with UCB to translate the findings into industrial practice (Dr Amanda Weiss, Amanda.Weiss@ucb.com).

Title: Growth and productivity impacts of periplasmic nuclease expression in an Escherichia coli Fab' fragment production strain.
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrates for the first time how co-expressing a DNA-digesting enzyme (nuclease) and a biopharmaceutical product in microbial cells impacts their growth and productivity in a commercially relevant bioprocess used by UCB. Nuclease co-expression was previously shown to improve manufacturability and here it was unexpectedly observed to boost cell productivity. These data are significant for companies seeking to reduce costs and increase manufacturability of biopharmaceuticals produced in microbes. An EngD studentship was subsequently established to apply these findings to improve manufacturability of a novel biopharmaceutical with Cogent Ltd (Dr John Ballard, cogentuk@clara.net).

Title: Rapid acidification and alkylation: redox analysis of the MHC class I pathway.
AdditionalInformation: Rapid acidification and alkylation methods can be used to characterise the redox status of oxidoreductase enzymes which are increasingly useful in industrial biocatalysis. In particular they enable quantification of free cysteine residues within an enzyme domain or subunit. This fundamental study provided greater understanding of the usefulness of rapid acidification and alkylation methods for redox analysis of large, complex oligomeric transmembrane proteins. This has lead to more sophisticated analysis of enzymes like transketolase (see BiCE impact case study) in which cysteine residues play an important role in thermo-resistance of stability and activity that might limit its industrial application.

Title: Scale-up of Escherichia coli growth and recombinant protein expression conditions from microwell to laboratory and pilot scale based on matched k(L)a
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided an important first demonstration of the scalability of microwell scale microbial fermentation kinetics to 50L pilot scale (15,000-fold scale translation). Engineering correlations established from rigorous measurements of microwell oxygen mass transfer rates provided a predictive basis for scale-up based upon matched kLa values. Combined with a previous study on microwell fermentation process optimisation, using statistical Design of Experiments (Islam et al, 2007, DOI 10.1021/bp070059a), it provides an engineering framework for high throughput fermentation process development now being adopted by a number of the industrial partners involved in the BiCE impact case study (Dr David Pollard, Merck&Co, david_pollard@merck.com).

Title: Quantification of power consumption and oxygen transfer characteristics of a stirred miniature bioreactor for predictive fermentation scale-up.
AdditionalInformation: This work builds upon the design of a novel 50mL stirred miniature bioreactor for microbial fermentations (Gill et al, 2008, DOI 10.1016/j.bej.2007.09.001). It describes the first engineering correlations for prediction of gassed power input and oxygen transfer in such small scale vessels. These indicated that both kLa and Pug show a stronger dependence on gas superficial velocity than conventional scale bioreactors (>10L). A parallel bioreactor system was designed and commercialised as part of the BiCE impact case study with HEL Group (Mr Jasbir Singh, CEO, jsingh@helgroup.com) and a further EngD established on design of a bioreactor for mammalian cell applications.

Title: An efficient approach to bioconversion kinetic model generation based on automated microscale experimentation integrated with model driven experimental design
AdditionalInformation: Detailed kinetic models underpin successful bioconversion process design and optimisation but can be difficult to establish due to complex enzyme mechanisms and substrate/product inhibition effects. This work established a numerical approach for quantification of 6 independent kinetic parameters from a minimum number of experiments. When combined with automated microscale experiments this led to a 6-fold decrease in the number of experiments required (compared to conventional methods) and a 45-fold decrease in material requirements. This work formed the basis of our IChemE Innovation and Excellence award in Bioprocessing in 2010 and helped underpin the BiCE impact case study.

Title: Microwell Engineering Characterization for Mammalian Cell Culture Process Development
AdditionalInformation: Selection of high producing cell lines normally occurs in static cultures bearing little resemblance to ultimate bioreactor conditions. This work described the first successful suspension culture of mammalian cells in shaken microwells. It used combined modelling (CFD) and experimental approaches to rigorously characterise culture hydrodynamics and gas-liquid mass transfer. A subsequent EngD, using high productivity industrial cell lines, showed microwell cultures enabled more reliable selection of cell lines suited to large scale culture. Our industrial partner, MedImmune, has automated this approach and now routinely uses it for early stage cell culture process development (Dr Ray Field, FieldR@medimmune.com).

Title: Host strain influences on supercoiled plasmid DNA production in Escherichia coli: Implications for efficient design of large-scale processes
AdditionalInformation: The bacterial host influences the amount and quality of plasmid DNA that can be purified. This has important financial and quality implications when plasmids for gene therapy are made on a large scale. We show here for the first time a comprehensive examination and comparison of many E. coli host strains used in preparing plasmid DNA for applications such as gene therapy. A large variation was seen in plasmid quantity and the quality (supercoiled form) of the plasmid. We identified strains that gave large increases in the quantity and quality of the plasmid DNA.

Title: Synthesis of pyridoxamine 5 '-phosphate using an MBA:pyruvate transaminase as biocatalyst
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis B - Enzymatic
AdditionalInformation: Pyridoxamine-5′-phosphate (PMP) the amine and more stable form of vitamin B6 (PLP) is both scientifically and industrially important as a potent antioxidant and vitamin in human and animal nutrition. Currently there are chemical methods to synthesise Vitamin B6 but these are long and have many steps and the final conversion to PMP is difficult. We discovered a new method for PMP synthesis using a transaminase enzyme now used by Sigma Aldrich (Dr Roland Wohlgemuth, Roland.Wohlgemuth@sial.com). This enzymic synthesis is much more cost effective and the transaminase we have developed allows the easy conversion of PLP to PMP.

Title: A 1-step microplate method for assessing the substrate range of l-α-amino acid aminotransferase.
AdditionalInformation: The amino group is important in pharmacological compounds because it gives biological activity. Aminotransferases are enzymes that can be used to introduce amino groups into pharmaceutical compounds; there are many thousands of them but the substrate range cannot be inferred from the protein sequence and it remains an early bottleneck when selecting an enzyme for industrial application. We developed a rapid first round characterisation method applicable to the broad range of aminotransferases which can be carried out in high throughput mode in microplates. This approach helped underpin many of the outputs of the BICE impact case study.

Title: “α,α’-Dihydroxy Ketones and 2-Amino-1,3-diols: Synthetic and Process Strategies using Biocatalysts
AdditionalInformation: Biocatalysts in synthetic chemistry are advantageous as they are stereoselective and allow green conversions. Here we show how developments from the BiCE impact case study can be applied to make chiral amino-diols. To deliver this work we previously established new chemistries and assays (Sehl et al, 2012, DOI 10.1016/j.jbiotec.2011.12.023), identified novel biocatalysts and used protein evolution strategies (Strafford et al, 2012, DOI 10.1016/j.jbiotec.2011.11.017) to achieve rapid and predictive process scale-up. The new synthesis removed 8 steps from a previous chemical process performed by ALMAC reducing reagent and energy usage (Dr Moody,  tom.moody@almacgroup.com).

Title: The hybrid experimental simplex algorithm - An alternative method for 'sweet spot' identification in early bioprocess development: Case studies in ion exchange chromatography
AdditionalInformation: The adaptive simplex algorithm is a widely used optimisation method that does not require the calculation of experimentally expensive derivatives of the objective function. In this work, the simplex method is generalised to account for discrete changes in the independent variables; this generalisation is essential for facile use of the method for data generated during chromatographic separations. This new method was shown, with GE Healthcare, to be more efficient than traditional optimisation methods for adsorption of biologics in microwell experiments (Dr Eva Heldin, eva.heldin@ge.com). The approach could also have value for discrete numerical optimisation in avoiding degeneracy.

Title: Synthesis, crystallization and characterization of diastereomeric salts formed by ephedrine and malic acid in water
AdditionalInformation: Chiral resolution via crystallization is of great importance due to different pharmacological effects of enantiomers and the racemic mixture. The first objective of this EPSRC sponsored collaboration between UCL chemical engineering and UCL chemistry is to screen a family of salt pairs using a common chiral base. The second objective is to provide a dataset of the physicochemical properties of the resulting salt pairs. It is shown that observed differences in stoichiometry and hydrate formation during salt crystallization, leading to differences in physicochemical properties, could have a significant impact on resolution conditions and outcome

Title: An assessment of the use of ultrasound in the particle engineering of micrometer-scale adipic acid crystals
AdditionalInformation: Improved control of crystal product form is important to the manufacture of fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals. As part of our industrial CASE Award project with Pfizer, product particle characteristics of adipic acid obtained in a continuous crystallization process operated under continuous insonation were compared with the products of conventional dry milling techniques. Continuous insonation was found to be effective in producing highly reproducible particles comparable in size with micronization but with increased and more regular surface roughness of potential benefit to pharmaceutical manufacturing. This work led directly to £1M industrial collaboration with GSK and Pfizer sponsored by EPSRC (EP/I031480/1).

Title: Continuous crystallization of adipic acid with ultrasound
AdditionalInformation: Better control of crystallization processes is important to the future competitiveness of the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industry. In this collaborative CASE award project with Pfizer, operation of a novel continuous cooling crystallization system coupled with ultrasound technology to crystallize adipic acid from an aqueous solution was investigated and compared with conventional batchwise crystallization. The results demonstrate that the continuous sonocrystallization process presents the possibility of greatly improved crystallization operation compared with traditional methods with potential for competitive enhancements of pharmaceutical manufacturing methodology. This work led directly to further industrial collaboration with GSK and Pfizer sponsored by the EPSRC.

Title: Racemic Naproxen: A Multidisciplinary Structural and Thermodynamic Comparison with the Enantiopure Form
AdditionalInformation: Chiral resolution via crystallization is of great importance due to different pharmacological effects of enantiomers and the racemic mixture. This EPSRC sponsored collaboration between UCL chemical engineering and UCL chemistry highlights the complementarity of computational modelling in investigating chiral crystallization towards the goal of a fully predictive method for resolving agent design. This combined experimental and theoretical study provides a molecular systems approach to the design of crystal enantiomer separation processes.

Title: Mixing patterns in water plugs during water/ionic liquid segmented flow in microchannels
AdditionalInformation: Extractions are common in process industries but involve harmful organic solvents. Ionic liquids offer a green alternative to organic solvents but their use has been limited by high costs. Intensified, small-scale extractors require reduced amounts of solvent and will help the industrial uptake of ionic liquids. In the work carried out under a RAEng/Leverhulme Trust Fellowship micro-extractors for ionic liquids were characterised with advanced flow diagnostics techniques. The experimental approaches formed an essential part of a successful EPSRC Programme Grant. The microextractors are used in separations relevant to nuclear waste management. This work has led to two collaborative proposals with a number of universities and NNL on nuclear waste processing using innovative technologies and to an invitation to edit a special issue of ChERD.

Title: Investigation on heavy crude-water two phase flow and related flow characteristics
AdditionalInformation: The work is part of our on-going collaboration on two-phase flows with the China University of Petroleum initiated by Chinese government funding. The high toxicity of crude oils prevents their use in laboratory research projects and model oils are used instead. The paper demonstrated large differences in flow properties between crude and models oils. The findings have significant implications on the development of flow assurance models that have in their majority been based on findings from model oils. The work helped to attract industrial support from the oil industry (BP, Chevron) for an EPSRC funded Programme Grant on multiphase flows.

Title: Mass transfer during Taylor flow in microchannels with and without chemical reaction
AdditionalInformation: A rigorous numerical model is developed and validated against experimental data that enables mass transfer rates to be predicted in two-phase microfluidic systems operating under Taylor flow. Microfluidic systems have found wide applications in heat transfer equipment, in chemical analysis and even in production while operation under Taylor flow is common because it can enhance mixing and mass transfer. The paper is crucial for the development of microfluidic systems for mass transfer and reaction applications.

Title: A methodology for predicting phase inversion during liquid-liquid dispersed pipeline flow
AdditionalInformation: As a result of extensive work on dispersed two-phase flows, that has been funded by EPSRC and industry, we developed a methodology for predicting the phase volume fraction where the continuity of an organic-aqueous dispersion changes. The paper has been widely cited and the model suggested was shown to perform better than other approaches suggested in the literature (IJMF, 36, 930, 2010). The methodology has been taken up by Chevron (USA, K. Ioannou), for assessing the dispersion characteristics of different types of oils with water upon the initial fluid characterization for new or existing developments.

Title: Mechanism of photocatalytic water splitting in TiO. Reaction of water with photoholes, importance of charge carrier dynamics, and evidence for four-hole chemistry
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: Solar fuel synthesis, mimicking natural photosynthesis, has the potential to meet our increasing global energy demand. Sponsored by the  EPSRC Solar Hydrogen project, the paper, for the first time, illustrates that O2 evolution is a multielectron process, taking place extremely slow in the artificial photosynthesis process.  The finding  led to an article published in London Press Service  in 2007 (“Will Renewable Hydrogen Solve The Energy Crisis”). The direct evidence of the low energy conversion efficiency drove the new collaboration with the Photocatalytic Center in the National Institute of Material Science, Japan on efficient photocatalyst development.

Title: Coupling oxygen ion conduction to photocatalysis in mesoporous nanorod-like ceria significantly improves photocatalytic efficiency
AdditionalInformation: This paper  employs UV and visible light for the purpose of photo-mineralisation of organic contaminants.   For the first time, it is found that significant enhancement of oxygen ion conduction in the mesoporous ceria due to temperature increasing by IR irradiation, can greatly improve separation of photogenerated electrons and holes excited by UV and visible photons. This demonstrates  the feasibility and effectiveness of integration of thermal energy generated by IR and UV and visible photons in solar spectrum for efficient photocatalytic environmental purification. The success of the study initiated the formal collaboration between UCL and Wuhan University of Technology, China. .

Title: Correlating long-lived photogenerated hole populations with photocurrent densities in hematite water oxidation photoanodes
AdditionalInformation: This paper, based upon our previous work on the mechanism on solar fuel synthesis and joint   international collaborative work on photoholes fingerprint in Fe2O3 photoanode between UCL, Imperial and EPFL (Switzerland), elucidates quantitative correlation between the population of long-lived holes and the reason why the bias is necessary for photon-driven water splitting on these films. This work further strengthened the international collaboration between UCL, EPFL, the Japanese National Institute of Material Science, Imperial to optimise the performance of  Fe2O3 photoanodes for water photolysis.

Title: Facet engineered Ag3PO4 for efficient water photooxidation
AdditionalInformation: Water photolysis for H2 fuel synthesis has the potential to solve both increasing demand of renewable energy and climate change caused by CO2 emissions. In this work, Ag3PO4 crystals with {111} exposing facets have been successfully synthesized by a new facile method. The tetrahedral Ag3PO4 crystals outperform other reported materials for oxygen production from water. The quantum yield reaches ca. 100% at 400 nm and is more than 80% from UV throughout the visible range to 500nm; the highest recorded so far for water photooxidation. This led to a successful international collaboration between UCL and scientists in Japan and Spain.

Title: Towards an understanding of the effects of operating conditions on separation by microfluidic distillation
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first study in the literature which has considered a systematic investigation of the parameters affecting the separation of liquid mixtures at a micro-scale of such small proportions. The work has demonstrated that good separation can be achieved at a very small scale. This finding may have step-changing benefits to the lab-on-a-chip concept and to the bioprocessing industries in terms of quick separation of potentially new drugs during the development stage which will considerably reduce costs and time-to-market

Title: A systematic approach for modeling chromatographic processes - Application to protein purification
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers the challenging issue of protein separation from a feed with a large number of components. Process development for such separations is traditionally based on extensive experimentation which is both costly and time consuming. The use of detailed mathematical models  has the potential for large savings, provided the models and the associated parameters are accurate. This work presents a systematic method which is applicable to a large number of protein separations for the development of such models. This paper lay the foundations for an extensive investigation into chromatography modelling which includes several industrial partners within the bioprocessing industries.

Title: Multi-objective optimisation of batch separation processes
VolumeTitle: Chemical Engineering and Processing: Process Intensification
AdditionalInformation: The performance of batch distillation and hybrid distillation/pervaporation processes depends on a number of different criteria that are often conflicting, e.g. revenue and cost. An effective optimisation of such systems therefore requires the consideration of multi-criteria approaches to accommodate for the multi-objective nature of the problem and to effectively evaluate and optimise the performance in order to meet the objectives. Although the optimisation of design and operation of distillation processes has been attempted before, this work is the first to consider the simultaneous multi-objective optimisation of design and operation of such processes.

Title: Simultaneous optimal synthesis, design and operation of batch and continuous hybrid separation processes
AdditionalInformation: Distillation is the most commonly used technique for separating liquid mixtures within the chemical industries despite being an energy and capital-intensive process. Many mixtures commonly encountered in the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries are, however, difficult to separate by normal distillation. Pervaporation has been hailed as an alternative and recently, hybrid processes have been proposed where the shortcomings of one method are outweighed by the benefits of the other, allowing for significant energy consumption and cost reduction. This work was the first to compare these three alternatives and to clearly demonstrate the considerable savings that are feasible with hybrid operation.

Title: Ozonolysis in Flow Using Capillary Reactors
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates for the first time the design and excellent performance of a microchannel continuous flow reactor based on a commercial platform (Vapourtec) for ozonolysis. The developed system and methodology was utilised at the GSK research centre at Stevenage to synthesise commercial important compounds. It proved to be robust and have better specifications than the commercial O-cube system. Given the utility and convenience of this approach, GSK took the decision to put together an in-house ozonolysis flow set-up based on the UCL approach (contact Mr Rob Wheeler at GSK : Rob.C.Wheeler@gsk.com)

Title: Reaction and Raman spectroscopic studies of alcohol oxidation on gold-palladium catalysts in microstructured reactors
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports research on a collaborative work between chemical engineering and chemistry on the topic of multiphase catalytic microchannel reactors. The reactors were designed, fabricated and utilised at UCL. The paper highlights the unique advantages of microreactors in terms of mass transfer, shows important comparisons with conventional batch reactors and demonstrates that these reactors when coupled with spectroscopic techniques can provide unique information-rich experimentation, not possible with conventional technology. This approach is now expanded through an EPSRC project (EP/J017833/1) to catalyst evaluation for bio-derived platform molecules valorisation,  as well as through the recently funded UK Catalysis Hub.

Title: Development of multistage distillation in a microfluidic chip
AdditionalInformation: Microfluidic separations is an important area in microprocess engineering. Distillation, even though it is an important chemical engineering operation, has had only limited success in the microscale. This paper shows a new approach in microfluidic distillation, utilising heat pipe principles for fluid movement. Microdistillation can have a significant impact in the analysis of small volume or high value components and in the design of microchemical plants. The paper presents the systematic approach we used to solve the various problems encountered. It is one of only a couple of papers internationally that has demonstrated  multistage distillation at an extremely small scale.

Title: Scalable reactor design for pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals production. 3. A novel gas-liquid reactor for catalytic asymmetric transfer hydrogenation with simultaneous acetone stripping
AdditionalInformation: Production of fine chemicals has various pitfalls which can result in worse performance when the scale is increased from lab to manufacture. This paper is the 3rd paper in a series on reactor design avoiding such pitfalls. The first 2 papers identified obstacles in scalability and provided a systematic approach of how to address them. In this paper this methodology resulted to a novel reactor design which is not only in principle easier to scale-up but also shows improved performance (lower reaction time) than the conventional batch reactor. Thus, the approach proposed provides a framework for better, faster reactor design.

Title: Approximate multi-parametric programming based B&B algorithm for MINLPs
AdditionalInformation: Model-based optimal synthesis and design of chemical processes and products results in computationally complex combinatorial optimisation problems involving integer variables (representing the existence or not of process units, molecular group etc.) and continuous variables (representing temperature, viscosity etc.). An algorithm which performed better than the state-of-the-art techniques is presented. The novelty is in mathematically reformulating the integer variables as parameters and then obtaining only an approximate parametric solution of the resulting multi-parametric nonlinear program, to efficiently guide the search of the optimal solution. This work was presented at an international conference and then invited as a full length journal paper.

Title: Novel model reduction techniques for refinery-wide energy optimisation.
AdditionalInformation: The quality of the crude oil is diminishing and the specifications on the quality of the products are becoming stricter A novel mathematical modelling and optimisation technique with potential to address these practical issues is presented. The reduced models developed in this work were used by researchers at Carnegie-Mellon University for refinery planning. This work was part of an EPSRC funded project on energy efficiency. The work was invited as a full length journal paper from a conference oral presentation.

Title: An Artificial Neural Network approximation based decomposition approach for parameter estimation of system of ordinary differential equations
AdditionalInformation: Development of new technologies involves first investigating them in the lab and then scaling them up to the pilot plant and finally further scaling them up to plants at commercial scale. A novel approach with the potential to effectively deal with the difficult issues of nonlinearity and noise associated with the scale-up is presented. This work is cited and discussed in a recent review paper in the computers and mathematics literature. This work forms the basis of the work that will be performed in a recently funded EPSRC project on developing reaction kinetics for biomass conversion.

Title: A mixed-integer programming approach for optimal configuration of artificial neural networks
AdditionalInformation: Artificial Neural Network (ANN) models are ubiquitous in all the domains of chemical engineering with more than 200 reported applications including in the areas of distillation, reaction, crystallization and vapour-liquid equilibrium. ANN can model highly complex and nonlinear systems. However one key bottleneck has been the ad-hoc and hit-and-trial approach for obtaining the appropriate number of nodes and layers in the network so as to avoid under-training and over-training. This paper for the first time presents an optimisation model to overcome this limitation, automates the procedure and reduces user intervention; we used it for refinery-wide optimisation in a separate paper.

Title: Limitations of quadrature-based moment methods for modeling inhomogeneous polydisperse fluidized powders
AdditionalInformation: In this work I discuss important limitations, related to diffusive transport, of new Eulerian models recently proposed in the literature for polydisperse fluid-particle systems, developing two new Eulerian models that overcome these limitations. The models focus on fluidized beds, but can be applied to most multiphase systems. Of relevance to the multiphase flow community, these models should aid the design and analysis of fluid-particle process units. It has led to two collaborations: Cambridge/Chinese Academy of Sciences (analysis of a heat transfer problem of industrial relevance) and Imperial College/Nottingham University (modelling of dense polydisperse reactive fluid-particle systems) for new funding applications.

Title: Direct Quadrature Method of Moments for the Mixing of Inert Polydisperse Fluidized Powders and the Role of Numerical Diffusion
AdditionalInformation: Researchers extensively use models to describe how fluid-solid systems behave. In real systems, particles are polydisperse and their sizes change in time. Models should predict, besides the fluid dynamics, also the evolution of the particle size distribution. This is seldom done. This is one of the first models that, in an Eulerian framework, achieves this. This work, in collaboration with the Politecnico of Turin, should interest the modelling community of multiphase polydisperse dense systems, in particular fluidized beds and crystallizers. It formed the basis for discussion with physicists and mathematicians at Imperial College for new funding applications.

Title: CFD simulations of segregating fluidized bidisperse mixtures of particles differing in size
AdditionalInformation: This work analyses, using an Eulerian multiphase model solved through Computational Fluid Dynamics, the behaviour of segregating fluidized bidisperse mixtures. Aiding to find the correct operating conditions to promote (as in classifiers) or prevent (as in most fluid bed reactors) segregation, this work should assist to design, operate and analyse fluidized beds, particularly tapered fluidized-bed classifiers, where the unit shape is used to promote segregation. In collaboration with the University of Naples, this work has led to a new joint research project with the latter and a collaboration with the University of Genoa.

Title: Apparent viscosity measurements in a homogeneous gas-fluidized bed
AdditionalInformation: In collaboration with l’Aquila University, this work introduces a new rheometer for the investigation and viscosity measurement of uniform fluidized suspensions. Two features are noteworthy. The rheometer can measure the viscosity of fluidized powders at voidage values often used in the operation of real process units. Most rheometers, conversely, only treat aerated or compacted powders, at lower void fractions. Moreover, the rheometer permits to assign and control the shear rate, and is therefore able to reveal and quantify non-Newtonian behaviour. This instrument, through the rheologic data that it provides, can assist in the design of process units that handle granular systems in flow.

Title: Role of strong zeolitic acid sites on hydrocarbon reactions
AdditionalInformation: In this work we used a previously developed own novel method for coke classification to elucidate the effect of zeolite acidity strength on hydrocarbon reactions  and enable development of improved catalysts. The coke classification method distinguishes between soft coke/coke precursors whose structure and composition changes by thermal treatment and hard coke which stays unchanged by thermal treatment. The novelty of the paper is demonstrating the selective poisoning of strong acid sites by hard coke. This way we were able to show that cracking and hydride transfer are catalysed by strong-acid sites, whereas weak acid sites catalyse only double-bond isomerisation.

Title: Deactivation studies during 1-pentene reactions over HUSY zeolite
AdditionalInformation: The novelty of this paper lies on the study of the effect of formation of coke and its individual constituents – based on a novel coke classification method- on individual hydrocarbon reactions. Further novelty is the elucidation of the dynamic character of hydrogen release from coke components undergoing structural changes and its contribution to gas phase reactions. A study of the effect of various process parameters, like temperature and time-on-stream, on deactivation and product distribution should lead to the design of improved catalyst systems.

Title: Monte-Carlo simulations of methane/carbon dioxide and ethane/carbon dioxide mixture adsorption in zeolites and comparison with matrix treatment of statistical mechanical lattice model
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we discuss the development of obtaining multicomponent adsorption isotherms calculated using an exact statistical mechanical lattice model and Monte-Carlo simulations. The key achievements of this approach are twofold. Firstly, once parameterised against the much more expensive Monte-Carlo isotherm a rapid exploration of the adsorption parameter space can be made. Secondly, the lattice model can provide a deep insight into the fundamental adsorption behaviour which otherwise can be difficult to obtain. Hence, the combination of statistical mechanical Monte-Carlo and lattice model studies form a powerful tool.

Title: LAS acid reactive binder: Wettability and adhesion behaviour in detergent granulation
AdditionalInformation: The work reported here showed that detergent manufacture, a major part of Unilever’s worldwide business, is dependent on relative humidity due to the wetting properties of the reactive binder used. It explained problems Unilever experienced in the manufacturing process when carried out in humid countries, such as India. The work received first prize for the Young Researcher of the Year at the UK Particle Technology Forum 2007, and was funded entirely by Unilever, following previous consultancy projects on binder wettability. The student, Sarah Germaná, was employed by Unilever’s rival, Procter & Gamble, as a result of relevant conference presentations.

Title: Kinetic study of accelerated carbonation of municipal solid waste incinerator air pollution control residues for sequestration of flue gas CO2
AdditionalInformation: The aim of this work was to investigate the possibility of sequestering flue gas CO2 in APC residues with a view to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. For the first time a kinetic reaction model was developed. The findings have been used to develop the World’s first commercial facility to treat APC residues and other wastes by carbonation, operated by Carbon8 Aggregates Ltd. This plant is currently producing pellets for use as artificial aggregate and is leading to other commercial projects to treat a variety of waste streams. A patent has been granted in the USA, Canada and Australia .

Title: Low energy synthesis of cement compounds in molten salt
AdditionalInformation: The world cement industry is responsible for 5% of anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions. This paper describes a novel, low-energy route to cement manufacture, the production of cement clinker minerals via molten salt synthesis. Major components of cements were successfully synthesised at the lowest temperatures ever reported. The work utilised electrochemistry to bring the ionic components of the reaction together and has lead to two major EPSRC projects, one on the reaction of pure cement products with Magnox nuclear waste (DIAMOND) and the other on the use of molten salts (and electrochemistry) in the reprocessing of Generation IV spent fuel (REFINE).

Title: Techno-economic performance of energy-from-waste fluidized bed combustion and gasification processes in the UK context.
AdditionalInformation: Sponsored under a grant from the EPSRC Sustainable Urban Environment Programme, this paper showed the potential of using fluidized bed technology for the efficient treatment of urban waste. This work led to collaboration with an engineering consulting company in Rome (Germana & Partners Consulting Engineers) on the design of an industrial-scale fluid-bed combustion plant to treat 250,000 tonnes of waste and produce 34 MWe of electric energy. It  led to collaboration with another company pioneering the use of a plasma arc in biomass gasification in the UK, Advanced Plasma Power, to support the scale-up of their pilot waste gasification plant

Title: Modelling the impact of stream impurities on ductile fractures in CO2 pipelines
AdditionalInformation: Pressurised pipelines are considered to be the most practical method for transporting captured CO2 from fossil fuel power plants for subsequent storage. Funded by the EPSRC MATTRAN project, this work for the first time presents the development and validation of a fully coupled fluid-structure model for accurately predicting the material toughness required in order to avoid propagating ductile fractures in CO2 pipelines. The above model has been extensively employed by the authors to assist National Grid to determine the suitability of the current stock of UK natural gas pipelines for transporting CO2 for offshore storage pipelines.

Title: When does a vessel become a pipe?
AdditionalInformation: Central to the safety assessment of pressurised pipelines transporting hazardous materials is the prediction of the transient discharge rate in the event of pipeline failure.  This paper addresses the precise conditions under which the transient outflow from a punctured pipeline may be modelled as that emanating from a vessel with the result of orders of magnitude reduction in the computational run time.  This finding has enabled the authors to assist  Petrobras in Brazil in the design of its ultra-high pressure sub-sea pipelines.

Title: Courant, Friedrichs and Lewy (CFL) impact on numerical convergence of highly transient flows
AdditionalInformation: Central to the safety assessment of pressurised pipelines is the prediction of the transient discharge rate in the event of pipeline rupture. Such data determines minimum safe distances to populated areas and emergency response planning. This paper addresses the critically important issue regarding the appropriate size of the discretisation elements whilst ensuring stability and practical computational workloads for the numerical simulation of such flows. This finding along with those presented in the nominated publications 2 and 3 has enabled the authors to assist National Grid to determine the suitability of the current stock of UK natural gas pipelines.

Title: On the modelling of valve point loadings for power electricity dispatch
AdditionalInformation: This paper highlights a feature of the models used by the power dispatch modelling community which addresses the effect of valve openings on the performance of electricity generators.  The model used for many of the case studies in the literature exhibits behaviour that is not realistic.  The model parameters were derived from actual performance data.  However, it appears that nobody has previously looked at the behaviour of the models with the actual parameter values derived.  In this paper, we describe the unrealistic behaviour and attempt to motivate the community to address this deficiency.

Title: A multi-objective optimisation model for a general polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell system
AdditionalInformation: The design of fuel cells typically needs to attempt to satisfy conflicting objectives, such as minimising the size of the equipment while maximising the efficiency.  This paper presents a multi-objective optimisation model for investigation of the trade offs between conflicting objectives.  The results show that there can be an easily identified subset of the design space where both objectives can be reasonably satisfied.   This work provides the basis for more rigorous design by practitioners that are not optimisation experts and should prove to be a useful reference article for future work in this area.

Title: A rewriting grammar for heat exchanger network structure evolution with stream splitting
AdditionalInformation: Heat exchanger network synthesis is a problem that has long been a focus of research. However, the vast majority of tools have not addressed the complexity of design introduced by stream splitting in the design of the actual network of heat exchangers.   The resulting software tool, part of the Jacaranda system for automated process design, has been made available.  As a result of this paper, I was invited to be on the organising committee of the 2011 Congress of Evolutionary Computation (CEC2011) and an invited speaker at the CREST Open Workshop (COW13).

Title: A multi-objective genetic algorithm for the design of pressure swing adsorption
AdditionalInformation: The design of separation processes based on pressure swing adsorption is becoming increasingly important due to the need to retrofit CO_2 capture technologies on existing power plants.  However, PSA process inherently have conflicting performance indicators: increasing the purity of the desired product will usually lead to a reduction in the recovery of this product.  This paper presents a robust procedure able to identify the optimum operating conditions that achieve the best compromise between the objectives.  This work underpinned the proposed work in a subsequently funded EPSRC project on integrated CO_2 capture for power plants, EP/G062129/1.

Title: Effect of clamping pressure on ohmic resistance and compression of gas diffusion layers for polymer electrolyte fuel cells
AdditionalInformation: This work examines the mechanical properties of polymer electrolyte fuel cells during operation.  Understanding expansion and contraction of fuel cells has allowed the Flexi-Planar Stack to be developed that allows fuel cells to be incorporated within printed circuit boards.  This led to us winning the Carbon Trust Polymer Fuel Cell Challenge (£500k) and proof-of-concept funding (£50k).  We are currently spinning out a new company with further investment from the Carbon Trust of £500k.  This work was highlighted in The Engineer, “Scientists develop new method of making hydrogen fuel cells” March 2012 and various Carbon Trust press releases.

Title: Stripping voltammetry using sequential standard addition calibration with the analytes themselves acting as internal standards
AdditionalInformation: A novel two-step standard addition calibration procedure for stripping voltammetry, whereby the analytes under investigation act as internal standards for each other, is described. In this way, the benefits of an internal standard for improving precision are obtained, without the requirement to add internal standard solutions. The new procedure substantially improves precision and accuracy compared to traditional standard addition without internal standardisation. This procedure is now been adopted and routinely used at the National Physical Laboratory (UK) for analysing a wide range of samples and is starting to be adopted internationally at other leading National Measurement Offices.

Title: Application of a GaPO4 Crystal Microbalance for the Detection of Coke Formation in High-Temperature Reactors and Solid Oxide Fuel Cells
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, a piezoelectric crystal microbalance sensor based on gallium orthophosphate has been shown to monitor mass deposition at temperatures up to 900 °C, with the ability to detect coke formation on a Ni-modified crystal demonstrated. The work represents a new class of analytical technique capable of studying surface reactions at high temperatures. This is now being funded by the NPL and options for commercialising it are being explored. This work has led to the invited plenary lecture at Electrochem 2011, the UK’s premier electrochemistry conference.

Title: What Happens Inside a Fuel Cell? Developing an Experimental Functional Map of Fuel Cell Performance
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper describes research led by Brett spanning 10 years in the area of fuel cell diagnostics. This resulted in 12 papers and over 400 citations, making it one of the leading bodies of work in the world.  The work led to Brett winning the DeNora Prize (International Society of Electrochemistry), many invited plenary and keynotes (Electrochem 2010, ISE 2010), funding (EP/G060991/1, EP/J001007/1) and industrial support (Intelligent Energy, NPL).  CO poisoning detection described in the paper has facilitated catalyst discovery in Brett's lab(3 patents) and formation of the spin-out, Amalyst, in 2012.

Title: The measurement of powder flow properties with a mechanically stirred aerated bed
AdditionalInformation: This paper stems from original work in particle technology sponsored by EPSRC-BP Chemicals on the rheology of fine aerated powders (gb.smith@btinternet.com); work in collaboration with the University of Salerno-Italy. Previous work (two papers) presented a novel methodology for testing powder flow by linking measurements in a mechanically stirred aerated bed (UCL) with data from shear testers (Salerno). We present here an innovative model to predict powder flow properties at low consolidation levels. This work led to obtain funding from Dow Corning (marc.thibaut@dowcorning.com) for a PhD Studentship to study the fluidization of industrial cohesive powders linked with rheological studies.

Title: Thermodynamic modelling and evaluation of a two-stage thermal process for waste gasification
AdditionalInformation: Sponsored through an Impact Studentship with Advanced Plasma Power (APP) (chris.chapman@app-uk.com), this work assists the development of a two stage fluid bed energy form waste gasification – plasma converter technology. This paper demonstrates that the two-stage process significantly improves gas yield and carbon conversion efficiency whilst maintaining high energy performances when compared to a single stage process. The analysis is supported by experimental data from the APP two-stage demonstration plant in Swindon. This work led to consolidate the collaboration with APP and to win funding from ETI to design the first integrated two-stage plant in UK between 5MW and 20MW.

Title: Optimal production allocation and distribution supply chain networks
AdditionalInformation: A mathematical programming framework for the design and operation of global supply chain networks in the process industry with focus on financial and tactical operational issues within a company while accounting for production balancing among sites. The proposed optimisation framework facilitates decision-making related to production allocation, site production capacity, purchase of raw materials and network configuration while considering financial aspects (e.g. exchange rates, duties) and supply chain costs. This work has resulted in an industrial project (Syngenta) that addressed capacity planning in agrochemical supply chains.

Title: Optimal synthesis of chromatographic trains for downstream protein processing.
AdditionalInformation: In the biopharmaceutical sector, chromatography is the most widely used unit operation for protein purification, which is a major production cost. This paper addresses the need for systematic methodologies to design optimum downstream protein purification sequences from a number of alternative chromatographic steps at minimum cost while satisfying stringent purity requirements. Such decision tools can greatly facilitate the selection of new candidate drugs by early analysis and development of purification trains. This work was undertaken in collaboration with Biochem. Eng. (UCL), and culminated in a successful bid (EP/I033270/1) to establish the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Emergent Macromolecular Therapies.

Title: A mixed integer optimisation approach for integrated water resources management
AdditionalInformation: A systems approach for sustainable exploitation of water resources using mathematical programming. Such systems-based, decision-making approaches are of crucial importance to address the growing problem of water shortage globally. Based on water demands and wastewater production as well as geographic characteristics of each region, the proposed optimisation framework determines optimal locations of desalination, wastewater treatment and reclamation plants together with water conveyance infrastructure at minimum annualised total cost.  This framework is particularly suitable for water deficient areas as already demonstrated through application to real case studies mainly in Greek islands.

Title: An optimisation framework for a hybrid first/second generation bioethanol supply chain
AdditionalInformation: This paper studies hybrid first/second generation biofuel supply chains with focus on dedicated energy crops such as miscanthus and SRC (suitable for UK set-aside land) in addition to wheat and wheat straw to address environmental issues such as global warming, air quality and resource depletion.  The impacts of technological learning on the economic and environmental performance of the supply chain are also investigated. Extension of the above work to account for uncertainty issues has been supported from an EPSRC-funded project (EP/J01074X/1) establishing the basis for a new collaboration with the group of Prof Maravelias (University of Wisconsin).

Title: A methodology for global-sensitivity analysis of time-dependent outputs in systems biology modelling
VolumeTitle: Journal of The Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: This sophisticated methodology (only very recently published) will be key for exploring sensitivity and accuracy in complex physiological models to build towards use of complex quantitative phenomenological models in medicine.  The method will be used to identify weaknesses that require more accurate data necessary if they are to be used in a clinical setting.    The paper has inspired further work with clinical colleagues (in liver disease) identifying more accurate parameter values with a view to their use in diagnosis of liver disease.

Title: A model of localised Rac1 activation in endothelial cells due to fluid flow.
AdditionalInformation: This documents a new research area for Chemical Engineering in collaboration with biochemists to clarify the causes of atherosclerosis. The approach is interdiscplinary linking the forces caused by blood flow over the cells, mechanical deformation of the cellular structure, and consequent polymerisation affecting the chemical pathways in the cell.  The contribution shows how process systems engineering approaches help clarify complex biological problems.  It has also led to work of others experimentally exploring the main biological hypothesis underlying the model of the response of Rac1 to shear stress.  A full understanding will lead to better treatments for atherosclerosis

Title: A composite computational model of liver glucose homeostasis. I. Building the composite model.
AdditionalInformation: The computational system which underpins the approach was taken up on a trial basis by the Merck company in New Jersey as a trial for an in house model curation system.  The work led to an invitation to give the plenary lecture on ‘the Role of Computer Aided Process Engineering in Physiology and Clinical Medicine’ at the 19th European Symposium on Computer Aided Process Engineering.  The work led to an invitation  from the Ministerial Industry Scientific Group of the UK Department of Health’s Medicine and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency to address the agency on the use of Systems Biology in the approval of drugs related to liver disease and other conditions.

Title: Process design in SISO systems with input multiplicity using bifurcation analysis and optimisation
AdditionalInformation: The paper documents an important new methodology for ensuring safe designs for potentially unstable process systems.  The paper has been referred to in a recent AIChEJ state of the art review of controllability analysis.

Title: Characterization of the 3-dimensional microstructure of a graphite negative electrode from a Li-ion battery
AdditionalInformation: In order to effectively engineer batteries for high performance applications, it is essential to understand the functional materials on which these electrochemical devices are based. This paper was a world first, presenting the application of high resolution X-ray tomography to explore the microstructure of Li-ion batteries and its relationship to cell performance. Published with General Motors, this paper has led to a formalised funded collaboration with GM and has also initiated a number of collaborations in industry and academia in the UK, Germany and USA. We have also made this data set available to the user community for standardisation

Title: 3D reconstruction of SOFC anodes using a focused ion beam lift-out technique
AdditionalInformation: This paper was amongst the first to utilize new focused ion beam techniques to characterise SOFC electrodes in 3D and the first to provide detailed experimental information on the techniques for data collection. As a result of this paper I have been invited to participate in an international working group (organised Riso-DTU, Denmark) on SOFC characterisation. It is the most cited paper from the journal Chemical Engineering Science for 2009/10 and was a major contributing factor to further funding in this area in the Supergen Fuel Cells Phase 2.

Title: Analysis of triple phase contact in Ni-YSZ microstructures using non-destructive X-ray tomography with synchrotron radiation
AdditionalInformation: The new field of X-ray nano computed tomography provides a step change in achievable resolution – facilitating non-destructive CT with sub-50nm resolution. The 32-ID beamline at the Advance Photon Source (Argonne, USA) was amongst the first beamlines in the world to install this capacity. As an early user of this new facility, this paper was amongst the first published by the user community using data from the new beamline and demonstrates proof-of-concept work to apply x-ray absorption spectroscopy imaging to SOFC microstructures – a technique that has been subsequently replicated by a number of groups in USA, China and France.

Title: Microstructural analysis of a solid oxide fuel cell anode using focused ion beam techniques coupled with electrochemical simulation
AdditionalInformation: Tomography techniques for SOFC using focused ion beams provide detailed microstructural information, allowing evaluation and comparison of electrodes, however they are perhaps most powerful when utilised in tandem with simulation tools. This paper details the integration of significant developments in tomography and modelling tools to explore microscopic phenomena occurring in SOFC electrodes in silico – amongst the first papers to effectively combine these tools, it shows the potential to combine macroscopic and microscopic characterisation methods and to validate computer simulations. Based on this and other publications in this area – I have published an invited review paper in this field.

Title: Multiscale modeling reveals poisoning mechanisms of MgO-supported Au clusters in CO oxidation
AdditionalInformation: We combined for the first time density functional theory calculations with the graph-theoretical kinetic Monte Carlo framework to explain the puzzling inactivity of MgO-supported Au6 toward the CO oxidation reaction. This effort is part of a larger research thrust aiming at bridging the “materials-gap” in computational catalysis. This challenge lies in the fact that real catalysts rarely behave like the bulk structures typically used to model them. We addressed the challenge by explicitly taking into account the structure and charge states of supported Au6. This is a transformative step towards the accurate modelling of real catalytic structures.

Title: A pH-sensitive laser-induced fluorescence technique to monitor mass transfer in multiphase flows in microfluidic devices
AdditionalInformation: Despite their apparent advantages, microsystems need to be scaled-up to reach industrially relevant production levels. To perform this step predictably detailed knowledge about the mass and heat transfer mechanisms on different length scales is needed. This work presents for the first time a non-invasive and high-resolution method to quantify interfacial mass transfer in gas-liquid flows on the micro-scale. This allowed identifying the physical mass transfer mechanisms and relating them to the individual reactor design and to the performance on larger scales. This knowledge found application within the Novartis-MIT Center for Continuous Manufacturing (Dr. Berthold Schenkel, Novartis Basel).

Title: A nature-inspired approach to reactor and catalysis engineering
AdditionalInformation: This invited “perspective” article appeared in Elsevier’s Current Opinion.  Thanks to its immediate response, I became member of the advisory board. The paper outlines the philosophy of nature-inspired chemical engineering, taking a mechanistic basis to guide innovative, computationally assisted, rational design of catalysts and reactors and leads to an entirely new way of thinking about process intensification and design of resource efficient systems. The article led to invited keynotes (ISCRE22 and AIChE, 2012), the RSC Catalysis Science & Technology Award Lecture (2012), and several invited talks in industry and academia. The approach is utilized in the EPSRC Catalysis Hub (co-I).

Title: Effects of surface curvature and surface chemistry on the structure and activity of proteins adsorbed in nanopores
AdditionalInformation: This article demonstrates, for the first time, how stability and activity of enzymes in aqueous medium can be increased multiple-fold by confinement in oppositely charged nanopores. Given the importance of enzymes in numerous applications and physiology, this is a game-changing fundamental discovery. This paper on “super fit enzymes” was highlighted by the June 2011 issue of Materials Today. It was invited by PCCP for a Special Issue on Materials Innovation, and prompted invitations for two other publications. The paper also led to numerous invitations for keynote and plenary presentations at international conferences (EMCC-7, NanoFormulation 2012, Sino-US Congress on Chemical Engineering).

Title: Nature-inspired energy-and material-efficient design of a polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell
AdditionalInformation:
This article proposes a PEM fuel cell with an innovative, lung-inspired design that promises to overcome, in a disruptive manner, practical issues that have limited the broader implementation of fuel cell technology.  Significant decreases in amounts of expensive catalyst, facilitated water management, reduced transport limitations, higher stability, and easier scale-up can all be realized. 
The paper was highlighted by the New Scientist, Green Car Congress, and many online forums. It was the basis for funding from the U.S. NSF IGERT program. The work has been presented at invited lectures in Norway, Turkey (EMCC-6, 2010), etc. A prototype is under development.

Title: Non-equilibrium dynamics of block copolymer micelles in solution: Recent insights and open questions
AdditionalInformation: This invited highlight paper was chosen for the cover of Soft Matter, and discusses original research (in the context of other findings in the literature) on the thermodynamics and kinetics of the transformation of block copolymer micelles from spherical to cylindrical/caterpillar-like. Fundamental new insights, and gaps in our understanding are discussed, inspiring new research: the paper was top-10 most accessed when it appeared. The work has important implications for applications that use block copolymers for drag reduction, nanomaterials synthesis (micellar templating), and therapeutics. The article helped my former PhD student, Antonia Denkova, to become Lecturer at TU Delft.

Title: Hierarchical composites reinforced with robust short sisal fibre preforms utilising bacterial cellulose as binder
AdditionalInformation: This work on the manufacturing of sustainable composite materialswas was funded by EPSRC . In collaboration with FZMB GmbH and Cytec Engineered Materials (kingsley.ho@cytec.com), we demonstrated that bacterial cellulose can be used to produce high performance hierarchical composite. UK and US patents had been filed for this technology (e.kirkby@imperial.ac.uk). Numerous industries including UPM Finland (antti.laukkanen@upm.com) and Elmira Ltd (enrico@ctsusa.us) are interested in the potential of this technology for use in expanding the potential of nanocellulose in composite industries. This work has also led to an EPSRC follow-on fund for a 12-month post-doctoral project on expanding the potential of this technology

Title: De novo synthesis of a metal–organic framework material featuring ultrahigh surface area and gas storage capacities
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, a novel Metal-Organic Framework material was first computationally designed for a specific application (increased gas storage), and then synthesized in the lab. As a result we reported the highest H2 uptake recorded by any material. This study set an example and led further research in the computationally aided rational design of new materials. Due to its significance, Nature Chemistry invited Prof. Shimizu (University of Calgary) to write an opinion article about our paper. This study involved a collaboration with chemical engineers and chemists at Northwestern University, and was funded by the US Department of Energy.

Title: Ultrahigh Porosity in Metal-Organic Frameworks
AdditionalInformation: In this collaborative effort with chemical engineers and chemists at the University of California (Los Angeles) and Northwestern University, new ultra porous and very high surface area Metal-Organic Framework (MOFs) materials were developed, one of which showed, at the time of the publication, the highest specific surface area ever recorded among all types of materials. The MOF materials reported in this paper showed exceptionally high porosities and gas (hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide) uptake capacities, such that world records for both porosity and carbon dioxide storage capacity were reported. This study was sponsored by the US Department of Energy.

Title:
Enhanced CO
Adsorption in Metal-Organic Frameworks via Occupation of Open-Metal Sites by Coordinated Water Molecules
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we reported an unexpected discovery where a small amount of preadsorbed water increased the amount of CO2 capture in a Metal-Organic Framework material.  This phenomenon was first discovered by computational methods and then later verified by experiments. Following our study other researchers from different parts of the world reported similar observations in other materials. The discovery was patented by UOP LLC, A Honeywell Company (US Patent No: 8,227,375). This study was a collaboration between academia (Northwestern University) and industry (UOP LLC, Des Plaines, IL, USA) with funding from US Department of Energy.

Title: Screening of Metal−Organic Frameworks for Carbon Dioxide Capture from Flue Gas Using a Combined Experimental and Modeling Approach
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: By combining experiments and molecular modelling, this work laid the groundwork for future studies in which computational methods will be used as screening tools in the design of nanoporous materials for CO2 capture. Furthermore, it showed that CO2 capture capacity at low pressure directly correlated with the heat of adsorption, and having a high density of open metal sites was key to provide increased heats of adsorption. This study was a collaboration between several universities (Northwestern University, University of Edinburgh, University of Michigan, Vanderbilt University) and industry (UOP LLC, Des Plaines, IL, USA) with funding from US Department of Energy.

Title: Liquid water can slip on a hydrophilic surface.
VolumeTitle: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by the US National Science Foundation (award # CBET-0853657) and by the US Department of Energy (award # DE-SC0001902). In this manuscript we presented computer simulation results that have the potential of changing our understanding regarding water flow on surfaces or through membranes. As stated in the title, we found that water can slip on surfaces that it wets, which contradicts conventional wisdom. Our results have provided interpretation for unexpected experimental observations, subsequently reported by others (e.g., PNAS USA 109, 2012, 7187; Nanoscale 4, 2012, 2621).

Title: SDS surfactants on carbon nanotubes: aggregate morphology.
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by the US Department of Energy (award # FG02-06ER64239). This was the first of a series of manuscripts published by Striolo on the morphology of surfactant aggregates adsorbed on carbon nanotubes. Two follow up manuscripts were highlighted on journal covers (Journal of Physical Chemistry C, in 2011, and Soft Matter, in 2013). The 2009 manuscript settled the literature argument on whether surfactant aggregates on nanotubes were ordered or disordered. Many continued our work to determine the surfactant features needed for stabilizing aqueous carbon nanotubes dispersions (see, e.g., the subsequent publications of Prof. Blankschtein, from MIT).

Title: Hydration structure at the α-AlO (0001) surface: Insights from experimental atomic force spectroscopic data and atomistic molecular dynamics simulations
AdditionalInformation: This work was supported by the US Department of Energy (awards # DE-SC0001902 and DE-AC02-05CH11231). This manuscript represents the successful conclusion of ~ 5 years of research on the structure of water at contact with solid surfaces. Striolo, as well as many others, conducted numerous computer simulation studies on this subject. In the present manuscript we demonstrated a satisfactory agreement between computer predictions and experimental data (both those we obtained by a collaboration with LBNL, and those reported by others in the literature). The agreement opens up numerous research directions in which computer simulations can guide technological advances.

Title: Molecular design of stable graphene nanosheets dispersions.
AdditionalInformation: In this manuscript we were the first simulation group to investigate possible methods to stabilise dispersions containing graphene sheets. It was found that functionalization of the graphene edges could be useful, provided that branched groups were used. Subsequent experimental data obtained on small graphene sheets (similar to those simulated by us) showed that the techniques we proposed were indeed appropriate. The stabilisation of graphene sheets in various organic solvents can enable many practical applications for this fascinating material.

Title: Mathematical Modelling of Protein Precipitation Based on the Phase Equilibrium for an Antibody Fragment from E. coli Lysis
AdditionalInformation: Precipitation is an important operation in biopharmaceutical purification yet the mechanism of protein precipitation in multi-component solutions is not well understood. Existing models lack fundamental understanding of the process. Here a new model is developed based on how the protein solubility changes during the process. The model structure is generic and robust and adequately reflects the non-linearity of protein precipitation kinetics. It thus provides new fundamental insights to protein precipitation in multi-component, complex protein solutions and can be applied to industrial processes to improve process design, model-based optimisation and process control.

Title: CO2 pipelines material and safety considerations
VolumeTitle: HAZARDS XXI: PROCESS SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION
AdditionalInformation: Awarded the IChemE Frank Lees  Medal for the most meritorious IChemE publication in safety and loss prevention, this paper co-authored with the HSE,  for the first time presents a comprehensive account of challenges associated with the safe and economical pipeline transportation of CO2 captured from fossil fuel power plants for subsequent geological sequestration.
