This work has led to a number of investigative projects targeting the issues involved funded by the EPSRC (MATTRAN), National Grid (COOLTRANS), and two EC FP7 projects coordinated by the main author (HM) involving collaboration between researchers and industry from several European countries, Canada, China and USA.

Title: Investigation of bending fatigue strength limit of alloy steel gear teeth
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: A prediction of fatigue life of metal gear teeth in mechanical transmission systems is always a challenge, as available fatigue test data often differ from analytical predictions. This paper, through a thorough examination of current predictive methods, developed a statistical analysis using a three-parameter Weibull distribution with experimentally justified percentages for reliability and confidence. An excellent correlation between experimental data and predicted results demonstrated the usefulness of this method. The work has led to an international collaboration with Beijing University of Science and Technology. For confirmation: Prof I. Ashcroft, Dept of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Nottingham. Ian.Ashcroft@nottingham.ac.uk.

Title: Evaluating damage in smart composite laminates using embedded EFPI strain sensors
AdditionalInformation: A significant challenge to the development of an effective non-intrusive structural health monitoring for aerospace applications is to use internally embedded fibre optic strain sensors to detect, monitor and evaluate the initiation and propagation of structural delamination. Through a comprehensive investigation involving sensor survivability, manufacturing, design and faithfulness of interior sensing signals, this paper devised a stiffness-based scheme for estimating the size of the detected delamination. For confirmation: Prof S. Ogin, Dept of Mechanical Engineering Sciences, University of Surrey. s.ogin@surrey.ac.uk.

Title: Design, manufacture and evaluation of bending behaviour of composite beams embedded with SMA wires
AdditionalInformation: The development of smart adaptive structural technology often requires the use of embeddable actuators, creating conflicting demands. The holy grail of achieving a maximised synergistic effect to mitigate conflicts is to establish an understood mechanism between actuator and shape change throughout design, manufacturing and performance evaluation. This paper, expanded from an invited keynote at the 1st International Conference on Smart and Nano Materials in Engineering, was the first to look at these issues and followed by a seminar given at Beijing University of Science and Technology. For confirmation: Prof M. Gilchrist, Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, University College Dublin, Ireland. Michael.Gilchrist@ucd.ie

Title: Impact damage and energy-absorbing characteristics and residual in-plane compressive strength of honeycomb sandwich panels
VolumeTitle: Journal of Sandwich Structures and Materials
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses a significant scientific and technological issue about the retainability of in-plane compressive strength of impact-damaged composite structures. A novel approach developed via artificial delamination embedment and impact and quasi-static testing verifications showed systematically that the strength reduction mechanisms could be ascertained only when baseline and damaged panels were ensured to fail similarly and were assessed using transverse strains. The work led to an invitation by the NPL for participating in a round robin exercise in an investigation of compression-after-impact strength. For confirmation: Dr G. Sims, NPL, graham.sims@npl.co.uk

Title: The Use of Perforated Damping Liners in Aero Gas Turbine Combustion Systems
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the application of damping technology within a gas turbine engine environment, and the concepts/methods outlined have been used to design damping systems for various engine demonstrator programmes. The work has also given rise to several patent applications (e.g. EP1006812). "The design methodologies described in this paper have been incorporated within Rolls-Royce and used within demonstrator engines and, if required, would be used within future Rolls-Royce products" John Moran, Rolls-Royce Corporate Specialist (Combustion).

Title: Aerodynamic performance of a coolant flow off-take downstream of an OGV
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the fundamental aerodynamics and design criteria for an off-take located in close proximity to an outlet guide vane. It highlights the importance of component interactions and describes techniques to maximise diffusion of the off-take flow. The knowledge gained was subsequently used to design a cooling flow off-take for an intercooled aero engine within the NEWAC (http://www.newac.eu/) integrated EU programme. The same technology is currently being used to design a cooled cooling air system within the EU project IMPACT_AE (http://www.impact-ae.eu/)

Title: The Impact of Compressor Exit conditions on Fuel injector Flows
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes how fuel injector flow field uniformity degrades with increasing airflow, thereby compromising the performance of future, low emission, lean burn aero-engines. Understanding the fundamental aerodynamics has enabled several alternative future concepts to be developed which will be tested within the ‘Building UK leadership in Aerodynamics’ Novel Aerodynamic Design and Integration Technologies TSB collaborative programme. "The need to investigate new and novel solutions is essential for us to keep ahead of the competition. This work has improved current understanding and provided knowledge based solutions worthy of further investigation” Ken Young, Rolls-Royce Chief of R&T (Combustion and Casings).

Title: Acoustic Damping of a Helmholtz Resonator with an Oscillating Volume
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the means of extending the effective performance of Helmholtz resonators by use of a unique oscillating volume. The work was conducted in collaboration with Cambridge University (Engineering Department) who also introduced active control to this concept. The work is part of a suite of studies into resonator performance and their use for the potential suppression of combustion instabilities and the problems associated with such an application which has led to several patents (e.g EP1669670, US7448215, EP1862739, US7857094)

Title: Creep damage study at powercycling of lead-free surface mount device
AdditionalInformation: This was one of the first papers to address power cycling damage in lead free solders. This is an important aspect of electronic solder joint reliability that has so far not received much attention, but will gain increasing importance with the impending need for industry to eliminate lead from the solders used in those safety critical sectors that currently have an exemption from the RoHS directive, particularly aerospace. The paper has received citations from a number of international authors e.g. at the University of Queensland and in Chinese universities. The research student entered industrial employment with Siemens immediately after graduating.

Title: The effect of droplet ejection frequency on the dimensions of inkjet-etched micro-via holes in poly4(-vinyl phenol) thin films
AdditionalInformation: The authors systematically presented the effect of drop ejection frequency on the size of inkjet etched via holes for the first time and the concept of a threshold frequency below which no hole enlargement occurs, was identified and demonstrated experimentally. The understanding generated by this work will help industry to successfully implement low cost printed/plastic electronics products, a technology in which the UK has great expertise and described by the BIS report Plastic Electronics: A UK strategy for success as “a sector in which Britain has huge potential for leadership, and with it employment and economic growth.”

Title: The impact of substrate temperature on the size and aspect ratio of inkjet-dissolved via holes in thin poly(4-vinyl phenol) dielectric layers
AdditionalInformation: In this paper the authors identified for the first time how temperature effects the relationship between solvent etched via hole size and the number of solvent drops dispensed. The understanding generated by this work will help industry to successfully implement low cost printed/plastic electronics products, a technology in which the UK has great expertise and described by the BIS report Plastic Electronics: A UK strategy for success as “a sector in which Britain has huge potential for leadership, and with it employment and economic growth.”

Title: Mechanical characterization of individual Ni/Au coated microsize polymer particles
AdditionalInformation: This seminal study was the genesis of significant on-going collaborative research into metallised polymer particles with the Universities of Trondheim (Professor Zhiliang Zhang - zhiliang.zhang@ntnu.no) and Vestfold (Professor Knut Aasmundtveit - Knut.Aasmundtveit@hive.no) in Norway, and extensive industrial collaboration e.g. with Conpart AS, Norway (CTO, Dr Helge Kristiansen Helge@conpart.no) via e.g. EPSRC IeMRC Grant References SP/09/01/04 and SP/02/0?/10, Mosaic AS funded LU project (J12505) and a current IeMRC funded PhD project (J13288). PhD researcher is now at Imperial contributing to packaging of interplanetary exploration experiments. The paper has received at least 8 citations e.g.by researchers at NUST, Norway and KAIST, Korea.

Title: Energy economy analysis of the G-Wiz: a two-year case study based on two vehicles
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART D-JOURNAL OF AUTOMOBILE ENGINEERING
AdditionalInformation: This paper provided actual data from the operation of two battery electric vehicles on public roads over a period of two years. Analysis showed that for this particular type of vehicle, the relation between drop in state of charge of the battery pack and distance travelled depended on previous usage and led the introduction of a novel “usage factor”. The latter was most affected by usage over the previous few days, with decreasing effect further into the past. The usage factor was correlated with the depth of discharge, recharge energy of the vehicle and calculated range.

Title: Conductive materials for polymeric bipolar plates: Electrical, thermal and mechanical properties of polyethylenecarbon black/graphite/magnetite blends
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper examined the potential of some new materials for bi-polar plates for fuel cells. Polyethylene composites containing carbon black, graphite and magnetite were made using both injection moulding and compression moulding and tested for their electrical and thermal conductivities and mechanical properties. The carbon black composites exhibited better electrical conductivity than the other fillers. Injection moulding produced composites with more material stability and greater mechanical strength than compression moulding although the latter produced composites with higher thermal conductivities. The mechanical properties of the materials were acceptable, but further work is needed to improve the electrical conductivity.

Title: Identifying the early adopters of alternative fuel vehicles: A case study of Birmingham, United Kingdom
VolumeTitle: Transportation Research Part A: Policy and Practice
AdditionalInformation: This paper studied what motivates people to purchase alternative fuelled vehicles. Cluster analysis was applied to census data to identify potential alternative fuel vehicle drivers in Birmingham, UK. Almost 60% of areas with a high concentration of individuals who most closely fitted the profile of an alternative fuel vehicle driver were found to be located across four wards furthest from Birmingham city centre. The paper demonstrated how Census data can be used in the initial stages of identifying potential early adopters of alternative fuelled vehicles. It has already led to Birmingham City Council funding further work.

Title: Polyethylene-carbon material for polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell bipolar plates
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications
AdditionalInformation: The purpose of this work was to explore the possibility of making bi-polar plates from injection moulded polyethylene, which would be much cheaper and faster and hence better suited to mass production than the current machined graphite. Although polyethylene has low electrical conductivity, it was felt that blending it with materials such as graphite could lead to a material of sufficient electrical conductivity. Polyethylene-carbon plates were made and specimens tested but whilst the resulting composites could be injection moulded and had good strength, the conductivity was still too low. Further work could lead to a usable material.

Title: Air-related mechanisms of noise generation by solid rubber tyres with cavities
AdditionalInformation:
This paper describes a new technique to measure the noise generated within tyre tread cavities. In particular it reports a new methodology to identify the air pumping noise generated by the tyre cavity.
The research gained recognition when initially presented to the Institute of Acoustics Spring Conference, 2006 where the first author was awarded a Commendation by the Conference Technical Committee because of the ‘high quality’ of the paper. 
This research is being further developed by a project modelling tyre internal cavity resonance noise for Jaguar Land Rover (JLR order no: EJC PO12 M46170, £47,000, 2012).

Title: Vehicle noise primary attribute balance
AdditionalInformation:
This paper uses novel customer ratings to identify the optimal noise attribute balance in a vehicle. In particular, a methodology for analyzing the datasets is presented that reveals the interaction of the attributes.
The quality of this research was confirmed in the U. S. 2012 JD Power APEAL Survey when the Land Rover Evoque, developed using these techniques, scored highest for ‘Overall Interior Quietness’ against its direct competitors.
The authors have been invited to submit a modified version of the paper to the professional journal Noise and Vibration Worldwide.

Title: Measurement of vibrational energy flow in a plate with high energy flow boundary crossing using electronic speckle pattern interferometry
AdditionalInformation:
This paper reports the development of an ESPI based measurement technique for plate bending wave intensity using wavenumber domain processing. In particular, a new filter design and signal manipulation are proposed in order to reduce the contaminating effects of optical noise and signal truncation and so obtain a more accurate representation of the intensity field.
This research is being continued by a PhD studentship entitled ‘Vibrational power transmission and reflection through structural connections’ funded by the Ministry of Higher Education Malaysia and the National Defence University Malaysia (1 Oct 2009 – 31 Mar 2013).

Title: Structural-acoustic behaviour of automotive-type panels with dome-shaped indentations
AdditionalInformation:
This paper reports on a structural-acoustic optimisation technique that reduces the radiated sound power of a panel without increasing its weight. In a novel approach, the panel is optimised without specific knowledge of the input force characteristics.

This research was initiated by Jaguar Land Rover with a PhD Studentship in 2006 (JLR order no: EJC PO05G07660) and is being further developed in a new project (PhD studentship + 18 months RA) entitled ‘Modelling vehicle noise variability to improve design robustness’ as part of the EPSRC/JLR Programme for Simulation Innovation, EPSRC Grant number, EP/K014102/1, £1.68M, 2012-2017).

Title: Integrated system fault diagnostics utilising digraph and fault tree-based approaches
AdditionalInformation: This was the first paper to identify failures within a system using fault tree and digraph modelling methods within the fault diagnostic process.  The method has supported research in fault diagnostics, an underpinning research area being pursued by BAE Systems/Systems Engineering Innovation Centre. Contact: John Pearson.

Title: Fault diagnostics of dynamic system operation using a fault tree based method
AdditionalInformation: Invited paper for the Special Issue of the Journal of Reliability Engineering and System Safety.  Leading authors and papers from the Internationally renowned reliability symposium, the 18th European Safety and Reliability conference, were invited by the editors of the Special Issue (Terje Aven, Jan Erik Vinnem and Carlos Guedes Soares).  Contact C.Guedes Soares.

Title: An offshore safety system optimization using an SPEA2-based approach
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses a method to minimize safety system unavailability and also find the balance between its unavailability and other limitations on its operation, e.g. life cycle cost.  The findings of this paper provided a sound scientific foundation that underpins the optimisation research in EPSRC bid in ICT Manufacturing, ‘Adaptive Informatics for Intelligent Manufacturing (AI2M)’.

Title: Phased mission system design optimisation using genetic algorithms
AdditionalInformation: Providing the foundations of a new line of safety critical system analysis and design optimisation, this work was fundamental to the Ministry of Defence, in particular supporting and enhancing the Through Life Support divisions research, whose systems formed the practical element to the theory of this paper.  Contact: Richard Denning.

Title: Structural stability of multi-folding structures with contact problem
AdditionalInformation: The micro-structure design of materials is becoming an increasingly important area of work.  To gain an improved understanding of the behaviour of materials with a micro-structure of cellular structures, such as honeycomb materials, it is first important to understand the behaviour of multi-layered folding pantographs which is equivalent to the cellular structure.  The research work is collaborative and is co-authored with a research collaborator from Hiroshima University.

Title: Multilevel Optimization of Composite Panels Under Complex Load and Boundary Conditions
AdditionalInformation: Engineers have and continue to strive to reduce the design time of an aircraft whilst at the same time increase the level of complexity of the design itself.  Engineers will benefit from having an approximate picture of the design space they are working in and they can then make an informed decision in which direction a design can progress in.  The research work is collaborative and is co-authored with a research collaborator from Cardiff University.

Title: Homogeneous trees of second order Sturm-Liouville equations: A general theory and program
AdditionalInformation:
The paper was first presented at the Proceedings of the Tenth International Conference on Computational Structures Technology (doi:10.4203/ccp.93.186).  It was invited and then extended and published in the journal special issue on Eigenvalues of Continuous Systems.

The paper is a first one to include a short computer program which can calculate eigenvalues for a class of quantum graphs.  This paper arises from inter-disciplinary “blue skies” research and represents an additional step for the transfer of knowledge between the two disciplines. The research work is collaborative and is co-authored with a research collaborator from Cardiff University.

Title: Finite element buckling analysis of stiffened plates with filleted junctions
AdditionalInformation: Current industry practice is to idealise the true geometry of a stiffened panel for buckling analysis.  Future design practice should make allowance for true geometry to be accounted for in buckling analysis since some geometries can cause buckling behaviour to be quite far from what is predicted.  This also leads into other effects which can lead to detrimental performance.  This joint work was completely performed at Loughborough.

Title: Point mobility of a cylindrical plate incorporating a tapered hole of power-law profile
VolumeTitle: JOURNAL OF THE ACOUSTICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA
AdditionalInformation: The outcome of this paper is a solution to the bending plate equation of motion with a variable material property which can actually be incorporated into an industrial design suffering from vibration problems. A singularity with some mathematical profiles of variable property thickness can be used to reduce vibration in structural circular panels. Discussions have been held with engineers at Jaguar Land Rover which are ongoing to find locations on the vehicle where these can be tested in practice.

Title: Damping of flexural vibrations in rectangular plates using the acoustic black hole effect
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new innovative approach to reducing the amplitude of structural vibration, through an easily integrated design. It provides a possible alternative to industrial manufacturer’s choice to cover plates undergoing flexural vibration with damping material rather than incorporate highly efficient and focused energy absorbers. The method described in this paper has been used as supporting evidence in a further EPSRC funded, multi-university study, “PEALS: Periodicity Enhanced Attenuating Layers and Structures”, led by Professor Keith Attenborough of the Open University, contactable at K.attenborough@open.ac.uk.

Title: Tyre/road interaction noise-Numerical noise prediction of a patterned tyre on a rough road surface
AdditionalInformation: The coupled structural-acoustic simulation models developed in this paper have been used in the EU and industrial framework six project QCity to examine the impact of poroelastic road surfaces on the radiated noise from urban automotive traffic. The contradiction between the legislative test methods accentuating tyre tread patterns against real world driving conditions where carcass vibrations are more important are highlighted in the QCity results, also shown in this paper. The research outputs are all publically accessible at http://www.qcity.org/ and the project organiser can be contacted at Mr. Nils-Åke Nilsson na.nilsson@acoustic.se.

Title: Tyre/road interaction noise-A 3D viscoelastic multilayer model of a tyre belt
AdditionalInformation: The numerical prediction model described in this paper has been used as the primary noise prediction tool for tyre design in the EU framework six project QCity, which assessed the impact of tyre design changes on noise levels, alongside industrial partners, where finite elements were impractical. The research outputs are all publically accessible at http://www.qcity.org/, specifically the model has been used to provide results in work packages: “WP3.4 Parametric studies of tires and road parameters” and “WP5.11 Test of new quiet passenger tyre designs”. Contact the project organiser Mr. Nils-Åke Nilsson na.nilsson@acoustic.se

Title: Effects of variation in depth and side cut angulations in LASIK and thin-flap LASIK using a femtosecond laser: A biomechanical study
AdditionalInformation: Millions of patients have been treated using LASIK, recent adoption of femtosecond processing is gaining as having most control. This work provides the first quantified study of optimum side cut angles for minimised strain gradient across the patient’s cornea. One of the single most significant parameters in long term vision degradation generated from such surgery, this provides the quantified basis for new sub corneal lamellae surgery paving the way for enhanced analysis. Independent opinion would be available from David O’Brart, President of the UK Society of Cataract and Refractive Surgeons. david.obrart@GSTT.nhs.uk

Title: An optical method for automated roadside detection and counting of vehicle occupants
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A key enabling technology in the establishment of effective road congestion management is automatic vehicle occupancy counting. Here a patented concept was trialed at various locations in the UK and USA. Commercialisation has resulted with a UK company; Vehicle Occupancy Ltd and recently an American subsidiary; Vehicle Occupancy Detection Company, who employ 4 people; they have sold equipment based on this concept in both countries. This featured 9 minutes into the 2011 opening address by John Chambers CISCO CEO at the Oracle Open World 2011 featuring our equipment as his example of future complex computing requirements, at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xWTw7ky9sPI

Title: In vitro quantification of the stiffening effect of corneal cross-linking in the human cornea using radial shearing speckle pattern interferometry
AdditionalInformation: A new non-invasive technique to quantify Riboflavin cross linked UV stimulated stiffening of the cornea by a factor of 4. The combination changes the cross linking of the corneal reinforcing collagen fibres. This, in turn, changes the stiffness locally of the cornea and consequently the shape of the cornea. The mapping of a patients corneal stiffness means very precise correction can be effected without surgery. This potentially will replace current surgical intervention and this instrument and technique could be used for patient determination prior to corneal shape correction. This has encouraged further scholarship.   Objective opinion from David O’Brart, (david.obrart@GSTT.nhs.uk)

Title: Age-Related Differences in the Elasticity of the Human Cornea
AdditionalInformation: Correct measurement of Young’s Modulus in the human cornea is a critical parameter for a wide range of invasive surgical procedures. Until the publication of this paper it was believed amongst some in the ophthalmic community that the elasticity of the cornea weakened with age! This is the first detailed wide age range study which establishes the level of stiffening which takes place. Human corneas double in stiffness from the age of 20 to 100. The data value is for correction in incisional and ablative surgery prediction. Citation increase this year suggests expanding awareness. Objective opinion from David O’Brart (david.obrart@GSTT.nhs.uk)

Title: Computer simulations of evaporation of pinned sessile droplets: Influence of kinetic effects
AdditionalInformation: The long standing problem of the relationship between the diffusive and kinetic regimes of evaporation has been resolved. Computer simulations of the evaporation of small sessile aqueous droplets, which combine diffusive and kinetic models, were developed that included the latent heat of vaporization, Marangoni convection and Stefan flow. Experimental validation showed that the diffusive model was relevant; deviations from this, caused by an increasing influence of the kinetic effects, became noticeable only if the droplet size was less than 1 µm in size. The work was presented at three international Invited/Keynote lectures in Haifa, Israel; Madrid, Spain and Noosa, Australia

Title: Spreading of Aqueous Solutions of Trisiloxanes and Conventional Surfactants over PTFE AF Coated Silicone Wafers
AdditionalInformation: The kinetics of spreading of “superspreaders” (aqueous trisiloxane solutions) was investigated over highly hydrophobic and smooth TEFLON coated silicon wafers in order to reveal the nature of the mysterious “superspreading” phenomenon. At low concentrations the kinetics agreed well with our theoretical predictions, whilst at higher concentrations the spreading processes proceeded in two stages: an initial very fast stage, then a much slower second stage; the latter also occurred according to our theoretical predictions. The work was presented as two international invited lectures in Capri, Italy and Homs, Syria. Potential applications include the agrochemical and printing industries.

Title: Colloidal dynamics: Influence of diffusion, inertia and colloid forces on cluster formation
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper suggested a new method of producing computer simulations of colloidal suspensions that takes into account Brownian, hydrodynamic and colloidal forces between particles based directly on Langevin equations. Neither of the previous models were capable of direct calculation of aggregation and disaggregation of clusters in the suspensions and the transition from reversible to irreversible coagulation based on colloidal interactions between the particles.  The new model allows directly calculating rheological properties of colloidal suspensions and was initially presented at two international conferences.

Title: Why do aqueous surfactant solutions spread over hydrophobic surfaces?
VolumeTitle: Advances in Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: One of the most debated phenomena in the field of surfaces, viz. why aqueous surfactant solution droplets slowly spread over hydrophobic substrates, has been completely resolved. The work proved that the kinetics of slow spreading are determined by the autophilic phenomenon, which results in a decrease of the total free energy of the droplet. The work has been presented at 3 international invited talks/lectures and, as a result of this paper, Starov was elected a Section Editor of “Current Opinion in Colloid and Interface Science” and a member of the Board of the International Association of Colloid and Interface Scientists.

Title: Residues within the Transmembrane Domain of the Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 Receptor Involved in Ligand Binding and Receptor Activation: Modelling the Ligand-Bound Receptor
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by AstraZeneca and was driven by their need for a structural model of the GLP-1 receptor.  This receptor is involved in the synthesis and release of insulin in response to glucose and is hence a target in the treatment of type II diabetes.  Peptide receptor agonists already exist but are not ideal therautic agents. The existence of a structural model and the identification of amino acid residues involved in ligand binding can now be used in the development of targetted small molecule, orally active therapeutic agonists by the industry.

Title: Multiparameter flow cytometry for the characterization of human embryonic stem cells
AdditionalInformation: This work was completed as part of a BBSRC-Bioprocessing Research Industry Club funded project and demonstrates the importance of using multi parameter flow cytometry in assessing embryonic stem cell quality as it enables several markers of cell phenotype to be assessed at once on single cells in a high throughput fashion.  Tracking cell phenotype  throughout a stem cell bioprocess is critical given that these cells are the product and thus the quality of the cells, and not just the proteins they produce, is paramount.  The resolution obtained with this technique is greater than is currently possible with other methods.

Title: The physical characterisation of a microscale parallel bioreactor platform with an industrial CHO cell line expressing an IgG4
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded as part of a KTP award in conjunction with TAP Biosystems (Neil.Bargh@tapbiosystems.com). During the project the ambrTM microbioreactor system, which enables multiple cell populations to be tested in parallel during bioprocess development, was developed and optimised. AmbrTM is now on sale worldwide (www.tapbiosystems.com/tap/cell_culture/ambr.htm) and is already on-site in companies such as MedImmune and Eden Biodesign. Here, and at several conferences, the physical characteristics of ambrTM, including power number, have been presented, which will enable users to develop scale up strategies that more accurately replicate this development scale tool.

Title: Culture of human mesenchymal stem cells on microcarriers in a 5 l stirred-tank bioreactor
AdditionalInformation: Cell-based therapies are part of a growing healthcare industry. With the number of stem cell-based products reaching clinical trials rising, methods for large-scale cell expansion are now needed. This is the first report of mesenchymal stem cells being sucessfully cultured on microcarriers in a 2.5 L stirred tank bioreactor. This work was part-funded by Lonza Biologics (Germany) and formed part of a larger BBSRC Bioprocessing Research Industry Club-funded project. It has helped secure a new CASE-funded PhD studentship with FujiFilm Diosynth Biotechnologies and led to interest from other companies (e.g. Celgene).

Title: Identifying tyre models directly from vehicle test data using an extended Kalman filter
AdditionalInformation: This paper is cited as an exemplar of underpinning research in support of the recently announced multi-institutional ‘Programme for Simulation Innovation’ (PSi) (EPSRC EP/K014102/1).  The department of Aeronautical and Automotive Engineering at Loughborough University was invited by Jaguar Land Rover to join the consortium in recognition of its research excellence.

Title: Optimisation of high-speed crash avoidance in autonomous vehicles
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Vehicle Autonomous Systems
AdditionalInformation: Following appointment to the Editorial Boards of the International Journal of Vehicle Autonomous Systems (IJVAS) and its sister publication, the International Journal of Vehicle Performance (IJVP) in recognition of being ‘a renowned expert in the field of vehicle system dynamics and control’ (Subhash Rakheja, Executive Editor, IJVP, June 2010) this paper was invited for a special 10th Anniversary edition of IJVAS ‘with invited papers only from top experts’ (Kevin Deng, Editor in Chief, IJVAS, December 2010).

Title: Evaluation of a new body-sideslip-based driving simulator motion cueing algorithm
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: An entirely new concept in vehicle motion cueing, this technique was first announced in an invited contribution to Cambridge University’s Vehicle Dynamics and Control symposium (David Cole, April 2011).  Vehicle handling expert Damian Harty (Chief Engineer, Prodrive) tested the algorithm in June 2012 and noted this was ‘the first time I remember driving a simulator and talking about the cars (being simulated) instead of the simulator (itself); a compelling step in the right direction, in my opinion’.

Title: Model predictive driving simulator motion cueing algorithm with actuator-based constraints
VolumeTitle: Vehicle System Dynamics: international journal of vehicle mechanics and mobility
AdditionalInformation: This real-world application of Model Predictive Control attracted critical praise from test subjects in blind comparisons against an optimised conventional motion cueing algorithm.  The MPC aims to provide better reproduction of a simulated vehicle’s accelerations on a motion platform by optimising use of the rig’s limited displacement envelope.  Vehicle engineers from Jaguar Land Rover, with experience of vehicle handling and motion simulators said the MPC yaw response was more natural (Tim Cotgrove), there was better feedback of the car’s stance (state), and the car felt more capable up to the limit (Adam Southgate).

Title: A micromechanism study of thermosonic gold wire bonding on aluminum pad
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the research outcome of a collaboration with Nanyang Technological University Singapore, for the first time elaborating the fundamentals of the bonding mechanism of Au/Al bonds produced by the wire bonding process at micro- and nano-scale using XTEM analysis. This led to optimum manufacturing of such bonds to enable more reliable ultrafine pitch interconnects. ASM Ltd at Singapore (Siva@asmpt.com) participated and supported the research and can verify the significance and quality of this research to industry.

Title: Initial formation of CuSn intermetallic compounds between molten SnAgCu solder and Cu substrate
AdditionalInformation: The authors have developed a new methodology, enabling a detailed in-situ investigation of the interfacial reactions at the solder/substrate interfaces, which was not possible before this publication. It uncovered the fundamentals of the formation of intermetallic compounds in the soldering processes. The paper since published has been cited 26 times attracting widespread attention in the electronics manufacturing research community, and has led to extensive international collaborations with UCLA (kntu@ucla.edu) (USA), CityU (HK) and HUST (China), e.g. through a Royal Society Kan Tong Po Visiting Professorship based at CityU, HK (EEYCCHAN@cityu.edu.hk).

Title: Growth of Intermetallic Compounds in Thermosonic Copper Wire Bonding on Aluminum Metallization
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a pioneering research on the fundamental understanding of interfacial characteristics of Cu/Al bonds induced by thermal aging process. Both K&S Corporate (iqin@kns.com) and ASM Ltd (Siva@asmpt.com) considered this has a significantr impact on the electronics industry to enable reliable ultrafine pitch interconnects, and paved the path of the entire copper wire bonding industry which has today become a mainstream interconnect technology. Scientifically, it addressed the Cu-Al IMCs growth kinetics which is correlated to the diffusion process of aging.

Title: Behavior of aluminum oxide, intermetallics and voids in Cu–Al wire bonds
AdditionalInformation: This reports a collaborative work with Nanyang Technological University Singapore, the Australian National University, Australia and Alabama University, USA addressing copper wire bonding mechanisms by examining the interface using high resolution TEM. This paper has been cited 19 times since published and attracted significant attention from wire bonding industry, leading further global research activities on copper wire bonding. This can be affirmed by the expert at Kulicke & Soffa Corporate (iqin@kns.com), and the first author has been retained as a result of this work by Kulicke & Soffa Corporate, a top wire bonding company in USA.

Title: Micro-scale modelling of bovine cortical bone fracture: Analysis of crack propagation and microstructure using X-FEM
AdditionalInformation: Based on the high-quality research done in this paper, authors were invited to a keynote lecture at the International Conference on Computational and Experimental Engineering & Sciences ICCES'11, 18-21 April, 2011, Nanjing, China.

Title: Analysis of anisotropic viscoelastoplastic properties of cortical bone tissues
VolumeTitle: JOURNAL OF THE MECHANICAL BEHAVIOR OF BIOMEDICAL MATERIALS
AdditionalInformation: Based on the research introduced in this paper, the authors were invited to join an international collaboration with professor Tariq Khraishi from the Mechanical Engineering Department, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, USA. Consequently, a collaborative research proposal was submitted to the National Science Foundation (NSF), USA to expand the research in the area of bone tissue. The outcome is pending

Title: Regenerative medicine, resource and regulation: lessons learned from the remedi project
AdditionalInformation: This paper, an outcome of the £5.76M EPSRC remedi innovative manufacturing Grand Challenge, focuses on how UK and US Regenerative Medicine SMEs can be assisted to grow and deliver next generation products by satisfying regulation and securing reimbursement. Using product led case studies the work gave direct benefit to collaborating SME’s including Bioceramic Therapeutics (m.stevens@imperial.ac.uk),  Orthomimetics (andrew.k.lynn@gmail.com) and RegenTec  (rquirk@regentec.net).  It significantly influenced the design of the successor TSB Regenerative Medicine value systems call and one of the three funded projects by focussing on the key uncertainties for business (Zahid.Latif@tsb.gov.uk).

Title: Results from an exploratory study to identify the factors that contribute to success for UK medical device small- and medium-sized enterprises
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper secured a £23k study funded by Association of British Healthcare Industries (ABHI), Department of Business Enterprise and Regulatory Reform, Research and Regulation and Department of Health (DH) confirming earlier conclusions. In consequence recommendations were made to DH via the Ministerial Sub-sector Strategy Group in Medical Technologies to influence DH behaviour to enhance SME competitiveness. Initially unwelcome, the recommendations were ultimately recognised on the DH website. Some recommendations were further input into EU policy via DG SANCO. This can be confirmed by trade associations ABHI (oliver.wells@ahbi.org.uk) and Eucomed (John Wilkinson former CEO now Devices Director MHRA John.Wilkinson@mhra.gsi.gov.uk ).

Title: Concise Review: Mind the Gap: Challenges in Characterizing and Quantifying Cell- and Tissue-Based Therapies for Clinical Translation
AdditionalInformation: This paper (journal impact factor 7.8) available as a free download “opinion piece” has considerably influenced discussion on the regulatory landscape and methods for characterising stem cell products. It assisted the Loughborough Centre for Biological Engineering to secure a role in the group formed by the British Standards Institution to create the Publically Available Specification PAS 93:2011 “Characterization of human cells for clinical applications” and more particularly to influence the direction of the emerging PAS (a pre-standard), forcing a major redrafting to make it more acceptable to business. This can be confirmed by BSI (Ben.Sheridan@bsigroup.com).

Title: Precision manufacturing for clinical-quality regenerative medicines
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper integrates work in the automation quality and engineering of human stem cell culture as demonstrated in the Loughborough led EPSRC Innovative Manufacturing Grand Challenge in Regenerative Medicine and uses this integration to define the future research needs for the stem cell manufacturing field. This paper formed part of a Discussion Meeting on "Ultra-precision Engineering" held by the Royal Society in March 2011. It was the sole paper addressing biological manufacturing. This meeting caused The Royal Society and The Royal Academy of Engineering to organize joint meetings.

Title: CFD analysis of microchannel emulsification: droplet generation process and size effect of asymmetric straight-through microchannels
AdditionalInformation: A three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics model was developed to simulate droplet generation in asymmetric straight-through microchannels. The model enables optimisation of geometry and spatial arrangment of asymmetric microchannels and prediction of their performance. The results were used to design and fabricate silicon microchannel arrays for mass production of uniform microdroplets with drop productivity exceeding 10 million Hz. This research was supported by the Food Nanotechnology Project of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of Japan and done in collaboration with National Food Research Institute. Dr Vladisavljevic’s visit was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

Title: Effect of dispresed phase viscosity on maximum droplet generation frequency in microchannel emulsification using asymmetric straight-through channels
AdditionalInformation: This research funded by The Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (L-05555) was conducted in collaboration with Tsukuba University, Japan. A novel asymmetric single crystal silicon chip consisted of 24,000 T-shaped microslots has been developed, fabricated and tested for mass production of monodispersed microdroplets. Due to high precision of photolithography and dry reactive ion etching and a high aspect ratio of the channel outlets, the droplet generation rate exceeded 3 million Hz. This research was presented by Dr Vladisavljevic on more than 10 seminar lectures held worldwide and led to a UK-JSPS Bridge Fellowship award.

Title: Emulsion templating of poly(lactic acid) particles: droplet formation behavior
VolumeTitle: Langmuir: the ACS journal of surfaces and colloids
AdditionalInformation: Monodispersed biodegradable poly(lactic acid) microparticles were produced using novel axisymmetric (3D) glass microfluidic devices with flow focusing. In a 3D device, the dispersed phase is entirely surrounded by the continuous phase during drop formation, due to circular cross section of the flow-focusing orifice, which prevents wetting of the channel wall with the organic solvent used to furmulate the droplet phase. The particle size was precisely controlled by hydrodynamic conditions and orifice size. This research was funded by EPSRC and conducted in collaboration with the Weitz Group at Harvard University.

Title: Manufacture of chitosan microbeads using centrifugally driven flow of gel-forming solutions through a polymeric micronozzle
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: A novel microfluidic strategy for fabrication of hydrogel microbeads was developed based on a centrifugally driven pulse-free flow through radially arranged micronozzles. The fabricated chitosan microbeads were collected directly in a standard Eppendorf tube to allow easy post-production handling without cross contamination. A novel mathematical model for the prediction of the size and production rates of microbeads was developed and validated. This research was supported by an Alexander von Humboldt scholarship awarded to Dr Vladisavljevic and conducted in collaboration with Freiburg University (Prof. Zengerle Group: zengerle@imtek.uni-freiburg.de). Micronozzles used in this work were commercialised in the PipeJet-TipTM nanodosage systems.

Title: Finite element analysis of stress distribution on modified retentive tips of bar clasp
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the result of collaboration with School of Dental Technology, Hacettepe University, Turkey and Faculty of Dentistry, Ankara University, Turkey. This study investigated deformation behaviour of retentive tip of a tooth bar clasp characterized by its shape and material. As a result of this research, Prof. Gulsen Can (email: Gulsen.Can@dentistry.ankara.edu.tr) from Faculty of  Dentistry, Ankara University, Turkey utilized finite element analysis technique to determine whether or not different materials and tip forms were suitable for tooth bar clasp applications.

Title: Finite element modelling of thermally bonded bicomponent fibre nonwovens: Tensile behaviour
AdditionalInformation: This paper received the best paper award from the Nonwovens Cooperative Research Center (NCRC), North Carolina State University, USA (Prof. Behnam Pourdeyhimi - head of NCRC - bpourdey@ncsu.edu) which is the largest research platform of nonwoven companies (3M, DuPont, Procter&Gamble, etc.) in the world.  The developed model was introduced to the member companies (US Army NSRDEC, 3M, FiberVisions, etc.) of NCRC to reduce time and cost of design and optimization of nonwoven fabrics.

Title: Computation of mechanical anisotropy in thermally bonded bicomponent fibre nonwovens
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports the first software for computing mechanical anisotropy of nonwoven fabrics. The software was developed for design and optimization of nonwoven fabrics. The paper has an international academic co-author, Prof. Behnam Pourdeyhimi, NC State University, USA. The research was conducted in collaboration with the Nonwovens Cooperative Research Center (NCRC), NC State University, USA. The code got recognition of world-leading international textile companies (Mr. Thomas Godfrey - US Army NSRDEC - Thomas.Godfrey@us.army.mil; Mr BradEaton - 3M - bweaton1@mmm.com; Dr Carl Wust - FiberVisions - Carl.Wust@FiberVisions.com) at NCRC.

Title: Numerical modelling of damage initiation in low-density thermally bonded nonwovens
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduced the first numerical model to predict damage initiation and evolution in thermally bonded nonwovens. The numerical model may serve to nonwovens industry for design and optimization of nonwoven fabrics considering their deformation and failure characteristics. This paper was the result of an international collaboration with the Nonwovens Cooperative Research Center (NCRC), North Carolina State University, USA. The numerical model got recognition of world-leading nonwoven companies (US Army NSRDEC, 3M, FiberVisions, etc.) at NCRC.

Title: An assessment of large eddy simulations of premixed flames propagating past repeated obstacles
AdditionalInformation: This work is a result of close collaboration between Loughborough University and The University of Sydney (Prof. A.R.Masri) in the development and assessment of LES for general purpose combustion simulations when flow/chemistry interactions with solid boundaries are important. The application is very important in explosion safety and vehicle engine combustion. The later application of the model to engines has contributed to Loughborough university been selected as co-invistigator in a JLR_EPSRC Psi funded project. Contact Dr Steven Pierson,Principal Technical Specialist, JLR Powertrain Analysis (spierso2@jaguarlandrover.com.

Title: Calculations of explosion deflagrating flames using a dynamic flame surface density model
VolumeTitle: Journal of Loss Prevention in the Process Industries
AdditionalInformation:
This paper represents one of the most successful applications of its kind , demonstrating  the
implementation of  dynamic flame surface density models using the laminar flamelet concept
and the large eddy simulation (LES) techniques for turbulence and combustion modelling. The application is very important for future safe design of on- and off-shore chemical processing plants. Published in the Journal of Loss Prevention in the Process Industries, used by design engineers. This paper contributed to Loughborough University being selected as co-investigators in an EPSRC funded Hydrogen safety project  SUPERGEN programme collaborating with Nottingham and Birmingham universities. Contact  David Grant ( David.Grant@nottingham.ac.uk)

Title: LES Modelling of Premixed Deflagrating Flames in a Small-Scale Vented Explosion Chamber with a Series of Solid Obstructions
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents large eddy simulation (LES) results for the University of Sydney explosion flames. The results were found to be extremely useful for design engineers of chemical processing plants. The flow configuration itself has been internationally recognised as an excellent benchmark for validation of turbulent premixed flame models. This paper has been used as references in a recently funded EPSRC SUPERGEN programme in collaboration with two other universities, namely, Nottingham and Birmingham universities. Contact Prof. David Grant ( David.Grant@nottingham.ac.uk)

Title: Dynamic flame surface density modelling of flame deflagration in vented explosion
AdditionalInformation: This paper is part of a series of papers arising from international collaboration with The University of Sydney, Australia. The scope of the work is fundamental studies into modelling of premixed combustion in laboratory scale explosions. This work has continued over number of years and our most recent research has been recognised by other groups as world leading. Contacts: Prof Thierry Poinsot, (poinsot@imft.fr) CERFACS, France.

Title: Processing of bulk nanostructured ceramics
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time in the world that it is possible to produce genuinely nanostructured ceramics using industrially viable process routes. To date the work has led to invitations to present 1 keynote, 1 plenary and 5 invited lectures at international conferences and the award of the Verulam Medal to Binner by the UK’s Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining in 2011 (http://www.iom3.org/content/award-winners-2011). The technology for nano zirconia has been licensed to MEL Chemicals (contact Mr Paul Rimmer, Technical Manager – Ceramics, paul.rimmer@melchemicals.com) for commercial production and other nano ceramics are being developed to a similar point.

Title: Hydrothermal aging behavior of nanocrystalline Y-TZP ceramics
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper led to a patent being filed (Patent Appl. No. 0821674.9, Nanostructured ceramics, Binner JGP, Vaidhyanathan B, Paul A and Annapoorani K) that covers the fact that the very disruptive phase change that occurs when yttria partially stabilised zirconia is exposed to moisture at room or elevated temperatures is eliminated if a nanostructure is retained. The technology has been licensed to MEL Chemicals (contact Mr Paul Rimmer, Technical Manager – Ceramics, paul.rimmer@melchemicals.com) for commercial production.

Title: UHTC-carbon fibre composites: Preparation, oxyacetylene torch testing and characterisation
VolumeTitle: JOURNAL OF THE EUROPEAN CERAMIC SOCIETY
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time in the world that it is possible to produce composites that can withstand >2500oC for up to 6 mins. With primary applications in the field of hypersonic flight, the original funding by DSTL has been continued to 2015 with a focus on scaling up the component size (Prof Peter Brown, Capability Leader – Materials & Structures, DSTL, PMBROWN@mail.dstl.gov.uk). The missile company MBDA have also recently agreed to fund 2 years research on making complex-shaped components and a £4.2M Programme Grant (EP/K008749/1) was funded by EPSRC to broaden the work into other fields.

Title: Interfacial reactions and wetting in Al-Mg/oxide ceramic interpenetrating composites made by a pressureless infiltration technique
AdditionalInformation: The scientific understanding that was achieved during the work that led to this publication resulted in Binner being invited to give an invited talk at Cellmat 2012 in Dresden (http://www.conventus.de/16187/) and the new composites have been considered by DSTL for armour applications (Prof Peter Brown, Capability Leader – Materials & Structures, DSTL, PMBROWN@mail.dstl.gov.uk), the Home Office for anti-cut materials (Jessica Sorrell, Centre for Applied Science and Technology, Home Office Science, Jessica.Sorrell@homeoffice.gsi.gov.uk) and by industry (e.g. Cumi-Murugappa in India, contact: Shyam S Rao,  VP – Business Head – Eng. Ceramics & Metz, shyamsr@cumi.murugappa.com) for their very significant wear resistance.

Title: Compressor/diffuser/combustor aerodynamic interactions in Lean module combustors
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
AdditionalInformation:
Undertaken as part of INTELLECT_DM, an EU funded (€7.7m) collaborative programme. Knowledge gained has been transferred to industrial partners and will enable them to embody improved understanding of aerodynamic interactions into their combustor design philosophies. The work highlighted the need to develop integrated and knowledge based design methods and led to involvement in two further EU projects - KIAI (€8m) and IMPACT_AE (€7.4m).
“Highlighting, at an early stage in the development process, the aerodynamic interactions generated by changing architectures is invaluable to the success of a cost effective development programme”. John Moran, Rolls-Royce plc

Title: Integrated Outlet Guide Vane Design for an Aggressive S-Shaped Compressor Transition Duct
AdditionalInformation:
Undertaken as part of AIDA, a large EU funded (€8.2m) collaborative programme, the immediate impact of the integrated design is the ability to reduce engine length and weight and thereby reduce fuel burn. Improved knowledge has also been utilised in two further EU collaborative projects – NEWAC (€70m) and LEMCOTEC (€68m) – aimed at further improvements in core-engine efficiency.
“The increased understanding and the improved design methodologies this work has developed are now embedded into Rolls-Royce design philosophies”, Tony Rae, Rolls-Royce plc.

Title: Production of erythrocytes from directly isolated or Delta1 Notch ligand expanded CD34⁺ hematopoietic progenitor cells: process characterization, monitoring and implications for manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper identifies and discusses the manufacturing consequences of variability in the cell input population for a manufactured cell product, specifically red blood cells. It identifies novel patterns in cell behaviour and presents concepts for monitoring and control based on the observed dynamic changes in the cell population and associated markers. This is an important model to enable cell therapy manufacture more broadly and was recognised in review as an important conceptual step for the industry. Marc Turner, Professor of Cellular Therapy University of Edinburgh and Medical Director at the Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service. marcturner@nhs.net ; 0131 536 5700

Title: Application of response surface methodology to maximize the productivity of scalable automated human embryonic stem cell manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows that a high level of precision in manufacturing control of stem cells can be achieved with appropriate use of statistical models. It discusses the difficulty of applying statistical models to complex biological processes, and develops our understanding of how to define the boundaries of an optimisable process unit. We anticipate that this paper will stimulate new approaches to manufacturing process definition. Dr Julie Kerby, Pfizer Neusentis, Julie.Kerby@pfizer.com ; 01304 640687

Title: A novel automated bioreactor for scalable process optimisation of haematopoietic stem cell culture
AdditionalInformation: This paper underpins the bio-manufacturing development requirements of a large international DARPA funded blood pharming consortium. It defined a plausible optimisation route to solve previously intractable problems in blood manufacture. The novelty subsequently provided the platform for the award of a personal EPSRC Early Career Fellowship, with international industrial and clinical partners, using the same cell lineages and systems to develop further bio-manufacture solutions. Marc Turner, Professor of Cellular Therapy University of Edinburgh and Medical Director at the Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service. marcturner@nhs.net ; 0131 536 5700

Title: Automated, Scalable Culture of Human Embryonic Stem Cells in Feeder-Free Conditions
AdditionalInformation: This paper developed a method for the production of human stem cells at high quality and scale through understanding the impact of robotic processing parameters on process performance. It was part of a set of three that led to the IChemE International Bioprocessing Innovation and Excellence Award (2009) and was selected for a spotlight feature in the journal, a feature selected by the editors to highlight particularly important research contributions. The scientific advance also led to steering group membership of a public-private partnership aimed at exploiting stem cell science as products. Dr Julie Kerby, Pfizer Neusentis, Julie.Kerby@pfizer.com ; 01304 640687

Title: The need for muscle co-contraction prior to a landing
AdditionalInformation: This paper used a computer simulation model to demonstrate for the first time why co-contraction is beneficial and, above a certain height, necessary to land safely.  It was the outcome of an international collaboration with Associate Professor Graeme Caldwell (fourth author) from the University of Massachusetts (gc@kin.umass.edu) and contributed to the first author being invited to give an invited keynote lecture (title: Computer simulation of sport: insight, optimisation and application) at The XXIII Congress of the International Society of Biomechanics in 2011 (invited by Professor Serge Van Sint Jan, sintjans@ulb.ac.be).

Title: Predicting maximum eccentric strength from surface EMG measurements
AdditionalInformation: The paper estimates in vivo maximum muscle forces that had previously only been obtained through in vitro testing and maximum tetanic simulation.  It originated from two conference presentations at the American Society of Biomechanics Annual Meeting in 2007 by the named authors (http://www.stanford.edu/group/asb2007/ASB_2007_Full.Program6.pdf).  Based on these presentations the first author was asked to present the work more fully in an invited presentation (titled: In vivo limitations to maximal neuromuscular function of the quadriceps) at The Mayo Clinic, Rochester, USA 2009 (invited by Associate Professor Zachary Domire, domirez@ecu.edu).

Title: Neuromuscular function in healthy occlusion
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the largest published database of “healthy” neuromuscular activity of the masticatory muscles under various occlusion conditions.  It was funded by grants from the British Society of Occlusal Studies (£10k) and Mrs Marion E Mundy, Houston, TX (£40k) and led to funding for two further studies related to dental occlusion, one funded by Mrs Marion E Mundy, Houston, TX (value £60k) and the other by RGP CAD/CAM LLC (value £126k).  Further, it is ranked in the top 10% of cited papers published by the Journal of Oral Rehabilitation in 2010 (www.scopus.com).

Title: A combined muscle model and wavelet approach to interpreting the surface EMG signals from maximal dynamic knee extensions
AdditionalInformation: This paper combined experimental joint strength and EMG data with subject specific muscle modelling and wavelet analysis to provide a comprehensive state space solution.  It originated in an abridged format as a conference presentation at the Biomechanics Interest Group annual meeting in 2007.  Based on this presentation the first author was asked to present the work as an invited presentation (titled: Surface EMG Characteristics of dynamic contractions: A combined muscle model and wavelet approach) at the annual British Association of Sport and Exercise Science Conference in 2007 (invited by Dr Polly McGuigan, m.p.mcguigan@bath.ac.uk).

Title: The relation between the virtual actuator and the dual observer
AdditionalInformation: The idea of using a dual observer as a virtual actuator to provide fault tolerant control has gained significant traction within the European fault tolerant community, and this paper is one of the seminar publications.  This paper lead to an invited presentation at Caterpillar Technology Center in Peoria, Illinois, USA, and it was an important factor for the award of a string of industrial research projects from Caterpillar and the ETI.  Further research on this idea is actively being pursued at universities in Newcastle, Loughborough and Bochum.

Title: Optimal Charging of EV's in a Real Time Pricing Electricity Market
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Alternative Powertrains
AdditionalInformation: A repeating optimisation approach is applied to the charging of battery electric vehicles (BEV), adapting earlier work on building heating. The paper demonstrates that in a smart grid, it is possible to both provide electricity load shifting to the grid and cost savings to the user. This creates a strong business case across the vertically segmented electricity market to develop smart charging strategies for electric vehicles. The results are the basis for further research on the stability of smart markets. It also spawned an industrial collaboration into the optimisation of renewable energy use in combination with traditional generator sets.

Title: Investigating the performance of a combined solar system with heat pump for houses
AdditionalInformation: The use of renewable energy sources for space heating is one of the most important challenges in reducing CO2 emissions. This paper investigates the control challenges posed by combining a solar heating system with an electric heat pump. This paper presents results on the use of a model based predictive controller (MPC). Through load shifting to night time electricity, an electricity cost reduction of  10% is achieved. A PhD project has started and produced promising initial results on the use of MPC for reducing the electricity cost when charging electric vehicles.

Title: Influence of Amorphous Component on Melting of Semicrystalline Polymers
AdditionalInformation: This paper is an outcome of research grant provided by the Dutch Polymer Institute, The Netherlands. The paper addresses molecular aspects of melting behavior in a semi-crystalline polymer. The findings are that the rate at which the chains are detached from the crystalline surface, are dependent on entanglements (physical network) in the amorphous region of the polymer, thus invoking melting kinetics.  The influence of melting kinetics on processing has been patented by the Dutch Polymer Institute. (WO/2013/034582). The research student involved, A. Pandey, received the Paul Schlack Man-made Fibres Prize 2012 for his thesis work, see http://www.polymers.nl/News/News_archive/Paul_Schlack_Award_for_Dr._Anurag_Pandey

Title: Influence of Shear in the Crystallization of Polyethylene in the presence of SWCNTs
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses structure development in the presence of carbon nanotubes. The observations are that due to epitaxy matching between carbon nanotubes and polyethylene, higher crystal orientation is observed during shear deformation. These findings are of technological relevance as they help in developing light weight materials that can be applied in electromagnetic shielding, thermal and electric conductivity. The work has been extended to other carbon fillers including graphene oxide.

Title: Influence of Superheated Water on the Hydrogen Bonding and Crystallography of Piperazine-Based (Co)polyamides
AdditionalInformation: The paper is an outcome of research grant provided by the Dutch Polymer Institute, The Netherlands. The paper addresses dissolution of a series of hydrogen bonded aliphatic polymers in superheated water and ionic solutions. The paper shows that under specific conditions water is a good solvent for the synthetic polyamides. The work has been extended to a range of synthetic as well as natural polymers having hydrogen bonding motifs. In the presence of ionic solution(s) amorphous polyamides can be obtained at room temperature, and the oriented structure could be retained on removal of the ions. Technological relevance of these studies has led to a patent application EP08152691.5.

Title: Crystallization and dissolution of flow-induced precursors
AdditionalInformation: The paper is an outcome of research grant provided by the Dutch Polymer Institute. The paper addresses structure development during flow conditions. For good miscibility, polymers having high and low molar masses have been synthesized by supporting two different catalytic systems on one support. Findings are that the high molar mass component, having the high relaxation time, acts as a precursor for the crystallization of the low molar mass component - leading to the unique shish-kebab morphology. The work has been considered as a paradigm for the start of several new studies.

Title: Strength prediction of adhesive joints after cyclic moisture conditioning using a cohesive zone model
AdditionalInformation: There exists an industrial need to be able to accurately predict the lifetime of adhesively bonded joints. This need is particularly significant in the aerospace and automotive sectors. A fundamental requirement leading to the prediction of joint lifetimes is an understanding of the three-dimensional moisture uptake in adhesives combined with an assessment of the damage created and the ability of the adhesive to recover strength upon moisture loss. Such information has not previously been discussed in the literature. This paper, however, provides both empirical data and validated models to fulfil this important industrial requirement.

Title: Novel methods, incorporating pre- and post-anodising steps, for the replacement of the Bengough-Stuart chromic acid anodising process in structural bonding applications
VolumeTitle: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF ADHESION AND ADHESIVES
AdditionalInformation: This paper was a result of a collaborative EPSRC-funded programme (EP/D025958/1) involving Bombardier Aerospace and Goodrich Engine Control Systems. It details an approach to optimising replacements for the industrially-used chromic acid anodising (CAA) process. CAA replacements are desperately sought with a sunset date for hexavalent chromium usage in Europe of September 2017 and REACh regulation potentially having a significant industrial impact. The replacement processes developed are currently being studied by a collaboration of 17 industrial and academic partners in a follow-up project funded by EPSRC (EP/K504063/1). A number of patents have resulted from this initial study eg. GB0500407.2.

Title: Unified methodology for the prediction of the fatigue behaviour of adhesively bonded joints
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides details of a predictive tool for the determination of adhesively-bonded joint lifetimes. A unified fatigue method has been proposed which accounts for the accumulated damage caused by cyclic loading in bonded joints and which more accurately predicts joint lifetimes in the service environment. This approach is significant in that it advances understanding of joint failure beyond the currently-used fracture mechanics-based approaches. For this reason, this study will help increase industrial adoption of adhesive bonding.

Title: Hot and cold cleaning methods: CO2 and Nd:YAG laser ablation, sodium hydride immersion and CO2 cryoblasting
VolumeTitle: Transactions of the Institute of Metal Finishing
AdditionalInformation: This paper details three solutions to the previously unsurmountable problem of how to efficiently remove crosslinked resins from resin transfer moulding tools; a significant problem for the aerospace sector. It also details the laser and cryoblasting cleaning mechanisms, which were previously not fully understood, enabling process optimisation. The underlying study was funded by Bombardier Aerospace, the World’s third largest airframe manufacturer. Bombardier Aerospace, now uses the cryoblasting approach detailed in this paper to clean large-scale industrial tooling. This paper was presented at the IMFAir Conference, July 2009, and won the Canning Medal from the Institute of Metal Finishing in 2009.

Title: Explicit non-linear model predictive control for autonomous helicopters
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: An advanced explicit nonlinear model predictive control algorithm has been developed to address the complicated fast and nonlinear helicopter dynamics. The proposed algorithm has been implemented on a small scale helicopter and flight tests have been performed with promising results. The work has been awarded the Charles Sharpe Beecher prize by the Institution of Mechanical Engineers as “the most innovative paper on an aerospace subject published by the Institution” in 2013.

Title: Measurements and LES calculations of turbulent premixed flame propagation past repeated obstacles
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of a series arising from international collaboration with Sydney University, Australia. The scope of the work is fundamental studies into premixed combustion in laboratory scale explosions. Through experiments and simulations this paper characterises the fundamental behaviour flame propagation in the presence of repeated obstacles. The data is novel and the use of the LES technique and the developments presented are novel. This work has continued over number of years and this research has been recognised by other groups working in similar areas as world leading. Contacts: Prof Thierry Poinsot, (poinsot@imft.fr) CERFACS, France.

Title: Modelling of Instabilities in Turbulent Swirling Flames
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a methodology for the prediction of instabilities using large eddy simulation (LES) results for the Sydney University swirl flames. This work results from close international collaboration between Loughborough University, Canfield University and Sydney University. In this work the large eddy simulation technique is applied for the modelling of non-premixed combustion and the transient data sets obtained from LES are used to predict instabilities in combustion. The combustion LES results were found to be leading in independent assessments made at the TNF8 workshop (Heidelberg) in comparison with other international groups' results http://public.ca.sandia.gov/TNF/8thWorkshop/TNF8.html.

Title: Large Eddy Simulations of Swirling Non-premixed Flames With Flamelet Models: A Comparison of Numerical Methods
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents comprehensive large eddy simulation (LES) results for the Sydney University swirl flames series. This work results from close collaboration between Loughborough University and Imperial College, London in the development and assessment of the LES technique for combustion. The paper presents the most comprehensive comparisons of methods used in the Large Eddy Simulation of non-premixed combustion problems. Cited by many the work has received good recognition as world leading in this area. http://public.ca.sandia.gov/TNF/8thWorkshop/TNF8.html.

Title: Flamelet Based NOₓ-Radiation Integrated Modelling of Turbulent Non-premixed Flame using Reynolds-stress Closure
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents one of the successful applications of its kind that demonstrates the implementation of a compatible radiation calculation methodology using the laminar flamelet model and the Reynolds Stress Closure Model (RSM) for turbulence combustion modelling. The application is very important in gas turbine and aero engine combustion. Contact Dr M. Ravikanthi, Rolls-Royce, Murthy.Ravikanti@Rolls-Royce.com

Title: Analytical methods for waste minimisation in the convenience food industry
AdditionalInformation: The research highlighted the size of the waste problem in the UK food sector and proposed a number of analytical tools to minimise such waste. A sustainable approach to food production, explored in this paper, represent one of the most pressing challenges facing the food & drink sector, and has been highlighted as a critical area for further R&D in the ‘UK Global Food Security Strategic Plan 2011-2016’ (http://www.foodsecurity.ac.uk/assets/pdfs/gfs-strategic-plan.pdf). The work reported has also led to a successful multi-university (Nottingham, Birmingham and Loughborough) research proposal (with £4.5M of EPSRC funding) to establish a ‘National Centre on Innovative Food Manufacturing’.

Title: A novel separation process for recycling of post-consumer products
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the development of a new recycling process, i.e. air-pulse separator which has led to a separation improvement of 10-25% compared to existing technologies for fragmented waste particles with similar ‘terminal velocity’.  The process is a vital element of the automated footwear recycling system developed at Loughborough, and has been exploited by one of the largest global clothing and apparel recyclers (Soex Group - pmzikian@soexgroup.com).  The research has also been the subject of a number of keynote and invited presentations including International Conference on Flexible Automation and Intelligent Manufacturing -Sweden-2008, and International Workshop on Green Engineering, EPFL_Switzerland–2010.

Title: Impacts of environmental product legislation on solid oxide fuel cells
AdditionalInformation: The reported work has promoted the implementation of ‘eco-design considerations’ from the outset in the product development process of the primary industrial partner (Royce-Rolls Fuel Cell Systems –rowland.travis@rrfcs.com).  The research has also been reported in a number of keynote and invited presentations including International Workshop on Intelligent Manufacturing System - Switzerland (April-2008), Workshop by FP7 Coordination Action on Clean Products and Production - Belgium (October-2008). The paper has also led to collaborative discussions with a leading expert, namely Professor Jean-Claude van-Duysen (University of Lille), for a European project to develop eco-design tools specifically tailored for Solid Oxide Fuel Cells.

Title: Minimising Embodied Product Energy to Support Energy Efficient Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The research provided a distinctly different approach to achieve energy efficient manufacturing, and supported decisions related to maximising ‘return on investment’ for energy efficiency improvements, which has been adopted by primary industrial partner (General Motors - jorge.arinez@gm.com).  The research has also been the subject of a number of keynote and invited presentations including European Workshop on Energy Efficient Manufacturing during MANUFUTURE Conference – Sweden-2009, CIRP Working Group in Resource Efficiency - Paris-2010, and International Industrial Technologies Conference–Brussels-2010. The research is also the subject of a large EU-initiative in collaboration with ‘Fraunhofer Institute for Manufacturing Engineering and Automation’ in Stuttgart (Steve.Rommel@ipa.fraunhofer.de).

Title: Co-Nonsolvency Effects for Surface-Initiated Poly(2-(methacryloyloxy)ethyl phosphorylcholine) Brushes in Alcohol/Water Mixtures
AdditionalInformation: The fundamental studies on the unusual solvent-dependent swelling of biologically-relevant PMPC thin films in this paper were integral to subsequent work at Sheffield studying the friction response of these coatings (DOI:10.1021/la1043848) for applications in biomimetic aqueous lubrication.

Title: Biocompatible polymer brushes grown from model quartz fibres: Synthesis, characterisation and in situ determination of frictional coefficient
AdditionalInformation: This work was a key preliminary study for subsequent work at Sheffield in studying the friction properties of “super-lubricious” PMPC thin polymer films (DOI:10.1021/la1043848), which are excellent candidates for biomimetic aqueous lubrication systems. The development of biocompatible and non-biofouling thin film coatings in the paper led to contract research work with DSTL (NAHOPKINS@mail.dstl.gov.uk)

Title: Layer-by-layer deposition of polyelectrolyte macroinitiators for enhanced initiator density in surface-initiated ATRP
