AdditionalInformation: This paper developed scalable initiator chemistry for growing thin surface-initiated polymer coatings. Based on this work, I was invited to join a AUS$442k  Australian Research Council proposal (DP110100041) as an international partner investigator, applying this technology for ultimate application in the minerals and mining sector. This successful proposal included in a fully-funded research sabbatical in Australia including an invited lecture at Newcastle University Australia (with Erica.Wanless@newcastle.edu.au), three publications to date (DOI: 10.1021/mz3003566, 10.1021/la4004092, 10.1039/C3CP52281D) and several more in preparation. An invited review paper in 2009 on this technology also resulted (DOI: 10.1002/pi.2529)

Title: Effect of colloidal substrate curvature on pH-responsive polyelectrolyte brush growth
AdditionalInformation: In this work, the details of the production of pH-responsive polymer/silica core/shell nanocomposite particles are explored and optimised, along with the details of the size-dependant pH response. The synthesis protocols and results from this fundamental study have enabled several active new research themes, including “double-shell” diblock polymer-coated particles with improved colloidal stability for applications (with Erica.Wanless@newcastle.edu.au) and the development and testing of new models for the ultrasonic characterisation of core/shell nanoparticle suspensions (with Valerie Pinfield V.Pinfield@lboro.ac.uk).

Title: Using bubble functions in the multi-scale finite element modeling of the convection-diffusion-reaction equation
VolumeTitle: International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the last in a series of 10 published by the authors between 2005 and 2010 and provides the most complete finite element model for the predictive analysis and solution of problems encountered in the design and manufacture of chemical reactors. The model is based on a new multi-scale approach developed by the authors. This removes the need for ad hoc artificial stabilisation techniques that are traditionally used to overcome computational difficulties for solving convection and reaction dominated problems, which often occur in chemical reactors.

Title: Three-dimensional finite element modelling of coupled free/porous flows: Applications to industrial and environmental flows
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented a robust, computationally cost effective three-dimensional model that provided an important new tool for the solution of a wide range of problems involving combined free / porous flow processes encountered in the filtration and membrane separation industries, e.g. those involved in sea water desalination or underground flow. Linking of the mathematical models of free and porous flow regimes was achieved without the introduction of arbitrary boundary conditions between them. This allowed the solution to proceed without time consuming iterations and therefore the model preserved computing economy in the simulation of large scale industrial or environmental problems.

Title: Development of a predictive mathematical model for coupled stokes/Darcy flows in cross-flow membrane filtration
AdditionalInformation: This paper explained the computational aspects of the mathematical modelling of the cartridge filters widely used in aeronautical applications. The work was part of the €4.7M EU (AST5-CT-2006-030863) funded project SUPERSKYSENSE on smart maintenance of aviation hydraulic fluid and was important because it extended the theoretical work of the authors; it was awarded with the Gold Medal of the Filtration Society. The main outcome of the work has been the development of a software package now used as a CAD tool by SOFRANCE S.A. to design and manufacture safely disposable environmentally efficient aeronautical filters for Air Bus.

Title: A multiscale finite element space-time discretization method for transient transport phenomena using bubble functions
VolumeTitle: Finite Elements in Analysis and Design
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented a new practical numerical technique, in which both temporal and spatial variations of field unknowns can be treated by a single multi-scale scheme; it is the first time that such a solution had been proposed. It therefore provided a very robust and efficient method for time-stepping in transient problems involving non-uniform changes of field variables with respect to time, which often occur in elastomers processing.

Title: A multi-body human model for rear-impact simulation
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Whiplash is a major problem in rear impact crashes, costing the EU economy over 12 billion Euros in compensation claims annually. Seat design is a major factor in whiplash injury. The computational human model facilitates rapid evaluation of car seat designs to reduce whiplash effects. The paper describes a collaboration with Thatcham's state-of-the-art Crash Research Laboratory, which dynamically tests hundreds of seats for whiplash rating. Thatcham provide their facilities to test seat designs informed by the simulations. Contact: Mathew Avery, Crash & Safety Manager, Thatcham, Tel: 01635 868855, Email: matthew.avery@thatcham.org.

Title: Feedback Device for Improvement of Coordination of Reach-to-Grasp After Stroke
VolumeTitle: Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation
AdditionalInformation:
Stroke is the most common cause of disability, with four per cent of NHS costs associated with stroke rehabilitation and care. Relearning through prolonged task repetition is essential to achieving the best possible long-term outcome, but only short-term rehabilitation is available to most patients. Equipment which could be used daily in the home to assist rehabilitation therefore has enormous potential, but must be affordable. The low-cost system trialled here can potentially enable major improvements in rehabilitation by wide-scale availability for use on a regular basis.
Contact: Prof. Marion Walker: marion.walker@nottingham.ac.uk.

Title: Automated people-counting by using low-resolution infrared and visual cameras
AdditionalInformation: Non-contact counting of people in buildings is required in many applications for safety, security and commercial purposes. Safety in buildings, especially for fire risk, depends on knowledge of numbers and whereabouts of people. Infra-red imaging provides the most effective means, however the cost of available high resolution systems remains prohibitive for most applications.  This paper describes a novel approach using only 16x16 pixels.  The imaging algorithms developed enable low cost and reliable counting of people independent of lighting conditions whilst avoiding the problems of invasion of privacy inherent in visual imaging.

Title: Energy-absorbing car seat designs for reducing whiplash
AdditionalInformation: Whiplash injury in car accidents accounts for 80% of personal injury claims. Whiplash behaviour is complex and improved methods are urgently needed for evaluating rear impact safety at the design stage. This paper describes a new type of multi-body computational model simulating biofidelic responses in a far more computationally efficient way than other methods. This enables fast, reliable assessment of seat designs for whiplash mitigation in the early stages, facilitating the design process as well as assisting development of safer products.  Contact: Mathew Avery, Crash Safety Manager, Thatcham, Tel: 01635 868855, Email: matthew.avery@thatcham.org

Title: Residual Stress Distributions Around Indentations and Scratches in Polycrystalline Al₂0₃ and Al₂0₃/SiC Nanocomposites Measured Using Fluorescence Probes
AdditionalInformation: This publication proposed a model to quantify dislocation density in alumina ceramics by using fluorescence spectroscopy, and revealed a key role of nano-sized dispersions in governing lattice plastic deformation and fracture damage in this type of ceramics. Such understanding has since become essential knowledge in the exploitation of nanostructured ceramics for armour applications under high strain rates, and in understanding their damage mechanisms. This has led to two projects studying armour ceramics funded by EPSRC/MOD, and DSTL/UK industry respectively, in collaboration with a number of University and industry partners.

Title: Friction Surface Evolution of Carbon Fibre Reinforced Carbon/Silicon Carbide (Cf/C-SiC) Composites
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: The development of friction surfaces of carbon-fibre/SiC composites was systematically investigated when they are used as the rotor of friction brakes. A key conclusion is that friction transfer layer, essential for consistent friction performance, cannot be sustainably developed on a ceramic surface, and a dedicated friction surface must be engineered to ensure safe braking during driving. A £2.5M research project was later funded by the Technology Strategy Board with a consortium including vehicle constructors, component designers and friction materials/composites manufacturers in UK. Proprietary formulations and manufacturing technologies have been developed and validated for further business exploitation.

Title: Mechanical behaviour of the constituents inside carbon-fibre/carbon-silicon carbide composites characterised by nano-indentation
VolumeTitle: JOURNAL OF THE EUROPEAN CERAMIC SOCIETY
AdditionalInformation: The essential mechanical properties were characterised using nano-indentation in carbon-fibre/carbon-silicon carbide composites manufactured through different routes and/or using different carbonaceous raw materials. The outcomes have implied that the processing routes and carbonaceous raw materials can be widened without necessarily sacrificing the quality of carbon/ceramic composites. This research has implications for the use of carbon fibre material wastes for manufacturing high-value ceramic composites. The exploitation of the use of carbon fibre wastes has been considered through cooperation with companies such as FORMAX and Jaguar Land Rover to develop low-cost ceramic composites brake discs, funded by both industry and ERDF.

Title: Microstructure of friction surface developed on carbon fibre reinforced carbon-silicon carbide (Cf/C-SiC)
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This research revealed the microstructure of the friction transfer layer and its relationship with key constituents in ceramic composites. The underpinning reasons  for why a sustainable friction layer is barely developed during braking were experimentally validated. It was concluded that SiC, a key constituent in carbon ceramic composites, is unlikely to be a good choice for achieving the expected friction performance under all braking conditions. The understanding has led to an industry/academic consortium to explore appropriate ceramic constituents for the friction surface. The outputs have been recognised by Bentley as a possible step change for braking applications for ceramic composites.

Title: Effect of tabs on rectangular jet plume development
AdditionalInformation: This is the 4th paper in a series reporting experimental studies of different techniques for enhancing the rate of mixing in the near field of supersonic jet plumes from complex non-axisymmetric nozzles, such as are commonly found in military aerospace propulsion. The detailed near-field velocity and turbulence data provided achieved the twin objectives of: (i) providing valuable new guidance to designers for optimum choice of number, shape, and geometric configuration of tab vortex generators for maximum mixing at minimum drag penalty, and (ii) delivering the data needed to validate CFD model predictions of these flows.

Title: Subsonic Jet Mixing via Active Control Using Steady and Pulsed Control Jets
AdditionalInformation: This paper employed Laser Doppler Aneormetry to measure active control of jet mixing using both steady and pulsed control jets (CJs). Unlike previous studies, this was performed at Reynolds/Mach numbers representative of current aero-engine design practice. Evaluation of performance over a range of pulsed CJ design parameters (pressure ratio, Strouhal, and mode numbers) identified the improved effectiveness of active control, demonstrating (for the optimum parameter set) an increase in mixing leading to potential core length reduction of 50%, and enhancing near-field turbulence levels by 30%. The turbulence measurements provided a previously unavailable data set for turbulence model validation.

Title: Large Eddy Simulation of supersonic jet plumes from rectangular con-di nozzles
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper was selected to appear in a Special Journal Edition. Results presented demonstrated that LES is superior to RANS CFD in capturing near-field development of supersonic plumes from rectangular nozzles. Comprehensive evidence was produced that judicious combination of mesh design, an SGS model calibrated to capture integral length scales, and a synthetic turbulence inlet condition method, enabled correct prediction of both highly accelerated nozzle boundary layers and the boundary layer to shear layer transition essential for accurate plume near-field simulation. The success of the synthetic turbulence method has persuaded Rolls-Royce to adopt this in their in-house code.

Title: Large Eddy Simulation of Liquid-Jet Primary Breakup in Air Crossflow
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated a novel two-phase flow Large Eddy Simulation methodology developed by the authors to be capable of accurately predicting complex primary breakup of a liquid jet in air cross-flow, an important configuration in combustor fuel injection. The algorithm proved more robust than existing alternatives for high density ratios. Analysis of simulations for breakup onset time with low turbulence conditions produced a new correlation. Implementation of a synthetic turbulence inlet condition method proved successful in capturing the practically relevant case of high air turbulence;  Rolls-Royce has now begun to implement the two-phase flow methodology in their in-house code.

Title: Large Eddy Simulation of a complete Harrier aircraft in ground effect
AdditionalInformation: The methods presented in the article have been incorporated in the Rolls-Royce flow simulation software and used for installation aerodynamics applications

Title: Jet noise: Acoustic analogy informed by large eddy simulation
AdditionalInformation: Resulted in an invitation to present at the Royal Society Workshop on ‘Frontiers of numerical jet modelling: from engineering to environmental flows’ at the Kavli Centre, January 2011, and at Internoise 2011, in Osaka, Japan, September 2011

Title: Large Eddy Simulation of a Controlled Diffusion Compressor Cascade
VolumeTitle: Journal of Flow, Turbulence and Combustion
AdditionalInformation: Resulted in an invitation to participate in the European Commission funded Marie-Curie project COPA-GT (Coupled Parallel Simulation of Gas Turbines) with seven other European partners.

Title: Towards Large Eddy Simulation of gas turbine compressors
AdditionalInformation: The methods for turbomachinery presented in this article have been incorporated in the Rolls-Royce flow simulation software. The article has resulted in an invitation to lead the UK Applied Aerodynamics Consortium of 10 universities for funding by EPSRC.  Also led to an invitation to present in a special technical session at the ECCOMAS conference in Vienna in September 2012.

Title: Design of a force acquisition system for high-energy short-duration impacts
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces a new approach to the assessment of protective equipment in sport, overcoming the limitations of traditional methods to allow detailed time resolved transmitted short duration force profiles to be captured.  The enhanced detail available from such measurements will support a better understanding of impact injury in sport and facilitate improved testing standards and product development. (Ref Dr Craig Ranson, International Cricket Council Medical Committee, craigranson@me.com)

Title: Viscoelasticity of multi-layer textile reinforced polymer composites used in soccer balls
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the culmination of a series of papers analysing the influence of material properties and construction on ball performance.  This work has underpinned innovation and development of football designs by adidas for tournament balls including those used at the FIFA World Cup. Contact Dr Tim Lucas, Engineering Director, adidas, tim.lucas@adidas.com

Title: Laser tracking system for sports ball trajectory measurement
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The ability to provide detailed launch measurements is highly relevant in the competitive sports ball and implement sector, but has recently found further application in sports officiating.  This paper reports the first active feedback controlled sports ball tracker capable of responding to ball velocities of up to 10 m/s in an arbitrary direction.  This new approach has potential to influence the design and development of future technologies in this area, and can be verified by Luke Dodd, Software Development Engineer, HawkEye (luke.dodd@hawkeyeinnovations.co.uk)

Title: The application of simulation to the understanding of football flight
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the result of an international industrial collaboration with adidas innovation team that significantly influenced their designs of footballs used on major international tournaments. It has subsequently influenced FIFA, the world governing body of football, to commission Loughborough University to undertake further research with a view to influencing the quality standards used to certify elite match balls.  Contact Johannes Holzmüller, FIFA, Johannes.Holzmueller@fifa.org

Title: PIV study of the flow field generated by a sawtooth impeller
AdditionalInformation: Noise is usually removed from Particle Image Velocimetry data using a velocity magnitude range filter, however, modern methods of calculating turbulence dissipation rates require numerical differentiation of velocities, which introduce further error. This is the first paper to compare the resulting noisy signal to the distribution of dissipation rates that could have resulted from real intermittency effects, allowing much improved filtering of measurement errors. The PhD Student, Heema Unadkat, won the IChem Fluid Mixing Processes Subject Group prize in 2009 for the work and this journal paper was invited following her presentation at the 13th European Conference on Mixing.

Title: Investigation of the Effect of Temperature Cycling on Surface Features of Sulfathiazole Crystals during Seeded Batch Cooling Crystallization
AdditionalInformation: The work relates to Direct Nucleation Control of batch crystallisations, which is a technique developed at Loughborough that is currently being extended to continuous operations within the scope of the £5M EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing for Continuous Manufacturing and Crystallisation, directed by Prof Alastair Florence  at Strathclyde. This paper directly contributed to our track record in making the bid for this Centre and also for the related DTC. The PhD student, Rushdi Abu Bakar, was selected to present his work at the SET for BRITAIN Exhibition at the House of Commons in 2009.

Title: Combined quadrature method of moments and method of characteristics approach for efficient solution of population balance models for dynamic modeling and crystal size distribution control of crystallization processes
AdditionalInformation: Efficient methods to solve population balance equations for the model-based optimisation of crystallisations processes are proposed. The PhD student, Erum Aamir, won the UK Particle Technology Forum 2009 prize for a presentation on this work and was selected for a training course with BASF through this industrial collaboration. The work allowed us to engage in a collaboration with Electrical Engineers at University of Strathclyde on plant-wide modelling and control.   With Professor Andonovic (i.andonovic@eee.strath.ac.uk), we have recently been awarded a £3M EPSRC Future ICT-enabled Manufacturing grant on "Intelligent Decision Support and Control Technologies for Continuous Manufacturing of Pharmaceuticals and Fine Chemicals".

Title: Modelling of mass transfer in gas-liquid stirred tanks agitated by Rushton turbine and CD-6 impeller: A scale-up study
AdditionalInformation: The work relates to the development of methods to combine CFD and population balances, as applied to fermenter scale-up. The expertise described here allowed us to bid successfully in collaboration with Marco Oldiges (m.oldiges@fz-juelich.de) from Forschungszentrum Jülich, partners in TU Berlin and industry for a €2M ERA-IB EU FP7 project on "Systematic consideration of inhomogeneity at the large scale: towards a stringent development of industrial bioprocesses". The paper is directly related to gaining a better understanding of dissolved oxygen heterogeneities in large scale fermenters and, in the new project, will be enhanced by coupled with realistic metabolic rate models.

Title: Robust nonlinear predictive controller for permanent-magnet synchronous motors with an optimized cost function
AdditionalInformation: This output is a result of an international collaboration with four authors from three different countries (Canada, UK and USA)  based on my original work. The work developed a nonlinear control scheme with theoretically established properties for permanent magnetic synchronous motors and was implemented and tested on a laboratory scale. My contribution was to develop the algorithm and its stability analysis. The research closely links with industrial projects being currently worked on with Triumph Actuation and Motion Control Systems UK Ltd for developing electromechanical actuators in replacing traditional hydraulic actuators in aircraft.

Title: Path-following control for small fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles under wind disturbances
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Robust and Nonlinear Control
AdditionalInformation: The flight paths of small unmanned aircraft are very vulnerable to strong winds due to their limited mass and size, however keeping close to a planned trajectory is essential for many tasks such as remote sensing or searching. This invited paper describes a new design of path-following-function for small aircraft in adverse wind conditions. A real time wind estimator has been developed using disturbance observer techniques originally proposed by me so the influence of the wind can be compensated. It has been used successfully for guiding a small unmanned aircraft during a geographic survey by Geography colleagues at Loughborough University.

Title: Piecewise constant model predictive control for autonomous helicopters
AdditionalInformation: The algorithms presented in this paper have been implemented on different sizes of unmanned helicopters for both indoor and outdoor flight tests. An explicit nonlinear model predictive control algorithm has been developed and the work was awarded the Charles Sharpe Beecher prize by the Institution of Mechanical Engineers in 2013. The work lead to the creation of a number of industrial collaborations in the field of unmanned flight and consequently to receipt of a number of grants, including £1M from EPSRC. This work is still ongoing.

Title: Nonlinear disturbance observer-based control for multi-input multi-output nonlinear systems subject to mismatching condition
AdditionalInformation: This paper extends the applicability of existing, nonlinear disturbance, observer-based control techniques originally proposed by the author in 2000. Since its appearance, this method has been applied to a wide range of applications such as motors, robotics, aircraft and grinding machines by researchers around the world. It also has aroused considerable theoretic interest worldwide, leading to further developments in a number of PhD theses in Canada, China and USA. This joint work with Chinese scholars relaxed the matching condition on disturbance and uncertainties required in the original approach and is expected to yield a much wider range of applications.

Title: Laser stripping of TiAlN coating to facilitate reuse of cutting tools
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The research discussed in this paper was performed in collaboration with Rolls-Royce plc and Teer Coatings Ltd (co-author). The motivation for the research was to increase sustainability in high value manufacturing processes by effective use of laser cleaning technology. The results of the work were a key element in the multi-million pound laser cleaning project, SAMULET-1 (Strategic Affordable Manufacturing in the UK through Leading Environmental Technologies).  The laser cleaning methodology evolved from the paper has been adopted within Rolls-Royce, Derby, UK to clean aerospace alloys prior to electron beam welding (Mark Turner; mark.turner@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Laser net shape welding
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the relationship between bead shape and mechanical performance in laser welding through numerical simulation and experimental analysis. This study was the first of its kind to couple temperature and geometrical factors to predict residual stress. The findings were chosen by distinguished CIRP members for presentation at the prestigious CIRP2011 General Assembly Conference. By considering the significance of the research outcome, the results were reported (Winter 2012) in UK Association of Laser Users (info@ailu.org.uk) Magazine (by invitation only).

Title: Numerical simulation of laser machining of carbon-fibre-reinforced composites
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: A new computational methodology was proposed in this paper to understand the thermal behaviour of complex phases in an-isotropic fibre reinforced composites. This is the first time that laser machining has been simulated with a realistic mesh in these materials and the initial results were well received within international scientific community. Since publication, a parallel research programme in this area has been established with the Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology, (Z L Li; zlli@SIMTech.a-star.edu.sg). The manuscript was further recognised by including it as book chapter in “Advances in Laser Materials Processing Technology: Technology, Research and Application” by Woodhead Publishing Limited.

Title: Modelling of the melt pool geometry in the laser deposition of nickel alloys using the anisotropic enhanced thermal conductivity approach
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This research output was part of a European Union project (FANTASIA) on implementation of laser cladding in industry with research partners TWI and Rolls-Royce (Daniel.Clark@Rolls-Royce.com). The focus of the research was on the simulation of large area deposition to predict the effects of thermal stress. The distinctiveness of the paper is a new enhanced thermal conductivity term that makes computation over large cladding areas possible. The technique described in this paper is now used by industries to design laser clad parts. One such example was reported by TWI and Rolls-Royce in “doi: 10.1177/0954406212470363; Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science, 2012”.

Title: In situ observation of the oxidation of S32101 duplex stainless steel at 900°C
AdditionalInformation: This work, funded by the Outokumpu Stainless UK Research Foundation, is the first to present results of the in-situ oxidation, in a scanning electron microscope, of a lean duplex stainless steel, concentrating on the oxidation of the phase boundary between the ferrite and austenite phases.

Title: Interface study by dual-beam FIB-TEM in a pressureless infiltrated Al(Mg)-Al2O3 interpenetrating composite
AdditionalInformation: The mechanism by which aluminium-magnesium can be infiltrated into ceramic preforms is not well understood and relies on complex reactions at the metal/ceramic interface.  The understanding gained in this work permitted the development of process conditions to allow other alloy/ceramic composites to be manufactured using pressureless infiltration, and ultimately lead to investigating the system for possible ballistic applications EP/G006059/1 Co-Continuous Metal-Ceramic Interpenetrating Composites (IPCs) for Light Armour Applications.

Title: High strain rate characteristics of 3-3 metal-ceramic interpenetrating composites
AdditionalInformation: The newly developed 3D ceramic/metal composite material, produced at Loughborough University, has distinct properties particularly when bonded to a ceramic front face.  Further developments were made through a follow on fund EPSRC grant:  EP/G006059/1 Co-Continuous Metal-Ceramic Interpenetrating Composites (IPCs) for Light Armour Applications.

Title: Whisker growth morphology of high temperature oxides grown on 304 stainless steel
AdditionalInformation: The work considers some of the complex oxide morphologies that form during high temperature oxidation of 304 stainless steel, in the as-cast condition, showing the influence of surface finish.  The work was presented as part of a keynote lecture at 7th European Stainless Steel Conference - Science and Market, in Como, Italy, September 2011. http://www.aimnet.it/allpdf/stainless2011.pdf, and http://www.metallurgia-italiana.net/eng/manifestazione.php?id=89&idc=4

Title: Harmonic decomposition analysis of contact mechanics of bonded layered elastic solids
AdditionalInformation: This journal paper is the fore-runner in contact mechanics of bonded elastic layered solids (hard wear-resistant or soft lubricating coatings). It is based on harmonic decomposition of contact pressures as waves, penetrating the bulk of composite structures, a totally original approach. It has been applied to a host of contact problems, including in the EPSRC Program Grant, Encyclopaedic (£2.5 M with 3 academic institutions and 6 industrial concerns). The method is superior in accuracy and computation to finite element analysis. This can be corroborated by Dr. Sebastian Howell-Smith, Technical Director, Capricorn Automotive, leading providers of advanced coated pistons (Sebastian.Howell.Smith@Capricornauto.co.uk ).

Title: Effect of lubricant molecular rheology on formation and shear of ultra-thin surface films
VolumeTitle: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
AdditionalInformation: This journal paper highlights the effect of the mechanism of solvation in the formation of thin adsorbed low shear strength films at asperity summits in nano-scale. The fundamentals underlying the formation of these films have evaded description for the better part of a century. The mechanism is crucial in the understanding of the friction and adhesion in all forms of contact.   This can be corroborated by Dr. Christopher Warrens, Senior Technologist at BP-Castrol; chris.warrens@uk.bp.com

Title: Formation of ultra-thin bi-molecular boundary adsorbed films
AdditionalInformation: Formation of low shear strength boundary adsorbed films is crucially dependent on the molecular composition of fluids/lubricants.  Some species enhance load carrying capacity whilst others such as boundary active long-chains reduce friction through adsorption to solid barriers. Using the statistical mechanics approach of Orstein and Zernick with a Percus-Yevick potential, a new method for prediction of thin boundary films is established with the importance of molecular species and concentration demonstrated. This is the first paper to apply this approach to thin surface films. Corroboration will be provided by Dr. Christopher Warrens, Senior Technologist at BP-Castrol; chris.warrens@uk.bp.com

Title: Physio-chemical hydrodynamic mechanism underlying the formation of thin adsorbed boundary films
AdditionalInformation: Recent years have witnessed the inadequate traditional definition for friction, being dependent upon physical length scales. In minutiae, molecular species of a real fluid act according to surface energy and adsorption potential. Therefore, the molecular composition and concentration affect boundary friction. This paper demonstrated these effects with wide ranging practical implications for multi-species polymeric chains. The fundamental finding is the description of friction by expended energy, which contributed to the Faraday Discussion 156:  (http://www.rsc.org/ConferencesAndEvents/RSCConferences/FD/faraday-discussion-156.asp) by the leading tribologists, Contact: Dr. Sebastian Howell-Smith, Technical Director, Capricorn Automotive (Sebastian.Howell.Smith@Capricornauto.co.uk ) and Dr. Chris Warrens, Senior Technologist, BP-Castrol: chris.warrens@uk.bp.com

Title: Measuring the risk of sustaining injury in sport a novel approach to aid the re-design of personal protective equipment
AdditionalInformation: This work has, amongst other factors, enabled the author to forge a new strategic collaborative research relationship with, Nike, Inc.. Research grant income totalling £122k has been secured during 2011-13. The collaborator (jorge.carbo@nike.com) has described the work as being “of critical strategic importance to [their] current research and development programme” with the investigators offering “expertise that [they] simply are not able to access anywhere else.” Additional collaborative research projects are also presently being discussed, with a £28k project scheduled to commence on July 8th.

Title: Radial vibration measurements directly from rotors using laser vibrometry: The effects of surface roughness, instrument misalignments and pseudo-vibration
AdditionalInformation: Typically laser Doppler vibrometry measurements from rotating structures such measurements are performed with the use of retro-reflective tape surface treatment. Such measurements include cross-sensitivity to motion components other than that of interest (and noise due to the laser speckle effect); much effort has been invested in investigating the significance of this. Recently, however, it was found that polished rotor measurements do not exhibit such an effect and this paper offers the first thorough experimentally validated mathematical treatment of this. Dr. Christian Rembe (c.rembe@polytec.de) of Polytec, GmbH, the world’s leading laser Doppler vibrometry manufacturer, can verify the importance of this output.

Title: Understanding the dynamic behaviour of a tennis racket under play conditions
AdditionalInformation: This research output is the result of an extended international collaboration with a leading Austrian research scientist, Dr Stefan Mohr (s.mohr@head.com), who can corroborate the fact that the research is world-leading. The reputation of the researcher in this area is one of the bases of an international research collaboration with Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, to which the author has been invited to give short courses and research seminars on this and other topics on several occasions in recent years.

Title: The effects of ball impact location and grip tightness on the arm, racquet and ball for one-handed tennis backhand groundstrokes
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this paper has influenced Dr Karl Cooke, Sports Science Manager at the Lawn Tennis Association, to promote the use of regular biomechanics assessment of elite tennis players to better understand and so hopefully avoid injury. Loughborough’s excellence in this field, evidenced in part here, was the basis for the LTA’s recent (2012) willingness to collaborate with the authors on a project to assess potentially injurious behaviour amongst elite tennis players, and continues to inform the research partnership between the two parties. Dr Karl Cooke, LTA

Title: Subject-specific computer simulation model for determining elbow loading in one-handed tennis backhand groundstrokes
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this paper established a theoretical platform for two doctoral theses [Glynn, J (2007) Biomechanics of Tennis Strokes; Kentel, B.B. (2009) Computer simulation of one-handed backhand groundstrokes in tennis]

Title: Evaluation of a subject-specific, torque-driven computer simulation model of one-handed tennis backhand ground strokes
AdditionalInformation: The author's expertise in tennis stroke motion capture and simulation, evidenced here, was the basis for a subsequent successful bid to attract partners and funding through the EPSRC Knowledge Transfer Partnership. Internationally competitive motion-capture equipment manufacturer Charnwood Dynamics recognise that their own standing is enhanced by association with academic partners with the quality of research represented in this paper.

Title: A computer simulation model of tennis racket/ball impacts
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this paper established a theoretical platform for two doctoral theses [Glynn, J (2007) Biomechanics of Tennis Strokes; Kentel, B.B. (2009) Computer simulation of one-handed backhand groundstrokes in tennis]

Title: Reduction and degradation of amyloid aggregates by a pulsed radio-frequency cold atmospheric plasma jet
AdditionalInformation: Working with electrical engineers we have demonstrated that gas plasma treatment is able to eliminate amyloid aggregates from solid surfaces. The latter are widely accepted as a non-infective model for prions. Current methods of sterilising surgical instruments are unable to eradicate prions, and therefore for neurological procedures the instruments are discarded after single use to eliminate the risk of transmitting spongiform encephalopathies. The work was funded by the Department of Health and plans are currently in hand to obtain funding from the NIH in the United States to develop a prototype device for use in hospitals.

Title: Complex responses of microorganisms as a community to a flowing atmospheric plasma
AdditionalInformation: This study was conducted in collaboration with electrical engineers and Camden BRI (a food research organisation). Recognition of the methods used in this work led to an invitation by the European Cooperation in Science and Technology (COST) to participate  in the drawing up of biological standards (COST Action MP1101) aimed at enabling the sterilisation performance of different plasma configurations to be compared. The ultimate objective is to accelerate the introduction of gas plasma technology as a tool for microbial decontamination. This work is currently exploring  additional collaborations with groups in York and Prague.

Title: Cold atmospheric plasma disinfection of cut fruit surfaces contaminated with migrating microorganisms
AdditionalInformation: Although focussing on gas plasma treatment, this work led to the identification of a parameter, the rate of internalisation of bacteria, that would prove useful in assessing the suitability of any surface treatment for fresh produce to ensure maximum decontamination. The wide variety of both spoilage and pathogenic organisms included in the study has led to interest in this work being shown by research groups investigating plasma decontamination of foods and surfaces in general.  The work was funded through Hortlink and conducted in collaboration with commercial food processors.

Title: Effect of preharvest UV-C treatment of tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicon Mill.) on ripening and pathogen resistance
AdditionalInformation: The results published in this work show for the first time that hormetic effects may be induced whilst fruit is still on the vine. This offers new possibilities for applying this form of treatment in commercial glasshouses with the objectives of extending shelf life and achieving a reduction in the huge quantities of fresh produce that are discarded by consumers. Proposals for follow-on funding to investigate the mechanisms induced by hormesis (BBSRC), and strategies for implementing treatment in the horticultural sector (TSB and Horticulture Development Agency) are in progress.

Title: Constrained sintering kinetics of 3YSZ films
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: A customised optical dilatometer has been invented to measure the strain of thick films constrained by a rigid substrate. The dilatometer is able to resolve changes in film thickness of approximately 7nm under isothermal heat treatment conditions at up to 1400°C. The article proved that the apparatus is the only one for accurate kinetic measurements at such high temperature. The dilatometer assists in  understanding  high temperature behaviour of composites/cermets, e.g. SOFCs (Solid Oxide Fuel Cells). DTU (Denmark Technical University) and Forschungszentrum Jülich in Germany both recognised the quality of the work and are utilising the approach for their SOFC research.

Title: Stress induced by constrained sintering of 3YSZ films measured by substrate creep
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This study opened the possibility of measuring internal stresses developed within multi-layered structures. The measured stress can then be utilised to form complicated 3-D composities/cermets via a single heat treatment process, so called co-sintering, using dissimilar powders. This fabrication process enables us to open up a completely new co-fabrication method for functional composites/cermets. The research findings became seminal work for EPSRC funded, MAAD-SOFC, EP/I034059/1; the proposed stress measuring method is being used to understand a life-stress relationship to calculate the life at normal operating conditions. The calculation assists understanding of experimental results from the accelerated life testing of SOFCs.

Title: Constrained sintering of 8mol% Y₂O₃ stabilised zirconia films
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: Optic dilatometer was developed to measure sintering kinetics of a SOFC material, 8YSZ, being  the most common material for SOFC electrolyte layer. The measurement paved the way in understanding the co-sintering behaviour of a multi-layer structure, and proposed a new co-fabrication process that significantly reduces fabrication time and energy consumption, also significantly reducing the manufacturing cost of SOFCs. RRFCS Ltd (merged with LGFCs in 2012) uses the proposed fabrication process for their production of SOFCs. Successful applications will not be limited to SOFC fabrication but will be widened to where structural and functional composites and cermets are required.

Title: Increasing the toughness of nylon 12 by the incorporation of functionalized graphene
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the effect of incorporation of functionalized graphene (FG) on the mechanical properties of nylon12 for the first time worldwide. Just ~0.6 wt% of FG caused a significant improvement in the ultimate tensile strength, elongation, impact strength and toughness. The paper provides new evidence for how graphene can improve the physical properties of polymers and discusses the reinforcement mechanism. The results were also presented at Graphene 2012 held in Belgium and as an invited talk to the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Title: The mechanical properties and morphology of a graphite oxide nanoplatelet/polyurethane composite
AdditionalInformation: This is believed to be the first paper focused on investigating the application of graphene as a coating material. Significant reinforcement of polyurethane (PU) using functionalized graphene (FG) was reported, with the results showing that there is a strong interaction between the FG and the hard, crystalline segment of the PU, which allows effective load transfer. The Young's modulus and hardness of the PU were significantly increased by ~900% and ~325%, respectively. The resultant high resistance to scratching indicates promise for applications of these composite materials in surface coatings.

Title: Highly conductive carbon-nanotube/graphite-oxide hybrid films
AdditionalInformation: This article focuses on the development of hybrid graphene/carbon nanotube films as conductive materials; the preparation, structure and electrical conductivity were reported. Since the paper was published, the concept of hybrid graphene/carbon nanotube materials has been applied to development of field-emission and electrochemical devices and capacitors. The results were also reported as an invited lecture to the Chinese Academy of Sciences. The work has led to a PhD studentship on graphene coatings supported by TATA Steel.

Title: Electrical conductivity of ion-doped graphite/polyethersulphone composites
AdditionalInformation: A doping method was developed for enhancing the electrical conductivity of conductive polymer composites. The electrical conductivity of insulating polyethersulphone (PES) was improved by incorporation of <3 wt% of electrically conductive graphite and ionic compounds such as LiCl. Just 0.06 wt% of the latter enhanced the electrical conductivity by two orders of magnitude and this effect was stable even at high temperatures. The PES based materials could be considered as conductive engineering materials for automotive and aerospace industries. The method is currently being considered for application to the development of low cost heat shrink cable products.

Title: On the energy leakage of discrete wavelet transform
AdditionalInformation: Collaboration with an international Author from Department of Precision Instruments, Tsinghua University. Contact Prof F.L.Chu. chufl@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn. This paper was published from EPSRC IMCRC (£18m) funded work (Project 198), to understand crucial aspects of advanced control of manufacturing machines. Condition monitoring of machines and also the produced workpieces is the research area, the aim being to form a holistic understanding of the machine and process health, so that appropriate action can be taken, either automatically or by manual intervention.

Title: A theoretical analysis of billiard ball dynamics under cushion impacts
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: Adaptive model based operation of machinery is a complex area of research. The work reported in this paper, based around automated cueing in billiards, allowed us to show how adaptivity, with reference to a mathematical model, could be used to enable new levels of machinery performance. By using billiards we could communicate these ideas to a wider audience unaware of the complexities of advanced machinery control. Widely acclaimed by the American Institute of Physics Journal as a fundamental contribution to billiards modelling and understanding. Contact: David P. Jackson, Editor, ajp@dickinson.edu

Title: Active spindle system for a rotary planing machine
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: International Authors from Department of Mechanical Engineering, Politecnico of Milan, Italy, P. Albertelli, M. Monno and G. Bianchi Institute of Industrial Technology and Automation–CNR, Milan, Italy. Contact:  paolo.albertelli@polimi.it. This work was a collaborative effort established during the FP6 Eumecha-pro Network of Excellence. ITIA-CNR in Milan and Polytechnic di Milano placed a staff member in the Loughborough University Mechatronics Research laboratory to create a more complete model of a piezo-electric actuated machine tool spindle that compensates for structural vibration and tool setting errors that influence the tool path through the workpiece and hence the surface quality.

Title: In-process surface profile assessment of rotary machined timber using a dynamic photometric stereo technique
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This work is one of several strands that convinced Rolls-Royce to select Loughborough University to lead the Intelligent Automation theme at the £40 million Manufacturing Technology Centre. This collaboration led to the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Intelligent Automation award, total project value of £12.7 million, which also led to the High Value Manufacturing Catapult Centre award. Contacts: clive.hickman@the-mtc.org, john.brownell@rolls-royce.com.

Title: Iterated upwind schemes for gas dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an international collaboration with the National Centre for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) in Colorado. The paper is first to extend the class of NFT solvers to all speed compressible flows and to document the advantages of entropy conserving methods for low Mach number flows. The proposed, first, unstructured mesh NFT solvers laid foundations for long-term collaborative developments with NCAR. The significance of this new class of solvers for atmospheric research is acknowledged by Dr Andreas Dörnbrack, DLR (The German Aerospace Center), Andreas.Doernbrack@dlr.de who is one of international partners on the follow up £250,000 NERC NE/G004358/1 funded project.

Title: An edge-based unstructured mesh discretisation in geospherical framework
AdditionalInformation: The unprecedented unstructured mesh based numerical simulations of challenging global atmospheric flows and novel technology, contained in the paper, form a background for unstructured mesh developments within the recently awarded US DoE project on Multiscale simulation of moist global atmospheric flows, valued at £430,230 with a travel grant of £8000 allocated to Loughborough University. The new project is lead by W.Grabowski, FRMetS, at the National Center of Atmospheric Research CO USA, with Loughborough University as an international partner. Unstructured meshes will be used in NCAR's future studies of moist atmospheric processes related to climate and climate change; e-mail contact: grabow@ucar.edu

Title: A multidimensional positive definite remapping for Lagrangian solutions of the Noh problem
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports an original and effective numerical treatment for the common, unphysical, wall heating problem which can occur in Arbitrary Lagrangian Eulerian (ALE) multimaterial hydrocodes. The solution exploits unique properties of a novel fully conservative multidimensional positive definite remapping. Multimaterial ALE models are among core technologies used by the Atomic Weapons Establishment (AWE PLC) who has funded (£69,000) and allocated further funds (£75,000) for this bespoke research. Contact: Andy.Barlow@awe.co.uk. (Head of Computational Physics Group). The first author reported this work during invited talks at AWE and the Los Alamos National Laboratory, USA.

Title: An edge-based unstructured mesh framework for atmospheric flows
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a significant contribution to the NERC funded (£254,174) NE/G004358/1 project. It provides evidence about the viability of sound-proof unstructured mesh models. The paper opened new avenues for simulations, that lead to demonstrations of the validity of sound proof models beyond the limits usually assumed from linear analysis; Followed by invited lectures at the Royal Meteorological Society workshop, at NOC and NCAR and a series of minisymposia on sound-proof modeling at SIAM and Frontiers of Computational Physics conferences and the Newton Institute special session,contact Dr Nils Wedi, The European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts, e-mail Nils.Wedi@ecmwf.int.

Title: Plastic deformation of multicrystalline thin films: Grain size distribution vs. grain orientation
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the result of an international collaboration with California Institute of Technology, USA and Loughborough University. The paper demonstrates some of the capabilities of a theory of small scale plasticity. The theory and technique is currently being extended to model amorphous materials in collaboration with Carnegie Mellon University and Loughborough University.

Title: Modeling dislocation sources and size effects at initial yield in continuum plasticity
VolumeTitle: Journal of Mechanics of Materials and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper was a result of an international collaboration with Air Force Research Laboratory, Wright-Patterson Air force base, USA; California Institute of Technology, USA and Carnegie Mellon University, USA. Active research based on this work is being conducted at Loughborough University in collaboration with Carnegie Mellon University, conducted under the aegis of Prof. Acharya (email acharyaamit@cmu.edu) and co-workers. Also related work is being carried out at Laboratoire de Physique et Mécanique des Matériaux, C.N.R.S., France, led by Prof. Claude Fressengeas (email claude.fressengeas@univ-lorraine.fr).

Title: Continuum modeling of dislocation interactions: Why discreteness matters?
AdditionalInformation: Based on this seminal work to characterise the fundamental dislocation interactions in crystalline materials, several research groups, most recently at Oxford (contact C.L.Hall, Cameron.Hall@maths.ox.ac.uk) are extending the technique using discreet-to-continuum aysmptotics. Additionally, several papers based on this work have been published from the Mechanics of Materials Group, Eindhoven University of Technology, The Netherlands. The paper has been cited 38 times till date.

Title: FE/SPH modelling of orthogonal micro-machining of f.c.c. single crystal
AdditionalInformation: This publication is the first work to use an established modelling technique used in astrophysics in the modelling of micro machining processes. The paper demonstrates key improvements in a transformative manufacturing technique, which has since formed the basis of a UK/India (DST/EPSRC) grant worth ~1.2M with LU leading the project. The work is also being showcased by Dassault Systems SIMULIA Corp (the developers of a widely used finite element package ABAQUS; e-mail manoj.chinnakonda@3ds.com) to demonstrate to the industry and academia the wide-ranging advantages of the proposed modelling technique.

Title: Higher mode sound transmission from a point source through a rectangular aperture
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: This paper focused on developing computationally efficient, approximate analysis for sound transmission through apertures over a wide frequency range. The analysis was an extension of previous work by the authors on plane wave sources to point sources that are more representative of engineering situations. The technique developed used simplified analysis to estimate the higher order sound pressure scattered by the aperture from a point source of a known sound pressure level. Unlike other solutions, the technique allows the absolute sound pressure level to be estimated rather than a relative value compared to the source strength.

Title: Effect of geometrical and material imperfections on damping flexural vibrations in plates with attached wedges of power law profile
AdditionalInformation: There is a need to develop methods that will lead to increases in the structural damping in systems without a significant increase in weight and that are simple to apply. This paper demonstrated that the concept of the power law wedge, developed previously theoretically, can be applied to realistic structures and lead to increased overall damping. In particular, the paper considered experimentally the effects of introducing imperfections to the exponential profile of structural elements. It demonstrated that the imperfections, typical of those inherent in mass production manufacturing, do not result in significant reduction of the damping values of the wedges.

Title: A hybrid modal decomposition approach for higher-order modes in circular ducts
AdditionalInformation: Measurement of the sound field in a circular duct over a wide frequency range is complicated and time consuming due to the spiralling wave front of the higher-order modes. This paper developed a technique for simplifying the process by using a limited number of measurement points and a simpler model of the duct. Results demonstrated that the technique can be used to extract the information on the higher-order modes to the same level of accuracy as the standard full calculations and may thus be used for further analysis of the effect of devices inserted in the duct to control noise.

Title: Investigation into higher-order mode propagation through orifice plates in circular ducts
AdditionalInformation: This paper applied the hybrid decomposition techniques developed in an earlier paper by Horner & Hu to establish general observations about the higher acoustic mode transmission through orifice plates installed in circular ducts. A number of different orifice hole locations and combinations were analysed using the hybrid technique. These were then used to establish general rules about higher acoustic mode reflection and transmission from different types of orifice plate. The paper also highlighted the contribution to the overall sound field of the evanescent mode growth that occurs just before the cut-on of each higher order mode.

Title: Vortex breakdown in swirling fuel injector flows
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
AdditionalInformation: Work was funded by the EU FP5 MOLECULES project. The technical auditor, Prof. Jochen Fröhlich, invited collaboration on this subject with Dresden University via Erasmus projects which have continued with the exchange of Masters students for the last 5 years. Numerous research projects have continued on this subject directly funded by Rolls-Royce: applying the techniques and analysis described in this paper to help develop low TRL,commercially sensitive, low emission fuel injector designs.

Title: Comparison of unsteady Reynolds Averaged Navier-Stokes and Large Eddy Simulation Computational Fluid Dynamics Methodologies for Air Swirl Fuel Injectors
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
AdditionalInformation: This work has guided the CFD methodology adopted by Rolls-Royce in designing and developing fuel swirl nozzles, essentially determining the turbulence modelling approach for this class of flows. The researcher having gained his PhD on this subject is now employed by Rolls-Royce and has further developed CFD methodology to enable it to model the effects of volcanic ash clouds on internal components of gas turbines.

Title: Residence time measurement of an isothermal combustor flow field
AdditionalInformation: The methodology detailed herein was successfully used to analyse and diagnose problems with Rolls-Royce (Canada) industrial engines and aided the redesign of the combustor to mitigate emission concerns. This paper presents the methodology that had been developed for this diagnostic study, but as applied to a non-commercially sensitive related combustor flow problem.

Title: Validation of LES Predictions of Scalar Mixing in High-swirl Fuel Injector Flows
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides a unique data validation set for CFD and helps instruct the modelling approach that should be utilised to describe mixture fraction PDF’s. This is essential for the accurate prediction of combustion product composition. It is a long term CFD development that will evolve from this work but is enabled primarily by the existence of the high accuracy, synchronous velocity-scalar measurements and the associated statistics reduced from them.

Title: Design and Implementation of an Integrated Performance Monitoring Tool for Swimming to Extract Stroke Information at Real Time
AdditionalInformation: Outlines the foundations of a performance monitoring system to support elite swimmers in the lead up to the 2012 Olympic games and beyond. Used in extensive testing of Olympic swimmers to determine optimised setups and capabilities for starts and turns. Resulted in significant gains for individual athletes and a revolution in monitoring capability for the UK's elite athletes. Recognised as "world leading" by international experts and migrated to UK development centres. Featured in press and BBC (radio, television). Concepts fundamental to the award of £8.1M EPSRC programme grant “Elite sport performance research in training with pervasive sensing” P24146 (ref: g.z.yang@imperial.ac.uk).

Title: Combining business process and failure modelling to increase yield in electronics manufacturing
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Outlines the development of a novel software toolkit for "right first time" manufacture within the high value, low volume, electronics-manufacturing domain for aerospace and defense systems. The novel architecture structured to enable the integration of a variety of physical, physics-based, experimental and discrete-event models. Demonstrated to predict errors within products identified as the main causes of failure within electronics manufacturing (ref:chris.willie@ge.com). Focus of additional EPSRC (£400k Design for Increased Yield in the electronics manufacturing supply chain) and TSB (£544k EMPATHY: Electronics Manufacturing Process Enhancement Towards High Yields, BD008K) research. Exploitation via EPSRC KTA (£50k) to migrate tool to shop floor.

Title: Innovative virtual prototyping environment for reconfigurable manufacturing system engineering
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The component-based approach to Virtual Engineering detailed in this publication are significant in terms of reduced modelling time and skills required to implement the models (ref: leslie.lee@HSSMI.org) The VPE tools and system architecture outlined has been utilised by distributed engineering partners within the automotive and aerospace industries where the requirement for rapid virtual prototyping, re-configuration and reuse is vital to continued success and the difficulties encountered with the deployment of current proprietary tools (ref: adaly1@ford.com). The work has been fundamental to exploitation and research activities in Virtual Engineering at Loughborough (e.g. £5M EPSRC CIM in Intelligent Automation 09/6664).

Title: Information structure required for life-cycle monitoring of electronic products
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The information that needs to be embedded within an award winning technology (IEEE-I-MAPS UK, 2012) of intelligent devices and sensors into PCB’s that supports reading, writing and generation of lifecycle information is detailed in this paper. The technology has been adopted by collaborators, Invotec Ltd. (ref: viv.amos@invotecgroup.com) in the process of gearing production facilities to offer the capability to customers. Research supported by a TSB award (TP101155-1428-87248-EP/J501748/1: £422k (LU)) and underpins two EPSRC awards (Adaptive Informatics for Intelligent Manufacturing: EP/K014137/1: £1950k (LU) and Knowledge Driven Configurable Manufacturing: EP/K018191/1: £880k (LU)).

Title: Numerical analysis of thermo-mechanical behavior of indium micro-joint at cryogenic temperatures
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents results of several years of research into indium micro-joints for large-scale sensors using a multi-scale finite-element model accounting for main deformation mechanisms in them. Based on the quality of research, the authors were invited to present a Keynote Lecture at the 15th International Symposium on Plasticity 2009 in St. Thomas, USA and an Invited Lecture at the IUTAM Symposium Advanced Materials Modelling for Structures AMMS 2012 in Paris, France. The latter was followed by an invitation to submit a review chapter on the mechanics of microelectronic devices to the book published by Springer in 2013.

Title: Damage in adhesively bonded CFRP joints: Sinusoidal and impact-fatigue
AdditionalInformation: The suggested analysis of a specific loading regime - impact fatigue - allowed prediction of structural integrity of various vibro-impact systems. This led to invitation to join a new British- Polish-Israeli-Ukrainian research collaboration, funded by EU as project "VIBRO-IMPACT MACHINES BASED ON PARAMETRIC RESONANCE: Concepts, mathematical modelling, experimental verification and implementation" (total EUR 1.8m). These results were also presented as a Keynote Lecture at the 8th World Congress on Computational Mechanics in Venice in 2008 and as an Invited Lecture at the International Symposium on Vibro-Impact Dynamics of Ocean Systems and Related Problems 2008 in Troy, Michigan, USA.

Title: Finite element analysis of forces of plane cutting of cortical bone
AdditionalInformation: Advanced finite-element models for analysis of various machining operations developed in the Mechanics of Advanced Materials Research Group at Loughborough (headed by Professor Silberschmidt) led to an invitation to co-ordinate Work Package `Simulations’ within the FP7 European Network `Macro, Micro and Nano Aspects of Machining’ (2008-2012, EUR 3.7m) that involved research institutions from Germany, Switzerland, Finland, Slovakia, Poland and industrial companies (ALSTOM Switzerland, ThyssenKrupp Titanium and Volkswagen). These models were presented in a Plenary Lecture at the 2nd International Conference on Vibro-Impact Systems, Sanya, China in 2010.

Title: Analysis of fracture processes in cortical bone tissue
AdditionalInformation: A first comprehensive analysis of the development of fracture processes in cortical bone, accounting for its microstructure and properties of constituents, led to an invitation to make a presentation at the meeting of Technical Committee 2 on Micromechanisms of the European Structural Integrity Society at Oxford in 2012. It was also presented as an Invited Lecture at the IUTAM symposium "Fracture phenomena in nature and technology" in 2012 in Brescia, Italy. As a result of high quality of obtained results, it was suggested to submit an invited paper to the Special Issue of this journal.

Title: Bio-plastics in the context of competing demands on agricultural land in 2050
AdditionalInformation: Paper requested by Wuppertal Institute for preparation of "land and soil report 2012” (helmut.schuetz@wupperinst.org) and used in presentation to European Parliament by Friends of the Earth “Policies to tackle Europe’s land dependency November 2011” (http://ec.europa.eu/environment/soil/pdf/may2012/10%20-%20Michael%20Warhurst%20-%20final.pdf). Informed Greenpeace’s ‘land use policy’ 2012 (ikruszew@greenpeace.org). Invited to RCUK sandpits: Bioenergy Scoping Workshop, April 2012; SUPERGEN Bioenergy, October 2012; EPSRC resource efficiency, July 2012. Invited to lecture on paper UCL, January 2013. Paper has been downloaded 84 times and has over 100 views (researchgate and publisher statistics). Has been cited in successful bids to the value of £4.5Million e.g. EPSRC Centre for Food Manufacturing.

Title: Human performance index -A generic performance indicator
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This work arose from an EPSRC funded UK/Japan Network on Human Adaptive Mechatronics.  The mix of human skill elicitation and automation enabled activities with the MTC and further EPSRC and Industry funded National Centre of Excellence in Intelligent Automation (£10.8m) – Industrial Partners Rolls-Royce, Airbus, AEC, Ford, Nissan.  Via the MTC it also links to the HVM Catapult Centre.  Contact John Brownell (John Brownell@rolls-royce.com).  Clive Hickman (clive.hickman@the-mtc.org).

Title: The use of aerial images and GPS for mobile robot waypoint navigation
AdditionalInformation: Interdisciplinary project linking Engineers and Geographers (Parkin, Chandler) with international authors from UNAM, Mexico and the fusion of camera images with GPS for improved navigation.  Contact Prof Gonzalez-Villela (vjgv@unam.mx), Prof Tarn – citer of the work (tarn@wuauto.wustl.edu)

Title: A New Project Scheduling Approach for Improving Multi Product Multi-Period Production Planning Problems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes collaborative work with the Narmak, Tehran and the Department of Industrial Engineering, Islamic Azad University, Shiraz Branch, Iran, thus includes International Authors.  Contact Prof S Noori, (snoori@iust.ac.ir) from the Iran University of Science and Technology and Dr Zorriassatine from the Islamic Azad University (far.zor@gmail.com).

Title: Vibration characteristics of MR cantilever sandwich beams: Experimental study
AdditionalInformation: Internationally collaborative work with Magneto-rheological specialists at the University of Radom, Poland and ITESM, Mexico. The inclusion of smart machine elements to intelligent machines gave capability which fed forward to Rolls-Royce selecting Loughborough to lead the Intelligent Automation theme within the MTC. Contacts Prof Z Kesy (zkesy@interia.pl), Prof Snamina – citer of the work (snamina@agh.edu.pl), John Brownell (John Brownell@rolls-royce.com).  Clive Hickman (clive.hickman@the-mtc.org).

Title: Surface modification of chromatography adsorbents by low temperature low pressure plasma
AdditionalInformation: The output has led to an on-going academic collaboration with Dr James Walsh from the Department of Electrical Engineering and Electronics, University of Liverpool (J.L.Walsh@liverpool.ac.uk). Two more papers on the use of cold atmospheric plasmas to modify chromatography supports are in preparation and will be submitted to ‘Applied Physics Letters’ and the ‘Journal of Chromatography A’ early next year. Further, this output has led to a collaborative PhD project between the University of Birmingham and University College London funded by the Centre for Doctoral Training in the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Emergent Macromolecular Therapies.

Title: Multi-cycle recovery of lactoferrin and lactoperoxidase from crude whey using fimbriated high-capacity magnetic cation exchangers and a novel "rotor-stator" high-gradient magnetic separator
AdditionalInformation: The output, which was funded by EU FP6 STRP (NanoBioMag) shows how far the technique of High-Gradient Magnetic Fishing has come since its invention a decade ago, i.e. to the brink of commercialization and on-site testing within the bioprocess industry sector. Its findings played an important role in securing a follow-up 17 partner strong European Framework 7 Large-Scale Collaborative Integrating Project (MagPro2Life). The rotor-stator magnetic separator described in this work is currently available as a commercial prototype through PerkinElmer chemagen Technologie GmbH & ABBIS bio process automation (Vulkan Technic Maschinen-Konstruktions GmbH).

Title: Integrated system for temperature-controlled fast protein liquid chromatography comprising improved copolymer modified beaded agarose adsorbents and a travelling cooling zone reactor arrangement
AdditionalInformation: This is the first in a series of outputs concerning the advance of a radical integrated approach to chromatography exploiting ‘smart’ materials and new column hardware for the recovery and purification of macromolecular targets. The work was funded by a €12M European Framework 7 Large-Scale Collaborative Integrating Project ( ‘Advanced Magnetic Nanoparticles Deliver Smart Processes And Products For Life’, MagPro2Life) aimed at delivering leaner, greener and more sustainable manufacturing technology for valuable bio-commodities. The MagPro2Life consortium features 15 partner institutions and 10 leading academic groups.

Title: Phased mission modelling of systems with maintenance-free operating periods using simulated Petri nets
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to efficiently analyse the performance of maintenance free operating periods applying techniques that enables the analysis of fleets of units such as aircraft. The work was sponsored by BAE Systems, underpinning their research into the effectiveness of maintenance free operating periods.

Title: A numerical model of fibrous filters containing deposit
AdditionalInformation: The work developed in this paper was considered to be leading research in the area of filtration modelling by Professor Colbeck, University of Essex, and led to an invitation to write a chapter on filtration for a forthcoming book on aerosol science. This will be published in Aerosol Science, Technology and Applications,  Publishers: John Wiley and Sons, Editors: Ian Colbeck and Mihalis Lazaridis.

Title: Numerical investigation into the loading behaviour of filters operating in the diffusional and interception deposition regimes
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to efficiently model the evolution of particulate deposit within a filter using a straightforward numerical approach. It led to an on-going dialogue with Dyson Ltd who are interested in collaborating to develop the model further (contact; Kay Yeong)

Title: Improved efficiency in the analysis of phased mission systems with multiple failure mode components
AdditionalInformation: Invited to contribute to a special section on Reliability and Risk Assessment of Complex Systems in IEEE Transactions on Reliability. This paper introduced a new efficient method of analysis of phased mission systems enabling decisions on mission configuration to be undertaken in real time for aeronautical systems. Sponsored by BAE Systems.

Title: A Methodology to investigate the relationship between lower-limb dynamics and shoe stiffness using custom-built footwear
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART P-JOURNAL OF SPORTS ENGINEERING AND TECHNOLOGY
AdditionalInformation: The research culminating in this publication was EPSRC funded (£1,095,013); Caine (CI). Cash contributing collaborators included, athletic shoe manufacturer, New Balance. Using ‘world-first’ techniques documented in the paper, customised footwear was developed using additive manufacturing and worn by performance athletes including Paralympian, Ben Rushgrove, as captured in the Channel 4 documentary, ‘BEN’, broadcast on 18/08/12. New Balance (contact: Robert.Odonnell@newbalance.com) are scaling up additive manufacturing of footwear as a result of this research. The work published here led to Caine being invited to Co-Chair a Royal Academy of Engineering International Conference, "How can sport drive engineering innovation?"

Title: Design, manufacture, and evaluation of traction features on sprint footwear using laser sintered nylon-12 sole units
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART P-JOURNAL OF SPORTS ENGINEERING AND TECHNOLOGY
AdditionalInformation: The research culminating in this publication was EPSRC funded (£1,095,013); Caine (CI). Cash contributing collaborators included, athletic shoe manufacturer, New Balance. Numerous proprietary processes and technologies were developed (one of which was patented, WO2010049725; 2010-05-06; inventors include Caine), including that described in the paper. Research presented in this paper was delivered by Caine in a Keynote Address, at the request of David Delpy, CEO, EPSRC, to R&D policy makers at the Science Museum as part of their 'Made in GB' exhibition. First author (Vinet), was head-hunted by Nike based on her presentation of this work at a conference in Austria.

Title: Design and testing of a novel interactive playground device
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Research underpinning this publication was EPSRC funded (£161,160); M.P. Caine (PI). Additional cash and in-kind support was provided by UK outdoor playground equipment manufacturer, Playdale (Managing Director, John Croasdale; JC@playdale.co.uk; 01539 539770) to fund a PhD student (Hodgkins, P). This publication, describes the development and validation of an interactive device encouraging health-enhancing physical activity amongst children. The proprietary technology was granted a patent (GB2444707, 2008-06-18; inventors Caine and Hodgkins). Sales of the device, manufactured in the UK, exceed £1M. The published technology won the Ispo-TUM Academic Challenge Innovation Award in (2006) and the Lord Stafford Innovation Achieved Award (2008).

Title: Benchmarking the ball-garment frictional properties of rugby union shirts
AdditionalInformation: The research culminating in this publication was partially funded (£69,135) by the EPSRC and industrial collaborator, Nike (contact: Rens.Tukker@Nike.com). The paper describes a novel methodology for ascertaining dynamic friction forces during shirt–ball interactions and is the first to report such properties in sports apparel. The research presented in the paper was fundamental to the development of Nike’s 2007 and 2011 Rugby World Cup garments (worn by the England and French teams). This paper resulted in an invite to author a Commentary with colleagues from MIT, entitled, “Materials and Technology in Sport,” in Nature Materials (Impact Factor >32).

Title: An Alternative Formulation of the Dynamic Transmission Error to Study the Oscillations of Automotive Hypoid Gears
VolumeTitle: Journal of Vibration and Acoustics: Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This investigation led for the first time to a direct connection between Noise, Vibration and Harshness (NVH) severity and the geometric features of hypoid gears (automotive differentials) under realistic torque/vehicle speed conditions. The importance of this research is recognised by industry and the main conclusions are taken aboard to improve the existing NVH assessment tools (confirmation may be sought from Prof. Patrick Kelly, Clutch System Technical Specialist, Ford R&A Engineering Europe, e-mail: pkelly7@ford.com). Results of this work have also led to an invited lecture entitled “Developments in Transmissions and Driveline Efficiency” (IMechE, Automobile Division, 2012).

Title: On the dynamics of lubricated hypoid gears
AdditionalInformation: This work has investigated the dynamics of hypoid gears (in automotive differentials) under high load capacity.
