The quest towards lower CO2 emission has increased the focus on alternative powering systems (electric and hybrid drives) and to their Noise, Vibration and Harshness (NVH) behaviour. Therefore, novel analysis techniques are required to predict the dynamics of their sub-systems. The recognition of the co-author’s expertise in this area led to an invitation to join the TU1105 COST Action (http://www.cost.eu/domains_actions/tud/Actions/TU1105). Confirmation may be sought by Ms Nuria Campillo_Davo (Chair of the Action), Universidad Miguel Hernandez de Elche (email: ncampillo@umh.es).

Title: Non-linear vibro-impact phenomenon belying transmission idle rattle
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: The major findings of the EPSRC funded research project EP/D050332/1 (2006 - 2009) on transient oscillations in manual automotive transmissions were presented in this paper. The latter is the most expensive Noise, Vibration and Harshness concern that automotive industry is facing nowadays in terms of warranties. The paper culminated in an effective multi-physics predictive method, the findings of which struck an accord with the key interests of Ford Motor Company, affecting their approach to investigate NVH issues (confirmation may be sought from Mr Duncan Metcalfe, Manual Transmission Systems - Core Engineering Supervisor, Ford PD Europe, e-mail: dmetcal1@ford.com).

Title:
Transient Tribo-Dynamics of Thermo-Elastic Compliant
High-Performance Piston Skirts
AdditionalInformation: Major findings of the EPSRC funded Programme Grant Encyclopaedic EP/G012334/1 (£2.1M with 3 academic institutions and 6 industrial partners, 2009 - 2013) were presented in this paper, which comes as the result of collaborative work between three of the project partners (Loughborough University, Sheffield University and Capricorn Automotive Ltd). The necessity for a multi-physics, transient approach when designing piston skirts for high performance applications has recently received increased attention from industry. This statement can be corroborated by Dr Brian Fitzsimons, Chief Engineer - Powertrain, Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd, e-mail: bfitzsim@astonmartin.com).

Title: Measuring Pore Diameter Distribution of Gelcast Ceramic Foams from Two-Dimensional Cross Sections
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: The detailed knowledge of substrate evaluation method contributed directly to the initiation of a 4.5 year research program (£559,246) into particulate filter substrates with Jaguar Land Rover [Ken Hansen, Jaguar Land Rover, khanse21@JaguarLandRover.com]. In addition, the conclusions of this paper are now being used directly by  Department of Ceramics Glass and Cement at the Slovak Technical University, Slovakia to advance manufacturing processes and generate accurate library data of porous material characteristics for use in building, catalysis, thermal and acoustic insulation and filtration industries [e.g. Bazelova et al, Ceramics – Silikaty v55(3) 240-245].

Title: Analysis and optimization of gel-cast ceramic foam diesel particulate filter performance
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The test methods shown were a primary factor in the decision of Jaguar Land Rover to initiate a 4.5 year research program (£559,246) continuing this research theme [Ken Hansen, Jaguar Land Rover, khanse21@JaguarLandRover.com]. It had a direct impact on the technology decisions regarding gelcast ceramic foams as diesel particulate filters within Caterpillar [David Heaton, Caterpillar, Heaton_David@cat.com].

Title: Turbo-discharging turbocharged internal combustion engines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This invited article is the only published data showing the performance of Turbo-Discharging applied to turbocharged engines. This research was pivotal in attracting circa £1m investment to develop and exploit the technology with AltEnergis which required a level of confidence in the interaction between turbo-charging and turbo-discharging systems. The ability to analyse complex air systems demonstrated in this paper led to an invitation to work with Caterpillar on their Energy Technologies Institute sponsored Heavy Duty Vehicle Efficiency Program [Paul Moore, HDV Efficiency Program Lead, Moore_Paul@cat.com].

Title: Electrodeposition and characterisation of Sn-Ag-Cu solder alloys for flip-chip interconnection
AdditionalInformation: The paper combines successful electrodeposition from complex electrolyte formulations coupled with the difficulty of simultaneously depositing three disparate metals.   A successful conclusion was the production of finely shaped arrays at the micron level.   The work has stimulated conference presentations at the Electronics Packaging Conference, Singapore (December 2009) and Electronic Components and Technology Conference, Las Vegas, USA (June 2010).

Title: Electrodeposition and Characterization of Eutectic Sn-Ag Alloy as Solder Bumps for Flip-Chip Interconnection
AdditionalInformation: A paper describing the electrodeposition of a lead free solder alloy for electronic chip interconnection.  The paper combines electrodeposition from complex electrolyte formulations producing finely shaped arrays at the micron level. The work stimulated a conference paper at the International Conference on Electronic Packaging, Beijing, China (August 2009).

Title: Tin-manganese alloy electrodeposits - II. Corrosion performance studies
AdditionalInformation: The discovery of tin whisker growth from this alloy coating began our research into this phenomenon.  This has resulted in a IeMRC/EPSRC grant (£440K FEC) and invited keynote lectures at the Institute of Metal Finishing AGM (2012) and plenary lecture at the World Interfinish Conference 2012 (Milan, Italy).  It has established Loughborough as an important world centre of metallic whisker research (which can be substantiated by R.W.Gregory, Rolls Royce Submarines bob.gregory1@rolls-royce.com) culminating in the 6th International Tin Whiskers Symposium (organised jointly with the University of Maryland, November 2012), being held at Loughborough.

Title: Responsive behaviour of galvanic anodes in concrete and the basis for its utilisation
AdditionalInformation: The effects of rainfall and fluctuations in temperature were monitored, clearly showing, for the first time, that the current outputs of zinc and steel anodes correspond to the activity of the steel reinforcing bar that they are protecting.  The methodology of this work was extended to concrete repair treatments subsequently culminating in an international conference paper at Corrosion 2011 (Houston, Texas, USA,  March 2011).

Title: Application of filtration blocking models to describe fouling and transmission of large plasmids DNA in sterile filtration
AdditionalInformation: The paper summarises findings of collaborative project between Loughborough University and the EPSRC IMRC in Bioprocessing in the Biochemical Engineering department of UCL http://www.ucl.ac.uk/biochemeng/industry/imrc .  It forms part of a major program of pre-competitive research on bioprocessing of plasmid DNA to ensure safe production of novel therapeutic vectors.  The UCL IMRC collaborates with a range of leading Healthcare businesses, including GSK, Pfizer, Merck, and many others. http://www.ucl.ac.uk/biochemeng/industry/imrc/UCL_text_2011_FINAL_-_Print_Ready.pdf. Examples of the potential gene therapeutic applications are summarised at the website of the Cystic Fibrosis Gene Therapy Consortium: http://www.cfgenetherapy.org.uk/research/aerosol.html

Title: A validated model of GAG deposition, cell distribution, and growth of tissue engineered cartilage cultured in a rotating bioreactor
AdditionalInformation: This theoretical study of engineered tissue growth reported in this paper has been the first publication to successfully model cartilage tissue growth on the basis of a prior knowledge of cell population and extra-cellular matrix production and destruction rates.  The work came out of the EPSRC Grand Challenge project “Regenerative Medicine – a New Industry” led by Prof David Williams at Loughborough University  and in collaboration with Keele University and Nottingham University (£4,200,000).  It feeds into ongoing activity in the manufacture of mechanically stimulated intervertebral disk tissues.

Title: Numerical investigation on fluid flow of gear lubrication
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Fuels and Lubricants
AdditionalInformation:
The paper reports the first study of the oil-air multiphase flow in a model gear box using
computational fluid dynamics and optical diagnostics. The work was part of TSB-sponsored project KTP 001293 (value £198,088) entitled “Development of a model for vehicle manual transmissions design” in collaboration with Romax Technology Ltd. The findings of this project, including the improved understanding of oil flows and lubrications in gear boxes, have been used by the company to develop their digital simulation tools and engineering design solutions for transmissions and driveline systems including Romax Designer  http://www.romaxtech.com/products/romaxdesigner.aspx .

Title: The Arrival of Genetic Engineering Strategies for Delivery of Nonviral Plasmid DNA-Based Gene Therapy
VolumeTitle: IEEE ENGINEERING IN MEDICINE AND BIOLOGY MAGAZINE
AdditionalInformation:
The paper provides a major review of therapeutic gene delivery methods as well as brief summaries
of findings of work at Loughborough University on aerosolisation of aqueous plasmid DNA solution
by means of a commercially available nebuliser. The work was part of a collaborative project with
Professor Mike Hoare at Biochemical Engineering department of University College London and
forms part of an integrated strategy for bioprocessing, formulation and delivery. The website of the Cystic Fibrosis Gene Therapy Consortium identifies the attractiveness of the
aerosol route for non-invasive treatment of CF: 
http://www.cfgenetherapy.org.uk/research/aerosol.html

Title: Measurement of the mechanical properties of granular packs by wavelength-scanning interferometry
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports the outcomes of a long-standing project to measure with unprecedented accuracy the force distributions, at the individual grain level, on the boundaries of granular bead packs. An invited paper on this project was presented at the Gordon Conference on ‘Granular and Granular-Fluid Flow’ in Oxford.

Title: 3D Heterogeneous stiffness reconstruction using MRI and the virtual fields method
AdditionalInformation: The Virtual Fields Method (VFM) provides a direct measure of spatial distributions of material mechanical properties from full-field experimental data and is far superior to iterative schemes based on the finite element method. This paper, the result of an international collaboration with a US and two French groups, reports the first extension from the usual two dimensional samples to fully three dimensional datasets. It provided the theoretical foundations for a successful £430k EPSRC grant proposal (EP/F02861X/1, 2008-2011) which addressed the problem of mapping three-dimensional modulus distributions in damaged composites.

Title: Convection in three-dimensional vibrofluidized granular beds
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides the first comparison between experimental 3D convection patterns within a rapid granular flow, and those predicted by a finite element model. The research was initiated during the Granular Physics programme at the Kavli Institute of Theoretical Physics, University of California at Santa Barbara, at which Prof Huntley was an invited long term participant.

Title: Single-shot profilometry of rough surfaces using hyperspectral interferometry
AdditionalInformation: Hyperspectral Interferometry, invented by Huntley and co-workers, is protected by international patent application PCT/GB2010/001379. Developments funded by a Royal Society Brian Mercer Feasibility Award and regional Innovation Fellowship have resulted in a recent Heads of Terms agreement with Renishaw to license the IP. The technology is now being developed further with Dr Ruiz seconded for 30 months to Renishaw under a Royal Society-funded Industry Fellowship.

Title: Simulation of photosensor-based hairiness measurement using digital image analysis
AdditionalInformation: The hairiness of yarns is a very important characteristic of textile yarns, which requires accurate measurements. Instruments available in industry are typically photosensor based and their accuracy is limited by the nature of the sensor. This paper demonstrates an application of the prize winning (2006 Charles E Ives Award, J. of Electronic Imaging) digital image processing and illumination techniques, previously developed by the authors, to an unparalleled simulation of the industrially used photo-sensor devices to achieve a more accurate measurement of yarn hairiness. (Professor Dominique Adolphe, Textiles Mechanics and Physics laboratory, ENSISA, the Université de Haute-Alsace (UHA), dominique.adolphe@uha.fr)

Title: Yarn twist measurement using digital imaging
AdditionalInformation: Yarn twist measurements are typically destructive and time consuming. This paper reports a non-destructive yarn twist measurement using digital image processing technique, which was first to combine back and front lighting together with a hybrid frequency and spatial domain analysis. The methods developed enabled a fast and accurate measurement of yarn twist, which is an important parameter that affects the structural integrity of textile yarns. (Dr Hugh Gong, Reader, Yarn and Nonwovens Technology; School of Materials, The University of Manchester, hugh.gong@manchester.ac.uk).

Title: Finite element simulation of low-density thermally bonded nonwoven materials: Effects of orientation distribution function and arrangement of bond points
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of publications originating from the collaborative work with the Nonwovens Cooperative Research Center, NC State University, Raleigh, NC, with a history dating back to 1998. Modelling anisotropic, non-homogeneous, discontinuous, highly non-linear and flexible structures is a very challenging task. This paper reports an approach to the modelling of nonwoven fabrics consisting of solid bond points dispersed in a random fibre matrix that combines first time the micromechanical properties of fibres, the orientation distribution of fibres and the bond pattern used for bonding the nonwoven. (Professor Behnam Pourdeyhimi, Director of the Nonwovens Institute; email: bpourdey@ncsu.edu)

Title: A parametric finite element analysis method for low-density thermally bonded nonwovens
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative work with the Nonwovens Institute, NC, is the first parametric approach to modelling of discontinuous, anisotropic, non-homogeneous and highly nonlinear structure of nonwovens. The problem of developing a new model every time time for a different structure has been solved by the parametric modelling technique, which allows simulating complicated patterns and structures. This work sets the standards and leads the research in this field.  (Professor Behnam Pourdeyhimi, Director of the Nonwovens Institute, North Carolina, USA; email: bpourdey@ncsu.edu)

Title: Development and evaluation of new control algorithms for a mechanical golf swing device
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents latest developments of a unique robotic simulator. The importance of this work is recognised by Paul Wood, "It is an extremely complex engineering problem to create a machine that can swing with great accuracy and repeatability but that will also mimic a human swing to a satisfactory degree. Any development of a more advanced golf swing robot that could be shown to mimic a human swing better than existing technology while maintaining reliability and repeatability would be of great interest to both club and ball manufacturers." (Research Engineering Manager, Ping Golf USA, paulw@ping.com, +1 602 687 5419)

Title: Measurement and analysis of grip force during a golf shot
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first major in-depth study of the dynamic grip force applied during a golf swing. The project was conducted in collaboration with Callaway Golf (USA). The authors were invited by Kim Blair (Cooper Perkins, +1 781-266-6375, kbb@cooperperkins.com) to present the work at the Better Golf Through Technology conference at MIT attended by leading biomechanists and coaches in the USA. The research also led to a £150k grant from the EPSRC (IMCRC) to develop a human grip simulator for robotic testing of sports equipment.

Title: The use of structured relationship modelling techniques as a tool to elicit customizable product features
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents a wider field of research investigating the relationship between players' perceptions of sports equipment and product design/performance. Research has been conducted with leading manufacturers (Callaway Golf, Dunlop Slazenger, HEAD Sport, adidas) and sports governing bodies (FIFA, English Hockey, GB Taekwondo) leading to ten journal publications. The quality of this work was recently recognised by FIFA, who commissioned a research programme worth >£200k (cash) to ensure player opinion informs future improvements in playing surface developments (Stuart Larman, Fédération Internationale de Football Association, +41(0)43-222 7516, stuart.larman@fifa.org).

Title: Determining the effect of cricket leg guards on running performance
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents work completed as part of a £1.4m research project (EPSRC (IMCRC) and industrial cash) into personal protective equipment worn in sport in collaboration with leading manufacturers (adidas, Dunlop Slazenger) and governing bodies (GB Taekwondo, MCC). The paper investigates the inhibition of running motion caused by protective equipment and makes design recommendations that will be of particular relevance to manufacturers of cricket leg guards.

Title: 3D reconstruction of a gas diffusion layer and a microporous layer
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this paper established a new, multi-disciplinary methodology for studying gas diffusion performance in fuel cells. We enhanced the traditional lattice Boltzmann numerical model to study the gas diffusion mechanisms by equipping with real-world sub-micron structures obtained from X-Ray tomography. This revealed the relationships between material structure and fuel cell performance. The results formed design guidelines for a next generation gas diffusion layer by Technical Fibre Products and, as a result of the work, Chen was invited to give a lecture at Beihang University in 2012 and received an Adjunct Professorship at Tianjin University, both in China.

Title: A multi-function compact fuel reforming reactor for fuel cell applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported a new approach to combining a range of chemical reactions, including burner, reformer and CO selective catalytic reductions, efficiently into a single unit. This involved developing new methods for thermal energy management, advanced heat exchanger technology, system temperature control and thermal flow analysis. Efforts in system optimisation of this complicated thermal system through energy conservation analysis initiated a subsequent study of entropy generation minimisation. It led to a three-year EPSRC and BAE Systems co-sponsored research project on avionic environment control systems and subsequently the concept was developed into an engineering product by Intelligent Energy Ltd.

Title: Simulation of liquid water breakthrough in a nanotomography reconstruction of a carbon paper gas-diffusion layer
AdditionalInformation: Reported the successful completion of the TSB funded project TP/6/DAM/6/S/K3032H. The project has been described by the TSB project management officer, Mr. Norman Bolton, as the most successful and productive project he has supervised. 3 PhDs, over 20 publications and significant improvements in fuel cell performances as direct outputs of the project were achieved. (Contact: Mr. Norman Bolton, email: normanbolton@virginmedia.com)

Title: Kinetic study of NaBH4 hydrolysis over carbon-supported ruthenium
AdditionalInformation: NaBH4 hydrolysis over carbon-supported ruthenium is a promising alternative hydrogen storage concept and this paper reported the kinetic mechanisms involved and the methodology for optimising the concept. We expanded the existing understanding of NaBH4 in NaOH solution and NaBO2 in water, and developed the mechanism of NaBH4 hydrolysis in NaBH4, NaBO2 and NaOH solutions. As a result of the work, Chen was invited to deliver a series of lectures in the field at Jilin University in 2012 and Intelligent Energy Ltd is currently looking to develop the concept into a portable hydrogen storage system for next generation mobile phone applications

Title: Tribology of piston compression ring conjunction under transient thermal mixed regime of lubrication
AdditionalInformation: A fast analytical approach, yet with scientific rigour is developed for thermo-elastohydrodynamic analysis. The paper is well received and already cited several times in a short period. The approach used is favoured for industrial applications and already adopted by some leading bearing and seal manufacturers, working with the author. The statements made can be verified by Mr Phil Carden, Senior Analyst at Ricardo: Phil.Carden@ricardo.com

Title: Transient elastohydrodynamic lubrication of rough new or worn piston compression ring conjunction with an out-of-round cylinder bore
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART J-JOURNAL OF ENGINEERING TRIBOLOGY
AdditionalInformation: Predictive methods are often devoid of salient features of the physical systems. For the compression ring/cylinder liner conjunction in internal combustion engines, the important issues include prediction of parasitic frictional losses from realistic out-of-round cylinders with progressively worn ring profiles and corresponding effect on emissions. The essence of this approach, not hitherto reported in literature, improves the validity and quality of predictions which can be relied upon and improve the industrial research and development practice. The developed approach is adopted by Capricorn Automotive for advanced piston-cylinder systems and can be verified by Dr Sebastian Howell-Smith, Technical Director at Capricorn: Sebastian.Howell.Smith@capricornauto.co.uk

Title: An analytical approach for analysis and optimisation of slider bearings with infinite width parallel textures
AdditionalInformation: Contrary to traditional belief, it has been shown that roughening of conjunctional surfaces with textured patterns can mitigate the undesired effects of frictional losses. However, optimisation of texture geometry and patterns has not been ascertained, leading to a plethora of ad hoc testing. This paper provided the first comprehensive multi-objective optimisation analysis of lubricated slider bearings with mechanically engineered (textured) surface(s). The approach was adopted for piston-ring/cylinder liner contact showing desired practical outcomes, which can be verified by Dr David Adams, Senior Technologist at Ford: DAdams@ford.com

Title: Thermo-mixed hydrodynamics of piston compression ring conjunction
AdditionalInformation: The cavitation phenomenon has paradoxical effects in lubricated conjunctions. It can reduce friction, whilst adversely affecting load carrying capacity. It can promote sealing functionality, whilst at the same time causing surface erosion. A fundamental study taking into account the mechanism of cavitation and its effects has been long overdue for sliding contacts, requiring detailed combined CFD, rheological modelling and thermal analyses. This paper combines these features with rough surface topography providing the basis for quality-based research and development work in industry. This statement can be corroborated by Dr Chris Warrens, Senior Technologist at BP Castrol: Chris.Warrens@bp.com

Title: Nonaqueous polymerization of vinyl chloride: An environmentally friendly process
AdditionalInformation: The work, funded by EPSRC and supported by the VinylSum network in collaboration with INEOS Chlor Vinyls, UK, aimed to improve the environmental impact of PVC, following campaigns by Greenpeace. The paper established the feasibility of a non-aqueous process and led to a subsequent research grant awarded by the Norwegian government. The project partners for the process scale-up were the Norwegian Polymer Institute, Norner, Ineos UK and Ineos Norway. The process can potentially be applied by the suspension polymer industries to reduce energy requirements.

Title: Dispersion of nanoparticles in poly(vinyl chloride) grains during in situ polymerization
AdditionalInformation: The work aimed to improve the sustainability of PVC through the development of nanocomposites and was funded by the EPSRC VinylSum network (www.vinylsum.org.uk/), in collaboration with Ineos Chlor Vinyls, UK. The paper used a reliable experimental method to investigate the dispersion patterns of nanoparticles in nanocomposites produced via in situ polymerisation. The findings were presented at the International PVC conference (UK), and at the IOM3 meeting on ‘Innovation through Sustainable Materials’. The work attracted interest and visitors from nano-particle additives industries (Solvay and Elkem).

Title: Synthesis and micellization of a pH-sensitive diblock copolymer for drug delivery
AdditionalInformation: The PhD studentship was competitively awarded by the LU Graduate School. This new polymer offers a ‘universal’ drug delivery system - it encapsulates drugs without conjugation. The work will be presented at the ‘Frontiers of polymer colloids’ conference, Prague, July 2014. The paper created opportunities for collaboration with the University of Claude Bernard, Lyon, France (charcosset@lagep.cpe.fr), which led to the publication of a second journal paper ‘pH sensitive micelles for targeted drug delivery prepared using a Novel membrane contactor method’ in ‘Applied Materials & Interfaces’ ). It has also provided data for new EPSRC and EU grant applications.

Title: Aggregation effects in the cake filtration of interacting binary mixtures
AdditionalInformation: The paper proposed a new model for a poorly researched, but industrially important, technical area.  As a direct result of this published work the research student, Kuhan Chellappah, was employed by BP and subsequently shortlisted for the Tallow Chandlers Award.  The journal paper provided the basis for an invited presentation on ‘Filtration of fibre/particle mixtures’ at the 11th World Filtration Congress in Graz, Austria  and a follow up paper by Chellappah has been shortlisted for The Filtration Society Suttle Award.

Title: Penicillin G solubilisation into AOT reverse micelles
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a practical investigation of a growing research area.  The research student, Siti Mohd Sepatar, was awarded 2nd prize for her presentation of the paper at the IChemE competition ‘What’s new in Fluid Separations?’ held at GSK in Stevenage, UK in 2008.  Mohd Sepatar has since continued work in this area in her home country of Malaysia and been awarded a patent, research grants and silver and gold medal awards at  INATEX exhibitions.

Title: Nanofiltration: A technology for selective solute removal from fuels and solvents
AdditionalInformation: Preliminary investigation into the application of nanofiltration to a new area led to an invitation to give a plenary paper ‘The transport mechanism in organic solvent nanofiltration – convective or diffusive’ at the 3rd International Organic Solvent Nanofiltration conference (2010) at Imperial College, UK.  The work also led to a joint research application ‘Separation mechanisms in non-aqueous nanofiltration: Membrane swelling effects’ with Prof. Kuo-Lun Tung, National Taiwan University (kuolun@cycu.edu.tw).

Title: Cake filter scale-up, simulation and data acquisition - A new approach
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Chinese Institute of Chemical Engineers
AdditionalInformation: The paper, invited for a Festschrift issue in honour of Prof. Shiao-Hung Chiang, describes concepts that underpin development of Filter Design Software used by many multinational companies (e.g. Clear Edge, Friesland Foods, BASF, Akzo). The work led to a plenary ‘Filter selection, scale-up and simulation in the 21st century’ at 2009 AFS conference in Minneapolis, USA, and a keynote  ‘Equipment selection and process design for solid/liquid separation’ at 2011 Filtech conference in Wiesbaden, Germany.  Partly as a result of this paper, in 2011 EST was invited to be Editor-in-Chief for an Elsevier major reference work ‘Filtration and separation handbook’.

Title: Combined EBSD/EDS tomography in a dual-beam FIB/FEG-SEM
AdditionalInformation: This was the first paper to report an automated combined Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD)/Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) collection procedure and data set.  This is significant because a large proportion of the dual beam instruments world-wide were bought specifically for 3D serial sectioning and combined EBSD/EDS is the pinnacle of 3D analysis in a dual beam.  Shortly after this work was published I was invited to present this work first at Microscience (Jun 2010) and then at the National Institute of Materials Science in Japan (Sept 2010).

Title: Role of Elemental Sublimation during Solution Heat Treatment of Ni-Based Superalloys
AdditionalInformation: In this paper the role of evaporation and oxidation on structural instability during solution heat treatment of Ni-based superalloys is investigated.  A new mechanism for surface defect formation is proposed that challenges the conventional design of heat treatment protocols for common single crystal superalloys.  This initial collaboration with the Rolls-Royce castings group has expanded into an ongoing collaboration, which has resulted in a further publication (also submitted to Metallurgical and Materials Transactions), a conference presentation (abstract submitted for Superalloys 2014) and invitations to contribute at regular internal casting review meetings.

Title: Evaluating surface deformation and near surface strain hardening resulting from shot peening a tempered martensitic steel and application to low cycle fatigue
AdditionalInformation: In this collaborative paper a comparison is made between the techniques that can measure surface plastic strain distribution in tempered martensitic steels.  This is necessary as a first step in the process of getting these techniques accepted into component lifing procedures within the power industry sector.  This paper builds on the previous work at Loughborough University where a methodology of measuring plastic strain in shot-peened Ni-alloys was developed (Acta Materalia 59 (12) p4825-4834 (2011)).  This methodology, however, had to be adapted in this follow up paper to account for materials with inherent grain substructure.

Title: The use of combined three-dimensional electron backscatter diffraction and energy dispersive X-ray analysis to assess the characteristics of the gamma/gamma-prime microstructure in alloy 720Li™
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated the first 3D combined EBSD/EDS datasets with the new generation of high speed EDS detectors and has led to invitations to present the work at the University of Warwick (Department of Physics Feb 2012) and in future at the University of Cambridge.  This publication has also lead to a recent (funded) collaboration with the King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) in Saudi Arabia to work on 3D combined EBSD/EDS on an aluminium alloy.  This work has also led to on-going development work with major EBSD/EDS suppliers (Oxford Instruments and EDAX).

Title: Expansion of human mesenchymal stem cells on microcarriers
AdditionalInformation: This is the first ever paper to take a Chemical Engineering approach to understanding and optimising the expansion of human mesenchymal cells on microcarriers in an agitated environment for regenerative medicine purposes. This publication has formed the basis of 6 invited oral presentations at International Conferences (including 2 keynote and 2 plenary). These conferences were: 10th Annual Bioproduction meeting, Berlin, Germany; 9th European Symposium on Biochemical Engineering Science, Istanbul, Turkey; Bioprocessing and Stem cells Europe, London, UK; Cell Culture 2012 San Diego, USA; UKNSCN 4th Annual Science Meeting, York; Scale-up and Manufacturing of Cell-Based Therapies. San Diego, USA.

Title: Effect of sterilisation by gamma irradiation on the ability of polycaprolactone (PCL) to act as scaffold material
AdditionalInformation: This paper, in collaboration with academic colleagues at Birmingham University, was the very first published by the Biological Engineering Group at Loughborough concerned with the bioprocessing of human cells for Regenerative Medicine purposes and as such it underpinned the award of three successful BBSRC BRIC grant awards in that area totalling ~£2.2M. These grants are BB/G010404/1 ‘Developing scalable and standardised manufacturing methods for human pluripotent stem cells’ (with Nottingham); BB/I017062/1 ‘Bioprocessing research for cellular products’ (with Cambridge University) and BB/K00462X/1 ‘Expansion of human multipotent stem cells in aqueous/aqueous two phase systems’ (with Birmingham University).

Title: Scale-down studies for assessing the impact of different stress parameters on growth and product quality during animal cell culture
AdditionalInformation: This is the 17th paper in a series that has refined a scale-down two-compartment experimental model that can be used to model the impact of any range or combination of potential heterogeneities known to exist at the large-scale on bioprocess productivity. This work led directly to an invited oral presentation at the 2nd BioProScale Symposium 14–16 March 2012. Berlin, Germany, which in turn led to an invitation to join a European consortium which successfully bid for an £1.5M 7 partner ERA-IB EU/BBSRC (BB/L001284/1) project ‘Systematic consideration of inhomogeneity at the large scale: towards a stringent development of industrial bioprocesses’

Title: Physiological effects of the addition of n-dodecane as an oxygen vector during steady-state Bacillus licheniformis thermophillic fermentations perturbed by a starvation period or a glucose pulse
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the fourth in a series of papers concerned with a European collaboration developing multi-parameter flow cytometry for understanding how Bacillus spp. interact with the engineering environment for bioprocess optimisation. This publication led directly to an invited oral presentation at the 2nd BioProScale Symposium in March 2012. Berlin, Germany, which in turn led to an invitation to join a European consortium which successfully bid for an ERA-IB EU project ‘Systematic consideration of inhomogeneity at the large scale: towards a stringent development of industrial bioprocesses’. The project includes 7 partners across Europe and is worth over £1.5M

Title: Bulk video imaging based multivariate image analysis, process control chart and acoustic signal assisted nucleation detection
AdditionalInformation: This is one of four journal publications that resulted from a collaborative project between Loughborough University, ETH Zurich, Switzerland, and New Mexico Institute of Technology, USA. A new crystallisation monitoring approach, Bulk Video Imaging (BVI), was developed that combines low-cost imaging hardware with a complex analysis algorithm to provide a high performance system for early nucleation detection.  With respect to the Loughborough contribution one of the visiting researchers supervised was awarded the 2011 Excellence Award in Crystallisation by the European Federation of Chemical Engineering and another received 1st Prize in Computing and Process Control at the 2009 AIChE Annual Meeting.

Title: Model based robust control approach for batch crystallization product design
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to propose a robust, model-based control approach for crystallization processes and provide experimental evidence of the benefits of the approach to reduce variability in crystalline product quality. The work received the “Best Paper Prize” by the Computer Aided Process Engineering Working Party of the European Federation of Chemical Engineering at the 18th European Symposium on Computer Aided Process Engineering (ESCAPE) and has led to several invitations to deliver seminars at prestigious institutions abroad (Otto von Guericke University of Magdeburg; ETH, Zurich; Purdue University and the Technical University of Delft, amongst others).

Title: The impact of direct nucleation control on crystal size distribution in pharmaceutical crystallization processes
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduced a new crystallisation control approach that enables the production of products with superior quality and consistency. The approach has been implemented in a pilot plant at AstraZeneca and the work has resulted in several invitations to give plenary or invited presentations, e.g. at the International Symposium on Industrial Crystallization, Switzerland (www.aidic.it/isic18/webpapers/pro.html); the American Association for Crystallization Technology,  (www.ucs.iastate.edu/mnet/_repository/2012/crystallization/pdf/agenda.pdf); the 3rd Indian Process Development Conference,  and many other invited talks at companies and universities worldwide. Related work was one of six shortlisted projects for the “Core Chemical Engineering award” of the 2010 IChemE awards for Innovations and Excellence

Title: Optimal seed recipe design for crystal size distribution control for batch cooling crystallisation processes
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a new, model-based systematic crystalline product engineering approach  based on the design of a seed recipe to achieve a desired crystal size distribution. The work provides a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed approach using simulation as well as experimental studies. It led to the development of a project, which received a prestigious European Research Council (ERC) Research Fellowship in 2011, entitled “CrySys – Crystallization Systems Engineering – Towards the development of a next generation intelligent crystallisation systems” and an invitation as a distinguished speaker at the Discovery Chemistry Congress 2012: Formulation and Solubility, Munich, Germany (http://selectbiosciences.com/conferences/biographies.aspx?speaker=789641&conf=FS2012).

Title: The sensitivity of human mesenchymal stem cells to vibration and cold storage conditions representative of cold transportation
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of the first to focus on understanding the consequences of mechanical stresses on stem cells due to transportation vibration and one of the major outcomes from the project funded by TSB (£548,006) and EPSRC (£226,383) in collaboration with Intercytex (Paul Kemp:  pkemp@intercytex.com).  The work is of great interest to the regenerative medicine community, in particular industry, as understanding the critical levels of vibrations and forces for cellular products will assist in the design of appropriate packaging.

Title: Human cell culture process capability: A comparison of manual and automated production
VolumeTitle: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to report the use of automated cell culture for batch production processes, including measurements of the process capability of both the manual and the automated process. The demonstration is being used to support the justification of this approach to bioprocess scale up in global industry by collaborators TAP Biosystems. Moreover, it has already been cited by 10 leading groups in the fields of biology, bio-processing and biomedical engineering. This publication laid the foundation for further research on application of manufacturing engineering sciences for production of cell-therapeutic products.

Title: Incorporation of Hydroxyapatite Sol into Collagen Gel to Regulate the Contraction Mediated by Human Bone Marrow-Derived Stromal Cells
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows the application of nano-materials to manage the contraction of tissue-engineered constructs as cells grow within them. This publication was recognised by Jillian Cornish from University of Auckland and is one of the factors contributing to the FP7 IRSES funding for our international collaboration with her and Tim Woodfield from University of Otago in New Zealand, and University of Leeds, University of Southampton, University of Oxford, University Medical Centre Utrecht, University of Minho and Polytechnic Institute of Leira from EU region on skeletal tissue engineering and regeneration.

Title: Influence of calcium phosphate crystal morphology on the adhesion, spreading, and growth of bone derived cells
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of a series of publications concerning the application of calcium phosphate as biomaterials for bone implants, focusing on establishing the effects of particle size on cell adhesion and growth. The importance of the findings has been reflected by 8 citations from other international peer groups, including the leading group of Osamu Suzuki (suzuki-o@m.tains.tohoku.ac.jp). Dr. Gbureck was the international collaborator from the Department for Functional Materials in Medicine and Dentistry, University of Wuerzburg.

Title: Aerodynamics of battle-damaged finite-aspect-ratio wings
AdditionalInformation: The research by Loughborough University into the aerodynamics of battle damage wings addresses a fundamental, but little understood, issue in terms of aircraft survivability. It has provided a valuable and fundamental basis to understanding the mechanisms present, and importantly, their consequences in the overall context of aircraft platform survivability" - Dr Andrew Irwin, Technical Manager, Advanced Projects, Future Combat Aircraft Systems, BAESystems. This paper led to Loughborough’s involvement in BaToLUS (Battle Tolerant Lightweight Unmanned Aircraft Structures) a European Project funded by the European Defence Agency and involving EADS(Germany), Onera (France), Saab (Sweden and BAE Systems.

Title: Maneuver of Fixed-Wing Combat Aircraft
AdditionalInformation: This was an invited contribution that arose because the editors were aware of the authors' research into performance metrics for thrust vectored aircraft. Details of the developed metric are included in the contribution. This research was significant because it was the first metric to allow the effects of thrust vectoring to be assessed without the need for high order equations to describe the flight dynamics.

Title: The influence of simulated missile warhead fragment damage on the aerodynamic characteristics of two-dimensional wings
AdditionalInformation: This paper is significant because it is the first study to quantify the aerodynamic effects of a common form of battle damage. One reviewer stated “This paper presents good work on an important issue, with very good quality experimental data to provide more insight on the aerodynamic effects of a specific type of wing damage.” The research was funded by BAESystems and led to Loughborough’s involvement in the BaToLUS European project. Upon completion of BaToLUS,  Jonathan Stanley  (Procurement Engineer, BAESystems) sent an unsolicited e-mail  saying “ BAE thanked Loughborough for their professional approach and for a job well done! “

Title: The influence of laser hardening on wear in the valve and valve seat contact
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of the few contributions to knowledge which highlights the development of hard wear resistant surfaces achieved through laser hardening, used for engine valve seats as an alternative to the conventional hard inserts.  The work was achieved in conjunction with JCB Power systems, a leading UK manufacturer of off-road diesel engines.  This statement can be corroborated by Mr Bob Womersley, Chief Engineer, JCB Power Systems. (bob.womersley@jcb.com)

Title: Tribology of the ring-bore conjunction subject to a mixed regime of lubrication
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This is one of few research outputs in tribology concerning the piston ring in internal combustion engines.  A key feature of the predictive work is its conformance to the “industry standard” experimental findings at Chevrolet, indicating the quality of its included detail. The paper has been cited 10 times in a period of 3 years, which is well in excess of the norm in this field of research. This statement can be corroborated by Dr Sebastian Howell-Smith, Tech. Director, Capricorn Automotive (Sebastian.Howell.Smith@capricornauto.co.uk)

Title: Influence of tyre transience on anti-lock braking
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This is a forerunning paper dealing with the integration of the ABS system and tyre transient behaviour. In particular, the effect of tyre relaxation length upon ABS performance has not hitherto been evaluated, accounting for several citations in a short period since its publication. This statement can be corroborated by Dr Hubertus von Chappuis, Technical Specialist Ford Motor Co, Germany (hvonchap@ford.com)

Title: The influence of piston ring geometry and topography on friction
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: The effect of topography and conjunction geometry on friction has been predicted in a new approach using roughness parameters such as Rpk and Rk as an alternative to all previous research which used Ra or Rq roughness parameters, which are unrepresentative of plateau-honed cylinder liners. The predictions made in this manner conform much more closely to observations in practice and represent a novel approach to compression ring analysis. This statement can be corroborated by Dr Sebastian Howell-Smith, Technical Director, Capricorn Automotive,  (Sebastian.Howell.Smith@capricornauto.co.uk)

Title: Corrosion characterization of tin-lead and lead free solders in 3.5 wt.% NaCl solution
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first published worldwide that addressed the corrosion behavior of lead-free solders with a comparison to lead containing solders, including an established protocol for salt corrosion tests as applicable to automotive and aerospace sectors, where corrosion of electronics interconnect is of critical concern. The work has been followed by other authors when addressing solder alloy groups e.g. in 2013 by Asri (asmakamaru@gmail.com) and Mohanty in Prof Kwang-Lung Lin’s group (matklin@mail.ncku.edu.tw) and Osario’s (wislei@fem.unicamp.br, Campinas) body of work in this field). The work has proven seminal and is much cited (36) in related journals (27) and conferences (9)

Title: Formation of Ag3Sn plates in SnAgCu solder bumps
VolumeTitle: MATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING A-STRUCTURAL MATERIALS PROPERTIES MICROSTRUCTURE AND PROCESSING
AdditionalInformation: Derived from an invited paper presented at the 2009 TMS Spring Meeting on Pb-Free Solders, this more extended and cited (6, e.g. mingli90@sjtu.edu.cn) paper described the underpinning phenomena and materials processing variables that are key to ensuring reliable solder joints. These have in turn directly underpinned the core of the successful case for support in the EPSRC/IeMRC project “Design for increased Yield” (within EPSRC award EP/H03014X/1, 2010-2015, Challenging Environments Theme, £294k), where the observations are being captured in design software as process/materials design rules for electronics products.

Title: Formation of Sn dendrites and SnAg eutectics in a SnAgCu solder
AdditionalInformation: This paper is reprint and extended treatment of an invited paper at the TMS 2009 Lead-free Solders Workshop, SFO, USA at the TMS Spring Meeting Conference. It is one of the first papers to address these phenomena and as such is cited (8 e.g. joel.cugnoni@epfl.ch) by others working in this field. The research reported has underpinned the case for support for follow-on EPSRC IeMRC project “Design Tools for the Manufacture and Implementation of Pb-Free Solder Joints : Materials Modelling Challenges”, (under GR/T07459/01, 2009-2010, £98k) addressing the modeling of the phenomena first described here.

Title: Product life cycle information management in the electronics supply chain
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This journal reprint of prize winning conference paper “Innovation Italy Awards, Sustainability, 06/2012, “Embedded RFID to enable sustainable manufacture”, (http://www.qu-id.it/wp/wp-content/uploads/QUI12_Awards.pdf ), describes an approach for award winning embedding technology (IEEE-I-MAPS UK, 2012) of intelligent devices and sensors into PCBs, that allow life-cycle information to be written, stored, read and updated throughout product life. This has been adopted by Invotec (invotec-group.com), who offer it to their customers as an additional feature and is supported by a subsequent TSB award (TP101155-1428-87248-EP/J501748/1, £333k). The technology underpins a £2.5M EPSRC award (EP/K014137/1), developing capabilities in multiple industries and into back-end ICT systems.

Title: Modelling the high temperature behaviour of TBCs using sequentially coupled microstructural-mechanical FE analyses
AdditionalInformation: Research at Loughborough over a number of years has resulted in the development of a theoretical model based on thermodynamic and kinetic principles that allows the prediction of interdiffusion between a coating and a nickel-based superalloy substrate as a function of initial processing and service conditions (EP/F029748/1). Here, the model has been integrated with a sophisticated finite element model for the first time to simulate the mechanical behaviour of a coating system. The combined model is able to predict the stress concentrations and therefore the likely delamination mechanisms of the coating, which are essential for determining service behaviour.

Title: Assessment of surface hardening effects from shot peening on a Ni-based alloy using electron backscatter diffraction techniques
AdditionalInformation: Shot peening is an important industrial process used to impart additional fatigue resistance on components such as turbine blades used in jet engines. A validated experimental technique has been developed in this work using electron back scatter diffraction to assess the degree of strain hardening induced by peening. The method has been applied to industrial turbine components to assess the influence of initial peening on service life, and has facilitated the development of guidelines for pre-service processing in industry to ensure optimisation of the safe working life of components. The work led to an invited presentation at EBSD 2012 (http://www.rms.org.uk/events/pastevents/2012events/EBSD2012).

Title: Modeling of Microstructural Evolution in an MCrAlY Overlay Coating on Different Superalloy Substrates
VolumeTitle: METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A-PHYSICAL METALLURGY AND MATERIALS SCIENCE
AdditionalInformation: Coatings are frequently used on high temperature alloys to provide additional protection in aggressive oxidising and corrosive operating environments. This paper highlights the fact that a coating should not be an afterthought, but needs to be an integral part of the design process. The validated model has been used to predict the useful service life of existing components and also to design new enhanced coatings, which are currently being patented. This research has led to several invited presentations at international conferences (e.g. http://www.htcpm2012.com/ and http://www.iom3.org/events/optimom in 2010) and has led to new funded projects with industrial partners.

Title: Microstructural Evolution of Boron Nitride Particles in Advanced 9Cr Power Plant Steels
VolumeTitle: Metallurgical and Materials Transactions A: Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper established a methodology for re-dissolving boron nitride formed during processing of creep resistant steels; in related research, we have shown that boron nitride is associated with the formation of creep cavities. This technique has been implemented on a new steel developed in a £1.8M collaborative project funded by the Technology Strategy Board (TP11/CAT/6/I/BP074G). It has been demonstrated that this steel has significantly improved mechanical behaviour as a result, and a test component is to be trialled in a power station (Contact: craig.degnon@eon.com). This led to a keynote presentation at the EPRI conference on materials for power plant (http://www.cvent.com/events/7th-international-conference-on-advances-in-materials-technology-for-fossil-power-plants/agenda-f86961e02e7046f292622f403df9f045.aspx).

Title: Modelling transdermal drug delivery using microneedles: Effect of geometry on drug transport behaviour
AdditionalInformation: This key paper has enabled the academic and industrial sectors to relate the effect of mechanical properties of skin to diffusivity of large molecules for transdermal drug delivery from microneedles (MNs). It has enabled Dr Olatunji, the first author, and her current employer (FIIRO, Nigeria) to determine effectiveness of MNs developed from natural biodegradable polymers extracted from fish scales, which also enabled them to submit a patent application in Nigeria. The framework is already being implemented for developing MN systems for Nemaura Pharaceuticals, UK in the framework of an EPSRC CASE studentship (2010-2014; EPSRC voucher number 10002490).

Title: Nutrient transport in bioreactors for bone tissue growth: Why do hollow fibre membrane bioreactors work?
AdditionalInformation: Molecular interactions can be important for mass transport in tissue engineering bioreactors when large molecules, e.g. proteins, are involved. For the first time this modelling paper has demonstrated how to quantify these interactions and their effects on mass transport in bioreactors. This key paper led to an international research grant in 2010 from the Royal Society (UK) to Dr DB Das and Dr A Sundaresan (Texas Southern University, USA, sundaresana@tsu.edu) to apply these principles for determining nutrient requirements in NASA bioreactors, which were used to quantify cellular response under micro-gravity conditions.

Title: Transdermal drug delivery by coated microneedles: Geometry effects on effective skin thickness and drug permeability
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, this paper proposed a novel numerical modelling scheme to quantify effective drug transport (e.g., permeability) through skin for microneedle (MN) systems depending on MN geometry,to aid design and optimise more accurate microneedles. This paper has received significant attention from the pharmaceutical and academic sectors, e.g. it led to an EPSRC case studentship (2010-2014; EPSRC voucher number 10002490) to help design MN for Nemaura Pharmaceuticals, UK. It has also helped to design and optimise MNs by Vaxxas, a spin-off company from University of Queensland, Australia, led by Prof Mark Kendall (m.kendall@uq.edu.au).

Title: Dynamic effects on capillary pressure-Saturation relationships for two-phase porous flow: Implications of temperature
AdditionalInformation: Accurate characterisation of dynamic capillary pressure is needed in analysing two-phase flow in porous media. For the first time this paper has developed a model to simulate the effect of temperature on the dynamic capillary pressure, which enables users to carry out much more reliable predictions. This paper led to the development of new analytical correlations by Professor F Civan, (fcivan@ou.edu) University of Oklahoma, US. It also led to improved understanding of bubble coalescence in porous material, as reported by Professor E Kontturi  (E.Kontturi@aalto.fi), University of Aalto, Finland.

Title: Radiation absorption and optimization of solar photocatalytic reactors for environmental applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented new key fundamental concepts in photoreaction engineering linking the catalysts optical properties to the radiation absorbed in solar photoreactors. The concepts described have been implemented at the European Union Solar Research Facility at Platforma Solar de Almeria (Director: Sixto.Malato@psa.es) for the design and analysis of solar photoreactors used for environmental and renewable energy applications. The impact of the research was recognised internationally through an invited Plenary Lecture at the 6th European Meeting on Solar Chemistry and Photocatalysis: Environmental Applications, Prague, 2010 and an invited Keynote Lecture at the 15th International Conference on TiO2 Photocatalysis, San Diego, 2010.

Title: Photocatalytic oxidation of multicomponent mixtures of estrogens (estrone (E1), 17β-estradiol (E2), 17α-ethynylestradiol (EE2) and estriol (E3)) under UVA and UVC radiation: Photon absorption, quantum yields and rate constants independent of photon absorption
AdditionalInformation: This paper utilized for the first-time in the literature radiation transport modelling for the evaluation of quantum yields of photodegradation of multicomponent mixtures of estrogens. The work led to an EU SFERA grant which enabled the process to be demonstrated at the EU Solar Research Facility at Platforma Solar de Almeria (contact: Sixto.Malato@psa.es). The impact of the research was recognised internationally through an invited Plenary Lecture  (2013 International Symposium on Environmental Science and Technology, Dalian, China) and an invited  Keynote Lecture (15th International Conference on Advanced Oxidation Technologies for Treatment of Water, Air and Soil, Niagara Falls, USA, 2009).

Title: Carbon nanotubes/titanium dioxide (CNTs/TiO₂) nanocomposites prepared by conventional and novel surfactant wrapping sol-gel methods exhibiting enhanced photocatalytic activity
AdditionalInformation:
This paper presents new advanced nano-structured photocatalytic materials with enhanced photoactivity, based on the synergy between carbon nanotubes and TiO2 semiconductor materials. The scientific novelty of the work led to Li Puma receiving the E.ON Research Award (www.eon.com/en/about-us/innovation/research-initiative/research-topic-2008.html) and to winning a £920,000 research grant from E.ON AG (Germany). The impact of the research was recognised internationally through two invited Keynote Lectures at the International Conference on Recycling and Reuse, Istanbul, Turkey, 2012 and at the 14th International Conference on TiO2 Photocatalysis, Niagara Falls, USA, 2009, and as an invited lecture at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, USA.

"

Title: Effective quantum yield and reaction rate model for evaluation of photocatalytic degradation of water contaminants in heterogeneous pilot-scale solar photoreactors
AdditionalInformation: This paper used pilot-scale experimental solar data and literature results to formulate and validate a new generalised model of solar photocatalytic degradation of emerging contaminants. It introduced a new concept of “effective quantum yield” to model photoreactors kinetic data leading to industrial take up by CatalySystem Ltd, funded by the IP Group (Director: neil.foster@catalysyem.com). The impact of the research was recognised internationally  in three invited Plenary Lectures (1st latin-American Congress on Photocatalysis (LACP 2012, Morelia, Mexico); the Fourth Int. Conf. on Chemical and Bioprocess Engineering (ICCBPE  2012, Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia); XVIII Encontro Luso-Galego de Quimica (Vila Real, Portugal, 2012)).

Title: The Effect of Interface Topography for Ultrasonic Consolidation of Aluminium
AdditionalInformation: The paper presented research performed as part of an EPSRC grant (IMCRC275 - £656,055). The cutting edge work involved international exchange and collaboration with a US based academic (Kenneth Johnson, kejohnson@olivet.edu) and a US based industrial partner (Solidica Inc., info@solidica.com). The research output resulted in a new collaboration with two international industrial partners, one multi-national aluminium manufacturer (Constellium (France), christopher.glazebrook@constellium.com) and one high-tech machine builder (Fabrisonic LLC. (USA), mnorfolk@fabrisonic.com); with resultant funding of £141,133. In addition the international recognition the paper received led to an invited talk and paper at the 2012 Solid Freeform Fabrication Symposium in Austin, Texas (http://utwired.engr.utexas.edu/lff/symposium/).

Title: Crankcase sampling of PM from a fired and motored compression ignition engine
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, this paper reported a comprehensive optical and sampling investigation of engine particulate formation through crankcase processes. This proved vital to Caterpillar in the development of strategies for crankcase emission control and led to the design of particulate control systems that are being considered for patent application (V. Page, Caterpillar IPSD, Page_Vivian_J@perkins.com). The demonstrated multiphase flow expertise led to an invitation to lead the spray research team for an international research consortium in a multi-million pound project for the development of injection systems for diesel engine after-treatment.

Title: Large eddy simulation and PIV measurements of unsteady premixed flames accelerated by obstacles
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the findings of a research project that won the Institute of Physics prize for best research presentation at the IOP Combustion Physics Conference. The paper provides a new insight into flame/turbulence interaction and the research work was carried out after an invitation to establish international collaborations with University of Naples, working with Prof. Di Benedetto and Prof. V. Di Sarli (vdisarli@irc.cnr.it)

Title: Experimental Measurement of Local Burning Velocity Within a Rotating Flow
AdditionalInformation: The work reported in this paper was part of an extensive study into turbulent combustion that has provided an insight into important aspects of turbulent combustion processes. New experimental techniques and data analysis processes has provided novel fundamental data. This has strengthened Loughborough’s international collaborations and developed research links with Jaguar Cars (D. Richardson, dricha69@jaguarlandrover.com) and Caterpillar IPSD (Page_Vivian_J@perkins.com ) and University of Kyoto (kawanabe@energy.kyoto-u.ac.jp). This also led to an invitation to be Visiting Professor at Kyoto University.

Title: Time-Resolved Particle Image Velocimetry of dynamic interactions between hydrogen-enriched methane/air premixed flames and toroidal vortex structures
AdditionalInformation: On-going research collaboration with University of Naples has produced several experimental and modelling papers that have provided an insight into important aspects of turbulent combustion processes. This paper reports the results of a collaboration into hydrogen-methane combustion that used new experimental techniques and data analysis processes to provided novel fundamental data that is being used for LES development (Prof. V. Di Sarli, vdisarli@irc.cnr.it). The understanding of turbulent mixing and combustion processes led to an international collaboration on natural gas engine development in a project that has resulted in hundreds of natural gas-fuelled vehicles on the road (Hardstaff Group (D. Hylands,dhylands@hardstaffgroup.co.uk).

Title: Methods for the quantification of pseudo-vibration sensitivities in laser vibrometry
AdditionalInformation:
This paper was one of 37 selected in the journal’s 'Highlights of 2011-2012'
collection. Articles were chosen on the basis of their “originality, potential impact in the field, referee endorsement, downloads and citations”. http://iopscience.iop.org/0957-0233/page/Highlights%20of%202011-2012. The methods proposed attracted attention from Polytec (the world’s premier manufacturer of laser vibrometers) who then supported a next stage study reported in a follow-on paper (Contact: Eric Winkler, Vice President, Polytec GmbH, Germany e.winkler@polytec.de) and by  the ISO group (TC108/SC3/WG6) during the development of ISO 16063-41 "Laser vibrometer calibration" (contact: committee member Thomas Bruns, PTB Braunschweig (German equivalent of National Physical Laboratory), thomas.bruns@ptb.de).

Title: Pseudo-vibration sensitivities for commercial laser vibrometers
AdditionalInformation:
This work was conducted in partnership with Polytec* (Contact: Eric Winkler, Vice President, Polytec GmbH, Germany e.winkler@polytec.de) through loan of instrumentation for test which then resulted in the invitation to deliver the keynote lecture at their 2011 UK Vibrometer Users’ Group Meeting http://tinyurl.com/d4tqzct 
*Polytec is the world’s premier manufacturer of laser vibrometers.

Title: A universal framework for modelling measured velocity in laser vibrometry with applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the basis of an invited lecture ahead of 10th International Conference (2012) on Vibration Measurements by Laser and Non-contact Techniques (sponsored by Optical Society of America and Society for Experimental mechanics http://www.aivela.org/test_10th/short_course.html), an invited paper for a special issue of Review of Scientific Instruments (“Development of a scanning head for Laser Doppler Vibrometry (LDV) using dual optical wedges”) and an invited paper at the international conference ‘Measuring by Light’ (November 2013, organised by Shell, Polytec and the Free University of Brussels).

Title: Stress measurement in East Asian lacquer thin films owing to changes in relative humidity using phase-shifting interferometry
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the result of collaboration between Loughborough University and the Victoria and Albert Museum (London), to understand the degradation mechanisms of urushi, a natural lacquer used in the manufacture of luxury goods in ancient Japan. The research assisted museum curators (Shayne Rivers [s.rivers@vam.ac.uk]) in the design of a conservation strategy for The Mazarin Chest, the masterpiece of the V&A urushi collection. Part of this work was included in the book 'East Asian Lacquer: Material Culture, Science and Conservation', S. Rivers, R. Faulkner and B. Pretzel (editors), Archetype Publications (2011).

Title: Depth-resolved Imaging and Displacement Measurement Techniques Viewed as Linear Filtering Operations
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper presents a common mathematical framework for describing optical tomographic methods. It focuses on techniques recently developed for mechanical characterization of scattering tissues and polymers. This work formed a section of an invited book chapter: J. M. Huntley, and P. D. Ruiz, "Chapter 2: Depth-resolved displacement field measurement " in Advances in Speckle Metrology and Related Techniques, G. H. Kaufmann, ed. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co.KG, 2011), pp. 37-104.

Title: Hyperspectral interferometry for single-shot absolute measurement of two-dimensional optical path distributions
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes theory and proof of principle experiments of a technology for single-shot, full-field profilometry invented at Loughgborough University by J.M.Huntley, P.D.Ruiz and T. Widjanarko (PhD student). The IP is currently protected by UK patent P43368GB. It was important in securing funding for further developments towards commercialization: Innovation Fellowship (2010/03/01 – 2011/01/01 - £15,806), and Royal Society Brian Mercer Feasibility Award (2010/10/01 – 2011/09/30 - £29,948). The background Intellectual Property was licensed by Phase Vision Ltd in Jan 2012. P.D. Ruiz was awarded a Royal Society Industry Fellowship (Oct 2012-Apr 2015) to develop a commercial system with Phase Vision.

Title: Measurement of all orthogonal components of displacement in the volume of scattering materials using wavelength scanning interferometry
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Optical Society of America A: Optics and Image Science, and Vision
AdditionalInformation: P. D. Ruiz received the “best paper award” at ‘Speckle 2012: V International Conference on Speckle Metrology’, held in Vigo, Spain, in September 2012 (Conference chair: Dr. Ángel M. Fernández Doval, adoval@uvigo.es). The technique described in the paper enables the measurement of three dimensional deformation fields with high sensitivity. This pushes the boundaries of optical methods beyond surface metrology and opens exciting new possibilities in non-contact mechanical characterization of materials and tissues.

Title: Two-dimensional growth of SrTiO₃ thin films on (001) MgO substrates using pulsed laser deposition and reflection high energy electron diffraction
AdditionalInformation: The paper was the output of an EPSRC portfolio project (GR/S60471/01) which investigated the very first pulsed laser interval deposition technique to grow heteroepitaxial films for microwave applications. Because of this work, Dr Tse was invited to give a seminar in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Ohio State University. The seminar raised significant interest from OSU and enabled collaborative work with Prof Hamish Fraser (fraser.3@osu.edu), such that Dr Tse was able to use one of the most advanced aberration corrected microscopes in OSU, and also led to another publication in Thin Solid Films (http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tsf.2011.12.033).

Title: Effect of growth defects on microwave properties in epitaxial Ba₀.₅Sr₀.₅TiO₃ thin films grown on (001) MgO by pulsed laser deposition
AdditionalInformation: This published work was supported by a £6.47M EPSRC portfolio grant (GR/S60471) on understanding the science and application of superconducting thin films. We used the basis of this work to tailor the microstructure of the ferroelectric films e.g. suppressing the formation of threading dislocations, in order to improve the tunability. This led to a new method to fabricate more efficient films used in microwave communication application (http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.3254182). The main results reported in this paper have also been presented and well received in several conference presentations given by Dr Tse, such as EMAG and the International Symposium on Integrated Ferroelectrics.

Title: Holography, tomography and 3D microscopy as linear filtering operations
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides for the first time a theoretical comparison of 3D optical imaging techniques and was the basis of invited papers at Photon10, Southampton, UK, MNF2011, Thessaloniki, Greece and Fringe 2013, Stuttgart, Germany. The analysis has been applied to medical imaging and published recently in the chapter “Coherent Microscopy and Optical Coherence Tomography for Biomedical Applications” in the book “Micro and Nano Flow Systems for Bio-Analysis”  Springer Ed. Collins. 2013

Title: Coherence scanning interferometry: Linear theory of surface measurement
AdditionalInformation: This paper jointly authored by Professor Richard Leach from the National Physical Laboratory, derives from first principles the transfer characteristics of coherence scanning interferometers when applied to surfaces. The paper defines for the first time a “foil model” of surface scattering from homogenous media that is defined in terms of the optical material properties. The work was instrumental in Loughborough obtaining a “Research Excellence Grant” as part of the £3.2m EU EMRP Project “Microparts” led by PTB (German National Standards laboratory). Ulrich.Neuschaefer-Rube@ptb.de.

Title: On measuring 3D flow within inkjet droplet streams using a digital holographic microscope
AdditionalInformation: This  paper was part of an extensive study in which holographic microscopy was applied to the measurement of fluid velocity. It was shown for the first time that it is possible to image through the curved surface of droplets to provide high fidelity, 3D images of seeding particles contained therein. The work paves the way to simultaneous measurement of flow velocity within droplets, bubbles and ambient fluid and  this capability was a key element  in establishing the International Institute for Cavitation Research in 2011- a £1.2m collaboration with City University and TU Delft funded by Lloyd’s Register Educational Trust .

Title: Determination of overlap in lidar systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper jointly authored with Dr Andrew Sandford and James Richards Campbell Scientific Ltd results from a collaborative project to develop a new design of ceilometer, an instrument which reports cloud and vertical visibility information, principally for  aviation safety. Factory based characterisation of overlap is reported for the first time which is key to the low altitude performance and commercial success of the Campbell CS135 ceilometer.  “Sales and orders in the first 4 months have been worth more than £240k – which exceeds any similar high value product released by the company” – source Dr Andrew Sandford Technical Director (Andrew.Sandford@campbellsci.co.uk).

Title: Application of laser backscattering for monitoring of palm oil crystallisation from melt
AdditionalInformation: This is the first time that the Focussed Beam Reflectance Method has been used to monitor a fats-based system. This work was orally presented at the American Oil Chemists Assocation Annual Conference, Seattle, Washington State, May 2008. The technique allows much better control of the crystallisation and is now being employed by the Malaysian Palm Oil Board (Dr. Elina Hishamuddin) for optimising palm oil fractionation.

Title: Application of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations to spray-freezing operations
AdditionalInformation: This is the first  published English language journal paper to have studied spray-freezing using CFD. This work was originally presented as a lecture at the 16th International Drying Symposium, Hyderabad, India, November 2008. As a result of this it was invited for a special issue on Non-conventional Drying Technologies for the journal “Drying Technology”. This work also lead to an invited keynote lecture at the 4th International Symposium on Spray-Dried Dairy products, Melbourne, Australia April, 2009  on the wider topic of spray freeze drying, of which spray freezing is the first part of the process.

Title: A computational method for extracting crystallization growth and nucleation rate data from hot stage microscope images
AdditionalInformation: This is a newly invented method, which was developed on a BBSRC funded project in collaboration with the University of Nottingham. An invited lecture on this topic was presented at the conference “Crystallisation and Physical Properties of fats: from Molecules to Market”, Ghent, Belgium, 2008. This paper lead to direct interest from two companies who wish to use this technique to study fat systems: Nestlé (Chong Peng Siong, Nestlé Product Technology Centre, York, and Loders Croklaan B.V (Krish Bhaggan, IOI Loders Croklaan B.V., Wormerveer, Netherlands)). Both companies are sponsoring PhD students who are using the technique.

Title:
Kinetic study of the acidolysis of high oleic sunflower oil with stearic–palmitic
acid mixtures catalysed by immobilised Rhizopus oryzae lipase
AdditionalInformation: This work was orally presented at the EuroFedLipid conference, Krakow, Poland in  2012. The results are being used by the project sponsors to develop and refine their industrial enzymatic interesterification process for producing tailored ingredients for cocoa butter equivalents (Krish Bhaggan, IOI Loders Croklaan B.V., Wormerveer, Netherlands). Included in the paper is a novel probability model to calculate equilibrium triacylglycerol compositions from enzymic interesterification reactions of any fat systems – this has potentially huge application.

Title: A diagnostic service tool using FMEA
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a practical methodology for implementing Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA) in the novel area of diagnostic analysis. References: Dr Mohammad Nor mdamin@mfi.unikl.edu.my) , Malaysia-France Institute, Malaysia (a training organisation set up by the French motor industry for the training of car repair technicians) where the work has guided their diagnostic training/documentation and Dr P.C. Teoh, Motorola, Malaysia (pcteoh@wou.edu.my) where FMEA has been adopted using the method described.

Title: HADRIAN: a virtual approach to design for all
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes research in EPSRC's Sustainable Urban Environments Programme. A new methodology for the assessment of human environments was built upon the SAMME computer human modelling techniques which have been a benchmark for the last three decades, and is now in use to consider accessibility issues for disabled and elderly people, working with Transport for London (TfL) on the Docklands Light Railway. Funded by EPSRC with University College London, London Metropolitan University, RNIB, Camden & Hertfordshire Councils as collaborators. Three EPSRC grants totaling £2.3M to consortium, £490,000 to Loughborough. Reference: Martin Freer, Director CCD Design & Ergonomics Ltd (martin.freer@ccd.org.uk)

Title: The HADRIAN approach to accessible transport
VolumeTitle: Work - A Journal of Prevention, Assessment & Rehabilitation
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes research in EPSRC's Sustainable Urban Environments Programme. The paper describes a new methodology for the assessment of human environments which has been used to consider accessibility issues for disabled and elderly people, working with Transport for London (TfL) on the Docklands Light Railway and the London Olympic site.
