This particular paper is aimed at practitioners concerned with safety and rehabilitation issues. Three EPSRC grants totaling £2.3M to consortium, £490,000 to Loughborough. Reference: Martin Freer, Director CCD Design & Ergonomics Ltd (martin.freer@ccd.org.uk)

Title: The effect of information mobility on production quality
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes an experimental study of the use of mobile information systems (hand-held Personal Digital Assistants – PDAs) for large scale assembly work (trucks in this case but could be aerospace, construction etc). The work was carried out with the active involvement of Volvo Trucks as part of a large European Union Integrated Project (MyCar, NMP2-CT-2006-026631). Reference: Thomas Lezama (Thomas.lezama@volvo.com) Volvo Group Trucks Technology.

Title: Dopant contrast in the helium ion microscope
AdditionalInformation: This first demonstration of secondary electron dopant contrast (SEDC) in the helium ion microscope, carried out with Harvard University, led to the production of a Carl Zeiss application note (available here: http://ow.ly/puOvA), further publications and collaboration with Carl Zeiss and Harvard University, including a RAEng funded visit to Harvard. I have presented results from this paper at various academic events including a Harvard University Special Seminar, and 3 additional invited seminars. In addition, results have also been presented by David Bell (Harvard) and Cornelia Rodenburg (University of Sheffield).

Title:
Experimental Investigation of Low
Temperature Diesel Combustion
Processes
AdditionalInformation: This paper was a result of a collaborative EPSRC research project (EP/F031351/1) between Loughborough University, Ford and Cambustion Ltd. The project enabled a break-through in ultra-low emissions low temperature combustion, which makes it more viable for commercialisation and reduces the need for expensive exhaust after-treatment systems; contact: Dr. Emad Wahab ewahab@ford.com. The work has led to a series of subsequent papers including presentation at the prestigious ASME IC Engines Conference in Vancouver, 23–26 September 2012 Paper: CEF2012-92049 http://www.asmeconferences.org/ICEF2012/pdfs/FinalProgram.pdf

Title: An investigation of string cavitation in a true-scale fuel injector flow geometry at high pressure
AdditionalInformation: This paper was a result of a collaborative TSB funded “LEDAM” project between Loughborough University, City University London, Caterpillar and Cambridge Consultants. For the first time it shows measurements of cavitation in diesel fuel injection nozzles at true scale and at elevated pressures (>2000 bar). The work directly led to the Loughborough research team being invited to join a consortium and win a major research funding bid to run the “International Institute for Cavitation Research”  comprising Loughborough, City University London and Delft University of Technology, funded by the Lloyd’s Register Educational Trust (LRET) (£1.3M) http://www.lr.org/about_us/LRET/research.aspx

Title: Un-throttling a direct injection gasoline homogeneous mixture engine with variable valve actuation
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Engine Research, Special Issue Paper
AdditionalInformation: This invited, special issue paper is part of an extensive EPSRC research project (GR/S91727/01 and GR/S91734/01) between Loughborough University, UCL, Lotus and Continental called ‘HOTFIRE’ that produced a novel combustion system to enable SI petrol engines to have dramatically reduced fuel consumption and real-world CO2 emissions of over 19% and yet retain excellent drivability and performance. Results led directly to new high specific power output, high fuel economy, low CO2 emissions turbocharged ‘down-sized’ engine demonstrated in the Opel Astra car; contact: Clive Card ccard@lotuscars.co.uk. The HOTFIRE project won the automotive category at The Engineer Technology and Innovation Awards (2008): http://www.theengineer.co.uk/news/prized-pioneers/308303.article

Title: Pulsed Discharge Regeneration of Diesel Particulate Filters
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this high impact factor journal was conducted by an interdisciplinary team comprising mechanical engineers, electrical engineers, materials scientists and physicists. The paper reports a completely new method of using plasma discharges to very efficiently clean high efficiency diesel particulate filters that reduce diesel engine exhaust particulate emissions by 98%. It has wider applications to ceramic surface cleaning in general.  The research was funded (total £764k) by EPSRC (EP/H024492/1) and Caterpillar, in association with 3DX-Ray Ltd. The technique has been granted full patents (US 2011/0283,886 and EP 2 169 191 B9). Industrial contact David Heaton heaton_David@perkins.com.

Title: NPL Measurement Good Practice Guide No 116: The Measurement of Rough Surface Topography using Coherence Scanning Interferometry
AdditionalInformation:
NPL GPG No. 116 is the culmination of five years of LU research in CSI. The internationally reviewed guide defines state of the art application/development of CSI for surface roughness measurement, with key explanations of errors/uncertainties, uniquely developed and evaluated by the authors. It is co-authored and published by NPL in printed/PDF format, is being cited as a key text by international industry experts. This led to an invitation to author a second GPG on Focus Variation. To date (25/06/2013), 749 PDF and 380 printed copies downloaded/circulated.
(Dr Peter de Groot, International GPG Reviewer, Director R&D, Zygo Corp, USA, Peterd@zygo.com).

Title: The use of areal surface texture parameters to characterize the mechanical bond strength of copper on glass plating applications
AdditionalInformation: Glass is a viable alternative to traditional PCB materials. This work (co-funded and co-authored by the NPL) has for the first time directly improved the quality of mechanical adhesion of copper on glass (required for electronic circuits) using laser surface ablation, and monitored/quantified using new ISO 25178-2:2012 areal parameters. The authors were invited to submit this reviewed work as part of the NPL/academia/industry high profile case study portfolio, aimed at disseminating new advances and engendering best practice in engineering science and metrology, for surface manufacture and measurement. (Prof. Mark Gee, Surface Engineering & Tribology, NPL, UK, mark.gee@npl.co.uk)

Title: The development of novel interchangeable pistons for pressure performance optimization in a gas-operated dead weight pressure balance
AdditionalInformation: This research was co-funded and supported by D H Budenberg Ltd, SIRIM Berhad - Malaysian National Metrology Lab. and the UK NPL, and reports the world’s first dead weight pressure balance that can accept interchangeable piston cylinder assemblies, for static pressure standard development. This allowed the investigation of pistons with differing surface texture, significantly increasing float/spin time (40+ minutes), a direct quality measure of a primary/secondary static pressure standard. This work was published in the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM)/IOP Metrologia journal (Impact Fac. 1.902) (Dr Ian Severn, Lead Scientist, Acoustics & Ionising Radiation, NPL, UK, ian.severn@npl.o.uk).

Title: Surface measurement errors using commercial scanning white light interferometers
AdditionalInformation: This research was completed in collaboration with NPL, Taylor Hobson Ltd (Ametek Inc.) and Veeco (UK) (now Bruker Corp.). Coherence Scanning Interferometers (CSI) are routinely used worldwide for non-contact surface metrology and analysis. Characterization/quantification was achieved for the first time in a range of CSI instrument/data uncertainty components. A direct consequence of this work was the award of the Ametek Inc Helmut N Friedlaender Award for Leadership to JNP, subsequent development of CSI calibration concepts by LU, and invitation to author the now published NPL GPG 116. (Dr Bob Bennett, Technical Director, TH Ltd, Bob.Bennett@ametek.co.uk).

Title: Microwave-assisted low temperature fabrication of nanostructured α-Fe₂O₃ electrodes for solar-driven hydrogen generation
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated for the first time the use of an eco-friendly, microwave irradiation method for tailoring the photo conversion efficiency of nanostructured iron oxide electrodes for solar driven hydrogen generation. A direct correlation between efficiency and microwave power level, >60% energy savings and 40% lower processing temperature were achieved that resulted in the ability to use flexible plastic substrates. The work led to invited talks at ICACC 2011, 2GCMEA 2012 in USA and ICMAT 2011 in Singapore. A book chapter, an invitation to enter the Eni Award and election to the membership of AMPERE management team were also ensued.

Title: Microwave sintering of multilayer integrated passive devices
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to report a simple and efficient method of making multilayer capacitor/varistor-based Integrated Passive Devices (IPDs) using a microwave-assisted approach to overcome significant processing hurdles related to co-sintering and inter-diffusion faced by the electronics industry. This resulted in the manufacture of dense electronic components in 10% of the total cycle time and their performance surpassed competitive commercial devices. The work led to 3 invited talks (ICS 2010 and ICAM 2011 in India; ICACC 2011 in USA) and an invitation to join a multi-university/industry EPSRC proposal. The author also received the prestigious Glory of India Award.

Title: Dense nanostructured zirconia by two stage conventional/hybrid microwave sintering
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: Due to problems with agglomeration and grain growth, it is very difficult to make large enough nanoceramic components to allow detailed property measurements. This paper demonstrated a new hybrid microwave/conventional two stage sintering route for the fabrication of genuinely nanostructured zirconia ceramics. This resulted in limiting the grain growth to a factor of 3 whilst 20 was normally achieved even with the state-of-the-art pressureless sintering, thus followed/cited by many global practitioners. The work led to invited talks at EUROMAT 2009; IISc, Bangalore in 2010; R2i event in UK, 2012 and ~£0.9M EPSRC/DSTL funded UNICAM grant between Loughborough and Oxford Universities.

Title: Compositional effects in nanostructured yttria partially stabilized zirconia
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Applied Ceramic Technology
AdditionalInformation: Zirconia ceramics are excellent for a number of applications where temperature capability and mechanical durability are required. The optimum compositions for achieving peak performance in micron-grain components are well known, however this paper for the first time demonstrated that when these materials are manufactured with a nano-scale structure, these compositions are no longer ideal. This work indicated the compositional effects in nano-YSZ systems and set out a rationale for achieving vastly superior nano-zirconia ceramics with less rare-earth usage for applications such as bio-implants, SOFCs, petrochemical valves. The work also led to an invited talk at ECerS’2011 and TSB-funded ZIRCIMP grant.

Title: A consideration of methods of determining the radiative characteristics of jet fires
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers the methods used to determine the radiation characteristics of jet fires. A fraction of the heat radiated is generally used, obtained from experimental data employing a single-point source model and considered to remain constant. This work demonstrates that this approach is incorrect and that a multi-point source model is needed, thus correcting errors present in the much referenced paper of Sivathanu and Gore, 1993. Similar problems arise if a uniform surface emissive power is used for solid flame models. A new multi-point source model is proposed that more appropriately represents emissions of thermal radiation by hot gases.

Title: Vapour cloud explosions in a long congested region involving methane/hydrogen mixtures
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports work performed as part of the €17M EC-funded Naturalhy project, which studied the feasibility of adding hydrogen to the natural gas network; a key aspect to this concept is ensuring the safety of the infrastructure. The results presented relate to large-scale vapour cloud explosions that were performed involving natural gas/hydrogen mixtures in geometries representative of full scale plant. The results were used in the development and validation of explosion models and risk assessment methodologies. This work demonstrated that the current natural gas network is capable of accepting up to 30% hydrogen without adversely affecting safety.

Title: Vented confined explosions involving methane/hydrogen mixtures
AdditionalInformation: Large-scale confined explosions are reported involving natural gas/hydrogen mixtures representative of domestic and commercial properties. The work was undertaken within the EC-funded Naturalhy project investigating the feasibility of adding hydrogen to the natural gas network; a key aspect to this concept is ensuring safety during the use of gas by the general public. The results have been used in the development and validation of explosion models. It has been demonstrated that explosions become more severe as the concentration of hydrogen increases, but remain within acceptable limits for the range of hydrogen concentrations that the infrastructure is capable of transporting.

Title: Gas build-up in a domestic property following releases of methane/hydrogen mixtures
AdditionalInformation: The work considers the behaviour of natural gas/hydrogen mixtures released into volumes representative of rooms within domestic properties. Information was acquired that assisted in the development and validation of models to predict the movement and build-up in concentration of the released gas. The results were also used in the development of a methodology for predicting the increase in explosion frequency expected from the replacement of some of the natural gas with hydrogen. The work was part of the EC-funded Naturalhy project, which involved 39 industry and 10 universities to study the feasibility of adding hydrogen to the natural gas network.

Title: Aerodynamic drag reduction of a simplified squareback vehicle using steady blowing
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses the need to reduce aerodynamic drag of road vehicles without compromising the styling. The influence of steady blowing, applied at the vehicle trailing edge, is investigated and demonstrates a net aerodynamic drag power reduction. The strength of the paper lies in the technical insight provided by the surface pressure and PIV measurements; these suggest that some of the drag reduction demonstrated could be realised using passive methods that would not normally be tried. This technical value was recognised by JLR who are now funding a two year research programme at Loughborough to investigate passive techniques.

Title: The aerodynamic performance of a range of FIFA-approved footballs
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the journal version of a keynote address at the World Congress on Science & Football (WCSF) 2011 Japan. The paper includes detailed aerodynamic test data and flight simulation results for several footballs including the World Cup 2010 ball. Given the considerable amount of speculation and unsubstantiated technical comment regarding ball flight, the technical value of the paper lies in the use of a sophisticated experimental technique, combined with flight simulation to disprove a number of commonly held, but often published, misconceptions regarding ball flight.

Title: Measurement of a bluff body aerodynamic yaw moment magnification and damping using a dynamic wind tunnel facility
VolumeTitle: Journal of Applied Mechanics, Transactions ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a collaborative research project with Universiti Teknologi Malaysia. The experimental work was all conducted at Loughborough and the analysis was a joint exercise. With the unique approach of a freely oscillating wind tunnel model it was possible to demonstrate for the first time the coupling between the automotive model motion, or onset conditions, and the aerodynamic loads. This has generated a number of new avenues of research at Loughborough but the method has also been adopted at other institutions, including NRC Canada and RUAG Technology Switzerland.

Title: Experimental Studies of the Aerodynamics of Spinning and Stationary Footballs
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: Funded by EPSRC/IMCRC the work in this paper was the first in the world to describe a credible method of measuring the aerodynamic loads on a football. The paper also demonstrates differences in behaviour between footballs with different panel designs and is the first to demonstrate the underlying cause of ‘wobble’ during flight. The technical contribution and credibility of the methods was recognised when the technical department of adidas, based in Germany, funded Loughborough to apply the techniques described to the aerodynamic development of its future tournament footballs. This includes the 2010 and 2014 World Cup footballs.

Title: Spray forming of bulk ultrafine-grained Al-Fe-Cr-Ti
VolumeTitle: Metallurgical and Materials Transactions A: Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science
AdditionalInformation: The paper was a result of collaboration with Oxford University part funded by EP/E040608/1 to develop bulk nanostructured alloys to potentially replace Ti alloys.  It demonstrated a scale-up route to the commercialisation of these alloys.  We secured several days of beamtime at The Diamond Light Source and ISIS to apply synchrotron x-ray and neutron techniques to investigate the microstructures.  As well leading to presentation at SRMS-7 in Oxford 2011 (http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S2044820110000882 and http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S2044820110000870) it lead to an invited to talk at the Defects in Structural Materials Workshop - Applications for 3rd Generation Light Sources (http://www.diamond.ac.uk/Home/Events/Past_events/Defects.html)

Title: Unusual observations in the wear-out of high-purity aluminum wire bonds under extended range passive thermal cycling
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
AdditionalInformation: The paper addressed for the first time the effect of damage restoration and accumulation on bond degradation during thermal cycling.  The work was developed from a multi-disciplinary collaboration between Nottingham and Loughborough Universities and applied advanced characterisation techniques for the first time to study microstructural evolution at the wire/device interface.  This was presented at a number of international conferences on microelectronics (EUROSIME 2007, IMAPS 2008, HITECH 2008).

Title: Pitting corrosion of spray formed Al-Li-Mg alloys
AdditionalInformation: Investigations of these alloys led to a TSB grant (Recyclable Ultra Light Mixed materials Automotive Platform TSB Project No: TP/8/MAT/6/I/Q1573K) including several industrial partners including Boal Extrusion, Innoval Technology and Atlas Composites being secured to exploit these materials as hollow extrusions. The project optimised compositions for high strength extrusions and produced for the first time hollow extrusions in these alloy types.  This work was presented at ICSF VII in Bremen, Germany in 2009 and lead to a related journal paper (http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/mawe.201000643).

Title: X-ray Spectromicroscopy of Mineral Intergrowths in the Santa Catharina Meteorite
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the first application of micro-focus Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (μ-EXAFS) on the I18 beamline at The Diamond Light Source to examine meteorite materials with respect to the meteorite’s early life and possibly conditions in the early stages of the Solar System. As well as helping to develop μ-EXAFS, this required a new sample preparation technique to perform site-specific investigations – developed at Loughborough using Field Ion Beam microscopy.  This technique was further applied to the study of intermetallics extracted from complex high strength alloys and was presented at SRMS-7 in Oxford 2011.

Title: Non-destructive analysis (NDA) of external and internal structures in 3DP
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the investigation and production of an in-machine vision system used as a quality assessment and verification tool in Additive Manufacturing (AM / 3D printing). The need for such a system has been identified as part of an international NSF roadmap as important to the further industrial adoption of AM. This work has been recognized, by the Sir John Gains Prize Award, as the No.1 example of research (Research Student Category, chosen from 60 such students) from the Loughborough EPSRC IMRC (grant totalling £18M).

Title: Advanced computer-aided design for bone tissue-engineering scaffolds
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the study of efficient automated computer-aided-design of biological structures, initially by a PhD investigation. The successful results of this work led to engagement with a major international consortium regarding its extension into tissue engineering applications. This has resulted in securing major EU research funding (€11 Million, beginning Nov 2011), with the author as Principle Investigator at Loughborough and leading this research topic in the 20 partner consortium.

Title: Characterization, quantification, and replication of human sinus bone for surgery simulation phantoms
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the identification of target properties and consequent manufacturing using Additive Manufacturing (3D printing) to produce simulation phantoms for endoscopic surgery in the sinus. The work was conducted as part of an EPSRC research project (£194,861) with clinical collaboration. This work resulted in the Best Young Scientist Award at the 3rd International Conference on Additive Technologies. The work was also presented as an invited keynote talk at the 5th bi-annual International VRAP Conference 2011, Portugal.

Title: New discoveries in ultrasonic consolidation nano-structures using emerging analysis techniques
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART L-JOURNAL OF MATERIALS-DESIGN AND APPLICATIONS
AdditionalInformation: This paper concerns the investigation and analysis of the Ultrasonic Consolidation bonding phenomena facilitated by Dual Beam Focused Ion Beam (DBFIB). The work has been awarded the 2011 IMechE SAGE Prize Award for Materials: Design and Applications. The work will be given as an invited keynote talk at 17th CIRP Conference on Electro Physical and Chemical Machining, Belgium.

Title: Excimer laser machining of microvias in glass substrates for the manufacture of high density interconnects
VolumeTitle: Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics
AdditionalInformation: Glass is becoming a key substrate material for electronic devices and this research investigated an important method for the fabrication of interconnects. The laser machining of surfaces is also being used in conjunction with electroless copper plating (see journal paper entry for Cui, Hutt, Scurr & Conway) in a research project in collaboration with Imperial College, London and University of Leeds (Prof. I Robertson, I.D.Robertson@Leeds.ac.uk), under the IeMRC/EPSRC grant reference EP/H03014X/SP/02/03/10 (122k to LU) enabling the integration of electrical waveguides into low temperature co-fired ceramic for high frequency applications.

Title: The Evolution of Pd/Sn Catalytic Surfaces in Electroless Copper Deposition
AdditionalInformation: The research identified limitations in the use of Pd/Sn catalysts for electroless plating. This resulted in the development of a collaborative project with Coventry University (Dr A. Cobley, aa2266@coventry.ac.uk) funded by EPSRC/IeMRC [under grant EP/H03014X/SP/03/05/11 (£156k to LU)] to investigate alternative functionalised copper nanoparticle catalysts. This research has also been combined with laser machining (see journal entry for Bhatt, Hutt & Conway) to explore the electroless plating of glass and low temperature co-fired ceramic for high frequency electronics in an IeMRC/EPSRC project with Imperial College and University of Leeds (Prof. I Robertson, I.D.Robertson@Leeds.ac.uk) [under grant EP/H03014X/SP/02/03/10 (£122k to LU)].

Title: The Thermal Stability of Alkanethiol Self-assembled Monolayers on Copper for fluxless Soldering Applications
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Components and Packaging Techologies
AdditionalInformation: The use of self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) for protecting copper foils from oxidation has been extended to nano and micron scale copper powders in further projects. These include two IMCRC/EPSRC programmes [grants EP/E002323/(202 & 256)  (£228k to LU)] one of which has developed copper conductive adhesives. The research on SAM preservation of copper led to an invitation to Hutt to be a visiting academic for an A-STAR research project at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore [“Advanced Metal Bonding with Self-Assembled Monolayers”, led by Prof. Chee C. Wong, WongCC@ntu.edu.sg].

Title: A comparative study of the interfacial reaction between electroless Ni-P coatings and molten tin
AdditionalInformation: This is a collaborative paper from a project between Kings College London and Loughborough University, building on Loughborough’s extensive experience of electroless nickel plating as a solderable finish for electronics manufacturing. This research considered the effect of high temperature on the growth rate of intermetallics and the applicability of these coatings as barrier layers for liquid solder interconnects, thereby providing data on the potential of these materials for use in harsh operating environments that are of particular relevance to the UK electronics manufacturing industry.

Title: Design and Development of a Novel, Integrated Bowling Machine for Cricket
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in the paper details the first prototype development of a bowling system for cricket. The original work was funded by the EPSRC IMCRC to the value of £40K (Virtual Reality for automatic training). The outcomes of this research resulted in a second grant application being submitted to IMCRC and a further £85K being awarded (Intelligent integrated ball delivery system).

Title: Preparation and Characterization of Organoclays based on an Amphoteric Surfactant
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the preparation of a new organoclay by reaction of a biodegradable surfactant (CAB) with montmorillonite clay. Conventional surfactants used in organoclays are obtained from animal fats, whereas CAB is a biodegradable, plant-derived surfactant that is also amphoteric. The biodegradable, reactive surfactant enables organoclay to be used in bio-nanocomposites for biomedical or packaging applications. This work led to funding of a Research Assistant (RAIS) project in September 2009, sponsored by Robinson Brothers Ltd. (kbchakraborty@robinsonbrothers.co.uk), to develop a biodegradable polymer composite for flexible packaging, which the company is seeking to exploit.

Title: Surface energy measurements of coated titanium dioxide pigment
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, an equation was derived to convert measured values of contact angle on coated pigments into the true Young’s contact angle. This is an original equation. It has been used to obtain accurate surface energy measurements of coated pigments and hence to predict how well these pigments will disperse in different plastics and paint resins. This knowledge helped to secure a TSB funded Knowledge Transfer Partnership (KTP008703) with Viaton Industries (hbeedle@aol.com) to develop surface treated mineral filler powders for the plastics and paint industries.

Title: Preparation and thermal characterisation of poly(lactic acid) nanocomposites prepared from organoclays based on an amphoteric surfactant
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates improving the properties of poly(lactic acid) (PLA) by developing a PLA nanocomposite using a newly developed organoclay.  It led to an invitation to write a chapter on ‘Biodegradable Polymer Nanocomposites’, now published in ‘Advances in Polymer Nanocomposites’, Woodhead Publishing 2012 (ISBN 978-1-84569-940-6). The research was first presented at the Society of Chemical Industry conference on Bioplastics Processing and Properties in April 2009 http://www.soci.org/News/Bioresources/Bioresources-Bioplastics-Processing and has led to funding from PepsiCo (Elliott.Orlik@intl.pepsico.com) for a one year post-doctoral study on PLA/PHB blends and a PhD project to investigate improving the moisture barrier of bio-based resins and blends.

Title: Water vapour permeability of poly(lactic acid) nanocomposites
AdditionalInformation: This study examines how the water vapour barrier properties of poly(lactic acid) (PLA) are affected by the concentration and dispersion of nanoclay. This is the first paper to quantitatively model water vapour permeability of PLA nanocomposites and apply a tortuosity model to give a theoretical prediction of experimental results. Sponsored by PepsiCo (sridevi.narayan-sarathy@pepsico.com), this polymer has significant potential to be used as biodegradable food packaging because of the enhancement of water barrier properties while maintaining transparency. The work was presented at Eurofillers 2013, Bratislava, 25th-29th August 2013, Paper OP25 http://www.eurofillers2013.sav.sk/documents/scientificprogramme.pdf.

Title: Energy optimisation in manufacturing systems using virtual engineering-driven discrete event simulation
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Following collaboration with Ford UK on the application of virtual design, energy optimisation at device level was developed. The idea originated from a need at Ford Dagenham, to control and reduce electrical energy usage in manufacturing facilities. The industrial contact for this project was Dr Leslie Lee (Leslie.Lee@HSSMI.Org) director of HSSMI. The paper was accepted on the first round of review by 4 IMechB reviewers with particular interest on controlling inertia and velocity of devices to minimise energy. The integration of simulation and virtual design was praised by the reviewers and the industrial partners as advancement in virtual engineering environment.

Title: Synthesis and characterization of size-selective nanoporous polymeric adsorbents for blood purification
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates the use of a novel membrane emulsification process for the preparation of molecular sieving adsorbents tailored for the selective removal of small proteins (middle molecular weight toxins) whilst excluding essential blood proteins e.g. human serum albumin. The adsorbents were tailored for artificial kidney and artificial liver applications. The project was a joint collaboration between industrial (Jim Dale, Purolite) and clinical partners (Graham Warwick, Dept  Nephrology, University Hospitals of Leicester) and has generated considerable clinical interest. The project was funded by EPSRC including an international visiting research fellowship grant for Trochimczuk (Wroclaw University, Poland).

Title: Nanostructured synthetic carbons obtained by pyrolysis of spherical acrylonitrile/divinylbenzene copolymers
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates a novel two-step process by which low cost synthetic nanostructured carbons may be prepared using the relatively cheap precursor material acrylonitrile/DVB copolymers. The paper also demonstrates the possibility of tuning the microporosity of the resulting carbons. The paper is the result of an international collaboration between the Universities of Loughborough and Wroclaw (Poland) working in the field of nanostructured engineered carbons for separation and purification applications. Work by the lead author (Malik) in the field of nanostructured adsorbents has lead to an invitation to join the editorial board of Journal of Nanoscience.

Title: Synthesis and characterization of nanostructured carbons with controlled porosity prepared from sulfonated divinylbiphenyl copolymers
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the result of an international collaboration between between the Universities of Loughborough and Wroclaw (Poland) working in the area of nanostructured engineered carbons for catalyst supports.  The paper  demonstrates a novel two-step process for manufacturing nanostructured catalytic carbons with atomically dispersed metal clusters within a tunable nanostructured carbon support matrix. The collaborative work has lead to an exchange of researchers between the two institutions, as well as an invitation to join the international organisation committee of a series of biennial conferences held in Poland (ŚWIERADÓW ZDRÓJ, June  2013).

Title: The inactivation of Bacillus subtilis spores at low concentrations of hydrogen peroxide vapour
AdditionalInformation: Hydrogen peroxide in vapour form (HPV) has found increasing use in sterilisation of medical and food processing equipment as well as for large-scale applications e.g. disinfection of MRSA and C. diffcile from healthcare environments such as hospital wards. This paper shows how HPV inactivation kinetic data for Bacillus subtilis spores may be used to predict the sterilisation times of such processes. The work has generated interest amongst clinicans and other heathcare practioners (in the NHS), as well as international decontamination equipment manufacturers (Bioquell). The latter have expressed an interest to engage in collaborative research.

Title: The separation of immiscible liquid slugs within plastic microchannels using a metallic hydrophilic sidestream
VolumeTitle: Lab on a Chip - Miniaturisation for Chemistry and Biology
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces a new technique for separation of immiscible liquids in a microchannel using a main hydrophobic capillary and a hydrophilic sidestream. A new pressure balance model is proposed which accurately predicts the lengths of the main and side capillaries for best performance, and is extendable to other geometries. This paper directly resulted in an invitation from the Process Intensification Netherlands group to present the work to PIN-NL network industrial and academic members (H.N. Akse:  henk.akse@traxxys.com) in Ultrech, May 2011, and resulted in an international collaboration with Dortmund  Technical University (David Agar: agar@bci.tu-dortmund.de).

Title: The effect of protein-precipitant interfaces and applied shear on the nucleation and growth of lysozyme crystals
VolumeTitle: Acta Crystallographica Section D: Biological Crystallography
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the discovery of "fingering instabilities" in microbatch anti-solvent crystallisation of proteins and their direct impact on nucleation and production of single large crystals, which is a requirement for protein crystallography. Additional experiments using controlled microshear demonstrated the beneficial effect of shear on crystallisation of protein crystals. This paper challenges the current understanding about the effect of diffusion and the use of shear on protein crystallisation, as can be confirmed by Professor Sir Tom Blundell (tom@cryst.bioc.cam.ac.uk ), co-author of this paper and hundreds of publications in the area of protein crystallography.

Title: A simple device for multiplex ELISA made from melt-extruded plastic microcapillary film
VolumeTitle: Lab on a Chip - Miniaturisation for Chemistry and Biology
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the production of low-cost multiplex test strips with colorimetric and fluorescent ELISA assays from a continuous plastic microcapillary film. It helped securing follow-on funding from BBSRC for pre-commercial development of the technology, and formation of a new spin-off company (Capillary Film Technology). It led to seminar invitations at UCL  and Dortmund Technical University, and a project evaluation by Protein Logic Ltd (a Cambridge based biomarker discovery company), and further commercial enquires from head of division scientistics at Alere (largest worldwide diagnostic company;  Alan Thomson), Merck Millipore (Christian Hunzinger) and Swiss Precision Diagnostics (Dave Smart).

Title: Fast cation-exchange separation of proteins in a plastic microcapillary disc
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development of ion-exchange plastic microcapillary discs for disposable subtractive chromatography and rapid protein separations based on small differences of pI. It was shown that superficial liquid velocities can be increased up to 2 orders of magnitude when compared to packed bed columns. This paper resulted in an invitation to join a EU KBBE consortium (VALORBIO) of 12 SMEs and academic partners in Bioprocess Intensification led by UCL (Dan Bracewell: d.bracewell@ucl.ac.uk). MedImmune is currently sponsoring a PhD at Cambridge as a result. This work has also resulted in new patent (WO/2011/117579).

Title: Multi-sensor driver drowsiness monitoring
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This curiosity-driven research demonstrates that selective data fusion using fuzzy logic can indicate driver vigilance and alertness levels in an acceptably non-intrusive way. It promises more robust methods of automobile accident avoidance in the future. The work has been continued on a new framework for Active Vehicle Safety (AVS) systems by integrating driver status prediction as an uncertainty measure in robust control synthesis, in association with Professor John Hansen, Department of Electrical Engineering (john.hansen@utdallas.edu) at the University of Texas at Dallas.

Title: Facial recognition techniques applied to the automated registration of patients in the emergency treatment of head injuries
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates a solution to the surgical problem of alignment of the pose of a patient in preoperative space to that of the intra-operative space. The work was carried out in collaboration with consultant neurosurgeon Michael Vloeberghs who promotes innovations in healthcare (Michael.Vloeberghs@nottingham.ac.uk) and utilises a synergy between white light and CT images of the patient's head.

Title: Non-contact laser sealing of thin polyester food packaging films
AdditionalInformation: Originally funded (total £683k) by DEFRA/LINK project AFM114, this work demonstrates advanced, tooling-free sealing methods for the food industry, providing significant cost savings and more trouble-free production. The Authors are the first to demonstrate this application. Close collaboration with UK food packaging and producing companies Northern Foods, RPS Containers Ltd and Packaging Automation Ltd (graham.j@pal.co.uk) led to UK and US patent applications. Separate invitations were received from Aston Photonics Cluster (with Rofin-Baasel and Schott AG) and the Welding Institute (with Innventia AB and Northern Foods, ian.jones@twi.co.uk), to join FP7 STREP consortia for “Factories of the Future” focused calls.

Title: A methodology for design and appraisal of surgical robotic systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a methodology for “good design” of new assistive devices for surgery as well as putting in focus advances in robotic surgery. The work is in collaboration with a Consultant Neurosurgeon at a local hospital, and has also contributed to Renishaw (Neurological Products Division (NPD) - http://www.renishaw.com/en/delivering-precision--6332) supporting financially a project on automated skull drilling (Kenneth.Nai@Renishaw.com, paul.fielder@renishaw.com ), as well as in collaborating in research for innovative techniques for neurosurgical procedures.

Title: Unprecedented high-modulus high-strength tapes and films of ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene via solvent-free route
AdditionalInformation: These findings have important implications for the synthesis and processing of ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE), a polymer used for demanding applications such as bullet-proof vests, prostheses and climbing ropes. The specific reaction conditions described have allowed the development of a polymer that can be processed, solvent-free, to make tapes and films of unprecedented tensile modulus and strength. The research, and the laboratory facilities at Loughborough, are sponsored by Teijin Aramid, and 4 joint patents have been filed to date. Process upscaling is on-going and will constitute the second generation of the product (Endumax®) launched in 2011 by the company.

Title: The simulation of in-plane tyre modal behaviour: A broad modal range comparison between analytical and discretised modelling approaches
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first of three publications investigating the potential for improvement of computational efficiency and accuracy of tyre models designed for ride/NVH analysis, by looking at sensitivity of tyre modal response to physical and numerical parameters. This work resulted in an invitation to lead a 3-hour workshop at the 5th Intelligent Tyre Conference in Frankfurt in Sep 2009. In addition, it has led to an invitation by Professor Christian Oertel (Brandenburg University – Germany), to participate in an international consortium of Universities under the title: Competence Network “Energy Efficiency of Technical Systems and Robust Engineering”

Title: A modal-based derivation of transient pressure distribution along the tyre-road contact
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Passenger Cars - Mechanical Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the second in a series of three, looking at the integration of an elastic ring model with a viscoelastic tread for calculation of normal pressure distribution. The paper is the first to highlight the importance of bandwidth on the accuracy of calculation of contact pressure distribution. The work was first presented at the 2009 SAE World Congress and was then included in the SAE Int. J. of Passeng. Cars, after being rated as “one of the most outstanding SAE technical Papers of 2009” according to a letter from the editor, Jim Thomson.

Title: Frictional contact behaviour of the tyre: The effect of tread slip on the in-plane structural deformation and stress field development
AdditionalInformation: The last of three papers in a series combines the structural elastic ring tyre model with a comprehensive friction law and looks at the interaction between structural dynamics and friction. Although a purely numerical piece of work, its predictions have been confirmed by experiment in the paper: Tuononen, A.J. Laser triangulation to measure the carcass deflections of a rolling tire. Meas. Sci. Technol., 2011, (22), doi:10.1088/0957-0233/22/12/125304, which refers explicitly to our work. The work carried out in this paper attracted interest by Michelin – France who have sponsored a PhD student to work at Loughborough on numerical tyre modelling.

Title: A study on the effect of road friction on driveline vibrations
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this paper was co-sponsored by Jaguar Land-Rover and the EPSRC. The strength of the paper lies in the fact that it is the first to explain driveline frequency migration as a function of the levels of tyre-road friction. The results of the project have been fully incorporated in JLR’s engineering practice. This success has led JLR to pursue further tyre modelling work with Loughborough, within the £1.7 million PSi project. Following publication, the work was also presented at an invited lecture at the Vehicle Dynamics and Control Seminar at Cambridge University in April 2011.

Title: The configuration of design and manufacture knowledge models from a heavyweight ontological foundation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new approach to inter-systems communication so as to better comprehend the complex interactions that exist between product design and manufacturing systems. These ideas are now being actively pursued within Rolls-Royce plc to develop improved methods for manufacturing systems specification and hence minimise the problems of integrating new systems within complex manufacturing environments. Contact Mr Neil Hastilow, Rolls-Royce chief of manufacturing systems (neil.hastilow@rolls-royce.com)

Title: Knowledge reuse in manufacturability analysis
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Robotics and Computer-Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This work has provided new guidelines for manufacturing knowledge reuse when utilising computational systems.  This has led to a contribution to the SAMULET programme (SAMULET 5.6.1) that extended this understanding to new methods for manufacturing knowledge maintenance and re-use, funded by the EPSRC (£206K) and subsequently funded by Rolls-Royce plc (£75K) to take the research findings through to a substantive pilot implementation. Their funding emphasises the significance of the impact of this work on right first time design. Contact Mr G Wells (guy.wells@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Extending product lifecycle management for manufacturing knowledge sharing
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper details a new ontological approach to achieve interoperable manufacturing knowledge sharing in product lifecycle management systems. The work led to an invitation by the INTEROP-Vlab task group on manufacturing enterprise interoperability (MEI) to lead an FP7 factories of the future proposal entitled “Intelligent Systems Configuration Services for Flexible Dynamic Global Production Networks which has been funded (€ 3,550K  - FLEXINET 608627). Contact G Bhullar gbhullar@control2k.co.uk, the chair of the MEI task group.

Title: Methods for the capture of manufacture best practice in product lifecycle management
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented new understanding of how best practice manufacturing knowledge could be modelled and integrated into Product Lifecycle Management environments. It led to an industry funded (£80K) exploitation project with Rolls-Royce plc in order to develop a manufacturing ontology in the context of their Lifecycle Knowledge Desktop. This is as a key technology in exploiting knowledge-based solutions towards right first time design. Our industry lead for this work was Kevin Platt (Kevin.Platt@Rolls-Royce.com)

Title: Preparation and characterization of PLGA particles for subcutaneous controlled drug release by membrane emulsification
AdditionalInformation: It has been challenging to make narrow size range controlled release particles for the pharmaceutical industry at appropriate production rates. The research described shows how membrane emulsification can be used for the manufacture of subcutaneous drug delivery particles. Aspects such as emulsion then particle production, shrinkage and encapsulation efficiency control via osmotic pressure are reported, enabling a full understanding of the desired particle generation process. A number of protein-based therapy solutions (e.g. leuprolide acetate for prostate cancer treatment) are now being investigated by various organisations using the membrane techniques first described by this paper.

Title: Membrane emulsification with oscillating and stationary membranes
AdditionalInformation: Production of emulsions and dispersions by membrane emulsification at rates of practical use relies on the availability of a modular system that is scalable. The paper describes an adaptation of the modelling approach, and demonstrates how to use information generated using a small-scale laboratory test cell, to predict the performance of an oscillating membrane emulsification. The latter is a modular scalable technique now being used commercially to make products for ion exchange and chromatography resins, and similar high value product markets around the world. A spin-out company, Micropore Technologies, has commercialised these processes.

Title: Membrane emulsification using membranes of regular pore spacing: Droplet size and uniformity in the presence of surface shear
AdditionalInformation: A new membrane emulsification laboratory device, developed at Loughborough University using micro-engineered metal membranes, is reported together with a force balance model for emulsification. The model successfully enables prediction of results based on different operating conditions and can be used for emulsion scale-up to production rates of practical interest and thereby to the production of large quantities of uniform particles. The device and techniques are being used in many other laboratories around the World, both industrial (e.g. pharma for controlled release products) and universities (for membrane emulsification research). It has led to international collaborations and a commercially available product.

Title: Continuous membrane emulsification with pulsed (oscillatory) flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a highly energy efficient method of producing emulsions by membrane emulsification in a single pass over the membrane surface. The output reports international cooperative work with a well-known Italian research group for membrane emulsification (Enrico Drioli’s group:  e.drioli@itm.cnr.it), using the techniques developed at Loughborough University and  being commercialised by the Loughborough University spin-out company Micropore Technologies Ltd. A patent application has been submitted based on the technology. It is a method to avoid the otherwise troublesome necessity of recycling the formed dispersion during particle formation, which can lead to particle breakage and non-uniformity.

Title: A three-zone heat-release rate model for dual-fuel combustion
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This invited, special issue paper presented a method for analysing the thermodynamic performance of dual fuel engines.  This technique was used on a number of projects with Hardstaff who produce heavy duty dual fuel truck engine conversions.  This was part of the work which contributed to Loughborough University and Hardstaff winning the 2010 Lord Stafford award for Innovation and Sustainability.  This work contributed towards a successful EPSRC grant application to experimentally study dual fuel engines Grant No. EP/H050388/1. (Grant value £147,000)

Title: Measurements of laminar premixed methane-air flame thickness at ambient conditions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented high quality flame thickness measurements that are invaluable to CFD and combustion modellers in validating their complex codes.  The data supersede previous data sets due to the high quality superior optics used and advanced analysis employed.  The data obtained is currently being used to validate a laminar flame propagation model with reduced chemical kinetics at Loughborough.  The data was also used to validate a multi-zone combustion model to evaluate laminar burning velocities obtained from EPSRC Grant No. GR/N02511. (Grant value £63,000)

Title: A finite-volume-based two-dimensional wall-flow diesel particulate filter regeneration model
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports an advanced and complex diesel particulate filter model that, for the first time, adopts a multi-step kinetics scheme including both solid and gas phases. This model has been proven to yield realistic flow predictions and provides deep new insights into channel flows. It assists the designers of advanced diesel particulate filter systems to achieve soot reductions of over 95%.  The model has been used to support diesel engine particulate filter development with Caterpillar. Industrial contact David Heaton heaton_David@perkins.com

Title: Large eddy simulation of premixed combustion in spark ignited engines using a dynamic flame surface density model
AdditionalInformation: This paper was peer-selected by an international expert panel for the highly prestigious SAE International Transactions: Journal of Engines. It presents a large eddy simulation CFD model which incorporates a dynamic flame surface density model. The ignition and flame kernel development models were validated using unique experimental engine data at Loughborough and both the predicted flame development and heat release showed class-leading agreement.

Title: Innovations in experimental techniques for the development of fuel path control in diesel engines
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Fuels and Lubricants
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a new experimental strategy for the investigation of control methods in the fuel path of diesel engines. The need for high speed control of fuel path whilst implementing optimal controls for the engine air supply led to the new approach that was subject to extensive validation. The work formed the basis for a widely disseminated publication by National Instruments (contact Rob Lee, robert.lee@ni.com ) and the approach taken and success achieved was considered by the sponsoring organisation, Caterpillar, as a good basis for the continuation of the research; TSB funding was obtained (contact Robert McDavid, McDavid_Robert_M@cat.com).

Title: Development of model predictive controller for SOFC-IC engine hybrid system
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a control system design for a hybrid diesel engine-SOFC (solid oxide fuel cell) power-plant. The concept explored was the first in the published literature to consider the use of an SOFC as a fuel preparation device as opposed to a thermal management component. The proposed approach and the control solution were considered by Delphi to be a unique application of the potential of SOFC technology with substantial potential for management of alternative fuels (contact James Grieve, Delphi, m.james.grieve@delphi.com).

Title: Particulate matter prediction in both steady state and transient operation of diesel engines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the conception and evaluation of a modelling method for particulate matter emissions from diesel engines. The use of non-linear dynamic models represents a break with “traditional” methods and permits the inclusion of an analytical understanding of the system alongside “black box” elements. The work was regarded as novel in the field of emissions modelling with the potential to outstrip current methodologies (contact Timur Aliyev, Caterpillar Global R&D, Aliyev_Timur@cat.com). The proposed methods were considered a basis for an industrial application of modelling to support particulate trap regeneration (contact Johann Witte, HJS, johann.witte@hjs.com).

Title: Minimum data requirement for neural networks based on power spectral density analysis
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the design, implementation and demonstration of a novel method of using intermittent fuel flow measurements to estimate the continuous flow.   The reported work emerged from a series of experimental tests.  This is a unique application of the reported methodology.  The understanding of the amount of data and its frequency content is an important contribution to the understanding of how much data is needed to reach significant conclusions in regard to engine experimentation.   The results are demonstrated and validated using a demanding data set that underlines the rigour of the methodology.  (contact Robert McDavid, Caterpillar, McDavid_Robert_M@cat.com).

Title: Car seat design to improve rear-impact protection
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART D-JOURNAL OF AUTOMOBILE ENGINEERING
AdditionalInformation: This paper advances research work on whiplash safety. The paper, and related research on car seat design and analysis of impact responses of head-and-neck which address the problem of whiplash injuries, have led to Thatcham Motor Insurance Repair Research Centre (MIRRC) providing technical support and sled testing facilities for the testing of our seat designs. This work has promoted and enhanced the collaboration with Thatcham (Dr Alix Edwards, alix.edwards@thatcham.org).

Title: Automated surgical screwdriver: Automated screw placement
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This work stems from long standing research in assistive systems for surgery. This particular work is in collaboration with Mr Taylor, consultant orthopaedic surgeon (Glenfield Hospital, grahame.taylor@uhl-tr.nhs.uk). Mr Taylor holds this work in high regard, as it addresses a real surgical need. This work has been a catalyst in forming new research collaborations with other clinicians such as Mr Atul Gaur (Consultant Anaesthetist, atul.gaur@uhl-tr.nhs.uk), resulting in new medical assist projects, and a patent application.

Title: Performance Estimation of 2-Sliding Mode Controllers for Chatter Reduction in Linear Systems
AdditionalInformation: The paper stems from work on soft tissue grasping for robotic assisted neurosurgery. Theoretical and practical work in this area have been instrumental in Renishaw (Neurological Products Division) providing financial support for a project on automated skull drilling for robotic assisted neurosurgery (Kenneth.Nai@Renishaw.com, paul.fielder@renishaw.com), as well as in collaborating in research for innovative techniques for neurosurgical procedures.   Such work has also contributed to collaboration with leading neurosurgeons in robotic assisted neurosurgery (e.g. Professor Eljamel, m.s.eljamel@dundee.ac.uk).

Title: Robust contact force controller for slip prevention in a robotic gripper
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper which describes the application of control theory to robotic assisted emergency neurosurgery stems from collaboration with consultant neurosurgeon, Professor Vloeberghs (Michael.Vloeberghs@nottingham.ac.uk). It has contributed to collaboration with (and financial support by) Renishaw (Dr Kenneth Nai, Kenneth.Nai@Renishaw.com) on devices for neurosurgery. It has also contributed to a recent collaboration with Professor Eljamel (m.s.eljamel@dundee.ac.uk), a leading neurosurgeon in robotic assisted neurosurgery.

Title: Buckling, post-buckling and delamination propagation in debonded composite laminates. Part 1: Theoretical development
AdditionalInformation: This paper and its numerical applications partner were presented as an invited plenary lecture to over 300 delegates at the 16th International Conference on Composite or nano-Engineering (ICCE-16), Kunming, China, 20-26 July, 2008. Also, it was an invited research talk in Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, September 2009, in Imperial College, London, UK, December 2009.

Title: Buckling, post-buckling and delamination propagation in debonded composite laminates Part 2: Numerical applications
AdditionalInformation: This paper and its theoretical development partner were presented as an invited plenary lecture to over 300 delegates at the 16th International Conference on Composite or nano-Engineering (ICCE-16), Kunming, China, 20-26 July, 2008. Also, it was an invited research talk in Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, September 2009, in Imperial College, London, UK, December 2009.

Title: A theory of one-dimensional fracture
AdditionalInformation: This paper was presented as an invited plenary lecture to around 700 delegates at the 16th International Conference on Composite Structures (ICCS-16), Porto, Portugal, 28-30 June 2011.

Title: Mixed mode partition theories for one dimensional fracture
AdditionalInformation: This paper was presented as an invited plenary lecture to over 200 delegates at the 8th International Conference on Fracture and Strength of Solids (FEOFS 2010), 7-9 June 2010, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The work results in an on-going international numerical round-robin on mixed-mode fracture organized by the European Structural Integrity Society, Technical Committee 4 (ESIS TC4). The work also results in an invited lecture: Propagation criteria of delamination in composite laminates in the 9th International Conference on Fracture & Strength of Solids (FEOFS 2013), Jeju, South Korea, 9–13 June 2013.

Title: Uncertainty in competitive bidding – a framework for product–service systems
AdditionalInformation: This research has led on to further Impact Acceleration funding from both University of Bath and Loughborough University worth £15k. Our industry collaborators have recognised the value of this research to their business processes and are running pilot using the method with live case studies (on multi-million pound bids). [Dr Stuart Wicks, Head of Business Analysis, Rolls-Royce plc, stuart.wicks@rolls-royce.com; Paul Green, BAE Systems Military Air & Information, paul.j.green@baesystems.com; Tracey Clavell, BAE Systems Australia, tracey.clavell@baesystems.com].

Title: Approaches to displaying information to assist decisions under uncertainty
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a curiosity driven investigation from collaborative work between Bath (engineering and management) and Loughborough universities that has led to further funding on “Sustaining Electronic Industry through managing uncertainty in contract bidding” worth £165k from the IeMRC and £15k in cash from BAE Systems [David Houghton, BAE Systems Maritime Services, David.Houghton2@baesystems.com; Richard Trumper, BAE Systems Naval Ships, Richard.Trumper@baesystems.com].

Title: Uncertainty in through-life costing-review and perspectives
AdditionalInformation: This collaborative research was presented to over 60 industrialists from aerospace, defence and construction industries during the Estimating and Managing Through Life Costs seminar held at Bailbrook House, 12 November 2008. The author was subsequently invited to speak to Rolls-Royce costing engineers, Steve Wiseall [steve.wiseall@rolls-royce.com]. The research has led to further funding of a PhD studentship (funded by IdMRC, University of Bath) and a three-year collaborative project between Loughborough University, UWE Bristol and University of Bath titled “Costing for Avionics Through Life Availability”, £600k funded by IeMRC.

Title: Using Taguchi method to optimise performance and product cost at the conceptual stage of design
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a new process using the Taguchi method to optimise product performance and cost at the conceptual design stage. The collaborative work has led to a Knowledge Transfer Partnership with Depuy International, with implementation of the approach in their medical device design process [Karen Morton: kmorton@its.jnj.com]. Karen Morton is an industrial co-author of this paper.

Title: Calculation of ground vibration spectra from heavy military vehicles
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops the first analytical theory for the generation of ground vibrations by heavy military vehicles, such as tanks and armoured personnel carriers. The aim of this theory is to predict and explain ground vibration spectra of such vehicles, also known as their 'seismic signatures'. This knowledge can be applied for the detection and recognition of these vehicles by means of autonomous seismic sensors, which in turn can be used for monitoring and control of troops movements and peace agreements.

Title: On the theory of standing waves in tyres at high vehicle speeds
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new physically explicit theory of the well-known phenomenon of 'standing waves' in tyres. Such standing waves, or ripples of sufficiently high amplitudes, appear at high vehicle speeds and soon lead to tyre destruction and car accident. The new theory helps to understand this dangerous phenomenon better and to predict critical vehicle speeds, above which it occurs, as functions of different tyre parameters and air pressure.

Title: Wave-like aquatic propulsion of mono-hull marine vessels
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes experimental results on the development of a new method of aquatic propulsion for small marine vessels (an alternative to a propeller), which is based on localised flexural wave propagation in immersed flexible structures (fins) attached to the main body of a vessel. A model surface boat propelled by localised flexural waves propagating along its keel has been built and tested in open water. For the first time, the hydrodynamic efficiency of this method of propulsion has been measured. It has been shown that this method of aquatic propulsion, which emulates fish propulsion, is viable and efficient.

Title: Generation of Flexural Waves in Plates by Laser-initiated Airborne Shock Waves
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the results of a recently completed joint project with colleagues from the University of Hull. It was aimed at developing a laser-based experimental technique for reduced-scale experimental modelling of acoustic and seismic effects caused by above-ground explosions. The paper describes a new theory of flexural wave generation by laser-initiated air shock waves, which is verified by model experiments. Loughborough’s contribution to this paper is theoretical. The results of the paper can be used to predict seismic effects caused by explosions.

Title: Modification of montmorillonite with aminopropylisooctyl polyhedral oligomeric silsequioxane
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: The paper tackles two key problems in preparation of clay/polymer nanocomposites: exfoliation and thermal stability of the clays in the polymer matrices. A new concept of dual surfactants was developed and used for the modification of the clays which can be used to reinforce different polymer matrices. A potential application of these clay/polymer nanocomposites is for single use surgical instruments, such as needles, which was developed with industrial collaborators including AK Industries Ltd, Advanced Surface Polymers Ltd, and Rondol Technology Ltd.

Title: Effect of POSS on crystalline transitions and physical properties of polyamide 12
VolumeTitle: Journal of Polymer Science, Part B: Polymer Physics
AdditionalInformation: The paper, an outcome of a £1M TSB project on polymer nanocomposites for single use surgical instruments, focused on the investigation of the effect of POSS, a new nanofiller, on the crystalline structures of POSS/PA12 nanocomposites using an advanced in-situ characterisation technique: a real time FTIR.

Title: Synthesis of SnO₂ nanoparticles with varying particle sizes and morphologies by hydrothermal method
AdditionalInformation: One of the challenges for research in materials chemistry is to prepare particles with controlled structures, including the particle size, size distribution and morphology. The paper reports the synthesis of nanoscale tin oxide particles with different particle size and morphologies via a hydrothermal method, which resulted from an industry sponsored project. This has resulted in a patent and an industry production line of the product in China (Contact: b_s_sun@hotmail.com).

Title: In vivo biocompatibility and bioactivity of in situ synthesized hydroxyapatite/polyetheretherketone composite materials
AdditionalInformation: One of the key issues in bio materials research is to improve the biocompatibility of polymer materials. In this paper, an in-situ synthesis approach was developed to prepare biofiller-high performance plastic composites with much improved biocompatibility and mechanical properties. This was a collaborative research with a Chinese University, and has resulted in the formation of a spin-out company to produce this new type of composite in China (Contact leeweng@162.com).

Title: In situ imaging and height reconstruction of phase separation processes in polymer blends during spin coating
AdditionalInformation: This work was the result of a collaboration between Loughborough University and the University of Sheffield. It has been presented at several conferences and meetings (including Recent Appointments in Polymer Science 2011, High Polymer Research Group Meeting 2011 contact j.r.howse@sheffield.ac.uk). In addition to stimulating further research papers it has generated interest from the company Laurell Technologies Corporation (Tom Trowels uksalessupport@laurell.com).

Title: A solution concentration dependent transition from self-stratification to lateral phase separation in spin-cast PS:d-PMMA thin films
AdditionalInformation: This is part of an EPSRC funded project into optimizing the structure of organic photovoltaic devices (EP/F016433/1) that has generated several papers and has also led to the development of a new sample environment that allows the development of structure within solution cast ultra-thin films to be studied in real time on the I22 beamline at the Diamond Light Source (contact: nick.terrill@diamond.ac.uk).

Title: The impact of interfacial mixing on Förster transfer at conjugated polymer heterojunctions
AdditionalInformation: This work formed part of a collaboration which included Sheffield University, Cambridge University and the company Cambridge Display Technology (contact igrizzi@cdtltd.co.uk) and was supported by the EPSRC (GR/R36329/01 and GR/R26641/01). The work led to further papers from the collaboration which have had academic impact. The work has also been presented at these conferences: Recent Appointees in Polymer Science, Reading UK, September 2009 and European Conference on Neutron Scattering, Lund Sweden, June 2007 (contact a.m.higgins@swansea.ac.uk)

Title: Direct visualization of the real time swelling and collapse of a poly(methacrylic acid) brush using atomic force microscopy
AdditionalInformation: Stimuli responsive polymer brushes are of increasing interest as sensors, nanoactuators, and other nanodevices. This work has been presented at several conferences (e.g. PolyFilm 2008 http://www.polyfilm.group.shef.ac.uk/conference/downloads/polyfilm_programme.pdf ). The work has led to other papers by the authors and guided the work of several others.

Title: Preparation of polypropylene-clay nanocomposites by the co-intercalation of modified polypropylene and short-chain amide molecules
AdditionalInformation: A huge investment in polymer nanocomposites research is ongoing, yet there are few solutions that offer immediate commercial exploitation. This research demonstrates a route to achieve this, by incorporating a combination of functional additives to achieve intercalation by synergistic effects. As a fully trained Doctoral engineer in nanotechnology, Dr Ratnayake (UpulR@susnanotec.lk) subsequently became one of five pioneer Senior Scientists seconded by Government to the newly-established Sri Lankan Institute of Nanotechnology ( SLINTEC, 2008:  http://slintec.lk/ ), part of the National Nanotechnology Initiative, funded as a public / private partnership.

Title: Intercomparison of slip flow velocity measurements of filled polymers by capillary extrusion rheometry
AdditionalInformation: Polymer process simulation has developed rapidly, yet the occurrence of wall slip can compromise the accuracy of predictive modelling, hence the requirement for robust and accurate test methods to determine slip velocity during shear flow. The ‘measurement’ methodology focus presented in this paper required expertise from research groups with an excellent track record in processing; collaborators included the IRC in Polymer Engineering (Bradford University:  http://www.brad.ac.uk/acad/irc/ ) and the Polymer Rheology group at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL:  http://www.npl.co.uk/science-technology/composites-and-polymeric-materials/ ), part of a programme funded by the National Measurement System Directorate of the DTI.

Title: Optimum sintering region for laser sintered nylon-12
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART B-JOURNAL OF ENGINEERING MANUFACTURE
AdditionalInformation: This paper was an outcome from a £349k grant (EPSRC / IMCRC:  ‘Advanced Understanding and control of Polymer Sintering’), part of the Loughborough University IMCRC, http://www.lboro.ac.uk/eng/research/imcrc/. Based on an innovative ‘stable sintering’ platform concept, the research output creates opportunity for a wider range of polymeric materials to be utilised within the Additive Manufacturing community. A collaborating company (Burton Snowboards, USA) is now prototyping components using new elastomers, as a result of the research programme - see http://www.burton.com/on/demandware.store/Sites-Burton_US-Site/default/Craigs-Show.

Title: Fracture mechanics approach to compare laser sintered parts and injection mouldings of nylon-12
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART B-JOURNAL OF ENGINEERING MANUFACTURE
AdditionalInformation: Accurate application of fracture mechanics to viscoelastic materials is notoriously difficult. Significant plastic deformation in nylon-12 occurs, so that a modified J-integral technique was developed to obtain quantitative fracture parameters, a breakthrough approach for testing components produced by Additive Manufacturing (AM). The research outcomes demonstrate how AM parts can compete much more effectively in future with components produced by conventional techniques such as injection moulding. Authors of this paper received the ‘AM Strickland Prize’ (2011), awarded by the Manufacturing Industries Division of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (http://www.imeche.org/knowledge/industries/manufacturing).

Title: Manufacturability verification through feature-based ontological product models
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART B-JOURNAL OF ENGINEERING MANUFACTURE
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates use of ontologies for analysing manufacturability of engineering components in early design stages.  Part of a major project with Rolls-Royce plc with high industrial significance.  This research will continue under EU FP7 Project, FLEXINET, grant agreement no: 608627, commencing July, 2013.  Loughborough University co-ordinates FLEXINET and its 12 partners include leading researchers from Fraunhofer IPK and University of St.Gallen, developers and vendors of innovative ICT solutions, including TXT e-solutions SpA and HIGHFLEET, Inc. and industrial partners from across Europe.  FLEXINET is funded under a FoF NMP theme.

Title: Enterprise competence organization schema: Publishing the published competences
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Leading edge application of semantic web technology.  The ECOS schema was subsequently adopted and applied in use cases for the SYNERGY – FP7–ICT 2007 (ICT in support of networked enterprises) EU Grant Number 216089.  It was successfully applied in 2 industrial case study demonstrations at the final SYNERGY project review.  This paper also demonstrates international collaboration with Prof M K Tiwari from IIT Kharagpur, India, over a period of 10 years, through exchange of research and undergraduate students.  This research was also included in a Keynote presentation at IIT Kharagpur in Dec 2011 (Prof M K Tiwari, IIT Kharagpur, mkt09@hotmail.com)

Title: Design and development of a classification system for knowledge management tools and methods
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates the value of tacit knowledge and the challenges of achieving effective reuse of tacit knowledge.  This research has led to on-going industrial collaboration and further research into knowledge management solutions, e.g. EngDoc with JCB sponsors, funded by EPSRC  through The Centre for Innovative and Collaborative Engineering  at Loughborough University (Timothy.BARNETT@jcb.com or miles.pixley@jcb.com may also be approached to support this statement).

Title: A data mining integrated architecture for shop floor control
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The early curiosity driven research on data mining in manufacture which underpins the integrated architecture reported in this paper,  led to research exchanges with world leaders in the area (Prof Andrew Kusiak, USA,  andrew-kusiak@uiowa.edu)  and invitations to present at  The Institute of Industrial Engineers (IIE06) Annual Conference Orlando, Florida, and UKKDD-2007, Canterbury, University of Kent, and role as Guest Editor for Special Issue of Journal of Intelligent Manufacturing on Knowledge Discovery and Management in Engineering Design and Manufacturing (2009)

Title: A generalised approach to the calibration of orthotropic materials for thermoelastic stress analysis
AdditionalInformation: This research has resulted in further work being conducted in the area of TSA for composite materials (EPSRC grant EP/G042403/1) at the University of Southampton. There is on-going collaborative work between the authors at Southampton and Loughborough, for example further work was presented at the ICCM17 conference in Edinburgh, 2009 (http://eprints.soton.ac.uk/68663/)

Title: A multi-scale finite element approach for modelling damage progression in woven composite structures
