AdditionalInformation: This research work resulted in a continuing collaboration and a sponsored PhD research project with local SME M. Wright and Sons Ltd. (Loughborough Contract Reference J12796). The results from this work were also presented at the 15th European Conference on Composite Materials (ECCM15) in Venice, Italy, June 24-28 2012. Finally, this work has led to an EPSRC CASE award collaboration with GE Aviation (EPSRC CASE voucher number 12220745, GE Aviation contact: Dr S Mason, GE Aviation Systems, Kings Avenue, Hamble-Le-Rice, SO31 4NF)

Title: A Study of the Damping Linearity of Jointed Metal Plates
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by an EPSRC grant (GR/S66718/01) and was part of a study concerned with the quantitative prediction of modal damping in complex built up structures.

Title: The effects of local buckling and material yielding on the axial stiffness and failure of uniformly compressed I-section and box-section struts
AdditionalInformation: This work was presented as an invited plenary lecture by Professor J. Loughlan at the 6th International Conference on Thin Walled Structures, 5th – 7th September 2011, Timisoara, Romania (http://www.ct.upt.ro/ictws2011/Keynote.htm)

Title: Simulation of energy consumption in the manufacture of a product
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Computer Integrated Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The developed information structure is being used by General Motors (Detroit) to develop a real-time energy dashboard to support decision making (jorge.arinez@gm.com), whilst the simulation of energy consumption methodology has directly fed into the development of funded proposals for Grand Challenge projects within a National EPSRC Centre (http://www.industrialsustainability.org/projects/grand-challenges/eco-factory/). Furthermore, in 2012 the paper was the subject of an invited presentation within an international CIRP Working Group on ‘Resource Efficiency’, and in September 2012, the product perspective concept was used to influence an IEMA response to a Defra Consultation on the new Reporting Guidance for Business on Environmental KPIs (https://www.iema.net/iema-consultation-responses).

Title: Endwall Boundary Layer Development in an Engine Representative Four-Stage Low Pressure Turbine Rig
AdditionalInformation: The hot-film measurements performed on the casing of the fourth stage nozzle guide vane of the cold flow Affordable Near Term Low Emission (ANTLE) Low Pressure Turbine (LPT) rig are presented in this paper. These measurements were the first ones showing the state of the inlet endwall boundary layer in a cold flow LPT rig and highlight some of the challenges when modelling endwall flows. Results were compared with  and validated  those from a linear cascade of LPT blades. Paper nominated for the ASME International Gas Turbine Institute Turbomachinery Committee Best Paper Award in the category of Turbines.

Title: Production of porous silica microparticles by membrane emulsification
VolumeTitle: Langmuir: the ACS journal of surfaces and colloids
AdditionalInformation: The paper provided enhanced technical analysis of a microparticle production technology relevant to the manufacture of cell carriers, catalysts and inorganic ion exchange and chromatography resins, and was partly-sponsored by the nuclear industry (BNFL). A shortened version of this paper was presented at the international PSA2011 (Particulate Systems Analysis) conference held in Edinburgh (www.psa2011.com/files/technical-programme.pdf) and won the Brian Scarlett Memorial and Beckman Coulter Prize.

Title: Controlled production of oil-in-water emulsions containing unrefined pumpkin seed oil using stirred cell membrane emulsification
AdditionalInformation: The paper contributed to a better understanding of the drop detachment mechanism from the membrane pores in a novel stirred cell membrane emulsification system and introduced the new model based on the average shear stress.  The work was done in collaboration with Professor Milan Sovilj (miso@uns.ac.rs), Chemical Engineering Department (Novi Sad Serbia).  A related paper was presented at 18th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering CHISA and also at 46th Meeting of the Serbian Chemical Society in 2008.

Title: Stirred cell membrane emulsification for multiple emulsions containing unrefined pumpkin seed oil with uniform droplet size
AdditionalInformation: The work in collaboration with Professor Milan Sovilj (miso@uns.ac.rs), Novi Sad, Serbia demonstrated encapsulation of  water soluble compounds within the oil droplets, relevant to reducing fat content of food and drug delivery. This novel method avoids a high shear homogenisation stage which is usually needed to manufacture double emulsions  and opens up the possibility for preservation of shear and oxygen sensitive compounds in the water phase trapped within the oil phase.  The findings were presented at International Congress on Membranes and Membrane Processes (ICOM 2011) organized by the Membrane Technology Group of the University of Twente, Netherlands.

Title: Continuous flow stirred cell microfiltration of ion exchange media to determine mass transfer kinetics and equilibrium data
AdditionalInformation: The developed model and the continuous flow setup shortened enormously the time and number of the experiments needed to obtain diffusion coefficient and equilibrium constants of ion exchange material which then can be used for modelling of any other types of contactors (e.g. columns). The mass of material needed for the experiments was greatly reduced which is of great importance when dealing with hazardous or expensive materials. A part of this paper was presented at the Particle Technology Forum (Loughborough, 2012) and won the Formulation Group prize and the best poster prize at the DIAMOND conference (Manchester, 2010).

Title: Transient mixed thermo-elastohydrodynamic lubrication in multi-speed transmissions
AdditionalInformation: The paper is as the result of collaborative research with Cranfield University and the University of California at Santa Cruz. It was funded by Ford Motor Company (full PhD studentship - £66,000), combining NVH refinement and transmission efficiency through inclusion of tribology, thereby eliminating the otherwise piecemeal approach to transmission analysis (confirmed by Prof. Patrick Kelly, Senior Specialist at Ford: pkelly7@ford.com ). It integrates R&D on transmission engineering to a holistic approach. It has also led to an invited lecture for the 2012 and 2013 Jaguar-Land Rover Technical Accreditation Scheme, held at Cranfield University. Lecture entitled “Tribology & Contact Mechanics.

Title: Capturing localised extinction in Sandia Flame F with LES-CMC
AdditionalInformation: The combustion CFD model developed in this paper was implemented in the in-house CFD code of Roll-Royce PLC. The quality of the work is demonstrated by Rolls-Royce using the model developed to produce significantly improved CFD simulations of ignition in gas turbine combustion chambers. This is aiding their work on this vital aspect of gas turbine design. This can be verified by Dr Marco Zedda (marco.zedda@rolls-royce.com), Combustion Aerothermal Methods Manager.

Title: Aerosol nucleation and growth in a turbulent jet using the Stochastic Fields method
AdditionalInformation: This paper contains simulations of complex multiphase turbulent flow problems. This work was included as a supporting reference in the case for support for a successful multi-institution funding bid (EPSRC grant ref EP/K014102/1) which concerns turbulent multiphase flow.

Title: Simulations of the dispersion of reactive pollutants in a street canyon, considering different chemical mechanisms and micromixing
AdditionalInformation: This work applying sophisticated turbulent reacting flow CFD methods to traffic pollution dispersion was originally presented at an international conference (6th International Conference on Urban Air Quality) before being selected to appear in a special edition of this journal. Confirmation of this can be found with the online version http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.atmosenv.2008.07.033

Title: Simulation of the evolution of aircraft exhaust plumes including detailed chemistry and segregation
VolumeTitle: Journal of Geophysical Research D: Atmospheres
AdditionalInformation: This work has influenced the successful application of the Stochastic Fields turbulent reacting flow method, by myself in aerosol nucleation (doi 10.1016/j.ces.2008.05.012) and air pollution (doi 10.5194/acp-10-267-2010) applications and other groups working on combustion (doi 10.1016/j.combustflame.2010.05.010).

Title: Design of an airlift loop bioreactor and pilot scales studies with fluidic oscillator induced microbubbles for growth of a microalgae Dunaliella salina
AdditionalInformation: Carbon capture technologies based on algae have gained significant attention from industry due to strict emission targets imposed by government. Tata Steel (Bruce Adderley, Manager of Climate Change Breakthrough Technology, 01709 825536) have investigated this technology to offset carbon emissions by applying microbubble technology in a pilot project at their steel production plant in Scunthorpe (funded by TSB Carbon Abatement Feasibility Studies Programme, BR046G). The work featured in an IChemE/Elsevier webinar on 14.6.12 to discuss energy efficient biofuels production using microbubbles and was discussed on BBC Radio 4 Material World (4.2.11: Quentin Cooper — how microscopic bubbles boost biofuel production).

Title: CO 2 mass transfer induced through an airlift loop by a microbubble cloud generated by fluidic oscillation
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates the enhancement of mass transfer rates that can be achieved by novel microbubble technology, which consumes significantly less energy compared to conventional aeration methods. This patented microbubble technology (WO 2008/053174) was recognised with the Royal Society Brian Mercer Innovation award in 2010 for its potential to reduce the energy input by >20% during biofuels production. The work won the Senior Moulton medal from IChemE in 2009 and the AXA Insurance Cleantech Open UK ideas competition for its impact on various important industrial processors such as water treatment, biofuels production and bioreactor aeration.

Title: Microflotation performance for algal separation
AdditionalInformation: One of the main issues of producing biofuel from dense algae is lack of an economically feasible separation method with a high energy efficiency. This journal article and  research work on microbubble aided algae production  led to an invited plenary lecture at 4th Algae World Europe in Munich (May 2012). Also following a podcast on Scientific American, this article has been picked up by several websites, e.g. http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/content.php?sid=4795).   A patent was filed on microfoatation of algae to commercially exploit the findings.

Title: Evaporation dynamics of microbubbles
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a more energy-efficient way to dry products for food manufacture using tiny, hot microbubbles bubbles injected into water, causing evaporation without boiling. The research led to a pilot project with a South Yorkshire-based company using the technique to remove excess water from whey, commonly used as an animal food. A patent on microbubble distillation has been filed, as a result of this research and the work has recently been featured in "The Engineer" (http://bit.ly/15J0mxc).

Title: A comparison of stochastic and effective medium approaches to the backscattered signal from a porous layer in a solid matrix
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: The paper demonstrates by numerical simulation that the ultrasonic signal reflected by cavities/pores can be modelled by an effective medium rather than as discrete scatterers, resulting in simpler and faster computation. The application is for detection of porosity in aerospace composites; these simulations underpin the development of advanced imaging techniques in collaboration with the University of Bristol (Paul Wilcox: p.wilcox@bristol.ac.uk). Part-funders were Airbus (Kathryn Atherton: Kathryn.atherton@airbus.com) and Rolls-Royce (Tony Dunhill: tony.dunhill@rolls-royce.com), with algorithms  implemented by Qinetiq (Robert Smith: rasmith@qinetiq.com). The paper led to an invitation to speak at the Acoustics 2012 conference in Nantes, April 2012.

Title: Simulation of incoherent and coherent backscattered wave fields from cavities in a solid matrix
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: The paper answers the question as to when it is valid to simulate ultrasonic signals from porous regions as a coherent field, resulting in improvements in the efficiency of simulations supporting advanced developments in ultrasonic non-destructive testing. The application is to cavities in aerospace composites, underpinning the development of novel imaging techniques in conjunction with the University of Bristol (Paul Wilcox: p.wilcox@bristol.ac.uk). It has wider significance for models of scattering and of material heterogeneity by demonstrating that coherent wave propagation occurs even for a sub-sample of scatterer populations. The work was presented (invited) at Acoustics2012 (international), Nantes, April 2012.

Title: On the use of silver nanoparticles for direct micropatterning on polyimide substrates
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a fast, low-cost, and reproducible, direct micro-patterning process based on the growth of photo-reduced silver nanoparticles onto polyimide substrates. EPSRC funded research (3DMintegration, EP/C534212/1) where Dr. Kay was the senior researcher on this work package. The output from this work was recently commercialised through spinout company, Sansible (http://sansible.com/en/Home.html), which focuses on safe, low-cost antibacterial and antiviral nano technology coatings. The company recently won the elevator pitch section of the Converge challenge and a finalist of the 2012 competition. The IP from this research has been internationally filed for patenting: “Additive Metallisation Process”, (WO/2012/104594), 4/2/2011, Application Number: PCT/GB2012/000116.

Title: Progress towards the design and numerical analysis of a 3D microchannel biochip separator
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the design and numerical analysis of a three-dimensional biochip plasma blood separator using computational fluid dynamics techniques. The advantages of this 3D approach over a 2D separator is the increase in separation volume and the more effective depleting of the cell-free layer fluid from the whole cross section circumference of the device.

Title: Experimental assessment of mixed-mode partition theories
AdditionalInformation: This paper was presented by invitation at a meeting of Technical Committee 4 of the European Structural Integrity Society (ESIS TC4) in May 2012. It then resulted in an on-going international numerical round-robin on mixed-mode fracture, in which the authors are also participating. This paper was also presented as an invited lecture at the 9th International Conference on Fracture and Strength of Solids, Jeju, South Korea, 9–13 June 2013. As a result of this paper, the authors also co-chaired a session on the topic at the 17th International Conference of Composite Structures, Porto, Portugal, 17–21 June 2013.

Title: Partition of mixed modes in layered isotropic double cantilever beams with non-rigid cohesive interfaces
AdditionalInformation: This paper was published as the first paper of volume 111 of Engineering Fracture Mechanics. It was presented at the 17th International Conference of Composite Structures, Porto, Portugal, June 2013 and also at the 13th International Conference on Fracture, Beijing, June 2013. The early work in this paper was presented to all the delegates at the 6th International Conference on Fracture of Polymers, Composites and Adhesives, Switzerland, September 2011, which led to the authors participating in meetings of Technical Committee 4 of the European Structural Integrity twice per year, where topics related to this paper are now on the agenda.

Title:
A viscoplastic study of crack-tip deformation and crack growth
in a nickel-based superalloy at elevated temperature
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids
AdditionalInformation: The methodologies and findings of this research work led to a successful bid, EPSRC project (EP/E062180/1, £196k) in collaboration with Rolls-Royce plc (Dr MC Hardy, mark.hardy@rolls-royce.com) and Cranfield University (Prof JR Nicholls, j.r.nicholls@cranfield.ac.uk & Dr NJ Simms, n.j.simms@cranfield.ac.uk), investigating fatigue-oxidation crack propagation using a mechanistic approach.

Title: Prediction of crack growth in a nickel-based superalloy under fatigue-oxidation conditions
AdditionalInformation: The work has led to the successful bid, EPSRC project (EP/K026844/1, EP/K027271/1, EP/K027344/1, £750k in total, 2013~2016) with the University of Southampton (Prof PAS Reed, p.a.reed@soton.ac.uk) and Imperial College (Dr BA Shollock, b.shollock@imperial.ac.uk), investigating the physical mechanism of oxidation damage at a crack tip and its significance in crack growth. It is also in close collaboration with industrial partners including Alstom, E.On, Dstl and NASA.

Title: Discrete dislocation dynamics modelling of mechanical deformation of nickel-based single crystal superalloys
AdditionalInformation: This paper led to an invited presentation at the International Symposium on Plasticity and Its Current Applications, Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, 3-8 January 2011. The research also led to a collaboration with Huazhong University of Science and Technology of China (Prof MS Huang, mshuang@hust.edu.cn & Prof ZH Li, zhenhuanli@mail.hust.edu.cn), investigating the strong interaction between material microstructure and discrete dislocation dynamics in metallic alloys.

Title: Modeling of Oxygen Diffusion Along Grain Boundaries in a Nickel-Based Superalloy
VolumeTitle: Journal of Engineering Materials and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The research work has a direct link to the author’s award of the Royal Society-Leverhulme Trust Senior Research Fellowship in 2008~2009. It led to an invitation (by Prof NP O‘Dowd, noel.odowd@ul.ie) for a presentation at IWCMM 21, the 21st International Workshop on Computational Mechanics of Materials, University of Limerick, Ireland, 22~24 August 2011. The work was also presented at an invited seminar (by Prof CQ Chen, chencq@tsinghua.edu.cn) in the prestigious Tsinghua University of China in April 2012.

Title: Crack as modulator, detector and amplifier in structural health monitoring
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a phenomenon of modulation of the resonant response of a structure due to development of a crack and resulting filtration of the low frequency harmonics.  The materials were presented as the invited lecture at International Conference on Structural Nonlinear Dynamics and Diagnosis, Marrakech, Morocco, 2012 (Prof. Mohamed Belhaq, mbelhaq@yahoo.fr) and as a key-note lecture at the 3rd International Conference on Vibro-Impact Systems and Systems with Non-Smooth Interactions, Leinweiler, Germany, 2013 (Prof. Alexander Fidlin,  alexander.fidlin@kit.edu) with the author as the honorary chairman of the conference.

Title: Autoresonant control strategies of loaded ultrasonic transducer for machining applications
AdditionalInformation: Autoresonant control is a technique developed by the author for excitation of the vibratory systems with ill-defined nonlinear loading. Industrial promotion of ultrasonically-assisted machining relies heavily on autoresonant control. The content was presented as an invited lecture at International Workshop on Resonance Oscillations and Stability of Nonsmooth Systems, Imperial College, London, UK, 2009 (Prof. Jeroen Lamb, jeroen.lamb@imperial.ac.uk ), and as a key-note lecture at 10th International Workshop on Piezoelectric Materials and Applications in Actuators and 8 Annual Energy Harvesting Workshop, Hannover, Germany, 2013 (Prof. Joerg Wallaschek, wallaschek@ids.uni-hannover.de).

Title: Finite element modeling of a micro-drill and experiments on high speed ultrasonically assisted micro-drilling
AdditionalInformation: A high speed ultrasonically assisted micro drilling system with air bearings was developed and investigated. The paper was selected and printed in special section “Dynamics of Vibro-Impact Systems” of the Journal. The materials of the research were presented at the 2nd International Conference on Vibro-Impact Systems, Sanya, China, 2010 (Prof. Qingkai Han, qhan@mail.neu.eud.cn), with the author as the honorary chairman of the conference.

Title: Synthesis of snubber's spectral characteristics for vibration protection of sensitive components in airborne gyrostabilized electro-optic payloads
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART C-JOURNAL OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERING SCIENCE
AdditionalInformation: The paper is an outcome of the international research and development collaboration (with Ricor Cryogenic and Vacuum Systems, Israel) on optimisation of a nonlinear vibration protection arrangement during exposure of airborne gyro stabilised electro-optic payloads to the extreme environmental conditions. The paper was selected for a special issue of the Journal on Vibro-Impact Systems and presented as an invited paper at SPIE Defence and Security Conference: IR Sensors and System Engineering, Orlando, Florida, USA, 2008 (Dr. Gabor F. Fulop, Maxtech Intern. Inc. g***@***.com).

Title: Anharmonic interaction signals for acoustic detection of analyte
AdditionalInformation: This paper applies nonlinear acoustic principles for the first time for sensitive, selective and quantitative detection of surface-bound particles. This submission was accelerated through the review process with outstanding feedback. In a special note to Dr. Frances Ligler (ligler-office@anchem.acs.org), Associate Editor, Analytical Chemistry, the reviewer stated "It is seldom that one reads a paper that has some truly original ideas and analysis. This paper provided that reaction for me!" It also featured as one of the two piezoelectric immunosensors in the review article ‘Recent trends in antibody based sensors’ in Biosensors and Bioelectronics (http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bios.2011.10.023).

Title: Anharmonic surface interactions for biomolecular screening and characterization
AdditionalInformation: This paper establishes the nonlinear Acoustic Detection Technique (ADT) in liquid and demonstrates its potential for bio-sensing and molecular characterization. The significant potential demonstrated by ADT led to its selection in a 14.3m EUR EU consortium named RAPP-ID (www.rapp-id.eu, Project Manager: Pieter Moons, pieter.moons@ua.ac.be) to be feasibility tested for rapid point-of-care detection of influenza from breath. The ADT instrument is now being adopted by KTH Sweden (Prof. Wouter van der Wijngaart, wouter@kth.se) and KU Leuven (Prof. Jeroen Lammertyn, jeroen.lammertyn@biw.kuleuven.be) as a platform technology for further feasibility studies, with active interests and involvement from Johnson & Johnson (Dr. Lieven Stuyver, lstuyver@its.jnj.com).

Title: Probing biomolecular interaction forces using an anharmonic acoustic technique for selective detection of bacterial spores
AdditionalInformation: This paper establishes the nonlinear Acoustic Detection Technique (ADT) as a potential method for the first ever single bio-particle detection at the point-of-care in practice. This paper formed the foundation for invitation to participate in the proposal writing for a 3.4m EUR EU FP7 consortium, named NOROSENSOR, from KTH Sweden (Prof. Wouter van der Wijngaart, wouter@kth.se), the consortium lead. The proposal has been successful and now under partner negotiations. The three-year funding will allow exploring the feasibility of ADT for real-time environmental monitoring of airborne norovirus in critical public places, and help curb epidemics by triggering rapid response.

Title: Studying adsorbent dynamics on a quartz crystal resonator using its nonlinear electrical response
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates for the first time how the nonlinear acoustic response of a piezoelectric sensor, such as the quartz crystal microbalance, can be used to study the dynamics of adsorbed particles under mechanical excitation from the sensor surface. This rapid and low-cost platform potentially allows studying the surface-adsorbent interactions for a large population of adsorbed particles or cells with important applications from tribology to therapeutic discovery. This method triggered application interests from the biological community, such as Dr Yang Liu of Loughborough University (y.liu3@lboro.ac.uk) to study cellular migration under mechanical stimulation, which is key to wound repair.

Title: Porosity tailoring mechanisms in sonicated polymeric foams
AdditionalInformation:
This is an in-depth study of the mass and energy balances that allow the control mechanism for the creation of porosity tailored solid foams using sonication. This paper has been the basis of a technology applied in the food industry for the control of organoleptic properties and texture in bakery foodstuff. A TSB funded project (101138, £500k) along with companies in Scotland (Macphie, Ashley.Baker@macphie.com), England (Fosters), Wales (MONO) and Norway
(Nortek) is exploiting this effect to improve efficiency and market competition worldwide. This paper was selected as Featured article in ‘Highlights of 2009’ and had 690 downloads (July 2013)

Title: Effects of ultrasound on polymeric foam porosity
AdditionalInformation: This manufacturing technology enables the engineering of mechanical properties in cellular porous structures such as polymeric foams using ultrasound. The effect has been exploited beyond polymers. This work is the basis of two research projects on customised textures (EPSRC #EP/I000577/1, £244k; and TSB #101138, £500k) with industrial participation (Orthopaedics & Rehabilitation - Blatchford & sons [Saeed Zahedi , SaeedZ@blatchford.co.uk], and PACE-, and Food Industry –Macphie [Ashley Baker, Ashley.Baker@macphie.com], Nortek, MONO and Fosters- respectively). An International patent has been filed (‘Process for the manufacture of a leavened foodstuff and an apparatus therefor’ PCT/GB2012/051365, June 2012)

Title: Morphological and biological characterization of density engineered foams fabricated by ultrasonic sonication
AdditionalInformation: This paper pioneers the volumetric 3D characterisation of porosity engineered structures, unlike current methods which only describe local areas or bulk features. For the first time, this strategy couples features and location. Results on biological viability of cells seeded on scaffolds with a porosity graded structure created via sonication vs homogeneous structures are reported, with the former outperforming the latter. This extra dimension of information is crucial for the enabling of ‘mass customisation’ of orthopaedic implants. EPSRC funding (EP/J501335/1 & EP /K50337/X2012, Shaping Capability seed £30k) has enabled multidisciplinary research with mathematicians and computer modellers (Steve.McDougall@pet.hw.ac.uk)

Title: Model-based design of a plant-wide control strategy for a continuous pharmaceutical plant
AdditionalInformation: The design of a plant-wide control strategy able to mitigate perturbation propagation and provide quality assurance is crucial for future continuous pharmaceutical plants. The work addresses the model-based plant-wide hierarchical control strategy of the first integrated continuous pharmaceutical pilot plant, developed at MIT. The control strategy was implemented experimentally and contributed to the renewal of the Novartis-MIT project with $40M for four years. The research team gave invited talks during the International Pharma QbD Forum, in Berlin (2012) as well as the Pharma IQ’s 10th Annual PAT and Quality by Design Conference in London (2013).

Title: Emulsion copolymerization of styrene and butyl acrylate in the presence of a chain transfer agent. Part 1: Modelling and experimentation of batch and fedbatch processes
AdditionalInformation: The paper introduces a general mathematical modeling framework for batch and fed-batch emulsion copolymerization processes. It presents, in particular, a novel approach for population balance equations that considerably reduces calculation costs. The work directly contributed to a better comprehension and modeling of the diffusion controlled phenomena that determine the effect of the chain transfer agent on the polymerisation kinetic. I was invited to deliver a seminar about the main results of the work in the Institute of Information Engineering, Automation, and Mathematics in Bratislava, which enabled my PhD supervisor to engage in the Stefanik research program with the Slovak Institute.

Title: A plant-wide dynamic model of a continuous pharmaceutical process
AdditionalInformation: The work relates to the development of a plant-wide dynamic model of the first integrated end-to-end continuous pharmaceutical manufacturing pilot plant developed at MIT. The model enabled the evaluation of different recycling and start-up strategies, which provided tools to design cost effective and environmentally friendly processes. The work opened up new opportunities to develop plant-wide control and Quality by Design strategies for the pilot plant. As a result, it contributed to the renewal of the Novartis-MIT project and gave me the opportunity to win the best contribution award within Novartis-MIT center for continuous manufacturing.

Title: Multicriteria dynamic optimization of an emulsion copolymerization reactor
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a bench scale demonstration of the development and experimental implementation of a multiobjective optimization strategy. The objective is to tailor, at the nanoscale, the morphology as well as the end-use properties of the latex particles. A multicriteria decision aiding strategy was implemented to select the best feeding profile from the Pareto set. The strategy was developed to solve a problem initially raised by Rhodia for the paint industry. The optimization approach as well as the code developed during the course of this work are currently used to optimize a water treatment station in Marseille, France.

Title: Heat integration and analysis of decarbonised IGCC sites
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded the IChemE Junior Moulton Medal

Title: Designing Acid/Acid Co-Crystals through the Application of Hammett Substituent Constants
AdditionalInformation: Design rules for the preparation of cocrystals are seen as highly relevant to industrial practice. This paper is significant because for the first time we show how in one subset of acid-acid molecules the well-known Hammett criteria, used in understanding chemical reactivity, can be used in the successful design of co-crystallising molecules. This paper resulted in an invited review of the area by the Royal Society of Chemistry.

Title: Thermodynamic optimisation of distillation columns
AdditionalInformation: This paper details methods for thermodynamic analysis of distillation columns to facilitate more energy-efficient column design. This work represents a major breakthrough that could be of great benefit to design in practice. The concepts supersede the very well established, but significantly flawed, approach of Dhole and Linnhoff (1993 doi:10.1016/0098-1354(93)80043-M).

Title: TOF-SIMS with Argon Gas Cluster Ion Beams: A Comparison with C(60)(+)
AdditionalInformation: The demonstrated capability of C60+ polyatomic ion beams for molecular analysis and depth profiling in SIMS because of the greatly reduced bombardment induced chemical damage as a consequence of partitioning the beam energy between many atoms, has led to the realisation that ion beams of argon clusters (>1000 atoms) formed by supersonic jet expansion might further advance TOFSIMS capability. Using the J105 instrument this paper explores the differing capabilities of the two beam systems for single beam analysis. The paper has been found helpful in helping to delineate the benefits and drawbacks of each beam for bio and organic analysis.

Title: Synthesis of mechanical driver and power generation configurations, Part 1: Optimization framework
AdditionalInformation: Certain classes of processes in the process industries, such as liquefied natural gas production, demand huge amounts of power to drive machines that leads to extremely high capital and operating costs. This paper is significant in that it presents for the first time a systematic approach to the design of these complex systems, avoiding the traditional approach of relying on experience and trial and error. The work has already been exploited industrially by Process Integration Ltd  to improve the design of the liquefied natural gas processes in Korea.

Title: Reflection contributions to the dispersion artefact in FTIR spectra of single biological cells
AdditionalInformation: This was one of the key papers that got people thinking about the problems of infrared scattering and is now regarded as pioneering as evidenced by  "In two pioneering papers, the research group around Peter Gardner at the University of Manchester, UK," in Spectroscopy: An International Journal Volume 27 (2012), Issue 5-6, Pages 463–496. This, plus the other 2 papers led to P.Bassan being awarded the Royal Society of Chemistry award for best young Analytical Scientist in the UK and Ireland in 2010.

Title: Solid state and sub-cooled liquid vapour pressures of substituted dicarboxylic acids using Knudsen Effusion Mass Spectrometry (KEMS) and Differential Scanning Calorimetry
AdditionalInformation: To improve our understanding of the growth and evolution of pollution particles (aerosols) we need to understand certain properties of their constituent molecules, chief among these is the equilibrium vapour pressure in the sub-cooled liquid state.  This paper is significant because it reduces some of the uncertainties in pollution modelling by providing an experimental basis for choice of vapour pressure estimation method based on data from atmospherically relevant molecules. The results have been used in new vapour pressure estimation methods (Compernolle et al., Atmos. Chem. Phys., 11, 9431-9450, doi:10.5194/acp-11-9431-2011)

Title: Complexation of lanthanides, actinides and transition metal cations with a 6-(1,2,4-triazin-3-yl)-2,2′:6′,2′′-terpyridine ligand: implications for actinide(III)/lanthanide(III) partitioning
AdditionalInformation: An alternative ligand for the separation of minor actinides from lanthanides was studied for its speciation with numerous metal cations and their thermodynamic stabilities which, in this paper, indicated the 1,2,4-triazin-3-yl molecular component is essential for the successful separation of minor actinides from lanthanides by solvent extraction. This is significant because successful minor actinide/lanthanide partitioning in conjunction with transmutation could reduce the necessary lifetime of nuclear waste repositories from over 100000 years to as low as 300 years.

Title: Nafion®/mordenite composite membranes for improved direct methanol fuel cell performance
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the synthesis of a composite membrane for direct methanol fuel cells. It shows how functionalisation of the surface of a zeolite material can enhance the performance of the membrane. The paper is significant as it provides an improvement in the performance of the DMFC bringing it closer to market. The work has been further developed and this has led to a patent application (Patent pending number GB1013526.7, Holmes, Dawson and Shanmukham)

Title: Long-term deactivation of supported Pt catalysts in the dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane to toluene
AdditionalInformation: In this paper over 1600 reaction data sets obtained at atmospheric pressure and up to 30 bar, using a purpose-built pilot Fluidised Bed Reactor, were modelled. The study used in-house Pt-loaded catalysts, which proved to be superior compared with Industrial catalysts. The work has continued at KISR (the Kuwaiti Institute of Science and Research) where Faisal is now a senior research technologist. Japanese companies are interested in powering stationary sources using the technology.

Title: A linear model predictive control algorithm for nonlinear large-scale distributed parameter systems
AdditionalInformation: This recent paper presents a state-of-the-art model reduction methodology for model predictive control of large- and multi-scale systems. This is significant because this suite of techniques can provide innovative solutions for on-line control of complex industrial systems. This work has attracted invitations for seminars around the world (UK, USA, Australia, Spain, Greece) and for keynote lectures in international conferences and has attracted/received funding from the EU (FP6 and FP7) and from EPSRC. Results from this suite of methodologies have been published in a number of scientific journals and book chapters.

Title: Simulation of dynamics of adsorption of mixed protein-surfactant on a bubble surface
VolumeTitle: Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
AdditionalInformation: There is an industrial drive for more economical downstream separations in industrial biotechnology. The high surface area to volume ratio of foams make them promising for separating surface active bio-molecules. This paper is significant because it is the first to model and simulate the molecular transport of mixed surfactant systems from the Plateau border to its surface. The results reveal how foam fractionation separations can be engineered to optimise the separation of the target molecule.

Title: Enzymatic Catalyzed Synthesis and Triggered Gelation of Ionic Peptides
AdditionalInformation: Author publishes as Miller (maiden name). A novel route for synthesising self-assembling ionic-complementary peptides is presented; start with a solution containing soluble, easy to synthesize peptides, and simply add an enzyme to couple the precursor peptides together. This resulted in a sol-gel transition which made it possible to trigger gelation in the presence of cells, hence forming a 3D scaffold ready for tissue engineering applications. This method enables synthesis of ionic peptides without harsh chemicals and water as the only by-product. Moreover the materials are being trialled by clinicians for cardiac repair through an EU project.

Title: Effects of the contraction ratio on non-linear dynamics of semi-dilute highly polydisperse PAAm solutions in microfluidics
AdditionalInformation: This is a comprehensive study of the highly nonlinear dynamics of PAAm solutions in microfluidic contraction flows at different contraction ratios, highlighting the effects of different polymers, molecular weight and molecular weight distributions. The relaxation spectrum of PAAm solution in frequency up to 6650 has been obtained. It demonstrates the feasibility of Rheo-chip technology for use as a miniaturized rheometer for high throughput rheological characterizations. It is of significance to formulation design and processing control in 3D ink-jet printing, high-speed fiber spinning and coating, drug delivery, and oil recovery from porous media. A World-wide patent application has been filed (WO-2012017246)..

Title: Trends in Substrate Hydroxylation Reactions by Heme and Nonheme Iron(IV)-Oxo Oxidants Give Correlations between Intrinsic Properties of the Oxidant with Barrier Height
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: The cytochromes P450 catalyze a range of oxygen atom transfer reactions that are vital for detoxification processes in the liver. To understand the mechanisms of formation of toxic epoxides a systematic study was performed, which explains the mechanism of epoxidation and investigates the key factors that determine the rate constants. This is significant work and has led to the development of a predictive model that enables one to predict barrier heights of substrate epoxidation reactions from empirical data only. Finally, the regioselectivity of hydroxylation of epoxidation is discussed on the basis of the observed trends.

Title: Drying front and water content dynamics during evaporation from sand delineated by neutron radiography
AdditionalInformation: This paper was one of the first papers using neutron radiography to investigate water evaporation from porous media with a high spatial and temporal resolution. The results obtained illustrated the role of coupling between atmospheric conditions and transport properties of porous media on evaporation dynamics.  Also studied was the dynamics and morphology of the drying front displacement and water content distribution during evaporation. The findings of this paper have been used by many groups in different universities such as ETH Zurich, University of Arizona, University of Southern California, Utah State University, University of California Riverside, and University of Paris-East.

Title: Experimental and Computational Study of Functionality Impact on Sodalite-Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks for CO2 Separation
AdditionalInformation: We proposed a method to systematically modify a metal organic framework to improve its performance for CO2 capture. The many-scale modelling approach includes quantum mechanical calculations to determine the structure of the modified material, followed by classical simulations to assess the impact of the modification. The paper highlights the potential advantages when functional groups of different polarity are used, and their effect in accessible volume. The best material identified is currently being synthesized by the IFPEN, in France

Title: Strength of interactions between immobilized dye molecules and sol-gel matrices
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a theoretical framework for predicting the stability and responsiveness of dyes immobilised in silica sol-gel glasses. Dye-doped sol-gels have been widely used as optical chemical sensors, but until this paper there was no way of predicting whether the dye would remain in the sol-gel and also retain its functionality. The impact is that we can now look at the structure of a dye and predict its stability, where previously this could only be done by trial and error. This will save researchers much time and effort, and could lead to wider availability of stable optical chemical sensors.

Title: A novel process for enhancing oil production in algae biorefineries through bioconversion of solid by-products
AdditionalInformation: If algae based biofuel production is to become a reality, it is essential that processes are designed and operated with a minimum of waste production. This paper is significant because it establishes for the first time, at semi-industrial scale, the processing of solid residues from an algae oil process. The paper demonstrates the potential for the production of microbial oils from the carbohydrate fraction of the waste solids. The work has already started to attract attention in bioprospecting studies (e.g. in Argentina, lcuratti@fiba.org.ar) and has provided a basis for industrial consideration of algae biofuels.

Title: Fermentability of whole oat flour, PeriTec flour and bran by Lactobacillus plantarum
AdditionalInformation: This study demonstrates that oat flour and bran (usually discarded by the flour milling industry) has the capability to support a probiotic fermentation by human derived probiotic bacteria.  This is relevant because it could lead to the development of novel probiotic beverages suitable for lactose intolerant populations. Due to their perceived health benefits, probiotic bacteria have been incorporated into yoghurts and fermented milks for decades.  There has been a recent increase in the use of dietary components that help to maintain, or even improve, the gut micro flora balance.  Grains have added health benefits by increasing the intake of fibre.

Title: Three-dimensional mass spectral imaging of HeLa-M cells - sample preparation, data interpretation and visualisation
AdditionalInformation: The ability of the C60+ ion beam to probe the structure of biological cells using the new J105 buncher-ToF instrument is illustrated.  The importance of sample preparation to attain accurate chemical distributions using the vacuum based technology is investigated, and because of the high data output the need for multivariate computational methods for data interpretation and 3D visualisation is demonstrated.  The potential for the application of this mass spectrometry to fundamental studies of cellular and tissue chemistry is evident.

Title: Enrichment of fermentation media and optimization of expression conditions for the production of EAK16 peptide as fusions with SUMO
AdditionalInformation: This work is the first study to examine the utility of integrating a therapeutic production facility into a biorefinery, while at the same time demonstrating the utility of a newly developed protein fusion system for overproducing difficult to express peptides in collaboration with Life Sensors Technology.

Title: Pulse-duration dependency of femtosecond laser refractive index modification in poly(methyl methacrylate)
AdditionalInformation: Compares refractive index structures written at two wavelengths, over a range of pulse lengths. This work is significant since three and two-photon absorption mechanisms are identified as responsible for modification of poly (methyl methcrylate) at 800 nm and 387 nm.  Multiple short pulses of low laser fluence allow optimum control of photomodification. Outputs have been utilised by the Universities of Hyderabad, Liverpool, Aston, Barcelona, Politecnico di Milano, Istituto Nazionale di Ottica Applicata, Florence; and National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan, to optimise microfluidic and  lab-on-a-chip devices. EPSRC grants (EP/C002059/1, EP/D059771/1) funding this work were rated “internationally leading”.

Title: Quantitative analysis of saccharides by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
AdditionalInformation: Saccharides are important food components, often present as coatings or binders in formulated foods. Methods for their quantitative characterisation as thin films and as monomolecular layers on surfaces are rare, but our work demonstrated that XPS is a surface technique capable of differentiating and quantifying saccharides. The database we collated has since been used as a reference in more than 15 internationally visible studies (published, e.g., in AICHE Journal 2012; Chem. Eng. Sci. 2011, 2012; J. Food Eng. 2012; Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2011, 2010). The importance of this publication was highlighted on the journal website (most cited 2009 paper).

Title: Enzymatic digestion and in vitro fermentation of oat fractions by human lactobacillus strains
AdditionalInformation: In this work the digestion of oat fractions obtained by debranning technology was studied in vitro using enzymes of human origin.  The relevance of this study is that it shows that oat bran could have more potential to stimulate the growth of beneficial bacteria in the gut than other oat flours. Oats have received considerable interest for their high content in soluble and insoluble fibre. However, these fibres are not uniformly distributed within the oat kernel.  Oat bran obtained by debranning technology could potentially be used as a prebiotic ingredient in the formulation of health promoting foods.

Title: Experimental validation of polyhedral discrete element model
AdditionalInformation: The efficient handling and storage of granular materials, from large coal nuggets to tiny flour grains, have concerned engineers for many years. Models, such as those based on the discrete element method can help in predicting the behaviour of such systems but are only really useful if properly validated against actual data. Most models assume a spherical representation which, compared to real granular materials, is an enormous simplification. The significance of this paper is that it brings together experimental and theoretical (model generated) data for non-spherical, polyhedral, materials to provide powerful insights into the flow of granular solids in hoppers.

Title: Optimisation and analysis of microreactor designs for microfluidic gradient generation using a purpose built optical detection system for entire chip imaging
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports on a new mathematical model for the optimisation of microfluidic concentration gradient generators, as well as the experimental verification of the model using a whole-chip imaging system. The impact of this work is in two areas: the novel mathematical model that reduces the computational burden by orders of magnitude from a full finite-element model and in the use of whole chip quantitative imaging to show the concentration at any point in the network.

Title: A Biomimetic Ferric Hydroperoxo Porphyrin Intermediate
AdditionalInformation: One of the big controversies in cytochrome P450 chemistry relates to the nature of the active species, where some studies seem to give evidence of an active iron(III)-hydroperoxo intermediate, while other studies prefer Compound I. This paper highlights the differences in reactivity of Compound I versus iron(III)-hydroperoxo in substrate activation and highlights recent advances in the field. Moreover, it shows that the most likely scenario is a Compound I active species in hydrogen atom abstraction reactions. This is a significant observation and helps with future catalyst design and development.

Title: Non-linear dynamics of semi-dilute polydisperse polymer solutions in microfluidics: effects of flow geometry
AdditionalInformation: This is a comprehensive study on the effects of flow geometry, including three contraction ratio and two narrow channel lengths, on non-linear dynamics of semi-dilute polydisperse polymer solutions in contraction-expansion flow geometry. Design parameters in controlling the nonlinear dynamics of polymers in microfluidics have been identified. It is the first time to observe the time-evolution of multiple vertices in viscoelastic contraction flows. The results are of significance to better understanding nonlinear dynamics of polymer solutions and concentrated protein solutions, provide a blueprint for better design of microfluidics in a range of industrial processing such as filtration of concentrated protein solutions.

Title: Characterization and fuel cell performance analysis of polyvinylalcohol-mordenite mixed-matrix membranes for direct methanol fuel cell use
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows how using a different polymer/zeolite composite can enhance the performance of a composite membrane. The paper is significant as it provides an improvement in the performance of a direct methanol fuel cell, making it more commercially relevant. The work has contributed to a patent application (Patent pending number GB1013526.7, Holmes, Dawson and Shanmukham)

Title: A software tool for large-scale synthetic experiments based on polymeric sensor arrays
AdditionalInformation: The field of machine olfaction lacks tools for design and validation of sensor arrays. A virtual sensor array was created allowing tests on several aspects of machine olfaction: prototyping of signal processing, algorithm benchmarking, prototyping and research on neuromorphic and neuroinspired processing. Long term data from conducting polymer sensor arrays allowed development of an open source  software framework for large-scale synthetic experiments in machine olfaction, featuring sensor arrays with arbitrary numbers of elements, concentration profiles of arbitrary mixtures of three analytes and parametric control of the level of noise in data. Chemical sensing researchers now use this tool via http://chemosensors.r-forge.r-project.org/

Title: Classification of fixed urological cells using Raman tweezers
AdditionalInformation: This paper was one of the first studies to show that large eukaryotic cells could be trapped in an optical tweezer system and demonstrated that a range of prostate and bladder cells could be separated by this method. This established that such a system could be used as a viable diagnostic tool. This work has led to invitations as an invited speaker at international conferences. Several other research groups now use this method and led to an invitation to write a review of the field. Integrative Biology, 1 (2009) 43-52

Title: Availability and reliability considerations in the design and optimisation of flexible utility systems
AdditionalInformation: All manufacturing sites in the process industries are serviced by utilities systems for the provision of heat and power, which are on most sites the largest energy consumer. This paper is significant in that it presents for the first time an approach to avoid unnecessary over design for reliability, avoiding excessive capital and operating costs. The approach has been applied to a study carried out on behalf of BP on the optimisation of utility systems for new coal to liquids process technology.

Title: Transferability of coarse-grained force fields: The polymer case
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we show that the thermodynamic transferability of coarse-grained (CG) force field is possible. This is a very important issue in developing CG force-fields for soft matter because their transferability would reduce the time consuming part of the force field development. The methodology proposed in verifying such transferability has been used since the publication of this manuscript almost every time a new CG force field or a new CG technique are developed.

Title: Adsorption of CO2, CH4, and N-2 on Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks: Experiments and Simulations
AdditionalInformation: Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks are stable Metal Organic Frameworks that have attracted much scientific interest. This work represents one of the first attempts to show why some ZIFs are expected to be suitable for CO2 capture. We proposed a method to identify adsorption sites on ZIFs and assessed the potential of these materials for CO2 capture, the most expensive step in the reduction of carbon emissions from fossil fuels. This work has been used as a benchmark for assessing the potential of other materials (Huang, et al. Chem Eng Science 2011, DOI: 10.1016/j.ces.2011.09.009 ; Zhang et al. JACS 2013, DOI: 10.1021/ja401129h).

Title: Measurements of the linewidth of a continuous-wave distributed feedback quantum cascade laser
AdditionalInformation: Quantum cascade lasers are a new type of laser undergoing rapid development for applications in many areas of research and industry such as in gas monitoring and being able to measure  the linewidth is important in this process. This paper is significant in that it presents a new easier methodology for measuring the linewidth of these lasers which should lead to more precise and accurate measurements.  Our work in this area was discussed by Zare in Nature (482, 312, 10th February 2012) for precise isotope measurements.

Title: Characterization of Proton Transfer in Co-Crystals by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS)
AdditionalInformation: Determining the location of protons in organic crystal structures is important for understanding the properties of any organic material, including, for example, pharmaceuticals, organic electronics or ionic liquids. This work demonstrated that XPS is capable of reliably locating protons even in relatively complex organic structures. The approach has since been incorporated in published work from several leaders in the crystallisation field (HG Brittain, SL Price). Based on this paper the PhD student (first author) received the '2010 Young Scientist of the Year' prize of the British Association for Crystal Growth.

Title: Multi-beam second-harmonic generation in beta barium borate with a spatial light modulator and application to internal structuring in poly(methyl methacrylate)
AdditionalInformation: Femtosecond laser inscription by a frequency doubled laser beam with spatial light modulator (SLM) for parallel processing is described, for optimised inscription via control of both laser writing wavelength and beam profile properties. This is significant because it is the first demonstration of dynamic parallel processing at UV wavelengths. Parallel processing scales up laser manufacturing processes, by using multiple writing beams, and enhanced  beam quality. An output is an invited book chapter in Topics in Applied Physics: Femtosecond laser micromachining: photonic and microfluidic devices in transparent materials, edited by R. Osellame et. Al. Springer, 2011.  eScholarID:151810.

Title: Electrostatic depletion forces between planar surfaces
AdditionalInformation: An understanding of salting-out forces is needed to develop methods for predicting protein solubility in aqueous salt solutions and for describing protein retention in chromatographic separations using hydrophobic resins. This paper is significant because we show that salting-out forces between proteins do not decay with the Debye Huckel screening length as suggested by electrostatic theories, but instead the range of the force is given by the Bjerrum length.  This work demonstrates for the first time why salting-out interactions become stronger in moderately concentrated salt solutions.

Title: Multi-period design of heat exchanger networks
AdditionalInformation: This work develops an optimisation approach using simulated annealing for design of heat exchanger networks for multi-period operation. It is an extension of a previous work on single period heat exchanger network design, the significance of which is to largely enhance the operability of the designed heat exchanger network under variable circumstances. The technical innovation is the ability of simultaneous optimisation of all variables in the problem, which overcomes the shortcomings of sequential optimisation procedure developed previously for multiperiod consideration.

Title: Foam fractionation with reflux
Application of a cw quantum cascade laser CO2 analyser to catalytic oxidation reaction monitoring
AdditionalInformation: Mass spectrometers are traditionally used for detecting trace quantities of gas from reactive systems but suffer from many disadvantages. This is the first time that an all optical method involving cw quantum cascade lasers has been used for enhanced reaction monitoring for an industrially relevant catalytic reaction. This lower cost, more portable, more sensitive solution has been used by one research group and the technology is being transferred to the SME TDL Sensors Ltd (www.tdlsensors.co.uk).

Title: Identification of Protonation State by XPS, Solid-State NMR, and DFT: Characterization of the Nature of a New Theophylline Complex by Experimental and Computational Methods
AdditionalInformation: Understanding the molecular structure of organic materials is important for optimising their performance in products such as pharmaceutical formulations, and facilitating their processing (e.g. during milling). This work demonstrated how XPS, in conjunction with other solid state characterisation techniques, can be used to identify phases with novel physical properties, in principle even in the absence of crystal structure data. Its importance is highlighted by inclusion in the list of “Cocrystal Systems of Pharmaceutical Interest: 2010”, compiled by H.G. Brittain, one of the world leaders in pharmaceutical solid state science [Cryst. Growth & Design, 12 (2012) 1046].

Title: High-speed uniform parallel 3D refractive index micro-structuring of poly(methyl methacrylate) for volume phase gratings
VolumeTitle: Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics
AdditionalInformation: Multiple beam parallel processing by diffractive and holographic beam control, enables both high throughput and high energy efficiency, for scaled up manufacturing. This is significant because it  allows optimised beam quality to increase packing density of 3D structures, for optical data storage, and photonic crystalline structures. The technique has influenced  researchers at Utsunomiya University, Japan, for polarisation control and high packing density of nanostructures; and fabrication of integrated lab-on-chip devices with a single laser writing tool at Politecnico di Milano, permitting simultaneous creation of diverse structure, ranging from surface microchannels, diffractive optics, buried optical waveguides and micro-optics.

Title: IBIsCO: A Molecular Dynamics Simulation package for Coarse-graining Simulations
AdditionalInformation: This paper contains the description of a new molecular simulation software that can perform mesoscopic simulations for soft materials and liquids. It represents one of the few user-friendly software for these type of simulations and includes several features for equilibrium and non-equilibrium simulations. The software is used in a EPSRC project (EP/K016946/1) and the methodology proposed is going to be implemented in a worldwide molecular dynamics simulations code (DL_POLY)  and currently is used in another EU project (HPC-EUROPA2 (project number: 228398).

Title: Design principles of nuclear receptor signaling: how complex networking improves signal transduction
AdditionalInformation: In the paper we give a systematic model analysis of different possible network structures and their implications for signal transduction using nuclear receptor signaling as an example. The paper gives deep insight on the role of different structures for the effectiveness of the signal transduction pathway.

Title: Greenhouse gas measurements over a 144 km open path in the Canary Islands
AdditionalInformation: There has been a proposed European Space Agency (ESA) network of near-Earth satellites to measure continuously the concentration of greenhouse gases between the satellites but it is not known whether very long pathlength laser measurements are feasible or whether the selected lines are viable. This work demonstrates for the first time the feasibility of measurement over long pathlengths (this is the longest pathlength ever achieved in the IR) and shows the selected lines can be used. The long term project (up to 10 yrs) can now enter the next stage of development with ESA which has led to further funding.

Title: Bread dough aeration dynamics during pressure step-change mixing: Studies by X-ray tomography, dough density and population balance modelling
AdditionalInformation: There is an inherent challenge in measuring particle dynamics during the processing of opaque fluids. This paper is significant because it is the first report of X-ray tomography being utilised to image particles at points during the processing of an opaque fluid and to integrate the results into a population balance. The results and model demonstrate that the bubble number density decrease following a pressure step-decrease in bread dough mixing is short lived and therefore the necessity of timing the change for optimal bubble size, and therefore crumb texture, control.

Title: A techno-economic analysis of biodiesel biorefineries: Assessment of integrated designs for the co-production of fuels and chemicals
AdditionalInformation: This paper evaluates, for the first time, the economical/environmental feasibility of integrated biorefineries. This is significant because it demonstrates the viability of biomass-derived solutions. This work has attracted EU-FP7 funding and provides the enabling technology for relevant biotechnological advances; hence it is part of filed PCT and UK patents. It has led to invited seminar presentations, a keynote lecture at PRES international conference 2011 and has been adapted appropriately and taught in an MSc Biotechnology course at the University of Barcelona. Furthermore, it is the basis of an invited book chapter in a recent Royal Society of Chemistry volume.

Title: Model based evaluation of six energy integration schemes applied to a small-scale gasification process for power generation
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers 6 schemes for the integration of a biomass gasifier with a gas turbine generator. This paper is significant on a number of accounts. Firstly it addresses the generation efficiency of small scale plant which at typically less than 20% is uneconomic in the absence of substantial subsidy by proposing a novel scheme capable of delivering and economically viable efficiency of greater than 30%. Secondly the process technology evaluated has been granted a UK patent and thirdly the process technology is being commercialised by Keld Energy Ltd.

Title: The normalised Kumaraswamy breakage function: A simple model for wheat roller milling
AdditionalInformation: This paper relates wheat breakage to hardness distributions reported by the Single Kernel Characterisation System (SKCS). The work has led directly to keynote and invited presentations in Scotland (2008), Australia (2009) and the USA (2010); a book chapter (2007); a BBSRC-funded project on effect of wheat kernel shape on breakage (2009-2011); an HGCA-funded studentship on relating SKCS data to alcohol yield from wheat; a Marie-Curie studentship; an award in 2010 from Perten (the SKCS manufacturer) honouring my work in this area. Douwe Egberts  are looking to transfer the approach to model coffee breakage during roller milling.

Title: Acceleration of crystal growth rates: an unexpected effect of tailor-made additives
AdditionalInformation: It had been thought for many years that impurities and additives caused crystallisation rates to be reduced. This work provides the first direct evidence that in some cases, enhancement of crystal growth can be bought about. This has caused us and others to rethink many accepted ideas about the crystal/solution interface. We were able to turn two separate and independent discoveries of this effect into a single joint collaborative publication.

Title: Integrated design of diesel hydrotreating processes
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an application of molecular type and homologous series (MTHS) matrix representation of petroleum fractions for design of hydrotreating processes. Its novelty and significance are that the MTHS representation provides a consistent basis for considering both reaction and separation processes. The modelling thus takes into account adequately relevant trade-offs, allowing more efficient use of fossil fuels.

Title: Depth Profiling Brain Tissue Sections with a 40 keV C60+ Primary Ion Beam
AdditionalInformation: The introduction of C60+ primary beams by this laboratory in early 2002 enabled ToF-SIMS to provide a molecular depth profiling and 3D imaging capability for the first time. The ability to probe the chemistry of tissue in 2 and 3 dimensions is illustrated by a study of protein and lipid distributions in rat brain.  The importance of sample preparation temperature on the accuracy of the distributions is illustrated. The approach was embraced by many groups resulting in the wide up-take of the technology (~150 sales) and well over 100 reports using the C60 beam for analysis and depth profiling.

Title: Deep tunneling dominates the biologically important hydride transfer reaction from NADH to FMN in morphinone reductase
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: We showed previously (Science, 2006) that hydrogen transfer - an essential component of most biological reactions - is a quantum problem.  The significance of this study (e.g. highlighted in JACS Select) is in identifying molecular motions that echo experimental observations – relating (macroscopic) kinetic observations to (microscopic) protein motions and dynamics. The work has underpinned subsequent studies by a range of academic-based groups.

Title: Compartmentation prevents a lethal turbo-explosion of glycolysis in trypanosomes
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
AdditionalInformation: This paper tests a high-risk hypothesis that I developed by looking at a parasiteâ€™s biochemistry as an engineer. The test was particularly hard, involved the experimental activities of my own, and other international laboratories, but was successful! The success is the basis for differential systems-biology based drug design strategy. It suggests a number of new targets in the regulatory mechanisms that prevent the turbo explosion in many cancer cells. It has served as prime example for the new disciplines of systems pharmacology, systems toxicology and systems physiology at vision meetings of leading scientists

Title: Structural, spectroscopic and redox properties of uranyl complexes with a maleonitrile containing ligand
AdditionalInformation: The fundamental chemical and redox behaviour of uranium with a redox active ligand was presented in this paper detailing chemical species exhibiting a highly stabilised hexavalent oxidation state for the uranium centre. This is significant because oxidation state control of the actinides, like uranium, is vital in the management of spent nuclear fuel by either disposal, where certain actinide oxidation states are highly mobile in the environment, or reprocessing, where selective partitioning of actinides can be achieved by oxidation state control.

Title: Integrated recirculating foam fractionation for the continuous recovery of biosurfactant from fermenters
AdditionalInformation: Market uptake of biosurfactants and other bio-based chemicals is dependent on our ability to efficiently manufacture these molecules in a cost effective manner, through the engineering of novel production processes as presented in this paper. This is significant as the application of a unit operations approach to biosurfactant production and separation allows for these processes to be understood, controlled and optimised independently. Moving towards continuous production processes increases productivity over time, reducing costs.

Title: Life cycle sustainability assessment of electricity options for the UK
AdditionalInformation: This work provides a novel methodological approach to assessing the sustainability of electricity options, with the application in the UK. This work is significant as it shows that reducing carbon emissions can lead to an increase in other impacts. This is important and timely given the ongoing debate on the future of our electricity mix and the role of options such as nuclear, photovoltaics and wind. It was named 'hot paper' by the Journal (July 2013; http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1099-114X). The work is already being applied by others, including an EPSRC UK-India project on nuclear power from thorium carried out at Cambridge.

Title: What determines drying rates at the onset of diffusion controlled stage-2 evaporation from porous media?
AdditionalInformation: A new analytical model was proposed in this paper capable of predicting the onset of stage-2 evaporation from porous media appreciably improving the existing models. This is significant because the proposed model can be used to describe the drying behaviour of porous media important in many processes such as evaporation from land surface, drying of food, wood, and pharmaceutical products. The proposed model has been used by several research groups around the world such as University of California Berkley, Colorado School of Mines, ETH Zurich, Iowa State University, Pacific Northwest National Lab., University of Paris-Sud, and University of Southern California.

Title: Sustained glycolytic oscillations in individual isolated yeast cells
AdditionalInformation: In the paper we show that isolated yeast cells can display sustained oscillations. This is a new and significant finding since the current standpoint in the literature is that the oscillations are a collective property in populations and is density dependent. The paper is part of three back to back papers on yeast glycolytic oscillations that were also selected for the FEBS virtual issue and received the FEBS price for best contribution by a young scientist in 2012.

Title: Evaluation of the fermentability of oat fractions obtained by debranning using lactic acid bacteria
AdditionalInformation: In this work oat bran fractions obtained by debranning were used for the first time to produce a novel probiotic formulation.  This work revealed that oat bran (traditionally a by-product of the food industry) is suitable for fermentation with probiotic bacteria, produces higher cell populations than conventional substrates, and could be used to produce new probiotic drinks. The anaerobic breakdown of substrates, such as undigested polysaccharides enhances the formation of beneficial probiotic bacteria in the gut which is associated with a reduced incidence of colon cancer in various populations.

Title: Development of novel wheat biorefining: Effect of gluten extraction from wheat on bioethanol production
AdditionalInformation: In the development of biorefinery systems, significant cost reduction could be achieved due to the production of co-products and this paper focuses on the elucidation of technical aspects essential for computer-based cost optimisation. This paper is significant because it demonstrates that complete gluten extraction is feasible if free amino nitrogen for the ethanol fermentation is provided via on-site fungal autolysis. Nordisk Etanol & Biogas AB has used information from this paper in its planning of a new ethanol plant (http://www.nordisketanol.se/index.html).

Title: Assessment of the Feasibility of the Use of Conductive Polymers in the Fabrication of Ion Mobility Spectrometers
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to describe a method of making a form of mass spectrometer entirely from plastic moulded components. It is akin to making a mass spectrometer from Lego. The paper comprehensively describes how the materials were chosen, how they were moulded and put together to form the spectrometer and how the resulting instrument was tested. The impact is to show that one can make instruments that have previously been made of metal, glass and ceramics from low cost polymers without greatly degrading the performance.

Title: SAFT-γ Force Field for the Simulation of Molecular Fluids. 1. A Single-Site Coarse Grained Model of Carbon Dioxide
AdditionalInformation: Process Design for highly non-ideal systems and their mixtures requires accurate equations of state to predict fluid phase diagrams and the new equation, presented in this paper, appreciably improves existing models. This is significant, particularly for industrial applications, where a robust thermodynamic model is essential. This new equation of state has been adopted by advanced process modelling software company, PSE enterprise, and implemented in its commercial gProms programs (Costas Pantelides, Managing Director).

Title: Multiscale modelling approach combining a kinetic model of glutathione metabolism with PBPK models of paracetamol and the potential glutathione-depletion biomarkers ophthalmic acid and 5-oxoproline in humans and rats
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the culmination of four papers on biomarkers for drug detoxification in human liver, integrating modelling with experimental metabolomics and biochemistry. It is the first molecular systems biology model integrating from metabolic pathway to whole -body PKPD: multiscale and multilevel therefore (also connecting metabolism with gene expression). It is being used by both a pharmaceutical company (Yates, Oncology, AstraZeneca;  and an analytics company (Vissers, Senior Manager Scientific Operations at Waters; Corporation.

Title: Direct Analysis of Donor-Acceptor Distance and Relationship to Isotope Effects and the Force Constant for Barrier Compression in Enzymatic H-Tunneling Reactions
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: We showed previously (Science, 2006) that hydrogen transfer - an essential component of most biological reactions - is a quantum problem.  The significance of this study is in developing a “spectroscopic ruler” to measure small (sub-Angstrom) changes in [hydrogen donor] - [hydrogen acceptor] distances - determining such distances, and their impact on catalytic rate, is crucial to understanding how enzymes break carbon-hydrogen bonds.  The work has underpinned subsequent studies by a range of academic-based groups.

Title: Systems biology towards life in silico: mathematics of the control of living cells
AdditionalInformation: This paper integrates a number of theoretical approaches that we have developed/elaborated: Metabolic Control Analysis, Hierarchical Control Analysis (on gene expression and on signal transduction), Hierarchical Regulation Analysis, detailed kinetic modelling of networks (silicon cell) and mosaic non equilibrium thermodynamics.  It discovers and proves two new laws for the control of time-dependent biological phenomena.  This is significant because the time-dependence crucial to signal transduction in biology had been eluding theoretical analysis.  The paper has engineered  a bridge between biology and mathematics and was acclaimed at a major conference of Mathematics (International Conference on Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Zurich)

Title: Collision statistics in sheared inelastic hard spheres
AdditionalInformation: This paper used a highly efficient `event-driven' simulation algorithm to study flows of dense and inelastic hard-sphere systems as a prototype for a sheared granular material. Simulation results are compared with predictions from kinetic theory. The work has been recognised by Vicente Garzo (University of Extremadura) as demonstrating that Enskog kinetic theories are very accurate at obtaining transport properties of granular media, even for dense and inelastic systems: see European Physical Journal E, vol. 29, pp. 261--240 (2009) and Physics of Fluids, vol. 25, article 043301 (2013).

Title: Density of states for a short overlapping-bead polymer: Clues to a mechanism for helix formation?
AdditionalInformation: We show theoretically that helix formation in proteins can occur simply from having a stiff backbone, rather than directional interactions imposed by hydrogen bonding.  Within the biopharmaceutical sector, this knowledge is especially important to controlling unwanted aggregation processes in therapeutic proteins, which are driven by unfolding of secondary structure elements in proteins.  This simple model for helix formation is now being incorporated into simulations of minimalist protein models needed to access the time and length scales to study and predict aggregation.

Title: Time-dependent non-linear dynamics of polymer solutions in microfluidic contraction flow-a numerical study on the role of elongational viscosity
AdditionalInformation: Quantitative prediction of industrially relevant nonlinear polymer fluid flows crucially relies on having a suitable constitutive model.
