This paper presents a general constitutive model for nonlinear flow of semi-dilute polymer solutions, including comprehensive validation of the model and numerical methods. Parallel computing codes for large scale simulations of complex fluids are now developed and successfully run on HPCs with up to 30000 cores. It will facilitate digital design of fluid formulations and manufacturing processes for a wide range of industrial applications such as additive manufacturing, high-speed fiber spinning and coating, drug delivery, and oil recovery from porous media.

Title: Theoretical study on the mechanism of the oxygen activation process in cysteine dioxygenase enzymes.
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: This is the first computational study on the mechanism of the enzyme cysteine dioxygenase, which is a vital enzyme for human health involved in the detoxification and metabolism of cysteine. Understanding its mechanism is important for the development of drugs and treatments for various diseases. The studies predict a novel mechanism and address a recent controversy on the activity of the iron(III)-superoxo intermediate in catalysis. We identify the active oxidant and the environmental effects on reactivity of the enzyme. The paper already attracted interest abroad and has been cited by scientists from Universities including Texas, Singapore and Kyoto.

Title: Domestic heat pumps: Life cycle environmental impacts and potential implications for the UK
AdditionalInformation: Government is promoting the uptake of heat pumps through significant financial incentives to reduce carbon emissions. This paper reveals for the first time that this Government policy is misguided and needs to be changed as heat pumps have little potential to help meet UK carbon reduction targets. This is significant given the importance of both the UK Energy Policy and the Climate Change Act which binds the UK legally to reduce the carbon emissions by 80% by 2050. It is also significant as it demonstrates the importance of science-led policy. DECC have been in touch to discuss this further.

Title: A consensus yeast metabolic network reconstruction obtained from a community approach to systems biology
AdditionalInformation: Biology has been resilient to engineering because it was incompletely defined. This paper defines the entire (genome-wide) map of the chemistry (metabolism) of the most industrially relevant eukaryotic organism (bakerâ€™s yeast). It serves as paradigm for systems biology, for organizing a research consortium to integrate excessive amounts of molecular biology information and the same methodology has been used to produce the human metabolic map, a revolutionary basis for individualized medicine. It has received intensive attention from the food industry

Title: Large-Scale Domain Conformational Change Is Coupled to the Activation of the Co-C Bond in the B12-Dependent Enzyme Ornithine 4,5-Aminomutase: A Computational Study
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: Radical intermediates are highly reactive - and if uncontrolled highly toxic - species that have long fascinated biochemists and chemists alike. The significance of this study is in uncovering novel strategies employed by AdoCbl(cofactor B12)-dependent enzymes in the control of radical catalysis. The work has underpinned subsequent studies by a range of academic-based groups.

Title: Continuous Deposition of a Liquid Thread onto a Moving Substrate. Numerical Analysis and Comparison With Experiments
AdditionalInformation:
This paper considers, using simulation and experiment, Direct-Write
printing of silver-laden inks to produce electrically-conducting
tracks, leading to a novel (and highly sustainable) manufacturing
technique for producing electronic circuits.  For various
nozzle-substrate stand-off distances and nozzle-substrate tilt angles,
the domain of nozzle flow rates that permits steady state printed
track widths is identified.  Instabilities, that break up the
continuous printed tracks, are highly undesirable in this application,
but were avoided with sufficiently high flow rates and low stand-offs.
Vertical, rather than tilted, nozzle configurations were also found to
be better at producing thin tracks necessary for miniaturised
electronic devices.

Title: Optimization of Productivity and Thermodynamic Performance of Metabolic Pathways
AdditionalInformation: Improving industrial bioprocesses requires better control of metabolic pathways for such processes. This paper presents an essential step forward in establishing cellular pathway level control for productivity maximisation. The paper presents a combined analysis of flux balance analysis, pathway analysis and thermodynamic constraints in order to predict the maximum productivity of desired products and the optimal metabolic flux distribution. It brings a systems approach to the improvement of industrial bioprocesses at the most fundamental level.

Title: Resonant Mie scattering in infrared spectroscopy of biological materials - understanding the 'dispersion artefact
AdditionalInformation: This paper represented a major breakthrough in the field of single cell infrared spectroscopy. Prior to this paper the origin of spectral distortions that hampered analysis of spectra was not understood. Through a simple series of experiments on PMMA microspheres we established that the main cause of the "dispersion artefact" was a phenomenon that we termed resonant Mie Scattering.  Quote in a paper from Max Diem "It was not until 2009 that the observed distorted spectral features were resolved theoretically by the Manchester (UK) research group centred around P. Gardner."

Title: Superexchange Coupling and Slow Magnetic Relaxation in a Transuranium Polymetallic Complex
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first example of an actinide cluster to display both slow relaxation of the magnetization and effective superexchange interactions between actinide centers. This is significant because the work indicates that actinide-base single molecule magnets can be obtained, which have been proposed for use in advanced computing devices (i.e. molecular computers).

Title: Insight into the mechanism of inactivation and pH sensitivity in potassium channels from molecular dynamics simulations
AdditionalInformation: The process known as C-type inactivation, which prevents efflux of potassium ions from cells, is fundamental to the physiological role of potassium channels - controlling selective diffusion of potassium ions across the cell membrane in all types of living organisms. This study is significant because it proposes a mechanism for regulating potassium ion efflux which is likely to be shared across all potassium channels. The work has underpinned subsequent studies by a range of pharmaceutical company-based and academic-based groups.

Title: The Systems Biology Graphical Notation.
AdditionalInformation: In this paper we define a standard for the graphical description of biological systems. This publication is part of a series of publications where I have contributed to a set of standards in Systems Biology (Nature Biotech (2005) 23:1509-1515; PLOS Computational Biology (2011) 7:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1001122; BMC Systems Biology (2011) 5:198) that are now widely accepted in the field. Such standards are crucial for reuse of mathematical models and experimental data, and are used heavily in data management structures and Systems Biology research projects.

Title: Pore-scale dynamics of salt precipitation in drying porous media
AdditionalInformation: Pore-scale dynamics of salt precipitation in three-dimensional drying of porous media was investigated utilizing high resolution x-ray micro-tomography and scanning electron microscopy. This is significant because it is one of the first of its kind illustrating the patterns and dynamics of salt transport and precipitation in porous media at micro-scale using cutting-edge imaging techniques. The results obtained enhance our physical understanding about this complex phenomenon which is important in many natural and industrial processes, such as preservation of pavement, paintings and historical monuments, mineral-fluid interactions, CO2 sequestration in rock, and plant growth and vegetation.

Title: Calculation of direct correlation function for hard particles using a virial expansion
AdditionalInformation: Virial expansions are often used to calculate thermodynamic properties but, to our knowledge, this is the first attempt to use such an expansion to calculate liquid structure. We showed that an expansion of the hard sphere direct correlation function to 8th order gave remarkably good prediction for the radial distribution function and also excellent predictions of the structures of hard spheroid fluids. We believe this offers a new and fundamental way to calculate liquid structure.

Title: Fine-graining without coarse-graining: an easy and fast way to equilibrate dense polymer melts
AdditionalInformation: Invited paper for the Faraday Discussion 144. In this paper we present a simple way to set up a simulation of polymer melts. This easy procedure will popularize the simulations of polymers among non-experts and opens the way to a series of similar methods to set up complicated polymer structures. Several requests have been received to provide the software  to set up simulations of polymer melts and composites.

Title: Flexible Scheduling of Crude Oil Inventory Management
AdditionalInformation: This work presents a novel approach for crude oil inventory management of a refinery. An innovative idea is to propose an algorithm to provide a solution space instead of a single point solution that may help to minimize the loss due to late or early arrival of vessels, which leads to a far more practical solution than the ones from existing methods. The significance of this work is that it develops a new way of presenting the optimal solution that can provide much better guidance for design and operation in the process industry.

Title: Hydroisomerization of n-Heptane over Pt-Loaded USY Zeolites. Effect of Steaming, Dealumination, and the Resulting Structure on Catalytic Properties
AdditionalInformation: Commercially, bifunctional metal-loaded zeolites are used to hydroisomerise the light naphtha stream from atmospheric distillation towers. No such process exists for low-value heavy naphtha but using n-heptane, found in heavy naphtha, the impact of reaction conditions and catalyst properties on selectivity were studied. This paper is significant because for the first time a more realistic view of selectivity was obtained by linking conversion directly to research octane number (RON). Further collaboration has resulted with Raed Abudawood, olefins team leader in Saudi Aramco. Faisal Al-Otaibi is a newly appointed academic at King Abdullah’s University of Science and Technology (KAUST).

Title: Hierarchical structures based on natural carbons and zeolites
AdditionalInformation: The work was carried out to provide a cheap and easily manufactured ion-exchange medium which enhances the capability of zeolite materials. The paper is significant because it describes the use of a new structure in the treatment of heavy metal containing waste streams and the encapsulation of the contaminated waste in the structure for safe disposal.

Title: Design of a very large chemical sensor system for mimicking biological olfaction
AdditionalInformation: Biological olfaction involves processing information from up to 50 million receptors and understanding of the signal processing pathways involved is limited. Here we describe the design and fabrication of the largest array of chemical sensors in existence so far. It consists of 4096 organic semiconducting materials deposited on to a substrate of 4 cm.sq,  is expandable up to 16664 sensors and is designed to mimic aspects of the array of sensors found in biological systems. The data acquired allows development and test of computational models of signal processing of olfactory information in the brain of mammals and insects.

Title: Restriction point control of the mammalian cell cycle via the cyclin E/Cdk2:p27 complex
AdditionalInformation: In the paper we present a detailed model analysis to unravel the mechanism of restriction point control in the cell cycle. The significance of the analysis is firstly the establishment of a causal relation between cyclin E/Cdk:p27 and restriction point control and secondly the extension of the classical viewpoint of switch points driving the cell cycle to distributed control over the processes in the system.

Title: Mathematical modelling of time-dependent densified thickeners
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with the behaviour of solid suspensions with time dependent rheological properties. It presents a highly significant breakthrough in the mathematical treatment of this subject. The breakthrough itself is highly important as the science and mathematics developed are applicable to problems as diverse as the safe storage of tailings (tailings storage failures kill hundreds of people each year), through efficient hydro-metallurgical process design (aluminium production is one of the world’s greatest water consumers), to the preparation and storage of yoghourt and pharmaceuticals.

Title: Modelling mass transport in solid oxide fuel cell anodes: a case for a multidimensional dusty gas-based model
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents for the first time a detailed 2-D dusty-gas-based transport model for solid oxide fuel cells. This is significant since it enables accurate prediction of current losses in such fuel cells. This work has set the stage for a number of follow-up publications (one already published in IJHE), invitations for seminars, talks to international conferences (Europe, UK, USA), invitation for the H2FC Supergen Science Board, and invitations for proposal evaluations from the Swiss and the Dutch Research Councils. It has also led to a successful EPSRC application involving the study of catalytic electrochemical phenomena.

Title: Molecular Characterization of Gasoline and Diesel Streams
AdditionalInformation: A novel methodology to characterize gasoline and diesel streams into the molecular level is developed on the basis of molecular type homologous series matrix framework. The method comprises the enhancements of both representation matrix construction and transformation methodology of bulk properties into molecular composition, which brought the concept of molecular management in oil refineries much closer to commercial applications. This technology has been adopted in jointly developed software by Process Integration Limited and Sinopec, and successfully implemented in two oil refineries.

Title: One-pot synthesis of amino functionalized mesoporous silica materials: using simulations to understand transitions between different structures
AdditionalInformation: We proposed a rapid method to assess the effect of organic functional groups in the structure of ordered mesoporous materials obtained from a one-pot synthesis. Functional porous materials have many potential applications, from separation and catalysis to drug delivery. The cost of production increases with the number of different steps required for their synthesis; therefore one-pot methods are very attractive. Nevertheless, the quality of the product is difficult to predict in such cases. We proposed a method to predict the phase behaviour of silica-surfactant systems to understanding the effect of functional groups depending on their hydrophobicity, acidity and size.

Title: Structure and stability of isotropic states of hard platelet fluids
AdditionalInformation: Fundamental measure theory has been very successful in predicting the properties of hard sphere systems but the formalism cannot easily be applied to other shapes. Recently Schmidt has devised such a theory for hard platelets. This paper for the first time tests this approach, both against simulation and an exact virial expansion. It is shown that FMT theory cannot successfully predict the true equation of state for the isotropic phase as it misses crucial many body correlation. This paper has had impact on research by groups in Germany (Bayreuth), Netherlands (Utrecht), and in the UK (Imperial College, Bristol and Strathclyde).

Title: Flowsheet synthesis and complex distillation column design for separating ternary heterogeneous azeotropic mixtures
AdditionalInformation: This paper extends the applicability of the boundary value method for distillation design to heterogeneous azeotropic mixtures. Significantly, the paper allows the technically challenging and industrially relevant problem of design for such complex mixtures to be addressed systematically, towards development of energy and material-efficient separation systems.

Title: Solubility, metastable zone width measurement and crystal growth of the 1:1 benzoic acid/isonicotinamide cocrystal in solutions of variable stoichiometry
AdditionalInformation: The application of co crystals to drug development has recieved much exposure in recent years. This paper represents a perspective on the use of ternary phase diagrams to help design processes. This was viewed as a much needed aspect of a world dominated by structural chemistry.

Title: Evaluating the feasibility of commercial arabinoxylan production in the context of a wheat biorefinery principally producing ethanol: Part 2. Process simulation and economic analysis
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes aspects of collaborative work between process integration and cereal process engineering, drawing on the unique combination of these two activities within SCEAS to make a unique research contribution to the emerging area of biorefineries. This work addressed the key question of whether arabinoxylans could be extracted sufficiently economically to be commercially viable, and therefore whether further research in this area could be justified. The conclusion was Yes, such that further work has been funded, including a 2.6 million LINK-funded project that encompasses this aspect.

Title: Closed-form solutions for batch settling height from model settling flux functions
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new data analysis technique for converting suspension batch settling test results into a hindered settling function, a key rheological property of suspensions. Whereas previous analysis techniques fit batch settling data to assumed arbitrary functional forms, the technique outlined here makes no such a priori assumptions. It also adapts itself automatically to the experimental noise level present in the test data. Moreover batch settling is solved once only here, not multiple times, as would happen in extremely laborious conventional approaches. The hindered settling function, once determined, can be used for engineering design of suspension/wastewater sludge processing systems.

Title: Options for broadening and deepening the LCA approaches
AdditionalInformation: Twenty years since its early developments, Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) is being used extensively by industry and policy makes, but it is also at cross-roads: do we simplify or do we make it more complex? This paper proposes a way forward and makes recommendations to the European Commission that funded this research. As a result, the EC has developed new EU funding programmes in life cycle assessment approaches (http://ec.europa.eu/environment/ipp/lca.htm).

Title: A thermodynamic equilibrium consideration of the effect of sodium ion in acetoclastic methanogenesis
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an aqueous thermodynamic model of acetoclastic methanogenesis.  It is significant in that it fully takes into account the electrolyte behaviour of the reaction medium with particular consideration of the sodium ion. It is particularly important as it provides a sound fundamental building block upon which empirical studies of anaerobic digestion can be built, thus enabling appropriate resolution of the factors contributing to the industrially critical problem of digester instability.

Title: Elastic constants of hard thick platelets by Monte Carlo simulation and virial expansion
AdditionalInformation: Plate-like particles in colloidal suspension form nematic liquid crystalline phases which have been studied experimentally, particularly in Utrecht. This paper provides a comprehensive simulation and theroetical methodology for calculating the elastic constants of this phase. The contribution is significant in that we show how a high level virial expansion could deliver values for these constants in very good agreement with simulation. The approach was an original piece of theory.

Title: Monte Carlo simulations of self-assembling hexagonal and cage-like bifunctional periodic mesoporous materials
AdditionalInformation: The presence of different functional groups in a given porous material can improve the properties of the material. We have extended the work done before for the prediction of phase behaviour of inorganic oxide based porous materials with organic functional groups to systems containing different functional groups. The richness of the phases observed increases, indicating that subtle balances between surfactant structure and molecular interactions play an important role. We consider that understanding the distribution of different functional groups in a given material will have an important impact for their production and potential applications.

Title: In Situ Spectroscopy and Spectroelectrochemistry of Uranium in High-Temperature Alkali Chloride Molten Salts.
AdditionalInformation: The in situ characterisation of various uranium species generated either chemically or electrochemically in molten chloride salts at temperatures of up to 750 °C, indicating actinide speciation is quite complicated in these environments, was presented in this paper. This is significant because high temperature chloride melts have been proposed as a medium for the electrolytic separation of actinides from novel nuclear fuels with the advent of Generation IV nuclear reactors, and these results indicate that successful partitioning of actinides from this medium may be substantially more challenging than originally anticipated.

Title: Theory and computer simulation for the cubatic phase of cut spheres
AdditionalInformation: Monte Carlo simulations show that compressed cut spheres of aspect ratio 0.2 gives rise to an exotic liquid crystalline phase, which is positionally disordered but where the orientations have a cubic symmetry. This phase is termed the cubatic phase. Previous theory wrongly predicted the nematic phase to be the more stable. Such approaches only considered two-body excluded volume effects. We showed for the first time that higher order correlations result in cubatic ordering becomes the favoured state. This paper has had impact on research by groups in the USA, Netherlands, Spain , Sweden and UK, among others.

Title: Simulation of catalytic reduction of nitrates based on a mechanistic model
AdditionalInformation: The work developed microkinetic-continuum models for guiding the design of novel bimetallic catalysts based on nanostructured fibrous carbon support. This work is significant because the approach used in this study is generic and the example of catalytic nitrates reduction demonstrates the approach of using mechanistic models to perform detailed analysis of the relevant physical processes and deliver a good understanding of the overall process. The modelling approach adopted in this study can be generalised as a methodology of investigating complex reaction systems. The output received attention through featuring as the journal cover paper.

Title: What Factors Influence the Rate Constant of Substrate Epoxidation by Compound I of Cytochrome P450 and Analogous Iron(IV)-Oxo Oxidants?
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: High-valent iron(IV)-oxo intermediates are important structures in chemical catalysis but their properties are still poorly understood. In this paper a systematic study of the axial ligand effect on the catalytic properties of enzymatic iron(IV)-oxo oxidants is investigated. This is very significant research as these species have potential in industrial applications for the biosynthesis of compounds. It is shown, for the first time, that the potency of the oxidant is proportional to its pKa value. The paper comes with methods to predict rate constants of substrate hydroxylation based on empirical data only.

Title: Non-linear dynamics of semi-dilute polydisperse polymer solutions in microfluidics: a study of benchmark flow problem
AdditionalInformation: The flow dynamics of polymer solutions through micro-fabricated contractions is highly non-linear and extremely challenging to characterize. This paper is significant in being the first to demonstrate an integrated approach, including quantitative molecular characterization, rheometric and complex flow characterization and in-situ pressure drop measurement to map out various nonlinear flow dynamics regimes. The techniques for measurement of extensional viscosity and pressure drop have influenced research at MIT and elsewhere, as one of the coauthors was subsequently employed by MIT for further research in the area.

Title: Production of recombinant peptides as fusions with SUMO
AdditionalInformation: In this work, we show that Small Ubiquitin-like Modifier (or SUMO) proteins can be used as a fusion system for producing peptides recombinantly.  Significant problems due to proteolytic degradation and host cell toxicity are overcome when protecting peptides by SUMO leading to optimal protein expression levels.   SUMO has now become the method of choice by academics for producing difficult to handle products such as novel antimicrobials, and self assembling and/or amyloidogenic peptides.

Title: Mixing times for process vessels with aspect ratios greater than one
AdditionalInformation: Due to the trend in increasing process intensification, many process vessels are being reused at higher liquid heights above those used in the current industry standard mixing time correlation. This paper extends this correlation for greater heights revealing a surprising effect not seen by the original correlation. This is significant, particularly for industrial applications, as mixing times can now be calculated for these systems without extensive industrial trials.

Title: Mechanisms of femtosecond laser-induced refractive index modification of poly(methyl methacrylate)
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Optical Society of America B
AdditionalInformation: Optimised femtosecond laser inscription of photonic structures in polymers requires insight to the physical and chemical mechanisms involved; positive refractive index modificaton was related to both depolymerization and crosslinking mechanisms. This is significant because mechanisms were poorly understood causing non light guiding structures to be formed. Positive and permanent refractive index structures written at low energy, are necessary for scale-up for laser manufacturing processes, to create building blocks for 3D photonic devices. Outputs utilised by the Universities of Hyderabad, Liverpool, Aston, Politecnico di Milano, and National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Japan, for creating gratings and microfluidic circuits.

Title: Crystallography Aided by Atomic Core Level Binding Energies: Proton Transfer vs. Hydrogen Bonding in Organic Crystal Structures
AdditionalInformation: The reliable determination of the locations of protons and hydrogen bonds is of central importance for establishing structure/performance relationships for pharmaceutical compounds in their formulations. The generalised analytical approach established in this paper overcomes the uncertainties associated with traditional analytical methods for the determination of proton and hydrogen positions in crystal structures (diffraction, NMR). This work formed the basis for the award of a subsequent 2 year measurement programme at the NIST (Nat'l Institute of Standards and Technology, USA) beamlines of the National Synchrotron Light Source (Brookhaven, USA).

Title: Mid-infrared laser absorption spectrometers based upon all-diode laser difference frequency generation and a room temperature quantum cascade laser for the detection of CO, N2O and NO
VolumeTitle: Applied Physics B: Lasers and Optics
AdditionalInformation: Low-cost and compact approaches to trace gas detection are important in a wide range of fields. This work demonstrated for the first time that all diode laser low cost solutions are feasible for infrared difference frequency generation and that novel continuous quantum cascade lasers (QCL) can also be used for low-cost detection. Technology is being transferred to the SME, TDL Sensors Ltd (www.tdlsensors.co.uk) for the QCL who are designing it into a new range of products.

Title: Self-assembly and gelation properties of α-helix versus β-sheet forming peptides
AdditionalInformation: Author publishes as Miller (maiden name). This fundamental paper established design rules for controlling the self-assembly of ionic complementary oligopeptides into either alpha helical or beta sheet fibrillar assemblies. It demonstrates this can be achieved by changing only one key amino acid. Interestingly the formation of alpha helix secondary structure contradicts the literature, but we show that the previously reported experimental design was flawed. Our methods have since been adopted by other groups and the work has formed the basis of external collaborations in an EPSRC funded project in the synthetic biology area.

Title: Surfactant transport onto a foam lamella
AdditionalInformation: There is an industrial drive for more economical downstream separations in industrial biotechnology. The high surface area to volume ratio of foams make them promising for separating surface active bio-molecules. This paper is significant because it is the first to model and simulate the molecular transport mechanism from the Plateau border to the film. The results reveal the significance of the surface mobility for separations where reflux is used.

Title: Glycerol utilisation for the production of chemicals: conversion to succinic acid, a combined experimental and computational study
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel combined experimental and computational methodology for the bioconversion of crude glycerol to succinic acid. This is significant because it exemplifies in a definitive way the concept of integrated biorefineries that produce (bio)fuels and a series of chemicals.  The paper led to the award of the 2011 IChemE Innovation and Excellence Award for Bioprocessing. Furthermore, PCT and UK patent applications have been filed and proof-of-principle-funding through KTA has been awarded. We are currently working on the process scale-up and a licensing model is being developed to harness the resulting commercial interest.

Title: Long chain fatty acids degradation in anaerobic digester: Thermodynamic equilibrium consideration
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the first full overall thermodynamic consideration of the longer chain fatty acids in anaerobic digestion and builds on the work undertaken to understand the driving forces for the digestion process

Title: Bioethanol from waste: Life cycle estimation of the greenhouse gas saving potential
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows for the first time that significant greenhouse gas emissions can be saved - up to 95% compared to petrol - by producing bioethanol from waste in a novel gasification and fermentation process. This is significant given the drive to reduce carbon emissions and the need to switch away from food crops for fuel production. This work was in collaboration with Ineos and has helped to inform the Company on the environmental benefits of this process which in part influenced their decision to build first a pilot and then a full-scale plant in Florida (www.ineos.com/businesses/INEOS-Bio/Technology; www.ineos.com/en/businesses/INEOS-Bio/News).

Title: Numerical simulation of mass transfer in circulating drops
AdditionalInformation: Erminia Leonardi and Celestino Angeli, Centre for Advanced Studies, Sardinia and Department of Chemistry, University of Ferrara, have used the ideas presented in our paper to explain why a nominally fast diffusing species in a multicomponent diffusion system can in fact approach a final equilibrium quite slowly: see Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Research, vol. 48, pp. 5654--5660 (2010).  The reason is that in multicomponent systems, actual concentrations can be expressed as combinations of so called pseudocomponents, and (as demonstrated in our paper) it is the slower diffusing pseudocomponent which is rate determining for all of the actual components.

Title: Characterisation of heavy petroleum fractions using modified molecular-type homologous series (MTHS) representation
AdditionalInformation: In this work, a new compound class approach is used to represent any hydrocarbon stream (with boiling range up 700 C) via a modified molecular-type homologous series (MTHS) matrix. It is an innovative and practical approach to characterize complex heavy petroleum fractions with molecular composition, which can derive detailed molecular composition information from measured bulk properties. The significance of the progress is that the detailed kinetic models for refining processes can be applied without the need of expensive and time-consuming laboratory analysis.

Title: Development of conducting polymer sensor arrays for wound monitoring
AdditionalInformation: Noninvasive methods of monitoring the onset of bacterial infection in seriously ill patients do not yet exist.  We describe the  development and use of a broad specificity gas sensor array combined with solid phase microextraction methods for preconcentration of trace volatiles, to noninvasively detect volatile biomarkers signalling early signs of bacterial infection in burns patients. The technology and instrumentation developed may have large impact in the future for point of care patient monitoring.  Commercial exploitation is currently being negotiated.

Title: Synthesis and characterization of zeolite Y and ZSM-5 from Nigerian Ahoko Kaolin using a novel, lower temperature, metakaolinization technique
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the conversion of natural kaolin into zeolites. The use of Green Chemistry Principles has developed a thermal process to carry out the conversion. This is significant because it enables the reduction in process conditions from the originally required 6 hours at 1000 C down to just 6 minutes at 600 C. The study will provide a new industrial process for the Nigerian sponsors.

Title: Detailed reaction kinetics for the dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane over pt catalyst
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a detailed kinetic evaluation of the dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane system where there is much debate around the rate determining step and catalyst inhibition. Using model rate equations based on power law, single-site and dual-site Langmuir-Hinchelwood-Hougen-Watson kinetics and competitive and non-competitive Horiuti-Polanyi mechanisms. This work is significant in using wide ranging conditions from over 1000 experiments including reactions carried out on bi-products and with and without hydrogen feed. One of the authors, Rashid Usman has gone on to an academic position in the Punjab in Pakistan and continues to collaborate on the topic.

Title: Resonant Mie Scattering (RMieS) correction of infrared spectra from highly scattering biological samples
AdditionalInformation: Having established the origin of the scattering in a previous paper, Analyst 134 (2009) 1586, this paper presents a correction algorithm that allows an undistorted spectrum to be recovered from the measured distorted version. This correction algorithm is available for the community and is being used by 70 groups world wide. This work has transformed the field of single cell infrared spectroscopy and has led to invitations (keynote and plenary) at several major international conferences in Europe, USA and Australia.

Title: Optimal Design of Mixed Refrigerant Cycles
AdditionalInformation: Processes such as liquefied natural gas require extremely high duties of low level refrigeration, leading to extremely high consumption of power. This paper is significant in that it presents the first systematic method to optimise process configurations, different mixed refrigerant fluids, and different process conditions to reduce their huge operating costs. This work has already been exploited industrially by Process Integration Ltd to improve the design of the liquefied natural gas processes in Korea and to the operational optimisation of ethylene processes in PR China.

Title: A microfluidic device for self-synchronised production of droplets
AdditionalInformation: One of the problems associated with microfluidics is the large size of the associated control systems often required to perform on-chip operations. In this paper we describe a simple microfluidic system for producing a droplet in response to the passage of a first droplet that relies purely on physical phenomena without any external apparatus. This potential has wide application for performing droplet-based reactions, for example studying the precipitation and dissolution of pharmaceuticals as they undergo pH changes in the gut.

Title: Substrate and product inhibition kinetics in succinic acid production by Actinobacillus succinogenes
AdditionalInformation: Bio-refineries are being developed to produce not only the fuels, but also the chemicals of the future. Succinic acid is one such chemical that has recently reached commercialisation. This paper is a key output from an EPSRC grant that was rated tending to internationally leading and tending to outstanding.  The work is now widely cited and is significant because it has enabled the mathematical modelling of succinic acid production for the first time.

Title: Controlled germination to enhance the functional properties of rice
AdditionalInformation: Results in this work suggest that different malting strategies, with longer germination times could be designed to maximise the production prebiotic oligosaccharides in cereal grains.  This is significant because it is increasingly recognised the positive effects of non-digestible carbohydrates like prebiotics in the promotion of beneficial bacteria in the gut and human health.  Traditionally, malting processes have been developed to maximise sugar production for later fermentation like in the brewing process. These naturally developed prebiotics through these new malting strategies could be used directly as functional foods or ingredients.

Title: A New Dynamic in Mass Spectral Imaging of Single Biological Cells
AdditionalInformation: Although the introduction of C60+ primary beams has enabled ToF-SIMS to provide a molecular depth profiling and 3D imaging capability, high lateral resolution performance, is severely limited by the pulsed nature of current instruments.  A completely new instrument, J105, using a dc primary ion beam that overcomes many of the drawbacks is described. The stream of secondary ions is sampled using a buncher-harmonic-ToF arrangement. The concept is validated by studies of biological samples generating 2D and 3D images showing subcellular molecular localization while maintaining high mass resolution. Two £1m instruments have been installed in the US (2011) and Sweden (2012).

Title: Molecular components-based representation of petroleum fractions
AdditionalInformation: The paper extends previous work on characterising petroleum fractions in terms of the molecular type and homologous series. The work concerns the economically important product of diesel, improving the modelling of diesel hydrotreating, with its integrated reaction and separation processes; such modelling is vital if crude oil is to be used efficiently for transport now and in the future. The paper was highlighted in the IChemE Journals section of The Chemical Engineer in May 2011.

Title: The Structure of a Supersaturated Solution: A Neutron Scattering Study of Aqueous Urea
AdditionalInformation: In industrial crystallisation, the relationship between solution chemistry and crystal nucleation is critically important. This paper is the first ever example of the use of neutron scattering to provide structural information on the nature of the supersaturated solution state. It showed an unexpected response to metastability in which molecules of urea became more hydrated than expected.

Title: Value analysis tool for feasibility studies of biorefineries integrated with value added production
AdditionalInformation: This article was listed in the "25 Hottest Articles" (January to March 2008) of Chemical Engineering Science, illustrating the increasing importance of biorefineries and design issues associated with them, and the impact of innovations such as the one presented in this paper.

Title: Large-Scale Chemical Sensor Array Testing Biological Olfaction Concepts
AdditionalInformation: Biological olfactory systems are characterized by a large number of sensors with broad overlapping specificities where  the sensitivity and selectivity of the system is enhanced by huge redundancy of the olfactory receptor neurons. A realistic artifact of the olfactory epithelium was developed as a large sensor array mimicking features of olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs), including broad and overlapping selectivity to many odours, combinatorial responses, high redundancy, and different dynamic ranges exhibited by same types of ORNs.  The ability to classify, quantify pure analytes, and to segment binary mixtures is demonstrated, illustrating the potential of biomimetic sensing systems for practical applications.

Title: Understanding the behaviour of pulsed laser dry and wet micromachining processes by multi-phase smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) modelling
VolumeTitle: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
AdditionalInformation: Smoothed particle hydrodynamic modelling method is commonly used for the study of star behaviour and computer animations in films. This work is the first to apply such a modelling technique to laser micro-machining where multiple phase interactions (solid, liquid, vapour) take place. In addition, water flow was introduced during laser micro-machining of metals, which was modelled successfully. The model was validated by experiments and was used to understand the behaviour of laser precision machining of coronary stents with flow water. Such a machining technology has been commercialised by Swistec AG.

Title: Analysis of a two-fluid sprayer and its use to develop the number size distribution moments spray model: part II: computational analysis
AdditionalInformation: Project supervisor (student - Emekwuru). Addresses the latest methods of modelling using a moments-based spray model - of interest to spray modellers and sprayer developers. Moments-based approach based on modelling work at Manchester (Beck & Watkins, Proc. R. Soc. Lond. A, Vol. 459, pp1365-1394, 2003) now available in open source code OPENFLOW.

Title: Verification of 3-D parallel CDM software for the analysis of creep failure in the HAZ region of Cr-Mo-V crosswelds
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: The reported investigation verifies software {DAMAGE XXX} that runs at high-speed on parallel computers to analyse creep failure in 3-D welded steel components at 575-600C. The aim was to analyse initiation and growth of damage in pressure vessel welds in Nuclear plant. Industry provided test data on a 3-D welded structure, to benchmark 2 and 3-D Continuum Damage Mechanics analyses. Excellent agreement was obtained between experiments and the 2 & 3-D analyses. Subsequently, the software was used to analyse pressure vessel weld failure to the satisfaction of British Energy-EDF[Dean]. Paper underpinned a plenary lecture at an international conference.

Title: Towards the development of RANS models for conjugate heat transfer
AdditionalInformation: This research, part of Dr Uapipatanakul's  PhD programme, is probably the first to develop a RANS model for turbulent conjugate heat transfer, which can predict the penetration of turbulent temperature fluctuations into a solid. This opens the possibility for economical conjugate heat transfer simulations, which can provide reliable input for thermal fatigue analysis. Another major contribution of this investigation is that it proposes a model for the transport of the temperature variance and its dissipation rate, which results in the correct wall behaviour for both isothermal and uniform flux thermal boundary conditions.

Title: Approximate J estimates for circumferential cracked pipes under primary and secondary stresses
AdditionalInformation: This article interprets  finite element data in terms of fracture mechanics assessment methods.  This paper contains data which have contributed to a larger body of finite element and experimental data which are being used to develop revised, less-conservative and more comprehensive advice for the defect assessment procedure R6.  These revisions were drafted in 2012 with a view to validating the proposals against experimental data and then finalising the revisions by the end of 2013.  R6 is widely used and its developments have led developments in other defect assessment methods such as BS7910 and ASME FFS-1/API579.

Title: Whole-body inverse dynamics over a complete gait cycle based only on measured kinematics
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents an innovative clinical gait analysis technique using a novel combined approach based on the biomechanical modelling of the whole human body and the 3D infrared motion analysis system. The integrated methodology proposed has large application potentials in clinical gait analysis, ambulatory motion monitoring and rehabilitation engineering.. The work has drawn great attention from the biomechanical engineering community. The authors were invited to give a talk based on the work in the 8th World Congress on Computational Mechanics, (Venice, Italy, 2 August, 2008), a highly recognized meeting on mechanics theories and practices.

Title: The influence of geometry on the flow rate sensitivity to applied voltage within cone-jet mode electrospray
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides a significant step in understanding the role of various system geometries in the control of the electric field induced flow in electrosprays. This work is of great importance in the design of optimised electrospray systems for applications that range from mass specrometric analysis to novel drug delivery systems.  The results from this paper have been used in the optimisation of a novel high resolution printing technology from QMUL spin out company EMDOT Ltd.

Title: Simplified models for residual stress prediction in thermally sprayed coatings
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: Considerable efforts have been made in recent years to understand and predict the residual stress that develop during the manufacture of thermally sprayed coatings. This stress is important since its existence in high magnitudes in coatings can cause unpredicted failures arising typically from debonding, cracking, and spallation.  The simple analytical models developed, although restricted for the prediction of residual stress that arise from spraying a steel-alloy coating onto a copper-alloy substrate (a combination used in the casting industry)  have wide applicability. The first author of the paper was a PhD student and the work formed part of his doctoral thesis.

Title: Experimental investigation of buoyant flows in inclined differentially heated cavities
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This is probably the first systematic experimental investigation of three-dimensional and unsteady structures in natural convection flows in inclined cavities. Such flows are relevant to several engineering sectors, including the nuclear sector. The detailed flow and thermal measurements, which include fre4quency spectra of temperature fluctuations, reveal the presence of large-scale three-dimensional structures, not previously reported, quantify their effect on thermal mixing and also provide challenging validation data for CFD codes, for natural convection simulations. The work was partially funded by EDF-Energy (Barnwood), who are now fully funding a PhD study on mixed convection, and formed part Dr Esteifi’s PhD research.

Title: Receptivity of High-Speed Boundary Layer to Temperature Spottiness
AdditionalInformation: Correct prediction of laminar-turbulent transition location in the boundary layer is highly important for design of hypersonic vehicles. The paper presents results on direct numerical simulation of receptivity of a high speed boundary layer to temperature spottiness. A detailed theoretical interpretation of the numerical results has been obtained that reveals the mechanism of the early-stage instability of laminar boundary layer caused by temperature spots. Overall, the paper contributes to the fundamental theory of laminar-turbulent transition. In addition, the obtained results can immediately be used in the active flow control to delay/advance laminar-turbulent transition.

Title: Calculation of optimum cutting parameters based on minimum energy footprint
AdditionalInformation: This paper addresses two major society and industry grant challenges of energy and sustainability. In this paper introduced for the first time mathematical models and methodology (basis for software) for optimising energy use in manufacture through appropriate objective functions. The paper demonstrates that the energy intensity of machining can be improved by 64%. The paper is published in a key publication of the International Academy of Production Engineering. The bottom-up approach was key to winning a 1.4 million EPSRC EXHUME project in 2012 where I lead resource efficiency and optimisation in cross sector re-manufacturing.

Title: Internal resonance of vibrational modes in single-walled carbon nanotubes
VolumeTitle: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series A: Mathematical, physical & engineering sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper present the first molecular dynamics evidence to support the likely existence of automated vibration transformation in nano-structures. The influence of atomic scale interactions was demonstrated by bridging the gap between continuum mechanics model and atomic scale model. This automated vibration transformation may be potentially used in the design of nano-sensor and other devices. The project was supported by Shell. The co-author was a Ph.D student.

Title: Mesoscale mechanical model for intergranular stress corrosion cracking and implications for microstructure engineering
AdditionalInformation: Intergranular stress corrosion cracking (IGSCC) is the major deterioration mechanism in materials operating in aggressive environments with significant financial effects for many industries, e.g. nuclear, chemical, transport infrastructure.  Understanding the effect of material microstructure on IGSCC is essential for life assessment of existing structures and designing materials with improved resistance. This work brings to the engineering community an original modelling methodology combining microstructural, environmental and mechanical impacts on IGSCC. It has been recognised by Rolls-Royce (funder through MoD Nuclear Propulsion R&D Programme) and Amec (formerly Serco) as superior to currently used approaches and will aid their R&D programmes.

Title: Microcracks in nuclear graphite and highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG)
AdditionalInformation: The understanding of the behaviour of  micro-cracks in artificial graphite  under irradiation, as used in the moderators of nuclear reactors, is vital to the understanding of the build up of stresses. This work has lead to the Nuclear Graphite Research Group at Manchester obtaining a part in an EPSRC (EP/I003169/1) funded consortium investigating the fundamentals of irradiation behaviour in graphite. As irradiation induced changes to AGR and graphite component properties are determined by the behaviour of these microcracks this work is used as a justification for mechanistic models used by EDF for life extension and safety cases.

Title: Modelling the structural response of GLARE panels to blast load
AdditionalInformation: The structural response of fibre metal panels subjected to air-blast loading is described by using LS-DYNA. A cohesive tie-break algorithm is developed to model interfacial debonding between plies. The blast loads are simulated using a blast algorithm and a multi-material Arbitrary Lagrangian Eulerian formulation with fluid structure interaction. The numerical results were validated by experiments performed by industrial partners (EU-FP6 AST5-CT-2006-031011). The work secured MoD funding (MAST INV259, Qinetiq, Technical Manager AEGCS-Technology Insertion) and will assist designers to predict damage resistance/tolerance of complex multilayered hybrid structures subjected to explosive charges without resorting to empirical laws or extensive experimentation.

Title: Marine Cloud Brightening
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical & Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This extensive paper reports progress on several fronts in the proposed use of Flettner-rotor-driven, unmanned vessels to seed maritime stratus clouds, thus raising their albedo and alleviating impacts of climate change. The paper reaffirms the benefits of the approach (from the point of view of safety, effectiveness and cost) in keeping rises in the Earth’s temperature within bounds for two or three decades until very-low-carbon modes of living can be achieved.

Title: Modelling of the electrochemical process by the boundary element method
AdditionalInformation: Since electrochemical machining (ECM) is a complex process, modeling ECM so far has been restricted to simple drilling operations using finite elements. The paper is novel because it shows that other electrical machining operations such as turning and milling can also be modelled. These results have been verified extensively verified and the results are reported in the first author’s PhD thesis. Further experimental and modeling work has shown that it is possible to machine features using ecm techniques thus avoiding the use of expensive die sinking equipment.

Title: Non-Darcy effects on conjugate double-diffusive natural convection in a variable porous layer sandwiched by finite thickness walls
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: This study is intended to provide fundamental contributions to heat transfer in a porous media by optimizing the engineering parameters of interest as given by temperature and species fields. Porous media is an extensively researched engineering topic; however most man made applications are still preoccupied by rudimentary engineering design methodologies lacking in rigor and applicability. The effort in this study is specifically designed to provide a fundamental basis for useful engineering correlations dedicated for geothermal heat utilization in a way that complements and supersedes some of the publications in the recent literature.

Title: The effect of ultra-low frequency pulsations on tearing during deep drawing of cylindrical cups
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Invited to publish in a special issue of the journal and the work was funded by an FP5 grant. This part of the work was carried out in conjunction with TNO in The Netherlands and the technology was subsequently used in a 1000 press tonne designed and built by Neff Ltd in Karlsruhe. The economic impact of pulsating technology was demonstrated by FIAT, one of the FP6 partners, who were able to draw the oil sump for one of their cars in one stage rather than usual two.  This work is reported in Ali’s PhD thesis.

Title: Some swirling flow challenges for turbulent CFD
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper appeared in the 50th anniversary issue of Flow, Turbulence & Combustion. (The paper had arisen from a keynote lecture Launder had given shortly before.) It demonstrates the power of Unsteady RANS to provide a relatively cheap (compared with Large-Eddy Simulation) modelling strategy for large-scale structures in essentially unsteady flows and the benefits of the TCL stress-transport closure (previously developed by the authors) for complex steady flows.

Title: Apportioning aviation CO2 emissions to regional administrations for monitoring and target setting
AdditionalInformation: This paper built upon the high profile UK-focused aviation research presenting a new method for apportioning international aviation emissions to regions, using the example of the UK but of relevance to all nations world-wide.  The work was originally presented and written for the European Transport Conference where the paper won 2nd prize. The method was developed for a project funded by the North West Development Agency and has subsequently fed into debates regarding the inclusion of aviation within UK's Climate Change Act and regional carbon targets through engagement with the UK Committee on Climate Climate and Manchester City Council.

Title: Analytical solutions for heat transfer on fractal and pre-fractal domains
AdditionalInformation: The use of porous materials is evidently growing with applications ranging from lightweight structures, impact resistant foams to compact heat exchangers.  The ability to analysis these types of material/structures is severely inhibited by unrealistic representations of the underpinning geometry and computational issues.  The ability to obtain solutions on fractals is a major step towards the analysis of porous structures in commercial applications. The work has been extended recently with the development of a transport equation approach for fractals and a new PhD student has begun work on the analysis of porous heat exchangers and an EPSRC proposal is being prepared.

Title: Reynolds stress transport models in unsteady and non-equilibrium turbulent flows
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation:
The paper examines the capability of a number of stress transport models to predict a range of non-equilibrium turbulent flow features, in both steady and unsteady flows. Applications include flows with forced unsteadiness and impinging flows with natural large-scale instabilities. The contribution of different elements within the models are examined and evaluated, and some model modifications are tested. The results point towards elements in the pressure-strain process, and to some extent the lenthscale equation, that should be considered further in future modelling work of such flows.

The models and the reasons for their performance are analysed.

Title: The finite element analysis of melt flow behaviour in micro-injection moulding
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Micro-injection moulding is a key technologies for micro-manufacture. In this research, a Finite Element Analysis system is used to verify the effects of selected process parameters. A special attention is paid to the melt flow sensitivity when filling micro channels, particularly the factors affecting shear rate and temperature. The results of this investigation were compared with those reported in an experimental study. Conclusions are made about the accuracy and sensitivity of the proposed simulation model. The research reported in this paper is funded within the framework of the EC FP6 Networks of Excellence, “Multi-Material Micro Manufacture (4M): Technologies and Applications”.

Title: Validated numerical analysis of residual stresses in Safety Relief Valve (SRV) nozzle mock-ups
AdditionalInformation: So-called primary water stress corrosion cracking at dissimilar metal welds is a serious world-wide problem for pressurised water reactors.  It is driven by weld residual stresses.  Its risk is normally mitigated by application of weld overlays to potentially susceptible welds, a complex and expensive process that requires extended reactor outages and consequent loss of generation (typically £1.2M per day at Sizewell B in the UK).  This research produced accurate predictions of residual stress that supported an inspection-based mitigation strategy, avoiding the need for overlay welding and reducing overall operator radiation doses.

Title: Failure in Notched Tension Bars due to High-Temperature Creep: Interaction Between Nucleation Controlled Cavity Growth and Continuum Cavity Growth
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The investigation concerns high-temperature creep rupture of nickel-based superalloys, used in aeroengines; in particular, the multi-axial stress sensitivity of nucleation and growth of grain boundary defects that cause creep failure. The research was underpinned by test data from the National Physical Laboratory[Loveday & Dyson]at low and high stresses. Theories accurately predict extremes of behaviour observed in the experiments. Research has been well-received by industries {e.g. Alsthom[Perrin] & Rolls-Royce[Garwood] } that will make use of the constitutive equations to predict life scenarios of the superalloy vanes and blades of jet engines.

Title: Auto-ignition of diesel spray using the PDF-Eddy Break-Up model
AdditionalInformation: Project supervisor (student - Dhuchakallaya). Addresses issues of modelling auto-ignition of combustion using a moments-based spray model - of interest to spray and combustion modellers, and engine designers. Moments-based approach based on modelling work at Manchester (Beck & Watkins, Proc. R. Soc. Lond. A, Vol. 459, pp1365-1394, 2003) now available in open source code OPENFLOW.

Title: Laser generation of elliptical nanometre and sub-nanometre bump arrays on NiP/Al data storage disks and their effect on stiction performance
AdditionalInformation: The work has demonstrated a step improvement in hard disk system performance by reducing stiction (air resistance) forces by up to 85%, compared with the previous technology;  enabling higher scanning speed. This was realized by laser rapid production of elliptical nano-ridges (300,000 ridges/s) instead of circular nano-bumps in existing systems. This research was carried out in collaboration with a computer hard disk fabrication equipment manufacturer with three co-authors from the company who are commercializing the technology. The work also led to a new research contract of £210,000 from a UK company to explore other applications of the technology.

Title: Quantifying crack tip displacement fields with DIC
AdditionalInformation: Faster and more robust method than other full field experimental techniques to evaluate the deformation field ahead of a crack. Advanced structural integrity assessments for nuclear plant life extension are based on non-linear behaviour, which is best captured by the crack tip displacement.  Also has important application in ensuring the integrity and security of trans-continental gas pipelines.

Title: Tar reduction in pyrolysis vapours from biomass over a hot char bed
AdditionalInformation: Removing tar from biomass gasification syngas and subsequent clean-up for end-use remains a barrier for bioenergy deployment. This paper experimentally investigated the potential for biomass char to heterogeneously reduce tar produced as a by-product of the gasification process. The paper was significant, as the experimental setup allowed the heterogeneous effect of char and the homogeneous effect of thermal cracking to be assessed independently. Since publication it has received international attention – in particular in the Far East, where there is a lot of research in this field. The study was funded by the EPSRC SuperGen Bioenergy consortium.

Title: Shale gas: an updated assessment of environmental and climate change impacts
Publisher: Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research
AdditionalInformation: As a new source of fossil fuel, shale gas is viewed as prolonging the use of non-renewable energy supply and as a risk to an already strained climate. This multi-disciplinary report provided the first real insight into the climate change impacts of shale gas use. The impact and influence of the study has been very substantial; it has been the largest hits on the Tyndall Centre website. Since publication we have submitted written and oral evidence to several Energy and Climate Change Committee's Shale Gas Inquiries, provided evidence to European Parliament and have been interviewed for international and national media.

Title: Three-dimensional CFD modelling of PEM fuel cells: An investigation into the effects of water flooding
AdditionalInformation: This contribution is designed to explore a very important problem in the practical acceptance of the PEM fuel cells especially in the transportation arena. The water flooding issue , seriously impacts the acceptance of the fuel cell due to the delicate balance of water generation and removal mechanisms in that the oxidant transport and the ionic conduction are crucially dependent on prevailing water levels in the cell. This study which is widely quoted in the literature is a fundamental attempt at understanding the physicochemical and engineering attributes of the problem for the PEM fuel cell as a prime power source.

Title: Beyond 'dangerous' climate change: emission scenarios for a new world
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical & Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper followed the original global analysis published by myself and Anderson in 2008, and was part of a special issue of the journal focusing on 4 degrees Centigrade of global warming due to climate change. The purpose was to consider the difference between industrialised and industrialising nations in terms of emission mitigation and it was used as context for a range of detailed analyses of what a 4 degrees Centigrade temperature rise could mean for society. The work has led to numerous invitations to present findings at national and international business, policy and academic meetings.

Title: Changes in the stress in the femoral head neck junction after osteochondroplasty for hip impingement: A finite element study
AdditionalInformation: The paper addresses an important question in orthopaedic related medical research which has not been investigated previously. The output from the research includes guidance as to the safe depth of resection for surgeons when undertaking surgery of the type described in the paper and recommendations for post operative rehabilitation care. The model developed and recommendations made in the paper will lead to improved clinical outcomes in patients undergoing osteochondroplasty for hip impingement. One of the paper’s co-authors is a Consultant Hip and Knee Surgeon working at the Centre for Hip Surgery at Wrightington Hospital in Lancashire.

Title: Fracture simulation of restored teeth using a continuum damage mechanics failure model
AdditionalInformation: This work involves the collabration with external academics in USA.  The originality is the application of continuum damage model to fracture of dental materials.

Title: Sequential laser and mechanical micro-drilling of Ni super-alloy for aerospace application
AdditionalInformation: In microscale manufacturing, processes can be stretched to their limits of capability. In this paper a novel combined and complimentary laser and mechanical micro drilling process was developed and tested for aerospace application. The process can be used to increase the life of the mechanical micro tool by four fold, and to eradicate the geometric and thermal quality issues associated with laser drilling. This significantly improves edge quality of micro drilled effusion cooling holes by favourably altering the workpiece machinability, presenting potential for use in service critical and high value components. This led to industry funding by Rolls Royce Plc.

Title: Further investigation on the dynamic compressive strength enhancement of concrete-like materials based on split Hopkinson pressure bar tests. Part II: Numerical simulations
AdditionalInformation: This work has significant impact on the understanding of strain-rate enhancement of concrete-like materials. This paper offered solid evidence to show that the current practice widely accepted in research community and industrial application was flawed. Recently, the K&C concrete model in LS-DYNA has been corrected based on this finding. The subject has been invited as keynote in numerous invited talks and conferences [e.g. Keynote: 8th International Conference on Shock and Impact Loads on Structure, Adelaide, 2009; Keynote: European Cooperation in the Field of Scientific and Technical Research (COST C26), Southampton, 2009]. The co-author was a Ph.D.

Title: LES Predictions for the NASA Low-Speed Centrifugal Compressor Impeller
VolumeTitle: Transactions of the ASME, Journal of Turbomachinery
AdditionalInformation: This is a state of the art computational/design contribution towards identifying , delineating and managing the extremely complex aerophysics encountered in centrifugal compressors using Large Eddy Simulation validated via focussed experiments. Given the extremely wide usage of centrifugal compressors and radial inflow turbines in a large number of engineering applications, a fresh look at the flow physics via extremely accurate predictions is required as provided in this study. The intent via this study is hence to provide efficiency enhancements in future centrifugal compressor designs.

Title: Characterization of multi-jet electrospray systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents an important contribution in furthering the understanding of the electrospray process and has implications in the fields of space propulsion, materials processing and mass spectrometery. The work was funded by EPSRC and will be used to provide support for a funding application to EPSRC.

Title: The three-dimensional locomotor dynamics of African (Loxodonta africana) and Asian (Elephas maximus) elephants reveal a smooth gait transition at moderate speed
VolumeTitle: Journal of The Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: The paper successfully solved the locomotor biomechanics problem of the largest living land animal: elephants, which leads to a new definition of walking and running from a mechanical engineering perspective for terrestrial animal locomotion. The novel multiple inertial sensor technique and the mechanical modelling method proposed can be used to study animal and human locomotion in their natural environments without the constraints of the traditional methods. This work made a great impact in the biomechanics research field, and was reported by Nature (25 June, 2007) and Telegraph (27 June, 2007).

Title: Biaxial stress effects on estimating J under combined mechanical and thermal stresses
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: This article, which includes an industrial co-author (Budden), interprets finite element data in terms of fracture mechanics assessment methods.  This paper contains data which have contributed to a larger body of finite element and experimental data which are being used to develop revised, less-conservative and more comprehensive advice for the defect assessment procedure R6.  Importantly the results show that biaxial stresses are no more onerous than uniaxial cases. The R6 revisions were drafted in 2012.  R6 is widely used and its developments have led developments in other defect assessment methods such as BS7910 and ASME FFS-1/API579.

Title: Exploring the scope for complementary sub-global policy to mitigate CO2 from shipping
AdditionalInformation: The debate on sub-global CO2 policies for shipping focuses on emission apportionment. This study outlines the case for nations, regions and organisations to directly influence shipping at sub-global levels, in addition to actions by the International Maritime Organization. The outputs are very policy and industry relevant, as the Government is currently deciding how to include national shipping and aviation in the climate change targets. It has been presented to Internationally and was referenced in the Committee on Climate Change’s "Shipping review". Recognition of our efforts has led to a new consortia project being funded by EPSRC (Shipping in changing climates).

Title: On the Evolution of Local Material Properties and Residual Stress in a Three-Pass SA508 Steel Weld
AdditionalInformation: This work was funded by Rolls-Royce Marine and was carried out in collaboration with Rolls-Royce and Serco. The list of authors includes engineers from Rolls-Royce and Serco. This work provided valuable experimental data and insights that led to improvements in the industrial modelling strategies which are applied to account for the effects of phase transformations on residual stresses in multipass steel welds. These modelling strategies are currently applied by Rolls-Royce and Serco for safety assessments on components in nuclear propulsion systems for submarines.

Title: An experimental investigation of laminar flow separation control using an array of synthetic jets
AdditionalInformation: Successful implementation of flow control technologies on aircraft wings has great potential for fuel saving and yet the fundamental fluid mechanism associated with the use of flow control devices is still not well understood. This paper was the first reported in the literature evaluating round synthetic jets for controlling the delay of laminar flow separation over a wide range of operating conditions. The results provide the basis for selecting the optimal operating conditions in practical settings. This work was undertaken during a project funded by EPSRC (EP/E047041/1) and Airbus.

Title: Atomic-scale finite element analysis of vibration mode transformation in carbon nanorings and single-walled carbon nanotubes
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The proposed dynamic atomic-scale finite element method can increase the efficiency of molecular dynamics simulation by reducing the computational efforts to an order-N problem. The project was supported by Shell. The co-author was a Ph.D student.

Title: Size Effect and Tool Geometry in Micromilling of Tool
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the process mechanism governing the size effect in micro-milling, in particular the effect of ratio of un-deformed chip thickness to the cutting edge radius on process performance. The paper provides a step change into the selection of optimum micro-scale cutting conditions and tooling for obtaining the best surface finish and best edge quality to support high precision microsystems manufacture. I was the PI of the 1.1 million project that developed the technology with 6 industrial partners (Rolls Royce, Microsystems, Teer Coatings, Rainford Precision, WRL Prototype and Agie Charmiles) with £0.4 million EPSRC funding.

Title: Nonlinear Problem of Active Sound Control
VolumeTitle: Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics
AdditionalInformation: In the active sound control, we protect a domain from noise coming from outside while the wanted sound (produced inside) retains unaffected. For the first time, the solution has been obtained for nonlinear problems. This pioneering result can be applied to the attenuation of noise generated by turbulent flows. In particular, it can be used for active control of combustion instability. The solution to the problem has been achieved via nonlinear potentials that were first introduced in this paper. The developed technique can be used far beyond the active sound control, for example,  for domain decomposition in parallel computing.

Title: Kinematic Analysis and Control Design for a Nonplanar Multirotor Vehicle
VolumeTitle: Journal of Guidance, Control, and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper documents the design of and control synthesis for a new class of highly manoeuvrable multi-rotor rotary wing vehicles developed in collaboration with BAESYSTEMS and MBDA which have the ability to simultaneously translate and rotate in arbitrary directions. The concept has been patented and £100 funding received to explore commercialisation. The paper is significant because it is the first to fully describe a new class of vehicle with potentially significant benefits over conventional rotary wing craft, and also provides detailed mathematical analysis needed in order to synthesise a viable control system.  I was the lead academic on this project.

Title: Vibration-based condition monitoring of rotating machines using a machine composite spectrum
AdditionalInformation: A completely new approach is proposed in this research for vibration-based fault diagnosis (VFD) for rotating machines. The proposed method uses a significantly reduced number of vibration sensors for a machine for fault(s) diagnosis. It is expected to reduce instrumentation by 75% compared to the conventional vibration fault diagnosis method and the complex diagnosis process used presently by industry. The proposed method may leads to the future research trend in the VFD for rotating machines.

Title: The influence of organic and inorganic fertiliser application rates on UK biomass crop sustainability
AdditionalInformation: There is limited literature outlining best practice agronomic conditions for energy crops. Life cycle assessment determined the impact of growing energy crops, compared to producing natural gas. From a policy perspective it is important, as it examines the wider environmental impacts (acidification and eutrophication), which are not as apparent compared to GHG savings. This has been disseminated at an EU/UK level (eg Defra, Environmental Agency and Committee on Climate Change). It has informed further research examining the human toxicity impacts associated with biomass combustion. This study was a joint collaboration with Rothamsted Research, funded by the EPSRC SuperGen Bioenergy consortium.

Title: Comprehensive numerical analysis of a three-pass bead-in-slot weld and its critical validation using neutron and synchrotron diffraction residual stress measurements
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: Weld residual stresses can have important detrimental effects on long term structural performance of welds in a number of industries.  Their significance is often assessed using simple conservative estimates that can lead to unnecessary repair or replacement of components.
