This research contributed to an international benchmarking programme aimed at improving the accuracy of both residual stress measurements and predictions, and demonstrates the state of the art in residual stress prediction in austenitic steel welds

Title: An impulsive receptance technique for the time domain computation of the vibration of a whole aero-engine model with nonlinear bearings
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes one component of a suite of novel computer algorithms that have been developed in collaboration with the Whole-Engine Modelling Group of Rolls-Royce (RR), significantly advancing the reliability of design calculations for aircraft engine vibration attenuation. This work was funded by EPSRC grant EP/D054575/1  with additional in-kind support and collaboration from RR (165k GBP). It has secured follow-on funding for Dr Pham Minh Hai (21.5k GBP, PhD Plus). It has also contributed to the successful bid for a current EPSRC grant EP/ I029184/1.

Title: A full voltage-controlled nanoelectrospray system and its steady characteristic analysed by empirically equivalent circuit method
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents an important contribution to the field of electrospray detailing an equivalent circuit model that can be used to model electrospray systems to enable more accurate current characterisation of these systems.

Title: Shaft instantaneous angular speed for blade vibration in rotating machine
AdditionalInformation: Recent trend for the turbine blade health monitoring is done by the exorbitant and intrusive blade tip timing method. Now a non-intrusive method has been proposed and also validated experimentally and theoretically to do the BHM in much simpler and cheaper manner. It uses the shaft torsional vibration during the machine run-up or run-down operation for the BHM. The method can implemented to the turbo-generator (TG) sets in power plants, aero engines, etc. it is now plan to apply on a steam TG set at EDF plant site.

Title: Assessment of effective stress intensity factors using thermoelastic stress analysis
VolumeTitle: Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design
AdditionalInformation: Awarded 2009 SAGE Publishing Prize for Best Paper. International collaboration.Technique has applications to life extension of aging aircraft and power generating plant.

Title: Computations of Modes I and II Stress Intensity Factors of Sharp Notched Plates under In-Plane Shear and Bending Loading by the Fractal-Like Finite Element Method
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: M Treifi is a PhD student and KL Tsang was a PDRA on an EPSRC project who carried out pioneering fractal-like finite element method (FFEM) work at Manchester. Over the past two decades, the FFEM has been developed by researchers in Hong Kong and Manchester as an accurate and efficient method to compute stress intensity factors (SIFs) of different crack problems. This paper is a new development of the FFEM to analyse singularity problems associated with sharp notches. SIF values for single off-centre edge-notched plates under in-plane shear and bending loading conditions, which were unavailable in the literature, are presented.

Title: Tailoring the hydraulic impedance of out-of-plane micromachined electrospray sources with integrated electrodes
AdditionalInformation: This paper forms a valuable contribution to the design of a multi headed electrospray source. The primary application of this source is for electric propulsion however it is of great interest to electrospray mass spectrometry and the electrospray community in general.  The work detailed in this paper was funded in part by ESA and has directly led to subsequent funding for the development of an electric propulsion system under a European framework FP7 grant Microthrust.

Title: The movements of limb segments and joints during locomotion in African and Asian elephants
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the world’s first comprehensive research on the limb and joint kinematics of the largest living land animal: elephants. The latest biomechanical modelling and 3D motion analysis techniques are integrated to investigate a large in-vivo dataset including both Asian and African species. This work provides a comprehensive database on locomotor kinematics of elephants, which offers essential and fundamental information for biological locomotion and evolution studies and also animal health management. This work has generated impacts in animal biomechanics and biology research fields and was selected as the highlighted story in Journal of Experimental Biology.

Title: Consideration of elastic follow-up in the treatment of combined primary and secondary stresses in fracture assessments
AdditionalInformation: Numerical results have shown that current methods for treating secondary stresses in fracture codes can be over conservative in some cases where there is no elastic follow-up but non-conservative in cases with significant elastic follow-up. This paper derives a theoretical framework which covers both of these cases and therefore provides a rational basis for updating fracture assessment methods. The results have been used to draft revisions to the R6 defect assessment procedure and the proposed revisions are currently being assessed against a wide body of numerical and experimental data.

Title: On the Flutter and Drag Forces on Flexible Rectangular Canopies in Normal Flow
AdditionalInformation: This contribution provides experimental data and theory for aerodynamic and aeroelastic behaviour of flags and canopies in turbulent flow, both solid ones and perforated.  Applications include paragliders, flight stabilers and ground-based systems.  The analysis of the drag data indicates that a proper scaling parameter is the crosswise length scale.  A further study addressed the drag characteristics of the canopies with perforated planforms. A detailed study into the flutter characteristics of the canopies in the turbulent wind is presented. This work was funded by the EPSRC.

Title: Characterizing Phase Transformations and Their Effects on Ferritic Weld Residual Stresses with X-rays and Neutrons
AdditionalInformation: This work was carried out in collaboration with Cambridge University. It illustrates how both neutron diffraction and synchrotron X-ray diffraction can play an important and complementary role in assisting the design of novel weld filler metals. Such filler metals exploit the fact that solid-state phase transformations have a strain associated with them. On cooling after welding, this strain can compensate for or offset thermal contraction strains, and thus mitigate residual stresses. Through control of the filler metal chemistry, it is possible to engineer advantageous residual stress distributions in welds, by achieving a specific martensite-start temperature on cooling after welding.

Title: Shaped tube electrochemical drilling of good quality holes
AdditionalInformation: In order to reduce the amount of blades that are scrapped due to the cooling channels, which are electrochemically drilled, we, with the help of a KTP grant, investigated the effect of different process parameters on the quality of holes drilled in blades for industrial gas turbines. The industrial partner was ELE Advanced Technologies Ltd in Colne (contact person: Mr P Calderbak, Operations Director). With the help of knowledge gained from this project, the company were able to reduce the amount of scrap by more than 50%.

Title: Back to the Future? A Re-examination of the Aerodynamics of Flettner-Thom Rotors for Maritime Propulsion
AdditionalInformation: Paper shows close agreement with existing Large-eddy Simulations at low Reynolds number and low spin ratios. Excellent agreement with most experiments at high spin ratios. Demonstrates for the first time that the addition of discs to the spinning cylinder (as proposed by Thom) is not desirable. Explains why Thom’s data exhibit anomalous behavior, why relatively simple eddy viscosity models do as well as stress-transport schemes for that flow and, finally, how negative drag coefficients arise when discs are present.

Title: Void fraction prediction in annular two-phase flow
AdditionalInformation: First void fraction prediction method that includes both conventional and microscale channels. Biomathematics inspired, this model shows no scale effect related to the channel size in annular flows. Work funded by Swiss National Science Foundation. This paper is in the top 5 most downloaded from the publisher website for the year 2012.

Title: Numerical simulation of the interaction of a circular synthetic jet with a boundary layer
AdditionalInformation: Successful implementation of flow control technologies on aircraft wings has strong potential for fuel saving and yet the fundamental fluid mechanism associated with the use of flow control devices is still not well understood. This paper reports the numerical simulations undertaken to obtain a further insight of the structures of the vortices produced by the interaction between a round synthetic jet and a laminar boundary layer and their impact on the near-wall flow. This work has been followed by many researchers using different numerical techniques.

Title: Comparative Study of Predictive FE Methods for Mechanical Properties of Nuclear Composites
AdditionalInformation: The paper outlines the methodology of image-based modelling and shows that it can reliably predict bulk mechanical and physical properties of materials with complex architectures. It is also demonstrated to be better than more standard approaches to modelling.

Title: Application of recently developed elliptic blending based models to separated flows
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper, on advanced turbulence models for industrial applications was undertaken in the context of the EU funded FP7 ATAAC project for which I was PI and the first author was my PDRA, and I previously co-supervised his PhD. All models are implemented in open source CFD software and used by industry. This work forms the main topic of an industrial collaboration with the commercial CFD code developers CD-adapco.  Having demonstrated their effectiveness, we are now working with this partner to implement and validate both advanced models into their commercial CFD code.

Title: The Effect of Laser Beam Geometry on Cut Path Deviation in Diode Laser Chip-Free Cutting of Glass
AdditionalInformation: Laser cutting of glass sheets is an extremely important industrial manufacturing process. The process, however, results in deviation from the cutting path at the edges of the glass sheet, a major problem widely recognized by glass industry. This paper investigates this problem and suggests a remedy. First, a rigorous thermo-mechanical analysis of laser glass cutting process is carried out which provides an explanation for the occurrence of this problem The experimental work is then carried out on glass sheets provided by Pilkington Glass. It is concluded that changing the laser beam shape can significantly improve the quality of the cut.

Title: The Tyndall decarbonisation scenarios-Part I: Development of a backcasting methodology with stakeholder participation
AdditionalInformation: This article presents results from an extensive scenarios project, including the development of a spreadsheet-based energy-system scenario tool. It has been widely used by those engaged in energy scenario research. This paper was part of a series of outputs including a highly acclaimed policy document - Decarbonising the UK, and led to numerous high profile media appearances, invited international conference presentations and Select Committee calls for evidence. The approach has been used in EPSRC projects on shipping, electricity and Sustainable Consumption Institute projects on food, and been re-developed for use in a Chinese context too.

Title: Towards integrated design of fluidic controls for a flapless aircraft
AdditionalInformation: Aircraft normally use moving flaps to control their flight direction; however use of flapless technologies can lead to reduced cost and signature. I was the lead academic on the team that developed the flapless controls for the DEMON technology demonstrator aircraft for the £6m EPSRC/BAESystems FLAVIIR research project which concluded in 2010. This paper represents a key output of the FLAVIIR project, documenting low order design methods. The co authors were my PhD students. Knowledge transfer to industry has been enhanced through appointment of Michie as a Senior Aerodynamicist at BAESystems

Title: Simulating avian wingbeat kinematics
AdditionalInformation: The mechanics of flapping wing propulsion is of interest to biologists studying bird physiology and engineers wishing to build flapping wing vehicles. This paper makes an original contribution to the understanding of the biomechanics of bird flight through application of engineering inverse simulation and optimisation techniques. It provides insight into the long standing problem of characterising the gait of flapping creatures, and provides tools for optimisation of flapping wing design. Work in this paper has directly led to receipt of funding for a £110k bio-inspired research project by BAESYSTEMS in 2012. I was the lead academic on this work.

Title: Development of a Two-velocities Hybrid RANS-LES Model and its Application to a Trailing Edge Flow
AdditionalInformation: Combining deterministic (LES) in statistical (RANS) representations of turbulence enables localised refined definition for large-scale industrial simulations. This was developed via EU projects with major aerospace industries, e.g. EADS and Dassault (projects DESIDER, ATAAC, continuing with Go-Hybrid). It has been extended to heat transfer, e.g. with EDF for thermal stress impact on power plant lifetime. CD-Adapco, second largest worldwide CFD software vendor, is implementing it for local-global effects, for example car mirror acoustics and drag.

Title: Reconstruction of turbulent fluctuations for hybrid RANS/LES simulations using a synthetic eddy method
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: Producing quick and accurate predictions for industrial flows is the driver for coupling Large Eddy Simulation to Reynolds Averaged Navier Stokes methods. This paper addresses how to generate time dependent fluctuations for LES fields consistent with the embedding RANS statistics.  Inaccurate turbulence fluctuations yield long development times and negate the entire coupled approach. The importance of the problem is indicated by the number of methods in the literature; since this approach is not predicated on digital filtering or other academic methods, it performs at least as well as other methods and is thus suited to commercial CFD codes.

Title: Particle image velocimetry measurements of the interaction of synthetic jets with a zero-pressure gradient laminar boundary layer
AdditionalInformation: Successful implementation of flow control technologies on aircraft has great potential for fuel saving. In this paper, by using an advanced flow measurement technique the impact of synthetic jets on a laminar boundary layer separation control is investigated in detail.  This work helps to lay the foundation for the subsequent three-year project sponsored by EPSRC (EP/E047041/1) and Airbus studying the interaction mechanism of synthetic jets with a separating turbulent boundary layer.

Title: Accurate prediction of residual stress in stainless steel welds
AdditionalInformation: The residual stresses generated during welding can have significant detrimental effects on in-service structural performance.  The advanced gas cooled reactor fleet hs suffered a number of instances of cracking at welds, caused by weld residual stress.  This research formed a key part of a programme to understand the risk of cracking in boiler support structures.  Its successful completion removed a restriction that would have required four reactors to close in 2010 or 2011.  Instead, they are currently allowed to operate until 2019.  This life extension represents a major contribution to the UK economy.

Title: Improved Boundary Conditions for the DNS of Reacting Subsonic Flows
AdditionalInformation: Combustion accounts for approximately 80% of global power production. Meeting increasingly stringent emissions protocols is contingent on a much better understanding of turbulent reacting flow physics, and Direct Numerical Simulation provides the highest fidelity method of achieving this goal. Past reacting flow simulations have been plagued by instabilities in the flow evolution driven by boundary induced instability. This paper extends our earlier low Mach number expansions to reacting flows; it is important since it not only provides a fuller diagnosis of the cause of the instabilities, but also produces asymptotically accurate estimates to remedy them.

Title: Comparisons of weakly compressible and truly incompressible algorithms for the SPH mesh free particle method
AdditionalInformation: SPH is potentially the next generation of CFD codes thanks to its simplicity (meshless, ideally suited for GPU computers) and Lagrangian framework suitable for complex physics phenomena (turbulent eddies, scalar and particle transport, chemical reactions). The implicit incompressible flow solver allows faster simulations (larger time steps) and real hydraulics applications. This is one of many papers resulting from the early start on SPH by Manchester 10 years ago, thanks to initial support from EDF R&D and an EU project, creating an EU special interest group which is now the major hub of a worldwide research community.

Title: An evaluation of heat partition in the high-speed turning of AISI/SAE 4140 steel with uncoated and TiN-coated tools
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers - Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: The integrity of tools is the key issue in High Speed Machining (HSM), which concerns manufacturing industry.  It is dependent on the amount of heat entering the tool during machining. Hence, the design of new tools requires information on its heat partition characteristics. These are established here through a novel combined experimental-finite element approach. Two major tool developers, Sandvick Coromant, and Teer Coatings Ltd, have supplied tools for this research and this interaction has led to the design of new multi-layer coated tool systems. The new technique has also been subsequently adopted by other researchers in HSM.

Title: Label-free super-resolution imaging of adenoviruses by submerged microsphere optical nanoscopy
AdditionalInformation: This work sets a new milestone in biomedical imaging in that viruses at the size (75 nm) below the optical diffraction limit (200 nm) have been observed with a standard optical microscope coupled with microspheres without fluorescent labelling. In addition, theoretical modelling was used to explain the mechanism involved. The system is being commercialised through a spinout company  from the university. Professor Li received Sir Frank Whittle medal from the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2013 for the invention of the microscope and successful commercialisation of university research in industry.

Title: Development and application of the drop number size moment modelling to spray combustion simulations
AdditionalInformation:
Project supervisor (student - Dhuchakallaya).
Addresses issues of modelling combustion using a moments-based spray model - of interest to spray and combustion modellers. Moments-based approach based on modelling work at Manchester (Beck & Watkins, Proc. R. Soc. Lond. A, Vol. 459, pp1365-1394, 2003) now available in open source code OPENFLOW.

Title: Prediction of Flow and Heat Transfer through Stationary and Rotating Ribbed Ducts Using a Non-linear k Model
AdditionalInformation: Use of ribs to enhance surface heat transfer in internal cooling passages is a long established practice. In internal cooling passages of gas-turbine blades, rotation also influences the flow. Generating reliable and economical thermal predictions in ribbed and rotating cooling passages presents a challenge to RANS models. Numerically robust effective-viscosity models fail to produce accurate thermal predictions. Here the superior predictions of a non-linear effective-viscosity model of turbulence, developed in Manchester and validated over a range of applications, demonstrate that it is a reliable and cost-effective model, for the simulation of these cooling flows crucial to so many industrial sectors.

Title: Stress-strain and Fracture Behaviour of 0º/90º and Plain Weave Ceramic Matrix Composites from Tow Multi-axial Properties
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The paper demonstrates how the fundametal theory, addressed in two previous papers, can be harnessed using computational mechanics to predict the mechanical response of a complex woven Ceramic Matrix Composite laminate. The fidelity of the predictions has been confirmed by experimental results obtained by myself, and reported in a separate paper. Presentations have been made at an Int Conf., and to supporting bodies {UCSB California[McMeeking], Teledyne, Los Angeles[Cox] }, and have been extremely well received. Homogenisation technique, and orthotropic material description, have overcome severe deficiencies with other approaches used by industry.

Title: A receptance harmonic balance technique for the computation of the vibration of a whole aero-engine model with nonlinear bearings
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes one component of a suite of novel computer algorithms that have been developed in collaboration with the Whole-Engine Modelling Group of Rolls-Royce (RR), significantly advancing the reliability of design calculations for aircraft engine vibration attenuation. This work was funded by EPSRC grant EP/D054575/1 with additional in-kind support and collaboration from RR (165k GBP). It has secured follow-on funding for Dr Pham Minh Hai (21.5k GBP, PhD Plus). It has also contributed to the successful bid for a current EPSRC grant EP/ I029184/1.

Title: Residual Stress Distributions in a P91 Steel-Pipe Girth Weld before and after Post Weld Heat Treatment
AdditionalInformation: This EPSRC-funded work is based on research carried out by a PhD student in collaboration with The Open University and European Technology Development Ltd. This article shows that, in pipe girth welds, a region of highly tensile residual stresses coincides with the weld region that is vulnerable to premature creep failure in creep strength enhanced ferritic steels, and that these tensile residual stresses persist even after post weld heat treatment. This work raises the possibility that premature failures in these steels may be linked to residual stresses. The significance of residual stresses had not previously been investigated.

Title: Modelling damage evolution in composite laminates subjected to low velocity impact
AdditionalInformation: Impact damage as intra- and inter-laminar cracking (a current problem in structural design) is modelled using quadratic stress-based criteria for initiation and fracture mechanics to capture growth. The nonlinear shear behaviour is described by the Soutis shear stress-strain formula. ABAQUS is employed to simulate the impact response; interface cohesive elements were inserted between plies with appropriate mixed-mode damage laws, user-defined, to model delamination growth. Predictions are in a good agreement with measurements and observations. The analysis can be used to identify interfaces where nano-modified polymers are innovatively inserted by inkjet printing to prevent/delay delamination .

Title: Micro-stereolithography tools for small-batch manufacture of polymer micro-parts
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B, Journal of Engineering Manufacture.
AdditionalInformation: Layer-based manufacture of prototypes has a track record in the early assessment of products designs. Micro-stereography is a cost-effective tool-making technology that can replace traditional injection mould tooling materials, it is necessary to understand the new materials behaviour such as the thermodynamic loads experienced during the fabrication process. It was found that it is possible to manufacture moulds accurately using the µSL process. Process optimisation in terms of the stored thermal energy in the inserts can further improve the part accuracy. The research reported was funded by the FP7 programmes COTECH, Grant agreement CP-IP 214491-2 and EUMINAfab, Grant agreement FP7-226460.

Title: Application of a micromechanics model to the overall properties of heterogeneous graphite
AdditionalInformation: The paper develops and uses a novel modelling technique to predict the behaviour of multiphase materials. It is applied to nuclear graphite. The methodology has provided insight into the behaviour of reactor core materials and is likely to find further application.

Title: Mathematical Modelling, Analysis, and Design of Magnetorheological (MR) Dampers
AdditionalInformation: WW Chooi was a PhD student now with Ford UK. MR dampers are smart fluid dampers currently being developed and introduced into the high-performance car market. Most designs are fixed-pole valve mode devices, where the MR fluid is forced through an electromagnetically active annular gap. In established models, this annular flow is approximated by the flow of fluid through two infinitely wide parallel plates. The mathematical model presented in this paper represents the physical processes more accurately as it uses the exact geometrical characteristics of the annular gap. Therefore, the model enables more accurate design and scaling of MR dampers.

Title: The shape of a strain-based failure assessment diagram
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: This article was derivation of a revision to a previous strain-based failure assessment diagram proposed by the industrial co-author (Budden).  That equation had been shown to be non-conservative by comparison with some finite element data.  The new equation in this paper has been included in a  new section to the defect assessment procedure, R6, which has been endorsed by EDF Energy for release in 2013.  R6 is the standard defect assessment approach used in the UK nuclear industry and is also widely used elsewhere.

Title: Integration of biomechanical compliance, leverage, and power in elephant limbs
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a first-ever biomechanical study on very large animal locomotion using novel integrated 3D dynamic measurement and computer simulation techniques. The results reveal the remarkable integration of limb compliance, leverage and power on large terrestrial mammals, and also the fundamental size-related mechanical principles underlying critical constraints on gait choice, speed and limb design. This has significant implications on comparative biomechanics, legged robotics design and rehabilitation engineering. This work generated a great impact in the biomechanics research field, and was reported by Wired (29 March, 2010) and ScienceNews (24 April, 2010).

Title: An Alternative DDES Formulation Based on Elliptic Relaxation
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrates a novel formulation of a popular modelling scheme, which when coupled to the Delayed Detached Eddy Simulation approach, offers benefits over current industrial methods. Reviewers indicated likelihood for widespread citing. The work was part funded by an EPSRC and a FP7 grant on Aerospace and two leading industrial software developers wish to implement this new algorithm. The PhD student was employed in the CFD department of a motorsport company and has since been awarded a Knowledge Transfer grant to incorporate this modelling approach into their design methods.

Title: A unit cell for FE analysis of materials with the microstructure of a staggered pattern
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This work involves the collabration with external academics and the last author was a PhD student.  The originality is that the work deals with the periodicity involving a common  staggered configuration in textile composites which has been seldom addressed. Confusions on the application of boundary conditions appearing in the literature have been clarified.

Title: T-stress determination using thermoelastic stress analysis
VolumeTitle: Journal of strain analysis for engineering design
AdditionalInformation: The first documented full field experimental technique to measure T stresses in cracked bodies. More reliable integrity assessment, and hence life extension, of nuclear power plant requires knowledge of crack tip constraint, or T stress.

Title: Weak discontinuity annihilation in solidification modelling
AdditionalInformation: Solidification is at the heart of many commercial manufacturing processes and being able to accurately predict and control heat transfer is of major commercial interest and benefit.  Coupled to this is the continued development of the FEM, which is now an invaluable tool in most forms of commercial analysis.  The novel concept of non-physical variables (albeit restricted to non-physical enthalpy in the paper) has led to work on the non-physical finite element method (NPFEM) and presently the forming of an EPSRC proposal.  The co-author of the paper was a PhD student and the work formed part of his doctoral thesis.

Title: A New Divergence Free Synthetic Eddy Method for the Reproduction of Inlet Flow Conditions for LES
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a computationally efficient method of generating realistic turbulence fields, particularly with a view to their use for Large Eddy Simulation inlet conditions. It can therefore be used to either reduce the cost of pure LES calculations, or minimize the domain needed in hybrid RANS/LES type of computations. Part of the work was supported by EdF, and the methods has been implemented into routines for use in their Code_Saturne software.

Title: Residual stresses in laser welded ASTM A387 Grade 91 steel plates
AdditionalInformation: This EPSRC-funded work was carried out in collaboration with the Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (India), the University of Bristol and The Open University. It is the first article to report on the influence of solid-state phase transformations on the development of residual stress distributions in keyhole laser welds in ferritic steels. It shows that solid-state phase transformations lead to the development of compressive stresses in the fusion zone and tension in the heat-affected zone. These effects are more significant in keyhole welds than in multi-pass arc welds, since there are often no subsequent weld passes.

Title: Measuring the notched compressive strength of composite laminates: Specimen size effects
AdditionalInformation: Large composite structures can give much lower strengths than small specimens, so a proper understanding of scaling is vital for their safe and efficient use. The work was funded by EPSRC (GR/R89479/01) and industry with the aim to develop an understanding of failure mechanisms controlling the strength of composites of different dimensions and hence predict size effects without resorting to empirical laws. The MoD's Lead Capability Advisor for Structures & Materials and the Composites Test Specialist at Airbus, who were the project monitors, emphasised in their final evaluation the significance of the results on design rules.

Title: Investigation of surface treatment effects in micro-injection-moulding
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation: An important stage in micro injection moulding is part demoulding. During this stage, part-mould forces can cause defects to micro parts. In this paper it is evidenced that diamond like carbon and silicon carbide tool surface treatments reduced demoulding forces. The results and can lead to a fundamental increase in tool and part quality, and provide a national competency in manufacturing for Microsystems. The research reported in this paper is funded by the Multi-institutional collaboration EPSRC Programme “The Cardiff Innovative Manufacturing Research Centre” and the EC FP6 Project SEMOFS.

Title: Dynamic crushing of honeycombs and features of shock fronts
AdditionalInformation: This paper is generated from a project funded by EPSRC and the work involves the collabration with external academics.  The originality of the work in this paper is that it is the first published investigation dealing with the features of shock wave front observed in honeycomb strucutres via numerical simulation.

Title: Turbulence Modelling of Unsteady Turbulent Flows Using the Stress Strain Lag Model
AdditionalInformation: The development of novel turbulence modelling for mean unsteady flow follows from my PhD thesis. The work was partly funded by an EU FP7 project and has been widely disseminated via this network; it is also the topic of a research placement at Stanford University. Four further PhD projects have since been initiated following the same idea, two of which have applied the original model to fire modelling. We are working on a new version in collaboration with the commercial CFD company CD-adapco, who have identified that the motorsport industry would benefit from this model.

Title: Turboshaft engine air particle separation
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the only contribution available anywhere on the problem of engine-airframe integration with reference to filtration systems. This paper addresses air particle separation technologies used for helicopter turboshaft engines that operate around unprepared airfields. For the first time, a filter theory is derived to predict filter performance as a function of key parameters and useful operation time. The knowledge has been transferred to DSTL/Ministry of Defence; cooperation is now started with Rolls-Royce on the basis of these results. Furthermore, the student who worked on this project won a prestigious EPSRC doctoral prize.

Title: Control of robust design in multiobjective optimization under uncertainties
AdditionalInformation: In real-life design, there are inevitable uncertainties in input data. The decision-maker may often prefer a robust solution to a more optimal one if the latter design proves to be too sensitive to the uncertainties. In the paper, the trade-off between robustness and optimality is considered. For the first time, a quantitative measure of such a trade-off is suggested, which allows the decision-maker to obtain the most optimal solution with a prescribed level of robustness. The paper addresses important practical problems related to the effect of uncertainties in real-life multi-objective optimisation. T. Erfani was my PhD student during this work.

Title: Analytical Modelling of Kirschner Wires in Ilizarov Circular External Fixator as Pretensioned Slender Beams
VolumeTitle: Journal of The Royal Society Interface
AdditionalInformation: AR Zamani was an MPhil student. K-wires determine the axial stiffness of the Ilizarov fixator that is linked to the biomechanical environment for bone healing, which is clinically proven to affect bone formation and maturation. Thus, K-wires are crucial in limb lengthening and deformity correction treatments. The existing theoretical models are deficient because they do not include pretension or change in axial load due to transverse loading of K-wires. A complete model, which includes initial pretension applied to K-wires and the change in tension due to transverse loading, is presented. It can be used to determine the potential clinical outcome.

Title: Optimization of the position of the acetabulum in a Ganz periacetabular osteotomy by finite element analysis
AdditionalInformation: The surgical procedure simulated is used to correct developmental dysplasia of the hip a condition that affects 1-3% of newborns and is the cause of 29% of hip replacements in the under 60s. The model can be used to obtain an optimal position for the acetabulum that is patient dependant enabling surgeons to determine this prior to surgery leading to improved clinical outcomes. One co-author is a Consultant Hip and Knee Surgeon working at the Centre for Hip Surgery, Wrightington Hospital, Lancashire.

Title: The effect of plasticity theory on predicted residual stress fields in numerical weld analyses
AdditionalInformation: Finite element weld residual stress prediction is increasingly used in the nuclear industry to assess the structural performance of welds.  Industrial practitioners frequently perform such simulations using simple isotropic or kinematic material hardening models whose parameters are derived from monotonic testing of the weldment materials, since these are the simplest tests to perform and fit.  This paper makes abundantly clear the impact of these assumptions on predicted stresses, and emphasises the importance using more accurate mixed isotropic-kinematic models, despite their need for more extensive materials data

Title: Nanoindentation of histological specimens: Mapping the elastic properties of soft tissues
AdditionalInformation: The paper develops and uses techniques to measure elastic properties of soft tissues. These key data can be used in models to predict mechanical behaviour of complex biological systems.

Title: Fracture mechanisms and failure analysis of carbon fibre/toughened epoxy composites subjected to compressive loading
AdditionalInformation: The response of composites under compression requires relationships between damage and material properties and is a current problem that is carefully studied by Soutis and co-workers. In this paper, plastic fibre microbuckling is recognized to be the dominant failure mechanism in a relatively new carbon fibre/toughened epoxy composites; a model is developed that captures the non-linear shear response of the resin and its role in the initiation and growth of the fibre instability. The work assisted the sponsors (Vice President, Research and Technology at Cytec Engineering Materials) to improve resin systems with improved compressive and impact resistance.

Title: Prototype tooling for producing small series of polymer microparts
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Rapid tooling solutions can be used to manufacture prototypes and small part batches that are critical to design verification. The paper investigates a rapid tooling solution for fabricating "soft" inserts using new micro-stereolithography technologies. The inserts can survive the optimised moulding process and produce parts. With a focus on minimising production costs and lead time, micro-stereolithography is shown to be a real technology for Microsystems design validation. The Multi-institutional collaboration provides national competency in Design & Manufacture for Small-scale and Adaptive Manufacturing. The research was funded by the FP7 programmes COTECH, Grant agreement CP-IP 214491-2 and EUMINAfab, Grant agreement FP7-226460.

Title: Normalised Root Mean Square and Amplitude of Sidebands of Vibration response as Tools for Gearbox Diagnosis
AdditionalInformation: This research was developed from a collaborative EngD project funded by EPSRC and Qinetiq, UK and one of the authors is from the Qinetiq. Quick assessment of the condition of gearboxes in helicopters is generally done by the on-board Health and Usage Monitoring System (HUMS). The existing Condition Indicators (CIs) based-on the vibration data in HUMS are not always observed to be robust. Two new but robust CIs are developed and tested. The new CIs and can be extended to any gear system including Wind Turbines.

Title: Modeling and Analysis of Piezoelectric Energy Harvesting Beams Using the Dynamic Stiffness and Analytical Modal Analysis Methods
AdditionalInformation: Piezoelectric materials generate electricity when deformed by vibrations.  This paper presents a novel mathematical model of a piezoelectric energy harvesting beam structure that is shown to provide greater accuracy and a wider range of applicability than alternative models.  It was invited (by Prof W. Clark, University of Pittsburgh) for publication in a special issue dedicated to Energy Harvesting following an ASME conference presentation in California.  It was among this journal’s top ten most downloaded articles in February and March 2011.  Following graduation, the PhD researcher (Dr Sajid Rafique) has returned to work with the National Space Agency of Pakistan.

Title: Improved identification of squeeze-film damper models for aeroengine vibration analysis
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes one component of a suite of novel computer algorithms that have been developed in collaboration with the Whole-Engine Modelling Group of Rolls-Royce, significantly advancing the reliability of design calculations for aircraft engine vibration attenuation. Dr Groves was funded by an EPSRC DTA Scholarship allied with EPSRC grant EP/D054575/1. The work attracted the attention of Honeywell Aerospace, Inc, resulting in a joint bid for EPSRC funding. The EPSRC DTA project secured follow-on PhD Plus funding and contributed to the successful bid for EPSRC grant EP/ I029184/1.

Title: Modeling and Optimal Design of Machining-Induced Residual Stresses in Aluminium Alloys Using a Fast Hierarchical Multiobjective Optimization Algorithm
AdditionalInformation: Technique has been adopted by Airbus to reduce part distortion due to machining, and hence production costs, in large aluminum aircraft components. International collaboration (Germany) and industrial partner.

Title: Three-dimensional characterization and thermal property modelling of thermally oxidized nuclear graphite
AdditionalInformation: Nuclear graphite components provide channels for control rods and fuel cooling; thus graphite structural integrity is a safety issue. Fast neutron irradiation and radiolytic oxidation significantly change their porosity and microstructure. This paper reports the first application of micro-tomographic techniques to investigate structural properties/microstructure relationship. In this particular paper the spectra and orientation of the different shaped porosity is taken account of in models to predict the thermal conductivity. The results have been used to develop the basis of constitutive models used by EDF in reactor life extension and safety cases.

Title: An investigative study of the interface heat transfer coefficient for finite element modelling of high-speed machining
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers - Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: High Speed Machining (HSM) is one of the most important manufacturing processes being increasingly used for higher productivity and improved environment. However, the integrity of tools used in HSM is the key issue which has been the subject of this research. The collaborators are some of the leading machine tool developers such as Teer Coatings Ltd and Sandvick Coromant. This work develops a robust numerical model for precise modelling of heat partition in HSM. It  represents an important development in the integrity analysis of HSM tools which would greatly impact the future design of new coated tools.

Title: A robust k − ε − View the MathML source/k elliptic blending turbulence model applied to near-wall, separated and buoyant flows
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a highly accurate version of the v2/f model near wall RANS model, now adopted as standard in codes: Saturne (with EDF, open source) and STARCCM+ (of worldwide CFD company CD-Adapco). After three successive PhD projects we finally resolved the numerical stiffness of this model originating from Stanford University. This paper also provides Reynolds number independent calibration of the model, simplifying the long series variants proposed over past 15 years. Ongoing extensions, funded by EDF and CD-Adapco, include blending with wall functions for coarse grids.

Title: On the use of biorthogonal interpolating wavelets for large-eddy simulation of turbulence
AdditionalInformation: There is a growing recognition of the treatment of multiple scales in physical processes like turbulence. This paper develops a very novel idea arising from the natural separation of length scales found in wavelet transforms.  While it is too early after publication to comment on the impact of this paper, much of the fluid turbulence community has embraced the concept of self similarity. The approach is therefore timely, and has some history via dynamic LES subgrid models.

Title: Orthogonal Blade-Vortex Interaction on a Helicopter Tail Rotor
AdditionalInformation: This contribution represents a considerable advance in the understading of a  problem of vortex dynamics that occurs on rotating machinery, in particular on helicopter rotors.  This study is the first to demonstrate the effects of a non-linear physical interaction between a vortex and a solid surface, and opens up the way to the determination of other engineering analyhsis, such as aero-elastic response, acoustic emissions, and vibrations. This work was funded by the EU.

Title: Amplitude of Probability Density Function (APDF) of Vibration Response as a Robust Tool for Gearbox Diagnosis
AdditionalInformation: This research results from a collaborative EngD project funded by EPSRC and Qinetiq, UK and an author is also from the Qinetiq. Here the raw vibration data from the gearbox is further processed to remove the noise and then another new Condition Indicator is developed based on the Amplitude of Probability Density Function of the processed data. This new CI is observed to be much more robust and monotonically increasing with the propagation of the gear fault compared to the existing CIs. This research will further enhance the confidence and strength in the ‘GO or NO GO’ diagnosis process.

Title: The origins and use of the equivalent temperature concept
AdditionalInformation: For years the UK nuclear industry had been using a concept of equivalent temperature to describe changes in properties and dimensions in graphite moderated reactors. This work used pattern recognition and statistical analysis of the available data to show that it was not necessary to account for differences in flux rate measurements between material test and in-reactor data from operating nuclear plant. Consequently, the concept of “equivalent temperature” is no longer used by the UK nuclear industry.

Title: Lattice strains and load partitioning in bovine trabecular bone
AdditionalInformation: The paper develops and uses a novel methodology to further the understanding of trabecular bone in a number of disease states. This is helpful for osteoporosis studies.

Title: The near wall effect of synthetic jets in a boundary layer
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: Successful implementation of flow control technologies on aircraft wings has a strong potential for fuel saving. This paper reports the first detailed experimental study revealing the nature of typical vortical structures produced by the interaction between round synthetic jets and a laminar boundary layer as well as their near-wall impact. It presents a step forward in the understanding of the interaction mechanism for flow separation delay. This was continued in a subsequent three-year project sponsored by EPSRC (EP/E047041/1) with Airbus funding, studying the interaction mechanism of synthetic jets with a separating turbulent boundary layer.

Title: Systems and certification issues for civil transport aircraft flow control systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers the broader engineering, social and legal issues surrounding the application of advanced flow control technologies on civil transport aircraft. The work was undertaken in collaboration with Airbus as part of an EU project. A unique contribution is the use of historical case studies to provide insight into the path by which other disruptive technologies bought themselves onto aircraft. Timelines are shown that suggest the performance and maturity of current flow control technologies is such that it is unlikely they will make a significant contribution to ACARE 2020 emissions targets for the aviation industry.

Title: Super singular element method for two-dimensional crack analysis
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society of London - Series A: Mathematical, Physical & Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: KL Tsang was a PDRA on an EPSRC project on which the paper is based. It is a step change in the evolution of the fractal-like finite element method (FFEM). Conventional FEM does not represent the crack tip singularity accurately even when a very fine mesh is used; it requires special crack tip elements for accuracy. However, FFEM represents the crack tip accurately in analytical form, does not use special elements, produces accurate SIFs of cracks faster, more efficiently and can be used by non-experts. The super singular element method presented in this paper is a generalization of the FFEM.

Title: Elastic behaviour of a regular lattice for meso-scale modelling of solids
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: The materials used in existing infrastructure and industrial plants deteriorate during service. This work introduces an original paradigm to regard changes of any engineering property of interest as emerging from changes in materials' microstructure. The paradigm is developed into a modelling architecture that links discrete and localised meso-scale properties to the continuum material response. The approach is currently used for understanding damage evolution in quasi-brittle materials. This allows for informed fitness-for-purpose assessments and decisions with significant economic benefits, such as continuing operation and life extensions. The work was supported by BNFL and its continuation by EPSRC, EdF Energy and AMEC.

Title: Reframing the climate change challenge in light of post-2000 emission trends
VolumeTitle: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society - A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This was an introductory article in a special issue of Philosophical Transactions setting the scene for papers on geoengineering solutions to climate change. It has played a seminal role in the climate change debate at an international scale, challenging conventional modelling approaches and their more palatable conclusions with regards the mitigation challenge. Its influence has reached international businesses and policymakers as one of the first papers to suggest that UK, EU and global ambitions of avoiding a 2 degrees Centigrade temperature rise are outside of the current policy orthodoxy.

Title: Chaotic Modelling and Control of Combustion Instabilities due to Vaporization
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer.
AdditionalInformation: This study is a substantial contribution to understanding and combating combustion instabilities encountered in lean premixed combustors adopted for power generation and propulsion applications for control of NOx and other emissions. It focuses on fundamental physico-chemical process of liquid fuel vaporization as a contributing agent towards thermo-chemical instabilites routinely encountered in current generation dry low NOx combustors responsible for a variety of atmospheric effects. Additionally, the integrity of the hardware, especially for rocket motors , is liable to be degraded substantially via the instability which is modelled and validated for a routine design and development engineering.

Title: Intermittent transformation between radial breathing and flexural vibration modes in a single-walled carbon nanotube
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society. Series A: Mathematical, Physical & Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper predicted possible mode transformation in nano-tubes. This is the first publication to reveal the existence of this fundamental mechanism in nano-structures, supported by mechanics model and mathematical descriptions. This automated vibration transformation may be potentially used in the design of nano-sensor and other devices. The project was supported by Shell. The co-author was a Ph.D student.

Title: Sustainable machining: selection of optimum turning conditions based on minimum energy considerations
AdditionalInformation: The novel and pioneering work reported in this paper was the development of mathematical model for optimising the energy footprint for a machined product. This work presents for the first time, a model to minimise energy and hence carbon footprint of machined products. It is also a generic contribution and evidence base on the effect of system boundaries in environmental modelling. This was the first paper that led the way to the subsequent CIRP paper and award of £1.4 million EPSRC funding for Resource Efficient Manufacture. I am now the EPRC international impact lead for resource efficiency Sandpit projects.

Title: Multi-domain active sound control and noise shielding
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: In this paper a unique technique of active sound control has been experimentally realised. In contrast to the other existing approaches, we allow a wanted sound to be present in the protected domain. The implemented technique was theoretically elaborated in a number of my previous publications. For the first time, it was realised for a broadband noise attenuation. The results were published in one of the two most prestigious international journals on acoustics. There are very interesting potential applications of this approach in civil engineering, car industry and oil prospecting. I was the lead academic on this work.

Title: Comprehensive Analysis of Transport Aircraft Flight Performance
AdditionalInformation: This contribution addresses multi-disciplinary simulation methods in the context of commercial aircraft flight. A comprehensive simulation model has been developed, which can be used for mission fuel planning, envelope exploration aircraft certification and conceptual aircraft design. This is the first contribution to address flight mechanics from a holistic point of view.  This contribution provides measurable advances in the prediction of aircraft emissions and operational costs.  This paper was the most downloaded article in 2008. This knowledge has been transferred to the industry, in particular Thales Avionics (France), where they use a version of this computational model.

Title: Wavelets Methods in Computational combustion
AdditionalInformation: This work reviewed biorthogonal wavelets in computational combustion and articulated for the first time a scheme to unify the formal structures of Direct Numerical Simulation, Large Eddy Simulation and multiresolution analysis. Although the work was motivated by the strong length scale separation between (most) flames and turbulence, a key strength of the approach lies in its generality. The work is important to any process that contains multi-scale physics.

Title: Stochastic Modelling of Aerosol Deposition for LES of 90 Bend Turbulent Flow
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: Our general purpose unstructured grid code adapts mesh resolution to space varying large eddy scales for LES in industrial geometries. Additional particle trajectory modelling allowing differentiation for smaller than grid scale turbulence enables particle separation due to injection, particle inertial forces and wall deposition. These effects are important in a wide range of industries, from pharmaceutical and manufacturing (sprays, powders) to petroleum and energy sectors (petrol droplets, erosion, deposition, corrosion, soot and solid grains). Replacing simple “random displacement” by such an advanced Langragian sub-model is now actively pursued by academics and commercial CFD software distributors.

Title: EXPERIMENTAL INVESTIGATION OF THE EFFECT OF MECHANICAL LOADING ON THERMAL TRANSPORT IN CERAMIC MATRIX COMPOSITES
AdditionalInformation: An interdisciplinary team from MACE, Materials Science, and Manchester Computing has been working on characterising Ceramic Matrix Composites (CMCs) for high temperature applications in aerospace for over 13 years. It has been awarded 3 EPSRC grants with research carried out in close international collaboration with leading material (CMC) developers such as German Aerospace Establishment, Rolls Royce, Dornier, and Hitco. These organizations provided the materials used in this study. The experimental results presented are: (1) significant for further development of these complex materials, (2) extremely useful for their current users European Space Agency, NASA, BAe Systems, Rolls Royce, and Nuclear Industry.

Title: Numerical prediction of local hot-spot phenomena in transformer windings
AdditionalInformation: This work was initiated by collaboration with National Grid Power and identifies a new flow mechanism inside transformer cooling channels, which has hitherto not been reported and can have strong influence on design. Findings have been disseminated to the industrial partner and the transformer manufacturers and a proposal for ongoing work has been submitted.

Title: The use of central reflection in the formulation of unit cells for micromechanical FEA
AdditionalInformation: This work involves the collabration with external academics. The originality of the work is that it is the first time to exploit central reflection symmetry in the formulation of unit cells for micromechanical FE analysis of materials of periodic microstructures. It reduces the size of the unit cell to be analysed with a single set of boundary conditions under all loading conditions and any combined loading condition. Such a feature cannot be preserved if a conventional plane reflectional symmetry or a rotational symmetry has been used in order to reduce the size of the unit cell to be analysed.

Title: Up-regulation of Tension Related Proteins in Keloids: Knock Down of Hsp27,alpha2,beta1-Integrin and PAI-2 Show Convincing Reduction of Extracellular Matrix Production
AdditionalInformation: The mechanism of keloid formation is poorly understood, and there is no specific treatment to cure these lesions. The findings from the study offer further insight into understanding the disease pathobiology and demonstrate the potential use of a biological process (RNA interference) for future treatment of keloids. The study offers options for a potential therapeutic application of RNAi for keloid treatment which it is expected will be taken up and developed further leading to an effective treatment for the disease. One co-author is a consultant in the department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Wythenshawe Hospital, Manchester.

Title: Highly Resolved LES and URANS of Turbulent Buoyancy-Driven Flow Within Inclined Differentially-Heated Enclosures
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes RANS and LES modelling of buoyant flows under various stable and unstable stratification arrangements. The LES provides a detailed database for use in model testing, validation a dn development, whilst the RANS sheds light on the performance of a number of industially widely-used models, highlighting the necessity for more advanced models in certain cases. The work was supported by EdF, and has led to some improved modelling in their Code_Saturne software.

Title: A Non-Physical Enthalpy Method for the Numerical Solution of Isothermal Solidification
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Solidification is at the heart of many commercial manufacturing processes and being able to accurately predict and control heat transfer is of major commercial interest and benefit.  Coupled to this is the continued development of the FEM, which is now an invaluable tool in most forms of commercial analysis.  The novel concept of nonphysical variables (albeit restricted to non-physical enthalpy in the paper) has led to work on the nonphysical finite element method (NPFEM) and presently the forming of an EPSRC proposal.  The co-author of the paper was a PhD student and the work formed part of his doctoral thesis.

Title: Experimental study of thermal development in a rotating square-ended U-bend
AdditionalInformation: This study, presents extensive experimental data, on the local thermal characteristics of rotating cooling passages of complex geometry, for conditions which match those of gas-turbine blade cooling passages. It was part of an EPSRC-funded project, with Dr Kounadis a funded PhD student. The provision of accurate and detailed thermal data under such conditions is in itself a major technical achievement. The results advance our previously limited understanding of this topic and quantify and the effects of rotation and of fluid properties, which is important to designers. Of even greater importance is perhaps the contribution to the validation of CFD codes.

Title: Uni-axial stress-strain response and thermal conductivity degradation of ceramic matrix composite fibre tows
VolumeTitle: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series A: Mathematical, physical & engineering sciences
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports on a model of the degradation of the thermal conductivity with strain in Ceramic Matrix Composites. Problem was formulated with inputs from UCSB California [McMeeking]; Teledyne, Los Angeles[Cox]; HITCO, Los Angeles[Wilson]; Rolls Royce[Hicks]: Goodrich, Brecksville[Pruett] and DLR, Stuttgart[Krenkel]. The paper establishes a theoretical basis for the prediction of thermal conductivity degradation, for the design of complex woven composites in, missiles, space vehicles and hypersonic aircraft. Presentations to the above companies, that supported an EPSRC grant, have been well received and take-up will ensue. Main impacts: reduction of manufacturing porosity.

Title: Droplet size and velocity distributions for spray modelling
AdditionalInformation:
Project supervisor (student - Jones).
Addresses issues of modelling drop size and velocity effects for moments-based spray models - of interest to spray modellers. Moments-based approach based on modelling work at Manchester (Beck & Watkins, Proc. R. Soc. Lond. A, Vol. 459, pp1365-1394, 2003) now available in open source code OPENFLOW.

Title: Optical virtual imaging at 50 nm lateral resolution with a white-light nanoscope
AdditionalInformation: This work is a major breakthrough in optical imaging, demonstrated a world's most powerful white light optical microscope achieving a record imaging resolution of 50 nm, which has broken the theoretical diffraction limit of light (200 nm). This capability has open up new opportunities for the study of virus/cell interactions in real time. The work has been reported on by BBC (top science news of the week), New York Times, ABC, Daily Mail, Guardian and most scientific websites on imaging and biomedicine. The work has also been included by Research Council UK publication "Big Ideas for the Future" June 2011.

Title: Modelling Turbulence in Engineering and the Environment: Second-Moment Routes to Closure
AdditionalInformation: 400-page research monograph unifying and extending authors’ research on modelling turbulence by way of RANS closures. Novel presentations not found elsewhere are developed in Ch 3, 5 and 7. For example, the book is the first presentation on turbulence modelling to start with the most general  model and to successively reduce it to bring out simpler sub-classes, thus making clear the progressively greater restrictions on the range of applicability of the simpler schemes (Ch. 7). Very favourable reviews of book contributed by Dr. P. Spalart and Prof. E. Mastorakos, both highly cited experts in modelling turbulent flows.

Title: Voronoi-diagram-based linking of contour-parallel tool paths for two-and-a-half-dimensional closed-pocket machining
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel methodology to determine the optimum tool paths for milling pockets.  The methodology described is generic and can be applied to determine the tool paths for other milling features. The novelty lies in the fact that for the first time both technical and geometric factors have been considered to optimise the paths.   Part of the methodology has had an impact in industry - some CAM systems now generate the tool paths using the Voronoi diagram approach but have to yet implement the technological aspects.

Title: Differential cytotoxic response in keloid fibroblasts exposed to photodynamic therapy is dependent on photosensitiser precursor, fluence and location of fibroblasts within the lesion
AdditionalInformation: Current treatment of keloid disease is ill-defined and remains challenging. The paper demonstrates that photodynamic therapy can be used as a novel treatment for the site-targeted therapy of keloid disease. The paper’s findings add weight to the use of photodynamic therapy as an effective treatment for keloid disease and will encourage its use and stimulate further research in this area. Two co-authors are affiliated to the department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Wythenshawe Hospital, Manchester and two to The Christie NHS Foundation Trust.

Title: Modelling of three-dimensional jet array impingement and heat transfer on a concave surface
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: Cooling flows in turbine blades involve turbulent heat transfer in very complex geometries, thus providing a great challenge for relatively cheap turbulence modelling approaches. The paper describes the application of non-linear eddy viscoisty models and an advanced wall function, to a complex flow geometry involving multiple impinging and rotating jets. Some modifications are proposed for representing certain convection terms in the wall function to improve its behaviour in impinging flows. Results show the model can capture many of the flow and heat transfer features, and some areas suitable for further refinement are identified.

Title: Load shortening characteristics of marine grade aluminium alloy plates in longitudinal compression
AdditionalInformation: This paper extends previous work of the group to consider the collapse of aluminium alloy plates and stiffened panels. The paper presents the most in depth study of collapse of these types of structures to date, improving on previous studies by properly considering the influence of the heat affected zone and residual stress due to welding. These parameters are shown to have significant influence on the progressive collapse of thin plated structures. The research was funded by the US Office of Naval Research (Structural Performance of Aluminium Naval Vessels; reference N00014-07-1-0533).

Title: A Comparison of Computational Methods to Predict the Progressive Collapse Behaviour of a Damaged Box Girder
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds on previous work on progressive collapse [Dow2] by extending the analysis to consider the collapse of damaged girders.  The resulting analysis is unique and outlines clear differences in the behaviour of damaged and undamaged girders arising from the built in stresses due to the damage mechanism.  The research was funded by the US Office of Naval Research (Structural Performance of Naval Vessels; reference N00014-11-1-0650; £412k).

Title: Compartment level progressive collapse analysis of lightweight ship structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel methodology for predicting the collapse strength of ships, taking into account collapse modes which had not previously been considered. The research was funded by the US Office of Naval Research (Structural Performance of Aluminium Naval Vessels; reference N00014-07-1-0533; £241k). The methodology proposed is currently being incorporated into the Maestro ship design software used by the US Navy in its design processes and for use in vulnerability analysis (Maestro is maintained on behalf of the US Navy by DRS Design Solutions; contact: Tobin McNatt; tmcnatt@drs-c3.com).

Title: Simulation of ship grounding damage using the finite element method
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new model for material rupture, and also presents an innovative implementation of the model within an FE environment, allowing accurate failure predictions to be made with coarser, more practical, meshes.  The model is validated against experimental data.  This research was performed as part of the EC funded MARSTRUCT programme (Network of Excellence in Marine Structures; 506141; £223k).

Title: Global wave loads on a damaged ship
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents and validates a unique analysis methodology which quantifies the hydrodynamic loading and reduced stiffness of damaged ships, in order to support the development of damage tolerant ships.  The research was funded by the US Ship Structures Committee (Reliability Based Performance Assessment of Damaged Ships; ref. N00014-06-1-0669).

Title: An experimental investigation of the frictional drag characteristics of nanostructured and fluorinated fouling-release coatings using an axisymmetric body
AdditionalInformation: The paper assesses the hydrodynamic performance of newly formulated antifouling coatings by combining the drag and boundary layer measurements in a slender body apparatus, never previously used in testing antifouling coatings, allowing direct measurement of the drag forces. This builds on work published by the group in 2012, which presented the first measurements of performance of the coatings on flat plates [Atlar3].  The research was carried out in collaboration with International Paint (co-authors Davies and Williams), who have commercialised the coatings (contact: David Williams; david.williams@akzo-nobel.com).

Title: An experimental investigation of the effect of foul release coating application on performance, noise and cavitation characteristics of marine propellers
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a unique study on the effect of foul release coatings on the combined performance of a marine propeller. The research contributed significantly to the report of the Specialist Committee on Surface Treatment of the 26th International Towing Tank Conference (http://ittc.sname.org/proc26/htm/VOLII/11.pdf), which guides the maritime research community in defining research needs and establishing standard procedures for marine hydrodynamic measurement.

Title: Turbulent boundary layer measurements over flat surfaces coated by nanostructured marine antifoulings
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first hydrodynamic performance data on nanostructured antifouling coatings developed as part of the EC funded AMBIO project (Advanced Nanostructured Surfaces for the Control of Biofouling; 11827; £523k).  The paper presents the most in depth study of the hydrodynamic performance of nano-structured coatings available at that time, and in particular presented unique data on the performance of coatings on rough surfaces.

Title: Hydrodynamic development of Inclined Keel Hull-propulsion
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents in depth research on the performance of a novel inclined keel concept to improve the efficiency of container vessels. The validity of the approach was demonstrated on a large commercial vessel.  The research was carried out as part of the EC STREAMLINE project (Strategic Research for Innovative Marine Propulsion Concepts; 233896; £108k) and further large scale verification, confirming the value of the concept, has been carried out in the same project.

Title: Modelling of water wave interaction with multiple cylinders of arbitrary shape
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development of an efficient semi-analytical/numerical model for linear wave interaction with cylindrical structures of arbitrary shapes, which improves on previous models in terms of the range of phenomena which can be modelled and offers improved numerical performance, with computational efficiency being improved by a factor of 10.

Title: Wave interaction with a perforated circular breakwater of non-uniform porosity
AdditionalInformation: Elegant explicit analytical solutions are obtained for a general 3 dimensional short-crested wave interaction with a porous cylindrical breakwater. The analysis presented and the results of the parametric study not only provide significant insights of the 3D waves interaction with structures of non-uniform porosity, but have also directly led to the improved design of coastal and offshore structures (e.g., Xiao et al at Shanghai Jiao Tong University have used the analysis in the preliminary design of very large floating offshore base, Email: xiaolf@sjtu.edu.cn).

Title: An efficient scaled boundary FEM model for wave interaction with a nonuniform porous cylinder
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Fluids
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a development of a novel and highly efficient numerical model for simulation of water waves and porous offshore structures with a partially solid wall or opening. This is a major step forward in terms of the model complexity and potential application as previous models were only applicable for wave scattering problems by a structure of homogenous material.

Title: Hydrodynamic performance of solid and porous heave plates
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel experimental study on the hydrodynamic characteristics (added mass and damping) of oscillatory solid or porous disks since such heave plates have been widely utilised in floating offshore structures. The data and results provided benchmarks for future experimental and numerical studies by a number of groups (e.g., Li et al, Dalian University of Technology dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2013.04.012; An & Faltinsen, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jfluidstructs.2013.03.004), as well as for direct applications in engineering design (contact: Dr Yusong Cao, Research and Technical Manager, MARUNTEC-USA Inc., Email: Yusong.Cao@marineteckusa.com).

Title: Cost-Effective Condition Monitoring for Wind Turbines
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents and validates a novel condition monitoring strategy for wind turbines, which improves on previous schemes by being able to detect both mechanical and electrical faults from electrical measurements at the generator.  The approach is also computationally efficient, with the potential to support online conditioning monitoring.  Discussions are ongoing with Romax Technology (contact: Xiaoqin Ma; xiaoqin.ma@romaxtech.com) who wish to exploit the approach in their commercial wind turbine drivetrain health management system.

Title: Electrochemical Process for Micropattern Transfer Without Photolithography: A Modeling Analysis
AdditionalInformation: The process presented in this paper is a new method of microscale patterning which reduces the need for photolithography (the current platform technology) by over 95%. This is a new electrochemical method to manufacture micropatterns by plating or etching which has great potential in micro device and microfeature fabrication. The process has been patented in the US (Process for manufacturing micro-and nano-devices; US20080283501A1) and Japan (JP2008507630), and led in 2010 to the formation of a spin out company, Royenface, for its future commercial exploitation.

Title: Electrodeposition of microstructures using a patterned anode
AdditionalInformation: Work published by the group in 2008 [Roy1] established that microscale pattern transfer was achievable by etching, and that process was patented and is being commercialised by a spin-out company (Royenface). The process of transfer previously developed involved passivation of the surface. This paper builds from that previous research to show for the first time that maskless microscale pattern transfer by plating is also feasible. The technique is also being commercialised by Royenface to develop more sustainable methods for fabricating printed circuit boards, with support from the EC Eco-innovation programme (ECO/11/303550/SI2.62744).

Title: Effect of electrochemical structuring of Ti6Al4V on osteoblast behaviour in vitro
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented the first in depth study of the effect of electropolishing on the bioactivity of medical grade titanium alloy surfaces, and also allowed, for the first time, the relative importance of surface chemistry and surface roughness on the bioactivity of these alloys to be assessed, addressing an ongoing debate in the academic community at the time.  The results showed in vitro that bone formation was more significantly influenced by surface chemistry than surface roughness, over the range of values studied, and that electropolishing could potentially be used to optimise surface properties for bone ongrowth.

Title: A model for the corrosion of steel subjected to synthetic produced water containing sulfate, chloride and hydrogen sulfide
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents and validates a new physical model of pipeline corrosion, to improve on previous empirical or statistical models. This model allowed, for the first time, separation of abiotic corrosion (that happens in the absence of bacteria) such that the influence of bacteria on the corrosion could be quantified. The model combines effects of fluid flow, corrosion science and chemistry. The research programme was carried out in collaboration with Chevron (co-authors Page and Lawson).

Title: Selection of oxygen reduction catalysts for rechargeable lithium-air batteries - Metal or oxide?
AdditionalInformation: Lithium air batteries offer one of the highest theoretical energy densities of any battery. This paper reports on catalyst materials required to facilitate fast oxygen reduction in the battery. It shows for the first time that a low cost maganese oxide catalyst provides capacities of an order of magnitude greater than current Li battery (or any other battery) performance.  The work was part of £1.2M EPSRC project “An O2 Electrode for a Rechargeable Lithium Battery” (EP/E03649X/1; Newcastle award £501k), and is continuing through the £3M EPSRC Energy Transport Grand Challenge project “Crossing Boundaries in Energy Storage” (EP/I022570/1; Newcastle award £311k).

Title: A polymer electrolyte membrane for high temperature fuel cells to fit vehicle applications
AdditionalInformation: Polymer electrolyte fuel cells are central to the use of fuel cell technology. Operating at higher temperatures offers savings in cost and potential greater efficiencies.
