This work demonstrated that the power performance of a high temperature polymer fuel cell based on a composite structure could match that of current polymer electrolyte fuels cells whilst offering the option of superior operation for combined heat and power. The material costs for the membrane are a fraction of that of current technology.  The research was carried out through the £3.6M EPSRC Supergen Fuel Cell Consortium project (EP/G030995/1; Newcastle award £870k).

Title: RuO2 supported on Sb-doped SnO2 nanoparticles for polymer electrolyte membrane water electrolysers
AdditionalInformation: Electrolysis represents the only commercially developed method for generation of hydrogen from a renewable energy source such as wind or photovoltaics. Polymer electrolyte membrane electrolysers represent the best option for variable power operation at high current loads. This paper reports on the characterisation of electrode and cell performance data for new oxygen evolution catalysts that offer some of the best performance reported at a low operating cell voltage. This research was funded through EPSRC project “Collaborative Research in Energy with South Africa. Intermediate Temperature Proton Conducting Membrane Systems for the Hydrogen Economy” (EP/G042012/1; £346k).

Title: The effect of electrode parameters on the performance of anion exchange polymer membrane fuel cells
AdditionalInformation: Alkaline polymer exchange membranes present an opportunity to develop a low cost fuel cell. Until this paper the demonstrated power and efficiency performance of such fuel cells has been much lower than that of the sister acid, proton exchange polymer membrane fuel cell (PEMFC). Through parallel membrane and electrode development, a radical increase in power has been achieved, and the data reported in this paper represents the highest performance reported of alkaline polymer membrane fuel cells to date.  The research was supported by EPSRC project “Alkaline Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cells” (EP/F035764/1; £383k).

Title: Energy From Algae Using Microbial Fuel Cells
AdditionalInformation: This research presented in this paper, carried out in collaboration with Penn-State University in the US, demonstrated for the first time that microalgae could be used as a substrate for bioelectricity production, and also developed a rigorous methodology to determine power output in microbial fuel cells.  Power output determination is a standard technique which is necessary for any microbial fuel cell evaluation, and the developed methodology allows valid worldwide comparisons of microbial fuel cell power output.

Title: Identification of semi-parametric hybrid process models
AdditionalInformation: The paper identified the limitations of existing approaches to hybrid modelling and focused on developing a methodology that aligned with the implementation of such models in industrial situations. The research resulted in a new approach which was shown to outperform current techniques. The research was undertaken as part of the EPSRC research project VERTIGO (Vertical integration of product development and manufacturing, GR/R64407/01; £507k), with industrial collaboration from Avecia and GSK Pharmaceuticals.

Title: Maintenance affects the stability of a two-tiered microbial 'food chain'?
AdditionalInformation: The mathematical model developed in this paper tackles a particular aspect of anaerobic digestion processes, the stability of microbial food chains, with reference to wastewater treatment that had previously not been considered due to the complex mathematical challenges. The work was carried out as part of a Marie Curie Excellence Award (MEXT-CT-2006-023469  ECOSERV: designed ecosystem services for biological treatment) and is now being integrated into the general industry standard ADM1 (Anaerobic Digestion Model No. 1) as part of an EngD project at Newcastle in collaboration with Perceptive Engineering (contact: David Lovett; d.lovett@perceptiveapc.com).

Title: Dynamic data rectification using particle filters
AdditionalInformation: Significant research has previously been undertaken in the field of dynamic data rectification, and the research presented in this paper proposes and validates a new methodology which is applicable to cases where the process exhibits highly non-linear behaviour and the states are non-Gaussian, but is also able to detect outliers, process changes and the removal of measurement noise, all through the implementation of one algorithm. The results show significant improvements over existing models.

Title: Bayesian linear regression and variable selection for spectroscopic calibration
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this paper proposes and validates a new approach to spectroscopic calibration modelling. It simultaneously enables the achievement of i) a balance between model accuracy and complexity; (ii) providing a predictive distribution that automatically gives prediction intervals; (iii) removing the computational burden of cross-validation; and (iv) realising a variable selection strategy, a combination of characteristics which previous models had not provided.  The work was carried out as part of a DTI Succeeding through Innovation Award (Implementing PAT for successful development of Biopharmaceuticals in the UK), led by GlaxoSmithKline.

Title: Utilisation of key descriptors from protein sequence data to aid bioprocess route selection
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the findings of a joint academic-industrial research project with Avecia Biologics (now Fujifilm Diosynth Biotechnologies; co-authors Liddell and Kara). The paper shows that protein descriptors contain information that can be used to give an indication of the sequence of unit operations required when the product is manufactured. The algorithms developed extract the relationships from a historical industrial database and when new products arise their descriptors are determined and contrasted with prior experience to suggest the most likely recovery route. This approach enables a rapid assessment of the optimal recovery route for new products.

Title: Application of Agent-Based System for Bioprocess Description and Process Improvement
AdditionalInformation: Bioprocess design has traditionally been undertaken on a unit-by-unit basis, ignoring inter-unit interaction. This paper described the results of using modelling agents within an overall plant design framework to improve the performance of the whole process. The novelty of the approach lies in the agent based search approach adopted. This work was carried out as part of EPSRC project “Enhancing Manufacturing by linking models derived from ultra-scale down and early process data via an intelligent agent” (GR/T24005/01; £143k), and is being further developed through the EC funded F3 Factory project (“Flexible, Fast and Future Production Processes”; 228867; Newcastle award £222k)

Title: Forecasting for fermentation operational decision making
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development of a new fermentation end-point detection procedure, and demonstrated that improvements were made to the temperature control system. The generic nature of the approaches was verified using an antibiotic fermentation example from Sandoz (contact: Georg Kornfeld; Georg.kornfeld@sandoz.com). The predictive capability allows improved scheduling decisions to be made in the latter stages of batch process operation.

Title: Risk-based decision making in early chemical process development of pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper makes a significant contribution to the area of chemical process decision making in early stage development, and was carried out as part of the EPSRC “Process 2020 Innovation SatNav” project (EP/F016913/1; £242k).   The resulting decision tools have subsequently been developed further through the “Early phase process development toolkit (InsidePharmasystems)” project (EPSRC Follow on Funds; EP/I006303/1; £94k) to be exploited via the BRITEST consortium (contact Mark Talford; mark.talford@britest.co.uk), giving wide exposure of the multi-objective decision making to practitioners.

Title: Two-dimensional simple proportional feedback control of a chaotic reaction system
VolumeTitle: Physical Review E: Statistical, Nonlinear, and Soft Matter Physics
AdditionalInformation: The effective control of chaos in chemical reaction systems is crucial in order to mitigate long term unpredictability and non-uniform system performance which manifests as, for instance, irregular product concentration/selectivity as a chaotic reaction progresses. This paper describes the theoretical development of a new control algorithm that can be applied to regulate any chaotic system and demonstrates the superior performance of the new algorithm compared to a widely used alternative method.

Title: The influence of reaction temperature on the oscillatory behaviour in the palladium-catalysed phenylacetylene oxidative carbonylation reaction
AdditionalInformation: Research reported in this paper builds on work group reported in 2008 [Novakovic3] to present the first ever experimental study demonstrating that reaction temperature has a profound effect on the amplitude/period of pH oscillations in oxidative carbonylation reactions.  These reaction characteristics make the system promising for incorporation into smart polymer gels to develop biomimetic materials operating without any on-off switching of external stimuli. This research was the basis of a “New Directions for EPSRC Research Leaders Award” made to Novakovic (administered as a £295k supplement to the “Powering smart materials by oscillatory chemical reactions” fellowship award; EP/H003908/1).

Title: Product identification and distribution from the oscillatory versus non-oscillatory palladium(II) iodide-catalysed oxidative carbonylation of phenylacetylene
VolumeTitle: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds on previous work by the group [Novakovic3] which described the behaviour of the palladium-catalysed oxidative carbonylation of phenylacetylene operating in both oscillatory and non-oscillatory modes.  The paper was the first in depth characterisation of the reaction system, and the first to identify and synthesise all the reaction products and demonstrate that product distribution could be controlled by reaction conditions.

Title: Utilising high throughput technologies for the determination of the reaction network of the ʟ-proline catalysed aldol reaction
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the application of robotic, parallel synthesis platforms for use in predictive kinetic modelling. It was demonstrated that small scale synthesis combined with high throughput technologies is applicable to the determination of reaction networks and associated rate constants. Consequently experimental time and associated costs could be reduced significantly. The publication led to collaboration with Chemspeed Technologies (contact: Dr Jake Grace; jake.grace@chemspeed.com) who have applied the methodology to the automated optimisation of reaction conditions.

Title: Batch-to-batch optimal control of a batch polymerisation process based on stacked neural network models
AdditionalInformation: This paper showed for the first time that robust neural networks and iterative learning control can be integrated to obtain reliable and robust batch-to-batch control strategies for batch processes. The novel modelling and batch-to-batch control methods established in this paper are being further developed in a major collaborative project, the €5M EC FP7 Collaborative project iREMO (Intelligent Reactive Polymer Composite Moulding, NMP2-SL-2009-228662; Newcastle award £214k).

Title: Nonlinear wave modeling and dynamic analysis of internal thermally coupled distillation columns
AdditionalInformation: Internal thermally coupled distillation columns are a new type of distillation process that consume much less energy than conventional distillation processes. However, they have complex dynamics which makes the establishment of an excellent reduced model for control strategy design difficult. This paper presents and validates a novel nonlinear wave model for internal thermally coupled distillation columns.

Title: Fault Localization in Batch Processes through Progressive Principal Component Analysis Modeling
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a unique multivariate statistical process monitoring (MSPM) technique for the establishment of fault propagation paths, for the first time offering new functionality to MSPM techniques in terms of fault diagnosis and localisation.

Title: Fault detection in dynamic processes using a simplified monitoring-specific CVA state space modelling approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel formulation of state-space canonical variate analysis (CVA) models (using three parameter matrices instead of five) in models which were developed for the specific purpose of process condition monitoring. The method is shown to be computationally very efficient yet gives comparable or better fault detection performance than the conventional CVA based process monitoring approaches.

Title: Intensified Azeotropic Distillation: A Strategy for Optimizing Direct Amidation
AdditionalInformation: Direct synthesis of amides from their corresponding carboxylic acids and amines has been identified as the top priority for green chemistry research by the pharmaceutical industry. To date reseearchers have striven to find a better catalyst. This work approaches the problem from a completely different and new perspective: intensified azeotropic distillation (IAD). Using this essentially chemical engineering approach conversion has been considerably enhanced and exceeded the performance of catalysts alone. The combined effect of catalyst and IAD now offer a means to make amides in a far greener and more sustainable way. IAD may be applicable to all condensation reactions.

Title: A new autocatalytic thioacetate-enal addition reaction: A Michael addition or not?
AdditionalInformation: The Michael-addition is one of the oldest and widely used organic reactions. The accepted mechanism involves direct addition of a nucleophile to the remote carbon of the conjugated C=O. This work discovered that for the case of thioacetic acid,(and subsequently other systems) addition across unsaturated-aldehydes occurs in a multistep autocatalytic manner involving a double exotherm. This new two stage autocatalytic behaviour represents a significant discovery in a previously well established area of chemistry. The novelty of the work is due to chemical engineering methodology (adiabatic and reaction calorimetry and kinetic interpretation) combined with synthetic organic chemistry.

Title: A New Approach to the Synthesis of 4-Hydroxyethylsulfonylstyrene
AdditionalInformation: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from solvent-borne coatings (e.g, paints etc.) are a serious environmental problem.  This work aims to reduce VOC emissions through the design and development of a novel water-borne coating system based on bifunctional polymer monomers.  The process development included adaiabatic and reaction chemistry, kinetics, modelling and thermal runaway assessment, all leading to a new, environmentally benign process route.

Title: Mechanistic insights into transition metal-catalysed oxidation of a hydroxamic acid with in situ Diels-Alder trapping of the acyl nitroso derivative
AdditionalInformation: Hetro-Diels Alder cycloaddition reactions provide a powerful synthetic tool in natural product based drug design. Many of these natural products contain multiple chiral centres; therefore catalysts used during synthesis must be highly specific to achieve asymmetric synthesis. The purpose of this research was to understand the behaviour of certain transition metal catalysts through detailed mechanistic studies. Because of the complexity of the task a number of techniques were employed including reaction kinetics, NMR spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry and X-ray crystallography. The results showed that whilst one catalyst was sufficient to perform the oxidation, a second moiety was required to induce asymmetry.

Title: Probing interactions of the HIV protein GP120 with lipids and CD4 receptors
AdditionalInformation: This paper determines the self assembly and interactions of proteins and receptors involved in the attachment of the HIV virus particles to cell membranes. By understanding how the viral particle attaches at the molecular level strategies to block attachment can be derived. This paper demonstrates for the first time that part of the viral protein attacks and sinks into the lipids as well as specifically interacts with cell membrane receptors. The work reported in this paper was carried out as part of EPSRC project “Surface Nanostructures For The Study of Biomolecular Recognition, Chirality And Crystal Growth” (EP/F025688/1; £298k).

Title: Self assembly and pore formation of HIV GP160 revealed at molecular resolution
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates that HIV virus proteins can self assemble into pores big enough for viral DNA to pass through, in particular allowing understanding of transfection from the virus to the cell. The proteins can be resolved into molecular features with six molecules forming a distinctive pore. Such structures have never previously been observed in virus particles. From these model systems we can research unexplored mechanisms of HIV viral infection at the molecular level, in order to explore how viral protein assembly could be used in the development of new therapeutic targets.

Title: Characterising single fibronectin-integrin complexes
AdditionalInformation: The integrin/fibronectin interaction is responsible for cell adhesion and is fundamental to tissue healing, disease and repair. Integrins are over expressed in cancer cells and provide a target for many of the current and developing chemotherapies. The research described in this paper isolated, for the first time, single molecule complexes of individual integrins and fibronectins, and allowed confirmation that fibronectin binds to the head region of integrins and that the lipid bilayer stabilises such interactions. The paper shows the highest resolution image to date of a single integrin molecule and integrin/fibronectin complex.

Title: Creating a bio-hybrid signal transduction pathway: opening a new channel of communication between cells and machines
AdditionalInformation: The bio-machine interface has inherent difficulties associated with developing electronics to measure the few measurable signals eminating from biological tissues. In this work re-engineering the biology to fit the electronics is investigated (rather than fitting the electronics to the biology). Using synthetic biology we have been successful in creating mammallian cells that can respond to light signals by creating a machine readable signal. It is hoped that this new approach will spawn a new generation of biohybrid machines. The work was carried out as part of a joint EPSRC/NSF funded project on “Cyberplasm” (EP/H019081/1).

Title: Mechanical response of atomic layer deposition alumina coatings on stiff and compliant substrates
VolumeTitle: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this paper introduces and validates a novel stiffness modelling approach which has wide applicability to the mechanical assessment of very thin coatings on polymeric (low stiffness) substrates. The research was carried out under a Royal Academy of Engineering/Leverhulme Trust Fellowship, and the paper was selected by the editor for inclusion in the Virtual Journal of Nanoscale Science and Technology (Volume 25, Issue 3, 2012).

Title: Experimental and modelling techniques for assessing the adhesion of very thin coatings on glass
VolumeTitle: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
AdditionalInformation: This paper links the results of experimental adhesion assessment of coatings on architectural glass with the modelling necessary to extract quantitative adhesion parameters from the test results. For the first time good agreement between theoretical calculations of interface structure and energy and experimentally determined values was successfully demonstrated for a real engineering system. The research was funded through an EPSRC multiscale modelling grant (EP/C006852/1; £174k), with collaboration from Pilkington plc (now NSG) who used the results from the project to optimise their Optitherm product (contact: Paul Warren, paul.warren@nsg.com).

Title: Mechanical modeling of flexible OLED devices
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the result of collaborative research on the generation of organic light emitting diodes for lighting applications. This paper extends the range of OLED applications by considering the mechanics of coating systems with flexible substrates and submicron coatings. The work was supported by Kodak as part of their drive to find alternative uses for their photographic film production technologies (contact Chris Winscome, formerly of Kodak, now Visiting Professor at Brunel University, chris.winscom@brunel.ac.uk, and a co-author of the paper).

Title: Mechanical analysis and in situ structural and morphological evaluation of Ni-Sn alloy anodes for Li ion batteries
VolumeTitle: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this paper was the result of an international collaborative study funded by the Daiwa Foundation on the mechanical factors affecting the performance and life of a novel lithium ion battery material, and this was the first paper to clearly show how mechanical failure of electrode coatings can reduce battery life. This is a finding which has been subsequently confirmed for other high lithium-storage electrode systems (e.g. Li et al, J. Electrochem. Soc. 158(6), A689, 2011).

Title: Nickel nanoparticles catalyse reversible hydration of carbon dioxide for mineralization carbon capture and storage
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel technology for CO2 capture via a catalyst (nickel nanoparticles - NiNPs), conversion to carbonic acid in water, and subsequent mineralisation in water at or near room temperature and atmospheric pressure. A patent application has been filed to cover this work (P202887GB), and commercial exploitation is being pursued through an award from the University’s EPSRC Impact Acceleration Account.

Title: Silver nanoparticle toxicity in sea urchin Paracentrotus lividus
AdditionalInformation: In this paper the toxicity of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs; the most widely used commercial nanoparticle) is evaluated using sea urchin Paracentrotus lividus larvae as a model system. The research showed, for the first time, that the toxicity of AgNPs is predominantly from the AgNPs themselves and not predominantly from Ag+ ions leaching from the AgNPs.

Title: Volume fraction and temperature variations of the effective thermal conductivity of nanodiamond fluids in deionized water
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: Detonation nanodiamonds are materials which are available in high volume and they are commercially very cheap. Diamond is known to be the best thermal conductor and it is known that nanofluids show enhanced thermal conductivities when compared to micron sized particles, therefore leading ultimately to the best thermal conductor in fluids. This work studied for the first time the thermal conductivity of nanodimonds dispersed in deionised water and compared this to the various models of thermal conductivity in the literature. The research demonstrated thermal conductivity which is better than that from other carbon nanomaterials.

Title: Core and valence exciton formation in x-ray absorption, x-ray emission and x-ray excited optical luminescence from passivated Si nanocrystals at the Si L2,3 edge
AdditionalInformation: In this work the complete valence and conducting band of isolated Si nanocrystals (1.8nm in diameter) was mapped for the first time using X-ray emission spectroscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy at the Synchrotron facility in MAX-Lab, Sweden. Previous work only studied Si nanocrystals embedded in dielectrics. The research has provided new insights into which parameters are important for understanding the luminescence of Si nanocrystals

Title: Influence of water and the reactant addition sequence on palladium(II) iodide-catalyzed phenylacetylene carbonylation
AdditionalInformation: Combining experimental and modelling approaches the research presented in this paper improves our understanding of industrially significant carbonylation processes. By tailoring the reaction conditions we report for the first time the vital role of water and reactant addition sequence on product formation and selectivity. By gaining a deeper understanding of the underlying reaction mechanism high product conversions can now be achieved.

Title: Kinetics of styrene free radical polymerisation in the spinning disc reactor
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to model polymerisation kinetics in a spinning disc reactor (SDR) and to provide a mechanistic explanation for the rate enhancements observed in a number of earlier experimental studies of thin film polymerisations in the SDR. The mechanistic aspects of this modelling study have been subsequently applied in two industrially funded projects by Cray Valley France (a subsidiary company of Total Oil; contact [jacques.faure@crayvalley.com]), and Eastman Chemicals Company, The Netherlands (contact: Gerard Keijzer, [gkeijzer@eastman.com]), both of which were related to assessing the feasibility of SDR application to industrially relevant polymerisation processes.

Title: The influence of oscillations on product selectivity during the palladium-catalysed phenylacetylene oxidative carbonylation reaction
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports an experimental study which achieves reproducible oscillations in oxidative carbonylation reactions, a task that only one other group worldwide has achieved (Gorodsky at Lomonosow Moscow State Academy of Fine Technology; contact: Dr Sergey Gorodsky; gorodsky@yandex.ru). The work demonstrates a reaction with nonlinear dynamics that is of relevance in organic synthesis, and showed for the first time that commercially valuable products could be obtained selectively under different operating conditions. This research was the foundation of a five year EPSRC Career Acceleration Fellowship awarded to Novakovic (Powering smart materials by oscillatory chemical reactions; EP/H003908/1; £700k).

Title: Surface interactions and quantum kinetic molecular sieving for H2 and D2 adsorption on a mixed metal-organic framework material
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: In 2006 we published the first experimental observation of kinetic molecular quantum molecular sieving of H2 and D2 on carbon molecular sieves (J Phys Chem B 2006.110.9947). This paper describes the first observation of independent kinetic quantum molecular sieving of H2 and D2 in 2D channels in a metal organic framework and also the highest enthalpy of H2 adsorption at time of publication. The research led to further work within the £4M EPSRC Coordination Chemistry for Energy and Our Sustainable Futures programme grant (EP/I011870/1).

Title: Protecting group and switchable pore-discriminating adsorption properties of a hydrophilic-hydrophobic metal-organic framework
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first type of dual pore hydrophilic hydrophobic metal organic framework, and showed the first observation of kinetic molecular sieving of oxygen and nitrogen on a metal organic framework.  The work reported in this paper led to an EPSRC award (Hemilabile and Switchable Metal-Organic Frameworks; EP/K005499/1; Newcastle award £262k) to continue the collaborative research.

Title: Adsorption of Chloroaromatic Models for Dioxins on Porous Carbons: The Influence of Adsorbate Structure and Surface Functional Groups on Surface Interactions and Adsorption Kinetics
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first systematic study of the adsorption of dioxins on porous carbon under conditions representative of industrial applications.  The study identifies that the absorbate absorbent interaction is the key factor controlling adsorption, with the role of surface functional groups significantly less important than previously thought, with the underlying mechanisms for this also explained.

Title: Functional Hollow Fiber Adsorbent Materials with a Self-Regulating Composite Outer Layer for Gas Purification with Energy Efficient Electrothermal Regeneration
AdditionalInformation: This paper outlines the development of a new process which for the first time allowed optimised doping of carbon onto hollow polymer fibres, allowing the creation of an absorbent system which showed significantly improved performance over previously available systems.  The research was carried out in collaboration with Nano-porous Solutions (contact Colin Billiet; e-mail colin.billiet@n-psl.com), who have implemented the new process in the manufacture of adsorbent separation and filtration products.

Title: Influence of water content on failure of phenolic composites in fire
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to report on the rapid degradation of the strength of phenolic composite materials in fire, and the first to identify the importance of water content on this rapid degradation. Phenolics had been perceived to be excellent in transport applications, but this research showed that the phenolic composites studied did not provide good structural performance in fire unless the water content was significantly reduced.

Title: Effect of stress on the fire reaction properties of polymer composite laminates
AdditionalInformation: This was the first paper to systematically characterise the effects of stress on thermoset matrix composite fire reaction properties, which are key to the successful application of composites in transport. The work was initiated in the EC funded Momentum Marie-Curie Research Training Network (19198; Newcastle award £508k) and is being further developed in the EC funded FIRE-RESIST project (246037; Newcastle award £602k).

Title: Multiple objective optimisation of composite sandwich structures for rail vehicle floor panels
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the application of a novel optimisation technique to the lightweighting of composite structures in a transport application, which includes mass and cost as well as structural performance, and shows that significant mass savings (up to 40%) could be achieved without incurring a significant increase in cost.

Title: Investigation of the weld unzipping failure mode during collisions of welded aluminium rail vehicles
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops models of “weld unzipping” failure (brittle fast fracture) of aluminium alloy welds, research prompted by the Ladbroke Grove rail crash. The research formed the basis of two new standards (EN15085, Welding of Railway Vehicles; EN15227, Rail Crashworthiness) that must be implemented for any new aluminium rail vehicles. The paper was awarded the “2008 Safety in Engineering Award” by the IMechE and the “2009 Sir Alfred Rosling Bennett / Charles S Lake Award” by the Railway Division of the IMechE. The work was funded by the EC (ALJOIN, 00829) and the UK Rail Safety and Standards Board.

Title: Analysis of Micro-Elastohydrodynamic Lubrication and Prediction of Surface Fatigue Damage in Micropitting Tests on Helical Gears
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to experimentally validate a novel fatigue and damage accumulation model of gear life, with Newcastle leading the experimental work and Cardiff the computational. The work at Newcastle was funded by the British Gear Association and Rolls-Royce (contact: Mike Mountney, mike.mountney@rolls-royce.com), and the results have informed further collaborative work by the two groups.

Title: A numerical simulation to relate the shot peening parameters to the induced residual stresses
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows for the first time how modelling of particle dynamics using a discrete element (DE) approach can provide greater understanding and optimisation of the shot peening process to provide maximum strength benefit to engineering components. Combining the DE method, which gives understanding of particle interactions in the incoming shot stream combined with rebounding particles, with FE analysis of the resulting surface impacts is shown to be a powerful approach to understanding how shot peening process parameters can affect resulting residual stress generation in critical components.

Title: Magneto-Acoustic Emission and Magnetic Barkhausen Emission for Case Depth Measurement in En36 Gear Steel
AdditionalInformation: This paper compares the information you can get from two surface and subsurface stress measurement techniques (magneto-acoustic emission and magnetic barkhausen emission), and demonstrates how the two techniques can be used in a complementary way in order to provide a more complete picture of the surface and subsurface stresses than is available from either technique on its own. The paper then outlines a novel hybrid technique for the characterisation of surface and subsurface stresses.

Title: Contact fatigue performance of helical gears with surface coatings
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first in depth study of the performance of inorganic fullerene-like nanoparticles as a surface coating in gears. The results show that the coated gears improve performance, and the mechanism of that improved performance is explained. The research was carried out with EC funding (Fullerene-based opportunities for robust engineering: making optimised surfaces for tribology; 515840; Newcastle award £392k), and the coating material is being further developed by Ionbond (contact: Peter Hatto, peter.hatto@ionbond.com).

Title: Relation between the ratio of elastic work to the total work of indentation and the ratio of hardness to Young's modulus for a perfect conical tip
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented a new nanoindentation model to overcome the limitations of the commonly used Oliver and Pharr method for deriving modulus and hardness values from nanoindentation tests.  The paper shows that the Oliver and Pharr method is not accurate for very soft metals and very hard ceramics as a result of material pile-up and sink-in, and is also not generally accurate at small indentation depths as a result of tip blunting.  The new model addresses these limitations, extending the range of materials for which it is possible to use nanoindentation to derive accurate modulus and hardness data.

Title: Influence of partial slip and direction of traction on wear rate in wheel-rail contact
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the development and validation of new material models for use in the 'dynarat' model, a rail wear and crack initiation model developed at Newcastle, for simulating wear of new harder pearlitic rail steels. Samples of premium grade rail steels were provided by VoestAlpine and Tata Steel for testing and analysis. The paper presents a new method for simulating wheel-rail contact and derives a wear equation for standard rail steel track.

Title: Modelling rail steel microstructure and its effect on crack initiation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new microstructural model of rail steel for studying crack initiation and predicting rail life. The work was Project A2 in the EPSRC-funded Rail Research UK (RRUK) programme, and has been further developed as part of the EC funded project INNOTRACK (31415; Newcastle award £181k).

Title: Application of the structural articulation method to dynamic impact loading of railway bridges - a case study
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first application of a novel model of rail-bridge interaction, developed at Newcastle with sponsorship from Mott-MacDonald, allowing the interaction of different scales of irregularity in the rail with the response of the bridge structure to be evaluated for the first time, giving new insights into bridge design and maintenance.

Title: Three-dimensional modelling of rail steel microstructure and crack growth
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new approach to three dimensional modelling of crack initiation in a deforming microstructure. This work was Project A6 in the EPSRC-funded Rail Research UK 2 (RRUK2) programme (£220k). The model is verified with results from twin-disc tribological tests, and the paper offers new insights into the effect of large plastic deformations on early crack growth.

Title: Modeling composite high temperature behaviour and fire response under load
AdditionalInformation: This work reports and compares the high temperature behaviour and response under load in fire of two thermoset matrix composites and a thermoplastic matrix one. Properties are measured up to 400°C, well beyond the range previously reported. A combined material and thermal modelling approach was used to successfully predict the time to failure under a range of tensile and compressive loads in fire, extending the approach reported in 2010 [Gibson4] to consider thermoset as well as thermoplastic composites.

Title: Thermal-Mechanical Modelling of Laminates with Fire Protection Coating
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper, carried out in collaboration with colleagues at RMIT Australia, presents a new modelling approach to describe the thermal effects of the protection provided by two types of fire protection, namely passive and intumescent surface coatings, further extending the composites in fire models developed at Newcastle to consider fire protection coatings.  Thermal analysis of the coatings was combined with a thermal-chemical model for heat transfer through the fibreglass laminate substrate that lay beneath the fire protective coating, and the approach was used to successfully predict performance of the structures.

Title: Through-thickness elastic constants of composite laminates
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new and important composite laminate micromechanics model for deriving the elastic constants required for 3D modelling of a wide range of composite structures.  The model improves significantly on previous models in terms of the breadth of structures that it is applicable to and the accuracy with which through thickness properties can be derived.

Title: High temperature and fire behaviour of continuous glass fibre/polypropylene laminates
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to model the behaviour of a thermoplastic matrix composite material under load in fire. It was found that this thermoplastic matrix composite showed only a small reduction in failure time in fire, compared to conventional thermosetting matrix composites. Modelling of the fire response required a combined thermal and material modelling approach to be developed which successfully predicted the time to failure under different loads.

Title: Design and manufacture of injection mould tool inserts produced using indirect SLS and machining processes
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper was the first to show that new additive manufacturing techniques could be used in combination with high speed machining to create commercial quality tooling, with demonstrated use in three industrial trials. The paper also presents, for the first time for an additively manufactured tool, (i) durability data, and (ii) new insights on the effect of cooling channel placement on productivity and energy use.

Title: Laser sintering of blended Al-Si powders
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to study selective laser sintering of aluminium silicon alloys, and presents new insights on the combined effect of laser energy input, alloy formulation, and powder blend design in direct laser sintering of blended metal powders, by providing a detailed quantitative analysis of the relative importance of these factors to improve upon previous qualitative analyses.

Title: Simple parametric resonance in an electrostatically actuated microelectromechanical gyroscope: Theory and experiment
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper establishes the basis of parametric excitation in a MEMS sensor as a method of significantly enhancing the sensitivity of the sensor, a novel approach which has formed the basis of a significant body of research at Newcastle over the REF period.  The theoretical basis of the parametric excitation approach is established and experimentally validated.  The paper was awarded the 2008 “Water Arbitration Prize,” given by the IMechE Technical Strategy Board to the best original paper published by the Institution that year.

Title: The fabrication, characterization and testing of a MEMS circular diaphragm mass sensor
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel MEMS based biosensor design which is inherently temperature compensating, improving over alternative designs which must be explicitly compensated for temperature.  The sensor was manufactured and characterised to demonstrate temperature insensitivity and provide proof of concept.  The research was used as a key part of the case for support of the EC SmartHEALTH project (Smart Integrated Biodiagnostic Systems for Healthcare; 016817).

Title: Principles of a micro-rate integrating ring gyroscope
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the design of a novel MEMS rate integrating gyroscope, which avoids issues of noise and bias associated with “rate” gyroscopes. The potential performance envelope of the device taking into account fabrication tolerances is characterised.  The work reported in this paper has led to collaboration with UTC Aerospace Systems on defence applications for these type of gyroscopes (contact: Chris Gregory; Chris.Gregory@utas.utc.com), and will be continued through a new TSB project (Enhanced Gyro Control) led by UTC.

Title: A parametrically amplified MEMS Rate Gyroscope
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this paper was the first to apply parametric amplification to a commercial MEMS gyroscope, demonstrating that parametric amplification was a viable method of improving the performance of commercial devices.  This research led to Gallacher being invited to give a keynote presentation at the 9th International Conference on “Multibody Systems, Nonlinear Dynamics, and Control,” held as part of the ASME 2013 International Design Engineering Technical Conferences.

Title: An experimental study of high gain parametric amplification in MEMS
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents research on the practical optimisation of MEMS sensors operating with parametric amplification, with the underlying physics of parametric excitation analysed in detail in order that its effect can be exploited in micro-resonant sensor technologies.  Amplification of the dynamic response by two orders of magnitude is demonstrated practically.  Use of the dynamic properties of axisymmetric structures in sensing applications is being further researched within the EPSRC project “High Frequency Degenerate Mode Acoustic Sensors” (EP/K000349/1; £777k).

Title: Experimental investigation of parametric and externally forced motion in resonant MEMS sensors
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper builds on work published by the group in 2008 [Burdess1] which identified the potential value of parametric excitation of MEMS in improving sensor sensitivity.  This paper presents the first in depth experimental and theoretical study of parametric resonance and parametric amplification in electrostatic actuated MEMS, showing for the first time that the gain could be significantly increased (by an order of magnitude) with an appropriate parametric excitation scheme.

Title: Biomolecule Patterning on Analytical Devices: A Microfabrication-Compatible Approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel approach to the immoblisation of biomolecules onto biosensors, an approach which was patented by co-authors Suarez and McNeil (WO 2007007052 A2; US 20100285561 A1; Immobilisation of Biological Molecules).   The approach generates a thin (micrometer thick) porous structure on the surface which allows for penetration of biomolecules into the structure, and the paper demonstrates that this increases the level of biological activity. This research contributed significantly to the development of the case for support for the newly awarded £11M EPSRC Interdisciplinary Research Centre in Early-Warning Sensing Systems for Infectious Diseases (EP/K031953/1).

Title: Electronic Detection Strategies for a MEMS-Based Biosensor
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports on a novel electronic control strategy for a bioMEMS device, and demonstrates that the control strategy can be used to improve signal recovery to the stage where the sensor is commercially viable.  The research was a key part of the case for support in obtaining an EPSRC Nanotechnology Grand Challenge award (Detecting infectious organisms: a concerted approach using genomics, molecular engineering and nano-enabled bio-MEMS technologies, AptaMEMS-ID; EP/G061394/1; £1.8M).

Title: Issues associated with scaling up production of a lab demonstrated MEMS mass sensor
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this paper addresses scaling up production of a lab demonstrated bioMEMS device (reported on by the group in 2008 [Burdess2]) into a mass manufacturable biosensor aimed at commercialisation.  Using a new processing route over 5,000 devices were fabricated and tested for basic functionality, and over 50 had their frequency response characterised.  The devices showed excellent consistency with a relatively good yield for a first attempt at scale up, and the paper highlights how fundamental fabrication issues can be addressed whilst retaining performance.

Title: Dynamic characterization of MEMS using Raman spectroscopy
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel approach to characterising the motion of Raman active micro and nano mechanical vibratory structures, which, uniquely, has the capability of characterising in-plane motion without the requirement to map surface features. The work was performed as part of EPSRC project “Development of a Dynamic Micro Analysis Raman Spectroscopy (DyMARS) System for characterisation of MEMS and NEMS” (EP/C015045/1), and has led directly to further EPSRC support for the purchase of an ultra-high frequency laser vibrometer (two linked awards: EP/K022679/1 and EP/L001268/1), in order to continue to develop processes for leading edge MEMS and NEMS characterisation.

Title: The pizzicato knee-joint energy harvester: characterization with biomechanical data and the effect of backpack load
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds on previous work [Pozzi2] to present and characterise the world’s first wearable knee-joint piezoelectric energy harvester. The device was tested in a unique knee-joint simulator, driven by original kinematic data for a walking human carrying a range of backpack loads, and demonstrates that useful amounts of energy can be harvested.

Title: Plucked piezoelectric bimorphs for knee-joint energy harvesting: modelling and experimental validation
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to introduce plucking excitation as a way of designing highly efficient piezoelectric energy harvesters wearable by humans. Also for the first time, a coupled electro-mechanical FE model is developed for this type of excitation, and validated experimentally. The paper was selected as one of the Highlights of 2011 by the Smart Materials and Structures journal.

Title: X-ray enhanced sputter rates in argon cluster ion sputter-depth profiling of polymers
VolumeTitle: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B
AdditionalInformation: X-ray assisted cluster sputtering is a new effect, first reported and explained in this paper, and completely unexpected by the XPS community.  The effect must be controlled for accurate analysis with cluster ion beams.  US firm ThermoElectron, the largest XPS instrument manufacturer, has rewritten its main "Avantage" software and plans to reengineer hardware to cope with the effect (contact: Paul Mack; paul.mack@thermofisher.com).  The research reported in this paper supported the EPSRC proposal “National EPSRC Open-access Facility for Interface Engineering,” funded under the 2013 “Capital for Great Technologies” programme (administered as an additional £2.7M to the University equipment account, EP/K022679/1).

Title: A compact torsional reference device for easy, accurate and traceable AFM piconewton calibration
AdditionalInformation: Atomic Force Microscopy has been a key instrument in nanoscience for many years, but measuring pico or nanonewton forces (e.g. to compare the mechanics of individual molecules with theory) has been prone to errors. This paper presents the first, easy-to-use force calibration method traceable to the SI newton.  Traceability is essential to enable valid comparisons with theory.

Title: Accurate argon cluster-ion sputter yields: Measured yields and effect of the sputter threshold in practical depth-profiling by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and secondary ion mass spectrometry
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents and verifies the first analytical description of argon cluster-ion sputtering yields beyond empirical fits. It presents the first sufficiently sensitive weighing technology to accurately measure sputter yields, using the internationally leading facilities at the National EPSRC XPS Users' Service, a £3.1M EPSRC mid-range facility established at Newcastle in 2011.  All major XPS suppliers internationally have adopted gas-cluster technology, with strong uptake from customers (50% of new XPS orders to instrument manufacturer Kratos now specify this technology, contact: chris.blomfield@kratos.co.uk) and users will need this analytical description and reference data to plan and calibrate measurements.

Title: Stability of reference masses: VI. Mercury and carbonaceous contamination on platinum weights manufactured at a similar time as the international and national prototype kilograms
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents XPS evidence for mercury contamination of the primary kilogram and other reference masses.  The research shows a likely drift of 0.25 parts per million in the reference mass, which had previously been assumed to be correct to within a few parts per billion. The paper was the first to alert the international metrology community to issues with the storage of SI kilograms in the presence of mercury, and presents a new method to improve reference mass stability.

Title: A resorption cycle for the cogeneration of electricity and refrigeration
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel resorption cycle for the cogeneration of electricity and refrigeration using low grade heat, and demonstrates that the cycle can produce electric power and cooling together, with a higher efficiency than previously used technology (the Goswami cycle) under the same working conditions. The research was carried out as part of an EC FP7 Marie Curie Fellowship project (PIIF-GA-2009-253106 - Adsor-Resor Cycle - A new type adsorption-resorption cycle for the combined power generation and refrigeration driven by low grade heat, 2010-2011)

Title: A techno-economic assessment of biomass fuelled trigeneration system integrated with organic Rankine cycle
AdditionalInformation: The paper considers the Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) integrated with a conventional combustion process and waste heat recovery to provide electricity for commercial buildings. The paper presents an in depth analysis of the impact of different biomass feedstock on the performance of trigeneration plant, and an economic evaluation of the system is presented for a range of capital investment, plant load factors and fuel costs.  The work was carried out with Ulster University as part of the EPSRC funded BMT-CES: Biofuel Micro-Trigeneration with Cryogenic Energy Storage project (EP/F061978/1).

Title: Experimental study of the performance and emission characteristics of diesel engine using direct and indirect injection systems and different fuels
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents experimental research on biodiesel blends used as fuel for indirect injection and direct injection combustion system, and, uniquely at the time, reported the effect of biodiesel blends on both ICS and DCS engines.  The research showed that indirect injection can be used with biodiesel blends to significantly reduce NOx, CO, HC and smoke emissions, without modification.  The research was carried out as part of the EPSRC project BMT-CES: Biofuel Micro-Trigeneration with Cryogenic Energy Storage, EP/F061978/1 and subsequent ongoing collaboration with Guangxi University (Prof. Jin Cheng Huang hujch@126.com).

Title: The feasibility of the sustainable energy supply from bio wastes for a small brewery - A case study
AdditionalInformation: This study demonstrated how modelling tools can be used to develop practical new approaches to sustainable energy generation for commercial scale industrial processes in the food industry.  The research demonstrated how bio waste from a brewery, augmented by bio waste from nearby farms, could be used to create biogas to feed a boiler/engine CHP/trigeneration facility in order to generate sufficient electricity, heat and cooling for the production process.  The project was carried out as part of the EPSRC Thermal Management of Industrial Processes (EP/G056706/1) programme and the German postdoctoral programme (DAAD).

Title: A computational study of free-piston diesel engine combustion
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a computational analysis of a feature reported but not explained by numerous experimental studies on free-piston engines (FPEs), namely the influence of the piston motion on the in-cylinder processes. This research led to significant interaction with other international research groups, in particular collaboration, a joint FPE research laboratory and a funded PhD studentship (Boru Jia) with Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT) funded by the Chinese Government (Prof Huihua Feng: fenghh@bit.edu.cn).

Title: Croton megalocarpus oil-fired micro-trigeneration prototype for remote and self-contained applications: experimental assessment of its performance and gaseous and particulate emissions
AdditionalInformation: This paper, which was an invited theme paper by the Royal Society, presents the design and development of a trigeneration system specifically to use unprocessed plant oils. For the first time a detailed and comprehensive analysis of pure Croton megalocarpus properties and performance when used in a compression ignition engine was carried out. The research was funded by the EPSRC China-UK Programme and carried out as part of the BMT-CES: Biofuel Micro-Trigeneration with Cryogenic Energy Storage project (EP/F061978/1) which was coordinated by Roskilly.

Title: An experimental study of a direct injection compression ignition hydrogen engine
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a unique experimental comparison between conventional and direct injection in an engine system, and gives insight into the potential advantages of the new direct injection system. The research contributed to the award of a Leverhulme Trust Early Career Fellowship (Mikalsen – ECF/2009/0305) and a Carbon Connections UK Ltd project (Project 89 Bio-oil and Waste Hydrogen Dual Fuel CHP System). The research is being industrially exploited by TecnoVeritas  http://www.tecnoveritas.net/en/dualfuel-sb.php (Dr Jorge Antunes: info@tecnoveritas.net).

Title: Coupled dynamic-multidimensional modelling of free-piston engine combustion
AdditionalInformation: Due to the particular operating characteristics, conventional simulation methods for crankshaft-based engines are not fully suitable to predict free piston engine (FPE) performance. The research reported in this paper produced for the first time a coupled solver for FPE performance and operation. This revealed the influence of compression energy and ignition timing on the indicated efficiency, peak pressure and operational optimisation. The research contributed to the award of TSB funded project ‘Libertine FPE powertrain generator’ (TP 11623-73145) and the commercial development of the Libertine FPE Ltd. concept through modelling and simulation (Sam Cockerill: sam.cockerill@libertine.co.uk).

Title: Interactions between particles and quantized vortices in superfluid helium
AdditionalInformation: This work sets the theoretical basis for the implemention of PIV (Particle Image Velocimetry) and Particle Tracking experimental techniques in turbulent superfluid helium. The mechanism of interactions between tracer particles and quantized vortices, which is described in detail, advances understanding of superfluid turbulence and affects the interpretation of turbulence experiments performed by the PIV and Particle Tracking techniques. This work is being used by experimental groups in Florida (Prof. S. van Sciver, vnsciver@magnet.fsu.edu), Maryland (Prof. D.Lathrop, lathrop@umd.edu), and Prague (Prof. L.Skrbek, skrbek@fzu.cz).

Title: Quasiclassical and ultraquantum decay of superfluid turbulence
AdditionalInformation: The model of decay of superfluid turbulence developed in this work reproduces both the ultraquantum and quasiclassical regimes and gives a clear and unambiguous interpretation to recent experimental studies in the field carried out at Manchester (Walmsley and Golov, Phys. Rev. Lett. 100, 245301, 2008; contact: Professor Andrei Golov, andrei.golov@manchester.ac.uk) and Lancaster (Bradley et al., Nature Physics 7, 433, 2011; contact: Dr. D.I.Bradley, d.i.bradley@lancaster.ac.uk) Universities.

Title: Saturation of decaying counterflow turbulence in helium II
VolumeTitle: Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
AdditionalInformation: This work, resulting from international collaboration between theoretical groups at Newcastle and Palermo and the experimental group in Prague, resolves a decade-old contradiction between experiments on the decay of superfluid thermal counterflow turbulence. The physical origins of two different decay regimes, of the transition between them, and of saturation of decaying turbulent counterflow are explained for the first time. Quantitative predictions of the saturation time are made which enabled us to give a clear interpretation to decaying counterflow experiments.

Title: Interaction of ballistic quasiparticles and vortex configurations in superfluid 3He-B
AdditionalInformation: Theoretical and numerical analysis is developed of interactions between thermal excitations and turbulent vortex structures in superfluid 3He-B. A new effect of partial screening is discovered which may lead to re-interpretation of Andreev scattering experiments used for detection of turbulent structures in superfluids (such experiments are currently being carried out at Lancaster University (Prof. S.N. Fisher, s.fisher@lancaster.ac.uk), and Aalto University in Helsinki (Prof. M. Krusius, mkrusius@neuro.hut.fi)). This research presented in this publication led to a Leverhulme Trust Grant (Visualization of Quantum Turbulence; F/00125/AH; £121k).

Title: Drift-free kinetic equations for turbulent dispersion
AdditionalInformation: This paper solves a long-standing, fundamental problem in the correct formulation of turbulent dispersion models. The work presented in this paper identifies important, previously unrecognized, differences between contending models and showed that the approach developed at Newcastle provides the most consistent framework in which such models can be developed. Subtle errors inherent in other models are shown to lead to physically unrealistic predictions for dispersion in inhomogeneous flow that seriously compromise the applicability of these alternative formulations.

Title: Particle transport in a turbulent boundary layer: Non-local closures for particle dispersion tensors accounting for particle-wall interactions
AdditionalInformation: Involving collaboration with the Norwegian Institute for Energy Technology, and funded by the Multiphase Flow Assurance Center (FACE) (contact: Kristian Sveen jks@ife.no, http://www.sintef.no/sfiface), this work was the first to develop and test non-local closure models associated with particle transport in turbulent boundary layers. Follow-up work, aimed at implementing such developments within computational tools for nuclear accident safety case studies is now supported by the European Severe Accident Research Network programme SARNET2 (www.sar net.eu/node/4).

Title: Stochastic transport of particles in straining flows
AdditionalInformation: Concerned with aerosol segregation and agglomeration, this paper was the first to demonstrate the necessity and sufficiency of Brownian forcing to offset unbounded accumulation of particles along stagnation lines characteristic of high-strain regions in turbulent flow. The analysis identified important issues in the formulation of models for particle transport in counter-flows, demonstrating serious inadequacies in conventional closure models and throwing down a challenge to improve on the current state of the art. Follow-up work, aimed at addressing issues identified in the paper, is funded by the EPSRC (Computational Modelling for Advanced Nuclear Power Plants, EP/I003010/1; £236k).

Title: Hermite-DG methods for pdf equations modelling particle transport and deposition in turbulent boundary layers
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a major advance in the computational study of particle transport in turbulent flow. Innovative models and equally novel numerical schemes enable, for the first time, the direct computation (to high-order accuracy) of particle-fluid phase-space distributions in boundary layers. The resolution and efficiency afforded by the approach allows detailed analysis of velocity correlations and distributions, and has identified distributional features previously unobserved. A database developed from the work and made available to other researchers formed an essential part of their independent study (work by Lad and Issa at Imperial College, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijmultiphaseflow.2011.10.002).

Title: Novel methods for preparing phospholipid coated microbubbles
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents two new processes for producing microbubbles. The resulting bubbles are highly monodisperse in size, making them suitable for the drug delivery. The work led to patent application (PCT/GB2008/001050), and the processes have been adopted by other groups nationally and internationally (e.g. Cui & Campbell in Dundee, doi: 10.1109/ULTSYM.2008.0406; Filho et. al. in Brazil, doi:10.1186/1475-925X-11-71).

Title: Dynamics of Bubble Formation in Highly Viscous Liquids
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports research which significantly extended the range of fluids which could be used to produce microbubbles through demonstrating that fluids with viscosities over 480 mPas could be used to produce microbubbles. This significantly improved on previous work where the upper limit was 100 mPas (e.g Garstecki, P. et al Lab on A Chip, 2006, 6(3), 437-446). The research was a key part of the case for support for the EPSRC project “Photo-catalytic microbubble reactor for conversion of CO2 to Fuels” (EP/J02161X/1; £100k).

Title: Statistical properties of particle segregation in homogeneous isotropic turbulence
AdditionalInformation: The research in this paper builds on the work reported in 2010 [Reeks2] to investigate in detail the statistics of particle compressibility (as a measure of segregation) through direct numerical simulation of isotropic turbulence and make an important connection with the formation of caustics, the occurrence of singularities in the particle concentration and random uncorrelated motion. In particular the conditions at which the rate of production of singularities is maximum (an important mechanism in droplet coalescence) are defined for the first time.

Title: Segregation of particles in incompressible random flows: singularities, intermittency and random uncorrelated motion
AdditionalInformation: The paper develops and applies a powerful analytical technique for studying particle segregation in turbulent flows which has revealed hitherto unrecognized features that are very important in mixing and collision processes of particles in turbulent flows. It also shows that segregation is not a stationary process as had been assumed in previous studies. The work has implications for a whole range of industrial mixing processes and the enhancement of collision processes in clouds and the onset of rain. The work was carried out as part of the EPSRC progamme “Droplet Clouds in a Box of Turbulence” (EP/E029973/1; £194k).

Title: A Lagrangian approach to droplet condensation in atmospheric clouds
AdditionalInformation: A solution is given to a long standing problem in cloud physics, namely the origin of the broad size distribution of cloud droplets. This is shown to be due to the combined effect of dispersion of large and small scale turbulent structures. A novel method for tracking individual droplets is employed and kinematic simulation is used to overcome the problem of dealing with the large range of scales of motion in clouds.  The work in this paper led to Reeks being invited to give the 2009 Knox Millsaps Lecture at the University of Florida (contact:  Prof James Klausner, klaus@ufl.edu).

Title: Agglomeration of inertial particles in a random rotating symmetric straining flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a model based on a symmetric rate of strain flow field which reproduces all the features of particle segregation observed in direct numerical simulation of turbulent flows. It highlights deficiencies in the standard model for turbulent agglomeration and demonstrates the influence of turbo-phoretic drift (not recognised in previous simulations). The model forms the basis of a model of both agglomeration and breakup of aerosol particles. The work was funded by the Paul Scherrer Institute in Switzerland as part of the international COST share project ARTIST (Aerosol Retention in a Steam Generator, contact: Dr Abdel Dehbi, abdel.dehbi@psi.ch).

Title: Direct Numerical Simulation analysis of the Flame Surface Density transport equation in the context of Large Eddy Simulation
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study in which a Flame Surface Density (FSD) based reaction rate closure in the context of Large Eddy Simulations has been proposed to ensure that the models for all the unclosed terms in the FSD transport equation can be applied to different regimes of turbulent premixed combustion. The research reported in this paper played a pivotal role in the Case for Support of an EPSRC research grant EP/G008841 (Development of Unified Flame Surface Density Based Reaction Rate Models for the LES of Turbulent Premixed Flames; £188k), where ideas developed in this paper have been explored further.

Title: Scalar Dissipation Rate Modeling and its Validation
AdditionalInformation: This paper discusses the development of novel algebraic closures for the scalar dissipation rate (SDR) and turbulent flame speed in the context of Reynolds Averaged Navier Stokes simulations, which are of pivotal importance in the analysis and modelling of premixed combustion. The flame speed model proposed in this paper predicts experimental data under a large range of configurations. These findings have contributed significantly to the Case for Support of the EPSRC research grant EP/I028013/1 (Development of scalar dissipation rate based reaction rate models for the large eddy simulations of premixed flames; £158k).

Title: Direct Numerical Simulations of turbulent flame expansion in fine sprays
AdditionalInformation: The effects of droplet size, global equivalence ratio and the level of turbulent velocity fluctuation on the localised forced ignition of droplet-laden mixtures have been analysed for the first time using Direct Numerical Simulation. The results have significant importance for internal combustion engines and high altitude relight of aero gas turbines and played a key role in the Case for Support of the EPSRC research grant EP/J0/21997 (Fundamental understanding of turbulent flame propagation in droplet-laden mixtures; £266k). The research reported in this paper received the 2009 Distinguished Paper Award from International Combustion Institute.

Title: Effects of Lewis number on the reactive scalar gradient alignment with local strain rate in turbulent premixed flames
AdditionalInformation: The influences of Lewis number  on the scalar gradient alignment with local principal strain rates in turbulent premixed flames have been demonstrated and explained for the first time in this paper. This development plays a pivotal role in the modelling of hydrogen/hydrogen-blended combustion, which is expected to play a key role as an alternative fuel in automotive and aeronautical applications in the future.

Title: Effect of Spark Timing and Load on a DISI Engine fuelled with 2,5-Dimethylfuran
AdditionalInformation: The research reported in this paper builds on work reported in 2010 [Tian2] with 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), to move from a model experimental system to full scale engine tests. This was the first paper to thoroughly investigate the performance of DMF in a state of the art direct injection gasoline engine, and compared the performance with that of gasoline and ethanol. This research revealed that DMF has a similar engine performance to gasoline, indicating that it could be used as an alternative fuel for gasoline, without the need for a major engine modification.

Title: Laminar Burning Velocities of 2,5-Dimethylfuran Compared with Ethanol and Gasoline
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first in-depth assessment of the laminar burning velocity of 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), a novel bio-based gasoline alternative fuel. The research extensively tested the laminar flame burning velocity and combustion stability of DMF at various equivalence ratios and background temperatures, in comparison with gasoline and ethanol (currently the most widely used gasoline alternative fuel), demonstrated the viability of DMF as a gasoline alternative, and additionally presented fundamental combustion data to enable accurate calibration of numerical models (e.g. Somers et al, Combustion and Flame, 2013, 160, 2291-2318; Mehl et al, Energy Fuels, 2011, 25, 5215-5223).

Title: Dual-injection: The flexible, bi-fuel concept for spark-ignition engines fuelled with various gasoline and biofuel blends
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel bi-fuel technology for spark ignition combustion engines to allow for flexible utilisation of a primary fuel (gasoline) and a secondary fuel (ethanol) with any blending ratios. The potential of port fuel injection for the primary fuel and direct injection for the secondary fuel was investigated for the first time. A detailed experimental programme showed that this bi-fuel concept allowed precise control of the engine with improved control flexibility, and suggested optimum control in different conditions.

Title: On the drag of turbulent vortex rings
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows, for the first time, that the two theories on the evolution of turbulent vortex rings are approximately consistent for the early development of the rings. The evidence is provided by a rigorous experiment and in a novel approach which directly addresses the conflict between the two theories.

Title: Granular pressure in a liquid-fluidized bed as revealed by diffusing wave spectroscopy
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents one of the first measurements of granular pressure and temperature in a fluidised bed using diffusing wave spectroscopy, and in particular reports the first localised measurement of the pressure variation with height above the distributor.  Diffusing wave spectroscopy is an optical, non-intrusive measurement technique which is capable of measuring the behaviour of smaller and lighter particles than other techniques.  To validate the technique the measurements are compared with previous experimental studies, and the measurements are also used to identify areas for improvement in models of granular flow.

Title: Effect of geometrical parameters on fluid mixing in novel mesoscale oscillatory helical baffled designs
AdditionalInformation: This paper extends previous work by the group [Harvey1] to present the first study of the influence of the geometry of a range of helical baffles on mixing within mesoscale oscillatory baffle reactors.  The helical baffles are demonstrated to have a range of advantages over conventional baffle designs, and in particular exhibited a higher degree of plug flow over a wider range of operating conditions.  The paper also defines for the first time the experimental relationship between the degree of plug flow and the ratio of oscillatory flow amplitude to the helical pitch.

Title: Effect of bed depth on characterisation of slow pyrolysis products
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first in-depth analysis of the effects of bed depth and temperature on the yield and properties of char, liquid and gas products from slow pyrolysis of segregated municipal solid waste.  The paper showed for the first time that with an increased bed depth the char acted as a catalyst for cracking and re-polymerisation of heavy molecular compounds in the liquid phase, increasing significantly the concentration of CO in the gas phase, without increasing the yield of char.

Title: Biodiesel production from waste cooking oils
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents one of the first practical studies of the use of waste cooking oils for biodiesel, going beyond simply studying the biodiesel production process to also consider in detail the characteristics of the biodiesel as a fuel. The study showed the key importance of carbon residue and the distillation curve as the two most significant characteristics which limit the volume of biodiesel from waste cooking oil which can be blended with diesel to make fuel which conforms to retail standards for unmodified diesel engines.

Title: An integrated approach to energy and chemicals production
AdditionalInformation: In this work we show for the first time how a membrane-based oxyfuel process can be integrated with carbon dioxide utilisation chemistry. Carbon dioxide is captured in the membrane system and fed to an epoxidation reactor where it reacts with an epoxide to form a cyclic carbonate in an exothermic reaction. This work has been highlighted in 'Highlights in Chemical Technology', http://www.rsc.org/Publishing/ChemTech/Volume/2010/02/minimise_co2.asp (accessed 25 July 2011).

Title: La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3−δ microtubular membranes for hydrogen production from water splitting
AdditionalInformation: For the first time the role of oxygen permeation has been unequivocally demonstrated in membrane-based steam reforming of methane.  This process produces a syngas stream as well as a stream of pure hydrogen and is consequently of significant industrial interest.  This study stands out for the level of detail in terms of closure of material balances and proof of the role of permeation.

Title: A chemical looping process for hydrogen production using iron-containing perovskites
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows for the first time that chemical looping hydrogen production can be performed for more than 100 cycles in a stable manner (increased cyclability is a necessary condition of commercialisation). This was achieved by innovative materials choice. Rather than use iron oxide, which would undergo phase changes and lose structural integrity, an iron-containg perovskite was employed. The function of this material was predicted using a thermodynamic approach and good agreement in actual tests was observed.

Title: Controlled spillover in a single catalyst pellet: Rate modification, mechanism and relationship with electrochemical promotion
AdditionalInformation: This work shows for the first time that the catalytic activity of what is essentially a catalyst pellet (platinum supported on a perovskite oxide) can be controlled by manipulation of the oxygen chemical potential difference across the membrane. This important result means that catalytic mechanisms in supported catalyst systems need to be revisited, and offers the opportunity to exploit this mechanism for in-situ catalyst activity control.

Title: Online conductivity measurement of residence time distribution of thin film flow in the spinning disc reactor
AdditionalInformation: This is the very first paper to report on quantitative macromixing characterisation of fluid in a spinning disc reactor (SDR), conclusively establishing for the very first time the operating conditions for plug-flow behaviour. These results will be instrumental in modelling of reactions in the SDR flow field, to be undertaken to evaluate process intensification in early stage processes, a 3-year collaborative project between - Newcastle University and ICES, Singapore, recently awarded by GSK and the Economic Development Board (EDB) in Singapore, under the Green and Sustainable Manufacturing (GSM) programme (http://www.ace.gsk.com/GSM/Home.aspx)

Title: Micromixing characteristics in a small-scale spinning disk reactor
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to report on a fundamental quantitative study into the micromixing of thin film flow on a rotating disc. Prior to this work, we could only speculate about the improved micromixing intensity to explain the enhancements in reaction rates and selectivities observed in many industrially relevant processes but this comprehensive study now provides solid evidence for our hypothesis.

Title: Thermographic analysis of thin liquid flims on a rotating disc: approach and challenges
AdditionalInformation: No other paper exists in the peer-reviewed published literature which highlights the use of infrared imaging techniques for thin film flow temperature measurements in a spinning disc reactor. It is very challenging in practice to measure the temperature of extremely thin films without disrupting the flow field. This work thus represents a significant advancement in thin film flow characterisation using a non-invasive measurement technique.

Title: Intensification of gas-liquid mass transfer using a rotating bed of porous packings for application to an E. coli batch fermentation process
