AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to present a comprehensive mass transfer characterisation of porous mesh impellers in rotating bed reactors, and demonstrated both that a knitted wire mesh gave significantly better mass transfer performance than other designs over a wide range of viscosities, and that the improved mass transfer could be exploited for bioprocess intensification.  The research was used in the development of a high gravity bioreactor for the production of biopolymers as part of the EC funded project Bioproduction (Sustainable Microbial and Biocatalytic Production of Advanced Functional Materials; 26515).

Title: Development and evaluation of novel designs of continuous mesoscale oscillatory baffled reactors
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first systematic description of a range of new designs of oscillatory baffled mesoreactor. The designs were periodic smooth constrictions, with periodic hexagonal nuts on a central thread and a continuous helical baffle. All designs were shown to exhibit excellent control of processing time (narrow residence time distribution), and all are simple and easy-to-fabricate. The helically baffled reactor exhibited a high degree of plug flow over an operating window one order of magnitude broader than any design investigated before. The research was carried out as part of EPSRC project “Evolvable Process Design” (EP/F016999/1; £329k).

Title: Simultaneous Conversion of Triglyceride/Free Fatty Acid Mixtures into Biodiesel using Sulfated Zirconia
AdditionalInformation: This is the first description of the use of sulphated zirconia as a catalyst for simultaneous esterification of free fatty acids and triglycerides. "Direct synthesis" of the catalyst by heating mixtures of components is shown to be more effective than the more conventional "wet" technique. This means that a catalyst-free biodiesel production process based on low value (high free fatty acid) waste oil feedstocks is feasible. The free fatty acids would become beneficial rather than problematic. The research was carried out as part of the EPSRC project “Designer Catalysts for High Efficiency Biodiesel Production” (EP/F067372/1).

Title: Heterogeneous catalysis in an oscillatory baffled flow reactor
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes, for the first time, screening of a solid-catalysed liquid-liquid reaction in a mesoscale oscillatory baffled reactor, demonstrating one of the key advantages of this flow screening platform over conventional designs: it can easily accommodate various combinations of phases, including solids (which are extremely difficult to accommodate in conventional microchannel screening devices).  A reactor has been sold to Fujifilm Imaging Colourants, Grangemouth (contact: Doug Spencer  Doug.Spencer@fujifilmic.com) for process screening, and further commercial exploitation is being explored.

Title: Influence of various parameters on reactive extraction of Jatropha curcas L. for biodiesel production
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first systematic study of reactive extraction of jatropha for biodiesel production, and identifies optimal conditions for the process.  Jatropha is of interest worldwide as a promising biofuel crop, as it is high-yielding and can grow on relatively low quality land. Reactive extraction can produce biodiesel without the need for crushing and solvent extraction. This removes the need for hexane, which makes the process greener and applicable to small-scale on-farm distributed production.  This work was part of a UKIERI-funded collaboration with the Indian Institute of Petroleum (“Direct Production of Biodiesel from Non-edible Oilseeds” UKIERI SA07-0094).

Title: Continuous screening of base-catalysed biodiesel production using New designs of mesoscale oscillatory baffled reactors
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents and validates a new design of plug flow reactor for continuous, dynamic, mesoscale screening of two phase liquid systems at very low flow rates.  A high degree of plug flow is demonstrated experimentally via continuous steady state and dynamic screening.  The reactor produces repeatable results with significantly reduced volumes of reagents required and waste generated, and with operating times reduced by up to 90%, demonstrating the value of the reactor in screening and optimisation.

Title: The effect of component size and orientation on the concentrations of metal ions after resurfacing arthroplasty of the hip
VolumeTitle: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery: British Volume
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to highlight problems with a particular design of metal-on-metal hip joint, the DePuy Articular Surface Replacement (ASR), and to propose that wear was the cause, as indicated by metal ion levels in blood. In August 2010 the ASR was withdrawn worldwide by DePuy, at which point almost 100,000 had been implanted, and current revision rates are an unprecedented 44%.

Title: Blood metal ion concentrations after hip resurfacing arthroplasty: A comparative study of articular surface replacement and Birmingham hip resurfacing arthroplasties
VolumeTitle: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery: British Volume
AdditionalInformation: This paper extended work from 2008 [Joyce1], which indicated increased wear of the DePuy ASR hip resurfacing, to compare the performance of the ASR against another commonly used device, the Birmingham Hip Resurfacing implant. The results showed the ASR to be more sensitive to placement in terms of its performance, which was explained through a new concept, the Contact Patch to Rim (CPR) distance, which has subsequently become widely adopted (e.g. Underwood et al, 2012, J Eng Med, 217-26; Amstutz et al, 2012, DOI 10.1007/s11999-012-2347-y).

Title: Early failure of metal-on-metal bearings in hip resurfacing and large-diameter total hip replacement: A consequence of excess wear
VolumeTitle: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery: British Volume
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated conclusively that blood metal ion levels correlated to wear volume in metal-on-metal hip resurfacings, making it clear that the relatively poor performance of the Depuy ASR hip was wear related.  The research reported in this paper was included within the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Executive Summary Memorandum, a review of the safety of metal-on-metal hip implant systems published in June 2012, and has led to a new award from the FDA (ref. 1119680) to assess and report on ex vivo failed metal-on-metal hip replacements.

Title: Adverse reaction to metal debris following hip resurfacing: The influence of component type, orientation and volumetric wear
VolumeTitle: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery: British Volume
AdditionalInformation: This paper extended research from 2010 [Joyce3] to consider the performance of metal-on-metal hip resurfacings through a two country, three centre study, which generated the largest data set (outwith a national register) reported. The study confirmed that the mechanism of failure observed previously in one centre was consistent across all three centres.

Title: Surface functionalization of 3D glass–ceramic porous scaffolds for enhanced mineralization in vitro
AdditionalInformation: The paper applies, for the first time, enzymatic surface functionalization to macroporous glass-ceramic scaffolds, and demonstrates in vitro that this has a positive effect on mineralisation. This work will be further applied to development of tissue engineering substrates through ongoing research projects: the £5.5M Arthritis Research UK Tissue Engineering Centre (Arthritis Research UK Award 19429' Newcastke award £950k), and the €4M RESTORATION FP7 project (280575; Newcastle award €700k).

Title: In vitro biocompatibility of 45S5 Bioglass®-derived glass-ceramic scaffolds coated with poly(3-hydroxybutyrate)
VolumeTitle: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
AdditionalInformation: In this research a novel biodegradable polymeric coating derived from bacteria was used for the first time to improve the mechanical and biological properties of highly porous ceramic structure. The biodegradable polymeric coating was isolated from Bacillus cereus SPV by a fermentation process, and has potential as an osteoconductive tissue engineering substrate bone tissue.

Title: Magnetotransport properties of a percolating network of magnetite crystals embedded in a glass-ceramic matrix
AdditionalInformation: In this paper, the electrical transport and magnetoresistance of a series of novel magnetic glass-ceramics (which have potential for use in hyperthermic treatment of cancer) were studied for the first time and a new theory describing the magnetotransport phenomena was proposed. Although bulk magnetite is one of the oldest and most studied magnetic materials, the paper shows that its magnetic and electrical properties are completely different from those of magnetite crystals embedded in a glass-ceramic matrix. The paper demonstrates the importance of microstructure, sample preparation and post processing on the electrical and magnetic properties of these materials.

Title: Sintering and crystallisation of 45S5 Bioglass® powder
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to investigate the sintering and crystallisation of Bioglass® using heating microscopy, providing new insights into the processing behaviour of this important biomaterial. The work was carried out as part of a FP6 Marie-Curie Intra European Fellowship held by Dr Bretcanu (24248).

Title: In vitro method to characterize diffusion of dye from polymeric particles: A model for drug release
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents and validates a new model of drug release from particles which holds valid from 400 nm to 9 µm particle sizes, a range which previous models had not managed to encompass. The new model also offers improved understanding of drug diffusion from nano-particles, a key need for the development of drug release systems.

Title: Generation of microbubbles for diagnostic and therapeutic applications using a novel device
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the design, manufacture and characterisation of a novel device which extends the processing window for the creation of microbubbles, allowing smaller microbubbles, which are the most useful in therapeutic applications, to be created from large capillaries with excellent consistency of output.

Title: Mass Customization of Foot Orthoses for Rheumatoid Arthritis Using Selective Laser Sintering
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to present the development and evaluation in a patient trial of foot orthoses made using an additive manufacturing technique. The design and manufacture processes described in this paper have been further developed through the €3.4M EC FP7 Project a-footprint (Ankle and Foot Orthotic Personalisation via Rapid Manufacturing; 228893; Newcastle funding €364k). The research described in the paper was a key part of the case for support. The first author (Pallari) has subsequently moved to join Peacocks Medical Group in the UK, where he is leading development of new products based on the technology (contact: Jari.Pallari@Peacocks.net).

Title: Indirect selective laser sintering of apatite-wollostonite glass-ceramic
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new manufacturing route for porous bioceramic structures, which is being further developed in two subsequent major collaborative research projects: the £5M Arthritis Research UK Tissue Engineering Centre (Award 19429; Newcastle funding £950k), and the €4M EC FP7 Collaborative Project Restoration (Resorbable Ceramic Biocomposites for Orthopaedic and Maxillofacial Applications; 280575; co-ordinated by Dalgarno; Newcastle funding €700k). In both cases the research reported in this paper was used as a key element of the case for support.

Title: Frequency response of underwater ultrasonic transducers in the near field using polarimetric polarization maintaining fiber sensors</title>
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of SPIE the International Society for Optical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel application of optical fibre sensor by monitoring the output of ultrasonic transducers arrays. The work described in this paper, funded by EPSRC, has the potential to improve the performance of ultrasonic transducer arrays and extend their lifetime.

Title: Directly Modulated Wavelength-Multiplexed Integrated Microring Laser Array
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides unique empirical evidence about directly modulated microring laser array. This has the potential of building large scale, high density photonic circuits reducing both cost and power consumption. The work described in this paper was the culmination of FP7-funded multidisciplinary projects (‘WAPITI’ & ‘BONE’), and EPSRC aimed to build future optical network device using vertical integration technology.

Title: Ultracompact microring laser-based optical-add multiplexer
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first report of a microring optical-add multiplexer paving the way for photonic integrated circuits. The device has been tested at a modulation speed of 2.5 Gbit/s over 25 km fibre link. The work described in this paper was the culmination of an FP7-funded multidisciplinary project (‘WAPITI’), working towards new accurate coupling technology for optical microrings (a fabrication technique that has long frustrated the development of this class of devices).

Title: Link-Lock: an explanation of the chemical stabilisation of collagen
AdditionalInformation: This paper challenges the presumed notion of crosslinking as the primary mechanism of collagen stabilisation by chemical modification, applied in the processes of tanning of leather: the theory is backed up by observed results and logical argument. For the first time, all tanning reactions are explained: the idea can be used to develop new thinking, in terms of new commercial reagents for the market and new ways to use current products.  This approach to tanning chemistry has been taken on board by researchers in the field and by the supply houses: of the latter, Lanxess of Germany, through Dr. Dietrich Tegtmeyer, and Buckman of USA, through Elton Hurlow, have begun to rethink their chemical strategies for the development of the next generation of tanning products using link-lock theory.

Title: Diagnosing post-mortem treatments which inhibit DNA amplification from US MIAs buried at the Punchbowl.
AdditionalInformation: This paper illustrates a spin off which can come from experience in a technology, with an understanding of the underpinning science. From a familiarity of the effects of reagents capable of stabilising protein, knowing the outcome of those reactions and how they are characterised in analytical techniques, light can be shed on a problem outside the original technology. This can have wider application in the field of forensic science.

Title: Prediction in Leather Processing: A Dark Art or a Clear Possibility? Procter Memorial Lecture.
VolumeTitle: The Society of Leather Technologists and Chemists Journal
AdditionalInformation: Developments in the leather industry have been hampered over that last half century by the lack of input from scientists: although there had been progress from gifted technologists and the supply houses, there has been no firm basis upon which leather technologists can conduct trials in the confident knowledge of the outcome. This paper is the first attempt to bring together the author’s thinking about leather science, with a view to providing the leather industry with guidelines as to the outcome of reactions in which chemical species modify the properties of collagen and, importantly, the effects of combinations of reactions. Furthermore, for the first time, the model allows the industry to begin to predict processes to make leather with desired properties and performance.   This also has application in the wider field of proteinaceous biomaterials.

Title: The mechanism of chrome tanning.
AdditionalInformation: Since the introduction of chromium(III) tanning at least 100 years ago, perhaps 90% of the world’s production has been based on that chemistry.  During that time, most of the aspects of the reaction have been misunderstood or even wrongly assumed and accepted. This paper addresses all the wrong thinking and sets out the arguments for what is true.  Using information from the literature and applying modern analytical techniques, the principles of the tanning reaction with chromium(III) salts are presented in a way that allows the industry to review their processes.  In this way, operations can be made more effective, economic and with minimum adverse ecological impact.

Title: The nonstationary, nonlinear dynamic interactions in slender continua deployed in high-rise vertical transportation systems in the modern built environment
AdditionalInformation: The findings of this work provide an in-depth explanation of the mechanism of transient nonlinear interactions taking place in long low tension slender continua deployed and moving at speed in high-rise vertical transportation systems. The work informed the development of an active control algorithm to suppress vibrations of elevator cables in high-rise, high-speed applications commissioned by a leading international elevator company and the concept was awarded an international patent.

Title: The dynamic behaviour of a non-stationary elevator compensating rope system under harmonic and stochastic excitations
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with a challenging nonstationary deterministic and stochastic dynamic problem to predict transient resonance responses of moving elastic cables in an elevator system. The deterministic solution is found and then a novel stochastic model is developed. The work received recognition from the elevator industry and resulted in a number of commercial research contracts awarded to the University. The work reported in the paper informed the design of high-rise high-speed elevator systems worldwide.

Title: Use of electrochemical methods to examine different surface preparation methods for organic coatings on steel
AdditionalInformation: This paper inspired the main topic of Dr Sina Jamali’s PhD work at the University of Northampton. It has been cited 3 times (source Google Scholar). The paper shows that water-jetting is an excellent surface preparation method. The methodology presented in the paper has won recognition from a number of commercial national and international companies (Pronto Paints, Polmor Engineering, Bearward Engineering, Cummins Engines). The work challenges the traditional steel preparation method and provides hard evidence for the new environmentally friendly technique to be even more effective.

Title: Investigation into the effect of nano-silica on the protective properties of polyurethane coatings
AdditionalInformation: A previous form (but in all essentials the same) of this paper (published as part of EuroCorr 2011 conference proceedings) was requested to be republished (the only paper so chosen from some two hundred delivered at the conference) in the Journal of The Australasian Corrosion Association. It appeared in the May 2012 issue of that Journal. The paper will also be summarised as part of a book on “nanotechnology applied to coatings” being edited by Dr Andrzej Miszczyk at the Technical University of Gdansk. It is relatively recently been published but has already collected a number of citations (source Google Scholar).

Title: Development of an image analysis technique for measurement of Poisson’s ratio for viscoelastic materials: application to leather
AdditionalInformation: Although leather has been used for centuries because of its unique properties, unusually the physical properties that are normally associated with materials have not been explicitly defined. This paper describes how a tensile tester, a high speed camera and image processing software have been able to measure the Poisson’s ratio of leather, with surprising results.

Title: Relaying scene information to the blind via sound using cartoon depth maps
AdditionalInformation: Scene information may be relayed to a blind person via mobility aids that incorporate an image-to-sound mapping. Stereo depth maps are considered as a means of reducing the quantity of unnecessary information passed to the listener. The paper describes how a stereo edge depth map can be combined with a cartoon-like scene representation to reduce the data. Experimental results are included that demonstrate the effectiveness of this representation. Since publication, the method has been incorporated into a device called the vOICe created by Peter Meijer (http://www.seeingwithsound.com/).

Title: Application of neural-fuzzy controller for streaming video over Bluetooth 1.2
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows how AI can be applied in MPEG-4 video compression over Bluetooth in order to improve picture quality. A new buffer has been introduced at the input of the Bluetooth device which is controlled by a Rule-Based Fuzzy logic controller at the input and a neural-fuzzy controller at the output. The computer simulation results show that the proposed design improves the image quality, reduces data loss and reduces time delay, thus opening up the possibilities of transmitting moving pictures over Bluetooth.

Title: A dynamic stiffness element for free vibration analysis of composite beams and its application to aircraft wings
AdditionalInformation: The powerful and elegant dynamic stiffness method is developed for composite beams exhibiting geometric and material coupling between bending and torsional motions. The theory developed paves the way for modal analysis of high aspect ratio composite wings and provides prospects for aeroelastic studies to achieve desirable objectives when designing a composite wing.

Title: Use of computer algebra in Hamiltonian calculations
AdditionalInformation: The novel computer program developed provides an automation formulation based on Hamilton’s principle leading to the governing partial differential equations of motion and the natural boundary conditions of beam structures as the free vibration of complex elatodynamic systems. This significant implementation of the integration procedure benefitted from symbolic computation has been solved for the first time for a long time to reduce the human cost. It establishes how computer algebra can form part of the standard armoury of aeronautical structural engineers and surely of many other fields.

Title: Influence of Al on strength and impact behaviour of hot rolled plain C–Mn steels
AdditionalInformation: The influence of Al on the strength and impact properties of hot rolled plain C-Mn steels has been examined to establish the cause of the good impact behaviour. It provides the useful suggestion for future work to Nb to these steels to raise the strength level.

Title: Al as solid solution hardener in steels
AdditionalInformation: The examination of the Al influence on the strength of ferrite is benchmark for the research because an understanding of the role Al in influencing strength has become of importance in recent years.

Title: A model of friction for a pin-on-disc configuration with imposed pin rotation
AdditionalInformation: This research paper explains a new probabilistic model for adhesive wear under pin on disc configuration. The aim of the paper is to predict in real time the progress of adhesive wear. This concept was developing with the aim to characterize the performance of ferrous debris density and particle counter sensors. The foundation of this enhanced probabilistic model was based on the work introduced by Prof Tadeusz Stolarski (Brunel University). This model was recognised by some Tribology groups within UK.

Title: Influence of crosslinkers and crosslinking method on the properties of gelatin films extracted from leather solid waste
AdditionalInformation: The paper investigates the importance of the method and crosslinking agent applied to proteins in the application of surface coatings to leather. The research carried out was the culmination of an EU-funded multidisciplinary project, FP5 called RESTORM, at the time, one of the five largest EU projects. The research was presented at European and international conferences, viewed and cited on numerous occasions, this has lead to the development of other research projects such as the utilisation of keratin from tannery hair waste as a nitrogen source in fertilisers, as well as surface coatings for leather as a protein binding agent.

Title: Parameters for Composting Tannery Hair Waste
VolumeTitle: Journal of American Leather Chemists Association
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides important information on parameters, gathered through intensive studies, required for treating and degrading hair in composters with the ultimate aim of producing a source of nitrogen to be used in products such as fertilisers. The research was the culmination of SITA funding leading towards the development of protocols for the sustainable management of tannery hair waste. The paper was presented at national and international conferences, cited, viewed 41 and downloaded 21 times, in the past 4 months (ResearchGate) suggesting worldwide interest in the outcomes of the research. The paper has been translated to Portuguese and published in a technical trade magazine- Revista do Cuoro (Brazil). Further to this, other research projects now include treating and degrading leather waste for composting as a sustainable waste management strategy.

Title: Predicting Leather Handle like an Expert Artificial Neural Networks
AdditionalInformation: The quality of leather is usually judged by experts in the industry. This paper reports on a method of automating the process using a neural network model. The inputs are measurable physical characteristics of the leather, and the output is a numerical value which corresponds to the quality of the material. The importance of this research lies in the fact that the expertise could be automated, and that the method could easily be reproduced for other materials which rely on human quality assessment.

Title: Three-dimensional visualization of dermal skin structure using confocal laser scanning microscopy
AdditionalInformation: This unique paper investigates the utilisation of immersive technology for the assessment of dermal skin sections in a 5-sided viewing cube where the image stack produced from confocal laser microscopy, was assembled and disassembled. This study provides an opportunity to explore the dermis, as well as materials such as scaffolds in detail and so facilitate understanding of cell growth characteristics in a 3-D microstructure, to aid the development of novel tissue-engineering materials. Other applications may include human dermal imaging for dermatological purposes such as biopsies. The paper was viewed 13 times since the beginning of July 2013 (ResearchGate).

Title: The Prediction of Nonlinear Responses and Active Stiffness Control of Moving Slender Continua Subjected to Dynamic Loadings in A Vertical Host Structure.
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Acoustics and Vibration
AdditionalInformation: In this paper a novel multi-modal active stiffness controller is developed to suppress the dynamic response of long slender continua moving at speed in a tall host structure. This is a challenging nonlinear control problem. The proposed solution has attracted recognition from the international elevator industry and the work has been sponsored by ThyssenKrupp Elevator AG, a leading passenger transportation corporation. The work has informed the industry practice and the concept was awarded an international patent.

Title: The modelling, simulation and experimental testing $60#?tjl$62#?>of the dynamic responses of an elevator system
AdditionalInformation: The research described in this paper is aimed at the development of a novel computer simulation model to predict the performance of an elevator system. This task is extremely challenging due to the nonstationary nature of the system. The project has been funded by an international elevator company (ORONA EIC) and a regional Basque government in Spain. The results benefited the industry and the model has been adopted as design and analysis tools in the development of high-performance elevator systems.

Title: Use of optical profilometry in the ASTM D4172 standard
AdditionalInformation: This research suggests modifications of the standard test (ASTM D4172) by using the measurement of volume with a 3D profilometer (such an interferometer or a confocal microscope) instead of using only an optical microscope. This research underpinned a strong collaboration between the Lubrication Research Group of University of Oviedo (Spain) and Bournemouth University. This research gave rise to two presentations in top international conferences.

Title: Experimental study and analytical model of the cavitation ring region with small diameter ultrasonic horn
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops a new mathematical model to explain the location of cavitation clusters within the liquid by combining Analytical Mechanics Principles with Fluid Mechanics. This work was part of Dr.Gonzalo Garcia-Atance PhD dissertation which was sponsored by SKF. The location of cavitation clusters in ultrasonic cavitation is explained using Hamilton’s principle.

Title: Effects of cyclic stress and temperature on oxidation damage of a nickel-based superalloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first study of fatigue-oxidation interaction for a new nickel-based disc alloy used in the latest Rolls-Royce aeroengines. The results revealed for the first time the oxidation mechanism under selected variable stresses and temperatures. The measured oxidation damage was utilised to calibrate the essential parameters for an oxygen diffusion model.  The crack growth was then modelled using the finite element method and compared satisfactorily with the experimental results. The work won a Young Author's prize at the European Corrosion Congress 2010 (Moscow, 13~17 September 2010).

Title: Crystal plasticity modeling of cyclic deformation for a polycrystalline nickel-based superalloy at high temperature
AdditionalInformation: Although crystal plasticity was established in 1970s, this is a first paper to apply the theory to model the full aspects of cyclic deformation of a polycrystalline nickel-based superalloy, including cyclic hardening and stress-relaxation as well as monotonic behaviour. The simulations compared well with the experimental results, which also revealed some of the characteristics associated the mismatch of the mechanical properties of individual grains.  The work shed light on structure-property relation; and may be of particular significance in the evaluation and the prediction of crack initiation under fatigue loading conditions.

Title: Lattice Boltzmann simulation of power-law fluid flow in the mixing section of a single-screw extruder
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents simulation of non-Newtonian chemical mixing using the lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). This is one of the first applications of the LBM to non-Newtonian fluid mixing and follows on from the earlier work by the author on non-Newtonain blood flow models.  The effectiveness of the approach is demonstrated for the first time for a power-law fluid in a mixing section. The flexible nature of the approach and its application with alternative non-Newtonian models are also discussed. This work has spurred further studies by others (IMA J. App. Maths., 76, 790-816; J.  Non-Newtonian Fluid Mech., 166, 404-412).

Title: Three-dimensional modelling of the human carotid artery using the lattice Boltzmann method: I. Model and velocity analysis
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers blood flow at the bifurcation of 3D carotid artery model using the lattice Boltzmann method, representing the first application of this technique to a realistic 3D model of the carotid artery. A detailed representation of the flow field at the bifurcation was presented and a variation in the position of the maximum velocity was identified over a cardiac cycle. Understanding of flow in this artery is of vital importance in understanding and modelling the progression of atherosclerosis, which is one of the principle causes of mortality in the western world.

Title: Three-dimensional modelling of the human carotid artery using the lattice Boltzmann method: II. shear analysis
AdditionalInformation: This paper deals with wall shear stress (WSS) in the carotid artery at the region of the bifurcation.  WSS is known to be an important factor in the process of plaque rupture which can ultimately lead to stroke and/or death. Detailed results of the WSS around the bifurcation are obtained directly from the simulation, without the usual requirement to evaluate additional velocity gradients. The analysis revealed, for the first time, that the shear force on the wall of the initial sections of the internal and external carotid arteries is predominantly influenced by the artery geometry prior to bifurcation.

Title: Modelling complex geometry using solid finite element meshes with correct composite material orientations
AdditionalInformation: This article addressed solid hexahedral finite element meshes required for modelling composite components with complex geometric shapes. A new purpose written pre-processor was developed, which extrudes solid elements with element orientations that accurately match the complex doubly curved geometries. This new modelling technique has been used by Rolls-Royce as a part of their structural design tools (Mr E Ravey, Composite Specialist, Fans Global Engineering, eric.ravey@rolls-royce.com).

Title: Prediction of delamination in braided composite T-piece specimens
AdditionalInformation: The study of the failure mechanisms in T-piece specimens and prediction of their damage evolution are essential for the design of T-joint related composite components for fracture critical applications. This paper presented detailed modelling techniques and the failure criteria for damage initiation and delamination propagation. The work was carried out in collaboration with Rolls-Royce plc and the results are useful in the design of vans or blades of aero engines.

Title: Dynamics of trisiloxane wetting: effects of diffusion and surface hydrophobicitye
VolumeTitle: The Journal of Physical Chemistry C
AdditionalInformation: Superspreaders are exceptionally effective yet poorly understood wetting agents. Numerous models failed to explain the underlying mechanism of trisiloxane spreading and overlooked the effect of the substrate hydrophobicity.  In this work, a combined experimental and numerical approach has revealed for the first time the unique behaviour of superspreaders. Our model incorporates surface hydrophobicity as a crucial parameter; and it may be calibrated and serves as a powerful tool for the prediction of wetting dynamics of various superspreaders solutions. The work has opened a new direction in the understanding of superspreading phenomenon (Starov et al., 2012; Ivanova et al., 2011).

Title: A subject-specific pelvic bone model and its application to cemented acetabular replacements
AdditionalInformation: A subject-specific three-dimensional finite element pelvic bone model has been developed and validated using a human cadaver model, in collaboration with Beijing Huatou Biomedical Laboratory, China.  This is one of the few pelvic models ever published (together with Anderson et al, 2005 and Dalstra, 1996), perhaps the most detailed and up-to-date one for orthopedic research purposes.  We have offered free access to the model to the orthopedic research community.

Title: Dynamic enhancement of blast-resistant ultra high performance fibre-reinforced concrete under flexural and shear loading
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports findings from a collaboration of researchers in the UK and Australia of a relatively new material which has potential in blast protection.  Little experimental dynamic data was available for this material and no models of its behavior at high strain rates existed.  The paper reported the first comprehensive set of dynamic data for this material; revealed also that some of the existing models for strain rate effects in conventional concrete materials may be applied to this material.

Title: Assessment of fibre orientation in ultra high performance fibre reinforced concrete and its effect on flexural strength
AdditionalInformation: The paper addresses a key concern in the application and the performance of fibre-reinforced concrete.  The paper has spurred activities in model development to predict fibre orientation (CEM CONCR RES 2011, 41, 993-1000) and new techniques to assess fibre orientation (MATER STRUCT 2012, 45, 575-589).  The work also forms the basis for a new research proposal to EPSRC on mapping and modeling damage in fibre reinforced concrete.

Title: Spatial variation of residual stresses in a welded pipe for high temperature applications
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents measurements of residual stresses over the complete spatial range in a welded component used for high temperature applications. The techniques allowed realistic residual stress measurements near surface, and the results were used to assess the conservativeness of the standard defect evaluation codes such as R6. This project was performed with the support of EPSRC through the Supergen 2 programme, and in collaboration with power generation companies including Alstom Power Ltd, E.ON UK, Corus, QinetiQ, Rolls Royce plc, RWEnpower, Sermatech Ltd and Siemens Industrial Turbomachinery Ltd.

Title: Nonlinearity in apparent mass and transmissibility of the supine human body during vertical whole-body vibration
AdditionalInformation: In the third paper of the series of three, the dynamic responses of the whole human body were studied with extremely low magnitudes of excitation for the first time. This unique and complex experiment involved the measurement of vertical motion at three locations on the abdomen and chest with three different recumbent postures as well as the dynamic forces of the body. The relationship between varied degrees of nonlinearity and the locations and postures was revealed for the first time. It has spurred other studies, notably by Basri and Griffin (2011, 2012).

Title: Nonlinear dual-axis biodynamic response of the semi-supine human body during vertical whole-body vibration
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first of three papers studying the cause of a magnitude-dependent biodynamic nonlinearity during whole-body vibration. This unique experiment involved the measurement of vertical and fore-and-aft forces of 12 recumbent subjects. It applied a distinct intermittent excitation to examine the effects of shear history on the human body, providing the first experimental evidence of the cause of the biodynamic nonlinearity extensively reported in the past two decades. The study has influenced other studies in the area (e.g. Toward and Griffin, 2009, 2011; Basri and Griffin, 2011, 2012).

Title: Nonlinear dual-axis biodynamic response of the semi-supine human body during longitudinal horizontal whole-body vibration
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the second study of a series of three to discover the cause of the biodynamic nonlinearity, an acute problem experienced in many modes of transport. With the same magnitudes and types of excitation as the vertical-excitation study, this investigation applied longitudinal horizontal whole-body vibration to the recumbent person. The study demonstrated the need to quantify cross-axis response of the body when voluntary movement was eliminated, something conventional analyses often omit (e.g. Basri and Griffin, 2011; Matsumoto and Griffin, 2011).

Title: Characterization of polyetheretherketone-hydroxyapatite nanocomposite materials
AdditionalInformation: This paper examines the bonding strength of various loading levels of nano-scale hydroxyapatite particles in polyetheretherketone for developing novel bio-materials.  The generic knowledge on high performance thermoplastic PEEK derived from this study led to a KPT project in collaboration with Magma Global (contact Mr. S Hatton, Commercial Director, Steve.Hatton@magmaglobal.com), a world leading carbon fibre/ PEEK pipe designer and manufacturer for crude oil exploration.

Title: A Methodology for Combined Rotation-Extension Testing of Simple Steel Beam to Column Joints at High Rates of Loading
AdditionalInformation: Funded by the EPSRC, this new and unique experiment was designed to examine the dynamic behaviour leading to the failure of full-size beam-to-column connections in steel-framed buildings post the 9/11 catastrophe. The unique design of the testing facility allowed both tensile and rotational failures of connections from quasi-static to fast dynamic rates. This is the first paper from this original research. The new evidence includes reduced ductility than previously thought, which may influence future building design & assessment. Huang designed the full experimental setup and a FE platform for comparison purposes before he moved to UoP.

Title: Numerical Simulation and Sensitivity Analysis of Gas-Oil Gravity Drainage Process of Enhanced Oil Recovery
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a significant piece of work in simulating CO2-asssited gravity drainage EOR method. It has attracted much interest in reservoir simulation studies: 1302 downloads since 2007 and third most downloaded paper in 2010 (Onepetro.org).

Title: Effect of well pattern and injection well type on the CO2-assisted gravity drainage enhanced oil recovery
VolumeTitle: Journal of Petroleum Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: First ever reported mechanistic benefits of production strategy based on CO2-assisted gravity drainage EOR method using a full field compositional 3D reservoir model. It identified the key operational characteristics and other supporting mechanisms at the selective block level, exemplifying the fundamental theories (Cardwell Parsons Criteria).

Title: Delay or removal of aneurysm formation in the Anaconda wave energy extraction device
AdditionalInformation: Anaconda wave energy device consists of a pressurised flooded rubber tube, which, when excited with an external incident wave, permits generation of internal bulge waves that provide the mechanism for wave energy extraction. The paper presents a new technique to delay or remove aneurysm formation to maximise energy extraction.  The results of the work may be useful to the design and production of the full scale device.

Title: Predictions of aneurysm formation in distensible tubes: Part A - Theoretical background to alternative approaches
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a comprehensive study of numerical schemes to estimate the critical pressure level responsible for aneurysm formation in a distensible tube. The investigation explores the effect of several strain energy functions on the critical pressure for aneurysm, and the results are of generic values in related engineering and biomedical applications.  A referee commented that the paper represents “strong contribution to the field and could be a reference paper”.

Title: The evaluation of cutting-force coefficients using surface error measurements
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new approach for the determination of cutting-force coefficients. The main advantage of the new method is that it provides the simulation process with instantaneous cutting-force coefficients, which are independent of the cutting operation geometry. This development has spurred further work such as Liang et al, J Sichuan Univ (2011) and Wang et al, Int J Adv Manu Tech (2013).

Title: A generation of more efficient CNC tool paths using simulation modelling
AdditionalInformation: This work presents a new two-phase optimisation strategy for efficient planning of finishing end-milling operations when machining pocket-type features. The novel optimisation approach incorporates the design tolerance into an error stack that relates directly to the CAD/CAM output. The new off-line optimisation methodology creates a more efficient milling process with variable feed rate than conventional constant feed rate.

Title: Investigation of non-linear acoustic losses at the open end of a tube
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from an international collaboration between l'Université du Maine, France, and Edinburgh University. Numerical simulation, experimental measurement and analytical modelling were carried out to investigate the flow regimes which influence the termination impedance (energy losses) at the open end of a resonating pipe due to non-linear effects. The results identified, for the first time, the underlying physical mechanism responsible for a previously observed discontinuity in the termination impedance. The sensitivity of both the termination impedance and the observed regimes to the geometry of the opening was also demonstrated. The work has applications to acoustic and ultrasound waveguides.

Title: Modelling of morphology evolution and macroscopic behaviour of intercalated PET–clay nanocomposites during semi-solid state processing
AdditionalInformation: The unique feature of the research is that it accounts for the clay slippage phenomenon observed experimentally during processing, using a physically-sound cohesive zone approach. As a result, the model is useful for predicting the optimum processing conditions for the exfoliation of clay stacks during product forming. Figiel was invited to give a seminar talk on this topic at the Materials Modelling Colloquium Series at the University of Stuttgart, Germany, December 2012.

Title: Computational modelling of large deformations in layered-silicate/PET nanocomposites near the glass transition
VolumeTitle: Modelling and Simulation in Materials Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the development of a holistic nonlinear computational framework and tools for predicting large deformations of layered-silicate/PET nanocomposites near the glass transition. The modelling framework can predict the large deformation behaviour of polymer nanocomposites in the processing regime, hence useful for the optimization of processing conditions for such nanocomposites. The research is part of a comprehensive research programme that won the Composite Award 2009 from the Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining (IOM3).

Title: On the modelling of highly elastic flows of amorphous thermoplastics
AdditionalInformation: This paper examined an important type of problem of kinematic structuring of nonlinear constitutive models for large deformations.  It analysed systematically two generic kinematic approaches based on the additive decomposition of the rate of deformation tensor and the multiplicative split of the deformation gradient. The generic value of this paper is to facilitate users in choosing the most robust and accurate kinematic approach to build their nonlinear constitutive models, particularly for nonlinear viscoelastic flows of amorphous polymers. This research led to the winning of a research grant from the National Science Centre Poland (£90k) in 2011.

Title: Elastic constants for an intercalated layered-silicate/polymer nanocomposite using the effective particle concept – A parametric study using numerical and analytical continuum approaches
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported the development of an advanced modelling framework for predicting the effective elastic constants of polymer-clay nanocomposites. An important conclusion is that both FE and analytical approaches can account rigorously for the anisotropy of the effective clay particle, which is revealed for the first time.  This is of great value to material scientists and engineers for quantitative predictions of the elastic response of nanocomposites. The research contributed to the winning of a research grant from the Irish Research Council (~£65k) in 2010.

Title: 3D real-time micromechanical compressive behaviour of bone–cement interface: Experimental and finite element studies
AdditionalInformation: The paper reported the first work on the micromechanics of bone-cement interface, utilising in situ mechanical testing, time-lapsed microcomputed tomography (CT) and ﬁnite element (FE) modelling. The FE model was built from CT images and was able to capture the subject-speciﬁc mechanical responses and the damage evolution in situ under compression.

Title: Numerical investigation into multi-delamination failure of composite T-piece specimens under mixed mode loading using a modified cohesive model
AdditionalInformation: The failure mechanism of fibre composite T-piece specimens under mixed mode loading was investigated for the first time by simulating multi-delamination using a modified cohesive zone model with a new coupled damage scale introduced. It revealed that the interaction between tensile and bending plays an important role in the failure mechanism. This work formed the basis for a new proposal to EPSRC for developing an extended finite cohesive element enriched by a mixed damage scale.

Title: An advanced FRP floor panel system in buildings
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigated a pultruded CFRP floor panel for green buildings with low thermal conductivity features. The research produced design curves for practical applications of CFRP floor panels in low carbon construction industries for energy saving and reduction of CO2 emission, in collaboration with Arup. A proposal based on this investigation was selected by BIS and Innovation China UK (ICUK) for UK-China Technology Partnering Workshop on Advanced Material Technology 2013 funded by European Union to explore collaboration with Asia for developing green buildings globally.

Title: Strain Transfer Through the Aortic Valve
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel experimental methodology employing cell nuclei as micro-markers, in conjunction with a rigorous modelling approach, facilitating a 3D reconstruction of the strain field within the microstructure of aortic valves for the first time. The potential application of the devised methodology to map strain fields in valvular tissues under biaxial loads, and adoption for other connective tissues such as tendons, has since been explored and developed at Queen Mary and UoP.

Title: A viscoplastic study of crack-tip deformation and crack growth in a nickel-based superalloy at elevated temperature
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper reporting a comprehensive treatment of time-dependent crack growth utilising the concept of strain ratchetting, originally proposed by the authors (Zhao et al, FFEMS, 2004) for time-independent deformation. Ratchetting strain was used, for the first time, as a fracture criterion for time-dependent crack growth, an important step forward from the traditionally empirical or semi-empirical models.  The work has spurred the first attempt at experimental validation of ratchetting phenomenon, in collaboration with the University of Sheffield and Ecole Polytechnique.

Title: Discrete dislocation dynamics modelling of mechanical deformation of nickel-based single crystal superalloys
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a powerful novel method of 3D Discrete Dislocation Dynamics to simulate the interaction between microstructure features in nickel-based superalloys.  This is the first time such a sophisticated method is used for polycrystalline nickel alloys, and it offers some unique promises for a fundamental understanding of microstructure-properties relationship in this important class of materials.  Potential impact includes the optimisation of key microstructural parameters through material processing in order to achieve the best mechanical performance for aero-engine applications.

Title: A study of fatigue crack tip characteristics using discrete dislocation dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first micromechanics study of fatigue crack tip characteristics in a polycrystalline material using Discrete Dislocation Dynamics. The results revealed, for the first time, that ratchetting is associated with microstructural changes, including dislocation accumulation, dislocation climb and dislocation-GB penetration, and dislocation climb is the dominant mechanism. The work offers a step closer towards developing a physical-based model for fatigue crack growth.

Title: Damage evolution in acetabular replacements under long-term physiological loading conditions
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents some of the unique new results from a custom-made hip simulator for long-term testing of cement fixation integrity (Zant et al, JBME, ASME, 2006).  The major advances include a combined loading spectrum built from daily routine activities and the use of microCT in detecting the damage development inside of an acetabular reconstruct for the first time under selected physiological loading conditions.  The work was funded by the Arthritis Research UK and in collaboration with clinical staff at the local NHS hospitals.

Title: Modelling and optimisation of up-and down-milling processes for a representative pocket feature
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Precision Engineering and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The main aim of this research is to improve the efficiency of CNC machining by better process planning, improved accuracy and reduction of time when machining complex pocket features. The mathematical models, simulation  and optimisation techniques developed in this study have been experimentally verified for the first time for up- and down-milling under various cutting conditions. The results demonstrated that the variable cutting conditions have significant advantages over milling with constant cutting conditions in the reduction of the cutting forces and radial cutting tool deviation, and thus on surface errors.

Title: Characterisation and Evaluation of Nano Gelcoat Degradations in Marine Environment
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported our pioneering research on utilising a layer structured nano-clay as water barrier to improve conventional gel coat for protection of polymer composite structures in a marine environment. The knowledge generated from this study led to a number of research and consultancy projects with Pall Europe (Dr J-H Xue, Senior R&D Scientist, Jinghui_Xu@europe.pall.com), Safeguard Europe (Dr E Rirsch, Technical Director, eric.rirsch@safeguardeurope.com), Gurit (Dr H Francis, Laboratory and Testing Manager, Harvey.Francis@gurit.com), Materials Technology Ltd (Dr N Kenworthy, Technical Director, nick@mtechltd.co.uk) and Wartsila (Mr B Piggott, Development Engineer, Barry.Piggott@Wartsila.com).

Title: Biofouling resistance of titanium dioxide and zinc oxide nanoparticulate silane/siloxane exterior facade treatments
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first assessment of ‘self-cleaning’ properties of novel photo-catalytic nanoparticulate enhanced facade treatments. This research led to a long term collaboration with Safeguard Europe (Safeguard Europe, Dr E Rirsch, Technical Director, eric.rirsch@safeguardeurope.com) in a number of research and consultancy projects, in which novel functionaries such as energy saving and anti-fouling were commercially explored.  It has also led to the publication of a number of journal papers (e.g. Zhang et al, J of Construction and Building Materials 2013, 2012, 2011, 2010; J of Building and Environment, 2013 and J of Energy and Buildings, 2012, 2011).

Title: Study on Electrical Conductivity and Mechanical Performance of Polymeric Composite Flow Field Plates for Fuel Cell Applications
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports research funded by TSB (TP/4/EET/6/S/22094) in collaboration with Bac2 Ltd (Dr G Murray, Technical Director, graham@bac2.co.uk).  The findings from this research have contributed to the rapid growth of the company into a specialist in manufacturing of commercial-scale electrically conductive polymer composites, which have been successfully used as bi-polar plates, a key component in high performance fuel cell.

Title: Damage evolution in acetabular reconstructs under physiological testing in a saline environment
AdditionalInformation:
This is the first paper reporting the damage development in cemented acetabular reconstructs under a combined cyclic
loading block in a saline environment.   The work built on a unique hip simulation developed at Portsmouth for fixation testing, one and only this type in the UK.  The new development is in a custom-made environmental chamber which allows testing in more physiological loading conditions for the ﬁrst time.  The damage patterns discovered differ from those in dry conditions and more consistent with the clinical findings.  Work carried out in collaboration with the Queen Alexandra Hospital.

Title: Characterisation of a metallic foam–cement composite under selected loading conditions
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents results from a collaboration with the University of Siegen, Germany, funded by the British Council and DAAD. For the first time metallic foam/cement interface was assessed under mixed mode loading conditions, and the results compared with those from bovine/cement interface.  The work has implications on the use of artificial materials to build controlled morphologies to interface with cement, an advantage nature materials lack, so that morphological variables may be tailored to suit the application.

Title: Bone-cement interfacial behaviour under mixed mode loading conditions
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
AdditionalInformation: A comprehensive treatment of bone-cement interfacial behaviour is given in this paper.  For the first time microCT was used to provide the damage morphologies and cohesive zone modelling was also carried out to simulate and predict the mixed mode responses.  The work has spurred further work in this direction (Waanders et al, 2011, 2012; Miller et al, 2011; Tozzi et al 2012, 2013); and led to a joint proposal to EPSRC with the University of Southampton (Browne).

Title: Fatigue crack growth in laser-shock-peened Ti-6AL-4V aerofoil specimens due to foreign object damage
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the main findings from an EPSRC/MOD funded project, on which an impact case study UOP12FOD is also based. For the first time 3D residual stresses from foreign object damage (FOD) and laser shock peening (LSP) were evaluated and used to obtain an effective stress intensity factor, which was then used to rationalise the fatigue crack growth under simulated service conditions.  The results have provided increased confidence in using LSP in FOD susceptible components (UOP12FOD).  The generic method developed is also applicable to crack growth in a residual stress field, for example, in welded structures.

Title: Local plastic strain evolution in a high strength dual-phase steel
AdditionalInformation: This experimentally based research is a collaboration (EPSRC Grant EP/F023464/1) with Tata Steel Europe in IJmuiden (contact: Principal Scientist, Tata) that takes advantage of the advanced macro/micro testing techniques to bring benefit to the work on multi-phase steels. The research output has helped to develop steel products of the future, by providing a unique opportunity to investigate the effect of microstructural constituents on damage mechanisms. This research led to a £350K research grant provided by the Tata Steel Europe and M2i research institute in the Netherlands (R/112529).

Title: Bayesian sensitivity analysis of bifurcating nonlinear models
AdditionalInformation: Numerical modelling of non-linear structures is often hampered by large variations boundary conditions making full understanding of complex structures difficult. This was the first analysis of a bifurcating system using these sensitivity methods. The technology was derived from the machine learning community. The PhD student involved went on to continue the collaboration through a research position working with world-leading sensitivity analyst (JRC Ispra – contact details available). This new line of research successfully led to a Leverhulme grant "A Novel Methodology for Modelling Complex Bio-mechanical Systems using Bayesian Uncertainty Analysis" to develop this work further [RPG-2012-816].

Title: Bayesian sensitivity analysis of a model of the aortic valve
AdditionalInformation: This multi-disciplinary piece of work was performed in collaboration with the Probability and Statistics department at the University of Sheffield. It was the first use of Bayesian sensitivity analysis in a biomechanics model. The work led directly to a collaboration with the Politechnico di Torinocecilia.surace@polito.it and Nautilus S.p.A.(Contact details available), who sponsored a nine month research visit by the PhD student.  It also led to an invitation to present the 2010 British Society for Strain Measurement (BSSM) measurements lecture for one of the authors.

Title: Reproducibility of haemodynamical simulations in a subject-specific stented aneurysm model - A report on the Virtual Intracranial Stenting Challenge 2007
AdditionalInformation: This highly-cited paper has become a reference in the field, by showing the scientific community that computational tools can be used to give consistent information in support of personalised healthcare. The study is multicentre, multidisciplinary, and involved academia and industry. I worked collaboratively with ANSYS (contact: Head, ANSYS) to computationally predict the haemodynamics within treated patient-specific aneurysms. The aim was to demonstrate the feasibility and reproducibility of CFD analysis of aneurysm haemodynamics. Following the success of this study, five new research challenges of the same nature were organised, and results presented at major clinical seminars (7th Intracranial Stenting Meeting, USA).

Title: Three-dimensional contour bumps for transonic wing drag reduction
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposed and optimised a novel shock control device, a three dimensional shock control bump, for drag reduction on transonic aircraft wings. Due to the control, the drag can be reduced by over 20% at the design condition at high cruise Mach numbers with a broad operational range. The method has attracted strong interest from Airbus who further funded the work, and have been actively pursuing the approach for future wing concepts (contact:  R&T Integrator, Airbus).

Title: Surrogate-Based Multi-Objective Aerothermodynamic Design Optimization of Hypersonic Spiked Bodies
AdditionalInformation: The work reported in this paper proposes for the first time a novel and advanced multi-objective optimization method and solution for overcoming the problem of aerodynamic drag and aero-thermodynamic heating in hypersonic vehicles. This was the first study to provide a variety of configuration adaptations to the design of the spikes and the forebodies, which resulted in a balance between vehicle drag and surface heating.

Title: Behavior of Detached-Eddy Simulations for Mild Airfoil Trailing-Edge Separation
AdditionalInformation: Detached eddy simulation, as a hybrid of RANS and LES, offers important advantages for practical applications, in particular aircraft flows. This paper addresses the key issues of the accuracy of the approach for flows with mild trailing edge separation. Further insight into the various modelling strategies through numerical studies impacted on the development of the DG-DES code, which becomes the key tool for the EU FP7 project, MARS, led by the Sheffield team as the technical coordinator (Contact: CINME, Spain).

Title: Zipper layer method for linking two dissimilar structured meshes
AdditionalInformation: This research was supported by Rolls Royce under the CFMS and SIOLET research programmes (£444k, 2007-2012). As a direct result of the zipper layer method, Rolls Royce have developed an innovative casing treatment design that was shown to improve the stall margin at no cost to the engine efficiency. Two patents have been filed by Rolls-Royce to protect the meshing technology and the innovative casing treatment design (contact: Rolls-Royce Engineering Associate Fellow).

Title: Dispersion relations and wave operators in self-similar quasicontinuous linear chains
AdditionalInformation: This is the first significant contribution to bridging the gap between the fluid mechanics problem of fractal multiscale turbulence and the dynamics of self-similar quasicontinuous linear chains. It is a unique collaboration between the theoretical physics group (Modélisation, Propagation et Imagerie Acoustique), Paris 6 (Maugin and Michelitsch) and the Sheffield Fluid Mechanics Group. This first time research creates a mathematical formula that potentially provides an analytical description of the turbulent field, which significantly reduces time spent predicting complex flows, as well as contributing towards the ongoing goals of the ERCOFTAC networks SIG42 and SIG14 (http://www.ercoftac.org/special_interest_groups).

Title: The simulation of the flow within a hydrocyclone operating with an air core and with an inserted metal rod
AdditionalInformation: The results helped to clarify the nature of air-core in hydrocyclones and led to significant new insights into the structure of swirling flow. As a result of this work Nowakowski was invited to participate as CI on the Thai Research Fund (TRF) programme "An intelligent computer-based procedure for design of hydrocyclones for separation process". This generated practical guidelines for industrial users of solid-liquid separators as currently equipment manufactures sell standard equipment that is not necessarily appropriate for all slurry flow regimes.

Title: Analysis of the vibrational mode spectrum of a linear chain with spatially exponential properties
AdditionalInformation: The paper establishes a novel connection between mathematical analysis of multi-scale geometry and the nonlinear physics of fractals in continuum mechanics.  It introduces a theoretical framework to tackle a wide class of dynamic problems with the scale hierarchy of their microstructure as a common feature. The fundamental research presented in this paper is the first attempt to create the mathematical description which will ultimately lead to implementations in strategic applications (e.g. medical diagnostic tools, weather changes simulation software or air and maritime pollution prediction tools).

Title: Understanding air core formation in hydrocyclones by studying pressure distribution as a function of viscosity
AdditionalInformation: A novel approach for controlling the operation of a hydrocyclone was introduced. The central part of this research was the finite element software package developed by Nowakowski, which enabled investigation of the influence of the hydrocyclone geometry upon flow character. Other colleagues working on hydrocyclones have subsequently used the code and currently this research continues together with DuPont (contact: Area Manager Research)

Title: Quantitative Strain Analysis of the Large Deformation at the Scale of Microstructure: Comparison between Digital Image Correlation and Microgrid Techniques
AdditionalInformation: This is the first time DIC strain measurements applied to microstructures have been validated using an independent technique. The work funded by EPSRC (Grant EP/F023464/1, £4M) has been developed in partnership with Tata Steel Europe (contact: Principal Scientist). Results have led to the funding of a three year post-doctoral project funded by Tata Steel Europe and M2i – a government funded institute in the Netherlands – to apply this experimental procedure to automotive advanced high strength steels (Grant R/112529, £350k).

Title: Void growth and coalescence modelling in AA2050 using the Rousselier model
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new physically-based damage model for metals that incorporates not only void nucleation and growth but also coalescence in a Cellular Automata - Finite Element (CAFE) Framework. This work funded by EPSRC (Grant EP/F023464/1 - £4M) has been developed in partnership with Tata Steel Europe (contact: Scientific Fellow) where the model has been transferred. Research activity at Tata with the model has led to two successful EU-RFCS grants won by them.

Title: Identification of modes of fracture in a 2618-T6 aluminum alloy using stereophotogrammetry
AdditionalInformation: The technique described in this paper was applied to an aluminium alloy used by Cummins Ltd in compressor wheels of turbo-engines with failures observed after cyclic loading at high temperatures. The work has been carried out in close relationship with the company (contact: Principle Engineer). These experimental results analysed through a crack propagation model have provided the company with a tool to predict the fatigue life of the compressor wheels.

Title: Modeling and Optimal Design of Machining-Induced Residual Stresses in Aluminium Alloys Using a Fast Hierarchical Multiobjective Optimization Algorithm
AdditionalInformation: This work now used by AIRBUS was carried out during a Framework 6 European project (Grant RU/123554 - £250k) and resulted from joint research between the Universities of Sheffield and Hannover in Germany.  This work led to the development of a model-based software which is now used for the prediction of the distortion of aerospace parts due to residual stresses (contact: R&T Manager for Structures Test, Airbus).

Title: The use of pseudo-faults for novelty detection in SHM
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented the first use of damage metaphors in Structural Health Monitoring (SHM). One of the main impediments to industrial adoption of data-based SHM is the need for examples of data from damaged structures. This work proposes a completely novel method for selecting damage-sensitive features without the need for damaging the structure. This work was one of the few examples using a real experimental structure which arose from a collaboration with QinetiQ (contact details available) and was funded under an ESF-S3T Eurocores project "Smart Sensing For Structural Health Monitoring" (S3HM) (EP/E010849/1).

Title: An evidence-based approach to damage location on an aircraft structure
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented the first use in Structural Health Monitoring of the Dempster-Shafer network, an alternative to the probabilstic approach allowing for the expression of ignorance, thereby allowing greater confidence in damage identification predictions. The paper fused the evidence-based and probabilistic approaches and was conducted in collaboration with an international expert on Dempster-Shafer theory. The experimental work was funded by QinetiQ (contact details available) and conducted at their facilities in Farnborough. This is one of the few Structural Health Monitoring studies considering data from a real structure.

Title: On the identification of hysteretic systems. Part I: Fitness landscapes and evolutionary identification
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the first application of a self-adaptive optimisation approach to a particularly challenging problem; namely the identification of parameters relating to the modelling of hysteretic behaviour which is encountered in a large number of applications, such as automotive shock absorbers and aerodynamic stall. The approach resulted in several orders-of-magnitude improvement on previous work and has contributed to the award of a £4.2M EPSRC Programme Grant in Engineering Non-linearity (EP/K003836/1).

Title: Features for damage detection with insensitivity to environmental and operational variations
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: The paper addresses one of the major challenges preventing the transition of structural health monitoring from a research field into industrial practice with a novel application (first use of multivariate cointegration) of one of the major advances in econometrics from the last few decades. The proposed method outperforms previous approaches in a number of important respects. The work, funded by EPSRC grant GP/F035403/1 has led to guest lecture invitations at Los Alamos National Laboratory and the National Physics Laboratory. The technique is being applied at UCSD (mdtodd@ucsd.edu) and AGH University of Krakow (W.J.Staszewski@agh.edu.pl).

Title: Depletion of horizontal pair diffusion in strongly stratified turbulence: Comparison with plane two-dimensional flows
AdditionalInformation: This was the first paper to study particle pair diffusion in non-isotropic flows using the novel technique of Kinematic Simulation combined with Rapid Distortion Theory. The mechanisms leading to the depletion of diffusion in the vertical axis were clearly identified.

Title: Dispersion of heavy particle sets in isotropic turbulence using kinematic simulation
AdditionalInformation: This study is unique in that it assesses cases corresponding to Reynolds numbers non achievable by other numerical techniques. It was fundamental in improving our understanding of mixing and of the fundamental effect of particle mass on clustering. The effect of the Stokes number and Drift parameter are identified and calibrated. Analytical relations have been proposed on the effect of inertia on Lagragian topology. It provides the only benchmark set of results at large Reynolds numbers that can be used for validating classical CFD methods.

Title: Experimental study of a turbulent pipe flow through a fractal plate
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a unique experiment containing a pipe and a fractal orifice, providing bench mark test cases for advanced numerical methods and future experiments. The paper opens the way for a new kind of fractal shaped plate to be used as a flowmeter.

Title: Presence of a Richardson's regime in kinematic simulations
AdditionalInformation: This paper clarifies the influence of Reynolds number on sweeping effects in Lagrangian dispersion. This is very important in terms of modelling strategies. For the first time a clear limitation of steady synthetic turbulence models is quantified.

Title: Energy dissipation prediction of particle dampers
AdditionalInformation: The combined use of numerical and experimental work to study both frequency and amplitude dependence was first introduced in this paper and has since been carried forward by other researchers worldwide. Funded by an EPSRC Platform Grant (EP/D078601) on uncertainty modelling, it is the first journal paper to address the sensitivity of power dissipation. This understanding, along with previous collaboration which led to the particle dampers for the Trent 500 engine fuel system, has resulted in further £50K research funding from Rolls-Royce to develop numerical code for in-house design use (contact: Team Leader, Mechanical Methods)

Title: Temperature and strain rate dependence of syntactic foam under tensile and shear loads
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications
AdditionalInformation: The first publication on the steady-state strength of viscoelastic syntactic foams in the transition zone and used by Rolls-Royce to develop lightweight aeroengine fan and guide vanes, damped with syntactic foam fillers. The commercial sensitivity of this work restricted earlier publication although the associated commercial product Araldite 1641 won the JEC Composites Innovation Award for Aerospace Materials in 2006. The understanding gained from this work was used to design stronger materials and blade geometries which are currently used in commercial aircraft and military aeroengine test programmes (contact: Chief of Mechanical Methods, Design Systems Engineering, Rolls-Royce plc).

Title: Control of Particle Damper Nonlinearity
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper in which particle damper nonlinearity is deliberately controlled in order to optimise performance over any operating condition by applying pressure. This results in providing, for the first time, a consistent and successful method for this type of damper. The work was funded by EPSRC grant GR/T28393/01. This work has provided the basis of new collaborative research with Beihang University (China) to look at metal-rubber particles and has resulted in studentships funded by the Chinese government and further publications (contact: Prof. Jie Hong, Beihang University hongjie@buaa.edu.cn).

Title: Strategies for using cellular automata to locate constrained layer damping on vibrating structures
AdditionalInformation: This work presents the first research carried out into the use of cellular automata for optimising a multi-layer damping coating and was followed up by Rolls-Royce plc in order to improve the design of damping configurations in turbomachinery blading (contact: Team Leader, Mechanical Methods).

Title: Quantitative measurement of plastic strain field at a fatigue crack tip
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: In the novel technique developed here, the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) is applied to backscattered electron (BSE) images in order to map the mesoscale plastic strain distribution around the tip of a fatigue crack. This work is being further applied in both US and UK universities. The work describes the results of a new collaboration with Yang and Crimp begun at Michigan State University, when Tomlinson made a sabbatical visit to work with Patterson (now A.A. Griffith Chair of Structural Materials and Mechanics at the University of Liverpool). The visit was funded by an EPSRC Overseas Travel Grant (EP/H05197X/1).

Title: T-stress determination using thermoelastic stress analysis
VolumeTitle: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design
AdditionalInformation: This work was the basis of further significant developments, since the software presented in this paper to determine K and T-stress was adapted further by the authors for displacement data. This software is now being used with Cytec Ltd (two industrially funded PhDs and a KTP – contact details available) to quantify the fracture behaviour of new toughened polymer formulations for fibre composites. The novel technique to identify the crack tip from thermoelastic images led to innovative work on crack tip plasticity as part of a new collaboration with Michgan State University (Professor M Crimp (crimp@egr.msu.edu) funded by EPSRC (EP/H05197X/1).

Title: Crack paths under mixed mode loading
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrated the robustness of the software to determine stress intensity factors.
