Confidence was gained to further develop this software to incorporate functions to determine T-stresses, and the resulting program is now in regular use at the Universities of Sheffield and Liverpool for fracture mechanics investigations of novel materials (e.g. toughened polymers for Cytec (contact details available). The subsequent research on the fatigue failure of fibre metal laminates using the technique in this paper is being considered for potential applications by Airbus. (contact: R&T Manager for Structures Test, Airbus).

Title: On impact damage detection and quantification for CFRP laminates using structural response data only
AdditionalInformation: Use of composite materials in aerospace structures brings the significant problem of impact damage. Runway debris impact, bird strike or tool drop can induce invisible/barely visible damage that seriously affects structural health. Until now, it has only been possible to discern if damage has been caused if the impact force history is available; this will never be the case in operation. This paper provides a methodology that allows impacts to be classified as damaging or not using only response data. This led to an invitation to submit for an EPSRC feasibility study on composite monitoring, which was successful (EP/1033513/1, R/136617).

Title: Spatial scanning for anomaly detection in acoustic emission testing of an aerospace structure
AdditionalInformation: This is a completely new methodology for detecting cracks in aircraft landing gear during fatigue tests. The approach is based on novel signal processing of acoustic emission data taken from the field of epidemiology. The new approach proved capable of detecting cracks hours before the landing gear actually ruptured. It is the result of several years collaboration with Messier-Dowty with EPSRC and direct company funding. Messier-Dowty are discussing patenting the approach and the success of this project led directly to the award of a further £200k project with Messier-Dowty (contact details available).

Title: Lamb wave propagation modelling and simulation using parallel processing architecture and graphical cards
AdditionalInformation: The Sheffield group pioneered use of the LISA algorithm in general structural health monitoring and inverse problems. Implementing the algorithm on a CUDA system for the first time provided a 100 times+ speed up which allowed use of the 3D algorithm in optimisation routines for the first time, leading to further valuable research outcomes. This paper is a collaboration between Sheffield and AGH University Krakow. Initial code written in Sheffield was parallelised on a CUDA system by AGH. The package has now been given a commercial release through the company Innovatskia Polska (contact details available).

Title: Parameter estimation and model selection for a class of hysteretic systems using Bayesian inference
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows how a unified Bayesian approach to nonlinear system identification has many advantages over classical viewpoints and presents a new model selection criterion. The paper is the first use of Bayesian methods on Bouc-Wen hysteretic systems. The ideas here led to the part-funding of a PhD studentship by EDF (contact details available) and formed the basis of the Sheffield Workpackage for a successful EPSRC Programme Grant Application. EDF subsequently awarded the Dynamics Group a consultancy contract to investigate ways of exploiting technology like this for modelling nuclear reactor subsystems.

Title: An Evolutionary Complex Systems Decision-Support Tool for the Management of Operations
VolumeTitle: IOP Conference Series: Materials Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper pioneered the application of modelling and simulation techniques from the science of evolutionary complex systems in the field of Operations and Production Management. A design and decision-support tool has been developed for managers where the introduction or reconfiguration of new manufacturing technologies and practices, and the different evolutionary trajectories that a manufacturing system can take, can be explored. This has informed the £43M AMRC Factory 2050: a research factory involving Boeing, Airbus, Rolls-Royce and BAE Systems that is the UK’s first fully reconfigurable manufacturing and assembly facility.

Title: Communicative interaction as an instrument for integration and coordination in an aerospace supply chain
AdditionalInformation: This paper explored the effects of communicative interaction on integration and coordination of the commercial aerospace supply chain. This work helped develop the Fit For Nuclear (F4N) diagnostic tool, which helps companies to measure their current operations against the standards required to supply the UK’s new generation of nuclear power stations. This diagnostic tool underpins a £38 M grant from the Regional Growth Fund to develop a UK nuclear new build supply chain.

Title: A cladistic classification of commercial aerospace supply chain evolution
AdditionalInformation: This work was the first in the field to apply an evolutionary classification scheme at the supply chain level. By going beyond the individual firm, a better understanding of individual performances of the firms within the chain can be achieved. The benefits include a benchmark of best practice, a strategic tool for policy development, and scenario generation. This informed the proposal of the AMRC-led COPERNICO project, a €7.6m, European (FP7) funded collaboration between fifteen universities and industrial partners, including Rolls-Royce.

Title: Tool life and surface integrity aspects when drilling and hole making in Inconel 718
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the output of research work sponsored by AB Sandvik Coromant at the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC), investigating hole manufacture in Inconel 718.  It highlights key benefits available in surface integrity, namely white layer removal, reduced micro-structural deformation, and lower roughness, when using mill-boring as a finishing technique as opposed to reaming. It has led to a range of follow on research studies, the inclusion of AB Sandvik Coromant as a Tier 1 AMRC funding partner (£200k p.a.), and their sponsorship of multiple studentships in the EPSRC funded Industrial Doctorate Centre in Machining Science (EP/I01800X/1).

Title: Feasibility Study for Real Time Measurement of Wheel-Rail Contact Using an Ultrasonic Array
AdditionalInformation: This is the first piece of work to prototype an ultrasonic reflected based method where contact size, shape and pressure distribution have been determined experimentally. The contact patch between a wheel and railway track is small, under high pressure and constantly difficult to measure, however this work overcomes that issue by using an ultrasonic array to focus and integrate the interface non-invasively. Critically, the novel approach means that this method could potentially be used on live rail. Currently the technology is being installed on a railway roller test apparatus at Voestalpine (contact details available).

Title: Ultrasonic Measurement of Rolling Bearing Lubrication Using Piezoelectric Thin Films
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel sensor using sputtered piezo-electric material to measure oil films. The collaboration of three Universities was led by Sheffield. The sensor is small, thin and therefore suitable for measurement in confined spaces. Therefore, it is ideal for non-invasive measurements in rolling bearings. This approach is being trialled by SKF ERC Ltd (contact: Senior Researcher). It is being used as a condition monitoring sensor on a novel wind turbine gearbox bearing developed by Ricardo (contact: Chief Engineer - Innovation). The sensor and bearing is currently being tested under a DECC Offshore Wind Component Technology Grant (OWDIn 2012).

Title: A New Approach for the Measurement of Film Thickness in Liquid Face Seals
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the first successful non-invasive measurement of the very thin, yet critical, oil film that forms in mechanical face seals. Concepts from the NDT community based on ultrasonic reflection have been applied to this important tribological interface. The largest international seal manufacturer, John Crane Ltd (contact: Core Technology Manager) purchased instrumentation from our spin out company, Tribosonics Ltd. They use this to develop new seals and have published results independently. The US Society of Tribologists and Lubrication Engineers (STLE) awarded this paper the prestigious Frank P. Bussick Award in 2009.

Title: Piezoelectric sensors to monitor lubricant film thickness at piston-cylinder contacts in a fired engine
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: The piston ring is a major source of engine friction (equivalent to 3% of the fuel cost). This arises from the oil film which is very thin and fast moving in an aggressive environment. This research was undertaken using the EPSRC programme grant Encyclopaedic (EP/G012849/1), where we developed the first way to measure the film that does not require penetrating the engine cylinder. It can therefore be used on real engines with minor modifications. Wartsila (contact details available), a major manufacturer of marine diesel engines, use this approach on their RTX4 test engines to develop new ringpack designs.

Title: Virtual Fractional Flow Reserve From Coronary Angiography: Modeling the Significance of Coronary Lesions
AdditionalInformation: Coronary fractional flow reserve (FFR) is an important diagnostic measure: a major clinical trial was terminated early because it was considered unethical to keep patients on the control arm. Despite this only 15% of patients in the UK have FFR measured, mainly due to cost. We have demonstrated on a small cohort of 19 patients (39 lesions) that FFR can be estimated computationally, at low cost, from rotational angiography images alone, and based on these results have attracted £900k funding from Wellcome and the British Heart Foundation to develop the application further and to apply it to more complex cases.

Title: Accuracy vs. computational time: Translating aortic simulations to the clinic
AdditionalInformation: Sophisticated Fluid-Solid Interaction models are currently computationally intractable for routine clinical application, but capture the important physical phenomenon of finite wave speeds in arteries. Recognising that, at least to a first linear approximation, the one dimensional wave equation for a compressible fluid is exactly that for a distensible tube, this paper proposes a novel approach to arterial computational fluid mechanics using this analogy. The execution time is typically four times lower than an FSI analysis, and only 10% higher than for a simple incompressible fluid analysis. This has major implications for clinical translation.

Title: Numerical Modeling of Hemodynamics with Pulsatile Impeller Pump Support
AdditionalInformation: Ventricular assist devices (VADs) support patients in heart failure. We propose the first comprehensive cost function to support optimal engineering design by balancing competing and contrary physiological requirements. One controversy is whether a pulsatile VAD device should operate in synchrony with the failing heart, or in a counter-pulsation mode. The paper establishes the optimal relative phase under the constraint of the proposed cost function. Our route to impact is through our close collaboration with Berlin Heart, one of the most successful European VAD manufacturers (partners in 17M Euro euHeart project, extended visit of PhD student, joint journal publication in 2012).

Title: @neurIST complex information processing toolchain for the integrated management of cerebral aneurysms
AdditionalInformation: This study proposes and validates, through clinical feedback, a workflow for patient-specific management of intracranial aneurysms. The protocol and computational tools proposed for the extraction of relevant physical data from subject-specific datasets, have been validated by over 260 clinicians during various workshops worldwide. Its dissemination amongst the clinical community resulted in a consultancy/research collaboration between Marzo and a group of Neurosurgeons at Beaumont Hospital in Dublin, Ireland, through a key SME (contact CEO, IDAC Ireland Ltd).

Title: Hemodynamics and In-stent Restenosis: Micro-CT Images, Histology, and Computer Simulations
AdditionalInformation: Restenosis is a serious complication of coronary artery stenting. Whilst many papers describe the analysis of flow in stented arteries, these consider idealised geometries with symetrically-deployed stents. Data was obtained from pig experiments and a model of the deployed 3D geometry was reconstructed from micro-CT. The vessel wall reaction was determined from histological sections. Direct comparison of hemodynamic parameters and biological response supports the hypothesis that low and oscillatory WSS give an increased neointimal response. The realistic geometry gives to a markedly non-uniform distribution of WSS. The correlation with asymmetric growth cannot be appreciated in idealized geometries.

Title: Computational modelling and evaluation of cardiovascular response under pulsatile impeller pump support
AdditionalInformation: This is an important collaboration with a ventricular assist device (VAD) manufacturer, Berlin Heart, and uses numerical simulation to address a clinically important challenge.  A simulation of the cardiovascular response in heart failure was developed under the support of an INCOR impeller-type VAD. A series of VAD-assisted cardiovascular cases are studied. Key parameters of the VAD motion profile are systematically changed to investigate the potential of using the INCOR to produce a physiologically meaningful arterial pulse pressure within various physiological constraints. An optimization process, including the introduction of a cost function, balances the importance of characteristic cardiovascular variables.

Title: Importance of realistic LVAD profiles for assisted aortic simulations: evaluation of optimal outflow anastomosis locations
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: There is increasing interest in the use of left ventricular assist devices to support recovery rather than as a bridge to transplant. This puts additional requirements on the device; minimisation of damage to the patient's heart and major vessels is essential. This study, carried out in conjunction with Berlin Heart Gmb, investigates the importance of a realistic LVAD profile for evaluating aortic flow fields and compares potential anastomosis locations in a patient-specific aorta.  The work demonstrates the optimal location for the anastomosis and highlights the importance of simulation in the design of the surgical procedure as well for the device.

Title: Computational Hemodynamics in Cerebral Aneurysms: The Effects of Modeled Versus Measured Boundary Conditions
AdditionalInformation: Clinical practice rarely accommodates the requirements of a rigorous numerical study, leading to assumptions that may adversely affect the numerical predictions. Thus, patient-specific flow measurements to be used as boundary conditions in blood flow predictions are often unavailable in clinical practice. In collaboration with two leading universities (EPFL-Lausanne, UPF-Barcelona) and Philips Medical Systems (contact: Clinical Scientist), we went through the challenges of measuring flow in the cerebral arteries of aneurysm patients, finding that assumptions made in absence of these do not affect significantly the intraneurysmal haemodynamics. The quality of the publishing Journal demonstrates the significance of these findings.

Title: New insight into the soot nanoparticles in a candle flame
AdditionalInformation: This paper, plus three pages of supplementary information, reports a new discovery on soot nanoparticles in a candle flame. All four well known carbon forms, diamond, graphitic, fullerenic and amorphous particles, are identified, suggesting a new nucleation mechanism for diamond growth and fullerene formation in a combustion synthesizing process. The use of anodic aluminium oxide films as collectors is innovative and able to capture particles at their original state, allowing a clearer, comprehensive understanding of formation mechanisms. This work was completed in collaboration with St. Andrews University, and has great scope for soot particle sampling in practical combustion devices.

Title: Flame colour characterization in the visible and infrared spectrum using a digital camera and image processing
AdditionalInformation: This novel study has laid the foundation for the quantitative and innovative application of a modern colour digital camera for combustion monitoring and diagnostics in a real combustor. It has been used in assisting Rolls Royce (contact details available) identify hidden flames, and can also detect nonlinear flame and acoustic wave coupling. The methodology secured the funding of an EPSRC grant for Sheffield (EP/G063044/1 - £517,239) and a further collaborative grant with Lancaster University (EP/K036750/1 - £487,000).

Title: High speed stereoscopic shadowgraph imaging and its digital 3D reconstruction
AdditionalInformation: This is a world first successful demonstration on digital 3D shadowgraph/schlieren imaging and reconstruction, which is a breakthrough due to the innovative hardware set up and the quantitative (in design) digital 3D reconstruction and analysis. The developed hardware set up is considerably more accurate and simpler than the previous attempts. It is expected to have significant impact on the investigation of complex flow, where the flow is transparent but with density gradient such as the shockwave system and combusting flows.

Title: Wall temperature measurements using a thermal imaging camera with temperature-dependent emissivity corrections
AdditionalInformation: The accurate temperature measurement by a thermal imaging camera is difficult; especially on materials whose emissivity is a strong function of temperature because a thermal imaging camera has to assume a constant emissivity in evaluating the measured signal. In this paper an iterative methodology between the emissivity and temperature has been applied for the first time to evaluate the wall temperature with significantly increased accuracy. In many situations the surface emissivity is a strong function of temperature. The methodology developed will provide a significant impact on the accurate measurement of temperature using a thermal imaging camera.

Title: Modelling rail steel microstructure and its effect on crack initiation
AdditionalInformation: Advancement of knowledge has been produced in this research through bringing together metallurgy, fracture mechanics and research on plastic strain. The modelling techniques developed have led to further research funded by the Korean Railroad Research Institute (R/127618), and a project funded by the UK Railway Safety and Standards Board (R/126076) studying the sensitivity of rail steel plastic flow to applied wheel loads. The combination of disciplines produced new understanding of how railway rail steel grade affects crack initiation and growth, and is supporting management of the UK rail network by Network Rail (contact: Principal Vehicle Track Dynamics Engineer).

Title: Modelling and full-scale trials to investigate fluid pressurisation of rolling contact fatigue cracks
AdditionalInformation: The research was funded by the Rail Safety & Standards Board (project reference T355) and conduced in collaboration with Corus, ensuring good transfer of the findings to industry (staff now at Network Rail: Principal Engineer, Track & Civils). The mechanism of crack growth assumed since the 1930s to be responsible for safety critical cracks in railway rails is shown to be unlikely to act in the majority of cases, and more realistic alternatives are suggested. The Japanese Rail Technical Research Institute have requested information on the experimental techniques to support their research in this area (contact details available).

Title: Rail rolling contact fatigue dependence on friction, predicted using fracture mechanics with a three-dimensional boundary element model
AdditionalInformation: This EPSRC funded PhD research is innovative in linking 3D models with faster 2D models, producing output which is comprehensive but fast enough to apply. International recognition of this research is demonstrated from its use by the Korean Rail Research Institute (R/127618) to develop a model for the Korean network, and an invitation to speak at the Japanese Rail Technical Research Institute (Tokyo 16th June 2009). In the UK the outputs are embedded in training on track design and asset management by Network Rail for engineers using their Track Ex vehicle-track interaction models (contact: Senior Vehicle Track Dynamics Engineer).

Title: Simulation study of thermally initiated rail defects
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit
AdditionalInformation: This research was undertaken in collaboration with London Underground, who funded the study, to find the cause of an increasingly common type of rail defect on metro lines worldwide (600 defects on 840km London Underground network in 2006). A multi-disciplinary approach combining mechanical and electrical engineering with metallurgy was taken, with validation against samples taken from the railway. The findings led London Underground to commission design of a revised rail cross-sectional profile to reduce incidence of these defects (contact: Principal Consultant, Interfleet), and were presented at an invited presentation to the Permanent Way Institution London branch (contact details available).

Title: Coupled-volume multi-scale modelling of quasi-brittle material
AdditionalInformation: An original and novel formulation of the multi-scale framework, based on fundamental consideration of interaction between scales,  that can finally “objectively represent softening phenomena” (Arch Comput Methods Eng (2011) 18:341–393) has led to further development of multi-scale strategies in the international community (Arch. Civ. Eng, 2012, LVIII, 3:331-361). This work has now been taken up not only in its core area of concrete mechanics, but also biomechanics (J Mech Beh Biomed Mat (2010) 3(2): 189-202) and geo-engineering (Int J  Num & Analit Method Geomech (2012), 36 (2): 140-165).

Title: Stress concentrations in fractured compact bone simulated with a special class of anisotropic gradient elasticity
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This paper is co-authored by experts in the fields of biomechanics (Kuhl, Stanford University) and generalised continua (Aifantis, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki). The paper bridges the gap between the two fields, for the special case of bone material. It led directly to a further EPSRC grant (EP/J003816/1) "Adaptive Gradient Elasticity and Mechanical Stimulation in Bone Remodelling".

Title: Gradient Elastic Stress Analysis for Anisotropic Bimaterial Interface with Arbitrarily Oriented Crack
AdditionalInformation: This novel paper develops and extends the multi-scale methodology to the class of anisotropic materials, and furthermore contributes to a non-trivial task of analysing arbitrary oriented cracks at material interfaces. Critically, this paper also bridges the gap between computational mechanics and biomechanics and offers recommendations to medical practitioners.

Title: Turbulence in transient channel flow
AdditionalInformation: The finding is of fundamental significance in fluid mechanics. It reveals the true nature of a transient turbulent flow, making a connection between a 'turbulent flow' and the 'laminar-turbulent transition'. This provides a new approach to the understanding/analyses/prediction of unsteady flows which are encountered in many practical systems. Noting that flow control often involves exploiting transient processes, the new understanding will provide an avenue for the improvement of existing methods and the development of new strategies. In addition, transient turbulent channel flows can now be viewed as a new category of bypass transition, a significant contribution to this important field.

Title: Wall shear stress in accelerating turbulent pipe flow
AdditionalInformation: The research was conducted in a major facility at Delft Hydraulics sponsored by EC-HYDRALAB (Contract 022441-R113, involving 7 countries) and EPSRC (EP/C015177/1). Focusing on a simple but informative, linearly accelerating flow allows us to reveal for the first time the three-stage development of wall shear and its relation to turbulence. This work provides the theoretical background (frozen turbulence in Stage 1) for J. Hydraul. Eng., 137, 606-610, 2011. The new hypothesis regarding eddy stretching under flow acceleration is a stepping-stone to a more radical concept of transient turbulent flow transition proposed in J. Fluid Mechanics, 715, 60-102, 2013.

Title: Assessment of performance of turbulence models in predicting supercritical pressure heat transfer in a vertical tube
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
AdditionalInformation: We have assessed and categorized representative models developed over the last two decades according to their ability to represent/capture important physics that we have identified. We demonstrated that indirect buoyancy effect is insignificant and hence its modelling can be simplified (contradicting conventional assumptions). The work provides valuable guidance for modellers, and was highlighted as one of 12 key publications in the field in Annual Review Fluid Mechanics 2013,45:495-525 (page520). The topic of supercritical fluid heat transfer is important to many emerging technologies, including new-generation nuclear reactors and supercritical CO2 air-condition systems.

Title: An experimental study of pulsating turbulent flow in a pipe
AdditionalInformation: This is the first time that 2-component measurements have been made for a pulsating pipe flow (except for a brief conference paper in 1990), providing experimental evidence on the different behaviours of the different turbulence components, and establishing the trends with which the mean and turbulent fields respond throughout the pipe section. Its impact is demonstrated by the fact that it is one of the top cited papers published in the Journal over the last five years (Journal’s official website, February-October 2013).

Title: Cointegration: a novel approach for the removal of environmental trends in structural health monitoring data
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: The paper addresses one of the major challenges preventing the transition of structural health monitoring from a research field into industrial practice with a novel application of a key advance in econometrics. It is the first application of cointegration in the field and later work has shown that the method outperforms previous approaches. The work, funded by EPSRC (EP/F035403/1) has led to invitations to give guest lectures at Los Alamos National Laboratory (contact: Engineering Institute Leader) and the National Physics Laboratory (contact details available) and the technique is now being used at UCSD (mdt@ucsd.edu) and AGH University of Krakow (staszews@agh.edu.pl).

Title: High-Speed Nonlinear Finite Element Analysis for Surgical Simulation Using Graphics Processing Units
AdditionalInformation: A new computational modelling paradigm for surgical simulation is introduced: use of Graphics Processing Units to accelerate FE computations. This allows real-time solution of nonlinear models, where previously only linear models could be accommodated. The former are essential for modelling soft tissues reliably, but previously were too computationally expensive. The work was also presented at the MICCAI 2007 conference (highest ranked in field), where it was runner-up for the Young Scientist Award. It led to development of an open-source software package, NiftySim, which has been downloaded more than 800 times from SourceForge.

Title: Fast free-form deformation using graphics processing units
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
AdditionalInformation: An efficient parallel formulation of a widely-used image registration algorithm and an accompanying computational paradigm (based on GPUs) are introduced. Compared with existing formulations, this framework allows registration in 10's of seconds, rather than 10's of minutes. Immediately, then, it makes powerful registration technology accessible in time-critical clinical situations, the most obvious example being surgery, where it can greatly improve minimally-invasive guidance and planning. It therefore solves a key obstacle in clinical translation of this fundamental tool. The work was accompanied by development of an open-source software package, NiftyReg, which has been downloaded more than 4300 times from SourceForge.

Title: MR to ultrasound registration for image-guided prostate interventions
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduced a new type of "model-to-image" registration algorithm which allows in vivo registration of intra-operative ultrasound with pre-operative MR images. Registration of these two modalities is notoriously difficult, and this work not only facilitates this but allows it to be done in real-time in the operating theatre. The latter point is crucial for promoting clinical translation of the technology, where it has the potential to greatly improve guidance of minimally invasive procedures. The work was also presented at MICCAI (top-ranked conference in field) in 2008, where the lead author received the Young Scientist Award.

Title: On modelling of anisotropic viscoelasticity for soft tissue simulation: Numerical solution and GPU execution
AdditionalInformation: An efficient solution method for viscoelastic materials within FE solvers and a high-performance computational approach based on GPUs were introduced. Viscoelastic models are essential for realistic simulation of soft tissues, but have previously been ignored in the surgical simulation community because of their associated computational cost, which prohibited real-time solution. The methods presented here allow incorporation of viscoelastic models with an additional computation time of ~5% over purely elastic models. Incorporated into our existing real-time solver framework, therefore, they allow simulation at interactive rates. The framework was also implemented within the widely used open-source "SOFA" framework to promote dissemination.

Title: Effect of sub-optimal neuromotor control on the hip joint load during level walking
AdditionalInformation: Since the seminal paper of Seireg and Arvikar (1973), muscle forces have always been predicted by assuming that the neuromuscular control works according to some optimality principle. While this assumption is confirmed in normal healthy individuals, it appears inadequate for subjects affected by various degrees of neuromuscular degradation. This paper investigates, for the first time in the biomechanics literature, how the neuromuscular degradation might overload the skeleton of a patient during apparently normal daily activities such as level walking. The NMS-PHYSIOME consortium is now building this probabilistic approach into one of the most popular modelling software packages worldwide, OpenSIM.

Title: Are spontaneous fractures possible? An example of clinical application for personalised, multiscale neuro-musculo-skeletal modelling
AdditionalInformation: This work falsifies, using stochastic multiscale modelling techniques, the clinical theory that spontaneous bone fractures are physically and physiologically impossible. The paper proves that spontaneous hip fractures are possible in patients with severe osteoporosis and significant neuromuscular degradation. The work generated significant interest in the clinical community, because it provides a possible explanation, using a probabilistic modelling framework, to those 5% of hip fractures that cannot be associated to any traumatic event. This paper was invited in association to the opening plenary lecture that Prof. Viceconti gave to the XXIII Congress of the International Society of Biomechanics in 2011.

Title: Subject-specific finite element models implementing a maximum principal strain criterion are able to estimate failure risk and fracture location on human femurs tested in vitro
AdditionalInformation: The definition of a reliable failure criterion for human bones remains an open challenge. In this paper we demonstrate, for fractures induced by articular loading over three cadaver preparations, that a strain-based criterion is significantly more accurate that stress based criteria, and can be reliably used to predict bone strength under such loading conditions. This paper was cited on average ten times per year since its publication. All our subsequent work on the prediction of the risk fracture in osteoporotic patients was made possible by this work, including the clinical trial being conducted as part of the VPHOP international project.

Title: A new hip epiphyseal prosthesis: Design revision driven by a validated numerical procedure
AdditionalInformation: This research output describes an experimental and numerical investigation that drove Stryker Corporation to a revision of a prototype hip implant they had under development. The original design was found to reduce by over 20% the femoral neck strength, with a considerable risk of post-operative bone fracture. The new design that emerged from this study produced no weakening of femoral strength, and other improvements; it is now commercialised as PER prosthesis (Stryker Orthopaedics, Hérouville-Saint-Clair, France. Contact: contact: President Directeur General). The methods used can be applied to virtually any other prosthetic design.

Title: Selective laser melting of Inconel 625 using pulse shaping
AdditionalInformation: Laser pulse shaping is a technique used by the laser welding industry to improve weld quality. This is the first research integrating pulse shape control into an Additive Manufacturing (AM) process for fabricating 3D metal parts. Results indicated that specific laser pulse energy distributions exerted additional control over melt pool formation and subsequent part properties, e.g. surface finish and minimum part resolution. This research won a Best Paper award at the Solid Freeform Fabrication symposium in Austin Texas 2008. This work provides a compelling case for the adoption of pulse shape control in standard laser based AM systems.

Title: Quantifying the degree of particle melt in Selective Laser Sintering®
AdditionalInformation: The research yielded a novel, quantifiable method to assess how much of the material had been melted by a laser and correlated the results with mechanical properties.  This method is expected to be adopted by industry (under ASTM standards committee F42) to provide more depth to Quality Assurance and thus de-risk application of laser sintering within manufacturing.  This is very timely as Additive Manufacturing progresses from a prototyping tool to a manufacturing process.  This new level of understanding has helped the researchers to secure industry funding to develop new materials for Laser Sintering under confidential research contracts and consultancy.

Title: Optimum sintering region for laser sintered nylon-12
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Establishes hitherto unknown thermal boundaries in Laser Sintering, confirming previous suppositions that nylon12 can degrade in the process, leading to the new term “stable sintering region” – redefining thermal boundaries for successful sintering.  Results from this work have been applied by the researchers to develop new materials for Laser Sintering under commercially funded research/consultancy leading to at least one new product.

Title: Fracture mechanics approach to compare laser sintered parts and injection mouldings of nylon-12
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper won the AM Strickland best paper prize 2011, and was the first paper investigating laser sintered part performance through fracture mechanics.  This approach best replicates product testing methods adopted by industry partner Burton Snowboards (contact details available) for snowboard bindings in a safety critical application.  Preceding research identified ductility as the key weakness of laser sintered parts compared with injection moulded counterparts. However, we show that in some instances laser sintered parts deliver superior mechanical performance to injection moulded parts from the same material. We identify the influence of section thickness in terms of resistance to fracture.

Title: A comparison of barefoot and sprint spike conditions in sprinting
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This work established the efficacy of personalised sports footwear by examining the extremes of barefoot versus shod performance in detail using motion capture analysis with elite athletes.  The results showed statistically significant effects of shod versus barefoot performance in terms of various angles of motion that are known to influence overall athletic performance.  The results confirmed the validity of tailoring sports footwear for elite athletes and led to project partner New Balance  (contact: Senior Manager, Innovation and Engineering) announcing that some of its elite team athletes now compete in laser sintered footwear - a direct consequence of this research.

Title: A spatiotemporal statistical atlas of motion for the quantification of abnormal myocardial tissue velocities
AdditionalInformation: Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is a treatment strategy in cardiac electrophysiology with <70% success rate and costs of over £15k per device, so effective patient selection is critical. This paper presents a novel image-based patient selection paradigm classifying myocardial contraction patterns using a spatio-temporal statistical atlas. The method integrates knowledge on the physiological mechanisms leading to myocardial asynchrony, which sets it apart from competing approaches. As a result the PhD thesis of the leading author received a Young Investigator Award from the European Society of Cardiology at EuroEcho2010.

Title: Effects of the Purkinje System and Cardiac Geometry on Biventricular Pacing: A Model Study
AdditionalInformation: For the first time we demonstrated the critical importance of incorporating the Purkinje network in predicting patient-specific cardiac electrophysiology at an organ level. The analysis was carried out in the context of cardiac resynchronization therapy. The work cemented the collaboration with the group of Ed Vigmond in the University of Calgary. The proposed conclusions led to the realization that current literature suffers from the lack of adequate models of the peripheral cardiac conduction system (which we contributed subsequently to) and therefore many of the previous studies were misleading.

Title: Efficient 3D Geometric and Zernike Moments Computation from Unstructured Surface Meshes
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
AdditionalInformation: Zernike moments are a key tool in computer vision with applications in object recognition and retrieval. A numerical acceleration is presented, which enables a 2-orders-of-magnitude speed-up of their calculation and is applicable to any object of any dimensionality. Subsequently, we applied it to morphology-based risk assessment of cerebral aneurysms and shape-based aneurysmal classification/retrieval (cf. IEEE Trans on Medical Imaging, 26(9):1270-82). The method is in the process of being transferred to a major medical imaging vendor (Philips Healthcare) through an industrial contract.

Title: Automated Detection of Regional Wall Motion Abnormalities Based on a Statistical Model Applied to Multislice Short-Axis Cardiac MR Images
AdditionalInformation: Understanding mycardial wall motion is fundamental to assess cardiac function in stress-induced ischemia and myocardial viability. These are critical in defining care paths of patients suspected of coronary artery disease. Research was carried out with key opinion leaders in cardiology at Leiden Medical Centre, Netherlands (contact: Professor of Cardiology, LUMC), where the method is now clinically used.

Title: The Effect of Sustained Compression on Oxygen Metabolic Transport in the Intervertebral Disc Decreases with Degenerative Changes
AdditionalInformation: This paper was developed within a large European project on intervertebral disc substitutes (NMP3-LA-2008-213904; 348,000 Euro). This research has shown for the first time the beneficial effect of mechanical loading in the nutrition of the intervertebral disc, thus demonstrating how the level of patient activity can prevent disc degeneration. This study led to another European project (MySpine FP7-ICT-2009-6-269909; 680,000 Euro) in which the author is coordinator. This paper saw press coverage in BBC News, ABC Newspaper (Spain), and Science Daily.

Title: Computational modelling of the mechanical environment of osteogenesis within a polylactic acid-calcium phosphate glass scaffold
AdditionalInformation: This paper quantified the magnitude of local strains and stresses in a real non-homogeneous scaffold. This enabled the determination of the real level of mechanical stimuli that cells are subjected to. The paper contributed significantly to the author's receipt of the Jean-Leray Award (European Society for Biomaterials, 2010), for outstanding research contributions to the field of biomaterials.

Title: A finite element study of mechanical stimuli in scaffolds for bone tissue engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper was supported by the European project SmartCaP (NMP 13912, 378k Euro) and was the first finite element study of a scaffold with heterogeneous architecture. It was shown that the local mechanical stimuli perceived by the cells attached onto the scaffold could be 100 to 1000 times higher than the macroscopic loading applied directly onto the scaffold.

Title: The influence of the scaffold design on the distribution of adhering cells after perfusion cell seeding
AdditionalInformation: In a collaboration with world leading rapid-prototype biomaterial group of Prof. Grijma (The Netherlands) and the world-leading tissue engineering lab of Prof. Martin (Switzerland), this paper explores the combined use of experimental in-vitro tests and numerical modelling to study cell adhesion in a new tissue engineering scaffold. This work was part of a large European project (STEPS 500465; 248k Euro) and led to a European Research Council Starting Grant (GA 258321; 1,492k Euro).

Title: Chamber and microfluidic probe for microperfusion of organotypic brain slices
AdditionalInformation: This work is the first microfluidic probe of brain tissue for neuroscience studies, increasing the use opportunity of application for MFP compared to call work. This research has since been duplicated by research labs at UIC and UCLA, USA and acknowledged by IBM-research in Zurich, Switzerland. At publication, it was featured in the research highlights of the 'Lab on a Chip' Journal, a top percentile journal for the field of Microfluidics. Since publication, the novelty of this research has been discussed in three further review papers.

Title: A hybrid WKB-Galerkin method applied to a piezoelectric sandwich plate vibration problem considering shear force effects
AdditionalInformation: Novel results were obtained in the area of analytical modelling of the dynamics of a piezoelectric sandwich plate considering shear forces (SF). The work took into account time variant damping, significant for civil and aerospace engineering, which has never been done before due to mathematical difficulties. These difficulties could not be resolved even by applying numerical or finite element (FE) software but were resolved here applying the novel analytical WKB–Galerkin method. The obtained closed-form solution can describe a variety of dynamic processes within milliseconds without the need for re-meshing typical for FE.

Title: An approach to calculate the J-integral by digital image correlation displacement field measurement
VolumeTitle: Fatigue & Fracture of Engineering Materials & Structures
AdditionalInformation: This work was a collaborative research project with the University of Cape Town, funded by EDF energy (contact: Engineer, Graphite Core Project Team). The research integrated digital image correlation and finite element analysis, so that nonlinear fracture properties (e.g. energy release rate) can be extracted directly from experiments.  It has been used as a tool in other projects including an EPSRC grant (EP/J019992/1) and an Oxford Martin School funded project (Improving nuclear materials for the next generation - James.Marrow@materials.ox.ac.uk).

Title: Experimental Continuation of Periodic Orbits through a Fold
AdditionalInformation: This paper presented the first known example of experimental continuation. It was highlighted in Physical Review Focus, spotlighting exceptional research: Phys. Rev. Focus 22, 1 (2008), DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevFocus.22.1. Other researchers have applied the approach to impact systems (DOI: 10.1016/j.jsv.2013.05.033) and rotor systems (Mathematics in Industry 2010, pp 169-174, ISBN: 978-3-642-12109-8).

Title: Applying the method of normal forms to second-order nonlinear vibration problems
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper derived a new normal form method for nonlinear differential equations. The approach described in the paper became a key component of a successful EPSRC Programme Grant application (Engineering Nonlinearity, EP/K003836/1).

Title: Rosenbrock-based algorithms and subcycling strategies for real-time nonlinear substructure testing
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to redefine a numerical integration algorithm for use with real-time substructure testing. It has been used to provide new test data for studies such as: Marsico, Tzanov, Wagg, Neild, & Krauskopf, Bifurcation analysis of a parametrically excited inclined cable close to two-to-one internal resonance, Journal of Sound and Vibration, 2011, Vol 330, pp 6023-6035. DOI: 10.1016/j.jsv.2011.07.027.

Title: Causality in real-time dynamic substructure testing
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduced a new conceptual framework for real-time dynamic substructure testing based on the use of bond graphs. It has been applied in both our own work on experimental testing and also by others interested in Robotics, e.g. Rad, Maties, Hancu, & Lapusan, Hardware-In-The-Loop (HIL) Simulation Used for Testing Actuation System of a 2-DOF Parallel Robot, Applied Mechanics and Materials, 162, 334-343. DOI: 10.4028/www.scientific.net/AMM.162.334.

Title: Turbulent burning rates of methane and methane-hydrogen mixtures
AdditionalInformation: This novel research presents an extensive database of measurements of premixed laminar and turbulent of hydrogen/methane mixtures for a range of fuel/air ratios. This work provides essential information for both utilisation of such fuels and their safe handling. The use of this data paves the way for improved explosion models for these fuels, as little information on this subject has been available up until now. The research was financed as part of a European Union programme (NATURALHY - www.naturalhy.net).

Title: Measurements of the Three-Dimensional Structure of Flames at Low Turbulence
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel laser scanning technique applied to expanding turbulent flames.  The flames are reconstructed in three dimensions which allows the surface densities to be obtained. This type of experiment is essential for interpreting the 2D data found in pre-existing literature and is of use to LES and DNS modellers.

Title: The turbulent burning velocity of iso-octane/air mixtures
AdditionalInformation: Improvements in high speed cameras has resulted in this paper which establishes a comprehensive database of turbulent burning velocities for iso-octane (a gasoline surrogate). Comparisons are made with existing correlations to demonstrate where they may be further developed. The raw data is supplied with the paper in order to enable modellers to make detailed comparisons which was not previously possible. It is envisaged that this work will be a valuable resource for the validation of internal combustion engine models.

Title: Metal foam regenerators; heat transfer and storage in porous metals
AdditionalInformation: This research investigates the potential of open pore metal foams as regenerators.  Their performance is benchmarked against ball bearing packed beds.  The foams were shown to be superior both in terms of heat transfer and pressure drop.  In this inter-disciplinary collaboration with the Department of Materials Science, the metal foams are both manufactured and tested by the authors offering the potential to design more effective heat exchangers in the future.  The paper is an invited feature paper for a focus issue.  The work is a result of Royal Society Grant for £15,000 (124028).

Title: The influence of alternative fuel composition on gas turbine ignition performance
AdditionalInformation: The paper proposes a novel model for predicting gas turbine ignition performance based on individual fuel components and their vapour pressures. The model permits selection of fuel components, producing an optimum ignition loop that is particularly interesting for the development of synthetic fuels. This unique work was part of a Shell Global Solutions funded PhD, and resulted in Rolls-Royce making additional data available to evaluate the model at sub-atmospheric conditions (contact: Corporate Specialist - Combustion). The developing model led to a further funded PhD for GTL with Qatar, RR, DLR, Texas A&M University in Qatar (contact details available).

Title: Development of a Chemical Reaction Mechanism for Alternative Aviation Fuels
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a full chemical reaction mechanism for the modelling of biodiesel/kerosene blends. Unlike earlier models, which replaced the long chain biodiesel component with a simpler molecule, the molecule was modelled at its real length. The mechanism was used at the core of a larger model by the EU Network of Excellence, BCATS, to produce a unique database of aircraft emissions. The work has resulted in studies to evaluate the environmental impact of alternative fuels, specifically: The reactivity of exhaust emissions (Wiesen@uni-wuppertal.de), local air quality around airports (contact details available) and global climate change (D.S.Lee@mmu.ac.uk).

Title: Development of an Apparatus for the Degradation of Aviation Gas Turbine Lubricants
AdditionalInformation: A new pilot scale simulator for aero-engine oil degradation is presented. Small scale test rigs are hampered by their ability to mimic engine conditions in terms of flow, temperature and bulk chemistry. This work, carried out in conjunction with Rolls-Royce, is significant as it offers the potential to representatively degrade oils at a fraction of the cost of running an engine (contact details available). This work led to a PhD and work within the EU funded programme, ELUBSYS on the development of inline condition monitoring of lubricant and the development of chemical kinetic models of oil degradation (contact details available).

Title: Room temperature preparation of conductive silver features using spin-coating and inkjet printing
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates, for the first time, how conductive silver features can be obtained at room temperature using an inkjet printer silver carboxylate solution. This work shows how flexible, polymeric, transparent substrates can now be used; most of these substrates require low processing temperatures. NeoDec BV, a Dutch company, was founded as a consequence of this research in this paper (http://neodec.nl/index2.html & contact: CTO) and patent applications are in process.

Title: Terahertz metamaterials fabricated by inkjet printing
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates, for the first time, that inkjet printing is a viable manufacturing route for producing split ring resonators (which are manufactured structures used to produce a pre-determined magnetic response in various types of meta-materials up to 200 terahertz). This paper illustrates the 'transformative', efficient and environmentally friendly nature of inkjet printing as a manufacturing technology since the number of process steps needed to fabricate an end product are reduced; the function of the inkjet printed device is comparable to one produced by conventional lithography.

Title: Enhanced reproducibility of inkjet printed organic thin film transistors based on solution processable polymer-small molecule blends
AdditionalInformation: This work contributes to the printed electronics discipline, by increasing the reliability of inkjet printed polymers. We showed that the undesirable phenomenon of 'coffee staining' could be reduced by optimising the process. The variability seen in a polymer thin film transistor (TFT) decreased from 65% to 25%, resulting in more reliable transistors.

Title: Streamwise-travelling waves of spanwise wall velocity for turbulent drag reduction
AdditionalInformation: This is a completely novel drag reduction technique which generalizes the more common spanwise oscillation method. The net energy saving, computed from the power used to move the wall, is much higher than presently used methods, i.e. the maximum being 23%. For the first time, drag increase has been shown to occur for a range of forcing parameters. Researchers funded by EPSRC (EP/G061556/1, led by Imperial College) and Airbus (contact: Head of Aeromechanics, EADS) have already used these ideas. This research also led to experiments by a group in Nottingham (Timothy.Jukes@nottingham.ac.uk).

Title: Evolution and instability of unsteady nonlinear streaks generated by free-stream vortical disturbances
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the first spatial secondary instability study of nonlinear streaks generated by physically realizable free-stream vortices, and has offered crucial support for two EPSRC grants (EP/I016015/1 EP/I033173/1). One of the authors (X. Wu) was invited to open the 6th AIAA Theoretical Fluid Mechanics Conference in Honolulu, Hawaii, in 2011 by presenting these results.

Title: Changes in turbulent dissipation in a channel flow with oscillating walls
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents key results of a novel approach to study the physical mechanism of active turbulent drag reduction. The work originated from a long-lasting international collaboration involving researchers in Japan, Italy, and France. Prior to this work, it was unclear how a sustained turbulent drag reduction could be achieved by large-scale sinusoidal wall oscillations along the spanwise direction, despite wide numerical and experimental attempts. For the first time, this research proves how the oscillating wall acts on the vorticity lines to transiently increase the turbulent dissipation, which results in a lower turbulent kinetic energy and therefore drag reduction.

Title: Turbulent drag reduction through rotating discs
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel turbulent drag reduction technique. For the first time, turbulent friction has been shown to reduce by imposing the rotation of flush-mounted discs. This represents a first crucial step toward the practical implementation of spanwise forcing, which has only been studied in theoretical simplified examples until now. EADS (contact: Head of Aeromechanics) has expressed their strong interest and now partially fund one PhD student working on a related problem.

Title: Enhanced vibrational energy harvesting using nonlinear stochastic resonance
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents novel work conducted on a little known phenomenon in engineering: stochastic resonance. The paper is the first to show that stochastic resonance can be harnessed to enhance dramatically the throughput of oscillatory energy from a source to a sink, particularly when the source is predominantly random. This has practical applications to energy harvesting from strongly random wind and sea-wave sources. A new collaboration with the University of Tokyo has been created because of this work on practical mechanisms to demonstrate it experimentally, and led to a Research Fellowship at the University of Tokyo in 2012 for Cartmell.

Title: An analytical model for the vibration of a composite plate containing an embedded periodic shape memory alloy structure
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a novel extension to the concept of antagonistic action of shape memory alloy elements. We use the method to decrease the time constant for cooling of active SMA elements fitted to a composite plate, with the result that the plate is more usefully controllable for vibration control. The layout of the SMA elements on the plate is also useful for the reduction of two dimensional plate vibration modes.  The work provides an analytical solution for the plate, based on a hybrid Wentsel-Kramers-Brillouin-Galerkin method, whose solutions in the time domain compare favourably with the results of numerical integration.

Title: The implementation of an automated method for solution term-tracking as a basis for symbolic computational dynamics
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first ever journal publication to discuss Symbolic Computational Dynamics as developed within my research group. Our work shows that there are intricate and hidden structures within the emerging mathematics of analytically solved problems in the domain of nonlinear dynamics. This information, if extracted and expressed by means of a visualisation tool, holds the key to understanding much of the internal behaviour of complicated nonlinear systems. The work is based on perturbation based solutions for problems in nonlinear dynamics (based on systems of ODEs or PDEs/BCs), which led to new industrial links with Ardes (Contact: Director, Ardes).

Title: Modifications to the response of a parametrically excited cantilever beam by means of smart active elements
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded the IMechE’s Water Arbitration prize for 2011.  In this paper we proposed an entirely new analytical model for the vibration of a vertically orientated glass epoxy composite cantilever beam into which shape memory alloy strips are integrated to control vibration. The paper shows for the first time that this is an effective way of modifying the violent effects of parametric instability, and is important because it clarifies a new and generic modelling procedure.

Title: An application of the Peano series expansion to predict sound propagation in materials with continuous pore stratification
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: A new, advanced theoretical model has been developed in collaboration with a leading French university and applied for the first time to explain the experimentally observed acoustic behaviour of porous media with continuous pore size stratification. Subsequently, this model has been used to develop a new method for the optimisation of pore size gradient to achieve unusually high acoustic absorption in a thin porous layer. These materials can be manufactured from recycled matter to reduce the amount of industrial waste and protect the environment from high levels of noise.

Title: The effect of continuous pore stratification on the acoustic absorption in open cell foams
AdditionalInformation: A highly novel method for producing porous media with continuous pore size stratification is developed. The impact of this work is three-fold: (i) for the first time has been possible to manufacture efficiently relatively thin porous layers with improved sound absorbing properties; (ii) it is now possible to understand how continuous pore size stratification affects the ability of these layers to absorb sound; (iii) this work led to the development and validation of an advanced theoretical model for predicting the acoustical properties of porous media with stratification.

Title: The intensity of the field generated by a point source and reflected from a rough surface
AdditionalInformation: This work has been applied in collaboration with Yorkshire Water Services (contact details available) to develop a range of novel, non-invasive acoustic instrumentation which has been tested in the field and protected by a patent application (W0/2012/117261). The paper is published in Russian and English to maximise the impact. The originality of this work is in the novel derivation for the acoustic intensity field generated by a point source in the presence of a statistically rough surface. The method is novel because it has no limitations in terms of the problem geometry or statistical properties describing the surface roughness.

Title: Attenuation and scattering of axisymmetrical modes in a fluid-filled round pipe with internally rough walls
VolumeTitle: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
AdditionalInformation: The effect of statistical wall roughness on the acoustic field in a pipe/borehole made of an elastic material is treated analytically for the first time. The impact of this work is that it is now possible to invert the wall roughness characteristics from the knowledge of the dispersion relations in a pipe. The results have helped to design novel instrumentation for the rapid acoustic characterisation of conditions in underground pipes. This work is now exploited by Acoustic Sensing Technology (UK) Limited (No. 08301004).

Title: Fracture mechanisms and failure analysis of carbon fibre/toughened epoxy composites subjected to compressive loading
AdditionalInformation: This work represents a unique success in achieving both improvement in failure strain of the nanomodified composite systems, and their compressive modulus and strength, through complex experimental optimisation of the interfaces on a nanometer level. Toughness and compression strength of advanced polymer composites are the key properties in design and prediction of modern aerospace structures.  In other reported work, one is usually achieved with the sacrifice of the other. This work has been funded and further applied by Cytec Engineered Materials (contact details available) who are currently investigating manufacturing potential of this new nano modified composite system.

Title: Impact damage characterisation of composite laminates using a statistical approach
AdditionalInformation: The results obtained here showed for the first time that the novel method of outlier analysis detected all types of complex failure modes in fibre-matrix composites with outstanding precision. Barely visible impact damage in composite materials has been difficult to identify using non-destructive analysis despite the numerous earlier studies. The thresholds from the acoustic data in this study were established using Monte Carlo analysis. This success has led EPSRC (CIMcomp feasibility study, Sheffield reference R136617) to fund the team’s revolutionary study into acoustic monitoring of automated composite manufacturing in-situ, before solidification, that has never been undertaken in the past.

Title: Characterisation of thermo-mechanical properties of MgO–Al2O3–SiO2 glass ceramic with different heat treatment temperatures
AdditionalInformation: In collaboration with Bristol and Alstom, this work found that crystallisation in high temperature glass ceramic materials was a function of the annealing temperature. Subsequently, the mechanical properties were significantly increased without any change in the composition of the material. Glass fibres produced at Bristol were crystallised into glass ceramic and used in polymer composites at Sheffield, resulting in much higher stiffness and damping coefficient compared to E-glass composites. The fibres are currently used to reinforce lightweight metallic alloys to achieve the properties required for the new generation aircraft (contact: Programme Manager - Materials & HV Technology, Alstom).

Title: Improvements in carbon fibre reinforced composites by inkjet printing of thermoplastic polymer patterns
AdditionalInformation: This is a revolutionary study into manufacturing a new type of self-healing toughened advanced composites, funded by Air Force Office of Scientific Research (randall.pollak@us.af.mil). A relative increase of up to 100% in fracture toughness and over 30% in shear modulus was observed by accurately depositing only 0.025% of selected thermoplastic polymers between carbon fibre composite plies using inkjet printing technique. The properties are preserved after thermal (self-healing) treatment leading to longer durability without parasitic weight. US Air Force continues to fund the research and the technology has received strong interest and support from Boeing (john.a.baumann@boeing.com) and BAE Systems (Brett.Hemingway@baesystems.com).

Title: Homotopy semi-numerical simulation of peristaltic flow of generalised Oldroyd-B fluids with slip effects
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This output presents a new way of simulating peristaltic flow by means of the Homotopy Analysis Method (HAM). It is relevant for performing parametric analyses in a non-invasive manner which are highly demanded by several sectors including clinicians. This work has led to an international collaboration with the Indian Institute of Technology. HAM demonstrated excellent convergence and stability characteristics and proved to be extremely versatile in simulating Oldroyd-B fluids with complex boundary conditions. This method now allows a more realistic and accurate simulation compared to previous Newtonian-only procedures, meaning that the influence of wall slip condition can be modelled effectively.

Title: Feasibility of using optical coherence tomography to study the influence of skin structure on finger friction
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the first successful attempt to bring together bio-imaging (using Optical Coherence Tomography) and tribology to provide a detailed understanding of the effect of skin structure on fingerpad friction (and hence grip) and establish methods to determine real area of skin contact for which no reliable method exists. This ground breaking research has formed the core of an EPSRC grant (EP/K009699/1, £800,000) in which imaging and friction measurement will be carried out simultaneously to obtain a dynamic assessment of skin strain (during sliding). Philips (contact: Chief Technologist) and Unilever (contact details available) are collaborators in this project.

Title: Analytical prediction of chatter stability for variable pitch and variable helix milling tools
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the first accurate model of milling chatter for variable helix tools, which have the potential for an order of magnitude increase in machining productivity. The research was funded by Sims's EPSRC Advanced Research Fellowship (GR/S49841/01). Mann's (Duke University, USA) research visit was funded by a National Science Foundation CAREER award. In addition to solving the stability problem, the manuscript was the first to show the existence of period-one (cyclic fold) bifurcations for this configuration of system. The work has led to an industrially co-funded EngD studentship (contact: Manufacturing Director).

Title: The benefits of Duffing-type nonlinearities and electrical optimisation of a mono-stable energy harvester under white Gaussian excitations
AdditionalInformation: This article was the first to show that non-linear energy harvesters could be smaller than linear harvesters. Energy harvesting has become an important research topic because of its relevance to autonomous systems, wireless sensor networks, wearable sensors, etc. The present contribution is one of the few studies that has combined complex analytical methods with experimental data in order to demonstrate the practical value of non-linear energy harvesting.

Title: Energy harvesting from the nonlinear oscillations of magnetic levitation
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded the Doak Prize for an Outstanding Journal Article (2013), and was the journal's 'top cited' article in 2012-13. It was the first journal paper to propose the advantages of nonlinear structures in the performance of kinetic energy harvesters, which led to follow on EPSRC funding with the Mobile Energy Harvesting Systems Project (EP/H020764/1). Sims was funded by an Advanced Research Fellowship (GR/S49841/01) and the visit from the international collaborator (Mann, Duke University, USA) was facilitated by a National Science Foundation CAREER Award.

Title: Optimisation of variable helix tool geometry for regenerative chatter mitigation
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This was the first research to develop optimised variable helix milling tools, based upon a validated model. The work was funded through an EPRSC Advanced Research Fellowship (GR/S49841/01). The study demonstrated a five-fold increase in chatter stability and machining productivity, and has led to an industrially co-funded EngD studentship with Technicut Ltd (contact: Manufacturing Director). This EngD research will aim to implement the novel design concepts on future Technicut products.

Title: Die shape optimisation for net-shape accuracy in metal forming using direct search and localised response surface methods
AdditionalInformation: Though widely used in many other engineering fields, there is little attempt in applying direct search based optimisation methods to improve product dimensional accuracy in large material deformation processes. Funded by EPSRC (EP/C004140/1 and EP/C004140/2), the paper develops a complete set of formulations and computational procedures of three direct search optimisation algorithms and a new localised response surface method especially tailored for material forming processes. The methodology developed can be applied in tool/die designs in precision metal forming manufacturing to enhance product quality for near net-shape production.

Title: Roller path design by tool compensation in multi-pass conventional spinning
AdditionalInformation: Process design and determination of process parameters are critical in manufacturing fault-free and dimensional accurate spun parts in metal spinning. A trial-and-error approach is not uncommon in industry for new spinning process development and production. This paper is devoted to the exploration of a tool compensation technique in designing roller path profiles and produces a comprehensive computational analysis and experimental validation on the effects of roller path profiles on spun part quality. The work was supported by a KTP with Metal Spinners Group Ltd (contact: Engineering Director).

Title: Evaluation of dual-axis fatigue testing of large wind turbine blades
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: In collaboration with the UK’s National Renewable Energy Centre (Narec), this paper provides the first rigorous computational evaluation of simultaneous, dual-axis testing method for accelerated fatigue testing of large-scale blades, a process that is essential in the rapidly developing and global wind industry. The work reveals the benefits and limitations of the method affecting how future large-scale blades will be tested (contact: Principal Wind Specialist).

Title: Prediction of Wind Turbine Gear Micropitting under Variable Load and Speed Conditions Using ISO/TR 15144-1: 2010
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: Premature gear and bearing failures in wind turbine gearboxes are emergent issues for the offshore industry. The effects of operational conditions on gear micropitting failure are not currently considered. Supported by EU FP7 ReliaWind (212966), collaboratively with leading companies including Gamesa, Alstom Power Systems (contact details available), ZF Wind Power and SKF, the theoretical assessment of gear micropitting risk is conducted using SCADA data measured from a WT in field operation. Two potential applications may be explored: implementing the developed method into SCADA systems to monitor/benchmark micropitting risk, and applying the findings of operational effects to improve future gearbox designs.

Title: Understanding the influence of surface roughness on the tribological interactions at the shoe-surface interface in tennis
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology
AdditionalInformation: This presents the first parametric study of roughness effects on tennis court friction and was one of a series of papers produced by an EPSRC Responsive Mode project (EP/G037922/1, £280k). The understanding gained led to the development of new biomechanically-informed assessment methodologies for tennis courts. The International Tennis Federation subsequently funded a PhD studentship on the development of a novel portable system for characterising tennis shoe-surface interactions (contact Executive Director, Science & Technical, ITF).

Title: Modelling of mixed damage on fibre reinforced composite laminates subjected to low velocity impact
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new model for simulating damage in composite structures. This is the first time that distinct damage modes have been integrated into a finite element method, interacting with each other in a progressive evolution. As a result of this novel research, the author was invited to deliver a lecture to Rolls-Royce plc (a.mcmillan@glyndwr.ac.uk) which led to a grant from the same company (FSC0149). The code was available to industry and individuals via website (http://jlcurielsosa.org/software.html), which was downloaded 16 times/month on average since its publication (stats from http://www.one.com).

Title: Delamination modelling of GLARE using the extended finite element method
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the outcomes of research conducted on computational fracture of composites using novel numerical techniques. This was the first time that the Extended Finite Element Method has been applied for replication of cracks on GLARE, which has led to seminar invitations at Imperial College (v.tagiarelly@imperial.ac.uk) and Swansea University (a.j.gil@swansea.ac.uk). This has generated further collaboration with some researchers (pedro-baiz@imperial.ac.uk). Additionally, this research has led to international collaboration with LaCaN, Barcelona (jose.munoz@upc.edu) and University of Parma (brigh@unipr.it). It has also contributed to chairing a mini-symposium at the leading European Conference in Computational Methods: ECCOMAS Vienna, 2012 (http://eccomas2012.conf.tuwien.ac.at/).

Title: Analysis of a continuum-based beam element in the framework of explicit-FEM
VolumeTitle: Finite Elements in Analysis and Design
AdditionalInformation: This research, in collaboration with Swansea University (a.j.gil@swansea.ac.uk) proposes for the first time a new finite element for solving structural analysis problems. This element has the capacity of contracting/expanding as required for the analysis, which remedies previous technical problems that caused inaccurate data readings. This work now provides engineers with a novel numerical feature to solve large scale problems dealing with structures. For instance, this element was integrated within finite element software at CIMNE (International Centre for Numerical Methods in Engineering, Barcelona, Spain. jose.munoz@upc.edu). The element can be applied in other disciplines such as Civil Engineering or Bioengineering.

Title: Effect of oil and water mixtures on adhesion in the wheel/rail contact
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit
AdditionalInformation: In collaboration with Arup (contact: Associate Director), we developed a new understanding of adhesion events in wheel/rail contact. These events are important because they can result in train collisions. Methods developed uniquely correlate with the limited full-scale adhesion data available, and as a result have been incorporated into Network Rail technical specifications and testing protocols (contact: Principal Engineer, Track & Civils) for products to mitigate low adhesion. Follow-on PhD projects funded by Network Rail and LBFoster have been set-up to continue the work. This paper was awarded the IMechE Part F John Jarrett Davis Best Journal Paper Prize in 2009.

Title: Experimental and numerical modelling of wheel-rail contact and wear
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the output from an international collaboration between tribologists and dynamic modellers to highlight deficiencies in wheel/rail contact modelling approaches used extensively in commercial software. As a result of the findings, PhD projects are running with LBFoster Friction Management (contact: Engineering Site Lead) and Network Rail (contact: Principal Engineer, Track & Civils) to improve modelling by taking account of friction management products applied to the wheel/rail contact and generate more appropriate friction and wear coefficient inputs. The paper was on the most downloaded in the last 90 days list for Wear in December 2011.

Title: Understanding the Friction Mechanisms Between the Human Finger and Flat Contacting Surfaces in Moist Conditions
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the first time the mechanisms leading to increased friction in a fingerpad/object contact with small amounts of moisture present have been brought together and modelled. The work now forms part of an EPSRC grant (EP/K009699/1, £800,000), collaborating with tissue engineers, dermatologists, and industrial support from Philips (contact: Chief Technologist) and Unilever (contact details available).
