The understanding gained in the paper can help in dealing with health issues such as bedsores and blisters, where increased friction is damaging, and skin disorders including eczema.

Title: The effect of normal force and roughness on friction in human finger contact
AdditionalInformation: This presents the first study of the combined effects of loading and roughness on finger friction. This led to collaboration with the Chief Technologist in Tribology and Human Tissue Interaction at Philips Research (contact details available) and the award of a Marie Curie IAPP EU grant (ref: 286174, £300k) to examine human tissue interactions with medical devices, using methodologies developed in this paper. It also led to the award of a responsive mode EPSRC grant (EP/K009699/1, £700k) that will use Optical Coherence Tomography to study friction of skin.

Title: Human finger contact with small, triangular ridged surfaces
AdditionalInformation: This presents a novel analytical model that includes the different mechanisms of friction for the contact in question. Collaboration with the Chief Technologist in Tribology and Human Tissue Interaction at Philips Research (contact details available) led to a Marie Curie IAPP EU grant (ref: 286174, £300k) to examine human tissue interactions with medical devices. It also led to the award of a responsive mode EPSRC grant (EP/K009699/1, £700k) that will use Optical Coherence Tomography to study friction of skin. The model developed in the paper will be used to benchmark an FE modelling impact case study in the EPSRC project.

Title: High speed wear testing of an abradable coating
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the output of research council (EP/H023895/1 - £100k) and industry sponsored research into aero-engine abradable linings (used on the insides of compressor and turbine casings). It is the first time that adhesion of material to the blade has been imaged during the rub process. Crucially, this shows wear and adhesion occur simultaneously – events previously thought independent. For the sponsor, Rolls-Royce, performance of abradable materials is critical to engine efficiency, as adhered material can break away and cause combustor blockages (contact: Surface Engineer). It led to further Rolls-Royce funded work (£75k) and a co-sponsored PhD studentship (£33k).

Title: Ultrasonic measurement of railway wheel hub-axle press-fit contact pressures
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit
AdditionalInformation: This key publication demonstrates the use of ultrasound as a tool for contact pressure measurement, a technique pioneered in Sheffield. It is the output of an international, industry funded collaboration, and represents the first time that the interface contact pressure distribution on a wheel-axle press-fit has been measured un-obtrusively, in-situ, on a full-scale component. The work was undertaken in collaboration with Valdunes, and provided boundary condition inputs to a design and simulation package for wheel-sets. This tool was used in project work aimed at reducing the weight of TGV wheel-sets by removing mass from the wheel web (contact: Technical Director).

Title: Influence of the Interfacial Pressure Distribution on Loosening of Bolted Joints
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates contact mechanics in static and dynamic bolted joints using non-intrusive techniques, and was supported by a Royal Society Research Grant (RG090369 - £15k). The techniques developed allow mapping of interface contact pressures and their response to vibration, and can be applied to a wide variety of bolted connections in a range of industrial sectors including aerospace, automotive and power generation. This work has led to a Rolls-Royce funded research project (£55k) and co-funded studentship (£33k), both investigating the effect of crimps on seizure in bolted connections in aero-engines (contact details available).

Title: Application of Fastsim with variable coefficient of friction using twin disc experimental measurements
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents the output from an international collaboration between tribologists and dynamic modellers (lead, Universitat Politecnica de Valencia anrocar@mcm.upv.es) to highlight deficiencies in wheel/rail contact modelling approaches (used extensively to determine contact and wear by commercial railway operators). The critical output was differences of over 100% in predicted force and rail wear when using modelling data appropriate for wet and lubricated conditions. This work has led to funded research projects with LB Foster Friction Management (contact: Managing Director) to improve this aspect along with friction and wear coefficient inputs to the models.

Title: The influence of laser hardening on wear in the valve and valve seat contact
AdditionalInformation: This work proved that laser hardening of valve seating faces, in lieu of traditional seat inserts, was a viable process for the manufacture of low volume diesel engines. The work led to Slatter being contracted to give on-going technical advice (£9890 to date) to Caterpillar (UK/USA) compact powertrain modelling group, the development of experimental projects with Hoganas (Sweden) concerning the performance of clad valve seats and technical contributions to the work of Markisches Werk Halver (Germany) who are using the work to model wear of cladded valves in their large marine compressed natural gas engines (all contact details available).

Title: The influence of cryogenic processing on wear on the impact wear resistance of low carbon steel and lamellar graphite cast iron
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrated the improvement in wear resistance of cryogenically treated ferrous metals. It was supported by a UK SME, Cryogenic Treatment Services, and the results are used to support the technical and marketing aspects of their business (contact details available). The promise shown by these results supported a studentship partly sponsored by Tata Steel (contact: Principal Scientist). The impact wear aspects of the work have led to collaboration with researchers at VTT (Finland) (contact: Senior Scientist, Materials Performance) considering modelling impact.

Title: Sports ball aerodynamics: A numerical study of the erratic motion of soccer balls
AdditionalInformation: This was the first time that a study of the erratic motion of a slowly rotating soccer ball had been carried out. The understanding gained led to the development of a novel surface pattern and panel construction of a soccer ball in collaboration with Umbro (contact details available). The ball was subsequently adopted for all FA Cup and England international home matches.

Title: iTRAQ Underestimation in Simple and Complex Mixtures: "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly"
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first attempt at quantifying the accuracy and precision of label-based techniques in proteomics. Although it was carried out on iTRAQ proteomics, the consequences could be felt far beyond (eg, TMT labels). Not only has it allowed the quantitative proteomics community to realise until-then unsuspected pitfalls of mass spectrometry-based proteomics but it has introduced a new method for assessing technical and computational developments by mixing complex proteomes and simple mixtures of identifiable proteins. This approach has now shaped the practice of proteomics.

Title: Systems biology meets synthetic biology: a case study of the metabolic effects of synthetic rewiring
AdditionalInformation: Synthetic biology publications have long focused on bottom-up, genetic circuitry and overlooked the broader problem of the interaction between synthetic circuits and chassis. This article is a seminal work addressing this issue in the example of a light-sensitive engineered strain of E. coli. We show that systems biology and quantitative proteomics can be combined to identify the metabolic pathways likely to be involved in the decrease of fitness in chassis organisms. This aspect of synthetic biology will be crucial in long-terms development, for engineered organisms to be resilient to contamination, for example (Synthetic Ecology).

Title: Functional heterogeneity and heritability in CHO cell populations
AdditionalInformation: The result of a collaboration between Sheffield and Lonza Biologics (AJR and RJY), involving two Industrial CASE postgraduates funded by the EPSRC (CSL), the BBSRC (RKG) and a postdoctoral researcher funded by both Lonza and Sheffield (SLD).  This was the first study to systematically determine how to harness acquired genetic heterogeneity within parental mammalian cell populations to isolate variants that are inherently more “fit-for-purpose” as cell factories.  The theoretical outcomes of this work led to the award of a EU FP7 grant “PM-Cell: High-Throughput Cell Phenotyping”, and patent application (WO1317387.8).  Lonza have provided further funding for another Industrial CASE studentship.

Title: Cell line specific control of polyethylenimine-mediated transient transfection optimized with "Design of experiments" methodology
AdditionalInformation: The result of collaborations between Sheffield and MedImmune (OD, RF) and Sheffield and Pall (PLL), combining the work of two Industrial CASE postgraduates funded by the EPSRC (BCT) and the BBSRC (CRJS).  This paper pioneered the use of “Design of Experiments” statistical modelling to optimise a rapid means of biopharmaceutical manufacturing based on transient gene expression, which is now used frequently by biomanufacturing companies. The core statistical modelling approach has been extended via a EU FP7 grant to develop a new high-throughput cellular analysis product that predicts cell bioprocess performance (patent application filed; WO1317387.8).

Title: A mechanistic understanding of production instability in CHO cell lines expressing recombinant monoclonal antibodies
AdditionalInformation: The result of a research project fully funded by Pfizer in the USA (KD).  This work addressed a fundamental issue underpinning development of biopharmaceutical manufacturing systems - long-term stability of recombinant protein production by mammalian cell factories.  Overturning the prevailing theory that recombinant gene silencing was primarily epigenetic, we showed that the major molecular mechanism of instability for Pfizer’s cell lines was recombinant gene deletion.  This work has underpinned new Sheffield Industrial CASE studentships with Pfizer and UCB on gene vector stability and synthetic gene promoter design respectively.

Title: Impact of gene vector design on the control of recombinant monoclonal antibody production by chinese hamster ovary cells
AdditionalInformation: A collaboration between Sheffield and Lonza Biologics (AJR, JR, RJY), which combined novel gene vector design with mathematical modelling of recombinant monoclonal antibody production to determine how the cell factory and recombinant gene vector interact to control biopharmaceutical production kinetics.  This work underpinned a further multidisciplinary grant from the BBSRC BRIC (BB/K011197/1) to develop genome-scale computational models for recombinant gene design, and an EPSRC Industrial CASE studentship with UCB on design of synthetic promoters for biopharmaceutical production.

Title: Using a multi-faceted approach to determine the changes in bacterial cell surface properties influenced by a biofilm lifestyle
AdditionalInformation: Biofilms are ubiquitous in environmental, industrial and pathogenic processes and can have both positive and negative impact on human society.  Traditionally research in this field focuses on the internal biological processes (e.g. gene expression) involved in biofilm formation but this paper combines this approach with the study of important and fundamental physiological changes at the cell surface.  This paper validates that surface modifications during biofilm formation occur (through the use of two model systems) and understanding these specific changes will be crucial in developing effective future biofilm control strategies.  Approach is now being applied in multi-institutional EPSRC grant (EP/I031812/1).

Title: Macromolecular Fingerprinting of Sulfolobus Species in Biofilm: A Transcriptomic and Proteomic Approach Combined with Spectroscopic Analysis
AdditionalInformation: Archaea are frequently detected in biofilm communities in a wide variety of environments however limited information is presently available describing biofilm formation in this domain of life.  This international collaboration between Sheffield and Germany is the first paper to take a systems biology approach to studying biofilms in three archaea and provides a framework for future systems biology research for biofilms.

Title: Mechanisms of Bacillus cereus biofilm formation: an investigation of the physicochemical characteristics of cell surfaces and extracellular proteins
AdditionalInformation: The paper has initiated new collaborations including the recently awarded multi-partner EU COST Action (FA1202) “A European Network for Mitigating Bacterial Colonisation and Persistence on Foods and Food Processing Environments”. Bacillus cereus biofilms can be detrimental to industrial processes, for example biofouling of processed foods and within the dairy industry.  The changes in cell surfaces and extracellular environment are studied here to identify early indicators of biofilm formation and hence opportunities for process control.  Techniques have been developed through EPSRC fellowship (EP/E053556/1).

Title: High CO2 solubility in ionic liquids and a tetraalkylammonium-based poly(ionic liquid)
AdditionalInformation: Poly(ionic liquid)s for enhanced CO2 capture, an area of increasing technological and global economic importance. A high throughput screening method using a few mg of material through to bench scale studies.  Capture-release kinetics as well as selectivity-activity correlations against molecular structure.  This paper is important as it shows a huge increase in absorption ability through task-specific molecular design.  Represents a new way of thinking for carbon capture with implications for advanced capture techniques.  Part of the work that underpinned the funding of the 4CU Programme Grant and FP7 SCOT funding (more than €10M combined).  Led to several Pleanries and Keynotes.

Title: Supported phosphine-free palladium catalysts for the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction in aqueous media
AdditionalInformation: Single batch reactive crystallisation procedure for the production of biaryl products using an essentially water-based solvent and purification system.  Uses polymer-supported palladium catalysts, water soluble boronic acids with a trace of toluene to produce the biaryls that crystallise the reaction proceeds. Two-step graded filtering process removes catalyst and recovers product.  Potentially important industrial process that almost completely removes organic solvents producing the product in 100% conversion and purity.  Small excess of boronic acid used to achieve complete conversion is recycled back to reactor. Led to several invited lectures and inspired 4CU Programme catalysis work package.

Title: Comparative study of solvent properties for carbon dioxide absorption
AdditionalInformation: Study of the effect of functional group on CO2 sorption.  Monoethanolamine is industry standard containing amine and alcohol functions.  It is shown that if each of these groups are used alone, efficiency decreases.  Amines are less effective than MEA, while alcohols are better when combined with ethers.  Important structure-property correlations that have led to new sorbent design.  This paper represents a study on the fundamental mechanisms of absorption allowing rational design of new materials.  Led to funding through 4CU and SCOT (over €10M) and a number of Plenaries and Keynote lectures and appointment to International Scientific Board of ICCDU.

Title: Measurement of vapour pressures of ionic liquids and other low vapour pressure solvents
AdditionalInformation: Shows ionic liquids have measurable vapours pressure at elevated temperatures encountered in CO2 desorption processes using IL sorbents.  Caused a stir in the community as ionic liquids had been considered as zero vapour pressure materials.  Follow-up addendum paper shows conclusive evidence of IL in vapour phase above 100 °C (http://www.rsc.org/suppdata/gc/b9/b904407h/addition.htm).  Very important paper that highlights engineering limitations for low molecular weight ILs due to potential vapour phase contamination if moderate temperatures are required.  Led to funding through 4CU and SCOT (over €10M) and a number of Plenaries and Keynote lectures and appointment to International Scientific Board of ICCDU.

Title: Evaporation dynamics of microbubbles
AdditionalInformation: Microbubble generation by fluidic oscillation was patented by Zimmerman and Tesar [WO2008053174] and awarded in major markets, with a followup patent on microbubble distillation from this paper (2012).  There are a range of applications for microbubbles and promise of nanobubbles by same/similar mechanism, particularly for biomedical applications.  The widespread potential is echoed the winning case for the 2010 Royal Society Innovation Award. A spinout company with rights to microbubble IP, Perlemax, was established January 2011.  The first license to the technology for wastewater aeration and microflotation was sold in February 2012.

Title: Microflotation performance for algal separation
AdditionalInformation: Featured in podcast by Scientific American about this application of microbubbles.  The podcast went "viral" on the internet, with over 100 pages of google reporting it.  With lab bench bubble column experiments on microalgae dewatering exceeding conventional techniques, promises that if it scales to industrial scales, the mechanism will cut energy and capital costs relative to conventional dissolved air flotation to a few percent by exploiting laminar flow regime separations for high efficiency.  Patent was filed [US-2013-0092626-A1]. Follow-on applications to microemulsion separations (2013) and yeast are in press.  Reported in plenary lecture at Algae World Europe (Munich, 2012) by Zimmerman.

Title: Hydrogen Production from Water Vapor Plasmolysis Using DBD-Corona Hybrid Reactor
AdditionalInformation: Research reported in this paper underpinned the plasma microreactors patent [WO/2010/079351].  Low power consumption and high yield of ozone was demonstrated with pilot scale studies with United Utilities on water purification and wastewater treatment, crucially with microbubble mediated dispersion. A spinout company with rights to plasma microreactor IP was established (2011).  Feasibility studies for industrial application to highly concentrated wastewater and industrial scale laundry for cleaning and disinfection have been passed, with pursuit of designing for mass production as part of ongoing licensing discussions.  Hydrogen yields from plasmolysis matching electrolysis are reported here for the first time.

Title: An inverse method for rheometry of power-law fluids
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated experimentally that power law fluids have a two step parameter estimation process, with the second step a variation of the classical Hagen-Poiseuille equation, which generalizes to shear-rich flow fields for the first time here.  The Economist and Chemical Processing published feature articles about this work, which promises online, continuous monitoring of rheometry in many process industries.  Study is a key elment for patent filed in 2012 with spinout company Rheometrix Microsystems set up in April 2012.  Applications in food processing (Mondalez), consumer products (GSK), and biomass derived bio-liquids are being pursued.

Title: Direct measurement of surface granular temperature in a high shear granulator
AdditionalInformation: There are two great particle technology challenges: particle motion and rate processes. The Kinetic Theory of Granular Flow is a very promising theoretical approach embedded within commercial CFD codes that addresses both challenges. However KTGF starts from an assumption that the local distribution of velocities is Gaussian and so can be described by a single parameter: granular temperature. This assumption is essentially un-tested under processing conditions. In this work we have developed and applied a technique that can be used under industrial conditions showing that the assumption is legitimate meaning CFD predictions can be tested and rate processes quantified.

Title: Simulating the early stage of high-shear granulation using a two-dimensional Monte-Carlo approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a major contribution to the extension of the Reactor Engineering paradigm to particle technology. It combines the development of a computational engine (2D Monte Carlo), with new fundamental kinetics (for nucleation) and painstaking 2-D (size and composition) experiments to show that it is possible to describe the evolution of particle properties. For the first time this is done without using measured "starting points" knowing feed properties and rate constants enables full description of dynamic and final properties. The work was sponsored and co-authored by Astra Zeneca and led to funded international collaborative work aimed at technology transfer.

Title: A Mechanistic Model for Amorphous Protein Aggregation of Immunoglobulin-like Domains
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper is a collaboration between two world-leading groups: Hounslow at Sheffield and Clarke at Cambridge; between chemical engineers and biological chemists. It shows how the quantitative, rate based approach of the engineers may be applied to reveal wholly-new quantitative and qualitative insights into a pressing biological problem: proteins aggregation. The paper delivers impact of two types: it demonstrates that this type of approach can deliver such insights and reveals specifically in this case that aggregation proceeds on multiple time-scales, one of which is extremely slow, that aggregates are in-fact soluble and that “nucleation” occurs when solubility is exceeded.

Title: A priori prediction of aggregation efficiency and rate constant for fluidized bed melt granulation
AdditionalInformation: In industry the engineering of solid-phase processes is much less advanced that that for their fluid-phase counterparts because we cannot predict behaviour of solids from first principles. This paper is the culmination of some 15 years work by our group showing that by means of analysis at multiple scales it is possible to develop such descriptions. The narrow impact of this work is that those in industry wishing to size or rate spray granulators may do so from first principles using only measurable physical properties. More broadly it shows that such an approach is possible for many systems.

Title: Direct numerical simulation of solid-liquid-gas three-phase flow: Fluid-solid interaction
AdditionalInformation: In wet granulation, it is important to properly control the wetting and nucleation processes to maintain the desired attributes of the final granules. This paper presents a new computer model to simulate the wetting and nucleation processes. This is the first model which can provide accurate solid-fluid interactions with wetting effect, where no such work can be found in the literature. The model developed helps understand the mechanism of the wetting and nucleation processes and estimate the penetration times during actual granulation in industry. This work based on this model was shortlisted for the UKPTF Young Researchers Award in 2012.

Title: Meso-scale coupling model of DEM and CIP for nucleation processes in wet granulation
AdditionalInformation: In wet granulation, it is important to control the wetting and nucleation processes. In this paper, a solid-fluid coupling model is presented for these processes. Important phenomena such as the capillary suction are taken into account, where no such model can be found in the literature. The model can directly evaluate the characteristics of actual granulation in industry such as the binder penetration times into both static and dynamic beds, which are important for process optimisation. This work is also tied in with the Knowledge Transfer Partnership between the University of Sheffield and Procter & Gamble in 2011 and 2012.

Title: A micromanipulation particle tester for agglomeration contact mechanism studies in a controlled environment
AdditionalInformation: To investigate the interactions between particles in industrial pressure agglomeration processes, a novel device called Micromanipulation Particle Tester (MPT) is introduced. The MPT makes it possible to bring two particles into contact to assess the occurring forces and contact zone development whilst controlling all important process parameters. Based on the results, the agglomeration product quality can be predicted using DEM (Discrete Element Method) without effortful trial and error type bulk material studies. Related award: "RSC-PTG Special Award for Innovative Application of the Chemical Sciences to Granulation Technology" at the 5th International Granulation Workshop by the Royal Society of Chemistry (2011).

Title: Blade-granule bed stress in a cylindrical high shear granulator: I-Online measurement and characterisation
AdditionalInformation: This paper highlights the development of a novel online telemetric impeller pressure sensor system in a high shear granulator (HSG) and mechanistic modelling of the blade-granule bed stress. A correction parameter was introduced to account for bed fluidisation. Knowledge of the stress is useful for studying granule growth kinetics and growth behaviour, ultimately to characterise granule properties. The model can be extended to HSGs of different designs and applied in HSG scale-up. Related awards: “Best Pharmaceutical Relevant Poster” at the 5th International Granulation Workshop by GlaxoSmithKline (2011), “Best Poster” at the 6th International Granulation Workshop by TTC (2013).

Title: Templated formation of giant polymer vesicles with controlled size distributions
AdditionalInformation: The effectiveness and future usage of polymer vesicles are closely linked to their size. In this transformative approach, a new combination of top-down (lithography) and bottom-up (microphase separation) was employed to demonstrate precise control over the size of the polymer vesicles formed through self-assembly. This work offers a new route to controlled vesicle fabrication whilst also providing experimental evidence for the vesicle fabrication process. This work appeared on the front cover of Nature Materials in June 2009.

Title: In Situ Imaging and Height Reconstruction of Phase Separation Processes in Polymer Blends during Spin Coating
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates for the first time a real-space, real-time imaging technique that enables accurate recording and topography reconstructions to be made during spin coating.  Spin coating is a widely used industrial process, especially in the semi-conductor industry where thin films of polymer are used as lithographic photo-resists. Spin-coating also has the potential to serve as a manufacturing method for polymer based electronics.  Furthermore the in-situ measurements facilitate the development and testing of fundamental polymer physics. As a result this paper has significant impact potential, enabling a greater understanding of both processing parameters and underlying physics.

Title: Directed phase separation of PFO:PS blends during spin-coating using feedback controlled in situ stroboscopic fluorescence microscopy
AdditionalInformation: Directed phase separation during spin-coating is used in the production of organic electronics and has potential to take lithographic techniques beyond the optical resolution limit.  This paper describes the use of real-time information to directly determine the composition fluctuations and therefore control the phase separation during spin-coating. This approach, utilising a fluorescent polymer allows for the image intensity to be mapped to composition. The techniques can be applied to many other systems, therefore, will facilitate a deeper understanding of phase separation in general. This work has the potential for far reaching impact for both device processing and fundamental polymer physics.

Title: A Burkholderia pseudomallei Toxin Inhibits Helicase Activity of Translation Factor eIF4A
AdditionalInformation: This work paves the way for the development of novel therapies to combat the bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei which infects millions of people across South East Asia and Northern Australia. Furthermore, many US military personnel who served in Vietnam have been infected by the bacterium. Melioidosis, is one of the top three causes of death by infectious disease in parts of South East Asia and arises from infection by the bacterium. Melioidosis is difficult to diagnose, hampering medical intervention. This paper was an international collaboration and describes how a toxin produced by the bacterium kills cells by preventing protein synthesis.

Title: Small CRISPR RNAs Guide Antiviral Defense in Prokaryotes
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes how the immune system of bacteria avert attacks from viruses/bacteriophage. This seminal paper identified a new kind of bacterial defence system based on small RNA molecules. A key feature of this immune system is a genomic locus of Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR). This pioneering paper has been central to recent rapid advances in further mechanistic and structural analysis of many CRISPR systems in world leading research groups over the last 4 years. CRISPRs provide a new mechanism for limiting the spread of antibiotic resistance and adapting economically important bacteria for resistance against multiple phages.

Title: Structural basis for CRISPR RNA-guided DNA recognition by Cascade
AdditionalInformation: The work presented in this manuscript offers fundamental new insight in key structural and mechanistic features of the CRISPR system. This study provides major progress in understanding the composition, structure and mechanism by which CRISPR-associated (Cas) protein complexes use guide RNAs to recognise invader DNA. This was an international collaboration and describes an integrated multidisciplinary analysis of the Cas-protein complex from Escherichia coli called Cascade, and gives the first insight into how DNA is recognized. CRISPRs provide a new mechanism for limiting the spread of antibiotic resistance and adapting economically important bacteria for resistance against multiple phages.

Title: RNA-guided complex from a bacterial immune system enhances target recognition through seed sequence interactions
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes new structural and mechanistic analysis of CRISPR/Cas system in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This pioneering paper was an international collaboration and has been central to the understanding of CRISPR systems in world leading research groups over the last few years. The comparison between distinct CRISPR associated complexes are used to explain differences between how these complexes interact with target nucleic acids. CRISPRs provide a new mechanism for limiting the spread of antibiotic resistance, adapting economically important bacteria for resistance against multiple phages and more recently applications in genome editing.

Title: Dynamic behaviour of sewage sludge incineration in a large-scale bubbling fluidised bed in relation to feeding-rate variations
AdditionalInformation: This paper is part of a series of 27 papers published on the mathematical modelling of the waste incineration by SUWIC. The work was funded by Yorkshire Water and addressed a seriously neglected area of scientific research resulting in fundamental understanding of the dynamic behaviour of sludge incineration in large scale bubbling fluidised bed incinerators in relation to feeding rate variation. The results obtained from the study are currently being used by the Yorkshire Water to formulate strategies for optimising operation and developing new control systems for UK’s sewage sludge incinerator plants operated by the Water Industry.

Title: Mathematical modelling of sewage sludge incineration in a bubbling fluidised bed with special consideration for thermally-thick fuel particles
AdditionalInformation: A comprehensive mathematical model was developed to simulate a large scale sewage sludge incinerator. The model assumes bed consists of a fast-gas phase, an emulsion phase and a fuel particle phase with specific consideration for thermally thick fuel particles. It also takes into account through-flow inside bubbles as well as floating and random movement of fuel particles inside bed. Model was validated using operational data from a sludge incinerator. The main deliverables from this research were in the form of a series of validated models that are currently being used by UK water industry as practical design and operational tools.

Title: Hydrogen production from molten metal gasification
AdditionalInformation: The main objective of study was to develop a novel biomass gasification technology which uses a liquid metal bath in a two stage process: i) superheated steam is injected into an iron/tin melt and metal oxides are formed with H2 released; ii) carbon is injected, oxide is reduced, and CO and CO2 are released. The study was considered to be highly successful since it resulted in a very significant breakthrough in developing a novel technology that is highly efficient in producing hydrogen. The syngas produced needs very little cleaning for further use as a feedstock in industrial processes.

Title: Developments to an existing city-wide district energy network - Part I: Identification of potential expansions using heat mapping
AdditionalInformation: Sheffield already has an award-winning district energy network, incorporating an extensive city-wide heat distribution network for low-carbon energy provision for local populations. Through an in-depth analysis of heat demand in the city, a range of existing and emerging heat sinks were identified using GIS mapping.  Several key ‘heat zones’ linking heat sources and sinks were identified. This study has already had a major impact on the establishment of a firm Strategic Policy for Sheffield City. Results are now being used by the Council to design next phase of district heating which aims to double the scale of Sheffield heating network.

Title: Analysis of two-phase contacting in a rotating spiral channel
AdditionalInformation: The rotating spiral contactor is a novel concept developed within the Department for which the University was granted a European patent (EP 1703970 B), and which has been demonstrated to offer significant potential for fluid separations at the micro-scale. It offers unique potential for compact, low inventory and rapid mass transfer operations, including potential for operation in a gravity-free environment. This paper develops an analytical theory that extends prediction of behaviour up to the larger mm scale. This has enabled production of an optimised prototype device, which is planned to lead to the first generation of practical devices.

Title: Dewatering of HIx solutions by pervaporation through Nafion® membranes
AdditionalInformation: Work done in the Department as part of a major EU funded project has demonstrated that dewatering membranes can significantly improve the efficiency of thermochemical cycles for hydrogen production. This paper identifies Nafion as a potentially suitable material for this operation and provides directly applicable design data. This includes provision of test data at under realistic temperatures and pressures. Significantly this is the first study to include the presence of iodine in significant concentrations.

Title: Development of a micro-channel contactor-separator for immiscible liquids
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents details of a new concept in micro-channel fluid contactor-separator. A prototype device is built and tested. The paper presents its basic design and operating characteristics and limitations, thus enabling its detailed consideration for application within micro-channel systems, including both micro-reactors or mass transfer operations.

Title: Flow simulation in a complex fluidics using three turbulence models and unstructured grids
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Numerical Methods for Heat & Fluid Flow
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents details of flow simulations within the multi-port symmetrical turn-up vortex amplifier, (STuVA), a novel design of fluidic vortex valve which forms the basis of patents granted to the University (US Patent 6,402,820-B, EP 1,042,708-B1). The valve has been adopted as a key safety feature in the South Korean Advanced Power Nuclear Reactor (APR1400), which is being marketed worldwide and the first of which are scheduled to start commercial operation in 2013 and 2014.

Title: Density−Viscosity Product of Small-Volume Ionic Liquid Samples Using Quartz Crystal Impedance Analysis
AdditionalInformation: Ionic liquids (ILs) are the modern alternative as environmentally friendly solvents for clean chemical processes. They are considered as “designer solvents” with a choice of >1 million simple ionic liquids, each of which requires bespoke synthesis.  Samples of potential liquids are expensive and the intellectual infrastructure to select and design them has not existed until this research.  This paper contains a unique demonstration of how important physical properties can be measured using only microlitres of IL using a simple quartz crystal impedance analysis technique. This will enable high-throughput microfluidic systems for characterizing ionic liquids allowing easier selection for engineering applications.

Title: Evaluation of a Microfluidic Device for the Electrochemical Determination of Halide Content in Ionic Liquids
AdditionalInformation: Ionic liquids (ILs) are the modern alternative as environmentally friendly solvents for clean chemical processes. They are considered as “designer solvents” with a choice of >1 million simple ionic liquids, each requiring bespoke synthesis.  Samples of potential liquids are expensive and techniques to measure their purity at an extremely small scale have not existed until this research. Microfluidics are used to examine halide impurities (commonly found in ILs following synthesis). The work demonstrates the ability to quantify low concentrations of halide, at microlitre scale, even in ILs not measurable using current bench scale methods.

Title: High temperature oxygen separation for the sulphur family of thermochemical cycles - Part II: Sulphur poisoning and membrane performance recovery
AdditionalInformation: High temperature solid oxide cells are important in modern low carbon energy schemes (fuel cells, high efficiency electrolytic hydrogen production from steam and co-electrolysis of CO2/steam to syngas). Poisoning by sulphur is a major practical problem. This work identifies the poisoning mechanism and demonstrates recovery of cell performance after reverse voltage pulses.  This suggests the important possibility of in-situ cleaning techniques for poisoned electrode cells which routinely degrade in performance during use.  This work formed the basis of a successful bid for an EPSRC Platform grant (£4.7m) on the conversion of CO2 to fuels.

Title: Performance analysis of a folding flow micromixer
AdditionalInformation: This work, conducted in conjunction with the world leading Dutch micro-fabrication company Micronit, demonstrates a uniquely efficient approach to the design and use of micromixing elements in microfluidic systems. The work was entirely conducted at our Laboratories. The paper has two authors from the company which paid for the filing of a Patent (US 20100067323, March 2010). The work led to a licence being awarded for the sale of our designs by the company (contact: Managing Director).

Title: The polymer physics and chemistry of microbial cell attachment and adhesion
AdditionalInformation: Demonstrating a major multidisciplinary approach to understanding the molecular mechanisms of bacterial attachment, this paper reports fundamental physics and chemistry aspects of how polymers on bacterial cell walls react to surfaces. An outcome of the Cell-Mineral Interfaces Platform Grant (EPSRC (GR/S72467/01(P) - £760K), drawing on expertise from Chemical and Civil Engineering, Chemistry, Physics and Biology it provides a significant advance in understanding as evidenced by the researchers in Australia and Italy as well as Stanford, Houston and others in the US who have cited this paper in their work as well as a number of follow-on studies of our own.

Title: Adhesive and conformational behaviour of mycolic acid monolayers
AdditionalInformation: While this study has advanced understanding of the process of biological pollution control in soil and groundwater, it is an example of how research in one field can be useful in others, having been used by three international groups studying the control of tuberculosis and one looking at technique development. An outcome of the Cell-Mineral Interfaces Platform Grant  (EPSRC (GR/S72467/01(P), £760K), it draws on expertise from Chemical and Civil Engineering, Chemistry, Physics and Biology to demonstrate how the mycolic acid component of the bacterial cell wall behaves when approaching a surface and thus how these bacteria “stick”.

Title: Characterization of the Cell Surface and Cell Wall Chemistry of Drinking Water Bacteria by Combining XPS, FTIR Spectroscopy, Modeling, and Potentiometric Titrations
AdditionalInformation: The control of bacteria in drinking water systems is vital to the provision of clean potable water throughout the world. Conventional bacteriological methods neither capture the true range of bacteria present, nor their effects. This study innovatively brought together a range of technologies to make a significant advance in understanding bacterial/environment interactions, as evidenced by the large number of groups (over 20) from the UK, Europe, China, US (Yale, Rutgers and others) Japan, India, Australia etc. who have used this as a reference in studies varying from biofilm control to biocolloids and even Li-ion battery technology.

Title: Inhibition of biogas production and biodegradability by substituted phenolic compounds in anaerobic sludge
AdditionalInformation: An outcome from EU framework grant (FP4 CRAFT - Recycling and use of waste from olive oil production – Value: £610,000), this study partnered 5 EU countries and a University Spin-out (Bethan Technology Ltd.) in a major investigation into the fate and control and destruction of recalcitrant phenolic waste compounds in anaerobic treatment. The work has continued both internationally (Europe and Malaysia) and within the group at Sheffield with studies on other phenolic containing organic wastes and has been used by research groups in China, South Africa, Sweden, Germany and Greece as a reference to their studies of recalcitrant wastes.

Title: Analysis of a pressure-driven folding flow microreactor with nearly plug-flow characteristics
AdditionalInformation: The capability of micro-structured channels to provide a high degree of fluid mixing allows the ideal of plug-flow reaction under complete thermal control to be realised.  The theoretical work presented quantifies the plug flow performance of a high-efficiency mixer geometry for isothermal first and second order chemical reaction.  The work is a key step toward the eventual full model of a microchannel reactor.  Micronit Microfluidics BV in partnership with Flowid BV have recently developed a microchannel reactor for fine chemistry and pharmaceutical applications based on this work.

Title: Experimental demonstration of rotating spiral microchannel distillation
AdditionalInformation: Before this paper was published this novel technology, counter-current flow of two fluid phases in a rotating spiral channel, appeared theoretically to have considerable potential for opening up many new areas of phase contacting separations.  This paper successfully demonstrated the generic new technology for the first time, using the specific case of distillation to do so.  The work gives considerable confidence that the theoretical promise is real.  As a consequence a full general modelling has now largely been completed and applied to the design of a generic research device currently producing high quality data which will guide commercial device development.

Title: Thermal conductivity measurement of liquids in a microfluidic device
AdditionalInformation: A major strand of work is directed to developing property characterisation methods for efficient exploration of the large number of possible ionic liquids that can be formulated.  This paper advances this objective of measuring a wide array of physical properties using a microfluidic platform to enable both rapid and automated measurement.  The paper develops a chip-based thermal conductivity measurement technique based on propagation and detection of a thermal wave and associated sample handling procedures.  These techniques have been incorporated in subsequent microfluidic measurement chips for multiple property measurements on a single sample.

Title: Small volume laboratory on a chip measurements incorporating the quartz crystal microbalance to measure the viscosity-density product of room temperature ionic liquids
AdditionalInformation: The work demonstrates the large reduction in analytical sample volume using a microfluidic platform.  In this case, the sample volume required for quartz crystal microbalance measurement of viscosity and density is reduced by an order of magnitude compared with current commercial devices.  Improvements associated with more rapid measurement and greater control of sample integrity are further advantages of the microfluidic platform, in this case avoiding contamination by water for the hygroscopic liquids considered.  This measurement has now been integrated into subsequent devices for multiple property measurement.

Title: Self-assembled autonomous runners and tumblers
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a new method to manufacture micron scale swimming devices based on self-assembly.  These devices have the potential to perform transport tasks in microfluidic devices and drug delivery in the body. The paper has been featured in a cover article in “The Engineer” magazine (June 2013) as an example of a novel application of self-assembly. The concepts developed in this paper were used in the case for support for my EPSRC CAF Fellowship (EP/J002402/1).

Title: Size dependence of the propulsion velocity for catalytic Janus-sphere swimmers
AdditionalInformation: This work provides an experimentally rigorous study of the effect of dimensions on propulsion velocity for swimming devices. As further miniaturisation of these devices will undoubtedly be a future goal to enable applications such as drug delivery, understanding the scaling of velocity and what determines it will shape the design of future devices.  A theoretical explanation of the observed scaling is also given, which has predictive powers for future experiments and so is receiving further attention in the academic literature.

Title: A cross-species quantitative proteomic study of salt adaptation in a halotolerant environmental isolate using15N metabolic labelling
AdditionalInformation: This was one of the first papers to illustrate that cross-species proteomics can be comprehensively performed using existing DNA databases and the first to apply an elemental constraint with isotopic labelling. A double salt tolerant strategy was proposed for the first time in an unsequenced cyanobacterium not seen before and was therefore printed in a special issue of Proteomics journal and was interviewed for a podcast.

Title: Quantitative proteomics analysis of BMS-214662 effects on CD34 positive cells from chronic myeloid leukaemia patients
AdditionalInformation: Despite breakthroughs in treatment of chronic myeloid leukaemia directed at the causative oncogene, the result has been remission rather than long term cure. A new generation of drugs that is instead targeted at the leukaemic stem cell show promise. This study identified the downstream drug targets of BMS-214662 in patient material using proteomic approaches and was the first to analyse cytoplasmic and nuclear fractions of stem cell populations from patients with chronic myeloid leukaemia. The data contributed to award of CRUK funding CRU3637 as listed in the International Cancer Research Portfolio.

Title: Evaluation of the salivary proteome as a surrogate tissue for systems biology approaches to understanding appetite
AdditionalInformation: This paper evaluated saliva as a source of biomarkers of appetite. There is an unmet need for a robust and cost effective method of appetite assessment. The findings indicate that saliva has potential to provide an objective and cost effective measure of appetite, replacing current tests: the Visual Analog Score, and blood analysis which are, by contrast, subjective and invasive respectively. This work was performed in collaboration with Cultech, (contact: Director).

Title: Growth kinetics of hydrogen sulfide oxidizing bacteria in corroded concrete from sewers
AdditionalInformation: Hydrogen sulphide induced concrete corrosion is a huge economical problem in many sewer networks worldwide and it is caused by bacteria. This paper presents the determination of the growth kinetics of these bacteria under conditions that mimic those found in the sewer systems. This provides a move towards dynamic modelling of the corrosion process giving the potential for prediction of corrosion and odour problems. This model is currently under development for catchment scale applications.

Title: Corrosion of concrete sewers—The kinetics of hydrogen sulfide oxidation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first conceptual model of the process of hydrogen sulphide induced concrete corrosion. It has been used directly in a consultancy project for Thames Water Utilities Ltd – details subject to confidentiality agreement.

Title: A solvation-based screening approach for metabolite arrays
AdditionalInformation: A proof-of-principle investigation that provides a major direction and sets the agenda for the development of a solvation-based analytical array approach in metabolomics. The approach can be developed to provide rapid, yet very informative data for a wide range of biological and biomedical diagnostic and prognostic applications, in a way currently not possible with existing methodologies.

Title: A simple, reproducible and sensitive spectrophotometric method to estimate microalgal lipids
AdditionalInformation: This article introduces an innovative method to determine total lipids in microalgae that is very sensitive and more reproducible than existing techniques, especially with respect to determining lipids in microalgae with recalcitrant cell walls. It is directly applicable in the area of biofuel production from microalgae. The work led to a further publication (Analytica Chimica Acta, 2013, 776, 31-40) and in combination with other publications by the group led to a transnational (UK and India) collaborative BBSRC grant (BB/K020633/1) involving 3 UK and 2 Indian Institutes.

Title: Subsurface Biomolecular Imaging of Streptomyces coelicolor Using Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry
AdditionalInformation: First demonstration of 3D SIMS imaging to microbial systems - a major development enabling intracellular dynamics in microbes to be investigated in a novel way, potentially leading to discoveries. This article was found to be “One of the first papers to describe the application of SIMS–TOF imaging to the study of microorganisms in a way that allows some intact molecules to be observed. This is an important milestone for SIMS IMS in microbiology.” (Nature Reviews Microbiology (2011), 9, 683-694). The work contributed to invited talks (Advanced Metabolic Profiling ’11, System Biology Europe ’12) and an EPSRC grant (EP/I03453X/1).

Title: Explanatory multivariate analysis of ToF-SIMS spectra for the discrimination of bacterial isolates
AdditionalInformation: This is a technical work that demonstrates how multivariate analysis can be combined with SIMS to extract information relevant to bacterial classification with potential applications in bacterial taxonomy and biomedical fields/clinics. It demonstrates the utility of genetic algorithms in the field for the first time. The work contributed to invited talks (Advanced Metabolic Profiling ’11, System Biology Europe ’12) and an EPSRC grant (EP/I03453X/1).

Title: Depletion of PCBM at the Cathode Interface in P3HT/PCBM Thin Films as Quantified via Neutron Reflectivity Measurements
AdditionalInformation: We explained why the efficiency of the most common type of polymer solar cell is improved upon annealing, i.e. annealing increases the concentration of PCBM (the electron acceptor) at the cathode, therefore enhancing electron conduction. This work had significant impact upon the rapidly expanding organic photovoltaic research community and the wider renewable energy community. Our results provided the true mechanism for efficiency improvement upon annealing, contrary to the widely assumed mechanism of enhanced phase separation. Furthermore, we did this experiment using neutron scattering a technique not widely used by this community prior to this publication which has since become commonplace.

Title: The development of nanoscale morphology in polymer:fullerene photovoltaic blends during solvent casting
AdditionalInformation: We developed a world leading experimental setup to enable dynamic observation of nano-scale structure development in organic photovoltaic films in situ during the fabrication process. By combining two powerful measurement techniques simultaneously (x-ray scattering and ellipsometry) we were able to further understanding of the nanoscale structure formation crucial to polymer solar cell performance. This paper has been of great interest to the very large and very active organic photovoltaic research community because controlling nanoscale structure formation will be critical for future commercialisation of organic solar cells. It also attracted considerable media attention. BBC Radio 4 Materials today : http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00t9r4g

Title: Nanoscale Phase Separation of P3HT PCBM Thick Films As Measured by Small-Angle X-ray Scattering
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides rigorous experimental evidence that the widely held 2 phase model of bulk hetero-junction solar cells cannot be applied to the material system most commonly used to make organic photovoltaics. We were amongst the first groups in the world to demonstrate this. We proved that the system is more complicated than first perceived, consisting of a 3 (rather than 2) phase system including an intimately intermixed region. This paper has been cited by many leaders in the semiconducting polymer field such as Sir Richard Friend. This knowledge will help facilitate future performance improvements in polymer solar cells.

Title: A Phase Diagram of the P3HT:PCBM Organic Photovoltaic System: Implications for Device Processing and Performance
AdditionalInformation: This work was amongst the first systematic attempts to understand the scientific relationship between the thermal properties of the materials commonly used in organic solar cells, the processes used during the fabrication of devices and ultimately the device performance. It sets a precedent for how to characterise new polymer materials which are being developed. Deeper understanding of the material properties which determine the final device performance will ultimately lead to the production of higher efficiency polymer based devices which could revolutionise the solar cell market. Since 2010 organic solar cells have doubled in efficiency from ~5% to ~10%.

Title: Further developments towards a genome-scale metabolic model of yeast
AdditionalInformation: The yeast S. cerevisiae is an important organism in Industrial Biotechnology for the production of fine chemicals and biopharmaceuticals. In previous work we established an internationally-agreed model of yeast metabolism. This paper extends that model to capture metabolic pathways that synthesise precursors (terpenoids and fatty acids) of high-value chemicals. Hundreds of new reactions are added and errors corrected. The model outperforms all earlier models in benchmark simulations. The model is being used to guide the rational metabolic engineering of yeast cell factories with sufficiently high chemical precursor yields for Industrial Biotechnology to be economically viable for the chemical industry.

Title: Thermal Stability of Thaumatin-Like Protein, Chitinase, and Invertase Isolated from Sauvignon blanc and Semillon Juice and Their Role in Haze Formation in Wine
VolumeTitle: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
AdditionalInformation: This research identified the protein responsible for haze formation in white wine (chitinase). Wine hazes devalue wine and there is a significant cost associated with existing methods of protein removal. Differential scanning calorimetry was used to identify the thermally unstable protein and the thermodynamics where used to predict haze formation in whites at different temperatures. The finding is industrially important as it enables future research to focus on eliminating the haze-forming protein rather than all proteins as was previously the case. A new process using flash pasteurisation of grape juice has been developed based on the findings of this paper.

Title: Characterization of Low-Frequency Modes in Aqueous Peptides Using Far-Infrared Spectroscopy and Molecular Dynamics Simulation
VolumeTitle: The Journal of Physical Chemistry A
AdditionalInformation: Far-infrared spectroscopy is a powerful yet underutilised analytical technique mainly due to a lack of the knowledge required to enable interpretation of the spectra. This paper combined experimental work using a powerful synchrotron light source and molecular dynamic simulation to interpret the spectra of synthetic peptides. Both ab initio simulation of the infrared spectrum and vibrational density of states were used to confirm peak allocation to the secondary structure of the synthetic peptides studied. This technique is now available to the scientific community as an option for studying peptide structures.

Title: Thermodynamics of Grape and Wine Tannin Interaction with Polyproline: Implications for Red Wine Astringency
VolumeTitle: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
AdditionalInformation: This paper studied the molecular basis to astringency using isothermal titration calorimetry. Astringency is the dry mouth-feel associated with red wines and is currently assessed by sensory panels. This research showed that tannin binding to polyproline was a combination of hydrophobic interaction and hydrogen bonding, and that these interactions changed as wine matures and the tannins become more complex. This work supports the development of a binding assay as a measure of astringency for use as a quality indicator for wineries and wine importers. Put simply this will enable manufacturers and importers to supply wines of a consistently high quality.

Title: Terahertz and far infrared Spectroscopy of alanine-rich peptides having variable ellipticity
AdditionalInformation: The importance of this paper is that it confirmed the discovery of an extended hydration layer (>10Å) around polypeptides. The original discovery of the extended hydration layer was highly controversial and seemingly contradicted the findings of neutron and X-ray scattering studies. This study used terahertz time domain spectroscopy which is a more accessible technology than the earlier work with p-germanium lasers and should lead to further research into this phenomenon that was previously impractical. The extended hydration layer may play a pivotal role in interactions such as drug – drug target interactions and this understanding help in drug design.

Title: Physical and functional interactions between human mitochondrial single-stranded DNA-binding protein and tumour suppressor p53
AdditionalInformation: Tumour suppressor p53, a predominantly nuclear protein, is the most important protein in cellular regulation and a therapeutic target for cancer therapy. The protein is inactivated in some 50% of human cancers. A novel protein-binding partner (HmtSSB) of p53 in mitochondria was identified in this report. HmtSSB enhances the intrinsic 3'-5' exonuclease activity of p53, particularly in hydrolysing 8-oxodG present at the 3'-end of DNA. This suggested p53’s involvement in DNA repair within mitochondria during oxidative stress. This new functional role of p53 in mitochondria was reported the first time.

Title: Preparation of controlled porosity carbon aerogels for energy storage in rechargeable lithium oxygen batteries
AdditionalInformation: Li/O2 batteries will revolutionise the transport market because they possess energy densities over an order of magnitude greater than existing Li-ion technology.  The lithium oxidation reaction at the negative electrode is a three-phase reaction that is extremely complex to engineer.  The cells are based on a series of controlled porosity, highly conductive carbons from phenol-resorcinol resins and for the first time show an unequivocal relationship between the discharge capacity of the batteries and the mesopore volume of the carbons.  The carbons are more electrochemically stable than other carbons previously studied and have become the subject of further investigations internationally.

Title: Effect of activated carbon xerogel pore size on the capacitance performance of ionic liquid electrolytes
AdditionalInformation: Perhaps the Holy Grail of energy storage is to develop supercapacitors with an energy density approaching that of batteries.  This is because supercapacitors recharge in seconds and have cycle lives of over 10^6 (c.f. hours and 10^3 for batteries). Our strategy is to increase operating voltage (V) and intrinsic capacitance (C), E=1/2 C V^2. Ionic liquid based supercapacitors operate at higher cell voltages than commercially available devices. This paper is important not only because we demonstrate how to engineer pore architectures that optimise capacitance performance but also because we elucidate the mechanism why pore size is fundamental to performance.

Title: Towards an objective method to compare energy storage technologies: development and validation of a model to determine the upper boundary of revenue available from electrical price arbitrage
AdditionalInformation: Two of the main barriers to the widespread deployment of energy storage onto electrical grids are technology selection and to determine the potential income that can be gained.  This was the first paper to calculate an upper bound on revenues available on electrical spot markets through arbitrage.  The paper is based on UK historical data and is able to compare incomes from storage technologies of varying round-trip efficiency, self-discharge, size (MWh) and power rating (MW).  It is demonstrated that revenues are strongly dependant on mean electrical prices.  The model can also use artificial data reflecting different future energy generating scenarios.

Title: Interfacial Immobilization of Monoclonal Antibody and Detection of Human Prostate-Specific Antigen
AdditionalInformation: This paper has shown the best condition to adsorb antibodies to the surface for maximum antigen binding. The specific recognition between antibody and antigen is promising in many biomedical and biotechnological applications. However, most of the applications were limited by the low antigen binding efficiencies to surface-immobilized antibodies due to their improper surface orientation and packing density. This paper optimised the surface orientation, packing density and stability of the adsorbed antibodies for improved antigen detection. It provides important information for improving the biosensor performances hence improves the sensitivity of diagnosis such as the early detection of prostate cancer.

Title: Distribution nucleation: Quantifying liquid distribution on the particle surface using the dimensionless particle coating number
AdditionalInformation: Fluidised bed granulation is a difficult process to design and operate, due in large part to the lack of understanding of the process of granule formation and growth.  This paper focusses on granule nucleation, and defines the steps of distribution nucleation.  A new parameter (the particle coating number) is derived to predict particle coating, and is validated experimentally.  Using this parameter, the particle fractional coating can be predicted using simple known operating parameters.  This parameter has great potential to improve the modelling and design of fluidised bed coating and granulation processes.

Title: Active coke: Carbonaceous materials as catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrates a novel process and new class of catalysts for the dehydrogenation of alkanes: a major industrial process related to the production of polymers. It also forms the basis of a patent application (WO/2010/14000) in conjunction with Johnson Matthey Catalysts (JM). The new catalyst and process identified allows for the reaction to be run for longer times, at higher throughputs and with greater selectivity. These act to reduce the energy requirements, carbon emissions, waste-product generation and operating costs, thereby improving overall process sustainability. Additional research on this process is currently being pursued with JM (contact: Scientific Consultant).

Title: Solvent effects in the hydrogenation of 2-butanone
AdditionalInformation: Heterogeneous catalysis contributes to >35 % of global GDP, with liquid-phase reactions becoming of increasing importance due to the processing of bio- and renewable resources. Despite this, solvent selection for such systems remains a largely empirical process. This work employs a multi-disciplinary approach in order to elucidate the origins of observed solvent effects. It is shown that mass transfer, chemical and physical effects, in particular the structural dynamics of the solvent, can directly impact on catalytic performance. This allows for a more judicious approach to solvent selection, including the design of tailored solvents for individual processes, thereby improving catalytic performance.

Title: Treatment of Spent Pot-lining with Aluminum Anodizing Wastewaters: Selective Precipitation of Aluminum and Fluoride as an Aluminum Hydroxyfluoride Hydrate Product
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents, for the first time, the sustainable co-processing of SPL with etching wastes to recover AlF2OH for AlF3 production and reuse in aluminium smelting. This can save up to 66% of fluoride in AlF3 manufacture, which uses CaF2, an EU named critical material, as the source of fluoride. Aluminium and fluoride from three waste streams are recovered as a feedstock for the aluminium industry, without high temperatures or net input of chemicals. This has led to the Australian Research Council project LP100100165 with Fluorsid, a world-leading AlF3 producer, and the material recovery approach used in NERC grant NE/K015648/1.

Title: iTRAQ Identification of Candidate Serum Biomarkers Associated with Metastatic Progression of Human Prostate Cancer
AdditionalInformation: Prostate cancer is the most common malignancy in males in the Western world, and second most common cancer related death. Early diagnosis is essential to achieve cure. Many clinically insignificant cancers are over-detected and over-treated, hence the search for novel biomarkers. Protein biomarkers in serum are ideal for diagnosis. This proteomics-led paper employs our leading edge quantitative proteomics tools and analysis to elucidate new prostate cancer development pathways, and potential disease aggressiveness biomarkers for further evaluation and clinical testing. This is a strong collaboration with the Sheffield Medical School and colleagues in Oxford, Birmingham, London and Switzerland.

Title: Change of Carbon Source Causes Dramatic Effects in the Phospho-Proteome of the Archaeon Sulfolobus solfataricus
AdditionalInformation: Using a mass spectrometry proteomics technique developed for another purpose we dramatically recast understanding of the ubiquity and role of protein phosphorylation in the Archaea. Using our approach, we expand the known landscape of protein phosphorylation in all Archaea by 8 fold. Furthermore, this approach revealed a strong preference for phospho-tyrosine of >50%, where <10% be expected from the literature. This, coupled with the dramatic impact of carbon-source changes on the phoisphoproteome, fundamentally changes the understanding of phosphorylation in the Archaea. This collaboration with two German labs has led to 2 follow-up papers and two major grant applications.

Title: Inverse metabolic engineering to improve Escherichia coli as an N-glycosylation host
AdditionalInformation: We demonstrate, for the first time, that inverse metabolic engineering coupled with our quantitative proteomics workflow can improve glycosylation titre and efficiency of proteins in vivo in the biotechnology workhorse, Escherichia coli. This paper is highlighted in Biotechnology and Bioengineering as of special importance because glycosylated therapeutic protein manufacture is normally done in expensive and challenging animal cells. This work offers a potential cheaper and rapid solution to industry and led directly to follow-up BBSRC funding from the Bioprocess Research Industry Club (BB/K011200/1), which seeks “to help manufacture the drugs of the future”.

Title: Engineering a non-native hydrogen production pathway into Escherichia coli via a cyanobacterial [NiFe] hydrogenase
AdditionalInformation: Part of a wider set of hydrogen-related papers, this industrially funded work demonstrates transfer of a Nickel-Iron hydrogenase from a photosynthetic organism into the industrial workhorse Escherichia coli. This class of hydrogenase is less oxygen sensitive than many hydrogenases and offers potential for a substantial contribution to the hydrogen economy. We demonstrate this process adds parallel capability to E.coli, thus generating more hydrogen. This opens up the possibility of E. coli becoming a commercially efficient and effective economic hydrogen biofuels producer.

Title: In Situ Studies of Phase Separation and Crystallization Directed by Marangoni Instabilities During Spin-Coating
AdditionalInformation: This is the first real space in-situ study of crystallisation in polymer thin films during spin-coating. Moreover it shows that for a blend of amorphous and crystalline polymers phase separation and crystallisation are not linked, as was previously thought. The high degree of conjugation in many organic electronic materials results in a high degree of crystallinity with crystallinity closely linked to conductivity and device performance. This study helps in our understanding of the interplay between material processing steps and the resulting crystallisation allowing for informed decisions about solution processing of organic electronics leading to greater device efficiencies.

Title: Ether-Bond-Containing Ionic Liquids as Supercapacitor Electrolytes
VolumeTitle: The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters
AdditionalInformation: The selection of a suitable ionic liquid (IL) for a supercapacitor electrolyte has never been subjected to a rational selection or molecular design process.  Here we identify a highly promising, if not essential, feature of ILs, the presence of ether bonds within their structure.  We demonstrate explicitly that ether-bond containing ionic liquids can exhibit intrinsic capacitances double that of their alkyl chain equivalents.  Subsequent experiments based on these ILs (as yet unpublished) suggest that we have reached the energy density of Pb acid batteries.  This represents a major development in this area and will excite considerable interest.

Title: Does Impurity-Induced Step-Bunching Invalidate Key Assumptions of the Cabrera−Vermilyea Model?
AdditionalInformation: It was shown that the mechanism of recovery by activation of elementary step motion assumed by Cabrera and Vermilyea (C-V) is not applicable to a diverse set of common and technologically important crystal systems. A general condition that must be met for a crystal-impurity system to behave according to the C-V predictions was proposed. Understanding of these issues will likely be a pivotal prerequsite for controlling structural and compositional uniformity during crystallization of a wide range of materials such as nonlinear optical crystals, pharmaceuticals, and proteins where the crystal perfection and purity are of paramount importance.

Title: Phase Transformations of Glutamic Acid and Its Decomposition Products
AdditionalInformation: It has been shown for the first time that widely disputed claim that solid-solid phase transformation of metastable to stable phase of this kind of amino acid is incorrect. Solid-state transformation of alpha to beta polymorph was observed at temperatures above 140 degrees °C, together with, in sequence, cyclization to pyroglutamic acid and polymerization to polyglutamic acid. The former three phenomena are critical to the thermal stability of L-Glu in the food and pharmaceutical industries while the polymerization product because of its biochemical compatibility may be utilized for the design and fabrication of scaffold materials for tissue engineering applications.

Title: Identification of geometrical models of interface evolution for dendritic crystal growth
AdditionalInformation: Modern researchers are particularly interested in the emergent structures (sphelurites, dendrites and fractals) that form and influence the ultimate properties not only in the fabricated products, but also the formation of patterns in biological systems. This article combines physical and geometrical models for identifying the dendrite interface evolution of ammonium bromide crystals. It is one of the efforts in this area of complexity aimed at making these developments accessible to researchers in various related fields, so together we may begin to link the dispersed fragments of knowledge into a coherent picture of growth processes of both biotic and abiotic systems.

Title: The glycine-stimulated nucleation and solution-mediated polymorphic transformation of l-glutamic acid
AdditionalInformation: A dramatic enhancement of nucleation and solution-mediated polymorphic transformation processes of l-glutamic acid in the presence of glycine was demonstrated for the first time. These findings open new research avenues for better understanding and control of the observed phenomena relevant to industries dealing with production of polymorphic materials; from foods via specialty chemicals to pharmaceuticals. The accelerated processes should considerably increase the energy cost-effectiveness of the crystallisation of these materials by selecting/designing new nucleation/growth and shape-modifying accelerants.  This paper has been assessed by the editorial board as a highest-quality work and as such features on a cover of the issue.

Title: The inhibitors and enablers of maintenance and manufacturing strategy: a cross-case analysis
VolumeTitle: International Journal of System Assurance Engineering and Management
AdditionalInformation: This paper discusses the findings from empirical research at four North East of England manufacturing companies. The research identified a number of specific inhibitors and enablers of strategy which can be used by practitioners to pre-empt strategic failures and enhance the likelihood of strategic success. The work develops five generic areas; strategy, systems, people, leadership, and coherence for senior manager to focus on. This paper forms part of a wider investigation into the impact on manufacturing performance of the linkage between manufacturing and maintenance strategy. The research was sponsored by the Regional Development Agency ‘One North East’ as part of the Engineering Fellows Programme.

Title: Creating and Sustaining a Maintenance Strategy: A Practical Guide
AdditionalInformation: Research has shown that manufacturing companies are not creating maintenance strategies and linking them to their manufacturing and business goals. This journal paper provides a practical guide for maintenance managers proposing a generic methodology for the creation and implementation of maintenance strategy. A failure to develop and implement a comprehensive maintenance strategy can prejudice machine reliability and therefore negatively affect manufacturing performance. The potential benefits for maintenance departments are significant. A coherent maintenance strategy linked to manufacturing and business goals establishes a clear set of objectives for the maintenance function to follow. Moreover, a written and agreed maintenance strategy raised the strategic profile of the maintenance group within the plant through a measured contribution to the business. This paper forms part of a wider investigation into the impact on manufacturing performance of the linkage between manufacturing and maintenance strategy. The research was sponsored by the Regional Development Agency ‘One North East’ as part of the Engineering Fellows Programme.

Title: Towards a Simpler Selection Process for Maintenance Strategies
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Business and Management
AdditionalInformation: The main contribution of this journal paper was the proposal of two new methods for the selection of maintenance approaches at macro and micro levels. Firstly, the work questioned conventional wisdom in relation to the development of companywide maintenance strategies and suggested these that selection should be made according to the plant situation rather than defaulting to ‘planned maintenance’. Secondly, a rationalised process for the selection of maintenance strategies for machines is offered based on a simplified set of RCM parameters. Both innovations provide novel approaches which drive further research whilst at the same time offering useful tools for maintenance professionals to use in practice. This paper forms part of a wider investigation into the impact on manufacturing performance of the linkage between manufacturing and maintenance strategy. The research was sponsored by the Regional Development Agency ‘One North East’ as part of the Engineering Fellows Programme.

Title: The role of maintenance in energy saving in commercial refrigeration
VolumeTitle: Journal of Quality in Maintenance Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The main contribution of this paper is an explanation and overview of how maintenance can influence energy consumption in commercial refrigeration systems.
