This work was funded by the UK Government (DEFRA) and included collaboration with a number of food producers and other institutions. The resulting conclusions are of relevance for both refrigeration system providers in terms of designing more efficient systems and to refrigeration operators including producers and retailers in terms of reducing energy consumption and thus, costs.

Title: Development of Techniques to Manage Asset Condition Using New Tools
VolumeTitle: Asset Management: The State of the Art in Europe from a Life Cycle Perspective, Production & Process Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The main contribution of this book chapter is an overview of recently developed asset management tools, including many of those developed as part of the FP6 Dynamite project. This multi-partner project developed new maintenance and condition monitoring systems and tools to improve maintenance in a variety of sectors including major automotive manufacturers (Volvo and Fiat). Further examples of condition monitoring are presented including details the FP6 Posseidon project which led to the development of lube oil sensor for marine diesel engines. Such systems have the potential to avoid failures which can lead to costs in excess of $1m per day

Title: A New Integrated E-maintenance Concept
AdditionalInformation: The chapter was published in the book (outlined above) and formed one of many publications from the FP5 funded DYNAMITE project. This project was described by the European Commission as the most successful project, with regard to outputs, in the FP5 programme.  A software product, developed by one of the partners, is now fully commercial and supporting industry in monitoring maintenance activities. This project has developed one book and another book is under development.

Title: Maintenance strategy development within SMEs: the development of an integrated approach
AdditionalInformation: This paper was published in the Special Issue of the Journal of Control and Cybernetics following on from a presentation to the International Federation of Automatic Control (IFAC) in Poland.  This paper forms part of a series of three papers based upon my PhD.  This paper has supported the development of two FP7 and one UK government project proposal. The PhD, from which the paper is taken, has helped a number of local companies in developing a new approach to maintenance to increase quality and reduce manufacturing costs.

Title: Maintenance strategy development in the UK food and drink industry
VolumeTitle: International Journal Strategic Engineering Asset Management
AdditionalInformation: This paper was developed via conversations with leading companies in the food and drink industry and led to the development of a project funded by DEFRA.  The paper identified a lack of advanced maintenance and skilled operatives within the food industry. The outcomes from the project led to the development of a FP7 project and have informed maintenance teaching at the University of Sunderland.

Title: Value stream mapping: A dairy industry prospective
VolumeTitle: 2008 IEEE International Engineering Management Conference - IEMC Europe 2008.
AdditionalInformation:
ISSN: 978-1-4244-2289
This paper was developed from research into a number of companies involve  in food and drink production and packing, in particular companies  who are using large amounts of energy.  The project was funded by the department for environment, food and rural affairs (DEFRA). AMAP were invited to join the project because of their expertise in manufacturing techniques and technologies.  The project had four main research partners and 6 national companies including Sainsbury and Arla Foods.   The project was successful in that it identified a number of underlying problems in food and drink production.  The Value Stream Mapping exercise undertaken by AMAP proved that certain production processes were high users of energy. This allowed maintenance specialists in AMAP to introduce a number of techniques to reduce energy consumption.

Title: A Matlab toolbox for teaching modern system identification methods for industrial process control
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Mechanical Engineering Education
AdditionalInformation: This paper is concerned with system identification in process control. The work was undertaken during a secondment to Sunderland of a co-author (Maerte) from the University of Mons. It describes a recently developed suite of integral equation methods for identifying first and second order plus dead time models of industrial processes. One of the methods was applied to a laboratory process and a Matlab-based toolbox was developed to facilitate its use. It represents the beginning of an ongoing research project in which the algorithms are being further developed, for use with a wider range of applications, including mechanical systems.

Title: Appearance-based localization for mobile robots using digital zoom and visual compass
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the culmination of a project undertaken within the Centre for Hybrid Intelligent Systems at Sunderland University. It was a complex programme of work, reflected in the expertise of the authors; namely computer science, mechanical engineering, physics and mathematics, and computational neuroscience, respectively. The work itself required the application of the wide range of disciplines involved in the practical implementation of mobile robots, including novel sensor design, machine vision, mathematics, machine intelligence, and computer programming. It is an extensive paper and the experimental results are reported in detail. The Robotics and Autonomous Systems journal is highly regarded by those involved in this multidisciplinary area of research.

Title: Environment classification using Kohonen self-organizing maps
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel implementation of Kohonen self-organising maps (SOMs) to automatically classify environments from sensor, without the need for human intervention. It was primarily aimed at enhancing the navigational capabilities of autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs), but the method described would be equally applicable to unmanned autonomous aircraft. The work described in the paper was the result of experiments conducted during a successful PhD project and involved training and testing SOMs using realistic three dimensional environmental data obtained from digital elevation maps. Expert Systems is a respected international journal that publishes papers dealing with all aspects of knowledge engineering, for a wide range of applications.

Title: A generic controller architecture for intelligent robotic systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the culmination of a robotics research programme at University of Sunderland, focusing on both robot controller architectures and the design of modern robot control strategies. I supervised my co-author’s PhD in this area, although the paper was written during collaboration between Sunderland and Teesside Universities following his departure to the latter to take up a full-time academic post. The paper represents a serious attempt at devising an architecture that facilitates the implementation of the many so-called intelligent control strategies for robots that are to be found in the research literature, but which rarely get as far as widespread industrial application. It is a respected journal that aims to disseminate the application of research to the development of new or improved industrially-relevant manufacturing technologies, equipment, and strategies.

Title: Numerical Simulation of Damages in FRP Laminated Structures under Transverse Quasi-Static or Low-Velocity Impact Loads
VolumeTitle: Advanced Composite Materials for Automotive Applications: Structural Integrity and    Crashworthiness
AdditionalInformation: This chapter is considered to be the most extensive detailed output covering the damage simulations of laminated composites. The work is part of an extremely fruitful collaboration between Chiba and Tohoku University in Japan and the University of Sunderland. The work includes careful experiments and development of analytical/numerical tools with a particular objective of developing efficient analytical methodologies. The authors of this chapter are internationally distinguished for their huge contributions and committed to maintain the highest standard of research. This work and ongoing collaboration are supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) and multi-funders in Japan. This work carried out in this chapter has been extensively reviewed by 5 international experts before accepted in the book. It is worth mentioning that the entire book has also been extensively reviewed by more than 80 world-class experts in composite materials. This book is a pioneer on using composites in structural complements of vehicle body, which anticipated to be used as a main reference for all academic staff/engineers/students, and automotive industries.

Title: Finite element modelling of mode I delamination specimens by means of implicit and explicit solvers
AdditionalInformation: This paper is produced as a first output of a successful ongoing collaboration with the University of Oviedo in Spain. The work carried out in this research tackled the delamination problem using two solvers, implicit and explicit, considering two different fracture mechanics models, which makes it a unique in this field. The successful project results opened the door for more extensive collaboration in research project. Three more papers (2 journals and 1 conference) were written. It led also to strength the relationship between the University of Sunderland and University of Oviedo. Several projects and funding opportunities are under consideration at the moment.

Title: Finite element simulation of delamination growth in composite materials using LS-DYNA
AdditionalInformation: The work carried out in this paper is part of ongoing research funded and supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) in collaboration with the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC). The research work under JSPS/NSERC grant resulted in 12 papers (7 journals and 5 conferences). This paper delivers a strong base of understanding of the delamination propagation in composites materials using a novel FE model. The code written in this paper has been implemented in LS-DYNA software and it is now under consideration to be formally commercialised as a new tool in LS-DYNA. This paper has been extensively cited as a main reference in this subject.

Title: Development of Low Cost Carbon Fibre for Automotive Applications
VolumeTitle: Advanced Composite Materials for Automotive Applications: Structural Integrity and    Crashworthiness
AdditionalInformation: Currently, among real-world automotive material candidates, carbon fibre reinforced polymer (CFRP) composites offer unparalleled mechanical performance per unit weight. As such, their ability to reduce vehicle weight and improve fuel economy is similarly unparalleled.  This chapter identifies the barriers to CFRP adoption in automotive applications and cites the high cost of the fibre as the largest obstacle to overcome. It then gives a detailed account of the US DoE-sponsored research program, undertaken at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), designed to produce low cost carbon fibre for automotive applications. This is a research project of world-leading innovation and significance.

Title: Low Cost Carbon Fibre: Applications, Performance and Cost Models
VolumeTitle: Advanced Composite Materials for Automotive Applications: Structural Integrity and Crashworthiness
AdditionalInformation: In an earlier chapter, the Development of Low Cost Carbon Fibre for Automotive Applications project underway at ORNL was discussed. This Chapter presents an extension of that work in which vehicle weight reduction case studies are analysed in the context of the underpinning performance and cost models. Program goals stipulate a reduction of between 50% and 65% in the cost of raw fibre. The routes to this goal together with the interdependence between performance, cost and weight saving are analysed in detail.    This research is unique in scope and ambition and remains world-leading in its innovation and significance.

Title: Mixing assessment by chemical probe
VolumeTitle: Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of several outputs produced as fruitful results of a successful ongoing collaboration between several Universities in different countries. This includes participation from Lebanese International University, Lebanon, University of Paris Diderot, LUNAM University and ONIRIS, France, and Department of Computing, Engineering and Technology, University of Sunderland, UK. This work is supported by several grants including ADEME and CNRS. The work presents careful analytical and experimental investigation of micro-mixing quantification using chemical probe methods providing a better understanding of different limitations that arise in the final determination of local turbulence energy dissipation rate. This study provides solid guidelines for obtaining quantitative information from the chemical probe and for improving the accuracy by an adaptive protocol.

Title: The State of the Art in Fuel Cell Condition Monitoring and Maintenance
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the maintenance and condition monitoring of hydrogen fuel cells - this is significant since fuel cells are extremely high value assets and have sepcific maintenance needs. Poor maintenance can lead to accelerated degradation and reduced performance. The results of this study will be of benefit to organisations who are considering the application of fuel cell technologies - particularly in the automotive sector.

Title: Analysis of the Efficiency of Electric Vehicle Rapid Charge Systems
VolumeTitle:
Hybrid and Electric Vehicle Conference (HEVC) 2011
18-19 May 2011
Warwick UK
AdditionalInformation:
ISBN: 978-1-84919-504-1
This work, carried out in partnership with CENEX, ChargeYourCar and Strathclyde University, involved the evaluation of the first publically available fast charging system for electric vehicles in the UK. The results of the study highlight both the overall efficiency of the fast charging system and the effect it has on the local power grid. This piece of work was included in the SmartMove Case Study report produced by Cenex as part of a programme funded by the Department for Business, Industry and Skills (BIS) and was used to influence further decisions regarding fast charger installation in North East England.

Title: The effect of driving style on electric vehicle performance, economy and perception
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Electric and Hybrid Vehicles
AdditionalInformation: This paper is of key significance in the field of Low Carbon Vehicles.  Little work has been done to investigate age- related issues in the efficiency and usability of these new technologies.  The results of this study have significance to the automotive sector and society in general because they highlight important issues regarding the optimisation of battery range in electric vehicles and this has implications for the take up of electric vehicles, the automotive sector and the environment.  AMAP is currently conducting further work which builds on the findings of this paper and will inform the automotive sector about the design requirements for a key sector of the automotive market i.e. older drivers.  This work was conducted in collaboration with Cenex of Loughborough University.

Title: Modelling and Analyzing Hybrid Electric Vehicles with Single and Dual Epicyclic Power Split Transmissions
AdditionalInformation: The paper investigated new development power split transmissions (PST) and studied the performance of hybrid electrical vehicles (HEVs) using single and dual epicyclic power split transmissions. The development of PST has been a crucial feature in the technological success of hybrid driveline vehicles. A local company, AVID Vehicles Ltd have demonstrated the potential of this work in the conversion of a Nissan Note supplied by Nissan Motors UK Ltd into an electric powered car. An electric motor has been applied to the Note’s existing transmission, the efficiencies in each gear measured, and gear ratios established to achieve maximum efficiency from the driveline. This, and related, work on hybrid vehicles has gained international recognition and has been used as the basis for further developments, including novel gearbox control systems for electric vehicles. This paper is one among several outputs studied the impacts of the new transmission.

Title: Epicyclic Power Split Transmissions for Hybrid Electric Vehicles: Fuel Consumption, Vehicle Performance and Driving Aggressiveness
VolumeTitle: Global Journal of Research Engineering- Part B: Automotive Engineering
AdditionalInformation: As part of extensive studies to investigate the impact of continuously variable transmission (CVT) that can be adapted for hybrid and electric vehicles, this paper focused on the improvement of fuel consumption, vehicle performance, and driving aggressiveness for hybrid electric vehicles. A local company, AVID Vehicles Ltd have demonstrated the potential of this work in the conversion of a Nissan Note supplied by Nissan Motors UK Ltd into an electric powered car. An electric motor has been applied to the Note’s existing transmission, the efficiencies in each gear measured, and gear ratios established to achieve maximum efficiency from the driveline. This, and related, work on hybrid vehicles has gained international recognition and has been used as the basis for further developments, including novel gearbox control systems for electric vehicles.

Title: Impact of Second Life Electric Vehicle Batteries on the Viability of Renewable Energy Sources
VolumeTitle: British Journal of Applied Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper was written in order to understand the potential for the use of second life vehicle batteries in Smart Homes.  It built upon the successful CHEER project and opened up the possibility of creating a financially viable second use for used battery packs.  It has opened up the opportunity to collaborate with Sunderland City Council, Gentoo Social Housing and Zero Carbon Futures to create a new type of SMART home.

Title: Performance Analysis of Hybrid and Full Electrical Vehicles Equipped with Continuously Variable Transmissions
AdditionalInformation: This paper studied successfully the effects of adopting a continuously variable transmission (CVT) that can be adapted for hybrid and electric vehicles. This paper was one among several fruitful outputs investigating the new transmission technology in hybrid and electric vehicles. The results of this work have enabled theory to be built into a demonstration vehicle and verified with actual test data. The results are being used to model and develop a novel ultra high efficient gearbox control system for electric vehicles. The project is currently being further developed by the University of Sunderland and Hyperdrive vehicles at Cramlington. The research will lead to technology which will have a market lead, as it will achieve additional efficiency and range that will not be achieved by competitors. This paper is one among several outputs studied the impacts of the new transmission.

Title: Under Pitch Control Techniques for Crashworthiness Improvement: Analytical Approach using IHBM for VDCS and Extendable Front-End Structure
AdditionalInformation: This is one of several outputs concerning vehicle crashworthiness optimization using smart front-end structures. The Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) supported and awarded this research activity. The novelty of this work is that it combines the smart front-end structure alongside vehicle dynamics control systems as a unique solution for safer vehicles. This paper led to a new research direction for vehicle crashworthiness optimization. Based on this work, several travel grants are awarded to present research findings at national and international conferences. The research work resulted in 21 papers (9 journal papers and 12 conference papers).

Title: Numerical analysis of vehicle-to-vehicle impact using vehicle dynamics control systems for collision mitigation
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Dynamics and Control
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one among many papers published in in collaboration with Ain Shams University in Egypt. This project is fully supported by the Egyptian government to help enhancing Vehicle Safety. This paper produced detailed solution of controlling VDCS to enhance crashworthiness and to reduce fatalities. The control system developed in this paper clarifies the effects of VDCS on collisions mitigation and produces suggestions for optimum scenarios. The outcome of this paper is now being used as a base to develop a novel control system to significantly reduce fatalities and to eliminate severe dynamic response due ring impact. The outcome of this work has attracted potential partners in Europe to investigate it further as a potential direction of vehicle safety enhancement.

Title: Enhancement of vehicle safety and improving vehicle yaw behaviour due to offset collision using vehicle dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one among many papers published in in collaboration with Ain Shams University in Egypt. This project is fully supported by the Egyptian government to help enhancing Vehicle Safety. This paper contributed significantly on optimizing offset collisions which still the main source of collision fatalities. The outcome of this work was used to investigate/enhance the influence VDCS on more sophisticated crash scenarios considering occupants safety as well. The outcome of this work has attracted potential partners in Europe to investigate it further as a potential direction of vehicle safety enhancement.

Title: The influence of a vehicle dynamics control system on the occupant's dynamic response during a vehicle collision
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one among many papers published in in collaboration with Ain Shams University in Egypt. This project is fully supported by the Egyptian government to help enhancing Vehicle Safety. This paper contributed significantly on optimizing the dynamic response of occupants involved in collisions. The unique integration among VDCS, front-end structure, and occupant behaviour make this paper important to people interested in vehicle safety. It creates and delivers a quick and reliable response for vehicle collision which could be used in the initial concept design stage. The outcome of this work has attracted potential partners in Europe to investigate it further as a potential direction of vehicle safety enhancement.

Title: Crash analysis and energy absorption characteristics of S-shaped longitudinal members
AdditionalInformation: As part of our effort at the University of Sunderland to enhance safety and reduce fatalities, new S-shaped longitudinal members are developed and tested. This paper presents extensive finite element simulations of the crash behaviour and the energy absorption characteristics to investigate the design of optimized members.  The results are used as tools while carrying out the validation and experimental work. Detailed work of designing these new members using new lightweight materials are now being carried out as a new collaboration with Jilin University in China.

Title: The role of a driving simulator in driver training to improve fuel economy
VolumeTitle: DSC 2012 Europe Driving Simulation Conference, Paris, France, September 6-7, 2012
AdditionalInformation:
ISBN of conference: 978-2-85782-700-9
This paper contributes to knowledge on the most appropriate driver education interventions and elements of driver behavior requiring modification for reducing C02 emissions from road transport.  Ultimately, this research could contribute to improvements and reductions in C02 emissions which in turn will benefit communities and the environment.  The simulator element of the research study and driving simulator were funded by The Regional Development Agency ONE NORTH EAST, as part of the Zero Emissions Transport (ZET) Programme.  The on-road element of the study was conducted in collaboration with David Whiting of Fleet Technique, Sunderland.

Title: Visual information search in simulated junction negotiation: Gaze transitions of young novice, young experienced and older experienced drivers
AdditionalInformation: This paper is significant in the field of Human Factors and safety because it advances knowledge of drivers’ information requirements at junctions.  An understanding of where and how drivers search for information at junctions will aid the development of assistive devices such as collision avoidance systems which ultimately will reduce accidents at junctions.  Older drivers are overrepresented in multiple vehicle accidents at junctions and the number of older drivers on the roads is increasing therefore this work will be of benefit to the road safety sector and to society in general.  This study has interfaculty involvement with the department of Psychology and also the Lancaster University.

Title: Immobilisation of the knee and ankle and its impact on drivers' braking times: A DRIVING SIMULATOR STUDY
AdditionalInformation: Doctors have no objective information on which to base the advice they give to patients when asked whether or not they may continue to drive while recovering from a limb injury.   Currently DVLA legislation on driving simply states the a driver may continue driving if wearing a plaster cast so long as they are able to safely stop their vehicle in an emergency.  This study provides the medical profession with data on the impact of wearing a plaster cast upon drivers stopping distances.  It is of great significance because it provides data informing professionals in the medical and driving community of the safety implications associated with the wearing of leg casts, providing a basis upon which to provide advice to drivers.  The results will also inform practitioners working in the vehicle adaptation industry and those involved in the design of assistive devices. This work was conducted in collaboration with Surgeons and registrars at Sunderland City Hospital, National Health Trust.

Title: Migration Issues in Modularity for 1st Tier Automotive Suppliers
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Business and Management
AdditionalInformation: This paper identifies the key challenges and issues which automotive suppliers face as they make the transition from component manufacturer to cockpit module suppliers. The significance of the work can best be considered as: (i) a number of findings were discussed under four thematic groupings which have increased and progressed the knowledge associated with automotive companies making this transition, which have either not being outlined in previous work or covered in such depth and (ii) the development of a migration matrix which provides a framework for the issues associated with supplier migration. The work was collaborative with a colleague from another University.

Title: Measuring the status and alignment of Maintenance and Manufacturing Strategies – The development of a new model and diagnostic tool
VolumeTitle: Journal of Quality in Maintenance Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development of a new conceptual model and diagnostic tool. The conceptual model maps the linkage between manufacturing and maintenance strategy and contributes to new knowledge by defining the individual processes and links involved. The diagnostic tool provides senior managers in manufacturing companies with an audit tool to assess and analyse the status of their functional processes. It also advises the improvement activities that need to be carried out so that strategies can be successful. This paper forms part of a wider investigation into the impact on manufacturing performance of the linkage between manufacturing and maintenance strategy. The research was sponsored by the Regional Development Agency ‘One North East’ as part of the Engineering Fellows Programme.

Title: The Use and Impact of Manufacturing Productivity Improvement Tools and Methodologies within the Automotive Component Industry
AdditionalInformation: This research has highlighted a number of key issues which need to be addressed if real and sustainable benefits resulting from the application of continuous improvement tools and management methodologies are to be achieved. In essence the key contribution from this work is that a number of automotive suppliers are wasting valuable resource and missing key business opportunities in implementing a range of Continuous Improvement initiatives which are failing to deliver the impact expected. In addition, the research was undertaken with the cooperation and support of a global automotive OEM who provided unique access to their first tier supplier network and supplier performance data. The research was funded by the Regional Development Agency (ONE North- East) under the Engineering Fellows project.

Title: New integrated chassis control systems for vehicle handling performance enhancement
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Dynamics and Control
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents an important continuation of a long-established theme within our automotive control research team. This theme, namely integration of vehicle control systems, featured strongly in our RAE2008 submission. Integration of vehicle dynamics control systems are investigated by proposing a new control architecture involving braking, steering, suspension and driveline functions. Active control systems include brake-based electronic stability control (ESC), active front steering (AFS), normal suspension force control (NFC) and variable torque distribution (VTD). Results show that the integration strategy enhances vehicle handling stability through a reduction in vehicle yaw rate and side-slip angle, not attainable in standalone mode.

Title: The Influence of Electronic Stability Control, Active Suspension, Driveline and Front Steering Integrated System on the Vehicle Ride and Handling
VolumeTitle: Global Journal of Researches in Engineering- Part B: Automotive Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents an important continuation of a long-established theme within our automotive control research team. This theme, namely integration of vehicle control systems, featured strongly in our RAE2008 submission. In this study, a 6 Degrees-of-Freedom non-linear vehicle handling model has been developed. All four active chassis control systems have been evaluated in standalone mode over a wide range of vehicle handling conditions. Based on this analysis, a novel rule-based integration strategy has been proposed to improve vehicle handling. A comparison of the standalone and integrated strategies shows that the integrated control strategy can significantly improve vehicle stability.

Title: Theoretical and Experimental Analysis of Electromagnetic Variable Valve Timing Control Systems for Improvement of Spark Ignition Engine Performance
AdditionalInformation: The research carried out in this paper is supported by several industries and governmental agencies in Egypt. The work was initiated with an extensive collaboration between the University of Sunderland, UK and Ain Shams University, Egypt to meet the requirements of higher torque values at all engine speeds using a new variable valve timing system (VVT), which gives continuously variable valve actuation at all engine speeds. The outcomes from experimental and numerical analysis created solid knowledge and provided a clear direction to analyse the electromagnetic variable valve timing control systems of spark ignition engine performance improvement

Title: Preliminary study of improving the speed and cost of diffusion bonding of metal sheets
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: Published online before print September 2, 2013

Title: In Vitro Testing of a New Aspiration Thrombus Device
VolumeTitle: Journal of Stroke and Cerebrovascular Diseases
AdditionalInformation: Spence’s contribution to the paper was the base modelling for flow regimes and the choking of flow in the tube.

Title: Finite element acoustic analysis of a steel stud based double-leaf wall
Evaluation of the stiffness characteristics of square pore CoCrMo cellular structures manufactured using laser melting technology for potential orthopaedic applications
Quantitative analysis on the anisotropic behaviour of superplastic deformation in laser melted (LM) Ti–6Al–4V alloy
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the first attempt, worldwide, to conduct successful superplastic forming (SPF) tensile tests on Ti-6Al-4V manufactured by selective laser melting (SLM), at the University of Wolverhampton. In SLM unique shapes are realised. The paper, a result of collaboration between Professor Kibble, Dr Stanford and Dr Kim (Kyungpook University, South Korea) offers a materials breakthrough in combining ALM and SPF technology, an idea by Kibble. Subsequently, Kibble was invited and funded by Kyungpook University to present research on SLM technology to research centres in South Korea (September 2010).  Further international collaboration is being made.

Title: Effects of ball milling time on the synthesis and consolidation of nanostructured WC–Co composites
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Refractory Metals and Hard Materials

Title: Effect of milling temperature on the synthesis and consolidation of nanocomposite WC–10Co powders
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Refractory Metals and Hard Materials

Title: Quasi-dynamic visualization of crack propagation and bridging evolution in Si3N4 and SiC ceramics by mechano-luminescence
AdditionalInformation: A collaboration outcome between Kibble, Stanford and Kim (Kyungpook University, South Korea) while Kim was at Wolverhampton (1/09/2008 to 31/08/2009). The technique has wider application than ceramics, e.g. selective laser melted (SLM) TiAl intermetallic being processed at the University of Wolverhampton.  Standard fracture toughness (FT) characterisation of SLM materials is inappropriate as components have thin walls.  Use of mechanoluminescence (ML) coatings offer an alternative to conventional FT testing as the entire crack process to failure is measured, instead of FT post-mortem analysis, providing the alternative characterisation necessary. Further collaboration, involving ML, with Kim will link with the SLM processing work.

Title: Damage of lead-free solder joints in flip chip assemblies subjected to high-temperature thermal cycling
High temperature reliability of lead-free solder joints in a flip chip assembly
Evaluation of rheological properties of lead-free solder pastes and their relationship with transfer efficiency during stencil printing process
A systematic modelling and simulation approach for JIT performance optimisation
Knowledge management to support product development in cold roll-forming environment
VolumeTitle: The International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation:
This industry led research has applied IDEFO, modelling and case study techniques in a cold roll forming environment producing a decision support system that guides researchers to identify relevant information required to support future new product development.
Industrial Collaborator was Alan Harris, Metsec, PLC, Broadwell Road, Oldbury, West Midlands B69 4HF, UK.

Title: Brain-Computer Music Interfacing (BCMI): From Basic Research to the Real World of Special Needs
TWO-STAGE BIOMETRIC AUTHENTICATION METHOD USING THOUGHT ACTIVITY BRAIN WAVES
Analogue mouse pointer control via an online steady state visual evoked potential (SSVEP) brain–computer interface
ON THE COMPLEXITY AND ENERGY ANALYSES IN EEG BETWEEN ALCOHOLIC AND CONTROL SUBJECTS DURING DELAYED MATCHING TO SAMPLE PARADIGM

Direct Metal Laser Sintering of a Ti6Al4V Mandible Implant

Dr Peng Cao Auckland University City Campus, 20 Symonds Street, Auckland, Email: p.cao@auckland.ac.nz

VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture

The effect of ruthenium on the intermediate to high temperature creep response of high refractory content single crystal nickel-base superalloys

Numerical and Physical Modelling of Plastic Deformation and Heat Phenomena in Superplastic Forming Tools for Improving the Economics of the Hot Forming Process
VolumeTitle:
Metal Forming  2012
Proceedings of the 14th International Conference on Metal Forming, September 16-19, 2012, Krakow, Poland

Title: Using the General Gamma Distribution to Represent the Droplet Size Distribution in a Spray Model
AdditionalInformation: Knowledge of the distribution of drop sizes is needed in evaluating sprays/atomizers, and, critically, in the prediction of multi-phase flow hydrodynamics. The Rosin-Rammler expression, initially developed for powdered coal, is commonly used for representing droplet size distributions in sprays. This book chapter presents the application of a general Gamma distribution to represent the drop size distribution in a water spray model, and shows that it is a viable distribution function to use. Subsequent studies have shown that it can be applied to drop break-up/fuel sprays modelling. The chapter has been downloaded 2044 times (April 2012-March 2013; 14%-USA, 8%-India, 5%-China).

Title: ANALYSIS OF A TWO-FLUID SPRAYER AND ITS USE TO DEVELOP THE NUMBER SIZE DISTRIBUTION MOMENTS SPRAY MODEL, PART I: EXPERIMENTAL ANALYSIS
ANALYSIS OF A TWO-FLUID SPRAYER AND ITS USE TO DEVELOP THE NUMBER SIZE DISTRIBUTION MOMENTS SPRAY MODEL, PART II: COMPUTATIONAL ANALYSIS
Partially heated heat sinks in a zero-bypass

VolumeTitle:
2009 Third International Conference on

Athens/Glyfada, Greece, June 18-June 23, 
ISBN: 978-0-7695-3669-9

Title: Interpolation techniques for building a continuous map from discrete wireless sensor network data
AdditionalInformation: Published online 30 May 2011 in Wiley Online Library (wileyonlinelibrary.com).

Title: Information extraction from sensor networks using the Watershed transform algorithm

Title: A Token-Managed Admission Control System for QoS Provision on a Best-Effort GALS Interconnect
Adaptive Proactive Inhibitory Control for Embedded Real-Time Applications
A case for spiking neural network simulation based on configurable multiple-FPGA systems

A Biologically Plausible Real-time Spiking Neuron
Simulation Environment Based on a Multiple-FPGA
Platform
Direct evidence of ZnO morphology modification via the selective adsorption of ZnO-binding peptides
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study to provide unambiguous evidence of controlling ZnO nanoparticle morphology mediated by peptide adsorption. The evidence generated from a variety of state-of-the-art experimental techniques, provide a step change in nanoparticle preparation methods, supported by “demonstrated a unique peptide-based method to control metal oxide structures via facet-selective binding” (J. Phys. Chem. Lett., 3, 405, 2012). This research generated additional funding from the US Air Force (FA9550-10-1-0024, £283,333) and Marie Curie Training Network (“BIOMINTEC” PITN-GA-2008-215507 £227,929), and strengthened UK-USA collaborations leading to a joint publication in J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2012 (University of Akron, hh29@uakron.edu).

Title: From biosilicification to tailored materials : optimizing hydrophobic domains and resistance to protonation of polyamines
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
AdditionalInformation: This peer-reviewed article was featured in the Royal Society of Chemistry news and Materials Today. Reviewers stated “This is an outstanding study that rigorously establishes the chemical principles …...the manuscript is most highly recommended for acceptance by PNAS” (editor Aizenberg jaiz@seas.harvard.edu). This research resulted in subsequent funding (EPSRC EP/E048439/1 £268,248; USA-NIH 5R01DE017207 $445,230), new industrially relevant applications in biocatalysis, carbon capture and air decontamination (J. Mater. Chem. B 1, 1164, 2013. Chem. Commun. 49, 3161, 2013. Environ. Sci. Technol. 46, 13354, 2012) and an invited talk at the most renowned international conference in chemical sciences (American Chemical Society 2010, Stephen.Clarson@uc.edu).

Title: Electrostatic depletion forces between planar surfaces
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops a new theory for the interaction between particles with a low dielectric interior; the work accurately describes previous simulations and discovers a new physical interaction: the “electrostatic depletion force”.  This work led to an invitation to write a review paper (doi: 10.1039/b803783c) and invitations to speak at Imperial College (a.galindo@imperial.ac.uk), Leeds University (p.j.heggs@leeds.ac.uk), and Lund University (jan.forsman@teokem.lu.se).  It also initiated collaborations with leading researchers in colloid science at Lund University (per.linse@fkem1.lu.se, jan.forsman@teokem.lu.se).

Title: Finding bridges in packings of colloidal spheres
AdditionalInformation: The novel methodology in this paper identifies force-bearing ‘bridge’ structures in particle packings, for the first time validating simulation analyses against real experimental data from colloidal suspensions. The results featured in an invited international conference talk at ICEMS Kyoto international symposium, March 2013 ('Cell-Material Integration and Biomaterials Science', oap@icems.kyoto-u.ac.jp), showing their multidisciplinary significance through the novel linking of the behaviour of granular materials (particle heaps) to bio-materials (tissue, ie collections of cells). The paper has supported development of further international research collaboration, including upcoming PhD student visits, with Heinrich Heine University, Dusseldorf (Prof Egelhaaf, Stefan.Egelhaaf@uni-duesseldorf.de).

Title: Does gravity cause load-bearing bridges in colloidal and granular systems?
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the journal editors' suggested highlight (out of 74 articles in that issue), and was the subject of a Physics Focus article (Phys. Rev. Focus 28, 3 (2011), 10.1103/PhysRevFocus.28.3), one of only 22 across the whole 'soft matter'/granular materials fields in 2011. Its findings played a major part in a subsequent Carnegie Trust-funded cross-disciplinary project (2012-2014) with geologists (Z Shipton, Civil and Environmental Engineering, zoe.shipton@strath.ac.uk; Carnegie Trust admin@carnegie-trust.org) which will develop novel relations between colloidal/granular force response and earthquake and magma behaviour.

Title: Jamming and unjamming of concentrated colloidal dispersions in channel flow
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated novel consequences of concentrated particle flows and how to use geometry to avoid flow instability, leading to an invited conference talk ('Suspensions Processing' , Cambridge, 2012, Richard Buscall richard@rbgen.net). It has attracted multidisciplinary interest for its relevance in diverse areas including foods leading to consultancy work with Mars UK (isabella.van.damme@effem.com) . The paper’s findings are identified as instrumental in understanding some geometry effects on irregular flows, by Genovese and Sprakel (Soft Matter 2011 v7 p3889), who comment that the results “suggest that [vortex] formation is governed by flow reversal”.

Title: Growth kinetics of colloidal chains and labyrinths
VolumeTitle: Physical review. E, Statistical physics, plasmas, fluids, and related interdisciplinary topics
AdditionalInformation: This paper shows how structures and kinetics created by complex interactions lead to new and unexpected nano- and microstructure with applications including tunable membranes and films. Its novelty, importance and unexpected outcome is evidenced by Dinsmore (dinsmore@physics.umass.edu) who refers to the paper (J Physical Chemistry B 2011, vol 115, p7173) as showing how “the precise shape of interparticle potential curve has critical, nonintuitive consequences”.  Referees were impressed by the insight and rigour ('convincing, thorough, well explained', 'very interesting', ‘Serious physical analysis… substantiates the formation of these aggregates and more complex structures'  (pre@ridge.aps.org, Dirk J Bukman)).

Title: Integration of decision support systems to improve decision support performance
AdditionalInformation: Isolated decision support research is well-established. From critical in-depth analysis of the field new insights into Integrated Decision Support (IDS) are presented: 2 novel frameworks, 5 integration properties, 4 unique technology contributions, 3 approaches, and 5 key research challenges. The IDS supports design, logistics, clinical decisions, environmental sustainability, and travel. Turkish researchers (eoztemel@marmara.edu.tr) and Spanish researchers (angelica@usal.es) are aspiring to develop similar systems. Norwich Business School with Hong Kong Polytechnic University (h.chan@uea.ac.uk) use it as a basis for a “proper system” and the concept is of “vital importance”. Researchers from Germany (slaks@dbvis.inf.uni-konstanz.de) acknowledge IDS has great impact when deployed.

Title: Exploring the impact of technological competence development on speed and NPD program performance
AdditionalInformation: A novel model of technological competences is presented, within NPD, by showing where they originate and how they evolve through organizational learning. The work surveyed 111 European best practice companies in six countries over a three year period (i.e., Ericsson, AkzoNobel). The findings demonstrate that practices such as appropriate climate, project portfolio management and technological alignment are essential for technological competence development which turns in higher levels of performance. It has opened a new area of technological competence investigation in corporate entrepreneurship research as evidenced [Martín-Rojas et al., 2013). The research has extended to the US (songmi@umkc.edu) and Australia.

Title: Understanding inter-organizational decision coordination
VolumeTitle: Supply Chain Management: An International Journal
AdditionalInformation: A novel framework for examining decision making processes in supply chains, and its application using longitudinal case studies within one of the largest global toy manufacturers and its three customers, is provided.  The research demonstrated five key findings that can positively influence decision-making and coordination behaviours in an inter-organisational setting. Coretech (cahit.guvensoy@coretech.com) requested to use the framework to enhance value chain efficiency and effectiveness; stating: “A significant insight from this research is that managers’ use their intuition and take more risk when they deal with coordination problems characterised by information complexity or inadequacy for inter-organizational decision coordination behaviour”.

Title: Examining proactive strategic decision-making flexibility in new product development
AdditionalInformation: Creates a novel model of decision-making flexibility within the context of New Product Development, through the analysis of 103 European organisations (i.e. Philips, Danfoss) that reflect world-leading practices during a three year period (Editor: tonyd@temple.edu). The findings demonstrate that decision-making flexibility provides firms with an ability to adapt to changing environments and to develop innovation in product, and technological arenas. R&D manager of PACCAR Netherlands (loek.van.seeters@daftrucks.com) commented that ‘it was a fresh and helpful way to evaluate and think about the way they were organized for innovation’. This research lead to a new Turkish Science Centre project (co-investigator: nharmancioglu@ku.edu.tr).

Title: Putting the crowd to work in a knowledge-based factory
AdditionalInformation: The paper demonstrates how Internet crowdsourcing can be used to optimise various operations found in CAD/CAM. The work is notable because it reports the first systematic application of crowdsourcing to industrial geometric reasoning tasks such as 2D packing (12-30 profiles) and quantifying component similarity (500 shapes) using established benchmark data-sets. These results led to an EPSRC research grant (EP/J000728) awarded in 2011 to investigate the feasibility of using these applications to bring employment to rural workforces in Scotland and India. Outputs were used by Shapespace Ltd to optimise the shape matching algorithms incorporated in their PartBrowser software product (A.Sherlock@shapespace.com).

Title: Octree-based production of near net shape components
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel, integrated system for producing near net shape components based on the Octree decomposition of 3D models. The paper is notable for the results that establish, for the first time, the feasibility of a physical Octree approach to additive manufacture, and also for the Octree algorithms that were modified to support the application. The algorithms in this paper were further modified and incorporated in Renishaw's APEXBlade software (http://www.renishaw.com/en/apexblade--16411). This new product allowed around 5% reductions in probe path planning times and impacted not only on Renishaw but also the productivity of their industrial customers.

Title: Effects of ultrasound on polymeric foam porosity
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates experimental results that show how ultrasound applied during the expansion of polyurethane foam can control its porosity. The paper underpinned an EPSRC research grant at Strathclyde (EP/I000577, £190k) to investigate improvements to foam covering of prosthetic limbs, and a TSB project at Heriot-Watt University (TSB No 101138, £500k). The TSB project exploited the fact that the reported phenomenon for polymer foams was reproduced in bread (C.Torres@lboro.ac.uk). The TSB project involves a consortium of food companies and an on-going patent application (“Process for the manufacture of a leavened foodstuff and an apparatus therefor”, Patent Application No PCT/GB2012/051365).

Title: Managing the exchange of engineering product data to support through life ship design
AdditionalInformation: A new engineering data management solution is presented responding to existing data standards having minimal impact within the shipbuilding industry. 34 European maritime organisations were surveyed to establish data requirements for tool integration (bottom-up) and through-life modelling and design (top-down). This informed the creation of a unique engineering data management solution, significantly reducing model size and complexity, improving integration, and informing industrial practice (h.j.koelman@sarc.nl). Reviewers commented: “…never seen this being worked to a level as detailed as in here, or being implemented for a distributed cross-culture and cross-company engineer-to-order ship building environment. As such the work is innovative” (Guest-Editor: b.h.m.gerritsen@tudelft.nl).

Title: A collaborative platform for integrating and optimising Computational Fluid Dynamics analysis requests
AdditionalInformation: A technically advanced collaborative design platform is described, that is radically different from current thinking, providing a solution to the challenges of: tool interoperability; translation/transfer of product data, transaction management, and change notification. These challenges are known to cost industry “billions of dollars” (szykman@nist.gov). The platform was developed in direct response to industrial requirements through a develop/test/evolve iterative process. Industrial implementation has reported substantial benefits: significant (67%) reductions in workflow times; less reliance on experts; guaranteed data consistency; and elimination of human errors (gatchell@hsva.de; h.j.prins@marin.nl). The platform formed the foundation for the current €1.8M FP7 project EuroVIP (SCSO-GA-2011-266054).

Title: An integrated environment for organisational decision support
AdditionalInformation: An organisational decision-support solution for complex product development programmes, developed with a world-leading defence contractor, is presented. The work significantly advances the state-of-the-art, demonstrating strategic tactical and operational decision-support across life-phases using situational awareness to trigger complex emergent decisions. The decision-support solution was evaluated by BAE Systems and MoD representatives with 65-80% stating that it provided necessary support for complex development programmes (iain.mckenna@baesystems.com). The research: “reinforced evidence based decision-making within BAE Systems in particular Maritime – Naval Ships and was a prime driver for organisational changes to engineering information systems and other infrastructure” (ron.brittain@baesystems.com) - helping establish a strategic research partnership.

Title: Absorbing new knowledge in small and medium-sized enterprises : a multiple case analysis of Six Sigma
AdditionalInformation: Absorptive Capacity shows how manufacturing SMEs acquire and use Six-Sigma knowledge for creating and sustaining competitive advantage.  By critically analysing 18 UK SMEs, using semi-structured interviews with various levels of management, an innovative analytical framework is presented that for the first time combines Six-Sigma and absorptive capacity. The research sets the foundation for exploring organisational learning approaches, guides “best-in-class” practice for project selection and execution, and received support from the CEO of the Institute of Six Sigma Professionals (steve@lighthouseconsultants.co.uk): “these ‘informal’ routines which affect the success of LSS in SMEs are worth further consideration and offer an excellent insight”.

Title: Integrating DEA into Six Sigma methodology for measuring health service efficiency
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Operational Research Society
AdditionalInformation: The authors present a novel application in a healthcare setting by integrating Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) and Six-Sigma methodology to improve health service efficiency by over 25%. DEA has been formally introduced into the toolkit of Six Sigma and proved to be useful in improving physician’s productivity in any hospital environment. The case study sets the groundwork for challenging the current curriculum of Six Sigma for healthcare professionals and received very positive comments from both academics (hgitlow@bus.miami.edu); and practitioners: “This research shows how social and technical resources come together to create knowledge and enhance performance in Six Sigma projects” (lrsmith2@peoplepc.com).

Title: Change process : a key enabler to building resilient SMEs
AdditionalInformation: The first empirical model of how SME characteristics negatively influence their resilience is presented.  This was a longitudinal study involving coded interviews with 37 case studies over three years, 232 senior managers, and eight European countries. One reviewer commented: “the new insight should lead to interventions that would facilitate development of more resilient SMEs” (Editor: alexandre.dolgui@mines-stetienne.fr). From this work Prof. Bititci has been engaged by the Clyde Blowers Capital (owning companies such as David Brown Gears, Cone Drive, Parsons Peables, Moventas and Keto Pumps) to assist with the formalisation of the how they acquire and sustainably grow manufacturing SMEs (gmccallum@clydeblowers.co.uk).

Title: Managerial processes : business process that sustain performance
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Operations and Production Management
AdditionalInformation: This is the first empirical study that explores the relationship between the maturity of managerial processes and sustainable performance (Editor: Steve.Brown@exeter.ac.uk). The findings demonstrate that practices such as managing communication, change and culture are essential for underpinning higher levels of performance. This paper, using grounded theory across 37 European companies, has opened an area of multidisciplinary investigation facilitating collaboration amongst operations and strategic management researchers as evidenced by Mahdi and Almsafir (2012). Scottish Minister for Enterprise (jim.mather@btinternet.com) commented that “A significant insight from this research is that organisations with more holistic/integrated approaches to management perform better”.

Title: Performance measurement : challenges for tomorrow
AdditionalInformation: In response to emerging trends (e.g. multicultural collaboration, autopoietic networks, knowledge work) this paper presents a unique, forward looking, systematic literature review, exploring the readiness of contemporary performance measurement theories and practices in the context of future trends (Editor: O.Jones@liverpool.ac.uk). Traditional and systematic literature review techniques were combined to analyse performance measurement literature in the context of emerging business trends. Lamest and Brady (2012) suggested: “(this paper) challenges contemporary context for both researchers and practitioners, requiring fresh and innovative thinking”.  The paper sets the agenda for future research into performance measurement theory and practice to deal with emerging organisations.

Title: How to compare performances of firms operating in different sectors?
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper that starts a debate on how to compare performances of organisations operating in different sectors by creating and validating a framework that enables comparison of the overall performance of organisations operating in different sectors. The framework was designed in consultation with an industry panel and used to compare the performances of 37 different manufacturing organisations with some profound results that accurately predicted the demise of two of the lowest performing companies. The framework developed has been used by an international consortium of researchers to compare performances of firms from different sectors (Project manager  - williammcahill@eircom.net).

Title: Chemically blockable transformation and ultraselective low-pressure gas adsorption in a non-porous metal organic framework
AdditionalInformation: The material studied in this work shows remarkable selectivity and significant uptake of nitrous oxide, which is reversed by water contact, having  applications to platelet inhibition in wound dressings; the observed nitrous oxide capacities are "unprecedented” (Mizuno, Tokyo University, tmizuno@mail.ecc.u-tokyo.ac.jp, Angewandte Chemie); Zhou, Texas A&M, zhou@mail.chem.tamu.edu,Chemical Reviews). A patent has been filed (2012, WO2012020214) based on the materials presented in this work. Jaffrès and co-workers (University of Brest, pjaffres@univ-brest.fr,Crystal Growth and Design) have applied this research of using hetero-polyfunctional building blocks for controlled synthesis of a new suite of crystalline materials.

Title: Surface interactions and quantum kinetic molecular sieving for H-2 and D-2 adsorption on a mixed metal-organic framework material
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: This is the first experimental observation of kinetic isotope quantum molecular sieving in MOFs. The paper shows the highest observed enthalpy for hydrogen adsorption (Goddard, Caltech, wag@wag.caltech.edu, Physical Chemistry Letters). I delivered an invited talk to the British Crystallographic Association (2009) (Andrew Goodwin, alg44@cam.ac.uk). Zhou (Texas A&M, zhou@mail.chem.tamu.edu) stresses “more efforts should be devoted to […] new MOFs for quantum sieving separation”. Kaneko (Shinshu University; kkaneko@shinshu-u.ac.jp, JACS) has used the work to validate theoretical models; Schroder (Nottingham University; m.schroder@nottingham.ac.uk, Nature Chemistry) makes extensive use of the virial methods in subsequent hydrogen adsorption studies.

Title: What governs protein adsorption and immobilization at a charged solid surface?
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new paradigm for protein immobilization at charged surfaces, showing that the widely-accepted dominance of electrostatics needs to be supplemented with an understanding of the crucial role of protein flexibility (see Biophys. J. 100;3016 as an example of its influence on international research). It led to an Invited Speaker presentation at the BioInformatics meeting in Torun, Poland, June 2010 (organiser wiesiek@phys.uni.torun.pl). It has also led to a Knowledge Exchange project working with the SME “Solus Ltd” (contact ray.wakefield@rayal.com) on antibody adsorption for pathogen detection kits.

Title: New insights on growth mechanisms of protein clusters at surfaces : an AFM and simulation study
AdditionalInformation: This paper provides unique insight into the formation mechanisms of protein films that are essential for surface bio-functionalization, providing crucial information that is unobtainable in any other way.  It initiated joint research with the world-leading Genetically Engineered Materials Science & Engineering Center at the University of Washington (led by Prof. Sarikaya, sarikaya@u.washington.edu), from where a researcher worked with Mulheran to apply the methodology to gold-binding peptides. Along with [Phys.Rev.Lett. 100;068102], it led to a new EPSRC research grant (EP/E013384/2, £124,320, PI Mulheran) and an Invited presentation at the ACS national meeting in Salt Lake City, March 2009 (contact , sarikaya@u.washington.edu ).

Title: Mechanisms and dynamics of protein clustering on a solid surface
AdditionalInformation: This interdisciplinary work applies nucleation theory from condensed matter physics to protein aggregation at a solid inorganic surface, developing a new framework to understand fundamental processes in surface functionalization for biomedical applications. Along with [Langmuir 24;9648], it led to a new research grant "A multiscale modelling methodology for protein aggregation on surfaces" funded by EPSRC (EP/E013384/2, £124,320, PI Mulheran). The work initiated new joint research between Mulheran and Dr Gavin Bell (Gavin.Bell@warwick.ac.uk) from the University of Warwick on metal cluster nucleation and growth on chemically modified graphene leading to a new joint paper submitted to Physical Review in October 2013.

Title: Fibre cross-section determination and variability in sisal and flax and its effects on fibre performance characterisation
AdditionalInformation: New insights into measurement of natural fibre cross sectional area (CSA) and its variability. CSA values from fibre diameter measurements on flax and sisal fibres shown to be double the values obtained from actual observation of fibre CSA. This translates directly into errors in values of fibre engineering properties. Results have been followed up by Sørensen and Madsen (muas@risoe.dtu.dk) at Technical University of Denmark (J .Mater. Sci. 46:2011;6344). Publication led to invitation to present results at BEPS conference, Vienna 2011 (conference chair a.bismarck@imperial.ac.uk )and industrial funding of a PhD project (Maria.Soliman@SABIC-europe.com)

Title: Temperature dependence of the interfacial shear strength in glass–fibre polypropylene composites
AdditionalInformation: First publication by any group of results on direct measurement of the temperature dependence of interfacial strength in glass-polypropylene. Also describes unique method development, combining microbond testing in thermomechanical analyser. Paper reviewer stated this was an “excellent study” where the “quantification was particularly important” and that “the paper should be published rapidly as written” (CS&T editor Karl Schulte ‎schulte@tu-harburg.de). Results followed up by Arao (yoshihiko.arao@gmail.com) at Doshisha University, Kyoto, Japan (Composites Part A 55:2013;19). Resulted in KTA funded project with PPG Industries to evaluate their fibre products using our techniques (vanderwoude@ppg.com).

Title: The influence of fibre length, diameter and concentration on the impact performance of long glass-fibre reinforced polyamide 6,6
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the first published quantification of the different relative contributions of fibre length and diameter to the levels of notched, unnotched and multiaxial impact resistance of glass fibre polyamide composites. Described as “inspirational” by Ems-Grivory, a major producer of glass fiber reinforced polyamides (philipp.harder@emsgrivory.com). Being followed up by Yan at University of Southern Queensland, Australia (Composites Part B 46:2013;221) and used by researchers at South China University of Technology, Chinese Academy of Science, Shenyang, China, Chemnitz University of Technology, Germany, Sichuan University, China and the Hassan at the University of Malaya (ahassan@um.edu.my).

Title: The influence of fibre length, diameter and concentration on the strength and strain to failure of glass fibre-reinforced polyamide 6,6
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The research advances knowledge into the significance of fibre length and diameter for determining the strength of glass fibre polyamide composites. First systematic study publishing data contrasting the extreme differences in the composite strain to failure depending on fibre length. Resulted in two invited seminars at major materials suppliers to the automotive industry Rhodia, France, 2012 (Franco.SPERONI@eu.rhodia.com) and BASF, Germany, 2013. Used by Chevali at University of Alabama, USA (Composites Part A 41:2010;1253) and researchers at University of Girona, Spain, Dakota State University, USA, the Chinese Academy of Science, Shenyang, VTT Technical Research Centre Finland and Technical University of Denmark.

Title: Poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) hollow fibre membranes for gas separation
AdditionalInformation: This publication reports the first ever successful production of polyvinylchloride (PVC) gas separation hollow fibre membranes. O2/O3 separation by a membrane has been demonstrated uniquely with significant industrial implications - water sterilization/waste treatment etc.  Filtration Ltd funded the work, with others subsequently engaged e.g., Degremont Technologies (bernhard.paolini@degtec.com). Excerpt from reviews (editor Georg Krausch Krausch@uni-mainz.de): “This is a beautiful piece of work dealing with membranes made of hollow PVC fibres and their test for gas separation. The work is well done, clearly described and I cannot find any issue that would justify lengthy revisions. The work can be published as submitted.”

Title: Studies on gas permeation performance of asymmetric polysulfone hollow fiber mixed matrix membranes using nanosized fumed silica as fillers
AdditionalInformation: Novel mixed matrix hollow fibre membranes for gas separation were spun using fumed silica nanoparticles as fillers in polysulfone substrate. Under special loading and dispersion conditions, the presence of fumed silica particles increases the permeability of gases, particularly CO2, and heightens CO2/CH4 selectivity beyond unfilled polysulfone membranes. These performance enhancements have major implications for gas sweetening and natural gas recovery applications. The work is an international collaboration with support from The British Commonwealth (Twinning PhD Programme) and Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Professor A. Fauzi Ismail (afauzi@utm.my). Keynote Speech delivered at an international conference (Membrane Science and Technology, Kuala Lumpur, August 2013).

Title: Polysulfone mixed matrix gas separation hollow fibre membranes filled with polymer and carbon xerogels
AdditionalInformation: Advanced xerogel nano-materials have been produced, characterised and used to spin novel gas separation mixed matrix hollow fibre membranes with polysulfone as substrate polymer. The composite structures developed increase gas transmission and improve membrane selectivity for certain gas penetrants and highlight exploitable phenomena in mixed matrix membrane fabrication, structure and performance. The materials are exciting developments in the areas of carbon capture and storage, and oxy-fuel production. The research has resulted in industrial engagement from Doosan Babcock (vinay.mulgundmath@doosan.com) and Parker Domnick Hunter (Scott.Kelly@parker.com), and funding discussions are underway through Scottish Enterprise (Ana.Gallardo@scotent.co.uk). This work enhances advanced materials gas separation technology.

Title: Multiprotein interactions during surface adsorption : a molecular dynamics study of lysozyme aggregation at a charged solid surface
AdditionalInformation: The first successful simulation of multiple protein adsorption at a solid inorganic surface, providing a platform to develop tailored protein films with desired properties. It led to new joint with Dr Barbara Jachimska (ncjachim@cyf-kr.edu.pl) from the Polish Academy of Science, Krakow, with Mulheran a named consultant on a recent Polish National Science Council grant “Structure and properties of protein layers: from biomolecule to functional layer”. It led to an Invited Speakerpresentation to a CECAM Workshop at Lausanne, Switzerland in May 2011 (organiser stefano.corni@nano.cnr.it), and to aCCP5 Summer School Plenary Seminar at Cardiff, July 2012 (organiser john.purton@stfc.ac.uk).

Title: Extraction of chemical information of suspensions using radiative transfer theory to remove multiple scattering effects : application to a model multicomponent system
AdditionalInformation: A novel method developed by Thennadil  (doi 10.1021/ac9011667) is extended to industrially relevant situations, and its ability to monitor multicomponent mixtures was demonstrated.  This has led to a patent application (GB1120075.5, November 2011) and Proof of concept funding from Scottish Enterprise (grant number) for developing prototypes based on this methodology with a view to spinning out a high growth startup. Also the results of this work are being applied through a FP7 project (Grant 280813, OPTICO) to develop technology for monitoring suspension polymerisation reaction in partnership with BASF (libor.seda@basf.com).

Title: Extraction of chemical information of suspensions using radiative transfer theory to remove multiple scattering effects : application to a model two-component system
AdditionalInformation: This paper was highlighted in the Analytical Chemistry journal’s website for its novelty (J_Griffiths@acs.org). It reported a unique approach which combines physics of light propagation with traditional chemometric techniques to address a long standing problem in spectroscopic monitoring of the particle size and composition of suspensions encountered in pharmaceutical, food and agriculture and speciality chemicals industries. This work has led to international collaborations through a FP7 project (grant 280813, OPTICO) and a group in the food research institute IRTEA, France through a visiting researcher funded by IRTEA (jean-michel.roger@irstea.fr) and a CASE project with Fuji Film Imaging Colourants (jill.johnson@fujifilmic.com).

Title: Optical properties of apple skin and flesh in the wavelength range from 350 to 2200 nm
AdditionalInformation: The study applied a new approach to investigate the characteristics of apple tissue and skin through their bulk optical properties which are extracted from spectroscopic measurements using the radiative transfer theory. This study provided new insights which can help in the grading of apples and other vegetable and meat products using vis-NIR spectroscopy. Following from this study, the collaborating institution (Division of Mechatronics, Katholeike University) has set up a new group led by Wouter Saeys (Wouter.Saeys@biw.kuleuven.be) to further develop this approach.

Title: Relationship between the Kubelka-Munk scattering and radiative transfer coefficients
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Optical Society of America A
AdditionalInformation: The relationship between the parameters of the simple Kubelka-Munk theory and the parameters of the rigorous but computationally radiative transfer theory that was developed in this study, allows for real time spectroscopic monitoring of suspensions and powders. The results of this work have been used by other groups (e.g. Tablets characterisation, Reutlingen University, Rudolf.kessler@reutlingen-university.de). Through a FP7 funded project (Grant 238013, Multimod), using these results as a basis, we are investigating its use for monitoring emulsion polymerisation reactions, which has led to first prize for the best poster at the international conference, APACT 2013 (colin.g.clarke@nnl.co.uk).

Title: Quantifying adhesion energy of mechanical coatings at atomistic scale
AdditionalInformation: Lack of adhesion-energy values prevented accurate analysis of coatings in industry. For the first time, adhesion energy in tool-coatings was quantified at the atomistic scale with first principle calculations and linked to Finite Element modelling for coating analysis. The method was validated by world leading industry DIAD Group (Tooling) and TBZ-PARIV GmbH (software) (RTD Director, Dr. Maddalena Rostagno, maddalena.rostagno@diadgroup.com; Director, Mr. Jürgen Leopold, jleopold@tbz-pariv.de) which led to improved analysis accuracy by at least 30% and modelling efficiency by 10 fold. TBZ introduced the method/procedure to multi-scale cutting-tool analysis and developed a new EU-FP7 project together with Strathclyde (604240 - LoCoLite).

Title: Electronic property and bonding configuration at the TiN(111)/VN(111) interface
AdditionalInformation: With collaboration with internationally leading experts (named authors) to meet one of the challenges in material/manufacturing sciences, for the first time the atomic structure of TiN/VN interfaces has been revealed. First principle simulations were validated through experimental testing. The work provided a world-class coating industry with a method of obtaining desired  properties for nitride coatings for enhanced performances (AIN, Dr Gonzalo Fuentes, Project Manager, gfuentes@ain.es) and initiated collaborations with leading software company TBZ-PARIV (Director,  Mr. Jürgen Leopold,  jleopold@tbz-pariv.de) for industrial exploitation. These laid solid modelling foundation in EU M3-2S project (NMP3-SL-2008-213600, €4.7M, five industry partners).

Title: A new methodology for modelling erosion–corrosion regimes on real surfaces : Gliding down the galvanic series for a range of metal-corrosion systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents for the first time a 3D erosion-corrosion model and map predicting the transition between erosion-corrosion regimes, and reflects real geometry rather than the accepted practice of tailoring of 2D models to a 3D space. The model considers material properties; the effects of electrochemical potential and pH. The research has resulted in a collaboration request from Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile in the application of the erosion-corrosion model to the Chilean copper-mining industry (mwalczak@ing.puc.cl). Regarded as a paradigm-shift by the community, it has led to an invited plenary address at the 3rd International Conference on Tribo-Corrosion (blaupj@ornl.gov).

Title: Mapping erosion-corrosion of carbon steel in oil exploration conditions : some new approaches to characterizing mechanisms and synergies
AdditionalInformation: The application of an Erosion-Corrosion model within the oil and gas industry is presented for the first time. Using crude oil from the Sirte oil-field in Libya, and carbon steel from the National Oil Corporation, it reflects upstream and downstream environments and successfully applied within industry (ghaith.abdulrahman@uob.edu.ly). Led to the keynote presentation at 67th Conference for the Society of Tribologists and Lubrication (lewis.rosado@wpafb.af.mil). It resulted in a £1.01M EPSRC Award EP/K013319/1, to develop new materials for tidal energy systems. Has formed the foundation for a diverse range of applications by others: oil-sands slurry (fcheng@ucalgary.ca; and dengjingen@126.com), and hip-joint implants (Mathew_T_Mathew@rush.edu).

Title: Micro-abrasion–corrosion of a Co–Cr/UHMWPE couple in Ringer's solution : an approach to construction of mechanism and synergism maps for application to bio-implants
AdditionalInformation: A new approach for mapping tribo-corrosion for artificial hip-joints is presented. This reflected the first application of tribo-corrosion synergy mapping to bio-engineering applications. This paper tests Co-Cr/UHMWPE to optimise the tribo-corrosion regime, making this a viable alternative to the conventional implant that has recently been recalled (http://www.depuy.com/depuy-asr-recall-usen).  As such, the research advances the state-of-the-art, demonstrating that safety regimes for metal-on-metal hip joints replacements cannot be dependent on lubrication regime only. Informed an award winning paper at the 18th International conference on Wear of Materials. Led to the invited keynote presentation(Irina.Hussainova@ttu.ee) on tribo-corrosion, 21st International Baltic Conference on Tribology.

Title: Some comments on mapping the combined effects of slurry concentration, impact velocity and electrochemical potential on the erosion–corrosion of WC/Co–Cr coatings
AdditionalInformation: The third of a series of papers developed to describe a map for erosion-corrosion of metal matrix composite coatings, which defines the synergy between the erosion and corrosion processes based on the dissolution of the interface between the matrix and the reinforcement material. Used by Narayanan to develop a map for fretting-corrosion of Ti (Wear, 268, 11-12, 1537-1541, 2010) and Wang for defining erosion-corrosion regimes for Fe based amorphous coatings (Corrosion Science, 53, 10, 3177-3185, 2011). The paper is referenced in the ASTM G119 standard (revised 2009) and the methodology forms part of the ASTM G119 standard.

Title: Design for remanufacture : a literature review and future research needs
AdditionalInformation: This first critical review of Design-for-Remanufacture highlights gaps in extant literature and challenges within DFRem and contradicts accepted wisdom by showing that operational factors are key to successful Design-for-remanufacture implementation rather than designers’ knowledge of it.
