The Scottish Government independent consultant (john.taylor@optimat.co.uk) stated the research was: “key to us developing the policy options around remanufacture of vehicles in Scotland […] it helped us understand the barriers and opportunities in transitioning from the current supply chain model to a future circular economy”.  “[…] it refutes OEM’s use of  designer expertise as an excuse for not implementation design-for-remanufacture” (kwatt@ukwhitegoods.co.uk).

Title: Product design for product/service systems : design experiences from Swedish industry
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides concrete evidence of the influence of design-for-remanufacture on product-service systems for the first time. It demonstrates that Design-for-Remanufacture enhances product-service systems by removing obstacles and reducing costs. The research utilised design-for-remanufacturing guidelines within three international, different sector manufacturers: Toyota Material Handling Group,  Swepac International AB and Electrolux AB (REKO-project  lead: Professor  Björkman- mats.bjorkman@liu.se). The paper was given a “Highly-commended award” as the Journal’s most outstanding article for 2010; was given “excellence” in criteria including rigor, relevance, up-to-date and novelty (Editor: d.j.bennett@aston.ac.uk). Industry comments:  “enhances understanding of  sustainable manufacturing  strategies” - Jaguar Land Rover  (kgosai@jaguarlandrover.com).

Title: Application of active disassembly to extend profitable remanufacturing in small electrical and electronic products
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the first research investigating marrying active-disassembly and design-for-remanufacture to manage small-sized Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE). It refutes accepted wisdom by showing, for the first time, how to profitably remanufacture small-sized WEEE and how cost-effective remanufacture can be extended to sectors that were not previously viable. It included case study analysis of over 15 automotive Electronic Control Units (ECUs) given they are almost impossible to conventionally, profitably disassemble cleanly. Comments include:  “valuable new research foundation” (Austrian Society for Systems Engineering and Automation, bernd.kopacek@sat-research.at) and, “will assist sustainable-manufacture […] and is informative” (Wax-RDC Limited- damien@wax-rdc.com).

Title: A method for performing high accuracy temperature measurements in low-pressure sooting flames using two-line atomic fluorescence
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports on atomic-fluorescence temperature measurements with unprecedented accuracy, providing vital data for understanding soot formation in flames.  A leading research group at Lund University has built a diode laser instrument directly based on the one we developed in this work (marcus.alden@forbrf.lth.se).  Researchers at the University of Adelaide followed up on our work and state that our research resulted in “…calibration-free single-point measurements with higher accuracy and precision than that achievable with dye lasers…” (DOI:10.1007/s00340-011-4497-0). This is one of three publications supporting the case for award of an EPSRC SUPERGEN grant on direct flame solid oxide fuel cells (EP/K021036/1).

Title: High-repetition-rate combustion thermometry with two-line atomic fluorescence excited by diode lasers
AdditionalInformation: Accepted by Optics Letters without revisions (Topical Editor: Edward Whittaker, ewhittak@stevens.edu). Reviewer1: “This is an excellent paper describing kHz-repetition flame temperature measurements.” “...an important contribution to measurement and combustion science.” Reviewer2: “…reports a significant advance in thermometry.” This project resulted in an invited talk by IB at the University of Duisburg-Essen in 2009 and a joint project by a visiting student on measurement of metal atom concentrations in microwave plasma reactors used for nanoparticle synthesis (christof.schulz@uni-due.de).  This is one of three publications supporting the case for award of an EPSRC SUPERGEN grant on direct flame solid oxide fuel cells (EP/K021036/1).

Title: An assembly oriented design framework for product structure engineering and assembly sequence planning
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a novel framework to promote proactive design for assembly, which provides a foundation for a new approach for complex systems used by CALT (http://www.calt.com/english/).  The framework was developed through a combination of theoretical assembly-feature analysis and validation through eight industrial case studies. This work resulted in the first space international collaboration funded by the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology (DFB80730/Y11001). The research has formed the foundation for a portfolio of projects and the newly established Strathclyde Space Mechatronic Systems Technology Laboratory – first overseas joint research laboratory invested by the Chinese Government in space sector (http://www.sdi.co.uk/news/2012/06/adm-newsletter/university-of-strathclyde-collaboration-with-china.aspx).

Title: Microflow valve control system design
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper on micro-flow of discrete flow nature which provides a basis for high precision flow applications in any sector. A theoretical model validated by experiments, and a valve and control system capable of accurately controlling flow rates between 0.09 and 400 ml/h is demonstrated. The research outcomes won a National Award for Knowledge Transfer Best Partnership Awards 2010 and MCN product of the year three times (Fiona@scottoiler.com).  KTA project (KTA115878) to experimentally investigate 3% estimated efficiency gain, will provide evidence to help Scottoiler to be sole BMW chain lubrication system supplier by adopting a lubrication system.

Title: Thermally induced inactivation and aggregation of urease : experiments and population balance modelling
AdditionalInformation: The key contribution was a novel conceptual and mathematical modeling framework for the quantitative understanding of the kinetics of thermal deactivation linked to subsequent aggregation of an unfolded enzyme. J Sefcik presented a plenary talk on this subject at the 4th International Conference on Population Balance Modeling in Berlin in 2010 (contact: Prof. Andreas Seidel-Morgenstern, seidel-morgenstern@mpi-magdeburg.mpg.de).

Title: Biocatalytic induction of supramolecular order
AdditionalInformation: The key advance was rapid structural control of self-assembly for bottom-up nanofabrication of supramolecular structures together with mechanistic explanation for the observed relationship between enzyme clustering and cooperativity in biocatalytic self-assembly. Reviewer’s comment: "This concept is important both from the basic science point of view as well as for various technological applications." (Dr Anne Pichon, Associate Editor, a.pichon@natureasia.com) This work has led to a series of follow up collaborations and publications (e.g., Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters, 2011; Soft Matter, 2011; Langmuir, 2012) and inspired further work by leading international groups on cooperative self-assembly (Prof Zhimou Yang, yangzm@nankai.edu.cn).

Title: Effect of shear rate on aggregate size and morphology investigated under turbulent conditions in stirred tank
VolumeTitle: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
AdditionalInformation: The key contribution was a novel experimental technique to assess reversibility of aggregation and breakage in particulate systems under turbulent flow conditions. This approach allowed for the first time to perform direct experimental measurement of the smallest aggregate size subject to breakage under given flow conditions. This work has been instrumental for development of continuous crystallisation processes in the EPSRC Centre for Innovative Manufacturing in Continuous Manufacturing and Crystallisation (EP/I033459/1; £5.9M) where J Sefcik is a co-investigator (Prof. Alastair Florence, EPSRC Centre Director, alastair.forence@strath.ac.uk).

Title: The integration of information and ideas : creating linkages through a novel concept design method
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new method for the representation of information and ideas and a means of enhancing utilisation of digital information sources in conceptual design. It provides a novel link between information management and idea generation leading to robust concept generation. The paper outlines the derivation of the method from the 6-3-5 approach and its development though three empirical industry studies. Aspects of the methodology have been utilised in a KTP (Hulley & Kirkwood, bill.kilpatrick@hulley.co.uk) to ensure the embedded system was orientated around the needs of engineers.

Title: Towards the realisation of an integratated decision support environment for organisational decision making
VolumeTitle: International Journal of the Decision Support System Technology
AdditionalInformation: A fundamental novel architecture of an Integrated Decision-Support Environment (IDSE), that distinguishes from traditional systems by flexibly (re)configuring its functions to support various decision applications (Figure 1), is presented. The IDSE was developed from extensive industrial requirements analysis, concept generation and prototype testing in an industrial case study (EPSRC EP/D505461/1 - NECTISE). It provides a balance between integration reliability and flexibility, greater functionality, and user support tools to reconfigure the environment to suit their specific application needs (iain.mckenna@baesystems.com). The IDSE is generic, can be applied to any application, and has led to a strategic partnership with the Primary Contractor (Richard.Trumper@baesystems.com).

Title: Thermomechanical analyses of ultrasonic welding process using thermal and acoustic softening effects
AdditionalInformation: A new computational model is developed that introduces predictive capability of ultrasonic welding/consolidation process by incorporating frictional heating and acoustic softening effects based on intrinsic material behaviour for the first time (http://www.iom3.org/news/embedding-sensors-using-sound). The model was created from experimental data, verified through parameter assessment, and validated through experiments. The world-leader in ultrasonic consolidation process, Solidica Inc USA, used model results to accurately predict and optimise this process, significantly reducing the number of trials and resulting costs and time (dawn.white@solidica.com). Nanchang University China use the model to optimise the process of embedding sensors/actuators in structural health monitoring applications for GM China (zhuzhq@ncu.edu.cn).

Title: Interactions of amines with silicon species in undersaturated solutions leads to dissolution and/or precipitation of silica
AdditionalInformation: This is the first demonstration of harvesting silica from an unsaturated solution, which was achieved by rigorous experimentation of interfacial molecular interactions and dissolution-precipitation pathways. All three reviewers rated this article “highest” for significance, novelty, broad interest, and high scholarly presentation (editor David G. Whitten, whitten@unm.edu). Comments included: “This fundamental and well prepared paper is important as it should prompt further investigations …The reported results will provoke an interested reaction in a broader worldwide audience of chemists, biochemists, biologists and ecologists”, this “manuscript …. continues the tradition of excellent papers from that group.”

Title: Chemistry of aqueous silica nanoparticle surfaces and the mechanism of selective peptide adsorption
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper developed a new Interface Force Field, available for free, as substantiated by “a very recent study of Patwardhan emerges as a landmark” (Chem. Rev., 113, 4216, 2013). It also resulted in an invited talk (American Chemical Society, 2012, Stephen.Clarson@uc.edu) and supported external funding (US Air Force FA9550-10-1-0024, £283,333). All reviewers rated this “highest” for significance, novelty, broad interest, and scholarly and commented: “….this paper is quite significant in laying groundwork for understanding sequence/binding correlations.  I highly recommend publication of the manuscript” (editor Paul Cremer, cremer-office@jacs.acs.org).

Title: The impact of resources on decision making
VolumeTitle: AI EDAM - Artificial Intelligence for Engineering Design, Analysis and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: Novel insights on the nature and chronological emergence of impacts that resources can have in multi-organisational and stakeholder decision-making involving complex systems are presented. Using an industrially defined scenario involving experienced decision-makers, the demonstrated variety and significance of these impacts have established limitations of current decision-support solutions that significantly impair their ability to provide effective decision-making support. BAE Systems, a world-leading defence contractor, stated the research provided a “better understanding” that can “improve decision-making processes” (Iain.McKenna@baesystems.com). Reviewers stated that the “high quality” paper described research with “lots of potential”, making a “refreshing contribution” to a “long neglected area” (Guest-Editor: andy.dong@sydney.edu.au).

Title: Prediction of residual stress in multilayered coatings with a linearly elastic model incorporating density functional theory calculations
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, nanoscale high-precision density functional calculations (to obtain material data) and constitutive modelling of Representative Volume Elements (RVE) were combined to evaluate local residual stresses in multi-layered coatings at nanoscale (EU-FP7 NMP3-SL-2008-213600) in order to overcome tedious experimental procedures. The research was validated through physical tests of the coated surfaces. With this approach, practising engineers in leading companies (AIN, gfuentes@ain.es; DIAD group, maddalena.rostagno@diadgroup.com; TBZ-PARIV, jleopold@tbz-pariv.de) could, for the first time, predict the residual stresses caused by lattice mismatches in coatings an order of magnitude more precisely and efficiently than existing techniques/procedures.

Title: New technique for determining the critical loads of a thin coating on a tool–steel substrate by considering the initiation of cracks in the coating
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, parametric cohesive-zone modelling was introduced to coating failure analysis which led to a completely new approach for determining load-bearing capacity of a hard-coating on a soft substrate (EU-FP7 NMP3-SL-2008-213600). The approach and model were validated through nano-indentations at EMPA. The method replaced tedious testing/characterising procedures used in industry (Dr Fuentes, Technical Manager, AIN, gfuentes@ain.es; Dr Rostagno, RTD Director, DIAD group, maddalena.rostagno@diadgroup.com, and Mr Leopold, Director, TBZ-PARIV,  jleopold@tbz-pariv.de) for higher efficiency (at least 10-fold improvements). The work attracted a world-leading material research institute to standardise the procedure for more widespread applications (Dr Michler, Director, EMPA, Switzerland, Johann.Michler@empa.ch).

Title: Linking learning and knowledge creation to project success in Six Sigma projects : an empirical investigation
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a novel linkage between Six-Sigma and theory of organisational learning based on the execution of 52 Six-Sigma projects within the energy sector.  The contribution of deliberate learning is examined within a large organisation Vestas, Denmark. The findings reject the notion that investing in more resources for manufacturing projects enhances Six-Sigma project success rate. The reviewers stated: “This award winning research demonstrates how resources come together to create knowledge and enhance performance in Six Sigma projects” (linde037@umn.edu). The initial concept was presented and won the Honourable Award for Theoretical/Empirical Research Award at the 43rd DSI Conference 2012.

Title: Modeling of PAHs in low pressure sooting premixed methane flame
AdditionalInformation: This work proposes a new mechanism for the formation/consumption of PAHs in flames which challenges the main combustion mechanism in the literature.  The measurements made here are central to understanding soot inception in low-pressure flames.  This research was the subject of an invited talk by IB at the AIAA Aerospace Sciences Meeting in Nashville in 2012 (robert.w.pitz@vanderbilt.edu).  The work has led to on-going joint research with Lund University funded by a CECOST grant (zhongshan.li@forbrf.lth.se). This is one of three publications supporting the case for award of an EPSRC SUPERGEN grant on direct flame solid oxide fuel cells (EP/K021036/1).

Title: Electrostatic interactions of charged bodies from the weak- to the strong-coupling regime
VolumeTitle: EPL: A Letters Journal Exploring the Frontiers of Physics
AdditionalInformation: This paper develops the first theory that accurately predicts the properties of the electric double layer from the weak to the intermediate through to the strong coupling limit.  It led to invitations to speak at Lund University (jan.forsman@teokem.lu.se) and Utrecht University (r.vanroij@uu.nl), as well as at workshops and conferences organized by experts in the field (e.g., “Advances in modelling electrolyte solutions,” Statistical Mechanics and Thermodynamics Group, RSC, London, UK, 2012, andrew.masters@manchester.ac.uk; “New challenges in electrostatics of soft and disordered matter,” CECAM, Toulouse, France, 2012, jd489@cam.ac.uk).  This paper was included in the Best of 2010 Articles Collection for Europhysics Letters (http://iopscience.iop.org/0295-5075/page/Best%20of%202010%20Collection).

Title: DynamO : a free O(N) general event-driven molecular dynamics simulator
AdditionalInformation: In this work, we develop DynamO, the first open source event driven molecular dynamics code.  It is currently being used by several research groups around the world, including Australia (ANU, swilliams@rsc.anu.edu.au), Germany (University of Göttingen, Qiong.Bai@theorie.physik.uni-goettingen.de, RWTH Aachen University, hamidi@aices.rwth-aachen.de), The Netherlands (Unversity of Twente, j.s.l.gonzalezbriones@utwente.nl), and the United Kingdom (University of Bristol, Paddy.Royall@bristol.ac.uk, University of Manchester, r.curtis@manchester.ac.uk; University of Warwick, G.O.Rutter@warwick.ac.uk).  It also forms a key aspect of the work in the successful BBSRC grant “Understanding and predicting bioprocessibility: an integrated and practical approach towards improvement in bioprocess yields” (BB/I017194/1, £579,057).

Title: Six Sigma implementation Framework for SMEs : a roadmap to manage and sustain the change
AdditionalInformation: The authors present a unique and practical framework developed specifically for SMEs to assist with the implementation and sustainability of Six-Sigma. The longitudinal study over a four year period comprised of 80 UK manufacturing SMEs, and was followed by semi-structured interviews with ten of the companies. A multi-institutional team of academics from The Netherlands (jwj.timans@home.nl; c.t.b.ahaus@rug.nl; D.M.vanSolingen@tudelft.nl) actively approached Strathclyde to adopt this framework as a foundation for their research into Six-Sigma Framework in Dutch SMEs. The initial framework was presented and won the best Research paper award at the 41st DSI Conference 2010.

Title: Integrating design for remanufacture into the design process : the operational factors
AdditionalInformation: Previous research has focussed on technical aspects of design-for-remanufacturing. For the first time, the major external and internal operational factors (design priorities, OEM-remanufacturer relationships, designer motivation) affecting design-for-remanufacture implementation are identified and elaborated. The operational factors provide a framework for organising more effective design-for-remanufacture. The research engaged eight international and UK based electromechanical companies including Perkins, Terex, Caterpillar, ZF, and Cummins (Ridley_Sara_J@cat.com), through triangulation of document analysis, operational research, and semi-structured interviews. The findings are being used within the FP7 project GREENet (PIRSES-GA-2010-269122).  Industrialists have commented “it can help companies meet legislative and environmental pressures by assisting design-for-remanufacture implementation” (mark.danis@ts.fujitsu.com).

Title: Identifying the dominant failure mode in the hot extrusion tooling used to forge nickel based superalloy
AdditionalInformation: Describes a novel approach to enhancing the life prediction of die sets used in closed die manufacture of precision forged components.  It includes the identification and characterisation of the dominant failure modes for die sets based on an empirical study. The approach is being applied within the turbine blade forging facility at Rolls-Royce, Inchinnan resulting in a case study showing die life and reduced cost benefits,  (Dr Steven Halliday  steven.halliday@rolls-royce.com).  The work has also informed the on-going forging and modelling capability of the High Value Manufacturing Catapult and that of collaborators (e.g. Birmingham University (Prof Jeff Brooks , j.brooks@bham.ac.uk).

Title: Enhancing the design dialogue : an architecture to document engineering design activities
AdditionalInformation: A novel software architecture and system to identify and capture design activities and critical decisions during synchronous design is described.  The work provides a multi-media based approach for systematically capturing dynamic design decisions and rationale in real-time, enabling re-use in future projects. The work built on state of the art research coupled with an in-depth company based case study. The system was validated through its use in industry during design review meetings (james.ward2@baesystems.com). The approach was part of a larger programme of novel approaches to design documentation involving Cambridge, Heriot-Watt and Bath, and influenced subsequent work in each institution (chris.mcmahon@bris.ac.uk).

Title: Porosity tailoring mechanisms in sonicated polymeric foams
AdditionalInformation: The paper reports a theoretical model of energy and mass balances, for the five stages of polymerisation of PU-foam that identifies the physical mechanism by which ultrasound impacts on the resultant porosity. The paper underpinned an EPSRC research grant at Strathclyde (EP/I000577, £190k) to investigate improvements to foam covering of prosthetic limbs, and a TSB project at Heriot-Watt University (TSB No 101138, £500k). The TSB project exploited the fact that the reported phenomenon for polymer foams was reproduced in bread (C.Torres@lboro.ac.uk) and has resulted in a  patent application (“Process for the manufacture of a leavened foodstuff”, Patent Application No PCT/GB2012/051365).

Title: In situ monitoring of stirring effects on polymorphic transformations during cooling crystallization of carbamazepine
AdditionalInformation: This work reports on application of a novel, custom-built measurement system for in situ measurements of the effects of stirring on the resulting polymorph of carbamazepine during cooling crystallisation. The applicability of this work to other research fields is demonstrated by resulting joint research with the University of Glasgow (klaas.wynne@glasgow.ac.uk) on phase transitions in super-cooled liquids.  Reviewer comments (Associate Editor: Allan Myerson, myerson@mit.edu): “Interesting is the development and application of the custom-build setup for measuring simultaneously the attenuation coefficient and light scattering. The corresponding results reveal clear and useful trends regarding the formation of the main two polymorphs of carbamazepine.”

Title: Metaldehyde removal from aqueous solution by adsorption and ion exchange mechanisms onto activated carbon and polymeric sorbents
AdditionalInformation: Based on this research, a novel adsorption system shows complete removal of metaldehyde from water samples, identified as a national concern (WRC, andrew.davey@wrcplc.co.uk). We have been contacted by global companies (ACWA: pbrewer@acwa.co.uk; MWH UK Ltd: Karen.Murray@mwhglobal.com) seeking to develop this technology for water treatment processes. The system is now in field trials with Anglian Water (via ACWA), after being successfully verified with test samples from Scottish Water (graeme.moore@scottishwater.co.uk), efficaciously working to industry levels (<1 ppb), An invention disclosure has been filed and patent protection is underway (Chris Mort, Intellectual Property Manager attached to RKES, University of Strathclyde, christopher.mort@strath.ac.uk).

Title: Chemical transformations of a crystalline coordination polymer : a multi-stage solid–vapour reaction manifold
AdditionalInformation: Supported directly by beam-time at STFC and DLS, the paper demonstrates counter-intuitive behaviour of non-porous materials which show significant uptakes of CO2 and vapours contrasting their internal capacity. The research suggests synthetic routes to novel carbon capture materials, which are now the subject of an expanding national collaboration (two-way student exchange) with Brammer (University of Sheffield, lee.brammer@sheffield.ac.uk). The results underpinned a successful EPSRC-University of Sheffield fellowship application, for Vitorica-Yrezabal (currently University of Manchester; inigo.vitorica@manchester.ac.uk). Additional follow-up work, studying the role of fluoralkyl linkers in CO2 storage, has resulted in a further manuscript submitted to Journal of the American Chemical Society.

Title: Forced convection spinning of hollow fibre membranes : modelling of mass transfer in the dry gap, and prediction of active layer thickness and depth of orientation
AdditionalInformation: A novel mass transfer model provides insight into solvent evaporation rates during dry-jet/wet hollow fibre membrane spinning. The model improves the understanding of fabrication, structure and property relationships, and helps materials to be produced with heightened selectivities. This will assist membrane technology to be more widely implemented in a range of separation applications. This work has led to a visiting scholar invitation to Universiti Teknologi Malaysia in September 2013 to give talks and to participate in planning for further collaboration. Reviews include (editor Bart Van der Bruggen Bart.vanderbruggen@cit.kuleuven.be): “In my opinion this is excellent work, with scientific and technical relevance.”

Title: Prediction of the n-hexane/water and 1-octanol/water partition coefficients for environmentally relevant compounds using molecular simulation
AdditionalInformation: Results reported in this paper opened the possibility of using molecular simulation to predict solvation in an industrial context, and led to a Citizen Science project in the Iberian voluntary computing platform (project “Soluvel” at www.ibercivis.com/en/experimentos/). It was awarded the 2011 International Association of Chemical Thermodynamics Poster Award at the 25th European Symposium on Applied Thermodynamics (esat2011@spbu.ru). The Editor of AIChE Journal (Stanley Sandler – aichej@che.udel.edu) was particularly impressed by this paper, commenting: “I thought this was an excellent piece of work”, while peer reviews classified it as “an excellent manuscript that makes an important contribution to the literature”.

Title: Molecular dynamics simulation of self-assembly of n-Decyltrimethylammonium Bromide micelles
AdditionalInformation: This paper served as a reference-case for later work on modelling the synthesis of mesoporous silica materials, which led to two projects funded by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology (references PTDC/EQU-EQU/099423/2008 and PTDC/QUI-QUI/109914/2009 – total funding 240000 Euro) and a recent EPSRC First Grant (reference EP/L014297/1). New insights on the mechanism of micelle fusion reported in this paper were used by many other researchers working on understanding surfactant self-assembly (e.g., c.d.bain@durham.ac.uk; azp@Princeton.edu; K.Edler@bath.ac.uk; rlarson@umich.edu). It led to an invited lecture by M Jorge at the 9th National Meeting of Chemical-Physics in Aveiro, Portugal (jrgomes@ua.pt).

Title: Molecular dynamics simulation of the early stages of the synthesis of periodic mesoporous silica
AdditionalInformation: This work was recognised by the award of an Honorable Mention in the 2008 IBM-Portugal Scientific Prize (www-05.ibm.com/pt/pc/vencedores/) and a “Professor João Cabral Scholarship” by the Portuguese-British Association (assoclbdop@gmail.com). Together with a reference study on micelle self-assembly, it was used as the main support to build cases for an EU-funded “HPC-Europa2” grant (project number:228398), two projects funded by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology (references PTDC/EQU-EQU/099423/2008 and PTDC/QUI-QUI/109914/2009 – total funding 240000 Euro), and an EPSRC First Grant (reference EP/L014297/1 – total funding £125000) in partnership with the group of Monson (monson@ecs.umass.edu), who are world leaders in this field.

Title: Adsorption of propane, propylene and isobutane on a metal–organic framework : molecular simulation and experiment
AdditionalInformation: This paper was ranked within the Top 25 Hottest Articles in Chemical Engineering Science from April to June 2009 (http://top25.sciencedirect.com/subject/chemical-engineering/5/journal/chemical-engineering-science/00092509/archive/22/). This work is relevant to the use of MOFs in the industrially important issue of separating alkenes and alkanes. It led to an invited lecture on this topic at the 3rd Portuguese Young Chemists Meeting in Porto, Portugal (3pychem@spq.pt), and to an invitation by the editor of Molecular Simulation (Jerome Delhommelle - jdelhommelle@chem.und.edu) to write a review article on modelling adsorption in MOFs with open metal sites (article in press, DOI: 10.1080/08927022.2013.829228).

Title: The influence of void size on the micropolar constitutive properties of model heterogeneous materials
VolumeTitle: European Journal of Mechanics A: Solids
AdditionalInformation: Extends recently published work (Beveridge et al, 2013, Int. J. of Solids & Structures, 50, 1, p. 246-255) by presenting first experimental data and substantiating FE results determining the influence of void size on the micropolar elastic constitutive properties of heterogeneous materials with regular, periodic void distribution. The research, combined with other work of the authors, was subsequently enhanced and applied to the first numerically and experimentally confirmed  micopolar mechanical characterization of cortical bone as described in follow-up paper 'Cortical Bone Micropolarity: The Role of Haversian Canals', submitted to Scientific Reports (editor, scientificreports@nature.com, March 2013).

Title: A novel approach to modelling and simulating the contact behaviour between a human hand model and a deformable object
VolumeTitle: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: A new interactive environment for evaluation with force and visual feedback that can revolutionise human-computer interaction with a multiple sensory interface is presented. The biomechanical characteristics of the human hand were incorporated within a 3D Finite-Element model and illustrated through case-study simulation. The research led to collaboration with the internationally renowned maxillofacial deformity surgeon Professor Ayoub (Ashraf.Ayoub@glasgow.ac.uk) resulting in the development of the world’s first maxillofacial haptic model. The paper provided a foundation for a highly rated (13/15) Strathclyde led FP7 proposal (Jan’10, Thomas.Mckinlay@ec.europa.eu), and forms the basis for an additional ERC Synergy Grant proposal submission worth €9M (ERC-2013-SyG- 610191).

Title: Six-node triangle finite volume method for solids with a rotational degree of freedom for incompressible material
AdditionalInformation: Extends capabilities of previously published higher order CVFEM  (Pan & Wheel, 2003, Computers & Structures, 81, 5, p321-329) to the incompressible material regime. Demonstrates that the CVFEM remains 'locking free' on approaching the incompressible limit, unlike conventional FEM. Work has recently influenced and informed research by other international researchers, notably Cavalcante et al, University of Virginia, USA (Int. J. of Solids & Structures,49, 15-16, p2037-2050, 2012, Composites Part B-Engineering, 43, 6, p2521-2543 & 2012, J. of App. Mech, 79, 5) as well as authors themselves (Pan & Wheel, 2011, Int. J. for Num. Meth. in Bioeng., 27,9 p1411-1426).

Title: A control volume-based finite element method for plane micropolar elasticity
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
AdditionalInformation: First published FE based method to rigorously pass previously proposed element patch tests (Providas & Kattis, 2002, Comput. Struct., 80, 2059-2069) for heterogeneous materials exhibiting higher order constitutive behaviour. Subsequently developed by other international researchers investigating hetetrogeneous materials notably Pindera et al, University of Virginia, USA (Pindera et al, 2009, Composites Part B-Engineering, 40, 5, p349-378, Pindera et al, 2010, Int. J. Of Plasticity, 26, 2, p273-287 ) and enhanced by others at EPFL, Switzerland (Zhao et al, Int. J. Of Comp. Meth., 7, 1, p151-166 ) as well as the author (Beveridge et al, 2013, Comput. Struct., 129, p54-62).

Title: The influence of thermo-oxidative degredation on the measured interface strength of glass fibre-polypropylene
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: Presenting a completely new insight into the influence of polymer degradation on composite interface. Research outcomes of this paper challenge most existing literature findings in this area by showing directly how polymer degradation would affect composite interface. Industrial interest in the research has resulted in a KTA project with PPG Industries to evaluate their fibre products using the reported techniques [J. vd. Woude, Associate Director S&T at PPG Industries (vanderwoude@ppg.com)] and a new research partnership with Prof Johnson (michael.Johnson@nottingham.ac.uk) at the University of Nottingham to jointly study composite interface with recycled fibres.

Title: Development and application of micromechanical techniques for characterising interfacial shear strength in fibre-thermoplastic composites
AdditionalInformation: First paper describing the development and application of two micromechanical techniques for characterising interface in fibre-thermoplastic composites, leading to a potential testing protocol for thermoplastic composite interface. The demonstration of expertise in this area has secured KE activities through technical training for researchers from Leuven University (ignaas.verpoest@mtm.kuleuven.be) and institutional joint research, leading to a joint journal submission (abdullah.kafi@deakin.edu.au) at Deakin University in Australia. The research recently led directly to a joint EPSRC grant proposal with Prof Hand (r.hand@sheffield.ac.uk) at the University of Sheffield to currently under review (EP/L02330x/1).

Title: Interface strength in glass fibre-polypropylene measured using the fibre pull-out and microbond methods
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: First paper reporting a new discovery of previously unknown phenomenon of the effect of polymer degradation on interfacial properties in composites. The discovery was made through a direct comparison of interfacial characterisation for thermoplastic composites and revealed that polymer degradation can adversely affect interfacial properties in composites. The experimental measurement was carried out using two self-developed testing techniques. The outcomes led to a novel series of subsequent investigations [Composites Part A 42(10) & Polymer Testing 31(7)] and consequently led to a recent industrial invitation to visit BASF Germany (Johannes.sprafke@basf.com) to present the overall progress in this new area.

Title: Properties of benzene confined between two Au(111) surfaces using a combined density functional theory and classical molecular dynamics approach
AdditionalInformation: An accurate classical force field for benzene on gold was developed based on quantum calculations. The resulting simulations showed that thin films of benzene in gold form a layered structure.  This work led to the extension of a German research foundation grant, SPP 1369 (PI Kurt Kremer kremer@mpip-mainz.mpg.de) and the development of a multiscale model of polystyrene on gold [DOI: 10.1039/C2SM25567G; 10.1021/ma400357r].KJ was invited to give talks in the workshops "Software frameworks for ChallengingComputational Problems", Greece (Vagelis Harmandaris, vagelis@tem.uoc.gr), and "Stabilized noble metal nanoparticles, recent advances and present challenges", Finland in 2013 (Olga Lopez Acevedoolga.lopez.acevedo@aalto.fi).

Title: Influence of van der Waals forces on the adsorption structure of benzene on silicon studied using density functional theory
VolumeTitle: Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
AdditionalInformation:
This was one of the first applications of the van der Waals density functional theory to extended systems and was applied to the long-disputed topic of the chemisorbed adsorption structure of benzene adsorbed on silicon. It was found that van der Waals forces have a significant influence on the chemisorption structure, and the predictions were different from standard density functional theory. 
Karen Johnston was invited to give a talk based on this work at the van der Waals workshop, Helsinki, April 2008 (Andris Gulans gulans@physik.hu-berlin.de).

Title: A hierarchical dualscale study of bisphenol-A-polycarbonate on a silicon surface : structure, dynamics and impurity diffusion
AdditionalInformation:
This research describes the first study of adsorption of polycarbonate on silicon. Novel site-dependent surface interactions, based on quantum calculations, were developed for use in classical simulations, thus providing an accurate prediction of the interface properties of the system. It was found that the site-dependence is crucial in obtaining the correct dynamics at the surface. Only the polymer chain ends adsorbed on the surface, giving a brush-like structure, which affects the properties such as diffusion of impurity particles near the surface.
Referee comments (editor softmatter@rsc.org) “The paper discusses a very interesting topic … and the results reported are interesting.”

Title: Development of classical molecule-surface interaction potentials based on density functional theory calculations : investigation of force field representability
AdditionalInformation: The accuracy of classical simulations is determined by the quality of the classical force field, which is an approximation to the true quantum interaction. This work demonstrated a new, systematic and rigorous approach for generating accurate classical force fields for soft matter on solid interfaces, which is a challenging subject that is often left untackled.  Referee comments (editor Prof. Pavel Jungwirth, jungwirth-office@jpc.acs.org) were “This paper represents a significant new contribution and should be published as is. “

Title: Creation dependencies of evolutionary artefact and design process knowledge
AdditionalInformation: The first model of inter-relationship creation coupling and evolution between the product and process is presented. The research was founded on two detailed design protocol analyses and a questionnaire analysis of eight industrial system designers (robert.i.saxby@baesystems.com). The model provides the first robust foundation to develop decision support mechanisms for predicting the consequences of making technical decisions interlinked with project management decisions. Reviewers commented the paper is the first “in making a start at analysing the evolution of the design process in detail”, and “The paper is describing research within an area of high theoretical and practical importance” (Guest-editor: dcw24@cam.ac.uk).

Title: 250 nm glycine-rich nanodroplets are formed on dissolution of glycine crystals but are too small to provide productive nucleation sites
AdditionalInformation: The key contribution was a novel mechanistic model for non-classical crystal nucleation pathways. This insight provided an explanation for formation of protein coated microcrystals, which served as a basis for a successful BBSRC proposal (BB/F004664/1) where J Sefcik was a co-investigator. This work has further led to follow up collaborations and publications (Faraday Discussions, 2013) and is being further pursued in an EPSRC funded project (EP/J004812/1) led by J Sefcik. J Sefcik presented an invited keynote talk on this subject at the BACG conference in London in 2011.

Title: The electric double layer at high surface potentials : the influence of excess ion polarizability
VolumeTitle: EPL: A Letters Journal Exploring the Frontiers of Physics
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first to analyze the influence of effective ion polarizability on the differential capacitance of the electric double layer and develops a theory which is able to quantitatively reproduce experimental measurements.  The work leads to a new explanation for the saturation of the dielectric capacitance at high fields, which is important in the prediction and control of electrokinetic phenomena.  It has been used by a number of notable researchers in the field, such as Prof Martin Bazant (Department of Chemical Engineering, MIT, bazant@mit.edu).

Title: The micropolar elastic behaviour of model macroscopically heterogeneous materials
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Solids and Structures
AdditionalInformation: First paper to publish experimental data and corroborating FE results demonstrating mechanical behaviour of materials with regular, periodic voids is consistent with a higher order constitutive theory, micropolar elasticity. Lead author, Beveridge, awarded best PhD student paper for presenting FE based method for identifying constitutive properties from experimental data at UK Association for Computational Methods in Engineering (ACME) Conference, Nottingham, UK, April 2009 (www.acmeuk.org/prize.html). Methodology has already been successfully developed and applied in mechanical characterization of cortical bone as described in 'Cortical Bone Micropolarity: The Role of Haversian Canals' in follow-up paper to Scientific Reports (editor, scientificreports@nature.com), March 2013).

Title: Effect of brush thickness and solvent composition on the friction force response of poly(2-(methacryloyloxy)ethylphosphorylcholine) brushes
AdditionalInformation: The suitability of a novel material as next-generation coating for artificial joints was evaluated experimentally in this work. Impact of the work to the international scientific community is recognized by a travel award to Z Zhang to attend ‘Kerala 2014: Friction and Wear at the Nanoscale’ funded by International Nanotribology Forum (josephine.baer@mat.ethz.ch). The work led to new collaboration with Disordered Materials Group at ISIS (Dr Daniel Bowron, daniel.bowron@stfc.ac.uk). As PI, Z Zhang was awarded a prestigious five-days neutron beam-time (RB1300005) at ISIS that is operated by the Science and Technology Facilities Council.

Title: Morphological and quantitative frictional measurements of cotton fibres using friction force microscopy
AdditionalInformation: Through this industrial collaborative work, advanced methodology has been developed to improve the efficiency of personal care products and transferred to the external partner successfully (Peter.Doyle@unilever.com). Comments from peer reviewers include ‘This is a very elegant paper of importance to those working in the field of natural fibres’ (Publish editor Paul Cooper, materials@rsc.org). Relationship between Z Zhang and the researchers at Unilever has been developed, and more knowledge exchange activities are in discussion (Richard.barfoot@unilever.com).

Title: Adhesive and conformational behaviour of mycolic acid monolayers
AdditionalInformation: The concept of polymer physics and chemistry was introduced to interpret the microbial cell attachment and adhesion. The work led to an invitation to contribute to Faraday Discussion 139 at York (DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/B717046G). Z Zhang was invited to present this work in a variety of occasions including a sandpit event (http://gtr.rcuk.ac.uk/project/5F42F156-AAA3-44F2-9504-A6D09EE85DC0) which provides justification for the follow-up EPSRC Research Grant EP/I016589/1 ‘BioEngineering from first principles’ (£201K). This work confirms the potential of rhodococcus species for industrial application to clean up sites of oil pollution as recognized by UK, Belgium, and South African researchers (DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.plipres.2012.05.002).

Title: Directed single molecule diffusion triggered by surface energy gradients
AdditionalInformation: This work demonstrated the fine control of single molecules at small length scales. The work led to one of the key work packages of the follow-up EPSRC Programme Grant EP/I012060/1 ‘Low-Dimensional Chemistry’ (£4.05M). This novel work is a step-forward for nanotechnology to control the movement of molecules, and has been featured in several newswires (e.g. http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/09/090930112138.htm). Materials Today considers ‘the potential applications of this work range from coaxing cells to move and grow in specific directions to treat diseases, this could speed development of some long-awaited nanotech innovations’ (http://www.materialstoday.com/view/4491/controlled-movement-of-molecules/).

Title: Integrated product relationships management : a model to enable concurrent product design and assembly sequence planning
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a novel framework to promote concurrent and proactive design for assembly, detailing key relationships and their management in enabling right-first-time assembly of large complex mechanical systems in any sector. The research carried out systematic analyses of product features and their relationships and was later tested through a computational case-study and further tests to be reported. This framework is more efficient (50% lead-time reduction) in supporting design for assembly compared with traditional approaches as demonstrated by CALT (wfrank20080808@gmail.com). The research contributed to the establishment of Space Mechatronic Systems Technology Laboratory, which is the first established outside China (http://www.sdi.co.uk/news/2012/06/adm-newsletter/university-of-strathclyde-collaboration-with-china.aspx).

Title: A critical realism view of design artefact knowledge
AdditionalInformation: Existing knowledge of key product design elements and their relationships (FBS: Function, Behaviour and Structure) is well established (Gero et al). Using detailed protocol analysis throughout a five month project involving two designers, a new critical realist view (CR-FBS) was presented that challenges recognised knowledge in the field. The results are generic and can be applicable to all engineering design domains and provide a foundation to further confront accepted norms. Reviewers stated the paper: “constitutes a valuable contribution to the growing body of research that is developing around the FBS model” (Editor: I.T.Klaasen@tudelft.nl).

Title: Extended revenue forecasting within a service industry
AdditionalInformation: Forecasting revenue is fundamental to business success. Current theories only address forecasting on sales order recognition. The first generic, cross-sector/business, technique and resulting tool for service provision forecasting is presented. The tool was tested in a company using 10 clients for use with around half of the company’s client base of 200 UK clients and in other offices in the USA, Asia/Pacific and India. The result was an extension of the forecast window from one month using a company bespoke approach to three months, with a similar error rate of generally within ±10% (graeme.cox@sky.com – used to maintain company confidentiality).

Title: An optimization model for multi-biomass tri-generation energy supply
AdditionalInformation: This is the first model optimising major investment-related variables combining system-wide representation of both upstream (biomass) and downstream (energy products) supply chains, with the concepts of energy tri-generation and multi-biomass use. The model was the first demand-driven pull model, synthesising state-of-the-art approaches, and validated with a case study using real biomass data. It provides an innovative tool for renewable energy investors to financially assess and optimise biomass-to-energy projects, promoting renewable energy generation for existing and future energy demand. The revolutionary multi-biomass concept is acknowledged as innovative (p.k.dey@aston.ac.uk) and the relevance of the demand-driven approach to investor decisions is verified (kirby.calvert@queensu.ca).

Title: Fabrication of periodic nanostructures by single-point diamond turning with focused ion beam built tool tips
AdditionalInformation: A novel scale-up approach for manufacturing nanostructures was developed. Through theoretical modelling and experimentation nanoscale diamond tools (40nm) were fabricated for the first time using Focussed Ion Beam. It enables machining nanogratings in large areas with 3000 times higher efficiency than state of the art through diamond turning. The world-leading tooling manufacturer Contour Fine Tooling (Andrew@contour-diamonds.com) are in negotiations regarding commercialising the approach. Discussions are also underway with the international companies Seagate (rob.hardeman@seagate.com) and Renishaw (nick.weston@renishaw.com) for further exploitation. The research led to £537k EPSRC grant application (EP/L020289/1) still under review.

Title: Multiscale simulation of nanometric cutting of single crystal copper and its experimental validation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel multi-scale modelling approach to bridge the gap between atomic behaviours and their consequences on micromechanical properties. The findings on the influence of crystal orientation and cutting direction on machined surface quality were validated through experiments. The research provides not only in-depth and comprehensive understanding of nano-machining mechanism for the first time (Prof. S Bordas, bordasS@cf.ac.uk), but also a useful guidance for industrial exploration of nano-machining technique (Andrew@contour-diamonds.com). It also led to an invitation for a keynote presentation at the 12th US Congress on Computational Mechanics (Dr. Peng Qing, pengq3@rpi.edu).

Title: Influence of temperature and crystal orientation on tool wear during single point diamond turning of silicon
AdditionalInformation: The research discovered the tool wear mechanism during diamond turning of Si, which remained unclear for over 20 years. Through a pioneering MD simulation study it was concluded that high pressure phase transformation followed by the formation of SiC are the main reasons for abrasive wear in the cutting process. This theoretical finding was validated by experimental observations. The finding has greatly advanced knowledge in ultra-precision machining (d.j.robertson@durham.ac.uk). The world-leading IR optics manufacturers, Qioptiq (Tony.Jacklin@uk.qioptiq.com), Spanoptic (richard@spanoptic.com) benefit by applying the research resulting in machining of large (>200mm diameter) IR optics not previously attainable.

Title: A quantitative assessment of nanometric machinability of major polytypes of single crystal silicon carbide
VolumeTitle: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the first investigation on machinability of major polytypes of single crystal silicon carbide (SiC). Using a novel micro-structure modelling approach for SiC, implemented through Molecule Dynamics simulation, current knowledge was overturned by showing that 4H-SiC has better machinability in terms of achievable surface finish and surface integrity. The study provided a foundation for selecting SiC materials for manufacture of next-generation optical and electronic components (oriemer@lfm.uni-bremen.de, and world-leading SiC manufacturer, CoorsTek Ltd., kpfaffenbach@coorstek.com). The research has confirmed diamond turning of SiC in the German company Son-x, which specialises in ultrasonic devices (benjamin.bulla@son-x.com).

Title: A computational fluid dynamic analysis of the effect of weld nozzle geometry changes on shielding gas coverage during gas metal arc welding
VolumeTitle: Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, the effect of cross-drafts on the stability and defect control of welds, using protective shielding gases such as argon, is reported. Using Computational Fluid Dynamics, validated against experimental results, a multi-physics 3D transient state model was created. The research demonstrated the potential to reduce overall shielding gas consumption by up to 50% based on flow nozzle geometry changes, without compromising structural integrity. The potential cost savings led to an industry funded study (£79k) to visualize the flow characteristics of weld shielding gases between Strathclyde University, BAE Systems Surface Fleet (norrie.mcpherson@baesystems.com), and Heriot-Watt University (a.moore@hw.ac.uk).

Title: Systematic study of effect of cross-drafts and nozzle diameter on shield gas coverage
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation: This is the world’s first systematic study on the application of optical thermography techniques, numerical modelling and experimental validation of the effects of cross-drafts and nozzle diameter on shield gas coverage. The research resulted with a deeper theoretical understanding of the flow characteristics and enabled a significant reduction of shield gas use in a production environment, with no reduction in weld quality. The research outcomes were adopted by BAE Systems (Surface Fleet) bringing cost savings of £300k/year/yard (norrie.mcpherson@baesystems.com) and the technological advances were recognized with the Naval Ships UK Chairman’s Bronze Award in 2013 (navalships@baesystems.com).

Title: Friction stir welding of thin DH36 steel plate
VolumeTitle: Science and Technology of Welding and Joining
AdditionalInformation: Friction-Stir Welding (FSW) is a joining process typically used with aluminium alloys and other light metals. This is one of the first investigations, in collaboration with TWI and BAE Systems, on the highly novel application of FSW using shipbuilding grade DH36 steel, with an aim of demonstrating its viability within a shipyard environment. The experimental investigation significantly advanced the state-of-the-art with a more detailed understanding of the microstructure, mechanical properties and fatigue performance. The paper has formed the foundation of the successfully funded FP7 HILDA project [€2.1M, No. 314534] that aims to develop the technology to an operational readiness level.

Title: Effect of torch angle on arc properties and weld pool shape in stationary GTAW
AdditionalInformation: Navier-Stokes and Maxwell equations are combined within a multi-physics model to simulate complex arc welding phenomena and flow regimes within Gas Tungsten Arc Welding (GTAW). This novel simulation model, created through international collaboration with the University of Pakistan, allowed the torch angle to be varied and its impact on the arc and weld pool shape investigated. The research was unique, in validating this type of model with an experimental study, emphasising the appropriateness of the computational methods used. The simulation and experiments demonstrated that a more symmetrical arc and weld pool could be achieved using a 90° torch angle.

Title: Augmenting the 6-3-5 method with design information
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents for the first time a new concept generation method that integrates digital information support. It is based on Rohrbach’s well-established 6-3-5 Method that has received little update or development. The paper demonstrates through an experimental application that by incorporating information searching and sharing, the new method resulted in design concepts of superior quality, variety and detail than conventionally generated. The reviewers (Editor: yoram@eng.tau.ac.il) commented that this paper presented “an interesting empirical study comparing a traditional creativity method 6-3-5 against a modification of the method” and as such is a highly visible innovation in design methodology.

Title: Damage stability and survivability - 'nailing' passenger ship safety problems
AdditionalInformation: The paper provides a succinct account of contemporary developments, reflecting and detailing the contribution made to a paradigm shift from empirical to a scientific basis (RINA’s highest professional achievement, Froude Medal, http://www.rina.org.uk/article109.html and RAE Sustained Achievement Award, www.raeng.org.uk/prizes/sustained). It focuses on probabilistic frameworks and first-principles to address safety quantitatively and consistently. The paper demonstrates the implications on passenger ship design and operation of pertinent developments using Project Genesis as case study, the largest cruise ship ever built. Genesis set new goals and standards for the industry with many new ships now designed on the basis reflected in the paper (www.imo.org/About/Events/FSS/Documents).

Title: Easily retrievable objects among the NEO population
AdditionalInformation: Key output from European Research Council Advanced Investigator Grant 227571. First assessment of low energy asteroid capture trajectories using modern dynamical systems theory. Led to initial Non-Disclosure Agreement with commercial space venture. MIT Technology Review (August, 2013) noted that due to the publication “until now nobody had realized just how easily these bodies could be captured”. Influenced work by Tsirogiannis at University of Patras on low cost transfers (Cel. Mech. and Dyn. Astro. 117. 201-213, 2013). Work led to prestigious Royal Society of Edinburgh Lessells Scholarship for Garcia Yarnoz to visit University of Colorado.

Title: Lattice ellipsoidal statistical BGK model for thermal non-equilibrium flows
AdditionalInformation: A new framework for establishing thermal and compressible lattice Boltzmann models to capture rarefaction effects beyond the Navier-Stokes-Fourier equations. Transforming the current trial-and-error design method to exploit the non-equilibrium flow physics for new technologies. Co-authors Hadjiconstantinou and Radtke of MIT USA performed model validation using direct simulation Monte Carlo method. Co-author Shan of Beijing Institute of Aeronautical Science and Technology Research analytically verified the method. Currently being explored by Chinese Academy of Sciences for developing high-efficient combustion at the microscale (Zhang: zhw@mail.etp.ac.cn). Led to invited talk at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology and researcher exchanges with HKUST (makxu@ust.hk).

Title: Three-dimensional lattice Boltzmann model for immiscible two-phase flow simulations
AdditionalInformation: New three-dimensional lattice Boltzmann colour model for simulating accurately binary fluids with variable density and viscosity ratios. Key output of Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) funded research project LDRD 201000025DR. The ongoing collaborations with Valocchi of University of Illinois (valocchi@illinois.edu) and Kang of LANL (qkang@lanl.gov) led to subsequent journal publications (e.g. Transport in Porous Media, 99, 555-580, 2013). A parallelised in-house code developed from the model, being used currently at University of Illinois and LANL for simulating porous media flows. Led to a new research project WPI-I2CNER, sponsored by the Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology.

Title: Phase-field-based lattice Boltzmann finite difference model for simulating thermocapillary flows
AdditionalInformation: The is the first lattice Boltzmann phase-field model for thermocapillary flows with immiscible fluids of high density ratio published. It is a key output from research project LDRD 201000025DR funded by the Los Alamos National Laboratory, USA and led to subsequent work by Liu (Journal of Computational Physics, 256, 334-356, 2014). The developed model is now being used by the research group led by Prof Chuhua Zhang (chzhang@mail.xjtu.edu.cn) in the Department of Fluid Machinery & Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, China, for studying the fluid-elastic instability in respiratory bronchioles.

Title: Droplet formation in microfluidic cross-junctions
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a novel scaling law capable of predicting droplet size considering the effects of flow properties and geometries. It has gained extensive international recognition (one of the top 20 most cited papers in Physics of Fluids in 2012) and led to international collaboration with Prof Jinju Sun (jjsun@mail.xjtu.edu.cn) in Xi’an Jiaotong University, China, to explore model capability for simulating droplet dynamics on patterned surfaces. This in turn led to further papers reporting outcomes of collaborative research (e.g. Computers & Fluids, 73, 175-186, 2013; Physical Review E, accepted on 3rd Oct 2013, http://pre.aps.org/accepted/20078R18T021c518514d2c47239e2a009a2e6fe7f)

Title: Water transport through (7,7) carbon nanotubes of different lengths using molecular dynamics
AdditionalInformation:
This is the first paper to explicitly analyse the effect of carbon nanotube length on fluid transport behaviour. This work is of particular interest to nanoscale membranes for more efficient desalination and water treatment processes. 
The paper has initiated/informed several significant contributions by research groups around the world, including the Computational Science & Engineering Laboratory at ETH Zurich, Switzerland (Barriers to superfast water transport in carbon nanotube membranes, Walther et al., Nano Letters, 2013) and other research groups in Canada, Australia and China.

Title: Design of a formation of solar pumped lasers for asteroid deflection
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel concept for a planetary protection and asteroid exploitation using space-based solar-pumped lasers, which makes the manipulation of small- to medium-sized asteroids practically feasible. This work was funded by a grant from the European Space Agency (AO/1-5387/07/NL/CB) examining promising solutions to the threat posed by NEOs. The concept attracted the attention of the Planetary Society that supported its development with 3 grants worth £60k to conduct lab experiments to verify the models developed. The research led to an EU FP7 grant for £4.1M to form a training network on asteroid deflection and space debris mitigation (FP7-PEOPLE-2012-ITN).

Title: On the deflection of asteroids with mirrors
AdditionalInformation: Demonstrates the advantages and limitations of using solar concentrators for asteroid orbit deflection. Originally just an impractical conceptual sketch, this paper re-engineered the design, conducting detailed simulations to make this concept the most effective technique for medium and long-term asteroid deflection. The optimisation approach developed in this paper has been further investigated by CINVESTAV, one of the leading centres for evolutionary computation (http://www.cs.cinvestav.mx/~EVOCINV, Dr Oliver Schütze, schuetze@cs.cinvestav.mx). This work led to an invited Session Chair position at the International Symposium on Space Technology and Science/ISTS, 2009, supported by the Japanese Space Agency.

Title: Design of optimal spacecraft-asteroid formations through a hybrid global optimization approach
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Intelligent Computing and Cybernetics
AdditionalInformation: This multi-award winning paper developed a new, highly effective behavioural-based hybrid global optimization algorithm to determine optimal orbits for multiple spacecraft operating in close formation with an asteroid in order to alter its trajectory. The rigorous, systematic approach identified, for the first time, families of orbits for up to hundreds of spacecraft. The paper won the top Highly Commended paper from the journal (2008) and Emerald Publishing (2009) (http://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/09/magazine/09_5_asteroid.html?ref=magazine). This paper led directly to an ESA Ariadna grant (08-4301) and  3 international television documentaries. The concept was voted one of the Best Ideas of 2007 by the NY Times (http://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/09/magazine/09_5_asteroid.html?ref=magazine).

Title: Investigating the reliability and criticality of the maintenance characteristics of a diving support vessel
AdditionalInformation: An innovative ship predictive maintenance strategy was developed, which for the first time provides a methodology and unique tool to increase availability by minimising ship downtime (sol.judah@sserenewables.com). The developed methodology has directly resulted in the successful funding of INCASS (Inspection capabilities for enhanced ship safety) EU project, a 3 year 4,200,000 € project, co-ordinated by I. Lazakis (FP7/2007-2013, GA n° 605200) in which the maritime industry (shipping companies (csv@apanda.com), Classification Societies (kim.tanneberger@lr.org), research institutes) and academia cooperate in order to enhance ship safety through real time ship monitoring and predictive ship inspection and maintenance strategy.

Title: Robust design of a re-entry unmanned space vehicle by multi-fidelity evolution control
AdditionalInformation: This paper generalises the integrated design technique for the application to engineering areas other than aerospace. The work provides a step forward and basis for future joint projects with Thales Alenia Space (Mareschi, Aerothermodynamics Senior Researcher, vincenzo.mareschi@thalesaleniaspace.com) and Optimad Engineering srl (Telib, CEO, haysam.telib@optimad.it) on design approaches for space transportation systems.  Optimad Engineering srl are now co-sponsoring a PhD supervised by the author on uncertainty quantification for hypersonic flows. Led to the organisation of international mini-symposium on multidisciplinary-design-optimisation at EUROGEN-2013 (dgreiner@iusiani.ulpgc.es). The paper details a design approach that “looks practical and affordable for a vast category of industrial problems” (haysam.telib@optimad.it).

Title: A BEM-isogeometric method for the ship wave-resistance problem
AdditionalInformation: For the first time Isogeometric Analysis (IGA) was combined with BEM for solving the ship wave-resistance problem. The method achieved at least an order of magnitude improvement in convergence rates, and enabled accurate refinement of the computational domain without time-consuming meshing. The research is a decisive step towards seamlessly integrating CAD with CFD; validated within a range of industrial applications including: container-ship design (DNV); turbo-charger design (SIEMENS); and turbine-blade design (ANDRITZ-Hydro). The authors have been approached by the Universities of Texas at Austin and Brigham Young to initiate joint research (hughes@ices.utexas.edu, michael.scott@byu.edu) towards integrating T-splines in ship-analysis and design.

Title: VELOS : a VR platform for ship-evacuation analysis
AdditionalInformation: VELOS is a multi-user system for ship-design and crew-training, integrating features that provide a more accurate simulation of evacuees: on-the-fly alterations of environment events and crowd-behavior; continuous movement of passengers in the 3D ship's general arrangement; real-time ship-motions effect on the agents’ moving ability; and, health-index functionality for modelling smoke/fire. The International Maritime Organisation benchmarks have been used as a basis to validate the system. The profile of the VELOS system is recognised by inviting Prof. Kaklis to the prestigious Dagstuhl Seminar on “Virtual Realities-2013” and the Board of the International Virtual, Augmented and Mixed Reality Conference 2014;  http://www.dagstuhl.de/en/program/calendar/semhp/?semnr=08231,   http://www.hcii2014.org/vamr.

Title: A discrete methodology for controlling the sign of curvature and torsion for NURBS
AdditionalInformation: This work provides designers with a robust (controllable error) and extremely efficient (real-time computation) discrete algorithm that enables high-shape-quality design of 3D curves by designers immersed in a Virtual Environment. The research challenges the time-consuming paradigm for designing high-quality 3D curves by manipulating 2D projections. Practical needs for designing high-quality 3D curves arise in automotive industry (class-A surfaces for the exterior "skin" of a car), ship-design (design the chine curves of high-speed vessels), motorway design. Preliminary version of our work has been presented by Prof. Kaklis at the prestigious (by invitation only) Dagstuhl Seminar on “Geometric Modeling-2008”; http://www.dagstuhl.de/en/program/calendar/semhp/?semnr=08221.

Title: Polynomial cubic splines with tension properties
AdditionalInformation: A new family of generalized cubic splines that can be readily integrated into existing CAD systems for efficient and robust shape control, are presented. The research advances the state-of-the-art by enabling automatic shape control as opposed to time-consuming practice of manually adjusting control points. The approach, developed through collaboration with Universities of Sienna (costantini@unisi.it) and  Rome “Tor Vergata” (manni@mat.uniroma2.it), expands and integrates advanced shape preserving interpolation techniques, enabling a reduction of at least 20% in CAD-modelling times. Recognition within the CAD field resulted with Prof. Kaklis being approached to conduct an investigation on “CAD-PLM Integration” with BAE Systems (REF:4935707-10, Project:002).

Title: Considerations on the fatigue assessment methods of floating-structure details
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: A new method for the estimation of fracture-mechanics stress intensity factors in complicated structural connections is presented. Based on a novel "singularity length-scale" approach it does not require finite element analysis for its application. This allows (1) quick estimates of likely crack growth behaviour and (2) whole ship reliability analysis, modelling tens of thousands of cracks, where alternative finite-element based approaches demand too much person and computer time. The methodology has demonstrated that certain important recommendations in the present fatigue standard BS-7608 are incorrect, which has been acknowledged by the Chairman (stephen.maddox@twi.co.uk) of the committee revising BS-7608.

Title: Risk-based ship design
VolumeTitle: Risk-Based Ship Design: Methods, Tools and Applications
AdditionalInformation: This book launched a new design paradigm "Design for Safety", instigated and promulgated by Strathclyde. Chapter 2, the kernel of the book, introduces concept, theory and implementation to ships through the Risk-Based Design (RBD) methodology, reflecting the culmination and integration of fifteen years of collaborative research at national and international scales that completely transformed maritime safety.  Step changes range from worldwide impact through the introduction of new SOLAS rules (http://ec.europa.eu/research/transport/projects/items/eu_funded_safety_at_sea_project_has_worldwide_impact_en.htm) to the adoption of Goal-Based Standards at IMO (pierre.sames@gl-group.com).  RBD opened the door to innovation in the design of safety-critical and knowledge-intensive ships by offering a vehicle to cost-effective safety.

Title: Safety level of damaged RoPax ships : risk modelling and cost-effectiveness analysis
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a Formal Safety Assessment of RoPax ships with focus on cost-effectiveness of design measures for damage stability improvement, offering first-ever-quantification of the level of damage stability requirements. It is the first study to perform such analysis in a parametric manner, presenting a comprehensive risk model, methodology and tools linking sensitivity of potential risk reductions to implied costs. The contents of this paper provided evidence, at the International Maritime Organisation (Director: JWBooth@imo.org; MSC_85-INF-3) to justify improvements in damage stability of RoPax. This instigated further large-scale research internationally to address practical implementation issues in support of new legislation (FP7-SST-2008-RTD-1-233876).

Title: Numerical simulation of anchored ship motions due to wave and wind forces for enhanced safety in offshore harbor refuge
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a collaborative research between Japan and UK initiated to investigate eight casualties with ships anchored in severe weather.  The authors reviewed casualty data base, covering a four year period, and interviewed the ship masters to investigate the conditions which initiated and led to severe damage to their ships.  The results of this research  enables designers to determine the number of anchors necessary and optimum mooring configuration for safe anchoring of ships in severe weather. A paper based on this research results presented in 2010 at the Japan Institute of Navigation was given the best paper award-certificate available..

Title: A study of numerical ship underwater noise prediction
AdditionalInformation: This paper summarises research on the investigation of advanced underwater noise prediction models based on leading edge CFD modelling techniques for full scale modelling of noise generated by propellers including noise due to cavitation. This research is being carried out in collaboration with Shell (D.Connolly@shell.com) which is also providing valuable and unique full scale underwater noise measurements. This study has led to a new EU project AQUO (GA 314227) that aims at the assessment and mitigation of noise impacts of the maritime transport on marine life by proposing new standards and operational guidelines..

Title: Effects of curvature on rarefied gas flows between rotating concentric cylinders
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel application of the open source DSMC code “dsmcFoam” developed and validated through a series of benchmark test cases as an experimental analogue to verify continuum-based solvers for rarefied gas dynamics. The significant outcome was the ability to gauge the efficacy of a simpler (power law) approach to resolving Knudsen layers / curvature effects in rarefied gas flows. The developed code has been implemented by the US Air Force Research Laboratory (robert.martin2.ctr@edwards.af.mil Edwards Air Force Base) as part of their suite of computational tools for resolving high-speed rarefied gas flows.

Title: A DSMC investigation of gas flows in micro-channels with bends
AdditionalInformation: This work reports the application of the DSMC code, dsmcFoam, developed by Scanlon et al (Computers and Fluids. 39, 10, p. 2078-2089) to the field of microscale, rarefied gas dynamics. The research identified some non-intuitive flow behaviour where the addition of bends can actually lead to an increase in mass flow rate under certain conditions. Such effects can be taken advantage of in the design of micro electrical mechanical systems (MEMS) to enhance flow-rates.  This research resulted with an invitation to deliver a special workshop in Open Source Particle Methods at the DSMC13 conference, Santa Fe, 2013. (magalli@sandia.gov).

Title: Deterministic numerical solutions of the Boltzmann equation using the fast spectral method
AdditionalInformation: This paper extends the application range of the Fast Spectral Method (FSM) from atomic towards di- and polyatomic molecules in a direct solution to the Boltzmann equation in rarefied gas dynamics. The FSM is a complementary method to the open source DSMC code developed by Scanlon et al (Computers and Fluids. 39, 10, p. 2078-2089). The FSM can now be used in applications such as gas property diagnostics, which has led to an invitation and inter-disciplinary joint research programme with the Atomic Molecular, Optical and Positron Physics Group at University College, London (p.barker@ucl.ac.uk) focussing on experimental validation of these techniques.

Title: On the cycle mean value modelling of a large two-stroke marine diesel engine
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: The paper delineates the aspects of different approaches for modelling two-stroke marine Diesel engines and differentiates from the previous works since a novel modular model was developed in Simulink environment and extensively validated through previously published results. The model was then adopted in the research project EGREENSHIP (GA. No: 58-2011/GSRT, www.egreenship.com), by the industrial partner AVACA (nskarmeas@avaca.gr) and the research partner TSI (gstavr@electronics.tuc.gr) for designing a system to minimize the ship fuel consumption and emission combined with an engine fault prediction system.

Title: Ship propulsion plant transient response investigation using a mean value engine model
AdditionalInformation: The modelling of a merchant ship propulsion plant using Mean Value Engine approach is comprehensively developed by synthesising characteristics from previous approaches resulting in a new model platform. The results are extremely important for the development of ship propulsion plant models since all the features of the model are extensively described and thus the model can elucidate the complex interactions between the propulsion system components. The model was adopted by several researchers e.g. Department of NAME, University of New Orleans, USA, for the design and testing control schemes for marine propulsion systems (nxiros@uno.edu) and resulted in a joint publication (http://dx.doi.org/10.1115/ICEF2011-60199).

Title: Analytic perturbative theories in highly inhomogeneous gravitational fields
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new analytical method for rapidly generating low-fuel orbits for spacecraft around asteroids.
