This work is an output of a European Space Agency study titled "Analytical perturbative theories of motion in highly inhomogeneous gravitational fields". Contract number 4000104571/11/NL/KML. The Advanced Concepts Team at European Space Agency (led by Leopold Summerer leopold.summerer@esa.int) are now exploring the possibility of exploiting this method in future mission applications to asteroids. The paper was awarded the “Celestial Mechanics for Planet Earth” prize at The Sixth International Meeting on Celestial Mechanics, San Martino al Cimino (Italy), September 2013.

Title: Optimal geometric motion planning for a spin-stabilized spacecraft
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel method to improve the motion planning of small spacecraft through design of optimal global, smooth references using little computational power. An extension and application of this theory to design optimal and feasible attitude motions for micro-spacecraft is being at the University of Strathclyde as part of a Marie Curie Initial Training Network FP7-PEOPLE-2011-ITN no. 289240. The research is also being extended in a Technology Strategy Board and UK Space Agency funded project on optimal attitude motion planning and control for nano-spacecraft with industrial partners Clyde Space Ltd (Steve.Greenland@clyde-space.com, Senior Research Engineer at Clyde Space).

Title: Time-delayed autosynchronous swarm control
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates swarm behaviours observed in schools of fish from a systems engineering perspective. It is shown that vortex formations can be induced using knowledge of relative position and short term memory; i.e.  it is not necessary to have relative velocity sensors to form vortices. This enables collective motions in autonomous systems to be undertaken with limited sensor information. This paper has informed further research in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Princeton University USA (tunstrom@princeton.edu), the School of Biological Sciences, University of Bristol UK and Cristian Huepe Labs Inc., Chicago, USA.

Title: Multi-objective optimisation of a floating LNG terminal
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents one of the most critical results from the FP6 EU-funded research project GAS IMPORT FLOATING TERMINAL - GIFT (http://cordis.europa.eu/projects/rcn/73949_en.html)-(budget 3.2mil, Proj. No. TST4-CT-2004-12404). The resulting FLNG concept was regarded as at least 5 years ahead of its time as the first industrial contract for the construction of the first FLNG was signed is in July 2009 (http://www.shell.com/global/aboutshell/media/news-and-media-releases/2009/floating-lng-contract-28072009.html & SHELL was a reviewer of the project). The multi-objective hydrodynamic optimization presented and its findings for the size of the platform and the sizing of its skirts were acknowledged by the industry (http://www.doris-engineering.com/, messager.jc@doriseng.com)..

Title: Multi-objective optimization of oil tanker design
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the results of the Lloyds List Greek Shipping Technical Achievement 2009 Award Winning joint industrial project (http://books.informa.com.au/2009_GSA/#/23/zoomed). It is one of the first industrial applications of the Holistic Ship Design Approach where concurrently design, regulatory, hydrodynamics and detailed strength calculations are applied for the multi-objective parametric optimization of a double-hull AFRAMAX tanker design. The results have been applied in industry (pierre.sames@gl-group.com) and led to a number of on-going follow-up industry's research projects (http://www.gl-group.com/pdf/GL-BEST-plus-a-novel-Aframax-tanker-design-concept-broschure.pdf)

Title: Modeling and simulation of thermocapillary flows using lattice Boltzmann method
AdditionalInformation: The thermocapillary force induced by laser heating was for the first time successfully modelled and simulated to manipulate droplet motion in microfluidic channels. Led to a series of ongoing studies as part of the Laboratory Directed Research & Development Project of Los Alamos National Laboratory USA (qkang@lanl.gov) (see Physical Review E, 87, 013010, 2013; Journal of Computational Physics, 256, 334-356, 2014). Contributed to the award of Royal Academy of Engineering/Leverhulme Trust Senior Research Fellowship, 2013. Led to plenary talk at Microdroplets in Action Symposium, 26 July 2013, Christ’s College, Cambridge University, UK (Abell: ka204@cam.ac.uk)

Title: Peridynamic analysis of fiber-reinforced composite materials
VolumeTitle: Journal of Mechanics of Materials and Structures
AdditionalInformation: This is one of the first publications demonstrating the peridynamic formulation for composite materials. Furthermore, the constraints on material properties due to the pairwise force assumption are given for the first time. The formulation was improved later to remove constraints on material properties and was published as one of the chapter of the first book on peridynamics, “Peridynamic Theory and Its Applications” by E. Madenci and E. Oterkus, Springer, 2013. The author was invited to give a seminar at various prestigious institutions including Imperial College London (lo.iannucci@imperial.ac.uk), Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (yasser.kahlout@tubitak.gov.tr) and Seoul National University (secho@snu.ac.kr).

Title: Combined finite element and peridynamic analyses for predicting failure in a stiffened composite curved panel with a central slot
AdditionalInformation: This is one of the few publications which demonstrates coupling of peridynamics and finite element method in order to utilize the superior features of both techniques since peridynamics is powerful for failure prediction and finite element method is very accurate for determining displacement field in the structure. With the financial support of NASA Langley Research Center (alexander.tessler-1@nasa.gov), the complex composite structure considered in the paper was simultaneously analysed by using various other research codes and with respect to these other approaches, peridynamic predictions of failure modes and failure loads captured NASA’s experimental observations very well.

Title: Residual strength of sandwich panels with hail damage
AdditionalInformation: It is extremely important that both Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEM) and the airlines are able to classify hail strike damage quickly to determine the appropriate repair procedures in order to minimize disruptions of operations. The FAA and EASA require that a repair scheme for a major repair be submitted to the (OEM) for their approval before starting the repair. However, minor repairs can be approved by an airline’s design engineers. The paper presents a novel and fast computational methodology utilised by Boeing (hamid.razi@boeing.com) and airline engineers in the classification of repair types due to hail strike damage to composite structure.

Title: Optimized cross-slot flow geometry for microfluidic extension rheometry
AdditionalInformation: This was the first time a microfluidic device for complex fluid rheometry was fully designed using computational optimisation tools and the desired kinematics verified experimentally, breaking with the typical trial-and-error approach used for component design. It demonstrates the potential of these devices for complex fluid characterisation. The microdevice is now used to successfully characterise complex biologically relevant fluids (DOI:10.1103/PhysRevLett.109.128301). It has prompted a number of invitations for presenting seminars (j.rees@sheffield.ac.uk, gengsj@iet.cn, yongliangzhang@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn), as well as Keynote Conference Lecture at ECCOMAS-2012 (mmalves@fe.up.pt, robpoole@liverpool.ac.uk). This was a key paper for a recent successful application for an EPSRC First Grant Scheme (EP/L013118/1, £125k).

Title: Wake-tracking and turbulence modelling in computational aerodynamics of wind turbine aerofoils
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy
AdditionalInformation: The paper initiated the joint research and publications with CFD experts in UK (Dr Campobasso, University of Lancaster, m.s.campobasso@lancaster.ac.uk),‎ and Italy (Prof Bonfiglioli, University of Basilicata, aldo.bonfiglioli@unibas.it) on wind turbine analysis. Also led to joint research in the area of analysis and design of horizontal and vertical axis wind turbines with Optimad Engineering srl (Gallizio, R&D manager, Federico.gallizio@optimad.it). The proposed wake tracking algorithm presented in this paper allows for improvements in the resolution of wake shed. “This technique and the gained insight” (m.s.campobasso@lancaster.ac.uk) is at the basis of the co-authors’ activity for development of wind-turbine analysis software.

Title: Extensional rheology and elastic instabilities of a wormlike micellar solution in a microfluidic cross-slot device
AdditionalInformation: This is a thorough study entailing both sophisticated experiments and complex numerical calculations to understand elastic instabilities of wormlike micellar solutions under extensional flow at the microscale. The paper was key in establishing a research collaboration between MIT, Porto and Strathclyde that has led to subsequent joint research exchanges and publications (PRL 2012, 109, 12830; Biomicrofluidics, 2013, 7, 044108). It has also lead to a Marie Curie International Incoming Fellowship (FP7-PEOPLE-2011-IIF grant 298220) awarded to Haward to work on micro-biorheology with Alves and Oliveira, and McKinley being a partner in an EPSRC First Grant (EP/L013118/1, £125k) recently awarded to Oliveira.

Title: Purely elastic flow asymmetries in flow-focusing devices
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the first theoretical prediction of purely elastic instabilities in this micro-configuration, unravelling a useful mechanism for complex fluid mixing enhancement, a typically difficult task at the microscale. It features in a special issue of the Journal following an invited presentation (robpoole@liverpool.ac.uk). It was also at the core of a Plenary Talk in MEFTE-2012 (jviegas@lnec.pt) and guided subsequent work in this geometry (http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/jfm.2012.386). This phenomenon was confirmed experimentally, leading to an invited lecture at ExHFT8-2013 and a subsequent invited article in Experimental Thermal Fluid Science (pedro.coelho@ist.utl.pt). It was used as support for a successful ERC-Starting Grant (No.307499, €994k).

Title: Efficient microfluidic rectifiers for viscoelastic fluid flow
AdditionalInformation: This work was an important part of Sousa’s PhD thesis (supervised by Alves and Oliveira), which was granted the Iberian Award for the Most Distinguished PhD Thesis in Rheology 2011, a prestigious prize given jointly by the Portuguese Society of Rheology and the Spanish Rheology Group every two years (mtc@fct.unl.pt). The performance of the proposed device is significantly better than those achieved previously, and sparked new research on microfluidic diodes by the co-authors (RSC Advances 2012, 2, 920) and others (fridolin.okkels@nanotech.dtu.dk). This work formed the central part of an invited lecture in ExHFT8-2013 (pedro.coelho@ist.utl.pt).

Title: Robust multi-fidelity design of a micro re-entry unmanned space vehicle
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes integrated design techniques now adopted by ‎Thales Alenia Space (V. Mareschi, Senior Researcher, vincenzo.mareschi@thalesaleniaspace.com), and two  SMEs in Italy (Optimad Engineering srl - Gallizio, R&D manager, Federico.gallizio@optimad.it, and Exemplar Srl - Cavallero, R&D associate, claudio.cavallero@exemplar.com). The paper led to (a) new project with ASTRIUM France (Elegbede, RAMS Expert, CHARLES.ELEGBEDE@astrium.eads.net) on design approaches for space transportation systems, (b) invitation to organise international mini-symposium on multidisciplinary-design-optimisation at EUROGEN2011 (d.quagliarella@cira.it), and (c) organisation of the European workshop UQO2013, involving leading academic and industry researchers on uncertainty quantification and optimisation, and included Italian Aerospace Research Centre (Senior Engineer, d.quagliarella@cira.it).

Title: Evolutionary design of a full-envelope full-authority flight control system for an unstable high-performance aircraft
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The control system optimisation work presented in this paper extended joint research with Prof. G. Avanzini, Univerista’ del Salento (Italy), giulio.avanzini@unisalento.it, on control system design optimisation, and led to a new joint authored paper with Dr. F. Giulietti, University of Bologna (Italy), fabrizio.giulietti@unibo.it  to further research in this area. The paper demonstrates that multi-objective evolutionary algorithms can be used, for the first time, for the design of this kind of complex and heavily constrained control systems, usually demanding a lot of human time and effort. The research was evaluated through numerical simulations and verified against well-established models in the field.

Title: Human reliability analysis—Taxonomy and praxes of human entropy boundary conditions for marine and offshore applications
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a novel and step changing approach to Human Reliability for Maritime Sector to assess the human reliability quantitatively, and provide practical guidance to reduce maritime human errors through resilience. Led to the funding of 3.5 million Euro EU FP7 project ‘SEAHORSE’ starting 1 November 2013 (GA No: 605639, co-ordinated by Turan). SEAHORSE is the first multi-domain project on human reliability bringing the air and maritime domains together (Ronald.Vopel@ec.europa.eu). Led to joint research with world leading companies: TNO on human factors (wilfried.post@tno.nl), Danaos Shipping on operations (drc@danaos.gr) and classification society Lloyd’s Register on safety (Fai.Cheng@lr.org).

Title: Theory of a subjective vertical–horizontal conflict physiological motion sickness model for contemporary ships
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper, consolidates eight years of research from a EU project COMPASS (G3RD-CT-2002-00809), research projects and supported by dedicated laboratory with 20 full-scale ship trials, presents a step change in dealing with motion sickness. The novel theoretical model takes into account both vertical and horizontal accelerations and demonstrates the significance of horizontal acceleration on motion sickness particularly for HSC. This was used to assess the feasibility of catamarans for CalMac (scott.ure@calmac.co.uk) and is currently used by navies in design and operation via ABCD group (jelte.bos@tno.nl). Utilised in a project with SSE on Offshore Wind Farm access vessels (sol.judah@sserenewables.com).

Title: Global wave loads on a damaged ship
AdditionalInformation: The research summarised in this paper supports the development of technologies suitable for cradle-to-grave life cycle performance analysis and monitoring of ship structural systems. The prediction tools used in this study were results of two research projects. The research was the first to compare the wave-induced loads on intact ship and damaged frigate vessel by means of experimental tests and computational analyses (http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2013.03.016). A compressive set of experimental measurements detailed in the paper is being used for validation studies by a number of researchers in the Department and elsewhere (http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.oceaneng.2013.06.024).

Title: Scenarios for the assessment of the collision behavior of ships
AdditionalInformation: This paper summarises a research investigation carried out as part an EU Funded MARSTRUCT project Contract: TNE3-CT-2003-506141.  The objectives of this project were to carry out joint research on advanced structural analysis of ships and to establish a virtual European research institute. The collision scenarios and corresponding formulations presented in the paper will enable ship designers to assess rapidly and reliably the structural behaviour of vessels involved in collision and thereby taking necessary measures to improve safety. This project resulted in the establishment of the MARSTRUCT Virtual Institute, which enables partners to continue with their research collaboration and dissemination. http://www.marstruct-vi.com/marstruct2013/index.aspx

Title: Learning-based ship design optimization approach
AdditionalInformation: Ship design optimisation traditionally relies on the experience of individuals. This paper proposes a new machine-learning approach, analogous to human experiential learning: Q-learning is incorporated into a multi-objective optimisation scheme.  Computational efficiency gains of 25% and steel weight savings of at least 5% are compared against more traditional genetic algorithms such as NSGA-II. Its application has been extended by developing self-learning on-board decision support for Low Carbon Shipping-EPSRC project EP/H020004/1; and Low Carbon Shipping Conference (H Cui et al, 2011). Currently the technique is also being applied to optimisation of offshore wind farm access/maintenance activities for SSE ref: sol.judah@sserenewables.com

Title: The hydrodynamic flow around a yacht keel based on LES and DES
AdditionalInformation: This paper examines the effectiveness and efficiency of LES and DES simulations in assessing the racing performance of an America’s Cup yacht hull. Small changes in lift and drag have a marked effect. Particular attention is paid to an accurate description of flow over different keel/winglet geometries – grid shape and size, time step and near-wall turbulence resolution. A parametric study is presented against numerical models developed over the past decade. Similar methods have recently been incorporated into the design performance of a Sino-Japanese underwater robot, SUR II (Yue et al, IEEE Mechatronics & Automation, 2013).

Title: A seakeeping analysis method for an air-lifted vessel
AdditionalInformation: Numerical instabilities occur when calculating the motions of high-speed vessels. For a multi-hull, these difficulties increase due to the highly oscillatory integrands and logarithmic singularities. The paper focuses on a skirtless SES, having two separate plenum air cushion demi-hulls. Improved convergence and computational efficiencies were demonstrated. Research impacts on ship stability and passenger comfort. Based on additional work from FP5 EU project EFFISES (G3RD-CT-2000-00359), results were utilised by SES Europe to improve their SES catamaran designs (http://www.seseu.com/, ulf.tudem@brygga.no). Led to subsequent publications: Vassalos et al (J Ship & Offshore Structures, 2008) and Xie et al (International Shipbuilding Progress, 2011).

Title: Hydrodynamic loads during the deployment of ROVs
AdditionalInformation: Remotely-operated underwater vehicles have complex geometrical shapes presenting challenges to current CFD models. Accurate estimates of wave forces on ROVs, particularly near the free surface, are important to prevent damage or operational difficulties during launch and recovery; these can aid classification societies in developing more robust operational guidelines. The paper presents a comparison of numerical and experimental results for a Super Scorpio ROV model, supported by EPSRC (GR/L/57351) and industry (Ian Edwaters@halliburton.com). Morison’s inertial force, based on Stokes’ 5th-order wave theory and a hydrodynamic coefficient of 1.5, gives good agreement with measured values, without the need for complex theoretical models.

Title: An open source, parallel DSMC code for rarefied gas flows in arbitrary geometries
AdditionalInformation: This work presents, for the first time, a truly open-source direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) code for applications in hypersonic, rarefied gas flows such as planetary vehicle re-entry. The code was validated using comparisons with contemporary DSMC codes and is now in use across the scientific community including the Institute for Theoretical Electrical Engineering at the Ruhr University, Germany (www.tet.ruhr-uni-bochum.de/lehrstuhl) by Dr  Jan Trieschmann (trieschmann@tet.rub.de) and  The Institute of High Performance Computing, A*STAR, Singapore City, Singapore (www.ihpc.a-star.edu.sg) by Dr Zhi Shang (shangz@ihpc.a-star.edu.sg).

Title: Crew noise exposure on board ships and comparative study of applicable standards
AdditionalInformation: Based on EU Project ‘SilenV(GA No:234182), the first paper on exposure of seagoing crew to dangerous noise-levels on-board ships and proposes mitigating solutions to reduce the exposure. The paper highlights that ships that comply with IMO standards fail to comply with EU directive and this has led to new IMO noise standards (MSC.337(91)-IMO, 1 July 2014). This is part of Green Label Standards developed in SilenV under BV which plans to adopt them for classification of ships (eric.baudin@bureauveritas.com). Led to industrial collaboration with CalMac Ferries; Harbour Noise(cliff.bell@calmac.co.uk); and Aliaga Ship Recycling on Worker Safety (erkan.dereli@aliagadenizcilik.com) in ship digest project (UK/11/LLP/LdV/TOI-453)..

Title: Application of a new multi-agent Hybrid Co-evolution based Particle Swarm Optimisation methodology in ship design
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel and powerful optimisation methodology (HCPSO) developed specifically for complex optimisation problems such as ship design as it utilises faster search and evaluation characteristics while avoiding stagnations with the innovative e-disturbance technique. The approach reduces the optimisation time by 35%-60% while finding more accurate solutions. Extension of this work formed a chapter in a book by invitation (rchiong@swinburne.edu.my, Variants of Evolutionary Algorithms for Real-World Applications: ISBN 978-3-642-23423-1) and a journal (H Cui et al, CAD, Vo: 44, Issue 3,pp 186-195). The model was applied to development of route optimisation in EPSRC project (Low Carbon Shipping EP/H020004/1).

Title: Generation of optimal trajectories for Earth hybrid pole sitters
VolumeTitle: Journal of Guidance, Control and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: Key output from highly competitive European Research Council Advanced Investigator Grant 227571. Devised new families of optimal highly non-Keplerian orbits for continuous polar Earth observation and demonstrated significant operational benefits. Key finding since future US government Earth Observation and Telecommunications services plan to exploit non-Keplerian orbits (Dr P Mulligan, NOAA Office of Systems Development, patricia.mulligan@noaa.gov). Part of portfolio of work leading to 2011 Sir Arthur C Clarke Award for Space Research for McInnes’ group.

Title: Light levitated geostationary cylindrical orbits are feasible
VolumeTitle: Journal of Guidance, Control and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: Resolution of a 30 year old controversy demonstrating, for the first time, that displaced geosynchronous orbit are possible, thus disproving prior publications which claimed such orbits are impossible. Work supported by National Centre for Physics, Pakistan. Used by Lantoine and Russell at Georgia Inst. of Tech., and others, to relate to the classical Stark problem (Cel. Mech. and Dyn. Astro. 109. 333-366, 2011). Cited in successful nomination of McInnes for 2012 Royal Society of Edinburgh Kelvin Prize.

Title: Invariant manifolds and orbit control in the solar sail three-body problem
VolumeTitle: Journal of Guidance, Control and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: Key output from EPSRC grant EP/D003822/1. First use of invariant manifolds for solar sail trajectory design. Helped form the basis for a successful European Research Council Advanced Investigator Grant proposal. Used by Farres and Jorba at University of Barcelona to motivate solar sail trajectory control work (Cel. Mech. and Dyn. Astro. 107. 233-253, 2011). Led to collaborative work with Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics through CSF-funded Visiting Fellowship for Prof. Xu Ming (xuming@buaa.edu.cn).

Title: Maintenance/repair and production-oriented life cycle cost/earning model for ship structural optimisation during conceptual design stage
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the effect of the ship repair and maintenance process on the ship structural weight/reliability affecting the ship's life cycle cost and earning elements. This is the first study in the maritime domain utilising more than 300 ships' structural maintenance and repair data collected from shipyards and shipping companies as part of FP6 IMPROVE project (Contract No: FP6–031382). It provided the foundations for a number of journal publications in same field (DOI:10.1111/j.1559-3584.2011.00329.x, DOI:10.1080/17445302.2013.785728, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.marstruc.2010.07.003). The outcome of this paper directly contributed to winning a joint industry project (http://takvar.wix.com/drc#!eu-projects/vstc1=incass) in collaboration with a world-leading shipping company Danaos (drc@danaos.gr).

Title: Modelling the processes of cliff-top erosion and deposition under extreme storm waves
AdditionalInformation: Observations, model testing and calculation, demonstrate that large rocks found on cliff tops, previously thought deposited by tsunamis, were in fact moved much more recently by ordinary extreme waves. This work pioneered the estimation of wave impact forces on the side of ships in beam seas, which differ from bow impact, because there is a similar effect of a reflected wave on the incoming wave. This contributed to three years of researcher funding to explain to the Spanish court the loss of the Oil tanker "MV Prestige" (Solicitor: estelle.pattard@incelaw.com).

Title: Bow impact loading on FPSOs 1 - experimental investigation
AdditionalInformation: Motivated by lack of guidance in steep wave impact loading on marine structures, experimental work determined: characteristics and statistics of extreme, steep waves; and, the breaking wave forces on curved bows of FPSOs and conventional tankers. Two complex models using 64 data channels were used to create a comprehensive picture of pressure variation across the hull. The output of the research was directly used in the repair and strengthening of the wave-impact damaged BP-owned Schiehallion FPSO (Alwyn.McLeary@uk.bp.com). The work has provided the experimental basis for the SAFEFLOW project (G3RD-CT-2000-00271, Buchner@marin.nl) and HSE (www.hse.gov.uk/research/rrpdf/rr324.pdf‎) recommendations for designing for wave impact loading.

Title: Bow impact loading on FPSOs 2 - theoretical investigation
AdditionalInformation: Theoretical and empirical models for wave impact loads, based upon experimental data are described. Wave kinematics and rate of change of momentum were used to create empirical equations that were validated against the model tests. The work lead to the HSE document “Wave slap loading on FPSO bows” (www.hse.gov.uk/research/rrpdf/rr324.pdf‎) and the contribution by Barltrop to the SAFEFLOW(G3RD-CT-2000-00271) joint industry and EU funded project report. Safety cases for offshore platforms refer to these documents (Standing:BMT; Gaspar.Guzsvany@atkinsglobal.com). Consultancy work has been undertaken on wave impact forces on fixed and floating platforms and invited lectures given in Korea (jeompaik@pusan.ac.kr) and Norway (torgeir.moan@ntnu.no).

Title: Numerical simulation of water flooding into a damaged vessel’s compartment by the volume of fluid method
AdditionalInformation: Given over 20 years of sector-wide demands for improvements in ship damage stability, the main risk to human lives (TIP4-CT-2005-516278), this paper presents a novel, high fidelity method to address this problem effectively by accounting for ship-floodwater-sea interactions and complexity of internal/external flows. This is critical, as flooding rates provide information both on survivability and time to capsize, providing a platform not only for effective design for damage survivability but also for abandonment post-casualty. The research facilitated both aspects by offering accurate predictions and flexibility to address complexity in ship architecture (a.jasionowski@brookesbell.com).  It also instigated new research focus internationally (frederick-stern@uiowa.edu).

Title: An experimental study of unsteady hydrodynamics of a single scull
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment
AdditionalInformation: In this paper the hydrodynamic performance of a single scull is investigated via field trials and novel tank tests in collaboration with researchers from the University of Southampton and UNSW Australia (l.doctors@unsw.edu.au) funded by EPSRC EP/F006284/1. As part of the study further developments on our unsteady towing capability allowed arbitrarily complex motion patterns to be realised. This unique hydrodynamic testing capability is now used in work investigating unsteady phenomenon effecting tidal turbines (EPSRC EP/F062036/1) and has led to a new research project (EPSRC EP/J500847/1 Industrial Doctoral Center for Offshore Renewable Energy) on tidal turbine blade turbulence control.

Title: Resistance of a compartmented surface-effect ship
VolumeTitle: Journal of Ship Production and Design
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes a series of carefully controlled experiments on a compartmented surface-effect ship. The work demonstrates the growing expertise of the hydrodynamics facility for novel, non-standard testing of complex marine systems illustrated by numerous projects from the marine industry such as FP7 projects “SHOAL”  and "Ship arrestor" (Grant nos. 2316466 and 222575), Industry funded "Investigation of resistance reduction of an LNG carrier phases 2-5" (Shell UK Ltd, d.connoly@shell.com) and in the marine renewables sector such as "Safe and efficient personnel access to offshore wind turbines" (Technip Offshore Wind Ltd, Scottish & Southern Energy plc, Scottish Power plc,sol.judah@sserenewables.com).

Title: Unsteady finite-depth effects during resistance tests on a ship model in a towing tank
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes an extension of a previous study (J Ship Res 52(4):263-273, 2008) to the case of relatively shallow water. This work was partly funded by EPSRC EP/F019998/1. It is shown that the unsteady theory is in full agreement with the experimental results that are presented here for the first time. The novel experimental rig developed as part of this work and the experimental expertise gained is now being applied in an industry funded research project concerning the design of a unique articulated shallow water vessel for inland waterways (Scottish Canals 'Freight on the Lowlands' contact Richard.Millar@scottishcanals.co.uk).

Title: Unsteady effects during resistance tests on a ship model in a towing tank
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the phenomenon of oscillations in wave resistance during the constant velocity phase of a towing-tank resistance test on a ship model. This work was partly funded by EPSRC EP/F019998/1. Novel towing tank experiments that allowed programmed variation in the towing carriage velocity time history were developed in order to compare with unsteady thin-ship resistance theory. This novel experiment methodology has subsequently been developed and enabled a number of studies such as EPSRC funded project EP/F006284/1 on rowing and on the effects of unsteady flow on Tidal Turbines (EP/F062036/1 and Milne et al Ocean Engineering 2013, DOI: 10.1016/j.oceaneng.2012.12.027).

Title: An inflationary differential evolution algorithm for space trajectory optimization
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a significant advance on the convergence properties of Differential Evolution, a new approach to testing stochastic based algorithms and graphical 2D representation of a multidimensional search space. The paper led to a key-note speech at EVOLVE2011, a INRIA-CINVESTAV organised international conference on set-oriented numerics (schuetze@cs.cinvestav.mx). The conference version of the paper won the outstanding paper award at the Congress on Evolutionary Computation in 2009 (http ://www.cec-2009.org/paperAwards.shtml). The paper has been identified as one of the most significant contributions to the field (bconway@illinois.edu, University of Illinois, Journal of Optimization Theory and Applications, 2011).

Title: Improved shaping approach to the preliminary design of low-thrust trajectories
VolumeTitle: Journal of Guidance, Control and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents a new unified view on inverse optimal control approaches (geometric or shape-based approaches) for low-thrust trajectory design. It is the first treatment of the problem from a theoretical mathematical point of view. The paper led to an invited seminar at the State Key Laboratory of Astronautics Dynamics in Xi'an, China, 2011 (houliqiang2008@139.com) and a seminar series at JAXA (the Japanese Space Agency) in Tokyo in 2012 (stefano.campagnola@jaxa.jp or Kawakatsu.Yasuhiro@jaxa.jp). This paper was one of the key references that led to the acquisition of Stardust, a 4.1 Million Euros Marie Curie International Training Network (FP7-PEOPLE-ITN-2012, GA No. 317185).

Title: Preliminary space mission design under uncertainty
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first example of Evidence-Based Robust design for preliminary design of space systems with the potential to radically change the approach to space mission design. The European Space Agency  subsequently funded two research projects to further develop this idea: Innovation Triangular Initiative  co-supported by Astrium UK and VEGA (Euro50k) and a Network Partnership Initiative grant (Euro50k) (Quirien.Wijnands@esa.int). Astrium UK also provided an £85k ICASE scholarship (Stephen.KEMBLE@astrium.eads.net). The paper led to an invited key-note speech at EUROGEN2011 (d.quagliarella@cira.it) and to invited talks at INRIA Bordeaux in 2013 (pietro.congedo@inria.fr) and at ESTECO, University of Trieste in 2012 (poloni@esteco.com).

Title: A hybrid multiagent approach for global trajectory optimization
AdditionalInformation: First example of agent-based global optimisation combining local and global search through a hybridisation of agent-based search and deterministic branch & prune scheme with theoretical proof of convergence. The paper was recognised by CINVESTAV, one of the leading centres for evolutionary computation (schuetze@cs.cinvestav.mx), inspired developments  by a group in the University of New South Wales (barkat@adfa.edu.au) and led to: an ESA Ariadna grant (Euro36k) on the global optimisation of space trajectories (leopold.summerer@esa.int), an invited key-note at the Wuhan State University of Geoscience, China, 2010, (Prof. Maocai Wang, cugwmc@gmail.com) and an invited tutorial session at EVOLVE2013, Leiden, 2013 (emmerich@liacs.nl).

Title: Solar sail formation flying for deep-space remote sensing
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a novel means of continuous observation of the polar regions of the Earth using solar sail formation flying. The research was undertaken in collaboration with Alex Coletti of SM Resources Corporation (US consultancy on mission support) and Ben Diedrich (ben.diedrich@noaa.gov), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) in support of future earth observation technologies. This paper was key to the scientific programme of a successful Marie Curie Initial Training Network FP7-PEOPLE-2011-ITN no. 289240, 2012. An extension to consider formation flying using low-thrust propulsion will be undertaken at the University of Turku, Finland (Dr Mikkola, mikkola@utu.fi).

Title: Numerical simulation of the airflow–rivulet interaction associated with the rain-wind induced vibration phenomenon
VolumeTitle: Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics
AdditionalInformation: Novel numerical approach for Rain-wind induced vibrations, coupling time varying aerodynamic coefficients to development of water film. After oral presentation of the research at the UK Wind Engineering Conference, this paper was invited into a Special Edition of the journal (Dr J Macdonald, Editor, University of Bristol). Methodology presented now used by J.H. Bi, (jihong_bi@163.com), whose paper published in J Wind Eng Ind Aero 121, 49-59, 2013, demonstrated a new numerical approach “based on .. Taylor’s model” (i.e. this paper).  Research also led to invitation to collaborate with Birmingham University and to a successful grant award EP/J008370/1.

Title: Numerical simulation of rivulet evolution on a horizontal cable subject to an external aerodynamic field
AdditionalInformation: A new numerical model for the evolution of a thin liquid film on a stationary circular cylinder under the combined effects of pressure, shear, surface tension and gravity. Predictions of rivulet growth is consistent with previous experimental observations. This research led to the author being invited to deliver a research seminar at the laboratory of Prof E de Langre (delangre@ladhyx.polytechnique.fr), a leading international expert on Fluid-Structure Interaction, at Ecole Polytechnique, Paris (March 2009). The work is discussed in “Fluid-Structure Interactions : Cross-Flow-Induced Instabilities” by Paidoussis, Price and de Langre, as a model with “further refinements” compared to previous research.

Title: New developments in rain–wind-induced vibrations of cables
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the ICE - Structures and Buildings
AdditionalInformation: The development of a new model for the evolution and growth of water rivulets on a circular cylinder is presented. The work presented led to Taylor being invited by the UK Wind Engineering Society (WES) to present at a Technical Meeting, on Cable Vibrations at the ICE, London, (September 2009) organised by John Macdonald, (John.Macdonald@bristol.ac.uk). Additionally Taylor was invited by WES to deliver a public lecture on Wind Engineering at ICE Glasgow (March 2011) organised by Graham Knapp (Graham.Knapp@cstb.fr).

Title: A numerical investigation into the aerodynamic characteristics and aeroelastic stability of a footbridge
AdditionalInformation: This paper details research into the aerodynamic and aeroelastic characteristics of a motorway footbridge design, applying the vortex method fluid-structure interaction code developed by the author. The work identified a potentially severe aeroelastic instability problem with the design. This informed changes to the deck design concept, and led to corrective deck modifications being implemented in the constructed bridge. The findings of this paper has led to further knowledge exchange and impact with the Halcrow Group Ltd, on aerodynamic characteristics of bridge designs [contact: Iain Salisbury, SalisburyI@Halcrow.com, Halcrow Group Ltd].

Title: Accuracy analysis of high-order lattice Boltzmann models for rarefied gas flows
AdditionalInformation: This work for the first time proved that the high-order lattice Boltzmann model can reduce to linearised kinetic BGK equation which lays the foundation for lattice Boltzmann modelling of rarefied gas dynamics. Led to a new EPSRC research grant EP/I036117/1 valued at £350k. Opened up international research collaborations with MIT, USA (Hadjiconstantinou: ngh@MIT.EDU) on rarefied gas dynamics, leading to a joint publication (10.1017/jfm.2012.616) and researcher exchanges; and researcher exchanges with Xi'an Jiaotong University (Tang: ghtang@mail.xjtu.edu.cn) addressing flow in porous media funded by Royal Society of Edinburgh – National Natural Science Foundation of China (443570/NNS/INT): June 2013-May 2015.

Title: Phase-field modeling droplet dynamics with soluble surfactants
AdditionalInformation: Successfully captured, for the first time, thermodynamically non-equilibrium effects of surfactants in droplets dynamical behaviour in microfluidic devices. Paved the way for a new simulation tool for stepping beyond current empirical design methods that hinder the development of microdroplet technologies. Key finding led to several plenary talks e.g. the Opening Plenary Talk at 4th International Symposium on Physics of Fluids 13-16 June 2011, Lijiang China (Shu: mpeshuc@nus.edu.sg). Led to PhD thesis examinations at Singapore National University (regtslt@nus.edu.sg) and Oxford University (steve.sheard@eng.ox.ac.uk). Led to EPSRC Consortium Grant UKCOMES EP/L00030X/1, Mar 2013–Feb 2019 in which I lead the Microflow theme.

Title: Wake dynamics and rotor-fuselage aerodynamic interactions
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Helicopter Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes advancements to a core methodology, which had been developed over previous years as a novel computational method able to capture, to unprecedented accuracy and resolution, the detailed dynamics of the vortical features present in helicopter wake, and their interaction with the various components of the helicopter. These advancements were subsequently used directly under licence by Continuum Dynamics, Inc., one of the best-known rotorcraft consultancies in the US, to model and predict the aerodynamics of Sikorsky's X2 advanced-concept helicopter during the de-risking phase of its test flight programme (contact CDI Dr Glen Whitehouse, glen@continuum-dynamics.com, Sikorsky Alan Egolf tegolf@sikorsky.com).

Title: Eulerian simulation of the fluid dynamics of helicopter brownout
AdditionalInformation: This paper brings together work awarded two 'best paper' certificates/awards at international conferences: the American Helicopter Society Annual Forum, Montreal 2008 and Phoenix 2010 (AHS  contact Randy Johnson: rjohnson@vtol.org). This work embodied a new computational algorithm for brownout modelling that allowed an order-of-magnitude increase in computational efficiency and a significant improvement in accuracy over previous approaches. Subsequent application with the Agusta Helicopter Company, Milan, enabled analysis and, for the first time, understanding  of the anomalous brownout characteristics of one of their helicopter designs, leading to marked improvements in the helicopter's effectiveness under operational conditions (Agusta contact Dr Andrea D'Andrea: andrea.dandrea@agustawestland.com).

Title: Influence of blade aerodynamic model on the prediction of helicopter high-frequency airloads
AdditionalInformation: This paper summarises a three year contribution to an international workshop hosted by NASA and the German DLR to investigate methods of improving the prediction of helicopter rotor airloads in certain difficult instances, particularly descending flight. The research resulted in a novel computational method able to capture, to unprecedented accuracy and resolution, the detailed dynamics of the vortical features present in helicopter wake, and their interaction with the various components of the helicopter. A review paper of this effort described our approach as "one of the most successful" (Komerath et al. JAHS Vol 56 No. 2 2011) (lim@merlin.arc.nasa.gov Berend.VanDerWall@dlr.de).

Title: Wake structure and kinematics in the vortex ring state
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Helicopter Society
AdditionalInformation: This paper summarised four years of reseach into understanding pathological wake instability in the aftermath of a serious accident involving a Bell V-22 tiltrotor vehicle. The work led to a long-standing research collaboration with Maryland University (Prof J.G. Leishman leishman@eng.umd.edu) and helped to inform NASA/US Army and Bell activities in understanding and rectifying the phenomenon and returning the V-22 to flight status (Bell contact Dr Albert Brand ABrand@bellhelicopter.textron.com, NASA/US Army Dr Chee Tung chee.tung@us.army.mil).

Title: Low-thrust enabled highly non-Keplerian orbits in support of future Mars exploration
VolumeTitle: Journal of Guidance, Control and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: Article solves communication problem in future Mars exploration through the development and application of novel astrodynamics, enable by emerging space technologies. Prior to this, exploration of Mars by any high-value asset was prohibited due to communication blackouts caused by the Sun.  Led directly to award short-listing at the Times Higher Education awards for Outstanding Engineering Research Team of the Year 2010. Results continue to influence and inform the European Space Agency’s envisaged Mars communication architecture (Mr. F. Bosquillon de Freschville, ESA-ESOC, Francois.Bosquillon.de.Frescheville@esa.int) and have been used by University of Pisa (e.g. Celest. Mech. Dyn. Astron. 114(1-2), SI, 181-200, 2012.

Title: Solar sail science mission applications and advancement : solar sailing: concepts, technology, missions
AdditionalInformation: Presents the first parametric analysis of solar sail enabled missions, systematically extracting key enabling characteristics. Results identify critical obstructions in technology development due to a lack of applications of technology that exploit identified key enabling characteristics, introducing novel thinking to the field to overcome this blockage. Stated by Keats Wilkie (w.k.wilkie@larc.nasa.gov) of NASA Langley, at 3rd International Solar Sail Symposium (2013) to contain “the inspiration” for funded NASA work. Used by Université Paris-Sud (Thierry.Appourchaux@ias.u-psud.fr) and NASA-MSFC (C.Les.Johnson@nasa.gov) to direct the advancement of solar sail technology concepts. Continues to inform technology development within ESA (Constantinos.Stavrinidis@esa.int) and DLR (hansjoerg.dittus@dlr.de).

Title: Analytical landing trajectories for embedded autonomy
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Supported by Chinese Nature Science Foundation (grant 60535010), this article reports results from collaboration with the Department of Aerospace Engineering at the Harbin Institute of Technology, China, to inform the on-going development work of the future Chinese Lunar lander mission. Article presents new and novel techniques, introducing the concept of embedded autonomy to the guidance and control of future lunar landers through the use of Direct Adaptive Control. It is shown that the use the use of embedded autonomy in the control loop increase the robustness of the control system to multiple failures when compared with a ‘traditional’ control system

Title: Technology requirements of exploration beyond Neptune by solar sail propulsion
AdditionalInformation: Defines technology requirements, enabling technologies and roadmaps of future science missions. Early findings of the study directly incorporated into 2007 ESA Cosmic Visions call for science mission concepts, and the article continues to define both ESA and NASA technology requirements in the area of advanced solar sail propulsion technology. Used by Tsinghua University (e.g. Celest. Mech. Dyn. Astron. 111(4), 415-430, 2011) and University of Pisa (e.g. J. Guid. Control Dyn. 34(3), 923-927, 2011 & Celest. Mech. Dyn. Astron. 110(4), 343-368, 2011). Contributed to invitation (Constantinos.Stavrinidis@esa.int) of Macdonald to chair on-going ESA/DLR Gossamer working group on application of solar sail technology.

Title: Parametric finite-element studies on the effect of tool shape in friction stir welding
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an investigation of the effect of tool shape on Friction Stir Weld quality using a new, and advanced in the field fully coupled multiphysics model of the FSW process proposed by the authors (Eng Comp 27, 7-8, pp967-985). This model enables new insights into the significance of certain process parameters not easily studied experimentally. It is shown that pin radius has a major effect on the process and consequent weld quality, whereas shoulder angle is much less significant.  This is evidenced by  Rai et al in Science and Technology of Welding and Joining, 16, 4, pp325-342.

Title: Shakedown of a thick cylinder with a radial crosshole
AdditionalInformation: This paper, an outcome from EPSRC project (GR/S81841/010), investigates the effect of a cross-hole on the cyclic plastic response of a thick cylinder. It shows that the presence of a cross-hole significantly reduces the plastic shakedown boundary on a Bree-type interaction diagram but does not significantly affect the ratchet boundary (see Chen et al, Journal of Pressure Vessel Technology , Vol. 133, Issue: 3, Trans ASME, June 2011). This clarifies the appropriate stress classification for small diameter openings in cylindrical vessels in pressure vessel design by analysis.

Title: Design by analysis of ductile failure and buckling in torispherical pressure vessel heads
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the application of the authors' innovative work-energy based global plastic collapse criterion developed under EPSRC project (GR/S81841/010) to design by analysis of thin wall pressure vessels. Comparison with test and numerical results from the literature shows the criterion allows the designer to correctly identify the formation of critical plastic structural collapse mechanisms.  The criterion has subsequently been investigated by researchers at the Gebze Institute of Technology, Turkey (see Advances in Engineering Software, Vol. 45, Issue: 1, pp: 232-238, March 2012) and also in Iran (zehsaz@tabrizu.ac.ir) and Malaysia (Behzad.abdi@gmail.com).

Title: Multi-physics simulation of friction stir welding process
AdditionalInformation: This papers presents a new, fully coupled multiphysics model of the complete Friction Stir Welding FSW process. The advanced FE formulation allows recovery of residual stress, which is not possible in alternative CFD formulations. The numerical model is validated through comparison with external experimental results. This model has facilitated further research/numerical simulation of FSW tooling and process parameters (Proc IMechE Part B J Eng Manuf Vol 224 ,IssueB8, pp1161-1173, Int J Pres Ves & Piping Vol 108 pp2-6)  as observed by Rai et al (Science and Technology of Welding and Joining, 16, 4, pp345-342).

Title: Design analysis of ductile failure in dovetail connections
VolumeTitle: Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates application of elastic and inelastic pressure vessel design by analysis procedures to design of a type of connection used in large rotating machines such as hydroelectric motor–generators. Three analysis methods are investigated and validated against experimental results for model components. The methodology developed has subsequently been implemented by Hitachi in rotating equipment design process. Contact Dr.Eng. Tomohiro Naruse, Senior Researcher (Unit Leader) Hitachi Research Laboratory, Tomohiro.naruse.az@hitachi.com.

Title: Evaluating plastic loads in torispherical heads using a new criterion of collapse
AdditionalInformation: This paper, an outcome from EPSRC project  GR/S81841/01, proposes and investigates a novel gross plastic collapse criterion for strain hardening materials based on elastic and plastic work considerations.  This criterion advanced the field by clearly identifying the load at which gross-plastic deformation occurs, enabling quantification of the effect of material strain hardening on load carrying capacity.  Finite Element Analysis  application is validated against experimental results from the literature.  The procedure provides a suitable user-criterion for limiting gross plastic deformation in pressure vessel design by analysis.

Title: Unsteady wake modelling for tidal current turbines
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper (editor: a.s.bahaj@soton.ac.uk) reported a more computationally efficient process to appraise detailed vorticity characteristics from a tidal rotor. The paper was instrumental to Johnstone being awarded £0.5million under EPSRC Supergen Marine III to extend the work to include surface wave motion (robin.wallace@ed.ac.uk). Inha University, Korea invited the author to visit and present this together with a plenary paper at AWTEC 2012 followed by joint research with Strathclyde staff in Korea (chjo@inha.ac.kr). This resulted in new methods for modelling wave-current-vorticity interactions and downstream propagation to inform the spatial planning and performance of tidal arrays (ISSN: 0960-1481, v54, June 2013).

Title: Computation of solar radiation distribution in a solar still with internal and external reflectors
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a new, state of the art technique to quantifying the solar flux distribution within solar stills. It discretises the solar flux as individual spectral components and quantifies these individually within the computational assessment of energy flux. The researcher, Madhlopa, was awarded a Royal Academy of Engineering Newton advanced fellowship award, 2010, to further develop and apply this within a new prototype still (fellowship@royalsociety.org). Further joint research is underway in developing and prototyping this within a larger scale unit at the University of Malawi (amos.madhlopa@uct.ac.za).

Title: Analysis of a single point tensioned mooring system for station keeping of a contra-rotating marine current turbine
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports a new step change technology. It reports development and proving of a new generation of contra-rotating marine turbine (CoRMaT) which is regarded by the Scottish and UK governments as a disruptive technology (neil.ferguson@scotent.co.uk). This work lead to international patents Int. Pat. No. 0516149.2, the formation of a University spin-out company, Nautricity Ltd. in 2009 which attracted in excess of £6 million investment to commercialise this work. International research joint research with Dalhousie University, Canada (darrel.doman@dal.ca) and Nanyang Technical University, Singapore (nsrikanth@ntu.edu.sg) have resulted. This includes bi-lateral researcher exchange from Dalhousie and NTU to Strathclyde Aug.’13–Dec’13.

Title: Analysis of externally loaded bolted joints : analytical, computational and experimental study
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: Detailed analytical study of the bolted joint problem under external loads. The work corrects a long term industry design procedure and contradicts conventional design approaches. Checked by Engineering Sciences Data Unit who have adopted the work in the production of new industry standard (tom.gray@virgin.net). Approach adopted by British Standards Institution, PD5500 Design Methods Committee PVE/1/15 via, Mr Simon Earland (simon@earland.co.uk). Dr Warren Brown, PVRC chairman - new ASME standard, directly used the work in a keynote presentation at the PVP Conference, Paris, July 2013 (wbrown@integrityes.com). Outcomes  presented at IMechE  Symposia in 2011 & 2013 (paul.jackson@gb.abb.com)

Title: A three-dimensional finite element model of maximal grip loading in the human wrist
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: World first paper developing the full 3D FEA modelling of the whole wrist bone interaction including ligament and cartlidge modelling. Work has been used by medical implant groups in the UK and worldwide research groups in US (Prof Victor Kosmopoulos, University of Northern Texas, Fort Worth on ligament modelling (victor.kosmopoulos@unthsc.edu), Japan (Prof Yuji Tanabe, Niigata University which resulted in a research exchange in 2012 funded by Japanese Institution, y.tanabe@eng.niigata-u.ac.jp) and Malaysia (Prof Tunku Abindin – using our model in their biomechanical analysis of the wrist arthroplasty in rheumatoid arthritis (tkzrea@um.edu.my).

Title: Finite element model creation and stability considerations of complex biological articulation : the human wrist joint
AdditionalInformation: Analytical treatment of particular clinical issues of stability and load transfer in wrists with direct relevance to clinical practice. It has changed surgical practice by correlating wrist pain to misalignment (in Glasgow Mark Bransby-Zachary mark.bransby-zachary@sgh.scot.nhs.uk) and had wider impact in US, Japan and Malaysia: USA (Prof Victor Kosmopoulos, University of Northern Texas, victor.kosmopoulos@unthsc.edu), Japan (Prof Yuji Tanabe, Niigata University which resulted in a research exchange in 2012 funded by the Japanese Institution, y.tanabe@eng.niigata-u.ac.jp) and Malaysia (Prof Tunku Abindin using the model in the biomechanical analysis of the wrist arthroplasty in rheumatoid arthritis (tkzrea@um.edu.my)

Title: Performance of a nongasketed flange joint combined internal pressure and bending loading
AdditionalInformation: Publication informing the pressure vessel community which is the summation of a number of outputs over the preceding 5 years. An extensive comparative experimental and numerical study of a non-gasketed bolted flange joint. The verified FEA model is used as a benchmark analysis under complex loading (Dr Warren Brown, ASME Bolted Joint Working Group Chairman (wbrown@integrityes.com). Presented to the oil and gas sector, in an invited presentation in a special one-day symposium organised by the Pressure Systems Group of the IMechE ( Paul Jackson, ABB) in Aberdeen (Sept 2011 and April 2013) and in London (October 2013). (paul.jackson@gb.abb.com)

Title: An automated procedure for detection and identification of ball bearing damage using multivariate statistics and pattern recognition
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a new approach for condition monitoring of ball bearings based on the measured vibration signature of the bearings. The methodology has been recognized and followed by several research groups internationally in e.g. KULeuven (P.Sas@kuleuven.ac.be) and the University of New South Wales (Prof. Emeritus R.E.Randal R.Randal@unsw.au ), who acknowledge its impact as a “very promising and useful tool” for industrial applications. The method is being extended in joint research with scientific and industrial collaborators (gary.scott@xpd8solutions.uk).

Title: Vibration-based damage detection in plates by using time series analysis
AdditionalInformation: The paper is recognised to propose a “different paradigm for vibration-based structural health monitoring which is purely based on the measured time varying vibration response” by Chinese researchers (DOI:10.1016/j.jsv.2010.06.020). This is a key paper for an invited book chapter (Advanced Material Reviews, Eds. Litak et al 2011 .)  The method was extended in collaborative research with Gdansk University Poland, (wieslaw@imp.gda.pl). The methodology is acknowledged as “pioneering investigation” by KULeuven researchers (W.Heyeln@kuleuven.ac.be) and as “leading to considerable developments in structural health monitoring” (chan@bjut.edu.cn, Chan E., Probabilistic Engineering Mechanics, vol 10,3,2011).

Title: A phased array-based method for damage detection and localization in thin plates
AdditionalInformation:
The methodology has been demonstrated to work for a number of structures like e.g. plates, shells, beams and it was adopted and extended by teams from KULeuven, Belgium (H.Van.Brussel@kuleuven.ac.be) and Portugal (P.Ribeiro@up.pt), who acknowledge it as a “very useful development” in the field. The method is being extended for composite materials in joint research with a team from the University of Bologna and PZ6 Composites®, who recognize “its flexibility and deployment potential”( A.Zucchelli@unibo.it ) . 
This is key paper for Volkswagen Stiftung grant of 10K for collaborative research  with University of Liege (Volkswagen Stf NNL 212 12/2009 j.c.golinval@ulg.be ).

Title: Effect of circular holes on the ratchet limit and crack tip plastic strain range in a centre cracked plate
AdditionalInformation: First comprehensive investigation on the ratchet limit and crack tip plastic strain range for the cracked structure. New insight into cyclic plastic behaviour of cracks with detailed parametric studies. One of key outputs from EPSRC Grant EP/G038880/1. Cited and used by researchers from China (International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping, 101, 113–142, 2013). Led to further investigations on cyclic J-integral using the LMM (International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping, 108-109, 72-80, 2013). Delivered a step-change in modelling cracks using direct methods and secured an EngD project (NE89) funded by the EPSRC nuclear EngD centre and Siemens.

Title: On the shakedown analysis of welded pipes
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: First safety shakedown envelope for welded pipes. Key output from EPSRC Research Grant EP/G038880/1. Cited and used by researchers from China (10.3969/j.issn.1001-4837.2012.10.001, http://d.wanfangdata.com.cn/Periodical_ylrq201210001.aspx). The use of this research output in EDF Energy (David Tipping, david.tipping@edf-energy.com) significantly advance the internationally-leading role of the UK in the assessment of industrial and commercial welded structures (Prof Bob Ainsworth, robert.ainsworth@manchester.ac.uk). This and other related researches have secured 4 nuclear EngD projects (£0.5M in total, http://www.dalton.manchester.ac.uk/images/subr/files/Engdwebsiteprojectlist.pdf). Subsequent works developing fatigue and creep damage of weldments were reported in Int J Press Vessels Piping, 104, 1-13, 2013 and International Journal of Fatigue, 55, 112-125, 2013.

Title: Lower and upper bound shakedown analysis of structures with temperature-dependent yield stress
AdditionalInformation: Novel robust and efficient numerical method on shakedown analysis for practical engineering problems. Key output of EPSRC Research Grant EP/G038880/1. First time transferred this general-purpose technique for the evaluation of shakedown and limit loads from research into the engineering industry. Cited and announced in the UK R5/R6 Newsletter. Cited and used by Chinese researcher (Journal of Pressure Vessel Technology, 134, 011205-3, 2012) and Russia researcher (http://izvuzmash.bmstu.ru/articles/8/8.pdf). A software tool has been developed based upon this work, and has been widely used by key industries including EDF Energy (David Dean, david.dean@edf-energy.com), Rolls-Royce (Michael Martin, Michael.Martin@Rolls-Royce.com) and Frazer-Nash (Stephen Fox, s.fox@fnc.co.uk).

Title: Analysis and prediction of vortex-induced vibrations of variable-tension vertical risers in linearly sheared currents
AdditionalInformation: This original paper has advanced the idea of how to model and simulate the vortex-induced vibration of cylindrical structures in sheared currents. A reviewer stated “this paper presents a new prediction model for VIV response of long flexible riser” (editor, kashi@naoe.eng.osaka-u.ac.jp) by applying a powerful nonlinear modal analysis to tackle a challenging industrial fluid-structure interaction problem, and providing prediction results when compared with industrial experimental data and MIT predicted results (OMAE2008-57108 paper).

Title: Multi-mode interactions in vortex-induced vibrations of flexible curved/straight structures with geometric nonlinearities
AdditionalInformation: This original paper has provided a refined modelling and systematic approach to theoretically investigate the significant effect of multimode interaction due to geometric nonlinearities on the vortex-induced vibration of flexible structures. New insights are gained providing qualitative comparisons with experimental observations. The developed in-house analysis tool has been used in the research project funded by the Scottish Power Renewables (£20k, bcarruthers@scottishpower.com). This work has also led to new joint research and publications with the University of Sao Paulo on the flow-induced vibration experiment (g.assi@usp.br) and a service-rendered work funded by Balmoral company (b.bakewell@balmoral.co.uk).

Title: Reduced-order modelling of vortex-induced vibration of catenary riser
AdditionalInformation: This paper is funded by a Knowledge Transfer Partnerships programme involving the consultant company MCS Kenny and University of Aberdeen (KTP006264, £181k). It is based on a three-year collaborative project aimed at developing a new theoretical concept and tool to be integrated into the company’s world-leading software used in the industry for the analysis and design of marine structures. The new concept, models, methods and research outcomes have been presented to several companies in Houston USA including BP America, ExxonMobil, Chevron and Shell (michael.lane@woodgroupkenny.com), and at a number of seminars in Mexico (rjpadilla@dictfi.unam.mx), Singapore (YMLow@ntu.edu.sg), Bristol (john.macdonald@bristol.ac.uk) and Edinburgh (V.Venugopal@ed.ac.uk).

Title: Nonlinear longitudinal/transversal modal interactions in highly extensible suspended cables
AdditionalInformation: This paper has highlighted for the first time the important effects and chaotic behaviours of cable nonlinear dynamics having high axial extensibility that have been neglected by other researchers in the past four decades. The paper has created a fundamental understanding of possible dangerous dynamic interaction and associated parametric ranges important in practice. The effect of axial extensibility found is particularly important in the field of cable-stay bridges (J of Sound and Vibration 330, Marsico et al.; J of Engineering Mechanics 136).

Title: How motion trajectory affects energy extraction performance of a biomimic energy generator with an oscillating foil?
AdditionalInformation: Extraction of ocean energy using bio-mimetic oscillating motion is a newly developed concept. This research is well aligned to the industrial requirements on the study for improving device efficiency. For the first time, an optimal device oscillating motion profile at which the output power and efficiency reach the maximum is identified by using a CFD method. This research has recently led to an industry funded project in collaboration with ResHydro LLT USA company (slewinter@reshydro.com) for a long-term joint research on their flapping wing tidal devices development.

Title: Computational study on near wake interaction between undulation body and a D-section cylinder
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, this study combines two important physical phenomena together, i.e. elimination of vortex induced vibration of circular cylinder in offshore engineering with an energy extraction by swimming fish in biomimetic engineering. With this modelling, the results provide a new tool for VIV control method in offshore industry applications. This study led to a Royal Society Postdoctoral Fellowship (kimberley.hutchings@royalsociety.org). This study resulted in a new collaboration with Institute of High Performance Computing in Singapore via researcher exchange scheme (loujing@ihpc.a-star.edu.sg and nguyenvt@ihpc.a-star.edu.sg)

Title: Numerical investigation of angle of attack profile on propulsion performance of an oscillating foil
AdditionalInformation: Inspired by various flapping motions adopted by flying animals, this paper is the first time examining the oscillating motion profile effect on the propulsion performance of an oscillating foil. Results provide significant insights on the design of bio-inspired robotic fish and AUV. This led to the current joint research with France on a robotic fish design (frederic.boyer@mines-nantes.fr). The concept and simulation method used is further developed in subsequent research (Xiao et al. Renewable Energy Vol. 37, 2012) and one application under MARIE CURIE ACTIONS FP7-PEOPLE-2013-IIF (SEP-210112558) (pending).

Title: Resistance of a ship undergoing oscillatory motion
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study addressing the hydrodynamics of a ship advancing with periodic unsteady forward speed, including a theoretical prediction validated by a novel experimental approach. The study was implemented with a collaborator from UNSW Australia and built on a novel experiment technique developed via EPSRC-funded project EP/F006284/1, and the specific research was funded via EPSRC EP/F019998/1. The practical application of the study was initially in the prediction of performance of rowing shells for London 2012; however the development of the experiment technique and expertise subsequently led to EPSRC funded programme in unsteady loading on tidal turbines EPSRC (EP/F006284/1).

Title: Wave generation of a compartmented surface-effect ship
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: This study, carried out with an Australian collaborator (l.doctors@unsw.edu.au), grew out of a previous EPSRC-funded collaboration (EPSRC EP/F019998/1). Theoretical studies had predicted that wave generation and drag of air-cushion vehicles could be reduced by compartmenting the air cushion and operating the compartments at different pressures, but previous attempts had failed to demonstrate this in physical tests. Key challenges in maintaining pressure differential between compartments without increasing drag were identified and overcome, and the study demonstrated the benefits in a physical experiment for the first time.

Title: Hydrodynamics of an oscillating articulated eel-like structure
AdditionalInformation: This study addressed the topical subject of underwater vehicles propelled by swimming rather than conventional propulsors. These have been proposed for various civilian and military roles including pollution monitoring and surveillance in regions where conventional propulsors are unsuitable. A novel experiment study was implemented in which the hydrodynamics of the device was investigated, and compared with a simplified predictive model. The expertise gained in the study led to the participation of the authors in the EU-funded FP7 “SHOAL” project (ref 080796), and the collaboration was developed further through the “Ship Arrestor” project (ref 222575).

Title: Structure, conductivity and redox reversibility of Ca-doped cerium metavanadate
AdditionalInformation:
The phase and volume change on anode for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) may cause delamination of the anode/electrolyte interface. In this paper, Tao reports the first redox reversible anode for SOFCs and, for the first time, the terminology ‘redox reversible anode’ is used for SOFCs. This provides a new option to develop efficient anode for SOFCs. This opens a new research area and the method reported and the terminology is now widely used in research papers (e.g., doi: 10.1002/adma.201104852; doi: 10.1039/C3TA10404D).  
This work was supported by EPSRC SuperGen Fuel Cells project (EP/G030995/1).

Title: A fuel cell operating between room temperature and 250 °C based on a new phosphoric acid based composite electrolyte
AdditionalInformation: Currently the maximum operating temperature of conventional phosphoric acid fuel cells is 200°C. We developed a new core-shell composite electrolyte which extends the operating temperature of phosphoric acid based fuel cells to 250°C. This makes the cells more tolerant to impurities in the fuel, such as carbon monoxide. One of the referees of this paper commented ‘(this paper) is interesting in development of a new electrolyte for the PAFC’ (email:power@elsevier.com, manuscript No. POWER-D-09-02692).  This work was supported by EPSRC SuperGen 'Fuel Cells – Powering Greener Future’ project (EP/G030995/1).

Title: A direct urea fuel cell - power from fertiliser and waste
AdditionalInformation: This is the world's first report on direct urea/urine fuel cell. Urea is a safe and low-cost chemical which is an ideal energy vector. This work could solve on-board hydrogen storage problem for electric vehicles and have substantial impact on energy, environment and climate change. It has been highlighted by BBC News (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-11023725), New Scientist (http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20727741.400-pee-is-for-power-your-electrifying-excretions.html) and EPSRC News (http://www.epsrc.ac.uk/newsevents/news/2010/Pages/power.aspx). An EPSRC follow-on project (£130k) was funded based on this work (EP/H029400/1). S Tao was invited to give an oral presentation in the 218th Electrochemical Society Meeting, USA (email: schmidt_tj@email.de).  This research was supported by EPSRC project EP/F028083/1.

Title: On the experimental testing of fine Nitinol wires for medical devices
VolumeTitle: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
AdditionalInformation: The paper identifies test methodologies and compression stress-strain characteristics for small diameter Nitinol wire. This is a requirement for the development of material constitutive models imbedded in FE techniques and supports the analysis and product development of the Terumo Vascutek anaconda device, used to prevent abdominal aneurysm rupture. This work has been integrated into Vascutek via a KTP project (KTP 8620) and EPSRC  EP/H50009X/1. The work undrerpins Vascutek product development and has contributed to their success in Scottish Business Innovation of the year awards in 2013, (www.scottishbusinessawrds.co.uk, contact Tim Ashton VP Innovation, t.ashton@vascutek.com).

Title: Improved prediction of shell side heat transfer in horizontal evaporative shell and tube heat exchangers
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated experimentally and theoretically that existing methods for modelling evaporation in horizontal shell and tube exchangers over predict the heat transfer due to phase stratification at low heat fluxes.  An improved predictive model was proposed. Findings have directly influenced development of heat exchanger design within the market leading aspenONE heat exchanger software design suite [contact Jim NcNaught, jmcnaught@tuvnel.com]. The paper formed the basis of work by international groups researching improvements in heat exchanger design methods to further extend the pressure drop models (see Polly et. al, Applied Thermal Engineering V 50, Issue 1, 2013, Pages 1274-1279).

Title: Fault diagnosis of a diesel engine by using the analysis of instantaneous angular speed with a flexible model
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Vehicle Noise and Vibration
AdditionalInformation: The paper claims it is the first in using engine shaft instantaneous angular speed (IAS) to diagnose combustion related faults and other faults affecting the output of engines. The fundamentals developed in the research present a novel method in engine working condition monitoring and diagnosis. Since instantaneous angular speed is used, both theoretical and experimental results have shown an improvement on accuracy compared with traditional methods. The method has been implemented on-board ship of “Hainan Railway Ferry 3” [jgyang@whut.edu.cn] for engine working condition monitoring, contributing to preventative maintenance policy.

Title: An investigation into machine pattern recognition based on time-frequency image feature extraction using a support vector machine
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science
AdditionalInformation: The study focuses on methodology developed for processing and analysing signals with non-stationary and non-linear features which is very cutting edge R&D in pattern recognition for engine working conditions monitoring. The method is based on time-frequency image (TFI) feature extraction and support vector machines (SVMs). The new developed method is more accurate and convenient engine working conditions monitoring. The research has resulted in industrial application in Shenyang Blower Works Group Corporation, China [Qiang Yan: spm006@126.com]..

Title: An investigation into catalysts to improve low temperature performance in the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
VolumeTitle: Proceedings- Institute of Marine Engineering Science and Technology Part a Journal of Marine Engineering and Technology
AdditionalInformation: Improving low temperature performance of SCRs by using a cost-effective catalyst has been a challenge for both the academic and industry. The paper presents using Fe-based catalyst. With use of Fe-based catalysts, the reaction temperature of SCR has been reduced from 350°C to 150°C which is a significant advancement in SRC development, particularly when applying slow steaming for low carbon shipping where engine exhaust temperature is low. The researcher who undertook the work has continued the study and won a large multi-million CNY national project based the results from the project after he returned to China, xiaoyouhong@hrbeu.edu.cn

Title: Prediction of two-phase flow through a safety relief valve
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering
AdditionalInformation: Paper shows the rarely presented ability of CFD based two phase modelling approaches to predict critical flows in small refrigeration based safety valves and quantifies the accuracy against experimental data for non flashing flows. This and previous work underpins the development of analysis methods used in safety valves designed and manufactured by Henry Technologies Ltd, Glasgow, [contact CEO Sandy MacDonald, SMacDonald@henrytech.co.uk] and exploited via a KTP project on valve design (KTP 6318). The success of this work led to further studies in Henry product modelling on droplet separation modellingb (EPSRC Industrial Case Award EP/G501769/01) .

Title: Calculation of a lower bound ratchet limit part 1 – Theory, numerical implementation and verification
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a new capability in a state-of-the art direct method for ratchet analysis, with an accompanying paper demonstrating practical application. The method is referenced and adopted in the internationally recognised R5 structural integrity assessment procedure (and announced in the R5/R6 Newsletter). The associated software and users guide have been implemented by key industries, including EDF Energy (david.tipping@edf-energy.com) and Rolls-Royce (Michael.Martin@Rolls-Royce.com). Outputs from this research work led to a new EngD project (NE102, http://www.dalton.manchester.ac.uk) starting from 1st Oct 2013 and funded by the EPSRC nuclear EngD centre and EDF Energy.

Title: Large amplitude vibrations and damage detection of rectangular plates
AdditionalInformation: The paper proposes a novel approach for dynamic analysis and damage assessment that was further developed in two invited chapters in books (Robotic and Industrial Systems, Ed. G.Rigatos, and Advanced Materials and Processes. Eds. Oechsner A., et al Springer Verl.2010,ger9711@ath.forthnet.gr).
