The methodology has subsequently been extended by research groups in Poland (see e.g Warminski et al. MSSP, vol26 , 2012, j.warminski@lpu.lu.pl), Politecnico di Torino (e.g. Garibladi L. et al, JSV, vol331,issue 6, March 2012, Garibaldi Luigi [d001606@polito.it]) and University of Bologna(A.Marzani@unibo.it ) who acknowledge that the method has “considerable impact on the development of data-based modelling techniques”.

Title: Shakedown and limit analysis of 90° pipe bends under internal pressure, cyclic in-plane bending and cyclic thermal loading
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents an investigation of the static and cyclic ductile response of high integrity power piping subject to complex thermo-mechanical loading, with industry partner EDF Energy (david.tipping@edf-energy.com). Limit and shakedown load interaction diagrams obtained using the  Linear Matching Method (LMM) procedure and computer code developed are presented. These results extend the shakedown and  limit load design information currently available in national and international design Codes and Standards. The validity of the LMM as an effective and computationally efficient design by analysis tool is validated through comparison with incremental Finite Element Analysis.

Title: Blade loads on tidal turbines in planar oscillatory flow
AdditionalInformation: This is one of the very first journal articles addressing physical measurement of unsteady loading of horizontal axis tidal turbines. Unsteady loading is a key issue determining both ultimate loads and fatigue life of these devices and consequently is also potentially of great significance for floating offshore wind turbines. The study, carried out in collaboration with researchers from the University of Auckland, New Zealand, built on a novel test methodology developed in an EPSRC-funded project (EP/F006284/1), and a study presented by the same authors in a prize-winning paper at the European Wave and Tidal Energy conference (EWTEC 2011, http://www.ewtec.org/ewtec2011).

Title: Flow control for VATT by fixed and oscillating flap
AdditionalInformation: Inspired by our relevant biomimetic studies, this paper explores the potential to improve Vertical Axis Tidal Turbine (VATT) energy harnessing efficiency by using modified blades with fixed and oscillating flap. For the first time, this study applies this new concept to VATT performance optimization. The outcome of this research has led to a successful funding application for an International Exchange Scheme (supported by Scottish Funding Council) with Japan (hliu@faculty.chiba-u.jp), French institutions (Frederic.Boyer@mines-nantes.fr) and industry companies (Teral Ltd in Japan & ResHydro LLT in USA) on a project, aiming for improving device efficiency using some bio-inspired concepts.

Title: Drag amplification of long flexible riser models undergoing multi-mode VIV in uniform currents
AdditionalInformation: SHEAR7 is widely used by the industry for analysing vortex induced vibration (VIV) and has significant impact on marine riser design. For about 15 years, SHEAR7 utilised a drag amplification formula which had never been properly examined. The paper utilises test data to investigate this issue. It also considers the spatial variation of VIV. The work was part of the industrial efforts to improve design rules and was supported by several companies (i.e. Norwegian Deepwater programme) including Statoil (Kjell Herfjord, kjher@statoil.com) and BP (andy.sworn@uk.bp.com)

Title: VIV suppression of a two-degree-of-freedom circular cylinder and drag reduction of a fixed circular cylinder by the use of helical grooves
AdditionalInformation: The paper, for the first time, presents a new mechanism of suppressing vortex induced vibration through helical grooves around cylindrical slender body. There are no similar works anywhere else on VIV reduction by the use of groove. It also discovers, for the first time, the drag reduction effects of helical grooves. The research work opens up a new frontier on the effects of grooves on the wake, drag and vortex shedding. The work was supported by EU (EU HydroLab III programme; Alexandra Neyts, alexandra.neyts@ntnu.no) and BP (Andy Sworn, andy.sworn@uk.bp.com).

Title: Instability of a vertical riser in the wake of an upstream vertical riser
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a novel and original work on a topic where very few research papers are available. The author started the work in 1998, and after a number of years research, an innovative approach was discovered. The paper developed an entirely new approach, first of its kind, in dealing with the nonlinear wake effects by introducing techniques of non-linear system analysis. Much of the work, along with the earlier results, has formed the basis for DNV Recommended Practice on Riser Interference (DNV-RP-F203). The early stage of the work was also supported by EPSRC (EPSRC: GR/R35803/01)

Title: Hydrodynamic coefficients of two fixed circular cylinders fitted with helical strakes at various staggered and tandem arrangements
AdditionalInformation: The paper, by measuring the force on the downstream straked cylinder, shows for the first time among the research community that the force spectrum has a distinct peak, suggesting regular vortex shedding on the cylinder. The effect of  Strakes on hydrodynamic loading has not been investigated and In particularly, the interaction between straked cylinders is poorly understood. The paper provides very good  theoretical explanation why strakes are less effective in the wake flow and design strategy for more efficient design of straked cylinders.

Title: Development of a novel forward dynamic programming method for weather routing
VolumeTitle: Journal of Marine Science and Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper presents the first in the world using a novel forward algorithm method in 3 dimensional dynamic programming (3DDP) in weather routing optimisation, where all other available weather routing programmes use the backward algorithm method and 2DDP. The work was sponsored by APL, one of the largest containership operators in the world. Results published have been adopted by APL on weather routing optimisation software installed on their new buildings from 2012, [Sew_Kait_Thong@APL.COM]. The results presented by the same authors on 9th international symposium on marine navigation and safety of sea transportation won the best paper of the conference [http://transnav.am.gdynia]

Title: Synthesis of ammonia directly from air and water at ambient temperature and pressure
AdditionalInformation:
This is the world's first report on ammonia synthesis directly from air and water at ambient conditions. The impact on the ammonia industry will be revolutionary as it by-passes the hydrogen production and nitrogen separation stages and uses mild operating conditions. This paper was selected by The Latest Science (selected from all journals in the world) as paper of the month (February, 2013, http://www.thelatestscience.com/paperoftheyear.php). 
We were emailed by Toyota Motor via NineSigma (email:nakai@ninesigma.com), WindtoGreen LLC (USA, email:jack@windtogreen.com), Nagarjuna Group (India, pandey@nagarjunagroup.com), showing their interests in collaborative research or investment. The work was funded by EPSRC SuperGen XIV project (EP/G01244X/1).

Title: A comparison of plastic collapse and limit loads for single mitred pipe bends under in-plane bending
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a rigorous experimental and FEA investigation of plastic and limit loads of 90 degree mitred pipe bends under in-plane closing moments. It is shown that the failure mechanism and post-buckling behaviour are only identified by testing or by large deformation elastic-plastic FEA. This identifies a clear need to include non-linear geometry effects in inelastic design by analysis procedures.  The excellent agreement between the detailed tests and FEA  provide the basis for a design by analysis benchmark problem and has informed subsequent work by researchers in Korea Univeristy, Seoul (Int J Pres Ves & Piping, 87,10,pp550-558).

Title: A techno-economic analysis of tidal energy technology
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper was the first reporting of the technical and economic development of tidal energy technologies from empirical data (a.s.bahaj@soton.ac.uk). The economic limitations of tidal energy technologies deployed to date are identified together with the identification of engineering challenges needed to be addressed to deliver substantive reductions in capital and operational. As a result, the author was invited to deliver a plenary presentation at SEACORE, Singapore, Feb’13 (Michael.abundo@ntu.edu.sg). The work reported has developed new research collaborations with Southampton and Newcastle Universities resulting in a new collaborative £1.4 million research project being funding by EPSRC, Award No. EP/K013319/1.

Title: Two phase discharge flow prediction in safety valves
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
AdditionalInformation: The work extends the limited expermental database of two phase critical flows in safety valves and defines the accuracy of CFD based prediction models.  The work was part of a research collaboration with safety valve manufacturer Henry Technologies to develop better design tools for off-design performance.  This allowed Henry technologies to create a new range of CFD designed safety valves and develop a new high pressure testing facility. Further, the design methodology led to new research with Henry Technologies in the field of two phase frow oil separation with an EPSRC Case award (EP/G501769/01, 2008-13), contact CEO Sandy MacDonald, smacdonald@henrytech.co.uk.

Title: A virtual inspection framework for precision manufacturing of aerofoil components
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development and industrial validation of a virtual inspection system, based on the finite element method, which evaluates the dimensional tolerance of forged aerofoil blades. A particular strength is that a strong correlation was obtained with real inspection data from corresponding aerofoil components. The work was conducted as part of a series of EPSRC-funded projects in collaboration with Rolls-Royce. The techniques presented create a novel opportunity to evaluate the performance of components from as-manufactured geometry and properties.

Title: Kinetic and thermodynamic investigations on arsenic adsorption onto dolomitic sorbents
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript led to Professor Allen being invited as a plenary speaker at an International Environment conference ICEnv 2011 in Penang, Malaysia. The work secured PoC funding from Invest NI on granular adsorption processes, which has led to patented technology and a University spin-out company

Title: Evaluation of a new peat-based sorbent for metals capture
AdditionalInformation: This international collaborative manuscript was instrumental in the appointment of  Professor Allen as editor of Chemical Engineering Journal with particular emphasis on adsorption. Peat based sorbent systems are now finding application in metal recovery processes.  This research provided data which contributed to securing  the €3.0M EU Marie Curie ITN project 238273 ATWARM.

Title: Separation of acid-dyes mixture by bamboo derived active carbon
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript was awarded the prestigious Hong Kong Institution of Engineers Environment medal. Based on this work Professor Allen was invited to chair a special session at the ASCE conference in Hong Kong 2012.

Title: Adsorption of sulfur dioxide on chemically modified natural clinoptilolite. Acid modification
AdditionalInformation: Professor Allen was awarded an Honorary Doctorate Degree from UCTM in Sofia for this ongoing collaboration.  Prof Allen’s work on adsorption processes directly led to QUB participation in a ME3 Erasmus Mundus Programme- European joint Masters of Science in Management and Engineering of Environment and Energy, which has secured 10 years funding from the European Commission.

Title: Difference equation sensor characterization algorithms for two-thermocouple probes
VolumeTitle: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control
AdditionalInformation:
The significance of the work is that it proposes a novel class of difference equation (DE) algorithms for in-situ blind characterisation of thermocouples used for measuring rapid fluctuations. Unlike existing algorithms, the DE method gives a rigorous system identification framework that addresses biased estimation and provides substantial performance gains which have been shown in a comprehensive series of publications. Successful application in an internal combustion engine was described in SAE 2006-01-1319. The techniques developed at QUB were adopted by researchers at Oxford University, and research into their application continues at Universität Darmstadt - http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conengprac.2009.11.008
Contact: Professor Moriyoshi, Chiba University, Japan

Title: Project Omnivore: A Variable Compression Ratio ATAC 2-Stroke Engine for Ultra-Wide-Range HCCI Operation on a Variety of Fuels
AdditionalInformation:
Research relating to an innovative engine which was developed in collaboration with Lotus, Jaguar and Orbital (Australia) is described. The engine incorporated novel features which promoted highly efficient clean operation in an autoignition mode over a previously unattainable range of conditions, including idle. The potential of the engine to operate efficiently on a wide range of renewable fuels was recognised with the 2010 Automotive, Rail & Marine Technology and Innovation Award – http://www.theengineer.co.uk/awards/technology-and-innovation-award-winners-revealed/1006316.article. The level of innovation and originality can be confirmed by:

Jaal Ghandi, Professor of Sustainable Energy, Univ. Wisconsin-Madison

Title: A Theoretical and Experimental Study of Resonance in a High Performance Engine Intake System: Part 2
AdditionalInformation:
This paper is the final in a series of 3 which describe research, conducted from 2002–2008, on coupled 1D and 3D simulations of an engine and intake system. The simulations and experimental validation elucidated previously unexplained phenomena. The simulation approach was ground-breaking, and includes the first consideration of the influence of intake pipe separation on low frequency pressure fluctuations in the intake system.
This work has significantly added to the understanding of high performance intake systems, and has influenced the design of Formula 1 engines. 
Industrial contact: Dr N McKinley, Head of Simulation at Mercedes High Performance Engines

Title: The Potential of a New Type of Carburettor to Assist SORE in Meeting EPA / CARB Phase 3 Legislation
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a completely new carburettor concept to replace more complex fuel systems for small engine application.  It was developed in collaboration with Fjolblendir, an Icelandic Company, who now market this worldwide.   The technology gives tighter AFR control and better mixture preparation for improved combustion with reduced number of parts and lower cost of production.  The improved design gives 30 to 40% lower engine-out emissions.  It offers, for the first time, a new standard in small engine emissions by enabling operation of a 3-way catalyst with a mechanical fuel system to meet the strictest worldwide emissions regulations.

Title: Method and Apparatus for Testing a Catalyst Material
AdditionalInformation: This patent was granted by European Patent Office in August 2012 and is under examination in 4 jurisdictions: USA, China, India & Brazil.  It is the basis of the technology used in a spin-out company, Catagen.  This technology replaces the current approach of using engines to age auto-catalysts with a more repeatable and versatile technique.  This approach gives 50% lower capital cost and 80% lower running cost than the current industry solution, with 98% less CO2 emissions.  The company is marketing worldwide with a turnover of £200k in 2012, its first year trading, and projections of over £500k in 2013.

Title: Apparatus and method for adjusting filter frequency in relation to sampling frequency
AdditionalInformation: This patent was fully granted by US Patent office in July 2010.  It was developed in collaboration with Optimum Power Technology, a US company, who now market worldwide a product containing this concept.  They are working with larger companies to licence the technology.  This idea is a first in low-pass filtering for electronic signals that tracks the sampling rate.  The filter frequency is automatically set to the optimum value for noise reduction and tracks sampling frequency even at variable sampling rate.  This give best results without manual setting and allows the filter to follow the sampling under dynamic logging conditions.

Title: The Role of Process Parameters in Determining Wall Thickness Distribution in Plug-Assisted Thermoforming
AdditionalInformation: This work has significantly added to the fundamental understanding of the thermoforming process and the paper was the first published work to scientifically quantify the effects of the variables that control the process. The results have directly assisted industrial collaborators to improve the quality of the output from their production processes (Industrial contact: Mr F McNamee, Holfeld Plastics).

Title: Measurement of Polymer-to-Polymer Contact Friction in Thermoforming
AdditionalInformation: This work was the result of an international collaborative effort with the University of Stuttgart and the paper is the first in literature to publish validated comparative friction results relevant to thermoforming and to establish viable methods for the measurement of polymer contact friction at elevated temperatures. The results are currently being commercially exploited by the world’s leading manufacturer of plug materials (Industrial contact: Mr N Tessier, CMT Materials Inc.). It has also led to a recently successful application for commercialisation funding (£110k, InvestNI POC427) that aims to convert part of the measurement technology into a spin-out business.

Title: Simulation of the Plug-assisted Thermoforming of Polypropylene Using a Large Strain Thermally Coupled Constitutive Model
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first in the scientific literature to systematically describe in detail the development of a plug-assisted thermoforming process simulation. The work has resulted in a prototype software tool that is currently being used to find commercial solutions for industrial partners (Industrial contact Mr W Colquhoun, Kobusch UK). It was also successful in attracting commercialisation funding  (£100k, InvestNI POC36A) and as a result negotiations are currently at an advanced stage for this business to become a university spin-out company.

Title: A new model based approach for the prediction and optimisation of thermal homogeneity in single screw extrusion
AdditionalInformation: A novel non-linear model is described that for the first time provides control of the melt thermal profile in the commercially important polymer extrusion process. The work was awarded the Young Author Best Paper Award at the ICMIC conference in Shanghai, China in 2011.

Title: Alternative method to evaluate discharge coefficients. Part 2: case study
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART C-JOURNAL OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERING SCIENCE
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes a new experimental method for determining discharge coefficients extremely rapidly over a range of pressure ratios.  The method is particularly relevant for the rapid experimental optimisation of the ports on a four-stroke cycle engine cylinder head.  CFD was used to develop a simple method of analysis and identify areas for future enhancement for the experimental apparatus. The existing apparatus and method was validated against traditional steady flow experimental methods and shown to be accurate within 4%. Optimum Power Technology funded this research for commercial exploitation: Glen Chatfield, Optimum Power.

Title: Determination of the heat transfer coefficient at the metal–die interface for high pressure die cast AlSi9Cu3Fe
AdditionalInformation: The work described demonstrated that the previously assumed heat transfer between molten metal and a die casting die was much higher than previously supposed in the first few seconds of metal injection.   This was validated in a production environment through collaboration with Ryobi Aluminium Castings (UK).  Correcting this allowed more accurate simulation of the casting process resulting in a modified casting start up cycle which reduced scrap and increased casting yield by 4.5% leading to typical savings of £80000/yr/casting machine.  This was implemented across 11 casting machines by works manager David Watson saving the company close to £1M/year.

Title: Comparison of Experimental PIV Data and CFD Simulations for Flow in a Diesel Particulate Filter Inlet Diffuser
AdditionalInformation: Previous studies of flow distribution through automotive DPFs have used CFD.  PIV has been used to study automotive catalysts, but only rarely.  This paper is believed to be the first to describe the flow distribution into a DPF determined by direct experimental measurement using PIV.   The uniqueness of the experimental data prompted Ansys to offer use of their CFD DPF model in exchange for PIV experimental results for validation and development of the model:  Samir Patel, Ansys.

Title: Biaxial deformation behavior and mechanical properties of a polypropylene/clay nanocomposite
AdditionalInformation: A paper based on work conducted on £903,320 EPSRC EP/C006992/1 collaborative grant with Oxford University and Bradford University, led by Harkin-Jones. First paper reporting increase in ultimate tensile properties of melt processed polypropylene/clay nanocomposites and to demonstrate effect of nanoclay on material processability at high strain rates typical of industrial forming. Provided basis for subsequent successful EPSRC application (EP/E040446/1, £1.2 million) led by Harkin-Jones and for collaboration with Beckham at Georgia Tech. which led to paper in Macromolecules.

Title: Evolution of Clay Morphology in Polypropylene/Montmorillonite Nanocomposites upon Equi-biaxial Stretching: A Solid-State NMR and TEM Approach
AdditionalInformation: In this paper the results of a joint project with Georgia Tech University (funded by EPSRC and NSF) are presented. The significance of the work lies in the fact that numerous, labour intensive TEM tests to measure nanoparticle exfoliation may be replaced by a single NMR test and a TEM reference test. The results presented here provide the foundations for the use of NMR for on-line process control in the manufacture of polymer nanocomposites to detect exfoliation levels.

Title: The effect of temperature and strain rate on the deformation behaviour, structure development and properties of biaxially stretched PET-clay nanocomposites.
AdditionalInformation: An output from a £1.2 million EPSRC Grant EP/E040446/1 with Bradford University led by Harkin-Jones. This paper provides important guidelines to processors not to increase processing temperature to reduce forming forces (usual practice in industry) in PET-clay composites as this reduces exfoliation and final properties. This paper was instrumental in supporting a successful joint application with Qatar University to the Qatar National Research Fund for work on processing of polymer-graphene nanocomposites (NPRP 5 - 039 - 2 – 014,  £560,000 )

Title: Morphology, barrier, and mechanical properties of biaxially deformed poly(ethylene terephthalate)-mica nanocomposites
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to relate detailed material morphology to properties for melt processed, biaxially stretched PET-clay nanocomposites. Biaxial stretching is the deformation method involved in stretch blow moulding and thermoforming, processes responsible for forming the majority of PET. Results are directly applicable to industrial forming. Significant results include the large enhancement in modulus for PET/clay nanocomposites at temperatures greater than Tg indicating great potential for applications in ‘hot fill’ containers. A 49% increase in room temperature modulus was achieved which was the best modulus enhancement reported for melt processed PET/clay nanocomposites at the time of publication

Title: Investigation on drop penetration and wetting characteristics of powder-liquid systems in relation to the mixing of acrylic bone cement
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Nano and Biomaterials
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes physical characteristics of liquid-particle interactions of the constituents of orthopaedic bone cements. The interdisciplinary study is novel and of direct application to the two phase mixing of cements.  Knowledge of fundamental scientific principles are essential to optimize design of mixing systems and control the quality of the cement product. The authors have gained an international reputation of expertise in automated cement mixing that has attracted industrial interest from Summit Medical Ltd (UK), Stryker Corporation (USA) and recent Proof of Concept funding from Invest Northern Ireland.

Title: The modification of PLA and PLGA using electron-beam radiation
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research Part A
AdditionalInformation: Electron-beam treatment of bioabsorbable polymers is novel and has gained ongoing industrial collaboration from  Smith & Nephew (David Farrar, Biomaterials Manager, York, UK) with whom a Department of Health HTD project was funded.  An associated patent is now granted in the USA and Europe (US8025676B2, 2011). This paper reports the process characterisation, including computer modelling, essential to achieve predictable responses from implantable medical devices. The paper reports the potential for the design of orthopaedic implants that change in structural properties to stimulate fracture healing and accommodate transfer of functional loads as bone healing progresses.

Title: Wear paths produced by individual hip-replacement patients— A large-scale, long-term follow-up study
AdditionalInformation: Research collaboration with Musgrave Park Hospital Belfast brings the unique resource of routine outcomes data for hip replacement patients further than 10 years post-operation. The results characterise the spherical bearing articulations of 164 hip replacements in respect of parameters that are highly significant for wear of polyethylene sockets and hence, implant materials, design and operative placement and orientation.  This human derived data has not been recorded previously and can be exploited as independent inputs to ‘in vitro’ simulator studies. This research has contributed to the formation of research collaboration with the University of Leeds (UK).

Title: The potential of electron beam radiation for simultaneous surface modification and bioresorption control of PLLA
VolumeTitle: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research Part A
AdditionalInformation: This work, funded by UK Dept. of Health, represents continuing collaboration with Smith & Nephew (UK) through David Farrar, Biomaterials Manager, who maintains his company's interests from previous projects. The present study investigates surface changes that offer advantages for surface characteristics likely to provoke active healing responses by contacting tissues. This work will provide the main content of an invited technical presentation at IMRP2013, Shanghai.

Title: Influence of multiwall carbon nanotube functionality and loading on mechanical properties of PMMA/MWCNT bone cements
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine.
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated the application of nanotechnology using functionalised multiwalled carbon nanotubes to increase the mechanical properties of PMMA bone cement. The work resulted in a grant (AUS$1.8m) from the National Health and Medical Research Council (Australia) in collaboration with Peter Halley and Suzanne Smith. In addition it created academic and post-graduate secondments to Australia and helped create the now established collaboration between Queens’ University Belfast and University of Queensland.

Title: Real time monitoring of the polymerisation of PMMA bone cement using Raman spectroscopy
VolumeTitle: Journal Of Materials Science : Materials In Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This research, funded by a CAST award with Summit Medical, showed for the first time the utility and validity of Raman Spectroscopy for clinical monitoring of the progress of polymethylmethacrylate orthopaedic bone cement polymerisation.  This output resulted in Invest NI POC money (POC335) ‘Development of a fully integrated, intelligent bone cement mixing and delivery system’ (£106K). The technological advance and expertise was then translated to industry, Summit Medical Ltd, UK (David Foster).

Title: Quantification of all-ceramic crown margin surface profile from try-in to 1-week post-cementation
AdditionalInformation: This output was an international collaboration with the University of Minnesota, recognised pioneers in use of profilometry of biomaterials, where Mitchell is an Adjunct Professor.  It established the use of profilometry to quantify early dimensional stability of dental resin-modified glass ionomer luting cements.  The work was supported by NIH/NIDR grant DE09737 and industrial funding (3M ESPE, Rosalind Randall) providing a post-graduate secondment to Minnesota.

Title: Liquid marble formation using hydrophobic powders
AdditionalInformation: Prof Walker is associate editor of CEJ. The paper was an international first in demonstrating that liquid marbles can be formed with high density materials and led to the funding of the prestigious Royal Academy of Engineering Leverhulme Trust Senior Research Fellowship for Prof Walker for his work on powder processing. The work helped to secure on two PoC funding (Invest NI) on engineering application of SH materials, the patented technology with an expected launch in 2013. The work has initiated research collaboration with world leading group KTH, Sweden on another patent on membrane distillation.

Title: Validating Injection Stretch-Blow Molding Simulation Through Free Blow Trials
AdditionalInformation: The work has attracted subsequent industrial funding (~£500,000) which has been obtained from three multinational companies - Procter & Gamble, Danone and Sidel (part of the Tetra Pak group). The technique applied here has been the platform for developing a fully validated simulation for Procter & Gamble who are now using it to achieve savings of $3m/year on their products. It was a collaboration with Ecole Des Mines de Paris. Verifiable Contacts (Jim Shepherd (P&G), Serge Batkam (Danone) and Bernard Plantamura (Sidel)

Title: Biaxial Deformation and Experimental Study of PET at Conditions Applicable to Stretch Blow Molding
AdditionalInformation: It is the first paper to present experimental material characterisation data at industrially relevant conditions (i.e. appropriate strain rate). The work has resulted in collaboration with Université Paris-Est where the data has been the foundation for the development of a new mathematical model for PET (Verifiable contact: Prof. Luc Chevalier, University of Paris Est). The work has also attracted interest from Nestle and P&G who have funded research and short term studies to replicated and develop the tests performed in this paper.(verifiable contacts: Jim Shepherd (P&G), Guillaume Chauvin(Nestle)

Title: Experimental Investigation of Stretch Blow Molding, Part 2: Analysis of Process Variables, Blowing Kinematics, and Bottle Properties
AdditionalInformation: A spin out company (Blow Moulding Technologies) was setup in September 2012 based on the instrumentation developed in this paper.  The company has turned over in excess of £150,000 in the past 2 years and sold products in Europe and the USA.  The 2 lead authors are directors of the company.  Verifiable; contact: Yannis Salomeia, Blow Moulding Technologies).

Title: Nonlinear PCA with Local Approach for Diesel Engine Fault Detection and Diagnosis
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
AdditionalInformation: New theoretical ideas are presented to enhance the capabilities of nonlinear Principal Component Analysis (PCA), introducing Basseville's statistical local approach to produce normally distributed scores, thereby easing fault detection. Our laboratory is the first to apply statistical fault diagnosis to internal combustion engines. This paper includes unique experimental data for a 1.9 litre turbo-charged diesel engine. The programme was supported by a joint EPSRC grant (EP/C005457/1) with Electrical Engineering and £1m of engine test equipment from the Virtual Engineering Centre.

Title: Fault Diagnostics for Internal Combustion Engines – Current and Future Techniques
VolumeTitle: SAE Transactions Journal of Passenger Cars: Electronic and Electrical Systems
AdditionalInformation: This paper summarises the current techniques used to detect faults in internal combustion engines and presents a new statistical-based fault detection method based on non-linear principal component analysis (NLPCA). This method is more computationally efficient than traditional fault detection methods. The research was supported by a joint EPSRC grant (EP/C005457/1) with Electrical Engineering and £1m of engine test equipment from the Virtual Engineering Centre.

Title: Improved Process Monitoring Using Nonlinear Principal Component Models
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents two new approaches for use in process monitoring. The first is a combined principal component analysis and neural network technique that is more computationally efficient than traditional techniques. The second is a data reconstruction technique that can identify erroneous data from a faulty sensor and replace it with new data from remaining sensors. The research was supported by an EPSRC grant (EP/C005457/1) in conjunction with Electrical Engineering. The techniques presented in this paper facilitated a new research area for the School in area of fault identification within internal combustion engines.

Title: Aerodynamic performance of a bypass engine with fan nozzle exit area change by warped chevrons
VolumeTitle: PROCEEDINGS OF THE INSTITUTION OF MECHANICAL ENGINEERS PART G-JOURNAL OF AEROSPACE ENGINEERING
AdditionalInformation: This paper was awarded two distinct prizes by the Institution of Mechanical Engineers in recognition of its originality and significance; the Kenneth Harris James prize for the best paper on an aerospace subject published by the Institution in the previous year, and also the Institute’s George Stephenson Medal. The work is of direct relevance to aerospace companies developing more efficient air frame and propulsion solutions and was directly supported by Bombardier Aerospace (David Riordan at Bombardier Aerospace).

Title: A Comparison of the Flow Structures and Losses Within Vaned and Vaneless Stators for Radial Turbines
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery -Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: Turbocharging is a key technology for engine downsizing and CO2 reduction. Modern turbochargers utilize either vaned or vaneless turbines; this paper was the first direct performance comparison of the two different design approaches supported by detailed experimental measurements. This work is highly relevant to the turbocharger industry, which produces around 20 million units/year. The project was funded by EPSRC and a leading turbocharger company (Cummins Turbo Technologies, Nick.K.Sharp). All knowledge arising from the project was transferred to the company. Other international companies have also sought information and design input following the publication of this paper (Brayton Energy, Mr Tom Wolf)

Title: An Investigation of Compressor Map Width Enhancement and a Detailed Analysis of Inducer Flow Field
AdditionalInformation: This paper reported a study of compressor bleed slots for improving turbocharger flow range. Although bleed slots have been used for some time, the complex flow physics were not understood and the system had not been optimised. Flow range is of utmost importance to achieve drivability from aggressively down-sized, highly boosted engines. The work reported in this paper resulted in Cummins Turbo Technologies (Nick.K.Sharp) directly funding further work at the university in this area. This paper received the 2010 Outstanding Paper Award from the Hong Kong Institution of Engineers, and was presented by invitation at the HKIE Presidential Dinner.

Title: Through-thickness control of polymer bioresorption via electron beam irradiation
AdditionalInformation:
This work has been the subject of an invited presentation at European Society of Biomaterials (Purac Special Symposium, Dublin 2011) and an Invited Plenary at IMRP2013, Shanghai (more than 500 industry leaders and scientific experts). An associated patent is now granted in the USA and Europe (US8025676B2, 2011). 
New commercialisation funding from Invest Northern Ireland has been secured (£106k, 2013) involving Bioretec, Finland (Minna Veiranto, R&D Manager).  It is the first ever University-based research to attract funding from the UK Panel for Gamma and Electron Irradiation (£10k, 2012).

Title: Surface modification of poly(ε-caprolactone) using a dielectric barrier discharge in atmospheric pressure glow discharge mode
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, the relative contributions of physical roughening and functionalisation to surface wettability are reported and quantified. This work has catalysed new research into the field of surface functionalisation of polymers via atmospheric electron beam processes in collaboration with Comet AG, Flamatt, Switzerland (Willi Wandfluh) and Prof Arne Miller (Risø High Dose Reference Laboratory, Denmark).

Title: Accelerated degradation behaviour of poly(epsilon-caprolactone) via melt blending with poly(aspartic acid-co-lactide) (PAL)
AdditionalInformation: This paper contains the first published results demonstrating the potential for controlling  the bioresorption rate of this polymer. During the work an industrial collaboration was developed with Smith & Nephew (Prof David Farrar, Biomaterials Manager, York). Melt-processing issues identified during this work have led to the award of a major new FP7 Research for SMEs grant, €1m, 2013 (Bio-PolyTec, proposal no. 605086)

Title: A generic tool for cost estimating in aircraft design
AdditionalInformation: This work was part of a major £5M project on integrated approaches to design and manufacturing supported by industrial partners Bombardier, Thales and Caterpiller. The capability led to follow on projects applied to composite structures with Bombardier procurement (Stephen Cowan: General Manager Supply Chain) and invited conference papers (e.g. ICMR 2013).

Title: Uncertainty and Sensitivity Analysis in Aircraft Operating Costs in Structural Design Optimization
AdditionalInformation: This is the first paper to exploit uncertainty in an industrial design process that integrates manufacturing and operational costs.  The resulting capability formed a major part of the foundation for the costing work in the RECREATE FP7 project and is one of the core work projects that led to the early formulation of the Value Driven Design initiative.  This led to an invited presentation of the work at the 1st UK workshop on Value Driven Design and attendance at the NSF workshop on Complex System Design Washington 2010.

Title: Thermoforming carbon fibre-reinforced thermoplastic composites
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications
AdditionalInformation: This work emerged from a £1.5M multi-institutional project on Thermoplastic Composites, in collaboration with Limerick and Trinity College. The innovative approach developed new knowledge in processing these materials and brought a new partnership with Creative Composites (Jonathan Holmes) who are building on this with new materials and processes. This paper was awarded the SAGE Best Paper Prize in 2012 by the editorial board of Journal of Materials: Design and Applications.

Title: Evaluation of Gas Solubility Prediction in Ionic Liquids using COSMOthermX
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents work initiated on behalf of a multi-national oil and gas company to develop strategies for modelling processes containing ionic liquid. Combined with earlier work on the estimation of physical properties using group contribution methods this work allowed for activity coefficients to be determined for gaseous reagents in ionic liquids and other hydrocarbons. It was extended to allow for prediction of ternary phase diagrams and incorporated into Aspen Plus. The resulting data was able to aid in the preliminary economic evaluation of ionic liquid based processes and was presented at a number of international conferences.

Title: Highly selective and efficient hydrogenation of carboxylic acids to alcohols using titania supported Pt catalysts
AdditionalInformation: Carboxylic acid hydrogenation is a difficult reaction to perform and within industry is often achieved by non-catalytic methods. This paper was the first example of an approach which used computational design strategies to identify catalysts which could perform this reaction at milder conditions. The catalyst developed through this study was utilised by a UK-SME to enhance their inhouse capability and product portfolio. The developed catalyst has further been adopted by other groups around the world for different reactions.

Title: Batch and continuous biogas production from grass silage liquor
AdditionalInformation: This paper resulted from a need to understand and develop continuous biogas production from waste silage liquors. The data generated from the project was used to aid the development of an energy storage system as well as provide data and understanding to a local company in the design of their anaerobic digestion plants. Furthermore data from the work was also used to advise local government on biogas production and utilisation in the Northern Ireland region.

Title: Solvent effects in the hydrogenation of 2-butanone
AdditionalInformation: This paper brings together an international team to investigate solvent effects in liquid phase reaction. This paper represents  the first multi scale example including ab-initio calculations, terahertz spectroscopy and experimental data on kinetics and mass transfer to understand reactions of importance to many chemical and allied industries. The paper was nominated for the 2013 Eni award (an Italian multinational oil and gas company), which highlights the critical importance increasingly given by Eni to scientific research and issues of sustainability.

Title: Stiffened panel stability behaviour and performance gains with plate prismatic sub-stiffening
AdditionalInformation: Reports a highly original structural configuration leading to a significant increase in metallic stiffened panel structural efficiency. Novelty lies in identifying and tailoring panel stability behaviour. Rigorous experimental validation demonstrates potential end-user benefits. Has led to industrially funded collaboration to quantify potential performance gains in wing structures (Ken Poston, Head of Advanced Metallics: Strategic Technologies, Bombardier Aerospace).

Title: A Preliminary Structural Design Procedure for Laser Beam Welded Airframe Stiffened Panels
AdditionalInformation: Removes a long standing industrial restriction on performing preliminary design trade studies to consider laser beam welding. Collaboration with an international material supplier has supported rigorous validation (with novel material and process combinations) enabling the industrial partner to directly consider laser beam welding within their preliminary design processes (Christopher Glazebrook, Constellium).

Title: Buckling/post-buckling strength of friction stir welded aircraft stiffened panels
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
AdditionalInformation: The rigorous computational analysis represents the first publication of the quantified impact of friction stir welding on the static strength of large scale aircraft panel structure. The findings have led to further industrial collaboration, developing friction stir welding for wing panel assembly (Ken Poston, Head of Advanced Metallics: Strategic Technologies, Bombardier Aerospace).

Title: Remarkable stability of ionic gold supported on sulfated lanthanum oxide
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrated, for the first time, that using our acatalyst preparation method, surface gold could be stabilized at a high oxidation state on lanthanum oxide even when submitted to high temperatures. This works was selected for a presentation at the 9th European Conference on Catalysis  (EUROPACAT IX) and contributed to the successful funding of a project on gold catalysis with King Abdulaziz University of Saudi Arabia (contact Dr Muhammad A. Daous) and the CASTech project funded by EPSRC (EP/G012156/1).

Title: TAP studies of CO oxidation over CuMnOX and Au/CuMnOX catalysts
AdditionalInformation: In this work, it was possible to unravel the complexity of the distribution of active sites for CO oxidation of undoped and gold doped CuMnOx catalysts using kinetic characterization with a TAP reactor. This work was selected for a presentation at the American Chemical Society spring meeting in 2011 and contributed to the successful funding of a project on the study of a DeNOX process by Toyota (Contact: Dr Yuki Bisaiji).

Title: Influence of Methyl Halide Treatment on Gold Nanoparticles Supported on Activated Carbon
AdditionalInformation: This paper demonstrates for the first time that large gold particles supported on carbon and oxide supports may be dispersed resulting in up to atomic dispersion by a simple treatment under mild conditions.  This work was selected for a plenary talk lecture at the Brazilian ChemComm conference on sustainability in 2012   as well as for lectures at Europacat X and the ICEC in Lyon. It also contributed to the successful funding of a project on gold catalysis with King Abdulaziz University of Saudi Arabia (contact Dr Muhammad A. Daous) and the CASTech project funded by EPSRC (EP/G012156/1).

Title: Do dynamic work instructions provide an advantage over static instructions in a small scale assembly task?
AdditionalInformation: Completed as part of a novel collaboration with the School of Psychology at Queens, this paper examined digital manufacturing and its benefits in terms of the human aspects of learning.  The research focused on assembly tasks during manufacture and demonstrated the utility of digital media for operator learning in engineering assembly.  Including a rigorous experimental program followed by the statistical analysis of the outcomes, it contributed to the business plan used to justify the use of animated instructional materials within Bombardier Aerospace Belfast (Ref. Robert Burke, Director Manufacturing Engineering & Tooling, Bombardier Aerospace Belfast).

Title: Judging the ‘passability’ of dynamic gaps in a virtual rugby environment
AdditionalInformation: This paper represents an important advance in the use of virtual methods for knowledge acquisition in engineering. Building on a successful collaboration with the School of Psychology at Queen’s, the work resulted in the migration of digital learning research from conventional desktop applications to advanced virtual reality techniques.  It has resulted in the development of advanced VR capability within the school through a DEL funded PhD supplemented by £40k from Bombardier Aerospace (Ref. Robert Burke, Director Manufacturing Engineering & Tooling).  This work has been developed into a successful collaboration with Dr Karen Rafferty in the School of EEECS at Queens.

Title: Use of Digital Manufacturing to Improve Management Learning in Aerospace Assembly
AdditionalInformation: This paper examined Digital Manufacturing in the context of organisational learning.  Pre 2008 papers in the area covered general engineering applications but this material published the first quantified benefits of DM methods in terms of the impact of learning and knowledge acquisition on the assembly time and cost for an aircraft panel.  Based on the findings of this research, Bombardier aerospace Belfast have implemented a system for delivering animated build sequences from the CAD environment, direct to work cells on the shop floor (Ref. Robert Burke, Director Manufacturing Engineering & Tooling, Bombardier Aerospace Belfast).

Title: The use of process simulation methods in support of organisational learning in availability contracting
AdditionalInformation: This work represented a significant departure from the more traditional applications of digital methods in product design and manufacture - extending their applicability to novel business practices based on service support contracting.  The research examined the application of process simulation methods to the development of complex maintenance procedures for mature aerospace platforms.  The project was carried out in collaboration with BAE Systems who are among the first to look at availability contracting as a means of ensuring commercial sustainability (Ref. Jonathan Murphy, S4T Work Package Lead, BAE Systems, Warton UK).

Title: Effect of MWCNT addition on the thermal and rheological properties of polymethyl methacrylate bone cement
AdditionalInformation: This paper contains the first published results demonstrating the influence of MWCNT functionality and loading level on the rheological and thermal properties of PMMA bone cement. This work was preformed through an international academic (UQ and ANSTO) and industrial (Nanocyl-Michael Claes and Lucite International-John Hay) collaborative program. The results from this research program led to a research award from AINSE-Australia (#5830:AUS$90k-2011) to investigate innovative approaches for radiolabelling and tracking of different nanoparticles. This work has also resulted in two book chapter invitations on the topic of biomedical/bioengineering applications of CNT from Woodhead Publishing and InTech Press.

Title: Incorporation of multiwalled carbon nanotubes to acrylic based bone cements: Effects on mechanical and thermal properties
VolumeTitle: Journal of Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
AdditionalInformation: This work shows for the first time that MWCNT can be successfully added to PMMA bone cement using clinically relevant techniques, and highlights the importance of homogenous dispersion and chemical functionalisation. This output was instrumental in Dunne gaining a Royal Academy of Engineering/Leverhulme Trust Senior Research Fellow award (10225/2:£45k-2010) and being the catalyst for international research collaborations with University Calgary (Dr Les Sudak), University Queensland-UQ (Professor Peter Halley) and Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation-ANSTO (Dr Suzanne Smith). Dissemination of this research resulted in invitations to give international plenary lectures at Romanian Society Biomaterials and Swiss Society Biomaterials in 2011.

Title: Fatigue and biocompatibility properties of a poly(methyl methacrylate) bone cement with multi-walled carbon nanotubes
AdditionalInformation: This paper has been seminal in developing a collaborative research programme with Beihang University (Professor Xiaoming Li) to investigate the in-vivo response of MWCNT-PMMA bone cement via a large animal study. Further recognition is evident from the invitation to join an international research project with Universidad Pontificia Comillas (Professor Juan Carlos del-Real), focusing on the application of graphene-based nanoparticles in orthopaedic cements. Preliminary outputs from this research collaboration have included a podium presentation at European Society Biomaterials-2013 and postgraduate secondments. Exploitation includes knowledge transfer to Nanocyl-Claes and Lucite International-Hay, global leaders in design/manufacture of specialty CNT and acrylic based polymers.

Title: Reynolds Number Effects on Fully-Developed Pulsed Jets Impinging on Flat Surfaces
AdditionalInformation: A detailed experimental study of the use of pulsating jets for anti-icing heat transfer is presented, and an evaluation of how this could be fed into the design of such a system to enable effective heat transfer with a reduction in required energy discussed. The concept of a critical Strouhal number is introduced, proposed as an effective measure for practical design optimisation. The work represents a new collaboration between three European Research Institutions - Queens University Belfast, Institut Supérieur de l’Aéronautique et de l’Espace (reference Dr Emmanuel Benard), Toulouse and the Coventry University, UK (Dr Humberto Medina).

Title: Whole-Life Costing for Capability
AdditionalInformation: The work appears to be the first published work on the development of a multi-level modelling technique applied to a Network Enabled Capability environment. The work was undertaken as part of the EPSRC/BAE Systems co-sponsored NECTISE programme, and models delivered were ultimately delivered into BAE Systems through the project. The work contributed to the invitation to participate and subsequent award of Early's EU FP7 Collaboration Grant (ACP1-GA-2011-28474 2011-2014).

Title: Automated mixed dimensional modelling from 2D and 3D CAD models
VolumeTitle: Finite Elements in Analysis and Design
AdditionalInformation: Novel procedures for automatically converting complex CAD geometry into the efficient mixed-dimensional finite element models required by industry are detailed. Addressing the challenge faced by engineers in getting the right idealisation, thin-sheet regions where efficient meshes can be applied are automatically identified in the model. The procedures in this paper were incorporated into the commercial CAE package, CADfix (www.cadfix.com). This work led directly to QUB being invited into the CRESCENDO FP7 project and Rolls-Royce contracting QUB to investigate meshing in the SILOET project (TSB). It was validated on realistic engine designs during a KTS placement.

Title: Determining the parametric effectiveness of a CAD model
AdditionalInformation: Design optimisation using CAD models is complex because the way they are parameterised means it is difficult to achieve the shape changes suggested by analysis. This paper introduces the brand new and foundational concept of Parametric Effectiveness, which measures how good the parameterisation of a CAD model is for the purposes of optimisation. Benefits include allowing the optimum set of parameters to be selected, resulting in more effective optimisation. One reviewer commented that this work “is of significant value to the industry”.

Title: Strategies for adding features to CAD models in order to optimize performance
AdditionalInformation: This paper introduces a new concept of using intelligent interpretation of computational analysis results to identify and add new design parameters and features to a CAD model, thereby allowing the design to evolve in the optimum manner based on analysis results. The approach offers a radically new approach to managing the evolution of simple concept designs into detailed implementations, and will facilitate a major long term capability change in design systems.

Title: Preparation and characterisation of cellulose nanofibres
AdditionalInformation: Previously published work by the authors has demonstrated the high reinforcing potential of cellulose nanofibres in polymers, however their efficacy depends on their method of preparation. In association with the Agri-Food and Bioscience  Institute in Belfast,  this paper contains the first published comparison between the two prominent preparation techniques based on acid hydrolysis and high pressure microfluidisation and applies a range of analytical characterization techniques to investigate the chemical, thermal and structural properties of the materials produced. It provides an in-depth analysis of factors influencing cellulose nanofibre preparation and means for yielding high aspect ratio fibres with enhanced thermal stability.

Title: Interfacial shear strength and tensile properties of injection-molded, short- and long-glass fiber-reinforced polyamide 6,6 composites
VolumeTitle: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites
AdditionalInformation: In collaboration with the University of Malaya, a new methodology was developed using a model based approach combined with rigorous experimental validation, to predict and optimize the tensile properties of injection moulded glass fibre-reinforced polyamide 6,6 composites. The procedures adopted have direct industrial relevance both to designers and processors of such materials by defining the controlling influence of structural parameters on mechanical properties.

Title: Intelligent Assembly Time Analysis Using a Digital Knowledge-Based Approach
VolumeTitle: Journal of Aerospace Computing, Information, and Communication
AdditionalInformation: The research was funded by DTI and 8 industrial companies (DTI ref. TP/3/DSM/6/I/17364). The methods developed have been integrated into the production planning system by Bombardier Aerospace Belfast, and was proved to generate 80% time saving, equivalent to US$300,000 in relation to each programme, e.g. the C-series wing assembly (Director of Manufacturing, Robert Burke, Bombardier Aerospace). This methods were also bought by Airbus UK and integrated into their production system (Research lead: Allister Dare-Edwards, Airbus UK)

Title: Kinematic design of a family of 6-DOF partially decoupled parallel manipulators
AdditionalInformation: The article resulted in an invitation to present at the Sino-British/EU Academic Symposium on Development of Mechanisms and Robotics in Beijing 2010, which is a prestigious invitation-only event. The paper is highly innovative because a new synthesis method of designing decoupled parallel manipulators was proposed. By developing a mathematically elegant solution, a new family of parallel manipulators was discovered as a result. The work has opened a new field of designing parallel manipulators and have been well adopted in the robotics research community, e.g. Jun-Hee Moon and Weibin Rong.

Title: Kinematic modeling of Exechon parallel kinematic machine
AdditionalInformation: The work was part of a £2.5 million collaborative project with Airbus UK, Bombardier Aerospace Belfast and other 5 industrial companies. This research work overcomes the long standing limitations of kinematic machines in high precision applications by providing detailed characterisation of behaviours and synthesizing processes. The work led to the EPSRC grant (Ref. EP/K004964/1). Industrial contact: Mark Summers, Airbus UK; Glenn Rutherford, Bombardier Aerospace.

Title: Workspace evaluation of manipulators through ﬁnite-partition of SE(3)
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a new differential geometry approach to solve the fundamental challenge on qualifying and quantifying six dimensional workspace of manipulators. Unlike the existing workspace evaluation in 3-dimensional space, this approach enables more efficient process planning in 6-dimensions (position and orientation simultaneously), which is needed for many real applications, such as machining a blade of an aero-engine. One reviewer commented “The proposed formulation is very elegant and general.”

Title: Volumetric properties and enthalpies of solution of alcohols CkH2k+1OH (k = 1, 2, 6) in 1-methyl-3-alkylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide {[C1CnIm][NTf2] n = 2, 4, 6, 8, 10} ionic liquids
AdditionalInformation: This work was used to understand the effect of alkyl chain length on the imidazolium ring of an ionic liquid series on its mixing properties (enthalpy and volume) within alcohol mixtures. Behavioural insights including a non-monotonous variation on their mixing enthalpies as a function of the alkyl chain length on the cation were observed for the first time. This was supported by classical thermodynamics and molecular simulation approaches in order to understand the interaction and structure in solution. The work was invited for presentation at the Thermal Analysis Conference meeting, Belfast, U.K., 18-20 April, 2011.

Title: Phase Behaviour, Interactions, and Structural Studies of (Amines+Ionic Liquids) Binary Mixtures
AdditionalInformation: Original research article in collaboration with Prof. Costa Gomes, University Blaise Pascal (France) and Prof. Aim, ICPF (Prague) that demonstrates for the first time the differences in term of macroscopic and microscopic properties between (ionic liquid + amine) with (ionic liquid + alcohol) mixtures. Theses differences reflect their reactivity with other solutes like the PCl3. This work was selected for publication as an invited paper on the ChemPhysChem special issue on Ionic Liquids, as well as for a presentation at the American Chemical Society spring meeting in 2012.

Title: Thermal preparation of highly porous calcium phosphate bone filler derived from marine algae
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine.
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript highlights the optimum process conditions required to retain the original skeletal morphology of mineralised algae during the fabrication of hydroxyapatite. Such materials have direct application as bone fillers. This research contributed to securing of a Beaufort Marine Biodiscovery grant (Irish government funded, £1.4m), It furthermore resulted in the June Wilson Award (2011), for female scientist that shows excellence in the field of tissue engineering, biomaterials, pathology or related disciplines.

Title: Low-pressure synthesis and characterisation of hydroxyapatite derived from mineralise red algae
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript describes a novel manufacture process to fabricate hydroxyapatite bone substitutes from mineralised red algae. The resultant material has a similar chemical structure to bone with a unique porous structure suitable for tissue regeneration. This product has enormous potential as a standalone product, or a component of a tissue-engineering scaffold. The low pressure-temperature synthesis step, gives it a competitive edge over existing market technologies. This work led to funding from (1) Enterprise Ireland (PoC) on marine inspired biomaterials and (2) Invest NI on the in vitro characterisation of algal derived HA and its potential exploitation through industrial collaborators.

Title: Development of composite tissue scaffolds containing naturally sourced mircoporous hydroxyapatite
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript showed that algal derived hydroxyapatite (HA) was sufficiently robust to be fabricated into a tissue-engineered scaffold, using conventional casting methods.  After publication, I was invited to spend time at Dr Francisco de Monte’s Research group at the Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales in Spain, to apply this technology to cuttlebone. To do this, I received a Science Foundation Grant to fund the study and trip. This is currently an ongoing collaboration.

Title: Pharmacological Activity of Ibuprofen Release from Measoporous Silica
VolumeTitle: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
AdditionalInformation: This paper for the first time investigates the drug activity of ibuprofen after realise from MCM-41. All previous studies only looked at loading and pharmacokinetics of the drug after release. The study found that the interaction between drug and delivery system did not adversely affect the inhibitory activity of ibuprofen on COX-1 activity, thus lower drug dosages could be used to achieve analgesia. This work helped secure a highly competitive International outgoing research fellowship (FP7 - PEOPLE-2011-IOF) from Marie Curie, with Prof P Messersmiths at Northernwestern, who is a world expert in novel biomimetic approaches in tissue engineering.

Title: A Visual Analytics Framework for Strategic Airlift Decision Making
VolumeTitle: The Journal of Defense Modeling and Simulation: Applications, Methodology, Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper describes the new research field of Visual Analytics and puts it into a new context: aerospace applications and analysis, to which the emerging field had not yet been applied. A successful VA environment has been created, validated, and employed in the aerospace industry, clearly showing significant advancements in superior, justifiable decision-making for complex systems. The work has been invited and demonstrated to US Air Mobility Command, US Transportation Command, and the US Air Force Tanker Airlift Control Center. Industrial Contact Phil Fahringer, Operations Analyst, Lockheed.

Title: Defining a Research Agenda in Value Driven Design: Questions That Need to be Asked
AdditionalInformation: This invited journal paper is the key foundational document for the emerging research field of Value Driven Design. The paper establishes the essential Research Agenda for VDD, and is supported by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) Value Driven Design Program Committee, which was established to leverage the development of this important new field to the aerospace industry, and of which the authors were charter invited members. International and industry collaborations include Rolls-Royce (Steve Wiseall), USA (D.Mavris Georgia Tech, P.Collopy, University of Alabama) and Netherlands (R.Curran, Delft University). The work led to a strategic priority DEL PhD studentship.

Title: Control of the thickness of mesoporous titania films for application in multiphase catalytic microreactors
AdditionalInformation: A new method for deposition of stable mesoporous coatings with ultrahigh specific surface area onto microchannel walls has been developed. The previous method did not allow to increase the thickness of mesoporous coatings into the micrometer range without substantial deteriorating their mesoporous structure.  The new method has been used in gas-liquid-solid catalytic microreactors which are widely employed in fine chemical synthesis.  An invitation has been received to present this work as a plenary lecture at an international conference on chemical technology, XT-12, in Moscow, Russia, 18-23 March 2012

Title: 3D Analysis of Heat Transfer Intensification by Re-Entrance Flow Pin-Fins Microstructures with a Highly Thermal-Conductive Plate
AdditionalInformation: A new method for catalyst deposition on the inner walls of capillary microreactors is proposed which allows exact control of the coating thickness, pore size of the support, metal particle size, and metal loading. This paper was highlighted by the journal editors and the graphical abstract has been published on the issue cover page. An invitation has been received to present a key-note lecture ‘Sol-gel synthesis of mesoporous thin films for application in microstructured reactors” at the 1st Int. workshop on advanced nanostructured materials and thin films for industrial applications, Nottingham, U.K., 10-13 November, 2008.

Title: Pressure drop of gas–liquid Taylor flow in round micro-capillaries for low to intermediate Reynolds numbers
AdditionalInformation: A new mathematical model for prediction of the pressure drop in a two phase gas-liquid slug slow has been developed. This model allows to predict the hydrodynamic resistance in a capillary in a wide range of operating conditions with an accuracy of ±3%. This accuracy exceeds that of previous models by a factor of 4. The developed model is recommended for design of microstructured reactors operating under slug flow conditions. This model is included in a recent textbook of Th. Dietrich “Microchemical Engineering in Practice”. Wiley, Weinheim, 487 p. ISBN: 978-0-470-23956-8

Title: Droplet size control with methanol-repellent surface in a sampling device for continuous annular electrochromatography
AdditionalInformation: This paper originates from a NMP-2007-206707 project in the frame of European Community’s Seven Framework Programme.  An important industrial problem of control of the eluent droplet size down to the micrometer scale has been solved. The eluent droplet size defines the number of sampling compartments and therefore the separation efficiency of a continuous annular electrochromatograph (CAEC) device. A new sampling devise for a CAEC prototype has been designed and developed for separation of complex mixtures of high-value products and a wide range of both neutral and charged components.

Title: Transonic Aeroelastic Stability Predictions Under the Influence of Structural Variability
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents a significant breakthrough in simulating the effects of variability on transonic aeroelasticity (flutter) of wings and full aircraft configurations. The paper demonstrates how to integrate state of the art uncertainty quantification methods with a fast eigenvalue based aeroelastic stability method exploiting high-fidelity, CFD generated aerodynamics. The work presented in this paper lead to collaboration with TU Delft on data assimilation  methods (and subsequent publication) and was also invited to be presented at Airbus' Dipart meeting in 2010.

Title: Transonic Aeroelastic Stability Analysis Using a Kriging-Based Schur Complement Formulation
AdditionalInformation: This paper proposes a method that allows searches for transonic aeroelastic instabilities of realistically sized aircraft models in multidimensional parameter spaces using CFD. The paper introduces a formulation of a fast eigenvalue based aeroelastic stability method, based on a kriging predictor which allowed the automated and blind search for aeroelastic instabilities. The method demonstrated in this paper attracted strong interest from Airbus UK , it was implemented into DLR's (German Aerospace Centre) CFD TAU code and demonstrated to Airbus UK (Tom Wilson).

Title: In Silico Prediction of the Mechanobiological Response of Arterial Tissue: Application to Angioplasty and Stenting
AdditionalInformation: Recognition is evident from immediate reception following publication — it was the most downloaded article from the journal website in September 2011.  Further recognition includes an invited keynote at the UK Society of Biomaterials in 2012. Further development led to demonstration of potential to pre-clinically differentiate between different stent designs (published in Journal of Biomechanics).  Exploitation includes knowledge transfer through movement of Dr. Colin Boyle to Dept. Mechanical Engineering, University College London to work on the FP7 funded DISCIPULUS Digital Patient initiative (http://www.digital-patient.net/) and inclusion of the methodology within a successful US-Ireland partnership application.

Title: How can cells sense the elasticity of a substrate? An analysis using a cell tensegrity model
AdditionalInformation: This international collaboration [with Trinity College Dublin, Ghent University, Politecnico di Milano] was instrumental in attracting an invited keynote to the UK Society of Biomaterials in 2012.  Further development included an SFI funded PhD project investigating the influence of ageing on cell mechanical properties and mechanosensitivity (with initial results in review with Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering).  Exploitation of this research consists of: current preparation of an EPSRC First Grant, integration of new algorithms within a mechanobiology computational library shared between QUB, Trinity College Dublin, and University College London, and new collaboration with NUI Galway.

Title: Integrating wind power using intelligent electric water heating
AdditionalInformation: This original research was in collaboration with University College Cork. It examines demand response to improve power system operation in grids with high wind penetration. Main findings were that electric water heating resulted in electricity reductions of 25% and cost reductions of 38%. This is significant internationally as demand response is key to wind power integration. This research was used for a successful EPSRC proposal with Cranfield University, iGIVE (EP/L001063/1) worth £855k, to optimise electric vehicle loads charging. This work has also been developed further with Glen Dimplex leading to a European Union research application with KU Leuven.

Title: Transient Heat Conduction of Variable Stiffness Composite Laminate
AdditionalInformation: This paper investigates the impact of steered fibre design on the heat transfer characteristics of a laminate composite leading to better thermal performance in terms of transient response and maximum temperature achieved. A novel mathematical model was developed to simulate steered fibre composites thermal performance. It can be applied to coatings for ramjet engines, laser cutting of composites and other composites applications under high thermal loads. This paper led to collaborative work with a NASA Engineer (Dr K.C. Wu – Structural Mechanics and Concepts) now published in ‘Heat Transfer – Engineering Applications’, INTECH publisher (DOI: 10.5772/2434).

Title: On visco-elastic modelling of polyethylene terephthalate behaviour during multiaxial elongations slightly over the glass transition temperature
AdditionalInformation: The first paper to incorporate the effects of adiabatic heating at high strain rates into models for predicting the behaviour of PET. It is collaboration with Prof. Luc. Chevalier from the University of Paris-Est.

Title: An investigation of the influence of process and formulation variables on mechanical properties of high shear granules using design of experiment
AdditionalInformation: Mathematical models relating the mechanical properties of the granules to formulation variables were developed. The research methodology used in this paper has been transferred to another areas of particle technology research for example it has been applied to optimisation of granular fertiliser production process in our recent research project “Granular Fertiliser from Anaerobic Digestate Liquor (Greenius)” funded by Technology Strategy Board- Greenius Award – Grant No. 971283.

Title: Biorefining of perennial ryegrass for the production of nano-fibrillated cellulose
AdditionalInformation: The output from this research featured in the final of the 2012 Northern Ireland '25k' innovation competition and its commercial potential is currently under evaluation by PVA manufacturer Kuraray Europe Gmbh in Germany (contact Niklas Steinbach).The findings from this paper give, for the first time, a direct comparison between different protocols for producing nanocellulose from ryegrass, in terms of the quality of fibres produced, the mass, energy water and chemical balances of the different processes. It also demonstrates their relative effectiveness as reinforcements for polvinyl alcohol (PVA), providing the basis for subsequent process commercialisation and scale-up for industrial use.

Title: Feedforward Control of Shape Memory Alloy Actuators Using Fuzzy-Based Inverse Preisach Model
VolumeTitle: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
AdditionalInformation: The paper demonstrates the fuzzy based inversion method of the Preisach model and its ability to control the Shape Memory Alloy (SMA) actuator. This was the first paper to demonstrate the application of intelligent control technique to improve the accuracy and compensate for the hysteresis effect of smart actuator systems. This work has since found extensive applications in modelling and control not only for SMA but also for other actuators with hysteresis phenomena. The development in this paper has resulted in a project sponsored by the Korea Science and Engineering Foundation (KOSEF). Grant: 240,000,000KRW, No.2009-0080924.

Title: Adsorption of basic dyes from aqueous solution onto activated carbons
AdditionalInformation: Prof Walker is associate editor of the Chemical Engineering Journal and this publication led to the invitation to be guest editor of this special issue of Chem Eng J. on powder processes. The paper is investigates the engineering applications of novel activated carbons synthesised at QUB. The work secured PoC funding from Invest NI on granular adsorption processes, which has led to patented technology and a University spin-out company recently £1.1M from Technology Strategy Board, SBRI - Greenius Competition and Material innovation for a sustainable economy.

Title: Dilute acid hydrolysis of Lignocellulosic biomass
AdditionalInformation: Prof Walker is associate editor of the Chemical Engineering Journal. This paper contains the first published results for phosphoric acid-catalyzed hydrolysis using rigorous experimental techniques. This information is now being used by industry and has resulted in a new sponsored project funded by Investment Belfast ABC Fund aimed at improving the feasibility of utilising waste feedstocks for renewable energy production. The paper helped to lead Invest NI funding for the Centre Advanced Sustainable Energy (CASE) and €3.9M ATBEST Advanced Technologies for Biogas Efficiency Sustainability and Transport, EU FP7 -PEOPLE-2012 –ITN (Marie Curie).

Title: Effect of solution pH, ionic strength, and temperature on adsorption behavior of reactive dyes on activated carbon
AdditionalInformation: The paper is a completely novel investigation on the engineering science surrounding the area of the adsorption of large molecules on to activated carbon. Prof Walker’s work on adsorption processes directly led to QUB participation in the prestigious ME3 Erasmus Mundus Programme- European joint Masters of Science in Management and Engineering of Environment and Energy, which has secured 10 years funding from the European Commission and led to collaborative research projects with international centres of excellence in EMN France, KTH Sweden and BME Hungary.  The research help lead to the €3.0M EU Marie Curie ITN project 238273 ATWARM.

Title: Glucose Activation by Transient Cr2+ Dimers
AdditionalInformation: This study lays basis for the development of more efficient biomass transformation processes. Glucose dehydration is bottle-neck in lignocellulosic biomass valorisation. Most selective catalytic system for this step is the chromium(II)chloride-ionic-liquid medium. This contribution provides understanding of this critical step for the first time. We have clarified the reaction mechanism by combining state-of-the art experimental and theoretical techniques. The outcomes of this research led to international collaborations (Prof. Can Li, Dalian Institute for Chemical Physics) and successful research grant in 2011 (NWO China – Netherlands Joint Scientific Thematic Research Programme – Project Code: 700.10.701).
