Title: Microwave Irradiation for the Facile Synthesis of Transition-Metal Nanoparticles (NPs) in Ionic Liquids (ILs) from Metal-Carbonyl Precursors and Ru-, Rh-, and Ir-NP/IL Dispersions as Biphasic Liquid-Liquid Hydrogenation Nanocatalysts for Cyclohexene
AdditionalInformation: Several stable metal nanoparticles (M-NPs) were reproducibly obtained by fast, easy and energy-saving 10 W microwave irradiation using ionic liquids as novel nanosynthetic templates. The ruthenium, rhodium, or iridium nanoparticle/IL dispersions are highly active and recyclable catalysts for the biphasic liquid–liquid hydrogenations.

Title: Selective Hydrogenation of alpha,beta-Unsaturated Aldehydes and Ketones using Novel Manganese Oxide and Platinum Supported on Manganese Oxide Octahedral Molecular Sieves as Catalysts
AdditionalInformation: For the first time, OMS-2 has been shown to be an efficient and selective hydrogenation catalyst. High selectivities for either the C=C or C=O double bond at ~100% conversion were achieved. DFT calculations showed the dissociation of H2 on OMS-2 was water assisted and occurred on the surface Mn of OMS-2(001) modified by an adsorbed H2O molecule. In-situ HERFD-XANES can be used to probe the adsorbate concentrations and relate this to selectivity for liquid phase reactions.

Title: Force-induced activation of covalent bonds in mechanoresponsive polymeric materials
AdditionalInformation:
This seminal work opened the field of mechanochemistry in bulk polymers [1], and led to further funding from the US NSF (award number 1307354, $800,000).
According to a ‘News and Views’ editorial article [2]:
“The importance of Davis and colleagues’ work goes far beyond the reported mechanochromic effect — it may become a milestone in polymer science, because the authors’ general design concept can probably be adapted to make a plethora of materials that translate mechanical stress into all kinds of useful chemical reactions.”
[1] Brantley JN, et al. Polym. Int. (2013). doi: 10.1002/pi.4350
[2] Weder, C. Nature (2009). doi:10.1038/459045a

Title: Aerospace Stiffened Panel Initial Sizing With Novel Skin Sub-Stiffening Features
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Structural Stability and Dynamics
AdditionalInformation: This paper details a novel design methodology for buckling containment features on aerospace components.  The design approach enables accurate and efficient analysis of advanced structural geometries, suitable for both preliminary and detailed design.  The developed methodology has been rigorously validated experimentally and can yield significant airframe weight reductions in relation to traditional design practices.  The research output has been distributed to Alcan CRV (Frederic Bron) for implementation in their design tool suite, and led to further collaborative funding with Bombardier Aerospace Belfast (Ken Poston, Head of Advanced Metallics: Strategic Technologies,), and Alcan CRV.

Title: The Influence of Friction Stir Welding Process Idealization on Residual Stress and Distortion Predictions for Future Airframe Assembly Simulations
VolumeTitle: Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper results from collaboration with Bombardier Aerospace and TWI. It is the first to quantify the influence of simulation idealisation on the prediction of friction stir welding residual effects. The simulations where experimentally validated with relevant industrial material and processing technology. The newly developed comprehension is of significant end-user value, demonstrating simulation utility for airframe assembly design.

Title: A Novel Method to Enable Trade-offs Across the Whole Product Life of an Aircraft Using Value Driven Design
AdditionalInformation: This award-winning concept paper (2nd International Air Transport and Operations Symposium (ATOS) Conference), was invited as a journal paper and has contributed to increased collaborative relationships both locally (Jim Scanlan, Southampton; Steve Wiseall, Rolls-Royce) and abroad (Paul Collopy, formerly National Science Foundation, US; as of October 2013 University of Alabama, Huntsville). The paper presents an innovative and radical new approach to design and manufacturing trades and design decisions, resulting in a paradigm shift in how the aerospace industry considers whole product life cycle issues.

Title: Automatic decomposition and efficient semi-structured meshing of complex solids
AdditionalInformation: Won Best Paper Award at the 20th International Meshing Roundtable conference (2011). Since published in a special issue of Engineering with Computers. A reviewer commented “provides a significant advance over the previous work by providing further optimisation of meshes (in terms of degrees of freedom) through an (automated) understanding of the geometry that has a rigorous mathematical foundation.” Dr Ed Green (Rolls-Royce) commented “promises major improvements in meshing capability, recognised at a senior level in the company as the main barrier to the development of mechanical analysis”. Builds upon previous collaborations with Transcendata Ltd (Geoff Butlin, Chairman and CEO).

Title: Experimental Investigation of Stretch Blow Molding, Part 1: Instrumentation in an Industrial Environment
AdditionalInformation: This paper describes the development of patented instrumentation for the stretch blow moulding process that has led to the formation of a successful spin-out company. The instrumentation has been adopted by leading multinational companies resulting in substantial competitive advantage, cost and energy savings. (Jim Shepherd, Proctor & Gamble, Paulo Correia, logoplaste.com)

Title: Composites of poly(ε-caprolactone) and Mo6S3I6 Nanowires
AdditionalInformation: This paper, in association with the Josef Stefan Institute in Slovenia, is the first to describe the preparation, properties and structural characteristics of composites of poly(e-caprolactone) and Mo6S3I6 nanowires prepared using hot-melt extrusion, demonstrating an alternative means to using carbon nanotubes for achieving  high electrical conductivity in polymers.

Title: A comparison of stress intensity factors through crack closure integral and other approaches using eXtended element-free Galerkin method
AdditionalInformation: This work makes an important contribution towards the microscale modelling of damage in composite materials. A new approach of extracting stress intensity factors, necessary for predicting crack growth behaviour, within a novel extended element-free Galerkin (XEFG) formulation was developed and extensively verified against numerous existing analytical solutions.

Title: Predicting low-velocity impact damage on a stiffened composite panel
VolumeTitle: Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation: The high-fidelity, physically-based damage models, developed in this paper, advanced the predictive capabilities of numerical simulation in capturing the complex failure mechanisms in composite aerostructures. The correlation with independently published experimental results was superior to what had been published in the literature up to that point. This work laid the foundation for current research, sponsored by the Cooperative Research Centre for Advanced Composite Structures in Australia (contact Prof M. Scott (CEO)) , for the development of a computational capability for modelling the crushing of composites structures to improve the crashworthiness design of helicopter structures.

Title: Element-Free Galerkin modelling of composite damage
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to develop a computational meshless technique for the modelling of damage in composite materials. In doing so, it provided the modelling community with a new methodology for modelling crack propagation in composite structures without the limitations imposed by the use of the ubiquitous finite element method. It further provided an effective means of multiscale modelling of composite structures. This work laid the foundation for current collaborative research with India’s leading University, IIT Bombay, funded by the IIT Bombay-Monash Research Academy, which is developing mutliscale approaches to modelling damage in composites

Title: Efﬁcient modelling and optimisation of hybrid multilayered plates subject to ballistic impact
AdditionalInformation: The optimisation of hybrid, multilayered structures for ballistic impact is highly complex and computationally prohibitive. In this work, an efficient, phenomenological-based optimisation algorithm was developed which enabled the exploration of a large design space involving numerous energy-absorbing materials and structural configurations. This work led to the establishment of a successful defence-related consultancy firm, www.noveldefence.com, by the PhD student involved in this research.

Title: Implementation of Menter's Transition Model on an Isolated Natural Laminar Flow Nacelle
AdditionalInformation: This paper details a novel investigation of the design of a natural laminar flow nacelle undertaken in conjunction with an industrial partner, Bombardier Aerospace (Chief Technical Engineering Bombardier, David Riordan). The CFD model is validated with experimental data which was obtained within the same research programme and has been transferred to Bombardier for use as a design tool in future nacelle configuration work.

Title: What is the energy balance of grass biomethane in Ireland and other temperate northern European climates?
AdditionalInformation: This was one of the first research articles to investigate the energy balance of grass biomethane, and provided the foundation for greenhouse gas analyses, resource assessment and economic appraisal of the grass biomethane system. The research led to further collaboration with Bord Gáis, and was used in studies by Bord Gáis into the potential renewable gas resource in Ireland. The paper provided the basis for a chapter in an Environmental Protection Agency report and was highlighted in the European Commission DG Environment New Service. The paper was central to a presentation that won a national competition for postgraduate researchers.

Title: Periodic transonic flow and control
AdditionalInformation: This work analyses the control of periodic transonic flow control and how this fundamental knowledge could be translated into practical solutions for future air transportation concepts. This has fed into the TSB/Bombardier co-funded Environmentally Friendly Engine programme (Industrial contact Mr David Riordan, Chief Technical Engineer at Bombardier), and complimented the work in the FP6 UFAST programme (FP6 consortium lead Dr Piotr Doerffer, IMP PAN, Poland).

Title: Development of a bovine collagen-apatitic calcium phosphate cement for potential fracture treatment through vertebroplasty
AdditionalInformation: This work has been the topic of an invited keynote (GRIBOI-Boston-2013) and invited presentation (Bioceramics25-Bucharest-2013). Technology and know-how from this research has been adopted by industry (NHSBT-Dr Paul Rooney and DePuy Synthes-Dr Neil Watkins) to develop innovative biomaterials strategies for treatment of vertebral fractures. The research program associated with this output has led to hosting of international symposia (European Society Biomaterials-2009, World Congress Biomechanics-2011 and World Biomaterials Congress-2012) and securing of research funding from Orthopaedic Research-UK (#480:£80k-2012), MRC-UK (MC-PC_12021:£76k-2013) and NSF-USA (DMR-1306741:£880k-2013) with Cambridge University-Professor Serena Best, Colorado State University-Professor Tammy Haut Donohue and Trinity College Dublin-Dr Daniel Kelly.

Title: Digital Methods for Process Development in Manufacturing and Their Relevance to Value Driven Design
AdditionalInformation: This emerged from a multi-institutional collaboration involving Limerick, Trinity College and University College Dublin on bringing new digital methods into design & manufacture of composites. Its success directly led to an in invitation from Limerick (Dr Trevor Young) to join an EU Marie-Curie proposal, HiperComNet, collaborating with TU Delft, supported by Bombardier Aerospace (Keith Campbell) & Fokker (Michel VanToreen), and new projects from Bombardier (Robert Burke) on digital simulation in aircraft assembly.  It also led directly to an invited seminar to industry (NISP) on “Systems Engineering in the 21st Century”.

Title: Controlled spillover in a single catalyst pellet: Rate modification, mechanism and relationship with electrochemical promotion
AdditionalInformation: This paper discusses the interactions between a porous platinum film catalyst supported on a perovskite-type mixed-metal oxide possessing oxygen ion and electronic conductivity. Understanding of these interactions can lead to the development of highly tunable catalysts. To date, a keynote lecture based on this work was presented at the 7th International Conference on Environmental Catalysis in Lyon 2012. In addition, an invited lecture to the 2011 seminar series of the Chemical Process Research Institute in Thessaloniki Greece was also given based on the results discussed in this paper.

Title: Performance and characteristics of platinum, palladium/rhodium and palladium automotive catalysts when subjected to ethanol, acetaldehyde and a synthetic E85 exhaust gas mixture
VolumeTitle: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
AdditionalInformation: This paper contains the first published results for the oxidation of Ethanol and Acetaldehyde in automotive catalytic converters. The measurements were recorded using advanced research equipment that is not available in any other university. The results will ultimately lead to the development of catalyst formulations specifically suited to engines fuelled by ethanol. The information contained in this paper is now being used by industry and has resulted in a new sponsored project. Industrial contact Ken Hansen (Advanced Diesel and Gasoline Emissions, Jaguar Land Rover).

Title: Detached-Eddy Simulation of a Louver-Cooling Scheme for Turbine Blades
AdditionalInformation: The performance of a novel cooling scheme (Louver Scheme) for gas turbine engines was analysed using unsteady simulation, Detached-Eddy-Simulation (DES). More realistic prediction of the jet lateral spreading than that of the steady analysis has been obtained. This work is the result of collaboration with Pratt & Whitney Canada for the development of advanced cooling schemes. The outputs of this paper provide substantial benefits to the industry in terms of the validation and evaluation of new cooling schemes (Dr Sri Sreekanth, Hot Section Durability, Pratt & Whitney Canada).

Title: Development and Validation of a Forklift Truck Powertrain Simulation
VolumeTitle: SAE International Journal of Commercial Vehicles
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the culmination of a three year study in which advanced computer simulation techniques were developed to produce a validated design tool capable of predicting the performance and fuel economy of forklift trucks. The project was jointly funded by InvestNI and NACCO Materials Handling Group (NMHG). The resulting model is currently being used by engineers in NMHG (Portland) and Fleet (England). Based on the success of this research, further funding has recently been awarded to extend the model to include future hybrid and electric powertrain options. Industrial contact Dr Gopi Somayajula, Vice President, Global Product Development, NMGH, Oregon

Title: SpaciMS: spatial and temporal operando resolution of reactions within catalytic monoliths
AdditionalInformation: This work reports on an innovative technique that allows accessing 3D profiles of chemical reaction and temperatures within structured catalysts such as catalytic monolith. The technology reported in this work received and R&D 100 award in 2008. This works was selected for a presentation at the 6th International Conference on Environmental Catalysis, ANAKON 2011 and the 10th European Conference on Catalysis  (EUROPACAT X) and recently contributed to the successful funding of a project by Toyota (contact Dr A. Mohammadi), two projects by Jaguar Land Rover (contact Dr K. Hansen) and a EU project (ATBEST project, contact Prof M. Larkin).

Title: Numerical and Experimental Study of the Performance Effects of Varying Vaneless Space and Vane Solidity in Radial Inflow Turbine Stators.
VolumeTitle: Journal of Turbomachinery -Transactions of the ASME
AdditionalInformation: This paper was presented at the leading international turbomachinery conference (Turbo Expo) and was consequently recommended for publication in the ASME Journal of Turbomachinery. This detailed investigation of turbine performance used numerical and experimental methods to study two important design parameters impacting turbocharger design. The work was supported by Bowman Power, which is a high-tech engineering company producing microturbines and turbogenerators. The work led to new funding by Bowman Power (Mr David Lamb) to optimize turbogenerator design for biofuel generating sets and trucks, and to a further funded project using turbogenerators for the new hybrid London bus (TSB/Wrightbus, Brian Maybin)

Title: Prediction of ionic liquid properties. I. Volumetric properties as a function of temperature at 0.1 MPa
VolumeTitle: Journal of Chemical and Engineering Data
AdditionalInformation: This original research article realized in collaboration with Prof. Padua (University Blaise Pascal, France) demonstrated for the first time the possibility to predict volumetric properties of ionic liquids using group contributions. Using an ideal- volume methodology as a function of temperature up to 423 K this approach became the standard literature reference and led to a number of publications and book chapters in this field. It was extended to include pressure and utilised in partner industrial labs for the design of ionic liquid processes. Furthermore, this work was an invited presentation at the American Chemical Society meeting in August 2008.

Title: Low pressure carbon dioxide solubility in lithium-ion batteries based electrolytes as a function of temperature. Measurement and prediction
AdditionalInformation: This industrially relevant research was used to measure and predict (using COSMOthermX software) for the first time the CO2 solubility in electrolytes for Li-ion battery applications over a wide range of compositions and temperatures. The work was financed and performed in close in collaboration with the SAFT (a world leader in high technology batteries) to drive product development including the formulation of new safer battery electrolyte applications.

Title: Sliding window two-thermocouple sensor characterization for variable flow environments
VolumeTitle: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control
AdditionalInformation:
The extension of the new difference equation (DE) algorithmic approach to reconstruction of temperature in variable velocity flows is described. Successful application at QUB to measurement of exhaust gas temperature fluctuations in an internal combustion engine has been reported in SAE Paper 2006-01-1319. Isserman at Technische Universität Darmstadt in http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conengprac.2009.11.008 concludes: 
“good performance of the models and techniques has been shown in simulations and with real measurements. The latter are taken from a diesel engine where the exhaust temperature is an important variable for various advanced control and diagnosis concepts and will be even more important in the future.”

Title: Brittle-ductile transition during diamond turning of single crystal silicon carbide
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Machine Tools and Manufacture
AdditionalInformation: During this research, a collaborative industrial partnership was developed with Contour Fine tooling, UK. In addition, the Royal Society of Edinburgh awarded the John Moyce Lessells International travel scholarship to further develop this research with international collaborators Prof. Jiwang Yan (Kieo University, Japan), Prof. John Patten (Western Michigan University, USA) and Prof. Suhas S. Joshi (Indian Institute of Technology, Mumbai, India).

Title: Comparative Characterisation of 3-D Hydroxyapatite Scaffolds Developed via Replication of Synthetic Polymer Foams and Natural Marine Sponges
AdditionalInformation:
The work described represents research into the production of biocompatible bone-substitutes based on biomimetic architectures through the use of marine-sponges and the development of high-solid content/low-viscosity bioactive ceramic slips. 

This work led to international collaborations with Professor Patrick Prendergast (TCD), Professor Ruth Wilcox (University of Leeds) and Professor James Kirkpatrick (Johannes Gutenberg University, Germany) and formed the basis for securing follow-on funding from Science Foundation Ireland (Grant 06/IN.1/B86NSs, €62k). Prior to publication the work discussed received ‘Best Presentation’ (2008) and ‘Most Novel use of Materials’ (2008) prizes from the UK Society of Biomaterials and the Institute of Materials respectively.

Title: In vitro mesenchymal stem cell responses on laser-welded NiTi alloy
AdditionalInformation: This work consolidated an international collaboration with Prof. H.C. Man from the Hong Kong Polytechnic University and Prof J. Lawrence from the University of Lincoln. It describes, for the first time, the effect of laser-induced surface patterns on the mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) responses on shape memory NiTi alloy. The results indicate that there is significant potential for artificial control of differentiation and proliferation of MSCs by the laser-induced surface patterns. This will allow clinicians to grow tailored tissue and bone on biomaterials as well as increasing transplant effectiveness and efficiency.

Title: Effects of sintering temperature on morphology and mechanical characteristics of 3D printed porous titanium used as dental implant
AdditionalInformation:
The use of 3D printing as a new additive layer manufacturing technique to produce porous titanium brings the advantage of new computerised manufacturing to the clinical world. The possibility of design and manufacture of
patient specific dental implants in an efficient way is explored in this research. This project is funded under A*star scheme in collaboration with Singapore Manufacturing technology SIMTECH. This has led to negotiations on larger scale
collaboration between SIMTECH (Mustafa Shabbir Kurbanhusen) and QUB.

Title: Thermomechanical analyses of ultrasonic welding process using thermal and acoustic softening effects
AdditionalInformation:
The Ultrasonic consolidation (UC) process is introduced as a novel additive layer manufacturing process for multifunctional adaptive aerospace metal structures. This is first publication in simulation of the thermomechanical effect of UC which brings unique understanding of the process assisting its optimisation. The
research has led to two EPSRC grants, one joint with DSTL, another ONR (US) grant, funding of a fellowship from Chinese Government and collaboration with University of Utah (Brent Stucker), University of Liverpool (Elisabeth Mariani),
University of Nanchang and industrial partner SOLIDICA (Dawn White). A press release in Materials World magazine highlights the originality of the research.

Title: Finite Element Analysis of Drilling of Carbon Fibre Reinforced Composites
AdditionalInformation: With increased use of composites optimising the drilling process is a concern to tool manufacturers and aerospace industry. This 3D simulation with inclusion of real drill geometry and predictive capability for delamination induced during drilling provides a design tool for optimising the process, achieving longer tool life and avoiding costly parts rejection due to delamination. The research has resulted in approval of KTP in collaboration with Unimerco (Stuart Dawson), industrial fellowship of RAE, in kind support from Airbus, also current negotiations for further work with Bombardier, invitation for two review papers and joint proposal from University of Toulouse (Redouane Zitoune).

Title: Development and Validation of a Compact Thermal Model for an Aircraft Compartment
AdditionalInformation:
This work produced a novel methodology for the generation of Compact Thermal Models (CTMs) for mixed convection regimes in aircraft interiors. The CTMs were validated on an industrial problem in collaboration with the industrial partner (Airbus) as significant deliverable of the FP7 MAAXIMUS project (Dr. Matthieu Thomas).
The resulting models were delivered to Airbus to be integrated in a higher order numerical model for the stress and thermal analysis of aircraft barrel sections.
The methodology developed has provided the basis for the development of research projects on natural ventilation phenomena in the built environment (Dr. Marcus Keane-NUIG)

Title: Nile blue-based nano-sized pH sensors for simultaneous far-red and near-infrared live bioimaging
VolumeTitle: Journal of the American Chemical Society (JACS)
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports the preparation of novel biocompatible block copolymer nanoparticle probes that can be used as a new type of pH-responsive colorimetric/fluorescent biosensors. These nanoparticles can be utilized for probing intracellular microenvironments, as well as for imaging pH gradients within live tumor models. Therefore, they are expected to have a broad range of bioapplications especially in pathological conditions characterized by a pH imbalance. This work contributed to securing funding from ERC 'Advanced Investigator Grant' (PISA 320372) and EPSRC (EP/K006290/1) and establishing an academic collaboration with Prof. Kostas Kostarelos, University of Manchester, UK.

Title: Fibre embedding in aluminium alloy 3003 using ultrasonic consolidation process-thermo-mechanical analyses
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology
AdditionalInformation:
For the first time the mechanism of the process for embedding sensor or fibre in metal structures using ultrasonic energy is simulated. The process offers many innovative solutions in aerospace in the area of adaptive structures, wing
morphing, wing de-icing applications. A press release in materials world magazine highlights the originality of the work. The research has led to two EPSRC grants, one joint with DSTL and another ONR (US) grant, funding for a
fellowship from Chinese Government, collaboration with SOLIDICA Ltd (Dawn White), University of Utah (Brent Stucker), University of Liverpool (Elisabeth Mariani) and University of Nanchang (Zh Zhu).

Title: Improving MTM-UAS to predetermine automotive maintenance times
VolumeTitle: International Journal on Interactive Design and Manufacturing
AdditionalInformation:
The work was carried out in collaboration with the Research Centre of FIAT GROUP (Ref. Carmine De Martino, ICT Methodologies Manager). A new and innovative approach that allows designers to reliably predict the time needed to perform maintenance tasks from the first phases of product design was developed. 
The study has led to funding support for new collaboration projects and research activities with industrial partners. As a result, new procedures for ergonomics and manufacturing operations have subsequently been adopted by Rolls Royce (Ref. Tim Williams-Wood, Manufacturing Technology Programme Manager) and validated in aerospace industry.

Title: An investigation of Mode I and Mode II fracture toughness enhancement using aligned carbon nanotubes forests at the crack interface
AdditionalInformation: A novel approach was developed for introducing carbon nanotube (CNT) ‘forests’, aligned through the thickness, into a laminated carbon-fibre composite which significantly improved Mode I and Mode II fracture toughness.  This paper was instrumental in gaining an EPSRC feasibility project grant from the Centre of Innovative Manufacturing in Composites with additional support from the Centre of Innovative Manufacturing in Through-life Engineering Services, the appointment of Professor Hawkins as a senior research fellow and adjunct Professor at QUB, and support for the establishment of a CNT research capability at QUB.

Title: Carbon nanotube modified carbon composite monoliths as superior adsorbents for carbon dioxide capture
AdditionalInformation: Describes a novel formulation and activation process to control the microstructure of a phenol/formaldehyde polymer-derived active carbon monolith using just 1 wt% carbon nanotubes.  This increases post-combustion capture of CO2 (for greenhouse mitigation) and the adsorption / desorption kinetics to world leading levels with much less processing and expense than competing materials.  This paper was awarded the cover illustration in this very high impact journal and was instrumental in gaining an ongoing industry-funded (Australian National Low Emission Coal (ANLEC) R&D) project to further develop the technology.

Title: Understanding the synthesis of directly spinnable carbon nanotube forests
AdditionalInformation: Directly spinnable carbon nanotubes (dsCNTs) are a unique and technologically promising form of this material for making pure CNT webs and yarns. This paper comprehensively explores the many subtle parameters controlling the synthesis and has become a standard reference in this area with 66 citations.  The work described resulted in the author being invited to speak at the internationally respected invitation-only “University of Cincinnati - US Air Force Research Laboratory Nanotechnology Materials and Devices Workshop” in October 2011 and an invitation to write the first chapter of a book on advanced fibre materials (to be released 9th October 2013).

Title: Catalyst distribution and carbon nanotube morphology in multilayer forests by mixed CVD processes
AdditionalInformation: Substrate-based growth of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) uses two approaches – Catalyst Co-Injection (CCI) and Catalyst Pre-Deposition (CPD) – to produce very different morphologies.  This paper was the first to describe a combined process, resulting in mixed multilayer forests of fibre.  Critically, it demonstrated that one form of CNT is transparent to iron catalyst vapour, while the other form adsorbs it very strongly.  As the implications of this finding for issues such as novel catalysts, toxicology and future synthesis strategies are understood and further explored, it is anticipated to have a substantial impact in these areas.

Title: Automatic dimensional reduction and meshing of stiffened thin-wall structures
AdditionalInformation: Novel procedures for defining and implementing the brand new concept of ‘Simulation Intent’ have facilitated the automated conversion of CAD geometry of industrial complexity into efficient structural finite element models. The techniques demonstrated have led to development funding for the commercial CAE package, CADfix (www.cadfix.com). The work was performed within the CRESCENDO FP7 project and has provided the foundation for further funding from Rolls-Royce via the SILOET and GHandI TSB projects. It has also led to funding in the TOICA FP7 project in partnership with Airbus, Siemens, SNECMA and GKN Aerospace.

Title: Stress correlation between instrumentation and simulation analysis of the die for high pressure die casting
AdditionalInformation: By creating small pockets in the back of a production die at Ryobi Aluminium Castings (UK), strain gauges were applied close to the die cavity to record strain fluctuations caused by the casting process.  Correlating these to computer simulations, the surface stress in the die cavity was predicted.  By varying the casting cycle it was demonstrated that the thermal fatigue stresses can be reduced leading to extended die life.  The modified casting cycle has been implemented across the UK factory to reduce the company’s die maintenance costs and is being evaluated in Japan and the USA: David Watson (Ryobi UK).

Title: Clicking Well-Defined Biodegradable Nanoparticles and Nanocapsules by UV-Induced Thiol-Ene Cross-Linking in Transparent Miniemulsions
AdditionalInformation: This manuscript demonstrates the first examples of highly efficient synthesis of well-defined biodegradable nanoparticles and nanocapsules using transparent miniemulsion templates by UV-induced thiol-ene cross-linking. These nanomaterials are expected to have low toxicity and they can be used as biodegradable scaffolds for a variety of biomedical applications. This work established new academic links with Blaine A. Pfeifer and Paras N. Prasad, SUNY at Buffalo, US, which led to three more publications, DOI: 10.1002/pola.25016; DOI: 10.1002/adhm.201200094; DOI: 10.1021/mp300666s.
